column2: From Shooting and Fishing. In order that every known precaution may be taken to prevent an accident from the careless handling of firearms, the Meriden Gun Club is considering the advisability of adopting the following rules:

NEWARK, N.J., May 22 -- Step by step the arrangements for the New-York Times's inter-State bicycle relay race have been made, until now, with the big event only eleven days off, the committee of the Atalanta Wheelmen of this city, under whose supervision the preparations have been made, has only to wait for the wheels to be put in motion.

LONDON, May 22 -- Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, commander of the United States cruiser Chicago, was entertained at a banquet given in his honor last evening by the English publishers of his works, Sampson Low, Marston Co. A large number of guests were present.

More than 150 persons attended the sale, held in the Trinity Building salesroom by Mr. Peter F. Meyer yesterday, of lots at Bay Ridge on Second and Third Avenues and Eighty-fifth, Eighty-sixth, and Eighty-seventh Streets. Among the number were about a dozen women. The audience was exceedingly apathetic, and the best efforts of the auctioneer were insufficient to awaken any enthusiasm or to stimulate the bidding.

The Commissioner's and Sheriff's jury appointed to inquire into the advisability of the appointment of a committee of the estate of Mrs. Alma Louise Coddington met yesterday afternoon in the Special Term room of the Supreme Court.

LONDON, May 22 -- The Queen has knighted George Williams, President of the Young Men's Christian Association. Mr. Williams was the chief mover in the formation of the association, and the honor is conferred upon him in connection with the association's jubilee.

LA SALLE, Ill., May 22 -- A riotous demonstration occurred among the striking miners at the mines of the Union Coal Company, just across the river, this afternoon, in which eight or ten non-union men were seriously injured. Mine Superintendent Benjamin Hetherington and Edward Cummings were the most seriously hurt, both being beaten into insensibility.
An appeal to Republican editors to make notice in their papers of some protective tariff literature was sent out by Secretary Wakeman of the American Protective Tariff League the other day.

Gustaf A. Gronlund, President of the Scandinavian and Finlanders' Emigrant Company, now in the hands of a receiver, was held by Justice Martin in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning, in $6,000 ball for examination to-day.

BOSTON, May 22 -- Writing from Glasgow about the work at the yard of Messrs. Fife Son, at Fairlee, a yachting correspondent says: "In his latest designs Mr. William Fife, Jr., shows clearly the latest tendency to shallow hulls and long overhangs.

Berlin, May 22 -- The Unterhaus to-day adopted the Agricultural Chambers' bill, as amended by the compromise between the Conservatives and National Liberals, by a vote of 213 to 126. The Centrists, Freisinniges, and fifteen National Liberals voted against the bill. The amendment provides that the assembling of the chambers is optional, but they can at any time be convoked by royal decree at the request of the provincial councils.

St. John's Guild sent a letter to the Board of Estimate yesterday, asking for $30,000, and saying the Legislature had passed a bill requiring the city to pay that amount annually to the society. A similar bill was passed some time ago, giving the Gerry Society $30,000.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 22 -- Col. Burdett's forethought at the Springfield day of the First Regiment, Connecticut National Guard, in this city, no doubt prevented a disaster. The regiment, 700 strong, had marched to the South Meadows to take part in field manoeuvres, 6,000 rounds of blank ammunition having been issued to the companies.

Rosewell G. Rolston, President of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, testified before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary in the Northern Pacific inquiry. He served as a Director of that company from the Fall of 1888 to just prior to the receivership. He was the Chairman of the Committee on Finance in 1890.
PARIS, May 22 -- The French Ministry has been defeated on the Miners' Eight-Hour bill, and has resigned.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- "I think the people are not concerned so much about the inconsistencies of the Democratic Party as they are in the Tariff bill now before this Senate. Let us address ourselves to this question like practical business men.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 22 -- James Hunt Parke, son of Hervey C. Parke, President of the drug manufacturing company of Parke, Davis Co. of Detroit, Mich., who mysteriously disappeared from NewYork a month ago. has been found.

UTICA, N.Y., May 22 -- The essential points in the decision of Judge Merwin of the General Term of the Supreme Court, which holds the Ives law legalizing betting at race tracks to be constitutional, are as follows:

The most telling tribute to the value of the system of the institution is the reformation that is accomplished. Of the prisoners paroled from 1876 to 1892, it is estimated that nearly 82 per cent, were permanently reformed.

The committee having in hand the reorganization of the New-York and New-England Railroad announced at the close of business yesterday that there had been deposited with the Manhattan. Trust Company of this city and the Old Colony Trust Company of Boston 31,551 shares of the preferred stock of the railroad company, out of a total of 38.176 shares, and 156,054 shares of common stock, out of a total of 198,150 shares.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 22 -- On a very heavy track the sulkies set out for their engagements during the second week of the Spring circuit at Pimlico Park this afternoon. The threatening weather kept many persons away, and speculation was also light. Pantomime was the only favorite to win. Robert C. got distanced and Harry P. fell dead during a race.

The forthcoming trials of the indicted officials of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn are expected to disclose how much truth, if any, there is in the charges which have been made by the depositors of this and other recently wrecked State financial institutions against the State Banking Department, of which Charles M. Preston is Superintendent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- The triplescrew cruiser Columbia returned to her anchorage to-day off League Island Navy Yard from her deep-sea trial trip with her claim to be called "Queen of the Sea" fairly established.

TROT, May 22 -- In the Court of Sessions today a number of prisoners were arraigned on indictments for violation of the election laws at the election in the Thirteenth Ward this Spring. William Rabbitt and William Powers were arraigned on the charge of perjury in swearing that they were totally blind and unable to prepare their ballots without assistance.

The wedding of Miss Louisa A. Johnson to Robert Cooper Townsend took place yesterday at 2 o'clock in St. Bartholomew's Church, Forty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, the ceremony being performed by the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, rector of the church. The church was nearly filled with fashionable people.

On a recent Sunday afternoon the writer gave interested attention to the narration which follows. It is here reproduced almost exactly in the words of the lady from whose lips it fell -- Mrs. S. B. Cook of 250 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y.

We should like to have the candid opinion of Mr. Gray's investigating committee on the working of the policy of secrecy. We should say that it cannot be very favorable. So far, the committee has had before it a couple of Senators who were reported "in substance" to have testified to direct and explicit propositions of corruption.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 22.--The Democratic State Convention met at noon to-day, but, owing to the failure of the State Committee to decide on contests, adjourned until 4 P.M. At that hour the convention was called to order by Chairman Smith, whose mention of President Cleveland was loudly cheered.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 22 -- A majority of the delegates to the Republican State Convention are on the ground to-night. The convention will be called to order at 10 A. M. to-morrow, and its work promises to be sharp and decisive.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 22 -- Now that telegraphic communication has been practically restored to all points in the State, an estimate of the damage done by the flood of the past three days can be made. Although the rivers and streams were swollen to nearly as great heights as in the flood of 1889, the destruction wrought by the waters was not nearly so great as the inundation of five years ago.

Detectives from the Central Office were put on the track of the missing Gideon Granger last evening, with positive instructions to arrest him and bring him to Police Headquarters. This action was taken by Superintendent Byrnes at the urgent request of Commissioner McClave, who appeared very anxious to have his son-in-law, captured and produced before the legislative committee.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23 -- The doubt as to whether the Prohibition Party would put a ticket in the field at the next election in this State was settled to-day by the publication of a call for a State Convention for the nomination of candidates for Governor and Congressman, to be held in Dover on Thursday, June 4.

The Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic has worked unusually hard this year to make the Decoration Day exercises as interesting and varied as possible. The members are somewhat discouraged at the meagre responses to their appeals for financial assistance, as the drain upon their resources to meet cades of distress has been unusually large, on account of the prevailing hard times.

So far as the future of the reform of the civil service is concerned, the action of the House in Committee of the Whole on Tuesday is of very little importance. The appropriation then stricken out will probably be restored when the House takes up the bill. If not, it will be restored in the Senate and accepted by the House.

PARIS, May 23 -- Prince Karageorgevitch, the pretender to the throne of Servia, has written a letter to The Figaro, in which he says that not only will he not abandon his claim to the Servian throne, but he is prepared to support his legitimate right to it.

QUEENSTOWN, May 23 -- Passengers on board the steamer Majestic assert that the Paris crossed the Majestic's bow from north to south. The assertion is doubted at the offices of the White Star Company, as they have not received official confirmation of the report. At the offices of the American Line the story is declared to be "absolutely impossible."
PARIS, May 23 -- President Carnot this afternoon summoned M. Bourgeois to the Palace Elysee to request him to form a Ministry.

ALBANY, May 23 -- The warrants for the first payment of compensation to the delegates of the Constitutional Convention and the employes were presented to President Choate to-day for his indorsement. Each delegate and employe receives a per diem compensation, that of the delegates being $10 a day each.

A certain crowd of bookmakers are trying by every method in their power to have the rule prohibiting one-two-three betting in the books revoked. A petition to that effect has been presented to the Brooklyn Jockey Club, but no official action has yet been taken in the matter.

The committee representing the consolidated mortgage bonds and other issues of the Northern Pacific Company has made public the correspondence between the committee and the receivers relative to the appointment of William H. Phipps, formerly of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railroad, as Land Commissioner of the Northern Pacific Company.

LA SALLE, Ill., May 23 -- Great excitement prevails in La Salle to-night over the action, of the striking miners who are taking the law in their own hands and destroying the property of the mine owners and attacking the company men who are employed in keeping the mines up.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- There is no doubt about the efficiency of the turrets of the monitors. Despite the reports which have been circulated to the detriment of the turrets, they work excellently, even in a seaway.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Wheelmen who are going to start in the Irvington-Millburn race and The New-York Times 150-mile tri-State relay race are particularly pleased with the big rainstorm that has just passed over. Before the storm came the roads in New-Jersey were in very bad shape. The dust was in some places four inches thick on the road and was filled with loose stones.

Thomas C. Platt's Milholland faction of the Republican Party in this city is out for a Republican for Mayor for this Fall's local campaign. Tentatively it is also out for a straight Republican county ticket.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- It looked at one time to-day as if no progress would be made by the Senate on the Tariff bill. Mr. Gorman had spurred the obstructionists to renewed efforts by his speech, and for five hours the steel-rail paragraph was lost sight of in a torrent of expressions which could have no effect in determining the fate of the Tariff bill.

Sensations were not as much the order of the day before the Senate committee yesterday as they had been Monday and Tuesday, but there was plenty of interest in the proceedings. Gideon Granger, Police Commissioner McClave's son-in-law, was not present to resume the testimony against Mr. McClave which he began Monday, or to submit to cross-examination.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 23 -- It was stated at the Executive Chamber this afternoon that about twenty-eight bills out of a total of 527 remaining in the hands of Gov. Flower after the adjournment of the Legislature were unacted upon. It is not likely that all of these will the disposed of before to-morrow night at the earliest. The Governor has until Saturday night to close up his action in these bills.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 23 -- The Union County Roadsters of Railway gave the finest subscription musicale in the Opera House here last night ever given in Rahway. The Lyceum Ladies' Quartet of New-York, composed of Miss Marie Budworth and Miss Isabel B. Mosher, sopranos, and Miss Lillian Du Bois and Miss Kathryn Krymer, altos, was the chief attraction, and their fine singing took the house by storm.

The most important effect of the new rapid-transit law is the creation of a commission which will have no other object than to give practical effect to its purpose of providing a genuine system of rapid transit for this city. The fatal error of the old commission was the abandonment, after two years of faithful work, of the sole function for which it was created.
LONDON, May 23 -- Lord Rosebery spoke this evening in Birmingham to the meeting which had just inaugurated the Midland Liberal Federation.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 23 -- The court-martial of Lieut. James A. Maney of the Fifteenth United States Infantry, for the killing of Capt. Alfred Hedberg last October, which began this morning, at Fort Snelling, has taken a different line from that anticipated. Much to the general surprise, the indictment against him, instead of being confined to "conduct prejudicial to good order and military discipline," specifically charges him with the shooting of Capt. Hedberg.

The closing lecture in the historical course of lectures to public school children, at All Souls' Church, will be held this afternoon at 4 o'clock. Friday was the day set for the lecture, but the change has been made on account of the anniversary parade on that day. The lecture will be given by Gen. Horace Porter and the subject will be "Appomattox and the Surrender of Lee." School children are admitted free.

ALBANY, May 23 -- Thirty-three propositions were tumbled into the Constitutional Convention to-day as amendments to the fundamental law of the State. "And I venture to say," observed Judge W.D. Veeder of Kings, "not one of them will ever leave the committee to which it is consigned."

BOSTON, May 23 -- August Waiss, who lives with his father on Cornell Street, Roslindale, was awakened early this morning by two men ransacking his room. He grappled one of the burglars, whom he immediately recognized as his brother Carl, a young man who, on account of his dissipated habits, had not lived at home for a year or more.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The official report of the inspection at sea of the cruiser Columbia shows that she is incomparably the most economical naval vessel in the world.
Call loans were made at 1 per cent throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Strollers gave a performance here this afternoon for the benefit of the Home for the Incurables. A large and appreciative audience enjoyed the plays "Confusion" and "Raspberry Shrub Sec." The performance was given under distinguished patronage, and society made it fashionable.

-- The Memorial Day Committee held a meeting on Tuesday evening, and decided that School Superintendent Charles E. Gorton should take charge of the children's exercises in the morning at the Soldiars' Monument, on the Manor Hall grounds. The committee requests the widows and relatives of veterans to meet at the cemetery next Sunday afternoon to point out the graves of the soldiers, so that time will not be lost on Memorial Day.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 23 -- Several important incidents that have a bearing on the contest now before the General Assembly marked an otherwise very quiet day. The first was an attempt to bring the Auburn Seminary representatives to an acceptance of the General Assembly's terms of control, passed yesterday by so emphatic a vote.

The nomination of Congressman Oates for the office of Governor by the Democrats of Alabama is one of the most hopeful signs of a sound political tendency in the South that have appearedin a long time. The Democrats of that State have been swayed from a steady footing by several causes, and now they seem to be recovering their equilibrium.

-- Jane Stuart in Comic Opera Jane Stuart, daughter of Deputy Commissioner of Public Works Maurice F. Holahan of this city has made a great hit as a comic-opera singer in "The Beggar Student" at the Schiller Theatre, in Chicago. She sings the part of Bronaslave, daughter of the indigent Countess, and the comedy of the opera la about equally divided between her and Mr. De Wolff's General Ollendorf.
TORONTO, Ontario, May 23 -- Miss A.B. Blake, daughter of Samuel Blake, Q.C., one of the most prominent lawyers in Canada, and J.H. Rhinelander of New-York City, were married to-day in St. Peter's.

Richard Croker and Gen. Jackson, his partner in the Belle Meade breeding farm, were interested spectators at the sale of registered and half-bred hackneys and carriage and saddle horses yesterday at the American Horse Ex- change. Mr. Croker wore the Yale blue, the colors carried by his race horses, and discussed the top cross of hackney blood with Gen. Jackson, after the latter had purchased Polly, a hackney mare, imported from the Brookfield Stud.

Those who have been saying that the Republican Committee of Thirty's followers are "silk stockings" and dwellers in the "brownstone district" would have had an object lesson to teach them otherwise if they had attended the convention of the First Assembly District at 4 Greenwich Street last night.
"You are a liar, and you know it." said Contractor Thomas Dwyer to Architect Joseph Wolf yesterday at the meeting of the Park Board.

The Milholland wing of the Republican Party in this city is somewhat troubled because Mayor Gilroy appointed Charles H. Murray a Police Commissioner. Ignoring such disappointment as they may feel that Gen. Michael Kerwin, who had the indorsement of the Milholland leaders, did not get the place, they believe that the appointment of Mr. Murray was a bad omen for their side of the party.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Before the louse adjourns to-morrow the members will have an opportunity on a roll call to redeem the disgraceful record they made yesterday and to-day in their treatment of he Civil Service Commission, a record of such devotion to patronage as has not been made by any party for many a year.

Capt. Foutz's men played a pretty game of ball yesterday at Eastern Park against the Baltimores, and won with apparent ease. Kennedy, who was in the box for the local club, was at his best, and proved an enigma to the heavy-hitting Orioles. Mullane, who essayed to pitch for the visitors, was touched up father lively at times.

BOSTON, May 23 -- Local stocks were quite dull, and fluctuations were narrow. There is little news and less gossip. Wisconsin Central 5s were steady at 60. Bell Telephone dropped 1/2 , to 190. New-England Telephone was firm at 56 1/2 and Erie Telephone sold at 45. Lamson Store Service was quiet at 22 1/2 .

The balconies and boxes at Durland's Riding Academy were filled with well-dressed men and women last night, all eager to see the hackneys, from John A. Logan, Jr.'s, Oriole Stud sold at auction by John B. Doerr and incidentally to admire the Russian stallions, the property of the Grand Duke Dimitry of Russia, which were also to be sold.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 23 -- The Republican State Convention held here to-day had little work to do, most of the candidates virtually having been selected beforehand by Mr. Quay. The convention had only to ratify the selections, and it did it without going through the form of ballot- ing.

Prof. George John Romanes died suddenly at Oxford, England, yesterday. He was born in Kingston, Canada, May 20, 1848. He spent his boyhood in England, France, Germany, and Italy, and was educated by tutors and in private schools. In 1867 he entered Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge.
The will of Susan M. Pell, wife of John Augustus Pell, who died at Pau, France, last December, was filed in this city yesterday for probate. Her estate is valued at from $5,000,000 to $6,000,000.

QUEENSTOWN, May 23 -- When the steamer Majestic arrived here this morning from New-York she was boarded by Detective O'Neill, who arrested Thomas Feeney on information supplied in a telegram from London. Feeney is alleged to have run away from Brooklyn, N.Y., with a large sum of money belonging to his employers.

Robert A. Depew, seventy years old, a wholesale grocer of 103 Murray Street, who resided at 18 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, died of pneumonia Tuesday evening. He was a cousin of Dr. Chauncey M. Depew. He was born in Peekskill, and was brought up in business there in the employ of Isaac Depew, Dr. Depew's father.

The wedding of Miss Catherine Muckleworth Drew to Clarence Illingworth took place yesterday in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, East Twenty-ninth Street, at noon. The Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton officiated.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 23 -- Miss Isabella Edelsten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edelsten, was married this evening at the home of her parents to John H. Noble of Pittsfield, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Otis A. Glazebrook.

BOSTON, May 23 -- Capt. Ward's men played like Giants of old here to-day. At the first Half of the Opening inning defeat stared the New-Yorkers in the face, the score was 4 to 0 in favor of Boston, and the odds were that New-York would go home without a victory. But the Giants never faltered.

The upward movement in the stock market, which began on Monday afternoon last, and was sustained on Tuesday, was even more pronounced yesterday. The advance, which began with the determination of a well marked liquidation movement, was stimulated by the covering of short contracts, and higher prices, once made and being well maintained, encouraged the traders to take the bull side of the market.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 23 -- The Alabama Democratic Convention reassembled this morning at 11 o'clock. On the first ballot J.K. Jackson was nominated for Secretary of State. The present Incumbents, J.C. Smith, Treasurer, and John Purifoy, Auditor, were renominated by acclamation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 -- Harvard beat the University of Michigan at baseball to-day 7 runs to 5. Michigan started the scoring in the first inning with three earned runs on a hit by Hollister and Smeltzer's home run. Harvard finished the inning with four runs on errors by Beard and hits by Dickinson and Corbett.

According to statements made by members of the McClave family, Gideon Granger Is a degenerate scion of a good family. He is a, son of John Albert Granger, a real estate agent having an office at 15 Broad Street, and living in the Rutland, an apartment house at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- The better feeling on the local stock market continues, and values are gradually rising. Strength to noticeable throughout the list to-day,. and talk of still higher prices was indulged in. West Chicago opened at 141 1/2 , fell to 141, then rose to 141 3/4 , later declined to the opening figure, and closed lower at 141 1/4 . North Chicago was quiet at 241 1/2 .

WORCESTER, Mass., May 23 -- The nine colleges of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association admitted the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to membership last Winter, and now they are sorry. The new-comer attended the annual games at Worcester Oval in force this afternoon and won first place with ease, chiefly by reason of its superiority in middle and longdistance running and in bicycling.

Port Jervis, N.Y., May 23 -- The Rev. William H. Hudnut of the Presbyterian Church of this village and Benjamin Lord, a member of his congregation, were arrested in Montague. N.J., yesterday, by J.J. Van Sickle, for flishing in what Van Sickle claims is a leased stream. They were taken before a magistrate and released on their own recognizance, pending trial, May 29.

LONG VIEW, Texas, May 23 -- Two bold robbers made a daylight raid on the First National Bank of this city this afternoon, securing about $2,500. A general fight between the robbers and citizens ensued, in which two persons were killed and several injured.

Reasonable and dispassionate people must view with some impatience, and even disgust, the performances of the American Protective Association. Pretty evidently it is an organization of which the motive power is religious bigotry. It is neither more nor less creditable to invoke Protestant zeal in secular politics than to invoke Catholic zeal.

A few weeks ago it looked as though the annual coaching parade, which is to be held to-morrow, would not be a large or successful one, as many of the members of the New-York Coaching Club are in Europe, and some of them at home are in mourning. Since then, however, the prospect has changed, and it is probable that the parade will be a fair-sized one.

LA SALLE, Ill., May 24 -- This city is tonight in the hands of a mob of striking miners. All day they have had things their own way, and when Sheriff Taylor and his handful of deputies sought to put a restraining hand upon their actions they turned upon him and gave battle.

As we expected, the Congressman who were ready to vote to "starve out" the Civil Service Commission and nullify the law when they could do so without going on record were not ready to face the consequences when a record was unavoidable. Every appropriation stricken out in Committee of the Whole was restored yesterday in the House, and by a much larger majority than had been given the other way in committee.

James McNaught, general counsel for the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad, was recalled as a witness at the hearing before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary yesterday. He explained the terms of the contract entered into by the Northern Pacific and Manitoba people with the firm of Decker, Howell Co. for the completion of that road, Col. McNaught said the contract had been carried out in a satisfactory manner.

Mr. Gorman's speech had been prepared with care, and he read it from a written or printed copy. We do not see what excuse he can offer for his incorrect statement as to the protection given to the sugar refiners by the sugar schedule as it stands in the committee's revised bill. He asserted that the McKinley duty on refined sugar had been "reduced 75 per cent."

Edward B. Bartlett of Brooklyn, President of the Union Warehouse Company, sometimes called the Warehouse Trust, died suddenly of apoplexy yesterday morning in his home, 902 President Street, Brooklyn. He had been ill since Tuesday afternoon, but was not thought to be seriously so until late Tuesday night, when the stroke came which resulted in his death.

The last of the series of conferences in the interest of good municipal government that have been held every two weeks in the Amity Building, 312 West Fifty-fourth Street, was held last evening. "New-York for New-Yorkers" was the subject for discussion.

Mrs. Alma Louise Coddington, widow of Capt. Clifford Coddington, was married privately to James Waite Fellows at her residence, 44 East Sixty-sixth Street, by the Rev. Dr. John Hall of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

PATERSON, N.J., May 24 -- Charles Doebbler, who was arrested last night and brought to this city to-day by Detective Matthew D. Connell of the prosecutor's office, is a member of one of the Anarchist clubs of this city. He is the leader of the club whose headquarters is at Seidel's saloon, on Hamilton Avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The committee in charge of the horse show to be held at the grounds at Wissahickon Heights next week, have selected the following gentlemen to act as Judges:

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 -- The Populist State Convention met here to-day, with about 300 delegates present. Leroy Templeton was made Chairman. In his speech of acceptance he denounced the old parties and said that he hoped to see the day when there would not be a millionaire alive. He was loudly cheered.
Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Charles Scribner's Sons have almost finished their removal from 743 and 745 Broadway to their new building, built of white limestone and graceful with classic simplicity, on the east side of Fifth Avenue, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second Streets.

Mr. Frederic R. Coudert, President of the Manhattan Club and one of the principal leaders in the various movements for political reform that have been instituted in this city, yesterday paid his respects to the Rev. Madison C. Peters and the "A.P.A."

Since the referendum clause in the rapid transit law must act as a bar to final or decisive work by the new commission until after the November election, talk, of syndicate bids for a franchise was summarily abandoned yesterday.

There is not the least likelihood that the forces which we have described as controlling the administration of municipal affairs could by any manner of organization acquire or maintain that control if they were not able to ally themselves with one political party or the other, and bring to their support the strong sentiment of party attachment.
The question of the ownership of the water spaniel Prince came up in the Sixth Judicial Court again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Secretary Carlisle reached the Treasury Department late this afternoon, and thirty minutes later Assistant Secretary Curtis had taken the Congressional Limited for New-York. Before departing he had a consultation with Secretary Carlisle about Treasury finances, which have constantly decreased in Secretary Carlisle's absence.

The struggle between the Committee of Thirty and the Platt-Milholland leaders for recognition as the regular Rerpublican organization is likely, according to some members of both factions, to take place earlier than was anticipated.

Cooper Union was crowded last night when the woman's art department held its thirty-fifth annual reception. On the walls of the rooms there were studies of heads, drawings from the antique pen and ink sketches for illustrating purposes, and a large collection of designs in industrial art, all made by young women.

Among the pieces of special legislation which it was yesterday proposed that the Constitutional Convention should embody in the Constitution of the State were several pertaining to railroad passes. These propositions were not only trivial, but wrong. One proposition was that the railroads should transport free the Governor and certain other State officers engaged in official duties, and should not give free passage to any other persons.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 24.--Some of the members of the New-York Retail Coal Exchange were visiting the South Wilkesbarre shaft to-day in a body when one of the main boilers exploded. There were about twenty-five of the excursionists in the mine at the time, but none of them was injured.

There is much bustle and activity at the big Industrial Building, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, preparatory to the opening of the new permanent Commercial Exposition, which takes place during the coming month.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The market was only moderately active. As very little Reading seemed for sale it was bid up easily after the opening to the equivalent of 17. Simultaneously with the break in New-York Central, a drive was made at Reading, and it dropped quickly to 16 1/4, but was very steady after this at 16 1/2 all day.

Theodore Seligman, an executor and trustee under the will of Jesse Seligman, his father, yesterday filed a petition with the Surrogate's Court, and a citation was issued thereon to the next of kin and legatees under the will, returnable July 6, 1894. This action was preliminary to presenting the will for probate.
BALTIMORE, May 24 -- The Manufacturers' Record, in its weekly review of the business conditions of the South, says:

When ex-Mayor Grant took charge of the St. Nicholas Bank as its receiver he found among the supposed assets two 6 per cent. registered Government bonds, for $10,000 each, of the issue of 1861. They had been made out to Selah C. Carll. Powers of attorney were attached to them. When he made inquiry as to their value, he learned that original bonds, with the same numbers, had been canceled at the Treasury Department.

The member of the Constitutional Convention who proposed an adjournment from May 25 to June 5 because May 30 is Memorial Day has a very liberal idea of holidays. His resolution was laid on the table, which is a good place for it to remain. This convention will have a good deal of business to do, it is of the greatest importance, and it ought to be done with the utmost care.

TRENTON, N.J., May 24 -- The members of the Legislature spent the entire forenoon in conferences. As soon as the Senate convened, the Governor sent in the following to constitute the new State Board of Medical Examiners, all the schools of medicine being represented:

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 24 -- A riot occurred at the Washington Run mines of the Washington Coal and Coke Company at daybreak this morning. Thomas Kenan of Wood's Run and three foreign strikers were instantly killed and twelve or fifteen were wounded. Some of these are dangerously hurt and will die.

There is a marked difference between the attitude of the House and that of the Senate toward the tariff on steel rails. In the House 79 votes were cast in favor of putting steel rails on the free list, although the duty reported by the Ways and Means Committee was only 25 per cent., equivalent at present prices to $4.40 per ton.

For the third time within two days Register Ferdinand Levy yesterday secured a summons from Justice Feitner of the Yorkville Police Court for Florian Sicher of 447 East Seventy-fourth Street, who is charged with annoying respectable people of all nationalities, and especially Hebrews.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- At this morning's session of the Whist Clubs League it was announced that in the progressive match for fours which was played yesterday the Albany Club led with 789 points. Twenty-nine club teams took part in the match and 1,922 hands were played.

Twenty-five women were graduated last evening at the Post-Graduate Training School of Nurses, 163 East Thirty-sixth Street. They were addressed by Dr. Robert Abbe, Dr. J. Wert Roosevelt, Dr. Seneca Powell, and the Rev. Dr. Wilton. Merle Smith.

The motive of the leaders or the "Milholland movement" in coming out thus early in favor of a "straight" Republican ticket at the next municipal election is not altogether clear, but so far as any expression of opinion has appeared on the part of the Committee of Thirty organization it has been exactly in the same line.

William Astor, on Nov. 14, 1878, in anticipation of the marriage of his daughter Helen Astor to James Roosevelt. Roosevelt, executed a deed of trust to the United States Trust Company, by the terms of which he transferred to that company securities worth $400,000, to be held in trust, the income to be paid to his daughter for life.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Following is the report of the commission appointed to examine the New-York Post Office. It is addressed to the Postmaster General:
ALBANY, May 24 -- The reconstruction of the Sixty-ninth Regiment of New-York City is but a matter of a few weeks, it would seem, from the events of to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The foes of civil service reform were routed in the House this afternoon, when a vote was taken by a call of the yeas and nays to determine whether the House would stand by the action of the Committee of the Whole in rejecting the provision for salaries and expenses of the Civil Service Commission.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, May 24 -- Tuberculosis in cattle in this county seems to be more prevalent than is generally supposed. There is hardly a herd but has some diseased cattle, and while few have been killed by the ownrs many have been isolated.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The good feeling still prevails in the local stock market. The cable and "L" road stocks made a further advance. Neither of the cable stocks showed great activity, and the industrial list was very quiet. Not until the elevated properties came up for action was there any life in the market.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The rain ceased about 2 o'clock this afternoon, and a little later the sun showed itself for the first time in five days. The wind has shifted to westerly, and there is every indication that the great storm is now at an end. The rainfall since Friday last until this afternoon has been remarkable, and is the greatest ever recorded for May by the Weather Bureau here.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- In the West End, the fashionable residence portion of the city, a distinct earthquake shock was felt last night. Several parties returning from the theatre about midnight noticed the shock, which lasted about two seconds. Telegrams from Murphysborough, Ill., and Cape Girardeau, Mo., say that similar shocks were felt at those places at about the same time.

The Parkway Driving Club will open its track on Memorial Day, when a four days' meeting will be begun. The track is near the Gravesend race course, and so is easily accessible. The club will give $600 for special races to be decided on later. The entries for the several scheduled races for the meeting are as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The President, accompanied by Secretaries Carlisle and Gresham and Capt. Robbley Evans of the Lighthouse Board, arrived at Rich's Wharf on the lighthouse tender Violet at 11:15 o'clock this morning.
ALBANY, May 24 -- GOV. Flower has vetoed Assemblyman Lawson's bill to prevent the display of foreign flags or emblems on public buildings. In his veto memorandum, the Governor says:
Mecredy, the veteran Scotch, cyclist, has this advice to give racing men:

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- There was no lack of witnesses at the meeting of the star chamber Sugar Trust bribery investigation committee to-day, and the detail in which the evidence will be presented to Mr. Gray and his associates when they take up their newspapers in the morning can hardly fail to impress them anew with the folly of attempting to conduct an Investigation out of the sight and hearing of the public.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 24 -- Statement of the business of all lines of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company: All lines east of Pittsburg and Erie for April, 1894, as compared with the same month in 1893, show a decrease in gross earnings of $1,131,476.27, a decrease in expenses of $833,193.66, a decrease in net earnings of $298,282.61.

Music Hall was crowded with proud parents and admiring friends to witness the graduating exercises of the Law School of the University of the City of New-York last night, when the degree of Bachelor of Laws was conferred upon sixty-four young men and three young women, and that of Master of Laws upon six young men by the Chancellor of the University, Henry Mitchel MacCracken.

LONDON, May 24 -- Capt. Randle, of the American steamship Paris, has made his official report of the recent voyage of his ship from New-York. He confirms all the statements he made in his interview at Southampton yesterday, denying the stories told by passengers that his ship crossed the bows of the Majestic involving danger to both vessels.

ALBANY, May 24 -- The first signs of partisanship were exhibited in the Constitutional Convention this morning, and only a premature adjournment prevented an outbreak that at one time appeared to be unavoidable.

The trial of Mrs. Catherine Fitzgerald for the killing of Mrs. Carrie Pearsall Oct. 2 last, at 515 East Eighty-sixth Street, was resumed yesterday before Judge Cowing in Part II. of the General Sessions. Mrs. Fitzgerald's sister, Mrs. McGowan, sat beside her.

CENTRALIA, Ill., May 24 -- The Pittenger Davis mine in this city, which has been working for several days with about thirty men, was visited early this morning by a delegation of strikers from Duquoin and St. John's Mines. The miners attacked and badly damaged the works.

Justice William J. Gaynor in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday heard arguments on the writ of habeas corpus obtained by Philip J. Dwyer, President of the Brooklyn Jockey Club. Mr. Dwyer had been held without bail for the Grand Jury by Justice Walsh, his arrest having been caused by Peter De Lacy, after Judge Pryor's decision that the Ives pool law was unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- There will probably be about eleven additional appointments before August to the Naval Academy. The unexpected vacancies are caused by the presence at the Naval Academy of cadets credited to districts in which they do not reside. This is a violation of law, to which attention was directed during the discussion of the Naval Appropriation bill.

LONDON, May 24 -- The dinner to Rear Admiral Erben, Capt. Mahan, and the officers of the United States cruiser Chicago was given at St. James's Hall this evening. Lord George Hamilton, formerly First Lord of the Admiralty, presided.

TROY, N.Y., May 24 -- Judge Houghton of Saratoga County presided to-day in the Court of Sessions and heard argument on the motion to dismiss the indictment against John McGough because of alleged improper influence of the Grand Jury. McGough was indicted by the present Grand Jury for assault in the first degree in shooting William Ross at the Thirteenth Ward election.

Police Commissioner John McClave (Republican) made absolute denial yesterday of all the charges that had been made against him by inference before the Republican Senate committee which has had him under investigation for the last four days.

-- The New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad has begun a new system of fast through freight trains between New-York and Boston, which is an innovation in the matter of rapidtransit freight. The new system consists of regularly-scheduled trains, and a reduction of about five hours in time is made between these two points.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

The Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre was well filled last evening, when the No Name Dramatic Club gave a successful amateur entertainment in aid of the St. John's Guild Fresh-Air Fund. The club presented "Lot 49" and Gilbert and Sullivan's "Trial by Jury." The performance was under the management of Bowman Ralston, while the music was directed by Edwin J. Lyons.

BOSTON, May 24.--The market for local stocks was dull and lifeless, and prices differ but little from those of the past few days. Bell Telephone was steady at 190, with New-England Telephone 2 1/2 higher, at 59. A small lot of Dominion Coal sold at 20 1/4, and Lamson was firm at 22 1/2. Wisconsin Central 5s improved to 61, and the stock advanced 1/2, to 5.

The testimony of Mr. Walter Webb yesterday before the special committee of the State Senate undoubtedly points to one of the most flagrant of the abuses of the police. It is the same abuse to which Mr. MacLean directed attention in almost the last act of his official career. Mr. Webb's own action is precisely the action that any benevolent man who could afford it would be apt to take in like circumstances.

NEW-HAVEN, May 24 -- The annual initiation ceremonies of the Yale Junior Greek-letter secret societies took place Tuesday evening. Members of "D.K.E." and "Psi U.," robed in fantastic attire, early in the evening paraded the campus, singing fraternity songs, and then visited the rooms of those collegians who had been elected to membership in the societies.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Orders dispatching the Atlanta and Marblehead to relieve the New-York and San Francisco at Bluefields, as announced in the United Press dispatches last Monday, have been prepared by the Navy Department, and the commanders of those vessels have been directed to prepare to leave Hampton Roads the latter part of next week.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 24 -- In anticipation of the opening of the Smith heresy case by the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day, the auditorium and galleries of the church in which the convention is being held were overcrowded.

ALBANY, May 24 -- The Assembly Chamber was well filled with delegated and women in sympathy with the woman-suffrage movement at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, when the Constitutional Convention Suffrage Committee met to hear Miss Susan B. Anthony on the question of striking out the word "male" from the State Constitution.

The series of adresses by Union Generals on the great events of the late civil war was closed yesterday in All Souls' Church, South Ninth Street, near Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, by Gen. Horace Porter, who gave the school children who composed his audience a brilliant and vivid description of the surrender of Gen. Lee to Gen. Grant at Appomattox Court House on Sunday, April 9, 1865.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In less than three hours this afternoon the Senate disposed of twenty-one paragraphs of the Tariff bill. The preceding five hours had been devoted to useless debate, and little or no progress would have been made if the Republican obstructionists had not received an intimation that Mr. Harris, who is in charge of the bill, intended to demand an increase in the working hours of the body.

The Young Men's Republican Club of Brooklyn had a reunion last evening, at which its members were addressed by all its former Presidents, and a very interesting meeting it was. The club has had an unusual history. It was first formed in 1880 as a Garfield and Arthur campaign club.
The Manhattan Club at a meeting in its clubhouse last night adopted resolutions calling on the Senate for speedy action on the Tariff bill and denouncing the levying of an income tax.

A number of stories have been recently printed to the effect that Mr. James Gordon Bennett the proprietor of The New-York Herald, intends to build a "sky-scraping" office building on the site at Broadway and Ann Street which was for so many years the home of his newspapers. Some accounts even had it that an architect was already preparing the plans.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 24 -- The twenty-first national conference of charities and correction began its session in this city this morning, President Lucas C. Stores of Lansing, Mich., presiding. Joseph P. Byers, Chairman of the Committee on Reports from the States, and Levi L. Barbour of Michigan, Chairman of the Committee on State Boards of Charities, read papers incident to the work of their respective committees.

Warden Patrick Hayes of the Kings County Penitentiary placed extra guards on duty in that institution on Wednesday night, and there was considerable guessing among the guards and keepers as to the cause of the Warden taking this extra precaution.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 24 -- Rufus Batchelor has sent to the Hudson County Grand Jury charges that ex-Collector R. Cadmus Combes is $2,000 short in his accounts, and that ex-Councilmen John H. Donohoe and Richard A. Bridgman are guilty of malfeasance.

A small collection of antique silver plate was unpacked in the seizure room in the Barge Office yesterday, having been held for undervaluation. It arrived here several weeks ago on the steamship Umbria. J.R. Willis, an American residing in London, brought it over. He had packed it in a trunk and consigned it to himself.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 25 -- Italian and German silk weavers from Hoboken, to the number of 422, descended on Giveanend Brothers' silk mills here this afternoon with the avowed intention of compelling the employes to quit work. In the crowd were many women.

The anxious and, up to the present time, fruitless quest of President Carnot for a French statesman willing to undertake the responsibilities that M. Casimir-Perier has cheerfully and even hilariously laid down sheds a great deal of light upon the present political condition of France.

CHARLESTON, West Va., May 25 -- News reached here to-day that a body of striking miners from Pomeroy had crossed the river into West Virginia for the purpose of compelling the miners who are at work at Camden and adjoining mines to come out.

SARATOGA, May 25 -- The annual meeting of the American Baptist Publication Society convened in the First Baptist Church this morning. The seventieth annual report of the Board of Managers was presented and read by Col. Charles H. Banes of Philadelphia, the successor of the Rev. Dr. Benjamin Griffith, Corresponding Secretary, who died Oct. 24, 1893.

WALSENBURG, Col., May 25 -- About 450 coal miners from Fremont County passed here at noon bound for the Rouse Mine. They are in an ugly mood and are well armed. They say they will drive out all the working miners of Southern Colorado before they leave the country.

A sad scene of destitution was witnessed yesterday afternoon in front of Police Headquarters. For several hours a wagon, loaded with a few articles of old furniture stood beneath the windows of Superintendent Byrnes's office, while a thin, pale-faced woman, with three small children clinging to her, kept watch.

Gen. Maury's Southern sentiments are shown in his title perhaps more strikingly than in what he writes. He is a Virginian, perhaps, than of his State. We see all through the book his devotion to the South and his pride in his Southern attachment. Probably there live few survivors of the war to whom he would yield in patriotism, as men of the lost cause understand that word.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 25 -- The city was to-day crowded with politicians from every county of the Seventh District. Among the prominent Breckinridge leaders were Col. John O. Hodges, Desha Breckinridge of Lexington, W.P. Thorne, and Col. W.L. Crabb. W.C. Owens was here, and his leaders were Judge Askew of Scott, Harry Clay, Logan Hocker, and Edward Farrell of Lexington, and Emmett Dickson of Bourbon.

PARIS, May 25 -- The police have arrested three Anarchists named Gauch, Guerin, and Beaulleu, who are believed to be most prominent among the leaders of the Anarchist propaganda. Gauch is well born and reared, and is possessed of a fortune of 600,000f. In his lodgings the police found a will bequeathing to a comrade, named Jean Grave, 300,000f., in the event of his death.

Henry C. Rouse, one of the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, appeared before Master in Chancery Alfred L. Cary, in the Mills Building, yesterday. His examination was chiefly remarkable for the numerous objections raised by his counsel, ex-Senator Spooner, to the questions asked by the Board of Directors' counsel, Silas W. Pettit.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- As a result of the investigation made by the sub-committee of the Judiciary Committee into Judge Jenkins's action in preventing the employes of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company from striking, a resolution and two bills, the outgrowth of the report made by the sub-committee, were to-day submitted to the full committee, but not considered.

The question raised by Anthony Comstock as to the moral status of certain books was brought before Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday, when a petition from Joseph J. Little, the receiver for the Worthington Company, book publisher, was submitted to the court, asking for instructions as to what disposition he should make of several works of fiction which he found among the assets of the concern.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- When the Senate ceased operations at 5 o'clock to-day it had reached paragraph 177 of the Tariff bill, which is the last in the metal schedule.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., May 25 -- Striking miners to-day destroyed much property near this thriving little mining town, but, notwithstanding that many conflicts seemed inevitable, all were luckily averted, and no blood was shed.

The managers of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents celebrated the seventieth anniversary of the establishment of the institution yesterday at the House of Refuge, on Randall's Island.

The old brick four-story storage and furniture warehouse painted blue, belonging to Frederick B. Latimer, which has stood for a quarter of a century on the north side of Atlantic Avenue, just west of Court Street, Brooklyn, tumbled down yesterday afternoon.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 25 -- The sloop yacht Wasp, New-York Yacht Club, Mr. H.F. Lippitt of Providence, reached here this afternoon from Port Chester with her owner and party on board. They left the yacht here and proceeded to Providence. She is to await the return of her owner to-morrow evening, when she will proceed to Bristol, R.I.

ALBANY, May 25 -- Gov. Flower has signed Assemblyman Sulzer's bill providing for a transfer tax assistant for the New-York District Attorney, at a salary of $4,000 a year; a transfer tax clerk for the Controller, at a salary of $2,400, and a Surrogate process server in New-York City at a salary of $1,200.

LONDON, May 25 -- In the House of Commons to-day James O'Connor asked the Home Secretary, Mr. Asquith, to reconsider the case of John Daly, the dynamiter, with a view of releasing him from confinement. He said the extreme penalty imposed upon the Anarchist Polti was only ten years, while Daly had already been in prison more than ten years.

The first report of the investigating committee of the Senate, of which Senator Gray is Chairman, was submitted to the Senate yesterday. It is excessively unsatisfactory. It gives but a very meagre notion of what testimony the committee has heard and almost none of the value of that testimony.

The anti-Tammany forces seem not to be agreed as to the proper method of fighting Tammany this Fall. Wednesday night Mr. Platt's Milholland faction of the Republican Party in this city came out for a straight Republican ticket.

ALBANY, May 25 -- Judge Mirabeau L. Towns of Kings is a member of the Suffrage Committee of the Constitutional Convention. He attended the hearing yesterday at which Miss Susan B. Anthony made her speech. The Judge was much impressed with Miss Anthony's statement that in the population of New-York State the women exceeded the men by 7,000.

John N. Guthrie. John. N. Guthrie, who was well known in club life in Brooklyn, died at his home, 882 McDonough Street, yesterday. He was fifty years old, and was engaged in the tobacco business in New-York. Mr. Guthrie was a member of the Eckford and Union Clubs, and was a brother of ex-Supervisor at Large Samuel Guthrie.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 25 -- Gideon Granger, son-in-law of Police Commissioner McClave of New-York, arrived in this city from Yonkers yesterday afternoon. He has retained S.J. Stillwell, a well-known lawyer here, to represent him in his legal difficulties.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25 -- The Senate, which was to meet at 10 o'clock this morning, failed to come together, owing to the defection of Senator Ward of Salem, a Republican, who persisted in refusing to agree to vote for the passing of the vetoed Newark and Jersey City Board of Works bill.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A report exonerating Senators Kyle and Hunton and fastening the charge of attempting to bribe these gentlemen upon Major C.W. Buttz was delivered to the Senate to-day by Mr. Gray, the head, of the star-chamber bribery investigating committee.

BOSTON, May 25 -- The market for local stocks was dull and there were no features of interest. Bell Telephone advanced to 191, and closed at 190 1/2, a half point above last night's close. Erie Telephone sold at 44 3/4 for a small lot. Dominion Coal was quiet at 20 1/4. Boston and Albany receded 1, to 205, for one share. Fitchburg was steady at 70.

HEBRON, Neb., May 25 -- Benjamin Young, a farmer living three miles east of Hebron, defeated candidate for Sheriff on the Populist ticket last Fall, has arranged to organize a company to join the Coxey contingent and move on to Washington. He claims that 200 men will join the movement. J.S. Lichtenwalter, also a defeated candidate for Treasurer on the Populist ticket last Fall, will receive recruits at Hubbell and organize an Industrial Army.

Aside from the victory of the Giants, the features of the game at Eastern Park yesterday were the heavy batting of Doyle and the snappy work of the New-Yorks. In six times at bat, Doyle made three two-base hits and two singles, and the Giants, on the whole, played one of their liveliest games of the season.

It is hardly possible that Senator Vest understands what would be the actual operation of the amendment he recently introduced to the income-tax provisions of the tariff law or how much it is in conflict with justice and with the settled principles of law.

The agreement of the Western railroad Presidents to maintain rates and the appointment of a Board of Control to see that the agreement is adhered to had a beneficial influence on the prices of stocks generally and particularly of those of the Granger roads. The buying of St. Paul was excellent, and it was made up of orders not alone to cover short contracts, but for investment also.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., May 25 -- Coroner Batton has yielded to strong and general criticism on the inquest held by Justice Browneller, yesterday, in which the latter exonerated the deputies who killed the strikers at the Washington Run Mine, and to-night ordered the verdict set aside. He has directed Deputy Coroner Echard to hold another inquest, and to bring out all the facts in the case.

Suggestions are numerous as to the men who shall be placed in nomination for Mayor of this imperial city. It is understood that the Hon. Thomas F. Gilroy does not care for a second term, and the Hon. Hugh J. Grant has said to us that he will not accept office this year. His private business requires his attention, and we are glad to hear that he is making money.
Mr. John T. Williams has bought of Robert W. Tailer the two lots, together 50 by 108 feet, at 3 and 5 Waverley Place, north side, between Broadway and Mercer Streets, for about $135,000.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Cabinet met to-day for the first time in two weeks, all the President's advisers except the Secretary of the Navy attending. Theodore Runyon, the American Ambassador to Germany, who has just reached Washington, on special leave of absence from his post, was taken to the Cabinet meeting by Secretary Gresham, who was also armed with documents relating to the Samoan question.

BOSTON, May 25 -- This has been a quiet day so far as the interchange of civilities with the officers of the British ships goes, for the formal courtesies demanded by the international code of etiquette were finished with the Governor's call yesterday afternoon. The officers took their ease, therefore, most of them spending a good part of the day ashore.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The investigation into the alleged armor-plate frauds by the Carnegie Company was continued to-day, Capt. Sampson, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department, being examined.

Melancholia, extending over a period of several years, brought on by the actions of her husband, i the defense in the case of Mrs. Catherine M. Fitzgerald, who is on trial before Judge Cowing, in Part II., General Sessions, for the killing of Mrs. Carrie Pearsall, wife of Policeman John W. Pearsall, Oct 2, 189, at 515 East Eighty-sixth Street.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 25 -- The victory of Col. Gates in Alabama has created a stampede in the anti-Administration forces here in Georgia that has greatly disconcerted those gentlemen who have been so vigorously objecting to Mr. Cleveland and everything that he has done.

In the Senate, on July 26, 1892, Mr. Aldrich of Rhode Island read a long speech relating to the tariff, which had been prepared for use in the approaching campaign. With this speech he submitted for publication a considerable number of letters, received in response to his inquiries.
"You may persecute the American Protective Association as much as you please, but it will live and prosper and grow. It is spreading the light."

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., May 25 -- There was a lively struggle for a prisoner in front of the Police Court here this morning between four Queens County constables and Detective Kelly and Policeman Graham of this city. The prisoner was Frank Lijox of 150 Review Avenue, this city.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The nomination by the President to-day of C.C. Baldwin to be Naval Officer of the Port of New-York and J.A. Sullivan to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District to succeed M. Kerwin has occasioned considerable gossip among the politicians who have been waiting anxiously for these places to be filled.

ST. THOMAS, Ontario, May 25 -- An American flag in front of United States Consul Willis's office, in this city, was torn down, and destroyed last night by some members of the Queen's Own Rifles of Toronto who were under the influence of liquor. Some other members of the regiment who were in the crowd protested against the outrage, but were unable to prevent their drunken companions from carrying out their intention.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Seldom has so much gratification been expressed by public men generally as has been heard on all sides to-day over the United Press accounts of the great demonstration of good feeling in London yesterday at the banquet to American naval officers.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., May 25 -- The Rev. R.J. Cunningham, the Presbyterian divine and Professor of Philosophy in Wabash College, the leading Presbyterian institution in the West, is very indignant at the late action of the General Assembly regarding the control of theological seminaries.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 25 -- Though the sulkies did not entirely escape the rain to-day, there was enough of a respite to permit of deciding three events on the much-delayed card. Quite a crowd gathered and the sun smiled on the sport for nearly two hours. Then came a drizzle, in which the horses went on, but finally a heavy downpour brought the fun to a standstill, with nearly three hours of daylight left.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Senatorial bribery committee continued its inquiry to-day into the allegations concerning the Sugar Trust and its connection with the Tariff bill.

SARATOGA, May 25 -- The General Assembly convened as a judicatory again to-day to continue the hearing in the Smith heresy case, the prosecution having forty-five minutes of the time assigned to them still at their disposal.

LONDON, May 25 -- Benjamin Louis Cohen, member for East Islington, has given notice in the House of Commons that on Monday he will question the Government concerning the alleged racing of ocean steamers, calling attention to the statements made by passengers on the steamer Majestic.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The local stock market was stronger at the opening to-day, but before noon it weakened considerably, and prices sagged off, recovering fully at the extreme close. The report issued by the Lake Street "L" yesterday probably had something to do with the weakening of the stock.

Dun's Review will say to-day: "Storms and floods, prolonged strikes, and large exports of gold have done their utmost this week to give business a vacation. But the wants unsatisfied during the past year, belated and much lessened, and yet greater than those of any other nation, have caused a volume of trade quite large for the season.

MONTREAL, May 26 -- Emanuel Lasker, the German chess expert, beat W. Steinitz in the nineteenth game of the chess match for the championship of the world and $2,000 a side, and secured the match, the final score being: Lasker, 10; Steinitz, 5; drawn, 4.

The Park Commissioners have sent to the Corporation Counsel for his approval the modified contracts for the first and second sections of the Harlem River Driveway. The contracts were modified by the Commissioners to comply with the law which compelled them to make the sidewalk on the river side of the driveway continuous.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28 -- University of Pennsylvania defeated Harvard this afternoon in a very one-sided game. The visitors' playing was clean and full of snap, while the Harvard men seemed to lose all heart in the early part of the game. The Pennsylvanians bunched their hits, and Harvard made costly errors at critical times.

The New-York and Brooklyn baseball teams met on the Polo Grounds yesterday and furnished an exciting game to about 7,000 spectators. Meekin occupied the box for the home team and Capt. Foutz put in Stein and Dalley as the battery. The New-Yorks won by 1 run by timely hitting. Starting off with a lead of 5, the New-Yorks got a lead the Brooklyns were not able to overcome.

The Rev. Dr. Jerome Allen. The Rev. Dr. Jerome Allen, a well-known educator, who, until last Spring, was Dean of the School of Pedagogy in the University of the City of New-York, died yesterday, after a long illness, at his home, 398 McDonough Street, Brooklyn.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 10 -- The amount of property destroyed and the number of lives lost in the recent earthquake is not yet known. Reports are still coming in to Caracas day by day, however, and many believe that when the truth is known the loss will be appalling.

A bright day for the first time in a week, a half holiday, and the fact that the race for the Great American Stakes was to be run, resulted in bringing together to the Brooklyn Jockey Club track the largest crowd that has been there since Dr. Rice won the Brooklyn Handicap. It looked as if there were more than 10,000 people within the track inclosure.
The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessment and the heirs of the estate of the late Jay Gould are now debating whether the estate should be made to pay personal taxes to this city.

The experience of the New-York coal dealers who went down the shaft of the South Wilkesbarre Mine last week Is one which they never will forget. That the result was not serious to the party was due to the cool-headedness of the company's officials who had them in charge. Patrick Curtis, one of the party, describing the adventure yesterday, said:

On the corner of two quiet home-lined streets in Baysborough, on the Mil overloking Washington Avenue, there stood a modest slate-colored brick house containing a shop. Its show window rounded the angle and displayed to the passer-by all manner of wools and yarns and worsteds, tapestry work most rigidly ornate, and antimacassars severe enough in pattern to dry the oil from the head of the most extravagant of old-time beaus.

The big event of Memorial Day will be the Irvington-Millburn road race, over the famous New-Jersey path. This year the entry list is larger than last, and the chances arc that the twenty-five-mile road record will be lessened considerably. There are 155 young men training for this event, and they will do all in their power to secure the valuable prizes offered and gain the honor of capturing the biggest road race of the year.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 26 -- The convention of the American Baptist Publication Society was continued this forenoon in the First Baptist Church. Three addresses were delivered -- "Colporteurage," by the Rev. B.D. Thomas of Toronto; "The Work of This Society in the South," by the Rev. Henry McDonald of Atlanta, Ga., and "Tract Work," by the Rev. Dr. R.G. Seymour of Lowell, Mass.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary Lamont has determined on a new policy of administration in the War Department. It will go into operation on July 1, ana insures an economical and expeditious method. It abolishes for the first time in many years the red-tape system which has weighed down Government business in the War Department.

Probably the most notable assemblage of railroad men ever held in this city will be the Grand Convention of Railroad Employes of the United States, Canada, and Mexico, which will open this morning at the Lenox Lyceum. It will be under the auspices of the Order of Railway Conductors of America, and the sessions will be held to-day, tomorrow, and Tuesday, opening each morning at 10 o'clock.

Patents have been granted for making innumerable queer things out of paper -- such as carpets, electric conduits, lead pencils, roofing material, car wheels, boats, pails, coffins, brushes, and combs. Mattresses are manufactured out of paper pulp and ordinary sponge, springs being imbedded in the composition.

HAMILTON, Ohio, May 26 -- In the suit filed by ex-Gov. James E. Campbell against the Hooven, Owens Rentechler Company of this city the answer of the defendants was filed this afternoon. They say that in 1889 and 1890 Mr. Campbell, while in New-York City, borrowed $66,000 of the Southern Trust Company, giving as security 306 shares of the defendant company's stock.
CHAPTER XIII. (Continued). -- "WHAT LOVE WAS EVER AS DEEP AS THE GRAVE?"

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Mr. Gray's star chamber committee of investigation has been engaged to-day behind closed doors in discussing the question whether it will be possible to compel the newspaper men who have been examined by the committee this week to reveal the names of the persons on whose alleged statements they based their reports concerning the Sugar Trust's connection with the revised sugar schedule.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 26 -- One of the principal desires of the business man, after a day's hard work in the city, is a cozy, comfortable, and quiet home where he may enjoy relaxation with his family in a pure country atmosphere, enhanced by magnificent scenery. It is in Yonkers that such rest is to be found.

BERLIN, May 26 -- The bill to create Chambers of Agriculture throughout Prussia, the last measure of importance before the Landtag, has been accepted by the upper house without any considerable alteration of the form in which the Deputies passed it. According to the compromise, approved by the Government, the chambers will be instituted by royal decree.

WHITESTONE, L.I., May 26 -- Frank Taff of this place, the patentee of the finmotion propeller for steam vessels, grave an exhibition of the working of the device in the East River off this place to-day. The fins were attached, two on each side, to a thirteen-foot model, and were driven by a one-horse power engine.

The announcement was made in a Brooklyn paper yesterday that the accounts of County Treasurer Henry H. Adams were short $75,000, and that this shortage had been found by the expert accountant who was employed by the Board of Supervisors to go over the books for the last several years.

LONDON, May 26 -- For at least a passing moment Mr. Gladstone has been brought forward again to his legitimate place as the foremost of living men in the thoughts and solicitude of his fellow-countrymen.

A nation behaves very much as do the individuals that compose it. When it is overtaken by hard times, when business falls off, profits shrink or cease, and ready money is hard to get, it cuts down its expenses first for the things it can most readily get along without. Often, also, this process is made necessary by extravagant indulgence in this kind of expenditure.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26 -- The doors of the Golf Clubhouse were thrown open on Tuesday. Next month other features will be added and the grounds opened, and in July and August there will be two concerts a week by a band of Russian musicians.

The Seventh Regiment went out to Van Cortlandt Park yesterday morning and held its annual field drill, which was followed in the afternoon with a sham battle, in which more than 1,000 men were saved from annihilation simply because their cartridges were blank.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A man who said he came from New-York City and who represented himself as Assistant Surgeon J.E. Hendrickson of the army has been annoying army officers here this week. He called on several people and with remarkable boldness gave his assumed name and his alleged connection with the service.

One of the most remarkable things connected with the disclosure by The New-York Times of the workings in this State of the notorious A.P.A. is the fact that no man prominent and active in Republican politics has been found willing to express an opinion condemning the un-American propaganda of the vicious association.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary Carlisle to-day refused to revoke the order of Secretary Foster suspending all hat-trimming refunds. The amount involved in these cases aggregates. It is estimated, $55,000,000. In his letter to the counsel for Messrs. Fleitman Co., the importers, Secretary Carlisle says that when Secretary Foster issued the order of suspension, counsel for the importers demanded either immediate payment or a restoration of the cases to the docket for trial.
TORONTO, Ontario, May 26 -- Lieut. Col. Hamilton of the Queen's Own Regiment gives his version of the flag incident at St. Thomas as follows:

President McBride of the National Association of Coal Miners has issued an appeal to the strikers to "keep the peace and protect property," telling them, that the markets are short of coal and all that is needed now is to "remain firm." But outbreaks of lawlessness and violence are the inevitable result of such a strike as was ordered by McBride's association and of the methods employed to keep it up.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 26 -- The Summer season will open at this always popular resort earlier this year than usual. All the big hotels are open, and most of them have guests in unusual numbers for this time of the year.
A chief charm of the screen, which is described as well worth the attempt to duplicate, lay in the rich, subdued colors of the oriental embroidery that was a part of its decoration.

The New-York Yearly Meeting of Friends began in the meeting house in East Twentieth Street, opposite Gramercy Park, last Friday under circumstances of peculiar interest. One hundred and ninety-nine years ago the first yearly meeting of Friends was held at Flushing, L.I., and in 1794 the sessions were first held in New-York City.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 26 -- Mr. William H. Crane's steam yacht The Senator reached this harbor this afternoon about 4 o'clock, having steamed leisurely from Hyannis, Mass. The Senator left Boston Wednesday. She will remain Sunday, or perhaps until Monday, when she will leave for New-York, where Mr. Crane will join her.
According to calculations made by officers of the Cunarder Lucania, that vessel has eclipsed in point of speed, but not in time, the ocean record which she established last year.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day decided that the Western Union Telegraph Company was not liable in damages to the sender of a message in cipher for errors in transmission thereof.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- As there is practically no short interest in our traction stocks, the market to-day did not sympathize with the strength of New-York. The new Electric Traction rights came out to-day for the first time, selling at 18, which is equivalent to 86 for the full-paid stock.

Alfred L. Cary, Master in Chancery, appointed by the United States Circuit Court in Wisconsin to take testimony in the matter of the alleged irregularities in the past management of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, closed a two weeks' hearing in this city yesterday. He will resume the inquiry in Milwaukee on the 4th of next month.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 26 -- The challenge shoot between George Work, who won the Riverton Plate from Fred Hoey last week, and T.S. Dando of Riverton, for the same plate, took place to-day. The men shot at 100 birds each, under the conditions that ruled the match between Work and Hoey. There were many spectators present, including a large number of ladies and gentlemen from New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Boston, and Brooklyn.

CAPE MAY, N.J., May 26 -- Cape May has given notice that she proposes to throw off the lethargy of a dozen years and will compete with some of her neighbors for more than a local business, and she announces it as her intention to continue in these efforts until she has regained some of her lost prestige as the most fashionable seaside resort in America.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26 -- The United States cruiser Atlanta will be able to comply with the orders issued detailing her to fluty at Bluefields. The stores and crew of the United States steamship Richmond were to-day transferred to the Constellation, and the Atlanta will sail Monday morning, weather permitting, for League Island, with the Richmond in tow.

DENVER, Col., May 26 -- The exciting scenes of to-day in Cripple Creek resulted in the death of two men, William Ribeau, a Depuity Sheriff, who, some weeks ago, was driven out of camp by miners for his pernicious activity and r, and George Crowley, a well-know r.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 26 -- The Governor has ordered five companies of the Fifth Regiment to Pana.

Gideon Granger, son-in-law of Police Commissioner McClave, may testify again Tuesday before the Senate committee which is investigating the Police Department. This, however, depends, his lawyer says, on "certain things," which are believed to concern his wife's suit for divorce. Granger's lawyer is S.J. Stillwell of Mount Vernon, who said yesterday that, unless Commissioner McClave accepted a proposition which Granger would make to him.

The plans prepared by the Memorial Day Committees of the Grand Army of the Republic indicate that there will be a wide observance of the day next Wednesday, not only by the veterans, but by other people all over the country, and that the graves of the soldier dead will be more generally decorated than ever before.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 26 -- John J. Clifford, an attendant at the Buffalo State Hospital, has been suspended by the Board of Managers pending the action of Acting District Attorney Kendrick in the Felton case.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 26 -- As graduation week approaches, the number of visitors at the hotels is increasing.
