The cot- tages at Highland Falls, which have been Closed, through the Winter, are again beginning to show signs of life. Those at the military post have been occupied by the professors and officers attached to the academy.

There has been a considerable increase activity the past week, but the commission houses have had little benefit from it. The business has been all professional. About half of it seemed to be in Sugar, which has gone through a series of ups and down remarkable even for that stock. Saturday a week ago it closed at 94 3/4 ; yesterday it closed at 100 3/4 .

The question whether a newspaper correspondent may refuse to make known the source of the information he furnishes to his paper, which the Senate investigation committee appears unanimously to have decided in the negative, is not altogether one-sided. A correspondent may make pledges of secrecy which it would be not only dishonorable to violate, but injurious to him, as being calculated to lower his standing in his calling.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The price of wheat suffered at the hands of the Bears to-day. Pardridge and his following were at their old tactics and pressing their advantage for all there was in it. There was no lack of crop news of the calamity sort, but the bulls have too often pinned their faith to them, with the ultimate result of disappointment, and they felt no disposition to listen to them to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The bill for the repeal of the State bank tax was again under consideration by the House to-day, and its discussion occupied the entire session. No action was taken on the measure, and it went over until Tuesday. Mr. Springer of Illinois made a long speech in defense of the bill, and speeches were also made by Messrs.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 26 -- The political sensation of the hour here is the remarkable and sudden change of attitude on the part of The Atlanta Constitution, which has led the anti-Administration fight in the South, and which has been conceded to be President Cleveland's bitterest antagonist in this section.

The completion of the drawbridge and high viaduct over the Thames near the Tower of London is almost as important a matter to people who have to go to and fro between Bermondsey, Walworth, Camberwell and Peckham on the south bank of the Thames, and the eastern part of the old City of London on the north bank, as the suspension bridge is important to people who live in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Matilda E. Goodwin and her son, Clifford Coddington Goodwin, were before Justice Feitner in the Yorkville Police Court yesteraay charged with kidnapping Caroline Gladys Coddington, three years old, the daughter of Mrs. Alma Louise Coddington-Fellows.

The stock market was fairly active yesterday, considering the half holiday. The opening was rather animated, particularly in Sugar and in the Granger stocks. The former opened 1 8/3 lower, at 101, the manipulators not opposing the lower level. At the decline, however, there was good buying, which put the price back to 102 8/3.

As Treasurer of the Emergency Fund, started several months ago to give relief to the poor of the city by work, Charles S. Smith, ex-President of the Chamber of Commerce, submitted his accounts last week to be audited. The subscribers to the fund appointed as Auditing Committee, A.B. Hepburn, President of the Third Nations Bank, and James G. Cannon, Vice President of the Fourth National Bank.

BLUEFIELDS, Nicaragua, May 21, via New-Orleans, La., May 26, per steamer Espania -- The British war ship Magicienne has returned from Colon, whither she had gone to cable to the London office the arrival of Chief Clarence here under British protection and to ask for further instructions in the matter.
Since the Republican Party obtained control of the Municipal Government in Brooklyn many prominent Republicans who have tasted the sweets of office have become opposed to consolidation with New-York.

A marked change has lately come over the character and conduct of horse sale in this city, which has caused much talk of late, especially among ladies who have a love for the horse and a fondness for riding and driving. It has come about slowly but none the less surely, and the result is that the sales of stock from the well-known breeding farms are developing into a sort of semi-social function.

LONDON, May 26 -- The official celebration of Queen Victoria's birthday occurred to-day. The military ceremony known as the "trooping of the colors" took place on the White Hall parade ground, and was witnessed by the Prince and Princess of Wales, the Duchess of Albany, the Duchess of Saxe-Coburg; and other members of the royal family.

The yachting season all along the Atlantic coast will be formally opened this week. Decoration Day usually marks the beginning of the season, but this year several clubs hoisted their pennants earlier. Among these were the Larchmont, Atlantic, New-Rochelle, Riverside, Corinthian Mosquito, and a few of the smaller clubs.

Decent people were greatly amused when the Greenwich Anarchist, who had intended to blow up the Greenwich Observatory and the longitude therein contained, thus insuring the wreck of thousands of vessels left to sail the seas without any longitude whatever, blew himself up.

BOSTON, May 26 -- The market for local stocks showed little change, and experienced the usual Saturday dullness. Wisconsin Central 5s sold up 1/4, to 61 1/4, and there were no sales of the stock. The telephones were quiet and steady. Bell sold at 191, 1 higher than yesterday, and Erie at 45. Lamson was firm at 22 1/2.

From The London Economist, May 19, 1894. Although not perhaps abundant, there are some signs which seem to show that rather more equity may in the future characterize American railway schemes of reorganization. The New-York and New-England we referred to a week or two ago is a case in point, and it appears also to be regarded in that light on the other side of the Atlantic.

Col. Albert W. Bradbury, who was appointed by President Cleveland on the 22d inst. to be United States District Attorney for Maine, is a resident of Portland, in that State, where he has practiced law for several years. He is a graduate of Bowdoin College, where he had as classmates exSpeaker Thomas B. Reed, United States Minister to Sweden W.W. Thomas, Judge Symonds of the Supreme Court of Maine, and other noted men.

Probably few Americans who do not keep closely in touch with Lonaon happenings know much about George Bernard Shaw. His name does not appear in the latest edition of that invaluable but inevitably incomplete compendium, "Men of the Time," in which the only Shaws mentioned are Shaw-Lefevre and Capt. Shaw, the distinguished fireman.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- In the Senate this afternoon Mr. Vest (Dem., Mo.,) made a favorable report on the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill by submitting a substitute for the bill as it passed the House. To the second section of the bill the following additional provision has been added:

PARIS, May 26 -- After an hour's conversation with President Carnot, M. Dupuy consented this afternoon to undertake the formation of a Cabinet. He will return to the Elysee to-morow afternoon, probably with a complete list of his Ministry. After leaving the President M. Dupuy paid complimentary visits to ex-Ministers Raynal and Casimir-Perier.

Willow Street, Brooklyn, has a knocker. That is, not the street itself, but one of the quaint, old-fashioned houses that give that part of Brooklyn such a staid air of eminent respectability, and in their well-preserved and variously improved conditions impart to it as well a tone of substantial prosperity.

The help of this newspaper is asked for the suppression of an "oligarchy." The oligarchy in Question is composed of the Mayor of New-York and a private citizen, Mr. Elbridge T. Gerry, who, in his capacity of President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, has done this public some service of great value.

Prof. Herbert A. Howe, the astronomer of the Chamberlain Observatory, at the University of Denver, is now in Washington, superintending the shipment to that institution of a big telescope. For several months Mr. George N. Saegmuller and the scientific workers in his employ have been engaged in the construction of this telescope, which is considered one of the most complete in existence.
It was in this same May, not more than a week after the momentous episode of the Field Hospital and Nurse Fund Fair, that Marsena Pulford went off to the war.

Edward F. O'Dwyer of 15 Whitehall Street gave out yesterday for publication the following call, issued by business men, for a mass meeting to protest against the income-tax feature of the Tariff bill:

The theatre managers are beginning their vacations, and the theatrical gossip afloat pertains mostly to projected enterprises of next season. A column or so could be filled with the promises of new plays and new actors to come before this public in the Winter of 1894-95, but the promise of Spring is rarely fulfilled in the Fall in dramatic matters.

LONDON, May 26 -- The Government, strengthened, by a series of defeats of the Opposition on the budget, now hopes to pilot its way through the session. The sudden weakness displayed by the Opposition has been a surprise all around. Various causes have been assigned for this, but probably none of them is the real one.

The closing of the month of May show an inclination on the part of real estate men to hurry up transactions before the end of the active trading season. Many negotiations, some of them for very valuable pieces of property, are under way, and the next fortnight or three weeks should show some decided results.

Mrs. Ulysses S. Grant is spending a few days at the Fifth Avenue Hotel prior to her departure for Cranstons-on-the-Hudson, where she will spend part of the summer. Mrs. Grant denies the report that she is going abroad this season.

ORANGE, May 26 -- Over 4,000 people filled the grand stand, bleacheries, and available standing space at the baseball game between Yale University and the Orange Athletic Club at East Orange this afternoon. Several trains on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad unloaded almost their entire cargoes of passengers at the oval, and nearly a thousand bicycles were stacked against the fence during the game.

They were a party of newspaper men, and they fell to talking of printers and telegraph operators who had grown famous in their callings. They were sitting on the graveled roof of one of the wings of The Atlanta Constitution office, in full view of the editorial rooms, waiting with as much patience as they could command the result of certain deliberations in progress within said editorial rooms.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26 -- The uncertainty which existed among the Republican politicians since last Monday in regard to John O. Pitney's acceptance or declination of the position of City Attorney, tendered to him by Mayor Lebkuecher, was settled to-day, when the Mayor, received a cablegram from Mr. Pitney, in Europe, declining the place.

Washington, May 26 -- Edward Keys of Paterson, N.J., has been appointed Inspector, Weigher, and Measurer of Wood and Coal for the Interior Department, in place of James C. Leonard of Newark, N.J., resigned. The fees of the office amount to about $1,200 a year.

Just at present the musical world in this city is resting. We are in that season which is given over to the merry chimes of more or less delectable operetta music and the blare of brass bands across beakers of beer. Sousa's Band, a really good one, occupies the Madison Square Garden, and those who enjoy the music of a military band in a concert hall are having a delightful time.

Gov. Flower was the guest of honor at the last monthly dinner for the season of the Democratic Club, last evening, at its clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue, and 130 other guests and members sat down to dine with him. Ex-Senator Fox presided, and at his right sat the Governor, Henry K. Beekman, and Judge Truax.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 26 -- At 6 o'clock this evening a mob of strikers from the Moon Run Coke Company's plant raided the works of the Imperial Coal Company at Imperial, in the Mansfield Valley. Joseph Bete was killed. Whether Bete was a nonunion man or a striker is not yet known. None of the Deputy Sheriffs were at the plant at the time of the raid.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 26 -- The rain, which has fallen almost incessantly in the Catskills for the last week, has turned every rivulet into a mountain torrent and has made the beautiful valleys and hillsides dismal places indeed for the early Summer visitors. The week has been a quiet one even in Stamford, and cottagers have spent the time generally preparing for the coming season, of festivity.

Glenny failed in the cycle contest, Richards was too slow in the sprints, Morgan again lost in the mile run, and many other track athletes sent here by Yale did not cover themselves with glory in the intercollegiate championships yesterday, but sturdy Hickok, muscular Kershow, and speedy Cady saved the day, and once more the colors of "Old Eli" floated triumphantly.

AMHERST, Mass., May 26 -- Dartmouth again defeated Amherst in a very exciting game. Stearns went in the box for Amherst, as there was no available pitcher, and, although hit hard at times, pitched a creditable game throughout. Dinsmore again pitched for Dartmouth, but did not do as well as on Friday. He managed, however, to keep the hits well scattered, with men on bases.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 26 -- "Fantasma" was presented in Music Hall Thursday and Friday evenings by a talented company of young men and women. The entertainment was given for the benefit of the Auxiliary Board of Muhlenberg Hospital. It was a decided success and handsomely produced.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, sitting in equity, to-day, Judge Cox presiding, was enlivened by a preliminary hearing in a remarkable case.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, Curator of the Department of Public Instruction of the American Museum of Natural History, sailed for the British Isles Saturday on the City of Rome. He was accompanied by Mrs. Bickmore. Their trip abroad is for a specific purpose, although they expect it to be replete with pleasure.

President Gilman and the university people have always believed that Johns Hopkins was born on May 19, 1794. and have frequently given this date in official publications, notably so in a historical statement prepared by Dr. Gilman last December.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 26. -- The General Assembly confirmed the judgment of the Cincinnati Presbytery finding Prof. Henry Preserved Smith guilty of heresy at 4:30 o'clock to-day by an overwhelming vote. This result was reached after three tiresome days, during which the 500 judges were kept in close attendance upon the sessions.

The last shot has been fired by the Brooklyn anti-suffragists, camp has been broken, and active operations ended with the issuance of a pamphlet to be presented to the delegates to the Constitutional Convention and a list of names calculated to strike terror to the hearts of the opposing forces.

Preparations have been completed for the services at the unveiling of Alexander Doyle's statue of Horace Greeley, in Greeley Square, on Memorial Day. The occasion will be a notable one. The statue is distinctively a printers' memorial to the greatest of the craft, and members of the Press Club and the Typographical Unions of this city and Brooklyn, and Horace Greeley Post, G.A.R., will attend in a body.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club's meeting, by far the most successful in its history, will be brought to a close to-morrow, the two stakes left for decision on that day being the Fort Hamilton Handicap, for three-year-olds, at a mile and an eighth, and the Tremont Stakes, for two-year-olds. In the latter, the two-year-olds will be asked to run their full stake distance, three-quarters of a mile, for the first time this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27 -- This year the pamphlet containing the announcement of the courses of instruction has been Issued much earlier than usual, and the students are already preparing their programmes for the year 1894-5. In all, 210 full courses and 134 half courses will be given, ranging from Greek to blacksmithing and from economics to anthropometry.

Statistics having been put forward recently with regard to the sale of the works of modern French authors -- the object being to show that M. Zola is the most popular writer in France at the present day -- M. Francois Coppee. the poet novelist, protests against certain inferences drawn from the figures.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Eugene T. Chamberlain, Commissioner of Navigation, has prepared, as bearing upon pending shipping legislation, a memorandum concerning the taxation of vessels, which contains many interesting facts. The memorandum says:

SALT LAKE, Utah, May 27 -- Three hundred and twenty-five Commonwealers are being held by a strong force of police and Deputy Sheriffs at the Davis County line to prevent them coming through the county, and thence into this city. The officials are armed with an order of the District Court, declaring the Commonwealers a menace to property, and forbidding them entering Davis County.

The Rev. Dr. David G. Wylie, pastor of the Scotch Presbyterian Church, in which there have been dissensions for the last two weeks, preached yesterday morning on "The Office and Work of Ruling Elders." The occasion was the installation of Hugh Cheyne, John William, Archibald B. McPhail, and Alexander W. Turner as Elders, they having been elected last Wednesday.

ALBANY, May 26 -- There was considerable trading in Consolidated Car Heating stock this week. The inquiry was good at 60. while several round lots were offered at 61. The quotation remains unchanged at last week's closing figures. Troy Railway was in demand. A concession has been made in the asked from 83 to 82.

ALBANY, May 27 -- Now that the Constitutional Convention has started on its way, a fair opportunity has been obtained to look over its members, their records, their capabilities, the powers that controlled their nominations, the influences that have swayed them during life in their business or professions.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 26 -- The past week in the local stock market has been without feature. While there is considerable money about, the disposition on the part of buyers is to wait for lower prices and on the other hand those who have stock for sale prefer to take advantage of low rates for money, and borrow on their securities rather than sell them at the present quotations.
"I believe the people who low this city and their country ought to impeach Mayor Schieren before the Supreme Court.

The Republicans of this city are discussing the advisability of nominating "a straight ticket" for the next municipal election. Opinion is not unanimous as to whether this should be done, although some who are reckoned as prominent in the organization are in favor of drawing the lines strictly, and making an effort to defeat Tammany Hall without asking any assistance or making any "trade" with the anti-Tammany organizations which are not Republican.

LISBON, May 27 -- The Brazilian Government has accepted the mediation of England in its dispute with Portugal concerning the asylum granted by Portuguese naval officers at Rio Janeiro to Admiral da Gama and his staff. The commanders of the war ships Mindello and Affonso de Albuquerque, who received the fugitive insurgents, will be court-martialed in Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Private advices received in Washington from Peru state that Gen. Caesar Canevaro, Minister to the United States, who was elected First Vice President of the Republic of Peru last month, has been prevailed upon by his friends to stand for the national Senate from Lima.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., May 27 -- A notable event is to take place here on June 14, when the cornerstone of a monument will be laid with imposing ceremonies.

The net result of operations in the stock market last week was material gains for the large majority of issues. In the early part of the week the volume of trading was greatly contracted, but business improved later on. The lowest prices were made on Tuesday, and the highest on Friday and Saturday.

The author of these letters was the daughter of the fifth Duke of Devonshire and the beautiful Duchess, tie sister of the sixth Duke, the wife of that Lord Granville who was long the English Ambassador to Paris, and the mother of that Lord Granville, the statesman whom England lost only a few years ago.

SARATOGA, May 27 -- The result of a conference between committees representing the two national religious bodies now in session here led to a joint union service in the big convention hall to-night. It began at 9:30 o'clock, after the services in the regular churches were concluded. The audience numbered over 5,000 persons. The Rev. Dr. S.A. Mutchmore, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, presided.

The Rev. Newman Manning, a greatnephew of the late Cardinal Manning of England, preached last evening in the Twenty-fifth Street Baptist Church on "Romanism." He defended the Catholic clergy and laity from the accusations made against them by the A.P.A.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 27 -- In anticipation of the gala time of the year, the graduation of the first class men, the reception of the Board of Visitors, and the influx of visitors from all parts of the Union, the grounds of the academy are being put in perfect condition.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 27 -- The campaign in Georgia for the Democratic nomination for Governor has passed the speechmaking stage, and narrowed down to a contest be- tween the two candidates, Gen. Clement A. Evans and W.Y. Atkinson, for the capture of the mass meetings and primaries being held from day to day in the several counties.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 27 -- The northern part of the city, known as Kensington, is all agog to-day with the story of the elopement of pretty Nellie Shrively and the exciting pursuit made by her brother, the Rev. William Shrively, the pastor of the Kensington Methodist Episcopal Church.

PARIS, April 27 -- People have about decided that the poem of an opera is its main backbone; I might almost add attraction. This same -- shall I say "literary" tendency? -- is seen in painting. For a long time the French considered the Italians irreverent, and the indignation of the omnipotent Victor Hugo knew no bounds when Verdi took "Hernani."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Secretary Herbert's disinclination to build a submarine torpedo boat has been a matter of wonderment. The experts have generally agreed that subaquatic navigation is feasible and, applied to naval warfare, advisable. The foreigners who have pretended to a progression in the art have readily experimented with submarine boats, and some of the European navies, notably that of France, have adopted the idea.

ORANGE, N.J., May 27 -- The gentlemen and physicians who compose the Sanitary Committee of the Health Board of this city are at present an unpopular set of men among the fair sex of Orange. For many months this city has been infected by diphtheria to a considerable extent. Numbers of cases have developed in all sections and in a most mysterious manner.

Grand Army men were conspicuous at church yesterday. Probably more attend divine service on the Sunday before Memorial Day than on any dozen other Sundays. With their tattered flags the posts, many of them, marched to some house of worship and there listened to sermons intended to prepare them to decorate graves of comrades next Wednesday in the most fitting spirit.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In your Issue of May 24 you make an attack on the A.P.A., and by that you also attack the 2,000,000 members of the said organization. My object in writing this letter is for the purpose of having you carefully examine the A.P.A. side of the question, and see if you cannot easily discover enough and more than enough reasons for the existence of the A.P.A.

SARATOGA, May 27 -- The committee appointed by the Presbyterian General Assembly to confer with Prof. Smith concerning his future conduct to-day completed arrangements for the formal visit. This will take place to-morrow morning.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 27 -- The programme for Commencement Week has been arranged, as follows: Sunday, June 17, baccalaureate sermon by the Rev. Lyraan Abbott of Brooklyn; Tuesday, June 19, class day and senior ball; Wednesday, June 20, Woodford contest in oratory and commencement concert; Thursday, June 21, twenty-sixth annual commencement.
Fleet Capt. Charles T. Pierce of the Atlantic Yacht Club has made public the following orders of Commodore Banks regulating the Decoration Day celebrations:

HAMPTON, Va., May 27 -- If the heroic founder of the Hampton School -- "that Christian knight and latter-day Galahad, Gen. Armstrong," as the poet Whittier called him -- was present in spirit on this first anniversary it has celebrated without him, he must have rejoiced in the evidence that his parting bequest of his great work to the people of the country had been so honored.
The Brooklyn Tabernacle congregation worshipped yesterday morning and evening in the Columbia Theatre. The Rev. William P. George, D.D., of Kansas City officiated at both services.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27 -- Since the downfall of the "college crew," the attention of the Harvard students has been directed mainly to the dispiriting state of freshman athletics. Both the baseball team and the crew are at present in a financial box, on account of careless management, inclemency of weather, and disappointing work.

BERLIN, May 27 -- The Anglo-Belgian agreement as to sphere of influence in Central Africa has roused the Colonial enthusiasts to the usual outcry against English greed. In the Foreign Office, however, a totally different feeling is noticeable. The officials there, while acknowledging that the French have been thoroughly outwitted, contend that they have been cognizant of the Anglo-Belgian negotiations almost from the first, and have found their tendency highly advantageous to Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Ex-Speaker Sulzer of New-York registered at the Arlington this evening. He has been retained is the counsel of Henry Walker, the newspaper correspondent whose report relative to the alleged operations of the Sugar Trust in connection with the revised sugar schedule of the Tariff bill, have brought him before the Gray star chamber committee of investigation.

RIO JANEIRO, April 28. -- Just what happened to the insurgent cruiser Aquidaban on April 18 is still in doubt. The United Press correspondent saw the official cable from Admiral Goncalves, chief of the Government squadron stating that the iron-clad Aquidaban had been sunk by three torpedoes from the torpedo-chaser Gustavo Sampaio, (formerly Aurora.)

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 27 -- The team that will represent Pennsylvania, in The New-York Times tri-State 150 miles relay race has practically been chosen, though as yet Capts. Allen and Dimon, who have charge of the arrangements at this end, have announced the names of but five members.
The first meeting of the delegates to the grand convention of railway employes was held yesterday morning, in the Lenox Lyceum. The convention is to hold a three days' session.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Atter the severe arraignment of the A.P.A. in to-day's and yesterday's issues of The NewYork Times, will you permit one of its members to plead its cause? To begin with, the A.P.A. has by the daily press been just as much misrepresented as the better class of Roman Catholics have been maligned.

The crack cricket team of the New-Jersey Athletic Club played its first match in the championship series of the Metropolitan League Saturday at Bergen Point, and, true to expectation, they had an easy victory over the Victorias by 62 runs after declaring their innings closed with only five men out.

III. WASHINGTON, May 27 -- If the work of the joint commission of the Senate and House to inquire into the status of the executive departments were to be stopped now, and nothing whatever accomplished by it in addition to the reforms already secured by it in one year, it would have fully justified its creation.

BOSTON, May 27 -- Two Boston men, John Crowley, a well-known lawyer and a member of the Suffolk County bar, and Delos E. Goldsmith, a newspaper writer, faced each other just before last midnight and fought a duel.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 27 -- The Republican leaders of the State have passed the word all along the line that the Fall campaign will be formally opened on June 6, when a convention of all the Republican Clubs in the State will meet here. The most complete efforts possible have been made for the occasion.

LYNCHBURG, Va., May 27 -- The dedication at Appomattox Court House, the scene of the surrender of the army of Gen. Robert E. Lee, and the final act in the collapse of the Confederacy, to-morrow of the tablets erected by the Government to mark the interesting spots in that neighborhood will attract considerable attention.

Veterans of the war took possession of Brooklyn yesterday morning at sunrise and held it until midnight. It was a peaceful occupation. The soldiers bore gifts of flowers and other tributes of affection to the graves of dead comrades, and eloquent words were spoken in eulogy of the Nation's heroes.

The Senate expects to reach the sugar schedule by Thursday, or, if no adjournment is made over Decoration Day, on Wednesday. Then may take place the most strenuous struggle connected with the bill. The Republicans make no secret of their intention to try to put all forms of sugar on the free list.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The interview with me published in The Times of May 23 does not correctly represent either my spirit or sentiments. When your representative asked me for information concerning the A.P.A. I distinctly told him that I was not a member of the order, but that I had studied its aims and purposes.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27 -- Theodore S. Sehulz, a drug clerk employed by Dr. Beeker, at 130 Belmont Avenue, fought for his life for thirty minutes at 1:45 o'clock this morning, with a burglar. Sehulz sleeps in the rear of the store. He was awakened about 1:30 o'clock by a noise in the store, and on looking in saw a man at the till.

Lovers of the horse will be glad to learn that Tiffany Co. are about to issue a series of bronze statuettes of fashionable and popular breeds of horses. They are large enough to make a notable figure on a club table or the mantelpiece of a hall, but not so large as to be very dear and unwieldy.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., May 27 -- After several unsuccessful attempts, James L. Marquis of Philadelphia to-day succeeded in committing suicide. The man hung around the railroad station nearly all day, and his strange behavior and persistent efforts to remain upon the tracks when a train was approaching caused the station hands to keep a sharp watch upon him.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 27 -- The following telegram was received by Gov. Altgeld to-day from the Mayor of Elm wood:

PALATKA, Fla., May 27 -- This afternoon John Kane was shot in the head and dangerously wounded by Ernest Wolfe. Wolfe is a German and a member of the A.P.A., while Kane is an Irish Catholic. The men tell conflicting stories about the affair. Wolfe says that Kane called him "a -- -- A.P.A. man," at the same time striking him with a heavy stick. Wolfe says that he then shot.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27 -- With the rain over and gone, and having left the roads in excellent condition, the prospects of good trundling in The New-York Times's triState 150-mile relay race on June 2 are bright, indeed.

For some months our entertaining neighbor, The Sun, has been urging strenuously that in place of the Wilson bill, or any other Tariff bill constructed in accordance with the general plan of that measure, there should be enacted a Tariff bill which it has repeatedly published at the head of its editorial columns, the essential part of which is as follows:
HOUTZDALE, Penn., May 27 -- After the conclusion of Gov. Pattison's address to the miners and mine laborers last night, the meeting unanimously adopted the following resolution:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 27 -- Decoration Day the annual Yale-Harvard freshman baseball game in this city will take place. As it is the only athletic contest of any kind in the city that day, unusual interest is manifested in the event, aside from the customary class patriotism which will prevail.

If Senator Lexow's remarks about the character of the witness Granger in the police investigation were correctly reported, he indulged in a delightful Hibernicism in saying that "the Senate committee would be disappointed if it expected honest and honorable men to incriminate themselves."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 27 -- At the close of the present college year in June, the work of demolishing another building of the old Brick Row at Yale will begin. The Yale Corporation at Its Spring meeting last week voted that North Middle be removed, and it will be torn down and its site turfed over before the opening of the Fall term in September.

PARIS, May 27 -- The result of M. Dupuy's efforts to form a Cabinet is in doubt. Among the many conflicting rumors concerning the crisis is one that the Anglo-Belgian, agreement as to Central Africa has raised such grave questions between France and England that Casimir-Perier must be retained in the Foreign Office to protect France's interests.

There are some chess players, especially those looking upon the pastime as a sport, who do not care for drawn games. They regard games which are not decided one way or the other as loss of time, and so on. But even this class will have to admit that the eighteenth game between Steinitz and Lasker was an exhibition of great skill.

CONEY ISLAND, May 27 -- Mr. McGuinness and the elephant wept together today at Coney Island, and not even the spectacle of 25,000 pleasure seekers roaming along Surf Avenue and through the Bowery brought consolation to them.

It was shown at the recent annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters that the fire loss in this country last year was $167,000,000, which considerably exceeds the loss in any previous year, and that the business of fire insurance here as a whole had become unprofitable.

Sarah Duffy, an old news-woman who for many years conducted a stand for the sale of papers at Forty-eighth Street and Broadway, was knocked down and fatally injured by a horse and cab at Broadway and Thirty-first Street at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. She was removed to Chambers Street Hospital, where she died at 10:15 A.M.

We are disposed, to credit Mayor Gilroy with proper motives in his opposition to the plan of rapid transit which the new law was intended to provide for. It is, of course, conceivable that he would like to make political capital out of the construction of rapid-transit roads, if it is to be done at public expense, but we do not believe that his opposition is due to the fact that that is made impossible.

DENVER, May 28 -- The Commonweal Army from this city will not start for Washington until 2,500 men are enrolled. It is proposed to travel all the way by rail. The roll now contains 632 names. It is estimated that 700 more Commonwealers axe on their way to this city. Carter and his 275 followers have reached Pueblo.

Much gratification was expressed by members of the Maritime Exchange yesterday upon the receipt of news that President Cleveland had signed the act amending the rule of the road at sea. A series of regulations to prevent collisions at sea had been formulated by the representatives of all nations assembled for that purpose, to be made operative when formally approved by their respective Governments.

PHILLIPSBURG, Penn., May 28 -- To-night everything throughout the entire region is remarkably quiet. So far as could be learned, not one man applied for work this morning, the time set by the operators for a general resumption. Both miners and business men are anxiously awaiting the outcome of the attempt made by Gov. Pattison to bring about a conference of the miners and operators.

A meeting of business men was held yesterday afternoon at the office of the New-York Life Insurance Company to arrange details for the mass meeting called by business men of this city to protest against the passage of the income tax feature of the Tariff bill.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Capt. Sampson, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department, continued his testimony before the armor-plate investigating committee this morning. Mr. Cummings stated that inquiry into the first investigation by the Navy Department was about complete, (as far as Sampson was concerned,) and requested him to give all particulars concerning the second inquiry as far as it had gone.

The indefinite postponement of the test of the seventeen-inch barbette plate, at Indian Head, is not only a disappointment, but a matter of regret. Its immediate effect is to prolong the uncertainty regarding the degree of value of the Harvey super-carbonizing process for the thickest armor, and therewith to delay still further the completion of our three great 10,200-tonners, the Indiana, Massachusetts, and Oregon.

The delegates of the National Municipal League of Good Government Clubs met yesterday at the City Club, 677 Fifth Avenue, to organize and to adopt a constitution, and also to discuss the lines on which the league, whose object is municipal reform, should act.

We can well believe the announcement that comes from St. Petersburg by way of London that the Russian official world has been "struck with consternation" by the ukase of the Czar which takes away from the heads of departments the right they have hitherto exercised to appoint their own subordinates.
PARIS, May 28 -- It is now regarded as probable that M. Dupuy will succeed in forming a Ministry.

President Philip J. Dwyer of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, who was arrested on May 15 at the instance of Peter De Lacy, on the charge of contriving, proposing, and maintaining a lottery, in arranging for and conducting the Brooklyn Handicap, was discharged by Justice Gaynor in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 28 -- Judge Nelson of the United States Circuit Court to-day denied the application for a writ of prohibition to stop the trial by court-martial of Lieut. Maney for the killing of Capt. Hedberg on the ground that he had been previously tried and acquitted of the charge in the Federal courts.

RICHMOND, S.I., May 28 -- The trial of the twenty election officials indicted, for violations of the election laws at the election in Richmond County last November was begun before Justice Edgar M. Cullen this morning, and the court continued, in session until 10:30 o'clock to-night.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 28 -- The eightieth anniversary meeting of the American Baptist Missionary Union convened in the First Baptist Church this morning. The Rev. Dr. Augustus H. Strong, President, delivered the annual address.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 28 -- The Illinois miners and operators spent to-day here in conference, adjourning this evening to meet again Thursday. The object of the conference is to bring about, if possible, an agreement whereby the strike-may be settled so far as it relates to the Central and Southern Illinois coal fields.

The Orange Athletic Club baseball team has two hard games scheduled for Memorial Day at the Orange Oval, Grove Street, Cast Orange. The morning game will be with the Ironsides of Newark, one of the strongest semi-professional nines in this vicinity. The Orange nine has always had difficulty in defeating this team, and as both teams have been greatly strengthened this season, a fine contest may be looked for.

The Rev. F.M. Davenport of the First Methodist Episcopal Church delivered an address to the veterans of John C. Fremont and Kitching Posts of the Grand Army of the Republic on Sunday evening. The church was crowded. His subject was "Abraham Lincoln, the Soldier's Friend -- His Religious Life." The platform was handsomely decorated with flags, and within the railing were two stacks of arms.

NEWARK, N.J., May 28 -- Mrs. Jetta Gold and her friends accuse several relatives of an attempt to abduct and put her in an insane asylum while she was perfectly sane. The matter has been placed in the hands of a lawyer, and warrants will be sworn out for the arrest of all parties implicated in the alleged attempt.

The arrangements for The New-York Times's tri-State 150-mile relay race are going smoothly and speedily on. The teams representing New-Jersey and Pennsylvania have been definitely chosen and the relays in each case given out to the riders, who already are hard at work getting into racing trim and learning the peculiarities of the various sections of the course apportioned to them to travel over.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 28 -- The news of the removal of Sheriff Beck caused the greatest excitement in Buffalo. It spread through the political resorts about 9 o'clock, and the newspaper offices were plied with questions as to the accuracy of the report. Politicians found it hard to credit the statement.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 28 -- The Federal Court room was packed at 9 o'clock this morning to hear the verdict in the cases of F.A. Coffin, P.B. Coffin, and A.S. Reed, charged as officers of the Indianapolis Cabinet Company, with aiding and abetting Theodore P. Haughey, President of the wrecked Indianapolis National Bank, in the looting of that institution.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., May 28 -- The statements which were published in the New-York newspaper May 17, that a large portion of this community was opposed to George W. Gamble, Superintendent of the Public School, and without foundation.

NEWARK, N.J., May 28 -- Hundreds of wheels hummed over the famous Irvington-Millburn course yesterday. The course which is to be used for the road lace was almost in perfect shape, and many fast trials were seen during the afternoon. E.L. Blauvelt, who rides for the Elizabeth Athletic Club, has decided he will not compete. He confines his reason to the color question.

It is rather surprising to learn from a recent traveler that Thibet has its religious difficulties and divisions. Heretofore everybody has supposed that Thibet was in that condition to which Ritualists look back with yearning in the mediaeval Church, when the clergyman was the only person in the parish who could read and write, and when his opinions were taken for gospel by the illiterate laity.

BOSTON, May 28 -- Local stocks showed some strength to-day, but were not very active. Bell Telephone rose 2 points, to 193, with Erle Telephone at 45, and New-England Telephone 3 higher, at 59. There seems to be quite an investment demand for these stocks, especially the first-named. Wisconsin Central first 5s were steady at 61.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Col. Breckinridge, by his attorneys, Major John Shelby and Benjamin Butterworth, this afternoon presented to Judge Bradley of the District Circuit Court the bill of exceptions which Col. Breckinridge himself had prepared to the recent decision against him in the Pollard-Breckinridge breach-of-promise suit.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 28. -- The Sayville Gun Club, which has leased several hundred acres of the finest deer-shooting ground on Long Island, is being savagely assailed by the public gunners, who are realizing that public shooting grounds are being monopolized by moneyed companies. The Islip Protective Association leased a large tract of land last Fall, leaving only a small territory of land open.
The Kings County Board of Supervisors, at its meeting yesterday in the Court House, heard and debated on the report of the Law Committee, of which Supervisor Dike is Chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- A cloudburst this afternoon swept the extreme northeastern section of this city and the southern portion of Montgomery County, and within an hour did damage to the amount of over $100,000. The Reading Railroad was a heavy sufferer by the storm, bad wash-outs blocking three of its divisions.

Minnie Seligman produced, at the Madison Square Theatre, last night, a four-act play by indefatigable Robert Buchanan, called "Lady Gladys." It is just such a play as Buchanan always writes, with an involved and impossible plot, dialogue that is generally both agreeable and effective, and a few situations that are undeniably strong.

BOSTON, May 28 -- Insurance Commissioner Merrill to-day submitted to the Legislature Part 2 of the thirty-ninth annual report of his department relating to life and casualty insurance. The Commissioner says that, in the face of the extraordinary business and financial depression, life insurance as a whole has shown a wonderful vitality.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- On the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill rest the hopes of the Republican Senators.

The Yearly Meeting of the Society of Friends of Eastern New-York and New-Jersey, now in session in the quaint and spacious brick meeting house and school at Rutherfurd Place and East Fifteenth Street, has afforded opportunities for the reunion of many old acquaintances. The Friends in the city cannot accommodate all the visitors in their homes, and many of them are quartered in the upper rooms of the schoolhouse.

The downpour from the skies yesterday afternoon was postponed long enough to induce a fair-sized crowd of tennis enthusiasts to journey to Garden City, L.I., where the opening games of the Long Island Interscholastic Association's championship contest were held on the courts at St. Paul's Cathedral School.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 28 -- Considerable excitement has been caused here by a flagrant violation of the fisheries regulation by a fleet of American fishing schooners. The western shore of Nova Scotia is teeming with the finest mackerel ever taken in these grounds, and Friday about thirty United States vessels came within the three-mile limit, when the fish were schooling, and made big hauls.

The stock market yesterday was dull and generally lower. London appeared as a seller of stocks, the supposition being that the foreigners were taking profits on purchases made at a lower level last week. Many local trades also took profits, and as a result the advance which was the feature on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday was checked.

JAMAICA, L.I., May 28 -- In an old weather-beaten scow on Jamaica Bay Meadows, sick and insane, Mrs. Paul Ken has languished for two years without medical attendance, most of the time with no one to care for her, and with scarcely enough clothing to protect her wasted form from the rough blasts of Winter.

The Victoria Cricket Club played a very even game with the New-York eleven yesterday at the St. George Cricket Club grounds, Hoboken, and gained the victory by 13 runs. The batting exhibited was not of a very brilliant order, and A. Wyllie and J. Davey were the only men to secure double figures. J. Adam was very successful with the ball for the winners and secured in all seven wickets for very few runs.

The Provisional Committee of the NewYork State Democracy for New-York City met at the Reform Club last night and listened to reports on the work of organization in all parts of the city, after which important steps were taken for completing a permanent organization in all districts.

The United States ship of war Lancaster, homeward bound from the China station, passed Gibraltar May 2, and has not been heard from since. The vessel is not distinguished for great speed, and eighteen days was allowed for the passage across.
The convention of railway employes at the Lenox Lyceum yesterday morning was called to order by E.E. Clark. The delegates went at once into executive session.

The last meeting of the corporation of the University of New-York during this college year was held at the residence of Charles Butler, 78 Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Charles Butler. LL.D.; William A. Butler, LL.D.; William A. Wheelock, W. S. Opdyke, George Alexander, D.D.; John Reid, D.D.; Israel C. Pierson, Ph. D.: Chancellor Henry M. MacCracken, D.D., LL.D., and Augustus Juilliard were present.
The investigation by the special Senate committee into the affairs of the Police Department of this city will be continued in Part II, of the Superior Court at 10:30 to-day.
BOSTON, May 28 -- The British war ships Blake and Tartar sailed this afternoon, the Blake for Bar Harbor, Me., and the Tartar for St. John, N.B. Admiral Hopkins said to a newspaper man to-day:

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Except in West Chicago and Lake Street there was a light business transacted. There was no apparent reason for the decline in the above stocks except that the short interest is well covered, and there is no pressing demand for the stock on either speculative or investmeat account.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 28 -- A certificate of the consolidation of three big New-York City railroads was filed with the Secretary of State this afternoon. The leading railroad in the combination is the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, and the other two are the Metropolitan Crosstown Railway, and the Lexington Avenue and Pavonia Ferry Railway.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The hearing of the case of the Western Associated Press against The Washington News and the United Press, on an application for an injunction to restrain The News from receiving the United Press service, was continued before Judge Cox, on the equity side of the District Supreme Court this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate investigating committee is making a great pother about the witnesses who have been refusing to name the authorities for their publications, but there is a feeling abroad that it is neglecting opportunities for obtaining information in failing to call as witnesses the persons whose names have been connected with alleged sugar conferences and speculations.

The bills introduced in the House of Representatives by Mr. Maguire of California, which are ostensibly for the purpose of bettering the condition of the merchant seamen, have aroused a violent opposition among ship owners. If enacted, the shipping people say. these bills will destroy discipline, encourage mutiny, and place a premium upon desertion.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- No concessions, no arbitration, a deputy for every miner, and a determination to resume mining, was the result of the meeting here this afternoon of the coal operators of the bituminous region of Clearfield, Broad Top, and Beech Creek. The meeting was held in the office of the Berwind-White Coal Company, and about three-fourths of the operators of the regions were present in person or by representatives.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 28 -- Gov. Flower late this afternoon issued a proclamation or order removing August Beck from the office of Sheriff of Erie County. This action is a result of the charges preferred against the Sheriff last Fall. The Governor's official order reads as follows:

The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn met at 44 Court Street last evening to discuss certain resolutions which they will send to the Constitutional Convention. R.W.G. Welling of the NewYork City Club and of the Conference Committee of Twenty-one spoke at considerable length on the question of home rule.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 28 -- The programme for commencement week at Yale was made public to-day by the Yale Faculty. Only one important change from the usual order of exercises is announced, the address before the graduating class of the Law School, which will this year and hereafter come one day earlier than heretofore.

WAKEFIELD, Mass., May 28 -- The town of Wakefield, formerly South Reading, presented a holiday appearance to-day in celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of its settlement. The mother town of Reading, and sister town, North Reading, aided largely to make the celebration successful.

The trotting season in the vicinity of New-York will have a double opening on Decoration Day on tracks both within a short distance of this city. The Parkway Driving Club opens the regular season at its pretty little half-mile track at King's Highway, and the Flushing Driving Club will also offer a good matinee programme. The entries for the events at the Flushing Driving Club closed on Thursday of last week with full lists.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 28 -- The one hundred and sixth Preshyterian General Assembly wound up its business to-day, and adjourned to meet at Pittsburg on the third Thursday in May, 1895. The last hour was made the occasion of an exchange of courtesies between the Moderator and the various committees of arrangements.

Frightened out of his hiding place in Montreal, Canada, by the preparations which were being made for his extradition on the felony indictments found against him last week, Kenneth F. Sutherland, the former Police Justice of Coney Island, secretly hurried to Brooklyn, and yesterday gave himself up to the law.

NEWARK, May 28 -- The entries for the Passale River Amateur Rowing Association's regatta on the Passaic River Memorial Day were opened to-night. The list is much smaller than in former years, and instead of eighteen to twenty-two races, as in the past, there will be only thirteen this year. The intermediate single sculls attracted the largest number of crews, six being listed to start.

A series of explosions in the electrical subway in Spring Street, half way between Broadway and Mercer Street, startled the neighborhood yesterday afternoon for a dis- tance of several blocks and created great excitement.

ALBANY, May 28 -- The exposure in today's New-York Times of the attempt on the part of the Albany printing ring to raid the State Treasury in connection with the printing of the Constitutional Convention has created a profound sensation among the delegates who are here preparatory to the reconvening of the convention to-morrow.

It is natural for man not only to "indulge in the illusions of hope," but to have confidence in the prevalence of his own ideas. We are not only apt to judge others by ourselves, but to believe that it is merely a matter of knowledge and of reasoning to bring others to our own way of looking at things.

Messrs, J.R. Keene, August Belmont, John Hunter, F.K. Sturges, Col. W.P. Thompson, and Dr. G.L. Knapp of the Board of Stewards of The Jockey Club had a meeting lasting until long after 1 o'clock this morning, with representatives of Eastern and Western racing associations which have not as yet recognized The Jockey Club as the governing body of the turf.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Senator Walsh's speech in the Senate to-day has suddenly made the successor of Mr. Colquitt a man of prominence. The new Senator had already made a very agreeable and enviable personal reputation among his associates.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 -- Andover defeated Lawrenceville at the latter's grounds this afternoon by the score of 5 to 2. The game was well contested throughout, the New-England boys winning by their superior work at the bat. The batteries were Greenway and Kent for Andover and Ahret and Kafer for Lawrenceville. Andover will play the Princeton freshmen here to-morrow.

RICHMOND, S.I., May 29 -- The jury in the case of Martin Hughes, William C. Schreiner, and Thomas Hughes, Inspectors of Election in the Fourth Election District of Southfield, found them guilty this morning of a violation of the election laws in ejecting George Connell, a Republican watcher, from the polling place last November.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The discussion of the bill to repeal the 10 per cent. State bank tax law was continued in the House to-day. But little progress was made, however, in the matter of reducing the number of speakers on the list, only three being heard in the day -- Messrs. Cox (Dem., Tenn.,) and Black (Dem., Ga.,) in favor of repeal, and Johnson (Rep., Ind.,) against repeal.

BRAZILIAN CRUISER AQUIDABAN, DESTERRO HARBOR, Brazil, April 25 -- A portion of the Brazilian Navy came here to "take" the Aquidaban. It "took" her a week ago, but this is the first opportunity the correspondent of the New-York Times has had to send off the story of the fight and capture.

NEW-HAVEN, May 29 -- The fifth annual tournament for the tennis championship of New-England began here yesterday, on the courts of the New-Haven Lawn Club. Most of the local cracks are entered, and a number of players from the different colleges are here also. Harvard and Princeton have sent three men each, and there are also representatives from Columbia and Trinity.

The finishing touches are fast being put to the arangements for The New-York Times's tri-State 150-mile relay race, and there is no doubt that, with the course in good condition and the weather propitious on June 2, the crack roadsters of the three States engaged in the contest will trundle over the long stretch of road between Printing House Square and Nicetown Lane, Philadelphia, in short order.
CHICAGO, May 29 -- Gov. Altgeld declined to-day to be one of a committee of arbitration with the Governors of Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Ohio, and Indiana to settle the coal strike.
Sick and suffering and in fear of the result of a surgical operation, Miss Bernerdina Hoff killed herself with illuminating gas in her room, at 2,118 Madison Avenue, late Monday night.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The wholesale discharge of clerks, for which Secretary Lament has so long been preparing, took place in the War Department to-day, nearly 300 employes receiving notices that their services were no longer required. Many of them were also notified that they would be allowed pay until various dates in June, on account of regular leaves of absence.

Messrs. Philip A. Smyth, P.F. Ferrigan, and P.F. McKeon, the executors and trustees of the late Hugh Ferrigan, have sold, to the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine, the plot containing about 14 lots at the junction of Franklin and Fulton Avenues and One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street, for something over $25,000.

Mr. Edward M. Shepard, Assistant Attorney General, yesterday cleaned up the record of the remarkable work done in prosecuting the Gravesend conspirators against the suffrage. Final disposition was made of those remaining of twenty-three indictments found. Of the twenty-three persons indicted, twenty-one have been sentenced to imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The sugar schedule continues to attract the attention of the friends and enemies of the Tariff bill. The Republicans are perfecting their plans to defeat the bill through this particular schedule, and the Democrats are "lining up" for the strugle, with full confidence in their ability to maintain the schedule in its present shape.

By very clever pitching on the part of Meekin, the New-Yorks won a game from the Clevelands yesterday. It was the opening contest of the series with the Western clubs, and, in consequence, the rank and file of the army of metropolitan cranks were out in full force, and they were more than pleased at the good showing made by the Giants.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The lack of earnestness displayed by the Senate committee appointed to investigate the charges of corrupt practices in connection with the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill was illustrated in its action to-day in beginning war upon the newspaper men who have refused to divulge to it professional secrets.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Mr. Proctor (Rep., Vt.,) opened the debate on the Tariff bill in the Senate in opposition to the bill, particularly as to its effect upon trade relations with the rest of the American hemisphere, and its bearing upon the Canadian question. Mr. Proctor finished his speech at 11:45 A.M., and then Mr. Pettigrew (Rep., S.D.,) addressed the Senate, also in opposition to the bill.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 29 -- Gov. Flower has again shown his subserviency to the Sheehan element in Buffalo in his treatment of the Sheriff matter.

Kenneth F. Sutherland, the ally of John Y. McKane, who came back from Canada and surrendered himself to the authorities of Kings County on Monday, yesterday pleaded guilty in the Court of Oyer and Terminer in Brooklyn to stuffing ballot boxes in the Second, or "Bowery," District of Gravesend, and was sentenced to one year and eight months in Sing Sing Prison, where John Y. McKane is now confined.

President John King of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad has issued a circular addressed to the holders of the second consolidated mortgage bonds, the funded coupons of 1885, the income bonds, and the preferred and common stock. He says that in answer to many inquiries he desires to give the subjoined information:
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The President to-day transmitted to Congress the following letter from Minister Willis, dated Honolulu, May 10:

CHICAGO, May 29. -- The beginning of the end in the long litigation between William Sturges of New-York and John V. Farwell, ex-Senator Farwell, and others was reached to-day when, after a three weeks adjournment of the case, the closing arguments were begun before Judge Tuley, who is acting as final arbitrator in the case.

Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day. Time money was without change. The supply was liberal, but the demand was light. Rates were 1 per cent. for thirty days, 1 1/2 per cent. for sixty to ninety days, 2 1/2 per cent. for four months, and 3 per cent. for five to six months.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senator Peffer (Pop., Kan.,) last night addressed the Fitzgerald or Boston band of Coxeyites at its headquarters in Mount Pisgah (colored) Chapel. He said that a number of things had been in the way of the consideration of the various bills he had introduced for the benefit of the laboring men of the country.

Various causes helped an advance in yesterday's prices at the Stock Exchange. Traders are constitutionally averse to carrying contracts over a holiday. Since the professional element in the market has lately run bearish -- usually a promising sign for better conditions -- it proceeded yesterday to cover, by purchase, stocks which it had sold Monday.

The black bass fishing season opens to-day, and many anglers are taking advantage of the holiday to try their luck with the gramey fresh-water fish. Fishing-tackle dealers were busy yesterday in making up outfits for parties who were joyful in anticipation of their favorite sport. There are several lakes within easy reach of New-York City that will be well patronized to-day by anglers.

The Democrats of the Second Arkansas District will be guilty of an inconceivable blunder if they fail to renominate Clifton R. Breckinridge for Congress. Mr. Breckinridge is a Congressman who honors his district by representing it, and makes it a conspicuous unit in the total of the Congressional apportionment.

Unusually atractive and extensive Memo- rial Day programmes have been arranged both in New-York City and in Brooklyn. The main features in both cities will be the morning parades of the veterans of the late war, escorted by detachments of the regular army and navy, and several regiments and battalions of the National Guard of the State.

BUFFALO, May 29 -- Isaac H. Taggart is a well-known Buffalonian. He has lived here for many years. For a long time he was a conductor on the Erie Railroad, but for the last fifteen or twenty years he has been landlord of the Tucker House, a cheap hotel on Exchange Street, in the railway station district.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 29 -- The entries for the Crescent Wheelmen's meet on June 2 closed Saturday. One hundred and twenty-nine men have entered, and some of them will race in more than one event. The track is in fine condition and the meet promises to be very successful. The track is believed to be one of the fastest in existence.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 29 -- The court-martial engaged in the trial of Lieut. James A. Maney of the Fifteenth Infantry, for the murder of Capt. Hedberg at Fort Sheridan, was resumed this morning at Fort Snelling.

It would unquestionably be going too far to say that English yachtsmen are about to have a great awakening. The opportunity is to be given them to learn a lesson, but they will not do it. They will behave as Mr. Bunner says they did in regard to the matter of starting for a fire.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The third triennial meeting of the Congress of American Physicians and Surgeons began at Metzerott's Music Hall at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The attendance at the opening session was not large.

The session yesterday of the special Senate committee which is investigating the Police Department of this city, was not without interest, although it was lacking in any great sensational developments.

Cable Car 95 of the Third Avenue line crashed into a grain wagon belonging to William Lowe Co. of 426 East Fifty-fifth Street at Forty-third Street and Third Avenue at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Car and wagon were mingled in a general wreck.

Count d'Andiau. The death at Buenos Ayres is announced of Count Gaston Joseph Hardouin d'Andlau, the French General and former Senator, whose testimony at the court-martial before which Marshal Bazaine was tried secured his conviction, and whose part in the Legion of Honor scandals entailed his own condemnation.

The National Municipal League Convention reconvened yesterday morning at the City Club, 677 Fifth Avenue. The attendance of delegates was fully as large as on Monday. Charles Richardson of Philadelphia presided.
The convention of railroad employes, which has been in session for the past two days at the Lenox Lyceum, went at once into executive session when it met yesterday morning.

The morning session of the Yearly Meeting of the Society of Friends, at 140 East Twentieth Street, was opened yestreday with devotional exercises. The business meeting was then resumed. The Evangelical Committee made its report to the general body with the following recommendations, all of which were adopted:

PHILLIPSBURG, Penn., May 29 -- Two mines at Woodland which have continued to work off and on during the suspension stopped to-day, the operators agreeing not to start again until the strike is declared off. The coal was mined principally by farmers and day men employed about the mines.

Thousands of New-Yorkers are guilty of fast living, but do not know it. They are shortening their lives and laying up a train of ills for the future without being aware of the evils they are bringing upon themselves. They are in the midst of grave dangers, unconscious and unwarned!

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 29 -- The vacant place on the Pennsylvania team to race in The New-York Times's tri-State 150-mile relay race has been filled up by the securing of W.D. Osgood, the University of Pennsylvania crack. He will not only strengthen the team, but the fact of his participation in the contest has resulted in awakening the interest of "old Pennsy's" wheelmen in the details and the outcome of the big race.

LONDON, May 29 -- An appeal has been made by the Baroness Roques, the mother of Mrs. Maybrick, to the press of England and America asking their aid in behalf of her daughter, now serving a life sentence in Woking Prison for the murder of her husband. The appeal is accompanied by a pamphlet containing the latest evidence gathered in favor of the prisoner.
PARIS, May 29 -- The new Cabinet, as definitely formed to-day, is as follows:

It is desirable that the Constitutional Convention should avoid, so far as possible, any controversy about the authority of the Legislature in relation to its proceedings, for there is no way of bringing such a controversy to an issue. The question is as old as the existence of conventions called to frame or revise State Constitutions.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Judge Dittenhoefer, counsel for Messrs. Edwards and Shriver, the correspondents who refused to testify before the Senate investigating committee, said this morning in regard to the old law and the action of the Senate committee in transferring their responsibility under it to the District Attorney:

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29 -- The coal operators of the Pittsburg district will not wait longer than the end of this week for a settlement of some kind with the miners. If there is no agreement by that time a start to work will be made at some of the mines, probably in the Pan Handle district.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Mr. Rayner of Maryland to-day offered a resolution in the House looking to the abrogation of the Russian treaty in certain circumstances.

PARIS, May 29 -- The Patrie publishes to-day a sensational article in which it is said that M. Turpin, the inventor of the explosive known as panclastite, offered to the French Government some time ago a new explosive of very great power, to be used in an electric mitrailleuse firing automatically 25,000 bullets.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Senator Murphy is a well-contented man to-night. He had the satisfaction to-day of seeing one of his friends and henchmen nominated as Postmaster at Troy and confirmed within a few hours by the Senate.

" 'Troilus and Cressida' was not a good acting play and was a stage failure. Perhaps Bacon did write that, and I don't care if he did," said Mrs. Anna Randall Diehl, with emphasis, at the meeting of the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon.

Our always entertaining neighbor, The Sun, has been led by economic enthusiasm into error as to the purpose and interpretation of our remarks on Monday last concerning its proposed Tariff bill. This bill, we may remind our readers, imposes a duty of 35 per cent. upon "every article imported into the United States from any foreign country," all articles now on the free list, of course, being included.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., May 29 -- The Baptists of Atlantic Highlands expect soon to have a new home. The plans for their new church are completed, and in a short time the structure will be a notable feature of this pretty seaport town.
LONDON, May 29 -- Lord Salisbury, in a speech in London this evening, referred to the agitation against the House of Lords.

The committee appointed three months ago by the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen to investigate the Excise Department held a brief session yesterday morning and examined ex-Commissioners Schliemann and Cahill and ex-Secretary Dennis Short. It was the second business meeting of the committee.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., May 29 -- Since 2 o'clock this afternoon the mining district of Cripple Creek has been drenched by a hard, steady rainstorm. Everything is quiet in the various camps to-night, and no special movement has been made since this morning, either by the miners or deputies.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Postmaster General Bissell is opposed to the adoption of a Government telegraph in connection with the Postal Service. His views on the subject being requested by the Chairman of the House Committee on Inter-State Commerce, to which were referred several bills proposing a telegraph system in connection with the Postal Service, the Postmaster General to-day sent to Chairman Wise an elaborate reply, which closes as follows:

A United States Judge in one of the Western circuits lately undertook to define a labor strike, and his conclusion was that practically there is no such thing as a peaceable strike. He regarded it as necessarily a criminal conspiracy, involving violence and a lawless interference with personal and property rights.

ROME, May 29 -- To-day, being the anniversary of the victory of the Tuscan students over the Austrians at Curtatone, in 1848, the students of the University of Rome held a celebration in commemoration of the event. King Humbert, accompanied by Signor Baocelli, Minister of Public Instruction, paid a visit to the university and freely mingled with the students, with whom his Majesty conversed familiarly.
LONDON, May 29 -- It is reported in Rio Janeiro that Admiral da Gama will try to raise funds in Europe with which to renew hostilities in Brazil.
WALCOTT, N.Y., May 29 -- South Butler, a hamlet seven miles from here, was much wrought up yesterday afternoon by a kidnapping case. The facts are these:

"Suppose a society of Roman Catholics should conspire to disqualify Protestants from holding public office and should circulate slanders and disseminate libels about Protestant Christians, ministers and laymen, men and women? What a cry of just and indignant protest would so up from evangelical pulpits! Is it possible that, in the eyes of the Protestant ministry, the end justifies the means?"

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- In every way, today was livelier and more interesting at the horse show at Wissahickon Heights than yesterday. There were more people there, more celebrities, and a greater display of interest. The events of the day, according to the schedule, should have been more interesting, too, but they were a little lacking in spirit, with one or two exceptions.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The various medical societies which form the Congress af American Physicians and Surgeons held separate meetings this morning to hear papers read on the particular subjects to which each society is devoted. Several of the societies held business meetings, and two of them elected officers for the next year.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 30. -- The Italian cases against the City of New-Orleans for damages resulting from the death of the Italians in the Parish Prison assault on March 14, 1891, have been decided in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Having by their highwayman methods compelled the Finance Committee to shape the Tariff bill to their liking, the McKinley Democrats of the Senate have now resorted to falsehood and deceit to conceal from the people the results of their work. Their bulldozing of the Finance Committee was an act of party treachery, since it was in open disregard of the interests and the commands of the party.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 30. -- The cutter Barbara, New-York City, Mr. Joseph S. Boss, easily defeated her old rival, the yawl Gypsy, Mr. Joseph Dayton, in a twenty-eight-mile race today over a course from the Shore Line pier to North Hill Buoy, thence to Bartlett's Reef Light, Capt. Edward Griffin of the steam yacht Cossette sent the boats off and was the judge of the race.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The fight on the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill is close at hand. The lumber schedule will be finished to-morrow, possibly early enough to permit the beginning of the crucial test in the afternoon.
Fully 20,000 people gathered yesterday afternoon in the soldiers' burial ground in Cypress Hills Cemetery, and witnessed the Memorial Day ceremonies there.

The handsome bronze statue of Horace Greeley erected in Greeley Square, at the intersection of Broadway and Thirty-third Street, chiefly through the exertions of Typographical Union No. 6, was unveiled yesterday with simple yet impressive ceremonies, which were witnessed by a large concourse of interested people.
SOFIA, May 30. -- An enormous crowd gathered in front of the cathedral this evening, and would not disperse when ordered by the police to do so.

While everybody in New-York sympathizes with the protest of its business men against the proposal to resort to an income tax as a measure of revenue in time of peace, it may be questioned whether the protest will have a good effect toward its avowed object. The avowed and the real object of the protestants is, of course, to defeat the measure.

Mr. Cox of Georgia made a very earnest appeal for the repeal of the 10 per cent. tax on State bank currency on Tuesday, on the ground that the State banks would give currency in the agricultural regions where it is most needed, and where now it is most difficult to get it.

NORTHPORT, L. I., May 30. -- The woods for a distance of five miles around Commack, L. I., have been searched for the past two days in an unsuccessful attempt to find the two-and-a-half-year-old child of D. M. Nichols, who suddenly disappeared Monday. The little girl was opposite the house with an older sister, who left her for ten minutes to get a drink.

The chances are that if five ordinarily intelligent citizens of the State of New-York were asked at present who was the Superintendent of Public Education in the State, four of them would have to answer that they did not know. Three years ago four out of the five would have had no hesitation in naming Mr. Draper and would have entertained a tolerably clear notion that he was doing his work very well.

A long list of auction offerings is set down for to-day in the salesroom at 111 Broadway. The principal sale, that of the Lasak property, has been the subject of much rumor. One that is persisted in, is that the sale may be enjoined. Should this not happen, however, the bidding is apt to be lively. Details of sales are subjoined.

The observance of Memorial Day in New-York was closed last night with interesting exercises in the Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, under the auspices of the Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic. The proceeds were for the benefit of the sick and dependent of the organization.

BOSTON, Mass., May 30. -- The yachting season in Eastern waters was opened with fair success to-day by the open race of the South Boston Yacht Club off City Point. The wind was light northwest at the start, but changed to southeast before the finish, and blew with moderate strength. There was much of luck in winning, and the owners of new boats which did not get a place were not much discouraged.

From The London Times. Mr. Harold Frederic has never done better work than in "The Copperhead," and other the American war, (Heinemann.) Mr. Ferderic's boyhood was deeply suffused with memories of that war, to which, as he tells in the dedication, "the men-folk of his family went on the side of the North, and were killed."

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 30. -- Something of a sensation was caused at the reformatory investigation here this afternoon by a statement made by W.H. Peters, one of the board of five managers, while he was on the witness stand.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 30. -- Over four thousand people were well entertained this afternoon at the annual Spring meeting of the New-Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne, held on their Avenue A oval. Owing to the threatening weather hundreds did not arrive until 2 o'clock. The seating capacity of the clubhouse and grand stand were wholly inadequate and the club would do well to provide better accommodation in that line.

Brighton Beach, with the sanction of The Jockey Club, took advantage of the general holiday and opened its gates yesterday. The programme, which contained seven events, including a steeplechase, was in accordance with all regulations formulated by the head body, only one scramble for the older division being provided. Six thousand people saw the sport.

The members of the Atlantic Yacht Club always celebrate Decoration Day with what they call an excursion. Yesterday the excursion took place as usual, after the flag bad been formally saluted by all the yachts in the fleet.

MARSHFIELD, Wis., May 30. -- Six human lives were crushed out in a wreck on the Wisconsin Central Railway soon after 1 o'clock this morning at Mannville, near this city. Half a dozen people besides were seriously injured.

The subject of the above portrait is a prominent and much respected citizen, Mr. Robert Manson, of Wests Rye, N. H. Where Mr. Manson is known " his word is as good as his bond." In a recent letter to Dr. R. V. Pierce, Chief Consulting Physician to the Invalids' Hotel and Surgical Institute, Buffalo. N. Y., Mr. Manson says :
