Services in memory of the late Jesse Seligman were held yesterday in the Hebrew Orphan Asylum at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. About 1,000 members and guests of the Hebrew Benevolent and Orphan Asylum Society, of which Mr. Seligman was President for many years, were present.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 30. -- The Southern Inter-State Immigration Association organized its third annual congress in Augusta at noon to-day. President M. F. Bryan of Nashville presided. Speeches of welcome were made by Mayor J. H. Alexander, President Joseph R. Lamar of the Young Men's Business League of Augusta, Gov. W. J. Northen of Georgia, and United States Senator Patrick Walsh, President of the Commercial Club of Augusta.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- It would not Surprise some people who have given the matter careful attention if Vice President Stevenson did not certify to the District Attorney the cases of the newspaper correspondents Shriver and Edwards, who have refused to reveal professional secrets to Mr. Gray's star chamber committee.

BEAUFORT, S.C., May 30. -- The National Red Cross is nearing the completion of its work in the Sea Islands along the South Carolina coast. It has taken care of 30,000 sufferers from the great West Indian hurricanes of last August, besides assisting more than that number of persons outside the Sea Islands territory, and all on less than $35,000.

BALTIMORE, May 30. -- The Maryland Episcopal Diocesan Convention was startled this morning by Bishop Paret, who delivered the most sensational address ever heard in church circles in these parts. The session opened at Emmanuel Church With a devotional service, conducted by the Bishop.

SHARON, Mass., May 30. -- Between 12 and 1 o'clock this morning two freight trains came together at Sharon Heights, on the Providence Division of the Old Colony Railroad, wrecking the engine and three loaded cars, killing three and injuring two persons, one badly. The dead are:

The twenty-eighth set of races of the Harlem Regatta Association, decided yesterday on the Harlem River, was a success from every standpoint. Remarkable time was made in two events, and with a few exceptions the programme was run off as scheduled. The weather was not as favorable as it might have been, a raw wind prevailing nearly all day, and making it unpleasant for the spectators.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 30. -- The Yale-Harvard freshman same was played at the field today before about 1,000 persons. The game was slow and uninteresting and the Harvard team was not in the game at all. Yale both outfielded and outbatted Harvard, and the result was never in doubt. Paine, the substitute pitcher of Harvard's regular nine, was batted hard and at critical times, while Yale's pitcher was effective all through the game.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 30. -- The Martin road race run to-day over a course probably the finest in the country for road-racing purposes, was won by Louis Callahan of the Press Cycling Club, his time being 1:10:37, breaking the world's record for twenty-five miles of 1:11:281/2, made by " Nat " Butler over the Linscot Road May 5.

ROME, May 31. -- Cardinal Lecot started to-day on a mission from the Pope to M. Dupuy. His Holiness expresses the wish for amicable relations with the new Cabinet, and promises to insist that the French Bishops shall accept the French law as to church affairs.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Historic Arlington, just across the Potomac, with its many illustrious graves -- Sheridan, Crook, Porter, Meigs, and others -- and its thousands of "unknown" dead, is only one of a belt of national soldiers' cemeteries which gird the city, and at each appropriate exercises were held to-day.

Hamilton Wood, who fifteen years ago kept a large stationery store at Broadway and Ninth Street, committed suicide shortly after six o'clock yesterday morning by jumping from the roof of the Trafalgar House, at 117 East Fourteenth Street. He fell five stories, and his head was badly crushed.

All past performances in the road racing line faded into insignificance yesterday when A. H. Barnett, tte sturdy rider of the Elizabeth Wheelmen, won first prize in the Irvington-Millburn race. It was a signal victory. The winner not alone came in ahead, but he won all the prizes, breaking records for fifteen, twenty, and twenty-five miles.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- To-day an immense crowd saw, or, at least, tried to see, Fred Rau of Chicago win the great annual Western cycling Derby -- the Chicago road race. J. R. Bezuek was second, H. Van Herik third, and J. S. Kelton fourth. Over 350 of the 419 entries started.

MACON, Ga., May 30. -- The rear coach of a train on the Albany and Columbia Branch of the Southwestern Railroad, a division of the Central Railroad of Georgia, was over-turned by a broken rail at Holts this morning and forty people were injured, two or three of whom will in all probability die.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Upon the same day that Senator Goman delivered his apology for the compromise Tariff bill that deserves to bear his name, there was issued, as a supplement to the speech, a table of general averaged, comparing the average, rates of duty by each schedule of the Wilson bill, the amended Senate bill, the Mills bill, and the present law.

RICHMOND, Va., May 30. -- The monument erected on Libby Hill to commemorate the services of the Confederate soldiers and sailors was unveiled to-day with appropriate ceremonies, at which Gov. O'Ferrall, Gen. Wade Hampton, and other prominent people were present.

Except for the continued dearth of business, railroad managers throughout this country would have good reason to feel elated over recent achievements in the direction of restoration and maintenance of rates. The establishment of a board of control to regulate railroad freight rates in the West and Southwest is a step that seemingly cannot fail to have an important and beneficial effect upon railroad business.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 30. -- A monument to Thaddeus Kosciuszko was unveiled here to-day by the Polish people, assisted by the local post of the Grand Army of the Republic. During the forenoon the Rev. Father Szymanowski celebrated high mass, and the Rev. J. Strzelecki of St. Stanislaus's Church, New-York, delivered the sermon.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., May 30. -- In relation to current reports outlining the plans of the Russian and American capitalists to establish a line of Pacific steamships in connection with the Trans-Siberian Railroad soon to be completed to Vladivostock, it is asserted that the principal American port for the steamship company will be established here.

Fully 30,000 of yesterday's pleasure seekers and lovers of sport found their way to Morris Park in the afternoon. There were not nearly so many people there as were at the same track two years ago, which was due to the fact that it cost 50 cents to get into the field this year while heretofore entrance thereto has been free.

BUFFALO, May 30. -- Buffalo has a new Democratic leader to-night. He is Norman E. Mack, owner and editor of The Buffalo Evening Times, and Democratic State Committeman from the Thirty-second District.

The unveiling of a monument to Confederate soldiers and sailors is an occasion on which an orator, particularly if he be a clergyman, may claim large latitude. That certainly is what the Rev. R.C. Cave took yesterday at Richmond, when he claimed that the civil war was caused by the devotion of the South to the Union.

The New-Yorks and Clevelands broke even on yesterday's games, Ward's men winning in the morning by 2 to 1, while Patsy Tebeau's Spiders carried off the ball in the afternoon by 3 to 2, after a hard eleven-inning fight.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 30. -- Gov. Pattison to-day received a letter from the Sheriff of Fayette County telling of the lawlessness of the striking miners there. In response to the letter he has issued the following proclamation:

The cornerstone of the new Scotch Presbyterian Church was laid yesterday afternoon. at Ninety-sixth Street and Central Park West. The Scotch Church was organized in 1756, and the now building will be the fourth one its congregation has occupied since that year.

Nature dealt kindly by the Nation's old soldiers yesterday. With no rain, with neither too warm nor too cool an atmosphere, they marched under bright skies, past cheering thousands of onlookers, in memory of their own heroism and that of their dead comrades.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30 -- Princeton's ball players came up to Harvard, to-day confident at a victory, but were badly beaten. The visitor could not hit Highlands to any extent, while Harvard knocked Altman out of the box in the fourth inning, and batted Bradley nearly as hard.
St. Gabriel's Church, in East Thirty-seventh Street, of which Mgr. J.M. Farley, Vicar General, is pastor, was consecrated yesterday morning.

PORT RICHMOND, S. I., May 30. -- The Kill von Kull Yacht Club held its annual Decoration Day open regatta this afternoon over the tenmile triangular club course in Newark Bay. There were seventeen starters, and the little boats had all of the wind they could stand up under. In fact, some of them had more than they wanted, and were compelled to reef.

The unsatisfactory, almost hopeless, state if thing's in what we have been accustomed to call "government of cities," but what is more properly to be termed the conduct of municipal business. Is the result of tangling that business with party politics, and it has seen as inevitable as any other product of evolution, the irresistible outcome of the working of existing forces within the existing environment.

The organization of a new Executive Committee, or Board of Control, by the Presidents of the Western railroads practically shifts the responsibility for freight rate reductions from the Traffic Managers to the executive officers. The new agreement provides for three separate committees as follows:

ALBANY, May 30. -- Probably to-morrow will be "Labor Day" in the Constitutional Convention. An important conference took place this afternoon between a dozen delegates and Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, and J.E. Sullivan. These gentlemen for several weeks have been in communication with Judge Mirabean L. Towns of Kings, who arranged to-day's meeting.

Taslnawakan, otherwise Holy Blanket, a niece of Little Wound, the Sioux Chief who led the hostile Indians against the United States troops in the battle of Wounded Knee, was married yesterday noon at "Buffalo Bill's" Wild West encampment, in South Brooklyn, to Matowaungata, or High Bear, with ceremonies half Indian and half Christian.

PARIS, May 31. -- Paul Bourget, the well-known novelist, and Albert Sorel, the historian, were elected to-day members of the Academy to fill the vacancies caused by the deaths of MM. Ducamp and Taine. No votes were cast for M. Zola.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 31. -- The schooner yacht Coronet. Wing, owner, arrived from Bar Harbor and sailed for New-York to-day.
At auction, in Brooklyn, yesteraay, Mr. Jacob Cole sold twenty-seven lots on Apollo and Hausman Streets, between Meeker and Nassau Avenues, at from $200 to $410 each.

Music Hall was the scene last evening of the graduating exercises of the last class of the University or the City of New-York to be graduated from the old building in Washington Square. Many of the orations, and especially the address of the valedictorian, were memorial in their tone.

Senator Walthall of Mississippi has published a letter in that State, in reply to a request for his views, strongly deprecating any such distinction as "Administration" and "anti-Administration" among Democrats. He says "there is no principle to justify it, and its manifest inexpediency should forbid the drawing of such a line."
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The investigation into the alleged armor frauds was continued to-day.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 31. -- The convention Committee on Cities listened this morning to F.G. Black of Troy, who advocated the separation of municipal from State elections and the election of bi-partisan police boards.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- The opening and a few minutes immediately succeeding were the weakest spots in to-day's wheat market. The close was not quite as strong as at one time during the session, but the final figures were at a gain of 1/2 c over Tuesday. The Cincinnati Price Current's summary was favorable to the growing crop.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 31. -- Lieut. Maney was on the stand in his own behalf at the court-martial this morning at Fort Snelling, and some of ills evidence was quite sensational.

JERSEY CITY, May 31. -- In the Court of Oyer and Terminer this morning Dennis McLaughlin, G. Walbaum, President of the track; John C. Carr, and Nicholas Crusius, charged with keeping a disorderly house in the Guttenberg race track, through their counsel. Alien L. McDermott, withdrew the plea of not guilty entered by the defendants on their previous arraignment, and substituted a plea of guilty.

Critical observers who had the advantage of the experience of former occasions to guide them were unanimous in the opinion that the parade and review of the police force yesterday were by far the best in the history of the department.

After winning two of the three game played against the Clevelands, it was naturally expected that the Giants would have comparatively an easy time of it with the St. Louis Browns yesterday. But the uncertainty of baseball again manifested itself, and the Browns secured the game. Heretofore the majority of the defeats charged against the team were due to weak batting.

The French law of libel is not more reasonable, nor even more logical, than the law of libel in Anglo-Saxon countries. One of its absurdities is that anybody who sells a libelous article is guilty of libel. This is also the English and the American law. It is not more absurd than many other provisions of the law.

A year ago in March the gold in the Treasury, above the outstanding gold certificates, was a little under $107,000,000. From that time until the close of the calendar year, with the exception of a slight rally in July, it fell pretty steadily at the rate of about $3,000,000 a month until, on Dec. 30, 1893, it was a little under $81,000,000.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., May 31. -- The trial of the Inspectors of Election indicted for violations of the election laws at the polls last Fall was brought to an abrupt close this morning when pleas of guilty were entered for ten of them and counsel for the defendants entered a plea before Justice Cullen for mercy.

WALCOTT, N.Y., May 31. -- Bessie Drall, the kidnapped child from South Butler, was found with her mother in the cellar of a deserted house on the Ingraham farm, at Sterling, last night. The child was ill from exposure and fatigue, and was at once taken home. The mother had occupied the old ruin for three nights, but was discovered by neighbors.

W.D. Grand sold harness and saddle horses and ponies at Tattersalls yesterday afternoon. The ponies, which included a number of Shetlands, were from the Hazeldean farm of W.J. Sampson of Youngstown, Ohio, and they attracted a number of children to the sale. Good prices were brought by the ponies, the smallest and bestlooking pair in the lot going to J.R. Doyle for $160.

BOSTON, Mass., May 31. -- The Committee on Finance of the Legislature this afternoon reported unanimously in favor of the Meigs Elevated Railroad bill for the City of Boston and outlying towns. The bill is amended, inasmuch as the bond clause is stricken out, and provides that all locations in streets must have the approval of the Mayor and Aldermen of Boston and the Selectmen of the towns.

To what depths the American Protective Association degrades and humiliates the communities in which it gains a foothold is made manifest by a letter "To the Public" which was received yesterday at the office of The New-York Times. This letter was addressed to the people of Ohio by the broad-minded Protestant clergymen of Columbus. It is one of the most remarkable documents ever penned.

The members of the Aldermanic Law Committee gave a public hearing yesterday on the proposition of Alderman Morgan to exempt Fifth Avenue, between Twenty-fifth and Fifty-ninth Streets, from truck traffic, between 2 avid 7 P.M., from Oct. 1 to June 1. About a dozen Fifth Avenue property owners were present.
HARRISBURG, Penn., May 31. -- Gov. Pattison has received this dispatch from P. M. McBride, Secretary of the Mine Workers' Union:

LONDON, May 31. -- The thirteenth, international conference of the Young Men's Christian Association of all lands will assemble in Exeter Hall to-morrow. These conferences are held triennially. The first was held in Paris in 1855, and the last in Amsterdam in 1891. Intervening conferences were held in Geneva, London, Elberfeld, Hamburg, Berlin, and Stockholm.

There is one principle that ought to be strictly adhered to by the Constitutional Convention in revising or amending the organic law of this State. There should be nothing embodied in that law that is not strictly fundamental, affecting all citizens and all interests alike, and belonging to the permanent framework of government.

BAY SHORE, L.I., May 31. -- Mrs. T.N. William had a narrow escape from death this morning while leading a horse to pasture. The animal became suddenly enraged, and, turning quickly about, gave her a vicious kick, the force of which knocked her down.

NORTHPORT, L.I., May 31. -- Little Eddie Nichols, the two-and-a-half-year-old son of Daniel M. Nichols, who has been since last Monday night the cause of wakefulness, anxiety, grief, and wonder on the part of his parents and the village of Commac, where their home is, slept to-night in his father's house.
PUEBLO, Col., May 31. -- The cloudburst which last night sent a vast torrent of water down the valley and into this city caused a number of deaths and wrought widespread destruction.

The greatest auction sale of realty this year took place at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom yesterday. The sale was in partition, the property being that owned by the late Francis W. Lasak, once a partner of John Jacob Astor in the fur business. Mr. L.J. Phillips was the auctioneer.

ALBANY, May 31. -- The Governor this morning appointed the new tuberculosis commission, consisting of five members. The Secretary, one of the five members, is Dr. F.O. Donahue of Syracuse, President of the State Board of Health. He is to draw a salary of $250 a month and expenses. The other members are Prof. Law, Ithaca; Frank Shaw, Dunkirk; E.J. Wilbur, Oneonta, and William O. Squires, Canton.

Mr. Smith M. Weed, President of the Nicaragua Canal Company, has returned from his trip to San Domingo. His experiences have been interesting. Said he, in reply to the inquiries of a reporter of The New-York Times:

At the annual meeting of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, held in the company's general offices, in the Mills Building, yesterday, Directors were elected as follows: Collis F. Huntington, Henry Hart, Isaac E. Gates, Calvin S. Brice, Samuel Thomas, Edward Lauterbach, Russell Sage, George J. Gould, and R.P. Schwerin.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 31. -- Edward Martin, known as "the millionaire philanthropist," died in December last at Red Hook, and the general impression was that he was worth $1,000,000 in securities and real estate in Chicago. He lived with Serena Martin, his niece, at Red Hook, and she and Samuel Beers and a Mr. O'Connor or Cook County, 111., were appointed as executors, in accordance with provisions of his will.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: A Democratic Congressman who opposed the Wilson bill, and who finally gave the casting vote on the Ways and Means Committee to embarrass or kill it by tacking the income-tax feature upon it, was criticised for this act by the editor of one of the leading Democratic papers of Michigan.

An explosion in the liquor store of Solomon Kleinrock, on the ground floor of the five-story tenement 139 Suffolk Street, caused a fierce fire yesterday morning, and created a wild panic among the twenty families in the building. One child was burned to death and seven persons were injured.

ALBANY, May 31. -- The Assembly Chamber as crowded with women to-night when the Convention Suffrage Committee met to hear the arguments of the New-York City and Brooklyn suffragists in favor of striking the word "male" from the Constitution.

The resolution reported yesterday by the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs and immediately adopted by a unanimous vote in the Senate embodies the absolutely sound doctrine regarding the relation of our Government to Hawaii. The only Senator who made any objection to the resolution was Mr. Mills of Texas, and he simply refrained from voting.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The rules of the Senate operated to-day to prevent another sensational scene in connection with the star-chamber investigation which Mr. Gray is conducting. Mr. Hill offered his promised resolution directing the committee to throw open its doors to the public, but Mr. Cockrell, who is wedded to Senate traditions, objected, and under the rules it was tabled until to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The sugar schedule has been reached, but no progress has been made upon it, foe the reason that several set speeches and the noisy Mr. Dolph have stood in the way. It will be taken up in earnest to-morrow, and then the struggle will begin which will decide the fate of the Tariff bill.

CONCORD, N.H., May 31. -- Nothing but the traditional cheerfulness of a St. Paul's schoolboy could avail against the disheartening aspect of the weather this morning. The cricket match scheduled for this morning between the alumni and the school was necessarily postponed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- From statements made by the Cramps this afternoon, it would appear that some reports in Washington materially exaggerate the injury the cruiser Columbia has sustained. The building firm gave out this statement on the subject:

LONDON, May 31. -- Gen. Hewston, the American who was arrested yesterday afternoon for fatally injuring a street musician by driving the ferrule of an umbrella into his eye, the man dying a few minutes later, was arraigned in the Clerkenwell Police Station this morning charged with manslaughter.

Some curious testimony was given yesterday in Part I. of the Supreme Court, before the Sheriff's jury which is engaged in determining whether Mrs. Alma Louise Coddington-Feliows of 44 East Sixty-sixth Street is incapacitated by her alleged drinking habit from managing her four-milliondollar estate.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Contractors for the new naval vessels are bringing considerable pressure to bear on the Navy Department for money due them on account of the completion of their work. Most of the contracts provide for partial payments on the vessels as they reach various stages of completion, but for some time past sums aggregating over $1,000,000 have been due on at least ten ships.

Archbishop Satolli and Archbishop Corrigan sat side by side last night in Chickering Hall at the annual concert by students of the Catholic Conservatory of Church Music. The portion of the balcony which was occupied by them was decorated with the United States and Papal flags. There were many prominent Catholics in the audience.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., May 31. -- The labor leaders are very indignant over the proclamation issued by Gov. Pattison yesterday. They say that they believe it the duty of Gov. Pattison to issue another proclamation, directing it exclusively lo the coke operators, and compel them to dispense with the deputies' services at once.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 31. -- The feature of interest in to-day's session of the Southern Inter-State Immigration Congress was the adoption of the Atwood plan of colonization by county organization. This was the first paragraph in the report of the Committee on Resolutions and was savagely attacked by George Sharpe of Virginia.

PARIS, May 31. -- The vicinity of the Chamber of Deputies was jammed with sightseers long before the hour for the opening of the sitting of the Chamber today and the galleries were packed with visitors. United States Ambassador Eustis occupied a seat in the diplomatic box.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 31. -- Daylight was let in upon, three of the cases of alleged barbarity at the Elmira Reformatory to-day, and, although it required all day, it not only effectively disposed of these particular cases, but illuminated the last investigation in a way that was unpleasant for the prosecution.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 31. -- Gen. John Hewston, who is charged with killing a man in London, is one of the best-known of the old Californians.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- There is nothing essestially funny about a Senator six feet long, and with a beard reaching one-third of the Senatorial length, endeavoring to attract public attention in a serio-comic part, but if the performance is persisted in for hours, and done over again until, by repetition, it becomes ridiculous, it may provoke the injudicious to smile, as it certainly will induce the wise to grieve.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 31. -- The annual meeting of the Stewards of the Grand Trotting Circuit was held here to-day. The Stewards present represented the following places on the circuit: Saginaw -- W.S. Eddy; Cleveland -- S.W. Giles: Buffalo -- C.J. Hamlin and E.S. Eddy; Rochester -- George W. Archer and A. Collins; Hartford -- Burdette Loomis; New-York -- W.B. Fasig; Baltimore -- Robert Hough.

Just before the race for the Van Nest Stakes for two-year-olds at Morris Park yesterday afternoon, Gus Straus was asked to place a price on his gelding, Harry Reed, for the agent of a would-be purchaser. Straus hummed and hawed about for a time, and finally said that he would not sell for less than $7,000, the colt to run in his interest for the stake.

(All communications for this column must be Addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used In the Sunday edition or The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

-- Opportunities for arbitrage business, against which the New-York Stock Exchange has declared, were restricted almost to the point of prohibition yesterday, by the approval by the Governing Committee of a plan to group the telephones in the board rooms in boxes along the north and south walls of the room. These instruments are now scattered all over the room, and violations of the rule are easily possible.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 31. -- Prosecutor Holtzman is determined to investigate all the circumstances of the marriage of Actor Charles A. Coghlan to the woman who is alleged to have been his wife previous to his wedding to Kuehne Beveridge in this city. Inquiries are to be set on foot both in New-York and England regarding the legality of the alleged first marriage.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Acting Secretary McAdoo made public the official finding of the Selfridge Inspection Board on the trial of the Columbia this afternoon. In regard to a report that the hull of the crack cruiser, which is now being officially investigated, had been badly damaged during her run, Mr. McAdoo said:

PARK HILL, N.Y., May 31. -- The pleasantest feature of the "camp-fire tea" given here to-day by Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Sumner Teall was the entire lack of formality on the part of the host and hostess in receiving and entertaining their guests.

BUFFALO, May 31. -- A very important meeting, one which will do much toward creating a better condition of affairs in lake and rail traffic, was held here this afternoon. Some weeks ago lake and rail managers came to the conclusion that an organization of the lake lines at Buffalo was a necessity, and the call for a meeting was for this express purpose.
Speaking of the coming debate in the Senate upon the proposed sugar tax, The New-York Tribune says:

Trading in stocks was exceedingly dull yesterday, the total transactions being only slightly over 100,000 shares. In only two stocks, Sugar and Chicago Gas, did the volume of business approach 20,000 shares. There was an indisposition to do much in the first-named, while the Senate is discussing the sugar schedules.

The Vigilant, in a most unassuming way, started on her trip to England yesterday morning. She did not make much way, though, as the weather outside the Hook was not very Inviting. Heavy fog banks hung over the water, and the wind was not at all favorable. Capt. Jeffreys anchored the yacht in the Horst Shoe, and decided to wait until the wind was in the right quarter and the fog lifted.

JERSEY CITY, June 1. -- Another page was turned in the Hoffman House dispute to-day, when Vice Chancellor Green, sitting in Chancery Chambers, this city, granted an order declaring the charter of the Hoffman House Corporation forfeited. The order was granted at the request of A.Q. Keasbey of Newark, counsel for W.E.D. Stokes.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 1. -- Schooner yacht Cavalier, J.B. Hogan, arrived from the east to-night. She will probably continue west to-morrow.

VANCOUVER, B. C., June 1. -- The Frazer River rose ten inches more at New-Westminister yesterday and last night. The water was three inches above the highest recorded mark. The flood is still rising. From points further up the river come reports that the river is nearly two feet higher than has ever been known.

The postponed programme of the Parkway trotting meeting, which was interrupted by rain last Thursday, developed some good sport yesterday. Although the track was by no means fast, the horses of the 2:27 class trotted their second heat in 2:25 1/4, treating the spectators to a fine finish between Boy Blue and the favorite, Orange Bloom.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase of the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during May, of $6,603,030.58. The interest-bearing debt increased $460. The non-interest-bearing debt decreased $640,879.50, and the cash in the Treasury decreased $7,243,450.08.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 1. -- This was the second of four days that the trotters and pacers were able to fill their engagements at Point Breeze. The track was in bad shape, and the horses could not get anywhere near their limit. First came the 2:29 class, for trotters, which began Wednesday and was not finished, Kate and Wills A, dividing the three heats.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 1. -- There has been a fight in the woman suffrage camp for quite a while, and Helen M. Gougar and Susan B. Anthony are the most interested contestants. The former has written to The Republic, a weekly published at Argentine, Kan., in which she says of Miss Anthony: "She has never succeeded in the adoption of a single suffrage law.

The word "Go!" from President Luscombe of the League of American Wheelmen at 8 o'clock this morning from the porch of The Times Building will give the signal to the three men composing the first relay in The New-York Times's tri-State 150-mile relay race to start on their twenty-five-mile journey.

WASHINGTON, Ind., June 1. -- A mob of 1,000 striking miners from the mining camps of Daviess County has gathered at Cannelburg, nine miles east of this city, on the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Road, determined to prevent the transportation of coal through this State from the Kentucky fields to the markets north of here or from local mines to points outside of the State.

The seating capacity of Carnegie Music Hall was not severely taxed by the size of the audience which was gathered there last night to take part, as auditors, in the mass meeting of business men to protest against the income tax. The lower part of the hall was fairly well filled, but there were many vacant seats.

The second lot of the Rancho del Paso thoroughbred yearlings was sold in the sales paddock at Morris Park yesterday morning by Auctioneer William Easton of the American Horse Exchange, The prices realized exceeded those brought on Thursday morning, and the bidding was spirited. Most of the prominent owners of racehorses attended the sale.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- There is reason to believe that the next pamphlet containing evidence taken by Gray's select star-chamber committee will be far more interesting than that containing evidence taken prior to May 29.

SANDY HOOK, N. J., June 1 .-- The American rapid-fire guns gained points to-day in their contest with those of the best foreign makers. These tests have been going on for some time under the direction of the Government for the purpose of discovering the most desirable gun in all respects.

Yesterday's stock market was pretty much a repetition of Thursday's in all its characteristics. The volume of trading was slightly increased, but the gain was made up almost entirely in the transactions in Sugar. Fluctuations were very narrow in the general market, but at the close of business the majority of stocks were fractionally lower than the final prices of the day before.

The Grand Jury of this county has investigated certain sensational and palpably exaggerated charges against the management of the insane asylum on Ward's Island, and found, as usual in such cases, that they were made up of grossly distorted and highly colored statements, which concealed, rather than disclosed, the facts.

The testimony given before the Lexow committee yesterday was most interesting and suggestive. By the necessity of the case it was suspicious testimony, and by the necessity of the case it was not corroborated. By his own account the witness who gave it was an infamous person.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach, this office not later than Thursday evening.)

RICHMOND, Va., June 1. -- Gen. Thomas L. Rosser's speech Wednesday at the reunion of Confederate cavalrymen is all the talk in ex-Confederate and political circles. The General, in declaring that he despised the man who favored the payment of pensions by the Federal Government, does not reflect the views of Confederates or other leading Southerners here.

Direct accusations were made yesterday before the Senate committee which is investigating the affairs of the Police Department in this city against some of the police officials. They had to do with the collection of tribute and blackmail from houses of bad character.

The Kings County Grand Jury for the month of May yesterday handed in a bunch of presentments in the Kings County Court of Sessions. The most important one was against the Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, which the Grand Jurors characterized as a "blot on our civilization."

MEMPHIS, June 1. -- The greatest rate war in the history of railroading in the Southern States has broken out, and every road south of the Ohio and Potomac Rivers and some of the Eastern lines are involved. The trouble has been brewing for some time. Three or four lines have been secretly cutting rates on Eastern business for a month past, thereby reaping a rich harvest.

RICHMOND, Va., June 1. -- Miss Odette Tyler, the actress who recently broke her engagement with Howard Gould, the New-York millionaire, in an interview here last night told of her plans for the future. After having gone from one hotel to another to avoid detection by newspaper men, Miss Tyler's whereabouts were ascertained, and she consented to talk for the second time with a reporter since the unpleasant Gould episode.

LONDON, June 1. -- A meeting of the McCarthyite section of the Irish Party was held last night, at which it was announced that the appeal for funds issued a week ago by Justin McCarthy has met with gratifying success. Fifteen hundred pounds had already been received, and a large contribution from the Irish Federation in America.

Dun's Review will say to-day: "It is a sign of cheering import that in finished business, represented by clearings and railway tonnage, there has been less decrease since the strike began than might have been expected. But in inchoate business-the orders which start the wheels, to result in tonnage and payment weeks or months later -- there seems to be an actual decrease.

Miss Keyser trod on dangerous ground when she argued before the Constitutional Convention that women ought to be allowed to vote because, "with lower wages than men, there are more men dependent upon charity than women, and the aggregate savings of women in savings banks are greater than those of men."

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- According to official letters received at the Navy Department to-day, the damage to the Columbia resulting from striking an obstruction on her trial trip appears to be much more serious than at first reported, and not at all trivial in character, as the repairs will certainly cost the Government from $8,000 to $10,000, to say nothing of losing several weeks' use of the ship.

"Why women should ever want to have any one but a woman physician I don't know," said the Rev. Dr. E.A. Bradley last evening, in the pretty little theatre of the Manhattan Athletic Club Building, at Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street.

The Vigilant passed Fire Island at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. The wind was coming from the west and blowing about twelve miles an hour, and the yacht was bowling along in fine style, with all sails set.

LONDON, June 1.-Preparatory to the opening of the thirteenth conference of the Young Men's Christian Association of all lands the Central International Committee, consisting of thirty members, met this morning in one of the smaller rooms of Exeter Hall.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- It is stated on the best authority that President Cleveland and Secretary Carlisle have been in entire and perfect harmony in all their actions in regard to the Tariff bill. Secretary Carlisle's part In the preparation of the sugar schedule of that bill is officially stated as follows:

BOSTON, June 1. -- Job Turner, forty-five years old, formerly a member of the brokerage firm of A.B. Turner Brother, having offices in the Fiske Building, in State Street, shot himself dead yesterday at his farm in South Carver. The father, Job. Sr., died about five years ago, leaving an estate valued at about $1,000,000, equally divided among his five children.
BERLIN, June 1. -- The Tageblatt has a Belgrade dispatch which says that two battalions of infantry and the entire police force of Sofia have declared themselves for Stambuloff.

ALBANY, June 1. -- The Printing Committee of the Constitutional Convention submitted its report to-day, covering the outrageous scheme to rob the State for printing the detailed proceedings of the convention. The scheme has been exposed in the columns of The New-York Times.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 1. -- It is believed here to-night that an order will be issued by Gov. Matthews to-morrow calling out two regiments of the Indiana troops.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 1. -- The third and last day of the Southern Inter-State Immigration and Industrial Congress was largely social in its observance. The Congress met at 9 o'clock, and the two hours' session was devoted largely to the passage of resolutions covering matters of detail, votes of thanks, and like matters.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- The disturbed financial condition in Argentine and the pressure of offerings of that country's wheat on English markets, causing demoralization in prices at those points, were the reasons cited for to-day's break in wheat in Chicago. Other causes existed, but their influences were probably of less potency, although the sum total of their power would prevent any upward movement.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Corean Legation in Washington received a cablegram to-day from the King's palace, at Seoul, saying that the rebels had gained possession of Chunlato, the southern and chief of the eight provinces of the kingdom, that the lives of all foreigners were in danger, and that the presence of a United States war ship at Chemulpo without delay to protect Americans was urgently requested.

LIVINGSTON, S.I., June 1. -- The formal opening of the pretty clubhouse of the Staten Island Ladies' Club, which occupies a part of the Staten Island Cricket Club grounds, occurred this afternoon. More than 300 well-known Staten Island people were present, and the affair proved one of the most successful ever held under the auspices of the club.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- District Attorney, Birney, whose indictment of Col. F.C. Ainsworth has just been thrown out of court by Judge McComas, has appealed from the decision of Judge McComas to the District Court of Appeals.

PUEBLO, Col., June 1. -- The flood has partly subsided, the water having fallen fifteen feet. A few streets are passable for teams. The lower ground is still under water, and it will be over a week before the water can be pumped out. Fountain Creek has fallen two feet since 7 o'clock this morning, but as the approaches to the bridges are washed away it is impossible to reach the east side.

We remarked a few days ago, when it became known that Congress had added to the appropriation for the Bureau of Animal Industry $100,000 to be expended in suppressing tuberculosis or consumption in dairy herds, that the money would probably be used in carrying on investigations and in attempts to assist State authorities already engaged in the work of suppression.

When virtue is its own reward the regard is probably insufficient. The American people have long been accustomed to condemn with just severity their Senators and members of Congress who fall before the financial allurements of the lobbyist. A Senator caught taking a bribe in any of its protean forms is pilloried in thousands of newspapers and from thousands of platforms and pulpits.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 1. -- The interest in The New-York Times's big tri-State relay race has grown day by day, till not only the wheelmen of this city, but even the general public itself, usually so apathetic to cycling matters, has caught the general infection and is "rooting" hard, as the baseball cranks phrase it, for the success of the Keystone team.

ELMIRA, N. Y., June 1. -- The enemies of Mr. Brockway and the State Reformatory made a desperate attempt this morning to put in evidence the great mass of convicts testimony gotten together at the first investigation and lot it stand as reliable evidence in their attempt to kill off the institution.

SPOKANE, Washington, June 1. -- Further particulars of the flood which destroyed the town of Conconully, Washington, have been received. A cloudburst occurred, increasing the already overflowing stream into a torrent, which swept everything before it. Trees, houses, and rocks came down upon the bottom lands, where they lodged, forming a jam in places 15 feet high.

In contradistinction to the vicious, underhand methods of the American Protective Association, as exposed by The New-York Times, it is a relief to turn to the National League for the Protection of American Interests.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- An evening session was held to consider pension matters. In the course of the evening the rather surprising statement was made by Mr. Lacey (Rep., Iowa,) that, as the result of nine months' work of Congress upon pensions, only two private pension bills had become laws.

In consequence of the absence from court of Lawyers Brooke and O'Sullivan, counsel for Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, the convicted poisoner. Dr. Meyer was not sentenced by Recorder Smyth yesterday. He may have to remain in the Tombs until August, for the court was adjourned sine die.

With big Amos Rusie in the box the spectators on the Polo Grounds yesterday looked for a New-York victory and were prepared to see Ward's Giants overwhelmingly defeat the favorites of Christopher Von der Ahe. But again they were doomed to disappointment. The Browns outplayed the local players at all points and won easily.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 1. -- The mystery of the pool of blood, the old hat, and the abandoned horse and buggy, the finding of which caused such speculation yesterday, has been explained by John Cameron of Green Village. He says he owns the buggy, and loaned it to his brother Reuben and Edward Messier, who went to a dance at Berkeley Heights Wednesday night.

BOSTON, June 1. -- The Reorganization Committee of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company has received more than 37,000 shares of the preferred stock out of the 38,176 outstanding. The committee has also received more than 185,000 shares of common stock out of the total number of 198,150 shares.

Dobbins is getting to be a regular in-and-outer. Yesterday afternoon he won the Fleetwood Stakes, for three-year-olds, from a field of six horses in very clever fashion. It was not a very high-class field that he ran against, but he had run so badly at the Brooklyn track that the bookmakers laid 4 to 5 against him.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- If present plans shall be followed, there will be an onslaught made on the sugar schedule in the Senate to-morrow which may develop something racy.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Within a range that was confined to the restricted limits of 3/8 c, the price of wheat fluctuated to-day, with nothing of importance developing in the trade. Owing to the panic of yesterday in Argentina and the more than liberal offerings of that country's wheat in the United Kingdom, a panicky bunch of cables was expected from England to-day.

VANCOUVER, B.C., via Seattle, June 2. -- A wild waste of waters still whirls and roars through the valley of the Frazer. The ruin is complete. The waters have poured over dikes and over deserted prairie lands; millions of dollars' worth of property have been destroyed and hundreds of farmers ruined, and the worst is not over.

Still standing, in good preservation, and likely to be a landmark for many years yet, in Flushing, L.I., is the oldest Quaker meeting house in the State, perhaps in the country, and one which is closely connected with an event of peculiar interest to the Society of Friends.

From Hardware. Oil and gas stoves, while coming in competition with the old-time coal stove, have had no effect upon the sales of the latter. This is somewhat remarkable, but the history of a great many Improvements in civilization is like it. The gas or oil stove is simply an accessory to the range and the ordinary stove.

From The Boston Journal. A few days ago a dispatch was printed in the papers stating that William L. Guptill of Gouldsborough, Me., had been thrown from his carriage and killed, the details of the accident being also given. Thursday The Journal received this note written below the printed dispatch: "Mr. Editor; The above was clipped from a late paper! Yours truly, William L. Guptill."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The law of 1857, under which it is proposed to punish newspaper correspondents for not divulging professional secrets to the star chamber committee, was passed because of the refusal of James W. Simonton, a correspondent for The New-York Times, to answer questions put to him by a select committee of the House.

Very nearly half of yesterday's trading in the stock market was confined to Sugar certificates. The opening price was 101 1/2, and after some hesitation it began moving upward. There was mysterious talK about important developments in Washington, but the nature of the expected news was not divulged.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 2. -- This old resort is once more gaining in patronage in a gratifying way. It is noticeable already that the effects of push and energy are bringing new people to the place, and these people are bringing new ideas. As a Summer resort, nature has lavished unlimited riches upon the place.

Thomas C. Platt is hard at work endeavoring to arrange things so that he can have his own way in the making up of the Republican State ticket this year. He is making dickers and deals in various parts of the State to make his control of the State Convention sure and certain.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, June 2 -- Most important of the changes which will help in the prosperity of this season here will probably be the different management of the Casino. Sherry is to have it again, along with the privileges, formerly denied him, of supplying wines and liquors to the guests on the lawns and piazzas.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 2. -- After a conference which lasted all of this forenoon between Gov. Matthews, Adjt. Gen. Robbing, and Lieut. T.M. Defrees, United States Army, it was decided to call out nine companies of militia and a detachment of artillery with a Gatling gun, to suppress the depredations of the riotous miners massed at Cannellsburg.

LONDON, June 2. -- The book written by P.J.P. Tynan, the Captain of the Irish Invincibles, exposing the inside history of the murder of Lord Frederick Cavendish and Thomas Burke, in Phoenix Park, Dublin, in May, 1882, is certain to create a great sensation, and will necessarily draw forth a vast deal of denunciatory literature from the accused Parnellites.

-- The Yonkers High School Athletic Club has decided that Vivian Tompkins, who won several of the prizes in the annual games last Thursday, was ineligible, having failed to enter properly and have his name printed on the programmes. He was allowed to contest in the games under protest.

In the earliest times of purchase, a woman was bartered for useful goods or for services rendered to her father. In this latter way, Jacob purchased Rachel and her sister Leah. This was a Beena marriage, where a man, as in Genesis, leaves his father and his mother and cleaves unto his wife, and they become one flesh or kin -- the woman's.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

TRENTON, N.J., June 2. -- The Mercer County Wheelmen, whose representative, M. McGovern, was New-Jersey's champion in the fifth relay, turned out in great numbers at this point to watch the relay race. While awaiting the arrival of the men, the Mercer Wheelmen kept an eager eye on the bulletins to see how the race was progressing from relay to relay.

That road racing is becoming very popular here is admitted by everybody. Last Wednesday it is estimated that 75,000 persons witnessed the Irvington-Millburn race, and reports from Buffalo say that 30,000 saw the start of the Martin event. Road racing as a rule has been, confined to holidays, but the chances are that the time is not far distant when contests over favorite paths will be as numerous as the big meets.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A discussion that might have developed into something important and interesting was narrowly averted in the House to-day. Mr. Goldzier (Dem., Ill.,) offered a resolution asking the Commissioners of the District of Columbia to tell Congress why they had, as reported in the public press, decided to reduce the wages for common labor on public work in the District from $1.50 to $1 a day.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 2 -- The Fequot House will open this year earlier than in past seasons. The cottagers who dine at the hotel are among the first of the Summer visitors every year, and it is for their Accommodation and that of a number of applicants who have made requests for early accommodation at the hotel that Messrs.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Mrs. Lament will remain in Washington until the latter part of June, when she will go to the Secretary's old home in McGrawville, N. Y., to remain until some time in August, after which she will take her three young daughters for a season in the Catskills.

Having won the first big race of the year, the Brooklyn Handicap, Fred Taral, the popular idol among the jockeys of the country, went up to Morris Park yesterday and won the second of the great events of the year, the Metropolitan Handicap, this time with Ramapo. The horse that Taral had won the Brooklyn Handicap with, Dr. Rice, finished in the ruck.
Mayor Schieron's Gubernatorial boom has been set afloat in Brooklyn under circumstances which are exciting the greatest alarm among his friends and followers.

The arms of a Nuremberg family, Koch, provide us with a man all dressed in white, and holding a spoon in each hand; that is the cook. The implements, such as kettles and cauldrons, are furnished by the arms of many families of Castile and Aragon; the Pignatelli and the Montboucher give us saucepans; Padilla, three frying pans; Buttet in Vaud, a, grill; Escumont de Poislieres, a skimmer.

English cavalry swords are made particularly for cutting, (though with the steel scabbard it is difficult to understand how a keen edge is to be preserved,) and in the sword exercise cutting is very assiduously taught, and that, especially in the yearly mounted competition for swordsmanship prizes, the value of the point is impressed emphatically on the men.

Prof. Glardon talked and talked, replying unhesitatingly at great length to every question of the suffragists, without observing that Miss Tamberlain seated at the window which opens on the garden of the Presbytery, was quietly taking notes. Her direct look was severe, but there was an enchantment in the glances shot under her eyelashes.

WEST END, LONG BRANCH, June 2. -- The pigeon match between Welsh of the Riverton Gun Club and Work of New-York for the Riverton Cup was won by Welsh by a single bird. At the end of the first 25 each had killed 21. The

BERLIN, June 2 -- The Imperial Government's attitude to the last Anglo-Belgian agreement concerning possessions in Africa. has not yet been decided. In several newspaper reports it has been asserted, with a pretense of authority, that Germany has sent a protest to Brussels.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 2 -- The annual rush to the Catskills will begin next week, and by Saturday many hotels and boarding houses will throw open their doors to a large number of newly-arrived guests. Unfavorable weather has caused many city people who always go into the mountains early to remain at home, but if the week be a pleasant one hundreds of them will pass through this city mountainward.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- J.W. Davidson of the Washington Wheelmen of Tremont, N.Y., was the first man to finish in The New-York Times tri-State relay race. He crossed the tape at the corner of Nicetown Lane and Broad Street, at 6:15:45. Charles H. Measure of the Pennsylvania team finished at 6:16:50 and Whitfield W. Smith at 6:31:00.

At both the public and private sales stables there has been a very encouraging trade in horses of the better class during the week just closed. The demand has been for thoroughly-broken horses, fit for women and children to drive. They are wanted for use at the Summer resorts, about which people are thinking in spite of the thoroughly unseasonable weather.

BOSTON, Mass., June 2. -- The race meet of the Jamaica Cycle Club cause off here this afternoon. There were three races upon the programme, the chief event being the ten-mile open handicap road race. This race had on scratch such men as James Clark, Edward McDuffee, "Nate" Butler, (winner of the Linscott road race,) W.A. Rhoades of the Chicago Cycling Club, and George Cutler of the Eagle Cycling Club.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 2 -- A story has come to light that is likely to make trouble in the special Senate committee which is investigating the Police Department of the City of New-York. The State Controller has, up to this time, declined to pay any of the expenses of the committee except the hotel bills of the members that compose it.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The wellknown inventor, Hiram S. Maxim, the patentee of a rapid-fire gun and other ordnances devices, makes serious charges against Commander W.N. Folger of the navy, at present in command of the United States steamship Yorktown of the Bering Sea fleet.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Orders were cabled last night to the flagship Baltimore of the Asiatic squadron to proceed with all possible dispatch to the coast of Corea and take whatever measures are necessary for the protection of American interests. An official note of thanks will be sent to the King of Corea for his timely warning of the rebellion of some of his subjects which is said to be directed against Americans.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., June 2. -- The twenty-third day of the season for rifle practice at Creedmoor, L.I., was opened this morning by a detachment of the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn, composed of Companies E, F, and I, and men from all other companies who were unable to attend on their regular company days, under the command of Major Frederick H. Holmes, and under the supervision of Capt.

It is a mystery how the St. Louis Browns are kept in the background in the race for the League pennant. They won two games from the New-Yorks by the cleverest kind of ball playing, and yesterday they managed to make a draw of the contest on the Polo Grounds, although the Giants led in both batting and fielding.

DENVER, Col., June 2. -- The flood along the Platte is slowly subsiding. The water at Boulder was 12 feet deep in portions of the south side this morning, but it receded fast during the day. It is expected that trains will enter the city some time tomorrow. Mayor Cowie estimates the loss in Boulder at $350,000.

Puccini's "Manon" does not appear to have made a profound impression in London. The Westminster Gazette seems to voice the general opinion when it says: "Signer Puccini has composed in 'Manon Lescaut' a bright, melodious, cheery opera, and it was produced with complete success at the opening representation, of the brilliant opening representation, of the Covent Garden opera season last night.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Cushing's recent trip demonstrates that the system of inland navigation along the Atlantic seaboard, can be made to play a prominent part in a naval war. The Gushing was ordered to take a trip, with as few interruptions as possible, from Washington to New-York City, without going to sea.

Michael Sherry of 68 West Seventieth Street, the wealthy real estate owner who was stricken with paralysis at the Paris Place station of the elevated railroad on Thursday night, died at the Chambers Street Hospital early yesterday morning. He was unconscious most of the time after he was stricken until his death.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Although the Senate did not vote to-day on the resolution offered by Mr. Hill, which strikes a blow at star-chamber investigation by select committees, there is no doubt as to its decision when a vote is taken. Mr. Hill will stand practically alone in his effort to give the public access to the proceedings such as those Mr. Gray's committee is now engaged in behind closed doors.

The monthly Pilot Chart of the North Atlantic, which has just been issued by the Hydrographic Office, shows, as previous issues have clone, that the Atlantic is still plentifully strewn with derelicts, despite efforts made by the Vesuvius and other Government vessels to clear the ocean of these dangerous obstructions.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 2. -- Everybody is on the jump in this famous prohibition Summer resort. The big hotels are open, the bathing grounds are in full blast, the merry-go-rounds, razzle-dazzles, and crystal mazes furnish amusement for the giddy youths and maidens, and there are indications at every hand that the long-looked-for "season" has arrived.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., June 2 -- The close of the month brought many people from the cities to Halcyon Hall. While the black bass season opened on Decoration Day, on account of the high water from the recent rains, very few anglers met with much success.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 2 -- The 1st of June finds many cottagers already in Newport and the season in every way somewhat further advanced than usual. During the week the meeting here of Rhode Island's Legislature and the inauguration of State officials have served to enliven the cottagers.

New-Jersey riders won the grand tri-State relay race, promoted by The New-York Times, yesterday. The riders selected by the committee in charge of the little State were a sturdy set of young men, with recognized ability for climbing steep hills and spinning along smooth paths at a tremendous pace. They took the lead on the first relay from The New-York Times office to Paterson and held an advantage throughout the contest.

The recent exhibition of works by the pupils of the Artist Artisan Institute. 140 West Twenty-third Street, brought out clearly the difference between this school and others in the city. The battle Mr. John Ward Stimson is fighting is a battle for the elevation of industrial art. In many respects the institute gives the same kind of instruction as the Art Students' League and the art schools of the Academy and the Metropolitan Museum.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2. -- The steamer Australia arrived here this morning from Honolulu, bringing advices up to May 26. A United Press correspondent, writing under that date, says:

-- W.H. Jaques, who inaugurated the manufacture of heavy ordnance and armor at the works of the Bethlehem Iron Company, has associated himself with Horace See, the well-known engineer and naval architect, under the title of See Jaques. The firm has offices at 1 Broadway. It will engage in general engineering work, and consultation regarding the manufacture of guns and other war material, and the forging of armor.

From London Truth. Byzantium, Russia, and Egypt have all been in turn borrowed from by Sarah Bernhardt, who is as eager on pictures and sculptures at both Salons as if she were not the hardest-worked actress in Europe, and never went to bed before 2 in the morning. She is Rosicrucian in her hair, the shades of which vary according to the prevailing tone of her get-up. Of course, her locks are borrowed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 2. -- The New-England tennis championship in singles is over and Arthur Foote of Yale is the champion for the coming year. To-day he defeated Clarence Hobart in a five-set match, thereby winning the cup. The result was a great surprise, few thinking that Foote could down the mighty Hobart.

ELMIRA, June 2. -- While no final decision was made by the commission appointed by Gov. Flower to investigate charges made by a New-York newspaper against the managers of the State Reformatory, as to the place of holding all sessions, it is likely that they will all be held at the institution. The commission was unanimous in expressing an informal opinion that this would be best.

JEFFERSON BARRACKS, Mo., June 2. -- Passengers on railroad trains rushing along the west bank of the Mississippi River, south-bound from St. Louis, have their attention attracted, nine miles after leaving the metropolis of Missouri, by a United States flag floating in the breeze on a high bluff overlooking the river.

It was at an up-town soda-water fountain a day or two ago that there was enacted a little episode not without interest to the student of human nature. A rather imposing woman, standing at the counter, gave her check and an order, and as the attendant turned to prepare it the woman unconsciously or involuntarily moved along a pace or two.

The friendship of the Campbells had more practical value than a mere sentiment to be expended in criss-cross letters and autograph books, and to be vaunted for the annoyance of the less fortunate ones beyond its pale. It conferred a right, not transferable, to share in the benefits of wealth. They had received so much that out of very weariness they were forced to seek the pleasures of giving.

PATERSON, N. J., June 2. -- Five hundred spectators assembled in and about the Passaic Falls Wheelmen's clubhouse, on the Little Falls Turnpike, this morning to witness the arrival of the three bicycle riders in the great 150-mile relay race under the auspices of The New-York Times. The building was thronged with wheelmen, and the hill on the opposite side of the road was crowded with women and men awaiting the arrival of the racers.

Facts of decided interest relative to salmon at sea and in the coast waters of the Eastern States have just been published by the United States Fish Commission in a bulletin written by Mr. Hugh M. Smith. The purpose of the paper is to record the presence of salmon at points on the Atlantic coast or at sea in localities more or less remote from the places where fry have been deposited.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 2. -- The season here has been retarded by the continued bad weather during the past week. The large hotels have made preparations for an early season. There have been many additions to -the places of amusement, and all along the promenade on the beach front there have been extensive Improvements. The huge pier has been extended out into the ocean 200 feet.

When Henry Ward Beecher died it was predicted that Plymouth Church, in Brooklyn, would soon follow. To-day, under the ministrations of the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, the church has a congregation which taxes its seating accommodations to their utmost capacity, and each Sunday finds the church crowded to the doors.

Virginius Dabney, Deputy Collector of Customs, in charge of the warehouse division, died yesterday morning, in the Eighteenth Street station of the Third Avenue Elevated Road. He had gone there attended by his son, Noland Burr Dabney, to take a train down town. In climbing the stairway, he complained of difficulty in breathing and pain in the heart.

LONDON, June 2. -- It might be worth somebody's while to make a book tracing the influence of the weather on the world's history. I can remember in a vague way during the ten years of these dispatches numerous important events which dragged in, as a necessary part of their narration, an explanation by reference to current meteorological conditions.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 2. -- Another Cummer season has dawned upon the Jersey coast. The question before the hotel keepers and tradesmen is, "What will the harvest be?" The indications are that it will be eminently satisfactory, although a few croakers assert that the prevailing hard times and the fact that there will be no racing at Monmouth Park will prove detrimental to the interests of the Branch and other North Jersey resorts.

The stock market will not run long as it is now. Within thirty days there will be a decided change for better or worse. As things are, the trading has dropped down to two or three stocks. Two-thirds of the commission houses are doing next to nothing. Speculation in the general list is dead. It does not seem that enough speculative life is left to "energize" more than three or four stocks in a week.

LONDON, June 2. -- The Central International Committee nominated the following officers, who were unanimously elected: President -- Sir George Williams, founder of the Young Men's Christian Association; Vice Presidents -- Count Bernstorff, Alfred Andre, Prince Oscar of Sweden and Norway, and H. Thane Miller.

Minnie Seligman's acting in Robert Buchanan's impossible play, called "Lady Gladys," at the Madison Square Theatre, is so well thought out and so skillful in execution that it ought to have appreciation quite apart from the material with which it is associated. The love scene of Act II., for example, is played by Miss Seligman with truly remarkable delicacy and tact, with every possible emotion of the woman clearly expressed.

SING SING, N.Y., June 2 -- Warden Durston of Sing Sing Prison has issued orders allowing visitors to the prison and inmates, beginning with this morning, when, the Board of Health removed the quarantine which had been in operation for the last three months on account of the prevalence of smallpox. The disease has been stamped out, and the general health of the prison is good.

WEST POINT, June 2. -- Cloudy skies and threatening weather darkened the opening of the second day's examinations at the Military Academy. The oldest officer here does not remember colder or more disagreeable graduation days than those which the class of '94 are now experiencing. Visitors continue to arrive by every train, but the number so tar is not as great as in former years.

This is regatta week on the bay. Three big yacht races have been scheduled, and, after they have been decided, the yachts will go to the Sound and race off Larchmont next Saturday. To-morrow the thirty-seventh annual regatta of the Brooklyn Yacht Club will be sailed. Nearly forty yachts have been entered in the fifteen classes, and some rattling good contests are expected.
Warfare of the most aggresive and sensational sort will be begun this week by the leaders of the liberal element in the Presbyterian Church.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 2. -- The final week of the Lakewood season brought quite a revival of pleasure among the young people. The Laurel House, which marks the opening and closing of the Lakewood season, closed its doors Thursday, adding another successful season to the more than a dozen that make up the history of the house.

The war in Company C of the Eighth Battalion between Capt. O.W. Mooney and his men over the summary discharge of First Sergt. Eckenfolder promises in a very few days to rise to a white heat. The members of Capt. Mooney's command declare they will no longer serve under him. The members of the company have resolved to prefer charges against Capt. Mooney.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 2. -- The new racing track of the Crescent Wheelmen was opened to-day and proved, as expected, both fast and safe, though showers made it a trifle slippery. A big crowd was present, and the well-known "cracks" entered in the eight events were unstinting in their praises of the new track, which is an egg-shaped course, with an elevation of one foot in four on the turn.
BUFFALO, June 2. -- In an editorial article, under the caption " No Boss, No Dictator," The Evening Times, Norman Mack's paper, says:

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
ELIZABETH, N. J., June 2. -- Early in the day wheelmen from all over Union County began to gather at Wheatsheaf Hotel, the third relay point in the 150-mile race.
CHAPTER XVI. -- WHAT PEOPLE SAID. Sir Joseph was pleased with Lord Dunluce's quiet manner, in advancing his own claims.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The appearance of the Constellation at Newport marks the passing of the oldest commissioned ship of the navy. Its record is a long and interesting one. Its history is a part of our earliest commerce and its performances have been directed to the protection and maintenance of American rights on the high seas when such support was more necessary than it is to-day.

Capt. Ezekiel C. Baker, erstwhile Commander of the Brazilian war ship Nictheroy, is a sad sea-dog with a plethora of money and a superabundance of clothing. He is a tall, well-developed, handsome, deep-water sailorman -- a fine specimen of the product of the American merchant marine.

SANDY HOOK, June 2. -- People more than one hundred miles from Sandy Hook will see a strange light or beam of light coming from the big searchlight at Sandy Hook Proving Grounds some evening of thig week. This is the light that was exhibited at the World's Fair, and is the most complete apparatus of its kind.

From The London Globe. The inhabitants of Stonehaven have been not a little excited of late by the receipt of communications from benevolent Spaniards, offering to point out the spot where a large amount of buried treasure is to be found. The last of these letters, which is signed "Cesar de Cordoba," and dated Barcelona, is really a remarkable document.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 2. -- The legend of Hiawatha, so rhythmically told by Long-fellow, will form the basis of the great celebration which Onondaga County is to have during the week of June 4, Clark and Beauchamp, the local historians, have established beyond dispute that Hiawatha was the wise man and chieftain of the Onondagas, who called together the strongest tribes of the Iroquols, and founded the wonderful confederation of the Six Nations.

ORANGE, N.J., June 2. -- There is again trouble in Christ Episcopal Church, East Orange. It now looks as if there would be no boys' choir to sing there to-morrow, its members having gone out on a strike. Some time ago the former rector, the Rev. Horace S. Bishop, over whom there had been dissension in the parish, resigned, and soon after the arrival of his successor, the Rev. W.W. Davis, there was more trouble.

From The Westminster Gazette. Gravesend was considerably excited by the arrival of the United States cruiser Chicago yesterday. The Chicago, lately from Lisbon, sailed up the river at about 7 o'clock yesterday morning, and, after returning the salute from Tilbury Port, anchored off the town pier.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- That newspaper opinion is more acceptable to Senators than their savage attitude toward newspaper correspondents would lead some people to suppose was demonstrated late this afternoon, when the debate on the sugar schedule was waxing warm. Mr. Lodge was the first to call attention to this interesting fact.
LONDON, June 2. -- The Royal Navy Club celebrated with a dinner at the Metropole this evening the one hundredth anniversary of Lord Howe's victory over the French in the Bay of Biscay.

Gov. Tillman of South Carolina was, a few weeks ago, a great stickler for law and order. The question was then of enforcing a most odious and inquisitorial law, which he had advocated upon the express ground that it was odious and inquisitorial, and would disgust the "old aristocracy."

From The Baltimore Sun. It is estimated by Prof. Langley of the Smithsonian that the waste of force in producing light by means of gas is over 99 per cent, of the energy expended, whereas the firefly wastes none at all. His light is without heat -- a cold light. It is the result of some sort of obscure chemical action which scientists are trying to Imitate.

BOSTON, June 2. -- The "bouncer" type of boat is to be introduced to Boston waters. Messrs. N.B. Stone and William Allerton of the South Boston Yacht Club are building, a couple of fifteen-footers from a design by Thomas Clapham of Roslyn, L.I., the originator of the type, and expect to race them in the fifteen to eighteen foot sailing length class.

PARIS, May 3. -- Some things come to Paris from Chicago. The Mission de la Fieur, an old charity in New-York, is one of these, only I can't see where the flowers are to come from, unless Amercia sends them also. No one here, not even a demi-mondaine -- who enjoys the best of all else in this world -- has any idea of our flower luxury at home.

ORANGE, N.J., June 2. -- The Board of Governors of the Orange Club gave a farewell reception and dinner to Alfred O. Tait, a member of the club, last evening. He recently resigned his position as Superintendent of the Edison Phonograph Works of West Orange.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S. I., June 2. -- The baseball teams of the Staten Island Cricket and Athletic Clubs, old rivals, played their first game of the season at Livingston this afternoon. The game was hotly contested, but the rain, which fell throughout the nine innings, made a big score and many errors. The score:
LONDON, June 2. -- In an article on yachting in to-day's issue The Field says:

Mr. Byrnes is reported to have said yesterday that the disclosures before the Lexow committee on Friday must be followed by indictments. He is right. The committee may do as it thinks best as to the pursuit of its inquiries, but it has no such responsibility as rests on the District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- There are two drug shops in this town which do not depend upon the Washington public for patronage or profit. There are no signs above their doors, their windows do not contain the regulation glass vessels filled with colored fluids, and soda-water fountains do not tempt persons with nickels and cast-iron stomachs to enter.

The constitutional amendment proposed by a committee of the National League for the Protection of American Institutions embodies the sound doctrine in regard to the relation of the State toward any and all religious bodies. It is the doctrine of absolute and complete separation of Church and State and of the institutions that belong to each.

No one who was not confined to a house yesterday will need to be told that the day was one of those rare ones of June, "when heaven tries the earth if it be in tune, and over it softly her warm ear lays."

CONEY ISLAND, June 3. -- Coney Island fairly bristled with policemen to-day. In the Bowery and other popular resorts one saw as many peace guardians in walking two or three blocks as he would be likely to meet in as many miles up town in Brooklyn.

We apprehend that there will be little opposition in the Constitutional Convention to the plan of separating general and municipal elections by having them held in different years. There can be no difference of opinion about its importance among those who are seeking to promote the reform of city government.

The Rev. Dr. J. Balcom Shaw in the West End Presbyterian Church, One Hundred and Fifth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, last evening closed his series of sermons on the "Imminent Evils of Our Modern Metropolitan Life" with a talk on "Ecclesiastical Evils."

BROCKTON, Mass., June 3. -- The F.W. Billings fourteen-mile handicap bicycle road race took place here yesterday afternoon. There were eighteen starters. The course was from Warren Avenue, head of Park Street, to South Easton, turn to the left to Eastondale, to Algers Corners, Cochesett, to Clifton Heights, Warren Avenue.

The Rev. Watson J. Mosier, pastor of Grace Baptist Church, Decatur Street and Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday celebrated the first anniversary of his connection with that congregation. There was no special service, but it was a notable event in Brooklyn religious circles, for the reason that since he took charge of the church Mr. Mosier has labored without salary, having refused a fixed compensation for his work.

The steam yacht Atalanta, the finest-looking yacht afloat in her new coat of white paint, passed Sandy Hook at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon on her long trip across the ocean to the racea in which the Vigilant will try to beat all opponents.

LONDON, June 4. -- The Times says: "The selection of the Earl of Jersey to represent Great Britain at the intercolonial conference at Ottawa is a matter for general congratulation. His moderation, sound sense and judgment, and his trained capacity for dealing with financial problems are likely to be more valuable at Ottawa than an enthusiastic predisposition to accept imperialistic conclusions."

According to the press reports or the debate in the Senate on Saturday last, Mr. Aldrich of Rhode Island made two assertions which were so clearly false that we can find no excuse for him in the plea that his memory had failed him or in any other of the defenses that are sometimes offered in cases of this kind.

The public authorities of Brooklyn have very properly decided that they cannot under the present laws relieve manufacturers or any other class of citizens from the assessment of their personal property for taxation. They recognize the fact that it tends to discourage and drive away capital which might be invested in profitable enterprises for the employment of labor and for the increase of real estate values.

Mayor Schieren, Supervisor at Large Fitchle, Controller Corwin, City Auditor Weber, and County Treasurer Adams, composing the Board of Estimate of Brooklyn, will meet to-day to pass upon the requisitions for city and county purposes for 1895.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 3. -- A secret meeting of the pottery manufacturers of the United States was held in this city yesterday afternoon.
