Twenty-five representatives were present from Trenton, N.J.; New-Cumberland, West Va.; Fremont, Ohio; East Liverpool, Ohio; Toronto, Ohio; Steubenville, Ohio; Wheeling, West Va.; Kittanning, Penn., and Pittsburgh There has beef a strike in the pottery trade since the 1st of last January.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 3. -- Senator James A. Bradley is the owner of the famous board walk and the pavilions which line it on either side from Asbury Avenue to Deal Lake. Last year he was considerably annoyed by guests of the hotels, who complained that the best seats in the pavilions were occupied by the colored people, most of whom were hotel help.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 3. -- If the opinion of Victor Smith, a prominent Baltimore lawyer, is correct, the vessels which left Honolulu recently for Johnson Island will have their labor for their pains. The vessels referred to are the island steamer Iwalanl and the English cruiser Champion, each of which started for the island with the intention of claiming the property for its Government.

Evan Thomas, Chairman of the Business Men's Association, which organized the meeting that was held in Carnegie. Music Hall Friday evening, has received many additional telegrams protesting against the income tax. They came from all parts of the country -- from bankers, Boards of Trade, Chambers of Commerce, and men prominent in business circles.

Answer was made by Archbishop Corrigan, in St. Patrick's Cathedral, yesterday, to charges against the Roman Catholic Church such as the American Protective Association makes it its business to circulate. The Archbishop's able defense was listened to by a large congregation that attended the last mass of the day, celebrated by Mgr. Sbarretti, auditor of the papal delegation in Washington.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 3. -- ExJudge Joseph Folger Barnard, for thirty years a Justice of the Supreme Court, and for a number of years Chief Justice of the General Term in the Second Judicial District, made his first appearance yesterday since his retirement on Jan. 1 last as counsel in a case.

Central Park policemen were tired when the last rider and the last driver went from their precinct last night, for their day had been a busy one, what with the crowds of been a busy one, what with the pedestrians, riders, drivers, and more bothersome than all the rest -- an unusual number of runaways.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 3. -- Frank Burge of New-York has been notified of the arrival of a bay colt, full brother to the great Tenny. The dam, Maywood, is at Wilkes Lodge Farm, in this county.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 3. -- The handsome new home of the Poughkeepsie Tennis Club, built to replace the clubhouse destroyed by fire last year, was formally opened Friday night with the production by the members of the club of the play "Our Boys." The play was repeated yesterday afternoon and evening, large and fashionable audiences being present at all the performances.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 3. -- It is firmly believed here that the great coal strike will be declared off Tuesday, when the National Executive Board of the mine workers shall hold its meeting with the district Presidents in this city.

A fairly large congregation assembled in Plymouth Church last night to hear the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott give his views about the action of the Presbyterian General Assembly in excluding the Rev. Dr. Henry Preserved Smith from the pulpit. In his morning sermon Dr. Abbott announced that he would have something to say that would surprise his hearers.

The reputable Irishmen of New-York, without regard to their political affiliations, were aroused to expressions of indignation yesterday over the published charge of Dynamiter P.J.P. Tynan that the assassination of Lord Frederick Cavendish, Chief Secretary for Ireland, and of Under Secretary Burke, in Phenix Park, Dublin, in 1882, was instigated by Charles Stewart Parnell and the leaders who were associated with him in Parliament in the movement for Irish home rule.

(Reported by Messrs. Dick Brothers Lawrence, 30 Broad Street, New-York.) PITTSBURG, June 2. -- The market for home securities ruled dull throughout the week, but no concessions of moment were made in prices, and altogether the local market may be described as the firmest to be found anywhere.

LONDON, June 3. -- Jubilee sermons in connection with the Young Men's Christian Association Conference were preached this morning and evening in 1,400 churches in London and its suburbs, as well as all over Great Britain.

The English Radical was extremely happy when his leaders announced that the House of Lords must be abolished. Since that date, however, his happiness has been somewhat dimmed by the persistent and exasperating way in which his adversaries ask him to explain by what method he proposes to abolish the House of Lords.

Bishop Potter will conduct this evening the first exercises of a week's mission in the Cathedral Mission, 130 Stanton. Street. This series of religious meetings for the benefit of the residents of that quarter of the city will mark the beginning of the new order of things in the management of what was formerly known as the Old Epiphany House Mission, long maintained by St. George's Church.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 3. -- Everything at Yale points toward the close of the college year. Recitations in both the undergraduate departments the academic and the scientific, will close next Wednesday, June 6, and the final examination on the year's work will be begun at once. They will last about two weeks for each class in the two departments.

The imaginary conversations of William Dean Howells with himself, or to say better, between the several conflicting elements in Mr. Howells's character, on the subject of Socialism in its relation to the present state of civilization in this country, which were published in a monthly magazine, have here been collected in a substantial volume.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 3. -- One hundred of Vassar's many visitors on Decoration Day were members of the New-York branch of the Vassar Students' Aid Society, accompanied by their Secretary, Miss Halstead, and by a few members from Brooklyn and South Orange. The party was served with luncheon at the college.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 3. -- Every available seat in the auditorium and balcony in the First Presbyterian Church was occupied at this morning's service, when the pastor, the Rev. J. Ritchie Smith, preached the annual baccalaureate sermon to the cadets of the Mohigan Lake Military Academy and the Peekskill Military Academy.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., June 3. -- An international temperance congress was opened to-day in the great auditorium at National Prohibition Park. The congress has brought together workers for prohibition from every part of the country, and very appropriately the exercises of to-day were in the nature of a reception in honor of Gen. Neal Dow, ex-Governor of Maine and the father of the prohibitory law in that State.
LONDON, June 3. -- In the Clyde Yacht Club cruise on Saturday the Dakotah won easily. Yachtsmen say she can beat anything afloat of her own size.

WEST POINT, June 3. -- As the time approaches for the departure of the cadets from the old gray walls of the Military Academy an air of bustle and activity prevails which is foreign to the regularity and quiet which at other times characterizes this place. Many officers, too, must quit this delightful spot, and they are now busy packing up their household effects preparatory to leaving for their new commands.

TRENTON, June 3. -- The National Guardsmen of New-Jersey are looking forward with impatience to the period of rifle practice and the encampment of the Second Brigade. Rifle practice, according to division orders, begins July 9 and ends Aug. 31. The camp of the Second Brigade opens Saturday, July 14, and continues until the following Saturday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 3. -- The late William W. Cornell, in whose house was found a fortune of over $1,000,000, was one of the most eccentric and peculiar characters in Dutchess County. Prior to the death of his wife, fifteen years ago, he was a sufferer from tic douloureux, and had an idea that he was helpless.

The big tri-State relay race promoted by The New-York Times and its result was what the wheelmen in this vicinity were all talking about yesterday. That the race was a success far beyond expectation was said at every bicycle club in the city visited by representatives of The Times, and the opinion was freely expressed that it had already done much in the interest of road racing and its effect would be lasting.

HARTFORD, June 3. -- Under the new law, passed a year ago, conferring school suffrage on the women of the State, there will be a large female vote polled at the school district meetings, which will take place this month in most of the Connecticut towns. There are 1,300 districts in the State, and women will be eligible to office in each one of them.

Sadie Felsner, eighteen years old, jumped from the roof of the tenement 38 Goerck Street last evening and was instantly killed. She might as well have walked down the stairs or descended the fire escape, but she became panic-stricken when she looked out of the fifth story window at which she was sitting and saw smoke and flames coming out of the third-story windows.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, June 3. -- Fifteen business houses and twenty residences in this city were destroyed by fire to-day. A boy was killed, a man was fatally injured, and three other men were seriously injured.

The week in the stock market was one of the dullest of the year. It was broken by the holiday on Wednesday. There was a natural indisposition to enter into new undertakings pending the recess, and as business was light anyway, many operators took advantage of the opportunity to spend a few days in the country.
The announcement that the Rev. Dr. Charles L. Thompson, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, would preach on "The Higher Athletfes" drew a large congregation to the church last evening.

BERLIN, June 3. -- The clamor raised by the colonial enthusiasts over the Anglo-Belgian agreement has caused many to exaggerate the importance which the Government attaches to this partial reapportionment of Africa. The colonial partisans, with their new demands for more African territory, have left the Government almost as cold as they found it.

ORANGE, N.J., June 3. -- The vested choir of Christ Episcopal Church of East Orange struck to-day, as expected, and refused to sing. The cause was the discharge of the choirmaster, William I. Lyon, and the appointment in his stead of George J. Brewer, a personal friend of the rector. The choir, numbering thirty, assembled in the choir room this morning as usual.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3. -- The members of the class of '94 are now beginning to feel that their college career is almost a thing of the past. On Tuesday all recitations and lectures ended, and on Thursday the dreaded examinations began in earnest. Class Day is only three weeks ahead, and its nearness is emphasized by the long announcement of regulations which has just been issued by the Class Day Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Navy Department is in receipt of a cable message announcing the safe arrival of the United States war vessel Alliance at Barbados yesterday. This news was very gratifying to the department, as the Alliance was considerably overdue, and more anxiety was really felt on her account than in regard to the other two vessels which are still to be heard from, the Lancaster and the Marion.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3. -- The Naval Academy class of '94, which is to be graduated June 8, is composed of forty-seven members, thirty-four in the line and thirteen in the engineer division, as follows:

ORANGE, N.J., June 3. -- The New-Jersey members of the League of American Wheelmen have decided to take up the question of local politics this Fall and to work for the nomination and election of only such men for members of the County Boards of Freeholders as will pledge themselves to work indefatigably for better roads in their respective counties.
Muossa Daoud is the leader of the Syrian colony in New-York, as the little peddler Joseph, the natural Arab whom the artificial street Arabs assailed last week, said in court.

ALBANY, June 3. -- The Democrats of the State have every reason to be satisfied with the policy pursued by their delegates in the Constitutional Convention. It is true that a handful of Democrats, acting under the guidance of a badly-balanced delegate from New-York, who lives in Albany, has attempted to push politics to the front, but their methods have been defeated by the Republicans and discouraged by the more sagacious Democrats.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4. -- Hedwig Hubach, eighteen years old, of 392 South Ninth Street, died at the City Hospital at noon to-day from the effects of carbolic acid taken with suicidal intent, because her parents objected to her receiving the attentions of Fred Winkler, with whom she was evidently in love.

Joseph J. Casserly, who lives at One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street and Tenth Avenue, was arrested yesterday by two Post Office Inspectors on the charge of attempting to defraud the Post Office authorities. Some time ago William Roach of 93 Tenth Avenue passed a civil service examination with 87 per cent, for the position of porter in the Post Office.
The Young Women's Christian Association held its last monthly meeting for the season in the parlors of the association, building, in East Fifteenth Street, yesterday morning.

The stock market was somewhat broader yesterday, but the improvement was due almost entirely to professional operations. London quotations came higher, due probably to covering of short contracts. Most of the foreign orders were in St. Paul and Louisville and Nashville, although there were a good many in Atchison and one or two of the other international specialties.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 4. -- Merchants in the flooded districts are at work removing goods and raising them on platforms above the water. The river continues to rise, and the situation grows more serious.

Somewhere between three and four hundred people allowed themselves to be taken up to the top of the American Theatre last evening, and in the "garden" that has been constructed there most of them remained until midnight, gravely observant of the variety performance that went on upon the handsome little stage into which the horticultural department merges on one side of the building.
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Discussing what should be done for the navy, Hernando D. Money of Mississippi, who is one of the leading Democratic members of the House Naval Committee, said this morning:

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The star chamber sugar investigation of the Senate gives cause for many of the constant errors that are made because of its effort to filter the testimony given to it so that not too much of it shall get out while it is new.
VANCOUVER, B.C., June 4. -- Old settlers say the melting snow on the mountains will cause the Frazer River to rise twelve inches higher. This will mean another series of calamities.

One of the most exciting meetings ever held by the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen was that of yesterday, when all sense of parliamentary usages was cast aside, the President of the board was insulted, and the members accused each other of not being gentlemen.
We invite attention to a remarkable exhibition of cool mendacity.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs, after a recess of five days, this morning resumed its inquiry into the alleged armor-plate fraud. Lieut. W.C. Cowles, who was the first Inspector at the Carnegie works, was put on the stand.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. William Cole sold a number of lots in the new Twenty-ninth Ward. The corner of East Broadway and Lloyd Street went at $870 to W. Shipman. The adjoining one on East Broadway went to H. Thompson at $525. The next two were bought by the same at $450 each, and the next two, 25 by 152 each, also by Mr. Thompson, at $700 each.

During the thunderstorm early yesterday morning there was great commotion about the usually quiet neighborhood of West End Avenue and Eighty-second Street. A number of pistol shots in rapid succession aroused the peaceful residents from their slumbers, and brought several rubber-coated policemen to the scene.

CREEDMOOR, L.I. June 4. -- The twentyfourth day of the season for rifle practice at Creedmoor, L.I., was opened this morning by a detachment of the Twenty-second Regiment, composed of Companies C, F, and H and a part of the Field and Staff, under command of Capt. W.B. Smith and under the supervision of Brig. Gen. B.M. Whitlock, Inspector of Rifle Practice State of New-York, and Capt. M.E. Burnton, Inspector of Rifle Practice Twenty-second Regiment.

Civil Justice George F. Roesch made an unqualified denial of the statements made concerning him by Mrs. Augusta Thurow when she was on the witness stand before the committee. He said that, although her husband, Ernest Thurow, was a member of the Tammany organization in the Seventh District, he did not know him personally.
The following appeal to patrolmen was issued after the Senate committee's hearing yesterday:

Not since Chester A. Arthur was prominent in New-York City politics have there been such vigorous discussions and so many divisions among Republicans as to candidates for city offices as there is this year.

The committee appointed by the Kings County Board of Supervisors to investigate the accounts of County Treasurer Henry H. Adams reported to the Supervisors yesterday that there is a shortage of $77,981.29. This is about $3,000 more than was at first supposed, and from the report of the committee the shortage appears to be of long standing.

BOSTON, June 4. -- Local stocks were quite active, and certain specialties were strong, but the tone of the general market changed but little. Bell Telephone rose 2 points, to 200, and the other telephones sympathized, Erie gaining 2, to 47, and New-England selling at 60. Dominion Coal was steady at 21.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- The cruiser Minneapolis, which will leave Cramps' shipyard to-morrow morning on her builders' trail trip, is a sister ship to the Columbia, now in commission, and is the finest type of the commerce destroyer cruiser that has ever been built.

LONDON, June 4. -- A dispatch from TienTsin says that the Kirin and Manchuria insurrection is asuming serious proportions. The rebels, who are well armed with repeating rifles, have routed the Government forces on several occasions and massacred a large number of Chinese colonists. They have also captured the arsenal at Sarsaing, in which is stored nearly a million rifles.

The last of the consignment of yearlings from the Rancho del Paso breeding farm of J.B. Haggin was sold at auction by William Easton in the Morris Park sales paddock before the races yesterday. There were thirty-six head sold for a total of $37,675, making an aggregate of $122,400 for the lot, consisting of 118 head in all that were offered.

NEW-HAVEN, June 4. -- Yale defeated the University of Pennsylvania ball nine to-day here by the score of 13 to 5. Boswell, the visitors' lauded pitcher, was driven from the box by a fusillade of Yale hits in the third inning, and his successor fared little better. Two neat double plays by the Philadelphians and a magnificent running foul catch by Rustin enlivened an otherwise slow contest.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- The traction stocks were pressed for sale to-day, Philadelphia declining from 99 1/2 to 96 1/2, People's from 31 to 29, and Metropolitan from 112 3/4 to 111 3/4. Disgruntled holders say that the late boom in these securities was merely to let insiders unload so they could pick up cheap allotments later on.

John B. Ketchum, General Secretary of the United States Army Aid Association, is desirous of controverting the action of the War Department in questioning the sincerity of motive and utility of the operations of the association.

The twenty-third annual regatta of the NewJersey Yacht Club will be sailed next Tuesday. The judges will be Commodore F.S. Ketcham, Commodore A.J. Prime, and George G.E. Gartland. The Regatta Committeemen are A. Wenzel, William Sherman, and William F. Dickinson.

The twin-screw steam yacht Margaret, designed and built by Charles L. Seabury Co., Nyackon-Hudson, for Mr. John H. Rutherford of this city, was launched yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. Following is her dimensions: Length, over 75 feet; load-water line, 68 feet: beam, 11 feet 6 Inches; draught, 4 feet 6 inches. The bulwarks are 12 inches high above deck.

LONDON, June 5. -- The Graphic publishes this morning a notable interview with Sir George Grey, sometime Premier of New-Zealand and Governor of Cape Colony, concerning a future federation of English-speaking peoples. Sir George prophesied a close federative alliance of the United States and Great Britain.

LONDON, June 4. -- Count Bernstorff of Berlin presided this morning at the opening of the fourth day's conference of the Young Men's Christian Associations at Exeter Hall. The devotional exercises were conducted by Pastor Krummacher of Germany. Richard C. Morse of New-York, Secretary of the American International Committee, presented a paper on "Association Work in America."

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., June 4. -- "I came here to contend that prohibition does not prohibit, cannot prohibit, and never will prohibit; and to tell you that we in South Carolina have found a plan that utterly destroys the saloons."

WEST POINT, June 4. -- The third day of the examinations and exercises at the Military Academy began this morning. The examination of the first class in ordnance and gunnery was continued by Capt. Bruff in the lecture room of the philosophical department. There will be no failures in this branch, as it is purely military, and the boys are not apt to neglect the subject.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., June 4. -- Steele Walker, one of the largest wholesale grocery houses of this city and of the West, made a general assignment this morning for the benefit of their creditors. J.A.B. Weakley and William W. Wheeler of this city were named as trustees and are in possession.

ORANGE, N.J., June 4. -- The East Orange Cyclers have arranged their annual 100-mile run from here to Princeton and return, and it will take place on Sunday, June 10, the start to be made from the clubhouse in Union Avenue at 6 o'clock in the morning. The route will lie through Millburn, Plainfield, New-Brunswick, and Franklin Park.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent throughout the day.

Robert Fleming of London, who has been in this country for the last two months looking after Atchison affairs, has made a report, to the London bondholders' committee, in which he says: "In reorganization, any assessment that is to help the second mortgage bondholders must be real; that is, it must be without compensation beyond stock in the new company, or in some security entailing no additional fixed charge.

The exposures made by The New-York Times of the underhand work and methods of the American Prescriptive Association, impudently called by its promoters the American Protective Association, are attracting widespread attention.

The testimony given before the Lexow committee yesterday was quite as interesting and suggestive as the testimony given last Friday, and it had more elements of novelty. The testimony given last Friday by the keeper of an unlawful resort was simply the putting in an explicit and responsible form of rumors that every well-informed person has heard and has believed.

Kim Ok-Kyun was assassinated in Shanghai in March last. His death was the result of a plot instigated by the Corean Government, who selected the instrument of their vengeance in the personage of Hong-Tjongou, a Corean adventurer, who, after the murder, received the protection of the Chinese authorities and was taken back in triumph to Seoul on board of a Chinese man-of-war, which also conveyed to Corea the mutilated corpse of the once powerful conspirator.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 4. -- Mrs. Lizzie Halliday, who was lodged in the Sullivan County Jail September last on a charge of having murdered Paul Halliday and Mrs. McQuillan, will be tried June 18 for the crime.

The Casino muddle has been straightened out for the present, and, as The New-York Times has repeatedly foretold during the past year, Rudolph Aronson is again to take posession of the theatre, for the building of which he, more than any other man, was responsible.

UTICA, June 4. -- Gov. Flower visited New-Hartford, a suburb of this city, to-day, to speak at a Good Roads meeting, held under the direction of the Central New-York Farmers' Club, the Oneida County Grange, and the Oneida County League for Good Roads. In the course of his speech, the Governor said:
PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- There is now every probability that an effort to resume operations will be made to-morrow by a number of the bituminous coal operators with mines in the Clearfield region.

The primaries of the State Democracy organization in this city are to be held to-night from 7 to 9 o'clock. The enrollment is said to include about 40,000 voters. Although the primaries are held at the Assembly district headquarters, members of each election district organization will vote separately for delegates to the Assembly District Committee.
The Brooklyn and Long Island Preachers' Association of the Methodist Church met at 502 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, the Rev. R.S. Pardington presiding.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., June 4. -- The day in Cripple Creek has been a long wait for news of the moving of the deputies who were reported to be breaking camp at Divide at 8 A.M., but from one who passed through Divide at 5 P.M. it was learned that they were still in quiet occupation of their quarters there at that time.

Judges Beach and Truax of the Supreme Court yesterday decided the following cases brought by property owners to recover damages from the elevated railroads for injury to property along the line of the roads:

PARIS, June 4. -- At noon, to-day Mr. F. Atlee, the British Consul, performed the civil marriage ceremony uniting Miss Victoria Alexandrina Blackwood, daughter of the Marquis of Dufferin and Ava, British Ambassador to France, to William Lee Plunkett, son of the Anglican Archbishop of Dublin.

TROY, N.Y., June 4. -- The New-York State Circuit was opened to-day at Rensselaer Park, near this city. Over 3,000 people attended. The great men of the day were present. Johnson and Sanger met but once, and Johnson, after trailing the Milwaukeean for seven-eighths of a mile, beat him in a length. This was in the mile handicap, in which the two were placed at scratch, Bald having twenty yards, Titus and Callahan forty yards.

"This will be a great game," said Arlie Latham of the Cincinnatis yesterday, as he strode upon the diamond at the Polo Grounds. "We haven't won in three weeks, and it was last month, I believe, that the Giants scored a victory. When two hard-luck clubs meet, just look out for fun."

NEWARK, N.J., June 4. -- Over fifty members were present at the regular meeting of the Atalanta Wheelmen to-night, and the pretty clubhouse, at 50 Clinton Street, was illuminated until after midnight. Speeches were made, and "Rah! Rah! Tiger!" rang through the building everytime the name of The New-York Times was mentioned.

Favored by a perfect sky overhead and a cracking southwest wind, the Brooklyn Yacht Club held its thirty-seventh annual regatta yesterday. The sport was firstclass, and the members and their guests, who watched the races from the Iron Steamboat Cygnus, had a thoroughly-enjoyable time. The arrangements, thanks to the able management of the Regatta Committee, consisting of Louis Wunder, Chairman; Frederick W. Bobbett, and Frank L. Townsend, went off without a hitch.

It is probable that ex-District Attorney De Lancey Nicoll will be assisted by other lawyers in the work of defending the Police Department before the Senate Committee. It was said yesterday that one of these lawyers would be ex-Surrogate Rastus S. Ransom, and that he would be in court within a few days.

At the annual election at the Produce Exchange yesterday, the provision and oil trades supported R.B. Brown of the Occidental Oil Company for member of the Board of Managers, against C.E. Milmine of the grain house of Milmine, Bodman Co. Opposition was based on the fact that the place to be filled had been held by a provision man, and that trade felt entitled to name the successor.
More sensational testimony against Police Captains and their ward detectives was given yesterday before the special Senate committee which is investigating the Police Department of this city.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., June 4. -- A Jersey Central passenger train, leaving here at 5:08 o'clock, was wrecked by being struck by a Lehigh Valley freight train shortly after it left the station. Where the two roads cross, the Lehigh engine ran into the passenger train. It demolished the baggage car. No one was hurt. Travel was delayed three hours.

LONDON, June 4. -- The United States cruiser Chicago will leave Gravesend June 14. On June 11 Admiral Erben will give a dinner on board the Chicago, to which a large company of officers of the British Army and Navy has been invited. A number of ladies will also be present.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- In the case of the Associated Press against The Washington News and the United Press, in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, sitting in equity, Judge Cox this morning announced that he would continue until to-morrow the consideration of the kind of decree he would render on the only point upon which he was inclined to accede to any of the demands of the complaining association.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 4. -- Ex-Judge Thomas Nelson and Mrs. Nelson celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage at their home, the Welcher Place, in Washington Street, this afternoon. There was a large number of guests, many of them from out of town. Mr. and Mrs. Nelson received them on the lawn, which was handsomely decorated.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 4. -- A fight with a big mastiff was the experience of Paul Haghen during an exciting fifteen minutes last night. It began at 7:30, when Haghen, who is a stableman for a butcher named William C. Frank, returned from a walk and a swim, bringing with him to Frank's barn the big dog which invariably accompanies him at these times.

The Sheriff's jury, which has been sitting for two weeks in the Supreme Court hearing evidence pro and con on the charge that Mrs. Alma Louise Coddington-Fellows was a chronic inebriate and incapacitated thereby from managing her property or her children, failed to agree on a verdict last night and was discharged.

The thirty-sixth annual report of the Chamber of Commerce was issued yesterday. It reviews the work of that association for the last year, including action upon rapid transit, commercial relations with Canada, the Hudson River Bridge, the income tax, and reform in municipal government, and it describes the course and effects of the financial and commercial depression.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- In the House to-day the debate on the Bank Tax bill was continued. Mr. Rayner (Dem., Md.,) and Mr. Dalzell (Rep., Penn.,) spoke in opposition to the bill, and Mr. Cobb and Mr. Oates, both of Alabama, spoke in favor of the bill.

BOSTON, June 4. -- Writing from Glasgow, under date of May 23, a well-known yachting correspondent says: "The flutter occasioned in the Clyde by the arrival of the schooner Lasca had hardly subsided when another American challenger arrived, in the shape of the Herreshoffs' ten-rater Dacotah, which has been exercising all the available nautical talent of the Clyde in criticising her build and equipment.

An account of a double lynching in the village of Colfax, County of Whitman, and State of Washington, has just been published which seems to point out a new path of municipal and economical reform. It appears that there were in the common jail of Colfax two prisoners who were believed to have committed murder.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4. -- The Town Hall was crowded to suffocation to-night when the Excise Commissioners tried again to take final action upon the applications for license to sell liquor. The board is composed of John A. Daly, who favors license for all; Charles A. Quinby, who is willing to grant but ten licenses, and Joseph H. Mead, who is opposed to granting a single license.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 4. -- The Times to-day began taking the afternoon report of the United Press. In an editorial notice it says:

The assertion is frequently made that grand opera in English is not profitable. Yet a season seldom passes without a series of performances of this kind being given in this city. These entertainments are usually offered at moderate prices and with an array of singers who do not attempt to compete in reputation with the high-priced stars of such companies as Abbey Grau's.

Terrace Garden has undergone a wonderful transformation since last season. The buildings, including bowling alleys, cafes, and music hall, now cover a plot of ground 200 feet through, from Fifty-eighth Street to Fifty-ninth Street. These have been decorated sumptuously and in thorough good taste.

The Philadelphia Record, conceded to be one of the best and most widely circulated newspapers in the United States, has just celebrated its seventeenth birthday as a one-cent newspaper. During the period of its existence it has had a marvelous career of prosperity, outstripping many of its competitors. Even during the past year, when business depression was widely felt throughout the country, affecting in more or less degree every commercial and mercantile enterprise.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 4. -- The voters of Oregon to-day elected their entire State ticket -- two members of Congress, one Supreme Court Judge and full county and municipal tickets. Owing to the great extent of the flood, it will be a week or more before the full returns are received. In Portland the counting is slow, because of the great length of the ticket.

CHICAGO, JUNE 4. -- The annual Stock Exchange election overshadowed business to-day. The market opened stronger, but lost a portion of the advance before the close. The feature of the day was the liquidation of a large lot of Street Stable Car Company stock. Of late this has been a strictly investment security, and as investors are not doing much just now the selling naturally resulted in lower prices.

There was an apparently well-padded programme for the racegoers at Morris Park yesterday. There were originally sixty-eight entries for the six races, but twenty-five of these entries were scratched before the races, and another horse, Connors, was scratched after he had gone lame in his preliminary canter.

The estate of Roswell Smith has sold to a Mr. Wells, for about $80,000, the four-story brownstone dwelling 22 East Fifty-first Street, south side, about 80 feet east of Madison Avenue. The dwelling is the end one on the street of what are known as the Villard houses.

The Presbyterian League of New-York and Vicinity, of the formation of which exclusive announcement was recently made in The New-York Times, held a meeting yesterday, mainly for the purpose of drafting and issuing to the public a statement explaining the reasons for the existence of the organization.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Committee on Rules, at the opening session of the House to-day, through Mr. Catchings (Dem., Miss.,) reported an order shutting off general debate on the pending bill and amendments to repeal the State bank tax. The bill was to be further considered during the day under the five-minute rule, and then a vote was to be taken immediately after the committees had been called tomorrow morning.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 5. -- The Miners' National Strike Committee adopted the following resolution at 10 o'clock to-night, after being in executive session since 10 o'clock this morning:

LONDON, June 5. -- The conference of the National Reform Union, a movement in favor of the abolition of the House of Lords, or, at least, a considerable abridgement of the power of that body, was opened here this morning, with Philip James Stanhope, M.P., in the chair.

The Tariff bill made visible progress in the Senate yesterday. To have passed the direful sugar schedule is a long step and an important step. It has been demonstrated that the Sugar Trust is too much for the Democratic Senate, as it was too much for both houses of Congress in 1890, when the Republicans were in control.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Wheat scored another advance to-day, and, although the bulls made complaint that the grain was not proportionate to the value of the news, still they were satisfied that prices closed 1/6c higher than they did yesterday. There were many influences at work, and it would not have been surprising had there been a more substantial upturn.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., June. 5. -- The closing session of the International Temperance Congress at Prohibition Park today were the most lively of the convention, and several scenes were enacted of a somewhat sensational nature. The attendance was not so large as at last night's meeting, but those present, were frequent in their interruptions of the speakers.

BALTIMORE, June 5. -- The trouble among the striking miners in Allegheny County has become so threatening that an appeal was made this morning by the Sheriff and State's Attorney for military assistance. The telegram to Gov. Brown said that there was imminent danger of bloodshed at Frostburg.

ALBANY, June 5. -- The joint hearing of four committees of the Constitutional Convention on the involved question whether charitable or educational institutions shall be exempt from taxation will begin at 2:30 o'clock Wednesday afternoon. The hearing will be continued Thursday, and may be carried over till next week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- The one hundred and, thirty-eighth commencement of the University of Pennsylvania was held this morning. Gov. Pattison, Adjt. Gen. Greenland, Mayor Stuart, members of the Faculty, and the Trustees of the institution attended the exercises in the Academy of Music.

From The Brooklyn Eagle. Sane people enjoying the civilization of cities like New-York and Brooklyn find it difficult to attach credence to some of the reports concerning the doings of the American Protective Association in the Western States. Yet these reports are well vouched for. They bear the stamp of authenticity.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 5. -- The Fraser River is still rising. Railroad officials say the worst will probably come to-morrow. One can only surmise what is meant by "worst," as the list of disasters is most appalling already.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- At one time today it looked as if the star-chamber committee which is investigating the connection of the Sugar Trust with the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill, and of Senators with Sugar speculations, would promulgate an order throwing open the doors of its inquisition chamber to members of the press.

TROY, June 5. -- The trial of "Bat" Shea for the murder of Robert Ross was continued to-day. Several jurors were secured, but all of them are subject to peremptory challenges. Assistant District Attorney Fagan and George E. Raines of Rochester are conducting the prosecution and Galen R. Hitt of Albany and John T. Norton of Troy represent the defendant.

The General Committee of the Citizens' Union of Kings County met in the St. George Hotel, in Brooklyn, last night, to take action on joining the State and National Municipal Leagues. The meeting was called to order by President William G. Low, who stated that no legal action could be taken by the meeting, as there was not a quorum present, only thirteen members being in the room.
"Gentlemen, medicine is a great humbug. I know it is called a science. Science indeed! It is nothing like science."

LEWISTON, Me., June 5. -- The Republican State Convention held here to-day to nominate a candidate for Governor was called to order by J.H. Manley, Chairman of the State Committee, on whose nomination Congressman Charles A. Boutelle was chosen Chairman.

After five unsuccessful attempts, the Giants finally won yesterday. Their victims were that "hard-luck" aggregation from Cincinnati, and the game abounded in stupid plays, errors, and ragged baseball that would bring a blush to the cheek of a minor league beginner.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 5. -- The Republican State Convention is being held here for the nomination of State officers. The temporary organization was made to-day, Congressman Bellamy Storer taking the chair and delivering an address in which he extolled protection and referred to Gov. McKinley as "available Presidential timber."

OXFORD, Penn., June 5. -- The annual commencement in the collegiate department of Lincoln University, Lower Oxford, was held to-day. The class numbered forty-two students. It was the largest ever sent out from this school for colored men. The names of the graduates follow:

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Since the edict of the New-York Stock Exchange committee abolishing arbitraging, the local operators have been looking around for other stocks to trade in. They tried St. Paul, Reading, Sugar, and such other stocks as have active fluctuations, with fair success, but their latest fad is Philadelphia Traction.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Secretary of the Interior and Mrs. Hoke Smith left the city to-night for Chapel Point, N.C., where on Wednesday the Secretary will deliver the oration at the commencement of the university at that place, where for many years his father was one of the leading professors.

BOSTON, June 5. -- The market for local stocks was quiet, but the general tone was firm. Bell Telephone showed a remarkable but rather suspicious strength, and registered another two-point rise to-day. It closed at 202. Erie Telephone followed suit. It advanced 1/2, to 47 1/2, though why it should is rather a mystery.

The upsetting or a gas reading lamp nearly caused a serious fire in the sitting room on the second floor of the handsome old-fashioned house of ex-Mayor Edward Cooper, at 12 North Washington Square, about 8 o'clock last night.
ALBANY, June 5. -- At a meeting of the Regents of the University, held to-day, the following action was taken in regard to the incorporation and admission of institutions:

The Investigating Committee of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, with Alderman Clark in the chair, yesterday resumed its inquiry into the affairs of the municipal departments. Franklin Allen, the expert accountant who has been examining the accounts of the Truants' Home, testified that there was no proper record kept of the affairs of the institution.

LONDON, June 5. -- The Coroner's inquest upon the body of the street musician Burton, whose death was caused by Gen. John Hewston of California, who thrust the ferrule of an umbrella into his eye on May 30, was closed to-day, the jury finding a verdict of manslaughter against Hewston.

Advance copies of the amended Rule of the Road at Sea, which was approved by an act of Congress dated May 28, 1894, were received by Superintendent Houghton of the Maritime Exchange yesterday. The pressing necessity for some well-understood and mandatory regulations for the guidance of all vessels, whatever their nationality, has long been felt.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 5. -- For tomorrow is scheduled the demonstration by the Republican Clubs of this State. Organizations from this city, Hartford, Meriden, Derby, Middletown, Bridgeport, Stratford, and Waterbury, will be present.

ROME, June 5. -- Premier Crispi announced the resignation of the Italian Ministry in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. The resignations, he said, had been placed in the hands of the King, who, however, had reserved an announcement of his course in regard to a new Cabinet until later.
There was a large turn-out of independent Democrats last night at the meeting of the Democratic County General Committee, at the Criterion Theatre, in Brooklyn. Over 300 delegates were in attendance.

LEWISTON, Me., June 5. -- In the Second District Republican Congressional Convention this afternoon Nelson Dingley, Jr., was unanimously renominated. A resolution was adopted declaring that the Grand Army of the Republic and all loyal citizens of the Second Congressional District owed to Mr. Dingley a "lasting debt of gratitude" for his defense of the rights of the veterans of the late war.

LONDON, June 5. -- The services of the fifth day of the Young Men's Christian Association conference opened at 9:30 o'clock this morning in Exeter Hall with devotional exercises conducted by the Rev. H. Bach of Lyons, France. Alfred Andre of Paris presided.

Gideon Granger, Police Commissioner John McClave's ex-son-in-law, was John W. Goff's star witness before the special Senate committee, which is investigating the Police Department of this city, yesterday.

Kasper Roseweg of 314 West Forty-ninth Street killed himself yesterday morning by taking poison. Roseweg came here eleven years ago from Germany to better his condition. This was to him the land of promise, and here he sought for happiness and fortune.

Notice was sent yesterday to the chiefs of division at the Custom House requesting them to report to the experts of the Dockery Commission, who have been looking into Custom-House methods of doing business for the last week, the number of persons employed in each division, with their salaries and duties.

A tennis tournament was begun yesterday afternoon on the courts of the Jersey City Tennis Club, Bergen Avenue, between Highland and Glenwood Avenues, Jersey City Heights. Most of the local cracks were out, and among the entries were Bostwick, Arthur Runyon, and Paret of New-York; Fraser, Thurber, and McMahon of Brooklyn, and Case, Harmstead, and Ferris of Jersey City.

The Society for the Abrogation of the Russian Extradition Treaty has issued from its office, 44 Cedar Street, this city, for circulation and signing, a petition which will be presented to the President, Senate, and House of Representatives.

Southern railroad and steamship managers are looking forward to a series of interesting meetings in this city next week, beginning on Tuesday. The persistent and wholesale rate cutting now under way throughout the South has stirred up considerable bitterness of feeling, and some radical changes in the existing methods of preserving harmony among the Southern transportation lines, it is predicted, will have to be made.

Daniel Frohman, manager of the Lyceum Theatre, accompanied by B.H. Sothern, sails for Europe this morning in the Paris. Talking of his trip to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, Mr. Frohman said:
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The hearts of the Democratic leaders of the Senate are lighter to-night than they have been at any time since the revised Tariff bill came to the front.
The Brentanos have closed their newspaper rooms in Paris.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 5. -- President Edwin H. Abbott of the Wisconsin Central Railway was examined before Special Master Alfred L. Carylk in the Northern Pacific investigation to-day. He testified with regard to the winding up of the Chicago and Great Western Road and how it was organized and merged in the Chicago and Northern Pacific.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Ex-Speaker Reed has seemed for some time not to be so happy as was his wont. He has betrayed symptoms of irritation over small things -- matters which formerly would not have disturbed him in the least, matters to which, indeed, he ordinarily would not pay the slightest attention.

The new cruiser Marblehead, which has been at the New-York Navy Yard since the completion of her forty-eight-hour trial trip at sea, has received orders to proceed at once to Newport, R.I., where her torpedo outfit will be placed on board. Officers of the ship expected that the vessel would be ordered to attend the celebration in Marblehead, Mass., but affairs in Bluefields have caused a change of programme.

The American Proscriptive Association will certainly not have things all its own way in this State, as it has had in the West and in most parts of New-England, where its promoters have succeeded so well in deceiving honest people with their anti-Catholic campaign.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- The members of the Union League Club gathered this evening to do honor to Willard A. Smith, who was Chief of the Department of Transportation exhibits at the World's Columbian Exposition.

"Tennessee's Pardner," by Scott Marble, put forward at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night, is a border drama of a long-familiar pattern. A miner dies, and his partners, with the fatuity of miners in romance, write letters in his name to his daughter in Tennessee, because they think the knowledge of his death would break her heart.

Mr. McBride, in presenting the medal, said: "If I could utter all the feelings which are in my breast in regard to this matter, I could speak for a week. There are three reasons for which I take particular pride in performing this pleasing duty which has been delegated to me.

There is nobody in this town who understands better the bearing and the importance of the testimony given before he Lexow committee than the Superinendent of Police. This testimony, it may fairly be said, every intelligent person who has read it believes to be true. Every such person knows a great many facts that are compatible with it and no acts that are inconsistent with it.

WEST POINT, June 5. -- The class of '94 went through their last cavalry drill as cadets to-day. Capt. Craig, Instructor of Cavalry, Tactics, was in command of the squad. At 5 o'clock the boys, dressed in tight-fitting gray trousers and blouses, with buff leggins, which reached almost to the knees, assembled in the area of barracks and answered the roll call.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- The new triple screw cruiser Minneapolis left Cramps' shipyard at 9:25 o'clock this morning, and started down the Delaware River on her unofficial or builders' trial trip. The entire force of the yard stopped work as the Minneapolis went out into the stream, and gave the keen-prowed racer a hearty send-off and good wishes for a record-breaking trial.
The sugar schedule proposed by the Senate committee's "revisers" and by the Sugar Trust was adopted by the Senate yesterday, the majority on the test motions being seven or eight votes.

The Danish-American citizens of New-York, Brooklyn, and vicinity met last evening at the Tivoli, in South Brooklyn, to celebrate the granting of a constitutional Government to Denmark, which occurred on June 5, 1848. There was a large gathering of Danes by birth or descent, and the celebration was a happy one.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Mrs. Cleveland entertained the wives of Cabinet officers at an informal 6 o'clock tea this afternoon. Tomorrow morning she will depart for her Summer home at Gray Gables.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 5. -- The Dominion Line steamer Texas, Capt. Hunter, from Montreal May 30 for Bristol, England, went ashore at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon one mile inside St. Shotts, St. Mary's Bay, on the wildest and most dangerous headland of the Newfoundland coast, the scene of many shipwrecks.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Strong pressure has been brought to bear upon the President in the last week to secure the removal of Civil Service Commissioner Lyman.

"White-ash" breezes, fog, squalls, rain, and various other samples of weather were furnished for the Atlantic Club yachtsmen yesterday, and, as a result, they had a hard time with their twenty-ninth annual regatta. Last year the regatta was called oft because the yachts were unable to sail over the course in the light wind.
PUEBLO, Col., June 5. -- The incessant rains in canons above Canon City and Florence for the past forty-eight hours have done more damage than the flood of last Wednesday night.

By a well-earned victory over Larned yesterday afternoon in the invitation tennis tournament of the Casino Club at Summit, N.J., Parker showed that his defeat of Chace on Monday was something more than a fluke. The New-Yorker played a most brilliant game, and won in the fifth set by well-timed net work. Stevens defeated Foote by his usual deadly accurate play, the latter giving up somewhat toward the finish.
The exposures of police corruption before the Lexow committee had their sequel yesterday at the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners at Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries devoted considerable time to-day to a consideration of Mr. Maguire's bills -- ostensibly drawn to better the condition of American seamen, but, as ship owners declare, in reality to destroy discipline, encourage mutiny, and place a premium upon desertion.

Two large flags covered the wall at the front of the big hall in the Young Men's Institute of the Young Men's Christian Association, at 222 Bowery, last evening. They were surmounted by the figures 1844-1894, as the association the world over is holding a jubilee in celebration of its fiftieth anniversary.
The money market continued easy. Call leans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., June 5. -- Miss Helen Caroline Janssen and Randolph St. George Walker were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother on Richmond Terrace. Both the bride and bridegroom are leaders in society circles on Staten Island. Mr. Walker is the Secretary of the New-York Cotton Exchange and of the Staten Island Cricket Club.

More than 56 per cent, of the volume of the trading in yesterday's market was in Sugar stock, and the interest in its fluctuations was so great that at times the trading posts of all other specialties were abandoned by brokers to join in the Sugar crowd. The news from Washington was anxiously waited for, and pending the announcement of the voting in the Senate the price was very strong.

Brooklyn and Louisville had a lively game yesterday, and it was only after ten innings that the local club won. Kennedy pitched a grand game of ball, but the poor support given him was responsible for all the runs gained by the Colonels. For the Louisvilles, Menefee was hit hard, but sharp work by the fielders kept down the score.

Mayor Sehieren expressed great surprise yesterday that the Board of Aldermen should override his veto of the resolution granting a franchise to the New-York and Eastern Telephone Company. The action of the board, however, did not surprise many people besides the Mayor.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- The Quarryville section of the Lancaster and Reading Narrow Gauge Railroad, which extends from Lancaster, Penn., to Quarryville, Lancaster County, a distance of fifteen miles, was sold at auction this afternoon at the Philadelphia Exchange to Charles H. Locher, a Lancaster banker, for $300,000.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The bands of deluded Coxeyites intrenched in the two encampments at Highlands and Bladensburg, on the outskirts of Washington, are supposed to be suffering for the common necessaries of life, and the authorities of the City of Washington are now considering what they can do for their relief.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill, revised to meet the objections of the President, who last January vetoed the original measure, was passed by the Senate this morning. The only feature of its progress through the upper chamber was the explanation offered by Mr. Frye for withdrawing his opposition.

It is likely that the experience through which a number of the States of the Union are now passing in dealing with disorders growing out of the coal miners' strikes, added to those with the Coxey "armies," may lead to a more thorough and effective provision for preserving order and protecting property than we now have.

McKEESPORT, Penn., June 5. -- The expected trouble at the National Tube Works has occurred. A mob of 5,000 strikers tonight broke down the entrance to the mill yard and drove the workmen employed in the various departments out of the yard.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- There was not a very large amount of business transacted today, but there was a better tone to the market and higher prices prevailed. Liquidation in Street Cable Car still continues, but for a stock usually so inactive the market has absorbed the offerings without much trouble.

LONDON, June 5. -- Being dissatisfied with the examination of Canadian cattle by the Government experts who reported that the symptoms in the lungs of the slaughtered cattle examined were such as were always present in cases of contagious pleuro-pneumonia, Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian High Commissioner, engaged the eminent expert, Prof. Hunting, to conduct an independent examination.
The Directors of the Real Estate Exchange and Auction Room, Limited, met yesterday and resolved to pay no dividend for the half year just closed. There is a balance on hand for the period of $9,126.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 5. -- By the unfortunate eating of a poisonous root, which they thought was sweet flag root, five little boys in the Roman Catholic Sisters' Home of Mercy, about a mile back of this village, were killed and half a dozen more were made critically ill.

The one hundred and thirteenth annual convention of Masons of the Grand Lodge of the State, of New-York, which opened yesterday at the Masonic Temple, Twentythird Street and Sixth Avenue, promises to develop a good deal of electioneering work before it is concluded.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the New-York Driving Club was held last evening to perfect the programme of the Grand Circuit trotting meeting at Fleetwood Park. Five days of harness racing will be given in September, and the club has offered liberal purses, which promise to attract to New-York nearly all the fastest trotters and pacers in training.

The development of a plan of reorganization for the Union Pacifies Railroad Company, according to statements made by members of the Reorganization Committee, only awaits the approval by Congress of some terms of adjustment of the company's debt to the United States.

A lion cub about as big as a Skye terrier and striped, yellow and black strayed down Third Avenue from Harlem yesterday to explore that section of the city and inspect the cable system. Its curiosity nearly cost it its life, for it came very near to being run over by one of the cars.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Probably not since Easter week has there been so large and fashionable a gathering at a wedding in this city as attended the marriage of Miss Edith Cruger Sands to T.J. Oakley Rhinelander at noon yesterday, in Trinity Chapel, West Twenty-fifth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Matters were even worse for the harness races at Belmont Park to-day than yesterday, for the rain fell steadily and the thermometer went down with it to add to the discomfort. There is little sign of improvement to-night, and the Spring meeting may not be started at all.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- The tone of the market seemed to undergo a distinct change to-day. Although still dull, the volume of business was somewhat increased, and there was a slow movement toward higher prices. At the opening an active bear trader made a drive at Reading, but all he offered was taken at the equivalent of 17, and that was bid for more.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 6. -- The examination of President E. Abbot of the Wisconsin Central Railroad was resumed before Alfred L. Cary this morning. He said the work of getting Chicago terminals for the Central was conducted so secretly in 1885 that not even his private secretary knew anything about it.

The exposures of the un-American methods of the A.P.A., made by The New-York Times during the last three eks, have caused amazement and surse evesywhere. The publication of the A.P.A.'s literature, printed from day to y in the columns of this paper, has used people to wonder if such vile attacks on millions of American citizens, simply because of their religious belief, could possibly emanate even from the wost bigots in the nineteenth century.

LONDON, June 6. -- The great jubilee of Young Men's Christian Associations was celebrated to-day. It is the fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the first association, which occurred June 6, 1844, in a small room in St. Paul's Churchyard, under the shadow of the cathedral. Sir George Williams, the founder, is a man still active in business, and a leader in all departments of religious and benevolent work.

The unanimous adoption yesterday at the meeting of the National Reform Union of a resolution declaring that the "hereditary principle" ought to be abolished in the House of Lords is an act of considerable significance. The truth is that the House of Lords, as a factor in legislation, is an obsolete body, with nothing whatever to say for itself.

Prince Andre Poniatowski sailed for Southampton on the American Line steamship Paris yesterday morning. Shortly before 7 o'clock, the hour for sailing, the Prince arrived on the pier carrying a bundle of canes and umbrellas, a very modest-looking gripsack, and two or three comic papers.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- As the Senate approaches the wool schedule the men who have been feeding on McKinley treacle are gathering to see what they can save for themselves from the obliging protection Democrats of the Senate.

"Ridiculous" exclaimed Col. William Seward of the Ninth. Regiment yesterday, when told that rumor had it that he was to be court-martialed because his command did not parade last Saturday at Van Cortlandt Park for "instruction in extended order."
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Capt. Bartlett of the Atlanta reports that his vessel is in no condition to go to Bluefields.

The Star Theatre in Brooklyn was filled last evening with business men, who met to protest against the dilatory tactics of the United States Senators who are obstructing the passage of the Tariff bill.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: From all the discussion had in public concerning sugar in reference to the new tariff, it might as supposed that every feature of the situation had been brought to view; but there has been a notable absence in any speeches in Congress or articles in the public press concerning the position which the Sugar Refining Company occupies on the Pacific coast.
LONDON, June 6. -- Lord Rosebery's Ladas won the Derby to-day.

BUDA-PESTH, June 6. -- It was announced late this evening that Dr. Wekerle had submitted the following Cabinet to the King: Dr. Wekerle, Finance and Premiership; Charles de Hieronymi, Interior; Bela de Lukacs, Commerce; Emerich de Josipovich, Croatia and Slavonia; Baron Fejervary, Defense; Count Julius Andrassy, Minister near the King's person; Eoetvoes, Instruction; Daranyi, Justice; D. Banffy, (President of the Lower House,) Agriculture.

Speaking of his resolutions directing the Superintendent of Police to investigate the conduct of officers implicated in charges brought out in testimony before the Senate committee, Commissioner Murray said: "I take the stand that the Police Commissioners are a judicial body. They cannot be complainants, prosecutors, and judges at the same time.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Now that the Senate has passed the schedule that has been regarded as the most difficult one to get rid of, and the prospect brightens for a return of the bill to the House before June 20, the members of the House are beginning to talk about what they must do with the bill when they shall get it.

The stock market showed considerable improvement yesterday, notwithstanding that more than 40 per cent. of the day's business was in Sugar. The opening in that specialty was quite excited, more than 10,000 shares changing hands at anywhere between 107 and 108. Many thousand shares were subsequently traded in within the same limit, and eventually 108 1/4 was recorded.
The convention of the Masons of the Grand Lodge of the State of New-York held its annual election in Masonic Temple yesterday and chose the following officers: Grand Master -- JOHN HODGE of Lockport.

Promptly at 8:30 A.M. yesterday. Dr. W. Seward Webb cracked the lash of his long coaching whip over the flanks of a pair of black leaders, and a second afterward the old coach Pioneer, looking spick and span in its new coat of black and canary varnish, moved off from the front of the Hotel Brunswick on one of the longest coaching trips ever attempted in this country.

WEST POINT, June 6. -- The military exercises to-day were held at the foot of the hill north of the academy. Here the big guns of the seacoast battery are mounted. Rows of shells, artistically arranged in pyramidal shape, flanked the guns. The position, which is almost on a level with the river, is nevertheless a commanding one, the guns sweeping the river north to Newburg.

ALBANY, June 6. -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Cities this evening gave a hearing to President Seth Low of Columbia College on the reform of municipal government. Mr. Low was four years Mayor of Brooklyn. He was the only speaker. He submitted to the committee the following propositions:

ALBANY, June 6. -- The hearing before the four committees of the Constitutional Convention, Education, Taxation, Charters, and Legislative Powers, demonstrated that an important amendment was necessary to the proposition that was sent here by the National League for the Protection of American Institutions, that was introduced by Mr. Holls of Westchester, and is known as Amendment No. 2.

ALBANY, June 6. -- The convention is proseeding slowly with, the complicated printing question. It took up several matters in which the Albany printing ring is especially interested, and whose favorable passage would transfer thousands of dollars on an extravagant transit from the State Treasury to the pockets of the ring.

Returns from the primaries held Tuesday night by the New-York State Democracy were received at headquarters, 52 William Street, yesterday. All the districts were heard from, with six exceptions -- the Eleventh, Fourteenth, Sixteenth, Seventeenth, Twenty-third, and Twenty-fourth. In round numbers, the total vote cast was 17,000, Which Col. Robert Grier Monroe and exMayor William R. Grace regard as a very satisfactory showing.

It must be admitted, as a general ethical principle, that no man is responsible for the performances of his son-in-law. This general principle has a specially wide application in this country, in which, more than in any other, not only " beggars marry many," as Shakespeare asserts, but girls marry whom they please without consulting their parents.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 6. -- The woman suffragists of this locality will institute an interesting memorial observance on Saturday of this week by decorating the graves of suffragists in Hartford and Glastonbury. The ceremonies will be conducted by the Equal Rights Club of Hartford.
CHAPEL, HILL, N.C., June 6. -- This has been the biggest day in the history of the University of North Carolina, it being the ninety-ninth Comencement Day of the institution.

ALBANY, June 6. -- Good Government Club U of New-York City was incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day. The Trustees are Emanuel Hochheimer, Oscar Yenni, Solomon Michaelbacher, Joseph O'Dwyer, U.J. Smalley, Francis Schlieff, U. Frank, Solomon Sulzberger, Frank Meyer, Benjamin Morje, J. Solis Hittenbach, Samuel Schweizer, Simon D. Heinmann, Albert Plant, William S. Williams, and James S. Heath.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The Indian Appropriation bill was taken up in the House this afternoon, but, owing to a parliamentary dispute that immediately arose, its consideration was deferred by an early adjournment. Mr. Holman will call it up again to-morrow, and the discussion of its provisions will continue during the day and perhaps much longer.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 6. -- The decisive baseball contest between Harvard and Princeton, played on Yale Field to-day, was won by Princeton, 11 to 4. As the game was a postponed match from last Saturday, free rain checks had been given out, and, in consequence, about the same 5,000 people who were disappointed on that date were present this afternoon.

The Young Men's Christian Association of Brocklyn celebrated two events yesterday. The one was the fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the first Young Men's Christian Association, in London, by Sir George Williams. The other was the forty-first anniversary of the foundation of the Brooklyn Association.
James Galway of the Preakness stud yesterday sold his four-year-old mare Lustre, by Linden-Gleam, to the Gough Acres Stable, in whose colors she will hereafter race.

DETROIT, Mich., June 6. -- The seventeenth annual session of the Supreme Council of the Royal Arcanum began to-day. The report of the Supreme Secretary for the year ending Dec. 31, 1893, shows that there were, on Dec. 31, 1893, 1,543 subordinate councils, 20 Grand Councils, with a total membership of 148,224, and that the average membership during the year was 143,192.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 6. -- The steam tug Rambler, one of the best boats belonging to the Empire and New-England Transportation Company, was blown into fragments this morning, killing one man and injuring two others.

One hundred and fifty-eight young men received the degree of LL.B. at the commencement exercises of the New-York Law School, at the Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, last evening. The degrees were conferred by St. Clair McKelway, who represented the University of the State of New-York.
Out of the 1,120 graduates from the public and private schools of this city who tried to gain admittance to the College of the City of New-York only 596 succeeded.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- That the Republicans of the Senate have abandoned all hope of defeating the Tariff bill is known to every person who is in the confidence of the leaders.

COHOES, N.Y., June 6. -- A more successfully-managed race meet than that of the Cohoes Wheelmen, held at Rensselaer Park to-day, was never conducted. The day was fine, with no wind, and the track was fast. "Tom" Eck was accused of beating the gun in pushing off C.H. Callahan in the quarter mile, and refuted the charge.

The Brooklyn Aldermen, yesterday postponed for a few days their investigation of the contracts for supplies for the Truants' Home in order to give the expert accountant who has been at work on the books time to dig deeper down into the curious affairs of that institution.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A bill to increase the pensions of the survivors and widows of the Mexican and Indian wars from $8 to $12 a month has been agreed upon by the House Committee on Pensions. Commissioner Lochren estimated that the additional appropriation necessary to meet this increase would not exceed $1,310,000 per annum.

McKEESPORT, Penn., June 6. -- The National Tube Works to-night are surrounded by a crowd of at least 5,000 strikers and sympathizers. The men are nervous and anxious, for this has been a day of lawlessness and violence. Considerable property has been destroyed.

From The Sun of Yesterday. If the testimony given before the Lexow committee is genuine, if it is founded in truth and is not the product of conspiracy and fraud, then it reveals a condition of depravity and corruption in the Department of Police almost beyond human belief.

BOSTON, June 6. -- Until near the close our market was even more active than usual. Bell Telephone on the offering of small lots was very weak, losing most of the gain of two or three days, closed 200 bid. Erie was strong, and sold up to 48, but rested at the close at 47 bid, offered at 47 1/2.

TROY, N.Y., June 6. -- In the Extraordinary Oyer and Terminer Court for the trial of "Bat" Shea, about half the panel has been exhausted, and only two jurors have been sworn in. Justice Williams has decided to excuse jurors who are members of the A.P.A., but does not rule that a challenge for bias should be sustained.

The marriage of Miss Ellen H. Windom, daughter of the late Secretary of the Treasury Windom, to Bentley W. Warren of Boston took place yesterday at noon at the home of the bride's mother, 358 Lexington Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Brooks, rector of the Church of the Incarnation, officiated.

The marriage of Miss Juliet Kemp to Stephen Higginson Tyng, Jr., took place at noon yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Church, the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, rector of the church, officiating, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Stephen H. Tyng, father of the bridegroom.

ROME, June 6. -- Additional sensational testimony was introduced in the Tanlongo trial this morning. Signor Felzani, ex-Quaestor of the Treasury, testified that an order of arrest for Signer Tanlongo had been given to him at the office of the Minister of the Interior, and that Signor Giolitti's Cabinet Judge, who was charged with preparing the case against M. Tanlongo, confirmed it.

SING SING, June 6. -- The twenty-sixth commencement exercises at Ossining Seminary for Young Ladies, Miss C.C. Fuller, Principal, took place here to-day and were largely attended by the parents and friends of the students. Miss Rose Elizabeth Cleveland, sister of President Cleveland, made the address to the graduates.

The unsatisfactory work of the judges who presided over the great race of the double teams at Fleetwood last Saturday threatens to result seriously for the success of the Inter-City Cup contests. Matthew Riley has written a letter to Daniel McMillan, President of the Driving Club of New-York, declining to participate in any further races of the series.

The amphitheatre of the City Hospital on Blackwell's Island was gayly decorated with flags yesterday afternoon and festooned with fragrant box, in honor of twenty-two young graduates from the New-York City Training School for Nurses attached to the City, Maternity, Gouverneur, and Harlem Hospitals.

Another witness who swore with great positiveness that she had paid money directly, to the police to protect her in the business of keeping a disorderly house was the feature of yesterday's session of the Senate committee's investigation of the Police Department of this city.

At a meeting of the Trunk-Line General Passenger Agents in this city yesterday special rates were aranged for several important conventions to be held in Denver, Col. Excursion tickets will be sold for each occasion at one and one-third of the regular fare for the round trip between Eastern points and Chicago.

The movement for "suffrage reform" in Louisiana brings out some interesting admissions as well as some significant claims. There is pending in the Legislature at Baton Rouge not only a proposed constitutional amendment qualifying the suffrage, but a bill providing for the Australian ballot system.
Day wages will not be paid for resurfacing asphalt walks in Central Park after next Saturday night. The work will be finished by contract. Such was the decision of the Park Commissioners yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- The stock market was very quiet this morning, and at the same time comparatively steady, although slightly lower than on Tuesday. There was no special activity developed, and nearly all of the business was between room traders. The offerings of Street's Cable Car Company show a decided decrease, and prices were steadier, although declining from 23 1/4 to 22 1/2, closing at 22 3/4.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 6. -- The extension of telegraphic communication simply confirms all estimates made as to great destructiveness of the Columbia River flood. Thousands of acres of farm lands are submerged and crops thereon are absolutely ruined, several hundred miles of roadbed of the Oregon and Washington Railroad is washed away.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Short work was made of the State bank tax question today, when the House, after the prolonged debate on the subject, came to a vote.

Probably one of the reasons why so many people are seeking to have matters that properly belong to the domain of legislation "fixed and determined" by the Constitution, or to have various requirements and restrictions imposed upon the legislative power, is the difficulty that has been experienced in getting the Legislature to act wisely.

Albany, June 6. -- Chauncey M. Depew to-day attended the commencement exercises of St. Agnes's School here, occupying a seat upon the platform. His niece. Miss Elsie Depew Strong, was among the graduates.

NEWARK, N.J., June 6. -- The seventh annual century run from Newark to Philadelphia will leave Newark Saturday morning at 4 o'clock, rain or shine. This distance has been increased to a mile over a full century, and the new part added is through a beautiful portion of the country, free from the interruption of early-morning trade.

Having made an unbroken series of low records for the last few months, wheat turned in its course yesterday and advanced more sharply than on any other day this year. Continued bad weather, with reports of damage to the growing crop from frost, was the cause. All options opened at five-eighths of 1 cent per bushel in the morning above Tuesday's last prices.
SUPREME COURT -- General Term. -- Van Brunt, P.J.; ParKer and Barren, JJ.

The State Democracy seems to have constructed a very good practical working machine. It is a machine of the right kind, based on an enrollment and an actual vote in the election districts. The vote at the primaries held on Tuesday evening was a large one in proportion to the enrollment, and its results are satisfactory and encouraging to the leaders.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 6. -- The Republican State Convention to-day nominated Major E.N. Morrill of Hiawatha for Governor and W.A. Johnston of Minneapolis for Associate Justice. George W. Martin of Kansas City was a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination. He received 122 votes to 771 cast for Morrill.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 6. -- The Republican State Convention to-day made the following nominations: Secretary of State -- S.M. Taylor of Champaign; Member of Board of Public Works -- Charles G. Groce of Pickaway; Commissioner of Common Schools -- O. J. Corson of Guernsey; Judge of Supreme Court - -John A. Schauk of Dayton.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 6. -- The cutter Barbara, New-York Yacht Club, defeated the yawl Gypsy to-day in an eighteen-mile race to Bartlett's Reef, thence to Longhill Buoy, to the point of starting off the Shore Line Pier in this harbor. Joseph S. Bass sailed his own boat, the Barbara, and Joseph Dayton, owner of the Gypsy, handled that craft.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A large batch of papers relating to New-York State offices was sent from the Treasury to the White House this afternoon, and the persons most interested have in consequence placed their ears close to the ground.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 6. -- The Convention of the Republican Clubs of the State here to-day was held under discouraging circumstances. To begin with, Democratic weather dampened their ardor and cut down the number of delegates to half the expected and advertised number, and those who were present were drenched upon the march and put in an ill humor which even McKinley speeches failed to mollify.

The point in the Tariff bill on which it is certain that the House and the Senate will differ radically is the sugar schedule. That has also been regarded as the most dangerous feature of the bill in the Senate. It has been reached, fought over, and finally adopted by a combination which the Democratic leaders believe to be invincible to any future attacks.
