PEORIA, Ill., June 6. -- One man dead, several others on the verge of death, a number seriously injured, $30,000 worth of property destroyed, and many homes made desolate was the result of an attempt made to-day by the miners of the Peoria district to close the mine operated by Little Brothers in Tazewell County, a mile or more from Wesley City.
YONKERS, N.Y., June 6. -- Festival services commemorative of the two hundredth anniversary of the incorporation of its parish were held here to-day in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The marriage of Representative David H. Mercer of Beatrice, Neb., to Miss Birdie Abbott, sister-inlaw of Commissioner of Pensions Lochren, took place at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon in St. John's Church. The Rev. Dr. McKim of Epiphany Church officated.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 6. -- The principal society event of the season was the marriage this evening, in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, of Miss Agnes Bartlett, daughter of the late Gen. William F. Bartlett, to Henry A. Francis, a member of the Pontoosuc Woolen Company. The bride wore a white satin gown, veil, and orange blossoms.
The southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, reported sold yesterday, has been bought by Mr. John D. Crimmins.

But one witness, Dr. Louise G. Rabinovitch, a Russian, who was a physician in the service of the Department of Charities and Correction, was examined yesterday before the State Commission in Lunacy, in the committee room at the Park Avenue Hotel.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 7. -- The commission appointed by the Supreme Court took additional testimony to-day in the certiorari proceedings brought by the City Reform Club to set aside the contract given the Berlin Iron Company for erecting a new bridge over the Raritan River near this city.

BOSTON, Mass., June 7. -- No marriage thus far in the season has been attended by so little ceremony as was the marriage in King's Chapel to-day of Miss Laura Wheelwright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Wheelwright of 129 Beacon Street, to G. Herbert Windeler of London, England. At no marriage for a long time, however, have so many prominent members of society been present.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- A broom at the foretopmast and the figures 21.75 painted in big white letters on the funnel of the Minneapolis told every craft in the Delaware River this afternoon and the crowds on the shore the result of the big cruiser's preliminary trial trip off the Delaware capes and proclaimed to the world that the United States Government has another ship superior in speed to any vessel possessed by other nations.
Washington, June 7. -- A letter received from Representative Jerry Simpson says that his health is rapidly improving. He expects to return to Washington in about two weeks.

The annual meeting of the New-York Woman's Suffrage League was held last night at the home of Mrs. C.F. Lovell, 4 Lexington Avenue. Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake presided, and spoke of the progress made by the committee which went before the State Constitutional Convention at Albany.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- The market improved considerably to-day. There was much better buying than there has been for several days, and as a result prices appreciated largely in several lines. The most notable rise was in Street's Stable Car Line, which made a good recovery. It is said there was a large line covered by those who became frightened at the recent selling, and sold short.

The disappearance of Pennoyer from the American political horizon is a matter for congratulation beyond the confines of Oregon. Pennoyer is, in sooth, a horrid hoodlum. He calls himself a Democrat, and he was elected as a Democrat, but essentially he is a Populist in the most offensive sense of the term.

Rapid-Transit Commissioners Alexander E. Orr, William Steinway, Seth Low, and John Claflin, with Henry R. Beekman, who drew the new law, and will probably be chosen counsel for the commission, met yesterday at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce for a conference, preliminary to organization.

The American Proscriptive Association is extending its scope. Besides putting all Roman Catholic citizens of this country under the ban, it now proposes to "break down" every Protestant clergyman who dares to lift up his voice against its un-American and un-Christian persecution of ten millions of people on purely religious grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- The market started off with a tone that indicated a somewhat higher plane of values. The traders who were long of the tractions bid them up with seeming confidence. Electric Traction rights, usually erratic, were rushed up to 17 3/8, but around this figure selling orders were met and the price declined quickly to 16.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- There is a constantly growing belief that the Tariff bill will be in the hands of a conference committee of the Senate and House not later than June 25. Several of the leading Republicans of the Senate say that it will be out of the Senate by June 20.

The unanimous adoption by the Committee on Cities of the Constitutional Convention of resolutions which distinctly declare in favor of having elections for city offices and elections for State and national offices in alternate years, and which invite the co-operation of other committees having in charge the proposition of amendments that would be necessary to effect this, is a promising sign.

The conventions of the Grand Lodge of Masons of the State of New-York and of the women Masons who compose the Grand Chapter of the Order of the Eastern Star of the State of New-York were brought to a close yesterday, after installing the newly-elected grand officers.
CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 7. -- The following yachts passed here to-day:

The exasperation of George Frisbie Hoar with Joseph C.S. Blackburn probably reached its highest pitch yesterday. Of course, Senator Hoar is always in a state of general exasperation with Senator Blackburn, for he has an acute mind, while the Kentucky Senator has a dull one.

The letter sent by Edward D. Adams, Chairman of the Northern Pacific Reorganization Committee, to the receivers offers to lend the latter $1,000,000 on receivers' notes to mature before Sept. 30, such notes to bear 6 per cent., free of commission, to be prior to all obligations except the first mortgage bonds, and to be paid off in weekly installments by applications thereto pro rata of the net earnings.

LONDON, June 7. -- The delegates to the Young Men's Christian Association conference and jubilee and their friends, making a party of some 2,000, were taken to Windsor Castle by four special trains this morning. The castle and grounds, by special permission of the Queen, were given up to them for the day.

A review of the debate which preceded the adoption of the sugar schedule in the Senate Tariff bill and careful examination of the schedule as it now stands simply confirm the following assertions as to what the effect of that schedule would be if it should become a law:

DENVER, Col., June 7. -- Gov. Waite has been in communication by telephone with Victor all day, and this evening he said that no difficulty had occurred during the day, in spite of sensational reports sent out from Cripple Creek. One miner has accidentally shot himself in the hand in fixing his gun.

Twenty-six cases, on complaints made by agents of the Parkhurst Society, were tried by Justices Koch, Meade, and Hogan, in the Court of Special Sessions, yesterday. Twenty-two defendants were discharged because the Parkhurst agents, George R. Clarke and John Marratt, could not remember whether the prisoners were the persons against whom they had made the charges originally.

The experiment of spending public money for the purpose of furnishing employment has proved a failure in this city, and from the point of view of public economy it was bound to prove a failure. It has come very close to causing a public scandal, and such experiments are very likely to do that.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The caution in your issue of to-day that "It would be well to know something about the dispensary law on other testimony than Tillman's before accepting it as preferable to anything whatever" is well timed. Regard for truth is not one of Tillman's virtues. His utterances about the dispensary law have been especially marked by reckless and willful misstatements.

Lawyer Charles W. Brooke applied to Judge Fitzgerald in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday for the discharge of Horace F. Burroughs, a lumber dealer at 19 Whitehall Street, who was indicted on May 25, 1890, on the charge of forging a certificate of a lumber Inspector, W.A. Mitchell, of Brunswick, Ga.

Brooklyn and Pittsburg played a "tie" game at Eastern Park yesterday. At the outset it looked as though the Pittsburgs would win with ease. They were batting in a most lively manner, and at one stage led by 7 runs. Toward the latter part of the game, however, the Brooklyns made enough runs to even up matters, and, after ten innings had been played, darkness stopped the contest.

BUFFALO, N.Y, June 7. -- There are persons in Buffalo disagreeable enough to say that, in appointing Howard H. Baker Postmaster, the President has administered to Norman E. Mack a blow straight between the eyes, Mr. Baker is one of Mr. Cleveland's oldest and statvchest friends. He knew the President when he first came to Buffalo, and he has supported Mr. Cleveland every time he ran for office.

E.S. Ramsdell of the University of Pennsylvania, who tied the 100-yard intercollegiate record of 0:10 at the championship games and repeated the performance at Philadelphia last Monday has telegraphed his entry to Capt. Baxter for the 120-yard scratch race at the games of the New-York Athletic Club at Travers Island tomorrow.

The sale of the coach horses used on the trips made by the public coach Tempest between the Hotel Brunswick and the Country Club, Westchester, last month, brought a large number of coaching men to the American Horse Exchange last night, where the animals were sold by William Easton. The horses were all in good condition, and having been thoroughly seasoned, are ready to be made use of immediately.

The marriage of Miss Minnie A. Tompkins and Edward A. Shipman took place last evening at 8 o'clock in the Second Collegiate Reformed Church, One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and Lenox Avenue. The Rev. Dr. William Justin Harsha officiated.

Thirty-eight years ago, in a peaceful little Russian village, a peasant lad, who had taken more vodka than was good for him at a wedding, lost his mental equilibrium, and while in this irresponsible state entered the church. After having prayed at the images for a while, he put the wax candles in his pockets, and left.
BERLIN, June 7. -- Printer Schnedereit arrived to-day at his birthplace, Rathenow, in Prussia, and thus ended a walk which he began two years ago in Calcutta, India.

The marriage of Miss Mattie Henderson Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G.K. Knox, to Dr. Andrew A. Luin Barrett took place last evening at 8 o'clock at the home of the bride's parents, 68 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street. The Rev. Dr. James S. Ramsay of the Harlem Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries yesterday listened to the objections made by Vernon H. Brown and Capt. W.V. Nichols of New-York and Messrs. Earnshaw and Higbee of Philadelphia to the shipping bills introduced by Representative Maguire of California, and next Tuesday it will hear Mr. Maguire in support of his bills.

The Harlem Wheelmen are up and doing these days. Two scheduled runs every week with impromptu ones every night keep the members of the popular up-town organization in good condition for the frequent century runs that fall to their lot.

A large flag hanging from a line stretched between two houses, after the manner of a campaign banner, waved patriotically over the heads of a large gathering of women devoted to the spirit of the "new patriotism " in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. The flag was the property of the Woman's Health Protective Association of Brooklyn, which was holding its annual meeting on the grounds surrounding the house of Mrs. Jere Johnson, Jr., 168 Hancock Street.

ONEONTA, N.Y., June 7. -- The quarter-mile Oneonta track was soft and spongy for a large portion of the back stretch to-day, and the balance of the new sandy clay surface was soggy. The big racers dared not engage in the desperate finish they are accustomed to on a good track. Danger lurked in the heavy spot where the men were bound to bunch in a hard ride.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 7. -- The report that a Raymond-Whitcomb excursion train had been wrecked in the mountains is absolutely without foundation. The party passed here several days ago, and, owing to floods, has been detained at Field, B.C., comfortably housed in the Canadian Pacific hotel there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 7. -- At Naval Headquarters no advices were received to-day confirming or denying the report of the stranding of the revenue cutter Bear at the entrance to Sitka Harbor. The report is generally discredited.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- James A. Wright, senior member of the shipping firm of Peter Wright Sons, died this morning at his home, on Wissahickon Avenue, from paralysis. Mr. Wright was formerly President of the International Navigation Company, and was succeeded by Clement A. Griscom.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 7. -- Justice J.O. Dykman this morning filed the following opinion in the matter of the recent Mount Vernon election:

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- There are two vacancies in the Army Ordnance Department, and eight Second Lieutenants of the line have applied for the places. The examination for the commissions will take place in New-York, June 13. The commission in the Ordnance Department carries with it the rank of First Lieutenant, more agreeable duty, and quicker promotion.

A more captivating scene could hardly be imagined than Cedar Lawn, the residence of B.F. Stevens, Flatbush, presented last evening when the garden fete for the benefit of the Brooklyn Home for Consumptives was fully inaugurated.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Mr. Hoar (Rep., Mass.) offered a resolution directing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the justice and equity of the claim of the United States against the estate of the late Leland Stanford and to report, as soon as may be, whether it is expedient that such claim shall be forthwith relinquished and put at rest.

The Kings County Board of Estimate met in the City Hall yesterday to make provision for the county budget of 1895. Mayor Schieren could not understand why $190,000 should be used for the county jail, which is an increase of $30,000 over last year, and he wanted Commissioner White of the City Works Department to go over the item of $894,000 for county wards, as Mr. White was well informed on that subject.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Coxey, Carl Browfie, and Jones, notwithstanding all their professions to the contrary, are tired of martyrdom. Jones, the Philadelphia leader, was only sentenced to twenty days. The other two had the option of serving ten days more, or paying each $5 fine.

Superintendent Byrnes summoned the Inspectors and all the precinct Captains to his office at Police Headquarters yesterday and gave them a lecture which apparently was not relished. When the Captains came out from the presence of the Superintendent they looked like a lot of schoolboys who had been roundly scolded.
PATERSON, N.J., June 7. -- Ex-Gov. Rodman M. Price of New-Jersey died at the home of his daughter, at Oakland, at 12:20 o'clock this morning.

Fulton Council, No. 299, Royal Arcanum, of Brooklyn, tendered a reception last evening to Vincent L. Cook, Past Regent, who has just been elected Grand Orator of the Grand Council. Mr. Cook was formerly Grand Chaplain of the Grand Council, and is one of the most popular members of the order in this State.
MANOWN, Penn., June 7. -- This was an exciting day at the pit of the Youghiogheny Coal Company, although no violence occurred.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 7. -- A dispatch from one of the officers of the United States revenue cutter Bear says that vessel is fast on the rocks at the entrance to the harbor of Sitka and is almost a total wreck. It is conjectured that the vessel will be battered to pieces.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 7. -- The "Green Twigs" of this village have found out that they do not possess the essentials of of success in dealing in horses. Incidentally Flushing has learned that Samuel McCreery, a wealthy and charitable resident, who conducts McCreery's Express Company in New-York, is a great deal of a wag.

A gentleman has written all the way from South Africa to inform me that Mr. Gladstone is the real author of the flogging of Kaffirs for walking on the pavements at Johannesburg. The argument, if I follow it rightly, is that Boers flogged the Kaffirs, that Englishmen could hot interfere because Johannesburg is in the Transvaal, and that Mr. Gladstone restored the Transvaal to the Boers; argal: Mr. Gladstone caused the Kaffirs to be flogged.

Civil Justice George F. Roesch of the Fourth Judicial District Court, formerly a State Senator, was a voluntary witness yesterday before the Senate committee which is investigating the Police Department of this city. He wanted to explain away a statement Mrs. Augusta Thurow, formerly a keeper of a disorderly house, made on the witness stand last Monday to the effect that she paid money to him to secure police protection.

BOSTON, June 7. -- Leaving out the arbitrage and the copper stocks, transactions in our market have been practically nil. Bell Telephone, on small sales, has remained at yesterday's price, with no transactions in Erie Telephone. New-England is apparently being picked up gradually and at advancing prices, on the expectation expressed yesterday that the company will be able to make a new deal with the Bell Company by which the stock will earn increased dividends.

W.C. France of this city has a string of twenty horses in training at his Highland Farm in Kentucky. Frank McVey is training the lot. Most of the horses are the get of Red Wilkes, Allie Wilkes, 2:15, King Clay, and Charley Wilkes. Allie Wilkes, who earned his record of 2:15 to a high-wheeled sulky, is in training also, and has shown a quarter in 0:31 1/4.
The annual parade of the Williamsburg Sunday schools was held yesterday afternoon in Bedford Avenue, and fully 15,000 children were in line.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Norman. E. Mack, "Harmonizer" of Buffalo, met with a rude shock this morning just as he was about to call upon the President to offer some advice concerning the appointment of a successor to Postmaster Gentsch of Buffalo.

ALBANY, June 7. -- The Judiciary Committee held an important session immediately after the adjournment of the Constitutional Convention this morning. By special invitation, Chief Justice Charles Andrews of the Court of Appeals and ex-Chief Justice Robert Earl appeared before the committee and expressed their views upon the proposition to revise the judiciary article of the Constitution.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- The long-delayed meeting at Belmont Park began this afternoon, but the sulkies did not escape the rain, for it came down in time to prevent finishing the last event. There were large fields in all the classes.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 7. -- Seeretary of the Navy Herbert arrived here to-day. The annual competitive drill of the four companies of the battalion of naval cadets for the colors was witnessed by the Secretary and the Board of Visitors. Two thousand spectators were present. The contending companies were: No. 1, Capt. Winston Churchill; No. 2, Capt. Charles Webster; No. 3. Capt. Carlton F. Snow: No. 4. Capt. Daniel H. Cox. Capt. Snow's company won.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- When Mr. Fairchild was Secretary of the Treasury he directed attention, in one of his reports to the House, to the remarkable condition of the shipping laws that so discriminate against American ownership of vessels that there was a prospect of a continued decay of our shipping by name, while there was every inducement to Americans to put their money in foreign ships and dispense with the American flag.

At the meeting of the Board of Electrical Control in the Mayor's office yesterday the statement was made that several of the gas companies in this city had violated their obligations to the municipal authorities by laying in the excavations for their mains pipes containing electrical conductors.

Several times yesterday the Chicagos looked like winners in their game against the New-Yorks on the Polo Grounds, but Capt. Anson was doomed to disappointment. Just when the big, rosy-cheeked Captain from Cook County, Ill., was congratulating himself and felt certain that victory would perch on his banner, the Giants got in several batting streaks and dashed Chicago's hopes.

The annual Spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club will be sailed to-morrow. The start will be made off the clubhouse at 11 o'clock, and the judges will be on the tug Raymond. The club launch will leave the float with those who will watch the race from the Raymond on the arrival of the 9:04 train from the Grand Central Depot.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 7. -- Prof. William Dwight Whitney of Yale died at his home, on Whitney Avenue, shortly after 10 o'clock this morning. He was taken ill May 25, and, although gradually sinking day by day, hope was not abandoned by either his physicians or his family until last night, when it was discovered that his original ailment had been complicated by an attack of pneumonia.

The annual club handicap tournament attracted many of the members and friends of the New-York Tennis Club to the courts at One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street and St. Nicholas Avenue yesterday afternoon. The prizes offered are of unusual beauty and value. Though the entries are confined to club members, the list comprises Clarence Hobart, C.W. MacMullen, Stephen C. Millett, Calhoun Cragrin, Arthur Taylor, Sidney L. Smith, and others almost as well known.

On the opening day of the Gravesend meeting Correction took part in the opening scramble, and ran third to Stonenell and Dr. Hasbrouck. After the race it was reported that she had been kicked in the side and had two or three ribs broken, and that she would be retired from the turf. Yesterday afternoon she took part in the opening race at Morris Park.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- With Secretary Hoke Smith and Representative Straus opposed to the Holman proposition to take from New-York the Indian Supply Agency, in order that it may be transferred to Chicago, and with a point of order ready to be urged against the proposition, it is probable that the Indian Committee's hasty and mistaken action will be vetoed by the House, as it ought to be.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 7. -- Probably never in the history of legislation has there been such an outpouring of the advocates of any measure as graced the Assembly Chamber to-night. The occasion was the hearing of the Constitutional Convention Committee on Suffrage to the advocates of woman's suffrage throughout the Stats outside of New-York City, the last hearing having been devoted to the suffragists from the metropolis.

The commencement exercises of the Teachers' College and the Horace Mann School, which is allied with it, were held yesterday in the kindergarten room of the school. Hamilton W. Mabie, editor of Outlook, delivered an address, and Acting President John F. Woodhull presented diplomas to the following graduates:

A series of resolutions was adopted by the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, asking Congress to amend the inter-State commerce law. The resolutions were reported by the Committee on Foreign Commerce, and they set forth that the said law had not accomplished the results expected from it, and they asked that it be amended in the following particulars:

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The President to-day nominated A.E. Blakeslee to be Postmaster at Thomaston, Conn., and Charles F. Stone of New-Hampshire to be Naval Officer of Customs in the district of Boston and Charlestown, Mass.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7. -- Fully 2,000 people watched the movements of the cadets in their manoeuvres to-day. The battalion drill took place at 4:35 P.M., with Col. Mills in command.

A series of resolutions was adopted by the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, asking Congress to amend the inter-State commerce law. The resolutions were reported by the Committee on Foreign Commerce, and they set forth that the said law had not accomplished the results expected from it, and they asked that it be amended in the following particulars:

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 7. -- About seven months ago the Rev. J.E. Richards became pastor of the Baptist Church at Cape May Court House. In connection with the church there is a chapel at Dias Creek. At that village there is a Methodist Church, of which the Rev. Mr. Blackiston is pastor, which has a large congregation.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

The last of the "Good Government" conferences of the season was held last night in Amity Hall, 312 West Fifty-fourth Street. The speakers were Louis P. Gratacap for Tammany Hall, ex-Corporation Counsel Henry R. Beekman, for the Democratic Party; William J. Ghent, (by proxy,) for the People's Party, and H.B. Salisbury, for the Socialist Labor Party.

The last of the "Good Government" conferences of the season was held last night in Amity Hall, 312 West Fifty-fourth Street. The speakers were Louis P. Gratacap for Tammany Hall, ex-Corporation Counsel Henry R. Beekman, for the Democratic Party; William J. Ghent, (by proxy,) for the People's Party, and H.B. Salisbury, for the Socialist Labor Party.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- No news has yet been received by the Treasury Department as to the reported wreck of the revenue cutter Bear at Sitka, Alaska, and officials are inclined to the opinion that the rumor is untrue.

William H. Starbuck, the former President of the Housatonic Railway Company, recovered a verdict in the Supreme Court, before Justice Patterson and a jury, in this city yesterday, against the company for $14,451.62. Mr. Starbuck was President of the company from 1886 to 1892, when he resigned.

The subject of introducing military tactics and drill in the public shcools of Brooklyn was discussed at length before the Committee on Studies of the Brooklyn Board of Education in the large hall of the board in Livington Street, Brooklyn, last night. Many prominent citizens of Brooklyn and representative from at least a dozen Grand Army posts were present.

The employes of the New-York Post Office some time ago decided they would en- joy tendering a dinner to Postmaster Charles W. Dayton. They appointed a committee to make all arrangements incidental to the dinner and receive subscriptions. Through the efforts of their committee they obtained about $2,000 and then made the preliminary arrangements to have an enjoyable evening while honoring and showing their appreciation for Mr. Dayton.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The State Department has not heard to-day of any recent battles in Salvador, and from the character of the dispatches sent yesterday by Capt. Thomas of the Bennington, in which he stated that the revolution was over and the revolutionists in full possession of the capital, the reports of sanguinary encounters are discredited.

The Irish Republic to-day prints an article under the head of "A Talk with No. 1," (P.J. Tynan.) The article deals with the alleged extracts from Mr. Tynan's book recently published in The St. James Gazette. Mr. Tynan is interviewed, and denies that he reveals the identity of any person in his book.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, who was convicted of poisoning Ludwig Brandt in order to obtain his insurance money, passed last night in Sing Sing, where he will spend the rest of his life. He was sentenced to that institution yesterday morning by Recorder Smyth, and was taken there at 3 o'clock in the afternoon.

Col. William Seward of the Ninth Regiment was placed under military arrest by order of Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald yesterday afternoon, charged with disobedience of orders, in having failed to comply with the general order issued April 18, which named June 2 as the day on which Col. Seward should take his regiment to Van Cortlandt Park for drill in extended order.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- The bulk of the most important testimony bearing on the injury to the cruiser Columbia was heard by the court of inquiry at League Island Navy Yard to-day. The ship was dry-docked late this afternon and the court may make its examination of the dent in her double bottom to-morrow.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 8. -- The Common Pleas Court to-day decided three long-pending equity suits, growing out of the defalcation of ex-City Treasurer John Bardsley.
Mr. John H. Starin yesterday placed a steamer, barges, and his grove up the Hudson at the disposal of the Union Veteran Soldiers and Sailors of New-York and its vicinity.

More remarkable testimony was given yesterday before the Senate committee which is investigating the Police Department of this city. There were some very interesting witnesses, but the star witness of the day was Morris Jacobs.

It was settled yesterday at a meeting of representatives of the five Protestant Episcopal dioceses of the State of New-York, held at the See House, on Lafayette Place, that there should be a redistribution of the territory of the State, so that two new dioceses should be created.

By a series of unlooked-for circumstances the Giants have actually won three straight games. This, the grandest spurt of the season, has had the effect of once more arousing the enthusiasm of the poor heartbroken metropolitan crank, and if Capt. John Ward and his colleagues only keep up their good work perhaps all will be forgiven.

The recent platforms and declarations by the leaders of the Republican Party on the question of finance are discouraging. They have been all in the direction of some concession to the silver inflationists, and the two most extreme and inex- cusable are from the two adjoining States of Ohio and Pennsylvania.

Dr. Louise G. Rabinovitch, formerly a physician in the Women's Insane Asylum on Blackwell's and Ward's Islands, was again a witness before the State Commission in Lunacy yesterday. Her testimony was more sensational than on the previous day, for she accused the doctors of neglecting their patients in the most shameful manner, and even of administering poisonous doses in such quantities to keep them quiet as resulted, in at least one instance, in patient's death.

The facts and figures from the Bureau of Navigation of the Treasury Depart- ment which we published yesterday show very clearly that there is no reason why American capital should not be invested in American Shipping except that the Government will not permit it. It is quite largely invested in foreign shipping, which our Government cannot prevent.

PANAMA, June 8. -- Carlos Ezeta, who on June 4 abandoned the Presidency of Salvador and fled the country on the German steamer Valeria, reached here to-day. He is accompanied by thirteen of those who were associated with him in his administration. Secretaries Jimenez, Poirier, and Pinto are of the party.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The resolution offered yesterday by Mr. Hoar (Rep., Mass.,) in reference to relinquishing the claim of the United States against the estate of the late Leland Stanford of California was laid before the Senate to-day, and Mr. Hoar modified it so as simply to instruct the Judiciary Committee to inquire and report, as soon as may be, whether it is expedient that the claim be forthwith relinquished and put at rest.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 8. -- Gov. Flower returned from Watertown this afternoon and immediately proceeded to the Executive Chamber. He is contemplating with considerable pleasure a fishing excursion to Little Clear Lake in the Adirondacks next Monday or Tuesday.

TOTTENVILLE, S.I., June 8. -- Edward B. Kreischer, junior member of the firm of B. Kreischer Sons, brick manufacturers, was found dead with a bullet in his brain near the firm's factory at Kreischerville this morning. The fact that a revolver was found beside the body with one chamber empty is accepted as conclusive proof that he killed himself.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Last night the Lake Street surreptitiously commenced the con- struction of a loop upon the original right of way, which the Northwestern Elevated Company has so warmly contested in the courts of late. It is now settled that the Lake Street line will build to Wabash Ave- nue without further hindrance.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8. -- If ever the Atalanta Wheelmen had a big time, they had it to-night, on the occasion of the presentation of The New-York Times's handsome gold medals to the six members of New-Jersey's winning team in the tri-State 150-mile relay race, run on June 2, from New-York to Philadelphia.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Controller Roberts to- day submitted to the Constitutional Con- vention a communication in reply to the resolution which called upon him to submit in detail a statement showing the sources, extent, nature, and present investment of every fund and property belonging to or controlled by the State, of which either the principal or interest was devoted to educa- tional uses.
The graduation exercises of the Workingman's School and its Kindergarten Normal department were held last evening in Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue.

The case of Horace Burroughs, who was indicted May 6, 1890, for the forgery of a certificate of a Brunswick (Ga.) lumber inspector, was before Judge Fitzgerald yesterday, in Part II. of the General Sessions. Lawyer Chirles W. Brooke, who represents the defendant, asked that the indictment be quashed.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 8. -- At the morning session of the Synod of the Reformed Church in America the Rev. B. Bauman of Reading, Penn., Corresponding Delegate from the Reformed Church of the United States, addressed the delegates, urging a union of the two bodies. At the afternoon session nominations were made for Third Professor of Historical Theology in the Western Theological Seminary at Holland, Mich.

The Adams Express Company has been presenting to all its employes lately, and to applicants for employment, an agreement for signing, which exempts the company from any liability in the event of the signer being injured in the company's service.

In order to avoid a recurrence of the incident attending the recent eastward voyage of the Paris and Majestic, when those steamers were unjustly charged with racing, the American Line has decided to adopt immediately a fixed hour for sailing from New-York, wnich it has for some time contemplated, and for which its new terminus, at the foot of Fulton Street, was especially constructed.

MADRID, June 8. -- United States Minister Taylor has notified the Government that, owing to misinterpretation of the treaty with the United States, the customs duties are not property collected in the Island of Cuba.

Mr. F.W. Barrow, General Manager of the Buenos Ayres Great Southern Railway, running from Buenos Ayres to Bahia Blanca, sails for Liverpool per steamship Umbria to-morrow, en route to Argentina. Mr. Barrow has been in the United States for some two months, studying the system of operating American railways, with a view to adopting some of the methods in vogue here for the operation of the Buenos Ayres Great Southern.

The President has promptly signed the new bill authorizing the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company to construct a railroad bridge across the Hudson River, with its eastern terminus somewhere between Fifty-ninth and Sixty-ninth Streets. There is some compensa- tion for the delays and contests which this great enterprise has encountered at Washington in the perfection of the measure as it finally becomes a law.

The doubles in the Jersey City Tennis Club's open tournament fell to a pair of dark horses. The spectators on the courts at Highland and Glenwood Avenues, Jersey City Heights, had se- lected the Runyon brothers of the New-York Tennis Club as the winners, but they fell off in their play, and were easily downed by the Brook- lynites.

DENVER, Col., June 8. -- The Gulf train, with passengers for Central City and Georgetown, was wrecked in Clear Creek Canon, three miles west of Golden, this morning at 10 o'clock, and five persons were injured.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Senate has now reached Page 45 of the Tariff bill, which contains 231 pages.

A freight-rate war of unusual vigor and bitterness is now waging among the transportation lines in the South. It was started by one of the coast steamship lines because of dissatisfaction with the division of compensations for through water and rail business into Southern territory.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Senate committee charged with investigating the alleged deal between the Sugar Trust and Democratic Senators started in to-day on an interesting branch of its inquiry.

Six milk depots have now been opened by Nathan Straus, where the purest raw and sterilized milk can be purchased at actual cost prices. The depots are at the foot of East Third Street, at 317 East Ninth Street, 147 Eldridge Street, 22 Market Street, 201 West Sixty-third Street, and 324 East Fifty-ninth Street.

The United States cruiser Lancaster, which has been leisurely journeying homeward from the China station, arrived yesterday afternoon and went to an anchorage off Clifton, S.I. The vessel passed Gibraltar May 2, and has been expected daily for two weeks.
Dun's Review will say to-day:

All arrangements have been made for the fifty-second games of the New-York Athletic Club, which are to be held at Travers Island this afternoon. Murphy, the Yale trainer, who has been engaged to handle the New-York athletes, left for New-Haven to make arrangements for the Yale team to reach Travers Island by a special train, stopping at New-Rochelle this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Representative William A. Stone of Pennsylvania has filed the minority report of the Judiciary Committee on the action of Judge Jenkins of Milwaukee in restraining the employes of the Northern Pacific Railway from striking. The report also bears the signature of Mr. Bay of New-York, Mr. Powers of Vermont, and Mr. Updegraff of Iowa.
CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., June 8. -- The long strike in Cripple Creek is ended, and the settlement has been effected without bloodshed.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The investigation into the alleged armor-plate frauds was continued to-day, Lieut. A.A. Ackerman of the Bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department, being examined. He was a member of the board appointed by Secretary Herbert to conduct the first investigation into the alleged frauds.
When the members of the committee investigating the sugar tariff scandal be- gan to question Mr. H.L. Terrell they opened a mine of very interesting and suggestive information.

Everybody remembers the story of the British yeoman who complained of the claret that was served to him at an agri- cultural banquet. His complaint of the fluid was that, no matter how freely he drank of it, he got "no forrader." This naive complaint must be echoed by a large number of persons who have fol- lowed the testimony given before the Lexow committee.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- For the first time since the harness racers came here, over two weeks ago, they were able to fill their engage- ments this afternoon at Belmont Park without in- terruption by rain. The sunshine brought a prof- itable crowd, and there was some capital sport, in which favorites won most of the events. The exception to this was in the 2:29 trot, left unfin- ished yesterday after two heats.

WEST POINT, June 8. -- The field sports which were to take place at 9 o'clock this morning and the field artillery drill (school of the battery) were postponed until tomorrow. There was, however, firing with machine and rapid-fire guns, under direction of Capt. L.L. Bruff, Ordnance Department, at the target range during the afternoon.
Messrs. Terence Farley's Sons have sold, for about $50,000, the four-story brick and brownstone dwelling 58 West Seventieth Street, 23 by 65, with extension, by 100.
Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes, twenty-five years ago, made the following startling statement: "The medical profession is just emerging from the darkness of barbarism."

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- From private advices received at the Navy Department it appears that the Minneapolis will be the greatest premium winner ever built, and that no such velocity as she developed was ever approached by a war ship on preliminary trial, notwithstanding the poor quality of fuel used.

There is a paper published in New-York called The Times. That paper is right in line of improvement, and it is not surprising then that in looking about to see how to popularize itself it should select cycling as that means. It showed its wisdom when it did so, for the relay race it promoted and carried out to success last Saturday showed that it was up to the times.

Robert H. Parks. Robert H. Parks, at one time an active operator in grain and stocks in this city and Chicago, died yesterday at the Hahnemann Hospital, at Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, where he had been ill for several months. He first became known here about thirty years ago, when he joined his brother, C.C. Parks, who was a member of the old Gold Board.

The warehouse firm of E.B. Bartlett Co., consisting of the estate of the late E. B. Bartlett of Brooklyn, Albert C. Woodruff of 38 South Oxford Street, and Henry A. Nichie of 42 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, the surviving partners in the business at 5 Hanover Street, made an assignment yesterday morning to William W. Goodrich of 59 Wall Street.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 8. -- The schooner Water Witch, Atlantic Yacht Club, Commodore David Banks, arrived here this morning from New-York. She came through the Sound last night, and is at anchor off the Pequot, near the Summer residence of Commodore Banks.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 8. -- The fiftieth anniversary of the Freehold Institute, one of the best-known schools in the State, was celebrated to-day in Randolph Hall, the recitation hall of the school, and at the American Hotel. Old graduates of the institution wearing the school colors' of blue and white have been in evidence in the streets since yesterday, when they began to arrive.
The terms of fifteen members of the Brooklyn Board of Education will expire July 1, and Mayor Schieren will have to appoint their successors.
DENVER, Col., June 8. -- At least fifteen members of the Denver contingent of Coxey's Army lost their lives by drowning in the Platte River last night.

At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday Superintendent Byrnes submitted a report giving the result of his conference with Chairman Lexow of the Senate committee as to the propriety of a Police Department investigation of charges made before the committee. Inciuded in the report was a letter from Senator Lexow to the effect that the committee believed such an investigation would hamper its work.

Preachers, lawyers, and actors were roundly scored by Miss Mary Shaw at the Professional Women's League yesterday afternoon as "mouthers, mumblers, and conscienceless voice murderers." She gave a strong paper on culture of the speaking voice, which the league enthusiastically indorsed.

In exposing the vicious and un-American propaganda of the American Protective Association, The New-York Times has already presented many evidences of the close affiliation of the "Proscriptives" with the Republican Party. The Rev. Madison C. Peters, chief advocate in this city of the A.P.A., is on record as saying boldly that the organization of which he is so proud "works with the Republicans in the North."

But for the exciting finish in the Vreedland Handicap, in which three horses finished short heads apart and four others followed them in a bunch, the racing at Morris Park yesterday would have been decidedly tame. The weather was all that could be desired, and the fast time made in most of the con- tests showed that the track was in excel- lent condition.

The stubbornness with which prices of railroad securities hold in the face of conditions which might be considered sure to cause decline, suggests some reflections on causes. First and foremost we have easy money. But this is not in itself sufficient. Stocks have gone down in past times when money was as easy, as in the long decline following 1873.

Every lover of gardens hails the poet Pope as a foremost member of the craft. Though his grounds at Twickenham were of small dimensions, he contrived, by the inspiration of his own fine taste, and with the assistance of the two great professional gardeners, Bridgman and Kent, and the advice of that brilliant paladin.

The private charitable and educational institutions of this city are to undergo an investigation by two committees of the Constitutional Convention this week. Tuesday the Sub-Committee on Education, under the Chairmanship of Mr. Rolls of Yonkers, and the Committee on Charities, under the Chairmanship of Edward Lauterbach, will begin work in this city with the object of arriving at the answer to the question of whether private institutions should receive State money.

Before the racing at Morris Park yesterday there was a weeding-out sale of the racers which Messrs. J.A. Morris Sons have no farther use for. Col. Bruce sold the horses, those disposed of and their purchasers being given herewith: Certainty, ch. c., 4 years, by Royal Hampton-Certamen, by Ben Battle; Charles Littlefleld................................$400

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- When Mr. Linton, Republican and A.P.A. member of the House from Michigan, Thursday attacked the Catholics of the country for using some of the money appropriated for the education of the Indians he probably simply followed the dictates of the association, narrow and bigoted, of which he is a member, and which requires its members to wage unremitting war on "Papists."
The day appointed by the Ministry for the annual festival in honor of Joan of Arc In France is the second Sunday in May, the anniversary of the maid's triumph in Orleans in 1429.

POCAHONTAS, Ill., June 9. -- The through express, east bound, which left St. Louis at 8:10 o'clock this morning, on the Vandalia line, was ditched on a sharp curve one mile east of Pocahontas. The train was running at the rate of forty miles an hour.

Next to the universal dotted-veil habit, in working injury the sight, according to a writer in The Philadelphia Press, is the very popular use of colored lamp shades. In hall or drawing room the green, yellow, red, or pink "umbrella" shades are charming; in the room where people read, write, or sew, they are out of place.

China is absolutely governed by a bureaucracy, created by competitive examination, tempered by connections, interest, and bribery. The universal ambition is to become a Government official. There is the temptation of almost irresponsible power, with great prizes, and of many lucrative places, but, on the other hand, the blanks are innumerable, and the majority of the aspirants must resign themselves to mendicancy.

The tall flagstaff on the roof of The Times Building was yesterday crowned with a large glided ball and received a double coat of white paint. The work of climbing the pole and placing upon its apex, sixty-five feet above the roof of the building, the hollow sphere of gilded copper, 18 inches in diameter, was watched with interest from the windows and roofs of the adjacent structures, and hundreds of pedestrians stopped to gaze.

The Tenement House Committee appointed by the Governor to investigate the tenements of this city has been at work several weeks. Its labors, have thus far resulted in the laying out of an efficient plan to secure the information sought and a record of many of the sources of this information.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., June 9 -- The inclemency of the weather has proved a decided drawback to this village so far. Usually, everything is in full blast here soon after the arrival of June, but this year neither hotel nor boarding-house proprietors have hurried their preparations for the season's opening.

Extreme expenses made inevitable by the Triple Alliance, a commercial war with France as ruinous as military battles, reverses in Africa, in fine, all the forms of aggravation that lead to the overthrow of a Government have affected Italy, and still Humbert is King and Francesco Crispi is his Prime Minister.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 9.--The races of the Montclair Wheelmen over the Valley Road course this afternoon were well contested and witnessed by a large crowd. The road wag in pretty good condition, and for purely local riders the time was very good.

NEWARK, N.J., June 9 -- Military Park, the starting point of the great century run from Newark to Philadelphia, promoted by the Associated Cycling Clubs of the latter city, was certainly the liveliest spot in the whole State of New-Jersey at a time when, as a rule, all good citizens are slumbering, and, mayhap, snoring, peacefully.

ALBANY, June 9 -- The members of the nunerous commissions which have been established by the Legislature in the past ten years are somewhat exercised over a proposition pending in the Constitutional Convention to abolish their offices. A sub-committee of the Committtee on Legislative Powers is formulating an amendment based upon a proposition of Mr. Dean,(Rep., Chautauqua.) Judge Charles H. Moore of Clinton is Chairman of the sub-committee.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 9 -- The following companies were incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day:

ATLANTA, Ga., June 9 -- The anti-Administration campaign in Georgia, which has been gradually disintegrating for some time, was formally abandoned by its leaders to-day when the Democratic mass meeting of Fulton County, presided over by Evan P. Howell, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, adopted resolutions strongly indorsing President Cleveland and his Administration.

The shortage of $78,000 in the accounts of County Treasurer Henry H. Adams does not seem to be a source of much interest or anxiety to any one in Brooklyn. Mr. Adams himself apparently takes but a desultory notice of the discoveries of the committee of the Board of Supervisors. The committee in question has not been aroused to a high state of enthusiasm or excitement.

Wagnerians of New-York may be interested in the fact that they are not alone in the glories of their quarrel about Kapellmeisters. Catulle Mendes leads a row similar to theirs in Paris, in the following terms:

John A. Morris dipped one hand into one of his pockets, labeled "New-York Jockey Club," and took out $8,615, which he immediately placed in another of his capacious pockets, labeled "John A. Morris Sons' racing stable." In other words, with horses in his own stable he won the amount named in stakes that he had given to be raced for.

A large crowd visited Livingston, S.I., yesterday to witness the first game of the season between the crack cricket teams of the Staten Island Cricket Club and the New-Jersey Athletic Club. They were well rewarded for their visit, although the fielding of the Islanders was not up to first-class form.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 -- The conference at East St. Louis between miners and mine operators for the purpose of adjusting the miners' strike in Illinois came to order shortly after 11 o'clock this morning. J.A. Crawford, Illinois State President of the Order of Mine Workers, called the meeting to order.

The finds of M. Jacques de Morgan, Director General of Antiquities in Egypt, have been reviewed from time to time since his first success in April near the northern of the two brick pyramids at Dashur, not far from Saqqara. These pyramids are of brick, but there is evidence that they were once clothed with cut stone.

LENOX, June 9. -- Lenox cottagers and their numerous guests are looking forward with much anticipation to the wedding of Mr. William Stone Post and Miss Lilian H. Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thatcher N. Adams, which is to take place next Thursday, June 14. It will be an event, from a social standpoint, far surpassing any other in Lenox during June.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9 -- The dedicatory exercises of the new Alexander Commencement Hall, the gift of Mrs. Charles B. Alexander of New-York City to Princeton, were held this morning at 11:30 o'clock. The Caledonian games were held one week ago in order to leave this morning free for the event, and the ball was well filled.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 9 -- Lizzie Halliday will be tried for murder in a few days, and Sullivan County is excited regarding her fate.

In the time of Peter there were no great writers or artists among the Russians, but Court jesters and dwarfs were highly esteemed. Learning did not count for much, except among the clergy; but the great empire, we are told, was remarkable for her "Fools" of high degree, for even Princes were proud to hold the office.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- It looks as it the Government would be able to establish a naval station at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Admiral Walker has kept surveying parties at the place for some weeks, and even before he took command of the station Admiral Irwin had commenced the work of investigation.

WASHINGTON, June, 9 -- The report of June 1, consolidated from the returns of the correspondents of the Agricultural Department, makes the acreage of Winter wheat sown, compared with than which was harvested last year, 89 per cent., being decrease of one point.

Mr. Yates commenced The World with the late Mr. Grenville Murray as his partner, but he subsequently bought him out. Just before the issue of the first number I met him in a train, and he asked me to become one of his contributors. At that time little was known of city syndicates, market rigs, , and it struck me that it might be useful to let a little light into these dark places.

BABYLON, L.I., June 9 -- Ancient in name, but up to date in attractiveness as a Summer resort, this lively Long Island village awaits the influx of visitors that always follows the arrival of the middle of June.

GREENPORT, L.I., June 9 -- In this far-off section of Long Island the coming of the Summer guest means what might properly be termed an awakening from a long Winter nap. Very little preparation, however, is made here for the reception of the Summer girl and the Summer young man, their parents, and their friends.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Will you allow one of your constant readers to give his opinion concerning the American Protective Association, to which you are now devoting so much space in your columns, and which is making most interesting reading for the patrons of your excellent Journal ?

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 9. -- Desha Breckinridge, son of Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge, in an interview has said that W.C. Owens, Col. Breckinridge's opponent for Congress. "is by nature a coward, by instinct a traitor, by practice a liar, and by profession a gambler."

There is no bicycle club in the metropolitan district that takes more pride in its model organization than the Long Island Wheelmen, whose home is at 1,281 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. The club is one of the pioneer cycling clubs of the country, having been organized in 1882. The club is composed largely of quite elderly men, the average age being over thirty-seven years.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 9 -- The Academic Board was busy this afternoon reviewing the examinations of the graduating class. Following is the standing of the class in general merit, which was announced at parade this evening:

After reading Mr. Moore's story, one who is expected to express an opinion of it that shall have, at least, the tone of authority is conscious of facing a dilemma. From one point of view "Esther Waters" is clearly a work of art of extraordinary merit. As an example of realism in novel writing it has never been surpassed in England.

The reason why Tacitus will ever, by a large class of sympathetic readers, be placed facile princeps among historians is not far to seek. His grand elevation of moral dignity has never been surpassed. He has no relish for the ridiculous side of absurdity, but ever gravely unfolds its unreason, and writes like a man who had never enjoyed a hearty laugh.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 9 -- Adjt. Gen. Porter has made the following details for the State Camp, at Peekskill, for the coming season:

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- For a long time officers who are in command of posts, stations, and permanent works have complained to the War Department that they were put to needless labor by answering a series of queries sent from the Inspector General's office each year on huge blanks. The questions covered every conceivable condition in the army and embraced a wide range of topics.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 9 -- The Tax Assessors have completed their labors for the year, and find the valuation of Newport to be $34,703,650, about three-fourths of which is assessed upon Summer residents, chiefly New-Yorkers. The highest taxed property owner is Mrs. Elizabeth R. Gammell of Providence.

The bills affecting the laws relative to the merchant marine, which James G. Maguire, member of Congress from the Fourth Congressional District of California, has lately introduced in the House of Representatives, has provoked much comment among the owners and masters of American vessels.

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., June 9 -- Cottagers will find the island this Summer in many respects a more agreeable place to dwell on than it was a year ago. The Fergusons are spending a great deal of money in improving the roads and the construction of a sanitary system of sewerage which will embrace the whole southern part of the island.

TAHLEQUAH, Indian Territory, June 9. -- The attempt of a lone highwayman to rob the stage running between this place and Gibson City to-day resulted in the loss of three lives and the wounding of one person. The killed are:

Travers Island, the Summer home of the New-York Athletic Club and one of the prettiest spots on Long Island Sound, was taxed to its utmost capacity yesterday afternoon. The attraction was the fiftysecond games of the popular club. The gentlemen in charge of the arrangements had prepared an excellent programme, and lovers of this kind of sport could not resist the temptation.

-- Mr. Clarence B. Moore of Philadelphia has given to the Pennsylvania Museum a collection of 2,050 rare coins -- Greek, Phoenician, Roman, Indian, early British, early Swiss, Norse, and so forth. Of other coins and electro copies of coins the museum has about 6,000.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Private letters from Hawaii, which are later than some of the Government advices, represent that the Constitutional Convention promises to be a great disappointment to the men who organized the provisional Government with the idea of using it to secure annexation to the United States.
Mr. A.D. Hagans of Kingwood, West Va., has carefully preserved an autograph which Henry Clay wrote him fifty years ago. It reads:
