LONDON, June 9. -- A representative of the United Press had an interview to-day with Prof. Hunting, who has been conducting an expert examination of the lungs of Canadian slaughtered cattle, at the instance of Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian High Commissioner, the latter not being satisfied that the experts employed by the Government were disinterested.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 9 -- James Merritt, about thirty years old, who had been an invalid for some years, went to the old Maid of the Mist landing, under the cantilever bridge, to-day, seated himself on the bank with his feet touching the water, and, taking out a package of some poison, swallowed it, dipping up water in his hat to aid in washing down the powder.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

Prince de Polignac came out as a composer this week at the Salle d'Harcourt. Of his compositions one may say -- adapting the ban mot of a courtier of the last century on the voice of the Comte d'Artois, (afterward Charles IX.) -- he composes like a Prince.

Perhaps what is most wonderful in the revelations that are making of the police before the Lexow committee is not the flagitiousness of any particular vice that is corrupting and enfeebling the police, but the number, extent, and complication of the rascalities that seem to pervade all departments of the force.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 9.--During the last week the hotel proprietors here have become convinced that the season will be a prosperous one, as the Summer guests have been pouring in, notwithstanding the fact that it has rained nearly every day. Many of the smaller hotels and boarding Many of the smaller hotels and boarding also, and the cottagers from New-York, Philadelphia, and Washington have arrived, and the season has begun under very favorable conditions.

No one but a librarian, knowing the vast importance of such a work as is this "History for Ready Reference," and with cognizance of the insides of books themselves, could have undertaken this immense work. A man's reading must be complete when he knows, not alone what are the authorities, but has the judgment necessary to select the one or more authorities whose abilities are considered as the best.

Beginning one week from to-morrow, exJudge William G. Choate will begin hearings, as referee, in the suit to settle the rights of the St. Nicholas and Madison Square Banks in respect to the operation of a Clearing House rule. The right of the Clearing House Association to enforce this rule is quite as closely involved as are those of the two banks.

In the recent death of samuel F. Prentiss. Brooklyn lost a resident who had done much to promote the welfare and dignity of the community in which he lived. An eminent lawyer and a citizen of rare public spirit, he left a record of which his sorrowing relatives have good reason to be proud.

The annual exhibiton of the work done in the department of architecture of Columbia College was opened on Friday and will be continued to-morrow and Tuesday. The work of the graduating class fills one of the large laboratories. Each of the two classes next lower have a separate room devoted to their work.

The following events have been arranged for by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club: Saturday, July 21. race for the Osborn Cup for twenty-onefooters and the Moller Cup for twenty-foot catboats; Thursday, July 26 to July 29, annual cruise; Saturday, Aug. 4, annual regatta; Saturday, Aug. 18, ladies' day.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- At the request of Secretary Carlisle, the House Committee on Appropriations inserted in the Legislative bill a few lines to authorize the Secretary to appoint as the Chief of Revenue Marine a Captain or First Lieutenant of the Cutter Service. This was to enable the Secretary to make choice of some of the older officers of the service to direct the business in the central bureau.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 9 -- The Elizabeth Wheelmen added another wreath to their victorious laurels this afternoon by winning the tenmile road championship of Union County, and The Journal trophy in the greatest contest that has yet been run for that honor.
Richard Croker, who recently retired from the leadership of Tammany Hall, and two of his sons, Richard, jr., and Herbert, sailed for Europe yesterday on the Cunard steanlship Umbria.

Corporation Counsel McDonald has written a long opinion for the Civil Service Commission in regard to the provisions of the new law exempting veterans of the late war from the civil service laws for all positions in the public departments and upon all public works of the State of New-YorK the compensation of which does not exceed $4 a day.

The woman at the elliptical, rose-stuccoed house held up her hands in protest when a pair of wanderers stood at her door at 10 o'clock of an April morning and pleaded not guilty to the charge of breakfast; then bustled about to set them forth a hasty meal garnished with the excuses of a sharp-conscienced Connecticut housewife.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 9 -- The Naval War College, at Coasters' Harbor Island, will be opened for the season of 1894 Tuesday, June 12. Assistant Secretary William McAdoo will represent the Navy Department on that occasion. A large class has already been ordered to the college. It is expected that twenty-five members will be present on opening day.

RED BANK, N.J., June 9 -- This popular riverside resort is the Summer home of many prominent New-York people. Most of those who pass the season here have arrived, and indications point to a lively Summer.

The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage, just before sailing from San Francisco, wrote a letter to The Brooklyn Eagle about the fires which destroyed his three Tabernacles. In view of the facts which came to light after the fire, Dr. Talmage's remarks are humorous, if not a little absurd.

Three regattas are scheduled for this week. Tuesday the yachts of the NewJersey Club will race. The start will be made from Oyster Island Buoy, just below Liberty Island, and the yachts will race down the Lower Bay and back. About thirty yachts are expected to start, and, with a fair wind, the contest ought to be an interesting one, although none of the cracks will be out.

A correspondent of the Vossische Zeitung writes from Tunis that the last executions of criminals by hanging were so slowly and clumsily accomplished as to afford terrible spectacles, and the Government of the Bey applied to England for a model of the apparatus there used. The replies to this application came slowly and evasively, so that a Tunis joiner, a European, was intrusted with the making and carrying out of a practical gallows.

HAZLETON, Penn., June 9 -- In the conflict between the strikers and the coal and Iron Police, at Silver Brook this morning, three of the strikers were shot and several of the officers injured with stones and clubs.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 9 -- A pretty wedding took place Thursday evening in the Dayspring Presbyterian Church, when Miss Emma W. Menzer was married to Edward S. Torrence. The Rev. Charles S. Allison officiated, assisted by the Rev. N.S. Tuthill of Ardsley. The bride wore a gown of white silk trimmed with satin and point lace.
Warden Hayes of the Kings County Penitentiary was asked by a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday about the recent conspiracy among the long-term prisoners to escape.

W.C. Humstone, Superintendent of the Western Union Telegraph Company, said yesterday that he did not credit the report that the telegraph operators had organized a union and were arranging for a general strike to compel the telegraph companies to increase their wages.

HANOVER, N.H., June 9 -- Williams was beaten to-day in a poor exhibition of ball playing. Dinsmore was more effective, and the Dartmouths managed to hit the ball better than yesterday. Folsom played a phenomenal game, taking ten of eleven chances. Lewis was substituted for Clark in the second half of. the fifth, and through his wildness Dartmouth won the game in that inning.
An attempt was made to assassinate Chiero, the palmist, in his rooms, 432 Fifth Avenue, last night. The would-be assassin escaped. He left his dagger sticking in Chiero's cigarette case.

Mr. Cole's title page floes not intimate that his journey across Central Europe from the Vistula to the Rhine was made on a cycle. Indeed, the rider might infer from it that he had traveled by rail, by private conveyance, or that he had walked. Neither of these inferences would be true, however, for he rode a tricycle.

ILION, N.Y., June 9 -- A new star appeared on the New-York State bicycle circuit in the races of the Remington Cycle Club here to-day. Raymond McDonald of the Riverside Wheelmen, New-York, won the half-mile open, quarter-mile State championship, and lost the mile open by less than a foot to Helfert of Utica. These two and Jenney of Utica were the first three in every event.

The critical temperature of oxygen is -171, ( -113 C.) Above that point it remains obstinately gaseous -- interstitial movements are too active to permit its molecules to lay hold one of another. Nitrogen is till less amenable, its corresponding stage being reached only at the deeper depth of -233, (-147 C.) Such cold is unattainable by direct means; the intervention of liquid oxygen is required to produce it.

BOSTON, June 9. -- This has been the dullest half day of the season in our market, and outside of arbitrage Copper and one or two specialties there have been almost no quotations. Bay State Gas has had a semblance of activity yesterday and to-day around 8, while the firsts have reappeared at 83 1/2. There were also one or two sales of Central Massachusetts at 11 1/4.

WEST POINT, June 9 -- The cavalry exercises show the careful training bestowed upon the cadets during their four years' stay at the Military Academy. These young men, many of whom were never astride a horse before they entered the tanbarked riding hall, develop a proficiency which is extraordinary.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 9 -- The Rev. John W. Paxton, formerly pastor of the West Presbyterian Church, New-York, is rapidly recovering from his recent illness under the care of the physicians at the St. Francis Hospital.
Helen, aged eight, had been lunching at the house of a friend. At dinner at home she looked up suddenly. "Mrs. Blank is not at all like you, mamma."

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 9 -- More than two centuries ago, when the site of the beautiful City of Kingston was in the midst of an almost trackless wilderness, a little colony of God-fearing Hollanders settled on the spot and in a short time founded a church. Around this sacred edifice a cemetery gradually sprang up.

-- The recent wet weather and the labors of the gardeners and lawnkeepers have done much to enhance the natural beauty of Shelter Island. All the hotels -- the Manhanset House, the Prospect and Bay View Houses and West Neck Park -- are busy brushing up and painting, and the several properties, their surrounding lawns, flower beds, groves, and drives, all give evidence of busy preparations for the Summer season.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., June 9 -- The second day's racing of the Amityville Agricultural and Driving Park Association was held here to-day. The track was in excellent condition, and nearly 1,500 persons were present. An accident happened during the third heat of the 2:31 class race, when the br. s. Azmen, handled by Driver Powers, reared up as he was being driven on the track, and threw his rider out.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., June 9.--The brokers and refiners of the Wall Street branch of the American Sugar-Refining Company of New-York, to the number of 125, disembarked at Stoiber's Dock to-day and marched to Donnelly's Boulevard Park, where they had their second annual clam bake. They were under command of Thomas Marshall. After dinner they played games on the athletic field.

No prettier run for cyclists who have the necessary time at their disposal can well be imagined than the trip from New-York to the famous Delaware Water Gap. The New-York Times has received inquiries from several correspondents as to the best route to be taken to reach this "beauty spot" of nature, and the suitability of the roads for light wheels.
"Hera we are in last place." said Anson to his colts at the breakfast table yesterday morning. "Now, I want you to get a move on you and mow down those Giants to-day."

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 9 -- The Pequot House opened for the season Tuesday. Already many of the cottages are occupied, although the weather has not been of the kind that attracts people to the seaside. Not before the 20th will the season be fairly started at this old but popular house. The early opening with a small equipment was to accommodate the cottagers who take their meals at the hotel.

Food provision is the object for which birds periodically change their dwelling places. The sovereigns, the Bishops, the Barons of old and mediaeval times, when they had exhausted the resources of one estate, moved on to another. This was the reason of the constant journeyings of our ancestors in the days gone by, when each district provided for its own needs.

Taking a hint or two from Swift, Mr. Barry Pain has published, in the pages of Black and White, a few notes on "Hampstead Heath Etiquette," as a sort of first step toward a guide to "Bank Holiday Deportment." They embrace dress, deportment, music, riding, and love.

The Wild West, at Ambrose Park, has proved a great drawing card for the citizens of Greater New-York, and they are patronizing it with a liberality that is astonishing, in face of the disagreeable weather of the last three weeks. The weather has been a little better for the last few days, however, and it is safe to predict that the Wild West will continue to fill its spacious grand stand at every performance.
Gov. Flower, in his veto of the Flag bill enacted by the New-York Legislature at its recent session, committed a grave blunder.

We hear a great deal at the present day about "mandates," and mandate seems to be regarded not simply as a declaration of the will of a majority which must, in point of fact, be obeyed, but as the official utterance of an infallible Church which cannot, in point of logic, be erroneous. Now, I confess that I have always had a Weakness for the faithful Abdiel.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9 -- The third annual intercollegiate pigeon shoot was held this morning on the grounds of the Princeton Gua Club, the home team coming out the winner. At the last moment word was received from the Harvard Gun Club that its representatives would be unable to be present, so the match went on with the Yale and Princeton Clubs as the only contestants.

Baron Harden Hickey, whose meteoric apparitions as editor of a witty Parisian journal, as a Catholic converted to Buddhism, and as the author of "Euthanasia," a cheerful little book on the art of committing suicide, are not easily forgotten, is founding a principality by means of a prospectus.
They were talking of the removals into palaces of ancient book stores, which make of Fifth Avenue a Paternoster Row, grander and more elegant than the London model.

Mrs. Lydia C. Cox, who used to be known as Lydia C. Cocks, has not paid a judgment for $101 held by James J. Reynolds of Mount Vernon. On behalf of Mr. Reynolds, application was made yesterday to Judge Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas, for the appointment of a receiver in proceedings supplementary to execution, and Leroy B. Crane was appointed.

That was an interesting and instructive little paragraph in The Star which told the story of a five-dollar gold piece, suspected of being counterfeit, which was sent to the Director of the Mint by a Special Inspector of Customs at El Paso. The piece was defective, and upon its appearance, a man was arrested at El Paso and charged with the circulation of counterfeit coin.
"Orange, N.J." - The Times cannot undertake to answer questions of law. "E." -- Matthew Stanley Quay, United States Senate, Washington, D.C.

Daniel Cahey, twenty-five years old, a district messenger, who lives at 1,553 Broadway, was probably fatally stabbed last night by his uncle, Henry Rohlfs. The attack by Rohlfs followed a bitter quarrel the two had had about an hour previous to the stabbing. At a late hour last night Lahey was said to be in a very dangerous condition at Roosevelt Hospital.

New-York has proved almost as much of a loadstar to Western women as it has to the daughters of the South. One of the bright young women to whom the metropolis has given a cordial welcome is Miss Jessie Hubbell Bancroft, who is now recognized as one of the most successful exponents of the art of physical culture.

We have already referred to the resolution introduced in Congress for the abrogation of the extradition treaty with Russia. From the outset The Times has regarded this treaty as uncalled for, open to misinterpretation, inconsistent with the self-respect of the American people, and liable to abuses that are shocking to every American heart.

The opening game at the season at Berkeley Oval was played yesterday between the Morris Heights and Brooklyn Clubs. The wicket prepared was a perfect one for batting, and as a consequence high scoring predominated. A.H. Collins set the ball rolling by hitting out in terrific Style, and he compiled 59 runs in 32 minutes, the record for the ground.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, June 9 -- Cottages are renting exceptionally well this year. Some of the rentals are as follows: Mrs. William Rhinelander, New-York, Cottage F.; Mrs. John F. Hall, New-York, Cottage D.; Dr. Seward Webb, New-York, Cottage C.F.M. Allen has rented his cottage to Frank P. Tenney of New-York.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 9 -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yachts Embla, John H. Hanan; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Half Moon, Frank T. Holder, and Almy, Frederick Gallatin. Schooner yacht Enigma, George E. Chisolm.

The Harlem Wheelmen are beginning to make arrangements for what they confidently prophesy will be one of the biggest race meets New-York has ever seen, to be held on Sept. 15, at Manhattan Field. They have already raised $1,000 toward defraying expenses, and the Board of Managers in whose hands the development of the whole affair is placed mean to turn every week of the long gap between now and September to the best advantage.

BUFFALO, June 9 -- Thomas C. Platt is making a play for the Republican organization in Erie County. Nicholas J. Mock has just returned from a conference with the Tioga boss, and this is the meaning of an interview which he gave out to-day. Mock is a City Assessor, member of the Republican General Committee, and a power in the east aide wards.

-- According to the annual report of the Consolidated Exchange, issued yesterday, for the year ending May 31, stock sales for the year amounted to 52,722,300 shares, and bond sales to $27,705,000. In mining stocks there were sales of 344,810 shares, and pipe-line certificates for 3,940,000 barrels of oil were sold. Sales of grain reached 213,754,000 bushels, against 34,668,000 bushels in the previous year.

Many anxious eyes are turned toward the sky these days, for no one likes to go for an outing and get caught in the rain. Weather signs are not all humbug, for some of them are based on scientific facts. For instance, when the smoke blows down, the air is heavy with moisture, and that is a sure sign of rain unless some wind should come along to clear the atmosphere.
In an Interview with a reporter for the United Press yesterday a gentleman who has just returned from Colombia, after a residence there for several years, said:

LONDON, June 9.--If only for the sake of old times, it seems good to hear once more the Gallic cock clapping its wings and sending echoes of its fine defiant crow reverberating round among the neighboring barnyards. Even if we know that nothing is going to come of it, there are enough reminiscences of past splendor in the sound to kindle the imagination.

"Remodeling" or hats is getting to be quite a business. To some people this would seem to be an elegant way of speaking of the finishing over, trimming over, , of old or second-hand hats, but such is not the case. The great bulk of hats that are "remodeled" are new ones, or, more properly speaking, are unsold ones. They are not of the up-to-date pattern, and consequently are not salable.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 9 -- When Jon Jonson stepped outside the Ohio Penitentiary Monday morning, a free man, after over nineteen year' solitude in a virtual tomb, one of the most unique and interesting incidents in the history of that institution came to an end. For nearly a decade Jonson has been one of the characters of the place.

The latest thing in reclame comes from Germany. It is the aspiring young novelist -- doubtless in collaboration with his publisher -- who is the disseminator, while it is the super-sentimental nature of the average Fraulein that he regards as his "seed field." The young author writes a romance in whose heroine he incorporates as many physical and mental graces as he can well imagine to exist among Teutonic woman-kind.

-- Thomas Ellis, for many years prominent in this city as a jobber in grain and flour, died in Cincinnati Friday. He was burn near that city in 1813 and began business as a trader along the Ohio River. In 1853 be came to New-York and for twenty-five years did a large business in grain and flour. For twenty years he was an operator at the Produce Exchange.
LONDON, June 9 -- It is understood that the Prince of Wales has a half interest in the three-year-old colt Matchbox, the second horse in the Derby, which was purchased yesterday by Baron de Hirsch.

NORTHFIELD, Mass., June 9 -- A meeting of the Northfield Seminary Board of Trustees was held here this afternoon. Next Saturday there will be a reunion of former Hermon students at Mount Hermon and the alumni prize debate in Recitation Hall. Sunday, June 17, the commencement sermon to Mount Hermon and Northfield Seminary graduating classes will be preached in the Trinitarian Church.

Golf is fast becoming popular. Among society people it has got to be quite the thing. This favorite Scotch game can be traced so far back that the exact date of its origin is lost. While its adoption in this country has been slow, it is now firmly rooted, and this season promises to be its greatest.

The author of this very modest recital spent her Summer in a Mormon village in the company of a friend, "an enthusiastic student of birds," and when she tells us of this friend's persevering search for the elusive chat we find no difficulty in identifying her. Later the two are Joined by a botanist who "did the flowers: better justice;" studying them with the eye of the specialist.
There was a grand combination of May Day, Decoration Day, and Fourth of July at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, and the gayest kind of festivities all day long.
BOSTON, June 9 -- The following extended descriptions of the first two races of the Herreshoff ten-rater Dakotah came from Glasgow under date of May 26:

The committee representing holders of the first mortgage 6 and 7 per cent. bonds of the New-York and New-England Railway met for the second time yesterday in the office of Redmond, Kerr Co., 41 Wall Street. Those present were Charles S. Fairchild, Chairman of the New-York Security and Trust Company; Henry S. Redmond of Redmond, Kerr Co.; Morgan G. Bulkley of the Aetna Life, and Solomon Lincoln of the Boston Safe Deposit Company.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 9 -- This Charming and fashionable resort, rightly designated as the "Newport of Long Island," has already began to receive its Summer population. Many of the cottagers are here, and others are arriving almost daily. Southampton is the central one of a cluster of favorite Long Island villages, among them being Shinnecock Hills, Water Mills, Good Ground, Quogue, and the far-famed Hamptons.

The closing games of the Jersey City Tennis Club's open tournament were played yesterday afternoon on the grounds west of Bergen Avenue, between Highland and Greenwood Avenues, Jersey City Heights. The semi-final and final rounds of the singles were played, and, though the play was only fair, on the whole it was lively enough to hold the attention of a fair-sized crowd of spectators.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 9 -- The charms of this delightful resort, which the poet Bryant loved so well, were never shown to better advantage than now. Not the least of the advantages with which nature endowed this resort are its absolute immunity from malaria and the pestiferous mosquito. It is to persons afflicted with dyspepsia what Colorado is to consumptives; to the over-loaded and weary it is a haven of rest.

The Noonday Rest is the suggestive and attractive title of a suite of rooms just opened in Chicago for the benefit of working girls. The Rest is under the auspices of the Kilo Club, a well-known woman's club, and ladies of the club are daily in attendance to act as hostesses in the sense of seeing that all the frequenters are made comfortable and happy without realizing this care of them.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., June 9 -- Probably no resort on either the south or north shore of Long Island has sprung into greater prominence and popularity in so short a time than has Amityville. Situated on the Great South Bay, it was comparatively unknown to Summer visitors until a few years ago.
CENTRE MORICHES, June 9 -- Of the Summer of 1894 we may say, in the sweet and apropriate words of Willis G. Clark:

She who was lately all languor, calm as a statue, composed, dignified, moving with slow and queenly motion through a life that seemed to have lost all interest for her, now looks like a woman whose every nerve is strung to highest tension, whose delicate frame vibrates with suppressed energy.

In the cold months there were no cases in Western Europe, except possibly in the French departments of Finistere and Morbihan, on the west coast, where the epidemic of last year had not been entirely stamped out.

He has traversed in almost its entire length what is a terra incognita, that dreary stretch of land, the great Thibetan plateau. This, known as the Chang, "is by far the highest and largest plateau on the face of the earth -- compared to it the Pamirs, the socalled Roof of the World, sink into insignificance."

What nature could not do for the Summer opening on Long Island, man has endeavored to supply. Since early Spring busy minds and busy hands have been active in devising and creating new attractions for the enjoyment and comfort of Summer visitors.

A thrill which is something like a chill is felt by about one prominent citizen in each county in the State whenever it is announced that ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton is coming home from Europe.

BUDA-PESTH, June 9. -- The Liberal members of the lower house of the Hungarian Diet held a meeting this forenoon to give clearer interpretation to their resolution of last Saturday, declaring that they would express confidence in Count Hedevary when the Civil Marriage bill should become a law through his instrumentality, expressing their attachment to Dr. Wekerle, and urging the members of his Cabinet to remain in their positions as chiefs of the party.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 9 -- Mrs. Paul Wilcox, at her handsome home, Ivy Lodge, on Wednesday, treated her friends to a morning and an afternoon with Liszt, conducted by two well-known pupils of the great composer, Arthur Friedheim, who played the piano, and Albert Morris Bagby, who talked of musical life with his celebrated teacher.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 9 -- This North Shore yachting centre is ready to welcome the Summer visitor with open arms. Oyster Bay has a reputation for extending a hearty reception to those in search of recreation and rest. Here can be found not only comfortable places to reside during one's stay, but some of the charming scenery that has made the North Shore of Long Island really famous.

Save for the sale of the Tempest coach horses on Thursday evening, the public sales of horses last week were insignificant and the prices paid decidedly of the "bargain-counter" order. Even the sale of trotters and pacers at Fiss Doerr's on Friday afternoon was one that would seem to indicate that the bottom had dropped out of the market all of a sudden.

Part II. of the Regulations for the Military Forces of the State of New-York have been received by The New-York Times. It Is a handy little volume, and contains all the directions, and instructions relating to office duties connected with National Guard work at general, brigade, regimental, battalion, and company headquarters.

Lady Muriel was pretty and worldly. Gerald Mildmay loved her, and believed he was going to marry her. Gerald had made a fair debut in diplomacy, and his old uncle, Sir George, had told everybody that his nephew would be heir to L80,000 and that fine landed estate The Towers. But at seventy Sir George married his housekeeper.

It is said that to-day will be a very dry Sunday among the habitues of the wellknown saloons and resorts in the city. Everything, it is whispered, will be closed up tight. In the Tenderloin district, where everything has been open for years, the police will be particularly strict in enforcing the excise law.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 9 -- Miss Kittie Cheatham, the well-known actress, formerly of Daly's company and later connected with Charles Frohman's company, was united in marriage at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon to William Henry Thomson, a wealthy cotton, merchant of Liverpool, England.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- William Simsrott, the Secretary and Treasurer of the Switchmen's MutuaI Aid Association, is confined in a padded cell at the Washington Home in this city. He acts widly, raves at times, and becomes so violent as to require the watchful care of two or three strong attendants. Whether Simsrott is suffering from insanity or delirium tremens is not known.
Franz Stanislaus Ritter von Hrubijeleni, who says that he is a son of Maximilian, Emperor of Mexico, is now the proprietor of a dingy coal cellar at 236 East Fourth Street.

The first Quakers who came to New-England were two unprotected women, the one, Ann Austin, about sixty years of age, the mother of five children, and the other. Mary Fisher, her maiden friend, over thirty. They came from Barbados. Immediately upon their arrival they were taken from ship to jail, and for fear that any one would talk with them, and thereby spread their heresies, the window of the cell was boarded up.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 9 -- Brown beat Harvard to-day at baseball. 8 to 2. The game was lifeless from beginning to end, and no brilliant plays awoke the interest of the 1,200 spectators. Harvard was crippled by the loss of O'Malley and Scannell, and although Corbett played a faithful game, he could not hold Highlands for a steady period.

BUFFALO, June 9 -- Controller James A. Roberts makes a denial of the story that he has conspired with Gov. Flower to violate the civil service law by getting twelve clerks into his office without examination. An Albany story to that effect declared that the Governor had winked at the alleged plan and had given his consent.

On the night of Saturday, June 23, the National Saengerfest will begin at Madison Square Garden, and continue Sunday and Monday afternoon and evening. Up to this time but few of the details of this undertaking, which will bring singers from all over the country, have been made known. The plans have now assumed definite shape, and it is possible to give the facts of the convention of musicians.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 9 -- The steamer Queen, bound for Alaska, called here to take on board the Raymond excursion party from Boston, erroneously reported to have been wrecked. The excursionists are still flood-bound, and as there was no chance for their getting through from Banff for a week at least the Queen sailed for Alaska without them.

It is easily understood that a tramp, to whom all places are alike, would find a pleasurable excitement in a march. He is supported as he walks, which is all he cares for, and from being the most despised object in the community -- the beggar for broken food -- he suddenly finds a certain dignity and interest attaching themselves to him when he joins one of these armies.

The testimony of Dr. Louise G. Rabinovitch, given before the State Commission in Lunacy, regarding the management of the City Asylum for the Insane on Friday, has aroused the Commissioners of Charities and Correction and the managers of the asylum to a sense of the gravity of the charges to be made against them, and they will in future be represented at the hearings by counsel.

A warrant has been issued by Police Justice Tighe of Brooklyn for the arrest of William J. White, thirty years old, who is charged with stealing $7,000, the property of Mrs. N.E. Tomlinson, whom he married in November, 1893. Mrs. Tomlinson is forty-five years old, and was the widow of a wealthy stationery dealer of Ansonia, Conn.

FORT WADSWORTH, S.I., June 9 -- The annual reception of the Ladies' Tennis Club and Clifton Lawn Tennis Club took place on the beautiful grounds of the allied clubs at Arrochar this afternoon. The courts were in excellent condition and the weather was perfect. The cozy clubhouse was decorated inside and out with bunting and potted plants.

McKane's former bailiwick that tourist bicyclists will find pleasant and more attractive than the usual ride down the Boulevard. Cyrus W. Field the second, who had been ill for several months with consumption, died yesterday afternoon in his house, 166 West Sixty-fifth Street. He was the youngest child of the late Cyrus W. Field.

That much should be written about Verdi's "Falstaff" is not at all remarkable. Verdi has been for many years the representative man in the field of Italian opera and, in spite of the naming of certain young meteors, he remains to-day the one great master of the period. The death of Wagner left Verdi first in the realm of opera, and the grand old man's later years are producing the crowning glories of his career.
YONKERS, N.Y., June 9 -- There are few if any cities in this State that can lay claim to half the charms possessed by this beautiful suburb of the great metropolis.

The theatres have now been closed, except those given up to operetta and variety, which are not at all dramatic and which thrive in all seasons. In New-York the managers, after much experimenting with the weather and the public, seem to have agreed that the drama is out of season as soon as the frost has disappeared.

As far as the tennis world is concerned this week will be most emphatically "ladies' week." The eighth annual tennis, championship tournament in ladies' singles and doubles and the third annual mixed doubles championship will be held on the picturesque grounds of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, at Wissahickon Heights, Chestnut Hill, on June 12 and the following days.

ORANGE, N.J., June 9 -- The Fortnightly Club gave a reception and musicale at the residence of Mrs. Thomas H. Taylor in Highland Avenue on Friday evening, when Mrs. Charlotte Emerson Browne spoke on "What Woman Aims to Be," Miss Ella G. Smith gave a history of the club in verse, Miss Josie Taylor played the piano, Miss Baldwin sang, and Miss Thorpe played the violin.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9 -- Capt. Mackenzie won the baseball game with Yale for Princeton to-day by his terrific batting. He easily solved the great Carter's pitching, and twice, with Ward on first and one man out, he knocked a home run, scoring the four runs made.

Borough towns in England had formerly extraordinary powers. Each had its system of home rule, and was a little imperium in imperio. It controlled its trades, manufactures, and professional occupations, the numbers to be employed, and fixed the price of wages and commodities. It determined what were offenses against the order, morals, and well-being of the borough, and its codes assigned the punishments.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Sugar Trust Investigation committee, was later than usual in assembling to-day. E.R. Chapman of the firm of Moore Schley, Senator Brice'e brokers, who declined to testify yesterday until he had consulted counsel, was the first witness. He has retained Judge Dittenhoefer of New-York as his attorney, and the latter advised him not to tell any of the private business of his firm.

W. Steinitz has returned from Montreal, where he was entertained in royal fashion. He does not feel much disappointed at having lost the match to Lasker, and looks forward to another encounter with the German expert. The latter is perfectly willing to play the ex-champion, and has already thought of appointing a second, whom he expects to carry on the negotiations with Steinitz.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 9 -- There was an unusually large crowd at the annual tournament of the Mount Kisco Gun Club at this place yesterday, and some excellent shooting was witnessed. The principal event, a team match for the team championship of Westchester County, was shot by teams representing Peekskill, White Plains, and Mount Kisco.
The sales referred to in the accompanying list will be held at 111 Broadway, unless otherwise stated:

BLOCK ISLAND, June 9 -- Orders for supplies are just now giving the the steamer which connects this isolated bit of land with the business world all it can do. Presently the Norwich and New-Haven boats will begin their trips here, and then the season may be said to have really begun. The harbor is still in an insecure state, the second appropriation for the widening of its beach not having yet been granted.

Mgr. Satolli is most favorably disposed toward the Catholic Summer School of America. When in this city recently he received the Rev. J.H. McMahon, Director of the League of the Sacred Heart, who is Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Summer School. Mgr. Satolli's remarks concerning the school will thus be given in the next issue of The Catholic Reading Circle Review:

PORT HAWKESBURY, Cape Breton, June 9 -- The other day the Canadian cruiser Vigilant anchored here, and the American fishing schooner Lorring B. Haskell, Capt. Day, anchored at Hastings. The schooner proceeded to take in water without entering at the Custom House. This was contrary to the customs laws, but Capt. Day refused to comply with the regulations, even when notified by the customs officers at Hastings.

BERNE, June 9. -- A referendum was taken in the republic last Sunday on a proposal to insert in the Swiss Constitution a paragraph affirming the right of every male citizen to employment. This proposal originated among the Socialists and extreme Democrats, who hold that the Government should be obliged to provide work for able-bodied and willing workingrnen out of employment.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- The stock market was quite active for a Saturday. There were transactions in everything on the list, but, excepting in two stocks, there were no radical changes in prices. West Chicago was weak and Diamond Match strong. The former opened 3/8 below the closing figures of yesterday, at 142 3/8, and dropped down to 141 1/2.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 9 -- The wedding of Miss Hope Goddard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Goddard of this city, and C. Oliver Iselln of New-York took place at 12:30 o'clock to-day at the home of the bride's parents, on Brown and George Streets. There were 200 guests present from this city, New-York, and Newport.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 9 -- The season at this resort is gradually and prosperously opening. During the last weeks hundreds of cottages have been opened by families who have come to pass the Summer here. Cottages have been rented during the last few days which for years before have not had tenants.

BERLIN, June 9 -- M. Hanotaux, France's Minister of Foreign Affairs, touched a responsive chord in Germany when he attacked England's policy in Africa before the Chamber of Deputies last Thursday. He stirred the German colonial enthusiasts to fresh discontent and protest against the Anglo-Belgian agreement, and their demand upon the Government for a more aggressive colonial policy has already become loud and impatient.

The Senate sugar schedule postpones the imposition of the new duties until Jan. 1, 1895, and we have shown how this postponement would permit the Sugar Trust to import, possibly, a year's supply of raw material free of duty, and to collect from consumers in the year 1895 the duty of 40 per cent, which the Government needs and ought to have.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent. through the week.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, June 10. -- Advices from Southern Alaska to-day state that the settlers along the coast of North Prince of Wales Sound are alarmed over an Indian uprising. Two unknown white men, who were passing down the coast in an open boat, were assaulted and their bodies badly mutilated.

PITTSBURG, June 9. -- Local securities were less active throughout the week, but prices were well sustained to the close, not alone for stocks, but for bonds. In fact, all changes toward the finish were in the direction of better prices. Money rules easy enough, but the rule of scanning collateral closely is not varied.

ALBANY, June 10. -- The demagogical and ridiculous proposition that no Judge of a court should be allowed to sit as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention, and that the Judges already sitting in the convention should withdraw, provokes a good deal of amusement in this city.

A Cincinnati delegate to the convention held in this city recently by the National Municipal League declared that "the greatest source of political power in large cities" is the authority to license retail liquor dealers. Of this there is not the least doubt, so far as the City of New-York is concerned.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10. -- The last Sunday of the class of 94 at the Military Academy was quietly spent. The cadets, exhausted by the examinations and exercises of last week, gladly availed themselves of the day of rest. At the Catholic and Episcopal Churches religious services were held in the morning.

CONEY ISLAND, June 10. -- Mlle. Beatrice, a lion tamer at West Brighton, had a narrow escape from being killed to-night by a lion. It was Just 10 o'clock, and the inclosure on the pier, where the animals are on exhibition, was crowded.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Coxey, Browne, and Jones, leaders of the Comonweal, were released from jail at 9 o'clock this morning. No demonstration attended their departure. They shook hands with the Deputy Warden and watch officers, thanked them for their considerate treatment, and entered a carriage driven by Oklahoma Sam, and drawn by four Commonweal horses.

AURORA, N. Y., June 10. -- The exercises of the twenty-sixth annual commencement of Wells College began to-night with the baccalaureate sermon by President Frisbee, in the Presbyterian Church at Aurora. The text was from the Epistle to the Phillippians, iv., 8: " Think on these things "; the subject: " The Importance of Right Thinking."

ITHACA, N. Y., June 10. -- Many of the honors for commencement week have already been announced. These members of the senior class have been elected to the Phi Beta Kappa Society: Herbert L. Fordham, Jerome B. Lanfield, Adna F. Weber, John K. Lathrop, Harriet C. Connor, Nellie Hoag, Jessie M. Bunting, and Bertha Howell.

The story that Mr. Taylor narrates in this attractive volume is familiar in the contemporaneous knowledge of many who skill call themselves young. Coincident though many of these events were with our own civil war, Maximilian's ill-starred adventures possessed the power to fix themselves indelibly in the memories of all Americans.
BREWSTERS, N.Y., June 10. -- Bessie and Maggie Blainey, sisters; Thomas Scanlon, and Martin McClusker were drowned this afternoon while boating in Tilly Foster Reservoir.

An explosion which tore off the gable end of the tenement house at 379 South Third Street, Williamsburg, and dropped it on the roof of an adjoining dwelling caused great excitement in that thickly-settled-neighborhood about 7 o'clock last evening.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 10. -- Mr. Andrew S. Draper, who for the last two years has been Superintendent of the Cleveland schools and who has resigned, much to the regret of all who have the interest of the educational system of the city at heart, to accept the Presidency of the State University of Illinois, will enter upon his new duties, for which he is so pre-eminently fitted, with the new collegiate year.

The Rev. Dr. Louis Albert Banks spoke in the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, last evening, on the report of the Grand Jury charging cruelty in the treatment of prisoners detained in the Raymond Street Jail. He said, in part:

There will be eight more days of racing at Morris Park before the horses move down to the track of the Coney Island Jockey Club. The most important of the stakes remaining for decision are the Withers, for three-year-olds, which is down for decision to-morrow, and the Great Eclipse Stakes, for two-year-olds, worth $20,000, which is on for decision a week from to-morrow.

If any other of the men who have been talked of as Republican candidate for Governor had spoken the words which Dr. Chauncey M. Depew spoke to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, they could not be construed as anything else than a declaration that he was in the field for the nomination.
DUBLIN, June 10. -- An old woman who owned half an acre of ground at Nenagh, County of Tipperary, died Friday without leaving a relative or specifying an heir.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The resignation of the Second Assistant Postmaster General, Mr. J. Lowrie Bell, to assume the position of General Traffic Manager of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey is, as you stated in your editorial yesterday, another instance of the extreme difficulty of keeping able men in the Federal service.

In a few days the Brooklyn Bicycle Club will be fifteen years old. It is the oldest wheeling organization in Brooklyn. Growing rapidly in numbers and influence. It is becoming an unusually strong power among the wheelmen. Its members do not pay much attention to racing, but are much interested in tourist wheeling, and some run up remarkably good mileage figures for a season.

It is only proper that there should be no new peerages in the birthday list of honors, for it would be absurd for a party to increase the number of peers that is waging war against the principle of hereditary legislators, and that has discovered by experience that almost everybody who is made a peer by a Liberal Government soon becomes a rabid Tory.

Brooklyn. -- Annie Weiner, fourteen years old, of 29 Crescent Street, while walking under the structure of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, near Cypress Hills Cemetery, yesterday afternoon, was severely burned by a red-hot coal which dropped from one of the locomotives and set fire to her dress. She was taken to St. Mary's Hospital.

The war-over the Fifth Avenue Theatre between H.C.-Miner, the lessee and manager, and the Rosenfeld-Brothers, who hold a contract for filling the time at the house until next Summer is as bitter as ever. The opening of the theatre by the J.C. Duff Opera Company next Thursday night is in no sense a compromise.

The Rev. Newman Manning preached in the Free Baptist Church, in West Twenty-Fifth Street, on "Our Country and Its Perils." Although in this country, he said, greater religious freedom was enjoyed than in any other, still, there was danger from sectarianism. Foreignism was pointed out as another peril. Mr. Manning said:

Among the amendments to the Constitution to be proposed in the convention at Albany that are likely to be seriously considered is one prohibiting the Legislature from creating permanent "commissions" not consisting: of elective officers, and declaring that no public officer or Commissioner shall receive his compensation, or any part of it, from any private individual, association, or corporation.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $1,046,850. The banks now hold $76,918,250 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $410,100, an increase in specie of $1,456,000, a decrease in legal tenders of $1,818,300, a decrease in deposits of $1,258,200, and a decrease in circulation of $30,100.

Slowly, one by one, the school districts in the upper portion of the city are being provided with new schoolhouses. The annexed district has been more fortunate than other portions of the city, inasmuch as several large and commodious modern schoolhouse have been built there within the last four or five years.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 10.--Some curious facts about the senior class at Yale are made public by the issue last week of the annual "class book." It was edited by W. Joseph Tilson of Clear Branch, Tenn., and is the most complete book of its kind over published at Yale. The usual list of reminiscent class histories forms the introduction.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10. -- The perversity with which the Republicans forced to the front a series of bills designed to appeal to the intolerance of the zealots of the State was the predominant feature of the Legislature which has just practically closed its session here. The church and race antagonisms of the people of New-Jersey seem never to die.

It was erroneously announced last week that Bishop Thompson of Tennessee would preach yeaterday in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-flrst Street. In consequence a large congregation attended the services there yesterday morning. In Grace Church. Where Bishop Thompson preached, the attendance was not so large.

The Rev. Dr. R.S. Storrs preached the baccalaureate sermon before the students of Columbia College in the Collegiate Dutch Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, last evening. The church was crowded. Dr. Storrs took his text from Matthew, ill., 33: " Another parable spoke He unto them: The kingdom of heaven is like unto leaven which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal, till the whole was leavened."

The veteran soldiers and sailors of Brooklyn who read the long opinion of Corporation Counsel McDonald, in which he defines the law exempting them from civil service rules for all positions worth $4 or less a day, are very angry with Mr. McDonald. They differ with him in the construction he puts upon the law and they claim that his opinion on the matter is very weak.

Yesterday was one of the few fair Sundays of the late Spring season, with ail conditions favorable for the enjoyment of riding and driving. It was a great day in the parks and on the roads. The morning drive through Central Park and along Seventh Avenue was, as usual, made up principally of members of the road brigade on the way to the Fleetwood and the Suburban Club, with their trotters and light-harness horses.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The minority report of the House Marine Committee condemns in unmeasured terms the Fitian Ship bill granting free admission to American registry of ships built in foreign countries. It starts out by saying:

SUMMIT, N.J., June 10. -- The Casio Club grounds here, where the invitation tennis tournament, in which so many cracks took part, was played this week, are situated in one of the prettiest and most picturesque spots of that part of Summit known as the Hill Crest. Just beyond a gently-rising knoll, over which a winding roadway leads, nestles the little clubhouse.

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date in 1893. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

-- The lectures which Mr. Froude has recently delivered at Oxford on the life and writings of Erasmus will be issued this season in book form by the Messrs. Longmans. It is said that the ladies of Oxford have attended the lectures in such large numbers that undergraduates have found it difficult to secure seats.

The following letter has just been sent to each of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention, on behalf of the committee of the Eleventh Assembly District, New-York: Dear Sir: Permit me to call your attention to four points connected with the woman's suffrage amendment.

At a meeting of the Brooklyn Sunday Observance Association in the Hanson Place Baptist Church two weeks ago yesterday, the Rev. A.C. Dixon stated that a committee from the Brooklyn Temperance League had called on an official high in the administration of Brooklyn and complained that the Sunday excise law was being violated, and that all the saloons in Brooklyn had their side doors open.

The Broadway Traction Company has practically decided upon a system of underground trolley propulsion for its street cars, and will put it in operation on an experimental line of three miles of road in the annexed district. The streets through which it will run have not yet been selected.

-- The high-speed steam launch Daisy, New-York Yacht Club, Mr. S. Nicholson Kane, went into commission Saturday morning from Nyack. She will make a trip to Hyde Park, N.Y. The Daisy has just been fitted with a new safety water-tube boiler of latest design, and she runs much faster now than she ever did before. The Daisy was formerly the noted Henrietta.

No. 17 is the first case down on to-day's calendar of the King's County Supreme Court. It has reference to Convict No. 119-3, who is now seeing a six years' sentence in Sing Sing Prison. The title of the case is Bauer vs. McKane.

This is a year of unusual importance and interest in the politics of the country. Not only will the people elect an entirely new House of Representatives, which portends a possible change in the complexion of the legislative branch of the government, but in almost all the States officers are to be chosen from Governor down.

-- Back to Its Old Field. -- Herrmann's Theatre is a thing of the past, even its name having been blotted out. The building, which has been known as Herrmann's for the last four years, the lease of which was recently sold to Mr. Demarest, has been rented for nest season to Alexander Comstoek. who has christened it St. James's Hall.
The Negro Democratic League of the State of New-York sent out the following to-day: To the Negro Democrats Throughout the State of New-York:

Quite recently the aspirations of certain strong-minded ladies, who proposed to serve their country by enrolling themselves in a Female Volunteer Ambulance Corps, excited the risible faculties of a large portion of the press. But it would really seem now that the laugh was misplaced, and that lovely woman, no longer content to conquer by force of beauty, has determined to assert her supremacy by an appeal to arms.

The frigate Lancaster, which Arrived from China a few days ago, is still at anchor off Clifton, S.I. According to a report which was circulated yesterday, the vessel has been detained there by order of customs officers. It appears that some member of the crew sent an anonymous letter to the customs authorities, asserting that the ship had on board a quantity of opium, China silk, and other dutiable articles.

A veteran seaman now residing at Portland is a promising candidate for the honors of having survived the most epidemics of any man in Maine. When sixteen years old he caught the smallpox and was very sick. Four years later he shipped from Portland for Savannah. There he contracted the swamp fever, and for two Weeks hovered between life and death in a hospital.

Mr. Geoffrey Drage, in the course of a report on Russia, addressed to the Royal Commission on Labor, contributes some interesting details regarding beggars in that country. Thousands of men, women, and children (he says) regularly, set out from their homes with the object of earning their livelihood, not by work, but by begging.
A multitude went to the Central Park yesterday, despite the dog-day's heat, and found a Summer luxuriance of verdure, entertainment, and unhoped-for comfort.

Arrangements for the century run of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey and the Metropolitan Associated Cyclers of this city have now been pretty well settled. The schedule has been corrected since it was first given out, and now reads:
UNIONTOWN, Penn., June 10. -- A battle between seven armed deputies and a mob of 300 strikers occurred this morning at 9 o'clock at the Lemont No. 3 works of the McClure Coke Company.

BERLIN, June 10. -- The Imperial Currency Commission has adjourned and its minutes and speeches are in the hands of the printer. The original intention of the Commissioners was to keep their proceedings secret, but, with the Government's approval, they eventually decided to make all the debates public, and thus forestall the false reports which interested persons might spread.

The death of Emil Haberkorn, an orchestral leader, at Los Angeles, Cal., last Thursday, recalls the romantic story of Margaret Mather, the actress, Mr. Haberkern was Miss Mather's first husband. Se was the musical director tot J.M. Hill, when that manager first introduced Margaret Mather to the public as Juliet at the Union Square Theatre.

-- The game on Saturday between the Staten Island Cricket Club and the New-Jersey Athletic Club demonstrated conclusively the great strength of the Bayonne organization this season. It is conceded that the Staten Island Cricket Club has the next strongest team after the New-Jerseys, and the easy manner in which they were vanquished leaves little hope for the other teams which will have to meet the champions this year.

A good many New-York saloon keepers have destroyed their diaries since the Lexow Committee came to town. There are some left, however. Those who still cling to these interesting little memorandum books made an entry therein yesterday to the effect that it was the worst Sunday for side doors in the history of the retail liquor business.

The fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the Young Men's Christian Association was celebrated yesterday afternoon by a "Jubilee Day" in Association Hall, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. The branches of the association in the city were represented by delegations.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., June 10. -- One of the most remarkable timber belts in the world stands in Humboldt and Mendocino Counties of this State. It embraces 4,125 square miles, containing 132,000,000,000 feet of timber. With the aid of the microscope, scientists have found the age of some of those trees to be nearly 3,000 years.
HELENA, Mon., June 10. -- Reports from points west of this city, on the Northern Pacific and Union Pacific Railways, received to-day, indicate a bad condition of affairs owing to high water.

The Lexow committee will continue its investigations of the Police Department to-morrow morning. During the two days since the last session a great deal of work has been done by the attorneys who bring on the witnesses, and the line of inquiry followed last week is to be pursued still further.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Gen. Daniel E. Sickles of New-York stumped into the Senate Chamber a few days ago, dropped into a seat in the rear row, and rested his crutches against his one knee. Gen. Gordon of Georgia paused to shake hands with the veteran, and Gen. Falmer of Illinois also joined them.
PRINCETON, N. J, June 10. -- Prof. William Libbey, Jr., has just completed the furnishing of a room in the museum in Nassau Hall with the exhibits returned from the World's Fair.

It will be ten weeks to-morrow since the fourth draft of the Senate Tariff bill was laid before that body. It provided that the law should take effect at the close of the fiscal year, June 30, which gave nearly three months for its passage through the Senate and final action in the House. What probability there is that the bill can be completed in that time any one can judge.

-- The thirty-fifth anniversary of the episcopate of Bishop Henry Benjamin Whipple was celebrated at the thirty-seventh annual session of the Diocesan Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church in Minnesota, which was held last week in St. Paul. In a discourse rapidly reviewing his work the Bishop urged that the diocesa should have another Bishop, as it is now too large for one satisfactorily to discharge its duties.
VICTORIA, B.C., June 11. -- The following advices have been received by the steamer Arawa, from the United Press representative at Honolulu, dated June 3:

There was an extra feature at the Wild West Show at Ambrose Park, South Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, that might have distracted the attention of the spectators from the brilliant cavalrymen, bucking bronchos, and even the crooning squaws. If they had known it. But they did not, and reviewed the big show with the usual enthusiasm, and went home quite unconscious that right among them had sat three boxes full of New-York newspaper women.

The news yesterday favored the bears, and they were not slow in taking advantage of it. The Government crop report, which was issued on Saturday, made such a favorable showing that its accuracy was seriously called into question. There is no doubt about its being in conflict with the State reports, but again, on the other hand, it receives confirmation from independent sources which are usually not far astray.
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Lieut. Ackerman of the Bureau of Ordnance continued his statements relative to his investigation of the alleged armor-plate frauds before the House Naval Committee to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., June 11. -- The Supreme Court, through Chief Justice Beasley, today decided that women had no right to vote in New-Jersey, and that wherever they exercised the right of suffrage it was an illegal assumption of power.

Prof. David Burnet Scott, A. M., Ph. D., who occupied the Chair pf English Literature, Rhetoric, and Belles-Lettres in the College of the City of New-York, died on Sunday just before midnight, at his home, 112 West One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, of bronchitis. He had been connected with the public school system of NewYork City from its beginning, nearly half a century ago.

Summer weather is here. Like that dawn told of by the Ancient Mariner, it came at one stride. Sunday the weather was pleasant enough to satisfy the most fastidious. Yesterday it quit being pleasant and became outrageously warm. The mercury swelled up to its midsummer mark and kept there during the noonday hours.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- If any one had predicted this morning that the Senate would dispose of eighteen pages of the Tariff bill to-day, including the spirits and cotton schedules, he would have been laughed at. But that is precisely what the Senate accomplished, much to its own surprise.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 11. -- The liveliest meeting of the Ashland District campaign was held this afternoon. Between 5,000 and 6,000 strangers were in the city when the speaking began at 2 o'clock.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 11.--The report of the Scale Committee was adopted unanimously by the conference of the miners and operators at 10 o'clock to-night, and the conference adjourned.

No man can undertake to forecast, even approximately, the effect of the elections of next Fall upon the National House of Representatives. There is a common impression that the reaction against the Democratic Party which appeared in the State elections of last year will continue and will swing the House of Representatives strongly around, but there is a chance for a good deal of miscalculation in this matter.

It was on Saturday, the 2d inst., that Senator John Sherman and Senator Aldrich asserted repeatedly that there was no Sugar Trust in 1890, when the McKinley Tariff bill, with its great bonus to the Trust, was made and passed, and that there were no certificates or shares of any Sugar Trust on the market in that year.

At the regular meeting of the New-York Presbytery yesterday, in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church, on Fifth Avenue, near Eleventh Street, the Moderator, the Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield, pastor of the church, presided.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 11. -- Attorney General Hancock has received an application from the local authorities of Gravesend to bring an action in the Supreme Court to have the law annexing Gravesend to Brooklyn declared unconstitutional and set aside. Papers in the case were filed in the Attorney General's department by Andrew G. Cropsey of New-York, as attorney, a day or two ago.
Our neighbor The Tribune said on the 7th inst., in an editorial article concerning the Senate's sugar schedule:

The reform Board of Aldermen of Brooklyn, at their meeting yesterday afternoon, granted two valuable franchises to electric light companies and then bickered among themselves for an hour over the adoption of a resolution appropriating $100 for a national salute to be fired at that historic spot, Fort Greene, on the morning of Independence Day.

BOSTON, June 11. -- our market remains as inactive as for some time past, the telephone stocks, outside of the arbitrage stocks, taking the lead in activity. American Bell is up to 201 on rates of (58 shares, with Erie inclined to weakness on nominal transactions. The bidding for New-England Telephone still continues, but there is apparently very little for sale.
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The session of the Senatorial Sugar Trust investigators to-day was devoid of any sensational developments, but action of interest was taken by the committee in two cases.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, at their meeting yesterday, adopted, on motion of Mayor Schieren, a resolution ordering that after July 1 two bridge tickets be sold for 5 cents. This is at the same rate now asked for packages of ten.

It was with fear and trembling that the Giants faced the Louisvilles yesterday. The players from the State of Colonels have not been putting up a remarkably strong game of ball since they left home, but it was just about time for them to make a spurt and win a game. Hence the fears of the Giants.

The contest yesterday at Eastern Park between the Brooklyn and Cincinnati Clubs was marked by good batting. Both Dwyer and Stein were hit hard, home runs, three-baggers, and doubles being plentiful. Brooklyn at one stage led the men from the Rhine by 7 runs, but the latter played a remarkably strong up-hill game, and, by vigorous stick work in the latter part of the contest, came uncomfortably close to the Bridegrooms.

The all-around championship of the Amateur Athletic Union that will be held July 4 promises to be a very interesting event owing to the fact that each contestant will receive credit for his performances, and there will be no disqualifications. A great many prominent men, will compete who are specialists in their line, and they are in hopes that their percentages will be so high in the few events that they can hope for victory.

Twenty-two years ago, when Buddensiek began his building operations, which finally landed him in Sing Sing, he obtained, a loan of $10,000 with which he put up a five-story brick tenement with store at 288 Front Street. Yesterday this property was put up for sale under foreclosure of mortgage by Messrs, Smyth Ryan in the Trinity Building Salesroom.

There will be an addition to the army of racing cyclers shortly. Howard Mosher of Storm King, N.Y., the champion quarter-mile amateur skater of America, who has been, riding a roadster for a few seasons, has trained for racing, and feels confident that he can hold his end up with the best men in either class.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin to-day directed the detaching of Lieut. McLellan, in charge of the Life-Saving Service on the coast of New-Jersey, and his assignment to duty on the revenue cutter Forwood, at Mobile, Ala.
LONDON, June 11. -- A dispatch from TienTsin says it is reported that the Corean rebels are disappearing, having been warned of the approach of an overwhelming body of Imperial troops.
The handicap tennis tournament of the New-York Tennis Club is rapidly nearing its end. One more set will decide the doubles, and the consolation singles will be played off by Wednesday.

The heat did not serve to keep people away from Morris Park yesterday afternoon, though, thanks mainly to the wretched mismanagement of affairs on the elevated road system, it is a trip attended with as much discomfort as any that can possibly be imagined. No extra trains or cars are cut on the Second Avenue line, over which the bulk of the travel goes at double fare.

Horace F. Burroughs, "commission merchant and wholesale lumber dealer," of 136 Water Street, was before Judge Fitzgerald yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, on the order to show cause why the indictments against him for forgery and grand larceny, should not be dismissed.
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- If everything shall go well, the Navy Department will come into possession to-morrow of $1,200,000.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Representative Geary or California made an argument this morning before the House Pacific Railways Committee in relation to the indebtedness of the Central Pacific Railway Company to the Government. He thought it unfair for the Government to pursue the California stockholders of this road, when the Oakes Ames estate and other stockholders of the Union Pacific had not been proceeded against.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- During most of the day the local market was very dull, the dearth of commission orders either way being apparent. Later, however, the traders seemed to take on a little courage and bid the market up. Reading seemed especially scarce, and an attempt to buy the stock advanced the price very quickly to the equivalent of 17 3/4 on comparatively light transactions.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 11. -- All was bustle and confusion in and around barraoks to-day. Trunks and boxes war hauled out of the storerooms and the work of packing was begun. White-trousered cadets laden down with packages of every description crossed and recrossed the area. The bulletin board in the guardhouse was filled with notices requesting book borrowers to return their loans.

According to the latest reports from Honolulu, the new Hawaiian Constitution has been "promulgates." As no provision was made for submitting it to a popular vote for ratification, it presumably takes effect at once, and the new Government will be constituted under it as soon as the elections for which it provides have been duly held.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: The United States of America is greater than any religion.

The Atlas Line steamship Andes, which arrived in port yesterday from Port Limon, made a very unprofitable voyage. The vessel had on board a cargo of 18,000 bunches of bananas, valued at $20,000. Shortly after the steamship was docked, Bayard C. Fuller. Fruit Inspector of the Health Department, went on board the vessel and found that the bananas were unfit for use.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- The opening in wheat today was anywhere from 3/4c to 1 1/8c under Saturday's official close, and to-day's close, as compared with that day's last prices, was 1/2c better. The Government's monthly concentration of statistics continues to exercise less influence with each appearance, and the question of its correctness, as well as its demoralizing effect, becomes the theme of widespread gossip on each recurring 10th of the month.

Erastus Willian was put on trial yesterday before Judge Ingraham, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, on the charge of having forced the signature of E.W. Bullinger to a check for $5,000, and the signature of Ogden Brower to a check for $5,580.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

There is one lesson to be learned from the sessions of the Lexow committee that ought not to be lost. It is that the law can be enforced in this city whenever the police finds it more profitable to enforce it than to take money for not enforcing it. Last Sunday, for instance, was a dry Sunday.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- The appeal of Grand Chief Arthur of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and leaders of the other railway labor organizations against the now celebrated order of Judge Jenkins in the Northern Pacific case denying to the organizations concerned the right to strike and enjoining them from any concerted action to that end, was the special order in the United States Court of Appeals this morning.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11. -- The Vassar commencement concert was given this evening in the college chapel Nearly 100 alumnae were among the guests. It is expected that 200 will be here before the alumnae dinner to-morrow noon.

-- At the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday the Commissioner of Public Works was directed to asphalt Thirty-ninth Street from Madison to Park Avenue, at a cost of $5,250. Street Cleaning Commissioner Andrews asked the approval of the board in purchasing an electrozone plant for Riker's Island, to cost $37,000.

The question whether there shall be a straight Republican ticket in the local campaign this Fall was brought into the deliberations of the regular Republican County Committee at its meeting in Shepard Hall last night.

Capt. James K. Price, commanding the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station, was placed on trial before Police Commissioners Martin, Sheehan, and Murray yesterday on a charge of having failed to suppress an alleged gambling house at 345 West Thirty-first Street. The charge was formally made by Superintendent Byrnes.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- President Cleveland has at times been severely criticised by anxious and perhaps overzealous friends of civil service reform for expressions of impatience at the methods chosen by some of the advocates of the reform to impress the importance of their cause upon the people.

The twenty-fifth annual regatta of the Pavonia Yacht Club will be sailed next Monday. Yachts of the following clubs are invited to participate: New-York, Brooklyn, Atlantic, Seawanhaka, Knickerbocker, Larchmont, New-Rochelle, American, Marine and Field, Corinthian, Cedar Point, Riverside, Indian Harbor, Douglaston, Sewaren, and the clubs composing the New-York Yacht Racing Association.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- The week opened very quietly and with a market, almost devoid of public interest. There has been a liberal liquidation in West Chicago stock by parties who had accumulated around 144@145 and some operators who had sold around the latter figures last week recovered the stock to-day at 139 5/8@140.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- The class day exercises of the graduating class occupied the third day in the commencement week at Princeton College. The day began with the annual gymnastic exhibition. Following is the programme:

The Assembly district organizations of the New-York State Democracy met in most of the thirty Assembly districts last night, and formally organized by electing a Chairman, Vice Chairman, Secretary, and Treasurer in each district. Some of them also elected members to the County Committee, the basis of representation being one member for each hundred voters or fraction of a hundred over fifty cast for the Democratic ticket at the last Presidential election.

The Columbia Yacht Club, whose comfortable and cozy clubhouse lies at the root of West Eightieth Street, expects to have one of the most successful seasons in its history this coming Summer. A number of able members have recently been added, among them being W.J. Arkell; the fleet has been increased by several new boats, and the future of the club looks more prosperous than ever before.

-- The case of Catherine Bauer and her daughter, Kate, to compel John Y. McKane to make an accounting as trustee of the estate of the late Paul Bauer, came up in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday, but owing to the Illness of John B. Meyenborg, the case was postponed until the first Monday in July.

"The Macedonian had his phalanx; Caesar had his favorite legion, Napoleon had his Old Guard, but none were more trustworthy or would stay by their friends any longer than the John J. O'Brien Association will stay by its leader."

The Board of Supervisors of Kings County met in regular session in the Supervisors' Room, in the Court House in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. Supervisor at Large Fitchie presided, and announced that he had vetoed the resolution passed at a previous meeting to enter into a contract for telephones for the Department of Charities and Correction.

The London Tablet, a well-known Catholic paper of England, on April 28 last published a story in which it was said that Mgr. Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate, and the Rev. Dr. McGlynn had fallen out, and that Dr. Burtsell had been summoned to Rome by the Pope to explain his relation to the McGlynn case.

We have already had occasion to call attention to the ambitious and forth-putting character of Mr. W.F. Sheehan's Superintendent of Public Instruction, Mr. J.F. Crooker. The services by which any person commended himself to Sheehan as a suitable Superintendent of Public Instruction were, it is needless to say, rather political than pedagogical.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 11. -- A case of smallpox was discovered in the home of a family named Goodman, residing just outside this village, a few days ago. The patient was a four-year-old child, and, by direction of Dr. William H. Zabriski, Health Officer, the entire household was removed to a temporary pesthouse, a flimsy structure, built in 1892 by the town at Brookville, a small place five miles from here.
LONDON, June 11. -- The athlatic contests between the Yale and Oxford University teams will take place on the Queen's Club grounds, at Kensington, on July 16.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

AUGUSTA, Kan., June 11. -- The Walnut River is out of its banks and enormous damage has been done to crops. Wheat in the shock was swept down the stream, and that not harvested has been ruined. Fences and buildings have been washed away, and for more than a mile the St. Louis and San Francisco track is under water, and the transfer bridgre has been taken out six miles north, stopping traffic.

The old painter, Federico Madrazo, died yesterday at Madrid, where he had been for many years at the head of the Royal Academy. His fame in Europe was at one time great, but it was eclipsed by that of Fortuny, who became the typical Spanish painter, and it paled further under the ascendency of the star of his son, Raimondo Madrazo, whose oils and water colors are well known in the United States.

The sale of thoroughbred yearlings, the property of J.B. Clay, George H. Clay, T.C. McDowell, M.D. Richardson, P.P. Johnston, and Matt Simpson, at the American Horse Exchange last evening was well attended, and twenty-nine head were sold for $8,200. A brother to Hurlingham was offered, but as a reserve price of $2,500 had been placed upon him, and as this was not given, he was withdrawn.

Good Government Club F had a formal meeting and housewarming last night in its new quarters, at 524 Hudson Street. About half of the 400 members were present. Ex-Mayor Hewitt was expected to make an address, but he was unable to be present and sent the following letter, which was read by Alfred R. Conkling, who presided:
NEW-HAVEN, June 11. -- Yale has decided by a unanimous vote to send an athletic team to England to compete with Oxford in July.
