-- The Knickerbocker Yacht Club's annual regatta will be sailed Saturday, June 16. The start will be off the clubhouse at College Point at 11 A.M. There will be eight classes -- one for schooners, three for sloops, and two each for open and cabin catboats. Prizes will be given in all classes. The steamboat Laura M. Starin will accompany the yachts over the course.

LONDON, June 11. -- The reception given on board the United States cruiser Chicago, at Gravesend, to-day, was largely attended, and altogether a brilliant affair, in spite of the rainy weather which prevailed most of the day. The spar deck of the ship was covered with a canopy, and decorated with flags of all nations, those of the United States and Great Britain spanning the vessel amidships.
The Senate committee which is investigating the affairs of the Police Department in this city will resume its work in the Court House this forenoon.

LONDON, June 11. -- Advices received here report that the Sultan of Morocco died on June 7, and that the army proclaimed his son, Mulai Abdul, his successor. Private advices say that' the Sultan was murdered.

The six depots established through the philanthropy of Nathan Straus for the sale of milk, both raw and sterilized, and powdered barley, for food for the children of the poor, were opened yesterday, and were crowded by women and children. The depots are at the foot of East Third Street, 317 East Ninth Street, 147 Eldridge Street, 22 Market Street, 201 West Sixty-third Street, and 324 East Fifty-ninth Street.
The warm weather yesterday did not prevent the Senate committee which is investigating the affairs of the Police Department in this city from continuing its vigorous and remarkable investigation.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 12 -- George Peabody Wetmore to-day received the unanimous vote, of the Rhode Island Legislature for the office of United States Senator.

Fully 2,000 people gathered in the new armory of the Thirteenth Regiment in Brooklyn last night to take part in the inaugural arrangements for what is expected will be the largest fair ever held in Brooklyn.

The Committee on Contested Seats of the State Constitutional, Convention met in the City Hall, Brooklyn, at 10 A.M. yesterday. C.C. Lester presided. The principal witness examined was Assistant Attorney General Edward M. Shepard, who testified regarding the Gravesend election frauds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- Pennsylvania defeated Princeton in the eighth inning to-day by scoring 13 runs. Hizrot, the Tigers' pitcher, gave ten bases on balls in this inning and was hit rather freely. Altman had pitched for Princeton up to the eighth inning. Attendance, 3,000.

We directed attention two or three days ago to the fact that in the Senate's sugar schedule the additional duty of 10 cents per hundred pounds upon sugars coming from countries which pay an export bounty is to be imposed upon all raw sugars, as well as refined sugars, while the similar discriminating duty in the MeKinley tariff is carefully limited in its application to refined sugars.
Michael Angelo Maniero, employed by Rocco Verrille, a saloon keeper and banker, at 193 Hester Street, died in the street early yesterday morning under suspicious circumstances.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The weekly telegraphic crop reports received by the Agricultural Department as made public to-day show the following results by States:

The New-York Tennis Club continued its club handicap tournament yesterday afternoon. Only three matches were played, as the contests are nearly completed. By winning another set from Taylor and Cragin, Smith and Howard clinched things in the final of the doubles. Millett beat Frederick very easily in the consolation singles, and will probably face Byrne in the finals in that contest.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Mr. Henry O. Havemeyer, President of the American Sugar Refining Company, was the only witness examined to-day by the Sugar Trust investigators. He caused some astonishment among the members of the committee by his statement that he had never seen President Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- Mr. Isaac L. Rice to-day scored against the receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, and in so doing once more placed the security holders of the company under obligation to his energetic watchfulness. By his prompt action he has prevented a charge of $3,000,000 being placed ahead of the general and income mortgages.

-- State Bank Examiner A.C. Judson and Several clerks of the Plaza Bank were witnesses before the Grand Jury yesterday in the matter of the Harlem River Bank defalcation. John Joseph Kean, the cashier, has disappeared, and as his wife's father is a French Canadian and lives in Canada, it is believed that Kean has gone there.

ALBANY, June 12 -- At the request of Controller Roberts and to cover recent appointments of veterans in the Controller's Department. Attorney General Hancock today submitted a review and opinion concerning the State civil service laws affecting veterans, in which, after reviewing legislation giving preference to veterans of the civil war, he says:

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12 -- This day of commencement week was taken up with the graduating exercises of the John C. Green School of Science, the meeting of the National Princeton Alumni Association, and the alumni banquet.

The best attended of yesterday's auction sales of real estate in the Trinity Building salesroom was that of Mr. James L. Wells, who offered forty-two lots in the Twenty-third Ward, belonging to the Union Railway Company. The bidding was poor and the prices obtained were only fair. Thirteen lots in all were sold at auction, but a similar number were sold privately.

-- Salaries Likely to Tumble -- The actors and actresses who throng Broadway express a good deal of surprise at the backwardness of managers in making engagements for next season. In the past the best people have been snapped up almost before they returned from their tours, but it is not so this year. Managers, as a rule, show no eagerness to secure people for next season. This is due to two causes.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the, day.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Representative Maguire of California, the proposer of the bills to make extensive changes in the shipping laws, was to have made an argument this morning before the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries to support his bills. At 10 o'clock the committee was ready to hear him, but Mr. Maguire was not present.
Mrs. Fannie Falkenberg died early yesterday morning at her home, 204 East Thirty-ninth Street, at the age of nearly 103 years.

The Kings County Board of Estimate yesterday continued its pruning of departmental appropriations for the coming year. President Simis of the Board of Charities asked for $394,000 for the support of county wards, but, on Commissioner White's claim that the number of wards could be reduced, the appropriation was fixed at $320,000.
The Council of Confederated Good Government Clubs, at its meeting yesterday, adopted the following resolutions:

ALBANY, N.Y., June 12 -- The Ne-Ha-Sa-Ne Park Association of Poland, Herkimer County, formed with a capital of $400,000 to acquire Adirondack wild lands in the Counties of Herkimer, Hamilton, St. Lawrence, and Franklin, to preserve the forests and protect wild animals and fish, sell timber, , was incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 12 -- The scale agreement at Columbus has only shifted the ground of the coal miners' 'strike, instead of settling it. The miners assert that they will not accept fee terms agreed upon, and are an revolt against their officers.

LONDON, June 12 -- The steamship Faraday sailed from Messrs. Siemens Brothers' works at Woolwich at 7:30 o'clock this evening, having on board 1,600 miles of the Commercial Cable Company's new cable. She will proceed to a point 150 miles off the Irish coast, where she will splice on to the shore end, already laid.

A small crop of Republican candidates for Lieutenant Governor is beginning to spring up under the hot June sun. By this is meant a crop which is being grown for the second place on the ticket, without any reference to the first place.

Here and There -- Mrs. Elliot F. Shepard and family and Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart are among the prominent society people who will sail on the Majestic to-day. Mrs. Dunlap Hopkins will spend the Summer at Sharon, Conn. Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Kelly, Jr., will sail for Europe on the Majestic to-day. After the Suburban Handicap, Mr. and Mrs. Ward McAllister and Miss McAllister will occupy the Lyman cottage at Newport.

The Constitutional Convention's sub-committees on Charities and on Education were industrious yesterday in endeavoring to understand the questions covered by the amendment introduced by the League for the Protection of American Institutions, which would prohibit the State from giving money to private sectarian charitable institutions.

TRENTON, N.J., June 12 -- The marriage of Miss Sari Stretch Eayre, a cousin of Mrs. George W. Childs Drexel, to Francis Bayley. Lee took place at noon to-day in Trinity Church at Vincentown. The Rev. Lewis H. Lighthipe, rector of the Protestant Episcopal church, at Woodbridge, N.J., officiated, assisted by the Rev. Henry M. Barbour of Trinity Church, Trenton.

Mrs. E.B. Grannis, who is in constant correspondence with Gideon J. Tucker of the State Constitutional Convention at Albany, has received word from the veteran cavalier of the woman suffragists to send to the convention more signatures to the petitions for equal suffrage.

WEST POINT, June 12 -- The cadets of the class of '94 received their diplomas today. Previous to the distribution of the parchments an unusual amount of bustle and excitement was visible around barracks. Agents from railroad and steamboat companies checked trunks and saw that boxes were properly secured before shipping.

Brooklyn. -- Alderman Frank Hennessy of the Sixth Ward will be put on trial on June 25 for violating the election law last November, and his trial will be followed by the trials of a number of other offenders of the same character. Alderman Hennessy is accused of electioneering within a polling place.

WEST POINT, June 12 -- One of the most romantic marriages that have happened in this section took place to-day in the Church of the Sacred Heart, at Highland Falls, immediately after the graduation exercises were over.

The Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, who was for twelve years pastor of the West Presbyterian Church in West Forty-second Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, and who resigned his pastorate on Nov. 12, 1893, returned to New-York last night and is at the Windsor Hotel. With him are Mrs. Paxton and Miss Paxton.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 12 -- A man giving his name as Franz J. Anton-Phillip was arrested to-day while attempting to jump in front of a passenger train near the Chapel Street bridge with suicidal intentions. He was taken to the police station, where he said that he was a stock broker living at 16 Stuyvesant Park, New-York, and that he was connected with C.A. Harned Co., Mills Building.

W.S. Andrews, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, has executed a contract for trimming scows for one year with Pasquale Caponigri, who has agreed to pay the city $1,760 a week for that privilege, besides furnishing all the labor and material necessary for doing the work under the terms of the contract.

Erastus Wiman's trial on the charge of forgery in the second degree, was begun in earnest yesterday before Justice Ingraham in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Assistant District Attorney Wellman opened for the prosecution as soon as the Judge took his seat, and when he concluded, he inarched out his witnesses one after the other as fast as he could crowd them along.

Permission has been granted by Judge Jenkins of the United States court in Wisconsin to the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad to accept the one-million-dollar loan which was offered to the Reorganization Committee to pay interest due on first mortgage bonds July 10.

Mrs. Elizabeth Frances Evanhoe the divorced wife of Detective Sergeant Frank Evanhoe of Inspector McLaughlin's staff, of Brooklyn, turned up yesterday in the Lee Avenue Civil Court, in Williamsburg, as the widow of John C. Leahey, who was supposed to have been a bachelor, and who was accidentally killed by falling from the steps of his house, 71 North Second Street, Brooklyn, on the night of Aug. 8, 1893.

AURORA, N.Y., June 12 -- Class Day exercises at Wells College were held this afternoon. The decorations of Music Hall were in lavender, purple, and white. The background of the stage was formed in lavender, upon which was placed in purple letters "Per aspera ad astra." The front of the stage was banked with pansies and ferns.

The yachtsmen of the "Williamsburg, Club held their annual regatta yesterday. The yachts started to sail from North Beach to Sands Point and back, but had a hard time of it. By sunset only three of the thirty-seven starters had finished. The steamer Bay Queen was crowded with the friends of the yachtsmen, and they expected to see two exciting races, but they went home disappointed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- There was a disposition, to bid up stocks to-day, but the volume of business was still restricted, Reading sold-up to the equivalent of 17 5/8, and a line of long stock was closed out at about that figure, on which a moderate turn had been made. The Rice-Hartshorne party were reported as having blocked the Reading subway, at least as far as the receivers are concerned.

Members of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association were in session at the Hotel Waldorf yesterday for the purpose of arranging a plan of action for the annual convention of the association, which begins to-day. The association is composed of all the railroad and steamship lines operating south of the Potomac River and east of the Mississippi.

A matter of considerable interest to the residents of the upper portion of the city in particular, and to all residents of and visitors to the city, came prominently forward yesterday through the application made to the Board of Aldermen by the Metropolitan Traction Company.

Capt. Pfeffer and his fellow-members of the Louisville team are just now suffering from an aggravated attack of hard luck. They play a grand fielding game, take all chances on the bases, and bat hard, but all their powerful drives appear to go straight into fielders' -hands. Several times yesterday they looked as though they would have a profitable inning, but two double plays and clever work by Murphy and Doyle ruined all their chances.

The local politicians on the Republican side secretly hope that Mr. Croker will find it advantageous to remain away from New-York during the Fall campaign. They know that he is a hard worker during a campaign, for they had many evidences of it during the Fall of 1892. when the Presidency was at stake. Mr. Croker made many friends in that campaign.

-- Dr. Seymour Haden, the etcher, is personally known to many Americans, and by his etchings is known to every one. Admirers of his work will be glad to hear that his talents have been recognized in his own country and that he is now Sir Seymour Haden, while Mrs. Haden is now by courtesy Lady Seymour Haden.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- The open lawn tennis tournament for the championship of the United States in ladles' singles and doubles and mixed doubles was started to-day on the grounds of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, at Wissahickon Heights. The weather was all that could be desired, both for players and spectators., friendly clouds hiding the sun all day.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Harvey process of treating armor is not a failure. The ordnance experts to-day attended a test of one of the heaviest armor plates ever made in this country, at Indian Head Naval Proving Grounds.

A party of gentlemen on Monday last fell to discussing the merits of Frank Work's great teams, Edward and Dick Swiveller and Mahala and Sea Girl, the latter pair being a recent purchase. Mr. Work said that two such teams could not be got together in the world. He became quite enthusiastic over Mahala, who has a face record of 2:19 3/4, and Sea Girl, with a race record of 2:18 1/4.
TANGIER, June 12 -- The burial of the late Sultan Muley Hassen will take place at Rabat, whither the body has been sent under military escort.

TRENTON, N.J., June 12 -- The handiwork of Trenton's skilled labor and the hospitality of Trenton manufacturers were today shown to a party of twenty-two architects and sanitary engineers from New-York City. They were brought to Trenton for the purpose of having them see the character and manner of construction of American sanitary ware.

-- The National Union Bank, at 32 Nassau Street, which has been in existence a little over a year, and of which Congressman Joseph C. Hendrix is President, has made application to be admitted to membership in the New-York Clearing House. The bank has been examined by the Committee on Admissions and will doubtless be admitted at the next meeting of the Association.

From early morning until late in the evening Yesterday there was an exciting stir and bustle in the big brick building at One Hundred and Sixty-third Street and Eleventh Avenue. The New-York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb was holding its commencement exercises.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Tariff bill wag side-tracked to-day in order to give Mr. Quay an opportunity to unload the seventh installment of his statistical work on the tariff.

The A.P.A. -- the American Prescriptive Association, as it is now more generally called -- has reached Brooklyn, has opened a headquarters there, and is engaged in the secret attempt to make proselytes to its cause. Although of a professed political nature, the A.P.A., notwithstanding its boast of its adherence to and typical exemplification of American institutions, is going about its work in Brooklyn with extraordinary caution and privacy.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- There was plenty of business and plenty of news in the wheat market to-day. The weather was however, the predominating factor, other items not having a great deal to do with the formation of the tone, but assisting in a secondary manner. Complaints were thick as the harm that was resulting from insufficient moisture in the Northwest and South-west.

-- One of the star men at the Washington Wheelmen is G.W. Davison, the winner for New-York of the last relay in The New-York Times's tri-State race to Philadelphia, Last Saturday, riding from scratch in the two-mile handicap race given by the Westchester Cycling League, he finished second in the good time of 5:11. Stevens of the Yonkers Bicycling Club starting from the eighty-five-seconds mark, finishing first in 6:20.

BOSTON, June 12 -- Telephone stocks absorbed attention to-day. Bell gained 1 1/2 points, to 202 1/2 on the prospect that the bill in the Legislature to increase its capital will become a law in its present form. Erie runs counter to the current, spiling at 46 1/3, 7/8 off from last night's close. New-York and New-Haven was again active to-day for such a high-priced stock.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. Jere Johnson., Jr., sold, to George A. Gardiner, at $3,050, the two-story frame dwelling 844 Monroe Street, near Ralph Avenue, 22.2 1/4 by 100. He also sold a number of lots at Bay Ridge, at prices varying from $130 to $750 each.
The following account of a shipwreck, rescue, subsequent disaster and final salvation is given by Mr. A.W. Burch, of Rome, N.Y. It is exceedingly graphic and will be found most interesting.

After a spell of success and prosperity the Brooklyn's lost yesterday to the Cincinnati Club. The latter won by hard and opportune hitting. Both teams played a strong game in the field. Gastright was an easy mark for the visiting batsmen, who made thirteen hits for a total of twenty-one bases and earned all of their runs. Elton Chamberlain, who was in the box for the visitors, managed to keep the hits well scattered.

The lawless and unconstitutional organization known as the A.P.A., and described by The New-York Times as the American Proscriptive Association, is scattering its poisonous and lying literature broadcast through the State of New-York, bearing false witness against its neighbors and seeking to fan the embers of bigotry into a destructive flame.

The First Naval Battalion Dramatic Association last evening entertained its friends and those of the Naval Reserve on board the New-Hampshire with a most entertaining production of "Pinafore." It had been rewritten, and was fully up to date. The characters were well enacted, and the singing met with the hearty approval of the 300 invited guests.

BOSTON, June 12 -- There was a chilly reception for the harness racers at Saugus this afternoon, when the first meeting of the New-England Circuit began over Old Franklin course. The track had been heavily watered last night in anticipation of another blazing hot day, and the sudden change kept it from drying, As a result the footing was soft and the miles slow.

ALBANY, June 12 -- A week from Wednesday, June 20, promises to be the banner day of the Constitutional Convention up to date. Two great hearings will take place -- the arguments of Col. George Bliss and of Frederic R. Coudert before the joint committees in favor of permitting Catholic institutions to participate in the distribution of State funds, and the hearings on the various canal amendments to the Constitution.

ALBANY, June 12 -- The Cities Committee of the Constitutional Convention listened to some interesting arguments this afternoon from the committee of twenty-one appointed by the various organizations interested in municipal reform, including the Municipal Reform Clubs of the different cities of the State, and the City Reform and City Clubs of New-York.

The tennis players of the New-York Athletic Club have nearly finished their annual Spring handicap tournament. The deciding game in the singles, the only one remaining unplayed, will be contested by Gillett and Fish at Travers Island some day this week. The summary is:

Influences were clearly at work in the Stock market yesterday for a higher range of prices than has lately prevailed. The result did not appear in uniform advances bat in irregular changes which showed the clash of opposing forces. Each element in the market secured some advantages, but. those of the bears were slight and unimportant, while the other side made substantial headway.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 12 -- The feature of the commencement exercises of the University of Virginia to-day was the address of Chauhcey M. Depew of New-York.

Wall Street is interested in the announcement that the house of Spencer Trask Co., which has successfully promoted electric-lighting companies in this city and Brooklyn, has completed negotiations by which its friends will have the practical management of the Cleveland General Electric Company.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning, consists of TEN PAGES. It contains:

We should like to know whether the Senators of both parties who are responsible for the shameless bargain just carried out in the Senate realize what a tremendous argument they have been putting in the hands of the so-called Populists in their mad attack upon property and upon the principles of legislation that form the basis of property in all civilized nations.

The Park Commissioners have experienced another change of feeling in regard to the way what is left of the $1,000,000 given to them by the Legislature is to be spent. Last week they decided that they would discharge all the men employed by the day, and spend the rest of the money -- $600,000 or more -- by letting out the work to contractors.

Anson M. Stratton, who was formerly the so-called Republican executive member from Gravesend of the Republican General Committee, still maintains that there was no fraud at the election in Gravesend last Fall.

TRENTON, N.J., June 13. -- Attorney General Stockton this afternoon submitted to State School Superintendent Poland an opinion that women can vote at school meetings, notwithstanding the Chief Justice's opinion delivered in the Bergen County Road Overseer contest case, which generally had been interpreted as denying to women the right to vote at any election.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Tariff bill is still far from complete, and the members of the revision committee are engaged daily in the effort to smooth out difficulties which have arisen since the bill was reported last to the Senate.

The Council of the Confederated Good Government Clubs of this city has declared that the "only method of obtaining the united support of all good citizens opposed to Tammany Hall is the nomination of a municipal ticket outside of the national organizations, by those organizations whose sole aim is municipal reform, the candidates on that ticket to be selected for their fitness and without regard to national party affiliations."

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 13. -- At a mass meeting of miners this afternoon at Ten Mile Inn, near Camden, sixteen pits out of a total of twenty-one in the first and second pools of the Monongahela River, and those controlled by Brown Co., in the Youghiogheny Valley, being represented. It was the unanimous decision that the new scale was unsatisfactory, and that the demand for the 70-cent rate be further prosecuted.

ALBANY, June 13. -- After a debate which lasted two hours, the Constitutional Convention this morning accepted the report of the Judiciary Committee, which had reported in favor of abolishing the printing of the debates in The Albany Argus and The Evening Journal. The Albany printing ring, through its agents, made a stubborn fight, and at one time the result seemed to be in doubt.

New-York's horsemen seem to fare as badly in competition with the horsemen of Philadelphia and Baltimore as do New-York's hired nine of baseball players against the teams of the same cities. In the first of the series of inter-city harness races at Fleetwood yesterday, Philadelphia carried off the honors, its representatives winning the 2:30 and 2:20 class races with Frank Brown and Claudius, respectively.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The championship lawn tennis tournament was continued at Wissahickon Heights to-day. There was a better attendance than on the first day. A cool breeze blew across the grounds during the after-noon, and not only Interfered with the pleasure of the onlookers, but rendered it a difficult matter for the players to place the ball accurately.
PANAMA, June 13. -- A fire broke out this afternoon which endangered fully a quarter of all the buildings in the city. A high wind spread the flames.
SHANGHAI, June 13. -- The Japanese Government has sent a naval and military force to Corea to protect the interests of Japan in that country.
The Kings County Medical Society has approved the methods adopted by Health Commissioner Emery of Brooklyn and has adopted the following resolutions, which were sent to Dr. Emery yesterday:

The stock market yesterday was very dull, but the undertone was notably strong. Sugar was, as usual, the leader in the specialties. It sold ex dividend, and was somewhat heavy at the opening, but subsequently became strong. The statement of Mr. Havemeyer to the Senate committee that the company had earned $35,000,000 in three years was regarded as news by some people, and it induced buying.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 13. -- The one hundred and forty-seventh annual commencement exercises of Princeton College were held this morning in the new Alexander Hall. The class of '94 occupied the parquette, and friends filled the spacious hall. Dr. Patton, the Board of Trustees, and the Faculty occupied the rostrum.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Every State in the Union will find something interesting in a report just made by Secretary Carlisle. The Senate asked him by resolution to inform that body what changes had taken place in the Treasury Department from March 4, 1893, to May 16, 1894. It took some time to prepare the reply, for Senator Gallinger secured the passage of the resolution on April 19.

William Astor Chanler, whose recent explorations in Africa have made his name familiar to geographers and other scientific men, arrived in New-York from Europe on Tuesday on the steamship Aller. After a short stay here he will return to Europe and take the waters at Carlsbad.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 13. -- The Populist State Convention to-day renominated Gov. Lewelling by acclamation, the opponents of the nomination being unable to agree upon a candidate to present against him.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 13. -- The twenty-eighth commencement at Vassar College took place to-day. The college chapel, simply decorated with smllax, was crowded with guests when Mrs. Emily Jordan Folger, '79, marshaled in the procession of President, Trustees, Faculty, teachers, alumnae, and the graduating class.

There was as pretty a sight as one could wish to see in the chapel of the Packer Collegiate Institute, Brooklyn, last evening, when the young women graduates, wearing dainty girlish white gowns, received their diplomas from Prof. Truman J. Backus, the President of the school.

BOSTON, Mass., June 13. -- The Rev. E. G. Robinson, Professor of Philosophy in the University of Chicago, and formerly President of Brown University, died at the City Hospital here to-night. He had been in the hospital for special treatment.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 13 -- Fully 4,500 people attended the races of the Lake View Wheelmen, at Rochester Driving Park, today. The track was perfect and the day cool. W.C. Sanger complained of not feeling well and of a bad cold before the day's races.

H. Walter Webb, Third Vice President of the New-York Central Railroad, sailed for Europe yesterday afternoon on the steamship Majestic. He will seek needed rest in such parts of Great Britain and France as his inclinations and comfort suggest, returning to this city about the middle of July.

The industry which characterized the investigations of the Constitutional Convention's Sub-Committees on Charities and Education on Tuesday did not lag yesterday, as Messrs. Lauterbach and Holls and their colleagues visited nine institutions, each of which differed from the others in methods of management and in its scheme of financial vitality.

LONDON, June 13. -- Rear Admiral Erben and Capt. Mahan of the United States cruiser Chicago were among the guests at the Trinity House anniversary banquet this evening. The Duke of York, who was recently chosen Master, presided. The Prince of Wales, the Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha (Duke of Edinburgh,) the Duke of Cambridge, Prince Christian, Lord Salisbury, and the Earl of Rosebery were present.
A fear seems to exist among certain persons that the present investigating committee will not perform in its entirety the work for which it was appointed.

-- John S. Prince, the veteran professional bicyclist, who has been giving races against trotters in Cuba and the South, arrived in New-York yesterday and has been specially engaged by the Greenwich Wheelmen to train their riders on Manhattan Field for their forthcoming tournament. He will pay special attention to Outerbridge, who will try conclusions against Titus of the Riverside Wheelmen.

It is not to be denied that the Democratic Party in the House of Representatives makes a far better showing and has done far more to win the confidence of the country than the majority in the Senate. Its Tariff bill, despite the unnecessary and incongruous income-tax provision, was not only a much wiser, but a much more honest, bill than the one made in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- It is reported that as soon, as the new Government in Salvador shall be established and able to preserve law and order, President Cleveland will direct the surrender of the refugees now on board the Bennington to the proper judicial authorities, not, however, without the fullest guarantee on the part of Salvador that the prisoners shall be tried by an impartial tribunal organized in conformity with the Constitution of the republic.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13. -- The Naval War College was formally opened this morning by Assistant Secretary of the Navy William McAdoo. Besides the officers ordered to the class under instruction, there were present the officers from Fort Adams and the training and torpedo station and a number of prominent citizens of Newport.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
Mayor Schieren is the first Mayor of Brooklyn, who has come out boldly and declared that women should be represented in the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Mr. Reed has not often made a more interesting speech than that delivered by him this afternoon in the debate on the Indian Appropriation bill.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The resolution introduced in the Senate to-day by Mr. Hoar, and agreed to, asking the President to inform the Senate what objections had been made by countries with which the United States had entered into reciprocal commercial arrangements or treaties under the McKinley bill to the proposed reimposition of a duty on sugar, is understood to have been based upon representations made to the State Department.

BOSTON, June 13. -- There has been very little doing in our market to-day. Both West End Land and West End Street Railway are off half a point. Lamson sold at 21 in the board, but only 20 could be obtained for it in the auction.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn was asked yesterday to arbitrate the differences which have arisen between the Rev. Dr. John Kershaw of the Atlantic Avenue Congregational Chapel and a wayward canine that belongs to Herman Voss, a near neighbor of the preacher. Pastor Kershaw dwells at 354 Franklin Avenue.

TANGIER, June 13. -- The soldiers of the new Sultan are raiding the villages in the vicinity of Rabat, and have had several skirmishes with the tribesmen. A French mail courier has been attacked and his mail parcels stolen. The foreign residents are becoming alarmed, and are hoping for the arrival of European war ships to protect them.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 14. -- The published statement that Gen. Basil Duke of Louisville, editor of The Southern Magazine and brother-in-law and Chief of Staff of Gen. John Morgan, the famous Confederate raider, has assured Major Henry Clay McDowell that he will stump the Ashland district for him and against Col. Breckinridge if the latter should be renominated has caused a sensation.
Music Hall was crowded last night on the occasion of the one hundred and fortieth commencement of Columbia College.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Three witnesses were examined by the Sugar Trust investigation committee to-day. They were H. O. Havemeyer, John. E. Searles, the Treasurer of the American Sugar Refining Company, and H. P. Birney, chief clerk of the Arlington Hotel. Mr. Havemeyer's testimony was brief but interesting.

The Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, formerly pastor of the West Presbyterian Church, in West Forty-second Street, who is now staying at the Windsor Hotel, with his wife and daughter, declared yesterday that he would never preach in New-York again.
AURORA, N. Y., June 13. -- The twentysixth annual commencement of Wells College came to an end to-day. A meeting of the Trustees was held this morning, followed by the commencement exercises.

"Admitting all Mr. Wiman's faults, his weakness, his errors, even his guilt, if you will, I would rather, in the light of eternity, stand where he stands to-day than be in the position of Robert G. Dun, the free man, the millionaire, the 'honorable' citizen.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening:)

At auction, in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday, Mr. Richard V. Harnett sold, in partition, two pieces of property Belonging to the Aimer Mellen estate. The first of these was the five-story brick factory building 510 to 520 East Seventeenth Street, south side, 233.0 1/2 feet east of Avenue A, 76.4 by 92 by 76.4 1/4 by 92.

Baron Giovanni Nicotera, ex-Minister of the Interior and one of Italy's foremost statesmen, died at his home, at Vico Equense, near Naples, yesterday. Baron Nicotera was stricken with apoplexy in Rome on Feb. 24. He was removed to his home, but never fully recovered from the attack.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- There was a faint echo to-day in the House of the A. P.A. controversy provoked last week by Representative Linton of Michigan, the Republican who was supported in 1892 by the A.P.A., and whose seat is contested by Mr. Toumans, on the ground that he procured it by fraudulent representations to the voters of imminent revolution among the Roman Catholic voters of the State.

Mrs. Marie S. Wyse, who is fairly well known in New-York society, and who, two years ago, brought suits against Mrs. H. Burgoyne Wilson and Mrs. Louise FiskBryson for $50,000 damages for alleged slander, is again a party in legal proceedings. Her husband, William Sumner Wyse, from whom she is separated, seeks to recover from her the house 28 East Twenty-third Street, together with various stocks, bonds, and other property, valued at $150,000.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation a letter was read from the National League for Good Roads, bearing the indorsement of the Department of Agriculture, asking the board to participate in the road improvement conference to be held at Asbury Park July 5 and 6. The time is chosen because the National Editorial Convention will then be in session there.

Brooklyn. -- A. J. Butcher has been appointed foremen of street repairs by Commissioner White of the City Works Department. Mr. Butcher will get $4 a day. This is the first selection under the new act that permits appointment of veteran soldiers without a civil service examination.

Those who visited Eldorado last night to witness the first production of Benamela were evidently of the unanimous opinion that it is well worth the care in preparation that has been bestowed upon it. Differing in many respects from the spectacular, undertakings of former seasons, the effort seems to have been successfully made to preserve the most striking features of other years and to submit new effects of a brilliant order for the Summer's amusement.

NEWPORT, June 13. -- In Grand Committee of the Legislature to-day, George P. Wetmore was elected United States Senator. A dinner and a salute of 100 guns followed. The Anti-Policy bill was passed by both branches.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Charles M. Pepper, who has recently resigned his place as correspondent of The Chicago Tribune after admirable service for seven years, and Mrs. Pepper gave a farewell tea from 5 to 8 o'clock this afternoon. Their house was thronged with friends, who found the rooms decorated with flowers and growing palms.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 13 -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East-Steam yachts Viking, H.A. Hutchins; Almy, Frederick Gallatin; Awa, Alonzo Flint; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg, and Alicia, Henry M. Flagler; schooner yacht Varuna, Frank K. Sturgls; sloop yacht Indria, Mrs. C.B. Thompson.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 13. -- Summer for Long Islanders always begins with the opening of the June exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society. This was the first day of the fair, and, while the weather was somewhat disappointing, there was a large attendance. The crowd began to arrive about noontime, evidently feeling that the early hours of the day should be given to the exhibitors to arrange their displays.

Fifteen members of the Citizens' Union of Brooklyn gathered at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, last night. William G. Low presided and William P. Ferguson acted as Secretary. Speeches were made by Mr. Low, Charles Frederick Adams, and Mr. Curley in favor of the Citizens' Union joining the New-York State Municipal Reform Association.

Members of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association assembled in the Waldorf yesterday morning. Commissioner Stahlman called the Executive Board to order and asked for the report of the subcommittee which had been appointed to consider the question of rates. The report was not ready, and the committee adjourned for further deliberations.

BOSTON, June 13 -- Eastern yachtsmen who have been looking forward with considerable interest to the meeting of the Navahoe and Volunteer in the Eastern Yacht Club's annual regatta off Marblehead June 25 were very glad when they heard that the Navahoe was to come around the Cape and try conclusions with the old cup defender.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 13. -- The anniversary exercises of Andover Theological Seminary were continued to-day with examinations this forenoon and the meeting of alumni in the chapel this afternoon. At the latter the necrology of the year was read by the Rev. C. C. Carpenter, the Secretary.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., June 13. -- This ancient little village will be thronged with visitors to-morrow, and men-of-war will thunder out salutes on the river, while military and civic organizations parade ashore, in honor of the dedication of a monument to mark the spot where the final steps of the Revolutionary War were taken by Washington and Rochambeau.

The death of the Sultan of Morocco has opened to view what is no doubt an ordinary complication of Oriental politics, which looks all normal and proper enough in a history, but looks particularly queer when it is exploited by special correspondents and related by telegraphic cables.
The Jockey Club is to have a special meting at its rooms in the Cumberland this evening. Two changes in the rules have been suggested for consideration.

Nowadays it is a rare thing for a club to come to New-York and depart without winning one or more games from the Giants, but the Louisvilles were forced to do this. They played their third successive game against Ward's men yesterday and left for Boston last night with the stigma of three straight defeats charges against them.

The local baseball team suffered defeat yesterday. On the Polo Grounds the Giants were beaten by Pittsburg, making a lot of errors, and at Eastern Park the Brooklyn team had a close and interesting game with the "Patsy" Tebeau men and lost by a single run.

There is much weakness in the theory that witnesses who testify to having paid money for police protection in a nefarious and unlawful calling or in violating the law are not worthy of belief, and that, even if they did pay money to underlings or apparent go-betweens, that is no evidence that it reached the Captains or those higher in authority.

BOSTON, June 14 -- A cable to to-night's Herald from Gourock, Scotland, says: "The extra men of the Vigilant's crew, who came over on the Ethiopa, arrived here this morning, and are awaiting the arrival of the Vigilant, which is expected within ten days. The Vigilant's racing spars will be sent to Gourock, and she will be fitted out as soon as possible.
More testimony against the management of the City Asylum for the Insane was given yesterday before the State Commission in Lunacy, which met in the Park Avenue Hotel.

LONDON, June 14 -- A representative of the United Press had an interview with ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton to-day, and asked him if he would be a candidate for Governor of the State of New-York next Fall.
The one hundred and seventeenth anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes as the national ensign occurred yesterday.

Brooklyn and Cleveland played a lively game of baseball yesterday at Eastern Park in the presence of 4,500 persons. The hitting was hard and clean, and the Clevelands won because they were lucky and bunched their hits. McAleer's home run won the game. It bounded out of Burns's teach into the stand in right field.
LONDON, June 14 -- John Duke Coleridge, Lord Chief Justice of England, died at 8:50 o'clock this evening.

Very nearly half of the trading in yesterday's stock market was in Sugar certificates. They opened at 101 1/2, sold at 101 7/8, and then declined, with only occasional rallies, to 97, closing at 97 1/8, on sales of 110,671 shares. Insiders apparently did not resist the decline. The news from Washington was regarded as indicating further changes in the sugar schedule in a direction not favorable to the trust.

John S. Prince, who has just returned from Cuba, signed a contract with Receiver Friedman of the Manhattan Athletic Club yesterday, and is to open a training ground for bicyclists at Manhattan Field. Bicyclists can go to the grounds, be trained and coached by competent men, and prepared for their races. In addition to this, there are to be races every Wednesday and Saturday evening during the season, beginning on the 27th.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., June 14 -- The New-York State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution to-day placed in position the cornerstone of a monument to mark the spot where the French allies under Rochambeau joined the American Army, where Washington planned the Yorktown campaign, and where Washington and Sir Guy Carleton arranged for the evacuation of the American soil by the British.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn is happy because at a meeting with his Cabinet yesterday he was given to understand that the tax rate, which he feared would be extremely high, would not reach the figure on which he calculated. The members of the Cabinet shared the Mayor's pleasure.

The Mercury Wheel Club of Flushing, L.I., will hold a century run next Sunday to Sayville and back. The start will be made from the clubhouse at 6 A.M., and Sayville and dinner will be reached, according to the schedule, at 11:45 A. M. The run is a charming one, and takes the riders through such pretty towns and villages as Jamaica, Rockville Centre, Seaford, Babylon, and Islip.

BOSTON, June 14 -- Arguments were begun to-day before Judge Carpenter, in the United States Circuit Court, in the suit of the United States Government to annul the Berliner patent of the American Bell Telephone Company. This is the patent that now controls long-distance communication.

The Constitutional Convention's Sub-Committees on Charities and Education returned to Albany yesterday afternoon, well prepared to discuss the amendment of the League for the Protection of American Institutions, which would take State financial support from private sectarian charities.
BALTIMORE, June 14 -- The Manufacturers' Record, in its weekly review of Southern business conditions, says:

George W. Perkins, Third Vice President of the New-York Life Insurance Company, gave an elaborate luncheon at Clark's yesterday to the agents belonging to the Manhattan Department of the company, which includes all those living in New-York and Brooklyn. The luncheon was served at 1 o'clock, and 250 covers were laid.

GREENSBURG, Penn., June 14 -- About 1 o'clock this morning the citizens of Alverton were startled by a terrific explosion, which shook the houses in the village and in many instances broke the glass in the windows. It was soon discovered that the pumphouse of the McClure Coke Company had been blown up with dynamite.

Erastus Wiman's case will go to the jury to-day. At the close of court yesterday only one witness remained to be called, and his examination, Gen. Tracy said, would take not more than ten minutes this morning.

CITY ISLAND, June 14 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Alicia. H.M. Flagler; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Tillie, W.H. Starbuck; Marion, James J. Faye, and Evelyn, J.K. Hegeman. Schooner yachts Water Witch, David Banks; Avalon, Francis L. Leland, and Varuna, F.K. Sturgis. Sloop yachts Indria, Mrs. C.B. Thompson; Wizard, Col. William Hester, and Gloriana, H.M. Gillig.
A dinner was given at Delmonico's last night to Sir William Lane Booker, C.M. G., the British Consul General in NewYork, who is about to retire from the Consulate Service in this country.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

WASHINGTON, June, 14 -- Some of the testimony given yesterday before the Senatorial investigating committee by John E. Searles, Secretary and Treasurer of the American Sugar Refining Company, the socalled Sugar Trust, which was transcribed from the official stenographic notes too late for publication, was very interesting, particularly that part relating to the contributions of the trust for campaign purposes.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Terence V. Powderly, ex-General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, and A.W. Wright, ex-member of the General Executive Board, have issued and distributed among the members of the order a pamphlet answering and denying in detail the charges brought against them by the present executive officers of the Knights.

Louis Cohen, a licensed ticket speculator, was arrested Wednesday night by Police Captain Kenney of Brooklyn on a charge of selling tickets for the Wild West Show on private property, on Second Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, Brooklyn. He was in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus, and his counsel, Mr. De Fere, informed Justice Gaynor that Cohen was arrested on public ground and without a warrant.

The Treasury Department is said to be troubled with the question of what is to be done with the 3,000 unregistered Chinese laborers in the country, be the same more or less. Why not let them alone, so long as they are doing no harm? No money has been appropriated for sending them to China, and there is no absolute requirement that they shall be deported, though authority for it is given by the law.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 14 -- The races at the Binghamton Driving Park to-day were trotted on a fast track. It was a bad favorites' day, only one picked winner getting first place. In the 2:23 class for pacers race, as June Bug came around the turn on the last quarter, she dropped to the track, throwing her driver over her head. The driver was not seriously hurt.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The inveatigation into the alleged armor-plate frauds continued to-day. C. Edward Sill, the original informer, took the stand. He kept records and made reports for the Superintendent and Government Inspectors. He made two reports: One, of the actual work, for Cline, in black ink, and the other, the report for the Government Inspectors, in red ink.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- The third day's play in the championship lawn tennis tournament was favored by glorious weather, and a fashionable array of spectators witnessed a fine display of tennis. All the weaker players have been forced out of the competition in the main events, and that those who remain are fully capable of playing the same in a scientific manner was amply demonstrated to-day.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The members of the House Immigration Committee will leave Washington for New-York at 4 P.M. to-morrow. George Jennison will accompany the committee as Sergeant at Arms. They will take the 9:15 boat Saturday morning for Ellis Island, and will remain in New-York until Wednesday of next week.

Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta, "The Mikado," has not been heard here in several years, and it is not at all unlikely that many amusement lovers have never heard it at all. It will be their own fault if they do not take the opportunity now offered to hear one of the most delightful works ever offered for public edification.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- The adjourned hearing on the exceptions of Isaac L. Rice to the petition of the Reading receivers for permission to use $500,000 of the free securities of the company in their possession as collateral for the carrying out of a contract with the city for the construction of the Pennsylvania Avenue subway was had today before Judge Dallas in the United States Circuit Court.

The annual commencement exercises of the Hebrew Technical Institute were held at Arlington Hall, 19 St. Mark's Place, yesterday. James H. Hoffman presided, and there were with him on the platform, among others, Prof. M. Low, Dr. Leipziger, Dr. H. P. Mendez, and Leo Schlesinger. The band of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, played, several selections during the afternoon.

There are signs on every hand, which are no longer to be disguised, of the secret spread of the A.P.A. -- the American Protective Asssociation or the American Proscriptive Association -- through all parts of the country. From the Northwest it has come East, it has gone South, and it is extending into the extreme West.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Business on the Exchange to-day was almost entirely between room traders with but very few outside orders. The markets are apparently, quite steady, however, and do not yield to bear influences, while at the same time anything that indicates an advance is followed by liberal buying.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 14 -- A reception was given in Masonic Hall last evening by the Young Men's Literary Association to the Rev. Joseph Egan of St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church, who sails on Saturday for Europe on a commission, from Archbishop Corrigan to examine university work on the Continent.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 14 -- The State Prohibition Convention to-day nominated the following State ticket:
A fire which started in the basement of Vernon Brothers Co.'s paper warehouse, at 65 Duane Street, yesterday morning caused damage estimated at $250,000.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 14 -- The new Christ's Episcopal Church of this place was dedicated this morning. The ceremonies were conducted by Bishop Starkey of the Newark Diocese. The Bishop delivered the principal address. Other addresses were made by Archdeacon Jenvery of Hoboken and the Rev. F.B. Carter of Montclair.

MANHATTAN BEACH, L.I., June 14 -- Manager Hoffenheimer of Hagenbeck's wild animal show, which will spend the Summer at Manhattan Beach, gave a private performance this afternoon, at Manhattan Park. There were fifty spectators present.

LENOX, Mass., June 14 -- The marriage of Miss Lilian H. Adams, adopted daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thatcher M. Adams, and William S. Post, son of George B. Post of New-York, took place in Trinity Church at noon to-day. The skies were clear, the weather warm, and a large and fashionable company of society people were in attendance.
PANAMA, June 14 -- The greatest calamity that has ever befallen this city was the fire which started yesterday afternoon and burned fiercely for nine hours before it could be got under control
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- This significant order was issued by Secretary Carlisle today:

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 14 -- To-day Speaker Emerson of the Legislative Assembly, accompanied by Mr. McGrath, his colleague in the representation of the Placentia district, and late Chairman of the Board of Works, forcibly seized and carried away from the wharf of Shea Co., agents of the Allan Line, without paying duty, a bale of carpeting belonging to Emerson, which arrived on the steamer Siberian yesterday.

ALBANY, June 14 -- The anti-woman suffragists had a hearing before the Suffrage Committee to-night. The Assembly Chamber was filled with a throng of women, both for and against suffrage. Nearly all the women prominent in Albany society were present, as well as representatives from Syracuse, Kingston, and Poughkeepsie.

"I give you hearty welcome as daughters of the King," said the Rev. J.O. Wilson of the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church, Willoughby and Vanderbilt Avenues, Brooklyn, last evening. The Brooklyn Union of the King's Daughters and Sons was holding its quarterly afternoon and evening meetings in the chapel of the church.

PARIS, June 14 -- The Deputies discussed to-day proposals to amend the laws governing syndicates. Premier Dupuy accepted and spoke for the amendment proposed by Leon Guillemin, Republican deputy from the Nord, but it was barely carried, the vote being 188 to 177.

The steamer Aurora, with a party of excursionists, engineers and newspaper men, made a trip to the Cholera Banks yesterday to make soundings for the hotel which it is proposed to build out in the Atlantic Ocean in latitude 40 degrees 24 minutes north and longitude 73 degrees 37 minutes 30 seconds west.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 14 -- There was a large gathering of interested visitors on the Seton Hall campus this afternoon in front of Alumni Hall to witness the thirty-eighth annual commencement of the college. The Right Rev. B.J. McQuaid, D. D., Bishop of Rochester, presided in the absence of Bishop Wigger, who is in Europe.
ANDOVER, Mass., June 14 -- The graduating exercises of the senior class of Andover Theological Seminary were held to-day in the chapel. The graduates numbered twenty-six.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., June 14 -- A mad dog, that had undisputed possession of a vacant lot at Smithtown for several hours yesterday, made a savage attempt to bite Mrs. G. Ticehurst, who was driving by the lot with her little girl. The dog made a rush at the horse first; then he gave his whole attention to Mrs. Ticehurst.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Corean Legation received a cablegram this morning direct from the royal palace at Seoul, dated to-day, announcing the complete suppression of the rebellion and showing the falsity of reports from China yesterday that the King had fled to Japan and that the rebels had occupied Seoul.

In a certain church in Ireland a young priest was detailed to preach. The occasion was his first appearance, and he took for his text "The feeding of the multitude." He said "And they fed ten people with 10,000 loaves of bread and 10,000 fishes." An old Irishman said: "That's no miracle, Begorra, I could do that myself!" which the priest overheard.

Capt. Mayer of the firm of Grout, De Fere Mayer, Brooklyn, appeared in the Kings County Supreme Court, before Justice Bartlett, yesterday, and obtained an order compelling Civil Justice John Petterson to show cause why a case in which the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is a party should not be removed from his court to the county court.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 14 -- The favorable weather to-day brought a very large crowd of visitors to the Summer exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society at the fair grounds here. This was the second day and the attendance was far above the average for the society's Summer fairs.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The announcement that the United States Government would not hold refugees on the cruiser Bennington after the Salvadorian Government was thoroughly organized and capable of guaranteeing orderly judicial proceeding's and immunity from mob rule is fully confirmed in official circles to-day.

President Clausen of the Park Department is quoted as expressing his regret that the "additional" million-dollar appropriation was ever given to that department "for the relief of the unemployed poor." He wishes it had gone to some other department. It has, indeed, been a source of trouble to the Park Commissioners ever since the Legislature authorized its expenditure, and it has caused disappointment to many other people.

Messrs. Jones Co. have sold, for the Lederich estate, at $3,000 each, the two two-story and basement brick dwellings 172 and 174 Thirteenth Street, each 20.10 by 35 by 100, to Thomas Connors and Thomas J. McKenna, respectively.

The affinity between colored men and chickens has existed from the earliest times. The reason why the Egyptians hatched their chickens by artificial heat was undoubtedly the proximity of the native African negroes, which rendered it impossible for any Egyptian to keep a sitting hen long enough for her to hatch out a brood.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Assistant Secretary Reynolds of the Interior Department to-day rendered an important decision which is far-reaching in its effect and will involve the immediate cancellation of thousands of pension certificates issued under a ruling of the last Administration.

ORANGE, N.J., June 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. W.F. Wilkinson of New-York moved to East Orange a week ago and rented a house at 53 Halsted Street for the Summer. Yesterday Mr. Wilkinson went to New-York to meet his daughter, aged eighteen, returning from boarding school.
The inter-city cup races at Fleetwood last Wednesday brought out quite an array of fancy traps and fashionable turnouts, in addition to the usual multitude of trotting road rigs.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- As the time before the great race between Pennsylvania and Cornell elapses the excitement increases, and hundreds have made the trip to see the college men at work.

The evidence given yesterday by the ex-convict Appo is the most startling, the most appalling, that has yet been submitted to the Lexow committee. Of course, the man's character is as bad as bad can be. If he has a motive for lying there is no doubt that he will lie freely, fluently, and under oath.

Nothing of consequence was done at the meeting of The Jockey Club last evening. Dr. Knapp's proposed rule, requiring all horses to be ridden out for third money, which was supposed to be an entering wedge for the restoration of 1 -- 2 -- 3 bookmaking, was not considered. Under the rules, publication of a proposed change must be made in The Racing Calendar three times before it can be acted upon.
Commodore John Rodgers. Commodore John Rodgers of Oakland, Penn., died in that city Tuesday night. He was seventy-one years old. He leaves, a wife and two daughters.

The West Side tennis team. Fischer and Parker, returned from the Summit tournament covered with glory and sore spots. Their hard campaign against the experts is beginning to tell on them. Though their record has been excellent so far, they must win a tournament or two later on before people will consider them as formidable candidates for honors at Newport.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

-- Mrs. Sarah L. Stout died Wednesday at her home at Atlantic Highlands, N.J., of nervous prostration, from which she had suffered for two years. Her maiden name was Sarah Luciana Alderdice. She was born in Montreal, Canada, fifty-six years ago. She was a member or the Baptist Church and of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and of the King's Daughters.

BUFFALO, N. Y., June 14. -- Ex-City Clerk William E. Delaney, a prominent lawyer and Democratic politician, was shot in his apartments over the "Gold Dollar" saloon, about 7 o'clock to-night, by George A. Bartholomew, aged twenty-six years, of Victoria, Ontario.
DUBLIN, June 14 -- A boat containing 110 harvesters, crossing from Achill, Ireland, to Westport, County Mayo, was capsized this morning, and thirty-five of its occupants Were drowned.

The feature of yesterday's auction sales of real estate in the Trinity Building Sales- room was the offering, by Mr. William Kennelly, of the Charles G. Landon residence, 428 Fifth Avenue. This property measures about 25 by 100 feet, with fourstory brownstone dwelling. It is on the west side of the avenue, 48.9 feet north of Thirty-eighth Street.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 15. -- There was no marked change to-day in the condition of Judge William Walter Phelps, who is lying ill at his home at Teaneck. The doctors expressed their hope in the afternoon that Mr. Phelps would live through the night, at least. He has been in a state of semi-coma since early this morning.
Following is a complete list of saloon passengers who have been booked to sail by to-day's outgoing fleet:

NEWARK, N. J., June 15. -- With a screaming four-year-old child on the seat of the wagon, clutching the reins in his tiny hands, a maddened horse dashed down Central Avenue about 9:30 this morning. As the horse went clattering across Halsey Street, with the baby boy bounding on the wagon seat, there was a wild cry from a group of women standing on the side-walk on Central Avenue.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 15. -- The convention of coal miners of the Pittsburg district to-day indorsed the action of the national and district officers by accepting the sixty-nine-cent rate, and will resume work Monday. The vote was 89 to 31, but it was made unanimous immediately after the announcement showing that the official action had been indorsed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- Reading securities were inclined to sag to-day, on the rumor that there was trouble brewing with the various companies in regard to their putting out too much coal. While just at the moment on accpunt of the coal strike, the market is taking coal freely, at the same time, with this coal strike finished, there will have to be a very sharp contraction in the output to prevent great demoralization.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 15. -- These companies were incorporated to-day:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 15. -- The commencement festivities at Rutgers College opened this evening, and will extend through the remainder of this and part of next week. To-night the Glee Club concert was held in the Opera House. It was largely attended. Afterward came the cremation exercises of the sophomore class.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- The Thames course is now flagged for the races which are to take place June 28, the work of placing the white flags at the mile marks having been completed this afternoon. The crews were out this forenoon, but did not row long distances, their work being directed toward the perfection of the stroke and the correction of individual faults.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- There will be seven of this year's graduating class of naval cadets unprovided with commissions, unless a number of casualties or retirements occur before July 1. The class is not showing the anxiety usually displayed when vacancies are necessary for the lower members, and but one officer has recently been ordered before a retiring board with a view to making another place for a cadet.

The opening games of the tennis tournament for the championship of the Kings County Inter-club League will be played to-day on the courts of the Knickerbocker Field Club, Avenue A and Eighteenth Street, Flatbush. The five clubs composing the league -- the Kings County, Brooklyn, and Altiora Tennis Clubs, the Knickerbocker Field Club, and the Crescent Athletic Club -- will send two representatives to each of the contests -- the ladies singles and men's doubles.

Tweed's famous question, asked originally in derision, must recur with deep seriousness to every decent New-Yorker as he reads the reports of the investigations of the Lexow committee. Whatever motives actuated the appointment of that committee, it is already clear and incontestable that the committee has performed an enormous public service.
Just after the ferryboat Atlantic had been made fast at the foot of Whitehall Street at 6 o'clock last night several women ran from the cabin and said a woman was overboard.
To-day's road runs are: Bloomfield Cycling Association to Hackensack, N. J.

BUFFALO, June 15. -- George Bartholomew, who shot and killed ex-City Clerk Delaney last evening, was employed at the Ontario elevator, of which his father is Superintendent, as a tally man. His wife's maiden name was Frances Cook, daughter of Frank Cook, an employe of the Good-year Rubber Company.

The question as to the amount of protection given to the Sugar Trust by the duties in the Senate schedule is one of considerable importance, and we hope our high-tariff neighbor, The Tribune, will pardon us for pointing out that its opinions and assertions concerning the amount of this protection continue to be contradictory and confusing.

Brooklyn and Cleveland bad another nip-and-tuck struggle at Eastern Park yesterday, but on this occasion the former managed to score the odd run. It was a lively game throughout. The batting on both sides was hard, as the home-run column will show, and the fielding fairly good.

There was a lively time at the last meeting of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs. It will be remembered that the association reversed the decision of its Race Committee with regard to the barring of colored riders from the Irvington-Millburn race, and allowed Diggs and Simmons, the colored entries, to ride.

It was not the same old story yesterday. Strange to say, both the New-York and Brooklyn Clubs won their games. On the Polo Grounds the Giants took kindly to the pitching of Gumbert, and hit the ball hard and often. Meekin, who pitched for the local club, was in fine form, and retired the Pirates from the Smoky City with only half a dozen scattering hits.

The proposition to separate municipal from State and national elctions which is now before the Constitutional Convention is to have the approval of Tammany Hall. A reporter for The New-York Times called on Mayor Gilroy yesterday and asked him what his opinion was of having such a change made in the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- That wool is to go on the free list was declared by the Senate to-day, and there does not appear to be any likelihood that it will reverse its decision, although fresh efforts will be made to place a duty upon that commodity.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 15. -- At the trotting races at the Lower Park to-day the track record of 2:17 1/4, made by Charlie C. on Tuesday, was broken by Rebus, who went a mile in 2:15 1/4. The weather was fine to-day and the track fast. Attendance, 4,100. Summaries:

There was such a mass of flowers on the stage of the auditorium of the Long Island College Hospital, in Brooklyn, last night that there was hardly room for the graduates of the Training School for Nurses. There were sixteen of them, and they wore white Swiss caps and aprons and check dresses.

The stock market yesterday was esrtremely dull and was very narrow. Almost 70 per cent, of the day's business was in Sugar and Chicago Gas, and even these stocks were not more active than usual. At the opening Sugar was strong, while Chicago Gas was weak. Sugar opened at 97 1/4, advanced a full point, and then went back to 96 3/4.

The programme for the day's racing at Morris Park yesterday was made up of over-night events and consolation affairs, but for all that there was some good sport. The fields were fairly good, but eight of the thirteen were frightened out of the first race because Henry of Navarre was a starter.

Bicyclists who have never tried the Staten Island road run will find it interesting. The roads are good and there are several points of interest that it will pay the cyclist to visit. The Staten Island Ferry is at the foot of Whitehall Street. Up-town cyclists will find the best way to the ferry down Eighth Avenue and Hudson Street, Chambers to Broadway, and into Whitehall at Bowling Green.

The mountain climbers have made their attacks on the loftiest and least accessible of tall places. Having made Alpine peaks familiar to all climbers, having explored the Andes, and even made considerable headway with those African heights which we were taught to call the Mountains of the Moon, they now begin to make an impressive showing of conquest respecting the great Central Asian chains called the Himalayas, where lie the earth's loftiest altitudes.

Some startling particulars regarding the methods of Horace F. Burroughs, "commission merchant and lumber dealer," at 136 Water Street, were developed yesterday before Judge Fitzgerald, in the Court of General Sessions.

ST. JOHN'S. N.F., June 15. -- A moo organized by the Whiteway party made an attempt this afternoon, to seize the stores owned by Shea Co., agents of the Allan Steamship Company, where several hundred tons of goods are stored in bond.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- A bolt of lightning flashed from a suddenly-clouded sky just after 12 o'clock to-day over the ten-story. Teutonic Building, at Fifth. Avenue and Washington Street, and struck the immense cornice. A large piece of the ornamental terra cotta below was hurled to the pavement.

The Rev. James W. Putnam, pastor of the Trinity Baptist Church in East Fifty-fifth Street, has been indicted by the Grand Jury for criminal libel. The indictment is the outcome of a bitter fight made by the Rev. Mr. Putnam against the Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter, pastor of the Baptist Tabernacle in Second Avenue, near Ninth Street, last Summer.

A contest in prize speaking by graduates of the College of the City of New-York was held at Chickering Hall last evening. Alexander S. Webb, LL. D., President of the college, presided. On the stage were Charles L. Holt, Edward P. Steers, Charles H. Knox. Robert Maclay, and other Trustees of the college, together with Profs. Heberman, Compton, Stratford, Johnson, Fabregon, Tisdale, and Mason.
The race meet of the Elizabeth Athletic Cyclers at Waverly Park, N.J., to-day promises flair to be one of the cycling events of the season.

The class of '94 of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute had its annual class day exercises in the large hall of the college in Livingston Street, Brooklyn, last night. The class giving the entertainment is the first one started in under the college charter taken out by the Polytechnic Institute four years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- C. Edward Sill continued his testimony to-day before the House Naval Affairs Committee relative to the alleged armor-plate frauds. On taking the stand he deposited in front of him a mass of books, papers, and memoranda he had taken at the works. Chairman Cummings requested him again to state the nature of the books and papers.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Deputy Commissioner of Pensions D.I. Murphy said today that the Pension Bureau would be prepared July 1 to return to the Treasury Department nearly $25,000,000 as an unexpended balance of the $165,000,000 appropriated a year ago by Congress for the payment of pensions of all kinds.
A motion was made yesterday before Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court for the punishment of Hector W. Thomas for contempt of court because of his action in the Jones-Jones case.

RICHMOND, Va., June 15. -- Mrs. Belva Lockwood won a signal victory in Virginia to-day for women. For the past four years a struggle has been going on in this State to induce the Legislature to pass a special act permitting women to practice law, but without success.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 15. -- The first lecture of the War College course was delivered this forenoon by Commander C.H. Stockton. It was one of two upon "Preparations for War." The lecturer opened by referring to the advancement in warfare which has made wars shorter and more complicated.

CITY ISLAND, June 15. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Aquila, George A. Thayer; Jean, James Renwick; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Clermont, Alfred Van Santvoord, and Trophy, E.H. Bennett. Schooner yachts Sachem, F.T. Adams, and Varuna, F.K. Sturgis.

ORANGE, N.J., June 15. -- The Board of Directors of the Orange Athletic Club at a meeting last night decided to re-engage J.E. Dolt as physical instructor in response to the loud outcry from the members in protestation against his recent enforced resignation. His salary will be smaller arid duties much lighter, and he will be relieved of the responsibility of the nominal management of the club.
VIENNA, June 15. -- Five distinct explosions of fire-damp occurred in the coal mines of Count Larisch, at Karwin, Austrian Silesia, last night.

Arthur H. Mastin, counsel for the accused officials of the New-York City Asylum for the Insane, spent all day yesterday in an effort to Break down the testimony of Dr. Louise G. Rabinovitch, given last week before the State Commission in Lunacy, in which she arraigned those officials for criminal neglect and mismanagement.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations were filed with the Building Department during the twenty-four hours ending at noon yesterday:

There was a report down town yesterday in connection with gold exports that the banks would relieve the Sub-Treasury of further drain by supplying shippers from their vaults. What really happened was that the National City Bank, of which Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co. is a customer, furnished that firm with 5000,000 for export, after the firm had ordered the gold from the Sub-Treasury.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 15. -- This town is now practically bankrupt. An expert from New-York has reported an apparent deficiency of $100,000. To offset this there is $141,000 due in back taxes and assessments, but almost none of it is collectible.

WINFIELD, L.I., June 15. -- A very pretty home wedding took place at the home of Mrs. M. Ricke to-day, when her daughter, Miss Ida Ricke, and William Norrie of Whitestone, L.I., were married. The Rev. John A. French, D.D., of Flushing, officiated. Miss Frances A. Ricke, sister of the bride, was bridesmaid, and Charles A. Ellis of Flushing was best man.

Erastus Wiman, the developer of Staten Island, the advocate of commercial union with Canada, writer, orator, financier, the head and front for a quarter of a century of the greatest commercial agency in the world, was found guilty of forgery in the second degree yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

The murder of Frederica Borchinsky of Brooklyn and her four-year old son had been a mystery for two years and a half, up to yesterday, when Detectives Decker and Kennedy of the Sixth Precinct created a stir in police circles by arresting, in Justice Petterson's Court in Broadway, Max Borchinsky, the husband of the murdered woman and the father of the murdered child.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 15. -- Receiver Thomas F. Oakes of the Northern Pacific Road was cross-examined by Col. Silas W. Pettit to-day. He said he did not know that the Oregon and Transcontinental Company had agreed to gather the Chicago terminals together for $17,000,000, and that this price was afterward raised to $18,850,000.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 15. -- Funds are badly needed by the hospital in this village, which is supported almost solely by charitable contributions. Hard times and other drawbacks have cut off the revenue to such an extent that it is reported that the Trustees of the institution are without funds to pay current expenses, and unless some relief is speedily obtained the managers greatly fear that they will have to close the doors.

Some of the near relatives of the late Mrs. Kungunda Kugler are very much incensed because she cut them off by her will with a dollar each, while she left $300 in trust for her pet dog, "Bobby," and gave her wardrobe to the woman to whom the care of the dog was intrusted.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15. -- The annual class day exercises were held at Brown University to-day. The address of welcome was delivered by Clayton Sedgwiek Cooper, President of the class. The class oration was given by John Hope on "Brown University," and the class poem was written and delivered by Harold Dexter Hazeltine, the subject being "The Prince of Almorah."

William Lane O'Neill obtained from Judge Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, a writ of inquiry in a suit by Mrs. Margaretta C. Thompson, against Fannie Clark, otherwise known as Etta Thorn. The writ directs a Sheriff's jury to decide what damages Mrs. Thompson is entitled to receive.

Everything points to the Kings County Wheelmen having a "banner day" at their race meet on June 30. F.J. Titus, the Riverside crack, and W.H. Wells, who compose the Spalding team, are, with Horace A.
