Allen, the second man in the Irvington-Millburn race, among the first entries that will compete on the half-mile track of the Parkway Driving Club.

Mayor Gilroy has put himself on record, in an interview elsewhere printed in The Times this morning, as having no objection to the plan of separating municipal from general elections, provided they come in different years, and as being inclined to believe that it would be a good thing.
ALBANY, June 15. -- An amendment which Judge Charles H. Truax of New-York received and introduced this morning in the Constitutional Convention will no doubt lead to a vast amount of discussion.

ALBANY, June 15. -- Representatives of commercial bodies throughout the State met at the Delavan House, in this city, this afternoon and organized a "canal conference" to decide upon plans for canal improvements to be advocated before the Canal Committee of the Constitutional Convention.

A secret meeting of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Firemen and the non-brotherhood men was held at Horton's Hall, 210 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, last night, which lasted until midnight. The meeting was called for the purpose of taking action regarding the new schedule of trains on the elevated road, which went into effect Thursday.

The revelations in The New-York Times Concerning the underground workings of the American Prescriptive Association in Brooklyn have confirmed the suspicions entertained by many intelligent observers for some time past. At unexpected times and places the dragon of intolerance and bigotry has reared its head in the City of Churches, and, after trying to kindle differences between Catholics and Protestants into open strife, has slunk back under cover to await a more favorable opportunity.

BOSTON, June 15. -- Local stocks were quiet, and quotations were changed but little from yesterday. American Bell Telephone, opened at 196 1/2, 1/2 above yesterday's close, and advanced to 197, closing at that New-England Telephone advanced on small orders, reaching- 63 1/2, which is the highest it has sold at for years.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 15. -- Gov. Flower returned to-night from his trip of inspection of State institutions, which he commenced when he assumed the duties of Governor nearly three years ago. He was accompanied by the State Commissioners of Fisheries and Secretary Doyle, ex-Controller Wemple, Frederick P. Flower of New-York City, and W. George of Watertown.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Gen. Schofield has on his desk at the War Department the applications from this year's graduates at West Point for commissions in regiments of the army.
Messrs, C. Walker's Sons have sold for P.M. Platt to Mr. Clarkson, at $65,000, the stone-front building 259 Canal Street, north side, between Elm Street and Broadway, 26 by 85.

BOSTON, June 15. -- Matters progressed so slowly at the Saugus race course this afternoon that the card was not cleared at dark, the free-for-all trot being the undecided event. There was nothing notable in the racing. Only two horses made new records for themselves. The stallion Merry Bird was one of these, the staid trotter ending the 2:25 class, begun yesterday, in the first heat this afternoon, in 2:23 5/4.
Some interesting phases of dealings with the police were brought out by Messrs. Goff, Jerome, and Moss before the Lexow committee yesterday.

The congregations of the Central, First, West End, and Tabernacle Baptist Churches of Brooklyn, with their Sunday schools, enjoyed their annual union outing at Cold Spring Harbor, on Long Island Sound, yesterday. The large steamboat Gen. Slocum of the Rockaway Beach Line was chartered to carry the excursionists to the grove.

BERLIN, June 15. -- The Emperor and Empress observed the anniversary of Emperor Frederick's death by going to the Potsdam mausoleum this morning, offering silent prayer at the tomb and placing wreaths there. Hundreds of other persons were at the tomb this afternoon. Many of them left wreaths and great bunches of flowers.

NEWPORT,. R.I., June 15. -- Mrs. F.W. Vanderbilt has given to the Newport Hospital corporation a large sum of money, and plans have been made for a building for surgical purposes. It will be known as the Vanderbilt Surgical Building, in honor of its donor, and will be of brick and iron, 52 by 36 feet.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, or a small part of it, heard arguments to-day in favor of the Maguire Shipping bills from A. Fusureth, Chairman of the Legislative Committee of the National Seaman's Association, and from Representative Maguire of California, author of the bills, which are opposed by the New-York Maritime Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Senate Sugar Trust investigators started in to-day on what is considered the most direct, and, therefore, the most important branch of the inquiry. It is the branch, that consists in the examination of the individual members of the Senate, in alphabetical order, as to their knowledge or connection with dealings in Sugar stock or the sugar legislation of the Tariff bill.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The sessions of the Stock Exchange to-day were characterized by general inactivity. The market is in that peculiar position where bears do not care to be aggressive, as prices are low and the offerings of regular stock not at all large. There is but little, if any, public interest, and the little trading there is, is purely for room-traders' account.

The Quiet Inn stood at the intersection of two quiet streets in a quiet part of the city. Ordinarily a passer-by would not discern any outward signs bespeaking custom. Its shutters were closed, its curtains drawn, and all its light expended on its own interior. But one evening in early Winter a chance wayfarer did pause before it from a comprehension of its character.

It is not an unnatural question to ask what would the history of German music have been without the wonderful boy, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart? He not only developed the symphonic form, which had been established by Papa Haydn, but he made new departures in the treatment of quartets, was the father of chamber music for wind instruments, the originator of the part song, and the first composer who produced a genuine German opera.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16. -- The four-mile eight-oared shell race between Cornell and Pennsylvania on the Delaware River this afternoon was won by Cornell by five lengths in 21:12 1/2. Pennsylvania's time was 21:34 3/4. Cornell rowed a magnificent race from start to finish, while Pennsylvania's ragged work more than off-set their strength.

The Rev. James W. Putnam, who has been indicted for criminal libel on complaint of Maggie Burke, formerly of the Baptist Home for Young Women attached to the Baptist Tabernacle, in Second Avenue, near Ninth Street, was not arrested yesterday. His lawyer sent notice to the District Attorney's office that Mr. Putnam desired to preach to-day in his church, the Trinity Baptist Church.
WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The Treasury Department will begin business on Monday with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

It is not unnatural to begin an account of the leading German singing societies of New-York and Brooklyn with some account of the origin and growth of the German Liederkranz. Though it now shares its fame with its offshoot, the Arion, there was a time when it stood almost alone in the field which it cultivates. At any rate, it is the oldest of the large societies, having been founded on Jan. 9, 1847.

The population of India may be divided into two classes, those who have and those who lack courage and the power to fight. In Europe all nations belong to the former class, but there are in India whole nations and castes which, with occasional individual exceptions, are completely devoid of physical courage.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The arrival of the New-York from Kingston will be followed by the detachment of her commander, Capt. John W. Phillip, and his assignment to shore duty. The crack cruiser of the navy is considered the most desirable command afloat, and many covet the position.

The Tower Ridge Yacht Club held its second annual regatta yesterday at Hastings-on-the-Hudson, and the affair, which was under the management of Dr. E.N. Brandt, S.M. Shepherd, William Boss, Jr., Robert T. Dennis, and George Condit Smith, was a great success, and will doubtless encourage the young club to even bigger things next year.

There can be no question that it would be perfectly in agreement with the usage of civilized nations for Russia to commence war against Turkey with an attempt to seize on Constantinople by a sudden and unlooked-for attack; though it may be very well questioned whether Constantinople would necessarily fall in consequence of the appearance of a hostile fleet before it.

BERLIN, June 16. -- Although the exchanges of opinion between Germany and the parties to the Anglo-Belgian agreement still remain friendly and courteous, there is no question that the German Government has stiffened considerably in its attitude to the new partition of Africa. The Foreign Office here has objections to the treaty arrangement, as well as to the manner in which it was made.

A movement is under way in Brooklyn for the establishment of a trolley system of railroad, that will traverse Long Island, connecting the smaller towns with Brooklyn, and giving more adequate accommodation to the traveling public than they now enjoy.

In another week nearly all the twenty-One-footers will be out and yachtsmen will be anxiously looking forward to their first race, which will be on July 4. George Work's Minnetonka, W. Butler Duncan, Jr.'s, Houri, and W.P. Douglass's Devilfish are already at Larchmont, and the others are expected every day.

-- Bloomingdale Brothers have chartered the steamer Chancellor for next Tuesday, when they will take 1,000 children from the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum on an excursion to all the points of interest about New-York. June 21 Bloomingdale Brothers will take the same number of children from the Charities Organization Society on a like excursion.

The New-Jersey Athletic Club added one more victory to its record yesterday at Prospect Park, where it defeated the Brooklyn Cricket Club by 64 runs, F.J. Prendergast was in great form with the willow for the New-Jerseys, and his batting was the principal element in the success of the Bayonne organization.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 16. -- This fashionable and congenial suburb of the Greater New-York is delighted over the fact that the number of guests assembled within its healthful and attractive environment far exceeds that of a corresponding date last year. Figuratively speaking, the gates of the season were thrown wide open several weeks ago, and already Saratoga has cared for a cosmopolitan multitude numbering thousands.

Electrician Theodore White of the Citizens' Electric Light Company while repairing the motor in the telegraph department at Police Headquarters, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon forgot to turn off the current.

Two fires were started within four hours of each other yesterday in the tenement houses from 220 to 226 East Seventieth Street. Both fires were extinguished before much damage was done. The janitress, Mrs. Lamb, discovered that the matting in the hallway of 322 was on fire. She extinguished the flames with a bucket of water.

John W. Goff of counsel for the Lexow committee said yesterday that if the committee had a plan of action for this week it would not be divulged, and that all forecasts would be pure guesses. Such a scheme to hunt out police corruption with a brass band would be absurd. It would have one serious fault, the advertising of a hint to certain witnesses to keep out of the way.

JERSEY CITY, June 16. -- Fanned by a strong southeast wind, a fire that started in the buildings of the Central Stock Yards and Transit Company, at the foot of Sixth Street at 5:12 o'clock this afternoon, had, in a few moments, enwrapped the building ings and in an hour caused a loss of nearly $1,000,000.

Included in the class of eighty candidates in the General Term Room of the Supreme Court yesterday seeking admission to the bar, was one young woman, Miss Melle S. Titus. This is said to be the first time a woman has been examined in this department for admission to the bar.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The wool schedule is finally out of the way. Liberal concessions by the revision committee paved the way to its adoption. At one time today it looked as if it would continue to be a stumbling block for days to come.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Members of the Board of Trade, that is, those who are not in some way or another identified with the elevator interests, were considerably exercised to-day over a, report, which was widely circulated, that undesirable wheat only would be delivered on July contracts. The fear that this might really be so was a very important item in to-day's news on wheat, and had an influence for ill on prices.

ORANGE, N.J., June 16. -- The society people of the Oranges took great interest in the concert held at the Essex County Country Club this afternoon. The programme was furnished by Miss Rena Atkinson, the soprano prima donna; R. Payne Clark, the tenor of the Tavary English Opera Company; Arthur A. Seaton, the English baritone, and Miss Lucie E. Mawson, pianist.

The New-York Sangerrunde was formed on the evening of Nov. 4, 1848, and its name was chosen on New-Year's day, 1849. The first public entertainment of this singing society was given on Aug. 29, 1849, for the benefit of German refugees in Switzerland. The programme was a very good one.

It must be admitted that the "bench of British Themis'' has sustained serious, injuries in the public respect by the conjuct of the two latest dead of the conspicuous Judges. What mischief Was done in this way by the late. Justice Stephen is scarcely to be imputed to him for a fault.

The coins were made on hand machines, about the year 1821, by an Englishman named Peach, assisted by a boy; these two persons were the only parties acquainted with this singular episode in numismatic history. The doubloons were of the standard quality and weight, of 17 pennyweights 8 grains, and of the type of "Carolus IIII.," the die being made identical to that of the original pieces.

"He applies the eternal truth and the moral law as he feels it to, the life and times around him," said Mr. Curtis of Theodore Parker, and the phrase aptly describes his own performance in these little essays from the well-known Easy Chair. The series steps into line with the others with the same air of vigor and fresh life, so saddening as one recalls the extreme significance of the inscription on the final page.

Every one knows that during the Glacial Period the entire northern hemisphere was covered to an enormous depth with ice. Scientific men now inform us that another Glacial Period is among the certainties of the future. They can very nearly calculate the precise time when New-York and Paris and Pekin will be buried under hundreds of feet of ice, am despotism, constitutional monarchy, and republicanism will all alike be frozen stiff.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16. -- At the ladies' night entertainment at the Montclair Club on Monday, J.S. Burdette, the humorist, and Vess Ossmann, the banjoist, furnished a programme which pleased the stylish audience present.

When Mrs. Peary of arctic fame was asked, after her return two years ago, how she endured in her northern solitude the three months that Mr. Peary was away on his trip over the ice cap, she replied significantly, "It was better than sixteen months."

Of all the Cinque ports, Dover, perhaps, offered the least natural inducements to forming a harbor. But it was the gateway of the shortest cut to the Continent, and accordingly the commanding cliffs have been fortified from time immemorial. There was probably a standing British encampment on the heights that are now surmounted by a castle, which incloses thirty-five acres within its precincts.

By superior all-round work and opportune batting the New-Yorks won from the Pittsburgs yesterday. Both Rusie and Ehret were hit hard. Doyle's work at first and his three-base hit when all the bases were occupied were the features.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Mrs. Joseph. M. Carey will leave Washington June 20 with her two sons, who have been at school during the season in Philadelphia, and will go direct to her home at Cheyenne, Wyoming. Early in July they will go to the Yellowstone Park for a trip through the reservation and a visit to Capt. and Miss Andersen, who have quarters near the Mammoth Hot Springs in the park.

"One should be careful," said a model housekeeper, "what odors are allowed to linger about the rooms of a well-kept house. I have looked into the physical action of odors, and there is really something to be said about it. Goethe, you remember, could not tolerate the smell of apples, while Schiller, his illustrious compatriot, delighted in that rich, fruity flavor.

Something must be done to suppress the encore nuisatice. In some strange way managers of places of amusement at which operettas are given have got the notion that the public counts the number of encores on a first night, and estimates the success of a new production by the total number of repeats.

The Herriott family of San Francisco had many daughters -- Constance, Eleanor, Grace, Edith, Nan, and Marjorie. The mother was dead, and so was the father. Years before Mr. Herriott had committed suicide. Possibly the author presents that incident as explanatory of a certain unconventionality in the Herriotts.

Charles Hadlick, the General Post Office clerk who was implicated in the operations of the green-goods men in this city by Witness George Appo before the Lexow committee, was at work yesterday. He remained away from the Post Office Friday because he was ill.

The Brooklyn Aldermen endeavored a week ago to override Mayor Schieren's veto of a resolution granting a franchise to the New-York and Eastern Telegraph and Telephone Company. The vote was 13 to 6, and Alderman Cohn, in referring to the matter, spoke of the Aldermen who voted in the affirmative as the "Cold Thirteen."

If the following letters had been written by your best known and most esteemed neighbors they could be no more worthy of your confidence than they now are, coming, as they do, from well known, intelligent, and trustworthy citizens, who, in their several neighborhoods, enjoy the fullest confidence and respect of all who know them.

LENOX, Mass., June 16. -- This has been a gay week in Lenox on account of the Post-Adams marriage. Many young people who came up to the wedding have been members of various house parties, and informal dances and dinners galore have been given to them. Among those who have had house parties this week are George H. Morgan, William D. Sloane, Dr. Greenleaf, and Anson Phelps Stokes.

But, sensitive as are the salts of silver in the gelatine plates, they do not equal in this respect the living matter of the retina, on which images of objects are continually being formed and obliterated, Notwithstanding this, celestial objects can be photographed that will never be seen by the keenest eye, aided by the most powerful telescope that can be made.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 16. -- Troop A, which left New-York this morning, en route for the State Camp at Peekskill, arrived at the Westchester County Fair Grounds, about a mile back of this village, at 6 o'clock this evening. There were 104 men, dust-covered and looking as though they had returned from a long campaign.

The fact that Brooklyn has thirty German singing societies testifies to two things: first, that the city has a good-sized Teutonic population, and, second, that the sons of the fatherdand do not forget the customs of their native land in the city across the bridge. The Arion Singing Society of Brooklyn has an enviable record, which extends back a quarter of a century.

The Post Office of Chicago has been in a dangerous condition for a long time, owing to the foolish and in all ways extravagant methods pursued for buildings under the nominal control of the Supervising Architect at Washington. It is now reported that $4,000,000 will be appropriated by Congress for a new Post Office in Chicago.

According to the classiscal dictionaries -- and they ought to know -- Arion was a Greek poet and musician of Methymna, in Lesbos. He lived about 625 B.C., and his first name was not Mannergesangverein. He lived a sort of roving life, much the same as modern minstrels, though it is not recorded that he ever put in a season of forty weeks at one-night stands.

Mr. James frankly explains in his preface that these two plays, and two that are to be published later, were intended for representation, and that "they were addressed in each case with extreme, perhaps with extravagant, deference to a theatre, to a company, and especially to the presumable interpreter of the part supposed to be the most actable, or the most 'sympathetic.'"

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 16. -- The increase in electric roads in Connecticut during the, past year Was not been equaled in any State of its size in the country. At the last session of the General Assembly so many charters for electric railways were granted that the State is likely to be gridironed with electric roads.

The order for Mayor Schieren to show cause why a first-class theatrical license should not be granted to the Seaside Athletic Club at Coney Island was made returnable in the Kings County Supreme Court before Justice Gaynor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A peculiar instance of the operation of military justice is afforded by the case of Lieut. R.R. Steedman of the Sixteenth Infantry. The officer has been since Dec. 5 under a sentence of suspension for one year, during which period he was placed on half pay.

It is hard to imagine when the day will come when Ward McAllister will cease to be the oracle and supreme monarch of New-York's most exclusive and smartest set. No matter how long he reigns in New-York, however, there is one city where he may never again hope to gain the reverence and awe of the social world.

The members of the Corinthian Mosquito Fleet had a race off New-Rochelle yesterday afternoon especially for women. Ten boats started, and the guests of the members were taken out in the yachts and given an excursion on the Sound. They had a chance to see how the yachts were handled in a race, and appeared to be very much interested in everything that was done.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., June 16. -- Frederick J. Titus of the Riverside Wheelmen to-day rode the fastest trial mile of the year at the race meet of the Rockville Wheel Club. The day was fine and the track unusually good. Last season Zimmerman could not beat 2:21 on its surface, owing to the dust. Titus rode against the State record of 2:15 made by "Willie" Windle on this track, doing 2:07 easily.

I suppose we plume ourselves rather upon, possessing as a nation, a certain power of intellectual penetration. Some of us are always longing for something on which to exercise our minds, as wild boars are said to whet their tusks upon, an indigestible tree-trunk. It is essential to this purpose that the task should not be too easy.

LONDON, June 16. -- The Anchor Line steamer Ethiopia, Capt. Wilson, from New-York June 2, for Glasgow, was sighted at Tory Island at 9:05 A.M. to-day. She reports a large portion of her bow at and above the water line badly stove and broken by coming into collision with icebergs. Her bulkheads are watertight.

The season for bazaars and sales is again at hand. These affairs cluster in two portions of the year -- in Midsummer and again in early December to tempt Christmas buyers. At other times the contagion breaks out only sporadically.

JAMAICA, L. I., June 16. -- John Coyle, thirty-two years old, was arrested in Jamaica to-day, charged with having set fire to a hotel in Willow Street, in which Thomas Reese, his wife and four small children were sleeping.

Judge Dallas's decision on the exceptions of Mr. Isaac L. Rice to the petition of the Reading receivers in reference to the proposed subway, was rendered on Friday, bill the summary of it published in some of the papers of this city was grossly misleading, inasmuch as it stated plainly that Mr. Rice's exceptions had been overruled, and that the receivers' petition had been granted.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- The feature of today's market was its activity in all of the principal lines, but it wholly lacked interest, because of the narrowness and infrequency of fluctuations. Enough business was transacted in West Chicago to expect a difference of several points in figures, but the opening quotation, 141 3/4, and the closing price, 141 5/8, indicate its inertness.

The only ground upon which to rest the plea in behalf of Mr. Wiman, that he had no criminal intent in transferring money of the firm for which he acted to his own account, through the forged indorsement of a check drawn to pay a bill of the firm, was that he intended to make the amount good in time.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Ex-Representative Thomas M. Bayne of Pittsburg, Penn., killed himself by a pistol shot in the head at his residence at 10:15 this morning. Col. Bayne had retired in his usual health last night. He passed the evening with friends. This morning a servant who called him at 7 o'clock was told that he did not want anything.

Two well-known Harlem men were sent to hospitals yesterday, their relatives believing that they are suffering from insanity. One was Edward F. Hartley, who has a large furnishing goods store at 2,336 Third Avenue, and the other Edward McManus, twenty-flve years old, of 49 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street.

The expose of the methods of the American Protective Association in Brooklyn has stirred the indignation of Protestants, as well as Catholics. Words cannot express the detestation and contempt felt for the bigots who are trying by all sorts of covert devices to fan the religious differences existing in this country into flame.

The work of the past weeK has not resulted as wall for real estate brokers as many of them expected. A decided cessation in business is apparent. This has Shown itself markedly with regard to the demand for dwellings. Just now there is no such demand. Dickering continues concerning business property.

The annual report of William H. Maxwell, Superintendent of Public Instruction in Brooklyn, for 1893, to the Brooklyn Board of Education, has just been issued. It contains statistics bearing upon the overcrowded condition of the public schools, and particularly the primary classes, a state of affairs made necessary, Superintendent Maxwell declares, by the niggardly policy of the city officials, who have refused to make appropriations for adequate accommodations.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 16. -- Plainfield took on a holiday attire to-day, and the whole town turned put to witness the coaching parade. The walks were filled With people, and many houses, along the line of parade were decorated.

CONEY ISLAND, June 16. -- The regular season at Coney Island was begun to-day with the opening of the Manhattan Hotel, at Manhattan Beach, and the Sea Beach Palace Hotel, at West Brighton. The weather was warm and sultry and the crowd was the largest Saturday half-holiday one that has been seen at this resort in several seasons.

Judge Henry B. Kelley. Judge Henry B. Kelley of the Court of Appeals of Louisiana died this morning at his home, at New-Orleans. His history was an eventful one, and few men held higher place in the regard of the people than did this venerable jurist. He was born in 1823, in Huntsville, Ala., and was the son of Judge William Kelley, Senator from Alabama.

The Eichenkranz Society of Brooklyn, which is already making great preparations to celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary by a series of classical concerts in the Fall, came into existence in 1869 through a union formed by the Frauenlob and Quartet Club Singing Societies. Though small in the beginning, it rapidly grew to importance and prominence.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 16. -- Early this morning the enlisted men under the command of Col. J.G. Story of the Ordnance Department completed the last preparations for the reception of the troops at the camp. Few changes have been made since last season. The twenty shower baths have been increased to sixty, and a horse shed capable of accommodating 150 horses replaces the tent formerly occupied by the cavalry horses.

LONDON, June 16. -- For an uneducated, semi-savage Oriental despot, Muley Hassan has exhibited remarkable dramatic acuteness and a histrionic sense of the fitness of things in dying just at this time.
All the sales referred to in the accompanying list will take place at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated:

LONDON, June 16. -- The mutual concessions which have been made in the interest of the passage of the budget by the House of Commons by the end of the first week in July have greatly relaxed the tension of the opposing parties in Parliament. Nevertheless, the Government whips heartily wish that the coming anti-Lords conference, which is to be held in Leeds, were over.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 16. -- While other seaside towns are complaining of the backwardness of the season, this cosmopolitan resort is enjoying an early Summer "boom," and the hotel keepers in consequence wear expansive smiles as they see the crowded trains from New-York and Philadelphia roll into the Union Station.

If you will remember two little hints, you will have much less fear in going into the woods this Summer. First, poison vines, such as the ivy, have three leaflets on one stalk; therefore, beware of touching any three-leafed vine. It will be a good plan to cut out and keep the illustrations accompanying this paragraph for a reference at any time when in doubt.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 16. -- The last week, with its delightful weather, has brought scores of city people into the Catskills, and the outlook for a prosperous season is exceptionally bright. The ease of access into these beautiful mountains from New-York and Brooklyn has always been a great thing in their favor, and this year many people who have in former years spent the Summer at more distant resorts are coming to the Catskills.

PARIS, May 8. -- As I passed through the main entrance of the Old Salon, as it is now called. I met one of the most influential of Parisian art lovers. He was surrounded by his usual crowd of painters, sculptors, adepts, and flatterers. I arrested his somewhat royal progress, and, interrupting his more than animated monologue, I put the abrupt question: "Well, what is the Salon of 1894?"

When there is no drama at all in New-York -- in early Summer -- the London gay season is at its height and the theatres are all supposed to be thriving. Probably most of the London managers are making larger profits now than they were last Winter.

In retaliation for her arrest at Fanwood, N.J., last Thursday, Mrs. Annie Hoffman, who calls herself Mrs. Hoffman No. 2, charged Henry Hoffman in the Tombs Police Court yesterday with laceny. Mr. Hoffman is Superintendent of the Berwind-White Coal Mining Company of 55 Broadway, and lives at 252 Tenth Street, Brooklyn, with Mrs. Hoffman No. 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16. -- Newport's harbor is dotted once more with white-winged pleasure craft, her drives are filled with prancing horses and handsome traps each afternoon, the Casino has begun to have its visitors, and there is every evidence that the season is well begun.

PATERSON, N.J., June 16. -- To-morrow and Monday the Sabbath school of the First Presbyterian Church of this place will celebrate its centenary. In the year 1886 the lecture room of the church was damaged by fire, and the records of the Sabbath school were entirely destroyed. It has, therefore, been impossible to prepare an adequate history of the school for this occasion.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 16. -- In just ten days the first of the boat races on the Thames will take place. This year, as usual, it will be the triangular freshman contest between the Yale, Harvard, and Columbia '97 eights. With the departure of the Yale crew for its New-London quarters, the last of the oarsmen was on the scene of the race preparing for the struggle for the freshman championship.

NORWALK, Conn., June 16. -- The third annual handicap bicycle road race of the Alpha Wheel Club was held this afternoon, Mayor Edwin O. Keeler acting as judge. The course was ten miles, from the Green in this city to Gregory Point Hotel, return and repeat. The handicap limit was 5 minutes. There were seventy-three entries, including wheelmen from Brooklyn, Philadelphia, Newark, and other cities.

A fortnight before the first swallow the large bats were hawking up and down the road in the evenings. They seem to prefer to follow the course of the road, flying straight up it from the copse to the pond half way to Red Lion Lane, then back again, and so to and fro, sometimes wheeling over the Common, but usually resuming their voyage above the highway.

The Moderation Mission of Flowers made its one hundred and tenth distribution yesterday of blossoms from fields and gardens. Over 100 bunches of flowers were given away in Paradise Park, where eager eyes and lips appealed for a blossom or two. The flowers there given away carried sunshine to many a back tenement, and for a time, at least, made many hearts happy.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 16. -- The Yale Faculty to-day announced the university prizes and scholarships, as follows:

The Zollner Mannerchor is the second in Size of the German singing societies of Brooklyn. It was organized in November, 1860, by the election of L.G.T. Bruer, President C. Kauppius. Secretary, and F. Schmidt, Treasurer, A. Lux was chosen musical director, and the club was named after Carl Frederick Zollner, a musical composer of Leipsic.

The races of the Greenwich Wheelmen, to be held at Manhattan Field on Saturday next, promise to attract more than ordinary attention. There are seven events on the programme, five for class A men and two for Class B, and the entry list has already assumed large proportions. In the novice race The New-York Times has offered a gold medal that will induce the anxious youths to do their utmost.

Three of the industrial specialties made up practically the whole of yesterday's stock market. The total transactions for the day amounted to 46,910 shares, and of this amount 12,135 were in Sugar, 5,116 in Chicago Gas, and 5,995 in United States Cordage. Sugar moved between 97 1/8 and 98 1/8, and closed at the higher price, being a net gain of 1 1/8 points.

R.H. MACY CO. SIXTH AVENUE, 13TH TO 14TH STREET. We sell goods cheaper than any other house in the world, but for cash only. Sweeping reductions in slightly-soiled Ladies' and Children's Underwear, to close out; Fine French Gowns, Chemises, Drawers, Wrappers, Silk Shirts, Silk Waists, and Children's Short Coats.

Mrs. Marie S. Wyse, whose husband, William Sumner Wyse, is suing her to recover the house 28 East Twenty-eighth Street, besides stocks and bonds which he says are worth $150,000, filed her answer to his complaint yesterday.
The Essex County Country Club's house was crowded with the smart set of the Oranges yesterday afternoon, when a concert was given for the benefit of Victor I. Da Prato, the young violinist.
Last Sunday we spoke of the discoveries of the French director general of excavations in Egypt, Jaques de Morgan, at one of the brick pyramids in the waste about a day's journey from Cairo.

When the women who were anxious that women should be appointed as members of the Brooklyn Board of Education presented their petition to Mayor Schieren, he promised to reply to it as soon as he could give it the consideration which he deemed was necessary.

The feature of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's regatta yesterday was the race between the twenty-one-footer Houri, owned by W. Butler Duncan, Jr., and the Minnetonka, owned by George Work. This is the first race between boats in this class this season, and it was watched with interest:

Gold exports last week, as officially reported, reached $2,305,000. Germany took $1,500,000 and London $750,000. Imports of gold reached $13,571, which came from the West Indies. States for exchange posted Friday apply as well to Saturday, when bills are seldom sold.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Every first day of the week there falls upon the handsome great, red brick building at Pierrepont and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn, all the exaggerated silence and solemnity of a Puritan Sabbath. It is the home of the ancestors of the 400 of Brooklyn's culture and aristocracy, and the sturdy old New-England Puritans are so largely in the majority that for at least one day in the week they insist upon reigning supreme.

BOSTON, June 16. -- The usual Saturday dullness was experienced to-day in the market for local stocks, but prices held quite well, even a slight advance being experienced in some stocks. American Bell Telephone was strong under, the circumstances, the disappointment over the dividend being about offset by the prospect of favorable legislation.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., June 16. -- The poor city captive knows fall well that only a few short miles lie between him and Brentwood, where it is possible to exist without being constantly provoked by the rumble of wheels and other city noises, and where, when aspleep, one's dreams do not constantly run on "Afric's burning sands," as they are apt to do in metropolitan bed chambers when the mercury marks 98 in the open street.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 16. -- Nature must have created the place in its merriest mood. As a Summer Eden it is par excellence the leading resort in this neighborhood, which is famous for its beautiful villages and charming maidens. Malaria and mosquitoes never desecrated this Long Island paradise.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 16. -- The score or more of charming Summer resorts along the Sound are awakening after the long Winter of solitude to the fact that the season has opened, and hotels and cottages are fast filling with guests. The shores of Long Island Sound have always been a favorite place for New-Yorkers, and many of the points will he more inviting this season by reason of improvements made during the Winter.

James N. Platt, the well-known lawyer and partner of John M. Bowers in the law firm of Platt Bowers, at 52 William Street, died suddenly of heart failure at his home, 31 West Twenty-first Street, last night.

At the Berkeley Ladies' Athletic Club plans are being formulated to open a Class in which workers in Girls' Friendly and other clubs may receive instructions in light gymnastics which shall help them to give suitable drills to their club classes.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., June 16. -- The Arverne Hotel opened its doors yesterday and ushered in the season of 1894. There was no ceremony connected with the opening. All the attaches of the hotel were in their places, and the internal machinery necessary to cater successfully for an army of guests was in running order.

Five professional burglars, who are believed to have been concerned in extensive robberies in New-York and Brooklyn recently, have been captured within the past few days by Inspector McLaughlin's detectives. Photographs of four of the burglars, who have long records of crime and are well known in this country and Europe, are in the Rogues' Gallery.

In Le Nouveau Moniteur de Rome (Italy) of April 25 there appeared an interesting article under the heading "The Anti-Catholic Crusade." It is understood that the article in question was written by a distinguished Roman Catholic, the Rev. Dr. Richard L. Burtsell, who was transferred from this city to Rondout by Archbishop Corrigan, and who has been in Rome for the last two or three months.
FLUSHING, L.I., June 16. -- "Fear not, little flock, for it is your Father's good pleasure to give you the kingdom."

Dr. Alvah H. Doty, Chief Inspector of Contagious Diseases of the New-York Board of Health, yesterday advised the State Board of Health to quarantine Stapleton, S.I., without delay, to prevent the introduction into this city of a smallpox plague which prevails in that village.

The sangerfest which is to begin next Saturday in the Madison Square Garden will bring together the largest and most finely trained body of choral singers that ever assembled in the City of New-York. It is nearly twenty-five years since a music festival of this kind has been given in this city, and the preparations which have been going on all Winter insure a most interesting series of entertainments.

SING SING, N.Y., June 16. -- No agent and Warden of Sing Sing prison prior to Warden C.F. Durston, the present incumbent, ever attempted such improvements as he has and carried them out so successfully. It was never the rule for agents and Wardens to make improvements. They took possession of what was given to them, held it as long as possible, and were then relieved as politics or expediency might dictate.

Friends of the Rev. Dr. A.C. Dixon of the Hanson Place Baptist Church say they think he has made a mistake in fastening or attempting to fix on Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn the responsibility for the loose language of Police Commissioner Welles in defending the lax enforcement of the laws with regard to the closing of liquor saloons on Sunday.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 16. -- "I tell ye what it is, boys," said a lounger at the Post Office early in the week, "this hot weather will bring 'em down in shoals."

ISLIP, L.I., June 16. -- Of late years Islip has deservedly gained the reputation of being one of the most inviting and best-frequented Summer resorts of Long Island, and with each succeeding season it intrenches itself more firmly in the affections of the pleasure-loving New-Yorkers. The place is studded over with charming cottages, which have been recently renovated and decorated.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., June 16. -- The teams of the Staten Island Cricket Club and Jasper College played a closely-contested ball game at Livingston this afternoon. The feature of the game was the heavy batting of both teams. The score:

The opening games of the championship tennis tournament of the Kings County Inter-Club Tennis League were played yesterday afternoon on the courts of the Knickerbocker Field Club at Flatbush, L.I. With one exception the five clubs which belong to the league sent each two teams in the men's doubles, the only contest begun. The ladies' singles were postponed until next Saturday.

If there were any active speculation in railroad shares at this time, which most decidedly there is not, the reduction of its quarterly dividend by the New-Haven Company, and the official explanations given for the same, would have had a marked depressing effect on that class of securities. It had none, or none that amounted to anything.

Dr. D.A. Hurrison of the asylum for the insane at Breezehurst Terrace, Whitestone, L.I., was directed yesterday by Justice Gaynor to produce in the Kings County Supreme Court Mrs. Luella Oakes. Mrs. Oakes is the wife of Francis J. Oakes of the Oakes Chemical Manufacturing Company.

The following letter was sent to Police Commissioner Charles H. Murray yesterday by George McAneny, Secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, with reference to the avowed preference given to applicants for appointment on the police force because of political affiliations, in violation of the Municipal Civil Service Regulations:

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., June 16. -- The conviction of Erastus Wiman has been a very heavy blow to his family. The more because he has always been an affectionate husband and father, and because his wife and children have had unbounded confidence in and esteem and admiration for him.

NORWALK, Conn., June 16. -- The two hundred, and forty-fourth anniversary of the founding of Norwalk will be celebrated on Tuesday and Wednesday, June 19 and 20, with imposing ceremonies. These days will be observed as general holidays in Norwalk, and also in Westport, New-Canaan, and Wilton, the latter localities having once formed a portion of the original town.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 16. -- The week just closing has been one of unusual interest to the Republican politicians of Monroc County. Not in many years have caucuses for the Fall campaign been held at so early a date. This year's contest was avowedly begun thus early on account of the desire of the leaders to separate the canvass for the Congressional nomination from that for Justices of the Supreme Court.

It is not at all surprising that a German musical organization should take the name of a German poet. It was altogether due to the influence of a band of German poets that the composers of the Fatherland first sought to make their music intensely national. It was under the influence of German poets that Schubert wrote "Der Erlkonig," and Weber "Der Freischutz."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 16. -- The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the Congregational Tabernacle, has begun a crusade against the gambling places, the first fruits of which were seen in Police Justice Potts's court this morning. Acting upon evidence furnished by Mr. Scudder's agents, the police last night made raids at 44 Montgomery Street, and 28, 51, and 171 Newark Avenue, and arrested the proprietors and eighteen persons who were playing.

Mr. McCarthy has not lost his old faculty, of story telling. The cares and excitements of political life, and his studies of English political history, which have resulted in at least one very interesting volume, have not lessened his sense of the picturesque or dulled his powers of imagination.

Gen. Roy Stone, special agent and engineer in charge of road inquiry of the Department of Agriculture, has recently issued a circular calling attention to the proposed conference of road associations on the occasion of the meeting of the National Editorial Convention at Asbury Park, N.J., from July 2 to 6.

The Rev. George Frederick Burgoyne Howard, otherwise known as William Lord Moore, is safely held in the penitentiary at Columbus, but the unclaimed foreign estate industry has not been suppressed by the conviction of the most successful operator who ever was engaged in it.

Erastus Wiman spent a busy day in the Tombs yesterday receiving visitors. From 10 o'clock in the morning until late in the evening there was an almost constant stream of callers, all of whom were admitted to see the convicted man after sending in their cards to him. The pressure of visitors became so great that Warden Fallon finally turned over the council room to the prisoner.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., June 16. -- The warm weather of the last week has mellowed the touch of the billows that dash upon Far Rockaway's famous beach, and has also brightened up vegetation. Good results have come out of the modification of the atmosphere. The season has started off with a spurt, and everybody who seeks revenue from the Summer visitor is accordingly happy.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16. -- Commander C.H. Stockton was again this, forenoon before the class at the War College. His subject was the formation of war and coast defense charts. He held that such charts should show all features which enter into defense or attack. Seaports in time of war are all battlefields, though what special one will be used is not frequently foreseen.

BABYLON, L.I., June 16. -- There is joy in Babylon. The Summer visitor with trunks and bandboxes is here, and everybody is glad. Some came by day, and some in the cool of the evening. They got here, and their presence is shown in the increased life of the place. The whirl of gayety is whirling overtime already, and good intentions to rest and recuperate made early in the Spring have been forgotten.

The Old Colony steamboat Priscilla, the latest addition to the Sound fleet, will have her trial trip Thursday next. The vessel Will leave the North River, foot of Murray Street, at 11 A.M., and will return about 3 o'clock in the afternoon.
The first annual race meet of the Elizabeth Athletic Cyclers was held yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the New-Jersey State Fair Association, at Waverly Park, two miles from Newark.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 16. -- The warm weather of the past few days has sent from their city homes many of the families who spend their Summers in this part of Long Island. There is a large colony of people here now, and many more days will not elapse before the season at Southampton is well begun.

ROME, June 16. -- An attempt was made to assassinate Premier Crispi to-day, as he was riding in a carriage on his way to the Chamber of Deputies. As he arrived in the Vicinity of the Chamber at 2 o'clock this afternoon a man approached his carriage and fired two shots at him from a revolver.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16. -- This city by the sea is fast filling with visitors. The Summer girl, attractive, as of yore, in bright costumes and with a winning smile, is seen daily on the beach.

On Aug. 16, 1859, eight young men organized the Beethoven Mannerchor in Joseph Doelger's saloon in Third Street, and Organist Spoth became the musical conductor. He was followed by Ferdinand Amend, and the latter was in turn succeeded by Carl Trager, under whose energetic leadership the young organization rapidly gained strength.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 16. -- Flushing's Public Library occupies a modest-looking building. It stands at Jaggar and Jamaica Avenues, and was formerly the First Baptist Church. About four years ago, the library having outgrown its old quarters in Main Street, the present building was purchased by the library corporation and fitted up for the uses of the institution.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 16. -- William Walter Phelps, ex-Minister to Germany, died at his home in Teaneck to-night.

We advise every Democratic tariff maker, be he Senator or Congressman, and every Democratic policy maker, be he National Committeeman, Sage, or politician, to read, re-read, and many times read the report of an interview published in The Times of yesterday in which Col. A.L. Conger of Ohio set forth reasons why the Republican Party must put aside McKinley and McKinleyism and turn its face toward the future and lower duties.

The members or the Royal Arcanum are perfecting arrangements for their annual parade, which is to celebrate the seventeenth anniversary of the organization. The parade will take place in Brooklyn next Saturday evening, and it is expected that there will be at least 8,000 men in line.

A bullet killed Philip J. Moran at 562 East One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street at 5 A.M. yesterday, but an expert in gunshot wounds and a Coroner's jury must determine whether the death-wound was from the breast to the back or from the back to the breast.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 17. -- Fred T. Swain, President and principal stockholder of the Swain Lubricator Company, was shot and fatally wounded this evening at his office, 278 South Water Street, by Henry Vaughan, an engineer and former partner in the business of his victim.

It is a pretty generally received doctrine among modern sociologists that what is known as the public conscience, the standard of right and wrong in any given society, is an evolution, the resultant of innumerable experiences, from which evolved man concludes that on the whole he is happier if he does right than if he does wrong.

The following sales of realty are set down to take place to-day at 111 Broadway: By James L. Wells, auction sale, two lots, together 50.19 by 88.07 by 50.19 by 87.53, on the west side of Third Avenue, 110.4 feet south of One Hundred and Seventy-second Street.

The cruiser Cincinnati, which has made several false starts toward active service, has finally managed to get herself into commission. The vessel now flies the pennant of Commander Henry Glass. Her executive officer is Lieut. Commander J.D.J. Kelley.

Everything was bustle and business on the Harlem River yesterday, and the crews of the various boat clubs, brought out like the gnats by the warm weather, scudded up and down, the course between the Third Avenue bridge and Bronson's. All the barges were out, the trip being made in most cases to College Point, where the picnic grounds offer a pleasant change to the oarsmen.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The Navy Department officers have been watching with much interest the progress making on the timber dry dock at Brooklyn. The dock has been the subject of controversy of one kind and another since the contract was awarded to James Gillies some months ago. There was trouble about the bond, the site, and the amount of work he performed.

ALBANY, June 16. -- Notwithstanding that the offerings of local stocks have increased during the week, the tone of the market remained firm. There was less animation to the trading than for some time past. Changes in quotations were few and irregular. Celluloid stock is 1 point higher for the bid price at 68 1/2; the last sale was made at 70.

CONEY ISLAND, June 17. -- Many thousands of people came hither to-day in search of the coolness of which the cities gave them none. All the transportation companies ran carriers on the Summer schedule, and the trains and steamboats were crowded to their capacity.

A fire in the six-story factory building, 265 and 267 Cherry Street, last evening caused $4,500 damage and nearly resulted in the death by suffocation of two fire Captains and five firejnen. The men were overcome by smoke while in the building, and were rescued by their comrades.

But two days more of racing at Morris Park, to-day and to-morrow. Then the horses, the jockeys, and the crowds will move down to Sheepshead Bay, where there will be fresh sea breezes in place of the torrid blasts that have made Morris Park so very uncomfortable for the past few days.

The Gilders' Trade Section of the Central Labor Union and the Gilders' Union charge that the pictures and their frames in the Metropolitan Museum of Art are not well kept. Early in May a committee of gilders went to the museum and found that many of the frames needed repairs. They asked that they be given the work of repairing them.

THe Institute of the Holy Angels, at Fort Lee, N.J. conducted by the Sisters of Notre Dame, will have its commencement exercises and lay the cornerstone of its new chapel to-morrow afternoon. The new chapel will be of brick, with terra-cotta trimmings, and of Gothic architecture The cost is to be defrayed by subscriptions raised by a society composed of former pupils and patronesses of the institute.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- A handsome gold medal will be presented by the Union League to Rear Admiral A.E.K. Benham in recognition of his patriotic service in the harbor of Rio de Janeiro in maintaining the rights of United States merchant vessels during the Brazilian conflict.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 17. -- The A.P.A. mania which has broken out in this city with all its usual vindictiveness is rapidly becoming such a menace to the city's peace that active measures are being taken it many directions looking to its suppression. It is probably true that in no city in the country is there less need for an anti-Catholic movement of any kind than in Syracuse.

-- The Atlantic liners will play quite a conspicuous part in the midweek games which will take place in New-York this season. The team of the Germanic will encounter the Morris Heights eleven at Berkeley Oval to-day, while during the season the Campania, the Majestic, the Etruria, and others will be seen on the local grounds.
CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 17. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Neaera, Charles A. Gould; Tillie, W.H. Starbuck, and Halcyon.

Bonds have been quiet and generally strong. The breaking up of the coal strike, is looked upon as a most important event, opening the way for an improvement which a settlement of the tariff, whenever it comes, will greatly accentuate. Leading hankers express strong hopes that, while the Summer may see continued depression in the industrial world, the Fall will bring a pronounced rally.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your Sunday editorial on "Crime and Criminal Intent" suggests features of the Wiman trial that, in some instances, were overlooked by the press. For example, you admit that Wiman's "partners" were guilty of contributory negligence in doing their banking business in a manner which authorized Wiman to use the Bullinger check without objection on the part of the paying teller of the bank.
Noah Webster's definition of "dry" describes accurately the condition which confronted New-Yorkers yesterday, as far as the saloons were concerned.

Can Yale beat Oxford? That is the question that is agitating the minds of lovers of amateur athleites nowadays. Up at the New-Haven university the coming struggle between the representatives of Old Eli and the wearers of the St. George Cross is the sole topic of conversation in college circles.

BERLIN, June 17. -- Dr. Hans Blum, the author of "The German Empire in the Times of Bismarck," now promises to give the world a sensation in his suit for libel against Ignaz Auer and William Liebknecht, Social Democratic Deputies. Blum for years has associated with the least liberal of the Liberals, despite the fact that his father was shot for his democratic principles, and has launched the bitterest tirades against both Radicals and Socialists.

The weather which was apportioned to this locality yesterday was of a kind which can best be described as hot. From a sky guiltless of any cloud, the sun's blistering rays made one long for a recurrence however brief, or some of that chilling temperature which made New-Yorkers wonder when Winter would be over and when Summer would come.

PROVIDENCE, June 16. -- The local stock market for the past week has been a little more active, and a few of the bank stocks are somewhat weaker, namely, the National Bank of North America, the National Bank of Commerce, and the Third National. For the rest of the list prices remain about the same.

LONDON, June 17. -- The North German Lloyd steamer Stuttgart, from Bremen for Baltimore, with 500 passengers and a cargo of cement, went ashore at 6 o'clock this morning half a mile east of Start Point, coast of Devonshire. She was pulled off uninjured at 5 o'clock this afternoon. There was a dense fog at the time the steamer went ashore, and she had been run at half speed for hours.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- It is explained that the reason the troops recently ordered to the Indian Territory at the instigation of the Interior Department to eject intruders have not completed their work more promptly has been due to the extreme caution the Interior Department has pursued in pointing out such intruders.

The return of seasonable Summer weather has decimated the ranks of the road riders, many of whom are already off with their horses and traps to the seashore and the Summer resorts. But, while park driving diminishes with the approach of the heated term, the work of the harness horses in training at Fleetwood increases with each succeeding week.

JERSEY CITY, June 17. -- The Rev. John L. Scudder Invited the Hudson County Wheelmen to attend service at the Congregational Tabernacle this morning and listen to a special sermon on athletic sports. The club accepted the invitation, and sixty members, attired in the club uniform, rode on their wheels from the club-house, in Belmont Avenue, on the Heights, to the Tabernacle, at York and Henderson Streets.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 17. -- Bishop McQuaid, when asked to-day at the Catholic Seminary for a statement regarding the alleged snubbing by him of Father Thomas J. Ducey, pastor of St. Leo's Church in New-York City, on Decoration Day, after the consecration services in St. Gabriel's Church, New-York, was at first disinclined to discuss the matter, saying he thought it too trivial to demand notice.

(Reported by Messrs. Dick Brothers Lawrence, 30 Broad Street, New-York.) PITTSBURG, June 16. --- The home market for securities ruled very dull this week on lack of demand, save from investors who find no other use for idle funds. If there is any change at all in the money supply, it is the direction of further easement; but this is from offers of Philadelphia capital in this market.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 17. -- Dutchess County farmers are becoming afraid that they will be overwhelmed by a horde of locusts. They are swarming on trees, fences, and even on the standing grain and grass on the hillsides and meadows, and their monotonous and mournful music is heard in the field and forest from sunrise to sundown.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in, the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

For more than an hour yesterday a mad dog kept five women in a state of terror in the house, 305 One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, between Eighth and St. Nicolas Avenues. The dog was a foundling which suddenly went mad. The women were Senora Midenze and her four daughters. For several days the dog apparently had been ailing.

WEST POINT, June 17. -- The departure of graduates and furloughmen from the Military Academy marks the opening of the season here. The hotels are always so uncomfortably filled during graduation week with friends of cadets that the seeker after rest and quiet is forced to wait until the excitement is over and the transients have departed before engaging rooms.

SAN JUAN DEL NORTE, Nicaragua, June 11, (via New-Orleans, June 17.) -- Matters relating directly to the Bluefields and Mosquito Reservation affair have been of less interest here for the past five days than the sale of a good and valuable portion of the property of the Nicaragua Canal Company and the formal demand upon the Governor of this place for its return to the company.

Few people in this city outside of those directly interested in the institution are aware that there is a college in New-York where young men are not only educated as ministers of the Gospel, but also as doctors and surgeons. This institution is known as the College of the International Medical Missionary Society, and is situated at 118 East Forty-fifth Street.

The two factions of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks are again engaged in a lively war. For several years they have been carrying on more or less active warfare, hostilities having begun in a quarrel over the status of the New-York lodge.

ALBANY, June 17. -- From the number of propositions to amend the Constitution of the State now before the Constitutional Convention, it would appear that not a single section of any one article has been overlooked. Amendments covering all the sections have been introduced, and in addition many matters have been broached which are not proper subjects for the convention to consider, but rather belong to the Legislature.

Boston and Cincinnati have formed organizations for the decoration of public buildings like the Municipal Art Society of New-York, but the exhibition in Philadelphia of the cartoons that competed for the mural work in the Oyer and Terminer Courtroom has created the liveliest interest in the latter city.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 17. -- Very interesting politics will be played in Maryland during the next two years, and already the situation is becoming involved. Gov. Frank Brown has announced his candidacy for a second nomination, in the full knowledge of the fact that no Governor of Maryland has ever been re-elected since the office was filled by popular vote.

In the testimony of Mr. Vest we have an authoritative statement as to the names of the Senators who presented the Sugar Trust's demands and foisted upon the Senate Finance Committee and the Democratic Party -- so far as this could be done by the action of the Senate's Democratic majority -- the Sugar Trust's schedule of duties.

RED BANK, N.J., June .17. -- Fully 5,000 persons were present to-day at the ceremonies attending the laying of the cornerstone of the St. James's Roman Catholic Church. The weather was intensely hot, but the great crowd did not seem to mind it, and stood for hours in the glaring sunshine.

The centenary of the organization of the Sands Street Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, was celebrated yesterday by the congregation in its new edifice, the Sands Street Memorial, Henry and Clark Streets.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 17. -- Romance and mystery are mingled with the story of St. Ronan's Well, a ruined mansion that stands on a green wooded knoll overlooking Flushing Bay. Years ago a handsome mansion stood there, but now blackened and rainsoaked ruins mark the site, and the place is given over to reptiles.

For some time the British public has been puzzled and alarmed because of the mysterious smearing of the mango trees in certain districts of India. The sudden and simultaneous smearing of thousands of trees with a composition consisting chiefly of hair and grease was an incident which no one could explain.

The Surf Hotel at Fire Island, the property of the State of New-York, will nine days hence be opened again as a Summer resort. The hotel will be well remembered, if not agreeably, remembered, by a considerable number of persons who were compelled to make it their headquarters during the cholera scare two or three years ago.

GLASGOW, June 17. -- The Anchor Line Steamship Ethiopia, which sailed from New-York on June 2, arrived here this noon. As Capt. Wilson signaled off Tory Island yesterday, she collided with an iceberg in the Atlantic, and stove in her bow at and above the water line. Her passengers agree in this story of their experience:

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 17. -- The death of William Walter Phelps this morning was so peaceful that for some minutes after he had breathed his last his family, who were watching at the bedside, would not believe that the end had come. It was 1:50 o'clock when he died. The patient was unconscious to the end, and appeared to pass into a deep sleep.

HALIFAX, N.S., June 17. -- To-morrow morning Actor Charles Coghlan leaves this city for Souris, Prince Edward Island. He is accompanied by his wife. Coghlan is keeping his movements very quiet, and last night he put up at a second-rate hotel on his arrival here, in order to avoid recognition if possible.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent, through the week.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The bill introduced by Mr. Walsh of Georgia to create a commission whose business it shall be to formulate a plan for the establishment of a permanent exposition in Washington, has many advocates. The plan has commended itself to general public approval.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The belief is general among mine owners and operators in this city that 90 per cent. of the miners will go to work Monday under the Columbus scale of wages. Telegrams from the bituminous coal fields of Western Pennsylvania, Ohio, and parts of Illinois verify this prediction.
"City Corruption," was the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur's theme last evening in the Calvary Baptist Church, Fifty-seventh Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

The Church Temperance Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church, which has quarters in the Missions House, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, has commenced the formation of a Church Temperance Legion, for the benefit of boys and young men.

-- Mr. R.L. Stevenson not only has two South Sea stories ready for the magazines, but has finished a novel, which he calls "St. Ives," and has written two-thirds of another novel, entitled "The Lord Justice Clerk." The novel "St. Ives" relates the adventures of a French naval officer who was captured by the English and taken to Scotland, where he was imprisoned.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, June 17. -- Among the arrivals of the week have been Mrs. L.M. Taylor, Mrs. L. Clarke, Brooklyn; F.H. Conner, Boston; H.B. Stokes, T.C. Kelley, H.E. Tuttle, New-York; H. T. Wilhelm, S.R. Prentice, New-York; M. A. Saunders, Ralph Loveland, H.B. Noyes, Boston; Miss Fay Bunker, San Francisco; Mrs. D.A. Smith, D.A, Smith, Jr., Mrs. O. P. Hughes, Miss Agnes Hughes, Miss E.R. Hughes, Mr. and Mrs. J.M. Cowperthwait, Washington, and J.M. Pushee, Boston.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 17. -- A bigger crowd than on the first day attended the meet of the State Division, League of American Wheelmen, at Lockport yesterday. Among the officers present were forty-five members of the State Board. They met in the morning at the Grand Hotel, Chief Consul Charles H. Luscomb of New-York presiding.
William Hart, N.A. William Hart, N.A., the well-known landscape artist, died at his residence, 255 Sidney Avenue, Mount Vernon, yesterday, in his seventy-second year.

The report that cholera has reappeared in Hamburg has not been confirmed by any official notice received by Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Bureau, who is virtually the chief officer of our National Board of Health, and under whose direction the excellent sanitary inspection service at European ports was maintained last year.

JERSEY CITY, June 17. -- The Rev. Dr. John L. Scudder this evening delivered to a large congregation the sermon which he promised when, oh evidence, furnished by young men under his direction, four men alleged to be proprietors of gambling houses were arrested several days ago.

"Present appearances favor the conclusion that the industrial depression has culminated this week." So says The Chronicle of Saturday. It bases its conclusion on the "settlement" of the coal strike, although it admits that the settlement has not been acquiesced in by some of the more hot-headed miners.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 17. -- On Sunday. June 24, the commencement exercises of Yale University begin. For four days their varied programme will be continued. On the 27th, Wednesday, diplomas will be distributed to the members of the last department to graduate.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The Post tomorrow will publish an exposure of a plot which had for its object the destruction of the Capitol and, perhaps, other Government buildings, and which had been slowly developing for several weeks past. The Secret Service and police authorities, however, have been kept informed of the movements of the plotters, and would have been enabled to thwart them had their machinations approached actual violence.

Elaborate preparations are being made by the Bloomfield Cycling and Athletic Association for the great lantern parade to be held at Bloomfield, N.J., next Wednesday evening, when some 500 wheelmen, from all parts of the State, are expected to participate. Thirty-eight clubs have been invited and the Roseville Athletic Association, the Montclair Wheelmen, the Summit Casino, the Nutley, Belleville, and Rutherford Cyclers, and many others have already signified their intention of attending.

Erastus Wiman had a good many callers yesterday at the Tombs. He received a large quantity of flowers and five baskets of fruit. Mr. Wiman's children spent some time with their father both in the morning and in the afternoon.

Among the entries received up to date for the race meet on June 30 of the Kings County Wheelmen are Horace M. Alien, who finished second in the Irvington-Millburn race; F.J. Titus of the Riverside Wheelmen, and W.H. Wells of the Kings County Wheelmen, all entered for Class B events. In the Class A events Raymond McDonald, the new star of the Riversides, and the Kings County Wheelmen Beckwith and Raines will ride.

At almost every session of Congress there is laid before Senators and Representatives proof that the halls in which they meet are poorly ventilated and even supplied with air that has been polluted. The House Committee on Ventilation and Acoustics submitted a few days ago a report upon this subject.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- With the Democratic and Republican leaders predicting that the Tariff bill will be out of the way inside of ten days, and some of the enemies of the bill asserting with equal confidence that the end is not yet in sight, those who are anxious to see the measure in the hands of a conference committee find themselves in an uncomfortable position.

While reacting the reports of the recent debate on the sugar duties in the Senate, and the testimony given before the Sugar Scandal Committee, we have noticed a curious difference of opinion on the part of the representatives of the Trust and certain prominent Democratic Senators as to the amount of protection given, to the Trust in the Gorman schedule.

Music Hall was crowded from the parquet to the topmost gallery last night with proud parents, relatives, and friends to witness the graduating exercises of the class of '94 of the College of the City of New-York.

Representative Hatch of Missouri has succeeded in getting his foolish Anti-Option bill up in the House. It is greatly modified and mitigated by the changes it has undergone, but it is wrong in principle and would be pernicious in effect. It affords an illustration of the readiness with which a certain class of Democrats abandon the fundamental principles of their party under the influence of the vagaries of hare-brained Populists.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The charges made so generally these days that the Democratic Party has gone back on tariff reform are not true. The Wilson bill is an Honest attempt at this reform, and went, perhaps, quite as far in the direction of free trade as any one had a right to expect. The House of Representatives passed the Wilson bill in a reasonably short time.

There is nothing intrinsically improbable in the assertion of Dr. Hans Blum that two Social Democratic Deputies took French money when Boulanger was War Minister of France. That is to say, there is nothing improbable in it unless the character of these particular Deputies is much higher than the character of "labor politicians" in any country is very apt to be.

Whatever may fee done by the Constitutional Convention with regard to permitting the appropriation of public money for the support of "sectarian" institutions for charitable objects, it is certain that something should be done by proper authority to remedy an evil which has been growing for many years in this city.
James Olsen, a diver employed by the Chapman Derrick and Wrecking Company, came very near losing his life yesterday afternoon while searching for an anchor lost by La Touraine off Quarantine.

Mr. Hill was not quite satisfied with Mr. Vest's testimony about that visit of a group apparently led by Mr. Gorman and composed of Messrs. Gorman, Brice, Hill. Smith, Caffery, and White) to the sub-committee's room, where Mr. Gorman asked for a sugar schedule that would have given the Trust a protective duty equal to that which it enjoys under the McKinley tariff.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18. -- News received at Yokohama just before the departure of the Belgic indicated that the Corean rebellion, the termination at which has been announced by cable, had assumed serious proportions. The insurgents were reported to have succeeded wonderfully in winning the sympathy and confidence of the people in general.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Bituminous coal is not to go upon the free list. The Senate decided to-day that the rate of 40 cents a ton demanded by the "conservatives" should be granted.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 18. -- An injunction was issued this morning by Judge V.E. Peckham restraining the officers of the Grand Lodge from taking the books or appropriating any money of the Grand Lodge of the Order of Elks out of the State of New-York, the object being to prevent the adjourning of the Grand Lodge from this city to Atlantic City, N.J.

CONCORD, N.H., June 18. -- Mayor Busiel of Laeonia, by his recent announcement -- that he is a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor-an announcement only made after a careful review of the field and a conclusion that his chance for success is good-has created quite a stir in the Republican Party of New-Hampshire.

W.S. Hobart of San Francisco is going into coaching and will have a six-in-hand on the roads about here shortly. This kind of team is seldom seen except in mountainous countries, but it is as much of an improvement upon a four-in-hand as the latter is upon a pair. Unless the horses are thoroughly broken and have perfect mouths, a man of ordinary muscular development would soon find the work of driving them decidedly laborious.

GLASGOW, June 18. -- The Vigilant was towed to Glasgow from Gourock this morning and docked at the Hendersons shipyard. Capt. Haff has joined the yacht, and she will be fitted out at once under a covered shed. It will take longer to fit her than was expected, owing to the fact that her racing spars were used as a temporary bulkhead on the steamer Ethiopia, after the collision of that vessel with an iceberg.

The last meeting of the Plymouth League for the season was held last night in the Sunday school room of Plymouth Church, in Brooklyn. The league was organized soon after the death of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher for the purpose of preserving the social and general interests of Plymouth Church.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 18. -- Commander Stockton's lecture to-day before the War. College class was upon "Commere Destroying." His treatment of the subject throughout was based upon history. After alluding to the fact that the object of destroying commerce was to cause distress and the prostration of a country, thus forcing peace, he referred to the absence of international law upon the subject.

Arthur Irwin has a lively lot of ball players on the pay roll of the Philadelphia. Club, and if they continue to play the game that they put up against the Giants yesterday the public at large will realize that Philadelphlans are not slow in everything. The Quakers played with a vim and snap that were refreshing, and the poor old Giants played just the reverse.

BOSTON, June 18. -- Yesterday was the anniversary of the battle of Bunker Hill, but, being Sunday, the celebration was postponed until to-day. Everything was quiet until midnight, when the usual pandemonium broke loose, and big bonfires blazed on every available elevated point and vacant lot.

PITTSBURG, June 18. -- Col. W.A. Stone arrived from Washington with the body of Col. Thomas M. Bayne this morning. He was accompanied by Mr. Arthur Shannon, Mrs. Bayne's brother-in-law. Linn Smith and Arthur Kennedy met the party at the Unioa Station. The body was token to the home of Mrs. John M. Balph, a sister of the deceased, in Bellevue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At length, and at last, after fourteen years of Government efforts, Charleston has twenty-three feet of water on the bar, where scarcely seventeen feet were found before. The best of it is that with the completion of the jettles, which cannot be far off, there will be twenty-eight, if not thirty, feet.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Judge Advocate General Lemly delivered the papers in the Columbia's grounding inquiry to Secretary Herbert to-day at noon, when it is under-stood they, and a copy of the indorsements, were at once sent to the commanding officer of the vessel.
