WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Spain's threatened retaliation upon the United States for the proposed abrogation of the Cuba commercial treaty, whereby the sugar products of that country are admitted free into the United States in return for a material reduction in the rate of duty on exports from the United States, has not been long delayed.

The Senate Committee which is investigating the affairs of the Police Department in this city will resume work at 10:30 this forenoon. Jonn W. Goff, counsel to the committee, said yesterday that he could not say who the witnesses would be. There was a rumor that Harry Hill, once famed as the keeper of a concert hail in this city, would be called to testify.

Col. Conger's declaration that it would be political suicide for the Republican Party to enter the campaign of 1896 upon the platform of McKinleyism is important, because for the first time a representative Republican speaks out boldly the convictions that the serious and thoughtful men of that party have long entertained and privately expressed.

CITY ISLAND, June 18. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Aquillo, George A. Thayer; Marion, James J. Faye; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Evelyn, J.K. Hegeman; Helvetia, C. O'D. Iselin; Hirondell. C. G. Evans, and Tillie, W.H. Starbuck. Sloop yacht Chispa, F.L. St. John.

With a cracking southerly wind that got up at the start and blew without flagging till the finish to aid it, the Pavonia Yacht Club held its twenty-fifth annual regatta yesterday. The racing was most successful from all points of view, and the 500 and odd persons, men, women, and children, who followed the races on the iron steamboat Cygnus, chartered by the yacht club for the occasion, spent a most enjoyable day.

Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, so long famous for its charities, laid yesterday, with impressive cerempnies, the cornerstone of a group of buildings which are destined to be the crowning glory of the philanthropic work done by the members of that organization of Christian workers.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire, to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Richard Watson Gilder, Chairman of the Tenement-House Commission, has received from President C.G. Wilson of the Health Department suggestions and data that will be used in solving the problem of making the lives of those who live in tenement houses happier and healthier.

GLASGOW, June 18. -- J.D.B. Ramsay of Madison, Wis., who was a passenger on the Ethiopia when she came into collision with an iceberg on June 6, says the shock frightened the passengers greatly, everybody rushing to the decks. Glasses and dishes were thrown to the floor and articles of funiture were overturned.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- "Jaxon is a crank of the first water, and therefore will bear watching," said Chief Brennan to-day, referring to the half-breed former resident of Chicago, who was the leader of the Anarchistic plot to blow up the Capitol, the Treasury, War, and Navy Buildings at Washington.

NEW-LONDON, June 18. -- The Yale and Harvard Varsity crews and the Harvard and Columbia freshmen were on the river this evening, but they did not indulge in any long speed trials, contenting themselves with practice in starts and pulling over distances of half or three-quarters of a mile and receiving instructions from the coaches, with a view to the correction of individual faults.
-- John Yeats, a prominent iron merchant of St. John, N.B., and a Director and Vice President of the Bank of New-Brunswick, is dead. He was born to St. John in 1829.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 18. -- Seldom is there such a crowd of bicycle races as those that were run oft at the new Waltham track this afternoon. There were 5,000 people present, and the sport was unusually good. The contests were all sharp and the times were very fast.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 18. -- The Fall River Line steamer Plymouth is ashore on Rose Island, about half a mile from her landing place here. She lies on Spindle Rock at a bad place, and her hull compartments are undoubtedly broken.

Ex-Alderman Join J. Morris, who had been confined for two months to the Chambers Street Hospital, died there at 12:15 o'clock this (Tuesday) morning. None of Mr. Morris's family was with him at the time, only the house burgeon and a nurse being in attendance.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -- It was a drifting market ail day, and so narrow that traders were even more apathetic than heretofore. A drive was made at St. Paul, but as it was mostly short stock that was sold it rallied as soon as the pressure was off. Toward the close an effort was made to offer down Reading, and it sold at the equivalent of 16 3/4.

Secretary Sullivan of the Amateur Athletic Union says that among the bicycle riders of Hudson County there is great rejoicing now that The New-York Times has decided to present to the winner of the two-mile special scratch race, that is to be given by the New-Jersey, Athletic Club on July 4 at its carnival of sports, a handsome gold medal. This race is for the championship of the county.

The play in the Hudson River Tennis Association's championship tournament, which was continued yesterday on the courts of the Yonkers Tennis Club, Palisade Avenue, Yonkers, was of an interesting character. The Sands brothers of the New-Hamburg Club both won, C.E. Sands having the easier time, as his opponent failed to secure a game during the two sets played.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 18. -- The attempt to take away the steamer Silvia's cargo by force was not made last night, as anticipated. The steamer arrived in the midst of a heavy rainstorm, which lasted nearly all night, and the lauding of the cargo before morning was out of the question. This morning the steamer was taken across the Harbor, where a lot of hay was landed.

PATERSON, N.J., June 18. -- An accident happened at the River Street crossing of the Susquehanna Railroad, in this city, at an early hour this morning, in which twelve persons came near losing their lives by being ground beneath the wheels of the Deckertown express.

PITTSBURG, June 18. -- But few reports reached the city from the Pittsburg mining district to-day. It is safe to say, however, that at least one-half of the mines were started, and by Thursday it is expected that a majority will be in operation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -- Henry G. Bryant, the youngest man who has ever led an arctic expedition, and the party of six who will go with him to bring back Lieut. Peary from the far north, will rendezvous at dinner in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, to-morrow evening. They will leave New-York on Wednesday on the steamer Portia for St. John's, where the steam whaler Falcon awaits them.
Messrs. Douglas Robinson Co. have sold, for Louis Blun to Mrs. J. Russell Soley, the four-story high-stoop brownstone dwelling 70 East Fifty-fourth Street, 18.9 by 55 by 100, at about $26,000.

The Plymouth was launched from the shipyards of the John Roach Company, at Chester, Perm., in April, 1890. She is not so large as the Pilgrim and Puritan, but she is their equal in other respects. The vessel is a gracefully-proportioned craft, and is fitted with all the improvements and appliances which go to make up the modern passenger steamboat.

Goodwin Swift of 66 Broadway, electric and surface railroad constructors, promot ers, and bankers made an assignment yesterday to Lawyer Arthur E. Walradt of Doming Walradt of 11 William Street, without preferences. The liabilities are stated to be between $500,000 and $750,000, and the assets very large, but not immediately available.
James Francis Forshay shot his little son, Walter Steward to death in the kitchen of his home, 34 Vandam Street, yesterday afternoon, and then shot himself dead.

The Church of the Paulist Fathers, at Fifty-ninth Street, gives little evidence outside of Its fine proportions and its decoration within. Like the house of an Oriental or the basilicas of Ravenna, its dingy and repellent exterior acts as a foil to its fine interior and adds to the pleasurable surprise.
The old cruiser Marion, which has apparently been trying to make a record for an extended voyage, yesterday limped into San Francisco Harbor four months out from Tokohama.

William J. H. Trainor, "Supreme President" of the A. P. A., has been in the East some time to stimulate the work of organizing branches of the association of proscription. According to the Boston Journal he is now in that city to help the cause along, and, incidentally, to attend a convention of Orangemen, he being Vice President of the Imperial Grand Orange Lodge of the world.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 18. -- The twenty-seventh Annual convention of the American Railway Mechanics' Association met in the village ball at 10 o'clock this morning, and was called to order by President John Hickey of St. Paul, Minn., Superintendent of Motive Power of the Northern Pacific Railway. Prayer Was offered, by the Rev. George Royal of Chicago.

BOSTON, June 18. -- Mystic Park had its share of holiday pleasure seekers this afternoon, but the Circuit meeting began with a disappointment. The much-talked of 2:10 pace failed for want of three starters, all the slow ones being afraid of Paul. Blanche Louise was ready, though she had pulled up lame in her work, and Gil Curry would have started but for an objection to the entry of his gray pacer.

LONDON, June 18. -- The Anti-Lords Conference will be opened in Leeds at 11 o'clock on Wednesday morning, with Spence Watson in the chair. The committee of the Liberal Federation will submit to the conference three resolutions.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Secretary Lamont proposes to abolish the recruiting depot, and probably in view of this determination no more appropriations will be made by Congress for this purpose. The depot has been a sort of extra station, where the recruit was sent en route to the army post.

BOSTON, June 28. -- The open race of the Massachusetts Yacht Club, an event always looked forward to with anticipation by the local clubs as a part of the celebration or Bunker Hill Day, was sailed to-day off Nahant under very favorable conditions of wind and weather. A fresh southeasterly breeze and a smooth sea gave all the boats a good chance, and there was some lively sailing.

"I am of the opinion that the whole New-York. City delegation in Congress, with one exception, should be returned, at the election this Fall," said Controller Fitch to a reporter for The-New-York Times yesterday. "It Is an excellent delegation, and I believe the best interests of the city and the best interests of the Democratic Party would be conserved by its return.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Half a dozen Senators testified before the Sugar Trust investigation committee to-day. None of them admitted that he had speculated in sugar stock.

A Summer Parliament will be held at Long Beach during the coming season for such as may desire profitable recreation and entertainment without the surfeit and exhaustion attending the usual Summer assemblies.

The politicians, both Republican and Democratic, were very much surprised yesterday morning when they read in a morning paper that William Brookfield, Chairman of the Republican State and County Committees was going to resign both offices because he was heartily tired of the factional strife in the Republican Party and wanted to get out of politics.

PARIS, June 18. -- Alfred Andre, Director of the Bank of France, and a conspicuous member of the Young Men's Christian Association, gave a dinner this evening in honor of James Stokes of New-York. More than 100 persons, all members of the Young Men's Christian Association were present. The host proposed the health of President Carnot, and ex-Minister Jules Siegfried gave the toast to Mr. and Mrs. Stokes.

The appeal of John Y. McKane from his conviction in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, in Brooklyn, of misconduct of registry offices, reached the General Term, in Brooklyn, yesterday, and a great crowd was present to hear Col. E.C. James battle for the ex-Czar's freedom against Edward M. Shepard, through whose efforts McKane is now in Sing Sing.

The Civil Service Reform Association calls attention to the fact that the State law of May 19, 1894, which was intended to give the veterans of the war greater immunity from the restrictions of the Civil Service law, has really accomplished a result directly opposite to the one aimed at.

Ex-Congressman A.L. Conger of Akron, Ohio, formerly a member of the Republican National Committee from Ohio, whose interview in opposition to McKinleyism published in The New-York Times of Sunday, has attracted such widespread attention, arrived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. He is on his way to attend the commencement exercises at Harvard University.
Members of the New-York State Democracy met last night in several of the Assembly districts of the city to complete their organizations, and to elect members of the Executive Committee.

The suit of Augustus Cook, formerly a member of the Lyceum Theatre company, against his wife, Annie Cook, for an annulment of their marriage was tried at Special Term of the Supreme Court, before Judge Dugro, yesterday Mrs. Cook's stage name is Madge Carr, and she is a member of the Lyceum company.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 18. -- The work of securing a jury for the trial of Lizzie Halliday, the alleged Burlingham murderess, was begun Before Judge Edwards in a Special Term of Oyer and Terminer this afternoon. The crime with-which-she is now charged is the murder of Sarah McQuillan, the younger of the two women whom she decoyed from Newburg last September.

A performance which may possibly turn out to be amusing will take place to-day and Thursday at Creedmoor. Today the commander, staff, and First and Second Divisions of the First Naval Battalion will go to Creedmoor to shoot rifles at targets. On Thursday the petty staff and the Third and Fourth Divisions will go.

The stock market yesterday was extremely dull and fluctuations were narrow and unimportant. The opening was in good demand by the shorts, who covered fair lines. When this movement ceased the market became almost stagnant. The stock moved within 1 1/4 points all day, and closed 8/4 higher than on Saturday, at 99. The The transactions in it amounted to only 26,700 shares.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The declaration by Col. A.L. Conger of Ohio in favor of an anti-McKinley policy by the Republicans has caused considerable comment here, where Col. Conger is well known as one of the most active Republicans in the country. The Republican leaders in the Senate who are grumbling over the highly protective duties given by the revised Tariff bill are naturally not very well pleased with Col. Conger's views.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 18. -- The Cornell crew arrived in Ithaca at 6 o'clock this evening. There was a large welcoming party and the crew was drawn in state around the city in a gayly-decorated coach. The celebration has been postponed until to-morrow night, when there will be a double celebration if the freshman crew succeed in defeating the Dauntless crew of New-York.

A complete plan of reorganization of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad was approved yesterday by the committee of which R. Somers Hayes is Chairman. Some modification in the original draft were made to meet the wishes of foreign security holders, and the committee, it is said, now has satisfactory assurance of co-operation oil the part of the foreign holders.

Charles Hadlick, the Post Office clerk who was charged by George Appo before the Lexow committee with being an accomplice of green-goods operators, was suspended yesterday by Postmaster Dayton. His suspension will remain in force pending an investigation into the charges against him.

WHITESTONE, L.I., June 18. -- The Trustees of this village have not held a full meeting in three months, and there seems to be no probability that they can agree long enough to transact town business and provide for paying bills.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Secretary Carlisle is to render an opinion whether it is advisable to build the Nicaragua Canal by an issue of bonds or to pay for the construction in part by a coinage of the seigniorage in the Treasury.

Washington, June 19 -- Secretary Carlisle, Mrs. Carlisle, Logan Carlisle, and Miss Berry, daughter of Representative Berry of Ketuoky, will leave here to-morrow on the lighthouse tender Maple for a four days' cruise on Chesapeake Bay.

The will of Architect Edwin Baker, who died Monday morning at his home, 157 Congress Street, Brooklyn, was yesterday filed for probate with the Surrogate of Kings County, by John Sands, Sr., of 51 Decatur Street, Brooklyn.

At auction in the Trinity Building salesroom, yesterday, Mr. Peter F. Meyer sold, under foreclosure, at $19,687, to John C. Sullivan, the five-story brick flat 1,797 Lexington Avenue, east side, 46.11 feet south of One Hundred and Twelfth Street, 27 by 73.
Thousands of people saw Charles I. beheaded in 1648. It was a great show, a genuine tragedy, and free to the public.

ARLINGTON, N.J., June 19 -- The quiet village of Arlington has been greatly disturbed by an enraged father, who, armed with a shotgun, has been looking for the man who has carried off and married his sixteen-year-old daughter.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- After a fairly steady opening the market became feverish, but could not be called active. A drive was made at Reading, based on the report that the May statement would not make a very favorable showing on account of damage to the mines and railroad by the late floods.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 19 -- There was a clash between referee and riders at the second day's meet of the Bridgeport Wheel Club at Pleasure Beach. to-day. Bald, Titus, Coleman, Graves, and Warren, were out for the mile open, first heat. No time limit was placed, and all refused to set the pace.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 19 -- A large crowd was present to-day, when Judge Edwards took his seat on the bench for the second day of the trial of Mrs. Halliday for the murder of Sarah J. McQuillan. The jury secured last night was polled, and District Attorney Hill began his opening address to the jury.

The proceedings instituted in the name of John J. Emery for the purpose of preventing the execution of the proposed, general mortgage for $70,000,000 by the NewYork, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company came on for argument yesterday in Supreme Court, Chambers, upon an order to show cause why art injunction should not issue to prevent the proposed execution of the mortgages.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Georgetown University to-day celebrated its seventy-seventh annual commencement in the presence of many distinguished persons, including Vice President Stevenson and Cardinal Gibbons. Previous to the regular exercises, Cardinal Gibbons officiated at the unveiling of a bust of Judge William Gaston of North Carolina, the first student of the college, and after whom the public hall was named.

Commencement exercises of the class of '94, Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn were held last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The large stage was set as a drawing room, and was handsomely decorated with plants and flowers. The body of the house and the galleries and boxes could not accommodate the friends of the graduates and of the Institution.
The Brooklyn Aldermanic committee on Water and Drainage recently made two tours of inspection of the city water works, which cost the city $494.40.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 19 -- Archbishop Tache, who for more than forty years has been the head of the Roman Catholic Church in Manitoba and the Canadian Northwest, is dying to-night, and sinking very rapidly. He cannot live until the morning.

The Manhattan Bicycle Club held another of its well-chosen and enjoyable runs last Saturday and Sunday The start was made on Saturday after noon, the men taKing the steamer Mary Powell to Newburg. Newburg was reached at 5:45 P. M., and the riders had a most pleasant evening run by the light of a glorious full moon to Cromwell Lake, near Highland Mills.

-- Here and There -- Judge Pryor and his daughter, Miss Fanny Pryor, will sail for Southampton to-day on the steamer New-York. They have taken rooms at the Grand Hotel, in London, for the next few weeks, after which they will travel extensively on the Continent. Mrs. J.H. Hallenbeck and the Misses Hallenbeck of 111 West Seventy-sixth Street will leave town in a few days for Saranac Lake.

An examination in the case of Leander Richardson, editor of The Dramatic News, who was charged with assaulting John T. Sullivan, was had yesterday afternoon before Justice Ryan at the Jefferson Market Police Court.

Several complaints have been made recently against the Salvation Army by people who say that the army has become a nuisance in their neighborhoods, disturbing their Sunday rest and keeping them awake at night.

That Congressman W. Bourke Cockran is soon to return to full political affiliation with Tammany Hall is now hardly a matter of doubt. Everything points in that direction, and, indeed, it can be safely surmised that it is only a matter of selecting the most opportune time for his return to his former activity in the affairs of the organization.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The first result of Secretary Herbert's Pacific coast tour is an official investigation of the new Puget Sound naval station. Capts. Asserson, Menocal, and Prindle of the Civil Engineers' Corps left New-York privately last Friday night for Seattle on a mission the nature of which has been carefully kept private.

At last the new Rapid-Transit Commission is fully organized and has established its quarters permanently at 260 Broadway. Mr. Lewis L. Delafield, whom it has chosen as its Secretary, is a capable and public-spirited citizen, who has been a consistent advocate of a genuine system of rapid transit for the city and who is pretty sure to devote himself assiduously to promoting the work of the commission.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- There was little in to-day's market requiring comment one way or the other. Trading was limited in the extreme and the general sentiment of the room was bearish, influences were generally of an unfavorable tenor. Lake Street L was lower, on injunction proceedings secured by the Northwestern L Company.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The weekly telegraphic crop reports issued to-day by the Weather Bureau show the following results:

Nelson Wheatcroft, director of the Empire Theatre Dramatic School, comes from his Summer home in Seabright, N.J., every day to examine the applicants for admission to the next term of the school. Nobody is accepted who does not give evidence of ability for some line of stage work, and the rejections far outnumber the acceptances.

Yonkers. -- When the men who are building a sewer in South Broadway, near Lowerre, went to work yesterday morning they found an unknown man lying unconscious by the roadside. He was sent to St. Joseph's Hospital, where he died. He appeared to be a laborer, thirty years old. There was nothing about him to disclose his name or home.

The marriage of Miss Carrie Sfeiden to Thomas Hunt of Boston took place at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, in West Eighteenth Street. The Rev. Dr. Gallaudet, rector of the church, officiated.

Peculiar disclosures in regard to the circumstances under which Mrs. Luella Oakes, the wife of Francis J. Oakes, a chemical manufacturer of New-York, was transferred from a private sanitarium for inebriates in Whitestone, L.I., to an insane asylum at Darien, Conn., were made yesterday before Justice William J. Gaynor in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

The preparations for the Sangerfest of the Northeastern sangerbund, which is to begin on Saturday in the Madison Square Garden, are approaching completion. Outside the Garden yesterday workmen were industriously hammering on the triumphal arch at Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.

BERLIN, June 19 -- It is reported that Sir Edward Malet, British Ambassador, has sent his resignation to his Government in London, stating as the reason for his wish to retire that it is impossible for him longer successfully to represent the interests of England at the Court of the Kaiser, since, owing to recent acts of the British Cabinet, the confidence of the Emperor has been lost.
In the presence of members of the Stock Exchange and of a good attendance in the galleries, the ensign and compass of the Kearsarge were yesterday presented to the Government with fitting ceremony.

This afternoon the Coney Island Jockey Club begins its meeting at the beautiful Sheepshead Bay track. It will last for sixteen days, the Suburban being run to-morrow afternoon as the fourth race on the card. Most of the stables that have been racing at Morris Park have already moved to the Coney Island track, so that after to-day there will be plenty of horses for all the races.

The historical information about the relations of the police to the criminal classes in ancient times, elicited yesterday by the Lexow committee, was of undoubted interest. It was also of some value as showing how inveterate is the corruption of the upper ranks of the force and how necessary it is that any reform of it, to amount to anything, must be radical and thoroughgoing.

Eugene Leigh, part owner of the race horse Clifford, was one of the crowd of visitors that was at Morris Park yesterday afternoon to see the Great Eclipse and the Belmont Stakes run. It was the eighteenth and last day of the most successful meeting ever held by the New-York Jockey Club. The attendance has been uniformly large and the gate receipts have been simply enormous.

Weakness of the receivership group was the feature in yesterday's stock market. The semi-official announcement of an agreement on a plan of reorganization for the Atchison Company, involving an assessment of $12 a share on the common stock, induced selling of not only Atchison but others of the group.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning, consists of TEN PAGES. It contains:
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Three witnesses were examined by the Sugar Trust investigators to-day, but the testimony of none of them was important.

While Michael P. Ryan, the former Principal of the Gravesend Public School, and assistant of John Y. McKane, is serving his sentence in the Kings County Penitentiary, his property is being disposed of by law to satisfy the claims of his creditors.

Ex-State Treasurer Danforth having explained at Monday's hearing, before Referee Choate, in the case between, the receivers of the Madison Square and St. Nicholas Banks, how he saved the State's deposit of $250,000 from the Madison Square wreck, Frederick Uhlmann gave his reasons yesterday for saving $50,000 of the East River Bridge Company's money after he knew the Madison Square was insolvent.

There was a tentful of boys at the meeting last evening in the lot at Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twelfth Street. The meeting was under the direction of the Baptist Boys' Brigade, and companies were present from the Baptist churches of NewYork.

CINCINNATI, June 19 -- At the meeting of the Western Turf Congress, which adjourned at 12:45 this morning, the Washington Park Racing Assuciation was, upon application, elected a member of the congress. Hawthorne Park also made application for membership, but the application was voted down and the Secretary instructed to notify the association that a license would be granted it if such should be desired.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- If the Senate had rules which would enable the majority to exert the power it caught to possess, the Tariff bill would be in the hands of the conference committee inside of three days.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- The boom was out of wheat to-day, and prices were almost as weak as they were strong yesterday. They did not break as quickly nor with such nervous excitement as they displayed when advancing, but melted away gradually under the pressure of long wheat that did not all come out at once. Yesterday's enthusiastic buyers were cautious sellers to-day, and the seaboard let go of immense quantities throughout the session.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 19 -- The one hundred and twenty-eighth annual commencement of Rutgers College was held to-night. There was a largely-attended meeting of the alumni association. The report showed that twenty-four members died during the year.

Many of the merchants in the neighborhood of Broadway and Duane Street are complaining that the mall boxes in the hallways of buildings are being systematically robbed. G.A. Matteson, a hardware broker, at 111 Duane Street, has lost letters containing more than $1,000 in remittances, and how much more he will not know until complaints of receipts for remittances not being received are sent in.
PATERSON, N.J., June 19 -- During the electrical storm which passed over this section between 1 and 2 o'clock this afternoon the town was in almost total darkness.

ALBANY, June 19 -- This has been a day of hearings in Albany on constitutional amendments equally as important as those that will take place to-morrow. The committee rooms were buzzing from noon to 10 o'clock to-night, with the exception of two hours, from 6 to 8 o'clock.

Patrick H. Corrigan, Superintendent of the Brooklyn Truants' Home, was a reluctant witness yesterday before the special Aldermanic committee which is investigating the home and its management. The hearing was held in the City Hall. Mr. Corrigan's counsel, J. Stewart Ross, was present to advise him as to answering questions put to him by the committee.
All auction sales announced for yesterday in Brooklyn were adjourned.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Attorney General Olney has instructed Acting United States District Attorney Platt of the Southern District of New-York to at once institute suit in that district before United States District Judge Wallace against the North American Commercial Company to recover $132,000 for last year's rent and premium on sealskins due the Government from the company.

STAPLETON, S.I., June 19 -- The fact that a new case of smallpox has been reported to the Health Board of this place and the house where the case is said to exist has been quarantined became known to-day. Health Officer Feeny declared this to be like the others, a case of confluent chickenpox, but the public confidence in Dr. Feeny has become somewhat shaken by the positive statements of New-York and Brooklyn health officers.

None mourned more sincerely the death of Walter Forshay, the bright little fellow killed by his insane father at their home, 34 Vandam Street, on Monday afternoon, than his fellow-pupils to Public School No. 8, in King Street.

BALTIMORE, June 19 -- The trial of Dr. John D. Kremien for the murder by poison of Herman Hanbuch, alias John Forre, was continued in the Criminal Court today. Several witnesses were examined, and the evidence adduced was strongly against the prisoner. It was stated that just before Forre's death he said to his nurse: "The doctor knows I have money, and is killing me for it."
There were several runaway accidents in the city yesterday, but only one person was injured.

NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., June 19 -- JudgeChapman rendered his decision to-day in the Bonacum-Corbett case. Corbett's attorney gave notice of exceptance, and furnished bonds. Following is an extract of the decision:

The reports made by the Captains of the Eleventh and Fourteenth Precincts to the Superintendent of Police with reference to the existence of disorderly and illegal resorts, for the first quarter of 1892, referred to in the proceedings of the investigating committee at the morning session yesterday, were not made to Superintendent Byrnes, but to his predecessor, Superintendent Murray.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 19 -- The steamer Plymouth did not come off Rose Island at high tide this morning. Tugboat men desired to make a grand united pull and were allowed to do so by Supervisor Pierce, though he told them that it would be labor lost, and so it was.

TROY, N.Y., June 19 -- At the trial of "Bat" Shea this morning Ellis D. Haner, an Election Inspector, told of the prisoner forcing his way into a booth and assaulting him. Osborn O. Lansing, an eye-witness of the shooting, testified to the scuffle between Haner and Shea and his gang.

It was virtually decided yesterday that the city banks, will stand between the Treasury Department and further depletion of the gold reserve. The reserve is now $66,984,446, the lowest point since it was strengthened in February last by the bond issue of $50,000,000. Export demands for the next thirty days are estimated at $15,000,000.

BRADDOCK, Penn., June 19. -- The extent and damage by the cloudburst in the Turtle Creek Valley last evening was much greater than first reports indicated. Several persons are missing, and there is but little doubt that they were drowned. Growing crops were swept away and many buildings were wrecked.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 19 -- At exactly 7 o'clock this evening the Cornell freshmen crew crossed the line at the end of the two-mile race five lengths ahead of their rivals, the senior eight of the Dauntless Rowing Club of New-York. Cornell had an easy race, and won it with but little exertion.

This city welcomed the pouring showers which deluged the streets during yesterday. The weather was variable, the sun appearing at one moment, while the next it would be hid behind clouds, big rain drops pattering down. Shortly after noon there was a heavy thunder storm, accompanied by rain and vivid lightning.
The monthly report of the Civil Service Reform Association gives an interesting summary of the work which has been accomplished and of the things that have happened during the period covered.

We have no wish to make Col. A.L. Conger of Akron, Ohio, either a hero or a martyr, and if the views expressed by him, and published by The Times on Sunday last, with reference to the past and future of McKinleyism, have tended in either of those directions, it is not our fault.

While every Republican politician, as shown by The New-York Times, carefully dodges the American Proscriptive Association issue, a Republican paper is occasionally found which is not so discreet, and which does not feel called upon to mask its true sentiments of friendliness for the un-American propaganda of proscription.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 19 -- Never yet has the story been told of all the relations which the monster Sugar Trust bears to the lawmakers at Washington, who are charged with the making of laws affecting directly the cash account of that great monopoly. One chapter, which will startle all who have any interest in the progress of affairs at Washington, is furnished in some recent transactions in this city.

When the Brooklyn City Hall bell rings the hour of noon to-day the steamer Portia will depart from Robinson's Stores with the members of the Peary Auxiliary Expedition for St. John, N.B. There they will transfer to the whaler Falcon and start out on their search for Lieut. Peary and his brave wife and crew.

Police Justice Patrick Divver was accused by Frank Clark, a witness before the Lexow committee yesterday, with having started Edward Parmley Jones, the green goods, bunko, and three-card-monte man, in business. According to Clark's testimony, when Parmley Jones came to New-York he was a "straight" man, and Divver gave him the money to begin business.

An attachment was received yesterday by the Sheriff for $44,018 against Peter Mallett as surviving partner of the firm of Peter Mallett Co., warehousemen at 5 Hanover Street, in favor of the Empire Warehouse Company for money alleged to have been collected by the firm acting as agents of the company and never turned over to the company.

John S. Johnson, the Western cyclist, paid a flying visit to town last evening, accompanied by his trainer, "Tom" Eck. Johnson came on from Bridgeport. He was met at the station by George De Shay and Charles Scheier, the Chairman and Secretary, respectively, of the Race Committee of the Greenwich Wheelmen, at whose race meet on Saturday next the Western wonder is booked to ride.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Nicaragua Canal bill is rapidly assuming definite form. At to-day's meeting of the special committee which is engaged in formulating the measure it was decided that the number of Directors shall be limited to eleven, eight for the United States and one each for Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and the stockholders of the defunct Maritime Company.

Clifford Pemberton, Jr., Secretary of the Athletic Association of the University of Pennsylvania, writes to The New-York Times and says that Pennsylvania, "having challanged Yale to play a third game, claims the championship for 1894, as Yale declined the challenge." Secretary Pemberton's figures for the "big six" college nines to date are:

LONDON, June 19 -- The Ascot Stakes (handicap) of 20 sovereigns each, with 1,000 sovereigns added, distance about two miles, was won by Mr. A. Taylor, Jr.'s, Aborigine, 4 years. Sir R. Jardine's Red Ensign, 4, ran second, and Mr. T. Wadlow's Spindle Leg, 4, third. Glengall led Hettie Sorrel, Aborigine, and Quilon one-third of the way from the start, when Houndsditch passed Glengall and was followed by Hettie Sorrel, Theseus, and Red Ensign.

If Senator Aldrich had been less censorious of Democratic foibles, if he had shown or simulated less solicitude about Sugar Trust influence over Democratic legislators, he would not now appear the disgusting hypocrite that The Times's exposure of his close money connection with the Trust makes him out.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The income-tax provision of the Tariff bill is to be placed on the Senate rack to-morrow. By an agreement reached this afternoon all the amendments already offered are to be printed to-night for the convenience of Senators, and to-morrow the struggle if to begin in earnest.

LONDON, June 20 -- The University of Oxford, at its commemoration festival to-day, conferred the honorary degree of D.C.L. upon Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, commander of the United States cruiser Chi-. cago. The oration conferring the degree was delivered in Latin, and the exercises closed with great enthusiasm.
Following are the main points of the plan of reorganization, given out yesterday by the Atchison Reorganization Committee:

Benjamin Stoddert Ewell, President of William and Mary College, died Tuesday night at his home in James City, Va. He was born in Washington, June 10, 1810. He was a grandson of Benjamin Stoddert, first Secretary of the Navy. He was graduated at West Point in 1832, and assigned to the Fourth Artillery.

There was a public hearing of those interested in the reconstruction of the bridge over Newtown Creek, Long Island City, in the Army Building yesterday. Lieut. Col. G.L. Gillespie presided. Lucien Knapp of Long Island City made a speech recommending that the bridge be abolished and a tunnel be substituted.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The market has been, almost without feature throughout the, day and very dull. Philadelphia Traction announced an allotment of 100,000 shares of new stock at par -- $50 per share. The stockholders have the right to subscribe to one share of new stock for every two shares of old stock held by them.

Mr. Jefferson M. Levy, who soiled for Europe on the steamship New-York yesterday, has purchased, through E.A. Cruikshank Co., the five-story brick hotel building 1S West Street, 26.8 by 90, at $35,000. The seller was Robert C. Embrce, trustee for Alexander C. Bowden. This is the first transfer of the property since 1828.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Gwinn R. Hancock, a grandson of the late Major Gen. W.S. Hancock, who was appointed to the Military Academy by the President, will be admitted to that institution, although it is said the physicians have found him disqualified. The findings of the Medical Board, however, are based on a condition which the candidate says is due to the effort he has made recently to post himself for the entrance examination.

-- Chief Consul J.S. Holmes of the New-Jersey Division, League of American Wheelmen, says he will not reverse his decision, given at the Union County Roadsters, whereby C.M. Earts was disqualified. Mr. Holmes disqualified Earts, he says, for foul riding.
Harry Chamberlain, twenty-two years old, is in Bloomingdale Insane Asylum, and the members of his family refuse to clear up the mystery that surrounds his being taken there.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
Mrs. Luella Oakes, the wife of Francis J. Oakes, the millionaire chemical manufacturer, who for three years has been in an asylum, was formally liberated by Justice Gaynor yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 20 -- There was a hearing this afternoon before the Constitutional Convention Committee on Suffrage on Mr. Holl's proposition amendment, which empowers the Legislature to enforce, by law, the duty of voting. It is proposed that laws shall be made for ascertaining by proper proof the citizens whose duty it shall be to exercise the right of suffrage, and providing suitable penalties for the neglect of such duty.

The big open tennis tournament of the West Side Tennis Club was continued yesterday afternoon at the courts at Central Park ,West and Eighty-ninth Street. The prizes were placed on exhibition at the grounds, and are exceptionally fine. A gold watch is offered for the winner of the men's singles, the runner-up receiving a silver flask.

-- The General Passenger Agents of the railroads running into Pittsburg, and, in fact, all those included in the Central Traffic Association, met yesterday in this city. The meeting was called to consider the details of the matter of the Grand Army of the Republic men who will visit Pittsburg and attend their convention, to be held there some time in September.

St. John's, N.F., June 20 -- The English war ship Pelican was stranded in the Bay of Islands, on the west coast of Newfoundland, but was floated without much trouble. She ran aground on Sandy Shoal, where she remained eight hours, till flood tide, when the mail steamer Grand Lake towed her off. She suffered but slight damage.

On account of the exposures by The New-York Times of the shameful methods of the American Prescriptive Association, the leaders and champions of that society have been hard at work recently making efforts to blind the public as to the true objects of the "patriots."

ITHACA, N.Y., June 20 -- The Stewart L. Woodford Prize in Oratory was won to-night for the first time in the history of Cornell by a woman. She is Harriet Chedie Connor of Burlington, Iowa. Only once before in the history of the Woodford contests has a woman been a competitor. The contestants were:

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 20 -- Several of the star witnesses for the prosecution, in the case which a New-York newspaper is making against Superintendent Brockway, the Board of Managers, and the Elmira Reformatory, testified at the sessions of the commission to-day. They were inmates of the reformatory who claimed to have suffered great cruelty at the hands of Superintendent Brockway.

"Straight ticket or no straight ticket" is the great question now among the Republicans, politicians and others. As a general proposition, the exact condition of the plans of the Republican politicians is stated as follows: "If we cannot be certain of electing a straight Republican local ticket this Fall, give us a Republican for Mayor and let the Democrats have the other places on the ticket."

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Judge Dittenhoefer of New-York made an argument today before the House Committee on Patents in behalf of the New-York Dramatists' Association, of which Bronson Howard is President. He argued in favor of an amendment to the copyright law making it a misdemeanor to pirate copyrighted plays, and providing that an injunction granted in one circuit may be enforced in any circuit.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., June 20 -- Miss Gertrude Williams, daughter of the late William T. Williams of New-Brighton, and Willard S. Brown, a son of Vernon H. Brown of New-York, were married this afternoon at 5 o'clock in Christ Church. The ceremony was performed by Archdeacon Johnson.

The arrangements for the first century run of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey from Newark to Asbury Park next Saturday are completed.' The run will start in Newark at 5 A. M. Saturday morning, rain or shine. The roads will not be bad even if it rains, as over eighty miles of the route is macadamized road.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 20 -- The demand for to-day's New-York Times containing the story of Senator Aldrich's relations to the Sugar Trust was so great that before 9 o'clock the newsdealers' supplies had run out, and second-hand copies of the paper sold as high as 50 cents each.

Archbishop Ireland is at the Holland House. A dispatch from Minneapolis, Minn., printed yesterday, declared that the Archbishop left Minneapolis last Tuesday, and that it was rumored there that he was coming to this city on a commission connected with his rumored elevation to the Cardinalate.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- There were two transfers from the line to the Army Ordnance Corps to-day as the result of an examination which had been held at New-York before a Board of Officers. Nine Second Lieutenants of the line were in the competition, success in which meant a commission as First Lieutenant immediately and increased promotion in the future, besides the agreeable but technical work of a staff officer.
The graduating class of the training department of the Normal College had what was called "an hour with Longfellow" in the building yesterday afternoon.
The first rehearsal of the singing class of the Girls' High School, Brooklyn, yesterday, revealed to the public a collection of voices which rendered excellently well a very good programme.

The first auction sale held by Fiss Doerr at Durland's Riding Academy last week attracted such a crowd of buyers, and such good prices were obtained for the stock offered, that a second one, by the same auctioneers, was held at Durland's last night.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 20 -- The one hundred and twenty-sixth annual commencement of Brown University was held to-day in the First Baptist Church. The professors wore their doctor's hoods for the second time on such an occasion.

Brooklyn. -- The Rev. James W. Gilland, pastor-elect of the Westminster Church, and the Rev. Harland G. Mendenhall of the Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church have had the degree of D.D. conferred upon them by Lafayette College, at Easton, Penn.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Everybody in Washington read The New-York Times this morning, to see how Senator Aldrich and Mr. Searles had "drifted" together in business, and every one who read the story was puzzled to find some reason creditable to Mr. Aldrich for the Inclination of Mr. Searies to go into Providence street railways to the tune of $1,500,000 when "Sugar" had been paying so much better dividends than the best of street railways.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 20 -- This place was a Mecca for bicycle riders from all parts of the State to-night, and they came with their silent steeds and themselves bedecked with all kinds of gorgeous adornments. It was the great lantern parade of the Bloomfield Cycling and Athletic Association.

No testimony that was sensational in comparison with some of the testimony at the previous sessions was brought out by John W. Goff yesterday before the Lexow committee. But Mr. Goff had some interesting witnesses. The principal one was Harry Hill, "known all over the world," as he modestly said in giving his testimony.

Several hundred Yale men assembled at the American Line pier yesterday to witness the departure of the Yale athletes who are to compete against the Oxford team next month. Long before the hour set for the sailing of the NewYork the Yale boys boarded the steamer, talked over the prospects of the team, and whispered words of encouragement to the youths who are to carry the colors of Old Eli against the crack Oxonians.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

The work of preparing for the Sangerfest was carried on in and around the Madison Square Garden with great vigor yesterday. The grand stand for the accommodation of the choral body was gradually rising toward the boxes at the east end of the large auditorium, and there seemed to be no reasonable ground for doubt that the construction would be finished by Saturday morning.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 20 -- The funeral services over the body of Judge William Walter Phelps were held here this morning.

The eleventh race for the Suburban Handicap, the greatest event of the year in the estimation of the general public who are not persistent or professional racegoers, will be run at the Sheepshead Bay track this afternoon.

While the departure of the Chicago from Gravesend at last brought to an end the British hospitalities showered upon Admiral Erben and the officers of the vessel, for Capt. Mahan a crowning distinction was still to come in university degrees of LL. D. and D.C.L. These honors are paid him, of course, not as commander of a cruiser, but as the author of a book.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Lake Street declined from 16, where it closed yesterday, to 15, on the strength of the judiciary decision in favor of the right of every property owner on Lake Street to be indemnified, for the damage the construction of the road has caused. When the stock touched 15 a broker bid 15 1/2 for 2,000 shares, which caused an immediate reaction to 15 5/8.

TROY, June 20 -- In the Shea murder trial this morning Harriet Titus testified that she overheard a conversation near the polling place among a group of men, of which Shea and McGough were two, during which one of the men said to the others:

Considerably more than half of yesterday's trading in stocks was done in the industrials. There was increased activity in Sugar, it being freely sold early in the day, on the proposition to put the sugar schedule into effect immediately, instead of on Jan. 1 next. The decline consequent on the selling was checked by supporting orders from insiders.
Ex-Vice President Levi P. Morion's boom for the Republican nomination for Governor this year is growing.

Such surprise as appeared in the banking district yesterday when the announcement came out that $2,250,000 in gold had been taken from the Sub-Treasury for shipment to-day was due to the general expectation that the amount would be larger. It seemed well understood Tuesday that $2,750,000 would be taken.

LONDON, June 20 -- The Anti-Lords Conference, which was organized by the National Liberal Federation, was formally opened in Albert Hall, Leeds, to-day, in the presence of 2,000 delegates and auditors. The conference was called to order by Spence Watson, who in his opening speech declared that the attitude of the House of Lords was unbearable.

It appears that Divver indignantly denies the charges made against him under oath. His denial will carry the weight that belongs to a denial from a man from whom nobody expected anything else. But it will be remarked that Divver intrusted his vindication to a reporter. He prefers this unostentatious form of vindication to the cruel glare of the witness stand and cross-examination.

Erastus Wiman was sentenced yesterday to imprisonment for five years and six months in State prison, by Justice Ingraham, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Mr. Wiman took the sentence calmly and without flinching, as he did his arrest and conviction.

BOSTON, June 20 -- Local stocks were quiet and there was little change in the situation. American Bell Telephone was strong at 200, with Erie quiet at 44 1/4. West End Land was firm at 11. Bay State Gas was 3/8 lower, at 7 1/2. West End Street Railway advanced 1/4, to 46 1/2, but sales were light.
The subject of improving and beautifying New-York City was discussed last evening at the meeting of Good Government Club E, at the club's rooms, 338 East Twenty-third Street.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 20 -- The committee appointed by the canal conference held here last week appeared before the Constitutional Convention Committee on Canals this afternoon and submitted arguments in favor of increased canal improvements.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 20 -- The Harvard Varsity crew did some fine rowing this evening on the course on which they will meet the Varsity eight of Yale next week, Thursday. They came from their Quarters and rowed leisurely across to the start of the four-mile course, evidently with the intention of coins over it on time.

Persons interested in real estate in the Twenty-sixth Ward, Brooklyn, were in attendance at the arrears of tax sale, held in the Brooklyn City Hall Civil Court yesterday. Registrar Frederick W. Hinrichs and Deputy Registrar Sessions acted as auctioneers. The room was crowded, and 150 parcels of property were sold.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 20 -- All the evidence against and in favor of Mrs. Halliday, the alleged murderess, has been submitted to the jury. To-morrow the lawyers will sum up the testimony.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 20 -- The thirty-first annual session of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, now in convention in this city, at this morning's session, chose the following officers, who will be recognized as the regular authority of the Grand Lodge by all the lodges participating in convocation, until they have legal orders to the contrary:

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 20 -- Bound East -- Steam Yachts -- Wampanoag, Lieut. H.L. Willoughby; Linta, Walter Lutgen; Oneida, E.C. Benedict, and Emeline, C.W. Roche. Schooner yachts Agnes, J. Norton Winslow, and Varuna, F.K. Sturgis. Sloop yacht Katrina, George Work, and yawl Kwasind, Oliver Adams.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The second day's races in the Inter-City Cup contests between Baltimore, Philadelphia, and New-York, drew a big crowd to Belmont Park to-day. Nearly 100 visitors were on hand from the Fleetwood Club of New-York, while the Pimlico Club of Baltimore sent a delegation almost equally strong. They were taken to the track by special trains, and entertained in royal style by the Belmont Club.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The proceedings that are to determine the sanity of Patrick E. Prendergast, the murderer of Mayor Carter H. Harrison, commenced this morning before Judge Payne. The courtroom was crowded.

There was cause for general rejoicing on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The Giants played clever ball, won two games from their old rivals the Philadelphias and sent 8,000 enthusiasts home in a happy frame of mind. It is a long time since the dyed-in-the-wool cranks of this vicinity have gone to dinner with a keen appetite, but yesterday was an exception to the rule.

ROME, June 20 -- A forecast of the Pope's encyclical letter, which is intended to be his political testament, has been obtained. Whether or not it is authoritative cannot be ascertained. The forecast is as follows:

Senator Lexow cannot be much encouraged by the evidence in his hopes for his Bi-Partisan Police bill. The testimony given yesterday by Harry Hill, who used to keep a notorious dance house, related to a period when we enjoyed the blessings of a bi-partisan police and the Republicans had their share of the wages of sin.

When, recently, the action of the National City Bank in furnishing a considerable amount of gold to its customers for export was announced, we were confident that it was only an indication of the general policy that the banks of this city were sure to follow. The meeting on Tuesday, reported in our columns yesterday morning, showed that the sentiment of the bankers as to this policy was what we had expected.

The investigation by the State Commissioners in Lunacy, Dr. Carlos F. MacDonald, Goodwin Brown, and H.A. Reeves, as to the management of the insane asylums on Ward's and Blackwell's Islands, was resumed yesterday at the Park Avenue Hotel.

The Peary Auxiliary Expedition, which proposes to go to the arctic regions in quest of Lieut. Peary and his band of explorers, started on its journey yesterday. Henry G. Bryant of Philadelphia, who is the leader of the party, with his six companions, sailing from Brooklyn on the Red Cross steamer Portia.

-- Collector Kilbreth has released the paintings, bronzes, and ivory carvings belonging to Lewis Levison which were seized in April at the store of C.W. Schumann's Sons, 937 Broadway. At the time of the seizure Mr. Levison said he had left the articles on exhibition to please the firm; that they were household goods for his personal, use, and were not for sale.

IRONWOOD, Mich., June 20 -- At 6 o'clock this morning 800 of the striking mine employes met and formed in line, with the American flag at their head, and marched out of the city to the mines. They visited the Norris, East Norris, Aurora, Pabst, and Newport mines in turn, forcing all men at work to quit, and not a pick, shovel, or drill is in use at any of the mines.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senators fielded finely and batted Daub hard to-day, winning easily from Brooklyn. After the Senators had batted out singles with such rapid succession that Foutz could stand it no longer, he went in to pitch himself, but did no better. McGuire's drive for a home run was the star hit of the game. Weather hot. Attendance, 2,100.

There were no withdrawals of gold yesterday for export, although arrangements were reported for $1,000,000, to be shipped to-morrow. The Sub-Treasury received $400,000 from the banks. This payment was intended to replace in part the $2,250,000 withdrawn Wednesday.

A special meeting of the Union League Club was held last night for the purpose of electing a Treasurer in place of George Montague, who resigned some time ago and later on refused to reconsider his decision. The meeting was presided over by Gen. Horace Porter, President of the club, and Secretary George B. Adams looked after the records.

The New-York Tribune is disturbed by the disclosures in The Times concerning Senator Aldrich's association with the Sugar Trust or with persons representing that organization, and the expenditure of $1,500,000 of Sugar Trust money in promoting the undertaking which promises to make him a millionaire.

A great many stalls in the fashionable up-town boarding stables have been vacated within the last three days, and grooms are kept busy preparing horses and traps to be dispatched to the Summer resorts before Sunday.

The Stereopticon a Nuisance. -- Manager Gottschalk of the Madison Square Garden last night served a Summons on F.I. Rogers, who runs a stereopticon on the roof of a building at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, ordering him to appear in Jefferson Market Court to-day. Mr. Gottschalk obtained the summons from Justice Ryan yesterday.

ANNANDALE, N.Y., June 21 -- The annual flower show, a charitable enterprise, held on the campus of St. Stephen's College to-day, was most successful. The patronesses were Miss Cruger, Mrs. Douglas Merritt, Miss Julia Barton Hunt, Mrs. Levi P. Morton, Mrs. John N. Lewis, and Mrs. Geraldyn Redmond.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 21 -- In the campaign meeting at Lancaster to-day the Gubernatorial and Congressional candidates had the opening, and were followed by Senator Butler and Gov. Tillman, rivals for Senatorial honors.

Republicans who do not believe in the political proscription of citizens of this country on religious grounds have frequently expressed doubts lately that their party leaders are working everywhere hand in hand with the American Proscriptive Association.

Reports recently current in European markets that, on account of the discouragingly low price of wheat, much wheat-growing land in Russia, India, and Australia would this year be devoted to other purposes do not seem to be true of Argentina, where it is now reported that the wheat sowing is very heavy.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 21 -- The testimony at the reformatory investigation to-day resulted in a complete demonstration that several of the cases which a New-York newspaper has been parading before the public as "maimed for life" by the "brutalities" of Superintendent Brockway were frauds.

Brooklyn. James E. Van Olinder, organist and choirmaster, sued All Saints' Protestant Episcopal Church, before Justice Gaynor, in the Kings County Supreme Court, yesterday, for $600, which he claimed was due to him. He had made an oral contract in 1892 with Mr. Fulton, one of the Committee on Music.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary Lamont to-day announced the names of officers and civilians who would be retained as assistants to chiefs of army bureaus after his reorganization of the War Department goes into effect on July 1. Further circulars, giving detailed instructions, are under preparation, and within the week it is expected to have the new system in thorough working order.

The Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railroad trains will be running into Chicago by Aug. 1. The owners of the road, Drexel, Morgan Co., will organize a big elevator company, the elevator to be situated near the docks at South Chicago. The trains will enter the city over the Monon and the Western Indiana lines, striking the Monon at Dyer, Ind.

HOBOKEN, June 21 -- The twenty-second an- nual commencement exercises of the Stevens In- stitute of Technology were held this evening in the Hoboken Theatre, which was well filled by a fashionable audience, composed chiefly of the relatives and friends of the class of '94. President Henry Morton presided, and after the Rev. William R. Jenvey had made a prayer, delivered the introductory address.

BUFFALO, June 21. -- A big row has been caused among the Republicans of Chautauqua County by the attempt of Thomas C. Platt to revenge himself upon Assemblyman S. Fred Nixon. The Chautauqua Assemblyman, by his active help of Hamilton Fish in the last Assembly, increased the bitter feeling which the Tioga "Boss" long has had toward him.

There was a big crowd yesterday afternoon at the West Side Tennis Club courts to see the matches in the open tennis tournament, which have attracted so much attention for the last few days. There was a refreshment tent on the grounds for the guests and players, and Miss Collins, assisted by the Misses Mary and Katherine Millett and Miss Kopper, served tea during the afternoon.

Louis Sandeman of 112 East One Hundred and Eighth Street and John Smyth of 355 Eighth Avenue, both walking delegates of painters' unions, were fined $25 each in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday for conspiracy. The complaint was that they ordered a strike on Bleomingdale Brothers' building at Fifty-ninth Street and Third Avenue because George Sauer, the master painter, refused to discharge two non-union painters.

Ex-Judge William G. Choate, referee in the suit between the receivers of the Madison Square and St. Nicholas Banks, could not declare the hearings closed yesterday because Lawyer Untermyer had been unable to secure as a witness Simon Uhlmann, whose testimony is wanted in regard to his withdrawal of $4,700, the deposit of the Glen Ridge Mining Company, from the Madison Square Bank, after he had been warned that a crash was at hand.

ALBANY, June 21 -- D. Cady Herrick, one of the Supreme Court Justices of this district, appeared before the Judiciary Committee of the convention this afternoon and gave an interesting talk on the necessities for a revision of the judiciary article of the Constitution. Elihu Root, Chairman of the committee, said that there were between fifty and sixty propositions to amend this article, and that no two agreed.

D. Appleton Co. are definitely located at the commencement of the new district of the booksellers and publishers, which makes of the Fifth Avenue a Paternoster Row grander and nobler than its London elder.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary Hoke Smith is in earnest in his determination to carry out the policy enunciated in his circular of April 23 last, as a result of which the chiefs of the various bureaus of the Interior Department have established efficiency records. Before leaving for New-York last night, Secretary Smith expressed himself freely and earnestly in regard to this matter.

The ninth annual regatta of the New-Rochelle Yacht Club will be sailed on Saturday, June 30, off New-Roohelle. There will be prizes for five classes of schooners, ten classes of sloops, cutters, and yawls, three classes of jib and mainsail boats, and four classes of catboats. In each class two yachts must start or no prize will be awarded.

Mr. and Mrs. Teall's Campfire Tea. -- There was a large attendance yesterday afternoon and evening at Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Sumner Teall's "campfire tea" at Park Hill. About a week ago Mr. Teall set his many friends to guessing by announcing that at yesterday's tea two young society women would be among the entertainers in the vaudeville performance.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Another agreement, also by unanimous consent, was made by the House to-day respecting debate on the Hatch Anti-Option bill, by which two hours of to-morrow's session were set aside for consideration of amendments to the bill under the five-minute rule, and another hour, following them, is to be given the author of the measure to close the debate.

The Board of Indian Commissioners, in the recent debate on the Indian Appropriation bill, received highly significant expert testimony as to its value. The Hon. Dennis T. Flynn of Oklahoma declared that "there is scarcely a matter ever broached in Congress, or in the department, with reference to the Indian Service that these people are not around nosing in."
ALBANY, N.Y., June 21 -- The following companies have been incorporated with the Secretary of State:
James McCreery of James McCreery Co., 801 Broadway, is in favor of granting the St. Nicholas Avenue street railway franchise to the Metropolitan Traction Company.

The steamer Prince William II., which arrived from Port au Prince yesterday, reports a narrow escape from being struck by a waterspout. Second Officer H.J. Van der Goot, who was on the bridge at the time, gives the following account:
To-morrow afternoon there will take place at Manhattan Field one of the most important race meets of the present bicycle season -- that of the Greenwich Wheelmen.

Glen Island is beyond peradventure one of the most popular resorts in the vicinity of New-York, and yesterday, when its pleasure grounds were thrown open to the public for the first time this season, the people rushed there by thousands. Cool breezes blew, and the sweltering multitudes found surcease from the heat and humidity of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The commencement exercises of the Catholic University were held this morning in the lecture room of the university. The graduating class this year contains fourteen members, ten of whom received the degree of Bachelor of Theology and four that of Licentiate in Theology.

"Thank you for coming. It has been a melting occasion," said Miss Frances E. Willard, at the Calvary Baptist Church, in Fifty-seventh Street, last evening, when her friends gathered to welcome her on her return from England.

A portrait bust of the late Henry G. Pearson, formerly Postmaster at the City of New-York, was unveiled in the southern lobby of the General Post Office Building at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and, in the evening, an address in commemoration of Mr. Pearson's virtues and public services was delivered in the Berkeley Lyceum by Edwin L. Godkin.

John Hodge of Lockport, recently elected Grand Master of the Masons of the State of New-York, yesterday afternoon appointed the Grand Chaplains, Grand Stewards, District Deputy Grand Masters, and other officers of the Grand Lodge for 1894-5. The appointments are as follows:

The Brooklyns made a sorry exhibition of the New-York pitchers in the baseball game at Eastern Park yesterday. They batted out 16 runs, while the New-Yorks only scored 1. Kennedy pitched for the Brooklyns, and held the New-Yorks down to three hits. When the Brooklyns had such a big lead Gastright relieved Kennedy.

CONCORD, N.H., June 21 -- The twenty-fifth annual meeting and reunion of the Society of the Army of the Potomac was held in Representatives' Hall, in the State House, this afternoon, and was called to order by the President, Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles. The report of the Treasurer showed a balance of $1,697.

The trial by court-martial of Col. William Seward of the Ninth Regiment for alleged willful neglect and disobedience of Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald's order to parade the regiment at Van Cortlandt Park June 2 was begun at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last evening.

The fifth annual convention of the National Association of Life Underwrites has been held this week at the Auditorium Hotel, Chicago. At yesterday's session the principal feature of the proceedings was an interesting talk by George W. Phillips, the veteran Actuary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the city.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The remarks of Democratic Senators have not seemed so full of suggestiveness to Senator Aldrich the last two days as they have sometimes been.
The cornerstone to the new building for the Memorial Hospital for Women and Children, in Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, was laid yesterday afternoon.
The other races of the day were like the side dishes at an elaborate meal. They served to whet the appetite and aid the digestion of the piece de resistance.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The President will send to the Senate to-morrow the nomination of graduates of the Military Academy to Second Lieutenancies in the army, with their assignments to regiments. The list was approved by Secretary Lamont this afternoon.

John Engle, the oldest merchant tailor in Elizabeth, N.J., and one of the best-known business men in that city, died yesterday. He was seventy years old. Mr. Engle was for several years Receiver of Taxes, and also served a term as Alderman. He made a lot of money during the civil war making clothing for the soldiers. He was also the clothier for the Third Regiment and for the Police Department.
TROY, N.Y., June 21 -- Court reconvened at 10 o'clock this morning for the Shea trial. Adam Ross, second brother of Robert Ross, described the events leading up to the murder of his brother. He said:

AMITYVILLE, L.I., June 21 -- The second day of the June fair under the management of the Amityville Agricultural and Driving Park Association was held here to-day. The attendance was very large. The prominent feature of the trotting was the half-mile exhibition race, in which David Jones of Oyster Bay, now nearly eighty years old, drove his favorite b.h. David Jones around the track before a skeleton wagon in 1:18.

That many-storied marine edifice which is known to admirers of gigantic craft simply as the Priscilla, and to marine architects and engineers as the most magnificent specimen of her type afloat, yesterday gave to a number of invited guests a practical illustration of her capabilities as a hostess.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21 -- Up to 3 o'clock it looked as if the great Harvard-Yale game would not be played to-day. A heavy shower had set in, soaking the field, but at 3 o'clock the sun came out and the crimson and the blue began to practice. Notwithstanding the luck in weather, however, the crimson team was discouraged by the loss of Corbett at the last minute, owing to his mother's sudden death.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Diamond Match was the feature. It has been gradually advancing for several days. At the end of the first session to-day it was quoted at 128. Manipulation has been hinted at before, but until to-day nothing was obvious. This morning, however, plain evidences of it were noticeable in the trading.

ALBANY, June 21 -- Gov. Hogg of Texas and twenty-five of the Mayors of cities of that State, who have been swinging around the circle, taking in Chicago, Buffalo, and Niagara Falls, dropped into the Constitutional Convention this morning. The freedom of the floor was promptly accorded them, on motion of Mr. Cookinham, (Rep., Onelda.)

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A proposition to forfeit the lands granted by the Government to certain railways of the West and South which have not completed their lines within the legal period is now before the House Committee on Public Lands. The railway companies are fighting the measure, (which passed the House in the last Congress, but failed in the Senate.)

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate Sugar investigating committee has a brief session this afternoon, and examined George Ransom, son of Senator Ransom of North Carolina, and Arthur Barnes, Senator Ransom's messenger. Their evidence was entirely corroborative of that of Senator Ransom.

Official corruption in this city is not con- fined to the Police Department, if the testimony given before the Lexow committee yesterday, by Peter Lawrence McLaren, who is in charge of the steamship department of Carter, Mason Co., is to be believed.

There was further contraction in the volume of transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the total for the day being only slightly over 100,000 shares. In the afternoon the attendance of brokers was small, many having gone to the Coney Island Jockey Club races to witness the Suburban. Sugar and Chicago Gas were the features of speculation, and both were weak.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., June 21 -- Samoan advices to June 14, state that the British war ship Curacoa, and the German war ship Buzzard, visited the locality of the rebel camp recently and notified the rebels that if ten chiefs and fifty guns should be surrendered, no attack would be made upon them by the Government authorities.

The twenty-seventh annual regatta of the Columbia Yacht Club was sailed yesterday on the Hudson. The start was made off the clubhouse at the foot of West Eighty-sixth Street, and the yachts sailed as far as Yonkers, turning a stake boat anchored off the Yonkers Corinthian Clubhouse, and back.

The Southland was well represented at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, as nearly two hundred of her representative men gathered there in convention with many other Southerners who live in the North and rich Northerners having interests in the South.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 21 -- The twenty-sixth annual commencement of Cornell University was held in the armory on the campus this morning. The senior class, headed by the Trustees and the Faculty, formed in front of the library at 9 o'clock, whence they marched to the armory.

UTICA, N.Y., June 21 -- Four thousand people attended the diamond tournament of the Utica Cycling Club at Utica Park to-day. The track was in good condition. A strong wind blew down the homestretch and retarded the men. All the cracks were present, but the racing was tame.
Additional damaging testimony about abuses and mismanagement at the city asylums for insane was given before the State Lunacy Commission at the Park Avenue Hotel yesterday.

Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court rendered a decision yesterday authorizing Joseph J. Little, receiver of the Worthington Company, to sell for the benefit of the creditors of the concern certain books the sale of which had been prevented by Anthony Comstock, the agent for the Society for the Suppression of Vice.

BOSTON, June 21 -- George A. Stewart of the firm of Stewart Binney, yacht designers, died just before noon to-day, at the Massachusetts Hospital, of typhoid fever. He had become debilitated as a result of last year's hard work on the cup defender Pilgrim, and last Sunday was taken seriously ill at the Corinthian Clubhouse, at Marblehead, and from there he was taken to the hospital.

Everything is prepared for the formal opening of the grand National Saengerfest of the Northeastern Saengerbund, which is to begin at the Madison Square Garden to-morrow night. The building of the stand for the singers and the decorating of the Garden, as well as the hansome arch at Twenty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, will be completed this morning.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 21 -- The college crews did not do a great deal of hard work to-day in preparation for the contest they are to have on the Thames next Thursday. Perhaps they do not deem hard work necessary, for they are in the pink of condition, and are rowing in fine form now. Harvard's 'Varsity eight has made marked improvement since they came to the Thames.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Chairman Geissenhainer of the House Immigration Committee returned to Washington to-day. He will remain until a vote is taken on the Anti-option bill, and rejoin his colleagues in New-York Saturday morning.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 21 -- Mrs. Halliday was this afternoon declared guilty of murder in the first degree by the jury which has for several days heard the evidence in her case. The jury was out three hours and ten minutes.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 21 -- At morning drill to-day blank cartridges were given the troops, and the formation was that of battalion in extended order. As Troop A and the battalions use the same drill ground, the result was a realistic sham battle.

In the plain, old-fashioned Baptist Church which has stood in Macdougal Street for half a century and more were witnessed yesterday the simple and moving closing scenes of that strange double tragedy which startled Vandam Street Monday last. James Francis Forshay, the suicide, and Walter Stewart Forshay, the twelve-year-old son, who died by his father's hand, were buried together from the ancient church.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 21 -- Play was continued this afternoon in the tennis tournament of the Montclair Athletic Club, the courts being in good condition.

The trial of Capt. James K. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Precinct, who was accused by Superintendent Byrnes of having permitted gambling in the house 345 West Thirty-first Street, was concluded before the Police Commissioners yesterday, but no decision was rendered.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 21 -- Over 100 of the trunk-line officials gathered here to-day in response to an invitation of Mayor Frank L. Tenbroeck and the Common Council to view the situation and prepare in a general way for the throng that will follow them when convention week opens on July 2.

Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, in the Federal Building, Brooklyn, handed down a decision yesterday which is of great benefit to Brooklyn, and which Will compel the payment of about $1,000,000 into the City Treasury through the office of the Registrar of Arrears.

Ninety graduates of the academic department of the Normal College received the degree of B.A. yesterday, and 206 graduates of the normal department were given licenses to teach. All of these young women wore pretty gowns and carried colors of their departments, those from the academic department having bouquets of daisies in White and gold, and those of the normal department carrying lavender and white sweet peas.

Messrs. Goldman Rosansky have sold, for P. Lowenfeld, to S. Podway, at $36,500, the five-story brick building 232 East Broadway, extending through to 22 Division Street, 23.10 by 113; and for W.A. Murray, to Mrs. Bridget Bannon, the four-story brownstone dwelling 26 Rutgers Street, 25 by 85, at $18,000.
PROVIDENCE, June 21 -- The interest in this city in the relations between Senator Aldrich and the Sugar Trust has been on the icrease since Wednesday morning.
