(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

The court-martial trial of Col. William Seward of the Ninth Regiment, N.G.S.N. Y., who is charged with having disobeyed orders by failing to parade his command at Van Cortlandt Park for drill in extended order on June 2, was concluded last night in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.
"Pantomime is an exemplification of the proverb, 'Actions speak louder than words,' " said Miss Emma Field at the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon.

The West Side Tennis Club continued its open tournament yesterday afternoon on the courts at Eighty-ninth Street and Central Park West. Fischer and Parker met for the fourth time this season, and Parker scored his third straight victory over the tall West Sider. Parker showed better form than he has for some time.
TROY, June 22 -- The trial of "Bat" Shea for the murder of Robert Ross was continued to-day. John Lewis testified that he saw Shea shoot Ross. In the course of his testimony he said:

Mayor Schieren is determined to keep down the expenses of running the Government of the County of Kings and the City of Brooklyn for the year 1895, and he took a deep interest in the figures of the different departments at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday.

By defeating Runyon of the Yonkers Tennis Club, Charles E. Sands, the New-Hamburg crack, acquired the right to play H.D. Betts of the Pawlton Club of Newburg for the singles championship of the Hudson River Tennis Association. A good crowd witnessed the play from the clubhouse of the Yonkers Tennis Club. Sands placed his chop stroke down the line with deadly accuracy and returned nearly everything.

Perry, Oklahoma, June 22 -- Several prominent men have been arrested here on indictments for perjury and conspiracy. Among the number are Dr. W.J. Gillett, candidate for Congress on the Populist ticket and leader of the Coxey movement in Oklahoma; E.R. Cornell, a prominent attorney; Sheriff C.F. Parker of Lincoln County, and W.A. Morey, Government Surveyor.

"A slaughter house of the mind," is what Col. A.H. Rogers, ex-Deputy Street-Cleaning Commissioner, called the Ward's Island Insane Asylum yesterday before the State Commission in Lunacy. Col. Rogers was a witness against the asylum officials at the investigation being held in the Park Avenue Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 22 -- The thirty-three Police Lieutenants in Philadelphia were to-day ordered by Director of Public Safety Beitler to appear before a police court of inquiry to-morrow and stand trial upon a charge of taking money for police protection from the keeper of a disorderly house.

The Seventeenth National Sangerfest, or Singing Festival, of the Northeasten Sangerbund opened last night with a great torchlight parade. Ten thousand German singers from this city, from Brooklyn, and other nearby cities and towns, and from Philadelphia, Boston, Chicago, Cincinnati, St. Louis, Milwaukee, and other cities, marched with torches and banners.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 22 -- The Asbury Park Wheelmen and the Citizens' Committee are making elaborate preparations to receive the Century riders from Newark, N.J., to-morrow. The wheelmen will arrive about 7:30, and will be met at Deal Lake by the local wheelmen, the Mayor and Councilmen, and a brass band. The finish of the long run will be at the Ocean Hotel, the headquarters of the survivors.

-- The United States training ship Portsmouth, which has been undergoing repairs at the navy yard, will leave to-day for Newport. The vessel will proceed in tow to a point past Hell Gate, and make the rest of the way under sail. Commander John McGowan, who commands the ship, said to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday that so far as he had been informed no plans for the Summer cruise had been made.
Prof. Albert Bausch told the members of the Human Nature Club of Brooklyn last evening how they might "alter their characters and change the shapes of their heads."

ALBANY, June 22 -- The Constitutional Convention is under the guidance of a steering committee, which consists of the Chairmen of the twenty-seven committees. At the request of President Choate, the steering committee got together last evening and considered a number of propositions, principally those relating to adjourning over Fourth of July week and transferring the convention to Saratoga.

ALBANY, June 22 -- The Kings, Queens, and Suffolk Company of Brook, Suffolk County, was incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day, to manufacture all kinds of railroad supplies and rolling stock, to construct all kinds of railroads on contract, and to deal in real estate. The capital is $600,000 in preferred stock, divided into twenty-five-dollar shares, and $1,000,000 in common stock, divided into twenty-five-dollar shares.

It would not be unjust to St. Bonaventura to think of this book as the most pious biography yet written of St. Francis of Assisi. The Seraphic Doctor's legend gives one an impression of a little shop where are sold catechisms. Prayer Books, beads, crucifixes, images, and statuettes of the Virgin and the saints, rather than of the life retraced in these naive symbols.

ELMIRA, June 22 -- The enemies of the State Reformatory, by the witnesses which they called to-day, succeeded in making out a strong case in favor of the institution. If the defense had called the witnesses it hardly would have been possible to secure any stronger testimony in favor of the "college oh the hill" than the half, dozen or so of the prosecution's witnesses gave to the Governor's commission.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 22 -- Grand guard duty, the greatest event of the week at camp, was performed to-day. The object was to repel an imaginary enemy approaching the camp from the south.

Ex-Judge F.J. Fitch returned from his two weeks' fishing trip on the Neversink, in Sullivan County, on Thursday evening last. In answer to our question, "What success in fishing?" he replied: "Poor, in consequence of the cold weather and excessive rains. I caught but 121 trout and one red squirrel."

The managers of the Brooklyn and Morris Park tracks are once more united in opposition to the Coney Island Jockey Club, just as they were last year, when the Coney Island Club refused to be dictated to by the Board of Control of unsavory memory.

The hearing at Albany on Wednesday before the committee of the Constitutional Convention upon the proposition to prohibit the grant of public money to sectarian institutions was a very instructive arid illuminating performance. Mr. Coudert spoke, as he always does, with good sense and good temper, and the remarks of Col. Bliss were, as usual, shrewd and pertinent.

ORANGE, N.J., June 22 -- The play in the tennis tournament in the Orange Athletic Club was continued this afternoon at the Orange Oval in the presence of many spectators. The courts were in good condition, and the work of the contestants rapid and interesting. The play will be continued next Thursday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

FLUSHING, June 22 -- Several young members of the Seventeenth Separate Company, with a few of their friends, assaulted and badly injured Officer Joseph Stillwagon of the Flushing Police last evening. They were standing on Amity Street, near the Post Office, singing, and when they saw the officer coming they called him names.

Though the testimony of yesterday and the day before was by no means so sensational as that given at several previous sessions of the, Lexow committee, it may be doubted whether any previous testimony has been more significant and symptomatic than that which has made evident the habitual bribing of the police by storekeepers.

PUNXATAWNEY, Penn., June 22 -- The National Guard to the number of 1,000 men, under Gen. Wiley, arrived here this morning and proceeded direct to Walston, the mining town a few miles from here where the trouble has existed which led to the Governor ordering the militia here.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- As every astute observer of the stock expected, the first good opportunity to take profits in Diamond Match was seized by a few operators who had bought their certificates independent of the clique. On sales of 700 shares, the stock declined from 128 to 125, recovering at the extreme close to 125 1/2.

-- A report is current in the West that the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company is endeavoring to arrange for leasing or purchasing outright the entire Northern Pacific system from Billings, Mon., west, at which point the Burlington will connect with the Northern Pacific this Fall.

Brooklyn. -- Judge Benedict, in the United States court, yesterday granted an injunction restraining several dry goods and clothing firms from using or disposing of electric lamps, on which the Edison Electric Lighting Company claims to have the patent rights. The injunction will hold good until the Edison Company's rights can be judicially passed upon.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 22. -- The Thames Was in Splendid condition this evening for the college boat crews to prosecute their preparation for the contests they are to have on the Thames next Wednesday and Thursday. The five crews were on the water, but they kept away from each other. The Yale crews did some fine rowing that interested all who were witnesses of it.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- There was hardly an item of news that could be used to help prices of wheat to-day. Liverpool did cable an advance at the opening, but popular belief rejected the report, under the supposition that everything was not as it should be in foreign markets. Cargo wheat was reported weaker, and this was pointed to as proof that Liverpool was probably to some extent manipulated.

The annual regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club will be sailed to-day. The club steamer Dunderberg, after connecting with the train arriving at Oyster Bay at 10:24 A.M., will take members of the club and their guests to witness the start of the race, returning to the clubhouse at 1 o'clock, in time for luncheon, and in the afternoon will leave the club float in time to be present at the finish.
Having a local Republican organization of his own and a State Committee of his own, Thomas C. Platt has now opened up State Headquarters of his own.

Alfred Post Burbank, the well-known reader, reciter, and actor, died in this city, yesterday morning, of consumption, after an illness of about five years. He had just returned from Southern California, where he had been living during the last year in the hope of regaining his health. Mr. Burbank, who was born near Chicago on July 10, 1846, came of Puritan stock, and was a relative of ex-Gov. A.P. Burbank of Massachusetts.

BOSTON, June 22 -- The market for local stocks was almost at a standstill, and there was not tone enough to it to define. Quite a block -- over 150 shares -- of Boston and Maine was sold, which had the effect of breaking the price 3/4, to 145 1/2, while the preferred sold at 150. There was no gossip on the stock.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 22 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Halliday having been found guilty of murder in the first degree, Justice Edwards sentenced her this morning to die by electricity. This is the first sentence to this form of death that has been pronounced against a woman.

LAKE GROVE, L.I., June 22 -- A vicious stallion owned by James Foly of this place attacked a team of colts being driven along the village highway by Willis N. Hallock, eighteen years old, last night. On catching sight of the colts, the stallion bolted over the fence, and, throwing his weight against one of the colts, knocked the animal over the wagon pole.
BERLIN, June 22 -- Some of the exalted personages in Berlin have been receiving anonymous letters containing most infamous accusations and conveying dire threats.

A feverish opening, followed by weakness as the result of bear pressure, was the feature of the stock market during the morning. Sugar and Chicago Gas developed strength earlier than the general list, which, for an hour in the early part of the afternoon, was quite strong. In the last hour of business there was renewed weakness.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The resignation of Prof. T.C. Mendenhall as Chief of the Coast and Geodetic Survey is announced to-night, and with the announcement comes the report that he has told the President in his letter of resignation that his reason for resigning is that Secretary Carlisle has introduced into the bureau so much of inefficiency that it is no longer possible to conduct the bureau on a scientific basis.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19 -- Referring to the severing of the diplomatic relations between Brazil and Portugal, the recent address to the Chamber of Deputies gives the following information:

The Brooklyn Bridge had another suicide yesterday. The name of the unfortunate is not known. He jumped from the middle span of the bridge, spun around several times, and rose to the surface only once after striking the water. It is thought that he was instantly killed.

Ramapo's victory in the Suburban and the announcement that the Brooklyn and New-York Jockey Clubs had decided to give a race meeting at Morris Park on July 4, in opposition to the Coney Islanil Club, were more interesting topics of conversation among racing men at Sheepshead Bay yesterday than any of the events down on the card for decision.

The schedules of Charles A. Gerlach and his wife, Nettie A. Gerlach, of the Hotel Gerlach of 49 West Twenty-seventh Street, were filed yesterday. Charles A. Gerlach has liabilities of $645,579; nominal assets, $28,090; actual assets, $90, in cash.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- One of the surprising features of the tariff contest in the Senate is found in the steadfast refusal of the majority to adopt rules to enable it to carry out its will without unnecessary delay and to furnish a quorum on occasions when Mr. Harris, the parliamentarian in charge of the bill, desires to make a demonstration.

PAINTED POST, N.Y., June 22 -- The new Indian Monument was unveiled yesterday. The monument is 20 feet in height, the base being of granite, mounted by a life-size bronze figure of an Indian chief. The ceremony of unveiling was performed by the great-great-great-granddaughter of the original purchaser of the site.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., June 22 -- Mrs. E.C. Benedict, Mrs. Frank Hastings, a sister of President Cleveland, and Charles Hastings have arrived from Greenwich, Conn., on a visit to Mrs. Cleveland at Gray Gables. They came by the steam yacht Oneida.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Anti-Option bill passed the House this afternoon by a vote announced to be -- yeas, 150; nays, 87; present and not voting, 1.

The Lexow committee has not yet decided how long it will sit before taking a rest. Most of the members are willing to hold sessions all Summer, if necessary. The question depends for a decision very largely on Mr. Goff. It is on his shoulders that the burden of the work falls.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- All the messes on board of ships of war will hereafter be supplied with china and glass ware. Heretofore some of the messes have had to furnish their own outfit. Assistant Secretary McAdoo has issued the following circular on the subject. It is of interest to officers and sailors in the service:

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A serious disagreement has arisen between, the Immigration Bureau of the Treasury Department and the large steamship companies engaged in the immigration traffic and entering at New-York. As a result of this the steamship companies, acting under legal advice, have declined to pay bills aggregating $6,000 for the month of April, and the Immigration Bureau threatens to refuse clearance papers to vessels of the recalcitrant companies unless the bills are paid.

-- Fireman George T.F. Harris of Engine Company No. 8 fell through the pole hole leading from the dormitory on the second floor of the company's quarters, at 165 East Fifty-first Street, to the ground floor yesterday morning, and was fatally injured. It is supposed he rose from bed to go downstairs while half awake, and mistook the pole hole for the stairway.

Again the New-Yorks lost yesterday. Capt. Ward put in Rusie to pitch against the players from across the bridge and the Giants were confident of victory. The one-sided score of the day before did not disturb them in the least, and with the big Hoosier to twirl against Capt. Route's men the chances of a victory looked first rate.
"The service The New-York Times is rendering to the people in this fight on the A.P.A. is second in importance only to the service it rendered to the people when it crushed the Tweed ring."

-- This will be a busy day for the cricketers of the metropolitan district, every club in the league having a fixture on its books, while there will be no less than six championship matches. The New-Jersey Athletic Club will encounter the Manhattans at Bergen Point, the Morris Heights will meet the Staten Island Cricket Club at Berkeley Oval, and the Brooklyns will play Paterson at Prospect Park, these being all first-section games.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 22 -- Archbishop Tache who had been ill for some time, died at 7 o'clock this morning. It was thought yesterday that he might recover, but he suffered a relapse during the night.

J.V. Alexander, who has been on trial in the General Sessions, before Judge Martine, was yesterday found guilty of larceny In the second degree. The story developed on the trial was that Fernand Pontrichet obtained money from a money lender and gave a chattel mortgage on furniture in his flat, at 270 West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street.

A long step forward was taken yesterday in the movement among the city banks to stand between the Treasury Department and further depletion of the gold reserve. There had been no doubt since Tuesday's conference of bank Presidents that the relief needed would be furnished, although the conference took no binding action.

At a meeting of the Directors of the New-York Central Railroad yesterday a dividend of 1 1/4 per cent, for the quarter ending on the 30th inst. was declared. This is at the regular rate of 5 per cent, per annum, the Directors not deeming it advisable to make any reduction, although the estimated deficit for the quarter is $728,000, as against a surplus, of $30,267 for the corresponding quarter last year.

The Aldermanic Committee on Lamps and Gas of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen gave the Municipal Electric Light Company a hearing last evening upon their application for a franchise to cover the entire city.

-- Simon Uhlmann, who is wanted as a witness to explain his alertness in withdrawing the Glen Ridge Mining Company's deposit of $4,700 from the Madison Square Bank as soon as his brother Frederick learned of that bank's insolvency, failed to appear yesterday and the case in reference between the two banks did not go on. It awaits his return to the city.

ALBANY, June 22 -- Gov. Flower to-day pardoned Orrin Sperry, who was recently sentenced in Chautauqua County to imprisonment for one year and seven months for grand larceny, first degree. The Governor filed the following memorandum:
Every cyclist with a drop of sporting blood in his veins who is able to do so ought to attend the big meet of the Greenwich Wheelmen at Manhattan Field this afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22 -- Class Day was ended and with it the social career of '94. Under clear skies and with almost insufferable heat, the largest Class Day crowd ever in Cambridge wandered about the college yard perspiring, yet happy.
The only redeeming feature about yester- day's weather lay in the fact that the humidity in the scorched atmosphere was not as great as it might have been.

The advocates of sound revenue legislation -- which the income tax clearly is not -- may well ask that their cause be saved from its friends. Few men in New-York doubt the folly of the income tax from the fiscal or the party point of view, but no one who desires that blunder to be remedied can without a sense of extreme disgust read the carping, snarling comments of Senator Hill upon the measure.

Mr. Benjamin I.H. Trask, who bought the northerly corner of Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street at the Lasak estate auction sale on May 31, at $181,000, has resold the property for about $200,000. The Fifth Avenue corner measures 100.8 1/2 by 153.4. A riding academy covers the lot. Besides this there is a plot 76.8 by 100.8 1/2, touching the other and fronting on the south side of Ninety-first Street.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Unless the Pullman Palace Car Company consents within five days to arbitrate its differences with its late employes now on strike at Pullman, a boycott will be declared by the American Railway Union on every Pullman car running on railroads where the union has an organization.

The much-talked-of match race between the two Brooklyn road horses, Betty Lee and Free Trade, drew a considerable crowd to the Parkway trotting track yesterday afternoon. The main stakes were $1,000, and there was brisk and heavy outside betting on the result among the partisans of the two horses engaged. Free Trade had the call in the auction pools, selling for $50 as against $30 and $35 for the mare.

The following appears in The Baltimore American as a dispatch from Atlanta, Ga.: "There are indications that by the 1st of October there will be a mammoth consolidation of Southern railways, the largest of the kind ever consummated in the South. The consolidation will comprise three great systems, with lines in eleven Southern States -- Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Tennessee, and Kentucky.

It was a banner day at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, yesterday. From early morning until the small hours of the night, signs of festivity -- music and flowers, pretty young girls in pretty gowns, gallant young men, feasting and toasts, not to mention the more solid parts of the exercises, speechmaking and the presentation of diplomas -- were the order of the day.

FLUSHING, June 22 -- The Mercury Wheel Club expects a jolly good time to-morrow. ExSupervisor Dunton of Jamaica has invited the boys to dine with him at Roe's Hotel, in Patchogue, and later in the day to take a ride on his wonderful bicycle railroad. Mr. Dunton's capabilities as an entertainer are well known, and every member who can will make the run.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The special committee of the House Naval Affairs Committee to-day continued its inquiry into the alleged armor frauds, C.H. Craig, one of the informers against the Carnegie Company taking the stand.

The third Friday evening reception at the Atlantic Yacht Clubhouse last night was a big success. Those who went to the clubhouse at Bay Ridge found a cool spot, and, as a result, every one was very thankful to J. Fred Ackerman and John B. Lord, who are responsible for these pleasant evenings.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., June 22 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Tille, W.H. Starbuck; Emeline C.W. Roche; May, Commodore E.D. Morgan Stella, James Breslin; Evelin, J.K. Hegeman Starting, David Dows, Jr.; Reverie, F.G. Bourne; Neaira, Charles A. Gould; Orienta, E. R. Ladew; Almy, Frederick Gallatin, and Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 22 -- The fifth of the series of campaign meetings was held at Camden to-day.

BOSTON, June 22 -- The meeting at Mystic practically ended to-day with four races on the card and a big attendance. The racing was the best of the week, the track being much improved on account of yesterday's rain.

The testimony of the little people engaged in innocent callings who have been blackmailed by the police, or who have been persecuted for refusing to pay blackmail, is one of the most pathetic chapters of the Lexow investigation. The petty persecutions of Alexander and Levy, as detailed in our report to-day, show to what trivialities of meanness the force will descend.

LONDON, June 22 -- The Chronicle, The Telegraph, and The Pall Mall Gazette comment to-day upon the resolution introduced in Congress by Senator Allison, that the United States arrange by treaty with Great Britain for the arbitration of all differences not adjustable by diplomatic means.

The recommendation of the Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy that the course at Annapolis should hereafter include the entire six years, thus abolishing the present sea service of the last two years, touches a point of much interest. It is not wholly novel, having been suggested also by last year's board, yet with the proviso that it had not then been exhaustively considered.

The committee of citizens appointed to make arrangements for the annual convention of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which is to be held in Brooklyn in August, met in the Common Council Chamber in the City Hall yesterday morning.

A private letter from Chicago informs us that there is a noiseless but determined movement among the leaders of fashion in men's dress in that city toward the adoption by men of the shirt waist, which makes the girls look so delightfully cool in hot weather, and is the most sensible article of women's dress now in vogue.

CONEY ISLAND, June 23 -- The weather brought an old-time crowd to the island this afternoon. The people began to pour in from the steamboat piers and railroad stations at noon, and at 1 o'clock to-night Police Captain Clayton estimated that there were 30,000 visitors here. They were a Jolly, orderly lot, and spent money freely.

BOSTON, June 23 -- All the local yacht clubs united to-day in racing at the Winthrop's open, and the result was a large number of starters in each class and a fair amount of sport in a moderate air from the northwest.

-- Capt. S. Eardley-Wilmot of the British Navy, who has for a long time insisted that a limited number of warrant officers should be advanced to higher positions in the service, gives his reasons why they should be in a letter to The United Service Magazine. "In my opinion," he writes, "it is a mistake to entirely close the door upon legitimate aspiration for advancement.

LONDON, June 23 -- Although some of the visible commotion on the surface of the European situation has smoothed down during the week, there is no risk in saying that the danger underneath has been increased rather than diminished. It is true that England and Germany have ostentatiously composed their differences and publicly fallen on each other's neck in token of reconciliation.

As a specimen of the printers' art the souvenirs given at that memorable banquet in St. James's Hall to Rear Admiral Erben, Capt. Mahan, and officers of the cruiser Chicago cannot accurately be described as very artistic productions. But they are interesting as showing a genuine desire on the part of the entertainers to make the affair as agreeable for their guests as possible.

NEW-LONDON, June 23. -- During the last decade rowing at Harvard has been char- acterized by few victories and many defeats, while during the preceding period between 1876--when the eight-oared races between Harvard and Yale were established as annual events--and 1884 the record showed Harvard to have won five times and to have lost but three contests.

Although the card for the day's racing at the Sheepshead Bay track was not specially attractive, there was a very large crowd in attendance. Among these were a host of people who believed that they might escape from the intense heat of the city by a visit to the track. But the wind, what little there was of it, was not from the sea, and so the crowd had to sit or stand and swelter.
There were a number of persons overcome by the beat in Brooklyn yesterday, and one of the cases proved fatal. The list is as follows:

BALTIMORE, June 23 -- The Neptune liner Delaho, Capt. Evans, from Rotterdam, arrived to-day in a badly damaged condition. She had a his hole in her bow and some water in her fore compartment. Shortly after midnight Thursday, while off George's Shoal, near Nantucket, Mass., the Delano collided with the steamship New-York, from New-York for Southampton.

There is probably no regatta which is looked forward to with more interest than that given by the Middle States Regatta Association, and the coming regatta, which will be held on the Passaic River course, promises to eclipse all former efforts of this association. The indications are that it will rival the National in number and quality of entries, and it is looked upon by many as almost the equal of that powerful organization.
-- Le Temps of Paris has discovered a sculptor of promise in a young American named Barnard, a pupil of Boucher, with the influence of Rodin. In its issue of May 7 it says of him:

TROY, N.Y., June 23 -- The trial of "Bat" Shea for murdering Robert Ross was continued to-day and John C. Ross added to his testimony about the quarrel in front of the polling place. He said that his attention was attracted to his brother, Robert, who was in tackle with a man. Robert was holding him by the hand and swung himself free and started northward.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 23 -- Away up in the breezy Catskills the last week has brought ideal Summer weather, and the people who have fled from the sweltering heat of the city to the charming little villages in the valleys and on the hillsides of that historic range of mountains have greatly enjoyed the sunny skies and cool, bracing atmosphere.

The Staten Island Cricket Club expected an easy victory at Berkeley Oval yesterday against the Morris Heights team, but the home club was determined to make a good showing, and had it not been for three unfortunate run-outs they would have come very near to winning the match, which, however, resulted in a victory for the visitors by 36 runs.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- The process of marking up Diamond Match met with a further set-back to-day, when, with a continuation of the generally-bearish sentiment toward the whole list, the stock fell to 124. The bulk of to-day's trading was in West Side, which attracted attention by its marked weakness.

The West Side Tennis Club's open tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the Eighty-ninth Street courts. The favorite, Parker, was beaten by Millett after five close sets. Parker couldn't get any speed on his drives, and patted lobs gently back to Millett, who kept tossing them up until he got Parker out of position, when a swift cross-court shot would wind things up.

Among the many events announced for the coming celebration of Independence Day, there is one looked forward to with much interest by the residents of King's Bridge. That is the flag raising which will take place on the site where Fort Prince Charles was built by the British during the Revolution. King's Bridge is a spot of great historic interest.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June. 23 -- Every hotel, save one, is open here, and that would be open were it not for the fact that the Pennsylvania Railroad has chartered it for a party of Washington, Philadelphia, and Baltimore newspaper men who will arrive next Wednesday and remain until Saturday, when the hotel will open for guests.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 23 -- The bathing season at Sea Cliff is just opening, the water now being sufficiently warm to insure comfort to the bathers. The beach, which is admirably adapted for this purpose, is well supplied with all necessary conveniences, and much pleasure and benefit is derived by those who indulge.

ELBERON, N.J., June 23 -- It seems like drawing it pretty strong to say that it was uncomfortably cool here during the early part of the week, but such is the fact. On Tuesday, for example, when the New-York thermometers were up to all sorts of high jinks, light overcoats were in demand at Elberon.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., June 23. -- Old patrons of Richfield Springs will have difficulty in recognizing the eastern part of the hotel section this Summer, because of the big hole in what for years has been a block of four-story wooden hotels. Last Spring Mr. Eugene Earle, the proprietor of the Earlington, purchased the Davenport House, with several acres of land just back of it, in order to enlarge his park.

The proposition to make marriage by civil law obligatory in Hungary has had more than a quarter of a century of discussion, and still it threatens civil war. It is not easy to realize the difficulties of the condition. Marriage ceremony in Hungary may be civil or religious, as in New-York, but in Hungary civil marriage is reproved by popular prejudice.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 23 -- Randall Spaulding gave a reception last evening to the alumni of the Montclair High School in the school hall. After perfecting arrangements for the formation of an alumni association, a collation was served, and dancing and music followed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- The tone of the market throughout the day has been heavy. A drive at St. Paul and another at Reading carried those stocks lower than yesterday's prices, but even at the bottom prices of to-day they did not look specially weak. While prices have been marked down the last few days, no special weakness has developed and no large line of stocks seems to be for sale.

"An assignment that I desire is to interView Matthew Arnold's Philistine," said the reporter to himself, aloud, in his workshop, in front of a little mask of Pan, the sad, open mouth of which is red from the light that the velvet of an ancient costume on the wall reflects.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, June 23 -- The Thousand Islands of the. St. Lawrence were never more beautiful than they are at the opening of the season this year. While the month of June has brought beauty to this resort, it has also brought smiles to the faces of the hotel men, who up to date have booked more guests than for any corresponding month in several years.

The verdict in the case of Mrs. Halliday, who was found guilty of murder in the first degree at Monticello Thursday, illustrates anew the deficiencies of our criminal code in its application to the insane, or to cases where the plea is insanity. All the weighty testimony in the case tended to show that the accused woman is insane.
"For the house of God to be called Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, in the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, I now break ground."
UNIONTOWN, Penn., June 23 -- The jury in the Paddock cases returned their finding to court this morning, surprising everybody by announcing an acquittal for every one of the twenty-seven defendants.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 23 -- It is said that when the steamer Plymouth is freed from Spindle Rock she will depart from Newport, and will not be seen again for several months. Her condition, it is believed, is such from the straining that she has received that her engines will have to be removed before her hull can be properly repaired.

Since the Summit invitation tournament few of the tennis experts have appeared in public, the exceptions being M.P. Smith, who did excellent work on the Wissahickon courts during the ladies' championship tournament, and Fischer and Parker, who play in small tournaments when no big ones are handy. This week, however, will witness the return of the cracks to activity.

This pretty little story is from the pen of a young Brooklyn miss, who read it last week at the closing exercises of her school. Its fanciful and wholesome charm will be appreciated by other boys and girls than those who heard it.

Of late years the medical missionary has become an established feature in the Evangelical Christian Missions in China. The native Chinese doctors are generally quacks, and when once an American or European gains entry to a Chinese family and makes a cure, the Chinese doctors are forever dismissed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 23 -- The Grand Jury of the Circuit Court to-day reported an indictment for forgery in the second degree against Seward M. Werts of Fishkill for counterfeiting New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad tickets. His uncle, James M. Davis, who was arrested for being an accessory, was diseharged from custody.

The Riverside Wheelmen are making extensive preparations for their big race meet, to be held at Manhattan Field in July. Every effort is being made by the committee to bring the "crack" racing men of the country together in the several races and make the meet a grand success. Seven events in all will be contested, including the annual ten-mile race, in which the prize will be a f our-hundred-dollar diamand.

After a contest marked by the liveliest kind of hitting the New-Yorks won from the Brooklyns yesterday at Eastern Park in the presence of 8,000 persons. Kennedy, who has been pitching strong ball, was hit in all directions for home runs, triples, and two-baggers, and at one stage the Giants were in the lead by half a dozen runs.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 23 -- The century run of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey stirred up the local wheelmen here to-day. The bulletin board of The New-York Times in front of the Western Union telegraph office was surrounded by enthusiastic wheelmen all day. The route of the run was displayed and the movements of riders were recorded every half hour.

Although bicycling is slipping upon us more rapidly than golf as a fashionable sport, the very slowness with which the old Scotch game takes root over here is perhaps indicative of a more permanent foundation than the sudden meteoric invasion by the steel wheel of the world of fashion.
LONDON, June 23 -- The Duchess of York grave birth to a buy at 9:55 o'clock this evening.

BOSTON, June 23 -- The market for local stocks was too dull almost to chronicle, and the only feature of interest was the great strength in American Bell Telephone, which rose 3 points, on investment buying, to 203. As has been said before, there is no knowing where it is going to stop, but it does seem as if it would tempt investors at a much higher price.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 23 -- Notwithstanding the terrific heat to-day the crews on the river did as hard work this evening as at any time during their stay here. The temperature to-day was as high as it will probably go during the Summer, the thermometer showing 91 at the signal office. The noon practice was light because of the heat and to husband the strength of the crews for the severer trials this evening.

Probably one of the busiest men in Brooklyn these hot flays is a white-bearded, distinguished-looking man, whose services to the country as a naval officer might seem to entitle him to a long rest. He is Commander Edward Hooker of 289 Gates Avenue.

LONDON, June 23 -- The last critical debate of the present session of Parliament will take place next Tuesday, when the spirit and beer duty clauses of the Budget will come up for discussion. The event is deemed so vitally important that the Conservative whips positively refuse to accept any pairs and insist that the members of the party shall be present in full force.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The report of the resignation of Prof. T.C. Mendenhall seems to be premature and shrouded in mystery. He partly denies the report. It is said at the White House that there is no letter like that described in to-day's dispatches, and yet the impression given by Prof. Mendenhall's conversation is that his office has been at the disposal of the President since his inauguration.

Dr. Cook's arctic expedition will start from this city next Saturday, instead of from New-London, Conn. The steamship Miranda of Halifax is being put into readiness for a trip of three months to the polar seas.

When Herbert Spencer was in this country he made one general criticism upon the American people, which came as a surprise to most Americans because it appeared to lay undue stress upon a defect that seemed to them to be trifling, if even it should be accounted a defect at all.

Six steamships sailed from this port for Europe yesterday, and all went out crowded with Summer excursionists. The Etruria distinguished herself by carrying out the exceptionally large number of 475 saloon passengers. None of the other ships had any staterooms to spare.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- There comes a time in the session of Congress, happening soon after the Summer has set in, when the member begins to find out, after he has become weary of the six days' round in the Senate or the House, that he needs a breath of air that is not flavored with the taste of asphaltum pavements and that has a dash of the woods and fields in it.

An up-to-date disciple of Charles V. of Spain has held at a village of the Yonne Department, in France, a kind of dress rehearsal of his funeral while yet in the land of the living. For the past year, gravediggers and masons had been engaged in preparing the gentleman's tomb, and he had surveyed the work with loving care.

LONDON, June 23 -- The Britannia and the Satanita started this morning in the Southern Yacht regatta over the course from Calshot around the Spit lightship, around East Cape and Fast Sturbridge buoys, around West Brambles buoy, and back, the boats to sail twice over the course, a distance of 45 miles. There was a strong west wind. The Satanita won.

When the thermometer zigzags among the nineties and operators dally with the zephyrs out of town, the real es- tate brokers who still haunt their offices have ordinarily much leisure time which to think. As a person's thoughts matters of business are apt to be influent m a controlling degree by the condition or his own affairs, it is not surprising to find that pessimistic views prevail in many quarters.
Senator Daniel Bradley, the reform Senator of Brooklyn, one of the most active and painstaking members of the Lexow committee, gave his attention yesterday to the American Prescriptive Association.

-- The Symmes family is occupying the old homestead in Newfield, York County, Me., which has been in its possession 108 years. The house was erected 106 years ago, and the clapboards upon it are those which were put on it when it was built.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 23 -- The recent weather precipitated a rush to the "shore," and Asbury Park and Ocean Grove have captured a lion's share of the wearied city folk. To-day, for the first time this Summer, the afternoon express trains from New-York were run in two sections.

Two Governors spent yesterday in this city-Gov. Flower of New-York and Gov. Hogg of Texas. They both talked a good deal about the weather. They were entertained at the Arion Clubhouse Friday night, and got very well acquainted with each other.

A great Gas Trust is among the early possibilities in Brooklyn. A gas war which may result in the consolidation of all the seven companies now doing business in that city has been opened by the Fulton-Municipal Gas Company, which has reduced the price of gas to 90 cents per 1,000 cubic feet, to take effect July 1.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 23 -- The Guttenberg "Big Four" -- John C. Carr, Dennis McLaughlin, John N. Crusius, and Gottfried Walbaum, were called in the Hudson County Oyer and Terminer Court this morning for sentence, on their plea of guilty to an indictment for keeping a disorderly house. On the bench sat Law Judges Lippincott and Hudspeth, and Lay Judges Kenny and Hoffman.

Brooklyn. Mayor Schleren did not come to town yesterday, and President Wallace of the Board of Aldermen was Acting Mayor. The franchises of the Kings County Electric Light Company and the State Electric Light and Power Company were allowed to become operative without the signature of the Mayor.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 23 -- Ivy-covered St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Main Street, this village, is one of four churches of that denomination on Long Island whose early history is linked together. The other churches are St. George's of Hempstead, St. James's of Newtown, and Grace Church of Jamaica.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not letter than Thursday evening.)

The agility with which Mr. John Sherman hops from one position to another, when he is talking about the tariff and Trusts, is quite remarkable. He jumps from one side of the fence to the other, conveniently forgets facts that everybody is familiar with, conveniently remembers things that are not so, contradicts himself, denounces himself, (unintentionally,) and does it all without the slightest apparent sense of incongruity or inconsistency.

The musical value of a Saengerfest is not to be measured by the artistic merits of its concerts. This seeming paradox may be readily explained. At a Saengerfest hundreds of singing societies from various parts of the country assemble, and they inevitably sing together. It is generally conceded that a chorus of 100 can Sing better than one of 1,000, although it cannot make so much noise.

The most important yachting event on the cards for this week is the series of races between the yachts of the Yale and Harvard Clubs. This is the first time there has been an intercollegiate yachting event and it is to be an annual affair now.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- There was little of more than local interest in the race meet given by the South End Wheelmen to-day. Three thousand persons were present at Tioga track. This is a quarter mile, poorly banked, and dangerous to men of the weight and build of Sanger, Tyler, Taylor, Coleman, Graves, and Arnold, who were present.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Dr. Calvo, the Costa Rican Charge d'Affairs, characterizes as false the cablegrams from Panama announcing that President Yglesia is harboring political enemies of any other State. He says Costa Rica has not been torn by revolution, and consequently has not had to recover from any misfortune of any kind.

The intended formal opening of the Suburban Riding and Driving Club has been so long delayed on account of the extensive improvements made in the new clubhouse and grounds that it has now been decided to dispense with the usual formality altogether. Stabling room is now completed sufficient to accommodate nearly 100 horses, and the clubhouse alterations are now practically finished.

RED BANK, N.J., June 23 -- That Red Bank is full of cycling enthusiasm was fully demonstrated to-day. The old croakers who have heretofore despised bicycles and their riders have been converted through to-day's exhibition of pluck and endurance of the century riders.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., June 23 -- The incident of the week here was the fire in the Manhanset House yesterday morning. It was a close call for that handsome hotel, and the promptness with which the flames were extinguished speaks volumes for the proprietor, H.W.D. Lawson.

ORANGE, N. J., June 23 -- The production of "The Brownies in Fairyland," specially arranged by Palmer Cox, the author, drew a fashionable audience to the handsome lawn of Mrs. Thomas A. Edison in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, on Wednesday evening.

The Street has been a little startled by the gold shipments the past week. They ran up to such an unexpectedly large amount. Over eight millions in one week is something for which there is no precedent. We never before sent out so much in that time. Neither is the end in sight. This week shipments may also be large, and the experts say the outflow will continue into the middle of July.

PARIS, Sunday, May 27 -- Besides the rain, unusual to the season, and still more so after the April full-grown Summer, it has been almost bitterly cold. However, a friend told me a moment since that this came from the spots on the sun; and that if I wished to know anything more about it I should have to travel 233 years at the rate of 60 miles a minute.

BRIDGEPORT, L.I., June 23 -- The Post Challenge Cup yacht race was sailed to day over a triangular course of fifteen miles off this harbor. Old yachtsmen who witnessed the race say it was the best ever sailed on the Sound. Four boats were entered, but from the start the race was between the Hornet. owned by Capt. Charles Morris, and the Arlar, owned by Jeliff Brothers, a new boat and the challenger.

Almost unknown to the whites a score of years ago, though familiar to the Indians of the one locality on this continent where it makes its home, the ouananiche of the Lake St. John country is to-day deservedly one of the most prized of all the game fish of North America. It is the true land-locked salmon.

BOSTON, June 23 -- The funeral of George A. Stewart, the yacht designer, was held at noon to-day at the Bullfinch Place Unitarian Church, the Rev. Christopher R. Elliot officiating. Many beautiful floral tributes were sent by friends. The pall bearers were William P. Fowle, Arthur Binney, Bertram G. Waters, S.V.R. Crosby, Charles H. Taylor, Jr., and Theodore Jones, all associated with Mr. Stewart either at Harvard, in yachting, or in the field of journalism.

The Ameer of Afghanistan has just published an extraordinary, address to the Afghan people, which shows that, even in semi-civilized countries, an absolute ruler feels that his absolutism is the outcome of the popular will. In the humblest terms -- more like an electoral candidate than a despotic sovereign -- he demands permission from his people to visit London.

In planning for the comfort of the household during the heated term, the intelligent homemaker realizes that half the battle is gained when a cool appearance is secured. To this end she divests her rooms of every bit of drapery, window, mantel, and door hangings, and puts cool-looking mattings, which come now in inexpensive and artistic weaves, on the floors.

At the meet of the Greenwich Wheelmen, at Manhattan Field, yesterday afternoon, the Riverside Wheelmen made a grand showing. The colors of the riders of this popular organization appeared in front in several of the events, and in nearly every race a Riverside youth was close to the front.

AKVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., June 23 -- It has been delightfully cool down here during the week, and the guests at the Hotel Arverne have enjoyed every minute of their stay. The hotel is now under full headway, and the daily arrivals are large. A feature since the opening of the Arverne has been the concerts given by the Imperial Hungarian Gypsy Band that created such a sensation at St. Augustine, Fla., during the entire Winter.

The calling out by Gov. Pattison of a portion of the Pennsylvania National Guard, on account of the labor troubles in Jefferson County, adds one more to a remarkable series of similar experiences in that State. Its troops, in greater or less force, were ordered out for similar purposes in 1871, in 1872, in 1873, in 1875, in 1877, in 1891, and in 1892.

NEWARK, N.J., June 23 -- The two asphalt-paved streets bordering Washington Park on the northwest and southwest contained a whole army of wheelmen at 5 o'clock this morning. The line extended from the house of United States Senator Smith on Washington Place to the junction of Washington and Broad Streets.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., June 23 -- The capture of a basking shark 32 feet long by fishermen north of here not long ago was fishing that would have stirred the blood of al- most any New-York angler. The pectoral fin of the monster was 5.7 feet long; dorsal fin, 4.3 feet, and largest caudal lobe, 6.3 feet.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 23 -- At the campaign meeting at Sumter to-day Gen. Butler made a general and mild-toned speech, while Gov. Tillman again was on the defensive, and undertook to reply to the charges made by Gen. Butler.

So few women have cared to make a study of sanitary matters that the position in the literary world held by Mrs. H.M. Plunkett is not only interesting, but unique. Save several women of the medical profession, she is almost the only woman writer who uses her pen with authority on matters bearing upon public health and sanitation.

If New-York City is not depopulated today it will not be through any lack of desire to leave its heated confines. The Weather Bureau predicted that yesterday would be a red-letter day in the June calendar of this year, and its forecast for today is suggestive or blazing sun, cloudless skies, and torrid air.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 23 -- The preliminary season is over, and the big Summer season -- and it is the fond hope hat it will be big in a financial sense, at all events -- is about to begin. Several of the leading hotels, including the West End, the Scarborough, and the United States, open their doors to-day.

BERLIN, June 23 -- The friction caused between England and Germany by the Anglo-Belgian agreement was finally removed yesterday. For two weeks or more Chancellor von Caprivi and Sir Edward Malet, British Ambassador, have been at work upon the protocol, which was signed last evening.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- In the House to-day Mr. Cogswell (Rep., Mass.,) sent to the Clerk's desk the following letter, copies of which he said, were sent direct to pension claimants, in response to their requests for information regarding their claims:

HARTFORD, Conn., June 23 -- The controversy over the City Collectorship was ended to-day in an abrupt manner by Town Collector George W. Fowler (Dem.) taking possession of the office, acting under the advice of his counsel, Charles E. Perkins (Rep.) and John H. Brockelsby, (Dem.,) who is also Town Attorney.
Marietta Alboni, the world-renowned contralto singer, died in Paris yesterday.

At a recent smart ball in London the bride Mrs. Margot Tennant Asquith wore a gown of white satin, with lines of pale rink roses on the seams of the skirt, cleverly arranged, graduating from big flowers near her feet to tiniest buds at the waist. The bodice worn with this was an idealized "bow bodice," the entire front a large spreading bow of chiffon.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- All advices received here indicate an imminent prospect of the outbreak of active hostilities between Japan and China. These countries have been several times on the verge of war since 1879, when hostilities were averted by the arbitration of Gen. Grant when on his Eastern travels.

BAYPORT, L.I., June 23 -- This quiet little Summer retreat is already experiencing the new life that comes with warm weather. While not exactly bidding for the patronage of everybody, Bayport numbers among its outing colony some persons prominent in life. There are a good many who have cottages here, having found this place about right as a retreat from heat and the discomforts of city homes at this season.

Whenever a tuberculous cow, or the carcass of such a cow, has been found by the Inspectors in some slaughter-house in this city, the inquiries subsequently made by the city's Board of Health have established the fact that other cows in the dairy herds from which these cows came were also tuberculous.
The opening concert of the National Saengerfest, under the auspices of the Northeastern Saengerbundes and the United Singers of New-York, was given at the Madison Square Garden last evening.

WATCH HILL, R.I., June 23 -- New-York has been sweltering this week, but here it has been almost uncomfortably cold. What a remarkable difference in a four hours' journey! Monday, for instance, seems to have been a day of burdensome heat in NewYork. Here it was so-chilly that wraps, were a necessity and windows, could not be left open with comfort at night.

When ex-Congressman Conger of Akron, Ohio, gave out the interview against the McKinley law which was printed in The New-York Times of last Sunday, he not only set a lot of Republicans thinking, but he set a lot of his fellow-Republican politicians giving "reasons why" for Mr. Conger's frank statements.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- The American Derby run here this afternoon resulted in a complete surprise, as it was won by Rey El Santa Anita, the extreme outsider in the betting.

The regatta at the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club yesterday was remarkable for its close finishes. In three classes the winners were less than a minute ahead of the second boats, and the Gossoon beat the Minerva by only a margin of 9 seconds.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 23 -- The sixth annual regatta of the Yonkers Corinthian Yacht Club took place to-day on the Hudson with favorable wind and weather. The wind blew from the northeast. At 11:35 the starting signal was given and the fourteen yachts started.

A few weeks ago musical circles were convulsed over the antagonism of Herr Damrosch and Herr Seidl. It was announced that both would give German opera next season. Herr Steinway tried to unite the opposing factions. They refused to be united. Then Mr. Seidl said it wasn't fair, and he wouldn't play.

There are no signs to Brooklyn of the delay of the Aldermanic appetite. The mutations of personal fortune affect the private appetite, and it is susceptible also to the pernicious influence of the seasons, the weather, and the condition of the digestive organs. Even the state of the imagination and such little things as worriment and love occasionally exert a baneful effect on the private appetite.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- The proposed boycott of Pullman cars by the American Railway Union was the principal topic of discussion to-day among railway managers and employes alike. Most of the former professed to have no fear of a tie-up, claiming that the union was not sufficiently strong in this part of the country to enforce even its own orders.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 23 -- An order has been received at the Union Pacific office from Omaha directing that all motive power belonging to the Union Pacific be returned East, and stating that engines owned by the Oregon Navigation would be returned to this division. This change, it is understood, has been contemplated for some time, and lends color to the belief that the Oregon Navigation will soon apply for a separate receivership.

London was visited yesterday by a series of short thunderstorms, accompanied by heavy rain. Shortly after 11 o'clock a strange phenomenon was witnessed at Kingsland. A dense cloud suddenly burst and a ball of fire issued from it, followed by a deafening clap of thunder. The lightning played about the roof of the Kingsland Road Congregational Church, at the corner of Sandringham Road, and then descended to the roofs of the houses in Alvington Crescent.

Mr. Robert W. Lowe, well known as a facile and sensible writer about the stage and the compiler of a valuable bibliography of English theatrical literature, has stirred up some indignation by boldly defending stage censorship in a lecture at the Royal Institution. Mr. Lowe laughs at the idea that the public may be trusted to suppress impurity on the stage.

In Worth's shops in Paris, says a London print, there is dignity and severity almost classical. Everything is strict, correct, comma il faut. Clients occupy one of the many simply-decorated rooms en suite, all of which open upon the long corridor whose Windows overlook the Rue de la Paix. They are spectators rather than customers, while graceful creatures in a long procession, each appareled in the newest fashion, float airily by.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 23 -- Probably the most dastardly outrage connected with the recent trouble at Cripple Creek was committed shortly after midnight this morning. Adjt. Gen. Tarsney of the Colorado State National Guard, who was stopping at a hotel, was tarred and feathered by a mob.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- "If May had been a scorching month the Tariff bill would have been out of the way long ago," said a Senator to-day who has had experience of the effect of hot weather upon legislation. He is not alone in this opinion. Senators, of all legislators, have a decided antipathy to a high temperature.

Justice William J. Gaynor, in the Kings County Supreme Court, yesterday appointed Dr. Charles A. Walters of 111 Milton Street guardian of his children, Charles, eight years old, and Ada, six years old. He also made Frederick R. Scrimshaw of 35 Hendrix Street guardian of Ernest R. Scrimshaw, fourteen years old, and Alice S. Scrimshaw.

GREENFORT, L.I., June 23 -- The arrivals are the order of the day here. They come in by both boat and train, and the village is rapidly giving way to the entertainment of its Summer population. The fine fleet of pleasure boats that claim this place as their home port are finding daily employment.

Among the delegates to the Southern Convention, that has just been held in this city, were Col. Pat Donan, Vice President of the National Immigration and Colonization Company of Washington, D.C., and A.J. Millikin, who is at the head of a number of Industrial and development enterprises in Southern Virginia.

London's new Tower Bridge, which will be opened on June 30 by the Prince of Wales, is near the famous old Tower of London, and connects Bermondsey, Walworth, Camberwell, and Peckham, on the south bank of the Thames, with the western part of the old city, on the north bank.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 23 -- The Yale "honor list," as the senior appointments are called, was given out to-day. It contains the names of the members of the graduating class whose average scholarship marks during their entire course of four years entitle them to special mention.

Miss Melle S. Titus was informed yesterday morning that she had successfully passed her examination for admission to the bar, and, after being sworn in next week, she will be entitled to practice in the courts of this State.

Fourteen more singing societies arrived yesterday to take part in the great Saengerfest. They included societies from Trenton and Elizabeth, N.J.; Waterbury, New-Haven, and Bridgeport, Conn.; Allentown, Bethlehem, Easton, and Chester, Penn. The societies were first escorted to the headquarters of the Saengerfest at Terrace Garden, where they left their flags.
John C. Clark, a well-dressed Englishman, who says he is a London bariister, with offices on Bow Street, was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street police stationhouse last evening.

Should John W. Goff, counsel to the Senate committee which is investigating the Police Department of this city, call all the witnesses, he has subpoenaed before the proposed adjournment for the Summer Friday next it is probable that the week's work will be very interesting.

Bridget Kearns, twenty-nine years old, of 1 1/2 Monroe Street, and Sadie Dougherty of 5 Batavia Street, who wash dishes in the restaurant, 124 Chambers Street, came near losing their Saturday night off last night. Mr. Henry, the proprietor, who lives in Brooklyn, usually locks up the premises about 7 o'clock every night.

In extending its territory so as to take in the town of New-Utrecht, Brooklyn, has included within its domains historic old Fort Hamilton, where "Stonewall" Jackson was stationed long ago. The flight of time has covered the now almost obsolete defenses with moss and creeping vines, and the birds make their nests in the gaping portholes.

DEAL BEACH, N.J., June 23 -- This delightful little resort is pursuing the even tenor of its way. That means there is a general good time for everybody at the hotel and cottages. The warm weather in town has driven troops of visitors here, many of whom will remain for the season. There has not been so much going on, after all, for the gayeties of the season have not really begun.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 23 -- Early morning drill to-day was the last work of the first week's detail at camp. Troop A left for New-York at 10 o'clock. The troopers will camp to-night at Tarrytown and reach New-York about 2 o'clock Sunday afternoon. The troops were paid this morning and there was no battalion drill.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Naval officers who have been commending the action of Capt. Thomas of the Bennington for taking Gen. Bzeta on board as a political refugee are anxious about the report that he is to be asked to surrender him as a criminal. The naval regulations authorize naval commanders to grant refuge to political offenders, but not to solicit them to come on board.

When Augustin Daly returns to New-York in August he will find one of the features of his theatre missing. "Owen," the guardian of the stage door, before whom actors quaked and the casual caller trembled, has disappeared, and the Twenty-ninth Street door, over which he so long held despotic sway knows him no more.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 23 -- This has been a week of much interest here. The Elks convention which was in session Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, and the increased number of seaside guests made this always important resort, unusually lively. The promenade along the beach has been daily crowded with the visitors, and bathing has been indulged in by hundreds.

LENOX, Mass., June 23 -- The cottagers are nearly all here, a large delegation, coming up from New-York and Boston this week. They came just in the nick of time on account of the sweltering heat of the cities.

CHAPTER XXIII. -- (Continued.) CORALIE'S PRIVATE DIARY CONTINUED. Her ladyship's conduct becomes daily and hourly more extraordinary. After leaving the castle early this morning with Mr. Coverdale -- coolly declining my company, which I offered in my girlish, gushing little way, on the spur of the moment, determined at any rate to embarrass her by forcing a refusal -- she returns at 3 o'clock this afternoon without that inestimable parson.

-- A small-sized strike occurred on the Grammar School Building at Eighty-first Street and Avenue A yesterday. For several days the cornice and skylight workmen have been engaged in putting in ventilators. The tin and sheetiron workmen contended that this work came under their supervision. The walking delegate of the latter union visited the building and induced six of the twelve men at work to Quit.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 23 -- The Government fleet entered the harbor at noon to-day convoying the late insurgent war ship Republica. The Aquidaban is expected later, in tow of the Nictheroy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 23 -- Notwithstanding the fact that two conventions and one judicial body have just completed their labors here, and an exodus of delegates and lawyers has followed their places have been taken by the daily arrival of regular guests and new visitors. Saratoga, like New-York City, is a place of kaleidoscopic changes -- a perfect succession of dissolving views, and each one a perfect picture in itself.

PARIS, May 27 -- How many times nas Psyche tempted the poet, the author, and the dramatist, I wonder, not to mention the painter and the sculptor? Neither you nor I will live long enough to complete the list, for the end is not near. With all due respect to the Comedie Francaise, M. Louis Marsolleau will not be placed among the prize winners.

Fourteen colored persons were baptized in the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, opposite Morris Heights, by the Rev. Ernest Lyons of St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, 139 West Forty-eighth Street.

LONDON, June 24 -- Thousands of persons have Stood outside the gate at White Lodge to-day, scanning the bulletins concerning the Duchess of York and her boy baby. Both are doing well. The Sovereigns of Europe have telegraphed their congratulations. The first, of the dispatches came from the German Emperor.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 24 -- In reference to the report that the State Banking Department was investigating a Wall Street institution representing a million dollars, Superintendent Preston said to-night that it referred to the Bankers' Loan and Investment Company of New-York.

Whether certain lions at the Aquarium are, or are not, subject to compulsory education of a painful nature is only part of a very wide question. Many doubt whether anybody has any right to make any other body, or any beast, do anything which the subject resents. Thus we hear of the hardships of "compulsory Greek." Boys dislike it Quite as much as lions dislike jumping through paper hoops.

The foundering of the Nichols was in full view of fourscore fishermen who made up Harry Cushman's excursion party on the tugboat R.H. Sayre, which went to the Fishing Banks from Hoboken under the command of James Slattery.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 24 -- Edward Parmley Jones, as he is known in this city, the retired green-goods backer, according to the testimony before the Lexow committee, is no longer the owner of Meadowbrook Stock Farm, in the town of Fairfleld, which he purchased when he came to this city about two years ago, according to the land records of the town of Fairfield.

An article by the Rev. C.F. Aked of Liverpool in The Contemporary Review for June raises the question whether the whole anti-slavery battle will not have to be fought over again. Mr. Aked, who entitles his article "The Race Problem in America," does full justice to the wonderful progress made by the colored people since the emancipation.

One of the interesting features of the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, held at Niagara Falls last week, was an address on "Railroad Signaling -- The Block System," by John P. O'Donnell of England. Mr. O'Donnell is a civil engineer of distinction, and the fact that he is recognized as an expert authority on railroad signaling gives his utterances on that subject a special interest to railroad men.

Patrick Barnett must have had a wheel in his head when he wrote his will bequeathing to his nephew, William Barnett of England, u5,000 in a Boston bank and his "Patagonia Park estate at Manor Lake, Maine County, Massachusetts."

DETROIT, Mich., June 24 -- After three days of excessive heat a storm came up this afternoon during which an inch of rain fell in twenty-five minutes and a sixty-mile gale blew for half that time. During the gale hundreds of trees were uprooted in various parts of the city, and two electric-light towers were blown down.

JERSEY CITY, June 24 -- The tug James D. Nichols was built ten years ago by Nathan Levy of Philadelphia for John and James McCarthy, Hoboken dockbuilders. They sold one quarter of the boat to William Reeves of 1,208 Washington Street, Hoboken, who, in turn sold one-half of his share to John Farrell, the engineer.
Are venomous serpents susceptible to their own poison? In other words, what would be the result it one of them should happen to bite himself -- would it kill him? Indeed, it would.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 24 -- When the college crews finished their practice on the Thames last evening they had completed the hardest day's work they will do until they meet in the final tests next Wednesday and Thursday. The heat of the day had been terrific, and the coming of evening did not lower the temperature but a few degrees, for there was no air stirring.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The first bulletins of the assassination of the President of the French Republic were received in Washington just before 6 o'clock this afternoon.

That trotting rustle like a tiny pig, with frequent pauses, comes from the hedgehog; so does that faint whine.

Thomas E. Crimmins appeared as complainant in the Tombs Court yesterday, against William Coddington, forty-four years old, of 323 East Eighty-third Street, and John Conover, forty-nine years old, of 56 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street. The men were employed as timekeepers by John D. and Thomas. E.Crimmins, on the new Ninth Avenue cable road.

The question of railroad signaling has absorbed much of the attention of civil engineers and railroad managers in this country within the past two or three years. The competitive efforts to reduce danger to a minimum in the handling of the unprecedented passenger traffic during the Chicago Fair and the startling stimulus of the Lackawanna disaster on the Hackensack Meadows combined to awaken an uncommonly alert inquiry for the best methods of signaling on railroads.
PARIS, June 25 -- Sadi Carnot, President of the Republic, was stabbed mortally at 9:15 o'clock last evening in Lyons by Cesare Giovanni Santo, an Italian Anarchist, twenty-one years old.

The body of an unknown woman was found about 8 o'clock yesterday morning floating in the East River at the foot of One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street. It was taken to Bellevue Morgue. There was nothing on the body by which it could be identified, and, as there were no marks or bruises on it, it is supposed that death was caused by drowning.

ALBANY, June 23 -- The local security market was almost lifeless during the week. Nevertheless, whatever business was done was at firm or slightly-higher prices. The approach of the July disbursements for dividends and interest was responsible for a small inquiry for investment. Commercial Union stock was 15 per cent. higher on the asked price on the appearance of a small demand for investment.

Some 7,000,000 or 8,000,000 people will be immediately affected by it -- even at present.

At the fifteenth annual excursion of the Roman Catholic Total Abstinence and Benevolent Society of New-York City yesterday three persons were drowned.

To the Editor of The New-York Times. The question of woman's suffrage is certainly no longer to be considered a fad. The movement has taken definite shape, and the numbers in favor of it are, slowly, perhaps, but constantly growing. The circumstances and environment of woman at the present time has all to do with It. Old things are passing away, traditions are becoming obsolete, and the new age finds a new woman.

TRENTON, June 24 -- The New-Jersey politicians have hardly rested from the arduous duties of the longest session of the Legislature ever held when plans are being considered for the fight of next November. The Republican leaders have made a slate that is certainly going to make trouble before the ides of November.

At the Derby County Police Court yesterday a lad of fifteen, named Samuel Staton, was charged with sending a threatening letter to Miss Margaret Newton, daughter of Mr. C.E. Newton, a banker and ex-High Sheriff of Derbyshire. He was also charged with sending a similar letter to Mr. Newton, and with placing a canister containing gunpowder upon a windowsill at that gentleman's residence, Mickleover Manor, near Derby.

Ernest Williams, a colored boy known as "Spot Ball" Williams, because he plays good billiards, was shot in the thigh by a policeman whose identity is unknown at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. Williams lives at 148 West Twenty-seventh Street, with his aunt, Mrs. Harvey, who sells hot corn in front of the house.

The United States cruiser New-York, Capt. J.W. Philip, from Bluefields, Nicaragua, June 9, via Kingston, Jamaica, June 19, arrived in this port yesterday morning, and cast anchor off Tompkinsville, S.I.

George Clark, a medical student, thirty years old, died in his room on the third floor at the tenement 1,191 First Avenue at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. For four hours previous to his death he suffered with what closely resembled delirium tremens. Hard drinking and the heat combined are supposed to have caused his death.

Mary Guise Newcomb, a painter of animals, died of heart failure on Saturday in her home, 257 West Forty-fifth Street. She was the wife of Edward W. Newcomb, a chemist and dealer in photographic and art materials. Mrs. Neweomb was a native of Newark, N.J., and was twenty-nine years old.

"What is that?" asked Mary Jane, meekly, her eyelids drooping pathetically.

Some weeks ago, in performance of his duty, Public Printer Benedict expressed a quantity of waste gold leaf to the Philadelphia Mint, with the request that its value be returned to him in gold coin. He did not advertise the gold leaf for sale, as he might have done, but preferred to deal with Uncle Sam direct.

Last week's stock market was dull and feverish, the best result compared with the final quotations of the previous week being generally lower prices. Monday was characterized by great dullness and narrow fluctuations,. Tuesday by liquidation in the stocks of bankrupt companies, Wednesday by further dullness, with fully half of the business in the industrials; Thursday by further contraction in the volume of trade and still lower prices.

Two men, two women, and a six-year-old boy were drowned by the capsizing of an eighteen-foot catboat off the foot of Fiftyfifth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. A two-year-old-girl was rescued by employes of the Atlantic Yacht Club. The names of the drowned persons are unknown and the boat had no name.

HANOVER, N.H., June 24 -- President William Jewett Tucker delivered his first baccalaureate sermon before the senior class of Dartmouth College in the Congregational Church this morning. His discourse was scholarly and profound, and was delivered forcibly. His subject was "The Power of Self-Definition," and the text was from John, i., 22: "They said, therefore, unto Him, Who art Thou?
George P.A. Healey, the portrait artist, died yesterday morning, at 2:30 o'clock, at his home, 387 Ontario Street, Chicago, Ill. Mr. Healey was eighty years old, and was born in Boston.

ORANGE, N.J., June 24 -- The founding, in 1860, of Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church at East Orange was celebrated to-day.

ALBANY, June 24 -- Special interest is lent to the political situation in this State by the confidence of the Republicans that this is their year and that they will have a clean sweep, and by the fact that the nominations for Congress in the thirty-four districts will exercise more or less influence upon the choice of delegates chosen in many of the districts to the State convention.

WARREN, Ark., June 24 -- Bradley County yesterday gave Judge John S. Little an overwhelming majority over Clifton R. Breckinridge for Congress.
