The market for high-grade investment bonds has been excessively dull and without feature. The demand is light, the supply lighter, and prices, therefore, strong. Bonds like Chicago, Burlington and Quincy consol 7s and West Shore 4s have sold at or close to the highest price of the year. The Street continues generally hopeful despite Congressional delay in regard to the tariff.

The English language is spoken at present by 115,000,000 people, distributed as follows: British Islands, 38,000,000; United States, 65,000,000; Canada, (exclusive of French-Canadians,) 4,000,00; West Indies", British Guiana, , 1,500,000; Australasia, 4,000,000; South Africa, India, and other colonies, 2,500,000.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., June 24 -- Four fishermen were rescued from a wrecked catboat just outside the line of breakers off here this afternoon. Fully 10,000 persons cheered as two life guards from Wainwright Smith's bathing pavilion brought the four men through the breakers on two catamarans.

PUNKSUTAWNEY, Penn., June 24 -- At 8:30 o'clock to-night seventy-two private police arrived at the Adrain Mine. The car had no sooner stopped than it was surrounded by at least 1,000 miners, women, and children, who climbed all over the car, yelling and hooting. The policemen were unarmed. The militia was sent for, and Company F was ordered to the scene, about 500 yards distant, but was unable to disperse the mob.

BERLIN, June 24 -- Before starting for Kiel, Emperor William celebrated a little diplomatic triumph in the settlement of the dispute over the Anglo-Belgian agreement. He influenced Belgium and England to come to terms with France, and thus prepared the way for the pacific conclusion of the whole incident. It has been arranged that a revised convention shall be signed in Brussels shortly by the four powers concerned.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 24. -- The graduating exercises of the one hundred and ninety-fourth year at Yale were opened today by the delivery of the baccalaureate sermon before the seniors. President Dwight's discourse was of the usual orthodox character.

CONCORD, N.H., June 24 -- The appearance in pamphlet form of the first annual report of the New-Hampshire Forestry Commission calls attention once more to the effort that is being made to preserve and restore the forests of the Old Granite State. The movement may be said to be in its second stage.

Protestant ministers in Brooklyn are awaking to the fact that a new and strange force has recently made its appearance in their churches and has leavened congregations with a leaven of bigotry more subtle and powerful that the most direct and public teachings could effect.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 24 -- The steamship Professor Morse has arrived from Bluefields, Nicaragua. Everything was quiet there when the Morse left, and the long-expected move of England had not been made.

PUNXSUTAWNEY, Penn., June 24 -- Some time during last night twenty-five private police of the Bell. Lewis Yates Company, who had been stationed at the Eleanora Mine, were taken through this place and stationed at Walston Mine. At 6:30 o'clock this morning sixty Poles and Slavs were brought here from Rochester and Buffalo and were immediately taken up to Walston Mine.

DENVER, Col., June 24 -- A mass meeting of about 50,000 people was held in Lincoln Park this afternoon to condemn the outrage perpetrated upon Adjt. Gen. Tarsney Saturday morning in Colorado Springs. Speeches were made by I.N. Stevens, T.J. O'Donnell, Gov. Waite, J.B. Belford, and Judge Pratt.

VENICE, June 7 -- Once I lived in Venice, and was a householder, and paid taxes, and was the prey of a handsome gondolier and a flower girl in her sixty-third year. I can no longer proudly say in the Venetian dialect: "Mi so anca veniziano,'' but I revisit Venice once a year and try to imagine that I am still a Venetian.

An International Exposition of Costume will be held in Madison Square Garden from March 8 to March 16, 1895, inclusive. It will be held under the auspices of the Young Women's Christian Association and St. James's Mission, and the proceeds will be devoted to these organizations.

The fishing excursion which ended so disastrously was the tenth annual one of the Herring Fishing Club. The club consists of seven members. They chartered the Nichols, and, with a party of friends, whose number was estimated by the President of the club as sixty-eight, started from Pier 6, East River, at 7 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Party leaders on both sides of the Chamber agree that this week will see the Tariff bill out of the Senate; as to the precise date there is a divergence of opinion. Messrs. Harris and Jones expect to see the final vote taken not later than Tuesday evening. Mr. Aldrich, on the Republican side, says it may be taken then, but it will more likely be Thursday.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 25 -- Edward Bruwaert, the French Consul in Chicago, was greatly shocked to hear that President Cannot had been assassinated, but said such a thing, in view of the recent Anarchist crimes in Paris, was to be expected.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- One result of the assassination of President Carnot was the introduction in the House to-day by W. A. Stone of Pennsylvania of a bill defining the term "Anarchist," and providing penalties for crimes attempted by Anarchists.
LONDON, June 25 -- Queen Victoria to-day sent a long dispatch by private wire to Mme. Carnot, expressing her deep sorrow and sympathy.

PARIS, June 25 -- President Carnot's body was moved at 6:30 o'clock this evening to the railway station at Lyons, and there was placed in a car deavily draped with black. At 7 o'clock the special train to which the car was attached started for Paris, with Mme. Carnot, several officers of the late President's household, and a few other officials.

The meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday was made quite interesting by a war of words between Alderman Webster R. Walkley and Aldermen Clark, Cohn, and Guilfoyle, over a motion to change the minutes of the last meeting. Again the Aldermen were reminded that they had been elected by an accident, and that the people of Brooklyn were watching every movement made by them.

Whitelaw Reid, late Minister of the United States to France, was found last evening by a Sun reporter at his country residence at Ophir Farms. He expressed the prefoundest horror of the crime, and the highest appreciation of President Carnet.

Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court granted an order yesterday to show cause why a certificate of reasonable doubt should not be granted in the case of Erastus Wiman; otherwise the prisoner would have been taken to Sing Sing.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. Jacob Cole sold to Walter Davis, plaintiff, at $2,900 the property at 319 to 323 Van Siclen Avenue, east side, 150 feet north of Belmont Avenue, 50 by 100, with two-story frame dwelling. To Mrs. Amelia Walker he sold at $5,870, the three-story and basement brick dwelling 606 Carlton Avenue, west side, 81 feet north of Prospect Place, 20 by 40 by 100.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 25 -- Unless all signs fall and the totally unexpected happens Yale will win both the university and the freshman races to be rowed on the Thames here this week. That is not only the opinion of the partisans of Yale but of men who have no prejudice whatever in the matter.

-- Capt. Anthony Smalley, Representative from Nantucket, Mass., died yesterday after a lingering illness. His death was due to pulmonary complaint. He was born at Harwich, Mass., March 15, 1836, and when quite young shipped as a cabin boy. From this position Mr. Smalley rose to the command of many vessels, and retired from the sea some years ago.

The contest in prize singing yesterday was far more interesting than that of the previous day. On Sunday afternoon the societies of the first and third classes competed, and while those of the first did excellent work, those of the third were extremely poor. The organizations of the second class, it must be understood, do not stand second in order of merit.
The Secretary of the Woolen Manufacturers' Association, Mr. S.N.D. North, has published an attack upon the woolens schedule recently passed in the Senate, in the course of which he says:
The following is a list of saloon passengers who have been booked to sail by the vessels of to-day's outgoing fleet:

The last prize to be disposed of in the open tennis tournament of the West Side Tennis Club proved to be the only prize captured by the home players. Fischer and Parker faced Millett and Cragin in the final round of the men's doubles, and a close contest resulted in favor of the West Side team.

It is hard to blame the impulse of the Lyons mob to save the courts the trouble of dealing with the assassin whom they had caught red-handed. At the same time it is on every account fortunate that the impulse failed to fulfill itself in action and that the police were strong enough to repel the attack of the mob and to reserve the offender for a more orderly death.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 25 -- A female crank visited Gen. Harrison to-day at his house, but Private Secretary Tibbotts did not permit her to see the ex-President.

LYONS, June 25 -- Cesario, the assassin, shows not the slightest sign of agitation. He is perfectly tranquil, and at times appears careless, and even callous. He has admitted that he had for some time contemplated his crime. He produced to-day a programme of the Lyons festivities, giving President Carnot's route through the city.

Ludwig B. Goldhorn, once cashier of the Mannheim Insurance Company, 56 Beaver Street, who forged checks amounting to $18,000 and fled from the country April 20, pleaded guilty yesterday, before Judge Martine, in Part I, in the General Sessions. He reached New-York yesterday morning on the steamship Caribbee, from St. Thomas, West Indies, in charge of Detective William Sheridan of Inspector McLaughlin's staff.

BERLIN, June 25 -- The Post in its article on M. Carnot says: "He not only personified the tradition of the most glorious memories of the French Revolution, but he also personified the system of balancing the republican forces. Though his hand now fails France, the character which his regime gave to the State cannot be thrown out of constitutional lines by his tragic death.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., June 25 -- The expectation that President Cleveland will arrive at Gray Gables either on Saturday or Sunday, or at least before the national holiday, has led the cottagers along the shore to prepare for a demonstration in his honor.

BERLIN, June 25 -- Chancellor von Caprivi called at the French Embassy at 10 o'clock this morning to convey an expression of the sorrow and sympathy of the Emperor. Hundreds of carriages containing callers with similar messages continued to arrive at the Embassy during the morning and early hours of the afternoon.
RAHWAY, N.J., June 25 -- The fast track of the Union County Roadsters of Rahway is the favorite training track for wheelmen in this section of New-Jersey.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- This week marks the beginning of the Summer circuit for the harness racers in this city, and the card for the first of the meeting at the Philadelphia Driving Park this afternoon was an attractive one.

LYONS, June 25 -- The body of the dead President has been transferred from the small bed upon which he died to the Prefect's bed. The body is fully dressed, and upon the breast is the grand cordon of the Legion of Honor. There will be no postmortem examination, Mme. Carnot having expressed a strong desire that the body of her husband be taken to Paris as soon as possible.

A number of our esteemed Catholic contemporaries are at present busily engaged in puzzling their brains in trying to sound the why and the wherefore of the attitude, the strange attitude, we may say, of the metropolitan press with regard to the outbreaks, demonstrations, pretentions, professions, and practices of that society known as the American Protestant -- or Protective -- Association.

Not even the assassination of President Carnot can overshadow the horror of Sunday's drowning accidents in New-York Bay. The drowning of the Nelson family by the capsizing of a small yacht off Bay Ridge was one of that class of disasters which occur in considerable numbers every Summer.
They were celebrating their silver wedding, and of course, the couple were very happy and affectionate.

Only one sale was had at auction in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday. This was in partition proceedings, the auctioneer being Mr. Thomas A. McGowan. The property, a three-story brownstone dwelling, 147 East Fifty-sixth Street, 19 by 100.5, was knocked down to Thomas F. McLaughlin, the plaintiff, at $15,750.

Thomas McDonough died at his home in Montclair, N.J., yesterday morning, aged seventy three years. He was a son of the late Commodore Thomas McDonough and a brother of A.R. McDonough, the wellknown clubman. He was born in Middletown, Conn., and attended Yale University, which he had to leave on account of poor health.

The annual appropriation measure for the Indians has now to run the gantlet of the Senate, and if that body proves to be as conservative as the House in dealing with it, much of the threatened crippling of the Indian service will he averted.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Secretary Gresham received a message from Ambassador Eustis at 11 o'clock this morning announcing the death of the French President, and almost at the same moment that it reached him M. Patenotre, the French Ambassador, called, bringing the official notification of the death from the French Government.

LONDON, June 25 -- As scarcely one person in fifty sees a Sunday paper here, the vast bulk of the English people learned only to-day of the birth of an heir to the British throne, and then they found the intelligence thrust into second place by the astounding news that the President of the French Republic had been assassinated.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 25 -- The last baseban game of the season in the intercollegiate championship series will be played at the Yale Field to-morrow between Yale and Harvard. As Tale defeated Harvard at Cambridge last Thursday by the score of 5 to 1 the blue is booked as winner, but the occasion will be the social athletic event of the year.
The New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor gave its first ocean party of the season yesterday at the People's Seaside Home, West Coney Island.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 25 -- Miss Emma Juch, the famous and popular singer, was married to-day to Francis L. Wellman, Assistant District Attorney of New-York. The wedding, which was attended by a large number of prominent society people, took place here at the home of the bride.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The special committee of the House Naval Committee investigating the alleged armor-plate frauds further examined C.H. Craig, the informer, to-day. Mr. Craig continued his comparison of the reports and memoranda taken while in the employ of the Carnegie company, showing the changes made in the original reports by Superintendent cline for the purpose of deceiving the Government Inspectors regarding the treatment of plates.

Ever since Clifford was left at the post in the Brooklyn Handicap the racegoers of this vicinity have been anxious to see the big Western horse in a race where he had an even chance with the other starters. The opportunity presented itself yesterday, and Leigh Rose's thoroughbred won easily from an indifferent field.

Some encouragement in the matter of railroad business is afforded by the steadily increasing passenger traffic on most of the principal lines in the East and in the West. This increase is especially noticeable in the business of the various railroad lines centring in this city. Additional trains have been put on by each of the trunk lines within the past few days, to accommodate the rapidly swelling current of travel.

LYONS, June 25 -- In Lyons the evening has been varied by alternate periods of perfect quiet and intense excitement. Early in the evening a mob burned down an Italian grocery in the Rue Cuvier, and the Italian Musical Society's hall in the Rue Mazenod. The mob was dispersed by the police after the harm had been done, and for nearly two hours there was no sign of disturbance.

PARIS, June 25 -- La France makes a bitter attack upon Italy and upon Signor Ressman, the Italian Ambassador. The editorial declares that France ought not for a moment to tolerate the presence of Italian workmen. The same feeling is reflected by

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 25 -- The Democratic State Convention, which will assemble in this city on he 27th inst., will be a rather tame affair, as there will be contests as to but hree of the posts to be filled, that of Associate Justice, Land Commissioner, and Treasurer.

BOSTON, Mass., June 25 -- Five of the foremost American tennis experts began to-day the annual invitation tournament of the Neighborhood Club of West Newton. The five players are R.D. Wrenn, champion of the United States; Clarence Hobart, the well-known crack of New-York; A.E. Foote, tha Yale and New-England champion; F.H. Hovey, the ex-Harvard player, and Malcolm Chace, the Providence athlete.

Speaking of the report that there are wholesale Importations of miners for Pennsylvania, Dr. Senner, the Commissioner of Immigration, said yesterday that there was no doubt but that the laws were being evaded. With the facilities at his command, he could not remedy the evil. There are more miners leaving the country, however, than are coming in. Dr. Senner said:

The investigation which the Senate committee is making into the Police Department of this city will be resumed this forenoon. A large number of subpoenas were sent out from Mr. Goff's office yesterday, and this fact gave rise to the Impression that there would not be many "star" witnesses this week, but that Mr. Goff would use up the final days before adjournment in showing how corporation ordinances were not enforced.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 25 -- Schooner yacht Quickstep, Frederick Grinnell, owner, arrived todoy from the eastward.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 25 -- This is Class Day at Yale and the members of '94 are the hosts of the occasion. They have been in evidence at every nook of the college campus with their mortar-board caps and flowing gowns.

ROME, June 25 -- The police have not yet identified President Carnot's assassin, Santo, as an Italian subject. The story telegraphed from Lyons is that the assassin asserts that he is related to the family of Magnl Francisco, and attached to the Court of the Duke of Genoa. This statement has not yet been confirmed.

The admission of a stranger, who had moved into the vicinity but recently, into full membership in the church bothered Deacon Johnson very much. He disliked the man, and felt quite convinced he was not worthy to become a member, but he could make no definite charge against him.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Secretary of the Navy Herbert, speaking of Carnot's death, said:

DENVER, Col., June 25 -- President W.W. Tracey of the National League of Republican Clubs arrived from Chicago this morning to find matters Well la hand for a prompt opening of the convention at 10 o'clock tomorrow. He is pleased at the very large representation of delegates, which comprises every State and Territory.

Isaac Grossman of 63 Ridge Street was held in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday to answer a charge of felonious assault, preferred against him by Sigmund Lembeck of 116 Cannon Street. Both men are cloakmakers, and Lembeck says he was assaulted because he would not strike at the command of union men.

Many traders supposed that the assassination of the President of the French Republic would have a marked effect on the markets of the world, and, consequently, they were prepared to take the short side of the market at the opening yesterday. But the comparative steadiness of London prices made them hesitate, and the result was lessened trading rather than lower prices.

Among the saloon keepers arraigned yesterday before Justice Feither in the Yorkville Police Court for violating the excise law on Sunday was Ferdinand Pospisil, President of the Bohemian Saloon Keepers' Association, who was one of the star witnesses recently before the Senate investigating committee.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The President, in speaking to-night of the financial situation, said:

The anti-ring Democrats of the Nineteenth Ward of Brooklyn held a meeting last night in Garfield Hall, Marcy Avenue and Walton Street, for the purpose of offering an opportunity to the Democrats of the ward to enroll. Thomas P. Kenna, the Chairman of the Ward Conference, which is composed of the delegates to the General Committee, presided over the meeting, which was fairly attended despite the sultry condition of the weather.

The prize won by F.J. Titus in his match race on Saturday at Manhattan Field with W.D. Outerbridge is a horseshoe diamond pin valued at $150. It was presented to him yesterday. Titus is undoubtedly the only man New-York State can put up to compete with the cracks of Class B. His riding this year has been very consistent in its excellence.
The greatest Saengerfest ever held in New-York came to a most successful close last night at the Madison Square Garden to the inspiring notes of "Die Wacht am Rhein."

The American Protective Association appears to be busily engaged in secretly spreading Inflammatory literature concerning Roman Catholics. Through its agents it is covertly circulating in some of the Protestant churches, and through other channels, printed attacks on the Catholics of a nature calculated to Inflame Protestants against the followers of Roman Catholicism.

The committee on examination for admission to the New-York bar, consisting of Charles H. Daniels, Willard Parker Butler, and Frederick S. Wait, announced yesterday that sixty-six of the eighty candidates who took their examinations on June 16 had been successful.
WICHITA, Kan., June 25 -- The little village of Keighley, in Butler County, on the line of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway, was devastated by a tornado about 7:30 this evening.

HANOVER, N.H., June 25 -- Hanover to-day has been filled with a larger number of alumni and friends of the graduating class and the college than ever gathered in any previous year. The weather was perfect for the Class Day exercises. The programme was as follows:

At the regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board at Aldermen yesterday afternoon Alderman Walsh offered resolutions of sympathy and condolence on the shocking death of President Carnot of France. The resolutions were adopted by a rising vote. They were as follows:
The forty-fourth annual commencement of the College of St. Francis Xavier was held last evening at the Broadway Theatre. The house was crowded to the roof with friends of the graduates and college.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Unless the Pullman Palace Car Company before noon to-morrow accepts the proposition made by the American Railway Union, in convention, to arbitrate its differences with the strikers at Pullman, the order to boycott all cars owned by the Pullman company in operation on the railroads of the country will take effect.
Concerning a statement made in one of the Sunday morning newspapers regarding his wealth, Mayor Gilroy said yesterday:
Santo, the assassin of President Carnot, has been identified as an unadulterated Anarchist, whereas pity for other men of the same grade has been invoked on the pre-text that they were also thieves.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 25 -- William P. and George Taylor, the two brothers charged with the murder of the Meeks family, near Browning, Mo., on the night of May 10, were captured this morning at Batesville, this State, by Deputy Sheriff J.C. Stout of Baxter, and brought to this city at noon.

From facts ascertained yesterday it seems certain that the tug James D. Nicol, which foundered off Seabright, N.J., Sunday, with such fearful loss of life, had on board nearly twice the number of excursionists which the law allowed her to carry.

The Board of Engineers recently appointed by President Cleveland to determine upon the length of the span of the projected railroad bridge over the North River between New-York and Jersey City, and to pass upon the safety and practicability of the plans to be submitted by the company which is to build the bridge, met in the Army Building yesterday for organization.

TROY, N.Y., June 25 -- The fourth week of the Shea murder trial opened this morning. When court opened the first witness called was William Ross. He testified that he saw "Bat" Shea shoot Robert Ross. After relating the incidents that, led up to the murder, he said:

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United Press cable dispatch from Lima, Peru, saying that the employes of the Payta Custom House had fied, fearing an attack from rebels, was this afternoon shown to the Charge d'Affaires of Peru, Senhor Jose M. Yrigoyen.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 25 -- The State Convention of the Ancient Order of Hibernians opened in this city this morning. It is estimated that there are 10,000 visitors in the city. Mayor Aldridge delivered the address of welcome, which was responded to by Richard Curran, Chairman of the Executive Board of this city. Representatives are present from every county in the State.

PARIS, June 25. -- Ministers Faure, Poincare, Hanotaux, Guerin, Leygnes, and Barthou met in conference at 3 o'clock this morning, and agreed to convene the Congress at Versailles on Wednesday for the purpose of electing a President. The majority of the Ministry are favorable to the election of M. Casimir-Perier.

Fire destroyed a portion of the third, fourth, and fifth floors of the five-story brick factory building 438 and 440 East Twenty-third Street at 10 o'clock last night. The fire started in the rear of the third floor and Shot upward to the fifth.

Charles Nelson of Brooklyn took his family, consisting of his wife Emma, twenty-four years old; his son, Charles Nelson, Jr., five years old, and his daughter, Ida Nelson, eighteen months old, out sailing in a sloop Sunday morning. He had with him as guests Kitty Higgins, nineteen years old, and Victor Anderson, who was about twenty-four years old.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Navy Department is experiencing serious difficulty in taking proper care of the modern steel war vessels, the naval regulations providing that all such ships "shall be docked, cleaned, and painted at least once in six months when practicable," and that "under no circumstances shall more than nine months elapse without docking except by authority of the Secretary of the Navy."

BERLIN, June 25 -- The Lokalanzeiger says that the newly-discovered mine, which was intended to blow up the Czar, was laid near the Memorial Church in Borki, which the Czar was expected to visit shortly.
ALBANY, June 25 -- Gov. Flower has appointed Edward Jacobs, a prominent New-York lawyer, a Quarantine Commissioner, to succeed ex-Congressman Nicholas Muller, resigned.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- One of the many complications arising from the crash of the Keystone National Bank, and which ever since that disastrous event has proved a great embarrassment to Col. Oliver C. Bosbyshell, at that time Superintendent of the Mint, has just come to light. When the crash came in 1890 there was deposited in the bank the sum of $4,200 to the credit of the Superintendent of the Mint.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 25 -- Arrangements have been completed for the Colonial Conference, which will open Thursday, and for the entertainment of delegates while in Canada. The programme for the opening has been fixed as follows:
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- As the tariff Struggle draws to a close, the Democratic leaders show traces of the anxiety which consumes them.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 26 -- The two university crews had their final practice on the river this evening under the most adverse conditions. A stiff wind from the southeast kicked up quite a bit of rough water and blew up stream so sharply that good work against it was out of the question. So the long pulls that had been on the card for the evening had to be abandoned by both crews.

MANHATTAN BEACH, June 26 -- Pain's Amphitheatre was opened to-night with the magnificent pyrotechnic spectacle "Lalla Rookh and the Fire Worshippers," compiled from Thomas Moore's famous Oriental romance. More than 7,000 persons applauded the performance, which is the most beautiful ever given by Messrs Pain Son.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 26 -- Yale won the last game of the intercollegiate baseball scheduled for the season of 1894 this afternoon, defeating Harvard in a close, sharp fielding, but weak hitting, game. Yale was unable to hit Highlands and made but five hits, three of them scratches.

Three Brooklyn burglars met with an astonishing experience early yesterday, morning. The three cracksmen met some time before daylight in the yard in the rear of Robert Davis's paint store, 38 Myrtle Avenue. The Adams Street Police Station was only half a block away.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 26 -- Louisville was visited this afternoon by a severe electrical storm, which lasted half an hour. Many houses were unroofed and razed, and the occupants had narrow escapes. Large shade trees were blown down and several people were injured by electric wires. The storm came from the southwest, accompanied by heavy rain.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 26 -- John S. Johnson of Minneapolis, this afternoon rode the fastest mile on the Waltham track ever ridden on a bicycle. Mr. Johnson was paced by the Stearns riders on two tandems, under the direction of their manager, Tom Eck, to try to beat the world's record of 2:03 3-5 for the fastest mile ever made in public.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

It is quite natural -- indeed, it is almost inevitable -- that the French police should believe and try to make out that the assassin of President Carnot was not a political assassin in the old-fashioned sense, but a modern Anarchist. But the evidence in behalf of their contention is thus far very slender.

Sheepshead Bay race track was a most desirable spot yesterday afternoon. A delightful sea breeze blew across the field into the faces of the spectators. They inhaled the refreshing salt air, watched good racing, and went home with sharpened appetites.

BOSTON, June 26 -- Local stocks were very quiet, but the tone of the market was generally firm. Sales were mostly very small, with the exception of West End Street Railway, which was steady at 45 1/2 West End Land sold for cash 1/4 higher, at 103 1/4.

NEWTOWN, L.I., June 26 -- Henry Bosse of horse-bologna sausage fame has again become mixed up with the health authorities of this village. His horse-sausaga factory is situated in Willoughby Court, Maspeth. During the recent hot spell residents' in that locality complained of the nuisances maintained about the place.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 26 -- A large four-story brick building belonging to Wheeler Howes, wholesale coal, grain, and feed merchants, was gutted by fire this morning. William Judd, a fireman, while standing on a thirty-foot ladder, was swept off by the hose.

PARIS, June 26. -- A meeting of Republican members of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies was held this afternoon to decide upon a candidate for President to be voted for at Versailles to-morrow. The proceedings were characterized throughout by indescribable noise and continuous brawling. Deputies and Senators shouted at the tops of their voices over one another's heads.
The New-York State Democracy's new County Committee met last night in the great hall of the Cooper Institute ana effected its permanent organization.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 26 -- The Rev. Dr. John L. Scudder has been busy all day fighting various evils he complains of in this city. This morning he called on Chief of Police Murphy and told him that Charles S. Hutton, one of the poker gamblers whose arrest he caused last week, had informed him that he had paid the police for protection.
HANOVER, N.H., June 26 -- The public exercises of the Alumni Association of Dartmouth College were held this morning. A poem by Richard Hovey was read by Prof. Churchill.

LONDON, June 26 -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir William Harcourt moved the resolution which he announced yesterday, expressing the horror and detestation of the House at the assassination of President Carnot and the sympathy of Great Britain with the widow and with the French Nation.

The gathering together of sculptors in a society of their own has already borne fruit in a recognition of native workmen on the part of the Federal Government. Until they had done so, it was not possible for Government officials to realize how many they were, nor how much good material there was among them.

For the first time in many weeks there was a degree of buoyancy at the opening of the stock market yesterday, and, although the activity was not continued throughout the day, the prevailing tone was firm and the general sentiment was more hopeful than in a long while. The changed condition was directly due to the timely utterances of President Cleveland, published in all the morning papers.

It is an ill omen for the peace and order of France that the preliminary conference of Republican Deputies and Senators for the nomination of a successor to M. Carnot should have been marked by unseemly confusion and violence, and should finally have broken up without any decisive action.

Paul Amand Challemel-Lacour, President of the Senate, President of the National Assembly at Versailles, which is to elect to-day a successor to Carnot as President of the French Republic, was Governor of the City of Lyons in 1870, and successfully used persuasive eloquence and diplomacy then, against insurrection that he had not the armed force to quell.

A dispatch received in Philadelphia yesterday from Florence, Italy, announces the death there Monday night of E.P. Fabbri, who was formerly a member of all the Drexel banking firms. He retired from the Drexels in 1885, and is reported to have amassed a fortune of $20,000,000.

DENVER, Col., June 26 -- When the seventh annual convention of the National Republican League was called to order at 10 o'clock this morning, the Broadway Theatre, handsomely decorated for the occasion, was filled to overflowing with 1,500 delegates and Republicans from every State in the Union.

--Dr. A. W. Sheppard and a party of Brooklynites recently started after bluefish and caught several before they reached the appointed spot in Raritan Bay. Weakfish were so abundant that the bottom of the boat was soon covered with the handsome fish, and all thought of bluefish was abandoned. In a few minutes the voracious blues began to snap the weakfish bait and squids were again in demand.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 26 -- There were high jinks at the headquarters of the Yale crews at Gale's Ferry last night. The crews had received word from New-Haven of the victory of the ball team over the Harvard nine by a score of 2 to 0.

The second annual entertainment of the boys' department of Grammar School No. 94. of which John D. Robinson is Principal, was held yesterday afternoon in the schoolhouse, at Amsterdam Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.
LEWISTON, Me., June 26 -- The Maine Democratic Convention, composed of 898 delegates, met here to-day and nominated Charles F. Johnson of Waterville for Governor.

The French societies of New-York, which are not often in accord, were sincerely united last evening in an expression of grief telegraphed to Mme. Carnot and in an order for a wreath to be placed in their name on the catafalque of the President.
The Board of Aldermen, at its meeting yesterday, passed the following resolution upon the death of President Carnot:
MILFORD, N.H., June 26 -- This town celebrated the centenary of its incorporation to-day.

We are glad to see that the memory of our neighbor, The New-York Tribune, has been refreshed by our allusions to its sharp attacks, four years ago, upon Mr. Aldrich and his Republican associates in the Senate Committee on Finance, when it was reported that these Senators were about to increase the House bill's protective duty of 40 cents per hundred on refined sugar to 50, or even 60 cents.

LYONS, June 26 -- Forty Italian shops in this city have been gutted and burned, by the mob. The police are either powerless to suppress the disorders or else are disinclined, to do so. Any way, it is strange that they are never on hand in force until the damage is done, though they have in every case had ample warning.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The President's statement to the country, issued last night, strikes the local press that is not disposed to seek approval of the Administration, or the party of the Administration, as calculated to provoke the uneasiness that it was undoubtedly intended to arrest.

As in the case of the Hotel Royal fire and the Park Place disaster, the true number of victims of the overturning and sinking of the tug James D. Nicol off Sandy Hook, N.J., on Sunday, will probably never be known.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- "Expedition" seems to be a word dropped from the vocabulary of the Senate. Any effort to push business seems to be beyond the powers of the tariff managers.

The Rev. Dr. J. Coleman Adams of All Souls' Universalist Church, in Brooklyn, received a call on last Monday from a young man dressed in a cadet uniform and wearing a straw hat. The young man said he was a canvasser, and asked permission to copy the list of membership of the church, as he desired to do business with them.

ST. PAUL, June 26 -- At St. Paul the first serious effect of the American Railway Union's attempt to boycott the Pullman company was felt at noon, when all car cleaners, machinists, and carpenters employed on Pullman cars in the Northern Pacific yards deserted their places. At the Como shops all the painters and carpenters repairing Pullman coaches laid down ham- mers and brushes and went quietly to their homes.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- There was a fast track for the harness racers at Point Breeze this afternoon, and the sport was of high class throughout.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 26 -- The Democratic State Convention to-morrow will probably be more productive of good results within the party ranks than any gathering of the Pennsylvania Democracy for years. William M. Singerly, proprietor of The Philadelphia Record, will be nominated for Governor by acclamation, and with his selection will come a complete unification of the hitherto warring factions.

If a person wants something and that something is offered for sale, the presumption is that the person first mentioned will buy it if he can get it cheaply enough. This looks like an axiomatic proposition, but it is not true when it comes to applying it to real estate auction sales. Here the rule seems to be to wait for some one else to buy the property, and then to offer him an advance.

The most significant part of Mr. Cleveand's straightforward statement regarding the financial condition of the Government is the following: "The Administration still adheres to its pledge and determination to protect our national credit at all hazards and to keep the quality of our money equal to the best, so far as the limits of Executive power permit."
TRENTON, June 26 -- The Constitutional Commission to revise the judicial system of the State met at the State House to-day with nearly a full attendance.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The weekly crop report of the Weather Bureau of the Agricultural Department gives the following results:

A reorganization agreement was adopted by the Atchison committee, of which R. Somers Hayes is Chairman, yesterday afternoon. Capt. Hayes reached home from his Western trip just in time to preside over the meeting. The details of the plan were discussed carefully, and a few changes were made before the final approval.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The special House commute investigating the alleged armor frauds to-day completed the examination of C.H. Craig, the informer, and then examined W.A. Cline, formerly Superintendent of the armor press shop at the Carnegie Works. Cline had worked for the company for a good many years, and had superintended the building of the armor plate works.
ALBANY, June 20 -- William P. Burr of New-York introduced in the Constitutional Convention to-day a new amendment to prevent the organization of trusts which reads:

Leroy M. Lyon, a Washington Street merchant, told the Lexow committee yesterday that in the course of his meeting the exactions of the police a ward man had informed him that the Captain had paid $15,000 for his appointment.

ALBANY, June 20 -- The Constitutional Convention of the State of New-York tendered its sympathies to the people of France in the sorrow that has overwhelmed her in the assassination of President Carnot, and to the family of the stricken officer in the affliction they are suffering, by the adoption of a series of resolutions at to-day's meeting, the first since the tragedy.

Mr. Horace F. Burroughs, "commission merchant and wholesale lumber dealer," of 136 Water Street, has not escaped trial on the indictment charging him with forgery in the second degree. Judge Fitzgerald of the Court of General Sessions yesterday denied the order to snow cause why the indictment against him should not be quashed.

New-York banks made a further contribution of $230,000 to the Sub-Treasury yesterday toward making good last week's loss by export. This increases the aggregate bank contributions to the recent gold movement to about $7,000,000, of which about $6,000,000 has been contributed since the circular letter of apportionment was issued to the banks.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 26 -- The first event of to-day at Williams College commencement was the annual meeting of the alumni in the college chapel in the forenoon, the President, Hamilton W. Mabie, L.H.D., '67, presiding.

The Broadway and Seventh Avenue Railroad Company won a victory yesterday in the Special Term of the Supreme Court in its fight with the Empire City Subway Company, Limited, in regard to its right to use the conduit running along its line of road from the Battery to Fifty-first Street for the use of wires and electrical conductors in order to signal to any portion of the road in the event of accident or otherwise.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The boycott declared against the Pullman Palace Car Company by the American Railway Union went into effect at noon to-day. The order is supposed to include every railroad in the United States which handles Pullman cars, and, as declared by the union officials, every road which shall insist upon running the sleepers will be subjected to a strike if necessary.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 26 -- According to Yale custom, the second day of the commencement season is given over to the alumni and their celebration, and to the number of 800 they surged into Alumni Hall this morning to listen to addresses by prominent men of their classes who are here for reunion.

Application was made yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn to Judge Bartlett, by a committee of citizens of New-Utrecht, for the appointment of a commission to investigate the fiscal affairs of New-Utrecht.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 26 -- The class day exercises of Trinity College were held on the campus this afternoon before many guests. The members of the graduating class were seated in a semicircle facing the guests. Shirley Carter, the athlete, of Baltimore, was President of the day.

The Board of Engineers appointed by President Cleveland to consider the plans for the proposed bridge across the North River, to be constructed by the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company, with especial reference to its construction without a pier being placed in the river, and having a span at least 2,000 feet long, reassembled yesterday morning in the board room at the Army Building.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 20 -- The Prohibitionists set the political ball a-rolling in the Empire State to-day by opening the first of the conventions to nominate candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, and Judges of the Court of Appeals to be voted for in November.
The Saengerfest ended yesterday with a picnic in Ulmer Park, Brooklyn, at which nearly all the societies that took part in the grand concerts in Madison Square Garden were present.

CITY ISLAND, June 26 -- Bound East-Steam yachts Corsair, J. Pierpont Morgan; Aquilo, George A. Thayer; Emeline, C. W. Roche; Kanapahs, the Rev. William L. Moore; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Neaira, Charles A. Gouid, and Siesta, George Green.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 26 -- Train No. 6 of the Savannah, Florida and Western Railway, from Thomasville, due to arrive here at 7 o'clock this morning, was stopped one mile this side of Homerville, 126 miles southwest of Savannah, this morning at 1:50 o'clock by six masked white men. The safe in the express car was robbed of its contents, $1,222 in cash.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The decision of the Senate Revision Committee to offer fifty or more fresh amendments to the Tariff bill, taken in connection with the rumors seriously affecting the fate of the measure, has served to lessen the confidence of those who believed that the bill would leave the Senate some time this week.
The following is a list of saloon passengers who have been booked to sail by today's outgoing steamships.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

That there is no diminution of the antiCatholic feeling among the members of the American Proscriptive Association is shown by the quality of the literature which the organs of the association continue to pour out.

The inquiry into the management of the City Asylum for the Insane which is being made by the State Commission in Lunacy at the Park Avenue Hotel took a new turn yesterday, when an effort was made to learn what became of $500,000 which was appropriated in 1892 for the purchase of land and the erection of new buildings for the insane at Central Islip and Ward's Island.

PARIS, June 26 -- The special train conveying the body of President Carnot from Lyons to Paris arrived here at 3:10 o'clock this morning. The casket was at once placed in an ordinary hearse, and driven to the Palace of the Elysee, followed by five carriages, containing the widow and her sons and the members of the President's military household.
TROY, June 26 -- In the Shea murder trial to-day two thirteen-year-old boys testified to seeing "Bat" Shea shoot Robert Ross. Julius Mickle, one of the boys, said:
The list of speakers for the Fourth of July celebration of the Tammany Society, or Columbian Order, in the Wigwam was announced yesterday by Grand Sachem Thomas F. Gilroy.

The Board of Estimate of Brooklyn continued work on the city budget yesterday. They allowed to the Board or Education $2,200,000, instead of $2,995,000 asked; to the Board of Excise $19,750, instead of $24,450 asked, and to the Fire Department $1,133,050, instead or $1,161,050. The Aldermanic contingent account was fixed at $10,000, instead of the $20,000 asked. Commissioner White of the Board of City Works was heard in regard to requisitions for his department.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- For quite a while after the opening of the Exchange there was scarcely any business transacted, and it was not until near the close of the first session that there was anything doing worth mentioning. There was some demand for investment, however, in the dividend payers, but buyers selected the cheaper stocks.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., June 26 -- The first official test of the electric searchlight erected here for coast defense purposes took place at 9 o'clock to-night. The light has a power equal to 200,000,000 candles.

CINCINNATI, June 26 -- At Cincinnati there was no attempt to the up the Pullman cars. In the course of the day Judge William Taft of the United States court issued a call for the United States Deputy Marshals of Kentucky, at Louisville, Jackson, Moorehead, Mount Sterling, Pineville, and Pittsburg, to report at the Government Building, in Covington, to await orders.

BOSTON, June 26 -- Another petition was filed to-day in the United States Circuit Court by the receivers of the New-York and New-England Railroad asking the court to grant them authority to borrow $500,000 for the purpose of paying the interest on the first mortgage bonds which matured Jan. 1 and all other taxes now due and payable upon the property in their hands.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
Mayor Schieren made a most gratifying announcement to the taxpayers of Brooklyn yesterday when he said that the tax rate for next year would be lower than it has been this year.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 27 -- The squadron of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club sailed into the harbor shortly after 10 o'clock this mornings from New-Haven. It was the second day's run of the cumulative time race with wind averages, from Oyster Bay. The fleet started from Oyst'er Bay on Tuesday morning, and the race was most successful, particularly to the scientific members of this most exclusive club.

CITY ISLAND, June 27 -- Bound East -- Steam, yachts Barracouta, John R. Fell; Halcyon, Andrew R. Culver; Linta, Walter Luttgen; Viking, H. A. Hutchins; Siesta, George Green; Alicia, H. M. Fiagler; Veto, George Law; Nada, C. R. Flint; Susquehanna, Joseph Stickney; Dungeness, Mrs. L. C. Carnegie, and Maspeth, C. Meyer, Jr. Yawl Kwasind, Oliver Adams.

With every day'S evidence, before the Lexow committee, the conclusion becomes clearer and more unmistakable that the ultimate fault and the ultimate responsibility for the shocking and shameful state of things that has been disclosed rest upon the mass of inhabitants of New-York.

EMMITTSBURG, Md., June 27 -- The eighty-sixth annual commencement of the College of Mount St. Mary's, at this place, was held to-day. Cardinal Gibbons presided. The degree of LL. D. was conferred upon the Rev. W.J. Hill, pastor of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, Court and Congress Streets, Brooklyn, a graduate of this college.

Leopold Eidlitz, the architect who designed the new Superintendent's house and improvements for the buildings connected with the City Asylum for the Insane on Ward's Island and at Central Islip, L.I., proved a perplexing witness yesterday when the State Commission in Lunacy, sitting at the Park Avenue Hotel, tried to gain from him definite information respecting the buildings.

The Greene Avenue Baptist Church, Greene Avenue, between Stuyvesant and Lewis Avenues, Brooklyn, was crowded to its utmost capacity last evening, when the graduating exercises of Public School No. 25 were held. The platform was filled with flowers and plants.

BOSTON, Mass., June 27 -- Judge Colt of the United States Circuit Court to-day, in the case of Shebalto Saito, the Japanese who made applicatibn in court to become a citizen of the United States, decided against the petition. The Judge finds that, like the Chinese, the Japanese do not come within the term "white persons," as presented in the naturalization laws of the United States.
The Lexow committee was almost as busy with Tammamy Hall yesterday as with the iniquities of the Police Department.

The Influence of President Cleveland's interview, which was published on Tuesday morning, continued to be felt in the markets of the world yesterday. Higher prices reflected the growing confidence in American integrity. The London market was above ours at the opening, and prices continued strong throughout the day.
Mr. John N. Golding has sold for Mrs. H.C. Martin to a Mr. Watkins the fourstory brownstone dwelling 121 East Thirtyninth Street, 20 by 98.9.

In response to a resolution of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, asking for a statement of views relative to the provisions of the recent law for the increased compensation of some of the employes of the Department of Street Cleaning, Commissioner Andrews wrote to the Mayor yesterday that, in his judgment, all the salaries should be fixed at the rates named in the law.

Some indictments and criminal prosecutions are likely to grow out of the overturning and sinking of the steam tug James D. Nicol, off Sandy Hook last Sunday, by which two score and more persons lost their lives.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The feature or today's market was the break in Street's Stable Car stock from 22 5/8 at the opening to 15 at the close. This was due entirely to the reported action of the Western and Southwestern roads yesterday in reducing the mileage rate on cars upon which mileage was paid, except those of refrigerator lines.
Plans for the following new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 27 -- The final exercises of Commencement Week were held at Yale to-day. They began at 9:30 o'clock this morning when the seniors of the academic, law, scientific, and medical departments formed on the campus and marched through the Green to the Center Church, where they were given their diplomas.

SOUTHAMPTON, June 27 -- The American liner New-York, from New-York June 20, arrived here at 4:50 P.M. to-day. As a result of her collision near Nantucket shortly after midnight of the 21st with the Neptune liner Delano, bound from Rotterdam for Baltimore, the New-York shows only slight damage on her port side, under the bridge, and above the water line.
Jean Pierre Paul Casimir-Perier is in his forty-seventh year of age and in his twenty-third of public life. His record in the French Parliamentary Directory is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The market to-day acted as if the short interest was getting nervous. It was specially evident in St. Paul and in Philadelphia Traction. The same coterie that has been building St. Paul up in this market on bids for cash stock resorted to the same tactics to-day and was very successful.

After a long search The New-York Times has finally found a man who is willing to acknowledge active membership in the American Protective Society. He is Charles D.P. Glbson, a dealer in watches at 90 Nassau Street. His home is in Elizabethport, N.J.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 27 -- The yacht race between Yale and Harvard was a big success. Twenty-two yachts started, of which thirteen represented Yale and nine Harvard. Harvard was handicapped right at the start, and in the forty-foot class Yale had a walk-over, and, consequently, had seven points to the good.
LYONS, June 27 -- The trial of Santo, the assassin of President Carnot, has been fixed for July 23.

SING SING, N.Y., June 27 -- Interesting ceremonies attending the presentation of the charter to Mohegan Chapter of Westchester County, Daughters of the American Revolution, were had this morning at Grove Hill, the home of the Regent, Mrs. Annie Van Kensselaer Wells.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 27 -- The Albany County Wheelmen held their second annual tournament to-day at Ridgefteld Park. There was an attendance of over 4,000 people. The three-lap cinder track was banked low and considered dangerous, yet the racing was interesting throughout. Johnson, Sanger, and Tyler met in the mile, open. Johnson was lame from his fall in the races at New-York last Saturday, and had at first refused to ride.
The following is a list of saloon passengers who have been booked to sail by today's outgoing steamships:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 27 -- The proceedings of the Democratic State Convention to-day were of a somewhat turbulent character. Judge T.A. Byrne of Texarkana was elected temporary Chairman, and in his speech intimated that while the Democratic Party of the State was in prime condition the national Democracy was not, it having lost sight of the Chicago platform altogether.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

A meeting of stockholders of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad was held in the office of the Produce Exchange Safe Deposit Company yesterday afternoon for the purpose of protesting against the plan of reorganization recently submitted by the committee of which R. Somers Hayes is Chairman.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -- An Italian mass meeting, which was being held last night for the purpose of expressing regret for President Carnot's assassination, was broken up by Italian rioters.

ALBANY, June 27 -- A New-York morning newspaper contains a long communication from this city in reference to a request made by President McCall of the NewYork Life Insurance Company to the Insurance Departments of seven States outside of New-York to examine the affairs of his company.

PARIS, June 27 -- M. Dupuy was present at Versailles when the result of the balloting was read. In the courtyard of the palace a landau drawn by four horses, with four artillerymen as postilions, was waiting to convey the new President to Paris. M. Challemel-Lacour had gone into the President's chamber to announce to M. Casimir-Perier the fact that he had been elected President of the republic.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The report of the receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company for the month of May, 1894, shows gross receipts, $1,628,230.16; gross expenses, $951,283.39, leaving a profit in operating of $676,946.77; net receipts from others sources, $42,040.64; profit for the month, $718,987.41.

William M. Singerly is a native of Philadelphia. He was born on Dec. 27, 1832. With the exception of a brief period, he has lived always in Philadelphia. His father was Joseph Singerly, one of the originators of the street railway system of Philadelphia, from whom the son has inherited his marked business ability.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 27 -- A brisk southwesterly wind which has been, blowing all day compelled the postponement of the two-mile race between the freshmen crews of Harvard, Yale, and Columbia Colleges. The race will be rowed to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock if the water permits. As the wind has died down very considerably this evening the outlook for good water and a good race is very encouraging when the crews meet in the morning.

In the course of the debate in the Senate on Tuesday, Mr. Hill remarked that he represented all classes of the people of this State. If he has really desired to represent the people of New-York in his attitude toward all parts of the Tariff bill now pending in the Senate, we do not quite understand his course with respect to the Gorman-Brice sugar schedule.

PARIS, June 27 -- Crowds, attracted by the extraordinary event of the day, began arriving at Versailles at an early hour this morning, but the chief actors in the scene which engaged the attention of the world -- the Senators and Deputies composing the National Congress -- did not arrive until later.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Vice President to-day laid before the Senate this cablegram:

ALBANY, June 27 -- For an hour and half this morning the Constitutional Convention wrestled with the proposition to adjourn over next week. At the end of the argument the convention found itself it the spot where it began, with the subject still unsettled.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

TROY June 27. -- It was expected yesterday that the people would have all their direct evidence in the Shea murder trial in to-day and that the defense would then open. Mr. Raines, however, stated this morning that the people probably would not rest before to-morrow. It is now believed that the trial will last the remainder of this week and probably all of next week.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 27. --The community was startled shortly before midnight by the announcement that Chairman Doyle of the American Railway Union Grievance Committee had just telegraphed every division point on the Northern Pacific Railway system directing employes of the company to cease work at midnight.

Peter L. McLaren of the tea firm of Carter, Macy Co., 142 Pearl Street, who testified before the Senate committee to having paid money to Dockmasters Coye and Monaghan, but refused to repeat his testimony before the Dock Commissioners when they took the matter up for investigation, was sent for by Mayor Gilroy yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 27 -- The quietest and most memorable Commencement Day of the last twenty-five years has ended -- quiet on account of the absence of the usual punches from the college yard, and memorable because it is the line of demarcation between the first and second quarter centuries of the service of Charles William Eliot as President of Harvard University.

One of Col. North's string upset the talent in the opening race at Sheepshead Bay yesterday and began what afterward proved to be a hard afternoon for the guessers. Only two favorites won, and the bookmakers left the beautiful track by the sea in a very happy frame of mind.

SYRACUSE, June 27 -- Commencement at Syracuse University has this year been of unusual interest. The new Chancellor, Dr. Day of New-York City, was formally installed this afternoon, the Rev. J. M.. Buckley of New-York making the principal address.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House took up to-day the bill to admit New-Mexico as a State, and, under the five-minute rule, discussed it until adjournment. The bill was considered in the House, instead of in Committee of the Whole. Most of the time was consumed in unsuccessful efforts so to amend the bill as to require that English shall be the language taught in the public schools.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 27 -- Four thousand persons witnessed the closing races in the intercity series at Pimlico Park this afternoon. The weather was fine and the track fast, and the trotters made the best time that has yet been scored in this series of races to road wagons.

BOSTON, June 27 -- Clarence Hobart met defeat this afternoon at the hands of Malcolm Chace, and, as the result, Hovey and Hobart are to-night once more on even terms for first place in the West Newton tennis tournament. To-day was clearly Chace's day, and the young Providence player covered himself with glory by his successive defeats of two such cracks as A. E. Foote, the Tale expert, and Clarence Hobart.

WASHINGTON, June 27 The income tax is still pending in the Senate Committee of the Whole. The most conservative of the Democratic Senators had predicted that it would be out of the way by the time the Senate should adjourn this evening, but their prognostications proved to be incorrect.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 27 -- Franklin MacVeagh of Chicago, a stalwart Republican up to ten years ago, who has since been known rather as an Independent than as a party adherent, will be the next United States Senator from Illinois, should the Legislature to be elected in November have a Democratic majority. This was the decision of the Democratic State Convention this afternoon.

Judge Colt, in Boston yesterday, postponed until to-day the New-York and NewEngland hearing relative to the issuance of $500,000 receivers' certificates with which to pay interest and taxes. The postponement was to give Mr. Loring, representing the second mortgage bondholders, time to prepare an answer as to why the receivers' certificates should not be issued.

ROME, June 27 --The police arrested three Anarchists this morning in the precincts of the Chamber of Deputies. They were taken to the police station and searched. Each one of them had upon his person an accurately-drawn plan of the hall lobbies, entrances, , of the Chamber of Deputies, showing almost conclusive evidence that their design was to explode a bomb or commit some other outrage in the building.

BOSTON, June 27 -- The market for local stocks was startled into some activity by the remarkable drop in American Bell Telephone, which opened 13 points off at 190, declined to 188, and closed at 193. The unexpected had happened, and the Governor had vetoed the bill to allow the Bell Company to increase its capital stock.

TOTTENVILLE, S.I., June 27 -- Miss Mabel Blanche McCowan, daughter of the Rev. Dr. W.S. McCowan of this place, was married this afternoon to J. Travis King of Port Richmond, S.I., in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, of which the bride's father is pastor.

DENVER, Col., June 27 -- It was 11 o'clock when President Tracy called the National Republican League Convention to order. Mr. Thurston was again called to the chair. The Committee on Rules reported the adoption of the Thomas B. Reed House rules. It reported that the delegation present cast the vote to which the State and Territory is entitled, and that the college leagues have the same privilege.

For Governor -- WILLIAM M. SINGERLY of Philadelphia. For Lieutenant Governor -- JOHN S. RILLING of Erie. For Auditor General -- DAVID F. MAGEE of Lancaster. For Secretary of Internal Affairs -- Adjt. Gen. WALTER W. GREENLAND of Clarion.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Reports have reached the Navy Department of a remarkable phenomenon which occurred at the Norfolk Navy Yard a week ago to-day, through which two men were killed instantly and a number of others were knocked senseless by an electrical discharge. Considerable mystery still surrounds the occurrence, and it has not yet been possible to' obtain full particulars.

Maxwell Evarts, son of ex-Senator and ex-Secretary of State Evarts, who presided at the dinner of the class of 1884 Tuesday night, created a sensation. He bitterly attacked the administration of President Dwight, and his remarks were received with a few hisses and many cheers. Mr. Evarts said things which many graduates of the older classes have said for a long time quietly.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- Stewart Nicol, the eleven-year-old son of Capt. James D. Nicol, Superintendent of the Anchor Line of steamships, and his companion, "Willie Roff, the fifteen-year-old son of W.A. Roff of the Pennsylvania Railroad, were drowned while bathing in the Passaic River near their home this afternoon.

The County Committee of the State Democracy has declared in terms which might have been a little more explicit, but are still of unmistakatole purport, that it is not irrevocably committed to a straight-ticket policy. Mr. John Brooks Leavitt's resolution was a very full and clear declaration favorable to a union of all anti-Tammany forces in support of independent nominations.

HANOVER, N.H., June 27 -- Prayers held in Rollins Chapel this morning at 8:30 o'clock were the last that the class of '94 attended as undergraduates. President Tucker officiated. The commencement exercises began at 10 o'clock. At 9:45 every seat in the church was taken.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 27 -- The following companies were incorporated to-day with the Secretary of State:
Many boys and girls of the grammar schools of the city have been made happy with graduating diplomas.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- W.A. Cline, exSuperintendent of the Carnegie armor press shops, charged by Craig and Sill, his former clerks, with falsifying the records of the treatment of armor plates, finished his testimony before the committee investigating the alleged frauds to-day.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 27 -- The character of the evidence on which the enemies of the Elmira Reformatory are trying to make their case against Mr. Brockway was very well illustrated at the session of the Governor's investigating commission to-day.

EDINBURGH, June 27 -- It was definitely announced at the meeting of the Edinburgh Liberal Association to-day that Mr. Gladstone will not return to Parliament from Midlothian or any other constituency after the ending of the present session. The association unanimously recommended Sir Thomas Gibson-Carmichael as Mr. Gladstone's successor in the Parliamentary seat for Midlothian.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Besides the bust of Vice President Stevenson, there are now in the office of the architect of the Capitol awaiting the adjournment of Congress to be placed in vacant niches in the Senate Chamber the busts, of two former Vice Presidents -- Aaron Burr and Dallas.

CLEVELAND, June 27 -- Two games were played between Cleveland and Brooklyn to-day, the latter easily winning both. The first was distinguished chiefly by the hard and timely hitting of the visitors, costly errors by the home team, and awful umpiring. In the second game neither ditcher was hit so hard. The Brooklyns won by the same means as in the first game.

The fifth annual commencement of the girts' department of Grammar School No. 87 was held yesterday morning in the school building at the corner of Seventy-seventh Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Richard S. Tracy, one of the Trustees of the Twenty-second Ward, presided. Miss Annie V. Fox, Principal of the department, had assumed charge of the exercises.

-- Here and There -- Mrs. M.M. Shippen, the Misses Shippen, Mrs. Hilborne L. Roosevelt and Miss D. Roosevelt, all of this city, are at the Hotel de l'Empire, Paris. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lanier, who have returned from abroad will soon go to their Summer home "Allen Winden," Lenox, Mass., where they will remain until Christmas.

No sooner is the long strike of the coal miners fairly over than another, even more "wrong-headed, is entered upon by the employes of railroad companies in the West under the order of the American Railway Union. To judge of this arbitrary and unjust proceeding it is hardly necessary to consider the merits of the controversy between the Pullman Car Company and its workmen.

Ex-Congressman C.M. Shelley of Alabama, who was an Auditor of the Treasury Department in Mr. Cleveland's first term, was among yesterday's visitors at the Custom House. Speaking of the campaign in his State, in which Congressman W. C. Oates, the Democratic candidate for Governor, is opposed by R.F. Kolb, Mr. Shelley said the contest had developed into a national campaign in miniature.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- With the simple beginning of a few hundred discontented strikers at Pullman, Ill., who were attempting to force a local issue, the Pullman strike and consequent boycott has assumed the proportions of the greatest battle between labor and capital that has ever been inaugurated in the United States.
BALTIMORE, Md., June 28 -- In summarizing the record of Southern development for the past three months The Manufacturers' Record says:

ALBANY, June 28 -- The Constitutional Convention voted down to-day the proposition to transfer the convention to the cool retreats of Saratoga, voted in favor of adjourning from Friday to next Thursday, and unseated two Democratic delegates from the Thirtieth (Buffalo) District, on the ground that many fraudulent votes had been cast for them.

Political suicide is not unlawful, and no statute can be framed that would repress it. This is a free country, and any party may do what it likes so long as it does not openly violate the legal rights of others. But suicide, if not unlawful, is plainly unwholesome, and all sensible politicians should avoid it.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 28 -- For eight hours to-day the commission which is investigating Superintendent Brockway and his methods of conducting the reformatory listened to testimony given by inmates who said they had been paddled.

Richard Worthington of the Worthington Publishing Company of 747 Broadway was arrested yesterday on an order issued by Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court on the petition of Joseph J. Little, receiver of the company.

The Lexow committee is to be congratulated upon having found an honest, and courageous man and good citizen who refused to be blackmailed by the police. This was Mr. Kilpatrick, the builder, who testified yesterday, and he had also heard of another like-minded builder, Mr, David King.

There was a good attendance yesterday afternoon at the court of the Orange Tennis Club, at Mountain Station, N.J., to witness the continuation of the Middle States championship tennis tournament. The fair sex was predominant, as the ladies' singles was expected to furnish some interesting tennis. But the contest in that event proved decidedly tame, and the only really good tennis was played in the matches between Larned and Flscher, and Millett and Parker.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Representative Cummings (Dem., N.Y.,) this afternoon took to the White House the bill making Labor Day a national holiday, and President Cleveland immediately signed it.
LONDON, June 28 -- Lord Rosebery, in the House of Lords, to-day moved a vote of congratulation to the Queen on the occasion of the birth of a son to the Duke of York.
The Logan Club of Brooklyn tendered a reception last evening to Chairman Lexow of the Senate investigating committee at its clubhouse, 255 Sixth Avenue.

Few clubs in the United States are better known among cyclers and non-wheelmen as well than the Kings County Wheelmen. To be a Kings County Wheelman is synonymous with being a "scorcher," both on the track and on the road, for no club in the State has done more to promote cycling and keep the wheel before the general public through the medium of road runs and race meets.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., June 28 -- The third trial in the series of official tests of the Schuckert search light was held here to-night, under the supervision of the Ordnance Board, which has been endeavoring to ascertain the value of the light for military purposes. The test was not so satisfactory as the two already held.

BOSTON, June 28 -- The market for local stocks was generally dull, American Bell Telephone and West End Street Railway being featureless all day. The friends of the Bell Company rallied to its support, and the stock rose on comparatively small sales to 196. Brie Telephone recovered to 46 for a small lot.

At the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday afternoon between races the subject of conversation was regarding the death of poor old Raceland. The gelding was looked upon as a fixture on the turf, and no horse of recent years, with perhaps the possible exception of Parole, was so popular with the sport-loving public.

TROY, N.Y., June 28 -- On the reconvening of the court this morning James M. Adams was again placed on the stand. He described the fight at the time Hayner was ejected from the polling place. He said that at the time the final shot was fired by Shea, Boland was west of Ross, following McGough, and he was certain he did not fire the shot.

The Socialists in the French Assembly have, been rendering an important public service in spite of themselves. Of course it must have been in spite of themselves. The service consisted in the clear demonstration they succeeded in making that the election, of M. Casirair-Perier wag, in the actual conditions, a clear political and social necessity.

George M. Pullman, President of the Pullman Palace Car Company, who is now in Chicago, has issued a comprehensive statement to the public with regard to the efforts of the company to keep its works open and give employment to its men. Among other things, he says:

Senator Edmund O'Connor of Binghamton, a member of the Senate investigating committee, and a representative Republican from his part of the State, said some very interesting things about the investigation, about New-York City and State politics, and about Thomas C. Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

Charles F. Chatterton, who is probably as well Known as any other theatrical manager in this country or Europe, from his long connection with Augustin Daly and the firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, sailed for Europe Wednesday on the Paris. Mr. Chatterton has had several attacks of illness in this country during the last few years, and he is perfectly free from them in England.

"There is not the slightest doubt that distinct efforts have been made to bring about an alliance between the American Protective Association and the Republican Party in this State, and, as a good Republican, I declare most emphatically that the sooner the Republican Party clears its skirts of this organisation of so-called 'patriots' the better."
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 28 -- It was Centennial Day at Bowdoin, and the public exercises in commemoration of the one hundredth anniversary of the incorporation of the college were held in the Congregational Church at 10 A.M. The church was crowded to its utmost capacity, at least 2,000 people being present.

The Brooklyn Common Council, without consulting the wishes of the property owners of Jefferson Avenue, last week ordered the street lighted with arc electric lamps from Bedford Avenue to Tompkins Avenue. Mayor Schieren yesterday received from the property owners a formal protest, in writing, against the electric lights.

The exercises of the class of 1894 of Grammar School No. 47 were held in the morning at the school building, in Twelfth Street, near University Place. As the four upper classes from Grammar School No. 10 were lately incorporated with those of No. 47, the exercises were participated in by girl graduates of both schools.

The Hotel New Netherland at Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, which has been closed for several months, will be reopened about Sept. 1 by Stafford Whitaker. A lease was signed last night under which they agree to take the hotel for ten years.

From to-day on about 2,500 residents of Brooklyn will eat no more of the goods sold in any grocery, store that, deals in spirituous liquors, for 500 temperance women have said so, and these same women, have decided not to patronize any kind of store that sells liquors or orders them for customers.

The closing exercises of the girls' department of Grammar School No. 76, at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, of which Miss Kate G. Broderick is Principal, proved of great interest to the relatives and friends of the unusually large graduating class. The large assembly room was handsomely decorated with flags and flowers.

When the Lexow committee adjourns at the close of to-day's session, it will in all probability be until September. Chairman Lexow said at the close of yesterday's session that all the Senators and the counsel had practically agreed during the day to take the long Summer rest.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 28 -- The new St. John's Riverside Hospital, the gift of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cochran to the city, was presented and dedicated this morning at interesting services held in the hospital chapel, where there was assembled a large number of Yonker's representative citizens and their families.

William Spooner of 343 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street and Ernest Buchner of 337 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, each thirteen years old, were arrested last night charged with having thrown into the water Samuel Castrillo, eight years old, of 352 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, who was drowned last Monday at the foot of East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street.

The Kings County Board of Supervisors, at their meeting yesterday afternoon, by a vote of 22 to 8, refused to sustain the veto of Supervisor at Large Fitchie of the resolution authorizing the payment of the bill of ex-Senator James W. Birkett for $24,564,91 for work done at the county farm at St. Johniand, L.I.

LONDON, June 28 -- In the Souse of Commons to-day Stanley Leighton asked John Morley. Chief Secretary for Ireland, if the Government had given any attention to the special report showing the increase of insanity in Ireland from the habit of tea drinking.
