The intense heat of the past week, which caused so much discomfort and suffering among the well-to-do classed, fell with much more force upon the unhappy occupants of the tenements. The casual visitor passing through any portion of the east side at this period of the year cannot fall to be impressed with its congested condition.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Further changes in the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill may be made as a result of the complications which beset the managers of the Tariff bill.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 28 -- The presence, of mind and bravery of Gertrude Crawford, a fourteen-year-old daughter of Capt. William Crawford of the steamer John G. Christopher of New-York, which is at anchor in the river here, saved the life of her eight-year-old sister Addle last night. She also made a brave effort to rescue Charles Heins, the steamer's mate, but he was drowned.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 28 -- There were never so manyyachts in the harbor for an intercollegiate boat race as there were to-day, and it is doubtful whether there will be more when the New-York Yacht Club fleet comes in August. Yatchtsmen have had good weather, and have taken every advantage of their opportunities to witness the big boat race.

Collector Kilbreth has investigated the charges made betore the Lexow committee against customs officers. His conclusions, together, with an order forbidding officers to receive fees from steamship companies, were communicated yesterday to Acting Surveyor S.M. Blatchford in the following letter:

The town of New-Utrecht will become part of Brooklyn on Sunday. Commissioner Welles of the Police Department yesterday announced that the old town would be the Twenty-fifth Precinct and the Twenty-fifth Sub-Precinct. The former Will include that portion of the town from the city line to Fort Hamilton, and the latter will take in Bath Beach, Bensonhurst, and Unionville.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Unimportant and uninteresting, as the trade in wheat was to-day, there was nevertheless enough business to define a weak market. It would probably have shown greater depression had it not been for the firmness of corn and the reported sale of 100,000 bushels Spring wheat, partly for export. These two items checked the downward course of prices, but were not potent enough to cause a rally.

-- An order was signed yesterday by Justice Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, appointing Mrs. Annie Odell Allen, guardian of her nineteenyear-old daughter, Edith Bruce Alien, to protect her interests in an action by Her father, Harry Allen, to have his rights determined to the income of certain bonds Under a trust created on April 21, 1877, by Mrs. Ethelinda V. Allen, his mother.

Title was to have passed yesterday in the matter of the sale of the Bennett Building by Mr. John Pettit to Theodore A. Havemeyer, but the signing of the deed was postponed. It looks as though the transaction would not go through.

Final Judgment was rendered by Judge Glidersleeve at a special term of the Superior Court, June 21, In the suit of Dr. Jaeger's Sanitary Woolen System Company against La Boutillier Brothers of Fourteenth Street, for a violation of the plaintiff's right to the exclusive use of the name "Jaeger" or "Dr. Jaeger" to designate the goods manufactured by the plaintiff.
Graduation exercises were held in several of the grammar schools of the city yesterday, and diplomas and prizes were awarded to the successful and happy pupils.

One hundred and eleven delegates from the sixteen Good Government clubs in this city met in convention in Vienna Hall, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday to discuss the advisability of nominating a candidate for Mayor this Fall. The conference began at 4 o'clock in the afternoon and lasted until late at night.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 28. -- Southwestern Minnesota and Eastern South Dakota suffered death and destruction last night by a series of windstorms. Details of the damage done to life and property, which have been coming in slowly, show that ten persons were killed and twenty or thirty injured.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 28 -- The Michigan Democratic State Convention, held here to-day, made the following nominations:

NEWTON CENTRE, Mass., June 28 -- Miss Emily Fanning Hunter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen. V.A. Hunter, and Elias Bullard Bishop, son of Judge Robert R. Bishop, were married to-night in the First Congregational Church. Festoons of laurel, white palms, and masses of pink and white roses decorated the church interior.

Application was made to the Stock Exchange last Wednesday by the Reorganization Committee of the Northern Pacific Railroad for the listing of the Mercantile Trust certificates representing the deposits of Northern Pacific securities under the reorganization agreement. The committee, of which Edward D. Adams is Chairman, was able to show the Governing Committee that it represented more than $18,000,000 of the certificates.

LONDON, June 28 -- It is asserted that the murder of M. Carnot was planned in London on the evening of Feb. 6, the day after the execution of the Anarchist Vaillant in Paris. It is also said that circulars counselling the assassination were found among the papers seized at the Autonomie Club by Police Inspector Melville.

Grammar School No. 15, Brooklyn, held its graduating exercises in Association Hall, Bond Street, near Fulton Street, last evening. Among those present were Charles E. Teale, Charles A. Buttrick, Col. John Y. Colyer of the Board of Education, Principal William L. Felter, Miss Sarah Ball, Herman S. Johnson, Jennie H.D. Stone, and Alice M. Judge.

Many of Brooklyn's bright grammar school pupils received their diplomas yesterday. At Grammar School No 5, in Duffleld Street, there were seated on the platform during the commencement exercises Dr. John J. Colgan, Dr. Peter J. Curren, the Rev. L. Richardson, Thomas Stevenson, Ambrose Le Blanc, and Dr. William. T. Vlyman, the Principal.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- When an old busybody like Mr. Hoar stoops to the capers of such a comparative and trifling Senatorial youngster as Chandler the judicious must necessarily grieve. Chandler has assumed that role for himself, and in all the performances in the Senate by the Republicans he has been allowed to play the seriocomic villain.
PARIS, June 28 -- The police are confident that some of Santo's accomplices are in Toulouse, but decline to give their reasons.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 28 -- The Yale crews to-day verified the prophecy of The New-York Times of last Tuesday when her freshmen defeated both Columbia and Harvard, the three crews finishing as had been predicted. The Yale crew absolutely lost the Harvard crew in the university race, winning by about twenty lengths, instead of ten, as The Times had said was probable.

The new Board of Rapid-Transit Commissioners met yesterday afternoon in its new quarters, in the Home Life Building, on Broadway. There were present at the meeting Commisisoners Alexander E. Orr, Mayor Gilroy, Controller, Fitch, William Steinway, Seth Low, John H. Starin, and John Claflin.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Mr. W.E. Corey, Superintendent of the armor-plate department of the Carnegie Works, appeared before the armor-plate investigation committee to-day. He directed the work generally, he said, ordered the steel, and looked after its manufacture. One of his routine duties was to look over the reports of the foremen of the shops and see what work had been done during the previous twenty-four hours.

PARIS, June 28 -- President Casimir-Perier has accepted the resignation of Premier Dupuy and the other members of the Ministry, to go into effect after the funeral of M. Carnot, on Sunday, on which occasion M. Dupuy will deliver an oration in the Pantheon on behalf of the Government.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 28 -- This was Commencement Day at Trinity Colege. At 10:30 A.M. the Senatus Academicus met for prayers in Christ Church. At 11 o'clock the graduating exercises of the class of '94 were held in the Opera House.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- This was a very dull day at Point Breeze, the two classes being decided in straight beats without the semblance of a contest in either. The 2:10 pace, which came first, proved easy for Simmons, who brought 5 to 3 over the field. He equaled his half-mile track record of 2:16 1/4 twice and then had to step a second faster to shake Amelia off in the third heat.

When the Kings County Board of Estimate began work yesterday it was found that, notwithstanding the culling and, slashing that had been done in order to bring down the requisitions to a business basis, there was still an excess of $66,000 over the 2 per cent. limit.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- There was a disposition to sell the market to-day. The market opened a shade below yesterday's closing. The bears used the Western strike news as a club, and, in the absence of any support, prices were somewhat demoralized. Pennsylvania, Reading, and Lehigh Valley were all dull at slight concessions.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 28 -- The Democratic State Convention was called to order in this city to-day by T.J. Boynton of Montpelier, Chairman of the State Committee, who made a brief address. P.J. Farrell of Newport was made Chairman. These nominations were made by acclamation:

ALBANY, June 28 -- The Roma Athletic Club has been incorporated by the Secretary of State. The principal office is in New-York. Other New-York City societies incorporated are the Harvard Medical Society of New-York City, with objects to promote the scientific and social interest of its members. The Executive Committee consists of Drs. Reynolds W. Wilcox, Dillon Brown, Frank H. Daniels, Howard Lilienthal, Royal Whitman, and J. Winters Brannan.

ALBANY, June 29 --The State Forest Commissioners are apprehensive lest a little amendment which was tacked on the general game laws adopted by the last Legislature may work serious injury to the deer in the Catskills, which the Commissioners have been rearing for several years in the hope of restocking the mountain region with this game.

"Twenty millions to its debit; a lot of unproducing and abandoned alleged mining properties to its credit, and not one cent in its Treasury." That is the way in which Lawyer Hugh L. Cole sums up the condition of the Harney Peak Tin Mining, Milling, and Manufacturing Company of which Samuel Untermyer of this city is President.

HOBART, N.Y., June 20 -- St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, which was founded a hundred years ago, when Hobart was a little hamiet known, as Waterville, and was surrounded by a wilderness, infested with savage Indians, celebrated its hundredth anniversary to-day with interesting and fitting ceremonies.
The Kings County Wheelmen races will be held this afternoon at the Parkway Driving Club's track at Gravesend. It is a neat half-mile track, and some fast time ought to be made.

PARIS, June 29 -- Schoolmaster Guillemin of Bussieres-les-Claremont, in the Marne, was showing his pupils to-day how President Carnot had been stabbed. The children had gathered around him as he drew the knife.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29 -- Had it not been for the coolness of Chief of Police Eldridge and six of his men, a riot would have taken place at the place where Mrs. Margaret Rice, the evangelist, was speaking to-night. She attacked the city officials, and had about her a crowd of over 1,000 excited people, when the Chief ordered her to desist.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Mr. Hoar's cheap attempt to gain notoriety by refusing to consent to the consideration of the joint resolution to continue the existing appropriations for thirty days came to a ridiculous end to-day.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 29 -- The enemies of the Elmira Reformatory brought in some of their cases of alleged "cruelties" to-day, and in the attempts to discredit the institution, asked the inmates to rehearse their stories before the Governor's commission. They did so, one or two witnesses relating how they had been knocked down, kicked, and beaten in the bathroom.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The curious electrical phenomenon at the Norfolk Navy Yard last week, when two men were killed and a number of others stunned, continues to excite great interest among naval officials, and it is likely that a modification of the regulations relative to docking ships will be made as a result of pending investigations.

Frederick W. Hinrichs, the Register of Arrears of Brooklyn, is aroused over the appeal which the Litchfield estate has made to the Court of Appeals against the payment of arrears of taxes on its property on the ground that the law is unconstitutional. Mr. Hinrichs writes as follows:

It is the first impulse of almost every one whose indignation is aroused by the outrageous attempt to "tie up" the Western railroads to declare that the men engaged in such a proceeding ought to be punished, and that laws should be made and enforced to prevent the repetition of such an interference with the business of transportation.

There was mourning in the betting ring at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. George Smith, better known as "Pittsburgh Phil," made one of those plunges for which he is famous, on Candelabra, in the third race, and it is estimated that he carried away about $20,000. This season Mr. Smith has been rather unlucky, but yesterday he saw a chance to get even, and he sent out his money in large quantities.

Report of Debate of June 22, 1894. Mr. Allen -- I propose to put some things in The Record which the country ought to know. The Tariff bill can afford to lose one more day, if necessary, for the truth to be known to the country. The New-York World is a pretty fair Democratic authority, I suppose.
Sept. 10, at 10 A.M., was the date set last evening for the Lexow committee to reassemble and continue its investigation of the Police Department.

The departure of the Greenland expedition organized by Dr. Frederick Cook of Brooklyn, which was fixed for Wednesday, has been postponed until 4 o'clock this afterroon because of the non-arrival of the steamship Miranda from the Windward Islands.

Mr. J. Clarence Davies has sold for George Lang the property at the northeast corner of Bergen Avenue and Gerard Street, containing about four lots, to Mr. Charles B. Lawson, President of the Young Men's Christian Union, at $10,000. This plot adjoins one of six lots at the southeast corner of Bergen and Westchester Avenues, bought this week by Mr. Lawson for the purpose of restricting the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Vice President laid before the Senate to-day a communicaition from, the Secretary of Agriculture, in reply to a Senate resolution calling upon that official for a statement of the visible and invisible supply of wheat likely to be in the United States on July 1, 1894, and the number of bushels likely to be raised in each or the States.

Ex-Judge William G. Cnoate, referee in the suit between the receivers of the Madison Square and St. Nicholas Banks, finished yesterday the report he will make to the Supreme Court. He finds in favor of the St. Nicholas.

TROY, June 29 -- Witnesses for the defense testified to-day in the Shea murder trial. Their testimony was directed toward persuading the Jury that it was not "Bat" Shea who killed Robert Ross in the election riot last Fall, but John H. Boland.

It is quite conceivable that the remarks of Mr. Keir-Hardie in the House of Commons on Thursday may have shocked the august assembly to which they were addressed. The difference between private conversation and public discussion by orators or newspapers is nowhere more strenuously insisted on than in Great Britain.

Considerably less than 100,000 shares was the record of business to the stocK marKet yesterday. And of all the business more than a third was in Sugar. There was something over 10,000 shares of Burlington traded in, but other stocks both of railway and industrial companies were exceedingly dull. Sugar was marked up by the pool, but the general market was irregular.

Charles Scribner's Sons will supply the American copies of the new Edinburgh Edition of R.L. Stevenson's works. Only 1,000 copies are to be issued, and only 100 will come to this country. The first volume is promised for October.

The Hon. Edmund O'Connor of Binghamton, member of the State Senate, would probably be very much astonished if he knew that The Times and a majority of the decent voters of the State of New-York of either political party and of none heartily share his wish that Thomas C. Platt shall be nominated for Governor this year.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The close on wheat to-day was 1/8c higher than yesterday, but the tone throughout the entire session and until within a few minute the end of the day's trading was decidedly weak, and prices ruled 1/4 @ 3/4c under Thursday's final figures. The rally came about through the sale of 17,000 bushels of cash wheat by Seaverns, who afterward posed in the market as a buyer of the futures.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- President Debs and his associates of the American Railway Union made a radical move to-day when they formally boycotted every road represented in the General Managers' Association. Commissions were given to committees representing the employes of each road with orders to call out the men the instant sufficient support was obtained to warrant a strike.

The question of apportionment of the passenger business between New-York and Buffalo, both east-bound and west-bound, occupied the attention of the Executive Committee of the Trunk-Line Association for several hours yesterday. There has been some dissatisfaction on the part of two or three of the trunk lines with the present apportionment, and the purpose of the meeting was to consider the best means of settling all differences and satisfying each road.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I clip the following from one of the morning papers, which, It seems to me, deserves a very different comment from that it has received in the press, Mr. Goff is reported to have said to the so-called Lexow committee:

Samuel Spencer of this city, President of the new Southern Railway Company, successor to the Richmond Terminal, has issued the following executive orders, which explain the present status of the company:

Col. George Bliss, whose position in the Republican Party of this State has been a most prominent one for over twenty-five years, was asked yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times for his views on the American Protective Association.

The Brooklyn waterfront was visited yesterday by another, destructive warehouse fire. One of the large warehouses of the Woodruff Stores, owned by Franklin Woodruff, at the foot of State Street, just north of the Atlantic Avenue Ferry, was entirely destroyed, with all its contents.

In the testimony at the morning session it was shown that men who sold fruit from pushcarts, placed at street corners, paid $15 a month to the police for protection. This is almost as much as merchants who rent stores testified that they paid for noninterference when they used the sidewalk.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Grand Jury this afternoon brought into court indictments againt Elberton R. Chapman, broker of New-York, and John W. MacCartney, broker of this city, two of the witnesses who refused to answer the questions of the Senate committee.

ALBANY, June 29 -- In the Constitutional Convention this morning the proposition to publish the proceedings of the convention in two daily papers in Albany for distribution throughout the State was lost by a vote of 52 to 65. The minority voted almost solidly against the proposition.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 29 -- Senator John Hinchliffe of Paterson attempted to reach his home from Jersey City last night on the Susquehanna and Westera ain due at Hackensack at 10:43. He has pass that is no longer good, and Conductor Louis Jones told him so and at the same time demanded fare.

The forthcoming book to be written by members of the Professional Woman's League will probably be illustrated. The league has not made this statement in so many words, but it decided yesterday in favor of illustrated books.

The Forum has seldom printed a series of more timely articles than those which appear in the number for July. Mr. Coudert writes the opening paper, which deals with the A. P. A., a topic on which Prof. J. B. McMaster makes a further contribution under the heading, "The Riotous Career of the Know-Nothings."
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Superintendent Corey of the Carnegie Company, to-day continued his testimony regarding the alleged armor frauds before the special committee investigating the subject.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The news of the nomination of Franklin MacVeagh to be the next Senator of the United States from the State of Illinois was a great surprise to all the politicians here. As was the case about four years ago, when the Democrats of the country began to talk about a candidate for President, the most determined opponents of Mr. Cleveland are in Washington.
When Mayor Gilroy was asked yesterday what he thought of the adjournment of the Senate committee he said:

The communication, which Major Kipp took from Police Headauarters to the Lexow committee yesterday consisted of resolutions adopted by Commissioners Martin and Sheehan against the vote of Commissioner Murray. As adopted the resolutions were:
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Tariff bill has been reported to the Senate by the Committee of the Whole, and the Senate has adjourned until Monday.

TRENTON, N.J., June 29 -- The commission to revise the judicial system of New-Jersey held its regular bi-weekly session at the State House to-day. Much time was devoted to a discussion of the constitution of the highest courts. Ex-Gov. Bedle argued against disturbing the integrity of the Supreme Court.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- The market showed some tendency to-day to harden in spots, and there being little stock for sale, the drift was toward Higher prices. Philadelphia Traction was active. As the transfer books closed to-day transactions except for cash were ex the rights. For cash it opened at 100 5/3, and the first transaction ex rights was 85 3/4.

ST. PAUL, June 29 -- The Supreme Court handed down this morning a decision in the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway litigation, affirming the judgment of the court below, which concedes the right of equipment and improvement bondholders to demand payment of their mortgage from the railway company.

The second and last day of the sale of John A. Logan, Jr.'s, hackneys and half breds was held by Tattersalls yesterday afternoon and evening at Durland's Academy. The attendance was smaller than on Thursday, and many of the lots were of no better quality than may be had at the regular weekly sales. Bidding was not brisk.

-- The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company General Reorganization Committee announces that the agreement under which deposits are to be made will shortly be lodged for signatures with the depositories in New-York, Boston, London, and Amsterdam. Holders may deposit their signatures with depositories named in the plan, and will receive temporary receipts therefor, exchangeable hereafter for reorganization certificates of deposit.

All the public schools in this city closed yesterday for the Summer season, and the thousands of teachers and pupils, freed from their labors and responsibilities, have entered upon their well-earned vacation. The schools will reopen on Sept. 10, and during the interval improvements and repairs will be made to many of the schoolhouses.

Michael Donnelly was arraigned before Judge Martine in Part I. of the General Sessions yesterday for the fourth day of his trial on the charge of shooting at his former partner, Patrick J. McArdle, in Judge Bischoff's part in the Common Pleas Court on April 24.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- There were a good many changes among important naval commands to-day. Commodore L.A. Beardslee, who was recently promoted from a Captaincy, and has been in command of the naval station at Port Royal, S.C., will succeed Admiral Walker on the Pacific Station.

BOSTON, June 29 -- The market for local stocks was dull, with no special feature, unless it were the recovery of 4 points in Boston United Gas second 5s, which opened at 56, 1 above yesterday's close, and advanced to 59. The advance was occasioned by the statement that a, draft for the payment of the coupons had been sent to New-York as a denial of the rumor that July interest might not be paid.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge was the Phi Beta Kappa orator at Harvard Thursday. He devoted a good deal of attention to warning his hearers of the danger to the world of the critical spirit. It is a danger, he says, that "confronts all our large universities to-day, and which, I am sure, confronts that university which I know and love best.

The great front, doors of Trinity Church, modeled by Karl Bitter and cast by the Henri Bonnard Company, are on exhibition at the latter's foundries, West Sixteenth Street. The National Sculpture Society, of which Mr. Bitter is a member, has considered these doors merely as a piece of bronze casting, worthy of a special circular, and many hundreds of people have visited the place daily.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Quite unexpectedly to-day a contested election case was precipitated upon the attention of the House, and Thomas Watson of Georgia, the well-known Populist member of the Fifty-second Congress, was declared not to have been elected to the Fifty-third Congress from the Tenth District of that State, and J.C.C. Black was confirmed in his title to the seat.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The statement is made to-day from an authoritative source that no issue of bonds will be made by the Administration during the Summer, that the President and Secretary Carlisle are in thorough accord on the financial policy of the Treasury, and that an end to gold exports to Europe is believed to be about reached.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The buying of Lake Street to-day was of a character to confirm the report generally circulated that the Northwestern "L" and West Chicago Street Railway have secured control of the company. Thousands of shares changed hands, and, while the bears worked hard, there was such liberal buying that their efforts were unavailing.
PARIS, June 29 -- The police of Marseilles have ascertained that the assassination of President Carnot was the culmination of a plot.

Bradstreet's will say to-day: While there is no actual improvement in business throughout the country, there are more favorable prospects and better feeling among merchants, with an increased number of Instances where trade has been stimulated. The ending of the great bituminous coal strike is promptly followed by a sympathetic of railway employes, which threatens disastrous effect on business by reason of interference with distribution and travel.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 29 -- At the naval war college to-day Commander William B. Hoff lectured upon the fleet drill book. He explained at length the necessity of having a speedy and reliable system of signaling in these days of speedy steel war vessels. He contended that naval officers should be as much ashamed of inability to express themselves through the medium of signals as of an inability to write.

The Middle States championship tennis tournament will not be alone in its glory to-day. The tennis tournament arranged by the New-Jersey Athletic Club begins on the grounds at Bergren Point, and will continue until July 4. The Kings County Interclub League will continue its championship tournament on the Kings County Club courts at Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The principal changes embodied in the amendments to the Tariff bill offered to-day by Senator Jones of Arkansas are as follows:

Controller Corwin of Brooklyn made Mayor Schieren happy yesterday morning. The Mayor had worried considerably over the fact that the already close-cut budget was still $66,000 in excess of the 2 per cent, limit. When he heard from Controller Corwin, he said:
The forty-first commencement of Manhattan College was held yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House. Arch- bishop Corrigan presided. Also upon the stage were:
ALBANY, June 29 -- Albert Lee Van Huyck of the United States Engineering Corps was drowned at Mechanicsville this afternoon. He was employed on the dam across the Hudson, when he dropped his rod.

Populism is not Democracy, and Populists are not Democrats. The so-called Democratic Convention in Arkansas did well in voting down the resolution indorsing the Administration of President Cleveland, after adopting one resolution which was pure Populism and rejecting another which was the mildest sort of Democracy.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 29 -- The Summer meeting for the harness racers at Point Breeze ended very quietly this afternoon. Small fields faced Starter McCarthy in both classes, and for the third consecutive day favorites won offhand, J.M.D. made his second appearance of the week in the 2:20 trot, and was unbeatable as ever.

Storehouse K of Woodruff's s Stores, in Brooklyn, was a smoldering ruin yesterday. The front and rear walls were standing intact, but the greater portion of the south wall had fallen, showing within masses of charred timber, jute, and sisal grass partially consumed. From a dozen different points firemen directed streams upon the debris, which was still smoking, showing that the fire was not wholly extinguished.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Assistant District Attorney Taggart, who has charge of the cases against the Senate contumacious witnesses, was asked what could be done in a case where an indicted person in another city refused to appear in court to answer an indictment. He replied:

It was a holiday in London yesterday, so the market here was practically without orders from across the water. Many local operators were also away from business, and, as usual, the trading was extremely light The total transactions were only 26,237 shares. The heaviest trading was in Sugar, but even in that usually active stock less than 5,000 shares changed hands.

Exeter Letter to The Manchester Union. The old Cilley place on the Epping Road, which was at the time of the Granite State National Bank failure the home of Warren F. Putnam, the bank's President, has been sold under the hammer to Lorenzo Nealley and John M. Wadleigh of this town for $13,000.

LENOX, Mass., June 30 -- Archery will be one of the principal sports of the season. Miss Anna Shaw will probably have charge of the club, as she did last year. Among those who will take part in the shooting are Mrs. Richard C. Dixey, Miss Shaw, Miss Elizabeth Shaw, Miss Devereaux, and others.

A vast scheme of reorganization, embracing more than a dozen important railroads in the South, is developing steadily and systematically under the direction of the committee to which was intrusted a large majority of the securities of the old Richmond Terminal system.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., June 30 -- The chief amusement of the week has been the boating on the Shrewsbury. This is especially a diversion of the evening, when the moon brightens up the water and lends an air of romance to the picture. There is Quite a fleet of small boats attached to the hotel, and it is very seldom that they are not in use.

Brittany has produced her thinkers and philosophers, the Eastern Provinces their soldiers, Pitou her lawyers, the valley of the Rhone her orators. But Touraine is the land of keen wit, gay jest, and rich humor; it is the nursing mother of men of the type of Rabelais, Scarron, Paul Louis Courrier, and Balzac.

From The Lewiston (Me.) Journal. Mrs. Betsey Butland of Buxton, who died last week, was famous in her home community as the woman who saw the first elephant that came to Maine. The big beast was driven to Buxton from Portland by night and was kept in the Breweter barn by day and at night was taken out and driven along the road to Alfred.

Some of the most beneficent works among the poor in New-York City are carried on in such a quiet and unobtrusive way that the public has little or no knowledge of the good that is being accomplished by them. Among them are institutions founded and supported entirely by individuals of wealth and self-sacrificing devotion, who not only give their money but their time and personal attention to the work.

An open-air meeting was held last night in Union Square in favor of the underground rapid-transit scheme of the Chamber of Commerce. The meeting was called by District Assembly 40 of the Knights of Labor, and there were speakers also present from the Socialist Labor Party and the United Hebrew Trades Association.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Senator Walsh of Georgia, questioned to-day on the importance of the proposed exposition at Atlanta, said:

-- The monument to Antoine Barye, the sculptor, has been at last unveiled in Paris, where the prejudice in favor of grand classic sculpture still causes a certain coldness toward the genius who placed animals on a level with man in works of art. On the top of the shaft is a bronze copy of Barye's "Theseus Slaying the Centaur."

The game yesterday at Central Park between the New-York and Harlem Cricket Clubs attracted an unusually large crowd of visitors, and considerable interest was aroused in the match from the fact that the clubs were tied for the lead in the second section of the league. The New-Yorks, however, proved easy victors, winning by 46 runs, a result brought about chiefly through the good batting of J.E. Roberts and bowling of C. Moore.

TROY, N. Y., June 30. -- Stanley O'Keefe again took the stand on the reconvening of the court this morning, and Mr. Raines proceeded in the Shea murder trial with the cross-examination. O'Keefe said that he had served in the Albany Penitentiary.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., June 30 -- The hot weather has fairly opened the season here, and the prospects are bright. The place does not suffer so severely from the financial depression as some of the resorts less known and whose reputations have not been made by successive successful seasons.

If the committee takes up the Hollywood whisky scandal, which has caused talk in the Police Department for half a dozen years, some very interesting facts will probably develop. Of late there has not been heard so much of this matter, but a few years ago it was the most burning grievance that a powerful section of the business community, the wholesale liquor trade, had.

WINFIELD, L.I., June 30 -- At the meeting of the Knights and Ladies of Honor tonight, while several of the members participated in a heated discussion, Mrs. Schmitz, Chaplain of the organization, quietly left her seat, and, without any ceremony and before anybody was aware of her actions, cut off one aide of Theodore Scholle's curling mustache with a pair of scissors which she had concealed in the folds of her skirt.

The new fire-proof University Building, which will occupy the site of the old building of the University of the City of New-York in University Place, fronting Washington Square, and between Washington and Waverley Places, will consist of ten stories, besides the basement and sub-cellar. It will have a frontage of about 180 feet on Washington Square and a depth of about 100 feet on Washington and Waverley Places.

-- The Kansas Pacific Consolidated Bondholders' Committee, Silas B. Dutcher, Chairman, announces that it is about to petition the United Stales Circuit Court for the enforcement of its rights in the Cheyenne and Leavenworth division, and also for a proper allowance out of the earnings. Holders of bonds who have informed the Continental Trust Company of their intention to unite with that committee are invited to sign the agreement at once.

There is no getting around the arguments of children. One little girl that I know picked up a book in my presence and began reading backward, starting with the last chapter. I remonstrated with her for this bit of topsyturvydom, telling her that this was not the way to read a book -- that she should begin at the beginning, and read to the end, and not vice-versa.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 29 -- Starting out in life as a camp-meeting ground and rival of Ocean Grove, this place has developed within a few years into being one of the prettiest villages and most popular Summer resorts on the north shore of Long Island. The growth of Sea Cliff, while remarkable in comparison with many other older villages, is not so wonderful when the natural charms and advantages of the spot are known.

Sir William Lane Booker, C.M.G., the retiring British Consul General in this city, is a son of the late Thomas Booker of London. He was born in 1824, was educated at a private school, and later traveled extensively between the years 1844 and 1848 in the East. Southern Europe, the United States, and Canada.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Civil Service Chronicle, which made a great pother in its May number, upon erroneous information, about the transfer of Major Handbury, Corps of Engineers, from Louisville to St. Augustine, and made it appear to be necessary for The New-York Times to supply it with a correct account of the reasons for the removal of Major Handbury.

I regard with interest the Custom House officer, the first American I have seen on native soil, and can scarcely answer his questions for staring. He is a handsome, weary man, exactly like one of Leech's volunteer officers of 1860, and he writes rapidly, holding the pen between the first and second fingers.
NARRAGANSETT PIER, June 30 -- Thursday, the first drag hunt of the season, was run with J.J. Dwyer as Master of Hounds. There were thirty pairs of hounds and sixteen hunters.

ASBURY PARK, June 30 -- The incoming hosts to-day were almost too much for the railroad officials at the station. All day long and until late in the night heavilyladen passenger trains rolled into the station. At dusk the platform was a mountain of trunks, and the perspiring expressmen will labor until Sunday morning before the last Saratoga can be delivered.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $6,182,966, of which amount $906,489 was in dry goods, and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $192,706, and the exports of specie were $3,461,272.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 30 -- About 1,200 young men are now taking examination for admission to the two undergraduate departments of Yale University. Information has been received from most of the schools and cities where these examinations are held, but not as yet from some remote places like San Francisco and Tacoma.

A cool place and one filled with beautiful things is the series of galleries at 366 Fifth Avenue, where the second Summer exhibition of Mr. Clarke's Art House has been opened. It cannot be said that New-York neglects the Summer visitor nor the resident who has not fled to the mountains or sea.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Lake Street Elevated stock was again the centre of attraction in to-day's single session, with transactions amounting to about 5,000 shares. Despite the heavy trading, the certificates did not fluctuate violently, the range being between 18 1/4 and 18 3/4, with a closing at 18 5/8. West Chicago was quiet, moving between 136 1/8 and 136 1/2.

Mr. Clement Scott is of the opinion that before Londoners see Sarah Bernhardt in "Izeyl" they ought to read Sir Edwin Arnold's "Light of Asia." This is rather hard on Sarah Bernhardt, but probably Mr. Scott means well. There is reason to believe that Mr. Scott thinks Sir Edwin is a great poet. Mr. Scott is a poet, too.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30.-John Curley, a newspaper carrier, twenty-five years old, died this morning at the Third Precinct Police Station, after having been locked up on a charge of disorderly conduct. Residents of Adams Street, near Ferry Street, insist that death was due to a clubbing which they say he received at the hands of Policemen John Smith and Michael Long.

The "lady commercial" is fast becoming an institution in Birmingham, as elsewhere. She is, generally speaking, quite as smart and resourceful as her male competitor, and her sex gives her an additional advantage. Apart altogether from the difficulty of saying "No" to a woman, especially if young and handsome, the more drastic methods of getting rid of unwelcome importunities are obviously out of the question when the "traveler" is of the gentler sex.

Mr. Bishop's account of Bond's experiences at Monte Carlo is a singularly fresh and strong treatment of a theme about which the voice of wisdom uttered the last word long ago. A gambler may or may not be a knave, though gambling in any form is allied to knavery a leads to it. But a man who gambles seriously, hoping for profit, is a fool.

There is a pretty flutter among the public school teachers of San Francisco. President Hyde of the Board of Education, signing a lot of certificates recently, was struck with the number of them bearing the diminutives Maggie, Daisy, Essie, Ettie, and Birdie. The last seemed to him the worst of all.

SOUTHAMPTON. L.I., June 30 -- The preliminary season, which consists of the month of June, has been all that could have been expected. Many of the Summer colony of fashionable people who gather here participated in the pleasure of the month. Now that the regular season has opened, life at Southampton promises much in the way of social gayeties.

The residents of King's Bridge are going to celebrate the Fourth of July this year in the genuine old-fashioned manner, with a flag raising, patriotic speeches, and martial music, fireworks of the popular variety during the day, and the whole to conclude in the evening with a pyrotechnic display which will excel anything of the kind that has ever been seen in that quarter of the city.

BERLIN, June 30 -- Emperor William aroused general interest by his three-hour conference yesterday with M. Herbette, the French Ambassador, aboard the imperial yacht Hohenzollern. The interview did not end with marking Germany's sympathy with France in mourning for M. Carnot. It had a practical aim, which has been revealed clearly since the French Ambassador's return from Kiel.

Although Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn has not given entire contentment to the Rev. A, C. Dixon, the impetuous and aggressive pastor of the Hanson Place Baptist Church, his administration of the affairs of the City of Churches seems to have been satisfactory to the people at large, and especially the taxpayers, the men who have long borne the evils of the misgovernment of the Democratic machine ring.

At the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday morning a number of thoroughbred yearlings, the property of Lucius O. Appleby, were sold at auction. The prices brought were good, one of the highest-priced ones going to Orlando A. Jones for $4,000. The animals sold are as follows: Chestnut colt, by Sensation-Almy; O.A.

LONG ISLAND CITY, June 30 -- Mrs. Luella Oakes, who was discharged from an asylum for the insane last week by Supreme Court Justice Gaynor in Brooklyn, attempted to resume her place in her husband's household in this city Thursday evening, and was ordered to leave the house. Later she appeared in the Second Police Precinct Station and asked Sergeant Roulette to give her police protection.

Railway managers are looking forward to some action by Congress, this week, on the Patterson amendments to the Inter-State Commerce act. The most important feature of these amendments is that they propose to replace the existing anti-pooling clause by a provision permitting railroad companies to form pools under the supervision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

Considering its conflict with the Orange tournament, there was a remarkably good entry list for the open tennis tournament of the New-Jersey Athletic Club, which began yesterday afternoon at Bayonne. Calhoun Cragin, H. Howard, John Hobart, Sydney Smith, J.P. Paret, and F. N. Jessup are among the strong players entered. The last named holds the New-Jersey State championship.

The tobacco box belonging to the Past Overseers' Society of St. Margaret's Parish was originally purchased in 1713 at Horn Fair for 4d, by Mr. Henry Monck, and presented by him to the members of the society for use at their meetings. The society, out of respect to the donor, had it ornamented with a silver rim, on which his name was engraved.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Although there is general expectation that the Senate will dispose of the Tariff bill on Tuesday, no agreement to that effect has been reached by the leaders, and there is a chance that the contest may be prolonged until after July 4.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 30 -- The woman suffragists of this city yesterday celebrated the eightieth anniversary of the birth of Mrs. Emily P. Collins, who sent the first petition to the New-York Legislature, in 1849, asking for the right of suffrage for women. She was the organizer of the first Female Suffrage Society in Ontario County, N.Y., in 1848, and from that time she has devoted her life to the interest of equal suffrage.

EASTPORT, L.I., June 30 -- Eastport, one of the growing and prosperous south side villages, is rapidly becoming popular as a Summer resort. Added to its natural attractions is its freedom from the ills of many places. The pure air and excellent natural drainage make it a desirable spot for those seeking comfort and recreation together.

Franklin MacVeagh of Chicago was in this city yesterday with his family, which sailed on the Lucania for Liverpool. After Mr. MacVeagh had returned to his hotel from the steamship, a reporter for The New-York Times called on him to obtain his views on the political situation in his State, where he has been nominated for United States Senator by the Democratic Party.,

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 30 -- While the departure of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian fleet from here last Tuesday took away a majority of the yachts that make their headquarters here, and many of the gallant yachtsmen, there were still enough left to keep up the round of gayety that marks this place from the opening to the close of the season.

As a curative agent the snake, dead or alive, is thought highly of. In Suffolk they hold that goitre may be cured in the following manner: Let a second person hold the common snake by its head and tail, and draw it slowly nine times across the diseased neck; but after every third time the creature must be allowed to crawl about awhile.

NANTUCKET, Mass., June 30 -- Though the charms and much of the general interest in Nantucket may be attributable to her peculiarly rich history and the everywhere visible reminders of departed glories, yet the gifts of nature so lavishly bestowed will make this a place of ever-increasing delight, even after every vestige of her ancient civilization shall have departed forever.

Harry McDowell, thirty years old, an actor, who says he lives at 126 West Twenty-ninth Street, was stabbed in the left side of the neck last night in front of Bangs's beer saloon, at 1,214 Broadway, shortly after 10 o'clock, during an altercation with a man supposed to be Al Martin, who escaped.

That popular Brooklyn cycling organization, the Kings County Wheelmen, is rapidly going to the front as a promoter of first-class meets. The thirteenth annual contest took place at the Parkway Driving Club track yesterday afternoon, and from a racing standpoint it was a grand success. The fields were large, the contests close and exciting, wheelmen with national reputations took part in several events, and the time made in some of the dashes gratifying.
"Ein, zwei, drei, und so weiter," says the teacher, and the little German maiden picks up her needles and goes on "so weiter."

Tour attention has already been drawn to the remarkable haste with which a French squadron was dispatched from Toulon to the African coast. A clumsy attempt was made to explain that Rear Admiral Bourgeois and his ships had only started, in the ordinary course of things, for the execution of naval manoeuvres, in accordance with a settled programme, but no one was deceived as to the real object of the cruise.

Certainly nobody has been looking for the present year to make much of a record as a year for railroad building, and probably many will be surprised to learn that there has been more than a nominal amount of new road built. Yet the returns of track laid in 1894 up to July 1 show an aggregate of 495 miles.

We have pointed out several States in which the Democratic conventions have shown pitiable weakness and confusion in their resolutions on the currency question. The curious feature of the situation is that these are surpassed by instances in which Republican conventions have been just as mixed and weak.

WEST BRIGHTON, S.I., June 30 -- A return game of ball was played here this afternoon between the teams of the Athletic Club and the Englewood Field Club. With the exception of the fifth inning, when timely hits, assisted by costly errors, gave the Staten Islanders 6 runs, the game was hotly contested. The score:

Shoppers have become used to buying icecream freezers and sealskin cloaks, carpets and diamond rings under one roof, but live lambs are a commodity that heretofore has not been offered at bargain sales -- as they were at a Baltimore department shop the other day. Those who bought the lambs had to take them away themselves, and this the eager women managed to do by grasping the little creatures in both arms.

The offering of five-thousand-dollar purses for pacers at the Buffalo and Rochester Grand Circuit meeting this season is a strong reminder of the growing popularity of the pacing horse in harness racing.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 30 -- The races at the Dayton Bicycle Club tournament to-day at the fair grounds were the most exciting and decisive of the season. The half-mile track was in fine condition from pole to pole. Five thousand people were present. The day was bright, but very hot.

J.W. Reinhart, John J. McCook, and Joseph C. Wilson, receivers of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company, received yesterday the following dispatch from United States Circuit Judge Henry C. Caldwell, bearing upon the operations of that property during the strike:

There was considerable excitement yesterday morning at the Synagogue Israel Ansche Snvalk, in Forsyth Street, and for almost an hour two policemen held the doors closed against an angry crowd of men and women.

DEAL BEACH, N.J., June 30 -- Tennis, driving, bathing, and fishing are the order of the day. Tennis is not in great vogue at most of the Jersey resorts this season. It seems to have given way to bicycling. At Deal Beach, however, tennis holds its own, as of old. Manager Jones of the Hathaway Inn has had several extra fine courts laid out, and they are in use every pleasant day.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- One result of Secretary Lament's order reorganizing the methods of work in the War Department will be to enable that department to keep track of its real estate. The methods in this particular have been exceedingly loose and careless. Records of land have been only partially kept, and some of the property which is controlled by the War Department is now occupied by parties who evidently have no right upon it.

"The wonder to me is not that so many children die every Summer, but that so many live," said an observant student of wec humanity. "What, with ignorant mothers, careless mothers, and experimenting mothers, the vast majority have a far more perilous journey to make than the classic voyage past Scylla and Charybdis."

BABYLON, L.I., June 30 -- Bathing has had the call during this week. The weather drove nearly everybody into the water. Pleasures on land consisted of driving, tennis, croquet, and walks. The yachting element was out in force during the week, and the Great South Bay was alive with graceful boats loaded with merry parties.

BOSTON, June 30 -- To-day beats the record for dullness. There were hardly enough sales of local stocks to call a market. Wisconsin Central as declined 1/4, to 49, and recovered later to 49 1/2. A small lot of stock was sold at 4 1/2. Boston United Gas 2d 5s made a gain of 1, to 60. Dominion Coal was steady at 21.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 30 -- The Nation's birthday will be celebrated with unusual pomp and splendor in this city July 4 in the dedication of the magnificent Soldiers' Monument, which has been in process of construction for six years and had its inception in a movement begun fifteen years ago.
Comedian William F. Hoey has just encountered a distinctively ingenuous Britisher. The comedian formed his acquaintance during the Lucania's last incoming voyage, and the two breakfasted together.
"Benedict Arnold, that distinguished American 'patriot' of a century ago, was a good A.P.A. man," said Patrick Ford of The Irish World yesterday.

TERRA HAUTE, Ind., June 30 -- On his arrival home from Canada this evening, Chief Sargent of the Locomotive Firemen's organization, authorized the following official statement of the policy of his organization toward the Pullman boycott and the American Railroad Union.

Buffalo Bill and his Rough Riders are still entertaining crowded houses afternoon and evening at Ambrose Park, South Brooklyn. The educative merit of this exhibition is being appreciated by the people of New-York City and surrounding country, as it deserves to be. There is not a feature in the whole outfit but that might truly be considered educative.

The much-heralded revival of draperies gains favor slowly. The double and even treble skirts are seen chiefly in gossamerlike tissues and gauzes. For the most part, however, women do not seem anxious to adopt voluminous skirts; they prefer a medium style simulating the double skirt, by means of garniture--a notion which is a happy thought for renovating last season's gowns.

LONDON, June 30 -- The formal opening of the Tower Bridge, London's latest addition to her bridges across the Thames, has been looked forward to for months past as a memorable event of exceptional importance, not only as the culminating point of a wonderful engineering feat, but as opening up new facilities of traffic in the busy East End of the metropolis.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 30 -- General Master Workman Sovereign Issued an order to-night to the Knights of Labor to boycott every person who patronizes the Pullman Company or rides in a Pullman car. It reads.

Two events of importance in the history of this country will be observed in Huntington, L.I., on July 4. One will be the noisy celebration of Independence Day and the other the unveiling of a monument erected through public subscription to the memory of Capt. Nathan Hale, the patriot spy, who was captured by the British on the shores of Huntington Bay.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 -- The season is fairly opened at this Summer resort. The hotels have been doing a big business, The merechants along the famous prome- nade have outdone themselves in making their places attractive. Many prominent statesmen have been here this season, and more have engaged accommodations for the Summer. Washington society people are fast becoming patrons, and New-York City end Philadelphia send large delgations down

Among other expedients to raise money. Ivan resigned the Crown in favor of a Tartar Khan, who was baptized under the name of Simeon. Ivan feigned to withdraw himself from public affairs, but in reality he held on to them, and made the new Czar call in all the charters formerly granted to the monasteries and bishoprics, and all the charters were canceled.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30 -- James T. Hussey, a Philadelphian, about sixty years of age, committed suicide this evening by jumping from the end of the Ocean Pier in the presence of several hundred people. An intelligent setter, belonging to the proprietor of the pier, jumped over immediately after the man, and caught him by the neck.

Letter Carrier John J. Duffy, who is attached to Postal Station A, in Graham Avenue, near Broadway, Brooklyn, was severely bitten by a bulldog while he was delivering letters yesterday morning. It is feared that the injuries may prove so serious that Duffy will lose his right leg.
"I have nothing to say; the resolution speaks for itself," said Superintendent Byrnes yesterday.

The Atlantic Yacht Club will start off on its annual cruise this week. The squadron will rendezvous at Larchmont on Tuesday evening, and Captains will report on board the flagship Water Witch. The yachts will remain at Larchmont for the big regatta to be sailed on July 4, and after the race the squadron will sail to Oyster Bay, where it will anchor for the night.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Senator Sherman is disposed to be in earnest in his inquiry to ascertain if the Inter-State Commerce Commission may not have jurisdiction to recommend rates and regulations for the use of parlor and sleeping cars. He declares that his suggestion was contemplated before the strike and is not intended to affect it in any way.
From The Boston Budget. The approach of the annual Harvard-Yale boat race reminds the Saunterer of a little bit of conversation he overheard last year.

ELBERON, N.J., June 30 -- This has been a delightful week here. The weather was all that could be asked for, especially during the last few days. It seems almost incredible that New-Yorkers are complaining of a hot wave. But the people who set off each incoming train and breathe a sigh of relief vouch for it.
Don't throw lighted firecrackers above your head, especially if there are little girls with light dresses standing near you.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 30 -- A very pleasant entertainment was given under the auspices of the Ladies' Missionary Society of the Union Baptist Church, last evening.

Chancellor Edwards's action in granting an injunction against the purchase of the Chesapeake, Ohio and Southwestern Road by the Louisville and Nashville had been anticipated by railroad men, to whom this news from Louisville yesterday was, accordingly, no surprise. The Kentucky law prohibits the absorption of one railroad by a competitor.

A curious mania has come to light recently in Brooklyn through the continued suffering of its indirect victims. A woman living in one of the pleasant residence portions of the city has been annoyed now for nearly three years by the persistent appearance at her house of delivery clerks from the well-known shops, with C.O.D. parcels for her number, but not her name.

Two policemen of the East Twenty-second Street Station were attacked by a mad Newfoundland dog at the corner of Nineteenth Street and Third Avenue at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning. One of them finally dispatched the rabid animal, but not until his comrade had been bitten in the left wrist.

ORANGE, N.J., June 30 -- A large audience filled Music Hall on Thursday evening, when the commencement exercises of the High School were held. The essays were delivered by the graduates, Miss Edith Freeman, Miss Nellie Yatman, Arthur Wilson, and Harry Abrams.

The most conspicuous person at the Court of Catherine II. was Prince Potemkin; and it was he whom it most behoved the Comte de Segur to win to his interests. The Prince's influence was as unbounded as his ambition. If he did not originate the scheme of a vast eastern empire for Russia, he was at least its most zealous supporter.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 30 -- A handsome monument of Quincy granite is soon to be dedicated to the memory and in honor of the Revolutionary soldiers whose place of burial is in the old Dutch churchyard in Sleepy Hollow, that delightful spot in Westchester County made immortal by the pen of Washington Irving, whose body also rests there.

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., June 30 -- The Summer programme of the Round Lake Association has just been announced. The season of the schools will open Monday, July 9, with the art school under Mr. Chester Loomis of Englewood, N.J., and the school of music under Edmund J. Myer of New-York.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 -- The United Press correspondent, writing under date of Honolulu, June 23, says:

The President's statement on the national finances, the tariff, the Erie and other reorganization plans, have been quite obscured as topics of interest in Wall Street by the railroad strike. It was a surprise. The American Railway Union had never been heard of before. The Street was familiar with the names of the old labor leaders, like Arthur, Sergeant, Powderly, and one or two others -- but Debs.

Frank Englefield, Secretary of the Fish Hawk Fishing Club, whose headquarters in town are at One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street and Third Avenue, pulled twenty-four bluefish aboard in one day last week. The party hooked several bass and blackfish.

The most common form or "squint" is that in which the globe of the eye is turned inward. Fifty years ago "crossed-eyed" persons must have been much en evidence, judging from the forms of treatment laid down in the standard text books of that period for the relief of the deformity. Nothing was then known of the science of its causation, and the treatment of it, of course, was entirely at fault.

Mrs. Jennie Shurter of Kingston, N.T., accidentally set fire to her clothing yesterday morning at the home of her sister, Mrs. W. Ackerly of 160 West One Hundred and Third Street, and was burned so badly that she died soon after neighbors went to her assistance.

At the time when "there was a young truant, his name lazy Bill, who lived long ago, long ago," the young man was left to follow the evil tenor of his ways with only such occasional interruptions as might occur by reason of the administration of the maternal slipper or paternal rod.

The Schaffers will give an extra performance at Eldorado this evening at 8 o'clock. The demand upon the part of the public to see this wonderful family has been so great that the management has succeeded in getting them to give a special performance. In addition to their regular act, Mr. Sylvester Schaffer will give an exhibition in juggling and rifle shooting.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 30 -- The season is under full way, and the bright scenes of Saratoga Summer life have greatly increased within the last few days.

The past week has closed the season of college triumphs, whether of scholarship or of athletic prowess, and it is a little curious to note the kind of victory that attracts most attention and excites the greatest interest. Commencement at Harvard was largely taken up with a commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of President Eliot's administration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- Representatives of the American Railway Union have established a headquarters in this city, and on Monday, it is said, they will request the officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad to drop the Pullman traffic or suffer an extension of the strike to Philadelphia.

The midsummer heavens are, as usual, rich in themes for study and observation. Among the phenomena that one always finds at this season is the arrival of the earth at the aphelion point in its career. This event takes place on the 3d, when the fierce heat of Summer is mercifully tempered in the north temperate zone by the sun's 3,000,000 miles of extra distance.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., June 30 -- The great Ocean Grove Auditorium, erected at a cost of nearly $75,000, is completed, and all is in readiness for the opening services Sunday. Within three months' actual working time the vast open-air structure has grown to its present proportions under the careful supervision of the Rev. Dr. E.H. Stokes, the Chairman of the Building Committee, and his colleagues having the erection of the building in charge.

The subject of the above portrait is the Rev. Chas. Prosser, a much beloved and most devout minister of the gospel at Mount Carmel, Northumberland Co., Pa. Mr. Prosser's usefulness, was, for a long time, greatly impaired by a distressing, obstinate disease. How his malady was finally conquered we will let him tell in his own language.

SEOUL, Corea, May 22 -- War has broken out in Corea. Beginning as a local insurrection, it has made headway against all opposition, and now one entire province of the eight composing the realm is said to be to the hands of rebels.

NEWPORT, June 30 -- The prominent arrivals of this week include Mrs. William Astor, Mr. and Mrs. T.A. Havemeyer, and Mr. and Mrs. Ward McAllister. Many others are expected next week, which promises to see the season fairly opened.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Secretary Herbert issued an order to-day suspending all work in the navy yards that is paid for out of appropriations for the increase of the navy. This is caused by the failure of Congress to pass a naval appropriation bill, Attorney General Olney agreeing with Secretary Herbert that the joint resolution extending current appropriations does not cover the matter.

John B. Reagan, thirty-three years of age, a religious maniac, who lives at 233 West Eighteenth Street, was taken to the insane pavilion of Bellevue Hospital last night on the complaint of his wife, Maria, who said her husband had attempted to throw his one-year-old son Johnnie out of the thirdstory window.

When the President goes away he must go where he cannot be followed. He cannot travel in public conveyances, or stop at hotels, or try to take a rest at places which are frequented by other and, to that extent, happier people. Washingtonians forget what the Presidents before the war did with tneir brief vacations.
BURLINGTON, Vt., June 30 -- The four children of Mitchel Baker, second, were found murdered at Montgomery this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The entry of machine guns for the great naval competition closed to-day at the Washington Ordnance Yard. Seven weapons have Been presented for the tests, and for the next two or three weeks thousands of rounds will be rattled out of the devastating little instruments of death, in order that the navy may be equipped with the most efficiently destructive machines that modern ingenuity can produce.

At the bottom of the troubles in which our greed has landed us in Africa is the bad faith that has dogged our steps in Egypt. Both French and Germans perceive that our endeavor to hinder all European powers from encroaching on the territories through which the Upper Nile flows, on the ground that this may be injurious to Egypt, means that it may be injurious to us as the occupants of Egypt.

LONDON, June 30 -- Solid things are beginning to lift their heads again above the flood of confusion and consternation which swept over Europe on Monday. That which looms highest and compels most attention is the fact that Carnot's murder was no mere stupid, motiveless accident of the sort which individual cranks have been precipitating since the dawn of time.

BOSTON, Mass., June 30 -- F.H. Hovey is the winner of the first place in the West Newton Invitation Tennis Tournament. This afternoon he defeated Clarence Hobart in the unfinished match of yesterday, Hovey thus becoming the owner of the one-hundred-dollar trophy offered by the Neighborhood Club.

From The Newcastle Leader. Though there may be much truth in the belief that water may be found in hundreds of places when patiently sought for with the investigating spade, there is no doubt that the labors of Prof. Stone of the peripatetic water finder have brought their reward to the Town Moor Laundry Company.

One day in the central decade of this century there occurred a dramatic scene in the County Hall at Aberdeen, where Mr. Justice Stanley was holding a term of the Circuit Court. The great P. and Q.R.R. Company was defending its right or wrong of way, but at all events its way, along the river front against a claim of possession on the part of the city.

PARIS, June 30 -- Premier Dupuy this morning informed President Casimir-Perier of his decision to remain at the head of the Ministry. He will retain all of his present colleagues in the Ministry, and there will consequently be no Ministerial declaration upon the reassembling of the Chambers on Tuesday.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., June 30 -- The powerful Sandy Hook search light affords much pleasure to the sightseers resting upon the piazzas or the balconies of the big hotels and cottages, as well as to the all-the-year-round dweller, to all of whom the view is most novel and attract- ive. Its glare is bright but weird as it falls upon the buildings and the landscape, though on the water it is beautiful.

Forty years ago the Londoner who asked his solicitor to invest money in mortgages on farm lands that were sure to retain their value and by ready renting to make the interest safe stood a fair chance to get a mortgage on a farm in Essex at a minimum valuation of $100 an acre and a rental of $20 and taxes.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 30 -- It is probable that Long Branch will have the liveliest Fourth, of July of its recent history. The reason is that there are more people in town than has been, usual at this time of the year. Visitors are literally tumbling in here to-day, and the hotel proprietors are wearing a broad, expansive grin, which is much more becoming to them than the wrinkled brows of last season.

"Brethren, I have come all the way from the northwest to ask you to be good and kind to our mother cow, the cow that helped all of us to rear our children, the cow that has helped all of us to cultivate and fertilize our lands, and the cow that is affording us the best of good food that is to be found on this earth, namely, milk.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 30 -- The story of the life of James McNally, the reputed head of the green-goods business in NewYork, and whom the Lexow committee was anxious to have appear before them and testify, is an Interesting one. He was in this city a day or two ago, and from his lips came an account of his life and the business he carried on in New-York City.

-- Proctor's Theatre -- After weeks of preparation Manager Proctor announces the presentation at his Twenty-third Street Theatre to-morrow of his first series of living pictures. They will be shown twice a day in connection with the continuous performance, at 4 and 10 P.M. There will be thirty tableaus in all, some of the subjects being. "Rebecca at the Well."

John S. Johnson, the youthful cyclist from the Northwest, is indeed a wonderful rider. He proved that to the satisfaction of the most cynical at the Waltham track last week, when he covered a mile in 1:56. Think of it, a youth propelling a bicycle for a mile many seconds faster than a horse can trot!

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 30 -- Every variety of weather has found a foothold at Bar Harbor this week. It has been hot and it has been cold, and it has rained several times, with thunder showers for a change, and once or twice that bugbear of all Summer resorts, fog, has put in an appearance for a short period.

The Saengerfest, which closed on Monday night, was in every way a success. The merit of the choral singing was in many respects higher than that observed at any Saengerfest in the last twenty years. The chorus preserved its numerical strength in an unusual manner, and the pecuniary results were of the most, gratifying kind.
Ivy is much in vogue this year. Bonnets are made entirely of ivy, with little tufts of rose-pink roses in front and back.

BOSTON, June 30 -- The Hindoo, the twenty-one-foot centreboard yacht designed by Waterhouse Cheseboro for John H. Adams to race in the Larchmont class, was shipped to New-York to-day from MoIntyre Kirk's shops. Her hull shows a fine job of joiner work, and she will make a handsome boat with her polished mahogany sides and bright deck.

George Menge, a student in a college near Philadelphia and a resident of that city, is a patient in the Flower Hospital, at East Sixty-third Street and Avenue A, undergoing a course of treatment for a broken neck.

The one hundred and twelfth distribution of flowers by the Moderation Society, of which Sylvanus Lyon is Vice President and manager, took place yesterday afternoon in Paradise Park, Five Points. Mr. Lyon was assisted by the Rev. George H. Van Meter and a delegation of women from the Presbyterian Church of Arlington, N.J.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 1 -- The new Auditorium, the largest open-air place of worship in the world, was formally opened to-day, and the services were attended by thousands of Methodists from all parts of the country. The large platform was crowded with divines at the morning service. The members of the Camp Meeting Association and the Asbury Park ministers also occupied seats near the pulpit.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $1,552,- 025. The banks now hold $74,803,350 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $1,760,700, a decrease in specie of $5,976,500, an increase in legal tenders of $4,349,800, a decrease in deposits of $298,700, and a decrease in circulation of $51,600.

The Republican papers are publishing a silly story about the proposed reduction of the duty on tin plate. We find it set forth at length, with sensational head-lines, in The Philadelphia Press and The Chicago Inter Ocean, and from those prominent organs of McKinleyism it has gone into the columns of other papers, where it has become the subject of partisan comment, in which the customary indignation is displayed.

PROHIBITION PARK, Staten Island, July 1 -- Terence V. Powderly, ex-Grand Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, delivered an address this afternoon on "Labor and Some of Its Deadliest Foes." He discussed the Pullman strike, the late coal strike, and Socialism. His audience numbered about 200, nearly half women and children.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 1 The steam yacht Aztec of the Larchmont Yacht Club was run down in Hell Gate shortly before noon to-day by the Glen Island excursion steamboat Sam Sloan. Nearly ten feet of the yacht's stern was cut off by the sharp prow of the steamboat.
CHICAGO, July 1 -- The following is a summary of the reports at the General Managers' headquarters to-day from the various roads affected by the strikes:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 30 -- The local Stock market during the week has not been very active. There is, perhaps, a somewhat better demand for investments. The following sales have taken place: American National Bank at 49. Phenix National at 70 1/2, and Rhode Island National at 27 1/2. American Screw Company stock has sold at 221.

The American Proscriptive Association and its defenders and champions are making a great show of its platform, which announces that the organization proscribes no man on account of his religious belief.
SCARABS. The History, Manufacture, and Religious Symbolism of the Scarabaeus in Ancient Egypt, Phoenicia, Sardinia, Etruria, By Isaac Myer, New-York: Edwin W. Dayton.

The twenty-fifth, anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. George D. Hulst, Ph. D., of the South Bushwick Reformed Church, Bushwick Avenue and Himrod Street, Brooklyn, was celebrated yesterday with special services, which will be continued this evening.

The Rev. Francis A. Bottome, D.D., of the New-York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, whose home was at 41 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, and who was for a time pastor of Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, Washington Square, was killed last Friday in a carriage accident at Collington, near Tavistock, England.
LANDMARKS OF OLD TESTAMENT HISTORY. Samuel to Malachi. By Cunningham Geikie. D. D. 12mo. New-York: James Pott Co. $1.50.

The Pope is undoubtedly a very intelligent man, but nevertheless he is firmly convinced that everything of which he does not approve is the work of the Freemasons. The average Protestant, who knows that Freemasonry concerns itself with oysters and beer, instead of politics and religion, smiles at the Pope's delusion and wonders if his Holiness can possibly be ignorant that all the evil in the world is the work of the Jesuits.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The sixth statistical report of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, prepared by its statistician, has just been submitted. It covers the year ending June 30, 1893, for which a preliminary income account was issued in December last. Following is an abstract of the complete report:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent. through the week.

WASHINGTON, July 1-- The income-tax provisions of the Tariff bill, as reported to the Senate by the Committee of the Whole, differ materially from the provisions as originally reported to the Senate. The first section, which designates what shall be taxed, reads as follows:

"Discrimination against a man simply because he is of a certain religion is un-American. It matters not to us, as Americans, what religion a man enjoys, if he is true to us and of us and entitled to our privileges."

The carnival of sports to be given by the New-Jersey Athletic Club at its pretty grounds at Bayonne, N.J., promises to be the most interesting set of games and athletic events that has ever been given by the club. This is saying a good deal, as the recent field meetings of the club have been most successful and noted for well-contested events.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- While there is some natural anxiety among the friends of tariff reform concerning the fate of the Tariff bill in the Senate, there is nothing except anxious rumor to justify the suggestion that the bill will not pass in a few days -- possibly as soon as Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- There is talk of allowing the office of Commanding General of the Army to become vacant with the retirement in September of next year of Gen. Schofleld.

The United States Government has taken prompt steps to protect the mails from lawless interference by the strikers of the American Railway Union. Yesterday a detachment of but fifteen United States deputies took from a mob of 600 at Hyde Park seven men who had obstructed mail trains.

MANHATTAN BEACH, July 1 -- The Oriental Hotel was to-day the Mecca for New-York and Brooklyn politicians. Every train has brought them by dozens, and late in the afternoon the broad verandas were clustered thick with small-fry statesmen, who were stepping on each other's feet in their haste and anxiety to pay homage to the great men of their parties.

The Rev. D.A. Jordan, D.D., pastor of the Sands Street Memorial Church, Clark and Henry Streets. Brooklyn, delivered a sermon on "Anarchy Versus Americanism," last night. After describing the boundless resources of the country and the cosmopolitan nature of the people, he said in part:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 1 -- Although most of the passenger trains left on time to-night, the situation is growing worse. The strike of the Terminal Association yardmen last night on this side of the river was followed to-day by the walk out of the terminal men at East St. Louis. Iron Mountain men quit work at Carondelet to-day.

The formation of a new Panama Canal company, with the ridiculously inadequate capital of $12,000,000, will probably serve to prevent the canceling of the concession procured for the old company, or for the receiver of it, by Lieut. Wyse, and in all probability the company was made with this purpose in view.

BERLIN, July 1 -- The scandal caused by the arrest of the royal Chamberlain, L. von Kotze, and the rumors of his anonymous correspondence with high persons at Court, has grown to such dimensions and has so excited the public curiosity that the Emperor may be forced to convert the secret inquiry into an open trial.
