The fire at the Woodruff Stores, at the foot of State Street, Brooklyn, was still smouldering yesterday, and a great many persons visited the ruins. They were kept away from the walls in Furman Street, as the walls were expected to fall at any time.

The United States cruiser San Francisco, which, as flagship of Rear Admiral Benham, played an important part in the Brazilian insurrection, steamed into harbor yesterday, and chose an anchorage off Tompkinsville, S.I.
"Anarchy as a Fine Art in Brooklyn" was the subject of the Rev. A.C. Dixon's prelude in the Hanson Place Baptist Church yesterday. He said, among other things:

ALBANY, July 1 -- If the plans of the Republican leaders as now formulated shall be carried out, the Republican State Convention will be held at Saratoga as early as Sept. 15 -- perhaps before the Constitutional Convention shall adjourn.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Requiem mass for President Carnot was celebrated to-day in the Church of St. Matthew's, the leading Catholic Church of Washington. The mass began at noon.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 1 -- The Northern Pacific Railway Company this afternoon sent out a fully-equipped passenger train with a complement of Pullman sleepers. The train carried ten Deputy United States Marshals, four of whom were on the platforms of the cars. If the train is interfered with other Marshals will board it at Staples.

QUARANTINE, S.I., July 1 -- Gen. Carles Ezeta, who was forced, in the recent revolution in San Salvador, to abandon the Presidency of that republic, arrived here this evening, on the Colombian Line steamer Newport, from Colon.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- At a four-hours' meeting of the Trades and Labor Assembly, the largest labor body in Chicago, held this afternoon, resolutions were passed tendering all the aid possible to the American Railway Union, and empowering the Executive Board of the body to act as it sees fit.
LONDON, Ontario, July 1 -- Henry Herbert Thomson, a young Scotchman, was found dead in the river this morning. It is supposed that he committed suicide.

The Central Labor Union yesterday took action on the Pullman strike. Delegate Daniel Harris of the cigarmakers brought up the question, "The Central Labor Union ought to take suitable action in the general strike ordered by the American Railway Union, out of sympathy with the Pullman car employes," he said.

The Twelfth Street Reformed Church, in Brooklyn, was well filled last evening with members of the Kings County Sunday Observance Association, who met to celebrate the twelfth anniversary of their organization.

" I had an experience last year which I think was sufficiently thrilling to satisfy the most adventurous mind," said A. D. Cooper, a St. Louis artist. "I was down in Georgia on a sketching tour, and one afternoon wandered off into the forest and sat down on the trunk of a fallen tree to contemplate the beauties of nature.

It has been pretty definitely ascertained that the total pension expenditures for the fiscal year ending the 30th of the current month will be $25,000,000 less than the appropriation; and the Republican papers, as a means of capturing the soldier votes, are denouncing the saving as a great outrage, perpetrated by the Pension Bureau on worthy and honorable pensioners.

BERLIN, July 1 -- A solemn, mourning service for M. Camot was held in the cathedral this morning. At the Emperor's suggestion Chancellor von Caprivi, Gen. von Winterfeldt, Freiherr von Marschall, Gen. Bronsart von Schellendorff, most of the other Ministers, and numerous high Government officials were present.

ALBANY, June 30 -- There was a good investment demand for local securities during the past week. The bond list showed the greatest activity. Union Railway of New-York 5s, Westchester Electric guaranteed 5s, and Watervliet guaranteed 1st 6s were the favorite issues. Trading was fairly active throughout the entire list, with numerous changes in prices.

PITTSBURG, June 30 -- There were very few price changes worth noting this week. There is no change in demand from investors so far as can be discovered. This means that money is still in plentiful supply; in fact, the block of idle funds in the banks has been augmented rather than depleted, and the tendency on the part of bank managements is to shade rates.

ROCHESTER. N.Y., July 1 -- Monroe County Republicans who aspire to fill public office seldom fight to the bitter end. The reason is not difficult to find. Carrying caucuses has become so expensive an undertaking that men of short purses are forced out before the canvass is half over. The sudden withdrawal of avowed candidates has therefore come to be a matter of common occurrence.

The first Eastern "local district" of the American Railway Union was organized in Philadelphia yesterday by 275 trainmen of the freight service of the Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Railroads. It is stated that the meeting was distinctly opposed to taking any part in the strike against the Pullman Company.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 1 -- The strike on the Northern Pacific Railway arising out of the Pullman difficulty has finally spread to that portion of the system in Manitoba. The employes received orders to-day from the American Railway Union to go out, and at once complied. The railroad officials were greatly surprised, having been confident that the trouble would not extend to the Canadian portion of the line.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Every rail on the Rock Island Road at Blue Island, sixteen miles from this city, is blocked to traffic, rendering futile any attempt to get trains into or out of Chicago. A notice, reading, "All trains abandoned until further notice," confronted the public at the Van Buren Street station, and told in a few words the completely paralyzed condition of Rock Island traffic at this end of the line.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 1 -- The Right Rev. Thomas Martin Aloysius Burke was this morning consecrated as the fourth Bishop of Albany in the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception. The consecration service was the grandest ever held in Albany and lasted from 10:30 until 2:30 o'clock. The episcopal seat was made vacant by the death of the Right Rev. Francis McNierny, which occurred several months ago.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- Lewis H. Weiss, aged twenty-eight years, a negro desperado, ran amuck to-day in Germantown, a suburb of this city, with a revolver, and shot two persons and was himself shot four times by a policeman. Weiss became engaged in an altercation with a man and threatened to shoot him.
BASAL CONCEPTS IN PHILOSOPHY, By Alexander T. Ormond, Ph. D., Professor of Philosophy in Princeton University. NewYork: Charles Scribner'a Sons. $1.50.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 1 -- The big fleet of yachts that has been held at this port by easterly wind and continuous fog were released to-day, when the wind hauled to the west. Many of the boats took advantage of the opportunity and started out. There are still a score or more yachts here, a considerable number running in to-day.
A horse, hitched to a light-top buggy, ran away on the East Drive, Central Park, at 3:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Pension Commissioner Lochren will make his annual report between June 30 and Sept. 1, and it will be a document of great interest to every taxpayer and of decided importance to the party that made the change in the administration of the office. As stated in The New-York Times June 16.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 1 -- The American Railway Union gained its first foothold in the East to-day by the organization in Philadelphia, of a local district. From the sentiment of the railroad men at the meeting, the district will be but the opening wedge in the East for the most powerful labor organization that has yet arisen in this country.

The bond market last week, while quiet, was strong, prices closing generally as high or slightly higher than the week previous. The demand to invest maturing interest and dividends was plainly perceptible, helping to clear the market of floating bonds and tending to enhance their value. West Shore 4s sold up to 105 3/4, the highest price yet in 1894.

A matter that has not attracted the attention of vegetable biologists to any serious extent is the variable character of the odors of flowers. It has been noticed that mignonette, when growing in our gardens, is sweeter at times than at others, and that the common wood honeysuckle, Azalea nudiflora, certainly scentless as a general thing, is often quite fragrant. Of this latter point Mr. W. F. Bassett of Hammonton, N.J., remarks:

Rarely are so many important events crowded into a single week as in the one just passed. Monday brought the startling news of the assassination of President Cannot; on Tuesday. President Cleveland's opportune interview in regard to the condition of the United States Treasury was published; on Wednesday, the Pullman boycott assumed national importance, and on Friday the Committee of the Whole finished its work on the Tariff bill in the Senate.

TRENTON, July 1 -- The New-Jersey Society of the Cincinnati observes the national holiday by toasting the memory of George Washington, but this year the annual banquet will follow the unveiling of a monument and tablet to commemorate the massacre of a portion of the legion commanded by Count Pulaski.

The tennis event of the week will, of course, be the Tuxedo invitation tournament, which begins to-day on the courts in Tuxedo Park. The entire week will be given up to play. The winner of the tournament will play Hobart, who now holds the cup. Hobart won last year from E.L. Hall, who had captured the trophy in 1891, and successfully defended it against W.A. Larned in 1892.
John A. Burket, swindler, jail bird, and Rogue No. 83, is again in the toils of the law. He has half a dozen pseudonyms, and three months ago was discharged from the Crow Hill Penitentiary, Brooklyn.

The Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur preached last evening on the events of the week, his principal topics being the assassination of President Carnot, the Pullman strike, Sunday observance, and the police investigation.
Nine persons were rescued from a burning building in Brooklyn early yesterday morning by the heroic work of several firemen and policemen.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The strike news of course had some influence on quotations after the opening, but its influence was reflected principally in an indisposition to do business. A good many brokers left town on Friday to stay away over the Fourth, and their absence made it all the duller.

At a meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday, Commissioner White of the City Works Department reported that he had written to the Edison Electric Light Company in compliance with the request made a week ago in regard to the conduits which the company were putting under ground, and asked them what provision they were making in compliance with their franchise of carrying the police and fire wires.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Although the Constitutional Convention has been charged by many newspapers as developing into a prosaic and garrulous body, the leaders on both sides resent the imputation and manifest the fiercest indignation when the character of the work to be done is at all questioned.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2 -- At Pleasure Beach, opposite this city, on July 4, there will be unveiled, with proper ceremony, a monument erected to Capt. Kidd. The long, barren stretch of sand known as Long Beach until recent years, when it has become a favorite spot for excursions, is the spot where the pirate kidd in the year 1696 buried, according to accounts, his fabulous treasure.

CLEVELAND, July 2 -- One thousand disgusted people to-day witnessed a comedy of errors on the part of the home team and the worst exhibition of umpiring ever seen on the Cleveland grounds. Umpire Hartley forced Pitcher Griffith out of the box in the fourth inning by rank decisions on strikes and balls. Tebeau found fault with a bad decision in the sixth inning and was ordered out of the game.

-- At the request of holders of a large amount of Oregon Short Line first mortgage 6 per cent. bonds, R.C. Martin. John Bigelow, Cyrus J. Lawrence, Bernhard Mainzer of Hallgarten Co., and Gordon Abbott, Vice President of the Old Colony Trust Company of Boston, have been constituted a committee to protect the interests of the holders of these first mortgage bonds.
Swinging at the door of the billiard room of the United States Hotel, in Fulton Street, yesterday was the sign: "Railroad switchmen wanted; apply here."

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The crucial point in the railroad strike will be reached within twenty-four hours from midnight. This is the opinion confidently expressed at the headquarters of the railroad managers at a late hour to-night.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The striking railway employes within the jurisdiction of the United States court for this circuit, which includes Illinois and the greater portions of Indiana and Wisconsin, are confronted to-night by the strong" arm of the law in the shape of the most sweeping injunction that has ever issued from a Federal court under similar conditions.

LONDON, July 2 -- Cardinal Yaughan officiated at a memorial mass which was celebrated in the Church of Notre Dame, in Leicester Square, this morning, in honor of and for the repose of the soul of President Carnot. The altar and various parts of the edifice were draped in black, and a draped tricolor was placed upon a catafalque in front of the altar.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Administration has acted promptly and without unnecessary publicity in advance to assist the local authorities in maintaining order and preventing a suspension of the public business by the strike begun in the Pullman works.

Just as the shades of night were falling over the Sheepshead Bay track and the bookmakers were figuring their winnings, a clerical-looking youth with a gray tweed suit, a wide straw hat, and a pair of field glasses thrown carelessly across his shoulders walked down the lawn in front of the big grand stand.

Whatever they may find to lay on the shoulders of the Democratic majority in the Senate, the true friends of tariff reform may be thankful that no duty has been placed by that body on wool. That would have been an act, not so scandalous and disgraceful as the treatment of the sugar schedule, but of quite as great folly.
Mr. Gladstone will shortly receive an invitation to visit this country, which it is believed he will accept.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 2 -- The June examinations for entrance to Princeton College are about completed. They were held in forty-five different cities, towns, and preparatory schools, and, while three or four distant places have not been heard from, the work is practically completed. The Registrar's record shows a total of 487 applicants, of whom 150 took the preliminary examinations.
There is likely to be a fresh-meat famine in New-York in three or four days, unless some of the big trunk lines disentangle their Western connections from the railroad strike.

ASBURY PARK, July 2 -- The editors representing the National Association had far the better of their brethren in New-York to-day, for while the latter were sweltering between temperature and humidity at 90 and over, the former were enjoying themselves at this city by the sea with a thermometer of only 75 and no humidity to speak of.

The official investigation into the foundering of the tug James D. Nicol was continued yesterday before United States Steamboat Inspector's Fairchild and Barrett, in Room 156 of the Post Office Building.

BANGOR, Me., July 2. -- About 7 o'clock this morning a terrible accident occurred to the Montreal express going east on the Canadian Pacific Railway, on a trestle over the west outlet to Moosehead Lake, some twelve miles from Greenville. The dead are:

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Two resolutions bearing on the present extensive railroad strike were presented in the Senate during the morning hour to-day and were laid on the table for the present -- to be called up to-morrow.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The striking railroad men and sympathizing citizens of Blue Island derided and defied an injunction issued by the United States court to-day, and treated 300 law officers of the State and Federal Governments in the same manner.

BOSTON, July 2 -- In consecuence of the tie-up of freight trains in the West, there has been since Saturday an advance in the price of beef of from $1 to $1.50 per 100 pounds, and the prospect is that it will rapidly advance still higher.

The trial of Michael Donnelly, charged with attempting to kill his brother-in-law, Patrick J. McArdle, in the Court of Common Pleas, some months ago, was continued yesterday before Judge Martine in the Court of General Sessions.

Sarah Bernhardt has been received with genuine enthusiasm in London. Insular prejudices disappear under the spell of the greatest dramatic artist of this era. It is said of her that she has conquered and defied time. Her voice is still melodious and powerful. Her force is undiminished and her art is still matchless.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Second Assistant Postmaster General Charles Neilson of Maryland assumed charge of his office to-day, succeeding Col. J. Lowrie Bell, who resigned to become General Freight Agent of the Reading Railroad system. Referring to his conduct of the office, Mr. Neilson said:

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 2 -- A priest was summoned from Peekskill at noon to-day to administer the last sacrament of the Catholic Church to L.J. Welch, a private in the Eighth Separate Company of Rochester, who was supposed to be dying in the hospital tent. He was ill when he reached camp on Saturday and was taken from the train to the hospital in an ambulance.

TUXEDO PARK, July 2 -- The annual invitation tennis tournament of the Tuxedo Club began here this afternoon on the excellent courts of the club, the opening comfits being witnessed by the many Summer residents here. The entry list is exceptionally good, embracing most of the cracks from this action of the country, and most of the Eastern colleges are represented.

Frederick G. Pauly of College Point, in behalf of the residents of that town, yesterday procured a temporary injunction from Justice Gaynor of Brooklyn, restraining Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews from dumping refuse at Riker's Island. The injunction is returnable to-day, in the Kings County Supreme Court.

-- Koster Bial's -- A change was made in the policy hitherto pursued at Koster Bial's roof garden last night, vocal music being added to the instrumental, which has heretofore been the one feature of the entertainment. In addition to the Kossuth Hungarian Orchestra, Ruth Davenport, soprano; the Swedish Lady Quartet, Norma Willis, soprano; Theodore Hoch, cornet virtuoso, and the Elite Quartet appeared.

El Norte is a steamship which swings between this port and New-Orleans with pendulumlike regularity. The reports of strange marine happenings which her officers make are about as uniform. Not long ago she found her way into the newspapers, when Chief Officer Benson told about a fleet of phantom schooners which he had observed riding in the atmosphere off Cape Hatteras.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The sugar schedule ran the gantlet of the Senate to-day with somewhat disastrous results. The inability of its opponents in Committee of the Whole to change its provisions had encouraged its supporters to believe that it was impregnable.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The thirty-eighth regular season at McVicker's Theatre opened to-night with a production of the new play by Francis Reinau, entitled "An American Heiress," interpreted by a dramatic company under the direction of Joseph Brooks. The theatre was crowded by a representative audience, and its applause and enthusiasm pronounced the play a success.

The Grand Jury for July was sworn, in yesterday before Judge Maryine, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions. The Foreman is Vernon C. Brown of the Cunard Steamship Company. His office is at 23 Beaver Street, and he lives at 6 East Fity-eighth Street. These are the other members of the Grand Jury:

DENVER, Col., July 2 -- All roads are running passenger trains with sleepers attached, although some of the trains are considerably delayed. A Santa Fe passenger train arrived this morning with two Pullmans well filled with passengers, some of whom had been four days en route from Chicago.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Interest still centres in Lake Street L. The market for this stock was somewhat less active to-day, but transactions were nevertheless on a fairly extensive scale, among the trades being a number of 500-share lots. The stock opened at 18 1/4, but soon eased off to 18, several 500-share lots being traded in at this price.

Sir Charles Russell, who has been appointed Lord Chief Justice of England, as announced yesterday, was born in Newry, Armagh County, Ireland, in 1833. His father was Arthur Russell, and his uncle was the Very Rev. William Russell, D.D., President of Maynooth College. A brother is the Rev. Matthew Russell, S.J., who has long been the editor of The Irish Monthly.

LONDON, July 2 -- A dinner in honor of Dominion Day was given at the Westminster Palace Hotel this evening. Sir Charles Tupper, High Commissioner for Canada, presided. One hundred and twenty persons were present, including Lords Lorne, Norton, Brassey, and Swansea; Leonard H. Courtney, M.P.; Sir James Whitehead, M.P.; Sir E.J. Harland, M.P.; James Rankin, M.P.; A.D. Provand.

Duval County, Texas, passed into the cotton records yesterday for having produced the first bale of cotton of the new season. Usually July 4 has furnished an item of news to the effect that the first bale has been gathered and shipped for New-York. As often as the great holiday came around, Primus Jones of Georgia contributed this mite to it as long as he lived.

Arrangements are complete for the twenty-five-mile handicap race, promoted by Charles Schwalbach, which is to take place to-morrow on the Merrick Road. This is said to be well adapted for road racing, and those interested say that in time the Long Island Fourth of July race will excel the famous Irvington-Millburn.

Peter Butler, one of Boston's most famous merchants of years past, died Sunday, aged seventy-four. Mr. Butler had a most prominent career as a business man. Although not in any sense a politician, he had been recognized as a striking representative of the old-style Democrats, to which party he had been unswervingly allied since the death of his intimate friend, Daniel Webster.
Francis Stiebel has bought of the Japanese Fan Company the property at 169 Mercer Street, 25 by 100, with old building, at $39,000.

The question of the scant supply of water in Brooklyn nas been causing considerable anxiety to the Commissioner of City Works and the Aldermen. In order to take immediate action to relieve the city from a threatened water famine, the Aldermanic Committee on Water and Drainage held a meeting in the City Hall at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

From The London Daily News. A painful sensation has been caused in Berlin Court circles by the arrest of Herr von Kotze, one of the Chamberlains and Masters of Ceremonies. The arrest was made yesterday by special command of the Emperor, whose confidence Herr von Kotze is said to have enjoyed hitherto in a marked degree.

Dr. Charles Grandy, the young physician at Chambers Street Hospital who, as told in The New-York Times yesterday, refused three times Sunday night to sew up wounds from which Augustus Larson, who had been, stabbed in the face and hands by John Ericsson, was bleeding profusely, is likely to get into serious trouble as the result of his conduct.

The fifteenth annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club will be sailed to-morrow, and judging by the entries it will be the yachting event of the year. Altogether sixty-three entries have been made. Of these twelve are schooners, twenty-six sloops and cutters, one yawl, eight cabin catboats, seven open catboats, and nine twenty-one-footers.
A balky reform -- a reform that did not seem to want to reform unless compelied to -- engaged the indignant attention of the patrons of the bridge yesterday.
At noon yesterday the Board of Aldermen received from the Commissioner of Taxes the assessment rolls for 1894.

Major Willard Bullard, Chief Sanitary Inspector of the Health Department, died Sunday night at his home, 164 West Fortyeighth Street, of heart failure, produced by an attack of pneumonia. Major Billiard was sixty years old. He was born in Boston. His father was a machinist, and when Bullard was of sufficient age his father taught him his trade and started him off to earn his living.

SARATOGA, July 2 -- Railway troubles throughout the country, more particularly in the West, where trains have been stopped, prevented the Northwestern delegates from attending the sixteenth meeting of the Music Teachers' National Association, Which met at Congress Hall to-night. Eight hundred were expected, but the arrivals fell short of 100.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- News of the Corean rebellion, brought by the Peru, just arrived from Hongkong, is of an interesting character. Disaster after disaster had been met by Government troops, and the fall of the Government was expected at any time. The garrison of the town of Zenshu fell into the rebels' hands on May 31.

Plans are taking definite shape along the lines, indicated some time ago in The NewYork Times, for a judicial determination of the question whether or not the Union Pacific receivers shall operate various branches of that system whose rentals they are now expected to pay. Some of these lines, while not in themselves profitable, are rich feeders to the main line, while others are a weight and drag upon it.
"Mothers! It concerns the health of your children! Come!"

Dr. Herman Paul Faust of the Hebrew Christian Mission at 128 Forsyth Street sent to Mont Lawn. The Christian Herold's Open Air Home for children, over 100 children yesterday. They will remain at Mont Lawn for two weeks, and will have plenty of fresh air, good food, and healthful exercise.

The stock market was exceedingly dull, but in view of the strike, news was remarkably firm. London came somewhat lower, but orders from there were few and had little or no influence on prices. There was a disposition at the opening to sell stocks, but when the first rush was over, and no material amount of long stock was dislodged, the movement ceased and the market became steadier.

The attempt of the American Railway Union to lay an embargo upon the railroad traffic of the United States involves an issue compared to which the controversy between the Pullman Car Company and its employes sinks into insignificance. It is no longer a question of boycotting Pullman cars or of striking work on the railroads without justification and regardless of consequences, but of rebellion against law and order and public authority.

During these sultry and humid days, when those who live in the boat-appointed houses in the open districts of the city suffer to some extent, the tenement house population of more than a million and a quarter of men, women, and children, including 200,000 infants, swelters in cramped squalor.
The British bark James H. Hamlen, which sailed from this port June 19, bound for Demerara, has been towed into Bermuda, dismasted and abandoned.

Three or four months ago the Bell Telephone Company applied to the Massachusetts Legislature for permission to increase its capital stock from $20,000,000 to $50,000,000. The necessary bill was introduced, discussed, and passed. Under old statutes the company would have been allowed to issue the new stock to holders of the old stock at par, although the market price of the old stock was in the neighborhood of $200 per share.

The Navy Department's order to discontinue work on the four Government-built vessels will affect the two which are now in the New-York Navy Yard. These are the armored cruiser Maine, which only requires her two sideplates and a few finishing touches to be completed, and the cruiser Cincinnati, which was recently commissioned.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Representative Covert of New-York, the Chairman of the House Committee on Patents, has made a report on Representative Cummings's till to prevent the pirating of dramatic and operatic works. The report shows that the business of producing and staging plays and operas by American authors has largely increased in recent years, and that many of the best stage productions of modern times have been the work of American authors.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 2 -- The congested condition of freight traffic increased to-day. The railroads are applying every resource to the moving of passenger trains, but with poor success. Not one Wabash train arrived from the east or departed east. The engine crews scrutinize every man working in the terminal switch yards, and it is believed the appearance of non-union men will be the signal for them to strike.

ALBANY, July 2 -- A statement prepared in the State Banking Department of the condition of the State banks and individual bankers in this State, to the number of 205, shows that on the morning of June 7 the total resources and liabilities of these banks were as follows:

Another member of the American Proscriptive Association has been found who is willing to admit membership in that remarkable organization. He is Herbert R. Kinkaid of Brooklyn, who is employed in the real estate office of Prentlss Coles, on Reid Avenue, near Halsey Street.

LONDON, July 2 -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir William Harcourt moved the new clause relating to the levying of death duties upon property in the colonies belonging to persons domiciled in the United Kingdom. The clause insists that where the colonial duties are lower than the new estate duties, the difference must be paid into the British Exchequer.

Gen. Carlos Ezeta, the fugitive ex-President of Salvador, was in a communicative mood" yesterday, and talked freely, through the medium of a friend who acted as interpreter, about some of the events leading to his downfall of which he had not previously spoken.

MONTREAL, July 2 -- Nearly 10,000 people gathered on the Montreal Amateur Athletic Association grounds this afternoon to witness the races of the Canada Wheelmen's Association. The day, despite the excessive heat, was an ideal one, and the track was in fine condition. Nearly all the crack riders in the Dominion were present. The United States was represented by J.S. Johnson of Syracuse and C.H. Callahan of Buffalo.

BOSTON, July 2 -- The market for local stocks was generally inactive and uninteresting, a drop of 4 points in Boston and Albany being the only feature worthy of notice. That stock opened at 202, one below Saturday's close, and fell to 199. There is no apparent reason for this decline except that rather an unusual quantity -- about 100 shares -- of the stock came out.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times:" Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
The United States Government has abolished postal notes and money orders and has issued a new note which is to take the place of both and is to be known as the postal money order.

WEST CHESTER, Penn., July 2 -- Two tramps waylaid Miss Liazle Painter of Hopeweil on Saturday evening, and one of them received a pistol bullet in his arm. Miss Painter, who is a music teacher, was driving from the home of one of her scholars to Hopewell. In a lonely part of the road, a man, evidently a tramp, jumped out from the roadside and commanded her to get out of the wagon.

NEW-LONDON, July 2 -- The harbor and city retains its charms for yachtsmen. The schooner yacht Rebecca, New-York Yacht Club, is at anchor in the upper harbor, with her owner, Edward Dudley, and party on board. She reached the harbor late Saturday, remaining off the Pequot until to-day, when she went into the upper harbor.

ALBANY, July 2 -- There was a hearing to-day before Attorney General Hancock on the application of Mrs. Anna G. Woodruff, asking that the Attorney General bring an action in the Supreme Court to dissolve the Southern Central Railroad Company, which operates a road from Sayre, on the State line between New-York and Pennsylvania, to Fair Haven, on Lake Ontario.

The English graduate or undergraduate who travels in the States and visits Harvard, Yale, and other collegiate seats of the Republic, cannot easily believe in their athletic superiority. While there is much to admire in these institutions, the Oxford or Cambridge man misses something more than the dignity and discipline of the ancient English seats of learning.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 3 -- Harry Tyler won three of the four Class B events at to-day's race meeting of the Ohio Division. Sanger did not compete owing to a punctured tire, done while in practice. The attendance at the races which were held at Carthage was slim.

Preliminary preparations for building the great bridge across the North River were begun yesterday morning, when the tug Reba, towing a derrick barge, left the foot of Newark Street, Hoboken, with a party of engineers and surveyors on board.

Larchmont Harbor was well filled with yachts last night. In addition to the usual yachts that anchor in the harbor, there were the boats of the Atlantic Yacht Club, some of the Harvard Yacht Club, and a big fleet of boats that will take part in the regatta to-day.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The scenes in the Senate Chamber to-day were sufficiently exciting to satisfy the many persons who braved the high temperature to occupy seats in the galleries.

Congressman Walter I. Hayes of Iowa, a member of the party from Washington that arrived last night to attend the Tammany celebration to-day, said, in speakingof the strike in the West and of the possible action of Congress:

SING SING, N.Y., July 3 -- The Fourth of July will be celebrated throughout Westchester County in very much the usual manner. The small boys will explode fireworks of all kinds, and there will be meetings, picnics, and excursions of various sorts. In this village there will be patriotic exercises in the afternoon in the campus of Mount Pleasant Military Academy.

Nearly a billion and a quarter of dollars went into the coffers of the 1,890 railroad corporations in the United States during the year which ended June 30, 1893. Most of this immense sum was derived from carrying 593,560,612 passengers 14,229,101,084 miles, and 745,119,482 tons of freight 93,588,111,833 miles on 176,461 miles of railroad.

MONTREAL, Quebec, July 3 -- Since the international conference now sitting at Ottawa will discuss the proposed fast Atlantic steamshlp service, Sir William Van Horne, President of the Canadian Pacific Railway, expressed himself to-day upon this subject, to which he has given much attention. He said: "A fast Atlantic steamship service should be provided at almost any cost.

The final and complete returns of the Ontario election show that in the new Assembly the straight Liberals will number fifty, the straight Conservatives twenty-six, the Patrons sixteen, and the Protestant Protective Association members two. In a full House the Government will therefore have a majority over all parties of six, including the Speaker.

A club tournament of the Knickerbocker Field Club is now being held on the club grounds at Atlantic Avenue and East Nineteenth Street, Flatbush. A large number of the club members entered, and the tournament is witnessed in the afternoons by a large attendance.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- At 3:35 o'clock this afternoon the Grand Jury brought in indictments against Messrs. Shriver and Edwards, the newspaper correspondents, for refusing to answer the questions propounded by the Senate Committee, and both gave bail for their appearance when wanted.
Two singular facts are disclosed by an examination of the statistics of immigration it this port.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The first vote taken to-day on the Tariff bill was on Mr. Mills's motion of last evening to put burlaps and grain bags (270) on the free list. The motion was agreed to -- yeas, 28; nays, 17.

SACRAMENTO, Gal., July 3 -- This morning the station was cleared of people. This afternoon it fairly swarmed with humanity, pushing, pulling, hauling, and yelling. After the yard had been cleared of the blockade a train was made up, with San Francisco as its destination. It was composed of several mail cars; behind them were a number of objectionable Pullman cars and day coaches.
Messrs. Henry D. Winans May have sold for the estate of Carrie Hornthal the fourstory dwelling 6 East Seventy-eighth Street, 26.6 by 102.2, at $125,000.
Gen. Thomas L. James, President of the Lincoln National Bank, started yesterday for Harriman, Tenn., to assume formal charge of the Harriman Corporation, of which he has become receiver.
IRONWOOD, Mich., July 3 -- A riot occurred at the Norrie Mine to-day and a number of men were shot and the steam shovels stopped.

FLUSHING, L.I., July 3 -- In Brooklyn this morning Supreme Court Justice Willard M. Bartlett refused to grant representatives of the Village Trustees of Flushing an injunction to restrain the Flushing Jockey Club from holding its races on the Flushing driving track as advertised. Application for the injunction was made Monday afternoon by Corporation Counsel Sprague.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 3 -- A large number of visitors were in camp to-day. The weather was fine and the drills were creditably executed. Capt. Henderson of the Eighth Separate Company reviewed the evening parade, and Lieut. Barber of the Second Separate Company acted as his Adjutant.

That interference by violence or threats with the transportation of inter-State freight or of the mails is an offense against the laws of the United States is a proposition that no one with reasonable knowledge of the subject could honestly deny. The injunction issued by the Circuit Court of the United States for the circuit embracing Illinois and Indiana is issued beyond all doubt in strict pursuance of the law.

The Fourth of July is here once more, exactly on the minute. Old Father Time has no hired help; he does his own reaping, and winds the clock himself. He never "strikes," and no one ever ties him up. No matter how many carloads of bottled beer and sirloin steaks are sidetracked between New-York and Chicago, the Fourth of July is punctually here.
As a result of the united efforts in behalf of the unemployed people in the lower part of New-York City last Winter, a Committee of East Side Workers has been organized.

Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, who on Monday issued an injunction restraining Street Commissioner Andrews from dumping street refuse on Riker's Island, thereby causing great annoyance to the residents of the annexed district above the Harlem River and of the towns on the Long Island shore, yesterday modified the injunction, and permits the dumping of refuse, providing that it be properly disinfected and rendered inoffensive.

ASBURY PARK, July 3 -- While this city by the sea is showering its hospitality in abundance over the molders of public opinion and the dictators of thought in their respective localities, as the editors who form the National Association are called, the representatives from the South keenly feel the deprivation of their toddy and their midday julep.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Mortimer H. Bickley, President; Frederick Balt, manager, and John T. Anderson, foreman, of the Pennsylvania Steel Casting and Machine Company of Chester, Penn., who are accused of conspiracy and fraud against the Government by supplying it with gun castings of an inferior quality, were given a further hearing this morning before United States Commissioner Bell.
The formal invitation to ex-Premier William E. Gladstone to visit this country was sent last evening by Col. Edward Gouraud, Chairman of the organizing committee havhaving the matter in charge.
The poet came to interview the reporter. There was an expression of perplexity in the pale lilac of his eyes.
BERLIN, July 3 -- Chancellor von Caprivi held a conference with the chief of the political police last evening, when drastic anti-Anarchist measures were decided upon.

GLASGOW, July 3 -- The Largs regatta was sailed to-day, with a good northwesterly wind. The Valkyrie, Britannia, and Satanita started in the first race. Lord Dunraven was on board the Valkyrie, which, in consequence of her sail area having been increased by 1,200 feet, conceded the Britannia nine seconds. The Satanita allowed the Valkyrie and the Britannia each two minutes and twenty-six seconds.

TUXEDO PARK, July 3 -- The second day's play in the Tuxedo tournament has resulted in clearing up the lists considerably, and to-morrow will doubtless witness some great contests between the men who are now left in the competition. Malcom Chace, Edward L. Hall, and A.E. Foote are still unbeaten, though Hall came remarkably close to losing to Dr. E.C. Rushmore.

Improvement in railroad business promises to be a strong lever in the forces at work to legalize pooling. Practical arguments in its favor are springing to the front in every direction. Even the strike does not divert attention from tnis subject. The roads seriously affected by the action of the strikers have not had their hands so full as lead them to overlook the sentiment that has been growing in this regard.

The social as well as the sporting feature at Morristown, N.J., this Summer, is going to be the game of golf. Residents of that popular locality, not to be outdone by Newport and Southampton in the pursuit of the old Scotch game, have not only erected a handsome clubhouse and laid out admirable links, but are also playing the game With enthusiasm.

The low prices which have ruled at the auction sales of trotters in New-York during the past year have given more than one rare bargain to discriminating buyers. The chestnut gelding Cobwebs, that took a record or 2:16 1/4 at Philadelphia last week, is an example. He was picked up at Kellogg's for $550 by Joseph Turl, who drove him on the road in this city last Winter, stabling at Meade's, in West Sixty-second Street.

The independent investigation by the present ruling majority of the Board of Police into the iniquities of the department, as revealed by the evidence presented to the Lexow committee by its senior counsel, John W. Goff, made some progress yesterday.

ORANGE, N.J., July 3 -- Judging from the list or entries just completed the bicycle races and athletic contests to take place at the South Orange Field Club to-morrow will be spirited and close. There are a number of crack riders entered in the cycling events, and as the track is in almost perfect condition some good records will undoubtedly be made.

The final doubles in the New-Jersey Athletic Club tennis tournament were played yesterday at Bergen Point. J.P. Paret and E. Kinnard MacEnroe, after beating the Jessup brothers in a close three-set match, met John F. Hobart and Sydney L. Smith in the finals. The match was close throughout, and though Hobart and Smith won in straight sets, still in each of the sets there was but two games separating the winner from the loser.

CORRY, Penn., July 3 -- Fire broke out about 4:30 o'clock this afternoon in the pattern room of the Climax Iron Works, corner of Main Street and Third Avenue, and for a time threatened the whole south d of the city.
Mr. Singerly is his own platform, and the crudities of that on which his party has placed him will play but little part in the campaign.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 3 -- The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated David Overmyer as its candidate for Governor.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 3 -- The Illinois Labor Conference convened here this morning. At yesterday's meeting the fact was brought out that the main thing for the convention to work on is to get the members of the Trades Assembly, the Federation of Labor, the Single Tax Club, the American Railway Union, and the Knights of Labor to vote with the Populists to elect a representative to the United States Senate.
OTTAWA, Ontario, July 3 -- In the House of Commons to-night Mr. Edgar moved the impeachment of Sir Adolphe Caron, Postmaster General, and Sir Hector Langevin, ex-Minister of Public Works.

James B. Bouck is no longer President of the Brooklyn Board of Education. He was defeated for re-election yesterday at the annual meeting, and was succeeded by J. Edward Swanstrom. The vote was 24 to 20. Only one member of the board was absent, and he was in Europe on business.

It is believed in some quarters that the railroad strike will reach some of the great trunk lines running out of New-York. Railroad men, particularly those of the lines terminating in Jersey City, were very reticent yesterday when asked to tell how their business had been affected. Many of them declared that they had not felt the effects of the strike yet.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- The firmness of the market to-day was astonishing, in the face of the columns of strike news in the papers, and a continuous flood all day of bearish, unsettling telegrams. Of course, the dullness tended to protect values, rather than injure them. The most active stock on the list was Reading, which was strong all day, and closed right at the top, at the equivalent of 16 1/2.

FORT MONROE, Va., July 3 -- The cruiser Montgomery returned to Hampton Roads this evening, having met with a serious accident this morning at 10 o'clock while under headway and preparing for her highspeed trial.

Local dealers in fresh meats, both wholesale and retail, were freely of the opinion yesterday that unless the railroad strike is settled within two or three days there will be a meat famine in New-York. Prices were advanced again yesterday 2 and 3 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Tariff bill passed the Sate at 10:45 o'clock to-night by the decisive vote of 29 to 34.

Bettors who are not averse to accepting Short odds for their money had a prosperous afternoon at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. Four strong favorites romped home, and the other two winners were second choices, strongly backed. Altogether it was a disastrous afternoon for the pencilers, whose cashiers were kept busy between races tearing the corners off winning tickets and incidentally reducing the size of fat wads of greenbacks.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 3 -- John Conkling, the United States Immigrant Inspector detailed by Secretary Carlisle to investigate the causes of the strike in the vicinity of Punxsutawney, has returned to this city.

Lawrence Arnold, twenty-three years old, of 109 East Ninth Street, was Killed yesterday afternoon while repairing an electric fan in the dry goods store of William Jackson, 777 Broadway. In some way, while working about the fan, he received a shock that caused instant death.

PARIS, July 3 -- The inaugural message of the new President, M. Casimir-Perier, was read in the Senate and Chamber of Deputies to-day. The document was read in the Senate by M. Guerin, and in the Chamber by Premier Dupuy. The President says:

BOSTON, July 3 -- There was not enough market to-day in Boston to talk about, and there were next to no transactions in local stocks. There was no gossip on the Street and bulls and bears, longs and shorts, were equally silent. A more "Micawberish" attitude has perhaps never existed than obtains at present.

The Crescent Athletic Club has been holding during the week its annual handicap club tourney. The entries are divided into the first, second, and third classes. The second class is again subdivided into two minor classes, A and B, and the first and third classes into three minor classes, A, B, and C. The first class owes 15 and gives the second class 15 and the third class 30.

Sixty thousand shares was the record for yesterday's market, and of this, 18,500 shares were in Sugar. The stock named was more or loss heavy all day, declining from 101 to 99 1/2, and closing at 100 1/8, a net loss of 1/4. Chicago Gas was quits firm, and closed 3/4 higher, at 79, having sold as high as 79 3/8.

A pickpocket, who said he was James Doyle, forty-eight years old, of 16 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, was captured yesterday morning in St. Agnes's Church, that city, by the Rev. Father York, just after a funeral service. The service was over the body of Mrs. Annie E. Graham of 376 Sackett Street.

Myer J. Stein, lawyer and ex-Assemblyman, who testified for the defense at the trial of Michael Donnelly for assault with intent to kill Patrick J. McArdle, was arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by Judge Marline on a charge of perjury, and later he was indicted by the Grand Jury.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 -- The situation on the Wabash is more desperate than at any time since the strike began. All of its trainmen, including locomotive engineers, have left. Scarcely a wheel on the entire system is moving. The Chicago and Alton is also greatly embarrassed.

A curious and interesting change in the duties on screws, as they had been reported by the Senate Committee on Finance, was made when the paragraph fixing these duti was taken up in the Senate. In the McKinley tariff the duties are specific, ranging from 5 to 14 cents a pound, and they are so high that the importation of screws is prohibited by the tax.

Many well-known persons sailed on the two transatlantic steamships which left this port for Europe yesterday. A full list of the voyagers was printed in The New-York Times yesterday. Among those who sailed on the Aurania, for Liverpool, were thirty-five young men and women, composing the Amherst Glee, Mandolin, and Banjo Clubs.

There is great rivalry between the Committee of Thirty and the Platt-Milholland faction of the Republican Party as to which is entitled to the appointment of election officers under the Bi-Partisan Election Inspectors bill, which went into effect July 1.

There are two propositions apparently demonstrated by the election of CasimirPerier to the Presidency of the French Republic. One is that the republican form of government is necessary to France, the other that social conciliation is necessary to the republic.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I wish I might agree with your correspondent, "V.T.K.," who writes so charmingly in The Times of June 25, but, failing to accept her premises, I cannot follow with her to her conclusions. She starts from the mistaken assumption that suffrage is a privilege, instead of one of a series of duties standing in orderly and necessary relations to each other.

Justice William J. Gaynor in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday issued a mandamus ordering Mayor Schieren to grant a license to the Seaside Athletic Club of Coney Island for boxing and other athletic exhibitions.
Richard Croker and his two sons, Richard, Jr., and Herbert, are expected to arrive here from Europe to-day on the steamship Majestic, which is due at her pier before noon.

"This A.P.A. agitation is simply the old Orange movement transplanted from the North of Ireland to the United States of America. Its chief promoters, you will find, are Orangemen, and its aims, no matter how they may be cloaked, are the same old aims of the Orange society, which have proved such a prolific cause of riot, trouble, and bloodshed to the decent people of Great Britain."

ALBANY, N.Y., July 3 -- Attorney General Hancock to-day gave an opinion requested by the State Civil Service Commission on an inquiry received from the Civil Service Reform Association as to "The effect of Chapter 717 of the Laws of 1894 upon the standing of veterans with regard to the Civil Service Commission" of the State, and other questions.

LYNBROOK, L.I., July 3 -- The July meeting of the Long Island Trotting Circuit opened at Reserve Park, Lynbrook, to-day, about 2,000 persons being present. The feature of the meeting was the fast time made in the 3:30 class for trotters and pacers, one heat being trotted in 2:33 1/4.

The Drivers and Hostiers' Protective and Benevolent Union, composed of several hundred members of the Department of Street Cleaning, met last evening at the corner of Desbrosses and Hudson Streets to tender resolutions to their former Superintendent of Stables, Michael Kennedy. They had two bands or music and an abundance of fireworks.

It was reported a few days ago that the Democrats of the Senate Finance Committee had decided to modify the Grorman-Brice sugar schedule by two amendments, one providing that the proposed duties should take effect at once, and the other withdrawing the contingent protective duty of 1-10 of a cent upon sugar imported from countries where a bounty is paid.

The courts of the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club of Tarrytown were used for the club's annual tournament yesterday. As in most club tournaments, the point system was used, and it proved satisfactory. E.H. Thayer and Howard Thayer, fresh from college, played in the singles, and each won both of their matches. They will meet in the finals to-day.
Otto Heine, or Herre, died in Chambers Street Hospital yesterday afternoon of starvation. He was fifty-eight years old, and had been a commercial traveler in his more prosperous days.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 4. -- There are tour players still unbeaten in the singles of the Tuxedo tennis tournament, and much interest hangs on to-morrow's contests. Malcolm Chace Of Brown, James Terrey of Yale, Edward L. Hall of New-York, and Arthur E. Foote of Yale are the experts who will content the semi-finals tomorrow. Chace plays Terrey, while Hall plays Foote.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- The first violent death to be ascribed to the big railroad strike has taken place at Twenty-sixth Street and the Lake Shore crossing. The railroad company Says positively that the death was little Short of murder, and that the strikers on the Rock Island system are directly responsible. Leaders of the men on strike on the Rock Island are equally positive that the men were not strikers.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 4. -- Just as the troops in the State camp, were leaving the mess hall at 1 o'clock to-day, a terrific electrical storm broke over the camp. A bolt of lightning struck a converter box on an electric-light pole near the mess hall. The electric fluid ran along the wires, which extended over the whole camp.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 4. -- A large number of persons was attracted by the Crescent heelmen's meet to-day, the attendance being larger than at the opening of the track on June 20. A strong breeze hindered any record smashing. The races were very exciting and interesting.

Young America celebrated the one hundred and eighteenth anniversary of American independence with great vigor in Brooklyn yesterday. All the public buildings were decorated with the national, State, and municipal flags, while many of the private residences and large business houses also had the Stars and Stripes flying from their windows.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 4. -- In the presence of a multitude of people Huntington's memorial to Capt. Nathan Hale was unveiled to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Eugene Chamberlain, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, Treasury Department, has been making a study of local and State taxation on shipping in many States. Some interesting facts are brought to light -- for instance, that United States ships in foreign trade are free from all taxes in the States of Alabama, New-York, Delaware, and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Postmaster General Bissell has adopted the report of the commission of three Post Office officials appointed some time ago to inquire into the needs of the New-York City Post Office. The instructions to this commission were to examine into and report to the department regarding the advisability of establishing new city stations, forming new free delivery districts, increasing the carrier force, and creating new sub-stations and stamp agencies.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- General Manager Egan of the Managers' Association still remains steadfast in his purpose to fight it put to a finish with the American Railway Union. When asked this morning concerning the overtures made to President Debs for a settlement, Mr. Egan replied:

MASSILLON, Ohio, July 4. -- The miners of this district have been thrown into a state bordering on panic by developments in connection with the relief work in the last few days. The Relief Committee has been taking care of about eighty families, and it has been only through the most strenuous efforts that its charges have been kept from actual suffering.

The statement made to a correspondent of The Times yesterday by Mr. Pullman that he cannot "arbitrate" the claims of his former workmen is, on the facts known, a perfectly reasonable one, because practically the matter has passed out of his hands. The original demand for an increase of wages was declined on the ground that there was no work to be done that would even return cost at advanced wages.

Senator Patrick Walsh of Georgia held a levee at the Gilsey House yesterday afternoon, after his return from Tammany Hall, where he made a speech. The Senator has a great many friends in New-York, and whenever he comes here they seek him out.
WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Public interest is now centred in the prospective work of the conference committee, which probably will begin consideration of the Tariff bill in a few days.

The Larchmont Yacht Clubmen are very patriotic. They always celebrate the glorious Fourth with a regatta, and invariably this regatta is the best of the year. Yesterday's race was no exception to this rule. It was, in fact, the most important regatta that has been witnessed in many years.

Mrs. Julia. Rees, an aged widow, of 316 East Fifty-eighth Street, was shot In the left breast early yesterday morning and died before an ambulance could reach her house. She was in her kitchen, on the ground floor of her house, at the time of the Shooting.

The attitude of the United States Government in the disorders prevailing in Illinois and the West growing out of the "sympathetic" strike of railway employes has been in every way praiseworthy. The Administration has proceeded with the greatest care and deliberation, ascertaining the facts, the duties imposed by law, and the authority conferred to carry out those duties.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 4. -- The cutter Barbara, New-York Yacht Club, Joseph S. Boss, won her fourth race this season to-day, over an eighteen-mile course, of which the limits were North Hill Buoy, Bartlett's Reef Lightship, and this harbor. Her competitor to-day was the Ethel, regarded as a fast boat, and owned by Lieut. Chase, United States Army, stationed at Fort Trumbull.
ASBURY PARK, July 4. -- The thirty-third annual convention of the National Educational Association will meet at Asbury Park on Friday, and will continue in session until July 13.

Elsie Schultz, confused by fright during a fire in a boarding house at 891 Second Avenue yesterday afternoon, jumped from a second-story window to the pavement, striking on her side and fracturing her left hip and thigh. She also suffered internal injuries.

From The Philadelphia Times. A young lady on Walnut Street is the owner of a pug dog and also has a beautiful cat. Until lately these pets have been the most deadly enemies, and efforts to reconcile them failed until a short time ago some casks of wine were moved up from the cellar to the yard and one was broken.
Of the many incidents of interest to the social world yesterday one of the most important was the arrival on the White Star Line steamship Majestic of Lord and Lady Randolph Churchill.

ST. JOHN'S, N. F., July 4. -- The steamer Falcon was docked to-day preparatory to starting for Greenland with the Peary auxiliary expedition. The work of overhauling: her will be speedily completed, as she will come off the clock to-morrow. She is to sail Saturday night.

From The American Register, Paris. The descendants of Queen Victoria are either now in possession of, or will in the natural course of events come to occupy, seven thrones -- those of the British Empire, the German Empire, the Russian Empire, the Kingdom of Greece, the Grand Duchy of Hesse, the Duchy of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, and Duchy of Saxe-Meiningen.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 4. -- The Kill Von Kull Yacht Club held an open regatta over the club course in Newark Bay and the Kill Von Kull this afternoon. The clubhouse, which commands a view of the whole course, was crowded with guests.

Since the veracious Eli Perkins visited those tin mines at Harney Peak and overtaxed his very elastic imagination in a written description of their fabulous wealth, scarcely anything has been heard of them until now, when some rather ugly legal proceedings bring them once more before the public.

The eighth annual festival and games of the New-York Letter Carriers' Association in Lion Park yesterday attracted a larger crowd than ever before in the history of the association. Postmaster Dayton was present, and the postal employes were out in full force with their families and friends.
Fully 10,000 persons attended the celebration under the auspices of the Tammany Organization of the Ninth Assembly District in Abdingdon Square last evening.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 4. -- Harry Tyler topped off a great day's sport at the Ohio Division L. A.W. race meet, second day, by riding a half mile, flying start, against time, in 1 minute flat. E.C. Johnson paced him a quarter and Sanger picked him up for the finish rather poorly. Tyler came on alone to the tape. This lowers the State record 1 1-5 seconds, flying time.
The fair weather made the Fourth unusually "glorious" for the many society people who are sojourning at lakeside and seashore and on mountain top.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Appropriate observance of Independence Day occurred at the Washington Monument. The Washington Light Infantry and Battery A of the District of Columbia National Guard, headed by the United States Marine Band, marched to the monument from the Arlington Hotel as an escort to the participants in the programme.
VANCOUVER, B.C., July 4. -- The steamship Empress of China arrived this morning from Yokohama with the following Oriental advices:

Paris Correspondent London Telegraph. From time to time indignant protests have been raised against the brutal scenes witnessed at the "Courses de Taureaux," as they are termed in this country, like the corridas in Spain, held at Nimes, Aries, Dax, and other towns in the South of France. Not the slightest attention has, however, been paid to these remonstrances.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 4. -- Meekin won the morning same all by himself. Three times at bat with three triples, struck out four men, and allowed but six hits -- two scratches -- was the record of the young man. The game was clean and well played throughout. Attendance about 4.000.
CHICAGO, July 4. -- "The firgt shot fired by the regular soldiers at the mobs here will be the signal for a civil war. I believe this as firmly as I believe in the untimate success of our course.

The body of a man was found at the foot of William Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and removed to the Morgue. In one of the pockets was a nickel-plated matchbox inscribed, "Compliments of M. Kern, 348 West Street, New-York," and on a finger of the left hand was a plain gold ring inscribed "L.E. to A.G."
BOSTON, July 4. -- At Franklin Park this afternoon sixteen heats were trotted and paced betwen 1 and 7 o'clock. As an extra attraction, the 2:13 pace was added to the card held over from yesterday.

Lysander Dickerson of Sterling, Ill., thus writes to The Chicago Journal: "In a recent issue of your paper I find an item describing at some length the moving of the old Liberty Bell into its new quarters in Independence Hall at Philadelphia, and a recital of the safeguards with which the historic relic is now surrounded. In this item the bell itself is described with more or less minuteness.

Citizens of King's Bridge celebrated the Fourth by raising the Stars and Stripes over the ruins of Old Fort Prince Charles, on the brow of North Marble Hill, and by appropriate exercises. North Marble Hill stands at the north end of Manhattan Island and commands the Spuyten Duyvil Creek and the Harlem River.

BAY RIDGE, L. I., July 4. -- The Ridge Club, an important athletic and social institution of Bay Ridge, moved into its new clubhouse to-day and celebrated the event with a reception in the morning and afternoon and a ball in the evening. The new clubhouse cost, including furniture, about $35,000.
WOODSTOCK, Conn., July 4. -- The Fourth was celebrated as usual at Roseland Park, Henry C. Bowne's country place. The speech of welcome was made by Congressman Charles A. Russell.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The Attorney General to-day telegraphed to United States District Attorney Milchrist, at Chicago, to have the Grand Jury convene as soon as possible, in order that indictments may be found against President Debs and other officials of the American Railway Union, in conformity with the omnibus injunction is sued by the United States District Court at Chicago. Commenting on this action, the Attorney General said:

BAYONNE CITY, N.J., July 4. -- The programme of sports provided for to-day by the New-Jersey Athletic Club, was successfully carried out. Much interest was taken in the individual championships of the Amateur Athletic Union, Edward W. Goff of the New-Jersey Athletic Club being victorious again, with a total score of 5,748 points.
At the Tombs the Fourth was passed much as other days are passed. There was no celebration or special services.

LONDON, July 4. -- The Yale athletes practiced at Oxford to-day. E.H. Cady and D.B. Hatch tried the hurdles. W.S. Woodhull made practice starts with the runners and was pronounced by all who saw him to be in fine form. W.O. Hickok and Alexander Brown threw the hammer.

Because the American Prescriptive Association does, its un-American work in secret, and because it has not so far dared to come out openly in a political campaign in this vicinity, as it has in so many other places, there are still persons who believe its importance has been overestimated.

CUBA, Allegany County, N.Y., July 4. -- Nearly all of Allegany County and a large portion of Steuben County came to this beautiful little town to-day to celebrate the Nation's natal day. At least 10,000 persons were on the ground, including a dozen fire companies, when ex-Speaker William Sulzer of New-York was introduced as the orator of the day.

From The Galveston (Texas) News. For the consolation of candidates for political office The News reporter will give the following story, which Barney Gibbs will verify as having taken place in one of the lower counties of Mississippi: Two men announced for the office of Sheriff -- one a smooth, affable, and very popular man, the other morose, self-conceited, and a perfect bore.

SPRINGFIELD, In., July 4. -- The State labor conference met this morning to adopt a platform. Two reports were presented, the majority, signed by four members, and the minority, which was very Socialistic in nature, signed by Thomas J. Morgan. It caused considerable discussion, but finally the majority report was adopted and the j convention adjourned sine die. The platform is, in part, as follows:

William H. Blackford, E.N. Rich, Frank T. Redwood, and J. Willcox Brown of Baltimore and Andrew J. Nuderdonk and Charles W. Opdyke of New-York have been appointed a committee to look after the interests of the holders of first mortgage bonds of the Carolina Central Railway Company.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 4. -- The fourth annual racing tournament of the Columbia Cycle Club attracted about 2,000 persons to Charter Oak Park this afternoon. The track was a little heavy and quite slippery. In the one-half-mile, open, T. Nelson of Springfield broke his collarbone. He was close behind Maddox, who finished second, when the former, after both had passed under the wire about ten yards, slipped and fell.

Seventy-one wheelmen had entered for Charles Schwalbach's twenty-five-mile road race that came off yesterday on the road from Freeport, L. I., to Jamaica, and return. Of this number, fifty-eight made the round trip, and did not seem much the worse for the hard spin under a hot July sun.

From The New-Orleans Picayune, July 1. There was celebrated in this city yesterday an event, remarkable, unique, and important in the highest degree. It was the centennial of the successful production of sugar in Louisiana.
WALTHAM, Mass., July 4. -- The track at this place has another bicycle record to its credit. Arthur W. Porter, the young Class A crack, made it, going the mile in 2:03 from a flying start.

Mr. and Mrs. Juda Grossman of 154 Orchard Street have a girl baby, born last Sunday, which has two extra fingers and one extra too. On each hand there is a second little finger, and on the left foot there are six toes.

PARIS, July 4. -- President Casimir-Perier held a reception to-day at which he received delegates representing the various departments of France. Among the delegations was one comprising the County Council of Aube, of which body the President was once the presiding officer.

NORFOLK, Va., July 4. -- After spending twenty-four hours at sea the United States ship Montgomery, the pride of Secretary Herbert and all Alabamians, met with a mishap yesterday morning which will lay her up for three or more months, and possibly take her out of commission during that time.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- With rifles leveled and revolvers drawn, half of the Second Battalion Fifteenth Regiment, United States Infantry, proceeded through a dense mob of more than 5,000 men, boys, women, and children to their camp in the stock yards to-day.

Col. William Seward of the Ninth Regiment, the senior Colonel of the National Guard of the State of New-York, was found guilty of disobedience of orders by the court-martial which tried him recently on the charges preferred against him by Brig. Gen. Fitzgerald, for Col. Seward's failure to parade his command at Van Cortlandt Park June 2, and the sentence was that he should be reprimanded.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4. -- Mrs. James P. Kernochan's reception from 4 to 7 o'clock this afternoon was a very brilliant social event. Sea View, the Kernochan residence, was covered with flags and bunting. The east veranda was inclosed, and there the hostess received her guests. Flags of all nations and national emblems were used to decorate this Improvised reception room, as were also palms and flowers.

From The Chicago Herald. The Hon. Lambert Tree, ex-Minister to Belgium and to Russia, once related the following: One day, while walking in the business centre of Chicago, he met a friend, who asked him what he was seeking. The question puzzled the diplomatic lawyer, until the interrogator explained that he had seen Mr. Tree's pictures in the windows of saloons.

This year's Fourth of July has to its credit a large list of accidents. Many small boys came to grief with toy pistols, big can non firecrackers, little firecrackers, and torpedoes. And the elder folKs did not escaps. Numbers who had not gained experience with years used revolvers carelessly with disastrous results or were burned by need-lessly -handled fireworks.

The quarrel that has existed for some time between receivers of Southern vegetables and fruits In this city and the Pennsylvania Railroad over the refusal of the railroad company to deliver the freight at its dock in this city has been amicably settled, and the goods are being delivered on this side of the North River.

The Paterson Cricket Club received a visit from the Morris Heights Club yesterday. The wicket played very badly, and it was soon seen that tall scoring was out of the question. It was then a tussle between the bowlers, and W. R. Wilson and A. Richardson proved equal to the task, and Morris Heights won by 17 runs.

The fact announced by The New-York Times yesterday that the French courts have directed Munroe Brothers Co., the bankers of Paris, to pay to Justin McCarthy the amount of the Irish Parliamentary Fund, which was in their charge, intensely pleased the friends of Ireland. They talked of it with no other differences in expression than came of their individual traits, for Justin McCarthy is liked, and the fund has been asleep for three years.

The prompt conviction of Bartholomew Shea of murder in the first degree for the killing of Robert Ross on the day of the municipal election in Troy shows that public sentiment in that city is sound, in spite of the demoralization that has been wrought by the Murphy machine.

HOBOKEN, N.J., July 4. -- A brutal murder was committed in this city this afternoon. The victim was Jenny Knittle, employed as a domestic in the family of Mrs. Mary Mulvany, 58 Garden Street, and the murderer Thomas McLaren, a Delaware, | Lackawanna and Western brakeman, at one time the woman's reputed husband and to whom she had borne four children.

HUDSON, Mass., July 4. -- Hudson was visited to-day by the most serious fire in the history of the town. It originated about 3 P.M. in a small building near F.H. Chamberlin's shoe factory, and, fanned by a strong breeze, spread very rapidly In an easterly direction. The following buildings were burned: Assabet factory, occupied by F.H. Cnamberlin; S. Wood Co.'s block, A.K. Graves's block, Lewis Block, and tenement building;

ASBURY PARK, July 4. --The delegates to the National Editorial Association's Convention and the representatives from the different press associations throughout the country, who have been here for several days, are enthusiastic and unstinting In their expressions of appreciation for the generous demonstrations and testimonials of hospitality which have been extended to them.

A holiday calm pervaded all the depots and yards yesterday of the railroads leading into this city from the west. The offices of the New-York Central, the Pennsylvania, and Erie roads were closed tightly, and outwardly there was no suspicion of strikes or impending trouble of any sort. Passenger traffic on all these roads was reported as undisturbed, and freight trains were said to be moving on schedule time.

Railroad managers in the West are much annoyed by a decision by the Kansas Board of Railroad Commissioners which is in effect an order to the lines within that State to scale freight rates I5 per cent. below the standard schedules. Practically this order is not alarming, because the Western lines in their eagerness for business have ignored the schedules and have made rates to secure it.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 4. -- There was an elaborate celebration of the national holiday at Prohibition Park, which drew 1,000 people to that place during the day, and over 5,000 in the evening. Among them were leading Prohibitionists from all parts of the State.

LONDON, July 4. -- Heats in the big amateur rowing event of the year next to the OxfordCambridge race, the single scull contest for the Diamond sculls, were rowed at Henley to-day. The first heat was contested by Vivian Nickalls of Magdalen College, Oxford, and Francis Boudin of the Societe d'Encouragement, Paris. The heat was won by Nickalls by four lengths.

After 118 years of independence the American people are beginning to take a common-sense view of their duty in celebrating the anniversary of the day when the country became free. Noise and processions through hot streets lined with sweitering crowds have been considered necessary to a proper observance of the Fourth of July.
Isidor Italia, forty years old, of 90 James Street, who has been a prisoner in Ludlow Street Jail since April 30, committed suicide by hanging himself in his cell at 7 o'clock last night.

Waltzer, the strong-limbed little animal from the Gideon Daily stable, showed his heels to the fleetest two-year-olds on the turf in the fourth Great Trial Stakes at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, and won the big prize in a common canter.

RED BANK, N.J., July 4. -- The Shrewsbury Yacht Club held its second annual regatta today. The weather was pleasant, a cool wind blowing about west southwest. Among those who viewed the race from the clubhouse were Sheppard Knapp, Edward Kemp, John F. James, and Assemblyman Richard Borden.

The boys and girls who have fathers, mothers, and homes were not the only one in the city yesterday who had firecrackers, ice cream, peanuts, candy, and music, and Went to bed tired and happy with the consciousness of having had a "real good time."
SACRAMENTO, Cal., July 4. -- The strikers won a victory here to-day, the troops refusing to disperse them when ordered.

WEST BRIGHTON, S.I., July 4. -- The ball team of the Hamilton Athletic Association of Philadelphia visited the Staten Island Athletic Club to-day and played two games. The morning game proved rather an easy victory for the Quaker City team. Both teams hit the ball well, but the visitors bunched their hits at times, when they were assisted by both the pitcher and fielders of the home team.

BLUE ISLAND, III., July 4. -- The great blockade on the Rock Island Railroad here was entirely raised at 1:15 o'clock this afternoon, and train that had been tied up for five days began to move. The first of the trains that were stalled at Joliet came up the track guarded by soldiers.

NEWARK. N.J., July 4. -- The Eagle Wheelmen of this city, whose membership list is composed exclusively of colorad men, held their annual handicap races on the Belgrove drive course, Kearny, N.J., this morning. The first event, the two-mile handicap, was won by James Thomas of Orange, (300 yards.) in 6:14, with William Saich of the Newark Wheelmen, Junior, second, in 6:18.

KAMLOOPS, B.C., July 4. -- Word has just been received of a fatal explosion on the North Thompson River, fifteen miles north of here. The steamer Queen left this morning bound for Lewis Creek, with eight persons on board. The explosion occurred when the steamer was near Brickyard. Five persons are missing. J.E. Saucier, Engineer Martin, and Capt. Ritchie were saved.

CINCINNATI, July 4. -- The Reds took both games from Brooklyn to-day. Each was marked by heavy hitting on both sides. In the morning game Latham hit a home run with three men on bases. McPhee duplicated it with two bases filled in the third inning. The Reds' playing was much better than that of the visitors.

Ex-Assemblyman Myer J. Stein, who was arrested Tuesday on a charge of perjury in the Donnelly-McArdle assault case, was at his office, 31 Park Row, yesterday afternoon. He says he is the victim of a mistake or a conspiracy, and that he will work unceasingly until he has cleared away the cloud from his name.

The Rev. Emil Perhacs, assistant pastor of the Reformed Catholic Church in Cumberland Street, near Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, who was arrested on the evening of April 17 last on a charge of stealing 55 cents from clothing in Dr. Charles H. Sheppard's baths, 81 Columbia Heights, has been acquitted by a jury in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, having satisfied the jurymen that he was innocent of the charge.

The English lawyer who was employed by Col. Jacques, the agent of the American "heirs," to obtain possession of the great Lawrence-Towneley estate, has been sent to the penitentiary as punishment for the part he played in the proceedings, and now it is quite probable that the agent himself will suffer in the same way.
