MANHATTAN BEACH, July 4. -- Persons competent to judge estimate that at the various resorts along the beach -- at West Brighton, Brighton, and Manhattan Beach -- there were 300,000 holiday pleasure seekers to-day.

The breaking of a record made the meet of the Tourist Cycle club, at the Clifton (N.J.) race track yesterday, particularly attractive New figures also were made for the track mile. There were, fully 4,000 people present.

Ex-Alderman James McGarry who for years was one of the most prominent Democratic machine politicians in Brooklyn, died at his home, 176 Nevins Street, that city, yesterday morning of Bright's disease. He had been ill for several months.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 4. -- A majority of the freight conductors of the Chesapeake and Ohio and Louisville and Nashville Roads went out on strike this morning, refusing to haul freight switched by non-union men. The yardmasters op the Chesapeake and Ohio at Covington quit work this morning, and the situation on that road is decidedly had. Fifty United States Peputy Marshals came from Columbus this morning and were distributed among the various railroad yards.

From The Cleveland Leader. The effects of hard times are very clearly shown in the returns of the Dow law tax collections, which are now being made by the various counties. Seven counties have thus far reported. All but one of them are rural counties, and only one shows an increase in the number of saloons.

There is something unique about Brighton Beach race track. No matter what attractions its near neighbors may offer to the racing public, whenever Brighton opens its gates there is sure to be a good crowd of speculators on hand. The grand stand was crowded yesterday, while the betting ring resembled a huge vat of sweltering mortality.

FLUSHING, L.I., July 4. -- The first races of the newly-organized Flushing Jockey Club were run off to-day without any interference from the authorities. It was expected that some effort would be made to prevent me making or foreign books on the track. There were a few Deputy Sheriffs present, but their mission was to preserve order and not to stop the sport.

BOSTON, July 4. -- An interesting part of the city's celebration to-day was the sailing regatta off City Point, in which nearly 100 yachts, from the thirty-footers down to the fifteen-footers of the mosquito fleet, competed. A moderate southwest wind blew until the larger boats were finishing, when a vicious squall came out of the West and laid their lee rail down and compelled them to take in all their kites.

Richard Croker returned to this city from England yesterday morning on the steamship Majestic. He went in a carriage from the pier to the Tammany Society's Independence Day celebration in the Wigwam, where he received a cordial greeting. Afterward he went to the races, and last night he started for Richneid Springs to join his family.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 4. -- Herbert E. Benton, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee of Connecticut, delivered the oration to-day at the celebration of the two hundredth anniversary of the settlement of Cheshire. Touching upon the political corruption in the State and Nation, and the danger threatening the public schools of the country, he said:

ST. LOUIS, July 4. -- The railroads did not make much of an effort to overcome the strike difficulty to-day. The majority of them have given their employes until tomorrow to return to work, and if by that time the men do not resume, their places Will be filled by non-union men.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- There was very little interest in the local stock market, and with one or two exceptions prices were easier all around, recovering somewhat toward the close of the last session. The syndicate engaged in obtaining control of the Lake Street Elevated has now secured the majority interest, and the market, left to itself, broke this morning from 17 1/2 to 16 1/4, subsequently recovering to 17 1/4.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., July 5. -- United States Marshal Baldwin and Major Gen. Dimond of the National Guard have had a consultation, and they agree that they are unable to cope with the situation.
Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday sent to Congressman Amos J. Cummings a letter, in which he says of Government interference with the strikes:

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Scenes of lawlessness were enacted to-day on a stretch of railroad territory occupied by the tracks of the Lake Shore and Rock Island, and running south for some three miles from the Board of Trade structure in the heart of the business district.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 5. -- Bright and early the yachtsmen of the Atlantic Club were getting their boats ready for the first day's run of their annual cruise. They seemed to feel very little of the effect of the glorious reception that the SeawanhakaCorinthian yachtsmen tendered them last evening.

Four years ago, as a sop to public opinion, the Republicans enacted a law for the punishment and suppression of Trust combinations. They had already passed the McKinley tariff in the House, and in the Senate they were enlarging the great gifts bestowed upon the Sugar Trust and other similar combinations in the House bill.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 6. -- There is now an intimation that the railroad strike may reach Pittsburg. Charles Naylor and J.E. Roe, the organizers of the American Railway Union, who came to Pittsburg Tuesday night, said this evening that they expected some action in support of the strike from the railroad men's union here.

Controller Pitch has prepared a statement showing the arrangement under which revenue is paid to the city by the street railway companies. No uniform rule governs payments. Some of the companies pay stipulated amounts for privileges; others are subject to car license fees, while recentlyincorporated companies pay for franchises according to the provisions of the general railroad law. Payments are regulated as follows:

ALBANY, July 5. -- When the Constitutional Convention was called to order this morning the special order was the adverse report of the Committee on Suffrage on Mr. Lincoln's resolution requesting Congress to draft and submit a constitutional amendment providing that no person not a citizen shall have the right to vote.

BOSTON, July 5. -- To-day's market for local stocks is but a repetition of that of Tuesday, almost nothing doing, and no feature worthy of notice. West End Land again to-day was the only stock traded in to any extent. The stock sold off 1/4, to 1 7/8, and the rights were firm at 8 3/8. Mexican Central 4s were steady, at 53.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Reports to the General Managers' Association as given to the press to-day are to the effect that the blockade on the Chicago and Alton at Bloomington had been raised with the aid of United States Marshals, and all trains were forwarded with old engineers and new firemen.

A trim-looking steamship, with yards square and braces taut, yesterday steamed down the East River, and, after some preliminary questions with signal flags, made fast to the Cob Dock of the New-York Navy Yard. The vessel was the old corvette Essex, which has been converted into an apprentice training ship, and into something resembling a modern cruiser at the same time.

ALBANY, July 5. -- The thirty-second convocation of the Regents of the University opened in the Senate chamber this morning. Prayer was offered by the Rev. A. V. V. Raymond, President of Union College.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Eugene V. Debs, President of the American Railway Union, has issued a long statement in justification of the great strike of which he is the central figure. The article is addressed "To the public," and reads, in part, as follows:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., July 5. --A large number of boatmen were at work today endeavoring to recover the bodies of the three men drowned by the capsizing of the sloop yacht Gazelle In Hog Island Inlet yesterday afternoon. The men made an extended search, but could get no trace of the bodies.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- What is left of the gilded statue of the Republic, near the eastern end of the Court of Honor, the central point of interest for thousands of visitors to the exposition last Summer, to-night looks out upon a waste of ruins and ashes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- The annual convention of the Christian Endeavor Societies of the United Presbyterian Church, or Young People's Christian Union, began this evening in the Second Presbyterian Church. About 1,000 delegates and others Interested in the work are in attendance. They represent 710 societies, with a membership of 30,824, not to speak of the junior societies, which number 125 and have a membership of 4,003.

There were two desolate homes in this city yesterday, as a result of the capsizing of the flshing yacht Gazelle off Rockaway Beach on Wednesday afternoon. A story was started among the friends of John Smith, one of those who was seen to go down, that he had been rescued, but no foundation for the story of the rescue could be obtained.

RICHMOND, Ind., July 5. -- On a rough and dusty track surprisingly good time was made today at the Indiana Division bicycle meet. The racing men came down from Cincinnati this morning. Pacemakers were put in all the races and low time limits placed. In the half-mile open a time limit of 1:10 made good racing. Sanger won in 1:02 4-5.

F.H. Downer, night station agent of the New-York Central Road, said last night that the two express trains from Chicago, the New-York and Chicago Limited, coming in at 6:30, and the day express at 7:05, had both arrived on time. Traffic was light on account of its being the day after the Fourth.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- Philadelphia Traction has certainly acted a good deal as its friends predicted. Whoever has been trying lately to depress the price of the rights and the regular stock has gotten tired, and the pressure being off, both are strong.

At auction, in Brooklyn, yesterday, Mr. Thomas A. Kerrigan sold at $2,700, to Jane Kingston, the two-story frame dwelling 10 Irving Place, east side, 195.6 feet south of Gates Avenue, 20 by 92.3 by irregular. To Charles M. Reed, plaintiff, at $3,200, he sold the two-and-one-half-story frame dwelling 403 Van Buren Street, north eide, 222.11 feet east of Tompkins Avenue, 27.1 by 100.

The effect of the great Western railroad strike on the meat, poultry, and fruit markets in this city is becoming more serious. Not only is a meat and poultry famine an early probability, but California fruits are now so scarce there is said to be not enough in this city to last over Sunday. The strike also bids fair to result in a lemon famine in the West.
GLASGOW, July 5. -- After the sinking of the Valkyrie, the Vigilant and Britannia started in the race alone.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- There was little of impressiveness in the reception by the House of the Tariff bill, which arrived in the lower branch of the Congress at noon to-day, by the hands of Clerk Cox of the Senate, who departed from his usual custom of sending a deputy to represent him.

ROME, July 5. -- The Popolo Romano says that police investigation has established the fact of the existence of a conspiracy, of which Cette was the centre, the object being to take the lives of the heads of the various European countries.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 5. -- Corean affairs occupy the greater part of the space in all the English-speaking papers brought in by the steamer Empress of China, which arrived yesterday. A writer in The Japan Herald on June 22 says;

The Middle States Regatta Association took definite action last evening on the much-discussed question of permitting college oarsmen who had competed in previous races to row in their annual events from another club. The matter aroused considerable interest, and was finally decided by vote in the negative.

ASBURY PARK, July 5. -- The practical or business end of the National Editorial Association's convention was wound up with this afternoon's session. The delegates will listen to-morrow morning to informal reports, showing what the State associations are doing. Committees will make reports in the afternoon, and miscellaneous and unfinished business will be transacted and officers for the ensuing year will be elected.

Walter Damrosch arrived from Europe on the Steamship Spree yesterday. He was in unusually good spirits, and is looking forward to a most successful season of German opera next Winter. His arrangements for opera for the coming season are almost completed and he promises a treat to the lovers of Wagner's operas.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The President, Secretary Lamont, Attorney General Olney, Postmaster General Bissell, and Gen. Schofield remained at the White House to-night until nearly 12 o'clock. Many telegrams were received and sent during the course of the evening.

Two vessels on fire at the same time in the upper bay yesterday attracted many tugs and the fireboat New-Yorker to that vicinity. One detachment of tugs swarmed around the Red D Line steamship Caracas and another grouped itself around the blazing hull of the Erie Railroad's steam lighter Dayton.

Mr. Louis Windmuller, in The Shipping and Commercial List and New-York Price Current of July 4 tells why he thinks a permanent tariff commission, the members of which should be appointed by the President, would be the best solution of the trade problem. He says:

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews announced yesterday that at his request Lieut. Commander Delehanty, United States Supervisor of the Harbor, had consented to permit the city refuse on flat scows to be unloaded at sea until changes approved by a committee of citizens can be carried out at Riker's Island.

While the stock market was exceedingly dull yesterday, prices were remarkably firm in the face of the disquieting strike news. London was a buyer of the international stocks in fair volume. The confidence displayed by the foreigners is said to be due to the firm stand taken by the Government in the labor disturbances in the West.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Acting on the decision to break the lawless features of the strike, Major Gen. Miles has been authorized by the President, through the Major General commanding the army, to bring eight additional companies of regular infantry to Chicago.

Advances have been made for a settlement out of court of the dispute between the city and the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and its associates over the title to the Desbrosses Street Ferry property. The railroad company had held undisputed possession of the property so long that when the city laid claim to it some time ago, a contest in court was challenged to settle the ownership.

Receiver Comer of the Georgia Central is in the city, having been summoned for consultation with those who have been trying to work out a plan of reorganization for the property. He reports that the fixed charges of the road for the first two years, under the plan now approaching completion, will be $1,900,000.

Atlantic City, N.J., July 5. -- A man named Hager, who says he is from Philadelphia, assaulted Col. John E. Mehres, proprietor of the Inlet Pavilion, this morning. Employes came to the proprietor's aid and turned the man over to the police. The assailant declared that he was commissioned by the Government to assassinate ex-President Harrison.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 5. -- Both Westervelt and Menefee were effective to-day, and the game was lost to New-York by errors of Richardson and Denny. The features were the brilliant fielding of Burke and Pfeffer. Attendance, 1,500. Score:

Edward Kilpatrick, a builder, of 660 West End Avenue, who, as a witness before the Lexow committee, accused ward detectives of the Old Slip Station of demanding money from him when he had contracts along the river front, appeared before President Martin of the Police Board yesterday as complainant agrainst Patrolman Calvin Nash of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, whom he accused of being insolent and impertinent.

The bill providing for rapid transit in the City of Boston has been passed by the Massachusetts Legislature and signed by Gov. Greenhalge, but it does not take effect until it has been approved by a vote of the people of the city. Mayor Matthews has sent to the Common Council an order for a special election, to be held on the 24th of the present month, for the sole purpose of taking the vote.

Senator Caffery of Louisiana promised, three or four weeks ago, to bring in an amendment to the Senate Tariff bill that should except imports of refined sugar from the general rule that the dutiable value of imported goods shall be "the actual market value or wholesale price in the principal markets of the country" from which these goods are exported.

Passengers crossing the Brooklyn Bridge early yesterday morning were attracted by a large barge, crowded with children and gay with bunting, which was being towed down the East River. The barge was the floating hospital of St. John's Guild, and the children were little invalids from the city hospitals, and sick babies from the tenement house districts having their Fourth of July celebration.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- In the House to-day on motion of Mr. Cox (Dem., Tenn.,) the bill was considered reported from the Committee on Banking and Currency, to permit States and Territories to tax greenbacks and Treasury notes as gold and silver are taxed.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 5. -- A collision took place this evening on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad in the cut near the site of the old Union Station.

The ashes of Philip Jaeger, who formerly kept a saloon in Avenue A, were thrown to the four points of the compass upon the waters of the lower bay shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning by a party of friends who were out on a fishing excursion.

Chief Inspector Doty of the Division of Contagious Diseases of the Board of Health was called in consultation with officials of the Staten Island Health Department at Edgewater Wednesday to devise means for fighting the smallpox outbreak on the island.

It is quite impracticable to determine how fast the House of Representatives will move in deciding on the differences between it and the Senate. Much will depend, to start with, on the conferrees named by Speaker Crisp. It is of a piece with the whole work of the Senate that seven conferrees were named by that body.

Much mystery was made at Police Headquarters yesterday over the finding of what looks to be a cartridge or projectile of the kind used in rapid-fire military guns, but which was spoken of as a "bomb." The thing is about six inches long and two inches thick. Its conical point is of polished steel.
Ex-Police Commissioner Joel W. Mason died yesterday at Hunter, in the Catskill Mountains, from general debility.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 5. -- In response to the 20,000 bulletins sent out to the road associations, wheelmen, and editors throughout the country by the United States Department of Agriculture, the delegates to the Good Roads Convention met in Asbury Park this morning at the Westminster Presbyterian Church.

The annual meet of the Riverside Wheelmen, to be held at Manhattan Field to-morrow, promises to be one of the leading local bicycle events of the season. In the novice race The NewYork Times has offered as a prize a handsome gold medal. All the youthful aspirants for cycling honors in this vicinity have entered, and the race ought to be an exciting one.

School Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer has bought of Joseph C. Hoagland the three six-story business buildings 9, 11, and 13 Walker Street, 62 by 107 feet, on private terms. The property rents for about $14.000.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 5. -- The railroad strike has about completely shut off the Chicago mails from Buffalo. Only a few bags are coming in over the Michigan Central, while a large amount of mall matter lies in abandoned trains in Chicago suburbs.

The county farm at St. Johnland has been the cause of much contention in the Kings County Board of Supervisors, and again at the meeting yesterday the county farm was the cause of considerable debate, in which Supervisor Shaw of the Ninth Ward called Supervisor Donovan to account for casting slurs upon the members.

The blustering talk in which the autocratic Debs indulged on the Fourth of July, about civil war and caring nothing for injunctions and indictments, clearly showed that that preposterous person had lost his head. If he is not too selfsufficient to take legal advice, it will be well for him to consult somebody who knows what resistance to the authority of the United States means.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 5. -- The last of the regular drills for the present detail of troops in camp was held to-day, as the ceremony of advance guard will be performed by all the available men of the Sixty-seventh and Eighth Battalions to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The special House committee investigating the alleged armor frauds to-day examined General Superintendent Schwab of the Carnegie Company. Mr. Schwab said his instructions to the Superintendents were that they should make the very best armor plates, regardless of expense.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The greater part of the day's session was occupied in the further consideration of the bill to permit States and Territories to tax greenbacks and Treasury notes. The bill was passed in an amended form, the vote being 173 to 41.
Dwellers in that classic precinct of South Brooklyn round about Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue are greatly perturbed and immeasurably indignant at the recent wholesale poisoning of their poultry.

The death of Robert L. Darragh, a wealthy builder, having cut short the proceedings to have him declared insane instituted by his children, they will now devote their attention to an attempt to break their father's will. When the will was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday, objections were also filed.

MANCHESTER, N.H., July 6. -- Miss Mary Fay, twenty-eight years old, a novice in St. Mary's Convent, was forcibly abducted from the convent yesterday by her brother, Peter A. Fay, a well-known lawyer of Lowell, Mass. Mr. Fay went to the convent and asked to see his sister, saying that her mother was very ill, and that she must go with him at once.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 6. -- The National Council of Education, made up of sixty prominent educators of the country, elected for six years by the National Educational Association, met in annual conference in the First Presbyterian Church, this morning.

Superintendent Byrnes means to have no nonsense in case the strike shall extend to this city. All policemen on vacation have been ordered back to duty, and Captains have been directed to see that each man of their respective commands carries a 38calibre revoler. The men showed their revolvers last night, and those who had smaller calibre than 38 were ordered to get new ones at once.

East Weymouth, Mass., July 6. -- An attempt was made this morning to burn the residence of Marshall C. Dizer, senior member of the firm of M.C. Dizer Co., shoe manufacturers. The fire was discovered in season to prevent much damage. It was set in the rear of the house, where the woodwork had been soared with kerosene. There has been some labor trouble at Mr. Dizer's factory lately.
(N.Y. Press.) It is not often that science makes a discovery that demands special investigation on the part of the newspapers. Once in a while it does, however, such as occurred in New-York recently.

Bridget Quinn is in Bellevue Hospital, her three-year-old son John is in charge of the Sisters of Mercy, her baby daughter Annie has been sent to Randall's Island, and all, so says her sister Sarah Vinnard, because of the supernatural powers of Mme. Tizzie, a singer at Eldorado, who is a spiritualist.

BOSTON, Mass., July 6. -- The races at the Saugus race track to-day lacked the vim and snap that characterized the events of the first of the week. The unfinished contest resolved itself into a race for second money. The chestnut mare Lady Logan, in the opinion of many, was in second position, but the judges saw otherwise, and the little stallion Doune was awarded the position, which carried with it the second money.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 6. -- W. H. Clopton, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Missouri, this morning petitioned Judge Thayer of the United States Circuit Court to grant an omnibus injunction covering seventeen railways in this city. Judge Thayer granted the injunction, to take effect at once.
Among the letters received by Erastus Wiman at the Tombs yesterday was one from a wealthy friend in Chicago, who wrote as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6. -- The strikers at the Oakland yards and along the mole and on the narrow-guage lines effectually maintain the railway blockade on all lines running down the mole. Whenever the strikers find a live engine they take possession of it, rake the fires, blow off the steam, and leave it dead on the tracks.

The London Standard's Shanghai correspondent quotes a report from the district of Hsing Knochow, in the neighboring provvinve of Anhui, where there are extensive coal workings. A party of miners recently Struck an ancient shaft, where history records that a great catastrophe occurred 400 years ago, the records being preserved among the local archives.

From The Indianapolis Sentinel. It is one thing to get a good servant and another to keep her. A lady living on North Pennsylvania Street was amazed to have a strange lady ring the bell and inquire if her servant was at home.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 6. -- Receiver S.R. Callaway of the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Railway surprised the strikers on that system this morning by fighting fire with fire. The men sent him a telegram last night to the effect that they would strike this morning at 6 o'clock by order of the American Railway Union.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The request made by Mayor Hopkins of Chicago upon Gov. Altgeld for troops to preserve order in that city has silenced some of the men here who were disposed to uphold the opinions of the Illinois Governor and permit the disorders in his State to develop greater

GLASGOW, July 6. -- The Vigilant and the Britannia will race to-morrow for the Queen's Cup in the contests of the Clyde regatta. Capt. Haff will steer the Vigilant and Carter the Britannia. The Vigilant will also sail in the races to be contested on the Clyde July 9, 10, and 11.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 8. -- The dalegates to the National Good Roads Convention assembled in the Westminster Presbyterian Church this morning at 9:30 for the second day's session of the meeting.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- A mob of about 500 people has held almost complete sway in the territory, including the towns of Kensington, Burnside, Fordham, and Grand Crossing, on the outskirts of the city along the Illinois Central tracks, since 8 o'clock this morning.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The town of Pullman is guarded to-night by a company of the State militia, in anticipation of an attack by the mob. The sky is lighted up with the glare of the flames from 2,000 or more freight cars that are burning in the Eldson yards on the Grand Trunk Road.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Two hundred and twenty-five freight cars on the Pan Handle tracks, between Forty-fifth and Fifty-ninth Streets, a distance of about one mile, were destroyed by fire between the hours of 6 and 8 o'clock to-night.

The Bed D Line steamship Caracas, which came into port on fire Thursday, was towed yesterday to the dock of the Anglo-American Warehouse, in the Erie Basin, where her cargo is being discharged. The steamship is not seriously damaged, but Mr. Bliss, one of her agents said that the cargo would probably be a total loss.

From The Williamsport (Penn.) Sun, (Dem.) That Mr. Singerly should be willing to lay aside his large business interests to take up the standard of Democracy and lead the party of tariff reform, in the face of the overwhelming majorities the Republican Party has rolled up in Pennsylvania for the past two years, is a concession to principle that should and doubtless will enlist the admiration and support of the voters of the State.

It is necessary to remind Mr. Egan, General Manager of the Railway Managers' Association, that the views he has expressed of the relation of the railroads to the strike are wrong and altogether unsound in law.

President William P. Thompson or the National Lead Company passed several hours at the Custom House yesterday with Deputy Collector Phelps. He went there upon summons to answer a complaint filed against his company by George Bruce, a discharged clerk.

BOSTON, July 6. -- The loading and sailing of the ocean freighters will be seriously interfered with this month on account of the great railway strike, producing an almost complete stoppage of cattle and grain shipments.

Rey El Santa Anita, the crack Western colt, winner of the American Derby and the Sheridan Stakes, arrived at Sheepshead Bay yesterday afternoon in good condition for the Realization Stakes to-day. Many of the visitors to the track went to the stable to take a look at the horse, and during the afternoon his chances with Senator Grady and Dobbins were discussed at length.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- A large number of telegrams have been received by the Superintendent of the Railway Mail Service from the various Division Superintendents in the West. Superintendent Troy, at Chicago, telegraphs that there is no blockade at Fort Wayne, Ind. The Marion and Chicago train on the Big Four has been held on the road.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 6. -- It seemed like tempting fate to-day. Thirteen of the Atlantic yachts entered in the race from Morris Cove to this port; the day was Friday, a day of ill omen to all sailors; the Water Witch was the thirteenth boat to cross the line, and the Ventura carried the number 65 on her mainsail, a multiple of 13.
In consequence of the strikes the West Shore Railroad Company has stopped selling tickets from this city to any point further west than Buffalo.

Messrs. Joseph Beck Co. have bought the property at the northeast corner of West Broadway and Walker Street, 50 by 75, with old buildings, at $72,500. Their intention is to erect a modern business structure on the site at the expiration of the present leases. The property rents for about $4,900.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 6. -- As soon as the Constitutional Convention was called to order this morning, Mr. Moore called up his resolution providing that after July 15 the convention shall sit on Mondays and Saturdays as well as on the regular days. The resolution was lost by a large majority.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Tariff bill is in the Ways and Means Committee, and tomorrow, if the programme of the majority should be carried out, it will be reported to the House and speedily go to the conferrees.

Commissioner Frederick W. Wurster of the Brooklyn Fire Department did not object to the firemen under his authority voluntarily contributing small amounts to pay for a silver service to be presented to Assemblyman Frank Schulz in recognition of his services in aiding the passage of the Firemen's Pension bill.

There was little marked change in the railway situation yesterday. A good deal of rioting took place in scattered parts of Chicago, and there was some serious destruction of property. Gen. Miles is evidently not yet prepared to take entire control of the work of restoring order. The Mayor has given orders for the prevention and dispersing of mobs by the police, which, if carried out, will relieve the pressure on the roads.

W.R. Laidlaw, who obtained a Judgment for $25,000 against Russell Sage last November for injuries received when he was made a buffer for the millionaire at the time of the Norcross bomb throwing in Mr. Sage's office, is considering another suit against Mr. Sage. Slander is his present grievance.

LONDON, July 6. -- The final races of the Henley regatta, were rowed to-day. The final heat for the Grand Challenge Plate was won by the eight of the Leander Club, beating the Thames Rowing Club's boat by half a length. The final heat in the pair-oared race for the Silver Goblets was won by the brothers Guy and Vivian Nickalls, who beat J. Crisp and G. Smith of the Kingston Rowing Club easily.

The Board of Street Opening yesterday considered an application to widen Lexington Avenue fifty feet on the westerly side between One Hundred and Twenty-eighth and One Hundred and Thirtieth Streets. Thomas Allison, William O. Campbell, and Postmaster Dayton appeared for the application. William H. Payne was the only one who appeared in opposition.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 6. -- "If the situation does not change within the next twenevery road leading into Buffalo." This was ty-four hours, look for a complete tie-up on said to-day by a Lehigh official.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 6. -- A heavy electrical storm broke over this city to-day. It lasted from 9:30 A.M. until 1 P.M., and in that time the rainfall, according to the Signal Service observer, was 1.84 inches. The downpour was most severe from 12 to 1 o'clock, when over an inch of rain fell.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Since Senator Hill voted against the passage of the Tariff bill there has been a good deal of private condemnation of him among his Democratic associates, and the language of the criticisms has become more heated and superlative from day to day.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 6. -- Wonderful riding was seen to-day at the Fort Wayne race meeting, when Lee Richardson, a thirteen-yearold Chicago lad, covered a half mile in 2:43 1-5, riding his safety backward. This is an unparallelpd feat, and it is the first time it has ever been performed in public. Richardson, though only thirteen, has ridden nine years, but never in public.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 6. -- Richard Lennox, alias R.E. Goodwin, alias H.L. Leonard, who is wanted in Milwaukee, Wls., for defrauding two banks of $35,000, was arrested at Absecon this morning, where he had a farm. He made a hard fight for his liberty and drew a revolver, but was quickly disarmed and brought to this city.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- A second telegram from Gov. Altgeld to the President reached the White House near the hour of midnight. It came over the private wire, and its contents were carefully read. Then the President dictated the following reply:

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 6. -- "Social Transformation" was discussed this afternoon by Prof. Bernhard Moses of the University of California. It was a discussion of the tendency of the times toward Socialism, and the opinion of a political economist on such tendency.
"One of the most prominent characteristics of Satan is tact," said Miss Emma Field at the Professional Women's League yesterday afternoon.

Henry R. Averill, a member of the Crescent Athletic Club and the Atlantic Yacht Club, and who was reported to be wealthy, committed suicide shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon by jumping from the Wall Street ferryboat Columbia while it was on its way from New-York to Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Holiday making having proved, very agreeable after the strain incident to the discussion and passage of the Tariff bill, the Senate only remained in session an hour to-day and then adjourned until Monday, when it is expected that it will settle down to business again, with one of the appropriation bills -- probably the Pension bill -- the principal basis of action.

What a treacherous load the Republican Party is carrying in its alliance with the American Protective Association, and how fatal this alliance must prove in the end, despite any temporary advantage that may be gained, is made very clear by Prof. John Bach McMaster, the distinguished historian, in the current number of The Forum.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- General Master Workman Sovereign of the Knights of Labor arrived here to-day from Omaha and went to the headquarters of the American Railway Union, where he went into conference with President Debs, Vice President Howard, and their associate Directors. The Situation was thoroughly canvassed, and Sovereign agreed to issue a general strike call to the Knights whenever a request to that end was presented.
"Baby carriages; as many of them as possible. There cannot be too many." This is one of the needs of the Tenement House Chapter of the King's Daughters and Sons that might seem to be easily supplied.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6. -- The Reconstruction Committee of the Western New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad has been advised that the Holland stockholders, representing 90,000 shares out of a total of 117,000 shares, had assented to the plan of reorganization and paid their assessments. Funded obligations of the company on June 30, 1893, were $34,976,826.
A depot for the sale of sterilized milk by the glass was opened near the park fountain in City Hall Park by Nathan Straus yesterday afternoon. The milk is sold at one penny a glass.

The United States Local Inspectors of Steam Vessels, Who have been investigating the foundering of the tug Nicol, by which about forty people lost their lives, yesterday filed their report with the Supervisor. The Inspectors find that the pilot, John C. Hyde, was guilty of negligence, and that he willfully violated the law in allowing his vessel to be overloaded.

A cool breeze meets one in the marblelined corridors of the Fine Arts Building on West Fifty-seventh Street as one penetrates to the galleries in which hangs the Group Exhibition of American Paintings. The order and general arrangement of the pictures have been somewhat changed since the day of opening, as regards groups of work by certain artists; but for the most part the collection is the same.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 6. -- The meeting of local railway men to consider the question of striking lasted until nearly daybreak this morning, and ended in a practically unanimous decision to go out. Committees were sent to the various yards to inform the men of the action taken and to notify them to quit work at 6 A.M.

The complaints against the method of laying asphalt walks in Central Park on account of their wearing out so quickly and leaving a rough walk or round pebbles very uncomfortable to walk on for persons with thin shoes have caused a comparison to be made with walks in Brooklyn parks.

BOSTON, July 6. -- It was the dullest day of the week in the Boston market. What little market there was showed a fair amount of strength. Boston United Gas seconds advanced 1/4, to 61 1/2. American Bell Telephone receded 3/4, to 198. West End Land rights were firm at 87-16, while the stock sold at 1 7/8.

From The Chicago Herald. WARSAW, Ind., July 2. -- B. W. Blanchard of the Mentone Stock Farm, who mysteriously disappeared eight years ago, has returned. William J. Studon was arrested for his murder, and, as the circumstantial evidence was strong against him, his mind became deranged and he committed suicide in the county jail while awaiting trial.

ASBURY PARK, July 6. -- Those delegates who have never experienced the sensation of an ocean breeze and who have been longing for one had their longing gratified this morning, when, for the first time within two weeks, the wind came out of the southeast heavy, strong, and damp, forcing the unacclimated men to topcoats and the women to wraps.

Great preparations have been made to receive an exceptionally large crowd at the Riverside Wheelmen's fourth annual race meet to be held at Manhattan Field this afternoon. There are 170 entries, and as the track has been overhauled since the Greenwich Wheelmen's meet, there is no reason why several records should not be broken.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Frye's "Industrials," who lately moved their camp from Highlands, Md., to the vicinity of Rosslyn, a little village across the river on Old Dominion soil, were visited yesterday by Capt. Mushback of the Alexandria Guards and ordered to get out of Virginia. Frye ignored the order, although Capt. Mushback threatened him with the bayonet.

ALBANY, July 6. -- The second day's session of the Regents' Convocation opened this morning with a much larger attendance than yesterday. The morning session was mainly devoted to a discussion of the report on secondary school studies by the committee of ten which was appointed by the National Education Association in 1892.

LONDON, July 6. -- In the House of Lords to-day the Marquis of Salisbury introduced a bill in regard to alien paupers, giving the Government powers to control immigration similar to those passed by the Government of the United States. The bill also deals with Anarchists. England, Lord Salisbury said, appeared to be the ground upon which Anarchistic plots were hatched.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Commissioner of Indain Affairs has received information from Capt. W.H. Clapp, the Acting Indian Agent at the Fort Berthold Agency in North Dakota, of the arrival of the l remnant of the followers of Sitting Bull, who fled into the British possesssions after the Custer massacre in 1876.

Commenting upon Commander Sturdee's Naval Prize Essay, which formed the subject of debate before the Royal United Service Institution, The Naval and Military Record (British) says that in some respects the essay is one of the most important contributions to the science of modern naval tactics that has been penned for many years past.

No doubt many persons wonder why the military at Chicago have not made short work of the mobs. The fact probably is that the officers in command of the United States troops have been exercising the greatest possible forbearance because they are aware that the street-riot drill of the new tactics, if put into operation, would result in certain death or injury to a great many men.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
ALBANY, July 6. -- In the Constitutional Convention to-day Mr. Towns (Dem., Kings,) offered the following resolution:
The funeral of ex-Alderman James McGarry will take place from St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, Hoyt and Sackett Streets, Brooklyn, this morning.

PITTSBURG, July 6. -- A large and enthusiastic meeting of railroad employes of this vicinity was held at Lafayette Hall to-night. Organizer Naylor explained the object of the American Railway Union. He advised the employes of all roads, regardless of what organized body they belonged to, that when the strike reached this vicinity they should take a week's vacation and join their brethren in this fight against the General Managers' Association and Pullman.

When Eugene V. Debs, a private citizen of Indiana, undertook to lay an embargo upon the railroad traffic of this country by inciting the employes of all the lines centring in Chicago not only to quit work but to prevent the operation of trains, in defiance of law and public authority, he entered upon a desperate and dangerous game.

The Aldermanic Committee on Water and Drainage met in the Brooklyn City Hall last evening to consider the requisition of Commissioner White of the City Works Department for $2,081,000 to extend the water system of Brooklyn.

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews issued a notice yesterday that he was prepared to receive applications for permits for the temporary occupancy of portions of the streets in this city from 4 o'clock P.M. to 8 A.M. on week days, and throughout Sundays and legal holidays, by licensed trucks or other vehicles (to which horses are not attached) owned by residents of this city who have the consent of the owner or lessee of the abutting property.

"If any one tells you that meat is neither scarce nor very dear in the New-York markets, he tells what is not so," said John J. Cunningham of Cunningham Brothers, beef, lamb, and mutton commission merchants, at 104 Barclay Street, yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times.

Justice Bartlett of the Supreme Court, sitting in Brooklyn, has rendered an opinion regarding fire-insurance policies which is of great importance to those taking out policies on their houses and furniture.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Attorney General Olney, being asked this morning by a United Press reporter as to the legal aspect of Gov. Altgeld's position, replied with much deliberation:

The history of this remarkable ware is exceedingly curious. In the first place, it was manufactured between the years 1540 and 1560, probably in Touraine. In the second place, its existence was quite forgotten until 1839, when M. Andre Pottier first announced it to the world. When one piece had been discovered others naturally turned up, but only about fifty examples have been found, and of these the majority are in England.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., July 7. -- The week at Shelter Island has been a gay one. The crowds who came here from the heat of the metropolis to breathe the pure fresh air and enjoy themselves have had a pleasant time. Deering Harbor, the home of the Shelter Island Yacht Club, has been a lively place.

In a situation so appalling as that created by the recklessness of Debs it is a great satisfaction to note even a single hopeful sign that the American workingman is growing in wisdom. Solid grounds for this satisfaction are afforded by the attitude the old-line brotherhoods have taken toward Debs's American Railway Union and its strike.

From The Boston Transcript, (Ind. Rep.) Thank heaven! we have a President who knows neither fear nor favor -- the antipodes of the late James Buchanan. The action of President Cleveland, Attorney General Olney, and of the United States courts is heartily indorsed by all good citizens, whoever they may be. It is necessary to stamp out mobbism, under whatever disguise it may pose as the protector of labor.
MONTREAL, July 7. -- The following is an extract from a private letter from Erastus Wiman, written in the Tombs, City Prison, New-York:

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 7. -- St. Lawrence breezes seldom indicate that the mercury is up in the nineties in the big cities, but the hotel men here have a way of finding out what the atmospheric conditions are away from home without consulting the Weather Bureau. When the mercury goes up their receipts keep pace with it.

ORANGE, N.J., July 7. -- The people of the Oranges are proud, and justly so, of their representatives in the National Guard of the State. There are three military companies in the Oranges and vicinity, composing the Third Battalion, with headquarters in the armory at William and Centre Streets.

In these large volumes Miss Simcox (we understand it is Miss) endeavors to enable "the economic student to utilize the crumbs that have fallen already from the explorer's table." She has collected all the fragments from the original documents.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7. -- Mrs. F.W. Vanderbilt and Mrs. W. Fitzhugh Whitehouse have large dinner parties to-night. Miss Gammell gave a brilliant young ladies' luncheon to-day. Mrs. Charles A. Whitney of New-Orleans to-day rented the Corry cottage, Bath Road. A brilliant hop took place at Leland's Ocean House to-night.

Last evening ended another prosperous week of the Summer engagement of the famous Hagenbeck trained animals, in the new arena at Manhattan Beach. The audiences have been large, and are steadily increasing. On the Fourth of July the big arena was packed, while 3,000 persons visited the menagerie, where the animals which take part in the exhibition, together with some two hundred and fifty monkeys, in the immense monkey paradise cage, are on view.

While the outward surface of affairs on the railroads of New-York State appears calm, and the officers of the roads express confidence In their men, the police and other authorities in this city believe that a strike may be declared either to-morrow or next day. In fact, they have received assurances from well-informed sources that a strike has been contemplated for several days.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Vice President Wickes of the Pullman Company will meet a committee representing the Pullman strikers by appointment to-morrow at noon in his office at the Pullman Building to discuss the differences between the company and the strikers, independently of the American Railway Union.

The dominant feeling in Wall Street is one of wonder -- wonder how the stock market keeps up in the face of the news. Nothing is doing; the fluctuations in the prices of railroad stocks have been insignificant; not more than the room traders Would make from their dealings on the daily gossip which comes six days out of seven.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- For the twenty-four hours ending at midnight there were sixtytwo fire-alarm calls from burning railroad property, nearly all being on the South Side. This is a remarkable record, according to Chief Sweenie. Several times railroad shops were fired.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 7. -- Nothing is being done in local yards except the movement of live stock and perishable freights by yard masters and officials. A mass meeting was held this afternoon at which an Executive Committee was appointed. The strike will be placed entirely in the hands of that committee, and the strikers will act under orders issued from it.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 7. -- No spot on the north shore of Long Island can rival Oyster Bay in natural attractions or in the number of handsome Summer homes. It has won a warm place in the affections of yachtsmen. As a result, stately residences adorn the shore front, while graceful craft lie either at anchor or glide through the waters of the bay and Cold Spring Harbor beyond.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- In a neglected corner of a stoneyard in F Street, in this city, stands a small cube of granite, one of Whose faces bears this inscription:

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The discussion at to-day's session of the House Committee on Pacific Railroads showed wide divergence of opinion among the members as to the better plan of securing a settlement of the Central and Union Pacific indebtedness to the Government. The suggestion was advanced that, since the bonds do not wholly mature until four years hence, it might be better to postpone consideration of the matter indefinitely.

Col. Seward of the Ninth Regiment, having been reprimanded by the Adjutant General and restored to command of his regiment, went with to the State Camp of Instruction, at Peekskill yesterday. It appears that the penalty inflicted upon Col. Seward has not given universal satisfaction. There were those who hoped that he would be dismissed from the service. They could not see how he was to escape being cashiered for disobedience of orders.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Carl Browne started on foot with seventy Coxey tramps for New-York City last night.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Major General Schofield said this morning that all the available troops were ready to move at a moment's notice if their presence was deemed necessary in Chicago and elsewhere, and he estimated that 2,000 more regulars could be put into that city within twenty-four hours.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 7. -- The last session of the Regents' Convention was held today. Bishop Doane of Albany presided. Prof. George P. Bristol of Cornell read a paper on "Can Sufficient Greek to Satisfy Reasonable Requirements for Entrance Examinations be Taught in Two Years in the Secondary Schools?"

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Mr. John Wanamaker, the last Postmaster General, will undoubtedly derive satisfaction from the fact that the Post Office Department has decided that the designs of the ordinary postage stamps which he adopted shall remain practically unchanged in the present fiscal year.

A Paris journal has been interviewing M. Bartholdi concerning reports from New-York that his Liberty Enlightening the World is in bad case, the rumor having been spread that it is in a really dangerous condition. According to the cable, the sculptor has pooh-poohed the story and laid it to the intrigues of people who wish to make something by having a commission given them to repair it.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Police officers guarding the Northwestern freight yards at Sixteenth Street and Ashland Avenue, adjoining the Burlington tracks, engaged in a hand-to-hand conflict with rioters at 8 o'clock this evening.

DEAL BEACH, N.J., July 7. -- Business and good times, too, have taken a great spurt down here this week. The hotel is well filled and all the cottagers have arrived. By necessity there has, as a result, been a good deal going on. Surf bathing has easily had the call. The beach at Deal is in excellent shape this year, and a number of new bathhouses have been erected.

The statement of President J. Edward Swanstrom of the Brooklyn Board of Education that the public school children of Brooklyn are overburdened with books and have more studies than they can intelligently cope with, has aroused the deepest interest in the City of Churches.

ASBURT PARK, N.J., July 7. -- The second day's session of the National Council of Education, held this morning in the First Presbyterian Church, was largely attended. E.E. White of Columbus, Ohio, E.C. Hewitt and John W. Cook of Normal, Ill., and others paid glowing tributes to the memory of those council members who had died during the past year.

The editors of New-York State had a great day yesterday, one that many of them will remember for a long time to come.

TROY, N.Y., July 7. -- Of the twelve members of the jury which convicted "Bat " Shea of murder, two are living in this city, and since the trial they have been the objects of much ill feeling. Onesime Beihumer, while on his way from work last night, was stoned by a gang of hoodlums, and is now under protection of a detective.

In this yard the stables are variously arranged. In one each "stud" was cut off from its neighbors; in others two studs were standing in rows together. A "stud" is assigned to each 'bus, and consists of five pairs. Of these four pairs are out each day, the fifth pair resting, unless some accident should entail a call upon their services.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 7. -- A steady stream of Summer people has poured into town and the cottages are full and the hotels are looking livelier, especially since the Fourth. The proprietors predict a good season, far better than they expected in the Spring. The applications for rooms have come in very fast for the past few weeks, and August will see many of the houses crowded.

Tuesday, July 10. -- By James S. McQuillen of D. Phoenix Ingraham Co., foreclosure sale, Lawrence Godkin, referee, 6 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, south side, 110 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 25 by 100.11 by irregular, five- story brick flat, with store. Due on judgment, $19,670.

LONDON, July 7. -- The steamer Alecto, Which sailed from New-York for London June 24, passed Portland Bill this morning. She sailed from New-York on the day that the tug James D. Nicol foundered off Sandy Hook, and it was hoped that she had picked up some of the missing excursionists, but in answer to signals she reported that she had not.

Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times. LONDON, July 7. -- The lapse of a week has served to confirm everybody's original impression about the new French President. Those who admired in him a Strong, self-poised, vigorous Executive, extremely conscious of his powers and resolute to let none of them rust in disuse, like him now better than ever.

SHELTER ISLAND, July 7. -- The contest for the Sanford Cup is the most important race during the cruise of the Atlantic Yacht Club. Each year Vice Commodore Philip G. Sanford offers this prize for all classes of sloops, and the race is held on the run from New-London to Shelter Island. This year eleven sloops raced for this trophy, and in another class three schooners raced for the honor of winning.

KENSINGTON, Ill., July 7. -- Pullman has been as an armed camp all day, and to-night the guard from Grand Crossing to One Hundred and Tenth Street has been increased. The Second Battalion of the First Regiment is in a position to repel rioters at any and all points along the two miles of Illinois Central tracks.

Funeral services over the body of exAlderman James McGarry were held in St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, Hoyt and Sackett Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. The church was crowded with the relatives and friends of the family and prominent Democratic politicians of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The record of target practice in the navy of ships in commission for the quarter ending March 31 has just been completed. In the main battery firing, stationary practice, the Monocacy leads with 62 as an average merit of each shot, and the Portsmouth with 36 and the Alliance with 13 follow.
It was a relative of the grandfather of Casimir-Perier, President of the French Republic, who founded in America the Society of the Sisters of the Sacred-Heart.

LENOX, Mass., July 7. -- The centre of attraction this week has been the Mahkeenac Lake Club boathouse. This has been the coolest place in Lenox, and the cottagers and their guests have assembled there, and had teas and a row or a sail on the lake.

A literary pursuit may have given embellishment to them, but they represent the characteristics of hardy men and women who live along the Maine coast.

For the consideration of $10.000, Eva Mann-Brill-Steele-Gaul-Hamilton has relinquished her claim to the estate of Robert Ray Hamilton, whom, it is alleged, she enticed into marrying her by means of a bogus baby which was palmed off on him.
Wheat made an advance of 8/8@ 1/2c, on better Western markets and local covering, with a light trade.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., July 7. -- At 7 o'clock to-night the steamer Falcon sailed for Bowdoin Bay, West Greenland, with the Peary auxiliary expedition, consisting of Henry Bryant, Prof. Libbey, Prof. Chamberlain, Dr. Ohlin, Dr. Witherill, Emll Drebitsch, and W.W. Bridgman. The Falcon was heavily laden, carrying 300 tons of coal and a year's provisions.

William J. Broadwell, a stock broker, who has an office at 7 New Street, is in Ludlow Street Jail under an order of Judge Gildersleeve of the Superior Court, in default of $25,000 bail, in an action by Ebenezer A. Kinsey to recover $45,279.51, which he declares the broker has converted to his own use.

In an interview with a representative of Harper's Bazar, Mr. W.D. Howells, who stands perhaps more than any other writer for the traditionally feminine woman, gives some interesting opinions concerning his attitude toward universal suffrage. After stating that both Mrs. Howells and he had "been rather opposed to the idea of women entering the political arena," he admits their complete, conversion by the young poet, the late George Pellew.

BERLIN, July 7. -- Chancellor von Caprtvi received from London last evening a number of special telegrams on the subject of Lord Salisbury's anti-Anarchist bill. These telegrams the Chancellor at once transmitted to the Emperor. It is surmised that some understanding has existed with Lord Salisbury in regard to the proposal, which, it is assumed, was designed to elicit an expression of public opinion in England.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Representative Marcus C. Lisle of Kentucky died at his home at Winchester, Ky., last night.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- At 11:30 to-night Senator Shoup of Idaho came to the White House with a dispatch he had just received from Gov. McConnell of Idaho, announcing that the Bunker Hill and Sullivan quartz mills at the Coeur d'Alene mines, at Wallace, had been blown up. The dispatch said the authorities are unable to cope with the trouble, and called upon the President for troops.

July, more than any other month in, the year, has been the time for riots and revolutions. Beginning with our own Declaration of Independence, July 4, 1776, we find also the French Revolution beginning in July, for on the 14th of July, 1789, the Bastile, that infamous Paris prison, was destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7. -- John W. Hayes, Secretary-Treasurer of the Knights of Labor, left Philadelphia this morning for Elberon, N.J., where, in company with a delegation of Chicago business men, he will endeavor to induce Mr. Pullman to take some action looking to a settlement of the strike.

From The London Telegraph. Strange things often happen at low-life weddings in Paris, and, as in a well-known farce, the bride and bridegroom, with their friends, sometimes finish up their festivities in a police station. A journeyman carriage builder married the woman of his choice on Saturday morning, and the wedding breakfast took place in a restaurant on the Avenue de la Grande Armee.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 7. -- An adjourned meeting of the gentlemen interested in the formation of a State Bankers' Association was held in this city this morning.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 7. -- This delightful resort has again settled down for a prosperous season, and the outlook was never more encouraging. The Prospect House is rapidly filling up with guests, and within a few days more the season will be at its gayest.

That unique midsummer excursion to the arctic, which was planned by Dr. Cook, and which is likely to prove a profitable as well as a pleasant trip to the scientists and sportsmen who form a part of it, was started yesterday on its way to polar seas.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 7. -- The members of the third week's detail were paid off this morning, and at the sound of the general call at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon the companies broke camp and were soon on the road to Roa Hook, where the troops embarked on the trains for home.

DECATUR, Ill., July 7. -- The Wabash is gradually resuming passenger traffic, and sent out trains to-day. There were thirty men imported here to act as Deputy Sheriffs. To-day these deputies were sworn in as United States Deputy Marshals. Two companies of State militia are still here. There is no trouble at all; the strikers are behaving admirably.

The wealthy men of New-York are ever coming to the front with aid that young men may attain a collegiate training to prepare them the better for the battle of life. Recently there may have been seen an interesting sight at the Teachers' College, in University Place. Over 150 boys, graduated this year from the grammar schools of the city, were busily at work in the various rooms of the college building.

BALLSTON, N.Y., July 7. -- Hezekiah Whittaker of Batchellervllle has been arrested on complaint of John H. Burke, State Forest Inspector, charged with grand larceny in the second degree committed in cutting about 300 market spruce logs from trees in State lands in the town of Providence. Whlttaker was committed to the County Jail.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., July 7. -- Normandie has lost none of its old-time popularity. The hotel is nearly filled even at this early date. The Fourth was, of course, patriotically celebrated with plenty of fireworks.

A daring highway robbery was committed on Fourth of July night at the corner of Houston and Mulberry Streets, within the shadow of Police Headquarters. Emil Lick, a member of the Liliputian company of actors, was knocked down and robbed of his gold watch by three footpads, who escaped. Lick reported his loss at Police Headquarters yesterday.

Joy and hope have been stirred up in the breasts of the Brooklyn patrons of the prize ring by the decision of Supreme Court Justice William J. Gaynor directing Mayor Schieren to issue a license to the Seaside Athletic Club for boxing matches at Coney Island.

From The Washington Post, June 30. Ex-Secretary of State John W. Foster and Mrs. Foster returned to Washington yesterday afternoon after an absence of almost a year. Mr. Foster's mission abroad was primarily to represent the United States in the Bering Sea arbitration at Paris.

There is nothing particularly enticing in the sound of "mud baths," and those who have tried them at Homburg and other places find them not agreeable as experiences, however efficacious they may be as a treatment. At most spas the process is simply that of pouring mud into one's bath, but at some Italian baths to which the fashionably sick are turning, a traveler who has taken them finds that they are quite different.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 7. -- The fifth annual parade and review of the battalion of youngsters summering at Asbury Park and Ocean Grove was the attraction this afternoon on the Board Walk. The muster of infantry, while not equaling in numbers last Summer's parade and review, excelled all former efforts in several particulars.

The anti-Catholic proscriptionists have been very busy during the last few weeks in Brooklyn, where they boast of four or five well-organized councils, and a membership of a thousand or more ecclesiastical bigots.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- After many months of labor upon it, the Tariff bill is now in conference. Before many days the conferrees will have succeeded in reaching a partial agreement, and probably before the end of another week the different conferences will have enabled the two houses of Congress to vote upon the bill that has been finally accepted by the respective committees.

From The Westminster Gazette. Rewi Maniapoto, whose death was reported on Saturday, was almost the last of the great chiefs of the Maoris. He was born in 1807, and was a warrior and leader in council among the Ngatimaniapotos from his youth. His earliest years were passed amid savage scenes of inter-tribal strife, ambuscades, fierce hand-to-hand battles, massacres, and cannibal orgies.

JERSEY CITY, July 7. -- Mrs, Adelaide Pooley and Miss Carrie Worth, the latter a very pretty girl, whose home is in Port Jervis, were arraigned before Justice Potts this morning for keeping a disorderly house, known as the Old Homestead, at Fourth and Monmouth Streets. The complaint was made by Arthur Doison of Ridgewood, N.J., who said he acted, at the instigation of the Rev. John L. Scudder.

To strike or not to strike will be the question decided this afternoon by a number of labor organizations in this city. A conference was held last night at 84 East Fourth Street between leaders of the American Federation of Labor, at which addresses were delivered by Charies B. Stover, President of the Chadwick Civic Club, and Daniel Harris, President of the State Branch of the American Federation of Labor.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 7. -- The pretty clubhouse and grounds of the Hillside Tennis Club were thronged with society people Wednesday afternoon. Tea was served from 4 to 6 on the grassy lawn between the clubhouse and tennis courts. There was an invitation tournament played, and it was watched with much interest.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., July 7. -- The hot weather has driven the city people to Cottage City with a rush. Four times a day the boat unloads the crowds. The hotel keepers are confident of a busier season than last. About half of the cottagers are here.

FIRE ISLAND, July 7. -- After being closed to the general public for two years, the Surf Hotel opened a few days ago, and already this place, famous for nearly a quarter of a century as a seaside resort, is beginning to take on the old look of life and gayety so familiar in the days when the hotel was conducted by D.S. Sammis.

Down on Beekman Street recently there has been a pushcart filled with straw hats, whose price, "50 cts.," was conspicuously flaunted.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The War Department is taking control of the railroads. At 12 o'clock Gen. Miles issued orders to Gen. Crofton to send regulars as follows: Two companies to the Union Station, two companies to Dearborn station, one company to the Northwestern, one company to the Grand Central, one company to the Rock Island, one company to the Illinois Central.

Not a single transaction of special note has marked the dealings of real estate brokers and auctioneers during the past week, so far at least as these have been called to public notice. This is, however, one of the things that is expected at this season of the year, and so calls for no further comment.

From The United Service Gazette. Nowadays the claims of bona fide centenarians are so fully acknowledged that it is only occasionally that a special "record" is worth chronicling. Such a case is assuredly that of Lieut. Nikolai Andrejevitch Sawin, now living at Saratoff, in Russia, who is stated to have been born on April 17, 1768, and who is consequently in his one hundred and twenty-seventh year.

Mme. Rejane and her fellow-actors of the Paris Vaudeville are at the Gaiety Theatre in London, their play being Sardou and Moreau's "Mlle. Sans-Gene," which has had such a long run in Paris. The play is not thought much of in London. William Archer calls is "a clever, mechanical, trivial performance in the manner of Scribe."

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 7. -- This always popular resort has settled down to its usual round of Summer gayety. The morning concerts on the hotel verandas begin the day's events. At 11, when this part of the programme is over, the crowds rush to the beach for the daily bath. That is usually over by 1, and then it is dinner time.

To-day will be a gala one at Eldorado, for, in addition to the usual afternoon and evening concerts, there will be a special performance of the celebrated Schaffer family at 8 o'clock, it being positively their farewell appearance in America, as they sail for Europe on the Fuerst Bismarck next Thursday. In addition, the management has engaged the famous "Black Crook" French quadrille dancers, who will precede the Schaffers.
CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., July 7. -- This resort is an extremely popular one with both New-Yorkers and Brookynites. Albany, this season, has also sent a numbers of representatives.

From The Pittsburg Chronicle Telegraph, July 3. There is a tale of a hat connected with last evening's windstorm in Allegheny, which, notwithstanding all opinions to the contrary, can be vouched for by half a dozen eye witnesses. A prominent Alleghenian was taking a drive on Perrysville Avenue with several members of his family, and started home shortly before the storm broke loose.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Gen. Schofield has sent orders to Brig. Gen. Otis at Vancouver, Washington, and to Brig. Gen. Merritt, at St. Paul, Minn., directing them to take charge of the Northern Pacific Railway lines and keep them open as a post and military road.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Division Superintendent Troy at Chicago this morning telegraphed the Post Office Department that the Alton had resumed regular mail trains. The Great Western mail train went out today on time.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 7. -- The ladies of Sea Cliff have had an unusually busy week entertaining friends over the Fourth and attending social gatherings. Tuesday evening the St. Luke's Chapter, Daughters of the King, gave a lawn party on the grounds adjoining the rectory. The decorations were tasteful and attractive.

GLASGOW, July 7. -- Much of the glory won by the British cutter Britannia to-day in her-race with the American centreboarder Vigilant, for the Queen's Cup, may be credited to the seamanship of the British yacht's crew. The Vigilant was defeated by about two minutes, corrected time, over a course with eight turns.

By far the most important as well as the latest form of dynamites or solidified nitro-glycerine are those designated not too happily an "blasting gelatines." Many persons imagine, quite naturally, that these consist of some form of gelatine, isinglass, or glue, converted by chemical means into a powerful explosive.

BOSTON, July 7. -- The local market was as dull as the preceding days of this week, and there were no events worth chronicling. No large lots were dealt in, and there was scarcely the fluctuation of a fraction in quotations. Mexican 4s improved 1/4, to 53 1/4. West End Street Railway was steady at 44, with West End Land 1-16 up, at 2.

ELBERON, N.J., July 7. -- Another week of fine weather and plenty of fun has drawn to a close. The cool breezes have swept over the bluff every day, the ocean has been at just the right temperature for bothing and, to crown all, the Fourth of July, with its fireworks and dance, turned up serene and smiling on Wednesday.

There was surprisingly little killing of rioters yesterday, only a score or so of wounded, yet the situation improved visibly and much in the twenty-four hours ending at midnight. The mobs of the lawless City of Chicago have been awed by the mere presence of Federal troops.
ANTWERP, July 7. -- At noon to-morrow the first international congress of the news-paper press will be formally called to order in the audience hall of the Municipal Council.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 7. -- The Phoenix Block, a five-story business structure, on Lower Westminster Street, was burned out this morning.

At the convention of the People's Party, held in Yonkers on July 4, Dr. E.B. Foote of 120 Lexington Avenue, who spends his Summers in Larchmont, was enthusiastically greeted as the probable candidate for member of Congress from the Sixteenth Congressional District.

TRENTON, July 7. -- Sea Girt has become the Summer capital of the State, as, while Gov. Werts, as Commander in Chief of the National Guard, is attentive to his military duties, he is not neglecting the business of the executive department and State affairs are considered on the broad porch of his hospitable cottage.
Inspector McAvoy has preferred charges against Policeman Patrick J. Kane of the Leonard Street Police Station, who is charged with using his revolver too freely on the Fourth of July.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 7. -- The Fourth and its baseball game were successes from the local standpoint. The day was much like other days, except that an occasional small baby popped a little torpedo and an occasional larger baby popped a big firecracker from behind a door when he thought the village policemen were out of sight.
