CHICAGO, July 7. -- The fires among the rolling Stock of the Pan Handle Road between Twenty-sixth and Sixty-third Streets were all out before 1 A.M., but the destruction was fearful while the fire lasted.

While the sulkies have been in active service for nearly two months, the sensations of the season are all in prospect. Instead of starting off with a flourish, after the manner of the gallopers, the harness racers make their annual appearance quietly in May and then gradually work up the situation to the climax known as the Grand Circuit, that invariably begins in July.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 7. -- The Music Teachers' National Association was the convention feature of the week. From a musical point of view it was a great success, but the attendance was ridiculously light. Eight hundred delegates were looked for, but only about 100 responded to their names.

WEST POINT, July 7. -- If one should ask Jose J. Rodriguez, ex-President of Costa Rica, what place outside of his own country he considered the most beautiful and picturesque, he would answer, without hesitation, "The Highlands of the Hudson." Ex-President Rodriguez, with his charming wife and daughters and Marlano Rodrlguez, arrived here several days ago.

The luck of the Riverside Wheelmen still sticks to that flourishing organization. Thus far in its short career it has held four big race meets, any one of which has been larger and a greater success in every way than any other given during the past four years on Manhattan Island. Its latest set of races, decided yesterday at Manhattan Field, proved equal to its predecessors.
Funds are being received for the erection of a lofty granite monolith in the form of an Iona cross to the memory of Alfred Tennyson.

For a Saturday there was a fair volume of business in yesterday's stock market; in fact, the trading in the two hours of business was considerably in excess of some days earlier in the week. London sold stocks at the opening, said to be the result of forced liquidation arising out of recent failures in that market.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7. -- All things considered, the market held fairly well. A sharp break might have been, in order, but the bears Kept their hands off and the bulls seemed to keep up their courage, but prices sagged off throughout the entire day. There is very little news to be had from the Pennsylvania and Lehigh Valley people.

The police believe that George Dougherty, whose father formerly kept the "Brighton," in Great Jones Street, and who was arrested Friday, is the man who shot Edward Meyer, the race-track messenger, in front of his home, at 1,503 Avenue A, early Friday morning. Dougherty gave himself up Friday afternoon, having heard that the police were looking for him.

"There is nothing so interesting as the study of the feet of different nationalities," said Philip Smith, who rides the second worst buck-jumping horse. Jumbo, in America. "A good rider should know his horse, his saddle, and use his arms and feet all right," said Mr. Smith," but that is not the point.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 7. -- Major William Haubennestel, who returned from State Camp to-day with his command, the Nineteenth Separate Company, said to-night that the feeling among the officers of the guard is that trouble on the railroads in the State of New-York is imminent.

From The London Daily News. M. Arsene Houssaye, while holding that M. Rochefort goes a little too far in praising the works of the English artists exhibited at the Grafton Galleries, thinks he is in the main right. The two writers agree in attributing the delicious peculiarity of Watteau to his having lived in England, and for a long time when there was a great English school of painting in its prime.

LONDON, July 7. -- A haze of intrigue so envelopes the inner life of Parliament that it is impossible to say whether or not Sir William Harcourt's threats to resign his seat and the leadership of the Liberal Party in the House of Commons are genuine, or who is likely to be his successor in the event of his retirement.

WEDNESDAY, July 11. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., assignee's sale, leasehold of 406 to 412 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, south side, 100 feet east of First Avenue, 88 by 100.11, one-story brick stable, nearly covering plot. Ground rent. $1,056; taxes,

HARTFORD, Conn., July 7. -- The oldest Freemason in the United States, Adna Adams Treat, was born in this city April 8, 1797. In 1823 he became a member of Apollo Lodge of Troy, N.Y., and he is still a member of that organization. In 1825 he married Miss Jane Reilay of Troy, who died Oct. 28, 1890.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 7. -- The strike situation in Buffalo seems to be unaltered today, but the fact still remains that the employes of the different reads seem to be ready to throw up their jobs immediately on notice from those who will lead the strike at this point.

Our talk rambled over many subjects. Much of it was personal on both sides, on mine of no interest. Kossuth spoke of his sons studying medicine at Naples, and of his plans to visit them having been often broken by doubts of his strength. He had fixed on Turin, despite its eager heats and colds, as suiting his health and diminished means, and staid on till it was too late to move.

Some of the very best amateur rowing of the year is expected in the annual races to be given by the Middle States Regatta Association next Saturday on the Passaic River at Newark. The events will comprise the fifth set given by the organization, and judging by the indications the lovers of aquatics will find a rare feast in this season's menu.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 7. -- Visitors have taken advantage of excursion rates, and have come in large numbers during the last week. The principal hotels have reaped a harvest, several of them having been forced to turn people away. The boarding houses and hotels of less importance have been very busy.

The announcement was made in the office of the County Treasurer in Brooklyn yesterday that at last the alleged deficit of $72,000 had been explained to the satisfaction of everybody, and instead of a deficit there is now a surplus of $28,000, believed to be the uncollected salary of the late Deputy County Treasurer James Gardiner.

ORANGE, N.J., July 7. -- A musical and dramatic entertainment is to be given at the residence of Mrs. Thomas G. Conway, in South Orange, on Wednesday evening, for the benefit of the Free Library. "The Lifeless Man," a play written by W.H. Aborn of East Orange, will be presented by Miss Alice Pulsford, Miss Ward, Fred Meeder, Ernest Pulsford, and George Delano.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Superintendent of Immigration Stump has addressed to the attorneys of the steamship companies a letter in which ha says that their communication of the 26th of June addressed to John G. Carlisle, Secretary of the Treasury, on the subject of maintenance of immigrants, has been referred to him for reply.

The British torpedo-boat destroyer Hornet, built by Messrs. Yarrow, was proclaimed to be the fastest war vessel afloat. According to The United Service Gazette, (British,) the Hornet's speed has been eclipsed by the Daring, another destroyer, which was built by the rival firm of Thornycroft. In the best of three spins over a measured mile, the Daring attained, against the tide, a speed of 29.268 knots.

Thomas Stevens, the bicyclist, who has made Several remarkable trips about the world on his wheel, has just returned from a long visit to India. He went to India, he says, to study the mysteries of Eastern magic, and claims to have made discoveries which will startle the world, occult and otherwise.

Public attention was focused recently on the condition of the walks in the Central Park, through a difference of opinion as to the expenditure of the million-dollar appropriation, part of which was destined for the employment of victims of hard times. The walks that required relaying so badly were of the kind known as monolithic, a smear or veneer of asphalt spread over coal tar and pebbles.

The office of United States Marshal Jacobus, in the Post Office Building, was the scene of a great deal of excitement yesterday afternoon, and rumors of wholesale arrests of professional opium smugglers floated about.

Various elegant preparations have superseded the coarse unguents and salves of former times. It would be impossible in our limited space to give a just idea of the wonderful improvements that have been made in this branch of pharmacy. Perhaps one of the most notable improvements is the preparation of an animal fat, called lanoline, which is now used as the basis of a large number of oinuments.

Darmesteter's great work on the ZendAvesta is the fruit of twenty years' study. It has gained for him the Volney Prize of 20,000f. from the French Academy as the most important production of French scholarship during the past decade. It sealed his claim to unrivaled leadership in the domain of Persian studies.

If Eugene Debs, President of the American Railway Union, or any of his associates come within the limits of this State with the purpose of stirring up such scenes of riot and disorder as they have brought about in Chicago they will find themselves behind the bars before they know what has happened to them.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 7. -- This has been a busy week for the railroads leading from New-York into the Catskills, for every day the flow of Summer travel into the mountains is increasing. There are several thousand city people enjoying the cool breezes in the Catskills, but the flood tide of travel has not yet been reached.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 7. -- Lieut. W. H. Stayton, formerly a naval officer, now a lawyer at New-York, in command of the Fourth Division, First Naval Battalion, State of New-York, with Boatswain's Mate Barter Seagraves and a boat's crew of sixteen men, arrived here in a man-of-war cutter this evening, having made the trip from New-Haven, where they arrived from New-York Thursday evening, and were joined by three officers of the Connecticut Naval Battalion.

Assistant Postmaster Morgan said yesterday that no mail had been received from San Francisco since July 1. Chicago mails were received Friday evening, except letters posted in that city on July 5, between 10:30 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. Mail due from Detroit had not arrived, and none was received yesterday from Memphis, Nashville, Milwaukee, or Omaha. Mails from Missouri, Arkansas, and the Southwest arrived on time.

BOSTON, Mass, July 7. -- The postponed annual regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club was sailed to-day off Marblehead, with the start and finish at Halfway Rock. The breeze was moderate from the southwest and soft in spots. In the schooner class there were but two entries, the Mayflower and the Marguerite, The former won with ten minutes to spare.

VALPARAISO, Chile, June 1. -- Lying re- cently in the harbor of Valparaiso were two long, narrow-beamed war ships of the Chilean Navy, which three years ago attracted, by their exploits, the attention of the civilized world. The two vessels are the Almirante Condell and the Almirante Lynch. They are sister ships, and for speed and all work demanding celerity of movement they have no equals in the Chilean fleet.

Mayor Schieren yesterday received a letter from Jacob Meurer of 571 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, in reference to the personal tax upon manufacturing corporations. Mr. Meurer begins his letter to the Mayor by asking these questions:

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 7. -- Pretty girls are making this seaside place their headquarters. They are here in force. You meet them bobbing up and down in the surf and strolling along the beach. They meet all incoming trains, and give the stranger at once a good opinion of Far Rockaway. In the cool of the evening they take either, to the outer beach or to the many pleasant walks around the village.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7. -- The steamer Monowai arrived to-day from Sydney, via Samoa and Honolulu.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- In an affray late this afternoon between a frenzied mob and a number of militiamen and policemen, in the thickly-populated district at Forty-ninth and Loomis Streets, on the Grand Trunk Road, twenty-five individuals were wounded, several of them fatally. This is a partial list of the casualties:

From The Chicago Standard. Strangers in the City of Washington, often remark on the custom of addressing one at all times of the day by the uniform salutation "Good-morning." It sounds odd to a Westerner to hear one address him with "Good-morning" at 5 o'clock in the afternoon. This custom is as old as the Congress of the United States, and the hours of executive business at the various departments.

The true salmon has never yet been successfully domiciled in New-Zealand waters. Why not? Because, it is said, the NewZealand seas do so abound in voracious fish, barracouta, sharks, and the like, that the salmon has no chance of returning undevoured from his first visit to the salt water.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 7. -- A large and fashionable audience enjoyed the ladies' entertainment at the Montclair Club on Monday evening. Hugh J. Emmett, the violinist and humorist, and W.F. Sanborn, the tenor, furnished the programme.

TUXEDO PARK, July 7. -- Once more the Tuxedo championship has changed hands, and the name of Malcolm Chace is the last to be inscribed on the silver shield of the massive trophy. Chace to-day defeated Clarence Hobart of New-York after a long five-set match, in which the most skillful single tennis was played that has ever been seen at Tuxedo.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The General Managers of the railroads this morning received a large number of telegrams from Eastern stockholders and Presidents of the companies represented by the association approving the course they have taken in the strike and giving them cordial support.

From The Cincinnati Enquirer. "In that country once known as the 'Great American Desert' embracing a portion of Texas and Arizona, there are no odors," said R.P. Senter of Dallas. "There, luscious grapes and many other fruits grow, especially near the cross-timber country, but there is no perfume; wildflowers have no smell, and carcasses of dead animals, which in dry seasons are very plentiful, emit no odors.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 8. -- The cruise of the Atlantic Yacht Club for 1894 is ended. The cruise this year was most successful, and one of the best the club has had for several seasons. Some of the yachtsmen would like to have continued the cruise, but so many boats went away from Shelter Island that there is nothing of the squadron left.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- At a late hour to-night President Cleveland issued the following proclamation:

ALBANY, July 8. -- Gov. Flower was at the Executive Mansion all day to-day with the exception of a couple of hours this morning, during which he attended church at St. Peter's. He still entertains the same convictions he expressed yesterday, that this State would not be troubled by strikes or strikers.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Vice President Wickes of the Pullman Company went to the company's office at noon to-day to meet a committee of the employes, as he had been requested to do. He waited an hour and a half, but nobody appeared. He then went home.

CANOJOHARIE, N.Y., July 8. -- An unsuccessful attempt was made last night to wreck the fast National Express train, east bound, on the West Shore Railroad, between this place and Fort Plain. This is train No. 20, due here at 11:35 P.M., and, in addition to the express cars, it usually has several Pullman sleepers attached.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., July 8. -- Kelley's band of Commonwealers, who took possession of a Chesapeake and Ohio freight train in Kentucky last night, were stopped as soon as they had entered West Virginia by two companies of militia from this city, who surrounded them at 3 o'clock this morning and kept them in captivity until the arrival of Gov. MeCorkle in a special train this afternoon.

NEW-LONDON, July 8. -- Lieut. W.H. Stayton, with a boat's crew of sixteen men from New-York City, proceeded from this point to Fisher's Island soon after daybreak this morning, to perform a tour of duty preparatory to the cruise of the New-York Naval Reserve, which will begin on the 21st inst. and continue for a week.

PARIS, July 8. -- The Government will introduce in the Chamber to-morrow a bill providing that oral or written incitation to crime, such as is practiced by the Anarchists, shall be tried before correctional courts, consisting of Judges without juries.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent, throughout the week.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 8. -- The Rev. Dr. A.B. Leonard of New-York, General Missionary Secretary of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in an address at the Prohibiton Park auditorium this afternoon, declared that the railroad strikers were Anarchists and that President Debs and Gov. Altgeld should be behind prison bars.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Mayor Hopkins did not reach his residence, on Prairie Avenue, until 1 o'clock this morning, when he was shown a copy of the dispatch from Washington containing the President's proclamation and the additional instructions of Secretary Lamont of the War Department.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 8. -- The newspaper special from New-York into the Catskill made its first trip up the West Shore Road to-day, carrying The New-York Times to the guests at the Kaaterskill Hotel and other points in the mountains. The train, loaded with big bundles of newspapers, pulled out of the Weehawken Station at 3:30 o'clock this morning.
At all the railroad stations in this city and Jersey City the situation was quiet yesterday.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $2,668,625. The banks now hold $72,134,725 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $18,709,400, a decrease in specie of $1,263,400, an increase in legal tenders of $2,409,900, an increase in deposits of $15,276,500, and an increase in circulation of $646,700.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 8. -- Nineteen persons, including men, women, and children, were tossed into the air by a train on the Long Island Railroad east of Glendale junction about 6 o'clock this evening. They were in a big picnic wagon, and were returning from a day spent in the woods near Jamaica.
All the armories in the city were deserted last night, and Brig. Gen. Fitzgerald, who went on Saturday to his country home, will not be in town until to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 8. -- Through a member of the Knights of Labor who stood high in the order under Powderly's administration and who, though secretly opposed to them, has enjoyed the confidence of John W. Hayes and the new executive board, the true story of the inception and growth of the conspiracy which has resulted in the present railroad strike was learned to-day.

"Organized labor" makes a miserable showing in its attempts to give aid and comfort to the Anarchists at Chicago. The agitators who met in this city yesterday in the name of the labor organizations took no action, beyond some sputterings about the calibre of revolvers and the cruel oppressiveness of Superintendent Byrnes.

The Rev. Dr. Herrick Johnson, a professor in the Presbyterian Theological Seminary in Chicago, preached yesterday in the pulpit of the Central Congregational Church in Brooklyn. The pastor, the Rev. A.J.F. Behrends, is in Europe. Prof. Juhnson did not allude to the railroad troubles in Chicago in his sermon, but he used some vigorous language to a reporter for The New-York Times who saw him before he preached.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- All day long conferences have been held at the White House between the President and his official advisers. Secretary Lament and Gen. Schofield came early and remained late, while Postmaster General Bissell and Secretary Gresham spent some time with Mr. Cleveland. Secretary Carlisle paid a brief visit.

GARRISON'S-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 8. -- Camp Cullom, which lies so snugly under the shadow of Crow Nest, is all excitement to-day over the fight which took place at dawn this morning on the old fighting grounds, near Fort Clinton. For many years the southwest corner of the fort has been used by the cadets as a place where they met and settled their difficulties by fistic combat.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- General interest at the headquarters of the General Managers' Association was to-day centred at Ham- mond, Ind. There has been no attempt to send out a single train from this city without having aboard an armed troop of soldiers, Deputy Marshals, or policemen, and in many cases these extreme measures have failed in their purpose, and have been the cause of many conflicts between the mobs and the soldiery:

From The Boston Transcript. "Press your pants while you wait," a sign in a tailor's window on Columbus Avenue, is an announcement that fills the mind with speculations. You can imagine a row of South End gentlemen waiting, all without their "pants," while the tailor puts the proper crease into these garments.

From The Washington Post, (Inc.) The whole country has reason to be grateful to Mr. Cleveland for the stand he has taken with reference to the outrageous demonstrations in Chicago under the leadership of the mart Debs. His determination to uphold society and execute the law is in the highest degree honorable to him and reassuring to a law-abiding people.
"The Strike and its Terrors" was discussed, before his sermon, yesterday, by the Rev. Dr. John A.B. Wilson, in the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, near Eighth Avenue.

With the Middle States regatta less than a week off, and a number of club races on the tapis, the oarsmen of Scullers' Row, on the Harlem, took advantage of the ideal weather and put in good practice work yesterday. The best work was accomplished early in the day, but at no time was the historic, river deserted by racing craft.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 8. -- Mr. Lloyd Phoenix's steam yacht Intrepid, New-York Yacht Club, returned to this harbor from a cruise today, and is at anchor off the Pequot House. A party of guests of the owner are aboard. The steamer Ladoga, New-York Yacht Club, Mr. John Hall, of Hartford, with Mr. Hall's family and guests, ran into this harbor this afternoon and came to anchor off the Custom House.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- In an interview last night, Judge Murray F. Tuley of the Cook County Circuit Court made some observations regarding George M. Pullman's refusal to arbitrate with his striking employes and his responsibility for the deplorable state of affairs now existing in Chicago.

UNION STOCK YARDS, CHICAGO, July 8. -- Shortly before 3 o'clock this afternoon the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad attempted to run a train of twenty cars, laoded with coal, into the city. When the train reached Root Street a crowd of hoodlums threw a switch and derailed two cars. Only three policemen were on duty at the crossing and a call was sent to Dexter Park for troops.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 8. -- No rain of any account has fallen in Ulster County for a month, and the country is experiencing a disastrous drought. Berries and small fruit are drying on the bushes, and the crops this year will be failures. Roads are deep with dust, and meadow land is burned gray. In Dutchess County the land is even dryer, and all crops are suffering greatly for rain.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 8. -- At 1:50 P.M. Company G, Ninth Regiment, United States Army, which left Fort Ontario yesterday, arrived here. There were forty-five men in the company, in command of Capt. Regan. The men are equipped with ammunition belt, filled with ball cartridge. The special consisted of two cars -- one of which was well supplied with ammunition.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 8. -- St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church, at Long Branch, was dedicated to-day, in the presence of a large gathering from Long Branch, Hollywood, Norwood, Elberon, and the surrounding towns. The dedication address was delivered by Bishop Cyrus D. Foss of Philadelphia. Addresses were also delivered by Presiding Elder Strickland, the Rev. Dr. Hanlon, the Rev. E.C. Curtis, and others.

From The Lowsville Times. The Adirondack League Club's preserve is the largest in the Adirondacks, and includes within its boundaries the finest fishing waters in the North Woods. It has twenty-five lakes, the largest being Honnedaga, six miles long, and the next largest. Little Moose, four miles long.

From The Philadelphia Times. The strange antics of a crazy engineer at Alton, Ill., suggest the fact that insanity is very frequent among railway employes. Two dramatic illustrations can be mentioned. There is living in New-Jersey, not far from Philadelphia, a man who for many years was the foremost passenger engineer between New-York and Philadelphia on the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Major Gen. Oliver O. Howard, commander of the Department of the East, talked of the strike last evening, in his colonial home on Governors Island, as he sat in an armchair in the strong light of a reading lamp. He was bronzed from his recent tour of inspection, and the empty right sleeve of his coat told of the loss of an arm at the battle of Fair Oaks, June 1, 1862.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8. -- Buffalo has been ordered "tied up." James Mellican, President of the local branch of the American Railway Union, received a dispatch tonight from President Debs, directing him to withdraw the members of the order here from service at once, and cautioning him to prevent any resort to violence.
Edward Kemp, who will spend part of the Summer at Red Bank, has bought a set of mail phaeton harness for a high-stepping pair of cobs.

The Central Labor Federation, which is composed almost entirely of delegates from unions that are Socialistic or affiliated with the Socialist-Labor Party, shut itself up yesterday at its headquarters, at 64 East Fourth Street. Most of the time of the meeting was taken up with denouncing capitalists in general, and the police and United States Judges.

Orrin Hickok is training for O.T. Mackey of this city the bay filly Siluarian, by Wilton, 2:19 1/4, dam Silhouette, by Hambrino, 2:21. Silurian is a full sister to Mr. Mackey's renowned filly Silicon that in 1892 gained a race record of 2:15 3/4, defeating Alley Bonner's bay colt Tony V. in the fastest contest ever seen between two-year-old trotters.

Great dullness and remarkable firmness in the face of disquieting conditions were the features of last week's stock market. The week was broken by the national holiday which came on Wednesday, and, as is not unusual at this season, many operators did not put in an appearance in the Street at all. The trading was very lignt, much more so than is usual even in this always very dull period of the year.

From The Lockport Journal, July 6. Mr. Crocker, Superintendent of Public Instruction, could certainly have learned something to his advantage by attending the annual meeting of the University Convocation at Albany yesterday. That gentleman recently, in a bumptious mood, substantially proposed arrogating to himself pretty much all the educational power in the State.
OMAHA, Neb., July 8. -- In answer to an inquiry as to why the meeting with Vice President Wickes was not held to-day, President Debs telegraphed as follows:

Assistant District Attorney Wellman, who has been charged with the prosecution of the police officials whose misdoings were revealed by the Lexow investigation, has announced that Capt. John T. Stephenson will be the first to be called for trial. Capt. William S. Devery will be next in order. Mr. Wellman says, and then will follow Capts. Cross, Murphy, Schmittberger, Allaire, Cartright, and Strauss, Inspector McLaughlin, and Capt. Jacob Siebert.

BERLIN, July 8. -- Emperor William has been much vexed by the Kotze scandal. When he ordered Kotze's release he determined to end also the gossip caused at Court by the arrest and inquiry. He instructed the new Grand Chamberlain, in a dispatch accompanying the order of release, to caution all Court officials that they must cease talking of the scandal or give up their places in the Court circle.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 8. -- The Summer Parliament for Religious and Secular Instruction opened here to-day with an attendance which gave assurance to the Long Beach Association that success is to crown the work it has undertaken for the Summer.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The official Naval Register for July has appeared from the Navy Department within six days of the date to which it is corrected, showing a promptness on the part of the editor, Ensign Russell, that is unusual in the publication of this useful directory.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, July 8. -- At a number of the towns west of Cheyenne the condition of affairs begins to present an alarming aspect, because of the continued suspension of freight traffic. Everything consumed in these towns has to be shipped in by rail. Supplies are running short, and if the strike continues many days longer actual starvation will stare the people in the face.

ALBANY, July 7. -- The extreme heat, the Fourth of July holiday, and the exodus of many financial men to the Summer resorts tended to restrict trading in local securities. Trading, however, considering the above, was fairly active. There was some investment demand, with sales of Municipal Gas 6s, Albany Railway 5s, and Union Railway of New-York 5s.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- From the hospital comes the intelligence that John Burke, mentions in the United Press dispatches of last night as being fatally wounded, died at an early hour this morning. John Klongenberger, another of the wounded, is in a precarious condition, and it is thought that he will not survive the day.

A great many people have asked why so much money has been spent on the navy, and why there are so few ships to show for it. They cite the fact that Congress votes enormous sums of money at every session for ships, and the Navy Department is continually asking for more. If one will carefully examine the following table he will readily see where the money is expended.

EVERSON, Penn., July 8. -- Unknown persons last night set fire to a train of cars on a siding at this place, and six box cars were burned. At 4 o'clock this morning the train was fired the second time and great damage would have resulted but for the timely arrival of deputies, who were on their way from Mount Pleasant to Scottdale.

It is surely a fallacy to look upon Cromwell's army as composed exclusively of saints. It must be borne in mind that throughout the period of Puritan ascendency one of the filthiest sheets to be found in any language was printed and published regularly in London every week, and that there were lewd livers, drunkards, and extortioners in the Long Parliament itself.

The United States Treasury commenced the new fiscal year on the 1st of this month with a total cash balance of $117,584,436. Of this amount, what is called the "gold reserve" was $64,873,024, and the "net cash balance" was $52,711,412. The net gold in the Treasury on the 31st of January was $65,650,175.

Interest was evinced in a meeting yesterday afternoon at Twenty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue of the New-York City Division No. 54 of the Order of Railroad Conductors. It was, however, the regular monthly business reunion, and nothing but routine affairs was discussed or transacted. The Chicago strike was not mentioned during the session, but it was informally discussed after adjournment.

The Rev. David James Burrell, D.D., who preached the inaugural sermon of the Summer Parliament, and who is the President of that body, is well known in New-York as one of the most eloquent and profound pulpit orators of the day. Dr. Burrell was born at Mount Pleasant, Penn., Aug. 1, 1844. He was graduated at Yale in the class of '67.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 8. -- From indications to-night, there is not much danger that the railroad men in Pittsburg, especially on the large systems, will strike, in sympathy with the American Railway Union. The feeling in favor of such a movement seems to have undergone a sudden change after the meetings of several railway organizations held to-day to take some action on the pending trouble on the railroads in the West.

Superintendent Byrnes yesterday remained all day in his office at Police Headquarters and perfected his plans for police protection in the event of a strike in this city. He does not propose to be caught napping by any mob, and he has made such arrangements as will effectually prevent any possibility of exhibitions such as have been given in Chicago.

Enigmatic and singular by the duality of his genius as a painter and a poet and by the characteristic of his ideal which united taste for symbolism with careful study of reality, Rossetti has tempted analysis of his life and work from critics and essayists of varied degrees of merit. Their list is long and imposing, but it contains the names of none more authoritative than F.G. Stephens and Esther Wood.

The official representatives of organized labor in this city yesterday voiced their sympathy with the American Railway Union and expressed sentiments showing them to be in thorough accord with the policy of the Western strikers.

From The Chambersburg (Penn.) Valley Spirit. The Democracy of the State approve the nomination of Mr. Singerly of The Philadelphia Record, not merely because he is an able, incorruptible man, but because they know his views on the tariff and other public questions and indorse them. The fact of his nomination by acclamation proves that Pennsylvania Democrats are as much in favor of tariff reform and honest government as they were in 1890 and 1892.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Superintendent of Mails Montgomery said to-day that mail-train service was better than for several days. Mails on the Rock Island, Illinois Central, Big Four, Pan Handle, and the Baltimore and Ohio were still tied up, but mails on the Lake Shore arrived and departed.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The strike situation in California is giving the officials much concern, and the failure to receive any information from that State to-day did not bring conviction that "no news is good news." Senator White received a telegram this afternoon from Los Angeles, signed by most of the business men of that city, urging him to protest against the removal or withdrawal of Federal troops.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 8. -- The Harvard Summer School has begun with increased courses and an astonishing increase in attendance. Last year the Summer schools in the East had a hard time, and the courses in the Harvard school were comparatively small. The total number of students was 346, of which 60 took the course in the Medical School, 56 studied physical training, 46 physics, 45 chemistry, and 22 English.

PARIS, July 8. -- Crooks, the American wheelman, was second in the race for the Chantilly Prize to-day over a course of three kilometers. A.A. Zimmerman beat A.C. Edwards in the match for 2,500f. a side. There were to be three heats in this match, but as both the first (of one kilometer) and the second (of two kilometers) were won by Zimmerman, the final heat was omitted.

CONEY ISLAND, July 8. -- The attractions which usually draw a crowd here on Sunday failed to do so to-day. It was too cold. There are no stoves in the big hotel corridors, and the breezes were so strong to-day that in the absence of stoves or steam heat overcoats were the proper thing.

The President has issued a proclamation which is at once a notification to all "good citizens" to keep out of harm's way in Chicago and in the State of Illinois and a warning to those whom he justly and with strict respect to truth and to law describes as "public enemies."

YONKERS, N.Y., July 8. -- The North Shore limited New-York Central express, which left New-York City at 4:30 this afternoon, met with a remarkable accident in front of the Hudson River Railroad Station at 4:50 this evening. The accident was caused by the locomotive of the express running into a door of a freight train which fell from a car a few minutes before.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Every morning and evening paper in Chicago printed in the English language, with all the job printing houses of the city, was represented at the meeting of District 16 of the International Typographical Union, held in Greenbaum's Hall this afternoon. It was the largest meeting of the union printers, of Chicago in the history of the organization.
LONDON, July 8. -- C.N. Jackson of Oxford, a steward of the Yale-Oxford contests, gave a dinner to the Yale athletes at Hertford College last evening.

PRAGUE, July 9 -- A bomb was exploded in Pilsen last evening in front of a hotel in which a number of members of a German society were holding a reunion. The front of the building was totally demolished. One of the members of the German society was killed and several were severely injured.

We directed attention a few days ago to the export trade in American carpets and to the assertion of the Secretary of the Woolen Manufacturers' Association that the substitution of a protective duty of 35 per cent. for the duties of the McKinley tariff would deal "a staggering blow" to the carpet industry in this country. The following remarks are taken from The American Wool and Cotton Reporter of the 5th inst.:

The proclamation of the President has been received by the country generally with a very sober sense of the deplorable situation that has made it necessary, with a sincere pity for the misguided men who have been betrayed into acts of violence that compel the Government to act, and with profound satisfaction that the President has clearly understood his duty and is resolved firmly to do it.
PARIS, July 9 -- Charles A. Dana, who has Just arrived in Paris after a tour of Northern Europe, was asked to-day by a reporter what had impressed him most during his absence.

PEORIA, Ill., July 9 -- The men in the Peoria Railway yards struck at midnight last night, and declare they will remain out until the strike is ended. This action was taken as the result of two sessions yesterday of the American Railway Union.

The President's proclamation concerning the Western strike was hailed with satisfaction in financial circles, the belief prevailing being that it would hasten the end of the difficulties. London, however, seemed to regard it as an intimation that the situation was more serious than had been supposed abroad, and consequently some stock for the foreign account was sold at the opening.
Mr. H.C. Bryan has sold for D. Frankenberg the five-story brownstone flat 214 West Forty-second Street, 25 by 93 by 100, at $47,500.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Although the news from the West to-day was of a less exciting character than it has been for several days, the general anxiety about the situation was undoubtedly greater.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- The General Managers' Association of the Allied Railroads in Chicago do not know that there is such a thing on the face of this earth as the Building and Trades Council -- that is, they take no official cognizance of such an organization, and as their troubles are in no way connected with the federated labor of the city proper, the order for a general strike does not bother them.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Naval Appropriation bill was passed in the Senate to-day with very little friction or delay. There was one amendment offered which might have led to considerable debate, and that was for the construction of two new steel-armored cruisers at a cost not exceeding1 $2,750,000 each.

Henry Cook, or Sir Henry Cook, or Dr. Cook, as he is familiarly known, one of the most plausible swindlers who ever operated, whose schemes have been known in a dozen States and fully as many countries in Europe, is a prisoner at Police Headquarters. He was caught yesterday afternoon, and the charge against him is one of the least in his eventful life.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- One of the biggest deals ever made in the navy was consummated to-day by the agreement of Rear Admiral Skerratt, in command of the China station, to go on the retired list, after forty years' service.

ROME, July 9 -- It is undeniable that the Pope is becoming greatly enfeebled, but his condition is not as yet dangerous. The recent intense heat has greatly affected the health of his Holiness and caused him to have frequent fainting fits. The gravity of his condition is naturally belittled at the Vatican, but there is nevertheless a great deal of anxiety among the members of the Pope's household.

Congratulations from a happy party of young and old people were showered upon the Rev. and Mrs. Richard Horton yesterday, it being the sixtieth anniversary of their wedding. An informal reception was held from 2 until 10 o'clock P.M. in Mr. and Mrs. Horton's apartments, 1,268 Second Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- There were no indications within the immediate limits of the city to-day that the railroad strike or boycott was in existence. On the majority of roads having their terminals in the city through passenger trains, as well as suburban trains, were moving on time.

GLASGOW, July 9 -- To American onlookers, the race, if it may be dignified by that name, between the centreboarder Vigilant and the cutter Britannia, for a prize of L75, suggested one of the old-fashioned flukes aver the old inside course of the New-York Yacht Club. Under the rules of American yacht racing, to-day's unsatisfactory match would have been sailed over again.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Rumors of dynamite plots are current in the stock yards section. At Camp Dexter the military forces have been increased by five companies of militia, two companies of United States cavalry, and thirty mounted police. Extra guards have been placed around the park, and all strangers are challenged at the fifty-yard line.

PORTLAND, Me., July 9 -- A telegram was received at Fort Preble Sunday from Washington, ordering the garrison stationed there to be ready to go to Chicago, on the Grand Trunk, at short notice. Company D of the Second Artillery, Capt. Rogers, is stationed here. The company moved out of its barracks to-day and went into camp, preparatory to moving.

DANVILLE, Ill., July 9 -- This has been a day of much excitement in this city and Grape Creek. Two women who were at their homes were killed by bullets fired by militia in an attempt to assist in moving a train, and two men were fatally wounded.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The statutes under which the President has issued his proclamation to the people of various States are embodied in Title LXIX. of the Revised Statutes of the United States, under the head of "Insurrection."

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Republican members of the Senate and House Committees of Conference on the Tariff bill were without occupation to-day, and all the people who are waiting upon their Knowing winks have already begun to shout about the minority being "shut out" from the conference.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 9 -- President Malican of the local branch of the American Railway Union was seen by a United Press reporter this evening, and in reply to inquiries as to the prospects for an immediate strike on the Buffalo roads in response to the telegram of President Debs, he said:

BOSTON, July 9 -- The Sugar Trust case has been argued in the Supreme Court before Judge Barker, and the court has the matter under consideration. Attorney General Knowlton asked the court to grant an injunction to stop the business of the American Sugar Refining Company, the defendant, within this State if it was satisfied after a review of the law that the act of 1891 was constitutional.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- Gen. Miles, when interviewed to-day in regard to the President's proclamation, was asked:

A fire in the White City brings on a frenzy and then we are treated to such flamboyancies as the following:

ANTWERP, July 9 -- The International Press Conference, which opened here on Saturday, held its first business session to-day. Upon motion of M. Torelli, Italian delegate, the members resolved to take steps toward forming a federation of all national press associations. They also passed the motion made by M. Berardis, ex-manager of the Independance Belge, that a committee be appointed to secure the protection of literary and news matter in the press.

Sarah Bernhardt's engagement at Daly's Theatre in London has been prodigiously successful. The receipts have often been as much as $2,000 a night. Her acting in "Phedre" fairly took the critics by storm. The Westminster Gazette says: "Admiration has often been expressed because Duse refused to put such a tax upon herself as playing every evening.

The strike is giving way before the President's proclamation, and under its own weight of wild recklessness and the complacent unreason of Debs. There was quiet in Chicago and its neighborhood yesterday, at various points the strikers ceased striking, and here and there Debs was repudiated by men of his own union.

Salida, Col., July 9 -- One of the watchmen in the roundhouse here threw some coal oil into the firebox of an engine in which fire was burning. The gas created exploded and a sheet of flame flashed out of the furnace. Ex-City Marshal Stevens, in trying to extinguish the flames, evidently inhaled some of the gas, for he complained of feeling sick and walked to a drug store.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9 -- Mrs. Fred W. Vanderbilt had a ladies' luncheon to-day, with fine floral decorations. Her guests were Mrs. Henry G. Marquand, Mrs. J.J. Wysong, Mrs. J.F. Stone, Mrs. George Henry Warren, Mrs. George Henry Warren, Jr., Mrs. J. Fred Pierson, Mrs. William F. Burden, Mrs. Nicholas Fish, Mrs. George W. Wales, Mrs. E. Livingston Ludlow, Mrs. William H. Osgood, and Miss De Barrit.
It is probable that the Republican State Committee will be called to meet at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in this city on or about Thursday, July 19.

While the record of railroad dividends for the half year ending June 30 was unfavorable, it may be considered surprising that suspensions and reductions were not more numerous. The Financial Chronicle, in the current issue, says the explanation is simple. Large numbers of the roads had been forced to take this step before the business depression developed.

LONG ISLAND CITY, July 9 -- But two of the nine persons injured in the collision at Trotting Course Lane, on the Long Island Railroad, Sunday evening, when a west-bound Far Rockaway train dashed into a wagon containing twenty-one returning picnickers, were in St. John's Hospital in this city this morning, where the wounded were taken after the accident.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The President sent to Congress to-day, with acoompanying correspondence, the following letter from the Secretary of State in relation to Samoan affairs:

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- The total anthracite tonnage carried over the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad last month, which reached 1,247,297 tons, was the largest ever transported by it in any month, being 77,173 tons more than the tonnage of the largest previous month, which was November, 1893.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 9 -- The initial steps toward tying up the entire railroad system of the city were taken at dawn to-day. One by one the engines in the yards were pointed toward the roundhouse, where they stood belching forth smoke.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Lower London prices and unfavorable strike news in yesterday's and again in to-day's papers were the principal causes of the decline in prices at the opening. After a drive by the bears the market showed some resistance and prices began to work toward a higher level. At first the traction stocks were inclined to sell off.
Whether Erastus Wiman shall go to Sing Sing Prison pending his appeal for a new trial or may be admitted to ball is to, be decided within a few days.

DENVER, Col., July 9 -- Judge Hallett of the United States District Court has issued an injunction restraining railroad employes and all other persons from interfering with the passage of the United States mails on all roads in Colorado. To enforce its terms a number of additional Deputy Marshals have been sworn in, and, if necessary, United States troops will be called upon.
CINCINNATI, July 9. -- The Tribune this morning says editorially:

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 9 -- The fear that they might be sidetracked somewhere by railway strikers caused almost one-half the members of the New-York State Teachers' Association to remain at home. When the President, George E. Hardy of New-York City, called the forty-ninth annual meeting to order to-night there were only about 400 in attendance, and he assigned the above as the sole reason.

ORANGE, N.J., July 9 -- Chief Consul James S. Holmes, Jr., of the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, has prepared the official programme for the New-Jersey State meet to be held at Asbury Park on Friday and Saturday of this week. It is as follows:

If there should be a strike in this city and violence should be set on foot the rioters would have quite a number of people to "put under the bed" before they could play even the slightest part as an opposing force.
There was little change yesterday in the condition of the railway trunk lines centring in this city, but railroad officials felt encouraged.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- Gen. Miles issued the following order this afternoon:

SAGINAW, Mich., July 9 -- This is the furthest Western point that the Grand Circuit has ever reaches, and the famous old series began this afternoon at Union Park before a crowd that numbered close to 5,000. The gate was free, and the small charge to the grand stand caused that vantage point to be packed with an enthusiastic crowd of Wolverines.

Mrs. Jane Anthony Eames. Mrs. Jane Anthony Eames, widow of the Rev. Dr. James H. Eames, for many years rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Concord, N.H., died Sunday night of paralysis, in Boston. She was one or the most widelyknown women in the State. She was born in Providence, and belonged to the Anthony family of Rhode Island.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- The strikers this morning retired temporarily from the station, and are massed at their headquarters awaiting orders from Knoz, their leader. In anticipation of the regular troops being called out, a number of the Sacramento strikers have been sent to Stockton to blockade the road and to warn the men of the approach of the soldiers.

ODESSA, July 9 -- The Russian steamer Vladimir, from Sebastopol for this port, was in collision in the Black Sea this morning with the Italian steamer Columbia, from Eupatoria for Nikolaieff. She went down almost at once, with all on board. A few persons were picked up by the Columbia, but between fifty and seventy-five, mostly passengers, are said to have been drowned.

It was not an easy matter for public business to pass through the hands of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday afternoon, because the members of the board, considering, perhaps, that they were meeting for the last time before the three months' vacation, spent a great deal of time blowing smoke rings and chatting in the ante-chamber.

Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, issued a call yesterday for a meeting of the Executive Council of the organization in Chicago Thursday next. He did so, he said, because he had received an earnest appeal from the Chicago Federation of Labor unions, which have resolved to participate in the railroad strike, that he should visit that city.
An informal report on the progress made by the Tenement-House Committee, of which Richard Watson Gilder is Chairman, came yesterday from its Secretary, Edward Marshall.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 9 -- General Master Workman Sovereign of the Knights of Labor said this morning that he had determined to delay the order for a strike of his order until Wednesday. He said:

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- The cruiser Minneapolis sailed from Cramps' shipyard at 3:05 this afternoon for her Government trial trip off the Massachussets coast. While the actual speed trial of the cruiser will last but four hours, the trip will consume seven days.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 9 -- The great railroad strike in the West is interfering with the arrival of the school teachers, and it is doubtful if half the expected number will be present at the opening session of the National Educational Association tomorrow. It is estimated that nearly 3,000 teachers have already reached Asbury Park.

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews appeared before the Board of Estimate yesterday to explain further about the form of contract he has prepared for the disposition of street sweepings. The Contract has been referred to President Barker of the Tax Department and Controller Fitch for report.

The Hon. M.D. Harter of the Fourteenth District of Ohio has contributed to The Forum a very interesting article on the currency question. He is a business man by occupation, and a successful one, and though business men do not by any means always understand the principles that control their own operations, Mr. Harter very clearly does.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The President this evening added to his proclamation of last night another of the same tenor, but more general in its application.

HAMMOND, Ind., July 9 -- The Federal troops were withdrawn from Hammond, by order of Gen. Miles, this morning, leaving on a special Michigan Central train for Chicago at 11 o'clock. One of the officers said that they were going to "clean up the stock yards." This leaves the Indiana militia, 730 strong, which arrived this morning, in possession of the railroad property.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., July 9 -- Three negroes employed at the Paynter Works of the McClure Coke Company came to Scottdale this afternoon. Strikers attacked and drove them over into Fayette County. Shots were exchanged, but no one was injured.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- The labor powers have spoken, and the most tremendous strike known to history will be inaugurated tomorrow when the evening whistles blow and 100,000 men abandon their work, not to return, it is said, until the Pullman boycott is settled.

The occurrences of the past week at Chicago will call the attention of the country very sharply to the necessity of protecting as well as regulating inter-State commerce. The power to regulate necessarily involves the power to protect. There is no doubt that Congress possesses full and exclusive power of regulation and protection, which implies a possible extension of Federal authority such as people have not been accustomed to think of.

The scene of racing was shifted yesterday to Brighton Beach, and for the first time in a number of years the popular little track by the seaside had an exclusive day's facing. There is a certain element with which Brighton is always preferable to any other track, and this crowd, with the troop of regulars who attend the other tracks, made the attendance a large one.

That was what the boys who spent the day at Sylvan Beach yesterday, played ball, went in swimming, and had plenty to eat and drink all day long, said after they came home last evening, and when a boy says "there is nothing to complain of" it generally means that he has had a pretty good sort of a time.

Present danger of a fresh-meat famine in New-York has been averted through the unexpected success of the commission dealers and their agents in creating to order, as it were, a supply from the grazing districts of the Middle States and some Western States. Hundreds of men have been through the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Ohio, Kentucky, and Virginia, gathering up cattle, and already there have been heavy shipments from these comparatively near-by regions.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Several New-York State offices, about which there has been much doubt, were filled to-day by the President.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10 -- The employes of the Southern division of the Columbus, Shawnee and Hocking Railway went out on a sympathetis strike with the American Railway Union movement this morning. The yards here are also closed. The northern division is yet uninterrupted.

The turmoil which has been raised in this country by the effort of a labor union to coerce the whole people into supporting a strike of the employes of one corporation in the State of Illinois ought to lead to the conclusive settlement of a question that has been unwisely left open for years.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- A general strike has been called -- or asked -- by General Master. Workman Sovereign, and, aided by the decision of the local unions to cease work, the greatest struggle in labors history has already begun in this city.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 10 -- The Seabright Tennis Club began its annual tournament this afternoon with a strong list of entries, which includes most of the well-known players. Among those here axe E.L. Hall, V.G. Hall, Malcolm Chace, the winner of the Tuxedo Cup; A.E. Foote, the New-England champion; Alfred Codman, John Howland, S.C. Millett, W.A. Parker, A.H. Lockett, and Richard Stevens, O.S. Campbell is also expected to be here later in the week.

Assistant District Attorney Francis L. Wellman is meeting with difficulty in getting testimony for the police trials because witnesses refuse to obey the subpoenas and are averse to giving any information.

The borings made recently in the North River by order of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company were considered this morning by the commission of engineers appointed by President Cleveland to determine upon the best methods of extending a span of not less than 2,000 feet, in accordance with the act under which the work of the company is to be carried on.

The expected order of General Master Workman Sovereign for all organizations of the Knights of Labor to strike did not reach the organizations, in this city last night.

SYRACUSE, July 10 -- The independent Republicans of Onondaga County, the Hiscock-Hendricks faction, to-night, at a meeting of their City Committee, decided to continue the fight against the regulars, headed by Congressman J.J. Belden, on every line, and to nominate a complete ticket this Fall.

Policeman Michael Burns of the East Twenty-second Street Station is either an exceedingly stupid or an exceedingly unfortunate man. Within an Hour on Monday night he arrested two married women of perfect respectability who were on the street with their husbands. The charge he made in each case was that the women were disorderly persons.

ELMIRA, July 10 -- Israel T. Deyo was the only member of the commission which is investigating the reformatory who put in an appearance to-day. Ex-Judge Learned of Albany had written that his health was such that he could not be here, although he suggested that the investigation go on in his absence.

BOSTON, July 10 -- A visit to all the railroad stations in Boston found the unanimous opinion prevailing that not a semblance of a strike would be seen here, and that New-England railway men had no sympathy with the American Railway Union.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10 -- The principal feature of interest at camp to-day was the work of the three signal corps of the First Brigade, under First Sergt. Super. Early this morning detachments were sent to Haverstraw and Yonkers.

Toulon, July 10 -- A serious fire occurred in the arsenal in this city last night and raged for two hours before the troops of the garrison and the crews of the war ships were able to extinguish the flames. The fire originated in the marine engine department, to which the flames were confined. Several soldiers and sailors were injured.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- The crisis at Sacramento will be reached soon. United States troops left for that city early this morning. They were armed and equipped as for a campaign. The intention is to move trains there at any cost. Four foot batteries stationed at the Presidio and one or two foot batteries that have been guarding Alcatraz went on board the steamer which left the Presidio wharf this morning.
There has been, in recent years, according to the testimony of Brooklyn physicians, a great increase of nervous troubles among the public school children of Brooklyn.

Judging from the attendance at the three days' racing given thus tar this year at the Brighton Beach track, the meeting will prove a good one from a financial point of view. On the opening day, with Sheepshead Bay as a counter attraction, there was a big crowd at the old seaside path. Monday the followers of the turf flocked to Brighton in large numbers, and yesterday standing room was at a premium.

CINCINNATI, July 10 -- Smith's presence to-day gave the Reds new life, and they went in to stop New-York's winning streak, doing it well. The seven-thousand-dollar battery, Meekin and Farrell, was hit freely. The fielding of Cincinnati was clean and sharp. Attendance, 1,000, Score:

CHICAGO, July 10 -- The situation, as reported by the General Managers' Association to-day, grows steadily brighter. Through passenger service on all lines leading into Chicago is quite generally resumed, and the suburban service is almost restored to its normal state.

President Cleveland's proclamations on the strike have strengthened the admiration for him among railroad and banking men, and have called forth the hearty approval of the business community. In every quarter his course is commended, party differences disappearing in the universal tribute of praise for his course.

President Debs of the American Railway Union, President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor, and other labor leaders who are responsible for strikes, have repeatedly affirmed that during the present strike and in strikes in the past all violent acts were done by men not strikers. During the present strike President Debs has over his own signature frequently stated that the members of his organization were not among the rioters at Chicago.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 10 -- At 12:30 to-day the city was shaken by a violent shock of earthquake, which was quickly followed by another equally severe. The duration of each shock was about twenty seconds. The people are thoroughly alarmed, and thousands have vacated their houses, fearing further shocks.

GLASGOW, July 10 -- To-day's contest for the Clyde Corinthian Cup, valued at L60, while ostensibly sailed by amateur skippers, was practically a professional event. Mr. W. Jamieson was at the tiller of the Britannia, and Mr. Nat Herreshoff manipulated the tiller of the Vigilant, but they were advised by the racing skippers of their craft.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- "Sugar" is here, and so are coal and oil and all the other interests that are in the Tariff bill, and everybody knows that they are here for business. Their object of attack is, of course, the conference committee on the Tariff bill.

The upward movement of recovery from the depths of panic depression is always slow, even when it is not retarded or checked by extraordinary interference with the normal operations of productive industry and trade. After such depression as that of 1873, for example, the movement of recovery may be extended over a period of six or seven years.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The President, accompanied by Private Secretary Thurber, returned from a two hours' drive in the country around Washington at 9 o'clock tonight and found Attorney General Olney, Secretary Lamont, Major Gen. Schofield, and Postmaster General Bissell awaiting him at the Executive Mansion.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- The National Association of Marine Engineers will not go on a strike to assist other labor organizations. E.H. Kenny, Chairman of the local Grievance Committee and of the Headquarters Committee of the National Association of Marina Engineers, was seen in regard to the matter, and said:
ALBANY, July 10 -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Prisons gave a hearing in the Assembly Chamber this afternoon on the proposition to abolish prison contract labor.

We pointed out the other day that the chief feature of importance in the condition of the revenues of the United States was their relation to the currency, and that this was the thing that foreign capitalists invariably look at. There is a striking proof of the truth of this observation in the latest number of The London Economist, in its remarks on President Cleveland's statement of a fortnight since.

LONDON, July 10 -- George F. Sanford and Stewart Sherrill of the Yale athletic team were arraigned before a magistrate at Oxford to-day charged with setting off fireworks in the streets on the Fourth of July. The young men admitted the charge, but said they were not aware that they were violating the law until warned by the police, when they stopped their fun. They were released upon paying costs.
Presidents Cleveland's admonition to Gov. Altgeld that there is no intention to interfere with Gov. Altgeld's business of preserving the peace in Illinois was very admirably worded.

The labor leaders in this city were not so vehement in their utterances yesterday, yet they all expressed a belief that there would be a general strike and that the American Railway Union was sure of winning its contest in behalf of the employes of the Pullman Car Company.
The rumor that Police Commissioner John McClave, Republican, is about to resign his office was renewed yesterday.

PITTSBURG, July 10 -- The employes of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad received an order to-day from President Debs to go out on strike at noon to-day, but after holding a meeting this afternoon it was firmly decided not to comply with the order. The employes telegraphed President Debs to that effect.

ALBANY, July 10 -- In answer to many of the criticisms that have been thrown at the Constitutional Convention for its failure to accomplish anything after two months of work. Mr. Elihu Root said this morning to the correspondent for The New-York Times that the policy of the convention had been to thrash all the material in committee and to bring it into the convention in so perfect a shape as to prevent unnecessary discussion.

RYE, N.Y., July 10 -- A fashionable wedding took place in Christ Church at 5 o'clock this afternoon, when Miss Charlotte Wiggin, daughter of Augustus Wiggin of Rye, was married to Lieut. John Adams Perry of the Eighth United States Infantry, eldest son of Brig. Gen. Alexander J. Perry, United States Army.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 10 -- Secretary Baer of the United Societies of Christian Endeavor arrived in this city from Boston this noon, and said:

MERRICK, L.I., July 10 -- The Summer Assembly of the Epworth League chapters of Long Island opened this morning on the camp meeting grounds at this place. Nearly 1,000 persons were present. The majority of them came from Brooklyn on a special train in charge of Eugene M. Travis, President of the South Brooklyn District League.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 10 -- What started out as an afternoon of lively sport at Union Park was spoiled by heavy showers that fell before a race was finished. The five heats trotted on a dry track were up to Grand Circuit form. Monroe Salisbury's string was delayed on the way from Chicago, and only reached here late this forenoon.
CHICAGO, July 10 -- The manifesto of Gen. eral Master Workman Sovereign to the Knights of Labor was issued to-night. It bears the date Chicago, July 10, and is as follows:
BETHLEHEM, N.H., July 10 -- The second day's session of the American Institute of Instruction was opened at Craft Hall this morning, Supervisor George H. Martin of Boston in the chair.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- "It is labor lost; not 150 Mayors would have the slightest effect on the Pullman Company," said Mayor Hopkins this morning, when asked if Mayor Pingree of Detroit had asked him to become one of fifty Mayors to join in an appeal to Mr. Pullman to allow the differences between him and his men to be submitted to arbitration.
TROY, N.Y., July 10 -- The Senate investigating committee resumed its hearing here this afternoon, and heard some interesting testimony.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The steamship lines, through their attorneys, have written to Superintendent Stump in reply to his recent decision requiring them to pay for the maintenance of immigrants pending examination by the United States authorities.

CONEY ISLAND, July 10 -- William H. McKelvey, recently appointed Inspector of Police of the Fifth District of Brooklyn, which comprises the former towns of Flatbush, Gravesend, and New-Utrecht, was tonight the guest at a dinner at the Manhattan Beach Hotel, arranged in his honor by his friends of the Seventh Ward, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, July 10 -- The market for local stocks was generally dull, but was fairly strong, and where any activity was shown scored what, for this market, was quite an advance. West End Land rights advanced to 9, and West End Street Railway rose 1/2 from last night's close, to 46 1/4. Both were quite active.

BABYLON, L.I., July 10 -- Gov. Roswell P. Flower paid his first visit to Babylon and Fire Island to-day. He arrived on a way train in time to take the State steamer Ripple, to whose pier he was driven in an open carriage drawn by a finely-caparisoned team of blacks owned by Edward Daily, an old-time Suffolk County Democrat.

One result of the farce-tragedy prepared by Debs has been to induce very serious reflection upon the part of the American people in general upon the civilization, or the want of civilization, of the Western people. It has been one of the leading characteristics of the American people in general that they were a law-abiding people.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- There was more business transacted to-day on the Exchange than for several past sessions, and the most active stocks, West Chicago and Alley L, appreciated in value. The former sold between 134 and 135, closing at 134 1/2, and the latter closed 5/8 higher as compared with the final sales of yesterday, or at 14 3/4.

A score of men representing labor organizations met in this city on Monday evening and issued a call for a mass meeting to be held to-morrow night. The primary purpose of the meeting, as stated in the call, is "to express sympathy with the Pullman employes and with President Debs and his followers."

DENVER, Col., July 10 -- The railway situation in Colorado is rapidly clearing up, and trains are going on all roads. A committee of the wealthiest citizens of Leadville have offered their services to the Rio Grande to serve in any capacity. As coke has been brought from Omaha, the Denver smelters will not be closed.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate has passed the Post Office Appropriation bill without amendment. A determined effort was made to-day to strike out the paragraph in the bill which calls for a subsidy of $196,614,22 for the fast mail between Springfield, Mass., and Atlanta and New-Orleans, but it failed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- The officials of the Penn Steel Casting and Machine Company of Chester, Penn., who are charged with furnishing the Government with gun castings of an inferior character, were given a further hearing to-day. Lieut. Charles W. Ruschenberger of the navy, at one time Government Inspector at the works, testified that when the bars were found to be right he sometimes authorized Manager Boldt and the company's chemist to do the stamping.

White ribbons to tell of sympathy with the Western strikers were distributed on the platform of the Cooper Union last night and were eagerly accepted and tied in the buttonholes of coats worn by men who attended the mass meeting of the Journeyman Tailors' Protective and Benevolent Union.

The New-York State Democracy is now fully organized in this city. Its Executive Committee, made up of two members from each of the thirty Assembly districts and empowered to add forty others by the County Committee, met in the small meeting hall of Cooper Union last night. There were only four absentees.

The stock market yesterday assumed a waiting attitude. Ail reports agreed that the railroads centring at Chicago were having less trouble in moving trains, but disturbances were reported on the Missouri Pacific and Louisville and Nashville. Furthermore, the threat of the labor leaders to cell out workmen in the general trades checked any disposition to undertake new ventures.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10 -- President John McBride of the United Mine Workers said to the United Press correspondent to-day that he would promulgate no order calling the miners out to co-operate with the American Railway Union.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 10 -- Despite the desperate and prolonged rairoad strikes nearly four thousand determined pedagogues have already reached Asbury Park, and others are still on their way. About two hundred from Chicago, a hundred and fifty from Georgia, and several hundred other Southern delegates arrived by special train.
CHICAGO, July 10 -- Judge Grosscup's charge to the Grand Jury is as follows:

At the meeting of the Board of Rapid-Transit Commissioners yesterday in its offices, 256 Broadway, a resolution was adopted declaring that the route and plans located and approved by the commission organized under the act of 1891 should, if practicable, be adopted by the present commission, to the end that the question of municipal construction of a rapid-transit railway be submitted to the electors at the general election in November.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 11 -- After the soaking it got last evening the course at Saginaw Park dried out quickly in the blazing heat this forenoon, and the Grand Circuit steppers trotted before another good-sized crowd. The two events left unfinished yesterday came first, and that for three-minute trotters proved easy enough for Expressive, as Monte Criato.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Postmaster Dayton was at the Capitol to-day, having completed his business with the Postmaster General, from whom he had secured all the necessary authority to enable him to proceed with the reorganization suggested by the commission, and he will at once take steps to establish the sub-stations allowed by the department.

SARATOGA, July 11 -- Saratoga this afternoon sent a trainload of teachers and art teachers to the National Educational Association at Asbury Park. The two State associations rapidly disposed of their business here this morning, in order that the members might attend the national body. The unfortunate clashing of dates was the cause of the rush and sudden exodus.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Mr. Haskins, chief clerk of the Dockery commission of experts, has returned from New-York, where the experts have been engaged for the past six weeks investigating the Custom House, Surveyor, and Naval Office. They have concluded their labors and are now engaged in collaborating the data, preparatory to beginning the preparation of their written report, which they expect to submit to Secretary Carlisle within a few weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Attorney-General Olney is not disturbed by the threats made by labor leaders to impeach him. He had no opinion to express to-day on the subject, he said, and had received no call from the labor leaders or their attorneys, and was not expecting any.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 11 -- Cleveland was gayly dressed in yellow and white and red, white, and blue this morning, when the delegates to the big Christian Endeavor Convention began arriving in force. Nearly every store, shop, and other business establishment in the down-town district was profusely decorated.

ALBANY, July 11 -- The second day's fight between those war veterans, Controller James A. Roberts and Secretary of State John Palmer, over another veteran, who was appointed by the latter to a post worth $4 a day, in violation -- so the former alleges -- of the civil service laws, was continued to-day.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 11 -- This morning finds ten roads tied up -- the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton, the Pennsylvania, the Wabash, the Hocking Valley, the Wheeling and Lake Erie, the Ohio Central, the Michigan Central, the Lake Shore, the Ann Arbor, and the Clover Leaf. There were no disturbances during the night and everything is quiet to-day.

There is at least one place where light seems to be breaking in on the true measure of the A.P.A. movement, and where, according to some observers, it is going down hill, as it must go as soon as the people understand its vicious methods and un-American principles.

A call has been issued by the Reorganization Committee of the Union Pacific Railroad for the deposit of the securities of that company and sixteen subordinate lines. The efforts of the committee up to the present time, it is asserted, have been directed toward the readjustment of the company's debt to the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Numerous letters have been received by the Postmaster General from railroad managers on whose lines the mails are carried, requesting the views of the Government as to the duties of the railway Companies in carrying the mails while the labor disturbances exist throughout the country.

ALBANY, July 11 -- The Constitutional Convention's Committees on Legislative Powers, Education, Taxation, and Charities gave a final hearing to-day on the question of abolishing sectarian appropriations.

President Chauncey M. Depew of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad beamed benignantly upon everybody in his office, at the Grand Central Station, yesterday, for he was pleased with the signs from Chicago.

BOSTON, July 11 -- The cruiser Minneapolis, which left Philadelphia Monday afternoon for her official trial trip, came to anchor off Boston Light, ten miles down the bay, at 2 o'clock this afternoon, after a fast and uneventful run from the Delaware Capes. The Minneapolis would have reached Boston five or six hours earlier but for the fact that she made the preliminary run over the official course to-day, instead of to-morrow.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The strike that has been pending in the Trenton Potteries since Jan 1 last was settled here to-day through the intervention of Senator Smith.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 11 -- Four fresh shocks of earthquake were felt here to-day. Many buildings have fallen, and others are on the verge of toppiing over. Many inmates of houses and shops and persons in the streets were caught by the falling walls and killed or injured.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- There was a decidedly bouyant feeling prevailing among operators on the Stock Exchange this morning, and higher prices were readily established for some of the leading stocks. This was due entirely to a belief that the backbone of the strike is broken and that it will not be long before normal conditions again prevail, at least so far as this city is concerned.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- The national headquarters of the Knights of Labor were deserted to-day by all the chiefs, none but assistants being in charge. Secretary John W. Hayes and Thomas B. McGuire and C. A. French of the Executive Board were in Washington yesterday in consultation with the attorneys for the Knights of Labor.

The State canvass in Alabama is pretty well advanced, as the election takes place on the 6th of August. As the most effective means of drawing support from Reuben F. Kolb, the candidate for Governor against Congressman Oates, the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee has issued a document to prove that he is practically a Republican candidate.

BUFFALO, July 11 -- Erie County formally launched Controller James A. Roberts as a candidate for Governor to-day. At a meeting of the Republican General Committee, representing every election district in the county, the following resolutions were unanimously adopted:
