WORCESTER, Mass., July 11 -- The Worcester Evening Gazette [United Press] last night made the following allusion to an editorial in yesterday morning's Spy, [Associated Press]:

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 11 -- Catherine Nolan, aged twenty-two, and her sister Elizabeth, aged sixteen, were received at the county jail, in Ballston Spa, this forenoon, on a warrant of Coroner Stubbs of Waterford, committing them to await the action of the Grand Jury on the charge or the murder of their brother, John Nolan, by administering arsenic.

BOSTON, July 11 -- Local stocks were quiet, and there was no special feature to the market, which held very well, in some cases advancing slightly. Bell Telephone sold at 100, the same as yesterday, and Erie Telephone advanced 1/2, to 45 1/2. Boston and Albany was strong at 204. New-England Street Railway was quiet at 12.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A horrible story of enforced cannibalism is contained in a supplemental report made to the Treasury Department by Capt. Healy of the Bear, in connection with the rescue of a portion of the crew of the American schooner James Allen, from Umnak Island, on June 14. The vessel left San Francisco April 14, and was wrecked off Amelia Island, Alaska, May 11.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Peace and quiet were maintained throughout the city to-day. It was a welcome relief from the tension of yesterday, and especially in view of the fears that had been entertained that the general tie-up ordered by the various trades unions might result in filling the streets with sympathetic strikers and in seriour disorder being possibly provoked.

John Morris, President of the Journeymen Stonecutters' Association, was shot by George Harrison, a, member, at the regular weekly meeting of the association, in Brevoort Hall, 156 East Fifty-fourth Street, last evening.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., July 11 -- The first train to leave with troops was ditched on a trestle eight miles from Washington, Yolo County. Engineer Clarke was killed and a soldier was drowned. Another soldier was dangerously injured. Two soldiers are missing.

There seems to be a general disinclination among the railroad men of Brooklyn to strike out of sympathy for their colleagues in Chicago and elsewhere. They are interested in the result of the present labor troubles, but they believe they can do more good for their cause by giving financial aid than by striking.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 11 -- The organizations belonging to the Knights of Labor in this city have held no meetings to take action upon the general order to go out. It is improbable there will be any strike at this point.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 11 -- Delegates to the National Educational Association are still coming, every train from New-York and Philadelphia having on board from 25 to 200 teachers. It is estimated that over 1,000 educators from the Eastern States have found their way to this famous seaside resort within twenty-four hours.

NEWTOWN, L.I., July 11 -- Frank Tynann, a carpenter, twenty years old, attempted to kill Annie McCarthy, aged eig-hteen years, in this village to-night. She was walking on Broadway with William Clark, her brother-in-law, and William Wade, twenty years old, of 455 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, July 11 -- John Sabine Smith appeared before the Constitutional Convention Committee on Apportionment to-night and continued the arguments in favor of the proposed apportionment amendment prepared by the Republican Club of New-York City.

On Monday evening the first of a series of living pictures will be produced at Eidorado, under the direction of Prof. Von Prittowitz Palm, Only two pictures will be presented; each will measure 31 by 18 feet, and will be the largest ever seen on any stage. Prof. Von Palm, has successfully produced pictures in all the large European capitals and in America.

ANTWERP, July 11 -- The United States cruiser Chicago, anchored in the roadstead here, was slightly injured this morning by contact with the tank steamer Azoff. The latter vessel, which was also anchored, broke her anchor chain and drifted against the Chicago, striking her broadside on. The Azoff was also damaged, but the injury to neither vessel is thought to be serious.

ST. PAUL, July 11 -- The Republican State Convention, which assembled here this morning, had 1,011 delegates. No nominations were made until 4:15 this afternoon, when Gov. Nelson and Lieut. Gov. Clough were nominated by acclamation.

ALBANY, July 11 -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Banking gave a hearing to-night on the amendment introduced by Mr. Riggs of Brooklyn providing for the taxation of the stock of trust companies and private banks. There ware present William Sherer, Secretary of the New-York Clearing House: Edward Ellsworth of the Poughkeepsie Savings Bank; J. Howard King.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 11 -- Gen. James B. Fry, United States Army, retired, died at 5 o'clock this afternoon, at the Case cottage, Kay Street, where he was spending the Summer. His family attribute his illness to overwork when he was Provost Marshal General of the army, just before his retirement, several years ago.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 11 -- Every train in and out of this city to-day has had on board a squad of United States troops. This has been done to prevent a repetition of the lawless acts of last night, when trains on the outskirts were stoned and passengers terrorized.

The pages of The Congressional Record which report the proceeding's and debates of the United States Senate for Tuesday and Wednesday, July 10 and 11, will be to the reader of that depressing publication like an oasis in the desert. The 8,000 or more pages that have preceded these have been filled with speeches, many of them not only dreary beyond all conception, but some of them very shameful in the spirit they have indicated.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Again to-night the President and his advisers were in consultation at the White House over the strike situation. At 9 o'clock Mr. Cleveland returned from a long drive with Secretary Lament and Private Secretary Thurber. Postmaster General Bissell arrived at the same time, followed soon after by Secretary Gresham and Major Gen. Schofield.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The wave of patriotism which swept through the Senate Chamber yesterday, engulfing anarchy and Populism, and bearing the assurance to the President that his efforts to suppress mob violence were in harmony with the best thought of the country, caused action to-day which will appeal to every loyal heart.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Following is the full text of the Land-Grant Forfeiture bill introduced by Representative McRae of Arkansas, which passed the House this afternoon:

Thomas C. Platt returned from Owego yesterday, and some of the Republican politicians were much interested in consequence. What is of particular interest to them now is the meeting of the Republican State Committee, which will soon be called to determine which Is the regular organization in this city, so that the Police Commissioners can determine from which list to name the Inspectors of Election, poll clerks, and ballot clerks.

PORT TAMPA, Fla., July 11 -- The revenue cutter McLane, Capt. O.S. Willey, arrived here Monday, and reports having seized the Spanish schooners Cuba, Antonio Suarez, Domingilo Sardina, Carmene, Adalante, and Juan Capdoton, all of Havana, for violation of the revenue laws and the Quarantine regulations.

Conferences Which, it was surmised, dealt with the independent investigation of the Police Department by Commissioners Martin and Sheehan, Superintendent Byrnes, and Assistant District Attorney Wellman were had yesterday at Police Headquarters, the Mayor's office, and the District Attorney's office.

ALBANY, July 11 -- A breeze was narrowly averted in the Constitutional Convention this morning by the discovery that Judge Mirabeau L. Towns of the Second District had prepared a substitute for the resolutions which were introduced yesterday by Delegate Dean, (Rep., Chautauqua,) and which, under the rules, went over. Mr. Dean's resolutions applauded President Cleveland for the manner in which he quieted the crazy strike at Chicago.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- General Secretary Hayes, of the Knights of Labor, when asked to-day if he and his associates of the Executive Committee were going to Chicago, replied:

BALTIMORE, July 11 -- The issuance of General Master Workman Sovereign's appeal to Knights of Labor to quit work will have no immediate effect here. Ten years ago the Knights of Labor had 50,000 members here; to-day there are less than 1,000, and none of these are in the employ of the railroads.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- In the excitement incident to the exhibition by the Senate yesterday of its preference for order and law over the vagaries of Peffer, the fact was lost sight of that the bill admitting Utah to the Union was passed. Just before adjournment, Mr. Faulkner, Chairman of the Committee on Territories, secured unanimous consent to consider the bill.

A graphic story of the painful progress of little children through the primary schools of Brooklyn was printed in The New-York Times yesterday. To-day's story deals with their entry into the grammar schools.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 11 -- To-day ex-President Harrison received a telegram from James W. Riggs, a member of the New-York Constitutional Convention, saying that the criticism imputed to him of President Cleveland's use of the Federal troops had been disapproved on the floor of the convention.

The proclamations this week by the President have already taken rank with utterances of his which have become historic. The chief difference in effect between what he said before and now says is that while before he compelled admiration for his courage and frankness, the opposite party did not always commend him; now his praise is universal.

The income-tax feature of the Tariffbill, like the rest of the measure, was considerably modified in its progress through the Senate. Depositors in savings banks, insurers in mutual companies, and investors in charitable, educational, or religious associations were exempted in terms express and secure.

About this time of year it is easy for even an unobservant person to note how the world takes its recreation. The result of even a moderate amount of discernment must be a conclusion that those who get the most enjoyment out of the Summer months are the very wealthy and those of moderate means.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., July 12 -- Strikers were less conspicuous on the streets to-day than heretofore. The people feel that the soldiers have had their feelings aroused by the stirring incidents of yesterday, and that they are not to be trifled with. The crowd of spectators around the picket line that bounds the station is very small, and the sentries are treated with marked courtesy.

The third annuel 100-mile handicap road race, run under the auspices of the Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark, N.J., will be run to-morrow, rain or shine, over the famous Newark-Princeton course. The race starts promptly at 8 A.M., and has a time limit of eleven hours.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: "At Pittsburg in 1877 three regiments of State troops got whipped out of their boots by a mob of strikers. The next day Just forty regular United States soldiers, under the command of a Lieutenant, quietly got out of the cars and put the mob to flight, and the leaders surrendered to the Lieutenant.

PITTSBURG, July 12 -- The Pittsburg Club signalized its return home to-day by losing to New-York. The home team was in a fair way to win in the fourth inning, when Rusie was substituted for German. Proper fielding would have saved Killen the four runs the visitors made off him in the first inning.

ROME, July 12 -- The Rev. Dr. Burtsell of Rondout, N.Y., will leave for home on July 17. His prolonged stay here has been due to the Pope's request that he remain. Father Burtsell will receive the Papal benediction, which he will convey to the Catholic parishes of Rondout and his relatives and friends.

BOSTON, July 12 -- Continued dullness and apathy characterize the market for local stocks. Both buyers and sellers are lacking, but when the former come into the market, even to a slight extent, prices advance, and when the latter, prices decline. The telephones rose a littte on small sales.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Dr. George O. Glavis, attorney for Atlantic steamship lines running from New-York to Europe, to-day appeared before the House Committee on Immigration, and spoke of the discrimination which is in operation under the present law against the lines of ships he represents, and which, favor the Canadian steamship companies.

OAKLAND, Cal., July 12 -- Early this morning about 150 strikers left their headquarters and went to the vicinity of Cedar Avenue and Seventh Street, where a few nights ago they derailed a flat car at the crossing. A long Oakland local train lay a short distance down the Mole in the same place where it has been stalled since one week ago.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- It is the opinion of careful and conservative observers to-night that the strike, so far as Chicago and its vicinity are concerned, is dying by inches. There may be a few more manifestations of its continued existence, in the form of minor walk-outs and similar demonstrations, but these will be but the spasms that precede final dissolution.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 12 -- Everything was quiet in Toledo to-day. Men are still out on ten roads, although on the Ohio Central and Pennsylvania they would go to work at any time if they were not in fear of violence at the hands of the strikers. Strikers are talking a good deal and making threats, but nothing more serious.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 12 -- The story of the reappearance of Fred A. Gower, telegraphed from Boston, finds few believers here among his old friends and acquaintances. The information came from a private letter in which the correspondent stated that Gower had reappeared in London, England.
After its long delay in reaching the Navy Appropriation bill, the Senate, as was expected, made short work of that measure, concurring promptly in most of its provisions as they had passed the House.

The collapse of the strike boom in this city is complete. There was not a labor agitator in town yesterday who ventured to suggest a tie-up. Officers of the Knights of Labor still said that if General Master Workman Sovereign should issue a call for a strike, it would be obeyed.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12 -- The basiness of building stone roads in New-Jersey has become a fixed one, and the State Commisioner, Edward Burroughs, has opened an office in the State House, where he will give his undivided attention to the subject of stone-road building. He has practically been at the head of the industry for sevral years, but not in the way that he is now.

Police Justice Robert E. Connollyl. Police Justice Robert E. Connolly, who for years had been well known in Democratic political circles in Brooklyn, but who has not enjoyed the best of health for several years, died at Grout Lake, Warren County, N.Y., yesterday.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 12 -- The result of the Seabright tournament this afternoon leaves Stevena and Chace still undefeated, and to-morrow will see the final round, the winner of which will play Larned, who is the present holder of the Seabright Cup. Chace seems to be the favorite, although Stevens has won the all-comers' for two separate years and is playing in fine form.

St. Andrew's Church, Harlem, was the scene of a pretty wedding yesterday, when Miss Martina De Lancey Wilkins, daughter of the late Lewis Morris Wilkins of the United States Navy, was married to William Shattuck Gould of Chicago, The Rev. Gouverneur Morris Wilkins, brother of the bride, officiated.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 12 -- Though there were slight manifestations of earthquake throughout the night, the city resumed something like its normal aspect this morning, the shops opening, and the inhabitants returning to their homes, whence they had fied.

The committee appointed to arrange for the championship meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, which takes place at Saratoga on July 21, met yesterday at the office of President James E. Sullivan and completed its plans. Those present were John Steil, New-York Turn Vereln; E.W. Hjertberg, Twenty-second Regiment Athletic Association; George Wood, S.A.C.; F.J. Barnes, W.A.A., and P.J. Doollng, Xavier Athletic Association.

The cornerstone for the chapel of the Embury Methodist Episcopal Church, at Lewis Avenue and Decatur Street, Brooklyn, was laid last night with impressive ceremonies. Three thousand persons were present.

, July 12 -- The Christian Endeavor Convention managers are enthusiastic to-night over the unexpected success of the meeting in point of numbers. Evidently the people have recovered from their panic over the railway strike and are coming to Cleveland as rapidly as the railroads can carry them.

The main purpose of the billl introduced in the House of Representatives by Mr. Straus of this city "to regulate railroad companies engaged in inter-State commmerce" is to prevent the abuses in management which have wrecked so many railroad properties, to the enrichment of those who have manipulated them and the impoverishment of those who have invested in them.

The Wall Street Journal makes a very good point, and one worthy to be pondered in contrasting the behavior of Chicago and St. Louis at the beginning of Debs's strike. If St. Louis had behaved as Chicago, St. Louis would probably have suffered like Chicago. But St. Louis had been there before, and knew what a great railroad strike was like and what an unmitigated nuisance it was.

ALBANY, July 12 -- The policy of the Constitutional Convention was explained fully by Elihu Root this morning in the course of a debate on a motion to adjourn. Mr Root said that there was no necessity for the convention to sit for two or three hours a day, that the members ought to be with their committees, where the great bulk of the work was being done.

Harry Reed, the two-year-old gelding which M.F. Dwyer purchased of John E. Madden for the reputed price of $12,000. Is proving a very costly animal for the Brooklyn "plunger." Up to yesterday the colt had cost Mr. Dwyer much more in bets than the colt cost originally, and yesterday, at the Brighton Beach track, Mr. Dwyer lost several thousand dollars more by backing the apparently much over-estimated youngster.

In the columns of The New-York Times the quick and painful progress of the children of Brooklyn through the primary and grammar schools of that city has been described. There remains but one more chapter. It deals with their hurried flight through the high school.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: South Carolina dearly loves politics. There is no doubt of it. This has appeared in many forms. In the early days it took the guise of what was called and is still known in history as patriotic opposition to England's aggressions. We owe much to Goldwin Smith for stripping some of the false glamour from this era of our history.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Two important assignments of naval officers were made today by Secretary Herbert. He designated Rear Admiral Kirkland as commander of the European naval station, although no orders to that effect were Issued, and ordered Commodore C.C. Carpenter to assume command of the Asiatic station.

"There can be no doubt that the A.P.A. is an outgrowth of Orangeism; in fact its councils are Orange lodges under another name. The objects of the two organizations are the same, except that the A.P.A. goes further than the Orange institution in its antagonism to Roman Catholics."

Justice Barrett rendered a decision yesterday in the case of Erastus Wiman, now in the Tombs under sentence upon a conviction of forgery, granting a certificate of reasonable doubt as to the legality of the conviction.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- It was a very quiet day on the Exchange, but at the same time the market was decidedly firm for the favorite stocks, with no disposition toward increasing business at the expense of values. The situation is not yet sufficiently settled to bring many investors into the market, and speculators are disposed to await further developments.

NEWARK, N.J., July 12 -- The annual meeting of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey was held at the Atalanta Wheelmen Clubhouse to-night. Delegates were present from the Tourist Cycle Club, Paterson; Montclair Wheelmen, Elizabeth Athletic Club Cyclere, Bergen County Wheelmen, Englewood Wheelmen, Elizabeth Wheelmen, Union County Roadsters, Rahway; Hudson County Wheelmen, Jersey City, and Atalanta Wheelmen.

LONDON, July 12 -- G.L. Fox of New-Haven took a party of Americans out to Rugby School to-day to show the boys how to play baseball. Those who played were Ames and Brice of Harvard, Thomson and Fox of Yale, Harrison and Safford of Williams, Rolfe, Thomas, and Walker of Amherst, and Davis of Groton Mass. The other members of the two nines were taken from Rugby.

Several railroad companies of this city are taking proceedings, by writ of certiorari, for the purpose of reviewing the action of the Commissioners of Taxation and Assessments in making assessments upon the property of the companies for this year. Writs of certiorari have been granted by Judge Andrews in a half dozen cases.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., July 12 -- The last day's session of the American Institute of Instruction was called to order by President Martin this morning in Crafts Hall. "The Every-day Uses of Herbartianism" was the first subject for discussion. Miss Margaret R. Smith of Oswego gave a detailed explanation of the system, and was followed in a further explanation by John T. Prince or the Massachusetts Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Cleveland informed a committee representing organized labor this afternoon that he would, in the near future, appoint a commission, composed of three members, of whom the United States Commissioner of Labor shall be the Chairman, under Chapter 1,063 of the Laws of 1888, to inquire into and investigate thoroughly the causes leading up to the present labor disturbances of the country.
Not only one but two dangers, each of them of the gravest nature, will beset the strikers if there shall be an attempt to bring about in New-York the disturbances which have prevailed in Chicago.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- Prendergast must die on the gallows to-morrow. The last loophole of escape from capital punishment was closed to-day for the murder of Carter H. Harrison Oct. 28 last.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 12 -- To-day the Populists of this State living in the back counties "set sail" overland for Little Rock, where, if promises shall be made good, one of the largest political conventions known to modern times will take place on July 19.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- London quotations again influenced opening prices, and as there was no support, prices were inclined to shade off. Very little strike news reached Philadelphia, and what was reported from Chicago showed the situation there to be improving. The anxiety now is about June and July earnings.

Nearly all the members of the committee appointed at the Southern conference at the Fifth Avenue Hotel June 12 to formulate plans for bringing into closer relation the business interests of the North and the South responded to the call for a meeting yesterday at the Mutual Life Building. The object of the meeting was to effect a permanent organization and lay out a plan of work.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- About all the news that is obtainable to-day of the work of the conference committee on the Tariff bill is conjecture, and a good deal of it is contradictory. The conferrees are about as reticent as it is possible for men engaged in a secret business to be, and even the most intimate friends of the members are able to obtain merely general and immaterial statements from them.
BOSTON, July 12 -- The hearing on the petition for permission to issue New-York and New-England receivers certificates was resumed this forenoon before Special Master Ware.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The progress made by the Senate to-day in the matter of annual appropriation bills was on a par with that made by it at the beginning of the present week. Bills which in previous Congresses have provoked long debates and occupied the time of the Senate for days and weeks have glided through during the past few days, meeting hardly an impediment.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- All local trains are running over the Santa Fe. Two overland Eastern trains, one of which was in two sections, have arrived, and one overland freight has been sent out on the Santa Fe.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- The managers of the Western Union Telegraph and the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company have been subpoenaed in Chicago, Milwaukee, and various other cities to appear and produce the telegraphic correspondence of Debs and other parties connected With the Pullman boycott and strike.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., July 12. -- Mrs. Mary Fahey of 47 East Seventy-sixth Street and Mrs. Barnes of West Fifty-third Street, New-York, narrowly escaped drowning while bathing at Sea Side this afternoon. Mrs. Fahey was carried out by a high wave. Life Saver Oscar Engel brought her ashore unconscious. Mrs. Barnes ventured out too far and was swept off her feet.

County Clerk Henry D. Purroy sailed for Europe on the Fuerst Bismarck yesterday. He will travel for about two months in Denmark, Sweden, Austria, and Germany. Daring his absence Deputy County Clerk P.J. Scully will be Acting County Clerk. Mr. Purroy said before sailing that he hoped wise counsels would prevail in Tammany Hall, and that in a spirit of unity the organization would go to victory at the polls.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The battle of the Boyne was fought over to-night in the very heart of the city, and as a result about twenty Irishmen are nursing cracked heads and cut faces and a dozen more are in the police station charged with inciting a riot.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- The Briggs House was the centre of labor interests to-day. President Samuel Gompers of the American Federation of Labor and a large number of the leaders of various branches of that order assembled to discuss the advisability of declaring a general strike throughout the country at this time. Officers of the American Federation of Labor present were:

The Prince of Wales's cutter Britannia has persistently beaten the American sloop Vigilant, but she has broken faith with the sons of Britain in a most shameless manner. For years Americans have heard of nothing but vast seas and howling gales of wind as familiar features of British yachting.
HAWKINSVILLE, Ga., July 12 -- Judge Charles F. Crisp was unanimously renominated for Congress from the Third Georgia District to-day. The following resolutions were adopted:

BOSTON, July 12 -- The cruiser Minneapolis, which anchored down the harbor yesterday afternoon, got up her anchor this morning, and, after taking on board a pilot, started for Cape Ann, the southern end of the official course over which her speed is to be tested.

One of the Students of the relations between employers and employed is Ernest H. Crosby, who from 1886 to 1889 was member of Assembly from the old Twenty-first District of this city, Chairman of the Committee on Cities, and author of the High License bill which was vetoed three times by Gov. Hill. Mr. Crosby, when he left the Legislature, was appointed a Judge of the International Court at Alexandria, Egypt.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., July 12 -- The School of Applied Ethics opened its third annual session to-day with an'attendance of seventy-five students. As in former years, the work of the school is divided into three departments -- economics, with Prof. Adams of Michigan University at its head; ethics, under Prof. Adler of New-York, and the history of religions, with Prof. Toy of Harvard University as director.
LONDON, July 12 -- A dispatch from Seoul, the capital of Corea, says:
ROTHESAY, July 12 -- To-day's race closed the Clyde regattas, leaving the Vigilant with a record of six consecutive defeats.
PITTSBURG, July 12 -- At Union Station to-day all trains were within a few minutes of regular time. There was a very perceptible increase in travel from Western cities.

JACKSON, Miss., July 12 -- The Democrats of the Third District, in convention at Vicksburg, renominated Congressman Catchings by acclamation. A resolution was passed, urging the Senators of the State to favor such change in the existing Senate rules as will properly limit debate and facilitate the discharge of business.

CHRISTIANIA, July 13 -- The yacht Saide has brought to Promsoe a dispatch dated at Danes Island, on the northwest coast of Spitzenbergen, on May 10, by Walter Wellman, the Polar explorer. The dispatch said:
MONTREAL, July 13. -- The arrest this afternoon of George W. Coulson, alias Carter, at Bangor, N.Y., on the charge of opium smuggling, has caused a sensation in this city.

ALBANY, July 13 -- Certificates for Cornell free scholarships have been sent to the successful candidates who underwent competitive examinations in June in the several counties, from the office of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- There was a decidedly better feeling on the Exchange to-day and more business was transacted, while prices were decidedly higher. There were some good buying orders on the floor, and the shorts, somewhat alarmed, rushed to cover. The strike situation is looked upon as favorable, and it is believed that the end of the trouble is at hand.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Republican attempt to make political capital out of the failure of the Democratic members of the conference committee to admit the Republican conferrees to their deliberations thus far came to an inglorious end this morning.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Senate to-day passed the River and Harbor bill and all but twenty pages of the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill was agreed to.
Erastus Wiman is free once more. He was released yesterday from the Tombs on $30,000 bail furnished by Charles Broadway Rouss, a Broadway merchant.

BOSTON, June 13 -- The officers of the Minneapolis trial board finished their inspection to-day. The crew of the vessel took a much-needed rest, the fires were allowed to go out, and the boiler tubes were cleaned. Everything is now in readiness for the trial, and it the weather should not be unfavorable the run will be made to-morrow.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As the privilege is usually accorded to the woman to have the last word, may I ask, through your columns, to make a short reply to your correspondent "W.C.C.," whose argument against woman suffrage is substantially that every ballot must represent a bullet, hence woman must be deprived of a vote because physically unable to enforce it at the point of the bayonet?

ASBURY PARK, July 13 -- "The little red Schoolhouse" was eulogized in a way that would have delighted the soul of Horace Mann and John G. Whittier by the educators who took part in the sessions of the American Educational Association to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Another shot was fired to-day at the seventeen-inch curved barbette plate made by the Carnegie Company for the battleship Oregon, at the Naval Proving Grounds. This time a Carpenter shell was used, taken from the same lot that failed to penetrate the Bethlehem seventeen-inch plate several weeks ago.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 13. -- The policy of Connecticut in regard to the education and training of the blind will be radically changed in September, when the new institute to be supported by the State will be opened here for all blind children in Connecticut under ten years of age.

TOULON, July 13 -- While the new French iron-clad Carnot was being launched at the naval yards here yesterday flames burst from her. The fire was quickly extinguished, when a quantity of matches and a bottle of turpentine were discovered to have been the cause of the fire.

The news that Debs had offered to call off the American Railway Union's sympathetic strike and leave the Pullman employes to settle their own troubles created consternation among local labor leaders and agitators yesterday. They at first refused to believe that Debs had acknowledged defeat, and declared the report a hoax until confirmation became so strong that they had to accept it as true.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- In deciding to appoint a "commission to investigate the late strike and the occasion of the controversy between certain railroads which were affected thereby and their employes," the President and his advisers have construed that the sections of the O'Neill act authorizing the appointment of a Presidential commission of inquiry convey an authority separate and distinct from the other sections providing for arbitration.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Eugene V. Debs and his associates in the management of the railroad strike, recognizing at last the futility of prolonging the contest, made an effort to-day to end matters with as little outward evidence of defeat as possible.

Charles S. Smith. ex-President of the Chamber of Commerce, has received from the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst a letter, written at Vevay, Switzerland, July 2, in which he addresses the citizens of this city upon the Mayoralty issue as follows:

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 13 -- The shock of earthquake which was felt in this city at 4:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon equaled in severity any of the seismic manifestations which preceded it, and affected a large area of territory.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 13. -- The number of Endeavorers in the city this morning was larger even than on yesterday. Several thousand belated delegates arrived during the night and early morning hours, so that when the second day's sessions began in the hall, tent, and churches that had been pressed into service for the overflows, the attendance lacked very little of the 40,000 originally counted upon.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Sugar is the stumbling block of the conference on the Tariff bill, and it is the greatest menace to the success of the conferrees. The country will be deprived of a tariff bill only by the persistence of the sugar Senators -- who are not representing the production of sugar, but the protection of the renners -- in their bold demands.

TRENTON, N.J., July 13. -- There came into existence to-day two monster trolley railway corporations. Articles of incorporation were filed in the Secretary of State's office of the Central New-Jersey Traction Company and the New-York and Philadelphia Traction Company, with a capital stock of $10,500,000. The fee for filing certificate and the deposits required by the railroad law were $28,000.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 13 -- M.J. Moore, a sixteen-year-old forger, was arrested and locked up nere to-night. He lived with his grandmother, Mary Bates, at Clinton Corners. Last May Mrs. Bates negotiated with the Danbury Savings Bank for a loan of $300 on her twentyeight-hundred-dollar property in Danbury.

From The Springfield (Mass.) Republican, July 10. Local interest in the now celebrated car contract which was one of the causes leading up to the great Pullman strike is heightened by the tact that the Wason Car Company was one of the bidders for the work. George C. Fisk, President of the Brightwood Company, in a conversation yesterday, made some interesting statements about the matter.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 13. -- Judge Taft of the United States Court of Appeals to-day found Phelan, sent here by Debs to manage the local strike, guilty of contempt in interfering with the operation of the Southern Railroad, now in the hands of a United States receiver, and sentenced him to six months in jail.

ALBANY, July 13 -- It may be stated with "semi-official" positiveness that ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton will not be a candidate for Governor of the State of New-York on the Republican ticket, and that Jacob Sloat Fassett of Elmira will be nominated if Thomas C. Platt shall control the convention.

The six Senators who called upon the sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Finance just before that sub-committee revised its sugar schedule were Messrs. German, Brice, Smith, Hill, Caffery, and White. Mr. Gorman was leader and spokesman. He requested or demanded that the sub-committee should impose duties which, as we have heretofore shown, would have given the Trust protection equal to the protection enjoyed and utilized by it under the McKinley tariff.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 13. -- John Callaway and Joe Woodley were hanged in the yard of the county jail to-day for the assassination of a prominent young man, Edward Grant, in his store near Montgomery one night last March.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The officers and Directors of the American Railway Union held a special executive meeting at their headquaters in Ulich's Hall this morning, for the purpose of making a proposition to the railway managers looking to a calling off of the great strike.

TERRE HAUTE. Ind., July 13. -- The New-York express train on the Big Four, westbound, was wrecked at Fontanet, this county, at 2 o'clock this morning, and the engineer and fireman were killed. The engineer was named Moehrman of Indianapolis, and the fireman, Fleck, was from Mattoon. Their bodies were found under the wreckage.

The Babies' Hospital, at 657 Lexington Avenue, has a deserted appearance. There are reminiscences of babies everywhere in rows of little empty cribs, some of them with tiny baby caps, little gowns, and shoes lying around them, but not a baby is to be seen anywhere about the house.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 13 -- The bicycle races this afternoon at the athletic grounds attracted nearly 4,000 spectators. The meet was under the joint auspices of the Asbury Park Wheelmen and the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen. There Were six races on the card, two of the events being for Class B men. The handicaps and the open races were run in two heats, there being so many entries.

The Vaquero, a twenty-one footer, built by the Herreshoffs for Herman Duryea, won the second race of the series off Larchmont yesterday. The Vaquero was sailed by her owner and the race was a remarkably close one from start to finish. The Houri was the second boat, and she was beaten by 1 minute 28 seconds.

George M. Pullman, President of the Pullman Palace Car Company, who arrived in this city from the Thousand Islands yesterday morning, issued from the company's offices, in the Mills Building, last evening, the following statement regarding the strike of the Pullman employes, which was made the pretext for the general railroad strikes in the West, and especially referring to the proposition of the now defeated strike leaders for arbitration:

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 18 -- Malcolm Chace of Brown University was the winner in to-day's final in the Seabright tennis tournament, defeating Richard Stevens in three straight sets, 6 -- 4. 10 -- 8, 6 -- 4. Chace was a strong favorite, and though Stevens mode a hard fight, the match was practically decided at the end of the second set.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- International complications have arisen between the United States on the one hand, and Great Britain, France, Italy, and Belgium on the other, in regard to the recommendation of Gov. Jones of the Choctaw Nation, in the Indian Territory, for the removal of certain intruders among the miners there who have been on strike and committing all kinds of lawless acts in their fight against the Atoka Coal and Mining Company.

Muhammad Alexander Russell Webb, President of the American Moslem Brotherheod, has been locked out of the offices, at 30 East Twenty-third Street, of The Moslem World Publishing Company, which are also the headquarters of the brotherhood in New-York.

Trenton, N.J., July 13 -- Abram P. Fardon, who was for many years paying teller of the First National Bank of Paterson, was found guilty in the Federal Court to-day on a charge of abstracting $10,600 from the funds of the bank. He was convicted a few days ago of certifying a check whose maker had not enough money in the bank to meet the payment.

LOCK HAVEN, Penn., July 13 -- Fire swept through the centre of Millhall borough this afternoon, destroying twenty houses and as many stables. The Wilt Hotel, Brady's Hall, and the Christian Church were among the buildings burned. Seventeen families are homeless to-night.

BOSTON, July 13 -- There were more different stocks traded in to-day than for some time, but lots were generally small, though prices ranged somewhat higher. Bell Telephone advanced 1, to 192. New-England Telephone was strong at 62 1/2. The Erie Telephone officials met to-day to consider a further extension of their telephone system.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- The Marquis Imperiali of the Diplomatic Corps arrived to-night to visit William Post. Other prominent arrivals to-day were Seth Low, Orme Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. R.M. Hunt, Miss Winterhoff, Park Terrill, Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Dudgeon, Mrs. H.C. Harding, New-York; Mrs. J. Soales, Syracuse, and William E. Pearson and H.A. Pearson, Jersey City.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- The change in sentiment was shown decidedly in the advance in traction and other local stocks to-day. Even at the Close after a material advance there was every indication that to-day's rise was but the forerunner of a handsome general improvement. The tractions were all active except Baltimore, which somehow or another continues to be a laggard, selling at 13 1/8.
ALBANY, July 13 -- The Cities Committee of the Constitutional Convention has formulated a number of sections, which have been printed for the use of the members.

Our tennis players will have at least one English opponent this season, and one or no mean strength. M.F. Goodbody, the celebrated Irish player, has stated that he will compete in some of our tournaments. He will play with E.L. Hall in doubles at Narragansett, and, of course, will not miss the chance of winning at Newport a week later.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 13 -- Upon the arrival of what is known as the bankers' special this afternoon, and after the line of carriages had started away from the station, some one of the drivers turned his horses across the line at the junction of Brighton and Ocean Avenues, causing eight runaways and smash-ups.

Samuel J. Campbell, the Republican leader of the Twentieth Assembly District for the adherents of the regular Republican County Committee, organized under the direction of the Committee of Thirty, was arrested yesterday on a bench warrant charging him with receiving bribes while a ward detective under Police Captain Gunner.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 13 -- It required less than three hours to dispose of the card for the filth day of the Grand Circuit meeting, and only one at the three classes deserved the name of a contest. Rose Leaf walked off with the 2:21 trot for foals or 1890, improving her record by stepping the first heat in 2:17 1/2. The odds were 3 to 1 on the speedy young mare from Chicago.

The announcement that Debs had declared the strike off came into Wall Street shortly before noon, and had an instantaneous effect. Before that prices had hesitated somewhat, but on the news they strengthened and moved up sharply. The buying was not very heavy, but those who wanted stocks had to pay advancing prices and the general tone, notwithstanding the small volume of business, was decidedly encouraging.

James F. Caldwell, who starts the horses at the Brighton Beach race track, yesterday announced his intention of giving up his situation at the track because the Stewards of the meeting, Col. S.D. Bruce, H. D. Mclntyre, and J.A. Hennessy, would not support him in his attempts to discipline jockeys who were disobedient at the starting post.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 13 -- The closing event of the Teachers' Convention tonight gave a fitting round-up to the interesting week. The exercises were held in the immense auditorium, which the Methodists have built as the headquarters for their camp meeting and other religious or literary gatherings at Ocean Grove.

No formality of "calling off" the strikes of the American Railway Union and of the Knights of Labor, and no pretense that President Cleveland's decision to appoint a commission to inquire into the cause of the recent troubles is a concession to arbitration can conceal the fact that these strikes were an absolute and complete failure.

That wise old slave Aesop tells how the jaws and the arms refused to supply and to grind food for the stomach which, they said, was a lazy thing living on its neighbors. Of course, the rebellious members suffered and grew weak. As what we call science did not exist in Aesop's day, it isn't likely that even he understood the full force of this fable.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., July 13 -- The killing of four members of Battery L of the Fifth Artillery in the train wreck at the trestle two miles from Sacramento Wednesday last was in a measure avenged by regulars belonging to the same company to-day, two men, both, however, disclaiming to be strikers, being shot.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The friends of good roads in this vicinity are much en- couraged by the results of the recent good roads conference at Asbury Park. They realize that a vast amount of preliminary effort is necessary to arouse public interest to the necessity of improving the national highways, and are gratified with the increasing evidences that in every State in the Union there is growing dissatisfaction with the existing conditions.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 13. -- Patrick Eugene Prendergast, the murderer of Carter H. Harrison, Mayor of this city, was hanged to-day twenty minutes before the noon hour.

The carnival of sport arranged by the NewYork Archdiocesan Union of Catholic Clubs, to take place at Manhattan Field this afternoon, should prove to be a feature in the athletic history of the year. The speedlest and best-known performers in this vicinity will take part, and owing to the intense rivalry among the different organizations composing the union some remarkable competitions may be expected.

From The American Register, Paris. The following details in connection with the Julius Tower in Spandau, which is at present undergoing pretty heavy repairs, may prove of interest. It contains the war treasure of 120,000,000 marks, yielding no interest. This large sum, consisting of crowns and double crowns, is from time to time, without long notice, counted by two members of the Imperial Debt Committee.

"There is no free temporary home in New-York for respectable women," said William Blake, Superintendent of Outdoor Poor of the Department of Public Charities and Correction, to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday afternoon.

When a voice in the audience at Cooper Union on Thursday evening received the mention of the name of George M. Pullman with the cry "Hang him!" there was a prompt and general answering cry, "Vote the Socialist ticket!" That was much more sensible and democratic and decent.

BOSTON, July 14 -- There were no transactions in the Coppers to-day. In this country the metal is firmly held at former figures, and producers and jabbers are both hoping for higher prices on the expectation, of the revival of electrical construction. Chicago Junction Railway and Stock Yards sold at 94 1/4, ex-dividend, against yesterday's sales at 97, a recovery of 1 1/4 points. A few shares of the preferred sold at 99.

The constitutional amendments relating to the government of cities, tentatively put forward for consideration by the convention's Committee on Cities, suggests a danger that pervades many of the efforts to secure constitutional changes, that of trying to do too much. It is desirable to accomplish many things which it is neither necessary nor desirable to "fix" in the organic law of the State.

Recent disclosures have, to say the least, raised a presumption that there are irregular means of obtaining admission to the police force. It may be shown that the candidates who have paid money have been simply bunkoed -- that what appears to be an organized system of bribery may be merely a case of imposition on one side and ignorance on the other.

NTTHERWOOD, N.J., July 14 -- About 200 guests are stopping here for the season from the principal cities. Frank E. Miller, owner and proprietor of the Hotel Netherwood, is as popular as ever. All the conveniences possible in a first-class, well-regulated hotel are to be found here. The hotel is situated on the Heights, of Netherwood, with lovely surrounding's, commanding a charming view of this section of picturesque Jersey.

A small army of cyclists will leave Sag Harbor early this morning in the first century run ever held on Long Island. Should the day be pleasant the affair ought to be a memorable one in cycling history. The route selected lies through the south-shore towns, and is one of unuaual attractiveness, being for miles in view of the Atlantic Ocean.
SACRAMENTO, July 14 -- Harry A. Knox, the strike leader, was arrested at noon to-day. He is charged with complicity in the murder of the men who lost their lives in Wednesday's train wreck.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 14 -- The warm days and cool nights meet the hearty approval of the average Saratoga visitor, whether he comes here for health or recreation or for both. When at home he is the personification of business activity, but at this centre of bubbling mineral springs he is quite another individual.

From The Philadelphia Record. Down in the cellar of a dingy-looking old house at 8 Christian Street lives probably the only survivor of Sir Austin Henry Layard's expedition, which excavated the ruins of the ancient City of Nineveh in 1849 and 1850. Sir Henry himself died in London last week at the age of seventy-seven.
There is an urgent need, an imperative demand in Brooklyn for an increase in the water supply.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Gen. Schofield has received the following telegram from Gen. MeCook, at Denver:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 14 -- The tennis tournament of the Morris and Essex Lawn Tennis League was continued this afternoon on the grounds of the South Orange Field Club. A fashionable and appreciative crowd of spectators watched the games. The courts wore in splendid condition and the play was spirited. The scores were as follows:

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The big strike, although a thing of the past, as far as the General Managers of the great railroads seem concerned, is further than ever from settlement from the American Railway Union point of view. The labor leaders, furious over the treatment accorded their proposal for peace by the General Managers, are determined to fight it out to the end.
Heat was the feature of yesterday's weather that held its own the longest, but the thunderstorm that came late in the afternoon was more worthy of attention.

From The Detroit Journal. Readers of more than one afternoon newspaper in Detroit will doubtless remember that the early signs of a big railway strike in Chicago were made conspicuous in the columns of The Journal before there were any indications in the dispatches printed in another afternoon newspaper that there was to be any strike of importance.

CHAPTER XXIX. --"LET A PASSIONLESS CALM BE MINE." -- Continued. A very few days served, to re-establish Lady Dunluce in her old home, and with the old housekeeper, and the old secretary, end some of the old servants still about her It seemed to her almost as if the past ten years had been one long dreary dream -- endless and infinite after the manner of dreams.
The property referred to in the accompanying list will be sold at III Broadway except as otherwise stated:

While the Grand Circuit has not been dong enough in progress to develop the record-breakers of the year among harness horses, some of the meetings preceding the one at Saginaw during the past week brought several sensations to light. This is especially true of a short but extremely lively programme across the Canadian border at Windsor, Ontario.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 14 -- The Saengerfest of the German singing societies of Westchester County, which will be held here on Monday, promises to be the greatest event of the kind ever held in this village. The large Court House, banks, and all public and private buildings were to-day covered with bunting in various artistic designs.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 14 -- John W. Reinhart, President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, has closed his residence at Netherwood for the Summer and has joined his family at Hot Springs, Va.

BERLIN, July 14 -- The persistence of the Social Democratic beer boycott, the recent return of two more Social Democrats to the Reichstag, and the reaction following the assassination of President Carnot have tended to increase discussion of the necessity that new repressive laws be enacted against the Socialists in Germany.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- If the tape of the Chicago stock ticker is any criterion, the strike is not only dead and interred, but a boom in local securities is at hand. The unusual advance to-day was not a recovery from depressed prices caused by the labor troubles, for neither local stocks nor bonds depreciated more than a fraction because of the industrial embargo centred here early in the weeK.

Commodore Pryer of the Corinthian-Mosquito fleet offered a handsome silver cup for the 21-footers to race for yesterday, and, incidentally, to give the New-Rochellites a chance to see a good race between this new racing class. The yachtsmen who own these boats appreciated Commodore Pryer's offer so much that eight started in the contest for the cup, and of this number two made their first appearance in a race.

DEAL, BEACH, N.J., July 14 -- This has been an uneventful vveek here. But that doesn't mean that people haven't enjoyed themselves. Time has passed pleasantly, however, Boating, bathing, tennis, driving, and dancing have received a due and proper amount of attention.

LONDON, July 14 -- United States Ambassador Bayard, commenting on the report that he is about to visit the United States with the view of being returned to the United States Senate, to succeed Senator Higgins, said to a United Press representative to-day that the story was a piece of common gossip.

There is a pleasant tale of a parrot which had got itself into trouble through profane garrulity and been vigilantly ducked by its pious owner. As the bird was drying his drenched plumage in the sun, he was overheard to soliloquize in a still unregenerate fashion: "I talk too damn much!"

There were about 800 persons in and about the grand stand at Elkwood Park Pony Racing Association's pretty course near Long Branch yesterday, the first day of the present meeting. According to the programme, racing is to continue every Wednesday and Saturday hereafter throughout the season -- presumably the season at Long Branch.

PITTSBURG, Fenn., July 14 -- New-York outbatted Pittsburg to-day and won with ease. Meekin was hit hard in the first inning, but after that he had the Pirates dangling on a string. The errors by Scheibeck and Lyons were of great assistance to the visitors.
Truly this is the age of press agents. Those seductive individuals acting in the interests of theatres have become familiar institutions to the newspaper reading public.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 14 -- At the Hotel George, Black Rock, there has been considerable gayety during the past week. The hotel is well filled.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- While rushing along at a high speed, the Chicago and Northern Pacific suburban train for Forest Home ran into an open switch at Fourteenth and Roby Streets last evening, and crashed into a heavy Wisconsin Central freight engine standing on the next track. Three passengers on the suburban were injured in the wreck, both locomotives were ruined, and two coaches were telescoped.

No thinking man can have failed to noticed that nature, in providing man with two eyes, seems to have acted on a different principle from that which has guided her in providing him with two ears, two hands, and two feet. The ears, the hands, and the feet are each independent of the other.

Suess, in "Das Antlitz der Erde," and Neumayer, in "Erdesgesehichte," have attempted to show that the Mosaic account of the deluge was copied with little change from an original Assyrian version, and that it was a local flood which took place in the plains of the Tigris and Euphrates, not in the Valley of the Jordan.
Ward McAllister sailed for Europe yesterday on the Cunard Line steamship Campania.

KEENE HEIGHTS, Essex County, N.Y., July 14 -- It is interesting to watch the effect of the pure invigorating air of this elevated piateau upon the visitors who come here with faculties deadened by the heated and oppressed atmosphere of the city. In a day or two they seem to be new men and women taking a keen interest in everything about them.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 14 -- Midsummer, the season when the big hotels in the Catskills are the centre of gay life, and every little hamlet is filled with happy city people, who, in the quiet of the surrounding mountain heights, forget the heat and cares of town, is fast approaching, and is bringing with it a host of Summer guests.

From The Lewiston (Me.) Journal. The late Millionaire Bryant of Biddeford found one reason to sticking to old Maine on the tombstones. "I've been out West," he said to a boomer who was trying to interest him in a Western enterprise, "and I didn't see a stone with an older age than forty on it.
From The Contemporary Review. Mr. Stead contrasts the labor movement, in England and America vastly to the advantage of the former country:

Ex-President Benjamin Harrison arrived in this city from Indianapolis yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock. He was met at the Pennsylvania Railroad Station by his son-in-law, Mr. McKee, and was at once driven to Mr. McKee's home, at 128 West Fifty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Railroad officials devoted their attention almost exclusively to-day to getting their traffic departments back into the old lines of doing business. The Rock Island, which had dispensed with the entire force in its general offices during the strike, notified its men to-day to report for duty Monday morning.

London has just been enjoying another of its Handel festivals. The enthusiasm of English music lovers for the great oratorios, it seems, will never die out. The audiences in the Crystal Palace were immense. The attendance at the rehearsal was 16,172, at "The Messiah" 20,375, at the "Selection" 21,139, and at "Israel" 18,720, making a grand total of 76,406.

EAST MORICHES, July 14 -- The regular annual regatta of Beachview amateurs was sailed to-day. Owing to a heavy squall or wind and rain which struck just as the judges were about to give the starting signal, but four ventured to start. Frank F.D. Lee of Baltimore entered the Tephyoos. Reed Dillworth of Brooklyn the Lafaunta, William J. Fields of Jersey City the Christian, and A.G. Ely of Brooklyn the Lotus.

The prevalence of tuberculosis, or consumption, in the dairy herds from which Philadelphia is supplied with milk has been admitted for some years past. The evidence procured from time to time indicates that in the dairy district of no other American city is the percentage of tuberculous animals no large.

LONDON, July 14 -- The convinced radicals and republicans of Europe find it necessary to brace themselves and put real backbone into their effort to stand erect against the blast of popular illiberal reaction which began with Cesario's crime at Lyons and has been swollen into a gale by the bulletins of savagery which Chicago and California have furnished during the week.

Messrs. Miller, Macoy, Menge, Kirby, Graham, and Dow, six young men interested in cycling and bold pioneers in everything pertaining to that sport, met in a small barn up town seven years ago and, by the flickering light of a solitary oil lamp, organized themselves into an association under the name of the Riverside Wheelmen.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 14 -- Capt. William Hansen, who last year sailed the Vigilant to success, was in the city to-day. "You have got to drive the Vigilant for all she is worth to make her go," said he, "otherwise you cannot expect to win."
Eugene V. Debs is not insane, nor at all likely to become so. He has a cool head, a firm purpose, and great self-reliance.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 14 -- The first Grand Circuit meeting ever held here ended to-day before a crowd that numbered close to 3,000. Fantasy's exhibition mile was the chief attraction, and the wonderful young mare turned the track in 2:09 with the utmost ease, and could probably have gone two seconds faster. A few big drops of rain had fallen Just before the trial, but they improved the footing.
CORTLAND, N.Y., July 14 -- The annual race meet of the Cortland Wheel Club to-day was well attended, and the track was in fair condition. Following is a summary of the events:

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 14 -- Clara Casper, the seventeen-year-old daughter of Joseph Casper, a Fort Lee grocer, was waylaid and assaulted about 7 o'clock this morning by an unknown man on the turnpike road, midway between Fort Lee and Leonia.

If no other variety of the milk of human kindness is in much demand just now, that of Nathan Straus is at least in vogue wherever one of his "sterilized milk" depots wooes patronage. There is one of them in the City Hall Park, overhung by vermiferous trees from which, in pendent hammocks of cobweb, caterpillars, careless of sparrowdom, lazily swing.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Mr. Springer (Dem., III.,) introduced in the House to-day a bill to create a National Board of Arbitration to settle controversies between employes and their employers. The bill is drawn on the lines of President Cleveland's message of April, 1886, relative to arbitration, and is intended to meet the suggestions made by the President on the subject at that time.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., July 14 -- Every incoming boat brings crowds of city people whom the heat has driven from the cities. The hotels and cottages are filling rapidly. The majority of the people have come simply for rest and recreation, but there are many who intend to study during July. The Martha's Vineyard Summer Institute opened last Monday, and the advent of several dozen pretty girls has already rendered the social life here attractive.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Among the papers which have been found by the officers of the navy who are preparing the records of the rebellion for publication is an account, by Rear Admiral Jouett, retired, of an incident that was not fully related until after the rebellion was long over. Reasons which do not appear to be clearly stated led to the suppression of the details at the time the original report was made.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A few days ago there appeared in a New-York paper an account of a rare Confederate relic now in the possession of Walter Aldrich, the bibliographer of Providence, R.I. -- a silk bandana handkerchief decorated with the portraits of Jefferson Davis, Beauregard, Semmes, Lee, Mason, Slidell, Morgan, Jackson; and Johnston.

A novel contretemps postponed a marriage arranged to take place in St. Paul's Church, Newton Highlands, on Tuesday evening. The guests filled the church, the wedding party arrived, the clergyman was in waiting. But the marriage did not take place till the following day. The bride-groom-elect, by a comical oversight, had omitted to secure the necessary civil license.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 14 -- The week at the hotels here has been unusually quiet. Even the boarding houses at Highland Falls have been afflicted with the prevailing dullness, and as a result the hops at the Military Academy have not been largely attended.

When MacGregror sailed his famous Rob Roy, about twenty years ago, he little dreamed that his humble cruising boat would develop into the fastest sailing boat for its size in the world, nor did Bishop Alden and Guernsey imagine, when they pioneered the canoe in American waters, that in fifteen years would be seen the most complete and efficient racing machine in existence.

BALTIMORE, July 14 -- The marriage at Providence, R.I., last month, of Miss Hope Goddard. only child of Col. William Goddard of that city, to Mr. C. Oliver Iselin, son of Adrian Iselin of New-York, is a conspicuous event in the history of a family once famous in American journalism and which has occupied a front place in national history.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- "The story is false from beginning to end. I shall ask Gen. Miles at once to do me the justice of denying it," said Mayor Hopkins to-day, referring to a report from Cincinnati to the effect that Gen. Miles, before the State militia was called out, called on Mayor Hopkins and asked if he intended doing his duty and would call out the State militia.

LAKE DUNMORE, Vt., July 14 -- This picturesque body of water lies in a dimple of the Green Mountains, whose pine-covered slopes rise almost perpendicularly from its eastern border. The western shore of the lake is more hospitable, and here are situated two of the finest hotels in the State. The Mountain Spring Hotel is the larger of the two, and with the cottages attached has accommodations for 350 guests.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Wheat gradually settled downward from the opening to-day. It seemed as though the only business done was for the purpose of squaring up accounts for the week and a few scalping trades of moderate size. The weight seemed to come from the selling side, and the slight loss to values was the natural result. There was less news even than ordinarily.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 14 --This has been political equality day at Chautauqua, Such a day is annually set apart here for the discussion of the subject of woman's right to ballot. The large number of special visitors on the occasion were warmly welcomed by Vice Chancellor George E. Vincent, who introduced as the President of the day Mrs. E.R. Clark, President of the Political Equity Clubs of Chautauqua County.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 14 -- Atlantic City is a trifle different from a majority of the other coast resorts, inasmuch as it does not look forward to the middle of July or later for the opening of the season and the beginning of gayety and social pleasures which always characterize life at Summer resorts.
Victor Herbert, with the Twenty-second Regiment Band, will give the usual Sunday afternoon and evening concerts at Eldorado to-day. Following is the programme:
LEW BEACH, Sullivan County, N.Y., July 12 -- Score a blank for trout fishing on the Beaverkill between the first few days of the open season and the midsummer fishing.

Paris Correspondent London Truth. I have witnessed all the grand funerals which have taken place in Paris since the ex-King of Westphalia died. None of them came near in splendor to the funeral of Carnot. If modest virtue does not now become the fashion it will be surprising. The Faubourg St. Honore on Friday and Saturday looked like a flower tournament.

The young artists who must live, work, and sleep in the studio are often puzzled how to manage the big, square space so that it shall afford the comforts of a home, and yet not give undue prominence to the domestic and sleeping arrangements. Wonderful transformations take place sometimes under the feminine touch within the barren space.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 14 -- Crow's Nest, the Summer residence Of Joseph Jefferson, was the scene to-day of a brilliant wedding, the contracting parties being Mr. Jefferson's niece. Miss Hester Wentworth, and Archibald Brown, a well-known business man and society leader of Chicago. The ceremony was performed in the drawing room by the Rev. E.E. Horton of Boston, in the presence of many guests.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- At the request of Mr. Sherman all those sections of the Legislative Appropriation bill which carried the plan of the Dockery Commission, for the reorganization, of the methods of accounting in the Treasury Department, were yesterday reserved, and to-day were made special subjects of discussion.

Statistics embodying the results of the year's work at the State fish hatchery at Cold Harbor will be ready for the public within a fortnight. President Huntington, when seen a few days ago, was kind enough to give The New-York Times some facts which will be interesting to both sportsmen and professional fishermen.

MIDDLE HADDAM, Conn., July 14 -- It is a curious link that connects, if a wellauthenticated tradition is to receive credence, this small, tranquil riverside hamlet of New-England with the stirring days of Cromwell's Ironsides, the Commonwealth, and the subsequent restoration in Old England.

Ocean transportation is at a discount. Almost any one can go to Europe now who feels so disposed. The price of transportation has ceased to be a factor In that journey, and time and comfort are the only two things to be considered.

Fifty years ago that housewife was considered careless indeed who failed to supply the family storeroom with delicious Summer drinks. The art of cup blending is not a difficult one to acquire, care not to allow any particular flavor to predominate being a chief requisite of success. With a good supply of syrups, which should occupy a conspicuous place in every cooling room, many refreshing and pleasant drinks can be quickly mixed.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 14 -- The delightful weather of the last week has been very much enjoyed at Sea Cliff. Lawn tennis, bicycling, horseback riding, and driving have been freely indulged in.

The little dickers and trades, for which there seems so much affinity in hot weather, are now in progress among real estate men. There is also the customary planning of large schemes for tentative submission just now, and to be put in an alluring an business-like form later on, when cooler weather and more settled conditions give promise of their being taken into serious consideration.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 -- George W. Conklin, a carpenter of East Orange, who never rode in a race before, celebrated his twenty-fifth birthday to-day by winning the great one-hundred-mile handicap road race of the Atalanta Wheelmen. He finished first, winning the handsome gold medal offered by The New-York Times, at 13 minutes and 30 seconds after 3 o'clock this afternoon, in good condition, considering the terrible struggle he had passed through.

OAKLAND, Cal., July 14 -- The efficacy of Gatling suns in dispersing rioters was demonstrated this afternoon, when a small mob, which attacked firemen on local trains, fled at the appearance of militia with the rapidfire ordnance.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 14 -- The Asbury Park Wheelmen scored another success this afternoon at their annual bicycle meet, held in conjunction with the NewJersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen. There were over 4,000 spectators in the grand stand and on the "bleachers."

ELBERON, N.J., July 14 -- Another delightful week has passed into history at this ideal seaside resort. The weather has been uniformly fine and cool. Yesterday, which was a scorcher at most places, was simply a little warmer than usual here -- not warm enough in the shade to even make fans necessary.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 14 -- While there will be many not canvasses for the Congressional nomination among the Republicans of the rural counties of the State this year, none will be more bitterly contested than that between Sereno E. Payne of Auburn and John Raines of Canandaigua, in the Twenty-eighth District.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., July 14 -- The season here is growing brighter with the arrival of each train. The owners and lessees of country seats have been arrivriving during the past week in such numbers that all the pretty cottages for which this resort is famous are now occupied for the Summer.

SHARON SPRINGS, July 14 -- A greater number of guests came to town during the last week than ever registered during the same period of time since the palmy days of long ago. Last season Dr. Alfred Gardner, who had made an extended European trip for the purpose of studying the apparatus of the baths, rearranged the houses here upon his return.

On the boat which left Pier 26 East River at 5:30 o'clock last evening for Sag Harbor were scores of cyclists entered to take part in the century run from that town to Brooklyn to-day. The evening sail up the Sound was one of the preliminary attractions of this run, which is the first of the kind ever held on Long Island.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 14 -- Great Questions of the day, such as the railroad strike, When will the Vigilant win? Is it warm enough for you? great social problems, such as What did Mrs. Blank-Dash wear at the hotel hop? Is Susie engaged to Jack? Do you own that four-in-hand, or just hire it? These great themes have been laid aside.

NEWPORT, July 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and Mrs. Paran Stevens are the only cottagers of prominence now missing from the New-York coterie. The Matter is on her way here from Europe. The Vanderbilts are expected in a fortnight.

TRENTON, July 14 -- Two thousand National Guardsmen of New-Jersey have pitched their tents on the broad greensward at Sea Girt, where the State has established a permanent camping ground. New-Jersey has a camp every year, but the expense is kept down by taking only onehalf of the division down at a time.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 14 -- Passenger trains are all promptly on time, while each day records rapidly-improving conditions in freight traffic. There is also an extremely gratifying improvement in industrials. This week there has been more work done in Pittsburg mills than in any week during the past fifteen months.

SAN JOSE, Cal., July 14 -- A small bridge near Mayfield, on the broad gauge line, was set on fire and completely destroyed some time during the night. It is supposed to have been the work of strikers. The railroad company replaced the burned bridge, and trains are now passing. All important bridges will now be guarded.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, July 14 -- The recent visit of the Atlantic Yacht Club, with the reception tendered to its members at the Prospect House, together with the new arrivals that nearly every train brings from the city, has made the past week a lively one and added much to the pleasure of guests at this place.

Like poets, drum majors are born, not made. One man may become a drum major in a week, while you can't make one of another in a lifetime. Without the knack of handling the stick he will never be an artist, and will, probably at the very moment when he should look his jauntiest, commit the crime, unpardonable in a drum major, of dropping his left hand to his side.

William Archer, in common with most of the "advanced" critics in London, does not like "The Professor's love Story." He is sorry that the author of "A Window in Thrums" wrote it. He esteems it "a mere patchwork of little mechanical devices, irrelevant anecdotes, wheezes,' and comic business."

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 14 -- If any one doubts that enterprise pays a big percentage, the doubter should go past the Spring House in these days when men are crying hard times and no money. Mr. Proctor's capacious verandas show througs of people who are spending their nobody-knows-how-many consecutive seasons in Richfield.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Treasury Department issued to-day without any further explanation than that contained in the body of the document itself the following circular in regard to the enforcement of United States neutrality laws in connection with the disturbed conditions of affairs in Nicaragua:

The second volume of Meneval's memoirs of Napoleon I. embraces the period from the battle of Austerlitz until the opening of the ill-starred Russian campaign. Therefore we see practically the close of the Emperor's prosperous days -- at least of the days when good fortune almost uniformly was his. His victories of Jena, Wagram, and Eylan are recorded and by one who attended Napoleon, not only on those occasions, but also in Spain.

The Library of Congress in not only one of the largest and most imposing buildings in Washington, but, owing to the good sense of Gen. Casey and others in authority, it is likely to be the most decorated of all the edifices of Washington save the Capitol. Even the new erections for the Corcoran Art Gallery will be far less ornamented with statuary.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 14 -- While the steamer Victoria, now here, was at Yokohama active preparations were making for war. Off Moji, on the Japanese coast, she passed a war ship and eight troop ships, carrying 10,000 Japanese soldiers to Corea. This action was taken by the Japanese Government after a report that China was going to send 12,000 men there.

In spite of the fact that it was intolerably hot at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, and every one that went there knew it would be so, there were more than 5,000 holiday pleasure-seekers and regular racegoers at the track to see the horses go round in the six races that were on the card for decision.
BAR HARBOR, Me., July 14 -- Our greatest enemy, the fog, looked in on us two or three times this week, but, very fortunately, did not seem content and did not make long visits.
Considerable discussion has been caused by the publication in The New-York Times of a letter relating to Federal office holders participating in politics, and of which the following is a part:

From London Truth. A large section of my countrymen and countrywomen, well-meaning ladies and gentlemen all of them, consider that all will be well with the African if they give him Christianity. To this end they lavishly give their money, and not a few of them their lives.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 14 -- The event most talked of here is the full dress hop which was given by W.B. Gerard on Independence Day to celebrate the formal opening of his mammoth hotel, the Glenada. The grounds surrounding the hotel were beautifully illuminated by Chinese lanterns and fairy lamps.

Aunt Jane has taken the veil. She had it on when a reporter for The New-York Times called to see her the other day. It was not the kind of a veil usually taken by the novice. This particular veil was of a bright blue mosquito netting, and Aunt Jane had it artistically draped over her crispy white hair and kindly dark face.

The open-air mass meeting or the Socialistic Labor Party, Populists, and Knights of Labor, which was held in front of the cottage in Union Square last night, and over which there has been so much boasting, was the veriest kind of a fizzle.

The national French, holiday which commemorates the fall of the Bastile, July 14, 1789, was fittingly celebrated yesterday. The date was also the centennial of the vertical tricolor, the national ensign, and in the early morning the quarters of the city inhabited by French were conspicuous because their flag was displayed side by side with the American colors.

The evidence furnished by The New-York Times that the Orange institution in this country and the A.P.A. are one and the same thing has not been very pleasing to the leaders of the "American" movement in this vicinity.

LOVELOCK, Nev., July 14 -- Robert Logan killed Dan Lovelock and Fred Sullivan, and was killed by his own wife, Thursday night. Mrs. Logan applied for a divorce, and her husband was insanely jealous of her. Mrs. Logon went to Cottonwood to visit her mother. The others on the stage coach were Lovelock and Sullivan. About dusk Logan overtook the stage on horseback.
