Dr. Parkhurst's address from Switzerland to the citizens of New-York, opposing a "straight" ticket for the Fall campaign and advocating a union of all forces in opposition to Tammany naturally created a great deal of interest among the politicians of all classes yesterday, and lent an additional zest to the discussion of the "straight" ticket question.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 -- A storm of thunder, lightning, hail, and rain occurred here between 3 and 4 o'clock this afternoon. It came up out of a clear sky, and was remarkable for its brevity, severity, and for the fact that it was local in character. The oldest citizen cannot recall such explosions of thunder and torrents of hail, and cottagers who have traveled extensively never saw anything like it.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 14 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Ituna, Alllson V. Armour; Veto, George Law; Siesta, George Green; Linta, Walter Luttgen; Marion, James J. Foye; Evelyn, J.K. Hegeman; Helvetia, C.O'D. Iselin, and Viola, F.W. Hawley. Schooner yachts Dagmar, R.W. Inman, and Avalon, Francis L. Leland. Passed West -- Steam yachts Nealra Charles A. Gould; Almy, Frederic Gallatln; Alda, W.P. Douglass; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Vlking, H.A. Hutchins, and Lorna.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The opinion is expressed by legislators of both houses who have watched the matter closely that the time is not far distant when parlor and sleeping car companies will find themselves restricted in the matter of rates by Congressional enactment.

SING SING, N.Y., July 14 -- That long peninsula extending out into the Hudson River a little north of Sing Sing, and known as Croton Point, is the delightful spot where the American Canoe Association is at present having its annual meet, and a more eligible spot could hardly have been found.

The Indian Harbor Yacht Club has issued a circular about the special races arranged for the season. Vice Commodore W. Osborn has offered a cup for the twenty-one-footers, and Commodore Moller has offered a cup for a race between cabin cats. The Osborn Cup calls for three races, and they will be sailed on July 21, Aug. 25, and Sept. 3.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 14 -- The Seabright tennis tournament was finished this afternoon, and William Larned of Cornell is again the champion, having defeated Malcolm Chace of Brown after four hard-fought sets. The score was 5-7, 6-2, 7-5, 6-8. Chace made a strong stand, but Larned won on his superior all-round work. The latter took the offensive from the start, and played a hard driving game, which had a telling effect on Chace.

A shorter through route running north and south in this city and a new cross-town street-car line will be the net results of a grant to the Metropolitan Traction Company which was confirmed yesterday by Justice Van Brunt of the Supreme Court.

ASBURT PARK, July 14 -- The coming of the educators this week proved a boon to the hotel keepers. The pedagogues came from nearly every State in the Union, and they came prepared to spend the Summer in the Park, for their railroad tickets will be good for return passage until Oct. 1.

HARTFORD, July 14 -- Thomas Chester Forbes, the only survivor of the great marine disaster that occurred in the harbor of St. Bartholomew, in the West Indies, Sept. 22, 1822, resulting in the loss of forty-nine vessels, is living at the age of ninety and one-half years at Danville, III., and is one of the best-preserved men in that State.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 14 -- Julian Pye Bliss made two new world's records on the bicycle at the track here this afternoon. He broke the existing flying-mile and standing-mile marks, with pacemakers. He rode the flying mile in 1:54 4-5, The standing mile he did in 2:00 flat.

JACKSON, Miss., July 14 -- Gov. Stone to-day received a letter from W.H. Hazen, Chief of the Secret Service Division at Washington, in which that official states that on account of the close similarity of the special warrant issued by the State of Mississippi to a Government obligation, it has been decided to be an apparent violation of the United States law relating to the imitation of notes of national banks of the United States.

The Minneapolis is a sister ship to the triple-screw racer Columbia, which recently earned for her builders a premium of $350,600. Like that vessel, the Minneapolis is intended as a commerce destroyer, pure and simple. In both, battery power has been sacrificed to engine power, and neither ship carries an armament that would warrant her commander in giving battle to anything more formidable than a second or third rate cruiser.

TORONTO, July 14 -- Five thousand people witnessed a good afternoon's sport at the Rosedale grounds this afternoon, the occasion being the Athaeneum Bicycling Club's big meet. The weather was fine and the track in splendid condition. The event of the day was the race against time by Johnson of Syracuse, who undertook to break his Waltham record of 1:50 for a mile.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Commissioner of Pension's on June 12 last issued a, circular directing Assistant Commissioner Murphy to make a thorough examination of the records of the Pension Office with a view of showing the present status of the bureau. For the first time since the establishment of the Pension Office, an accurate complete, and comprehensive investigation has thus been made, and the results are regarded as very satisfactory.

It may be accepted as a sure sign of the strike being over that Mr. Pullman has come down from his Canadian retreat. There was no particular reason why he should not have gone there when the fight became unpleasantly warm, because it was not the Pullman Company but the railroad managers who had to do the fighting.
William Bateman Leeds, for many years a well-known lawyer in this city, died at Lakewood, N.J., July 7. Mr. Leeds belonged to an old family of the Society of Friends, and was born in Richmond, Ind.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The Executive Committee of the American Railway Union met at the Revere House this morning and held a prolonged session. The refusal of the General Managers to consider their proposition for the settlement of the strike and the action of the Federation of Labor, the Brotherhoods, and the building trades were discussed at length.

The scene of the railroad troubles in Chicago is not exactly paralleled by any similar quarter in New-York. Here the New-York Central and Hudson River and New-York and New-Haven Railroads enter the city with a certain amount of dignity, leaving their smoke and grime underground, and are received by a neighborhood that does not fail to match with the stately trains which come and go at intervals.

MANHATTAN BEACH, L.I., July 14 -- Coney Island fairly swarmed with people to-day. At the Oriental, Manhattan Beach, and Brighton Beach Hotels the clerks had hardly time to breathe, so busy were they kept receiving the guests who came in a steady column from early morning until late at night.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 14 -- The first ball of the season, which took place at the Prospect House this evening, was the finest affair of the kind held in Bay Shore. Hundreds of invitations were sent out, and society people from Islip, Babylon, and other near-by places attended in large numbers.

Following is the programme for the concerts at the Manhattan Beach Amphitheatre to-day by John Philip Sousa and his hand. Miss Adele Ritchie, the well-known soprano, and Mr. Conrad Behrens, the German basso, will assist at both concerts:

CAPE MA'Y, N.J., July 14 -- Cardinal Gibbons appears to be the most conspicuous person here just now. He arrived on Monday evening, and is the guest of Cockroft Thomas, a wealthy Philadelphia merchant. The Cardinal, who visits him every Summer, will remain two weeks.

JERSEY CITY, July 14. -- Miss Irene Bothem of 75 Broadway, Marion, was found to-day by her brother, J. Wesley Bothem of 35 Richards Place, in the county jail, whither she had been sent for thirty days on a charge of intoxication.

Paris Correspondent London Telegraph. He has been subjected to another long interrogation by M. Benoist, the examining magistrate, when he dwelt again very complaisantly upon the circumstances of his crime, and added that he was proud to say he had committed it single-handed. In the course of the examination he was confronted with the cutler, Guillaume, who sold him the Catalonian poniard.

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., July 14 -- The convention of college and Seminary Presidents met here yesterday. Mr. Wheelock of the Regents' office delivered a lecture at the Auditorium last night on "Responsibilities of Colleges and Seminaries," in which he said the duty of these institutions was to turn out perfect men and women, not only as to intellect and morals, but as to physique.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Big Mr. Allen of Nebraska has managed to keep himself in the public eye this week. On Tuesday, while his fellow-Populist, Peffer, was scattering treasonable utterances in the Senate Chamber, Allen was creating terror in the Maltby Building, where many Senators have their committee rooms, and in a resort near the Baltimore and Ohio station.
The East River Gas Company hag finished its great tunnel under the East River from East Seventy-first Street to Ravenswood, a section of Long Island City.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Rioters caused trouble last night in the Belt Line yards, at Eighty-first and Wallace Streets. They threw switches leading from the Western Indiana main tracks into the yards, and two freight trains went from the main track into the sidings before the engineers discovered their error.

Encouraged by the great success of his milk depots, and gratified by the benefits conferred by sterilized milk in saving the lives of sick childen, Nathan Straus has decided to erect a permanent plant, which will be open all the year round. Mr. Straus is now consulting with an architect, and looking for a site.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 15 -- The cholera continues to spread with alarming rapidity throughout the city. Two hundred and eighteen fresh cases and 69 deaths were reported yesterday. From July 8 to to-day noon 875 cases and 294 deaths have been reported. The exceptional measures usual in the periods of such an epidemic are being enforced rigidly.

From The Chicago Herald, (Dem.) In availing of an extraordinary crisis during which laws are openly defied, peace disturbed, and the commerce and trade of the city paralyzed, to engage in prolix and contentious correspondence with the President, Gov. Altgeld has made a pitiable exhibition which the President In his latest message to the Governor kindly and manfully rebukes.
ALBANY, July 14 -- Local securities have held firm despite the decreased trading during the last week. There appeared to be a better inquiry for bonds than for the strictly local stocks.
PROHIBITION PARK, S.I., July 15 -- "Some Immigration Evils" was the subject of an address this afternoon by the Rev. Madison C. Peters, pastor of the Bloomingdale Reformed Church of New-York.

Cabdriver Peter Kelly, aged twenty-seven, of Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, and Policeman John O'Sullivan of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station bad an exciting race Saturday afternoon in which the cabman was defeated.

FARGO, N.D., July 15 -- The Northern Pacific strike situation is more complicated to-night than for the past week. The members of the Switchmen's Mutual Aid Society who had returned to work all struck at 7 o'clock.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 15 -- Major B.G. Thomas was selected by the Kentucky Association at its meeting here yesterday to represent the association at the meeting of the Turf Congress in Chicago next Wednesday. There is no likelihood that the Kentucky Association will withdraw, but it will ask that certain changes be made in the rules and that Hawthorne be admitted into the congress.

Nefeesa M.T. Keep, the editor of The Moslem World and The Voice of Islam, who claims that Muhammed Alexander Russell Webb owes her for services, still held possession of the editorial rooms on the third floor of 30 East Twenty-third Street yesterday, prepared to resist any attempt that might be made to dislodge her.

PLATTSBURG, July 15 -- The third session of the Catholic Summer School was formally opened here to-day in the beautiful church of St. John. A pontifical high mass was celebrated by Bishop Gabriels of Ogdensburg, assisted by the Very Rev. Joseph F. Mooney, Vicar General and Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New-York.

From The Westminster Gazette. The Grand Collar of the Legion of Honor which has just been remitted to the President was made for M. Grevy fifteen years ago. It consists of seventeen medallions in gold and blue enamel, one large on which is engraved the legend R.F., and from which depends the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honor.

We have lately had some very disgusting proofs of the way in which the protectionist policy has corrupted our National Legislature. Given legislation which may put millions into the pockets of private citizens and corporations, and the obtaining of that legislation becomes a matter of business.

From The Westminster Gazette. We are disappointed to find, that the Institute of British Architects had no authoritative word to say at its dinner last night on the ethics of the Tower Bridge. Sir Frederick Leighton, indeed, spoke of "transfusing into the thing of necessity the essence of beauty," but the precise application of this formula to the iron girder question remains unsettled.

From The Westminster Gazette. Yesterday the Lerwick authorities apprehended and lodged in jail the master of the Steam trawler Stephenson of North Shields, which was captured on the coast of Foula, Shetland, by her Majesty's gunboat Cockchafer, while engaged in trawling with-in the three-mile limit. The trawl was confiscated, but the vessel was allowed to go.

When at work Handel was often rough and peremptory -- dealing out torrents of abuse "ven tings vos mixed," to understand which one required to be intimately acquainted with French, German, and Italian. Yet these rages were healthy outbursts of a great mind, not morbid, jealous feelings.

NEWPORT, July 15 -- The Captain of the schooner Comanche, Mr. Ellsworth, owner, of Boston, which arrived to-day from Bar Harbor, reported that on Friday, off the Shoals, while reefing. Seaman Charles Fairland of Finland fell overboard and could not be saved. The body was not recovered. He has a brother, also a seaman, on the Comanche.

Saturday's rain gave a set-back to Sunday morning driving on the road yesterday, and there was not the usual brigade of horses and horsemen on Seventh Avenue and the roads above Central Park. At Fleetwood the track had not dried out sufficiently to permit of fast work, and the day's doings were confined chiefly to horse talk on the clubhouse piazzas.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 15 -- The tightness of money at Harvard has caused a cut-down in the list of Summer improvements, so that during the vacation only those improvements deemed indispensable will be made. For a year nearly every department in the university has been cutting its expenses as close as possible, and orders for apparatus, books, , have not been as liberal as heretofore.

MELBOURNE, July 1 -- While the towns, and particularly those of Victoria, are full of idle men, the country roads swarm with a variety of tramp known as the "sundowner." It seems to be an unwritten law of the country that any man traveling on foot who reaches a sheep station or a farmhouse before sundown in the afternoon is entitled to be cared for till the following morning.

We hope that our Brooklyn readers, and all our readers, for that matter, who care anything about public schools have followed the articles The Times has lately published regarding the amount of studies the public school children of that city in the so-called upper classes are required to undertake.

"Who killed the strike?" was the question discussed yesterday at the meeting of the Central Labor Union, which resolved itself into a Coroner's court of inquest to determine the causes of the collapse and death of the great railroad strike in the West.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 15 -- The thirteenth annual convention of the Society of Christian Endeavor closed to-night in a wave of enthusiasm.

NEWARK, N.J., July 15 -- It was late last night before a committee of the Atalanta Wheelmen had finished the computation of the net times of the sixty-seven men who finished within the eleven-hour limit prescribed for the 100-mile road race to Princeton and return.

BERLIN, July 15 -- Emperor William will sail from Bergen, Norway, on July 29, and will arrive on Aug. 1 in Wilhelmshaven, where he will be met by Chancellor von Caprivi. After a two days' rest in Potsdam he will start for the Isle of Wight.

TRENTON, July 15 -- The Mercer County Wheelmen have become enthusiastic over the remarkable increase in their membership during the past six months. They have now 285 active members, with more to be heard from at their next meeting. They are now the strongest bicycle club in Central New-Jersey, and do not entirely occupy the field, because there are three other clubs in the City of Trenton.

Neither Assistant District Attorneys Wellman and Osborne nor Superintendent Byrnes is noted for garrulity, especially when their official business is concerned, so that many statements and forecasts in regard to the course and scope of the independent investigation of the police force may be set down to inference or guessing.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 15 -- Bernard F. Gentsch committed suicide by shooting to-day. Though the shot that killed him probably was fired as early as 11 o'clock this morning, it was not until 2 o'clock that the fact was confirmed.

McKEESPORT, Penn., July 15 -- An effort will be made to-morrow morning to break the strike at the National Tube Works. The effort at resumption will be resisted by the strikers. The works are now in the hands of Sheriff Richards, who has 150 deputies on duty within the monster plant, and all who report for work to-morrow will be protected.

BUFFALO, July 15 -- Having exhausted its resources for investigating the management of the charitable institutions of the eastern part of the State, especially those under the jurisdiction of the Counties of New-York and Kings, the Committee on Charities of the Constitutional Convention, of which the irrepressible and energetic Edward Lauterbach of New-York is Chairman, is now looking into the management of the institutions of Western New-York.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Investigations made by Worthington C. Ford, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, Treasury Department, lead him to conclude that "the possible" revenue under the income-tax provision of the Tariff bill will range from $12,000,000 a year, at the lowest point, to $39,000,000, at the highest point.

BALTIMORE, July 15 -- Ed Hanlon, President and manager of the Baltimore Baseball Club, telegraphed from St. Louis that he had closed a deal with the Cleveland Club by which he had secured John Clarkson in exchange for Tony Mullane. "The acquisition of Clarkson and Gleason," said he, "increases our chance of landing the pennant at least 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- There were twenty-eight dismissals from the Pension Office yesterday. In all cases the dismissals were on account of inefficiency. The majority of the clerks dismissed had been employed in the Pension Office for a number of years, and had grown so old as to be unable to attend to their work.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., July 15 -- A strange affair took place here last night. Mrs. A. A. Dennett and her daughter Grace, sixteen years old, of Portland, have a Summer cottage here. Grace was alone last night, her mother being at Saco, when a man knocked at the door and asked If the young lady was alone.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- There was a slight majority In the House on Saturday in favor of the bill to permit the establishment of a reserve list of aged and incapacitated officers of the Revenue Cutter Service, but the point of no quorum was made, and the hour in which the bill could be considered was exhausted before anything further could be done.

From "A Nobody in Mashonaland." We came upon a man who was complacently skinning a lion he had shot the night before. It was a big beast, with terrific teeth, and paws as big as a soup plate. Each claw was a curved dagger, and it was easy to imagine what such an animal would do with a man.

A party of Pilgrims will leave Brooklyn on Wednesday morning, under the auspices of the Sisters of the Monastery of the Precious Blood on a pilgrimage to the famed Grotto of Lourdes in France. They will assemble at the Monastery, 212 Putnam Avenue, early on Wednesday morning, and mass will be celebrated at 7:30 o'clock, after which the party will breakfast in the refectory.

PLEASANT PLAINS, S.I., July 15 -- Since the completion of the macadam roads on Staten Island, cycling has grown to a remarkable degree until the town of Westfield boasts of more wheelmen and wheelwomen, per capita, than any other country district in the vicinity of New-York. Fully 150 of them turned out last evening, with 800 other spectators to witness the first bicycle road race ever held in the town.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Now that the railroads are getting their traffic in shape and business is assuming its normal condition, some speculation as to the cost of the great strike to the railroads and others in Chicago alone may be interesting. All the General Managers can say at present Is that they have insufficient data to hazard an opinion that could be relied upon.

CONEY ISLAND, July 15 -- Cayenne pepper is good thing, occasionally, for jaded appetites, but it is a bad cure for sore eyes, especially when combined with castile soap and tobacco juice, and made into a poultice. Gray Whirlwind, the chief of the band of Sioux Indians which has been showing here since the season opened, has found this out to his cost.
CHICAGO, July 15. -- The strike is dead, the city quiet, and peace reigns.
WINFIELD, L.I., July 15 -- About 200 persons assembled in Arnold's Hall here to-day in answer to the following notice, which was extensively circulated in this village and in Woodside yesterday:

From The Westminster Gazette. A largely-attended meeting, called by the Directors of the Falkirk Town Mission, has been held in the Town Hall, Falkirk, for the purpose of protesting against the institution of trotting races, with their attendant evils, in Falkirk. Mr. James Wilson of Bantaskin presided, and nearly the whole of the local clergy were present.

HOROKEN, N.J., July 15 -- A man about fifty-five years of age, who registered at Gonzala's Hotel on June 10 as John Powers, was found dead in bed this afternoon. Death is supposed to have resulted from an overdose of morphine.

It was in 1774, when the astronomer was thirty-six years old, that he obtained his first glimpse of the stars with an instrument of his own construction. Night after night, as soon as his musical labors were ended, his telescopes were brought out, sometimes into the small back garden of his house at Bath and sometimes into the street in front of his hall door.

PROVIDENCE, July 14 -- The local stock market for the past week has been, perhaps, a trifle more active. In the bank stock list prices were generally stronger, though in some instances the bid price declined. A small lot of American National Bank changed hands at 49. Commercial National Bank has been sold at 47 3/4 @ 48, and Globe National sold at 56.

Three ex-convicts had a fight in front of 54 Macdougal Street at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, over a woman, and Peter McMahon was cut from the forehead to the chin by one man, while George Babcock held him. The police will not make public the name of the man Who did the cutting, because he has not been arrested.

The "Western railroad strike, its failure, and the lessons to be learned therefrom by both employers and workingmen, was the topic in many pulpits in this city and Brooklyn yesterday. President Cleveland was generally commended for his action in calling on the military forces to suppress rioting, and the workingmen were told they could expect to gain nothing from following professional labor agitators and Anarchists.

Not long ago, in talking about the police scandals, we cited Mr. Herbert Spencer's criticism of the "criminal good nature" of the American character as in a large degree responsible for those scandals. His criticism is equally pertinent to Debs and his railroad strike, which never would have got to be a national nuisance if the beginnings of it had been firmly resisted by the public officers and private citizens of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- There probably will be after to-morrow no further opportunity for the Republicans to worry themselves about the chances of a disagreement of the tariff conferrees. The expectation of Democrats is that on Tuesday or Wednesday the conferrees will ask the Republicans of the conference to join with them in making a report to the two houses.

If there should ever be compiled a table in parallel lines of the accomplishments of poverty and wealth, poverty should have to its credit the Ossianic poems and wealth to its charge their fall, for this is the moral of the life of James Macpherson easily read, although not expressed, in the book by Mr. Bailey Saunders.

An old question has been raised by a recent utterance of that eminent exponent of Wagner and Liszt, Mr. Antan Seidl. The gentleman who presides with so much grace and distinction over the musical solemnities in the pavilion by the sad sea waves at Brighton Beach was the guest of honor at a dinner given recently by the society which calls itself by his name.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 15 -- It was a pleasant surprise to the many visitors at Lake Placid to be greeted by to-day's NewYork Times this afternoon, arriving as it did at Saranac Lake by special train at 4:05 o'clock, and thence by special engine to this place, arriving at 4:45.

The bond market the past week, while intensely dull, has shown great inherent strength, after a slight disposition to sell off in the early part of the week. The Atchison securities have been probably the most active bonds. The 4s were pressed for sale early in the week, but closed at 75.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 16 -- The statistics of the Summer school, furnished to-day by Secretary Chamberlain, show that the number of students, although larger than last year by fifty or more, is, nevertheless, not up to the total justified by the registrations upon the opening morning. Prof. Shaler and the other members of the committee looked for over 400 students, but to-day the final list numbered 346 only, as compared with 393 In 1892.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 15 -- Five thousand persons saw the first full dress par nade of the Second Brigade at Camp Werts at 6:30 o'clock this evening. The farmers throughout the county were well represented.

It is hardly necessary to do more than recite the events of last week to prove that the outlook for an early improvement in the financial and commercial situation is decidedly encouraging. After President Cleveland's proclamations issued on Monday and Tuesday, extraordinary perspicacity was not required to make it safe to predict that the Debs strike would last only a few days longer.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 15 -- There was a large and fashionable gathering on the grounds of the Grover House, at Caldwell, yesterday afternoon and evening, when a lawn fete was given for the benefit of the Mountainside Hospital of Montclair. There was a sale of flowers, candy, and fancy articles, also a Russian tea.

The Democratic members of the conference committee are trying to arrange the terms on which they can agree. They may say, as much as they choose, that they are not acting as conferrees. That is hardly true in form; in substance it is utterly untrue. The Republicans of the conference committee have not been called in, and have really had no part in what is going on, and probably no knowledge of it.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Some important work has been done under the army engineers in New-York during the last fiscal year. Col. G.S. Gillespie of the corps, who has charge of river and harbor work in that vicinity, has made his annual report to Gen. Casey, his senior officer, in Washington. He says:

The "Republican Board of Accidents," as the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen is now termed, held a meeting yesterday afternoon at which it was expected that some action would be taken to give Commissioner White of the City Works Departrment authority to use $750,000 to increase the Brooklyn water supply by 25,000,000 gallons daily.

Edward Austen's great Scenograph of the World's Fair was placed on exhibition at Madison Square Garden last evening. A large number of spectators were present. To those who had not attended the fair at Chicago the Scenograph gave a comprehensive idea of the beautiful buildings and grounds in their proper relations.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 16 -- Albert Hatch, aged twenty-one years, of 265 West Eighty-fourth Street. New-York City, was drowned in the bay near here last Friday. Hatch and two companions, Henry Carter and Henry Tenny, were on a yachting excursion from the city to this place on the yacht Thelma. Tenny dropped his pipe into the water and Hatch jumped in to recover it.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- There is no immediate prospect of the withdrawal of Federal troops from Chicago and vicinity. This is upon no less authority than Gen. Miles, the commandant of the United States troops at this point. Naturally the order for removal will come from the Secretary of War at Washington, but it will only come after such a course is recommended by the General.

Chasing favorites at the Brighton Beach race track has not been a very profitable business this year. Yesterday brought no exception to the rule, for Tom Skidmore was the only one of the batch that managed to win for his backers. But the mere fact that the favorites are beaten with astonishing regularity does not at all tend to keep the crowd away from the track by the sea.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The conferrees were hard at work to-day on the Tariff bill, and were much sought for by those who wished to know whether their interests were to be taken care of or were to suffer.

ALBANY, July 16 -- Senators O'Connor and McMahon of the special committee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which was authorized to investigate the administration of the State civil service laws and to report to the next Legislature, were this morning at the rooms of the State Civil Service Commission.

LONDON, July 17 -- The Graphic says in a leader on the Oxford-Yale games that Oxford had the advantage of a larger number of athletes to choose from. The writer expresses the hope that to-day's meeting is but the first of many.

Michael Kerwin belongs to that class of Irishmen who advocate dynamite, the knife, and the pistol to revenge the wrongs the mother country has suffered, and also to that wing of the Clan-na-Gael which tacitly approved of the murder of Patrick Henry Cronin.
"Capt. Michael Doherty to the bar," will usher in the first of the trials of the independent police investigation Thursday morning at 10 o'clock.
Police Commissioner John McClave has resigned and Gen. Michael Kerwin, Republican, has been appointed in his place.

ERIE, Penn., July 16 -- Farmer D.D. Turner kept the middle of the road out in Green Township Sunday evening, causing Phineas Bonney, a wheelman, to run into him. The wheelman accused Turner of being selfish.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 16 -- Edward Holloway, aged thirty, of Crawfordsville, Ind., the prisoner under arrest here for wrecking the New-York express on the Big Four at Fontanet, Thursday night, resulting in the death of Engineer Moehrman of Indianapolis and Fireman Fleck of Mattoon, confessed to-night.

In appointing Gen. Michael Kerwin to be a member of the Board of Police Commissioners Mayor Gilroy has dealt the deadliest blow the hand of man could have given to the Platt-Milholland policy of nominating a straight Republican municipal ticket this Fall. The appointment is not merely improper -- it is monstrous.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 16 -- The day at Camp Werts passed off successfully and was marred by no casualties. With the exception of ten minutes rain this afternoon the day was perfect. There were not as many visitors present as yesterday, although every incoming train brought scores of people.
ALBANY, July 16 -- Gov. Flower has issued an order directing the abatement of certain public nuisances In the town of Flatlands, Kings County, in which he says:

We printed on the 15th a very full explanation of the methods established by law for the appointment of policemen. It is plain that if this system were faithfully and intelligently administered from beginning to end, the men who are best fitted would secure appointments quite independently of any influence brought to bear upon the Commissioners.

There is apparently no limit to the resources of those who devise the stage work at the Casino in "The Passing Show," and as the specialists who try the new things on the public seem to delight In the chance to escape routine, amusement seekers get the benefit of a performance constantly new.

A committee from the July Grand Jury visited Riker's Island yesterday afternoon. The committee was appointed by the foreman of the Grand Jury, which body had heard complaints against the Commissioner of the Street Cleaning Department, William S. Andrews.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- The explosion of a Second Artillery caisson and the bursting of shot and shell caused frightful carnage among soldiers, civilians, and horses this afternoon, during a drill of regulars on Grand Boulevard, one of Chicago's finest driveways.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn, whose name has been mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for Governor, has decided that he will not accept the nomination. He also declares that he will not be a candidate for another term as Mayor.

An expert publishes in The American Wool and Cotton Reporter an essay on card clothing, the strips of wire-toothed card used for covering the cylinders of carding machines. Such card clothing is dutiable under the McKinley tariff at 50 cents per square foot, and the Senate and the House are now in disagreement as to the duty that shall be imposed by the pending bill.

A motion was made yesterday in the Superior Court for the appointment of receivers for the Umbrella Company, which is the corporate name for the "Umbrella Trust." Judge Gildersleeve, before whom the motion was made, appointed Miles M. O'Brien and Arthur C. Palmer temporary receivers and Gilbert M. Speir referee, before whom the corporations and co-partnerships forming the trust are required to show cause why the trust should not be dissolved.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., July 16 -- Great indignation is manifested here among anglers and guides at the recent promulgation of a piece of special legislation by the Canadian Government.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The latest telegraphic advices received here indicate that the Corean situation is substantially unchanged. It is stated that the Russian Government has expressed itself satisfied with the reply of the Japanese "Government disavowing any design upon Corean territory, but declining to "withdraw the Japanese troops from Corea until some action was taken to prevent the constant recurrence of the disturbances in that country which Japan complains of.

The games played yesterday in the open handicap tennis tournament of the Knickerbocker Tennis Club were fewer in number, but rather better in quality than those of Saturday, the opening day of the tourney. Paret furnished the feature or the afternoon, by defeating that rather disappointing youngster, Calhoun Cragin, when the latter seemed to have the match at his mercy.
The mental condition of Edward B. Hartley was the subject of inquiry last evening before Commissioners and a Sheriff's jury in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Through an error in the copying of the figures relating to the exports and imports of 1893 and 1894, the dispatch in The Times to-day on that subject did not give the right total, but the total of domestic exports only. The exports of domestic merchandise were $869,181,315, and those of foreign merchandise were $22,929,965, making a grand total of $892,111,280, and showing an excess of exports over imports of $237,275,407.

Steadily improving conditions are recognized by conservative operators and traders in Wall Street. The clarification of the labor situation so far as the railways are concerned and the probability of an early tariff adjustment are regarded as events which will have a vast influence on values in the near future, and consequently there is a much more hopeful feeling than has prevailed for many months.

BOSTON, July 16 -- The market for local stocks was on the whole dull, though West End Street Railway and Wisconsin Central were fairly active. The former opened at 48 and gained 1, to 49. The latter declined 7/8, to 3 3/8. Rumors of improvement in the earnings of West End Street Railway Company continue to be the bullish factor and scare the shorts into covering at these prices.

J. Herbert Bramwell, who died in Paris, July 13, was one of the prominent mining engineers of this country, and a pioneer of the famous Southwest Virginia coal fields. He was born in Liverpool, England, Nov. 26, 1846, and came to this country at an early age with his parents. He was educated at the public schools, and was graduated from the College of New-York of this city.

LONDON, July 16 -- A bust of the poet Keats was unveiled in Hampstead Church to-day by F.H. Day, Secretary of the American Memorial Committee, which gave it. Mr. Day explained the origin of the movement to place the bust in the church, and mentioned the principal American donors.
Another lion is in the path of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Activity in local markets still continues, with the market rather broader. Diamond Match and New-York Biscuit were added to the active stocks this morning and were traded in very freely; both were decidedly strong, the former on reports of large earnings and good buying orders.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 16 -- Gov. Flower to-day commuted the sentence of death passed upon Elizabeth Halliday to imprisonment for life, and filed the following memorandum:

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 16 -- The Rev. Charles R. Henderson of the University of Chicago spoke this morning on the subject of co-operation of public and private agencies in charities and correction. He explained the public system of charity which prevails in Germany, known as the Elberfeldt system.

BERLIN, July 16 -- Prince and Princess Bismarck arrived at the Stettin railway station in Berlin at 4 o'clock this afternoon on their way to Varzin. The train bearing the ex-Chancellor halted twenty minutes.

DETROIT, Mich., July 16. -- Alonzo J. Whiteman, at one time a member of the Minnesota Senate, the son of a millionaire, and worth $300,000 in his own right, occupies a cell in the Central Station. When arrested he gave the name of Frederick Henry Cooper, but he was recognized by a former friend in Columbia College, of which he is a graduate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 16 -- The German singing societies of the Westchester County Saengerbund had their fourth annual parade and festival here to-day, the latter being on the Westchester County Fair Grounds. The entire village was decorated with flags and bunting, in which the German flag held a prominent position.

BOSTON, July 16 -- The steamboat Stamford, Capt. Davidson, while coming from Plymouth this afternoon during a dense fog, came in collision with the British steamer British Queen, Capt. Smith, from London, which was anchored. The Stamford received slight damage from this collision, but continued on her way to Boston at quarter speed.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A meeting of the Louisiana and Texas representatives in Congress will be held at the Capitol to-morrow, at which the sense of the delegations will be expressed with reference to the Hawaiian treaty.
SING SING, N.Y., July 16 -- Frank Adams, alias James Henry, a convict at the prison, created a lively time in State Detective James Jackson's office this morning.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., July 16 -- A bad wreck on the Chicago and Grand Trunk Road, at this city, took place at 3 o'clock this morning. It was the work of some one who had a grudge against the road. The fireman was killed and a number were injured. Following are the names:
ALBANY, N.Y., July 16 -- John J. Merrill, the head of the Tax Department in the State Controller's office, gave out a statement to-day, in which he said:

JERSEY CITY, July 16 -- Two men who who gave their names as William Hall and Bernard McCabe, and who said they represented the Railroad Managers' Association of Chicago, engaged a room in a hotel here on Saturday and began a recruiting business. They hired a great many men and Shipped them to Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- In the House to-day the bill reported from the Committee on Judiciary "to establish a uniform system of bankruptcy" was ordered to be engrossed, but on its passage the vote of a quorum could not be obtained. The bill as ordered to be engrossed reads as follows:

LONDON, July 16 -- The crack athletes of Oxford triumphed over the champions of Yale at the Queen's Club, West Kensington, to-day, after a sensational tournament in which the Yale boys, although beaten, were by no means disgraced.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The tone of the market to-day was much stronger. London quotations not being lower, the traders were inclined to bid prices up, and they met with very little resistance. Outside of Reading, St. Paul, and Philadelphia Traction, the volume of business was small, the three stocks named contributing more than half the business.
Among the great engineering dreams of the age, to New-Yorkers, have been a bridge over the East River and a tunnel beneath its bed.

Messrs. Riker & Son have sold for Frederick Aldhous to Col. A.B. de Frece the four-story brownstone dwelling, 159 West Seventy-fifth Street, at $35,000. This is the first sale on the row which la about being completed. Col. de Frece is also negotiating, through Messrs. Riker & Son, for an apartment house on the west side in exchange for east side store and tenement property.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Treasury finances show an improved condition, due solely to large receipts from internal revenue, which have reached for the half month of July $15,000,000, out of a total of $20,500,000. The expenditures for the same period aggregate $18,000,000. This places the Treasury in a comparatively easy position, with available currency at large centres for daily use without having to transfer it from point to point to meet prospective drafts.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Utah practically passed into Statehood at midnight last night when President Cleveland signed the act enabling the Territory to be admitted into the Union. There was nothing dramatic about the signing. A tired President merely took up a silver penholder, in which an ordinary steel stub pen was inserted, and wrote, "Approved, Grover Cleveland," on the engrossed copy of the act.

The State Commission in Lunacy resumed its investigation into the alleged abuses in connection with the management of the city asylums for the insane poor at the Park Avenue Hotel yesterday, after a recess of three weeks.

BOSTON, July 17 -- The nineteenth annual convention of the National Amateur Press Association was begun to-day in the United States Hotel, this city. As the President and both the Vice Presidents were not in attendance, the convention was called to order by the Secretary, Miss Susan Robins of Abington, Mass.

Mr. Robert Ward has sold, for Nathan Kaplan, to Mary Schmalstrick, at $5,300, the two-story and basement brownstone dwelling 523 Bainbridge Street, 18 by 45 by 100. He has also sold, to the same, for Rufus T. Griggs, at $12,500, the four-story brick double flat 1,069 Lafayette Avenue, 25 by 75 by 100.

ALBANY, July 17 -- At the opening of to-day's session of the civil service inquiry Mr. Deming, counsel for the State Civil Service Reform Association, said that, having shown the day before that civil service laws similar to that in force in New-York had worked well in other States, he would undertake to show that in New-York corresponding good results had not been obtained.
The Iron steamboat Cepheus, which seems to have been wedded to mischance, has for a second time in her career found a resting place on the beach at Norton's Point.

As the steamer Glen of the Starin Line was passing Pier 23, at the foot of Beekman Street, in the East River, about 9:15 last night, she met in collision a railroad float towed by the tug William Palmer.

SHANGHAI, July 17 -- Nine Chinese merchant steamers have sailed from this port for Corea, and it is reported that they have gone to withdraw the Chinese troops from that country. This report is denied in official circles, where it is asserted that the Chinese position at Asan has been greatly strengthened.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 17 -- The following companies have been incorporated with the Secretary of State:

When the Giants appeared on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon for a little seance with the Senators, they were greeted with welcome shouts from 8,000 throats. The enthusiasts of this city who lost faith in their champions have forgiven Capt. Ward and his band of pennant seekers for past misdeeds, and they are now prepared to shout the praises of the team as loudly as ever.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 17 -- A series of fights here this morning in which Hotel Proprietor William Harris, Robert Munroe, and Mrs. Fitzgerald were badly injured, may yet end in murder. Both Munroe and Harris are in a precarious condition, and Mrs. Fitzgerald is badly cut up.
Policeman Jeremiah S. Levy of the High Bridge Police Station was arrested yesterday afternoon, in the police station, by Inspector Conlin.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 17 -- The annual meeting of the Trow Directory Printing and Bookbinding Company of New-York was held in this city this afternoon. The following Directors and Inspectors were elected by 13,651 votes, the opposition ticket receiving 1,196 votes. Directors -- Robert W. Smith, William H. Bates, Franklin W. Hopkins, G.P. Morosini, M.R. Lawrence, S.D. Page, E.M. Barnes; Inspectors -- E. E. Silkworth, Norman S. Dike, G.M. Van Saun.

The statement submitted by the National League for the Protection of American Institutions in support of the proposed constitutional prohibition of appropriating public money for any "institution, society, or undertaking which is wholly or in part under sectarian or ecclesiastical control," is convincing in its array of facts and conclusive in its arguments from the fundamental principle of the absolute separation of Church and State and of, all their interests.

Interest in speculation yesterday centred in the industrials, and of these Sugar and Distilling and Cattle Feeding were the most active. Sugar was fairly well held in the early trading, but became weak about noon, when it was announced from Washington that the tariff conference committee had determined to report a disagreement.

BOSTON, July 17 -- The market for local stocks was somewhat more active and was fairly steady. The feeling seems for the moment to be better, but not enough so to provoke any great interest in the market. American Bell Telephone was steady at 191 1/2, with Erie Telephone 1/4 higher, at 45 3/4, and New-England Telephone steady, at 62 1/2.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 17 -- At the invitation tennis tournament of the Essex County Club. in the second day's play, Stephen G. Millett of New-York beat John Howland of Yale, 6-0, 6-3, 6-1; Clarence Budlong of Providence beat Arthur Foote of Yale, 7-5, 6-3; Malcolm Chace of Providence beat George Hinckley of Providence, 6-1, 6-4.

Another lesson in the total depravity of inanimate objects has been given. Yesterday morning the cleric of English weather arose early in the dawn and hoisted the Stars and Stripes to the mizzen peak. Then he hauled out of its locker the chart of a "blooming duck pond," and said with a calm and desperate accent, "We are going to locate this objectionable piece of water over here to-day."

Gen. Michael Kerwin, Mayor Gilroy's new Police Commissioner, who is to help in the noble work of reforming that department was not in a very happy frame of mind yesterday, despite the new and profitable honor that has just been put upon him.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 17 -- Senator John T. Morgan is making an active and vigorous campaign for the Democracy. He spoke here to-day and at Bessemer tonight to audiences several thousand strong. He handles Kolb and his crowd with gloves off. In his speech here to-day he flatly contradicted Kolb's claims of fraud in 1892, and challenged him for proofs.

Before adjournment to-day the House and Senate will receive from their respective conferrees on the Tariff bill a report that they have been unable toagree, and asking further instructions. The instructions to be given in the House will necessarily depend on the nature of the report, on the explanations that may be given, and on the discussion that shall follow.

The Bankruptcy bill which has passed the House is practically a makeshift. Its operation is limited to two years, a period much too short to permit the act to have any decisive influence. As for its terms, the bill may be said substantially to cover and ratify, for the benefit of a bankrupt voluntarily taking advantage of its provisions, the laws of the various States.
After transacting considerable business yesterday afternoon, the Rapid-Transit Commissioners adjourned until Sept. 25, unless called together at an earlier day by the Chairman.

Edward F. Hartley, the dry goods merchant of 2,336 Third Avenue, who recently announced himself as an independent anti-Tamniany candidate for the Mayoralty, was adjudged insane yesterday by the Sheriff's jury which has been hearing his case for several days. He will be committed by the Supreme Court to an asylum.

LONDON, July 18 -- The American colony in London gave a Tale supper last evening in the Victory Room of the Criterion Restaurant. The guests of honor were the members of the Yale athletic team. The company sat down at the tables at 11 o'clock, Mr. Bayard, the United States Ambassador, acting as Chairman.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Secretary Carlisle, it is understood, will give directions, within a few days, to resume to a limited extent the coinage of standard silver dollars at the mints of the United States. Since the repeal of the Sherman silver purchase law last November silver coinage has been virtually suspended, only about 500 silver dollars having been Struck off bearing the date of 1894.

The opening of Summer schools for the children of the tenement house districts is the latest demonstration of the breadth of view with which the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor regards its work.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The only one of the wounded soldiers who may be added to the list of victims of yesterday's caisson explosion is Maurice O'Donnell, the lead-horse driver of the Second Caisson. He lies at Mercy Hospital suffering intensely from burns and bullet wounds. The other wounded soldiers were reported doing well.

BALTIMORE, July 17 -- The Orioles outplayed the Bridegrooms to-day and won easily. Gleason made his first appearance for Baltimore and was very effective, keeping the hits of the visitors well scattered. Robinson resumed his place behind the bat and was in fine form.

WALTHAM Mass., July 17 -- Six new world's records were established to-day at the Waltham Bicycle Park. Walter Sanger, riding for the Springfield (Mass.) Bicycle Club, tried for a mile without pacemakers, and with flying start. The existing record was 2:16 for such a trial, and was held in France.

LONDON, July 17 -- In the lawn tennis championship tournament at Wimbledon to-day Mrs. Hildyard beat Miss Austin two love sets, taking the championship, which Miss Dod did not defend. Crowds of people were present in the afternoon, when Mr. Pim successfully defended the championship against Mr. Baddeley, the ex-champion. The former won by scores of 10-8, 6-2, 8-6.

In its moral aspects the appointment of Michael Kerwin to the Police Commission is a matter of great concern to every respectable person in the community, since no one can feel that the peace and property of the city are as secure as they were before the appointment of this open advocate of crimes and violence and friend and associate of Clan-na-Gael criminals as an officer of law and order.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- With commendable promptness the Senate to-day confirmed the nominations which were favorably reported by the Judiciary Committee yesterday of Wallace Macfarlane to be Attorney for the Southern District of New-York, Fletcher C. Peck, to be United States Marshal for the Northern District of New-York, and John H. McCarty, to be Marshal for the Southern District of New-York.

The commission of engineers appointed by President Cleveland to advise upon the length of the span of the proposed North River Bridge gave a hearing yesterday to the committee appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to confer with them.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 17 -- W.M. Fishback and United States Senator James H. Berry are engaged in a hot fight for the United States Senatorship now held by Mr. Berry. Returns reached here to-night showing that Pike County, which voted yesterday, went for Fishback. The Governor has a fighting chance for the Senate, and indications are by no means flattering for Mr. Berry.

CROTON POINT, N.Y., July 17 -- Among the arrivals at the canoe camp to-day were Dr. Samuel K. Upham of the Seekonk Canoe Club of Providence, R.I. He was accompanied by his sisters, Miss Elizabeth Upham and Miss Ruth Upham of Claremont, N.H. William J. Stewart and Mrs. Stewart of the Ianthe Canoe Club of Newark, N.J., and Joseph Stewart of the same club also arrived to-day.

DETROIT, Mich, July 17 -- With one of the biggest prizes of the year to be competed for at the Grand Circuit meeting here to-day, the attendance was more than double that which greeted the light harness cracks on Monday. The spacious new stand was packed, and upward of 7,500 people were on hand to see the battle for the Horseman Stake.

Massillon, Ohio, July 17 -- Eugene Hankey, a tightrope walker and trapeze performer of Wheeling, West Va., while giving an exhibition in mid-air last evening was precipitated to the ground, a distance of 75 feet, by reason of the rope breaking. Physicians have slight hopes of his recovery.

Brooklyn will have to get along this Summer on a short water supply, owing to the tactics of the "Board of Accidents" in avoiding taking any action on the request of Mayor Schieren and City Works Commissioner White to authorize the sinking of driven wells to reinforce the flow from the water shed on Long Island.

The Treasury Department's prompt issue of a warning against unlawfully aiding the Bluefields insurrection by expeditions from the United States may not in itself possess much significance. It simply requires Collectors of Customs to enforce the neutrality statutes, and as the Nicaraguan Minister had notified Mr. Gresham of his fears that these statutes would be violated, the issue of the circular was demanded alike by courtesy and by custom.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 17 -- John Calderwood, President of the Miners' Union at Cripple Creek, for whom the authorities have been looking ever since the troubles there, has surrendered. He has been in hiding in Denver. He was admitted to bail in $5,000, and went to his home in Cripple Creek. Calderwood is charged with leading a riot, murder,

BANGOR, Ireland, July 17 -- The Vigilant acquitted herself gloriously to-day in her second contest over the Royal Ulster Yacht Club's course of twelve turns for the Rear Commodore's Cup, valued at $250, and a cash prize of $125. Some of the lustre of her victory was lost by the failure of the Britannia to finish.

HAZLETON, Penn., July 17 -- Eight miners were killed at No. 8 Stockton Mine this morning. Two hundred sticks of dynamite exploded among a crowd of men who were preparing to go to their day's work. All of these unfortunates were shattered and torn to fragments. The following are among the dead:

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, July 17 -- Rioting and destruction went on to-day worse than ever on the Rock Island Railroad. One bridge was blown up with dynamite, one burned, and a dynamite bomb thrown under a train carrying soldiers. Telegraph wires cut, train guards fired upon, and section men driven from their work are some of the occurrences of the day at Enid and Round Pond.

The cruiser New-York, which was detailed to take part in the speed trial of the cruiser Minineapolis off the Massachusetts coast yesterday returned to her old anchorage off Tompkinsville, S.I. The vessel arrived off the Bar Monday night, but was compelled to anchor inside the Horseshoe on account of fog. Secretary Herbert, who had witnessed the race of the Minneapolis for fame and premiums, returned on the New-York to this port.
LONDON, July 17 -- In the House of Lords to-day Lord Salisbury formally moved the second reading of the Alien Immigrant bill.
ALBANY, July 17 -- Morris Tekulsky, the delegate to the Constitutional Convention from Park Row, New-York, gave to-day's session of the Committee on Preamble and Bill of Rights a sporty character.

HAZLETON, Penn., July 17 -- Eight miners were killed at No. 8 Stockton Mine this morning. Two hundred sticks of dynamite exploded among a crowd of men who were preparing to go to their day's work. All of these unfortunates were shattered and torn to fragments. The following are among the dead:
Mr. J. Edgar Leaycraft has sold for C.H. Webster, as executor, to a Mr. Soutter, the four-story tenement, with store, 330 West Forty-second Street, 25 by 100, at $28,000.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Gen. Charles E. Hooker, representing the Seventh Mississippi District in Congress, has been quite ill at his residence in this city for some days with a combination of malarial and stomachic troubles. It is contemplated to move him to some health resort as soon as possible.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The market was rather feverish at the opening, with a tendency toward lower prices, and when the few London orders were executed business became very dull. The investment demand seems for the moment over. Pennsylvania is very steady around 49. Some one seems to continue to pick up Lehigh Valley.

Michael Kerwin, the friend of Alexander Sullivan, sympathizer with "No. 1" Tynan, and recently appointed Police Commissioner, walked down Broadway yesterday afternoon and paid his respects to Thomas C. Platt.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Thomas M. Cooley, ex-Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, whose eminent standing as an authority on constitutional law gives great value to his opinion, has written to the President as follows:
Following is a complete list of saloon passengers who have been booked to sail by vessels of to-day's outgoing fleet:

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The weakness developed in West Chicago yesterday afternoon was continued to-day, with a further decline to 138. There was comparatively little support given, although around 138 a great many buying orders developed. North Chicago was nominal at 241 1/2. Elevated stocks were dull and lower.

The Brooklyn City Railroad Company, which is the great trolley-car monopoly of Brooklyn, is making a desperate fight to avoid taxation. The road paid 10 per cent. dividends last year. The Brooklyn Board of Assessors has decided that the personalty of the company should be assessed at $1,000,000.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 18 -- The principal feature of the Second Brigade encampment to-day was the visit of Company D of the New-York Seventh Regiment, accompanied by the Seventh's cracK military band. This company is commanded by Capt. Villard Fiske of Jersey City, who is one of the State Riparian Commissioners and was private secretary to Gov. Abbett.

DETROIT, Mich., July 18 -- This was the banner day of the Grand Circuit meeting in point of patronage, the big field in the Merchants and Manufacturers' Stake drawing a big crowd. Nearly 10,000 were present. The race itself proved the least sensational of any that has taken place since the stake became the leading feature of the Detroit meeting.

ALBANY, July 18 -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Banking to-night gave a second hearing on the question of the taxation of banks and trust companies. David H. McClure of New-York City, a delegate in the convention, argued against the taxation of trust companies.

Saratoga, N.Y., July 18 -- Norma, the two-yearold daughter of John Riddell of St. Augustine, Fla., who was run over by the electric cars last evening while playing in William Street, in the rear of the Clarendon Hotel, died this morning, after the surgeon had amputated her left leg at the hip. Lewis Brues, the motorman, who was arrested, was held in $1,000 bail this morning to await the verdict of the Coroner's jury.
With envious eyes a long string of Republican candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination this year will read the announcement that Dr. Chauncey M. Depew has sailed for Europe.

It looks now as if New-Mexico might follow Utah into the Union under the legislation of the present Congress. Unlike Utah, she did not show at the last census quite as many inhabitants as are required for a Representative under the present apportionment but at least she had more people than Idaho and Wyoming combined, and both those Territories were made States in the census year.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- A semi-official organ of the Traction Company suggests the possibility of another increase in the rate of dividend by the Philadelphia Traction Company, and it really looks as if it were very possible. While this company will probably before another year be compelled to make another increase of its capital stock, it is real good cash and not water that is being put into it.

The Washington correspondent of The Brooklyn Eagle met Mr. Don M. Dickinson on Tuesday as that gentleman was coming from the White House. He reports that Mr. Dickinson said to him: "The time has now come for plain talk on the tariff situation. We have been fighting under the flag of the Democracy in the United States Senate men who are worse than traitors; they are highway robbers.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 18 -- Frederick W. Vanderbilt has reported to the police that on Monday a servant saw two men peering into the windows just as the family were going to dinner.

While it seems to be true that Debs is confined only in consequence of his refusal to give bail that he might have had, he is none the less an impressive object lesson of the danger of inciting to breaches of the peace. His refusal to give bail and his insistence upon being locked up are highly ridiculous.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 18 -- At 11 o'clock this morning Dr. Charles R. Henderson of the University of Chicago continued his series of lectures on the general subject of sociology, his special theme to-day being "Summary of a Rational System of Treatment of Crime." He held that such characters as Prendergast should be dealt with summarily after showing signs of mental unbalance.

The long-winded contest between Hamilton and Arthur Taylor, which has held back half the players in the singles and doubles of the Knickerbocker Tennis Club's open handicap tournament, was ended yesterday afternoon on the courts at Brook Avenue and One Hundred and Fortieth Street by the victory of Hamilton. This leaves five men, Paret, Howard, Hague, Hamilton, and Gillette, still in the race.

BALTIMORE, July 18 -- Sanger played his game poorly in the mile race at the Baltimore races to-day. He took a position too far back to-day, and could not get around in time on a steep embankment. Charley Murphy had the speed, and in the straight rode like a fiend. Titus worked through and beat his old team-mate, Bliss, by a foot for second.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 18 -- The cruiser Minneapolis, which reached League Island at midnight, proceeded to the shipyard this morning and was given a rousing reception.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 18 -- News from Bluefields by vessels Which left there July 10 report the situation in the Mosquito Reservation as serious.

Because the favorites had things all their own way at Brighton Beach on Tuesday there was a rush of bettors to the track yesterday. The card looked as if the races would again fall to horses that would naturally be favorites in the speculation, and the talent wanted to be on hand to share in the spoils.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 18 -- The Alcyone Cyclers held an enthusiastic meeting last night, and decided to have a fifty-mile road race on Labor Day, open to club members only. A number of handsome prizes will be given. The club had a moonlight sail to-night up the Hudson. Music was furnished by Drake's Band. The Elizabeth Wheelmen had a rousing meeting last night, and several new members were taken in.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The United States, acting independently of other powers, has made representations to China and Japan, through the American Ministers in those countries, looking to a settlement of the Corean controversy by peaceable methods. It is understood that about a week ago Great Britain, France, Russia, and Germany united in an expression to both China and Japan suggesting intermediation to the end of securing a better condition of affairs in Corea.

BOSTON, July 18 -- Local securities were very quiet to-day, with little change. Bell Telephone advanced 1, to 193, on small investment orders. Dominion Coal opened 1/4 up, but closed at last night's quotation of 20 1/2. Boston and Albany continues to advance, and rose 3/8, to 206 1/2. Fitchburg was quiet at 70.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- At the annual convention of the Manual Training Association, to-day George H. Kilbon, Principal of the Springfield (Mass.) Manual Training School, practically demonstrated at a work bench "How to Teach the Use of Saws," while the same method was pursued by W.C. Vandegrift, assistant instructor in the Toledo (Ohio) Manual Training School, in showing "The Best Method of Making a Tench and Mortise Joint."

Charles Marie Rene Leconte de Lisle, whose death in Paris was announced in The New-York Times yesterday, was one of the great poets whom poets have worshipped in a chapel. The people knew him even less than Ronsard, Alfred de Vigny, and Stephane Mallarme.

PARIS, July 18 -- Discussion of the Govermnent's Anti-Anarchist bill was resumed in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. M. Goblet, Radical Socialist, delivered a forcible speech against the bill, and Lieut. Col. Guerin, Republican, replied to it, amid the noisy protests of the Socialists. The disorder increased, and by the time Col. Guerin had finished his speech the Chamber was in a tremendous uproar.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 18 -- Two Northern Ohio inventors have just completed the plans of a new submarine vessel, from which much is expected by those who have examined it. It is the joint product of Daniel T. Freese and James D. Gawn, the first a sailor and the last a practical mechanic of North Amherst.

ALBANY, July 18 -- This has been corporation day in the Constitutional Convention. The morning session was enlivened by Henry A. Powell, a Republican from Brooklyn. He boldly charged that the corporations were running the convention, and predicted that the people would repudiate its work if the policy now governing it should be continued.

DULUTH, Minn., July 18. -- Big forest fires are burning throughout the country, and only heavy rains before there is a change of wind can prevent great destruction of standing pine and other property, in addition to the heavy damage that has already been done. From all the roads entering Duluth the report is one of forest fires all along the line.
LONDON, July 18 -- The House of Commons was crowded to-day in anticipation of Sir William Harcourt's announcement of the Government's programme for the remainder of the session.

BATH, N.Y., July 18 -- An eminence in the rear of the beautiful buildings of the New-York State Soldiers' Home, where rest nearly 900 Union soldiers, was the scene to-day of imposing ceremonies, the occasion being the dedication of a monument to their memory. A few years ago Samuel Dietz of Brooklyn, N.Y., bequeathed $15,000 to the home without conditions, and the Trustees have used the fund to erect a monument.
BAIREUTH, July 18 -- The tenth Wagner festival will begin to-morrow with a performance of "Parsifal," and already the town is invaded by hundreds of strangers.

Part of the plea which the Platt-Milholland faction of the Republican Party will make for recognition before Mr. Platt's State Committee, whe the committee meets next week, was made public last night in a circular addressed to voters.

The bark Emma T. Crowell, loaded with 39,332 cases of petroleum, was burned to the water's edge twelve miles south of Fire Island Tuesday evening, and her master, Capt. A.S. Pendleton, his wife, and the crew of sixteen men had a narrow escape from death by fire. The wreck is in the track of ships and is very dangerous to navigation.

In the utterances of very many of the men who have been in sympathy with the strike of the American Railway Union there has been a suggestion that the remedy for the evils against which the strike was intended to be directed is the ownership of the railways' by the Government; of the inter-State railways by the Government of the United States.

Dullness approaching stagna'ion characterized the stock market yesterday. The total transactions were only 98,622 shares, and of that amount 65,326 were in the three speculative industrials, Sugar, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, and Chicago Gas. Sugar was the feature of the day, and it scored a net gain of 2 1/2 points, closing at 102 1/4, its top price.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Immediately after the reading of the Journal in the House to-morrow, Chairman Wilson will report the failure of the conferrees on the Tariff bill to reach an agreement.

Alonzo J. Whiteman, the young man who was arrested in Detroit Mich., on Monday for complicity with James R. De Witt in passing a forged check for $50 on the Hotel Cadillac, in that city, has had a remarkable career, and is well known in this city.

At Prospect Park yesterday the Manhattans gained a victory over the Morris Heights team in a most enjoyable match by forty-eight runs. A.C. Dixon did the best work for the winners, with a rather lucky compilation of 20, while J. Rose played a good inning for 13, and B.C. Morton and C. Howell also added doubles.

The depositors of the defunct Harlem River Bank met at Lenz's Hall, 2,011 Third Avenue, last evening to take steps toward bringing back the fugitive bookkeeper, J.J. Kean, who is said to be in Canada, and to arrange for a thorough investigation if possible into the methods of the bank.

When the Lexow investigation was postponed for the Summer, The Times predicted that the postponement would prove to be an abandonment. The interesting question now arises whether the "deal" that has now been put so very much in evidence by the appointment of Kerwin had even then been arranged.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 18 -- The action of the Government in massing troops at Butte and Helena would indicate that the crisis is yet to come in Montana. At the Northern Pacific General Office Building it was learned to-night that a special train had left Fort Assinnibolne, via the Great Northern, bearing troops to Helena and Butte, where trouble is expected.

The swift cruiser Columbia arrived here yesterday morning and anchored off Tompkinsville, S.I. Close by lay the armored cruiser New-York, more formidable in her array of guns and military masts, though not so large. The Columbia, which is 416 feet long, is 32 feet longer than the New-York, and has four smoke funnels to the New-York's three.

Mayor Gilroy has resented the effort to fix upon the Tammany organization responsibility for the system of police corruption which he says has existed for thirty years under all administrations. This involves the admission of the existence of the system, and the Mayor has pretended to a willingness to have it exposed and rooted out.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Rear Admiral Joseph Fyffe, just promoted from the grade of Commodore, was retired to-day and leaves the Boston Navy Yard at the disposal of the Secretary. Such places are filled by Commodores, Senior Captains, and sometimes, as in the case of the Brooklyn and Norfolk Yards, by a Rear Admiral.

Samuel E. Morss of Indiana, United States Consul General at Paris, is at the Madison Avenue Hotel. He reached this city last Saturday, and will remain in this country untill about Aug. 20, visiting Washington for a few days, and then going to his home at Indianapolis.

The future of the Democratic Party for many a year to come lies in the hands of the Democrats of the House, and it will be decided by its action on the demands of Senator Gorman of Maryland, who is not a Democrat, not a Republican, and only in legal form a Senator, being in reality simply the agent of the Sugar Trust and the iron and coal interests of the country.

NEWARK, N.J., July 18 -- W. Fellowes Morgan, the well-known society man, who has a mansion in Short Hills, was served with a notice Tuesday night that he would be prosecuted by the Newark branch of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals for docking his horse's tall.
It is an old saying, proved true by long experience, that a man may be known by the company he Keeps.
On the steamships that sailed for Europe yesterday were many prominent persons bound across the ocean for health, pleasure, business, or all three.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 18 -- Some excitement was caused this afternoon when First Lieut. Frank Eastmead of the Fifteenth Separate Company of Poughkeepsie was charged with incompetency and relieved from duty. This is the second occurrence of the kind in the history of the camp, the former case being the discharge last year of Major William H. Pettigrew of the Forty-seventh Regiment of Brooklyn for the same cause.
There are to be two griddles for the police -- one in Mulberry Street Headquarters and one in the District Attorney's office.

There is a man at the Battery who says he is going to cross the ocean alone in a fortyfoot schooner. This brings up the old questlon: What good will it do? For many years human lives were sacrificed in the attempt to find the northwest passage even after it had been abundantly demonstrated that when found it would be commercially without value.

There was another session yesterday of the board of engineers appointed by the President to advise as to the length of the span of the bridge which the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company proposes to build over the North River, between Fifty-ninth and Sixty-ninth Streets, but no conclusion was reached.

The Giants had a nip-and-tuck game with the Washingtons on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Twice the scores were tied, and for a time the Senators looked like winners, but in the last inning the pace was too hot for the "tail-enders," and they made way for the Gotham pennant seekers.

The speech of Chairman Wilson in the House yesterday and the letter of Mr. Cleveland are to be taken together. Each reinforces and interprets the other. Mr. Wilson was grave; there was a touch of solemnity in his warning words. The situation was such as to make him feel at once its responsibility and its inspiration.

Ward Man Jeremiah S. Levy was taken from the Tombs yesterday morning to the General Sessions. He had found at bondsman, George Groeling, a saloon keeper of 133 Bowery. He gave as security for the fifteen-thousand-dollar bail a house and lot at 76 Rivington Street, valued at $15,000.

G. Redmond of 129 Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, is the owner of a dog for which the neighbors do not entertain the fondest regard. They complained to Mayor Schieren of inability to sleep, owing to the dolorous howling of the animal, who they say is accustomed to spend the night making noises at the moon.

"The Democracy of the land plead most earnestly for the speedy completion of the tariff legislation, which their representatives have undertaken, but they demand not less earnestly that no stress of necessity shall tempt those they trust to the abandonment of Democratic principle." -- President Cleveland's Letter to Chairman Wilson.

ROME, July 19. -- The Government has received information from Africa that a battle was fought on Tuesday between a force of Mahdists, 3,000 strong, and a detachment of Italian troops near Kassala. The Mahdists were defeated and the Italians took possession of Kassala, which they occupy. The Italians captured two flags and a number of cannon.

Uncertainty as to tariff legislation and the engagement of a million of gold for export were depressing influences in the stock market. More than half the business was in Sugar, and the stock fluctuated rather widely. It was weak in the early trading, but in the afternoon recovered all its loss and closed 1/8 higher than on Wednesday.

The vessels of the Iron Steamboat Company seem to be in hard luck just now. Tuesday the Cetus sent her sister ship, the Cepheus, to a resting place off Norton's Point with a big wound in her side, and Wednesday the Pegasus was beached off Twenty-seventh Street, South Brooklyn, after collision with the stock-yards boat General McCallum.

BALTIMORE, July 19 -- John E. Searles of New-York, Secretary of the Sugar Trust, and associates have purchased controlling interests in a railroad and three steamboat lines, and will form a company to monopolize traffic between Baltimore and the Eastern Shore counties of Maryland. Several hundred miles of railroad and fourteen steamboats are to be merged into one company, capitalized at $3,725,000.

CONCORD, N.H., July 19. -- Although the Republican Committee met here yesterday for the simple purpose of fixing the times and places for holding the State Congressional and minor district conventions of the party, the unusually large attendance, embracing more than 100 active Republican politicians from all sections of the State and every county, was by no means called out by this merely perfunctory work, over which there was supposed to be no contest.
Clifton R. Breckinridge, Mr. White's successor as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to St. Petersburg, nominated by the President yesterday, was born in Lexington, Ky., Nov. 22, 1846.

There is a radical difference of opinion between Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn and H.B. Haigh, President of the Manufacturers' Association, regarding an interview concerning the question of the personal taxation of manufacturing concerns.

Bluejackets who have grievances have their own peculiar way of making their dissatisfaction known. In naval nomenclature there is no uglier word than mutiny, and on board the cruiser San Francisco it is as opprobious as on other men-of-war.

The Department of Justice at Washington and United States District Attorney Dennis in California do not appear to be in agreement as to the suit brought by Mr. Dennis against the Southern Pacific Railroad Company at Los Angeles on the 17th inst. As we shall hear a great deal about this suit before we hear the last of it, the nature of it should be clearly understood.
