The charges made at the stormy meeting Wednesday night of the depositors of the defunct Harlem River Bank of collusion between Receiver Sickels and James Gamble and of scant courtesy shown by the receiver to depositors were denied yesterday by Mr. Sickels. He said:

BALTIMORE, July 19 -- In an interview with R.H. Edmonds, editor of The Manufacturers' Record, to be published in this week's issue, United States Senator Patrick Walsh urges the importance of prompt action in the Nicaragua Canal matter. The Senator says:

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The Federal Grand Jury to-day found no less than twenty-nine indictments, charging violations of the Inter-State act and the laws relating to the transportation of the United States mails, against forty-three individuals. It was, as District Attorney Milchrist put, it afterward, "a wholesale rounding up of everybody and anybody concerned in the railroad strike within the jurisdiction of the Circuit Court for the Northern District of Illinois."

ST. PAUL, July 19 -- E. Ellery Anderson of New-York, O.W. Mink of Boston, and Frederic P. Coudert of New-York, receivers of the Union Pacific, and John M. Thurston of Omaha, counsel for the receivers, were in the United States Circuit Court before Judge Sanborn to-day to present their petition in regard to eight non-paying branches of the Union Pacific system.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- United States Consul to Germany Henry Robertson reports to the State Department that he is informed that the Hamburg Steamship Company and the North German Lloyd Steamship Company have applied to the Prussian Government for permission to establish "control stations" on the frontier, for the purpose of examining Russian emigrants destined for America, and who are going by their lines.
"The business of our country timidly stands and watches for the result of our efforts to perfect tariff legislation." -- President Cleveland's Letter to Chairman Wilson.

NEWARK, N.J., July 19. -- Twelve-year-old Mary Hebry of 49 Oxford Street was run over by a Bowery Street trolley car this evening. The motorman stopped the car, and a crowd quickly gathered. The child lay screaming under the trucks. Thirty-nine men took hold of the car and lifted it off the tracks. Among the number was John Hebry, the child's father.

WHITESTONE, L.I., July 19. -- Nine privates in Company C, United States Engineers, at Willet's Point, were arrested yesterday for running the guard. One of the number, named Casey, who is an old offender, is now incarcerated in a cell in the post guardhouse. The others were fined and blacklisted.

For the second time, the State Commission in Lunacy shifted its inquiry yesterday into the management of the City Asylum for the Insane from the Park Avenue Hotel to cooler quarters on Ward's Island. The examination of witnesses was held in Dr. Macy's office, in the main building.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- It was 3 o'clock before the Senate received official notification of the disagreement. At that hour, Mr. Voorhees, Chairman of the Finance Committee and of the Senate Conferrees, directed attention to the action of the conference committee, and asked that the message of the House, which had just been received, conveying information of its programme, be read.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- After many months devoted to an exhaustive consideration of the subject, the House Committee on Pacific Railways to-day, by a vote of 10 yeas to 5 nays, agreed to report favorably the Reilly bill, looking to the adjustment of the indebtedness of the Central and Union Pacific Railways to the United States.

CITY ISLAND, July 19. -- Bound East-Steam yachts Tillie, W.H. Starbuck; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Helvetia, C. O'D. Iselln; Evelyn, J.K. Hegeman; Oneida, E.C. Benedict; Starling, David Dows, Jr.; Lorna, W.L. Stone; Oberon, William J. Matheson, and Aqullo, George A. Thayer; schooner yacht Avalon, Francis L, Leland.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Although the consideration of the Indian Appropriation bill was closed before the adjournment of the Senate on Wednesday, so far as the amendments recommended by the Appropriations Committee were concerned, the bill occupied the attention of the Senate during all of to-day's session.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The cruiser Columbia is under orders to leave New-York Harbor with the least possible delay and proceed to Bluefields with, dispatch, for the protection of Amercian interests. These peremptory orders from Secretary Herbert were sent to Capt. George P. Sumner, commanding the vessel, this morning, and it is expected that the departure of the vessel will not be delayed beyond to-morrow.
Those who hoped for cool weather yesterday were grievously disappointed, for the day proved to be the warmest 19th of July that has been known here during fifteen years.

LONDON, July 19. -- Sir Michael Hicks-Beach moved, in the House of Commons, to adjourn, in order to discuss the statement outlining the Government's programme made by Sir William Harcourt yesterday. The announcement of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, he said, had been received with general surprise and disappointment.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- The fact that Manhattan Elevated and Metropolitan Traction are selling so near the same price suggests a renewal of a former rumor. Some two years ago it was said that negotiations were made by parties interested in both of these companies toward either a consolidation of the two systems or the absorption of one by the other.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 19. -- The will of Judge William Walter Phelps, ex-Minister to Germany, of Teaneck, was filed with Surrogate Haring here to-day. It is as follows:
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The following is President Cleveland's letter to Representative Wilson upon the tariff situation, which Mr. Wilson read as part of his remarks in the House this afternoon:
NEWPORT, R.I., July 19. -- Thomas Sweeney, who was assaulted July 2 by Albert G. Burton, died this forenoon. Burton, who says he acted, in self-defense, has been arrested.

If either Mayor Gilroy or Thomas C. Platt hoped to capture any considerable number of Irish votes by the appointment of Michael Kerwin as Police Commissioner they have, according to every indication, made a serious mistake in their calculations.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- This has been, a memorable day in the contest for tariff reform, and none of those who wrere witnesses of the most striking incidents will ever forget them.

DETROIT, Mich., July 19. -- A world's record was smashed on the new track at Grosse Pointe to-day when the black gelding: Lord Clinton won a heat in 2:09. This is the fastest mile ever trotted by a gelding, either in a race or against time, and the heat was before an audience that outnumbered any of the big crowds that have been out to see the Grand Circuit flyers this season.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 19. -- The Central Market, occupying an entire block between Second and Third Avenues, North and Sixth and Seventh Streets, was destroyed by fire to-night, together with several small dwellings and a livery stable. The loss will be in the neighborhood of $500,000.

OGDEN, Utah, July 19 -- A distinct earthquake shock was felt at 3:05 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Dishes were shaken from tables, the walls of some large buildings were cracked, and many people were frightened into leaving their houses.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., July 19. -- The proceedings of the Summer school were opened to-day by Father Halpin, who delivered his fourth lecture on the immortality of the soul.
Two women were almost suffocated in the tenement, at 411 East Nineteenth Street, at 8 o'clock last night.

One of those old-fashioned games -- full of hard batting, hair-raising situations, and with a Garrison finish thrown in by way of good measure -- delighted a small crowd of cranks at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was frightfully hot on the Harlem diamond, and, although the rooters for the Giants experienced something akin to chills and fever, they felt themslves well repaid, because Ward's men won.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Impatient at the delays of Congress in coming to some decision on the tariff question, prominent business men of Chicago have united in an appeal that some definite action be taken at once.

STATE CAMP, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 19 -- This was a gala day for the Second Brigade of the National Guard of the State of New-Jersey, it being the Governor's day. Fully 10,000 people were on the grounds.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Secretary Lamont to-night made the following statement concerning the situation at Chicago and the removal of troops:

BOSTON, July 19. -- There was almost no market for local stocks to-day, and there were no interesting features to relieve the monotony of the situation. Prices, however, were generally strong. Bell Telephone advanced 1/2, to 194, and Dominion Coal 1/2, to 21. West End Land was firmer, at 2 3/8, on reports of good sales of land.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 19. -- President Diaz has appointed a committee which is to make a scientific exploration of the crater of the volcano of Popocatepetl, with a view to determining the amount of sulphur it contains and the best means of extracting it. The mountain belongs to Gen. Ochera, and the sulphur is already being taken out in relatively small quantities.

PARIS, July 19. -- The debate on the anti-Anarchist bill was continued in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, M. Jules Guesde, Socialist, opening the discussion with a charge that the police were primarily responsible for the increase in Anarchism in having covertly fostered an Anarchist propaganda in order to discredit Socialism.

"It may well excite our wonder that Democrats are willing to depart from this, the most Democratic of all tariff principles, and that the inconsistent absurdity of such a proposed departure should be emphasized by the suggestion that the wool of the farmer be put on the free list and the protection of tariff taxation be placed around the iron ore and coal of corporations and capitalists."
MOBILE, Ala., July 19. -- The Bluefields correspondent of The Register sends that paper the following details of the recent trouble in Bluefieids:

BOSTON, July 19 -- The Executive Council at to-day's session paroled two prisoners now at the State prison -- Frederick W. Keyser and John W. Powell. Keyser was sentenced in 1881 to eighteen years' imprisonment for breaking and entering. He was at that time but twenty years of age. Since his incarceration his conduct has been most exemplary.

Mrs. Carnegie's steam yacht Dungenesa made a trip around Sandy Hook Lightship and up the North River yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Carnegie, through Designer George B. Mallory, entertained some of the newspaper men and some who were interested in the construction of the boat.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- A bill in equity was filed in the United States Circuit Court to-day by counsel for the First National Bank of Rockville, Conn., charging fraud on the part of Seth B. Stitt Co., woolen manufacturers of Montgomery County, Penn., in the transaction of the business of that firm, which made an assignment several months ago.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 19. -- Splendid racing was seen to-day at the Pittsburg Athletic Club's tournament. The crowd present was about thirty-five hundred very enthusiastic people. The weather was insufferably hot. The new quarter-mile track was rough, ganger said he needed a pneumatic saddle and rode in but one race, the mile handicap, in which he quit, unable to take the bankings.

The trouble among the Republicans of this city, which is to come before the State Committee for settlement at its meeting next week, is likely to bring together politicians from all parts of the State who are rot members of the committee. Would-be candidates, with their "booms" for State nominations, will be among the number.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- "If you could sit a while in the Democratic cloakroom, you would be apt to hear some very violent language with reference to the President's letter," said a Democratic Senator late this afternoon to a correspondent of The New-York Times.

The second game of the Staten Island Athletic Club's carnival of cricket took place yesterday at West Brighton, where the Kings County St. George Club of Brooklyn suffered a most crushing defeat by 137 runs.

From The Minneapolis Penny Press, July 14. If there were ever a time in the world when the United Press demonstrated the fact that it is "A News Gathering Association," and not "A Stock Jobbing Corporation," that fact was thoroughly demonstrated yesterday. At 9:30 A.M. the Associated Press sent out to its entire Western patrons the information that "The strike is off."

The announcement that the French Ministry has made the new Press bill a Cabinet question gives great importance to that project of law and makes it desirable that it should be accurately understood. It is commonly called a project for a censorship, but it is nothing of the kind.

"The rank and file of the Democracy are downcast under the assertion that their party fails in ability to manage the Govenunent, and they are apprehensive that efforts to bring about tariff reform may fail; but they are much more downcast and apprehensive in their fear that Democratic Principle may be surrendered." -- President Cleveland's Letter to Chairman Wilson.
The weekly bulletin of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen, issued yesterday, contains the following items of interest to the cycling world:

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- There were more important changes in naval commands to-day. They were a surprise, as they changed the programme which had been laid down by Secretary Herbert. It was not decided to make the changes until yesterday afternoon, when orders which had been signed and were ready for the mail had to be recalled.

"I expect very few of us can say when our measure is perfected that all its features are entirely as we would prefer. You know how much I deprecated the incorporation in the proposed bill of the income tax feature. In matters of this kind, however, which do not violate a fixed and recognized Democratic doctrine, we are willing to defer to the judgment of a majority of our Democratic brethren.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 19. -- The fast mail and express train, No. 3, on the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad, which left here at 4:30 P.M. to-day, ran into an open switch at Esperance, thirty miles west of this city, turning the locomotive over, derailing the baggage and express cars, badly shaking up the passengers, and injuring the engineer and fireman.

Liquor dealers, both wholesale and retail, in this city and Brooklyn, were greatly interested yesterday in a decision rendered by Mgr. Satolli relative to the temperance question and the sale of liquor by Catholics. Mgr. Satolli declared, in effect, that no Catholic should be engaged in the liquor traffic. The Papal Ablegate's decision was provoked by the following circular letter issued by Bishop Watterson of Columbus, Ohio, to the priests in his diocese:

Now that President Martin of the Board of Police has announced that the Committee on Repairs and Supplies is to consist of Commissioners Sheehan and Kerwin, it is fair to assume that he, at least, thinks Kerwin is a congenial spirit of Sheehan, and they both are fitted to control the expenditure of so large a sum of money as is expended yearly under the direction of this committee.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 19. -- Adjutant Gen. Porter returned from Albany this afternoon, but did not relieve Col. Welch as Post Commander until after the evening parade. His first official act after assuming command was to issue an order directing Lieut. Eastmead of the Fifteenth Separate Company to return to camp for the remainder of his tour of duty, if he so desires.

The epistle of Platt to the people has made the war in the Republican Party in this city more bitter than it was before. The statements made by the Milholland wing concerning the enrollment of the Committee of Thirty, the former members of the County Committee who are prominent in the new organization, and concerning the Republican Club, simply drove in the wedge which is splitting the party.

ELIZABETH, July 19. -- A.H. Barnett, the winner of the Times Medal at the Irvington-Millburn race, has just received official notification that he smashed four records by his performance that day, and he now holds the following records: Five miles, 13:45, State record; fifteen miles, 42:40, American record; twenty miles, 57:12, American record; twenty-five miles, 1:11:18, State record.

BAIREUTH, July 19. -- The opera festival opened to-day with "Parsifal" before an audience which filled the great theatre and followed the performance from beginning to end with rapt attention, applauding, however only at the conclusion of the acts, which is the rule at all the performances here.

The appointment of the Hon. Clifton R. Breekinridge to be Minister to Russia is as creditable to the President and as honorable to Mr. Breckinridge as the circumstances which have allowed it to be made are disgraceful to the Democrats of the Second Arkansas District. Mr. Breckinridge is a man of pure character and unusual abilities who has the full courage of his beliefs.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The feature of the market was on the strength displayed in the elevated stocks, both Alley and Lake Street "L," with very little doing in the latter, although it advanced more by reason of the limited offerings than any present intrinsic merit. There was a fairly good demand, and higher prices were readily established.

The Knickerbocker Tennis Club continued its open handicap tournament yesterday on the club grounds at One Hundred and Fortieth Street and Brook Avenue. There were five close contests, one in the singles, and two each in the consolations and the doubles.

The Professional Woman's League gave a small and select "at home" yesterday afternoon, and a number of its friends and benefactors called to admire the clubhouse and offer their congratulations upon the continued success of the organization.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Much as the letter of the President was enjoyed by the mass of Democrats on the floor, there was an unreadiness to comment on it in conversation that was characteristic of the timidity of the House, or perhaps a distrust after the many mistakes of the House, to venture to express opinions that the country might not agree with.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The President sent to the Senate to-day the nomination of Clifton R. Breckinridge of Arkansas to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Russia, to succeed Andrew D. White, resigned.

Those who have followed the Reading litigation will recall that early in June Special Master Crawford completed his report on the allegations made by Mr. Isaac L. Rice against the receivers and managers of the property; that it was a very long document, and that it was unique in its conclusion that the only one who had sinned against the Reading property was Mr. Rice, the complainant.

The temperature yesterday reached 96 degrees at 3:30 P.M., the record made on Thursday, but the average was 85 degrees, 1 5/8 degrees higher than on the previous day. One fatal case of heat prostration was reported in Brooklyn.

From The Popular Science Monthly. Children's fanciful readings of things, as when they call the twinkling star a blinking eye, are but an exaggeration of what we all do. Their imagination carries them very much further. Thus, they may attribute to the stone they see a sort of stone soul, and speak of it as feeling tired.

The Manhattan Single Tax Club held a meeting at Twenty-third Street and Madison Avenue last night, and until further notice it will hold out-door meetings for workingmen on Tuesday and Friday evenings. Benjamin Dobbin presided, and said a single tax is the solution of present labor troubles and defective legislation.

This is the season of the year when certain politicians hie themselves to Saratoga and are generally reputed to talk things over on the cool verandas or on the banks of the lake as they sip cooling drinks.

The pier of the Jersey Central Railroad Company at the foot of Rector Street and the North River narrowly escaped destruction yesterday afternoon by a fire. A fire broke out in the record room on the second floor, and Cashier Walter Frazee was burned on the hands while trying to put out the flames. The pier where the fire occurred is occupied by the railroad company for freight purposes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20. -- If the people who have been trading in the tractions are not buying too much on paper profits, these stocks might do to buy, even after such enormous advances, but there is a constant tendency to double up and play double or quits, so that when something does happen there is a bad smash.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- In regard to the bill for the adjustment of the indebtedness of the Union and Central Pacific Railroads. which the House Committee on Pacific Railroads reported to-day, Mr. James B. Reilly of Pennsylvania, the Chairman of the committee and author of the bill, furnishes the following statement:

A statement setting forth various grievances of navy men, and which it is alleged was compiled for publication by a "committee" of dissatisfied tars of the United States cruiser San Francisco, was printed yesterday afternoon in several Brooklyn papers. From reading it, one would get a notion that the vessel was built during an eclipse and rigged with curses dark.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 20. -- Lieut. Eastmead of the Fifteenth Separate Company, who was charged with incompetency and relieved from duty by Col. Welch on Wednesday, and was yesterday restored to his command by Gen. Porter, arrived here to-day. He denies all the charges made against him by Capt. Howland of the Sixty-fifth Regiment, who was Officer of the Day when Eastmead was Officer of the Guard.

BOSTON, July 20.-- The only feature of the market for local securities was the drop in West End Street Railway, which declined abruptly to 47. This was partly occasioned by lack of buying orders and partly by the uncertainty which is felt over the approaching city election, when it is expected that the Rapid Transit bill will be accepted.

"Gen." J.D. Coxey has come to town. He arrived on the Congressional limited from Washington last night, and went at once to the headquarters of the People's Party, 50 East Tenth Street, where he was seen by a reporter for The New-York Times.
The Commission in Lunacy resumed, at Ward's Island yesterday morning, its inquiry into the abuses alleged to exist in connection with the management of the city asylums for the insane.
BERLIN, July 20. -- A dispatch from St. Petersburg this evening says that the cholera has abated notably there in the last twenty-four hours, and the climax is believed to be passed.

Twice within six months Hass Assman, tin can makers, have been burned out. Their factory, at 128-132 Jane Street, was completely burned out on April 19, and on Friday morning their building at 155-157 Bank Street was destroyed by fire.

OCEAN GROVE, July 20. -- The closing exercises of the Ocean Grove Sunday School Assembly wers held to-day. The feature of the morning session was the parade around the camp grounds by the officers and pupils of the school.

Thomas C. Platt's literary bureau in the Platt-Milholland movement made another vicious thrust yesterday at the regular Republican organization which was constructed under the direction of the Committee of Thirty.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The strike at the packing houses remains firm. President Taylor of the National Cattle Butchers' Union made a statement to-day in which he claims the men are now striking for a restoration of wages which the packers cut last February.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with absolute amazement the several publications in The Times of the past three days anent the appointment of Gen. Kerwin to the position of Police Commissioner, and I beg you will permit me to express my unqualified surprise that your respectable journal should have permitted itself to be made the medium of publishing attacks instigated entirely by personal malice and personal vengeance.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Wnile the stock market was abnormally dull, prices were remarkably firm, as there were no special offerings. Holders were not at all anxious to force sales at the expense of concessions, and it was difficult to fill buying orders for some of the securities. Lake Street, for the time being, seemed firm, and its friends are growing more numerous.

The fight opened in the Senate yesterday is between the majority of the American people on the one hand, honorably represented by the House, which has refused to accept the Senate Tariff bill, and by President Cleveland, who has firmly and frankly indorsed the House in this refusal, and on the other hand the Sugar Trust and the iron and coal companies, represented chiefly by Mr. Gorman of Maryland.

Mrs. Elizabeth Matthews, who occupies apartments in the Scarboro Mansions, at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, caused the arrest yesterday of her husband, Robert B. Matthews. She charged him with having removed from her custody an oil painting, the property of H.B. Jones, which she valued at $250. Mr. and Mrs. Matthews both claim to be art dealers.

From The Boston Saturday Evening Gazette. Fifty or more years ago Cornhill was an important headquarters for the book trade particularly antiquarian books. The two noted firms were Samuel B. Drake, himself an author, and Burnham Brothers. The Burnhams were the most remarkable, and their history is almost a romance.
The increase in New-York City's net funded debt during the first six months of this year, is explained by Controller Fitch in this statement issued yesterday:

Mr. Thomas B. Reed undoubtedly has his uses. He is a bold and unscrupulous party leader, who is not deterred by any considerations of reason or justice, or even policy, from pursuing the course that has been decided upon in the interest of the party, the party meaning to him simply the organization.
From The Philadelphia Times, (Ind.) An ideal national ticket to present the issue of the majesty of law to people of the country regardless of party would be as follows:
John L. Lyon, a well-known glass dealer at 29 Murray Street, resides at 570 Fifth Avenue. Among his servants he has long had a good-looking and intelligent mulatto, Andrew J Branie, as butler.

NEWARK, N.J., July 20. -- One of the fiercest fires ever known in this city started in Benjamin Joachmowitz's hat factory, 31 Boyd Street, about 12:30 this afternoon, and immediately spread to the buildings on either side, occupied by Russians and Polanders. The fire was caused by the explosion of the steam coil in the drying room.

From The Washington Post, July 19. A fortune in counterfeit cash, which has been gathered in by the servants of the Secret Service, was destroyed yesterday at the Treasury Department. It consisted of a lump sum of about $50,000 in bills of all denominations from ten-cent shinplasters, for which there is a considerable demand at present in certain sections of the land, up to twenty-dollar and one-hundred-dollar bills.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 20. -- In an old farmhouse on the outskirts of this village Mrs. Elizabeth Jervis to-day celebrated the one hundredth anniversary of her birth. In attendance at the celebration were her eight children, twenty-two grandchildren, forty-three great-grandchildren, and three great-great-grandchildren.

A publisher's note prefixed to this volume declares that the letters are published With Mr. Ruskin's consent; but he is in no way responsible for their arrangement and editing. Who the editor may be we learn not. Nor does the anonymous editor inform us who may have been the recipient of the letters.

PARIS, July 20. -- The new torpedo boat Le Grondeur ran into the harbor at Boulogne this morning at a high rate of speed and was abandoned at once by her crew. She had been partly turned and was filling with water.

The special commission of engineers appointed by President Cleveland to determine the length of span of the proposed bridge across the North River met in the Army Building yesterday morning. Engineer William Hildebrandt was present to give the board additional information concerning his plans for a suspension bridge across the North River, opposite Sixtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- One unacquainted with the situation would have known from the appearance of the Senate Chamber at noon to-day that something unusual was expected to occur. Every Senator who had not been driven from Washington by the intense heat was in his place.

Although it is early in the season, the indications already point to a more successful exhibition by the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden this Fall than ever before. Capt. Hyde, whose able management has contributed so much to the successes of the past, says that the entries in some of this year's classes will be superior both in quality and number to anything heretofore catalogued.

The failure on the part of the national legislators to pass a tariff bill has affected the country in a manner which as yet has received but little or no consideration except by those who feel the pulse of labor by making a careful study of the country's immigration and emigration.
Edmona Jean Baptiste Guillaume, a celebrated architect, died yesterday in Paris.

Justice Gaynor in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday rendered a decision touching the powers of the Department of Assessors. The decision was in the case of the Brooklyn Traction Company, who sued for a writ of certiorari to review the action of the Department of Assessors in fixing the assessed valuation of its property for 1893 at $1,015,500.

The annual championships of the Metropolitan Athletic Association will be decided this afternoon at Saratoga, under the auspices of the Saratoga Athletic Club. The games have attracted considerable attention, and a meeting of no little merit is expected. The flower of the athletes of the large cities gives the entry list an imposing appearance, and the more enthusiastic of the officials predict record breaking in several events.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The side armor of the battle ship Indiana was tested to-day at the Indian Head Proving Ground. The plate was selected at random from the entire lot of 615 tons, all Harveyized, manufactured for the Indiana. It was sixteen feet and one-half inch long, and stood seven feet high when resting on edge. From its top edge for 43 inches its uniform thickness was 18 inches throughout its length.

The Brooklyns gave a special ladies' day matinee performance at Eastern Park yesterday to signalize their safe though inglorious return from their scalp-hunting expedition to the South and the West. They had the aggregation at baseball players representing the Quaker City for their special guests, and the Grooms very politely showed them a few points on how to play the great national game.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- For a few hours to-day the protection Democrats, who do not care much whether there be a tariff bill or not, and the Republicans, who prefer to see the McKinley act retained as a proof of Democratic Inability to revise the tariff, were confident that all tariff legislation would fall.

Jesse W. Reno, R.W.G. Welling, and Edmond Kelly, representing the Reno double-deck tunnel plan for rapid transit, which the former Rapid-Transit Commission did not approve, have addressed a letter to the present commission, criticising the plan to be submitted to popular vote, and asking that a way be left open by resolution for the adoption of the Reno plan, should that seem advisable.

William C. Hord, a member of the firm of Street, Wykes Co., 44 Wall Street, New-York, which holds a number of Brooklyn City bonds, appeared in Controller Corwin's office yesterday, when a number of bids were opened for bridge, sewer, and local improvement bonds.

Maxwell E. Moore, referee of the New-York Athletic Club, had his horse, valued at $500, and his new wagon, valued at $300, stolen on July 3. They have been recovered, and Joseph F. Boehm of 2,153 Second Avenue is under arrest charged with stealing them.

KINGSTOWN, Ireland, July 20. -- It was the same old spectacular story of variable breezes, calms, rain squalls, and thunder showers. The Britannia's luck again attended her, and she won by 1 minute and 57 seconds actual time and 3 minutes and 7 seconds with her time allowance of 1 minute and 10 seconds.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The Massachusetts Naval Reserve will sail from Boston July 24 on the cruiser Atlanta and the monitor Miantonomoh for a four days' cruise. A camp will be established at Lovell's Island and additional quarters for the men will be provided there on the monitor Passaic.

DETROIT, Mich., July 20. -- Though the card for the fifth day of the Grand Circuit promised more sensations, the sport was stopped by a terrific thunderstorm before a race could be finished. The attendance fell off a little this afternoon, chiefly because the weather was threatening. In the 2:12 trot, which came first, ten well-known cracks started, with Ryland T. the tip.

John Kelly, who was arrested at 2:30 A. M. March 12, while carrying a bundle which was found to contain dynamite cartridges, was acquitted yesterday in the Court of General Sessions without being put to the trouble of making a defense.

How thoroughly the decent Irish-Americans of this city, as well as all other lawabiding citizens, resent the appointment by Mayor Gilroy of Michael Kerwin as Police Commissioner continues to be made manifest.
PANAMA, July 20. -- The Star and Herald says to-day:

Isaac Levy, who has a fur store in Third Street, this city, and another in London, England, was indicted for perjury yesterday, arrested on Judge Cowing's order, and released in $5,000 bail. Levy caused the arrest in England of Adolph and Montagu Bernhard, brothers, who were his agents, charging them with having misappropriated $4,000 and furs worth $1,000.

Ina Gunn, fourteen years old, was drowned in the Hudson River, at the foot of West One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street, last evening. With her cousin, Mamie Patterson, she had gone in bathing. Neither of the girls could swim.

BOSTON, July 20. -- The Bostons and New-Yorks opened the renovated South End grounds to-day, and a large crowd turned out to greet them. The heat was so intense that the cozy little grand stand, with a seating capacity of only 900, was totally inadequate to accommodate those who wished to witness the game from a sheltered position.

The feature of the racing at the Brighton Beach track yesterday afternoon was the handicap at seven furlongs. It was the feature in spite of the fact that Lady Violet, who has an attack of catarrhal fever, and Kingston were both scratched, the Dwyer and Belmont Stables trusting to their second strings, which were Armitage and Jack of Spades, respectively.

Boston Letter to The Providence Journal. There was a moral wave across the Charles last Sunday when the Cambridge druggists were closed up by the Mayor at the request of the ministers. The law is unquestionably on their side. It is a law which was adapted to stricter times than ours, and which has been allowed to slumber for years in innocuous desuetude.

ALBANY, July 20. -- The Socialistic Labor Party has come to town and knocked to-day the door of the Constitutional Convention. It brought two proposed amendments and a communication that struggled under the weight of a ponderous sentence that in length, intricacy, and general development surpassed Mr. Evarts's most brilliant effort in this direction.

From The Baltimore Sun, July 16. The right of Jacob and Henry Herman to remove the bodies of their parents from the cemetery of the Shearlth Israel Congregation has been sustained In a decree signed by Judge Dennis.

It is excellent news that forty-three more rioters have been indicted in Chicago for obstructing inter-State commerce and interfering with the transportation of the mails. The request of many business men in Chicago that the Federal troops shall not be withdrawn gives particular point to the action of the Grand Jury.

Midsummer dullness afflicted Stock Exchange circles yesterday. The total uns-actions were only 96,333 shares, and, as usual, more than the amount was in the industrials, speculation was exceedingly limited, and was confined to the professional traders. The continued uncertainly as a tariff legislation has killed all outside business, and the offices of commission brokers were practically deserted.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 20. -- This was the last day of the trotting meeting at Springfield. Results: 2:45 trotting, purse $300, Margaret C., by William L., first; Winchester second. Boss S. third; best time. 2:33. 2:20 pace, purse $250, Raven T., by Bay Tom, first; Pat Murphy second, Chestnut Burr third; winner's best time, 2:27.

From The London Figaro. A very amusing anecdote concerning the brother of the new President of the French Republic is related by M. Ziem, the Venice artist. The brother of M. Casimir-Perier was on intimate relations with Corot. He came, one day in 1875, to see the painter at Barbizon, just at the moment when Corot was putting the finishing touches to his "Biblis," a picture which represents nymphs sleeping in a wood.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 20. -- The features of to-day's campaign meeting at Lexington were the crying down of Cal Caughman, candidate for Congress, Butler's indorsement of Vice President Stevenson for President, and Tillman's abuse of Cleveland.

The bill for the admission of Arizona as a State, which has passed the House of Representatives and has been for some time in the hands of the Senate Committee on Territories, ought not to become a law, for the simple reason that Arizona is in such a condition in regard to population, industries, finances, and politics as to be unfit for Statehood.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 20. -- An iron safe which had been broken open and the contents rifled was found to-day in a ditch near the Pennsylvania Railroad, crossing at State Street, Stockton.

In an oak frame hanging in the Controller's office are a voucher and warrant which are very good examples of the amount of work necessary to correct a slight mistake. The original amount involved was 3 cents, but over $50 worth of time has been wasted on it.

From The Baltimore Sun, (Dem.) Not more welcome to the ears of the beleaguered defenders of Lucknow were the Pipes and bugles that announced that relief was coming than are to the American people the cheers that greeted Chairman Wilson's brave and statesmanlike words In the House and the trumpet-call to duty that rings and echoes in every line of President Cleveland's letter to Mr. Wilson, read in the same body.

Paris Dispatch to The London Daily Telegraph. Another of those once-famous dancing places of old times, the Elysee-Menilmontant, is about to disappear. Its neighbor, the Elysee-Montmarte, has been transformed into a concert hall, but there is no such luck in store for the Menilmontant Paradise, which is about to be completely demolished in order to make room for a goods depot of the Ceinture Railway.

Washington, July 20. -- Samuel E. Morss. Consul General at Paris, was at the State Department today. He is on leave from his post, and goes to his home in Indiana to-morrow. Charles Denby. Minister to China, who has been in Washington, for several days, will leave for his home in Indiana to-morrow.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 20. -- An explosion of 400 pounds of loose powder at Fort Pulaski at 9 o'clock this morning fatally wounded Ordnance Sergeant William Chinn, seriously injured Mary Washington, his mother-in-law, and set fire to the fort, causing intermittent explosions of ammunition and doing much damage to the fort.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 20. -- An investigation by an agent of the Treasury Department has, it is said, developed the fact that enormous quantities of frozen and salt herring brought here by American vessels from provincial ports and admitted free as products of American fishermen should have been classed as foreign merchandise, subject to duty.

WHITESTONE, L.I., July 20. -- The report of a rifle at Sentry Post No. 4 startled the garrison at Willet's Point about 10 o'clock last night. As there were three shots, which is the alarm for a fire or other serious happening, the signal was immediately taken up by the other posts, and for a while the place resounded with signals of distress.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 20.-- The most important business before the Baptist Young People's Conference to-day was the presentation of the financial statement, election of officers, and presentation of banners.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn has sent to the members of the "Board of Accidents" notices calling them to a special meeting on Monday next, to take action in regard to Commissioner White's request for money with which to provide for the city sufficent water. The Mayor's call was as follows:

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The stereotyped reason for the prevailing weakness in wheat is the moving now crop. No new excuse was given for another decline to-day. It would appear, however, that abssnce of nerve among the bulls and the fact that the demand for export or home consumption snows no great improvement are responsible for the inability of prices to recover from the present low status.

Bradstreet's will say to-day: The disappearance of the great railway strike of 1894, the revival of regular freight schedules, and the customary movement of produce and merchandise by water and rail have done much to restore something like the preceding volume of trade. The most encouraging statement is merely that general business is only approaching the usual midsummer proportions.

The Rev. A.J. Mason, vicar of All Hallows, Barking, writes to The London Times: " Jan. 10 next year will be the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the death of Archbishop Laud, who was executed on Tower Hill, Jan. 10, 1645, and on the following day was burled in the Church of All Hallows, Barking.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The halls of the Catholic University, near the Soldiers' Home, are practically deserted. Only two of the professors, the Rev. Dr. McMahon and Dr. Daniel Quinn, are now there.

BAIREUTH, July 20. -- For the first time in the history of the Wagner festivals, "Lohengrin" was sung to-day at the Festspiel Haus. It was an entirely successful performance, barring one great disappointment, and may be counted among the finest ever given here. The results of the performance to-day amply justified the months of labor which were spent in its preparation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 20. -- Frederick J. Titus added to his fame and fortune many links at this afternoon's races of the Cleveland Wheel Club tournament. Sanger, Johnson, Taylor, Graves, and Coleman refused to ride on the poorly banked, unsafe quarter-mile track. Several of the competitors ran over the bank, C. Murphy and Callahan going over a dirt pile and into a bunch of wheel trunks in the mile handicap.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 20. -- M.I.V. Flagier of Auburn, N.Y., gave an organ recital this morning. In the afternoon Theodore Roosevelt of Washington lectured, and concluded his course on "The Westward Progress of Civilization in the United States." Dr. Adams of Yale spoke of the English colonial system, and Dr. W.H. Tolman of "The Children of the Poor."

The opinion was substantially unanimous in the Street yesterday that there would be no tariff bill. "We must go to the country again on this," said one of the leading operators. The fight for tariff reform is not more than begun. It will go on till the reform movement is victorious, whether it be under Democratic or Republican auspices.

Two prominent members of the Administration, have discovered the beauties of Sorrento, one of the most charming spots on the Maine coast. Secretary of War Daniel Lament has been going there for a number of Summers, and two or three years ago built a house. This Summer he has leased his cottage, which is most delightfully situated, to Dr. F. H. Davenport of Boston.

DOLGEVILLE, N.Y., July 21. -- Nearly 1,000 men are now engaged in decorating the village preparatory to the arrival of 10,000 German turners Wednesday next, who will come to attend the twenty-fifth turnfest of the New-York Turn-Bezirk. It will be the largest gathering of German-American athletes ever held in America.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 21 -- Except at the Golf Club grounds, the week has been a very quiet one, though a marked increase in interest in the Casino dances has been apparent. The Golf Club promises to affect society here for a year or two. The drives have less carriages, and the club grounds are well filled.

There has been a great amount of talk in England and on the Continent about the opera "Signa," by Frederic Cowen, an Englishman, well known hare as the composer of the Scandinavian symphony and some neat songs. The opera has been performed in Milan, where it achieved only a moderate success, and was withdrawn because Mr. Cowen was supposed to have induced an English critic to write adversely about an Italian rival.

The scenes that have lately been witnessed in St. Peter's bear witness to what may be called an extraordinary recrudescence of Papal popularity. Imagine 20,000 persons closely packed from early morning till 6 o'clock in the vast area beneath Michael Angelo's dome, thousands outside in the great space in front, (once the race course of Nero, where hundreds of Christians were burned like torches in tubs of oil.)

Warren, Ohio, July 21. -- Fire destroyed a large part of the business portion of Orangeville this morning. The general store of E. R. Fell, Hunt Co.'s hardware store and the grocery store of Hyde Gather were consumed. Loss probably $20,000.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.Y., July 21. -- The second special regatta of the Shelter Island Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon over a course in Deering Harbor and Gardiner's Bay. The wind was fairly steady, a trifle too slack at times, but, aside from that, the afternoon was ideal for sailing, and every yacht and craft in the harbor not in the race was out to see the contest.

From The London Daily News. We learn that Gen. Boulanger's mother, Mme. Boulanger, nee Griffiths, a lady of Welsh birth, died a fortnight ago at the age of ninety-three in the apartment in Paris where she had lived for many years. For a few years she had been in a wandering state of mind, her faculties having declined about the time when her son's popularity in Paris was at its climax.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., July 21 -- Moonlight sails, tea parties, and receptions at the hotels have been the leading features of the past week at this place, and have furnished pleasant amusement for the many guests here.

DETROIT, Mich., July 21. -- As six events were still left to end the Grand Circuit programme here, the horses were summoned earlier than usual to-day. The track was in capital condition, the rain of Friday making it faster than ever. The two unfinished events came up first, and each was over in two heats.
SHANGHAI, July 21.-- An unconfirmed rumor is current here that war has bean declared between China and Japan.

This pamphlet contains a prophecy after the manner of "The Battle of Dorking" and Mr. Bellamy's "Looking Backward," but of a lighter trend and with a comic climax. The anonymous author of "The Women's Conquest," whom we understand to be Thomas A. Janvier, does not believe, probably, that the question of woman suffrage is really a vital issue in the year 1894.

BARTLETT, N.H., July 21 -- An increasing number of Summer tourists year by year discover the charms of this mountain location, the gateway to the famous Crawford Notch of the White Mountains. It hasn't been long since a trip to this region meant an abandonment of the arts of civilization, communion with the rude in art and nature.

From The San Francisco Bulletin, July 3. With Mrs. Stanford was her young lady secretary and her niece, a young miss of twelve years. Mrs. Stanford was dressed in deep mourning. She looked tired and agitated, and her eyes bore traces of recent tears.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 21 -- Delightful weather has given zest to the various outdoor and indoor amusements for which this resort is becoming famous. Coaching, driving, boating, bathing, fishing, billiards, and dancing are but a few of the many features of life here.
From The Boston Transcript. Congressman Reed thinks that the Tariff bill will be mistaken for a biographical dictionary. It may be worse than that, perhaps -- a political necrology.

The trial of Capt. Doherty and ex-Ward Men Hock and Meehan on charges which grew out of Augusta Thorow's testimony before the Lexow committee will be continued at Police Headquarters to-morrow morning.
The sales referred to in the accompanying list are scheduled to take place in the New-York Real Estate Salesroom at 111 Broadway, unless otherwise stated:

TISHALEE, Ga., July 21. -- There are about 3,500 electric watermelons being shipped North from this town. They are the visible and outward sign of an interesting experiment made by Mr. Jared Freesm, who has a large farm two miles south of here.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 21 -- That as a Summer resort this place is becoming more and more popular is clearly evidenced by the large number of guests who are arriving daily. Every boarding house is full, or nearly so, and many visitors are being entertained by private parties.

OCEAN GROVE, July 21. -- The Christian Arbitration and Peace Society met here to-day in annual convention. The Young People's Temple was filled with the members and well-wishers of the organization. Dr. N.L. Upham of Philadelphia, the Presidents of the society, presided. The members were welcomed to Ocean Grove by Dr. E.H. Stokes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21. -- The board room seemed to-day to be unusually empty, many of the brokers having gone away for their holiday. Those that were left took very little interest in Quotations. Such news as was obtainable seemed to favor the bulls. The scarcity of stocks for sale is made evident by the sharp advance when the orders are on commission.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Secretary Herbert has sent orders to Admiral Walker directing him to return home in the Philadelphia and relinquish his command of the Pacific squadron to Commodore Beardslee at San Francisco. These orders will go forward by the steamer leaving San Francisco July 26, and should be delivered to the Admiral not later than Aug. 2.

LONDON, July 21. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- There is not much change in the condition of business for the week just closed. Money is plentiful, but recently all gold arrivals have been taken for the Continent. There has been no movement of metal at the bank this week, either in or out.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 21 -- The following companies were to-day incorporated with the Secretary of State:

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 21. -- Since the trial of Cadet Valentine, hazing is no longer fashionable, and the plebes saunter around when tactical or cadet officers are not in the neighborhood with an easy assurance which heretofore was unknown in the fourth class. The plebes have no more social privileges than in the past.

Even John Schliemann could hardly have asked a more offensive question than was put the other day by Excise Commissioner Joseph C. Hacker to a Roman Catholic clergyman who appeared before the Excise Board to protest against the granting of a certain liquor license, because there were too many saloons in his neighborhood.

Thomas Hanlon, forty years old, a clerk in the employ of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, committed suicide last night at his lodging house, 63 Seventh Avenue, by shooting himself in the mouth and heart. He was sick in bed at the time, suffering with grip and with the return of an old trouble of the legs for which he bad undergone two operations.

The few houseboats seen in this country give an inadequate idea of the English houseboat, whose existence served as an incentive to the notion of building any over here, but whose actual model has been very much deviated from.

Of all recent dull days on the Stock Exchange yesterday excelled them. The total sales were a little more than 45,000 shares, and in many stocks classed in the active list there was no trading at all.

ELBERON, N.J., July 21. -- Driving seems to take precedence of everything else this Summer. Coaching parties of cottagers and guests at the Hotel Elberon have been frequent. On Tuesday Sandford P. Ross took out a party in his four-in-hand. The trip, an exceptionally delightful one, was to Red Bank, Oceanic, and home by the way of the Rumson Road.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 21. -- There have been many arrivals to-day of persons to attend the Young Men's Christian Association exercises, to be held to-morrow, Among the visitors are Gen. O.O. Howard of New-York, CoL A.D. Shaw, and Henry Bond of Buffalo. A reception was given this evening.

BERLIN, July 21 -- Encouraged by the terms of a short speech made by Prince Bismarck to a deputation of agriculturists at Coblitzau, while on his way from Friedrichsruhe to Varzin, the leaders of the Agrarian League a day or two ago addressed a communication to the ex-Chancellor asking his more active co-operation with the Agrarians in their political work.

The Summer of the strike riots and Debs, of financial "hardpan" and pecuniary deficiencies, of the tariff content and the voracious locust, is also the Summer of the mosquito. For seven years she -- for the offensive gnat is a female -- has not been so ubiquitous or so blood-thirsty.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The United States Army is to be concentrated in the neighborhood of the large cities of the country. This is the result of the labor troubles of the past few years, in the quelling of which the army has played so prominent a part.

A brotherly tribute which is credited to the Prince of Wales is his reply on one occasion, when he was asked who was the cleverest woman he had ever met. His answer was prompt. "My sister, the Empress Frederick."

The Squire is not a literary man in a general way. He believes in the Bible and Sir Walter Scott, and sometimes in the mellow, lamp-lit evenings he takes his Byron and rereads some of those wild love lyrics which in his youth, at a certain romantic time, he very likely knew by heart. He looks up from the book sometimes with very kindly old eyes at Madame, sitting opposite to him.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 21. -- The heat of the hottest Summer in years is sending thousands of people out of New-York, and a stream which seems to have no end is flowing from that city and Brooklyn into the cool regions of the breezy Catskills. The days in the Catskills are warm, of course, but the heat is never oppressive.

By a blast that spent its force sideways, instead of upward, the big tenement at the northwest corner of Sixty-seventh Street and Amsterdam Avenue was bombarded yesterday afternoon with a volley of broken stone. The building was considerably shattered, not having been constructed to withstand heavy fire

In "Marcella" Mrs. Ward betrays herself to have mastered the philosophy of the art of gowning, as she has got to the root of a good many other things. The faithful Betty, exercised over the toilet of the heroine for the Masterson festival, says trenchantly: "I wouldn't make you fashionable for the world.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 21. -- Even here, where the Atlantic breezes blow for twenty hours in the twenty-four, it is undeniably warm, but there is not an hour of the day when one may not find a cool, shady spot. Dancing for the nonce is not taken up, however.

From The London Dally Telegraph. London's general health during the past week has been remarkably good, the death rate -- 15.8 -- being much below the average. Nearly all the maladies to which modern flesh is heir to show a diminution, but one entry in the return of the Registrar General has not been seen in it for a long time -- the death of a child from English cholera.

The complications of local and State politics at the present moment only show more clearly than ever that the salvation of city government depends upon rescuing it from party politics altogether, which can only be accomplished by a separation of municipal from general elections.

Mrs. Sarah Franzblau of 260 Rivington Street yesterday gave to her fourteen-month-old baby boy Max a teaspoonful of carbolic acid in mistake for medicine. The child died from the effects of the poison in a few minutes. The mother is almost crazed with grief.

BOSTON, July 21 -- Many yachts are away on cruises to the eastward, and only a few local races have been in order for a fortnight. The Eastern squadron in at Bar Harbor, and several of the Corinthian boats arc on their way to that place. The South Boston and Winthrop Clubs are working slowly along the Maine coast. The Massachusetts Club will take a short cruise late in August.

The new building of the New-York Clearing House, as designed by R.W. Gibson, is of white marble, in Italian Renaissance style is detached from adjacent structures, and preserves its own separate character. The front is three stories in height, the first 20 feet, the second 25 feet, and the third 20 feet, with a domed roof of 20 feet more, making the upper cornice about 75 feet high.

BOSTON, July 21. -- It was a Saturday market, and dull at that. The only feature worthy of notice was the strength of Bell Telephone, which advanced 1, to 196. The reason for the strength is a rumor, and very indefinite at that, of a deal between the Bell Company and the Western Union Telegraph Company.
DEAL BEACH, N.J., July 21 -- There is some talk of organizing a tennis club. The number of experts here this year is unusual.

Henry N. Smith, who was once a central figure in Wall Street, and owned Goldsmith Maid, Jay Gould, and other famous horses, has been sued for professional services by Dr. Charles McBurney, the surgeon of 28 West Thirty-seventh Street, this city. The claim is for $4,000. Dr. McBurney is the consulting surgeon of Roosevelt Hospital.

KINGSTOWN, Ireland, July 21. -- Luck in faint breezes and ability in brisk winds gave victory to the American sloop Vigilant in the fifty-mile race to-day, three times over the kite-shaped course of the Royal St. George's Yacht Club. The Briton was beaten 3 minutes and 39 seconds, actual time.

Now is the time to go black bass fishing. though the law in this State permits the sport after May 29, the fish do not leave the spawning beds before the middle or lalter part of June. From the 1st of July to the first frosty days the bass will be running freely and feeding on minnow and moth.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 21. -- The lawn fete given on the pretty grounds of the Presbyterian manse on Thursday afternoon was a fashionable affair. Members of the Merrie Workers officiated at the various tables and the attendance was large.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, July 21. -- Moonlight on the Shrewsbury, rowboats everywhere, young people in them of course -- that has been the scene evevy night this week. In the daytime sailing parties have been more in vogue.

From The London Figaro. It is not generally known that it was owing to the gracious intervention of the Empress Eugenic that M. Sadi Carnot owed the commencement of his fortune. He had, in university language, been "plowed" in his examinations for the Ecole Polytchnique at the end of his two years of school work, and under these circumstances he ought to have then left.

From The Charleston News and Courier. The German carp is here to stay. Within six or eight years he has multiplied to an amazing extent. The lordship of the Santee and its branches he disputes with the redhorse, the catfish, and the mudfish; and since his increase is wonderfully rapid he bids fair in a short time to make himself more prominent than any of his rivals.

PORT RICHMOND, S. I., July 21. -- A Salvation Army camp meeting, which will last until Sunday, July 29, was begun at National Prohibition Park to-day. Three sessions are to be held daily throughout the week, and a long list of officers and privates from all parts of the United States will address the meetings.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 21. -- The State coiors that, fluttered from the central tower of the United States Hotel for forty-eight hours this week were first used here when Gov. Samuel J. Tilden made this hotel his Summer headquarters. That was almost two decades ago. This week they signaled the fact that the Chief Executive of the Empire State was occupying a cottage at the States.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Naval Ordnance officials, who are conducting exhaustive experiments at the Indian Head Proving Grounds with the view of obtaining a satisfactory smokeless explosive for big guns, were astonished yesterday by the remarkable results obtained with a sample submitted by an American company.

The decision of the Committee on Suffrage of the Constitutional Convention on the various amendments submitted to it in favor of woman suffrage undoubtedly closes the question so far as the convention is concerned. The decision was adverse to all the amendments, excepting only that which proposed to allow women to vote for school officers, and as to that no action was taken.
Lady Florence Dixie finds matter for an article of considerable length in a London paper advocating the organization of a corps of women volunteers.

In one of the fine new houses nearing completion in the upper part of the city is a new arrangement of the rain bath. Above the tub is a succession of circles of finely-perforated silver pipe, which at a touch release the shower. Encircling this coil is a solid pipe from which depends by rings a rubber curtain, to be drawn about the bather, to prevent the wide scattering of the falling drops.

SING SING, N.Y., July 21 -- A short distance from the camp of the American Canoe Association on Croton Point stands a very old and very interesting house worthy of a visit by the canoeists who may wish to relate after the meet what they have seen since they left their homes in various parts of the country.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 21. -- There are a large number of prominent persons here, among them many visitors from New-York. The place is alive with excellent Summer resort amusements. Aside from social attractions, there is much sport to be had with the rod and oar. Large quantities of sea bass are being caught every day.
RANSOMVILLE, N. Y., July 21. -- A cy- clone swept across a belt a mile wide near this place early this morning and did an estimated damage of $100,000.

NEWBURG, July 21. -- "I have been doing wrong, but it never came to me until now, and here it is all in a heap," said Dr. A. W. Brewster of Brooklyn to Recorder McCroskery, in the local court this morning. Brewster has been paying his way in the world when his cash was low by drawing checks on banks where he had imaginary accounts.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary Lamont has a peculiar case on his desk at the War Department. It came from Gen. Brooke, one of the department commanders stationed at Omaha, and involves a question which has never been raised before in military jurisprudence.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Shortly after 10 o'clock this morning Deputy Marshals appeared at the Revere House, where many of the labor leaders are staying, and proceeded to make additional arrests. They had warrants for the arrests of the members of the Board of Directors of the American Railway Union.

Lovers of literature may always visit the English counties of Cumberland and Westmoreland solely for the charm that poets have added to their lakes, which are bluish under white setting suns, as time adds verd antique to a Florentine bronze:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 21. -- The little City of Lorain, twenty-six miles west of here, at the mouth of the Black River, is at present the busiest place in Northern Ohio. Several months ago it was even duller than other towns of its size and character. Now hundreds of dwelling houses are being built, great shops are springing into life, and the river is being deepened.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 21. -- A delightful garden party, followed by an amusing parlor entertainment, was enjoyed at the pretty home of W.W. Cornish, in Bloomfield, on Wednesday afternoon and evening.

SHARON SPRINGS, July 21. -- There are now here about 600 guests. Of that number 300 are at the Pavilion. There is more gayety in Sharon at this time than is usual so early in the season. The opening of the baths early in June brings a large number of invalids, who spend their Summers under the strengthening influences of sulphur vapors sulphur showers, sulphur draughts, and sulphur douches.

At this season of the year one week is very much like every other to real estate men. Not a great deal of business is doing, and not much is expected. There is the usual amount of manoeuvring, which is like playing for position among billiard experts. Brokers who have done good business are enjoying themselves in country places, on the seaside, or across the ocean just like other mortals.

It is a melancholy and an alarming record. The mere brute violence which is everywhere rampant is bad enough, but that is by no means the worst feature of the story. What is far more appalling is the utter paralysis of public and moral authority. Arbitration neither side appears to have thought of.
The following statement was issued yesterday afternoon by Secretary Kobbe of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Reorganization Committee:

A suit was begun in the United States Circuit Court in this district yesterday, in the name of John Quincy Adams, against Russell Sage and the estate of Jay Gould to recover $11,000,000, being the amount of money taken from the Kansas Pacific Railroad Trust.

Mr. L.C. Elson, in a recent lecture, discussed the influence of women on music. Why is there no George Eliot in music? Mr. Elson admitted that there were no great women composers, but he dwelt on the indirect influence of women upon music, illustrated by the fact that many compositions owe their origin to the power of woman exerted upon this or that composer.

No heroine could have had a harder time of it than Laura, when her father, Col. Ingram, died. He left her only u300 and also bequeathed her a large family skeleton in the closet. Dora Russell does not tell you what it is at once. She leaves you in suspense, but you feel certain that something awful has happened.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 21 -- The town has been very happy for the last few days because hot weather always brings causes of rejoicing to a Summer resort. The native fondly believes that a thermometer at 90 drives people out of the city in much the same way that his shepherd dog hurries the cows from the pasture.

My uncle, Abel Duane, the untempered wind to my early orphanage, was a curious old recluse, absorbed in perpetual fussings over musty manuscripts and as reticent as their illegibility. Yet, once and again, he had seemed to me trembling on the revelation of a secret. "There is something I must tell you, George, my boy," he had said, "but plenty of time, plenty of time."

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The old-time beast, that in this city of magnificent distances the modern flat had no place, can no longer be made. The flat is here -- has been here for several years, in fact -- and the indications all point to many additions in the next year or two to this class of human habitations.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 21. -- Winthrop Rutherfurd of New-York occupies the Carey cottage, Narragensett Avenue, and Benjamin H. Bristow of New-York and his family have a Cliff cottage for the season. The Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford arrived tonight. He is a guest of R. Fulton Cutting, Ochre Point.
LYNN, Mass., July 21. -- A serious explosion occurred at 3:25 o'clock this morning in the six-story brick block on Union Street, near Central Square, owned by Edward E. Strout.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 21 -- Col. Welch and the other commissioned officers of the Sixty-fifth Regiment marched to Luxury Row immediately after the noon mess to-day and paid their respects to the Adjutant General. In a short speech Gen. Porter complimented them on the high degree of efficiency of the regiment.

The wonderful performances of the Hagenbeck trained animals in the new Hagenbeck Arena, at Manhattan Beach, have already created a profound sensation. Nothing like it has ever before been seen in this country. Since their engagement at Tattersalls, last Winter, many new features have been added, just as startling in their nature as those which won so much favor during that successful engagement.

From The New-York Recorder. Since the time when, in merry old England, Dr. Johnson declared "port" to be the only drink fit for men, the taste of the British wine bibber has undergone a considerable change. Some stout-hearted old country squire may still keep up the habit of "passing the bottle" around the board, but the "six-bottle men" have long since died out.

A trolley car was bowling along at a fine speed on one of the warm days of last week when gentle zephyrs made life endurable. Everybody in the car, even the conductor, looked happy and good-natured under the cheerful influences of the cooling breezes that made the women catch ribbons and adjust laces as these feminine fripperies rustled and fluttered.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, L.I., July 21 -- Old ocean and the company of Summer colonists who have taken possession of this place are having great times together. From early morning until nightfall merry groups of bathers plunge in the cooling surf that comes curling almost up to the entrance of the big hotel, while at evening cool ocean breezes sweep across the stretch of sands.

When the Brooklyn Aldermen come together to-morrow in special session, at the call of Mayor Schieren, to consider the urgent question of the extension of the water supply, they will find themselves confronted by annother subject of great urgency -- the growing pollution of the water.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 21. -- The midsummer whirl of resort amusements has fairly begun, and until Sept. 1 the pace will be rapid. Camping parties are the rage, and picnics of all kinds. As evening approaches, the hotel piazzas and walks are alive with handsome women, gayly dressed, while fine turnouts are encountered along the beautiful drives.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The report made to the House to-day by Mr. Reilly (Dem., Penn.,) on the bill to adjust the indebtedness of the Central and "Union Pacific Railways to the Government is very voluminous.

Time was when the American was the only Anglo-Saxon with a middle letter in his name. Three or four names might have been given the Englishman at baptism, but he never mentioned them in after life, confining himself to "James," "John," "Henry," or some other simple name.

HAMILTON, Ontario, July 21. -- Henry Freeman Jaynes, formerly cashier and accountant for Stanley, Woodhouse Hedderwick, solicitors, London, England, was arrested here to-day charged with embezzling u500 from the firm, Jaynes absconded December, 1893, but did not arrive in Hamilton until early in May of this year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 21. -- The annual track field championship meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union was held this afternoon on the Woodlawn Oval. The weather was superb and the attendance large. The 100-yard run had thirteen entries. Summary follows:

In its comments on the passage of the Tariff bill by the Senate, The London Standard says: "The Tariff bill -- sadly battered and mauled, far more reactionary and promonopolist than when it left the lower house, but still representing, at points, substantial encroachments upon the outworks of McKinleyism -- has been passed by a majority of five in a house of seventy-three.

A launch in these days is so smooth and so soon ended, rarely occupying more than twelve seconds from start to finish, that one scarcely realizes its difficulties. Three things are absolutely necessary: It must be on time, when the tidal water is highest; it must be of smart speed, so as not to stick on its downward journey to the water, and it must be accomplished without straining.

ORANGE N.J., July 21. -- The Board of Education of Orange, with the sanction of the Common Council, has at last accepted plans for a new school building to be erected at a cost of some $35,000. It will be in the Fourth Ward, at the corner of Forest Street and Valley Road, Orange Valley, and will be a handsome brick structure with trimmings of bluestone and with slate roofs.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The President, It is understood, shares none of the forebodings of the Democrats in Washington who say they see no outcome except failure of the contest between the House and the Senate.

A smaller subject and slighter materials than those used in the making of "An Easter Vacation" could scarcely be chosen by a novelist. A master in one of the English public schools, for the sake of looking after a delicate boy, passes his few weeks of leisure in the Spring at Luscombe, on the Devonshire coast.

Why, at least in fiction, should not both parties have a hearing? We certainly have had abundance of romances deprecatory of the Russian Government. It is the Baron with the long Russian name interposed between the two German ones who advances all the claims of Russia. The most impartial of readers, in studying Russian characteristics, is impressed with the two instincts of the subjects of the Czar -- mortal hatred of Poles and Jews.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 21. -- The torrid wave has proved a boon to the landlords, for the sweltering residents of the cities have flocked shoreward by the thousands. To-night the big hotels are putting up cots in their parlors and corridors for the unfortunates who arrived on the late trains, and the smaller houses are also filled with pleasure seekers.

The better part of the Gump family was in bed. They were five out of seven, four boys and a girl. The parental Gumps were enjoying that pre-retiring repose which comes to heads of large families only when the little ones are playing in dreamland. Mrs. Gump, needle in hand, is giving the attention so often urgently demanded by the seats of small boys' trousers.

LONDON, July 21. -- To-day's newspaper give long accounts of the celebration held at the Imperial Institute last evening in observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the laying of the submarine cables to the far East.

Jenner learned that there is a right and a wrong way in which to insert the virus -- in short, that the operation is a nice exercise of medical art. He discovered that certain eruptive diseases occurring at the same time make the best virus inoperative, and he ascertained that there are many circumstances that rapidly destroy the vitality of the virus when not properly cared for.

From The Philadelphia Record, July 16. The splendid record of the new war ship Minneapolis, which on Saturday, on her trial trip off the New-England coast, covered 26.57 miles an hour and earned for her contractors, the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, a premium of $402,500, places the new cruiser first upon the list of seven war ships which have earned for their builders over $1,250,000.

BLACK ROCK BEACH, Conn., July 21 -- Last night Newtown Beers entertained the guests at the George with a programme of dramatic readings. He was assisted by Miss Adele Reno, piano artiste and harpist, and J.D. Fitzgerald of New-York, baritone. The hop at the George to-night was another success.

The Naval Reserve of this State went to sea yesterday. During the forenoon the volunteer sailors crowded the decks of the cruisers New-York and San Francisco, and at 11:50 o'clock both vessels stood out to sea. The Columbia, bound for Bluefields, followed the squadron out of the harbor.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 21. -- The record left by Connecticut Chaplains in the war is an interesting one. Deeds of daring are told of the thirty or forty representatives of the cloth that would have done credit to any profession. Only a few of the men now remain, however, who acted as spiritual advisers at the front.

A Mr. Van Notten lost a ring in a lake and recovered it when the lake was drained. Moore tells how Byron's mother's wedding ring was found in the soil by the gardener on the day when Miss Millbanke's acceptance of the poet's proposal arrived. If this was good luck, the jealousy of the gods very soon avenged it.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 21. -- Friends of Gen. Sherman meeting at a New York dinner party not long ago, chanced to drift into a discussion of popular war songs, the famous "Marching Thro' Georgia" eliciting most attention.
ORANGE, N.J., July 21. -- A most enjoyable lawn party was given on the grounds of E.H. Bennett, Assistant Chief of the East Orange Fire Department, on Wednesday afternoon and evening.
"I made it all between 11 o'clock and 5 yesterday, and it cost only $1.50, buttons and all."

With a detonation that was heard for many blocks around, gas which had accumulated in the gallery over the water gate at the southwest corner of Sixtieth Street and Second Avenue exploded at 2 P.M. yesterday. The damage and injuries produced were slight, but the fright was great.

The Staten Island Athletic Club Cricket eleven brought their week's carnival of cricket to a conclusion yesterday at Berkeley Oval, where they wound up with a drawn game against the Morris Heights Cricket Club. The thunderstorm caused an adjournment of forty-five minutes after which the light was very bad and scoring most difficult.

Clifford A. Smith, a Brooklyn reporter, yesterday afternoon threw a lighted match in a hole in a steel plate which holds the bolts of a window in the Brooklyn Court House. There was an explosion. Mr. Smith's face was blackened, and his eyes were filled with black particles resembling powder. At the Eye and Ear Infirmary in Livingston Street his eyes were treated and he resumed his work.

The Arab colony in and about the lower part of West Street is becoming the headquarters of Orientals from different parts of the Turkish Empire, Egypt, Palestine, Syria, Aleppo, Bagdad, and even small tradesmen who come to America with their wares from Persia put up in that neighborhood, and drop into the simple restaurant to eat dishes cooked in Oriental style and to exchange news, sip Turkish coffee, and smoke the nargileh or Oriental water-pipe.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- At the close of business to-day the stated Treasury balance was $124,000,000, of which $61,000,000 is in gold. This leaves a currency balance of $63,000,000, from which is to be deducted $7,000,000 paid out for interest July 1 and not yet taken out in the daily statement of Treasury cash, making the true net currency balances $56,000,000.

These pilgrimages are mostly undertaken in the cold weather, because the river is then shallow and slow, and nobody gets drowned unless he is more than usually perverse. Also when the river is low, great tracts of sand are dry on either side of the water, and on these the pilgrims can conveniently camp.

D. L. Moody's Summer Bible Conference will be held at Northfield, Mass., from Aug. 1 to 13, and will be of unusual interest. It will occupy the new auditorium just being completed, where 3,000 hearers can be accommodated, and where the various services can be enjoyed with comfort and satisfaction unknown before.
