The meeting of the Republican State Committee, which is scheduled to be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Wednesday next at 11 A.M., will be the event of the week in Republican circles.

Funeral services in memory of William Henry Hall were held yesterday morning to the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, the presiding clergyman being the Rev. Joseph R. Kerr of the Fourth Presbyterian Church.

This large volume owes its existence to the demand for some work which should present not only the statistics of the mineral industries of the world, but at the same time convey some idea of the most recent improvements in the manufactures depending on mineral substance. The work addresses itself to the buyer, seller, consumer, and legislator.

CLEVELAND, July 21. -- W.C. Sanger won the sanctioned race of the Cleveland Wheel Club's tournament to-day. The day was cool and bracing, and the track much improved by the rain. The crowd was slim. Sanger said before the race that he would ride till he fell off the track. F.J. Titus pushed the big fellow so hard right up to the tape that the turn could not be held.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 21 -- That which has contributed largely to the success of Ridgefield as a Summer resort is the influence of many of the prominent physicians of New-York, who have induced their patients to pass the Summer here. One of the latest metropolitan doctors to take a cottage here is Dr. Clarence G. Beebe.

Those Who are pitying the new royal baby, who has been given seven names in baptism, (Edward Albert George Andrew Patrick David Christian,) may console themselves, for the probabilities are that he will never sign more than one-Edward. All England regrets that his father, the Duke of York, will have to be George V., for the Georges from. I. to IV. went from bad to worse, and the name is unpopular.

This book is a trifle enigmatical, but for that reason it is none the less interesting. John Hardhand belies his name. He is not hard-handed, nor hard-headed, but is determined to do the right thing, no matter how much he suffers. He ought to have married Theoretta Vick, but was afraid to face fortune while his father and the farm were in debt.

POTTSTOWN, Penn., July 21. -- Seven persons were badly shocked, one probably fatally, by a bolt of lightning this afternoon, at the Ringing Rock Park. It was the formal opening of the resort. When a storm arose at 3 o'clock the crowd rushed into a pavilion for shelter. Lightning struck a tree near by, and jumped to an electric-light wire, by which the current ran into the building.

From The London Daily News. A writer in the French press has been reading up the works of the Persian poet Sadi, after whom M. Carnot was named, and he has found several allusions applicable to the circumstances of the late President's life. It is well known that Sadi, although he succeeded, by all accounts, in living more than a hundred years, was of a pessimistic disposition.

In Strasburg there is the Ligue Patriotique, which may number some hundreds of members in the city. The raison d'etre of this secret society is to restore Alsace to France, and it is animated by an uncompromising hatred to the German rule. Nothing gave such vitality to this society as the repressive measures, and notably the law of passports, which Germany unhappily adopted some years ago.

Bernard Aschelrodt, a painter of 33 Attorney Street, is in the Mew-York Hospital with two broken legs and a frightfully burned face and body as the result of a practical joke, and two fellow-workmen, Robert Winters and Samuel McKeon, are prisoners awaiting the result of his injuries.
WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Senator Allen's report on the sugar investigation, which rill shortly be filed, with possibly some light modifications, is as follows:

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 21. -- A calm, a touch of thunderstorm, and another calm gave diversion to the sixth annual regatta of the Hempstead Harbor Club, which was sailed over the club course here this afternoon. In the various classes, thiry-three entries in all had been received. Out of this number but twenty-two boats started.

From The Buffalo Express. The small boy went fishing the other day. It was his first actual experience in that line, but he had often talked the sport over with his father and knew just what he would do in any emergency. He and his father got down to the dock about noon and received excellent reports from the other fishermen.

We have the amplest evidence that no great institution was ever happier in the character of those who presided over its birth and directed its earliest years. The original Directors of the Bank of England were among the leading merchants and the most influential citizens of London. No fewer than seven of the twenty-four were chosen, between the years 1696 and 1719, to fill the office of Lord Mayor; two others were members of Parliament.

Little Ralph January, Ethelinda Fuller, Catherine Ward, David Miller, and Mary, better known to her companions, as "Mamie," all came duly up to a reporter for The New-York Times one day last week, held out dusky little paws, further begrimed by several hours of play, to be shaken, and mumbled something that was supposed to be names.

Charles Harnischfeger, a Butcher, of 1,043 Second Avenue, owns a handsome St. Bernard dog named Osso, which cannot discriminate between a boy drowning and a boy swimming. In consequence of this lack of knowledge and discretion, Emanuel P.A. Farrie, fifteen years old, of 217 East Forty-fifth Street, is laid up with a number of ugly bites and scratches, which Osso yesterday morning, in a fit of mistaken zeal, inflicted upon him.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Bull tips on Strawboard that have been circulating the past few days, based on a letter received from a Director by an Insider, in which it was stated that the war that is being waged between the American Company and the Independent concerns would be ended next month, were evidently acted upon to-day.

WEST BRIGHTON, S.I., July 21. -- The Staten Island Athletic Club's ball team won the second same this season from the Brighton Athletic Club nine of Brooklyn, at the Staten Island Club's grounds. The game was closely contested until the seventh inning, when the Staten Islanders pounded out 3 earned runs, and the Brigntons bunched their errors in the eighth, giving the home team 2 more runs.

The heavy English dragoon in fiction gets himself into bad situations. No one ever was in a worse scrape than Phil Jervis. The present lady writer, whose theme always is the martial Briton, and who writes under a masculine name, delights in depicting adventures that occur in barracks. Phil, stationed at Blankhampton, was much given to flirting.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 21. -- One of the most remarkable astronomical instruments constructed in recent years has just been completed in this city. It is well known that in the new astronomy photography has come to hold a foremost place. Hitherto it has been the rule to use but one camera at a time, but the new instrument makes It easily possible to take six photographs simultaneously.

H. Arden Spencer of the People's Party says that the Executive Committee of the New-York organization have prepared the following plank, which is New-York's contribution, to the platform which will be adopted at the State Convention to be held at Saratoga Sept. 11 and 12:

Of the numerous aspirants for the trotting championship, Fantasy is now more prominently in the public eye than any of the others. The rapidity with which this young mare made speed last season in her three-year-old form and cut the record for her age nearly two seconds by her mile in 2:08 3/4 at Nashville, bids fair to be quite outdone by her development at four years.

LONDON, July 21 -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- Although it is apparent enough that the French Government will carry its proposed new press law through the Chamber of Deputies by a round majority, the character of the debate on the measure produces the effect on observers of a moral defeat for the Ministry.

The Summer school of the Long Island Chautauqua Assembly Association, at Point of Woods, Great South Beach, which was opened on July 4, has already proved a greater success than its promoters expected, and they have found it necessary to make additions to the excellent programme of Summer work and lectures which they planned in the beginning.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- After the opening loss to values and a further slight recession, coming from lower cables, large receipts, fine weather, and small export clearances for the week from both coasts. It looked as though the downward progress had at last been arrested, but after a rally had taken place on some buying against puts and by a few scalping shorts there was a resumption of the journey toward zero.

When I saw the bear vanish behind a hummock I took a short cut toward it. Just as I had reached this and was poking my head over the ridge, I was confronted by the bear. I bring my rifle to my shoulder instantly, but Bruin is quicker than I, and throws himself off the floe and into the water; the bullet only hits him in the hind quarters as he disappears.

One of the most provoking things about this war was the way one had to reluctantly leave one's food to the tender mercies of the fire on a sudden alarm. It was heart-rending, after a long and hungry march, to have to rush away to your station empty, only to return after the fight and find your food burned to a cinder.
There were private theatricals in the yard in the rear of Mrs. King's house at 323 West Forty-second Street last Thursday evening.

From The Chicago Journal, July 14. The regulars and the militia have won especial distinction in the struggle for the preservation of the American right of free labor. Everything they have been called on to do they have done with admirable alacrity. They have been most patient in very trying situations. They have restrained the soldiers' impulse to fight in the presence of the cruelest provocation.

The report has been circulated persistently during the last few days that there is to be an important conference of the leaders of the Democratic State "machine" in Saratoga this week, and that efforts will be made to select, in a preliminary way, the candidates for the important offices in State and City.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 21. -- The mercury bulbs indicate a high temperature in Kansas, both in atmospheric and political conditions. There are now four State tickets in the field, and, although a campaign was never before opened in Kansas before Sept. 1, the middle of July found the farmers in a hurry to get their cat crop in the shock in order to attend big political rallies in their counties.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 21 -- It was reported a year ago that a very large chestnut tree in the Pisgah Range that was green and in perfect health emitted smoke as if it was on fire at its base or inside. The vent was at the top of the tree.

JACKSON, N.H., July 21 -- Almost everybody who makes a trip to the White Mountains linger at Jackson a while to visit the waterfalls and other delightful bits of scenery to be enjoyed here. The many excellent hotels in this section are an added pleasure, and as a consequence there are gathered here a goodly number of guests when other sections are but scantily favored.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- For the second time, by the vote of 137 to 49, more than two-thirds of the members present, the House to-day passed a joint resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution providing for the election of United States Senators by the people.

The will of John Donovan, who died at, 144 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, on July 3, will be offered for probate in the Surrogate's office to-morrow, and it is likely that a contest will be made in behalf of Mrs. Mary A. Wheeler, Mr. Donovan's married daughter, on the ground of undue influence.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 21 -- This morning's session of the Baptist Young People's Union opened at 9 o'clock. In the morning there were addresses by the Rev. George E. Horr, editor of The Boston Watchman, and the Rev. Dr. Calvert, editor of The Christian Enquirer, New-York City, the two leading Baptist newspapers in the United States.

A terrible railway accident is reported from Bilbao by the Madrid correspondent of The London Standard. On a short narrow-gauge railway, running from Lezama to Bilbao, a train, composed of an engine, two passenger carriages, and three trucks, laden with stone, was descending a steep incline, when the brakes refused to act.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 21. -- One hundred and fifty of Plainfield's society people had an outing to-day to West Point. They, took the boat Favorite, at Jersey City. At West Point they witnessed a dress parade, returning home at night. Messrs. John M. Whiton, J. P. Munn, O. G. Waring, and Mr., Irving were the committee in charge.

The cool wave reached New-York last night. It was not, in fact, as hot as any time during the day, by an average of 4 degrees, as on Friday, but the increased humidity made most people feel even more oppressed than on the day previous, when the mercury reached 96 degrees.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 21. -- Father Kolaszewski, the pastor, and the other officers of the newly-organized Independent Catholic Church of this city, have issued a call to all the Catholic Poles of the United States, inviting them and all Catholics who are dissatisfied with the government of the Church of Rome, but not with the faith, to send delegates to the convention to be held here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 21 -- The season at this always fashionable resort is being enjoyed by nearly all the old friends and many new cues. Social affairs keep the Summer colony busy in the evenings, and bathing, driving, and lawn tennis divide the honors of the days. The weather has been delightful, and outdoor pastimes have had many followers.

In spite of the very muggy and uncomfortable weather, some 8,000 or more people went down to that sweatbox which is commonly called the Brighton Beach race track yesterday afternoon. There they sweltered and were thoroughly uncomfortable for over three hours in order to indulge the propensity for betting which has taken such a firm hold of the American people of late.

The Bridegrooms attained their second victory over the Quakers in the present series at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The game was a pretty one, and nearly 5,000 people saw it. Foutz's men put up a fast game from start to finish, causing their champions to wonder how the team got so much the worst of it while in the West.

I remember once an elephant was being sold by auction in execution of a decree, and for some reason or other it had not its proper "mahout," or driver, on its back. The sale was taking place on the large open ground or plain around the Courts, and a small crowd had assembled to listen to the bidding.

Paris Dispatch to The London Standard. M. Gautron, liquidator of the Panama Company, and M. Lemarquis, the judicial representative of the Panama bondholders, remembering that the prolonged interval before the resumption of the Panama Canal works will expire on the 31st of October, are making a determined effort for the constitution of a new company to complete the task that M. de Lesseps failed to carry out.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 21 -- For a cool, pleasant retreat and delightful surroundings, one would look long for a place more inviting than Hot Springs, in the mountains of Virginia, which is now entering upon the height of its gay season. The hotel porches are thronged at night with charming girls, and the parlors are as gay as music and dancing can make them.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 21. -- The steamship Rio Janeiro, which arrived from the Orient this morning, brought the following news from Honolulu:
PARIS, July 21. -- The Chamber of Deputies voted this afternoon the second article of the Anti-Anarchist bill, and proceeded to debate Article III.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N. Y., July 21. -- The tide of travel to the Thousand Islands seems to have fully set in. In the early part of the season hotel proprietors along the river were, in the language of one of the number, cutting their corners very close, fearing that the season might not be any more successful than last Summer.

Little Falls, N. Y., July 21. -- Calvin Brown, a farmer of Dennison's Corners, shot his hired man. Orville Miller, three times last night, inflicting grave injuries. The men quarrled because Brown requested Miller's wife to do work which Miller considered servile.

From The National (English) Magazine. At Logan, near the Mull of Galloway, there is a most interesting tidal fish pond. A rent in the cliffs facing the Irish Channel admits the salt water through a narrow fissure, protected by a grating, into a circular rock basin, some 30 feet in diameter and 20 feet deep.

Among the first passengers to land from the big Cunarder Lucania, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday morning, was C. G. Shayne, the well-known furrier of West Forty-second Street. Mr. Shayne, who was accompanied on his trip by Mrs. Shayne, looked the picture of ruddy health as he hurried down the gangplank to return the greetings of his many friends and wellwishers who had assembled on the pier to welcome him home.

A few weeks ago began at Laval, in the Mayenne, France, the trial of a priest, the Abbe Bruneau, who, in spite of his sacred calling, is charged, says the Paris correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph, with having perpetrated crimes atrocious enough, even if only half of them be brought home to him, to brand him as one of the most notorious criminals of the century.

BOSTON, July 21. -- The tie in the Essex County tennis tournament at Manchester-by-the-Sea was played off this morning. Hovey, Budlong, and Chace were even for first place. They decided to draw to see which two men should play for first prize. Chace lost, and Hovey and Budlong played the match. The games were played very listlessly, neither man playing hard.
The trouble between the steamship companies and the immigration authorities is likely to be adjusted very soon.
CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., July 21 -- The opening ball at the Hotel Brooklyn took place last night. It was a very bright social event, in what has been, up to date, a lively season.

While all the respectable, law-abiding Irish-Americans in this vicinity who labor unselfishly for the cause of self-government in Ireland disapprove of Michael Kerwin's appointment as Police Commissioner, the dynamiters, or physical-force men, of whom Kerwin openly avows himself one, are enthusiastic in their expressions of gratification over what they term their "recognition" by the Mayor of New-York.

LENOX, Mass., July 21 -- Many of the cottagers are talking of going to the seashore. This is about the time when they usually go to Bar Harbor, Newport, and Narragansett. The majority of them go to either Bar Harbor or York Harbor. They remain away from their cottages here from three to four weeks, returning the last of August in order to be ready for the "season" in September and October.

As used in English university towns, "living in lodgings" is an expression that calls to mind delightful visions of English schools and picturesque vine-covered cottages such as have been celebrated in song and story.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 22 -- A. Salvation Army lovefeast and experience meeting was held at National Prohibition Park this afternoon, conducted by the officers of the New-York central staff. Brig. Gen. Evans, who was promoted from a Majorship by Gen. Booth two weeks ago, was greeted with applause by the 1,500 persons in the audience when he arose to open the exercises.

Midsummer dullness has overtaken the stock market, and what little speculation there was last week was contributed by professional operators and traders, who are quite satisfied to take very small profits on either side of the account. The uncertainty of the tariff situation has put an effectual stop to operations for outsiders, and the offices of commission brokers are practically bare of customers.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. July 21 -- The week in the local stock market has been quiet, with few transactions. Prices remain about the same. A small lot of Industrial Trust Company stock has been sold at 102. There is some demand for this stock, but none is offered at the present time. Providence Telephone Company has sold at 112 and National Eagle Bank at 57 1/2.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $172,225. The banks now hold $74,113,600 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $87,600, an increase in specie of $209,800, a degrease in legal tenders of $143,500, a decrease in deposits of $423,700, and a decrease in circulation of $138.200.

The proposition, which is believed to be seriously under consideration, to increase the number of side shows and pennycatching devices in Central Park by the establishment there of a "water tobogganing slide," is another example of the tendency of Park Boards and a large proportion of the people for whose benefit that loveliest of pleasure grounds was devised and is maintained, to misconceive the purpose of such a park.

The water supply of Brooklyn is in a very unsatisfactory condition, with respect to both quantity and quality. It is insufficient, at the present rate of consumption, and the quantity in the storage reservoir -- now only 545,000,000 gallons, as against 865,000,000 on the corresponding date one year ago -- is being diminished by 15,000,000 gallons per day.

A rough-looking man, who said he was Timothy Burke, a laborer from Australia, was arrested by Detective Farrell of the East Twenty-second Street Station last evening in the act of running away with a pretty three-year-old Italian girl, and was locked up as a suspicious person. Burke had evidently been drinking, for the attempted kidnapping was rashly bold.
Policeman Wegman of the West Forty-seventh Street Station had as lively a time late Saturday night as he has ever had in a long term on the police force.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service has received a report regarding the "plague" in China from Dr. Stuart Eldridge, a member of the Imperial Board of Health of Tokio, and Health Officer of the port of Yokohama. The report is in the nature of a warning.

Those who read the report, published this morning, of Dr. Eldridge to Surgeon General Wyman, concerning the plague in China, should know that it was mailed at Yokohama more than a month ago, or on June 18. The little news received since that date, as to the epidemic, does not indicate that the mortality is increasing or that the disease has recently been spreading.

The tennis season is well under way and yet prophets, critics, and the like are utterly unable to secure data upon which to figure the chances of the coming champiohship tournament a month off. In past years, some player made so good a record in the early tournaments, that he was promptly installed as favorite for Newport, only to fall a victim in the tournament.

With his coat torn, several buttons pulled off, and his shield gone, Conductor Pasquall Bresha of the Fourth Avenue Line called for a policeman as his car emerged from the tunnel and turned into Forty-second Street Saturday night. Policeman De Groot of the Twenty-third Sub-Precinct jumped on the car prepared to grapple with a muscular rowdy.

From The Boston Journal. I have recently discovered that many women who go into the wilds of Maine go with other purposes than the securing of a good coat of tan to meet the September and October fashionable requirements. I chatted the other day with a woman whose yearly outing is devoted to searching out old furniture and such.

From The Westminster Gazette. It is not generally known, we imagine, that the present Pope was at one period of his life a passionate mountain climber. In Pietra-Stornina, on the walls of the old ruined robber castle of the Princes of Storno, there is a memorial tablet inscribed "To the Tourist, Giacchino Pecci," who is now Leo XIII.

"There is a very well-known anecdote," remarks the Paris correspondent of the London Times in a letter of July 6, "about the Venetian Ambassador at the Court of Louis XIV., who, while walking in the galleries at Versailles, was asked what had most struck him during his trip. 'What most strikes me,' replied the Ambassador, 'is to see myself here.'

From The Manchester (N.H.) Mirror. A caller at my office this week was B.P. Chadwick of Bradford, Mass., Deputy Commissioner of Inland Fisheries and Game in Massachusetts. Commissioner Chadwick was on his way to Suncook to look after some Frenchmen that have been illegally taking salmon in the Soucook River.

From The Westminster Gazette. We cannot all afford the time and money necessary to become experts in Alpine climbing, but, if our lungs and limbs are fairly sound, there is a good deal of mountaineering which can be done at home. In a little book ("Climbing in the British Isles") just issued by Messrs.

From The London Daily News. The first quarter of the financial year shows an increase on every item of the revenue but two, and those two are but of small importance. The Miscellaneous Revenue is less by u157,945, and the land tax less by u25,000. On eight other heads there is a total gain on the same quarter of last year of u1,054,569.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- That point is reached in the House when there is no measure of such importance as to command the assignment of a day for its consideration. The Committee on Rules will meet to-morrow to decide what committees shall be recognized during the week for presentation of business decided upon by them.

From The Baltimore Sun, July 16. It is evident to every observer of the current indices of public opinion that at no time since his first election has President Cleveland stood higher in the national confidence and esteem than he does to-day.

Police Justice Meade is incapacitated from duty by reason of illness. Justice Ryan sat for him in the Yorkville Police Court Saturday after he had officiated at the Tombs. It was arranged that yesterday Justice Burke should sit at Yorkville and that Justice Divver should attend to the Morrisania and Harlem Courts.

BAIREUTH, July 22 -- "Tannhauser" Was sung here to-day, and it proved to be the least satisfactory of line festival performances. The scenery and costumes were identical with those used in the performance of the same opera at the last festival, when they proved disappointing.
MEMPHIS, July 22 -- The report of an authorized interview with Senator Harris by its Washington correspondent appeared in one of the local papers to-day. Mr. Harris is reported as saying:

From The American Architect. We have received two documents describing a competition for a certain church, one from a member of the church committee, who thinks we might like to publish it for the benefit of our readers, apparently because he supposes it is so good, and another from an architect, who also thinks it would be beneficial to have it published, because it is so bad.
"Are we Americans, or what? was the topic discussed by the Rev. Dr. J.A.B. Wilson preliminary to his sermon yesterday morning in the Eighteenth Street Methodist Church.

MANHATTAN BEACH, July 22 -- Ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt, refreshed by the cool breeze which blew off the ocean to-day, decided to free his mind on the somewhat mixed condition of New-York City politics.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 22 -- Joseph B Lord, fifty-three years old, committed suicide by jumping from the steamer Pilgrim of the Fall River Line, at 2:50 o'clock this morning, as the steamer was oft Watch Hill.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Phylloxera plague has appeared in the sherry-wine district of Spain, and the United States Consul at Cadiz, in making the announcement to the State Department, says some of the principal vineyard proprietors are discussing the advisability of importing American stocks upon which to graft native vines in case the ravages of the parasite should destroy the vines.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 22 -- The services at the Astbury Park Auditorium to-day attracted thousands of worshippers. the Rev. B. Fay Mills, the revivalist, preached morning and evening.

Mr. Harold Baty contributes to The London Standard some further interesting details of the famous tortoises of the Seychelles Islands. "Nothing has struck me more than the animal's delight to get on a bare and rocky patch, the rougher the better, and there bask in the sun. The Seychelles, at the date of their discovery, were covered with timber.

BERLIN, July 22 -- Emperor William's voyage northward was interrupted in the middle of the week by bad weather, and since Thursday the imperial yacht Hehenzollern has lain stormbound in Folden Fiord. This enforced inactivity has chafed upon the Emperor's restless spirit, until he Is upon the point of returning to Potsdam.

St. Petersburg Dispatch to The London Standard. A recent trial of the new shell, invented by Admiral Makaroff; proved conclusively that the invention is a valuable success. Ten rounds were fired, six Makaroff shells and four ordinary Holzers. The first and second were fired at right angles. The Makaroff shell penetratea nearly 36 inches, the Holzer 8.

Charles Wilfred Mowbray, the English Anarchist, will speak to-night in Clarendon Hall, on "Anarchist Communism: What it Means." Mowbray is the guest of Justus Schwab, at 50 First Street. Schwab said yesterday that Mowbray had gone out of town and would not return until just before the meeting to-night.

From The Washington Post. Whatever may be said of many Congressional documents, published by the thousand only to be stewed away in the basement of the Capitol, where they taint the atmosphere and get the Capitol architect into trouble with the Ventilating Committee, no such charge can be laid against the works printed by the scientific bureaus.
Corean affairs, in spite of the secrecy with which Oriental diplomacy obscure them, are well defined.
Our Washington dispatches report the following statement made by "one of the managers" of the Senate majority:

The Tombs has seldom contained within its gloomy precincts a more interesting prisoner than the seventeen-year-old Russian Jewess, Lizzie Berus, or Patterson, who is to be tried to-day 011 a charge of having procured diamonds by bogus checks from several jewelry firms in Upper Broadway.

President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor has written over his signature an appeal for aid in behalf of Debs. The appeal opens with the statement that Eugene V. Debs stands as one of the most auspicious figures before the country.

Patrick McGowan, who was one of the men exploited by the prosecutors in the Elmira Reformatory investigation as a sad illustration of the paddling system, died on Saturday, at the Long Island College Hospital. He made an ante-mortem statement on the Friday preceding his death, to the effect that his health had been undermined and broken by the treatment he received at the reformatory, by order of Superintendent Brockway.

From The Chicago Journal. For some time the two newspapers owned by John R. Walsh (The Herald and The Evening Post) have been trying to run with the strikers and hunt with the law in regard to the attack of the American Railway Union on the peace and business interests of Chicago.

The Baltimore schooner Robert H. Mitchell sailed from this port early yesterday morning, and a few hours later furnished to residents and Summer visitors of Seabright, N.J., an illustration of a drowning craft.

Col. I. Trumbo, the organizer and leader of the protracted struggle for the admission of Utah as a State, was seen yesterday at the Plaza Hotel on the eve of his departure for the West. In speaking about the resources and the future prosperity of the new State Col. Trumbo said:

ALBANY, July 21 -- The feature in local securities was the demand for Cayodutta Electric first mortgage 6 per cent, bonds. There has been a good investment buying of them ever since both the principal and interest was guaranteed by the Fonda, Johnstown and Gloversville Railroad. The incorporation of a competing railroad from Amsterdam to Johnstown and Gloversville is not regarded seriously and is looked upon as a paper company.

The Sherman Bank, a State financial institution at 874 Broadway, ceases to exist to-day. It has in its coffers $115,000 belonging to depositors, and is anxious for them to claim their balances, as its cashier, Henry D. Northrop, who is to wind up its affairs, wishes to devote his entire attention to the assets of the bank.
Six men are under arrest, charged with stealing $950, on July 12, from Thomas Eagan of 88 Second Avenue.

ROME, July 22 -- Premier Crispi spoke in the Senate to-day concerning the defeat of the Mahdists last week and the occupation of Kassala. The triumph of Italy's colonial troops, lie said, would be followed by excellent results. The Mahdists now would probably pause in their course of pillage and murder.

ALBANY, July 22 -- After a struggle that has lasted two months, the Committee on legislative Organization of the Constituional Convention has promulgated the results of its efforts in the matter of legislatve apportionment. The plan has not been formally adopted by the committee. In the shape it is now in, the convention cannot adopt it without surrendering some part of its reputation for conservatism.

Julius Jones of 3,570 Madison Avenue, this city, and Henry Jacobs of 892 Union Street, Brooklyn, who were formerly engaged with Samuel Ketchum in the manufacture of cloaks at 510 Broadway, were arrested yesterday by Detective Sergeant Von Gerichten of the District Attorney's office, on a bench, warrant Issued on Saturday.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 22 -- A cold rain swept through the camp this morning, and was almost as depressing to the spirits of the militiamen as had been the intense heat of the preceding three days. None of the usual drills was held, and there was no church service.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The line of the defense of Debs, Howard, Keliher, and Rogers at the hearing in the contempt proceedings which will begin in Judge Grosscup's court to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock has been decided upon. Messrs. Erwin and Gregory will open their side with a vigorous attack upon the injunction which the defendants are charged with willfully disobeying.

PERRY, Oklahoma, July 22 -- D.H. Nourse, editor and proprietor of The Wellington (Kan.) Evening Mail, who had been sent to Round Pond and Enid, the seats of the railroad and Government townsite war, by a Kansas City paper, arrived here yesterday in a terrible plight. Nourse says the tone of his dispatches did not suit either the railroad or the townsite people.

No member of the State Republican Committee, which is to meet in this city Wednesday, was visible about the headquarters yesterday. In their absence the local lights had nothing to do but guess what the committee's sentiments might be with reference to the row between the warring factions in the party.

The People's Party picnic which was held yesterday afternoon in the Colosseum, Ridgewood Park, Brooklyn, was an oratorical rather than an amusement success. Considered as a picnic, it was a damp and distressing failure.

From The Philadelphia Press, July 16. An old-fashioned colored camp meeting was held yesterday in the woods near Elwyn Station, under the auspices of the Campbell African Methodist Episcopal Church of Media, Penn. There were as many white people as colored present, nearly all coming by train.

There is quite a mystery attached to the death of Albert E. Ednett, the four-months-old child of Mrs. Edward Ednett of 838 Bergen Street, Brooklyn. The baby died Saturday morning in the Memorial Hospital for Women and Children, in Pacific Street.

John Eagan, leader of a gang of roaghs, was held toy Justice Burke in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday to answer to a charge of larceny. The complainant was Charles Maxwell, who is employed as a painter in Bellevue Hospital.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The tariff fight promises to be renewed to-morrow without any clearly-determined policy on the Democratic side in the Senate except that the Senate will insist upon its bill and go into the new conference, if one shall be ordered, to maintain the amendments sent to the House.
One death is probably the result of a pleasure trip on the yacht Emma J., which began at 9 o'clock Saturday night and ended in the capsizing of the yacht early yesterday morning down the bay.

"I hope, I say, that whatever the fate of the present Tariff bill may be, this House will not consent to adjourn until it has passed a single bill putting refined sugar on the free list." These were the words of Chairman Wilson in his speech announcing the failure of the conference committee to agree.

In this work is given a history of the world for three centuries and a half, from the beginning of what are known as modern times and closing with the events immediately preceding the French Revolution. The period was one of great overturning, enormous developments, and magnificent progress.

Saratoga will take on a new sort of life, beginning this morning, for the racing season will open at the track of the Saratoga Association. That season, to last until Saturday, Aug. 25, promises to be the most successful one that has been had at the Springs in years, and one that will carry the oldtimers back to the days when the racing at this track was without question the best in the country.

The Church of Our Lady of the Scapular, in East Twenty-eighth Street, was filled yesterday morning, on the occasion of the observance of the feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel. The ceremonies were not quite so elaborate as had been planned. The curtailing of the programme was due to the death, last Sunday, of one of the priests of the church, the Rev. Father John E. Whitley.

ON BOARD THE CRUISER NEWYORK, Gardiner's Bay, L.I., July 22 -- The crack ships of the North Atlantic squadron, the cruisers San Francisco and New-York, bearing the naval militia, anchored here, seven miles from Greenport, this forenoon.
CINCINNATI, July 23. -- At 6:58 this morning a head-end collision between the incoming Big Four Chicago passenger and an outgoing engine occurred at Griffiths, fifteen miles from the city.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The continual drain on the Treasury gold for export to Europe is an interesting question. The gold reserve has been diminished since 1889 in this ratio: Jan. 31, 1889, $194,000,000; Jan. 31, 1890, $177,000,000; Jan. 31, 1891, $141,000,000; Jan. 31, 1892, $119,000,000; Jan. 31, 1893, $108,000,000; Jan. 31, 1894, $65,000,000.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 23. -- Though the third meeting of the Grand Circuit, which is on here this week, Has the largest number of horses ever seen at the Glenville track, the harness racers had but a short engagement to-day. The clouds were gathering as the people flocked to the grounds by thousands, and the rain began to fall before a heat was trotted.

Arthur P. German of Maryland is now in the twenty-eighth year of his service in the Senate Chamber of the United. States. From 1852, when at the age of thirteen he became a page, to 1866, when at the age of twenty-seven he ceased to be Postmaster of that body, his services were of the character indicated by these offices, and were, so far as we know, faithful, courteous, and acceptable.

For the sake of two bananas, value 1 cent, Giuseppe Tamasco, a push-cart peddler, fought with Francesco Collacio, in Mulberry Street last night, until Tamasco fell in the gutter stabbed to the heart. Collacio is a prisoner in the Elizabeth Street Police Station.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- It was another red letter day in the tractions. This market, however, is so narrow that when one of them is specially active the others take a back seat. It was People's Traction day on the board. Over 6,000 shares changed hands, and there was considerable excitement as the stock advanced in price.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Wheat declined in price yesterday more than on any day since it began its new series of low records, September options losing 1 5-16 cents per bushel from the previous low price, and December losing 1 1/8 cents. Unlike its record-breaking predecessors, the day brought activity, excitement, and an unsettled market.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- When it was learned this morning that Mr. Gorman had been at the White House in consultation with the President there were all sorts of rumors about the Capitol as to the course he would pursue in his speech.

OMAHA, Neb., July 23. -- General Master Workman Sovereign of the Knights of Labor, who is at the executive meeting here, says that all the packing houses in Chicago will stop to-morrow unless the rates of wages paid Aug. 1, 1893, are restored. He asserts that the Executive Committee of the Knights will go Debs one better in his request to boycott Pullman cars.

James E. Ward of the firm of James E. Ward Co., shipping merchants of 113 Wall Street, died yesterday at his country home, at Great Neck, L.I. He had been suffering from Bright's disease since the early part of last March. He was born in this city; Feb. 25. 1836.

Next to a bayonet or a club there is nothing that gives a riotous striker so much trouble to confront as an indictment. In one respect the indictment is more perplexing to him than the weapon, because good and wise men may be fatally injured by the reckless use of clubs or bayonets without having a chance to explain how good and wise they really are.

RONDOUT, July 23. -- The Shawangunk Mountain huckleberry crop, which is the chief source of supply to the New-York markets, is a total failure this year. Buyers for New-York, who in previous seasons have shipped 100 crates a day, have trouble this year to ship a dozen. The drought has caused the berries to dry up on the bushes.

This nineteenth century is witnessing the first visions of the approach of greatly-improved conditions among the children of the poor of this city. The children of their own free wills are flocking to the schools. Schoolroom discipline is preferred to the freedom of the streets.

Tickers and news slips, which jointly furnish the cue to speculation in Wall Street, gave the greater part of their service yesterday to quotations for Sugar Trust certificates and the speech of Senator Gorman. The spirit of Mr. German's remarks had been well divined when the market opened, that being nearly three hours before he began to unburden himself in public.

LONDON, July 23. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Chamberlain resumed the debate on the Evicted Tenants bill. He denied that there was any necessity for exceptional legislation, and suggested that the measure be withdrawn and the evicted tenants in Ireland be relieved through the reenactment and extension of the thirteenth clause of the Land act of 1891.

BOSTON, July 23. -- Telephone stocks were strong, with very light transactions. Westinghouse Electric was very weak, in spite of the unofficial statement that the company is doing a large business. It sold down to 33 on limited transactions, with the preferred selling at 52. Transactions in West End Railway were 200 shares at 46, an advance of 1 point.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Carnegie seventeen-inch Harveyized plate which was so easily pierced by the twelve-inch gun at Indian Head July 12, and which successfully resisted a similar shot a few days later, gave a good account of itself again to-day, and the lot of 600 tons of armor for the battle ship Oregon, which it represents, may yet be accepted by the Government.

A mass meeing of the citizens of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards to protest against the continuance of the Riker's Island nuisance was held last night at Laeffert's Hall, One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street and Willis Avenue.

The Reorganization Committee of the Northern Pacific Railroad, of which Edward D. Adams is Chairman, has received deposits of a majority of the third mortgage bonds, which fact, under the recent ruling of the Stock Exchange, ought to secure an immediate listing of the certificates representing that class of securities.

The Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, which has its headquarters in the United Charities Building, at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, sent out its eighth "ocean party" yesterday. One of the iron steamboats started from Twenty-second Street and North River and landed 1,000 happy excursionists on the Iron Pier at Coney Island.

The Committee of the Constitutional Convention on Legislative Organization has before it a report proposing that hereafter the Senate shall consist of 50 and the Assembly of 150 members and presenting the first apportionment under this plan. This report has been prepared by a sub-committee, and has not yet been adopted by the full committee.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 23. -- At 3 o'clock this morning a gasoline stove exploded in the restaurant and lodging house of William Hancock, 1,005 North Third Street. Fifteen persons were asleep on the second and third floors. Two were burned to death and three seriously injured. Following is the list:

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 23. -- The attendance at the meetings of the Salvation Army in Prohibition Park to-day was not as large as yesterday, but about a thousand', persons were present at the afternoon and Evening sessions. Capt. Walden led a knee drill at the morning service, and this afternoon an "O Be Joyful" service conducted by Ensign McKenzie and Capts. Bull and Walden.

George Francis Train was the conspicuous figure at the reception of the State Club, the Platt-Milholland social organization, at 29 West Twenty-second Street, to Gen. Michael Kerwin, the Police Commissioner, last night.

Policeman Conroy of the East Twentysecond Street Police Station was informed last night by persons living in the vicinity of Avenue A and Eighteenth Street that a family of the name of Stuart were allowing their three children to starve on the top floor of 435 East Eighteenth Street.

A ten-horse-power gas engine used for the purpose of running an elevator for the hoisting of wagons in the boarding stable of W. Durland Co., in West Sixty-second Street, has given rise to a serious difference of opinion between the proprietors of the stable and the tenants of the flats on the north side of West Sixty-first Street.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 23. -- The delegates to the Republican State Convention are here in large numbers, and more are coming by every train. Gen. Powell Clayton got in this morning, and his rooms at the Richelieu Hotel have been headquarters of the party all day. The colored delegates outnumber the white ten to one, and they are decidedly in favor of nominating a full State and Congressional ticket.
Mr. George R. Read has sold for the Catlin and Leavitt estate to a client, for investment, the five-story iron-front store building 83 and 85 Worth Street, 48 by 100, at $230,000.

The leading Republican politicians in this city, in the Thirty faction as well as in the Platt faction, talk of nothing but reform, but they are thinking of nothing but politics, party politics, straight Republican politics. Mr. Thomas C. Platt's very able monograph was read, we doubt not, with as great and sincere satisfaction in the Union League Club as in the headquarters of Mr. Milholland, if period

Thaddeus Davids. Thaddeus Davids died at his residence, the old Underhill homestead, on Pelham Road, New-Rochelle, early Sunday morning. He had been a prominent man in Westchester County since the second quarter of the century, and until comparatively recent years he was an active figure in commercial life in this city.

ROCHE'S POINT, Ireland, July 23. -- The Britannia and the Vigilant started in a race over the course of the Royal Minister Yacht Club this morning for a cup valued at u50. The course was laid out from Roche's Point to Poor Head, thence to Daunt's Rock and l back to Roche's Point, three times around, and then to the clubhouse of the Royal Cork Yacht Club at Queenstown, a distance of fifty miles.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Administration has three days in which to determine whether to recognize the new Hawaiian Republic promptly or to withhold its formal recognition another fortnight. The question will probably come before the Cabinet to-morrow, and, if decided then in the affirmative, formal instructions to Minister Willis may be telegraphed to San Francisco and forwarded to Honolulu by next Thursday's steamer.

The Republican State Committee will, in all probability, take no definite action whatever when it meets to-morrow at the Fifth Avenue Hotel on the controversy between the regular Republican organization of this city, as reconstructed by the Committee of Thirty, and the Platt-Milholland faction.

Five men were injured, one of them fatally, by the falling of a scaffold yesterday in the rear of the unfinished building 568 West Forty-second Street, just west of Tenth Avenue. The workman most seriously hurt was Antonio Manders, twenty-eight years old, of 106 Elizabeth Street. His skull was fractured, and at the Roosevelt Hospital, where he was taken, it was said he would die.

Six men have been arrested so far in connection with the aleged robbery of Thomas Eagan, real estate dealer at 276 Broadway, on the morning of July 13 last, in the Cafe Central, Fifth Street and Second Avenue. He alleged that he was robbed of $900, and admitted that he was intoxicated at the time of the robbery.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The address to-day of Senator Gorman, in which he setforth his attitude toward the President and his position on the Tariff bill, is given herewith:

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The hearing of the contempt proceedings against President Debs, Vice President Howard, Secretary Keliher, and Director Rogers under the attachment issued by Judge Seamans on Thursday last, was the special order in the United States Circuit Court this morning. Long before the usual hour for the commencement of business the spacious courtroom was filled to the doors, while hundreds who were unable to gain admission filled the outside corridors.

A day's trotting sport for the benefit of local charities has been announced by the Driving Club of New-York for Saturday. Aug. 4. A special committee, made up of Messrs. Samuel McMillan, Frederick Gerken, John Rudd, and T. J. Brady, has charge of the arrangements, and has made up the following excellent card:

The Board of Aldermen will officially confirm the tax rate at its meeting next month. It is thought that the rate will be $1.80 per $100, as against $1.82, the present rate. The Finance Committee of the Board of Aldermen now has the tax books in its custody preparatory to making its report to the full board at the meeting next month.

The Brooklyns played two games with Philadelphia at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. The double bill brought out more than 5,000 cranks, who saw their pets win and lose a game. The first contest was the game which the Quakers won at Brooklyn April 26, but was thrown out by President Young, owing to unsportsmanlike management on the part of Arthur Irwin, Philadelphia's manager.

Paul E. Taussis, an eighteen-year-old naval cadet, who up to yesterday was attached to the United States cruiser Bancroft, lying at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, died at the Naval Hospital a few minutes after he was received there as a patient yesterday afternoon. He was taken ill with sciatica last Thursday. Cadet Taussis was the son of Lieut. Edward Taussis, who is attached to the United States cruiser Atlanta, now in Boston Harbor.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The result of the Congressional nominating conventions now in progress and the voluntary withdrawal of some prominent Representatives indicate that there will be many well-known faces missing from the lower house of the next Congress.

NEWARK, Ohio, July 23. -- Rain caused the postponement of to-day's race meet in the National Circuit, given by the League of American Wheelmen. To-morrow, Tuesday, is the only vacant day in this or any succeeding week for a month to come. Chairman Raymond has been telegraphed to for a sanction for races to-morrow.

The surgeons at Bellevue Hospital grave up hope yesterday of saving the life of Joseph Kenney, who was taken to the hospital last Saturday from Third Avenue and Eleventh Street suffering from sunstroke.

For refusing to attend rifle practice on Sunday, because of religious scruples, Charles O. Cedarquist, a private in Company A. Second United States Infantry, stationed at Omaha, Neb., has been found guilty by court-martial of disobeying his superior officer and been sentenced to imprisonment at hard labor for six months, with a deduction of $10 a month from his pay during that period.

NEW-HAVEN, July 23. -- Charles Brunhoefer, a German, and a prominent member of the Bakers' Union of this city, was arrested to-night while distributing boycott circulars against Frederick Gaiser, the proprietor of a bakery at 169 Dixwell Avenue. Brunhoefer will be charged in the police court to-morrow with conspiracy against a tradesman.

Wakeman Holberton has just received a letter from A.L. Light, President of the Triton Fish and Game Club, in which Mr. Light says there are more New-Yorkers on the property now than ever before. Fishing is fine, trout being plentiful and of great size, four-pounders being common. The club's property lies about 100 miles north of Quebec, on the Quebec and Lake St. John's Railroad.
LONDON, July 23. -- The trial of the action brought by John R. Rogers against his wife, Minnie Palmer, the actress, was resumed in the Divorce Division of the High Court of Justice this morning.
SHANGHAI, July 23. -- The reports that China has declared war upon Japan are premature. War has not yet been formally declared, but hostilities are imminent.

The report that the Knights of Labor have been asked by General Master Work-man Sovereign to join the National Guard and thus get control of the militia of the different States is looked upon by labor leaders in this city as a canard.

The Brooklyn "Board of Accidents" yesterday decided that it was not superior to popular necessity and clamor, and voted, after its usual symposium of eccentricities, to appropriate the $750,000 asked by Commissioner White for the extension of the water works system so as to give 25,000,000 more gallons daily.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 23. -- About noon to-day Mr. and Mrs. J.R. Edwards and their eight-year-old son and a book agent, whose name is unknown, were drowned off Hutter's Point, five and a half miles up Otsego Lake. The party had left the house of the Edwards family, about four miles from here, to row the agent over the lake to Hyde Hall, situated on the other side, about eight miles from Cooperstown.

ON BOARD THE CRUISER NEWYORK, Gardiner's Bay. L.I., July 23. -- A beautiful day, a brisk easterly breeze, and a close adherence to their programme was vouchsafed to the naval militia to-day, but their labors were of little value in connection with the use of the ships.

BOSTON, July 23. -- The open tennis tournament of the Longwood Cricket Club, which has now come to be ranked next to Newport in importance, began on the club courts near Boston to-day. The drawings fall in such a manner as to make the early matches comparatively unimportant? so to-day's contests brought out no further sensation than the defeat of W. Gordon Parker by George H. Crocker.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 23. -- The first match of the Canadian tour of the Philadelphia cricketers commenced to-day against the Rosedale Club. The match was played on the beautiful grounds of the Toronto Lacrosse Club.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 23 -- Leopold Zimmermann, of the banking and brokerage firm of Zimmermann Forshay, 9 Wall Street, New-York, was thrown from a carriage here this morning. One of his legs was broken in two places and he sustained slight injuries about the face.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Mr. Preston, Director of the Mint, is informed that the New-Orleans Mint, in compliance with the recent order, has already coined 52,000 standard silver dollars. The mintage will continue until further orders. The Treasury has 121,000,000 ounces of silver which cost $126,000,000.

The Secretary of the Reorganization Committee of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company gave to the public on Saturday last a short statement concerning the results of an examination of the company's books which has been made by Stephen Little, an expert accountant. It had been discovered, he said, that the company's income between July, 1889, and December, 1893, was overstated, in the opinion of the accountant, by about $7,000,000.

CROTON POINT, N.Y., July 23. -- Racing at the canoe camp here began this morning. The first race called was the unlimited sailing race, which is event No. 6 on the official programme. The course was triangular, one half mile on each side, and was sailed over four times, making six miles in all. There was a time limit of two and a half hours.

The members of the New-Jersey Athletic Club are highly indignant at J.W. Goff. the athlete. He went to Saratoga with the team to compete in the Metropolitan championships, and it was thought that he would win the high hurdle race. At the last moment Goff said he was sick, and the race was won by Chase of the New-York Athletic Club.

NEWTOWN, L.I., July 23. -- Otto Eckholdt, reputed leader of the former band of Maspeth Anarchists, is agin in the hands of the law. Instead of devoting his spare time to the manufacture of dynamite bombs as heretofore, it appears from the complaint he has degenerated into a petty thief. He was accompanied by Rudolph Liese of East Williamsburg, and Max Fredericks, who boarded with Eckholdt.

ARVERNE, L.I., July 23. -- Unless the men who dump New-York City's garbage in the sea mend their ways the people of the metropolis may look for several vacancies in their Street-Cleaning Department. Said vacancies may be caused by violence at the hands of the outraged people who dwell along the beach in this vicinity, while the men who man the dumping scows will be the victims.

ELIZABETH, July 23. -- A warrant was issued to-day for the arrest of Mrs. George William, the widow of a well-known tugboat Captain The complaint against her was made by County Physician Edward R. O'Reilly, who says the woman has made threats against his life, and that she would blind him with vitriel because he recently testified in a olvil suit against her.

Charles Wilfred Mowbray, the English labor agitator and Anarchist, who for his violent utterances has been five times imprisoned in England, made his first appearance in public since his arrival in this country, at a meeting of Anarchists in Clarendon Hall last evening.
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 23. -- Gov. Tillman promised in one of his campaign speeches a few days ago to reopen the dispensaries on the 1st of August. To-day be issued a proclamation.

DOLGEVILLE, July 23. -- Every train arriving here to-day was crowded with visitors to the Turnfest, which will begin Wednesday and continue the rest of the week. Already the village has taken on a gala appearance, and many thousands of yards of bunting have been used in decorating the business houses and immense factories.

The Brooklyn Idermen have at last consented to appropriate the 4750,000 which is required for immediate use in order that the supply of water may be increased, and the appropriation has been made without the objectionable conditions which certain members of the board desired to attach to it.
The immigration officials made good their threat yesterday to examine on board ship the steerage passengers of such liners as have refused to pay for the maintenance of detained immigrants.

James E. Sullivan, representing the New-Jersey Athletic Club, and President Bartow S. Weeks of the New-York Athletic Club agreed on some very important matches at Saratoga after the last championship meeting, the races to take place at the Grand Olympia of the New-Jersey Athletic Club on Labor Day, Sept. 3, at the club grounds, Bayonne City, N.J.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The feature of the market was the absence of offerings. Liquidation seems to have stopped for the time being at least, and stocks have apparently settled into the hands of parties able to carry them. As compared with Saturday, stocks were practically unchanged, excepting West Chicago, which opened at 137 3/8 and closed strong at 139.

NEWARK, July 23. -- The excursion steamer Favorite was burned at 2 o'clock this morning. She tied up at the Electric Light Dock last night with 500 happy,passengers aboard, but all that was left of the once fine steamer this morning was a blackened hull, the smokestack, and the flagstaff at the bow.

It is difficult to see on what sound grounds the Senate's addition of a million dollars to the Agricultural Appropriation bill, for the extermination of the Russian thistle, can be defended. It is true that if the Federal Treasury is ever to do anything in the matter, it should be done now, in spite of the condition of the finances, since this pest of the crops is spreading rapidly at the West.

PROVIDENCE, July 24 -- A hotel and five cottages at Pleasant Bluff, a Summer resort in East Providence, situated on Narragansett Bay, were burned last night. The hotel was owned by Walter Comstock. It consisted of two parts, 80 by 32 and 120 by 50 feet, and was four stories high. Adjoining it were a big dance hall, a dining hall, a kitchen, and a barber's shop, owned by Comstock.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 24 -- Bound East. -- Steam yachts Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Aquilo, George A. Thayer, and Empress, F.A. Schermerhorn. Passed West. -- Steam yachts Nada, C.R. Flint; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Clermont, Alfred Van Santvoord, and Starting, David Dows, Jr.; schooner yachts Fenella, W.A. Hazard, and Comet, W.H. Langley.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A number of army officers have proposed an association for the purpose of placing before Congress, and urging its adoption, a measure which means the payment of a large sum of money by the Government. Among the officers concerned are Major S.M. Whiteside, Seventh Cavalry, and Capts. M.B. Hughes, Ninth Cavalry, P.S. Bomus, First Cavalry, and S.W. Fountain, Eighth Cavalry.

SARATOGA, July 24 -- A heavy rainstorm early this morning put a damper on the sport here, which has not yet been anywhere near the class expected. There has been a lot of trouble to get entries for the races, although there were between 600 and 700 horses at the track previous to the arrival of six carloads from Chicago on Monday afternoon.

Charles A. Dana, editor of The New-York Sun, and Mrs. Dana arrived home Sunday on the steamer La Bourgogne. They had made a two months' tour of Europe, spending the greater part of the time in England, France, and Russia. Mr. Dana is looking ruddy and robust after his outing, and greeted a Tribune representative warmly yesterday at his office in The Sun Building.

The principle that lies at the basis of the great body of human relations, especially in trade, is that with every right goes a corresponding duty. The trades unions in England and in this country have done much to teach this principle to the employers, who, being human and unequal to doing much more right than they found it to their interest to do, stood in plain need of the lesson.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The agitation in behalf of the new military department, to be known as the Department of the South, has been renewed. The Senators and Representatives of that section are urging the establishment of such a department.

-- The members of the Boys' Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association who are to camp out for two weeks on Petrie Island, in the centre of Lake Mahopac, will meet this evening in their rooms to perfect arrangements and receive final instructions. There will be about forty of them. Prizes are to be offered to the boys who catch the largest and heaviest fish during the encampment.

Interest in the trial of Captain Doherty and his former ward men, Hock, and Meehan, has waned, and there were not half a dozen persons in the trial room at Police Headquarters yesterday morning besides officials, newspaper writers, witnesses, and the defendants and their lawyers.

The Knickerbocker Tennis Club finished its third annual open handicap tournament yesterday afternoon. Smith and Howard winning first prize in doubles from Donahue and Hickox. A close match was not expected, it being generally conceded that Smith and Howard were superior at the odds given, but the same was interesting toward the end, as the New-York Athletic Club team made a gallant effort. The score was as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- The local tractions continue to be the principal speculative feature, the steam roads being practically neglected. It was People's Traction day again. Opening at 44, it sold rapidly up to 46. All the other street car stocks were strong, even Baltimore. Special agents sent to that city report that the company seems to be doing a good business, and that the lines are well built and are in good physical condition.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were ihade at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

CHENOA, III., July 24 -- Chenoa was visited this afternoon by another conflagration similar in character and extent to that which destroyed the most of its business houses four years ago. The entire business portion of the place east of the Alton tracks and south of the Toledo, Peoria and Western is destroyed, with a loss of over $100,000.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- From the moment when Senator Hill began his speech he commanded the close attention of every-body in the Senate Chamber. He said:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The alleged violation of the law of the United States by the State of Mississippi in the issuing of warrants bearing a similitude to United States money was considered at the Cabinet meeting to-day. Secretary Carlisle brought the subject up for discussion. It was decided to refer the matter to Attorney General Olney for such action as he deemed proper.

-- The fast steam yacht Columbia, built last year for J. Harvey Ladew by the Cramps, has been chartered by Eugene Higgins. She is now in commission, and will cruise with the New-York Yacht Club squadron next month. The Columbia was built to steam 18 knots an hour, but on her trial trip fell short of this speed, only showing an average of 17 7/8 knots in the four hours' run.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 24 -- The first few minutes of this morning's session of the Constitutional Convention were occupied in excusing members from attending the sessions.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 24 -- The weather conditions for the continuation of the PhiladelphiaRosedale cricket match to-day were not very favorable. Some rain fell during the morning, and it was nearly 3 o'clock when play commenced. Lyon and Clement, the not-outs of Monday, went on at that hour, Rosedale having lost one wicket on their second inning, for 45 runs.

Within the chancel rail of the French Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste, in East Seventy-sixth Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, is placed, in a handsome French gilt relicuary, a piece of the wristbone of St. Anne.

LONDON, July 24 -- The Japanese Minister has official information confirming the report of the engagement between Corean and Japanese troops at Seoul There is no doubt in the minds of the members of the Japanese Legation that the attack upon the Japanese garrison was instigated by China.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Mr. Tateno, the Japanese Minister here, to-day received a cablegram from his Government saying that Corean troops had made an uncalled-for attack upon the Japanese soldiers stationed at Seoul, the capital, and that their fire had been returned by the Japanese troops. With what result on either side the dispatch did not say, nor is the date or the skirmish given.

The New-York Republican State Committee will meet this morning at 11 o'clock at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and unless there is industrious "arbitration" during the morning hours, it will find it has on hand row in the local camp of large proportions and troublesome in its nature.

The Milholland Republicans of the Nineteenth Assembly District met last night at 320 West Fifty-ninth Street and decided to send to the State Committee a statement to the claims of their faction to regularity.

The following from London Fairplay shows the sentiment in English maritime circles concerning a statement recently made by William Cramp of Philadelphia, who is quoted as saying that the magnificent showing made by the cruiser Minneapolis proves that America is superior to England in shipbuilding:

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., July 24 -- A life and death struggle that lasted nearly two hours took place last night on the deck of the schooner Robert P. King, lying at anchor in Flushing Bay, about one mile off this village. The fight was between the vessel's Captain, Parker J. Hall, and Charles Duard, a Portuguese sailor.

Edward F. Hartley, the eccentric Harlem dry goods merchant, who recently escaped, from the Blooming-dale Insane Asylum, where he had been committed at the request of his wife, and who after his escape took refuge at a hotel in Jersey City, and was arrested there and taken to the Hudson County Jail, was discharged from custody yesterday.

The larger part of the vast number of propositions for amending the Constitution which have been submitted to the convention at Albany indicate a distrust of the Legislature. They consist of restrictions or requirements to be imposed upon that body, curtailing its discretion in regard to a great many subjects.
Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews, it is said, will come in for severe criticism from the July Grand Jury when that body adjourns on Monday.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 24 -- Smallpox is epidemic in the town of Rutherford. It first made its appearance in the family of Joseph Burkhardt three weeks ago, and only three persons were at first affected. They were removed to hospital tents in the outskirts and it was hoped that the spread of the disease had been prevented.

George W. Striker, the executor of the will of Henry S. Ives, has taken proceedings in the Surrogate's Court for the purpose of discovering whether the former Napoleon of finance did not leave more than $10,000 worth of property, which is the amount of his estate as named at the time of the probate of his will.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- A hospitable reception was accorded Lake Street "L" on the exchange this morning, several blocks changing hands at 19. It appears that some brokers are attempting to cover short contracts. Yet there is plenty for sale, for the stock closed soft at 18 1/4. On account of alleged improvements in the condition of the strawboard trade small blocks of American Strawboard brought 30.

PARIS, July 24 -- The discussion of the Anti-Anarchist bill in the Chamber of Deputies to-day was attended with a number of stormy scenes. The trouble began the moment the fourth article was reached, the second and third articles having previously been passed without difficulty. The fourth article provides that Anarchists imprisoned under the bill shall be kept in solitary confinement.

A meeting of the Reorganization Committee of the Atchigon, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad was held at 32 Liberty Street yesterday for the purpose of hearing a further statement from Expert Accountant Stephen Little. Capt. R. Somers Hayes, Chairman of the committee, presided over the meeting.

Is The Chicago Herald a geat daily news-paper, full of a high sense of its responsibilities as such and voicing the sentiment of any considerable part of the public, or is it merely the mouthpiece of John R. Walsh, a banker who only sees the interest of the public as it is reflected from the glittering surface of a gold coin?

ON BOARD THE CRUISER NEW-YORK, GARDINER'S BAY, July 24 -- Great-gun practice was not had by the Naval Reserves to-day because of the haze which would make the practice dangerous to merchant shipping in the "open." The flagship signaled, just before morning quarters sounded, at 9:30 A.M., that anchorage would be retained and the day's work would be sub-calibre practice.

Edward N. Dalton, clerk to the Brooklyn Civil Service Commission, whom Joseph L. Bergen accused of trying to extort $40 for assisting him to pass a civil service examination for the police force, was last night, after a trial, dismissed from the employ of the commission, but not because of Bergen's charges.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., July 24 -- The steamer Miranda, Capt. Farrell, carrying the Cook arctic expedition to Greenland, consisting of fifty-four persons -- professors, scientists, university students, and others -- for the purpose of exploring West Greenland, which left here Sunday, July 15, returned this morning disabled, having run into an iceberg at the entrance to the Straits of Belle Isle.

An explosion and fire, the origin of which may never be satisfactorily explained, occurred at 6:50 o'clock last evening in the five-story business building at 21 Walker Street, and for a time the lives of eight fire patrolmen were imperiled. The damage to the building and its contents is estimated at $50,000.

A committee from the Drivers and Hostlers' Protective Benevolent Union called on Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews last evening to present the alieged grievances of the drivers and sweepers of his department. The committee consisted of M.J. Kennedy, President of Branch No. 3; John Little, President of Branch No. 2, and W. Hogarty.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Long before the opening hour of the United States Circuit Court this morning the corridor of the third floor of the Federal Building was thronged with people waiting to gain admission to the room where was to be heard the continuation of the arguments in the case of Eugene V. Debs, George W. Howard, Sylvester Keliher, and Director Rogers of the American Railway Union, charged with contempt of court.

The Stewards at Brighton Beach reached a conclusion yesterday in the investigation into the running of "Alec" Shields's horse Logon in the last race on Monday, and until The Jockey Club, to which the matter was referred for further investigation, renders a decision Mr. Shields will not be allowed the privileges of a licensed trainer.

Ex-Assemblyman James F. Quigley of the Twenty-eighth Ward, Brooklyn, the Democratic leader in the Assembly in 1893 and a McLaughlin Democrat, was yesterday appointed a Police Justice to succeed the late Robert E. Connolly of the Gates Avenue Police Court. Justice Quigley will serve during Justice Connolly's unexpired term, which ends May 1, 1897.

The three distinct wallopings which the Giants received in Boston at the hands of the champions apparently had no effect on their nerves, for in the battle at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon they not only played pennant ball, but shut out the proud Orioles in what proved to be one of the prettiest games of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Mr. Caffery (Dem., La.,) followed with a motion to instruct the Senate conferrees to insert in the sugar schedule a provision to pay to the sugar producers of the United States for 1894 a bounty of nine-tenths of a cent a pound on sugar testing not less than 90 degrees by the polariscope, and of eight-tenths of a cent for sugar testing not less than 80 degrees.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- The registration for the historical pilgrimage to the New-England Revolutionary battlefields will not close until Saturday night, but about fifty pilgrims have already been enrolled, coming from fifteen States. They include college professors, clergymen, lawyers, business men, and public school teachers.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate Sugar Committee held a brief session this morning and examined Edward J. Levy, the representative of Wheeler Co. on the floor of the New-York Stock Exchange. The testimony was suppressed.
LONDON, July 24 -- Princess Eulalia of Spain, with her sons, Alfonso and Luis, and her daughters, Maud and Victoria, is sojourning for the season at Bushey Hail, near Hampton Court.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Invalid Pensions Committee of the House will call up five measures to-morrow for which it will ask consideration and which it will endeavor to pass during the three hours and a half set aside for them. One of these is the bill to pension the widow of Gen. John M. Corse of Massachusetts.

CLEVELAND, July 24 -- There was such a heavy track for the Grand Circuit meeting to-day that instead of starting at noon, as originally intended, nothing was done till after 3 o'clock. This only gave time to clear up Monday's card, which was disposed of in eight heats. The 2:35 trot for three-year-olds, which looked sure for Red Bud, with two heats in hand, terminated in a very unexpected fashion.

The race meet to be held on Saturday afternoon at Manhatan Field under the auspices of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs promises plenty of good sport if the large number of first-class entries can be taken as a criterion. The one-mile race for novices, the winner of which gets the handsome gold badge offered by The New-York Times, alone has sixty-three enthies.

The last number of The Examiner, the Baptist Church organ, had this to say in an editorial in reference to the amendments offered to the Constitution toy Morris Tekulsky, the Park Row liquor dealer, who is President of the State Liquor Dealers' Association and who is a delegate from this city to the Constitutional Convention:

ORANGE, July 24 -- A particularly sad, as well as an unusual, case of a mother's death of a broken heart, in less than three days after her son's untimely demise, has just been brought to light here. Last Friday morning the following death notice appeared in The New-York Times:

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Friends of Walter Wellman, while somewhat exercised, are not unduly alarmed over the reports from Norway which state the belief of experienced navigators that his entire expedition has perished in the arctic seas.

SPRINGFIELD, III., July 24 -- The Republican State Convention, which assembles in the Capitol at noon to-morrow, will be one of the largest and most enthusiastic gatherings of the party in Illinois since war times. Nearly all of 1,300 delegates were on the ground to-day, and they have brought in their van fully three times that number of members of marching clubs and party workers from all over the State.

Mr. Gorman belongs to a class of men who notoriously require a cool head and a long memory, and he probably now understands that fact more completely than ever before. For the first time since his career has had any national interest he is exposed before the country in his true character, and it is no comfort to him to know that he has exposed himself.

Saloon keepers and others interested in the liquor traffic in this city and Brooklyn are greatly disturbed by the indorsement of Bishop Watterson's instructions in regard to temperance policy in Catholic societies at Columbus, Ohio, by the Apostolic Delegate, Mgr. Satolli.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 24 -- A new labor union, the American Labor Union, has been launched on the troubled seas of the labor world, which its leaders say will gather under one banner the whole army of the toiling masses.
