It was decided to admit militiamen as members of the new organization, which the Directors claim will take the place of the Knights of Labor.

ROCHE'S POINT, Ireland, July 24 -- The surprising feature of to-day's race between the Vigilant and the Britannia was the remarkable light-weather speed developed by the centreboarder. It has never been paralleled under similar conditions over a fiftymile course. In her duels with the Valkyrie off Sandy Hook the best hourly average of the Vigilant was 8.82 knots.

Giuseppe Castellini, an Italian bootblack, shot his sweetheart, pretty fifteen-year-old Carmelli Blasi, last night through the heart, in the tenement 198 Elizabeth Street. As the girl fell unconscious to the floor Couseppe then turned his pistol on himself and dropped beside her with a bullet in his throat.

Industrial issues were less active yesterday than on Monday, and yet more than 65 per cent, of the day's business was done in three of them -- Sugar, Chicago Gas, and Distilling and Cattle Feeding. Sugar was fairly firm in the early trading, selling up to 105 1/4, but it developed weakness in the afternoon and closer at its lowest price of the day, 103 1/4, a net loss of 1 3/8 points.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 24. -- There was a notable test of the popularity of President Cleveland among the people, as distinguished from the politicians and office holders, at Smithfield, the county seat of Jonnston County, on Wednesday last.

-- A two-story frame stable at One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street and Mott Avenue, opposite the entrance to Fleetwood Park, used by Dr. George McAdam and Mrs. Florence Wilkins, was discovered to be on fire yesterday morning, and before the engines responded to the alarm a horse belonging to John M. Cartwell was burned to death.

Wheat made a low record again yesterday, September selling at 55 13-16 cents per bushel and December at 59 9-16 cents. This was five-sixteenths of a cent per bushel below the previous low record for each month. Declines followed heavy Western receipts and Bradstreet's estimate of only 404,000 bushels decrease in the world's visible supply, against 2,198,000 bushels decrease last week.

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., July 24 -- The tug Aries, the dispatch boat to Commander Miller of the New-York Naval Battalion, arrived from the war ships at 7:30 this evening and landed Quartermaster Anderson's party. The tug then proceeded to New-London in charge of Chief Boatswain's Mate Seagrave, to bring here to-morrow morning the detail of signalmen provided by Major Ives of the First Brigade, New-York National Guard.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Interest this afternoon centred in the caucus of Democratic Senators, which began soon after 3 o'clock. The Marble Room had been selected as the meeting place, and all the approaches to it were closely guarded.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- It is understood that no immediate action will be taken by the United States in the way of formal recognition of the Hawaiian Republic. The State Department is not yet advised with the formality that the occasion requires of the establishment of the new republic -- that is to say it has had nothing but telegraphic information.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28 -- The Aquidaban, or Vinte-equatro de Maio, as she is now termed, entered the dock at the Ilhadas Cobras yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- As Mr. German has chosen to allow accounts of his visit to the White House to go to the newspapers in such form as to misrepresent the facts of that visit, it may be just as well to say something about how Mr. Gorman came to call there and what was done while he was there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 24 -- Mrs. Leland Stanford and her attorneys have notified the Government, through United States District Attorney Charles A. Carter, that its claims for $15,000,000 against the estate of Senator Stanford have been rejected. Mrs. Stanford considers the demand of the Government unjust, and will not pay it unless compelled by the courts.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 24 -- The fight over the Tariff bill at Washington led to the arrest of J. Sterling Drake, a prominent business man of this place, to-day, on a charge of assault in the third degree. A warrant was issued, it is understood, for the arrest of Edward Dobson, a well-known citizen, on a charge of using abusive language.

BOSTON, July 24 - The telephone stocks continued strong, though most of the balance of the local list was weak. Bell Telephone opened at 197, and sold up 1/2. The advance now is attributed to a rumor of an extra dividend, though there would seem to be little foundation for such a report: New-England Telephone was firm at 62 1/2.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The discharge of 150 clerks from the Record and Pension Office of the War Department, which has been talked of for two months, will take place to-morrow, the unfortunate employes having received their notices this morning.
LONDON, July 24 -- The Standard prints a letter from Carl Siewwers in which the latter says he has received advices from Norway leaving no doubt that the Wellman arctic expedition is lost.
Postmaster Dayton has received from the heads of departments their reports, showing, in detail, the business transacted in each department during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1894.

Three laborers were instantly killed in an elevator accident yesterday at Clausen Price's brewery, Fifty-ninth Street and Eleventh Avenue. Two other men, also laborers, were injured, though not seriously.

NEW-HAVEN, July 24 -- Charles H.R. Miller, proprietor of one of the largest billlard rooms in this State, has been the target of the local branch of the Law and Order League of Connecticut. He was arrested recently for keeping his billiard rooms open at Savin Rock, ,a Summer resort, on Sundays, in violation of the Sunday law.
Following are interviews with members of the State Committee:
At a meeting of the Municipal Reform Club of the Twenty-eighth. Assembly District the following resolution was unanimously adopted:

Jenkins Van Schaick, whose membership in the Stock Exchange dates back to 1857 and who has been prominent in club life and local politics for many years, has suffered the displeasure of the authorities at the Exchange. They suspended him yesterday for thirty days. The offense for which they meted out this punishment occurred last Friday.

The Senate Committee on Territories has ordered favorable reports on the bills, which have already passed the House, admitting Arizona and New-Mexico to Statehood. We have already stated at some length reasons why Arizona is unfit to come into the Union at present. Her population is less than 60,000, her finances are in a bad condition, and her politics are controlled by corporations and the gambling element.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The much-discussed conference of Democratic Senators came to an end late this afternoon by the adoption of the resolution offered yesterday by Mr. Jarvis, that the Tariff bill be reported back to the tariff conferrees without instructions.

Henry Raabe Son's sawmill and cabinet factory, 319 and 321 West Sixty-fourth Street, at Twelfth Avenue, and the threestory frame building 326 and 328 West Sixty-fifth Street, were destroyed by a fire that started just after 7 o'clock last evening. Four families, including that of Mrs. Catherine Schroeder, the owner, were driven from the frame building.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Mr. Caffery, (Dem., La.,) who moved yesterday that the Senate conferrees be instructed to use their efforts to have a modified sugar, bounty for 1894 inserted in the sugar schedule, continued to-day the speech he begun yesterday in support of the bill.

The quick response of the Chamber of Deputies to the appeal of the Government in favor of the new bill against the Anarchists shows that the bill is not in advance of public opinion. The fourth and fifth articles were perhaps the most drastic of the whole bill, yet the majority in favor of them was overwhelming.

CONEY ISLAND, July 25 -- Two innocent-looking boys, dressed in yachting suits, and wearing diamond horseshoe pins in their lawn tennis shirts, were arraigned in the West Brighton Police Court to-day, charged with carrying concealed weapons without a permit.

BOSTON, July 25 -- The attraction of the double game and the fine weather brought over 4,000 people to the South End Grounds this afternoon. Both clubs were out in full force, with the exception of Griffin of the Brooklyns, Shoch taking his place.

Messrs. Cotter Brothers, the builders, have sold to W.W. Skiddy the recentlyerected four five-story brick and brownStone flats, 203, 207, 209, and 213 West Eighty-first Street, 37.6 by 100 each, at about $300,000.
James R. Bartlett, the Chairman of the Nicaragua Canal Reorganization Committee, and Smith M. Weed, a member of the committee, sailed yesterday morning on the steamship Teutonic for Liverpool.
ALBANY, July 25 -- Petitions in favor of fres speech, against sectarian institutions, and in favor of civil service, were presented when the Constitutional Convention session opened this morning.

BOSTON, July 25 -- The strength of the Bell Telephone and West End Street Railway were the only features in to-day's market. The former advanced 1 1/2, to 199, and receded later to 198. Plenty of funds being ready for investment and few stocks in which it looks safe to invest, are the real reasons for the strength of this Boston favorite.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 25 -- James W. Wadsworth, who was to-day appointed a member of the sub-committee of the Republican State Committee to pass upon the regularity of the contending factions in New-York and Onondaga Counties, will vote as Platt desires, in spite of his former reputation as an anti-Platt man.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The House Commerce Committee to-day decided to report favorably a bill prepared by Secretary Carlisle of the Treasury Department, amending Section 5,294 of the Revised Statutes, so that the Secretary of the Treasury may remit penalties provided for in laws relating to vessels, or discontinue any prosecution in connection therewith, except the penalty of imprisonment or of removal from office, upon such terms as he shall think proper.

Marshal Floriano Peixoto, Vice President of the Republic of the United States of Brazil, has addressed a patriotic message to the members of the National Congress on the occasion of the opening of the first session of the second Legislature.

Great dullness was the only feature or the stock market yesterday. The foreigners showed no disposition to trade on either side, the disclosures concerning the Atchison methods of bookkeeping apparently frightening them off. There was less done in the industrials, there being fewer rumors from Washington to influence fluctuations.

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., July 25 -- The work to-day with the Naval Reserves be- gan with "General quarters, clear ship for action," shortly before 1:30 o'clock, and when at 3:15 the flagship ordered practice to cease the San Francisco had used up thirty-nine rounds of ammunition and the New-York a total of seventy-one.

DOLGEVILLE, July 25 -- The streets of Dolgeville have been, filled all day with marching delegations of turners from all points between New-York City and Buffalo. The New-York City delegation did not arrive until evening, having remained several hours in Albany to visit the Capitol and other objects of interest.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 25 -- At the Waltham Cycle Park this afternoon, Harry Tyler of Springfield and Nat Butler of Boston made private trials of speed. Tyler rode a quarter, flying start, in 0:27 2-5; the third in 0:37 2-5, and the two-thirds of a mile in 1:14 2-5. This was a 1:51 clip had he finished the mile. He rode a quarter, standing start, in 0:31 3-5.

John H. McCarty, recently appointed United States Marshal for this district, took the oath of office before judge Benedict yesterday. Bonds of $20,000 were given for him by Charities Commissioner Edward C. Sheehy and David F. Porter, President of the Hamilton Bank, in West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. The office was then formally turned over to him by John W. Jacobus, the retiring Marshal.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 25 -- The hall of the House of Representatives in the State Capitol was packed to suffocation when James H. Clark of Mattoon called the Republican State Convention to order a few minutes after noon. It was the largest State gathering of the party that Springfield has witnessed since war times.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., July 25 -- The Trinity elections case, the most important of the whole series entered against the late Whiteway Government, inasmuch as Sir William Whiteway, late Premier, and Robert Bond, his Colonial Secretary and chief lieutenant, were accused of securing election by corrupt practices, was completed to-day.

PARIS, July 25 -- The debate on the Anti-Anarchist bill was resumed in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. After several amendments had been rejected, the paragraph in Article 5 inflicting the penalty of fine and imprisonment for publishing reports of Anarchist trials was adopted.

Detective Zundt of Brooklyn, who is assigned to aid the Fire Marshal in investigating the causes of fires, had a warrant given to him last Friday for the arrest of David Wenig, who is charged with extortion, the complainant being Jacob Klein of 74 Johnson Avenue. Zundt did not find Wenig until Tuesday night.

Another splendid exhibition of the national game took place yesterday at the Polo Grounds, when the Giants and the Orioles played the second contest of the present series. The home team was again victorious, and this state of affairs naturally pleased a very large majority of the 7,500 spectators. There was a delegation of enthusiasts present from Baltimore, to whom the second trouncing of Capt. Robinson's great team was a sore disappoinment.

One of the most interesting features of the meeting was the gathering of the numerous candidates for Governor in the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. They were in evidence, except Controller James A. Roberts of Buffalo, who has opened a supplementary headquarters at the Hotel Imperial.

R. Fulton Cutting, President of the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, has issued the following appeal to the public in behalf of the vacation schools in the crowded districts of the city:

The members of the Kings County Grand Jury, whom Justice Moore admonished because they wanted to take a pleasure trip at the county's expense to St. Johnland, and whom he instructed to finish their work yesterday, carried out the latter's instructions and handed in their report.

It is now reported that the strike in the iron-mining district of Michigan has been broken by the arrest of one Nolton, an organizer whose influence has been exerted among the miners to their great injury. Owing to the assaults of the strikers upon miners who were willing to work, it has been necessary to station companies of militia in the district, and several companies have been quartered at Ironwood.

The Seaside Athletic Club at West Brighton, Coney Island, will be formally opened on the night of Aug. 1 with an attractive card of broadsword and boxing bouts. During the past week considerable work has been transacted by the club, and everything is now in shape to proceed with a series of entertainments which will rival in the athletic line any that have been held during a long period.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- After such a rapid advance as we have had the last few days a reaction was naturally in order. We had it to-day. Those who have been bidding up People's to 46 began to distribute the stock around that figure. They have sold a good deal, and to-day started in to sell it down.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Lieut. Charles A. Stone, United States Navy, (retired,) ordnance officer of the Carnegie Company, to-day appeared before the special committee of the House investigating the alleged armor frauds. He knew nothing of the retreatment of ballistic plates 468, 531, and 619 until the facts were brought out in the investigation.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Maryland Democrats appear to be waking up to the reputation Gorman is giving the State by his opposition to honest tariff reduction and his hostility to the President.
The clubhouse of the Logan Club, at 255 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, was crowded with members and invited guests last night to welcome James A. Roberts, State Controller.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Messrs. Debs, Howard, Keliher, and Rogers of the American Railway Union are at liberty under bail pending the hearing of the various cases against them. They were, this afternoon, required to give $7,000 bond each, covering five new indictments, in addition to the contempt cases brought by the Government and the Santa Fe Railroad.

The trial of Capt. Doherty and ex-Ward Men Hock and Meehan was continued yesterday before the Police Commissioners at the Central Office, with no apparent advantage to the defense. Several witnesses testified to theoretical activity on the part of Capt. Doherty to get rid of the Thorow establishment.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- An ingenious swindle, by means of which New-York banks may lose in the neighborhood of $100,000, was discovered here to-day.

The Stewards at Brighton Beach are making records for themselves as honest officials, who will tolerate no crooked work. Yesterday they struck another horse from the list of those eligible to start at the seaside track. Addie was the suspect in this case, and her race yesterday fully justified the Stewards in the action taken. Addie is a clever sprinter, and has won from good horses at six furlongs.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The four-story brick warehouse and stables of the George W. Knox Express Company, occupying over a quarter of a block, at Second and B Streets, Northwest, were destroyed by fire early this morning. Three firemen lost their lives.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Tariff bill will go back to the conferrees, and the Senate will not give its conferrees instructions.

It did not take the Republican State Committee long yesterday to decide upon the time and place of holding the State Convention. It was evidently not interested in the question that brought every member of the committee to the meeting. The thing that interested them was the contest between the factions, or organizations, in this city, and the question of deciding upon their respective claims to regularity.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 25 -- The investigation to-day brought out more testimony from convicts in regard to paddling. First introduced to the attention, of the commission was Walter Conway, under which name was cloaked the personality of a former popular comedian, who last appeared in "McKenna's Flirtations."

The Fourth Assembly District just now is full of tailors and warfare. In the very forefront of the battle and the very heat of the warfare floats the all-conquering oriflamme of Lanty Ryan. His name would seem to identify him as the hero of an Irish serio-comic ballad, rather than with east side citizenship, but his occupation, according to the almost unanimous report of his neighbors, is that of a "Tammany politician."
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 25 -- Judge Lippincott in the Supreme Court to-day, decided a rather queer election case. In April last William O'Brlen and Allan Benny were the candidates for Alderman in the First Ward of Bayonne. Benny, who is a Republican, had been elected two years before, and held the seat. At the last election he and O'Brien had 260 votes each.

TOLEDO, July 25 -- Walter C. Sanger won the great mile race at to-day's meet of the Toledo Cycling Club. This race had more prizes and prizes of greater value than any previous one this season. The first prize was a Harvard trap, silver-mounted harness, fine horse whip, and robes, valued at $500. Diamonds were offered as prizes for each heat.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- About a dozen large plate-glass windows in the home of George M. Pullman, at the corner of Prairie Avenue and Eighteenth Street, were smashed with stones thrown by Simon Reskins, a Russian and an Anarchist, at 7:40 o'clock this morning. Reskins made no resistance when seized by Mr, Pullman's servants.
Some of the members of the Committee of Thirty's organization took a hostile attitude last night toward all things that might savor of compromise.

There were thirty-five members of the Republican State Committee in this city yesterday, and the majority of them, when interviewed by reporters for The New-York Times, favored the nomination of Levi P. Morton for Governor. These Republican leaders talked glibly about the Gubernatorial nomination, and were voluble in their suggestions as to the course which Republicans should pursue in this city next Fall.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A legislative muddle has been discovered that will have to be settled before Representative Clifton R. Breckinridge can start for St. Petersburg as the properly-equipped diplomatic representative of this Government at the Court of the Czar.
LONDON, July 25 -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Central News says:

BOSTON, July 26 -- The Brooklyns knocked Harry Staley out of the box to-day in the third inning, their terrific batting earning 7 of their 8 runs. Nichols went into the box in his place and held the "Bridegrooms" down to one hit in the next four innings, but he too had to suffer in the last two innings.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Gen. Kerwin will need to develop more careful habits of business and a greater regard for the public interest as a Police Commissioner than he manifested as an Internal Revenue Collector, if he hopes to win the commendation of the people of New-York.

-- An unknown Italian boy, about fourteen years old, was killed yesterday while walking With other boys on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad tracks near One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street. He was knocked by a north-bound freight train from a trestle to the meadow twenty feet below. His skull was crushed and both legs were broken.

Some of these days of discovery and invention a targe which will defy the "slings and arrows of outrageous fortune" may be found. Yesterday one that defied leaden hail was tested at the Seventh Regiment Armory, and eight rifle shots discharged at it when it was on the breast of a man did not harm him.

The vexed question of the final disposition of ashes and garbage which has engaged the attention of the sanitary and other municipal authorities for years has been referred by Mayor Gilroy to an advisory commission, who are expected to look carefully into the subject with especial reference to the cremation of garbage and the best system for cremation.

In one point of view the trial of Doherty has been a solemn and unamusing farce. Such must be the trial of any Police Captain before the present Police Commissioners. Change places, and handy-dandy, which is the Justice, which is the thief? Why has not Doherty been trying the Police Commissioners?
LONDON, July 26 -- The Central News has this dispatch from Shanghai:

PARIS, July 26 -- Meunier, the humpbacked Anarchist and associate of Francois and Ravachol, was placed on trial today for having blown up the Cafe Very, in the Spring of 1892. Meunier is supposed to have blown up the cafe to avenge Ravachol, who had been arrested there.

-- The Good Roads Racing Tournament to be given at Asbury Park on Aug. 30-31, and Sept. 1 is receiving the indorsement of cyclists and the friends of the good roads movement ail over the Country. The teams, after the Denver meet, will return to this city in special cars and will rest a few days at the seaside before the tournament begins.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 -- The local market for tractions was dull and narrow. The investment demand for the moment being largely filled, quotations for the stocks were left in the hands of traders. While not much stock was wanted, there was very little for sale. Philadelphia opened a little lower, at 95 1/4, and fluctuated between that and 95 3/4 all day.

A wildly-absurd story vas printed yesterday of the supposed sale of the Washington apartment house, for the estate of E. Just, at $450,000. As a matter of fact, the estate made an exchange of the property some months ago with Mr. Henry M. Denton of Jersey City. Now Mr. Denton has made another exchange with a Mr. Henriques, who represents the real party in interest.

SARATOGA, July 26 -- Pleasant weather brought out a much better attendance at the races here this afternoon. The ladies were more numerous than on any previous day, and, in their light-colored Summer dresses, gave the grand stand quite a galaday appearance. The sport was also the best of the meeting, though backers of the favorites had a little the worst of it, though they did beat three of the favorites.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., July 26 -- At the annual excursion of the Endeavor Club of the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Wards, New-York, at Donnelly's Boulevard Park to-day, Mary Dooley, a daughter of Bridge Policeman Dooley of 221 First Avenue, New-York, and William Coffey, a fireman, stationed in West Tenth Street, New-York, were drowned late in the afternoon.

BRIDGEPORT, July 26 -- The legal battle which has been In progress for some time between the consolidated road and the Bridgeport Traction Company resulted in a clash between these two corporations today.
NEWARK, July 26 -- The Bloomfield car stables were burned shortly after 12 o'clock to-day. All the horses were rescued.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 26 -- Weed, Parsons Co. of Albany, who have been awarded the contract for making United States stamped envelopes under the new four years' contract, beginning Oct. 1, have authorized negotiations with the present contractors here, the Plimpton Manufacturing Company, for the stamped-envelope machinery, which is patented and controlled by the Hartford concern.

The shipments of gold from this port to-morrow, it is thought, are likely to approximate $5,000,000. The Sub-Treasury filled orders yesterday for $2,200,000 of gold for export, the $200,000 being designed for shipment to Canada. The sum of $100,000 in gold was also withdrawn from the Sub-Treasury for domestic uses, and the Sub-Treasury received during the day $100,000 in gold certificates.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The tariff debate in the Senate to-day was enlivened by an address by Mr. Vilas, in which he made a vigorous defense of the President in reply to Mr. Gorman's attack. He spoke as follows:

-- At the meeting in Philadelphia of the State Baseball League, which began on Wednesday evening and lasted until 2 o'clock yesterday morning, E.K. Meyers resigned as President, and A.B. Johnson, owner of the Allentown team, was elected to fill the vacancy. A rule was adopted that all clubs except Philadelphia pay the visiting team half of the gate receipts, with a fifty-dollar guarantee, and one of $25 in case of rain.

CLYDE, N.Y., July 26 -- Regarding the dismissal of Capt. Doherty and his former wardmen from the police force of New-York City, Senator Saxton said this evening he was not surprised at the result. Asked his opinion of the action, he replied: "I regard this as the outcome of the investigation thus far held by the Senate committee.

BOSTON, July 26 -- Transactions in local stocks were light, but the tone was fairly firm on the whole. Boston United Gas seconds were strong at 56. American Bell Telephone was steady at 197, with Erie at 46 1/2. The New-England Telephone and Telegraph Company to-day declared $1 dividend per share, payable Aug. 15.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The struggle in the Senate over the Tariff bill has reached a point where all those engaged are in doubt as to the outcome. Many moves were made to-day which to some appeared to point to a speedy solution of the matter, but when the Senate adjourned, the complications had materially increased, and the enemies of the measure were in high feather.

Sugar led in activity in yesterday's market, exceeding its own record of Wednesday by 40,000 shares, and losing 2 1/2 per cent. as the result of the day's operations. News from Washington, as usual, stimulated trading. It came to the effect that the Senators who had championed the trust's interests were singing low just now, and could not hope to stand out against the forces roused against them.

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., July 28 -- The San Francisco and the New-York, which passed the night just inside the west end of Fisher's Island, went outside this morning to give the naval militiamen further practice at grunnery.
There may be a keener swindler somewhere on earth than "David Coleman," but it is doubtful. So far Mr. Coleman, whose present whereabouts is unknown, has these items to his credit:

CHICAGO, July 26 -- The market for West Chicago stock was a puzzle. It was generally believed that the dealers were largely short for the July account, and that the shorts were the heaviest raiders on the floor of the Exchange. Few expected that they would be able to cover without forcing much higher prices.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Tariff bill will not be safe until it shall have left the Capitol and gone to the White House.

Lewis L. Delafield has been selected by the City Club of New-York to appear before the Constitutional Convention and explain the principles of the amendments prepared by the Committee of Twenty-one appointed at the recent conference of municipal reform bodies.

"Will it be possible for the three Senators who are now held up to the country as agents and servants, not of the people of the United States, nor of their several States, nor yet of their party, but simply and solely of the Sugar Trust, to maintain that position without begging to be taken down?

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 26 -- An elopement is reported from the Thousand Islands. The husband is Arthur Singleton, an attorney of Yonkers. Last night he found his wife and Wallace Bronson on the boat going to Alexandria Bay. She refused to return to the husband, and threw him the jewelry he had given her and went away with Bronson.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 -- The cruiser Minneapolis, which recently returned from her very successful trial trip, will shortly be docked at the League Island Navy Yard by her builders. "This course will be taken not because of a request to that effect from the Navy Department at Washington," said a representative of the Cramps to-day, "but because the firm does not wish to have the same trouble with her as it had with the Columbia.

Some prominent Republicans, enraged because Thomas C. Platt had forced the Republican State Committee to refer the local row to a sub-committee of Platt men, said bitter things about Mr. Platt yesterday.

Acting under a provision of the Consolidated act, a Citizens' Committee, composed of Judson Lawson, G.W. Stokes, Orlando Smith, John W. Stevens, W.H. Arnoux, H.C. Robinson, and A.W. Lightbourne, proposes to investigate Charges made from time to time and in various ways that millions of dollars have been stolen from the city in the City Controller's office since the days of William M. Tweed by means of irregular and illegal issues of bonds.

The Governors of the Stock Exchange are putting forth earnest efforts to check the growth of arbitrage business in stock speculation. They have practically decreed that the "two-dollar" brokers who are permitted to do business on the floor of the Exchange shall not hereafter be permitted to give quotations to their principals over the Stock Exchange telephones.

The Chairman and another prominent member of the Reorganization Committee of the Nicaragua Canal Company have sailed for Europe, and the story is that they have gone to negotiate for capital with which to carry on the construction of the canal to completion. According to the report a syndicate of English capitalists has offered to furnish the amount required, which is estimated at $80,000,000.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 26 -- Saneer and Johnson ran in a dead heat in the mile open race to-day. The prize was a five-hundred-dollar bedroom set, brass bedstead, and mahogany furniture, silver mounted, the most sought after prize at the meet. C.M. Murphy was a close third, L.D. Cabanne, who yesterday took second to Sanger, was fourth, and Bald fifth.

The backers of favorites had an excellent day of it at Brighton Beach yesterday, for five of the six favorites passed the wire first. Young Reiff, J.J. McCafferty's jockey, has been riding in good form at Brighton, and every day this week he has landed two or three winners. Yesterday was no exception, for he rode three winners, and was placed in the other two races in which he rode.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 26 -- The prosecution in the reformatory investigation was discredited to-day by one of its own witnesses. Frank Wood, formerly an inmate of the reformatory, but now a convict in Auburn State Prison, was brought here to give testimony against Superintendent Brockway and the Board of Managers.

In The New-York Times of Sunday next there will be printed the first installment of Mr. W. Clark Russell's latest story -- "The Good Ship Mohock." Of course, it is a sea story, and of course it is a good one. As a writer of sea stories, Mr. Russell has made for himself a special place among modern novelists, perhaps among novelists of all time.

WEST END, LONG BRANCH, July 26 -- There were no signs of the "dull season" at the Proprietor's Ball at the West End Hotel to-night, which surpassed all previous ones in attendance, beauty of the decorations, and the attractiveness of the ladies' costumes.

John O'Connell, chief engineer and plumber of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, was arrested yesterday on the complaint or William Lockwood. business manager of the Association of Master Plumbers, on a charge of violating sanitary law by doing plumbing work in the hotel without a license. He was fined $25 in the Court of Special Sessions.

SARATOGA, July 26 -- Edwin Einstein, the originator of the Committee of Thirty, the last Republican candidate for Mayor of New-York, and one of the biggest contributors to the Republican campaign funds, is mad all the way through over the action taken by Mr. Platt's State Committee at its meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Wednesday on the Platt-Milholland Committee of Thirty's regular organization controversy.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Capt. James A. Hulton, Eighth Infantry, will lose his commission as an army officer July 31. The officer has just been found guilty by a court-martial at Fort Robinson, Neb., of charges of absence without leave, conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman, and disobedience of orders.

United States Secret Service men broke in the door of a furnished room on the top floor of 107 East Broadway yesterday afternoon, and captured, a notorious counterfeiter at work making spurious silver dollars. The prisoner is William Martin, alias Martin Kelly, fifty-two years old, who for years, when not behind prison bars, has manufactured bogus money.

Mrs. Nellie Fein, thirty-five years old, the wife of Samuel Fein, was brutally assaulted at her home on the second floor of the tenement at 138 Chrystie Street Wednesday morning by a young negro, who made good his escape. The case did not come to the knowledge of the police until Wednesday night, but they have a good description of the negro, and are making unusual efforts to effect his capture.

Private letters from Siberia announce the sudden death at Barnaul of the well-known Russian author and publicist, Nikolai M. Yadrintsef, who was for many years owner and editor of The Eastern Review, and who was regarded as one of the best informed men in the world with regard to the history, archaeology, and anthropology of Asiatic Russia.

Samuel Spencer, President of the new Southern Railway Company, issued an order yesterday, which will take effect, on Aug. 1. The lines of the company will after that date be operated in two systems, the Eastern system, comprising the Richmond and Danville and the Georgia Road, and the Western system, comprising the lines of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railway, and the Knoxville and Ohio Railroad.

The sending of the Tariff bill to conference again by the Senate without instructions will be equivalent to giving the Senate conferrees a free hand. Even the sending of the bill with a motion to "insist" on the Senate amendments would in practice be equivalent to giving the conferrees a free hand.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 26 -- The steamer Bay Queen and a barge carrying 2,000 passengers arrived at Shippen Point this afternoon. The party came as excursionists from St. Patrick's Alliance of Orange, N.J. About 5 o'clock three men of the party claimed that they had lost their watches and money while in bathing, and a disturbance was created in the pavilion.

ERIE, Penn., July 26 -- The marriage of the Rev. John De Witt of Princeton to Mrs. Eleanor M. Allen of Erie took place this morning at the bride's home. The groom is Professor of Church History at Princeton, and his wife is of the wealthy Wallace family of this State.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 26. -- The Rev. Jonathan Edwards Bell, editor of The Long Island Weekly Flag, published in this city, has been summoned to appear before a court-martial composed of members of Benjamin Ringgold Post, G.A.R., of this city, to answer charges of conduct unbecoming a soldier.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 26 -- The Constitutional Convention went into Committee of the Whole this morning, on the amendment introduced by Mr. Rocne of Troy, abolishing judicial pensions.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The friends of the Nicaragua Canal bill in the House are somewhat exercised to-day at the information which reaches Washington from New-York that Messrs. Bartlett and Weed of the Reorganization Committee of the Nicaragua Canal Company have sailed for Europe to consider the offer of certain English capitalists, who have agreed to furnish the money to complete the canal.

Grim-visaged harmony and most boisterous union now prevail in the Republican Party in New-York. It was all brought about at the meeting of the State Committee on Wednesday, when Mr. PJatt kindly caused certain factional differences that had broken out in the ranks of the party in this city to be referred to a committee in which he has the fullest confidence.
Michael Doherty is no longer a Captain on the New-York police force.
The weekly bulletin issued yesterday by Chairman Raymond of the League of American Wheelmen Racing Board contains the following of interest to cyclists:

The will of ex-Police Commissioner Joel W. Mason, which was executed on Dec. 12, 1891, was filed for probate yesterday in the office of the Surrogate. Ex-Commissioner Mason died at his country residence at Hunter, Greene County, July 5.
PARIS, July 26 -- Consideration of the Anti-Anarchist bill was resumed in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, and was finally passed by a vote of 268 to 163.
The investigation into the abuses alleged to exist in connection with the management of the city asylums for the insane poor was resumed on Ward's Island yesterday by the State Lunacy Board.

DOLGEVILLE, July 26 -- The parade of the Uniformed Turners from New-York City, Schenectady, Fort Plain, Utica, Rome, Auburn, Syracuse, Rochester, and Buffalo this morning was one of the most interesting spectacles ever witnessed in this part of the State. The female athletes, attired in picturesque bloomer costumes, won much applause by their superb marching.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.
Mayor Gilroy has received the following letter relating to the Harlem River Driveway from Augustus St. Gaudens, the sculptor; Stanford White, the architect, and W.M. Chase, the artist:
"David Coleman, capitalist," is still at large, although the police have been keeping a sharp lookout for him.

Thomas Wright of Chicago, who was found unconscious Thursday night on the sidewalk at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, died early yesterday morning at the New-York Hospital, without having regained consciousness. Death was due to a comminuted fracture of the right side of the skull.

Undoubtedly a large number of the Democratic Congressmen are anxiously studying their prospects in the conventions and elections this year. If their districts are close, their anxiety is increased. These men are being subjected to influence from two sources with reference to the tariff fight now on.

SARATOGA, July 27 -- Adelbert Truax of Glens Falls was arrested to-night, charged with assault, first degree. At Collamer's Corners, near Saratoga Lake, this afternoon, he shot his sister-in-law, Mrs. William A. Jones, and it is feared she may die. The shot was intended for her husband, but she stepped between the quarreling men just in time to receive the bullet.

Less than 80,000 shares was the record in the stock market yesterday, and very nearly half the business was done in the industrials. Sugar was the most active, and the prices followed the tenor of the Washington dispatches. The lowest price of the day was made just after the opening of business, and it closed with a net gain of 1/4.
Republicans of the Committee of Thirty stripe who were humiliated by ex-Senator Platt on Wednesday do not cool off rapidly. The sting of the Platt lash lasts.

HEART'S CONTENT, N.F., July 27 -- The final splice of the Anglo-American Telegraph Company's new cable was made at 11 A.M., Greenwich time, to-day, and the laying of the largest cable across the Atlantic was men sucessfully completed.
WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., July 27 -- The forest fires, which have been under control for the past few days, have broken out with renewed energy all along the lines of the Northern Pacific and Omaha Roads.

LAS VEGAS, New-Mexico, July 27 -- Two Mexicans dead, several others wounded, and two Americans in custody of the United States troops stationed at this place is the result of what might have been a much more deadly riot but for the calling out of the troops.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 27 -- Success follows Sanger. He is in good form. At to-day's races of the Zigzag Cycling Club in the national circuit. Sanger again beat Johnson, this time in a most decisive manner. Johnson did not take Sanger's rear wheel, but rode his own race throughout. The judges gave Johnson second place.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 27 -- A meeting of the racing wheelmen of the American League of Racing Cyclists was held in Parlor 371 at the Denison House this evening. Threescore of racing men, managers, and trainers were present. E.C. Bode was chosen temporary Chairman and F.E. Spooner Temporary Secretary. Chairman Bode stated that the objects of the meeting were to form a body to protect the racing men's interests.

LONDON, July 27-- The officials at the Foreign Office and the Chinese and Japanese Legations reiterated this evening that no official news of the war had been received. Numerous cable dispatches were delivered at the legations, but in no case could anything be learned concerning their contents.

ALBANY, July 27 -- The Cities Committee's second report on the question of home rule, which has been substantially printed in The New-York Times, was submitted this morning to the convention, together with a minority report which was signed by the following Democrats: Messrs. Hotchkiss, Fitzgerald, Marks, and Speer of New-York, Davenport of Kings, and Rawley of Columbia, who had this to say:

-- Receiver McNeill and General Freight Agent Campbell of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company have conferred with General Manager Dickinson of the Union Pacific and J.A. Monroe with a view of making a tariff agreement with the Overland along somewhat similar lines as the Union Pacific had with the Oregon Company before its absorption by the former company.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- By good luck, and not by superior numbers, the Democrats of the Senate have sent the Tariff bill back to the conferrees.

"Upper houses" are in a bad way. The right of the immediate representatives of the people to originate money bills is a tradition in English politics, and it is according to the English model that that right is explicitly secured to them by our Constitution, although the Constitution, with a clumsiness noticeable in so clear a piece of writing, declares that "the Senate may propose or concur with amendments as on other bills."

The telegraph and the steamship have created relations of mutual interdependence between the nations of the modern world that invest with interest and importance the breaking out of a war even in distant Corea. There is no longer any doubt that China and Japan have gone to war in earnest, and it is no less clear that the progress of hostilities will be watched with intelligent attention by Western nations.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The President has approved the following acts: The Naval Appropriation bill, authorizing the construction of a bridge across the Missouri River at Lexangtan, Mo.
Senator Edmund O'Connor of Binghamton, a member of the Lexow committee, was in this city yesterday.

The Committee of Twenty-one, representing various organizations in this State devoted to the reform, of municipal government, has formulated several amendments of the State Constitution which will be strongly urged upon the convention at Albany, and which, it is believed, that body and its committees are prepared to regard with favor.

As was told in The New-York Times of last Tuesday, residents on the south shore of Long Island have had cause to complain about the dumping of garbage in the sea by Italian contractors, which is washed by the tides to the beaches and interferes not only with bathing, but with the health of the Sumner resorts.

SHANGHAI, July 27 -- The Chinese transports sunk off the Corean coast by Japanese guns belonged to the fleet of eleven steamers which sailed from Taku on Friday, July 20, with 12,000 troops. The fleet left Taku under an escort of gunboats. The majority of the transports proceeded slowly with the gunboats, while the faster ones steamed at full speed, so as to land their troops as soon as possible.

Chiko, the gorilla, is dead. Before leaving New-York yesterday for his Summer home at Cobleskill, N.Y., William Wallace, Superintendent of the Museum of Natural History, received a telegram from James A. Bailey, part owner of Barnum Bailey's circus, now in Northern Ohio, stating that the manlike animal was dead, and that his body had been shipped to New-York.
ST. LOUIS, July 27. -- Albert Smith, one of the local leaders in the late railroad strike and a friend of Eugene V. Debs, President of the National American Railway Union, said to-day: ...

The Old Guard had its annual outing and clambake yesterday at Roton Point, on the Sound. Nearly 200 members, in full uniform, boarded the Iron Steamboat Cygnus at Pier 1 North River at 10:30. Rampone's Old Guard Band was on board, and the trip up the Sound was greatly enjoyed. Off Fort Schuyler the Cygnus was greeted with a salute of thirteen guns.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The sailing of the United States cruiser Bennington from La Libertad, Salvador, for San Francisco was a carefully-guarded, secret in the State and Navy Departments. What will be done with Ezeta and his three fellow-refugees on arrival can only be guessed at.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Interest in the stock market centred almost entirely in West Chicago. At the opening the feeling was quite firm. Buying by a broker whose orders usually run into a large amount started some of, the shorts who had not made their turns yesterday to covering, followed by a sharp quick advance from 135 to 136.

ALBANY, July 27 -- For an hour and a half the eagle bird screamed, the old flag constantly fluttered, while thunderbolts of patriotism aroused the more phlegmatic members in the Constitutional Convention to-day.

Dr. Carlos F. MacDonald, Lawyer Goodwin Brown, and ex-Congressman Henry A. Reeves, constituting the State Lunacy Commission, resumed, at Ward's Island, yesterday morning, their investigation into the abuses alleged to exist in connection with the management of the city asylums for the insane poor.

In all the sifting of the Lexow committee nothing was discovered which in the minds of most citizens was more important than the fact that Mr. Martin was informed that Mrs. Thorow's bonds had been taken, and that he refused to transfer the Sergeants implicated, according to Doherty's story.
LONDON, July 28 -- Several morning dallies print this dispatch from Tien-Tsin:

The question, of reducing the rate on interchanged freight cars from three-quarters of a cent to halt a cent a mile was discussed at a large meeting of railroad managers in the offices of the Trunk Line Association yesterday. Nearly all of the lines in the Central Traffic Association, the Trunk Line Association, and the New-England Association were represented.

"What's Martin going to do about it?" was the question asked everywhere yesterday when the sentence of the Police Board that Capt. Doherty and Policemen Hock and Meehan be dismissed from the police force was discussed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 -- The market was irregular. There were orders in only a very few stocks, and most of them seemed to be to sell. This was especially evident in Metropolitan. It opened nominally 119 bid, but the first sale was at 118 1/3. It then dropped to 117 1/2, and 100 shares changed hands at that.

Two little unattended tots, bearing tags which announced that they were Eliza and Elvira Gardner, nine and seven years old, respectively, were steerage passengers of the steamship Persia, which arrived at this port from Hamburg yesterday. They are on their way to join their father and mother in Cleveland, Ohio.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27 -- Five races remained on the programme of the grand circuit meeting from yesterday, and as only three of them were taken up this afternoon, the horses will be kept here till Saturday. The free-for-all pacers were the stars for to-day, and they furnished enough sensations to reward the big crowd for its continued patronage.

As was expected, F.N. Jessup turned up as the winner of the scratch singles of the South Orange Field Club's annual club tournament yesterday afternoon. By his victory over Holcombe Ward in the final round, he obtained the right to challenge Stanley Ward, the present holder of the club championship, for the cup and champion's title.

The funeral of George Montague, President of the Second National Bank and exTreasurer of the Union League Club, took place yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of Zion and St. Timothy in West Fifty-seventh Street. The services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Mottet of the Church of the Holy Communion, assisted by the Rev. Dr.. Tiffany and the Rev. Carl Schwartz.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27 -- Ex-United States Senator Warner Miller was at the United States Hotel here to-day. He is looking very much improved in health, and in response to a request for his views on the political situation, he made some very interesting observations.

The race meet of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs at Manhattan Field this afternoon promises unusually fine sport. There will be no Class B events, every race being for pure amateurs. The sport will begin at 2 and will be preceded by a band concert that should attract an early crowd.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Commissioner of Labor, Carroll D. Wright, has forwarded to the President his seventh, special report, which relates entirely to the slums of New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Chicago, being the results of an investigation ordered by Congress.

James Casey, the owner of Bushranger, who ran second to Prank Beard's Jumper St. Anthony, on Tuesday, was greeted with an unpleasant surprise yesterday, when Secretary Henry Buck of the Steeplechase Hunt and Pony Racing Association, to which all matters relative to hurdle races and steeplechases are referred, announced to him that he had been ruled off the turf for violation of Rule 161, Section 2 of the Rules of Racing.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- It is understood that the nomination of Edward J. Taylor, nominated to be Collector of Customs for the District of Niagara, is to be unfavorably reported from the Senate Committee on Commerce.

The steamship Saginaw, which yesterday arrived from San Domingo, brought her usual budget of revolutionary doings in that republic. There has been another conspiracy to slaughter President Heureaux, led, as is customary, by very young men. The conspiracy failed. The ringleader was shot, and his ten confederates, were warned to mend their ways, and were then set free.

"Botany should be ranked as an out-of-door sport," said Mrs. Sidney Rosenfeld at the Professional Woman's League yesterday afternoon. The industry of the little , busy bee improving each shining hour is not to be compared to that of members of the league when they take up serious topics during the hot weather.

The two days' trotting meeting of the Parkway Driving Club opened with three interesting races yesterday. The 3:00 class was prolonged to seven heats when it should have been won in three heats by the Brooklyn mare Meander. Starting favorite, she landed the opening round in the hollowest possible style, and would have shut out half the field if the distance judge had been at his post.
GRAND FORKS, N.D., July 27 -- The Democratic State Convention last night voted for fusion in part with the Populists. The vote was 166 to 81.

David Wenig's arrest at 103 Lewis Street, New-York, on Tuesday night last by Detective Zundt of Brooklyn promises to cause some interesting developments before the matter is settled in court. It has been stated on good authority that when Police Inspector Mackellar returns from his vacation he will end the scandal.

BOSTON, July 27 -- The feature of to-day's market as far as local securities go was the sensational decline in Boston Gas seconds, which opened at 55, 1 below last night's close; dropped 1/2 point at a time until they reached 53, and then sold at 50, with no intermediate quotations, and closed at 50 1/2. The stock declined 3/4, to 5 3/4.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27 -- Philip J. Dwyer. President of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, was this afternoon served with a summons in the suit brought against him for slander by David Gideon, damages being fixed at $50,000. The papers were served at the race track, and Mr. Dwyer at once retained ex-Senator P.H. McCarren of Brooklyn to defend the suit, the Senator being seated in the box with Mr. Dwyer when the papers were served.

Bradstreet's will say to-day: "Leading influences affecting the course of general trade throughout the United States within the week have not resulted in a net grain. Prolonged drought and hot winds have damaged corn and other crops in Nebraska, and fears are entertained of like losses in Kansas.

ON BOARD CRUISER NEW-YORK, OFF FISHER'S ISLAND, July 27 -- Able seamen ruled the deck of the big cruiser -- at least their portion of it -- last evening until an hour past the usual time for piping down. The occasion was a concert by the Naval Battalion.

SARATOGA, July 27 -- A feature of the racing here every Summer is the annual lawn party held at the race course. This year the management has arranged to hold the party on Saturday, Aug. 11. Gov. Flower, with a number of the members of his military staff, and several of the State officers have promised to be present.
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27 -- Thinking Democrats who are alive to recent political events and their significance are beginning to consider the value and power of party harmony.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 27 -- A succession, of disasters overwhelmed the prosecution to-day in the reformatory investigation. Nearly every one of their witnesses did them injury instead of strengthening their case. The commission adjourned to-day until Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The extent to which war is now flagrant between China and Japan is not clearly settled by any dispatches that have thus far been received either at the State or Navy Department or by any of the foreign diplomats. One difficulty in the way of obtaining accurate information is the entire interruption of cable communication with Corea.
According to a dispatch from Springfield, Mass., when the steamship Lucania sails out of New-York Harbor this morning she will carry off a King.

The Supreme Court, General Term, yesterday refused the application of John Y. McKane for a new trial. Justice Landon wrote the opinion and Justices Brown and Dykman concurred. The decision affirms the convictoin and sentence of the lower court.

The Senate Tariff bill gives protection to the Sugar Trust by three distinct provisions -- By the ad-valorem rate, which carries protection amounting to about 1/4 of a cent a pound, or 25 cents per hundred; by the specific duty of 1-10 of a cent on sugars from bounty-paying countries; and by the specific duty of 1/3 of a cent, openly added for the benefit of the combination.

Such treatment of rebate payments as has been disclosed in the case of the Atchison Railroad Company is very properly condemned because it misleads stockholders and others who desire to invest money in railroad stocks as to the real earnings of a railroad corporation and the real value of its securities as indicated by its earnings.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 28 -- The sentiment uttered by Col. G.T. Denison at the imperial federation meeting in London, England, is emphatically repudiated by the Canadian press.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 28 -- Mystic is filled to overflowing with Summer guests, including many prominent people from New-York and Brooklyn. Life here is continuous pleasure. One of the pleasantest cruises of the week was a trip made by a party of forty across the Sound to Shelter Island on the tug Westerly, which was chartered for the occasion.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. Augustus D. Shepard of the Gables, in East Front Street, are at Asbury Park.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 28 -- It would be difficult to find a more cosmopolitan gathering than the thousands assembled here. The midsummer season is providing for everybody abundance of amusement. The finest weather embellishes the daily round of events. The arrivals are unusually numerous.

The late Ma Ju-lung was formerly Commander in Chief in Yunnan. A memorial was presented to the Emperor by certain local notabilities, stating his good works, and praying that posthumous honors might be conferred on him. He had distinguished himself in the great Mohammedan rebellion of May, 1870.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Army medical officers are greatly exercised over the proposed reduction of their corps. The House insisted on lopping off thirty Assistant Surgeons, while the Senate agreed to maintain the department at its present strength. The result, in conference, was the agreement to decrease the number of Assistant Surgeons by fifteen.

From The Cincinnati Enquirer. Five monkeys escaped from their cage at Kohl Middleton's Museum on Monday. They went in different directions at one time and out of as many windows, while Joe, their keeper, after vainly trying in sections to head off the scudding scamps, let out a steam-thrasher yell for help, and the entire force of men hired by Manager Avery responded.

A chief who sat at the foot or the -- well, the board -- after proposing the health of "Tusitala," (the teller of stories, Mr. Stevenson,) who replied in a few kindly words to his island friends, commenced the function of sending round the kava. He would make no mistake about the order in which it should he served.

As a subject for serious consideration the thrift has given place the past few days to the condition of the corn crop, The average operator in either the stock or grain markets has about abandoned the effort to fathom the depths at which wheat will touch bottom. He is prepared for anything in that direction, and has lost the capacity for surprise.

Its principal food consists of the flesh of seal and walrus, but it also condescends to the carcases of whales, the larger kinds of fish, and other aquatic animals, and even, for want of anything better, to marine vegetables. It wanders about continually in search of seal, generally against the wind, as it has a good nose.

ALBANY, July 28 -- The aggregate resources of the twenty-six trust companies doing business in New-York City and Brooklyn on July 1, as shown by their reports to the State Superintendent of Banks, were greater by $6,076,659 than they were on Jan. 1 last. The total on Jan. 1 was $327,735,279, and on July 1, $333,811,938.
Said William Brookfield to Henry Grasse two days ago:

The wildest of wild hogs live both above and below Yuma, on the Colorado River. While the steamer was lying at Castle Dome landing a few days since, loading with ore, a fine band of them on the opposite shore came down to the river to feed on the banks, where the grass and weeds were green, and to get a drink of water.

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 28 -- The Canadian Pacific steamship Empress of India, from Hongkong and Yokohama, arrived last evening. She brings advices which indicate that the war now declared between China and Japan is very popular in the latter country.

It was about the middle of last August that a party of three, consisting of Henry Keller, Max Verner, and the writer, all veteran sportsmen, left Los Angeles for a hunting trip in the northwestern country, which it was estimated would occupy something more than two months. It is a long journey from Los Angeles to Montana, even as journeys go in this great country.

WALTHAM, July 28 -- At the track here this afternoon Harry Tyler made two attempts to break Bliss's existing record for the flying-start mile. He was not successful in his first attempt, going the distance in 1:55 3-5. His times for the two-thirds and three-quarters were as follows: 1:14 1-5; 1:24 1-5. These are world's marks. His second attempt was stopped by his colliding with the rear wheel of his pacers' tandem.

In Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable, I find that the letters W N S E used to be prefixed to newspapers to show that they obtained information from the four quarters of the world. The learned editor says the supposition that our word news is thence derived, though ingenious, is erroneous, because the old-fashioned spelling, viz., "newes," is fatal to the conceit.

It was an unhappy day for the South Sea Islanders when they were discovered by the civilized races. Up to that time the islands were populous and the islanders were healthy and strong. But the white man no sooner discovered the South Sea Islands than he began to kill off the inhabitants with his vices and his virtues.
If the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild, that model of modern charities, could possibly enlarge its work, it would do so now.

On the motion in the Senate last Friday to lay on the table Mr. Washburn's appeal from the decision of the Chair concerning his amendment calling for the withdrawal of the differential duty of one-eighth of a cent a pound on refined sugar, there was a tie, (32 to 32,) and the motion was lost.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 28 -- The midsummer rush seems to be increasing every day, and the railroads running to this city have Increased the number of trains to accommodate the crowds. There were 30,000 people in town last Saturday and Sunday, and every indication points to at least 50,000 arriving to-day and to-morrow.

WATCH HILL, R.I., July 28 -- While humanity in the cities and those who selected Summer resorts in the interior are wrestling, with the heat that threatens out and out cremation, those wise mortals who fled to Watch Hill at the first sizzle have not ceased to rejoice over the good fortune that guided their footsteps to this land of cool breezes, healthful air, and pretty girls.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- The United Press correspondent at Honolulu, writing under date of July 21, per steamer Australia, which arrived this morning, says politics are very quiet. All parties appear to accept the republic as an established Government and to acquiesce in the fact that the Queen's is a lost cause.

TAMWORTH, N.H., July 28 -- This charming vale is growing in popularity every year. Not only the hotels, but the farms are accommodating guests from everywhere. Among the boarders are a party of teachers from Ohio, and the visiters in the hotels are from every section in the country.

The last few weeks have produced a marked difference in the duration of the day as compared with the latter part of June. The places of the sun's rising, culmination, and setting are further to the south than they were five or six weeks ago, and the movement in that direction is continuous. Summer is, however, still to be enjoyed, as we can yet feel the sunshine throbbing on body and limb.

Nelson once saw an American squadron in European waters. Whether it was Capt. Richard Dale's squadron, in 1801, Capt. Richard Valentine Morris's squadron in 1802-3, or Capt. Edward Preble's squadron in 1803, I do not know, but it is said that the great chief paid much attention to the vessels, and that his verdict was: "There is in the handling of those transatlantic Ships a nucleus of trouble for the navy of Great Britain."

Cromwell's unparalleled rise to supreme power and the moral questions that strange rise suggests; the question whether his religious professions were sincere and his intentions in life upright; these we have found interesting, partly because they do not require us to travel beyond our insular frontiers.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 28 -- The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, under the management of Mr. George Bullock, ably assisted by the other members of the House Committee, shows a determination not to let life at this famous place become dull. This is proves by the large number of yachts in the harbor.

Workmen have been busily engaged for several weeks in excavating a large plot of ground at Schermerhorn Street and Third Avenue, Brooklyn, for the foundations of the new building for the First Baptist Church, of which the Rev. Cortland Myers is pastor. The new structure will be known as the Temple.

President William Harkness of the Brooklyn Department of Assessment yesterday submitted his report to Mayor Schieren. The total assessed valuation of real estate, not including that in the recently acquired county towns, is $501,647,301. The valuation of personal property is $23,360.085. There is an increase over last year of $15,115,795 in real estate, and $2,836,915 in personal estate.

Prince Roland Bonaparte, writes the Paris correspondent of The London Daily News, is building a splendid and spacious palace in the Avenue d'Iena. His garden is contiguous to the villa built by the late M. Grevy. The future residence of Roland Bonaparte is, structurally speaking, nearly finished.

LONDON, July 28 -- An official of the Chinese Embassy in London was interviewed this evening regarding the Corean imbroglio. He said that the report of the declaration of war between China and Japan was likely to be soon confirmed, but the fighting was not likely to be of long duration.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., July 28 -- The last week of July at Shelter Island brought lovely weather and a number of changes in guests. A few of the visitors leave this week for the mountains, but a large number of new-comers has arrived to take the place of the departing ones.

Mr. Cattery -- Mr. President: In view of the revelations which were made here yesterday it is not forbidden to me to disclose the secrets of my little prison house. The Louisiana Senators have been made the common target for the taunts of Republicans and the shot of our own side. We have been pointed at as the bete noire of the bill.

John W. Goff, the senior counsel for the Lexow committee, and Louis J. Grant of counsel for exCapt. Doherty and ex-Policemen and Ward Men Hock and Meehan were companions for four hours on Friday night.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 28 -- A reception was given in Willard Hall on Tuesday evening by the Woman's Christian Temperance Union. J.G. Van Cise, the lightning calculator, gave an exhibition of his skill, Miss Mary Brown played the violin, and Miss Marie Dodd selections on the piano.

Not long ago Miss Emma Thursby, in the course of a conversation with a Times representative on other subjects, spoke of the matter of children taking up the study of music. She referred to seeing children at the musical congress in Chicago. They studied by numbers instead of notes and, though they were very young, ranging in years from six up, and had been studying only a very short time, their proficiency was remarkable.

It took the combined efforts of six policemen, early yesterday morning, to subdue John Otto, a porter, twenty-six years old, who was crazed with drink, and he was severely clubbed. Otto was taken to Bellevue Hospital to have his wounds dressed, and the policemen were plastered up at the station.

As C.C. Bettes, the druggist, was walking home Monday night, he saw something on the sidewalk which he took for a brick. Mr. Bettes is a cyclist, and he was thoughtful enough to endeavor to remove the obstruction, which might cause some wheelman to come to grief, so he stopped and attempted to shove the brick off the walK with his foot.

At Berkeley Oval yesterday the Morris Heights and Victoria Clubs met for the second time this season in the championship series of the Metropolitan District Cricket League, and as on the former occasion, the home team came out victorious, this time by a margin of 26 runs.

Concurrent with the recent coming home Charles A. Dana have come also several European newspapers alluding in terms of unusual compliment to his exhaustive tour of observation in new fields of that ancient continent.

KAATERSKILL HOTEL, N.Y., July 28 -- The event of the present season at this delightful home near the clouds was the opening ball in the magnificent ballroom, connected with the hotel. The Kaaterskill is now entertaining about 500 guests, and among these are many charming and beautiful young women.

The Constitutional amendment for "Home rule" in cities, proposed by the Committee of Twenty-one of the municipal reform organizations of the State, provides that in cities of move than 800,000 inhabitants "the members of the Common Council shall be elected on a general ticket from the whole city, and in such manner that there shall be minority or proportional representation in such Council."

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 28 -- The season has thus far been a most successful one for the Summer resorts in this vicinity. It is a good many years since the Pequot House had as many guests as it has to-day. The rush set in during the week of the Yale-Harvard boat race on the river, and it has continued to date.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- The intense heat has driven many of the brokers out of town, and every one that is missing helps to increase the extreme dullness. No stock was active to-day, but quotations were made in a few. United Gas continues to advance, and must ultimately sell higher. It sold above 90 some years ago.

ELBERON, N.J., July 28 -- Preparations are making here for the big annual ball which will take place at the Elberon in August. This is always one of the swellest Summer affairs along the Jersey coast. Many prominent families of New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, and Baltimore are represented, and from Washington a large delegation from the Diplomatic Corps usually comes.

Four members of a German family who subsisted almost entirely for three months on bologna sausage, are in the Fordham Hospital suffering with trichinosis in its secondary stage. Their chances of recovery are not considered good.

It was in 1810 that Combe was first introduced to Ackermann. Ackermann was a German who came over to England to draw designs for coach builders, and about 1796 opened a print shop, first at 96 and afterward at 101 Strand, there ultimately becoming one of the most famous of London publishers.

MILWAUKEE, July 28 -- The fires in the forests are still burning, but some rain fell last night, and the fires are not spreading.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 28 -- The fraternity of the Beta Theta Pi's fifty-fifth annual national convention adjourned at noon to-day. Chicago was scheduled for the next convention, to be held the last week in July, 1895.
MADISON, July 28 -- The following telegram was received to-day at the Executive Office from Clarence Snyder of the state Board of Control, who is at Phillips:

ASHLAND, July 28 -- Northern Wisconsin is being swept by the worst forest fires in the history of the State. The losses already amount to millions of dollars, and unless rain falls speedily this enormous loss will be multiplied.

Three trolley-car accidents, one fatal, occurred in Brooklyn yesterday. George Hicks, three years old, of 41 Front Street, was killed by trolley car No. 419 on Front Street last night. The car was in charge of Motorman E.R. Underhill of 242 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. The boy was knocked down by the fender of the car and a wheel passed over his Chest. Underhill was arrested.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 28 -- These Springs have attained a wonderful reputation since the erection of the beautiful new bathhouse. While the waters have always been efficacious, formerly the means of using them was so primitive that nearly every one preferred going to Alx or Carlsbad.

It is an interesting campaign which is being carried on in Illinois, in the matter of the women nominees for the Trusteeship of the State University. Prohibitionists, as well as Democrats and Republicans, have nominated women for this office, and the respective claims of Mrs. Atkinson, Dr. Julia Holmes Smith, and Mrs. J.M. Flower -- the candidates -- are being earnestly urged.

MAYNARD, Mass., July 28. --James Mulligan of "Mulligan letters" fame, who figured prominently in the political career of the late James G. Blaine, died here this morning of general debility. He was well known for many years in financial circles in Boston.

The modest little trotting meeting of the Parkway Driving Club, which came to an end yesterday, was one of the most successful affairs of the season in the neighborhood of New-York. All the races were liberally patronized by local trainers and road riders, the slow classes in particular having brought out the largest fields seen in recent times at any of the neighboring tracks.

Among the people, numbering an indefinite number of millions, New-York City supplying one or two millions of them and the rest of the world the others, who have a direct personal interest in the establishment of some system that will furnish a really rapid method of getting from one end of the city to another is Mr. Jesse W. Reno.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 28 -- The season is one of the most prosperous that Nantucket has ever had. The majority of the guests are wealthy Western and Southern people. The local liverymen are reaping a harvest, for, since the railroad was destroyed last season in the storm, the only way of getting to 'Sconset is by carriage.

People who are not pecuniarily interested in play making and play acting are not thinking much about the theatre nowadays. But in spite of the midsummer dullness, the beginning of the theatrical season is near at hand. The distinction made in the theatrical trade between seasons regular and seasons preliminary need not bother playgoers.

In no country is education more highly esteemed than in China. The child of the working man as a rule cannot hope to get more than a mere smattering. But scattered through the country are numberless families, the members or which for generation after generation are always students, and from whom as a rule the officials come.

There is a story of a French dog whose breakfast was forgotten, whereupon he ran out into the garden, and returning with a sprig in his mouth, deposited it at his master's feet. It was a sprig of forget-me-not. The truth of this story is perhaps open to question, but a story almost as remarkable has been furnished to Cassell's Saturday Journal by a gentleman whose veracity is said to be undoubted.

LONDON, July 28, [Copyright, 1894] -- The slight hardening of money rates reported last week has not been maintained, owing to the enormous" supplies of money wanting employment. The harvest and holiday requirements will absorb some in the course of a few days, but not sufficient to reduce the supply to any extent.

ROME, July 28 -- The trial of Signer Tanlongo, ex-President of the Banca Romana, and the other officials of that institution who were accused of fraudulent practices, was concluded to-day, the jury bringing in a verdict of acquittal. The verdict was received with applause by the spectators in the courtroom, and the defendants were at once set at liberty.

NEWARK, N.J., July 28 -- The matinee trot of the Mutual Driving Association took place this afternoon at Waverly Park before about 1,000 interested spectators. The most interesting event of the afternoon was the finishing of the 2:30 trot of last Saturday. Reverlie won the deciding heat, but, to prolong the racing, the five horses in the race were brought out for another race, which was won by St. Albans in two straight heats.

An official connected with one of the big express companies is authority for the statement that his company is doing about one-half the business that it does ordinarily in Summer in handling travelers' luggage, and also that, instead of coming in bulk the latter part of June and just before the Fourth of July, as usual, what is doing has dragged along over a number of weeks.

ORANGE, N.J., July 28 -- This city is to enjoy additional fire protection in the near future, for plans have just been prepared and work will begin at once upon a new and cammodious hosehouse in Washington Street, opposite North Centre Street, in the Fifth Ward, and is a most advantageous locality for that portion of the city.

Here is as sombre and gruesome a tale as one might look for from a pesthouse. George Moore ranks Stevenson far below Poe, and in so doing, as his opinion of their relative merits is purely a personal opinion, merely suggests a comparison between them. This "Ebb Tide" is to the best work of the author of "An Inland Voyage " and "Kidnapped" as Poe's narrative of "Arthur Gordon Pym" is to his finest creations.

Probably the chief anticipated delight of every boy starting on his Summer outing is that of swimming if he can, of learning if he cannot, of bathing if that is his limitation, or even of wading, if only a little brook is his waiter privilege. Boys take to water like ducks, and with a little rational caution there is no reason why he should not be permitted to indulge in this favorite sport.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Joseph O. Curry, late President of the defunct Chemical National Bank, stands accused in a bill filed by Receiver Eli C. Tourtelot of wrongfully converting to his own use large sums of money. He is also charged with gross carelessness in making big loans to insolvent borrowers.

In the cold-storage warehouses of Plttsburg there were no rats or mice. The temperature in the cold rooms was too low. The keepers soon found, however, that the rat is an animal of remarkable adaptability. After some of these houses had been in operation for a few months the attendants found that rats were at work in the rooms where the temperature was constantly kept below the freezing point.

Business was quiet enough yesterday, but still there was a fair amount done for a midsummer Saturday. The opening was dull and irregular, with some pressure from London on Union Pacific and St. Paul. Sugar was well held by insiders, but it was thought that there was some profit taking by people on the long side.
