"Dogs have most acute ears in detecting differences to the quality of sound," said a musician recently. "I have at home a large Newfoundland that is a great lover of music. No matter in what portion of the house he may be, he always comes to me when I begin to play, lying close to the piano.

The cables of the Western Union Telegraph Company, the Postal Telegraph Company, the Commercial Cable Company, and the Gold Stock Company have been frequently cut recently and the service of the company has been seriously interfered with.

FLUSHING, N.I., July 28 -- There was more excitement on the shores of Flushing Bay this afternoon than there has been at any other period during the Summer. The occasion was the ninth annual regatta of me Long Island Rowing Association. The day was bright and clear, the sun oppressively hot, and scarcely a breath of air was stirring.

The Hagenbeck trained animals are fast growing in popularity at their headquarters at Manhattan Beach, and several times during the past week the arena has been crowded to its capacity. The daring of the various trainers of the wild animals is nothing short of marvelous, and it is a well-known fact that they take their lives in their hands at every performance.

BERLIN, July 28 -- The weather has been so fine for the past ten days that Emperor William has decided to extend his yachting cruise northward. Prof. Guessfeldt, his tutor in geology, accompanies him whenever lands, and helps him in his studies of the formation of Norwegian rocks. Guessfeldt wrote to a friend here this week an interestind description of an evening aboard the Imperial yacht Hohenzollern.

What should prove to be the most auspicious rowing regatta of the year will be the twenty-second annual set of races of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, on Aug. 10 and 11. Saratoga Lake has again been selected as the most desirable course for these contests, and with a liberal representation in the eight events, the best aquatic sport of the season should result.

DEAL, BEACH, N.J. July 28 -- Progressive euchre is all the rage. The prizes are expensive Then there is the ever-popular sport of crabbing. For this Shark River and Pleasure Bay are the objective points, and the proper thing is to hire a couple of stages, have lunch, and then go for the noble crab.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Two bright young naval officers will deliver the technical lectures this year before the student officers at the Naval War College at Newport. Naval Constructor Capps, who was for a time on duty at the Brooklyn Yard, will deliver a series of lectures on naval architecture.

There is a complicated fight going on in the Socialist-Labor Party and the order of Knights of Labor in this city, which may be far-reaching in its results, and may produce some effect in the next General Assembly of the Knights of Labor, where it is expected that Sovereign and Terence V. Powderly will make a great struggle for the office of General Master Workman.

DOLGEVILLE, JUly 28 -- The twenty-fifth turnfest of the Western New-York district closed to-night with a general Jollification and a dance at the picturesque High Falls Park. The affair has been the most successful of its kind ever held in the State. Some of the turnvereins left for home to-night; others will leave in the morning, but the popular Buffaloans will remain until Monday.
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 28 -- The suggestion of party unity presented in The New-York Times this morning already finds a responsive echo among Democrats who have been more or less prominent in politics.

ADELAIDE, South Australia, June 1 -- The traveler northward through the colony of South Australia, or in the country beyond Bourke, the furthest railway station of New South Wales, speedily becomes familiar with a spectacle that at first seemed extraordinary -- that of trains of camels solemnly swinging across the plains, conducted by swarthy Orientals clad in many-colored garments and wearing huge turbans of snowy linen.

These days of Summer bring great fishing to the Jersey shores. Off Barnegat the big blueflsh are running in large numbers, and scores of boats sail over the shoals with parties trolling, while others are anchored in favorite eddies and tideways, where the anglers "chum" the blues and enjoy still fishing with a rod.

BAR HARBOR, July 28 -- This is about the time when the people who are interested in Summer resorts are asking themselves whether or not the season is a success, and if a success, how much of a success. They have been asking this question at Bar Harbor, but as yet have not answered it to their satisfaction.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- An attempt was made shortly after midnight to wreck a Burlington engine by exploding a dynamite bomb under the wheels. Two men were seriously injured:

-- The family of Dawson Kline, a farmer, consisting of father, mother, and son, living near Briceton, Ohio, were poisoned by drinking water from a well near the house in which a large package of poison had been placed, it is supposed, by a malicious neighbor who had a grievance against Kline.

BAY SHORE, N.Y., July 28 -- The seventh annual regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Club took place off Islip to-day. The signal gun was fired by Alden S. Swan of Brooklyn at 11 o'clock. The boats got ready and crossed the line close together. The course was twenty miles. The first leg was west through the bay for five miles and back, and repeat.
Libraries are not to be excepted from the evolutionary law. Book lovers who have analyzed their minds and are sincere have not the slightest enthusiasm for any such theory.

BOSTON, July 28 -- Dullness and general apathy ruled to-day as far as local stocks were concerned. The only gossip was the old rumor received that the Boston and Maine is about to absorb the Boston, Revere Beach and Lynn. The former obtained control some years ago, paying as high as 190 for part of the stock, which has sold in the last few months around 88.

Commissioner White of the Department of City Works, Brooklyn, who has been working hard since he took office to secure for Brooklyn an adequate supply of water, is to have a conference with Jesse Johnson, Chairman of the Committee on Cities of the Constitutional Convention, in regard to the latter's proposed amendment in reference to the water supply of Brooklyn.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., July 28 -- The past week has not been a cheerful one here. The island was shrouded in fog and rain, which made life cut of doors unpleasant. The cottagers on the bluffs overlooking the water suffered from the cold and dampness. But now the sun has come out, August promises to be gay, and everybody is happy.
Col. H.H. Hadley celebrated the eighth anniversary of his conversion from a drunkard's life at the St. Bartholomew Rescue Mission, Forty-second Street and Third Avenue, last night.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., July 28 -- This has been a gala night at Halcyon Hall. Those who were at the opening last Fall of witnessed the closing festivities Thanksgiving week will long remember the constant delights and surprises with which these occasions were fraught. But to-night has had its own peculiar charms. Dancing began at 9:30 o'clock. It was a festival of flowers, each lady impersonating some blossom.

Before the Court of Cassation yesterday a story was told which shows that the terrible vendetta of past days still exists in some parts of Dalmatia. At Pado, near Cattaro, the brothers Pero and Grosto Gjokonowicz and one Jovo Bozovicz were neighbors. A trifle made them bitter enemies, Bozovicz's goats grazed on the brothers' land, and much quarreling followed.
Surrogate Fitzgerald has denied Mrs. Paran Stevens's application to remove John L. Melcher from the executorship of the Stevene estate which was announced some time ago in the papers.
What's the country made for but to yell in? You yell in the city and you get yanked right in. Free country! I don't think."

Probably this compact summary of the great Indian poems will find favor with the various clubs that have sprung up during the latter part of this century devoted to very modern phases of ancient beliefs and philosophies. There is in it a good deal of information of the sort appealing to those who have neither the time nor the love of research necessary to burrowing in the past in pursuit of personal impressions.

With a decided lack of display, the marriage of Miss Caroline Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel S. Jones of Chicago, and the Viscount Benoist d'Azy of France, was celebrated yesterday morning, in the Church of St. Catherine of Genoa, in One Hundred and Fifty-third Street, near the Boulevard.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 28 -- Two or three things have been decided during the month that will have an interesting bearing on the Fall campaign, particularly with reference to the Republicans.

Police Inspector John Mackellar of the Brooklyn Police Department has returned from his vacation. He was at Police Headquarters yesterday. He was asked concerning the arrest of David Wenig by Detective George Zundt last Tuesday night on the charge of extortion.

Horatio Henriques, a real estate broker, sixty-eight years old, shot himself in the head shortly after 6 o'clock last evening in his office, 62 Liberty Street. He was taken to Chambers Street Hospital, Where it was said he would recover.

Racing at Brighton Beach yesterday was conducted under trying circumstances to the patrons of the track, for, although so near the cool ocean, not a breath of air was stirring. The heat in the grand stand was oppressive, and in the betting ring the speculative public sweltered in perspiration and made feeble attempts to appear lively.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- One of the attaches of the Japanese Legation says the published story that the position of the Japanese residents in Shanghai la precarious, and that they are leaving the city, is inaccurate. He says the Japanese, together with the other foreign residents of Shaghai, live in a place separated from the native city, and are guarded by Sikh police amply numerous to protect them.

SING SING, N.Y., July 23 -- Ancient records, bringing to mind the almost forgotten names of persons who came upon the stage of active life, played their parts, and then retired, are occasionally found among the odds and ends of things piled away in heaps in the attic, not thought to be of any further use in mundane affairs.

The Dark Continent is now nothing like its name. We know it almost from end to end, and side to side, along each of its lines of longitude and parallels of latitude. True, Rider Haggard has civilly tried to cheer us back into the old paths of eerie belief; but though he does well in the matter, and gives us momentary thrills, he falls to convince us.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Eighteen enlisted men will this year be examined at Fort Leavenworth in September for the commission of Second Lieutenant. It is always an important matter, this one of examining men from the ranks for places among the commissioned officers. Each year young men who stand no chance of being appointed to West Point enlist in the ranks of the army and serve the required period.

ST. JOHN'S, July 28 -- The steamer Miranda, with the Cook arctic expedition, resumed her voyage to Greenland at 10 o'clock to-night, all her repairs having been completed this afternoon. The weather is very disagreeable, being marred both by rain and fog. The Miranda will not make much headway before daylight, owing to the necessity of avoiding icebergs, which are still numerous along the Newfoundland coast.

Cotton, though largely produced in the tropics, comes in far larger quantity from temperate climates. In 1891 the United States exported in quantity 2,907,359,000 pounds, valued at $290,713,000, or nearly u60,000,000, and Egypt exported a quantity of the value of about u9,000,000, while the export of tropical India was in quantity only 536,390,512 pounds, valued at u12,743,679, the contributions of the rest of the world being comparatively insignificant.
ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, July 28 -- During the last week Arverne has been in effervescence under the combined influences of incomparable weather and new arrivals.

Otto Oesterle, whose death on the 25th inst. was briefly noticed, was one of the best-known musicians in this city. He was born in St. Louis, Mo., in 1861. At fifteen years of age he held the highest rank as a flute soloist in Chicago. Later he Joined the Mapleson Opera Company in its Western tour, whence, coming to New-York, he joined Theodore Thomas's orchestra, where he remained nine years.

The New-York Times's dispatches from Saratoga yesterday, in which the probability of harmonious action by all factions of the Democratic Party in this State was set forth, were said yesterday to present the Situation accurately.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 23. -- The great event of the week was the ball at the West End Thursday night. Everybody was there and had a good time. It far sur- passed last year's event. The costumes were beautiful and the scene brilliant. Now the one subject of discussion is the coming horse show at Elkwood Park.

May Parker, a fortune teller, was found dead at 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon at 224 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, where she had lived for the past eleven months with her husband, F. Parker, an agent for a scale company.

At the Brooklyn Maternity, 46 and 48 Concord Street, Brooklyn, they are very wise about babies and baby lore. From ten to twelve little crimson-faced atoms of humanity are ushered into existence there every month. If only a sixteenth of them grow up to be Governors, Mayors, Aldermen, woman suffrage leaders, or any other bright and shining lights, the old building on Concord Street will be one of the most famous in the city.

The grown-up people of the town of Nutley, N.J., regard the fine new schoolhouse which they have just had built in their little park with an amount of pride that evens up very well with the $26,500 that the structure cost them. It has three stories and eight classrooms, in which the three grades -- primary, grammar, and high -- will find ample accommodation for some time to come.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 28 -- The people of the metropolis and many of its lesser sisters are all on the wing, If one can judge, that is, by the fact that this place literally swarms with pleasure seekers. Last week The Times had a story about Racquette Lake and the beauties of nature there and thereabout.

The fourth race of the series for twentyone-footers will be sailed off Larchmont next Saturday afternoon, and the owners of these small boats will add some more points to their scores for the cups offered by Commodore Husted, the Larchmont Yacht Club, and W. Gould Brokaw, and for the marine glasses given by The New-York Times.

Some time since two residents of Northville started off on a fishing excursion among the Adirondacks. While there they met with some fine sport, which, if we are to believe most Adirondack fishermen's stories, is by no means an unusual occurrence.

A shower which passed to the west of Elkwood Park yesterday afternoon cooled the air pleasantly, but the sojourners at Long Branch evidently thought it more comfortable on their porches than at the track. There were three races on the card. The last one did not fill, and a private match was made between L. Parisetti's Ayrshire and J.B. Hall's Nora.

Teddy Dolson, the bicycle repairer, on Friday night had an experience compared with which Tam o'Shanter's famous ride pales into insignificance. Instead of the horse with which Tam was equipped, Teddy had a bicycle; in the place of the witches, that pursued and plagued and almost crazed the Scotsman, the Cheyenne man was followed by hungry coyotes.

TRENTON, July 28 -- This Pall eight Senators and sixty Assemblymen will be elected. The latter will be under the comstitutional provision that all the voters of the county shall vote for the entire Assembly delegation. District lines have been abolished by an opinion of the Supreme Court, and further secured by legislation passed during the session.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 28 -- The height of the season has been reached and society is at its best. For several weeks the pace will be rapid, and then the deer-hunting Season will be at hand.
"It got down, to 85 below zero, and --" Just then the telephone bell jingled sharply.

A most remarkable meeting was held a few days ago in the parlors of afashionable hotel in Memphis. It was a gathering of a consideable body of the city's leading women, society and philanthropically regarded, who had come in response to a call for the women interested in furthering the manufacturing interests of the city.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 28 -- To those unfortunate people who have felt the hot wave in the noisy city, the guests at this place extend sympathy. It has been very pleasant here during the week. The Summer visitors have heard through the papers about the heat breaking, or rather melting, all former records in the city and suburbs, but it did not reach this delightful retreat.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 28 -- The greatest social event of the week was the german led by Prof. Loomis, a Yale College dancing master. There were about forty persons present from the select set of Cape May's Summer society. The affair was followed by a banquet.

If any one else had told the following story of canine sagacity except the worthy Secretary of the St. Lawrence Board of Trade there would be doubts in the minds of many as to its veracity, but "Marve" vouches for it, and there is nothing to do except to believe it.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- About fifty men and women students from seventeen different States decided some time ago to make a historical pilgrimage to the different places made famous in the Revolution. A gathering in Independence Hall this morning was the outset of the "pilgrimage."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 28 -- A pretty and successful lawn party was given Tuesday afternoon and evening on the handsome grounds of George A. Pfeffer, in Ralph Street, Belleville, for the benefit of the Fresh Air Fund. The various booths were in charge of Miss Irene Dunbar, Miss Eva Wadsworth, Miss Effie Scott, Miss Jennie Reeves, Miss Florence Leighton, Miss Marie Minion, and Miss Sadie Mapes.
We find in The Financial Chronicle, a journal for the opinion and character of which we have always great respect, the following with reference to the tariff:

In beginning these random recollections Mr. Fowler Indorses Walter Besant's ideas in regard to genealogies. Mr. Besant deplores the fact that the middle class in England nave no pride of ancestry. This may arise from the fact that there were once seemingly only two classes in England -- the somebodies and the nobodies.

TAMPA, Fla., July 28 -- The revenue steamer McLane, Lieut. O.S. Willey commanding, arrived at Mullet Key Quarantine Station. Tampa Bay, to-day with seven Spanish fishing schooners in tow. They were seized on the evening of the 24th inst. at Anclote Harbor for violation of the revenue laws and quarantine regulations. The following is a list of the vessels:

WEST POINT, July 28 -- Officers who have been spending their furloughs at various Summer resorts are returning to the post. They will report for duty Aug. 28. Instructions in military engineering are given daily in Fort Clinton. The construction of fascines, gabions, and other defenses are carried on in the northeast corner of the fort, near Kosclusko's monument.

TOLEDO, July 28 -- H.O. Guthrie and Britton Danbury came to Toledo from the West a short time ago. Guthrie secured a position as an operator in the Western Union office. Danbury purchased $1,700 worth of diamonds yesterday from M. Judd, and presented in payment a check on the Deseret National Bank of Salt Lake City.

DIXVILLE NOTCH, N.H., July 28 -- To one who loves nature -- wild, original, rugged nature, uncontaminated by the touch of that modern civilization which seeks to reduce everything to the level of the commonplace -- no accessible spot in New-Hampshire affords such, a joyful prospect as here everywhere abounds.

"When I looked out of my window at 8 o'clock this morning," writes Mr. W. Westall," a window which on clear days commands a view of Mont Blanc, my first impression was that I had slept full five months and been meanwhile transported to London. The mountains were blotted out and a fog shrouded Geneva.

From The New-Orleans Times-Democrat. Owney, the Railway Mall Service tramp dog, whose collar is tagged with the name of every large city in the Union, and whose travels have been more extensive than that of almost any man in America, is in NewOrleans again. His last visit here was in the Winter of 1892, long before which his reputation was well known here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- New-York and Philadelphia played the greatest game of the season here this afternoon, and the former won in the thirteenth inning. Weyhing and Meekin were the opposing pitchers when the game began, but New-York was hitting Weyhing rather too freely, and in the seventh inning Carsey took his place.

-- Narragansett Pier. -- Benjamin Wood of The New-York Daily News is at the Mathewson, Narragansett Pier. Mr. Wood, accompanied by his wife and daughter, drives every afternoon on the beach road. Miss Wood drives a beautiful span of spirited ponies, recently purchased for her by her father from Pierre Lorillard, Jr.

TRENTON, July 128 -- Colored people Of New-Jersey have suddenly recalled that the anniversary of the adoption of the Fifteenth Amendment of the Constitution has not been observed for years, and particularly in this State, and it is to be remembered in a demonstration at Mount Holly, the county seat of Burlington, on Tuesday next.

It was announced about two weeks ago that William Campbell, the millionaire wallpaper manufacturer of this city, had succumbed to the National Wall Paper Company, better known as the Wall Paper Trust, and that his plants in this city had been absorbed by that corporation.

The English have had an opportunity, this Summer, of acquainting themselves with more than one phase of American college life. They have not only seen types of our college athletes in the Yale team at Oxford, but they are learning what American college songs are, and how American college boys sing them.

The Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs held its second annual race meet at Manhattan Field yesterday, with the largest individual entry list of the season. Each event proved to be interesting, but the meeting demonstrated that no really fast work can now be accomplished on this track without running a great risk.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- The season at this resort is now at its height. All the cottages are occupied and the hotels are enjoying an excellent patronage. The recent burglaries committed in cottages here have rather alarmed the Summer population and have created the impression that the thefts are the work of local cracksmen.

BATSHORE, L. I., July 28 -- One would look long for a place more inviting than Bayshore, which is now at its gay season. The porches of the Prospect House are thronged with charming girls, and the ballroom every night is as cheerful as music and dancing can make it. Coaching is now at its height, and the Penataquit, which runs from the Prospect, has been a great success.
LONDON, July 28 -- The Cabinet has decided that the only possible course to be taken in order to secure the passage of the Evicted Tenants bill is a summary application of closure.

When Dr. Greene had left with Handel a new antnem for his opinion upon it, he told him that "it wanted air." "Air!" exclaimed its composer. "Yes, air; and so I did hang it out of de vindow," replied Handel. When the "Messiah" was being performed in Dublin, Dubourg led the band, and one evening had a close to make ad libitum.

Herr Schmelz's Senators were in good form yesterday as regards batting, but their field, work would bring a blush to the cheek of any Prospect Park amateur, and in consequence the Brooklyns won the game at Eastern Park yesterday.

Justice Parker of the Supreme Court has rendered a decision establishing the absolute ownership in the Church of the Strangers of a fund of $26,000, which was in the name of the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Deems, pastor of the church for many years, Who died in December, 1893.

Walston R. Brown, Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan, Andrew McLean of the firm of woolen merchants at 460 Broome Street, E.T. Smith, P.S. Pemberton, A.J. Appel, Charles A. Johnson, A.J. Spruter, V.M. Wilcox, Coleridge A. Hare, and Joseph Levy have organized under the State law as Directors of the Eighth Avenue Bank.

The "Fighting Fourteenth" Regiment of Brooklyn, 650 men strong, commanded by Col. Harry Michell, marched out of its armory in North Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, bound for the State camp at Peekskill.

A writer in The Pall Mall Budget wares poetic over the possibilities in cherries, confidently asserting that whatever its flavor, color alone would make the cherry a joy forever. With nature and art meeting in gentle rivalry out of the plebeian stewed cherries, the ambitious compote la evolved according to this formula:
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28 -- The weather continues to be dry here. The lawns are suffering and the public water supply is so low that the water company has published a warning.

PROVIDENCE, July 28 -- Louis Lansen, Oscar Nelson, and Albert Peterson, seamen of the schooner BeHe Worcester, were arrested here for mutiny this morning. The arrests were made at the instance of Capt. Coffin, commander of the vessel. The schooner carried a cargo of merchandise from New-York to Turk's Island, and the Captain says that, when three days out of New-York, the men grew mutlnous and refused to obey orders.

ORANGE, N.J., July 28 -- A pretty lawn party was given Wednesday evening at the home of William H. Crane in Mount Vernon Avenue by members of the Orange Dramatic Society. There was music by an orchestra, and violin solos by H.B. Jesson. The guests were received and served with refreshments by Mrs. W.A. Van Orden, Miss Nettle Crane, Miss Edna Fales, and Miss Meeker.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 28 -- Society at the islands is divided into two distinct and separate classes; one consists of those who spend the Summer or a part of it at the hotels, and the other class is composed of owners of islands. The true spirit of democracy which pervades this resort is shown in the subdivisions of each class.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 28 -- The mother and mother-in-law of Everett E. Brown, a coffee merchant, fought each other fiercely, in Justice James L. Millard's court, this morning, and spectators had a lively time separating them and their relatives, who joined in the conflict.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 28 -- Rain marred the second day of the Zig-Zag Cycle Club race meet. It fell heavily in the middle of the afternoon, but not seriously hurting the track. Sanger packed his grip, and when the rain stopped would not start in the great race of the meeting. J.P. Bliss, the record breaker, captured the big race very handily.

As a plagiarist Handel claims special attention. Other men's musical ideas crowded upon his receptive mind as lavishly as did his own, and he seems to have turned them very largely to account. A later age, with a more scrutinizing eye and analytical craze than his own, has discovered that Handel has justly entitled himself to the reputation of being a musical pirate, as bold and barefaced as was ever abroad.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 28 -- The ten days' camp meeting of the Salvation Army of the Central Division, which has been held in the National Prohibition Park Auditorium, will end to-morrow. There will be services in the morning at 11 o'clock, conducted by Brigadier Richard Evans, commanding the Central Division, and his Staff.

Two hundred patriotic Armenians, members of the Hentchakiste, or Greek Patriotic Association, organized to liberate Armenia from Turkish rule, marched through the street's of New-York last night with banners and transparencies. The banners were peaceful and quiet, and simply indicated that it was the Armenian Hentchakiste of New-York that was on parade, but the transparencies cried: "Down with the Turkish Government!" and "Hurrah for Armenian Revolution!"

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 28 -- The historical associations of this old Revolutionary town make driving in various directions edifying. Five miles to the northeast is the famous camp where Gen. Israel Putnam, with his half-frozen forces, passed a dreary Winter. To reach it one passes through some of the most charming bits of landscape in the New-England hills.

PENZANCE, July 28 -- A light and variable breeze made the American centreboarder Vigilant an easy victim for the Prince of Wales's cutter Britannia in the race off this harbor to-day. The time, considering the gentleness of the breeze, was very fast, the Britannia averaging nearly eight knots an hour.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- One of the bills that should have been brought forward earlier in the present session, and that now seems likely to be kept back until the second half, is perhaps as important to the welfare of the country, and particularly to the development of our navy, as any measure that has been suggested in many years.

The author of this book prefaces it with an ample and logical summary of its contents, which, in the beginning, offers a sore temptation to the weary reviewer to make the task of reviewing it as light as possible. But the temptation is easily resisted after he has read the opening chapter, for the style is so clear and invigorating that the mind soon loses its weariness and is refreshed.

What an utterly worthless little beast was Tubby, a bad son, a brute to his mother and father, an insincere friend, and a conceited puppy. His opinion of women was an insult to them. He gloried in a reputation for wickedness and the magnificence of his debts. He was as thick-skinned as a rhinoceros, and never felt the snub.

-- Funeral services in memory of Mrs. Frederick S. Gibbs were held at 427 West Twenty-second Street yesterday afternoon. The Rev. S. B. Ros siter of the North Presbyterian Church officiated. Among those present were Justice Meade. Gen. Among G. McCook, Assemblyman Southworth, W. H. Bellamy, Thomas L. Hamilton. Dr. H.B. King, Dr. T.K. Tuthill, William L. Turner, E. M. Fisher, G.W. Wiley, John Miller, and several members of the Republican County organiza tion.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Several reports regarding the "plague" in China have been received at the Marine Hospital Bureau. Secretary Denby of the United States Legation says that at Canton a novel and thoroughly Chinese method of checking the disease was hit upon.

The New-York Post Office Clerks' Association has petitioned the members of Congress individually to support what is known as the Post Office Clerks' Classification bill. They have sent to each member of the House a copy of the following:
Chemicals, paper stock, and soft-pine finishings fed a are in Fulton Street yesterday afternoon, to subdue which all the engine companies below Fourteenth Street and two water towers were summoned.

TRENTON, July 29. -- The bicyclists in the lower part of New-Jersey are making well-organized efforts to stir up interest for the local wheelmen as well as attract the attention of cyclers all over the State. Three "greatest meets in New-Jersey" are now on schedule, and whether they will be the greatest ever held or not in this State remains to be seen, but sufficient work will be put on them to make them interesting.

Paris Letter to The London Truth. A party of Russian students and studentesses mounted on cycles passed through Paris the other day on their way to the coast of Brittany. They sent trunks and portmanteaus with changes of raiment on before them to stations where they were to halt.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 29. -- The American League of Racing Cyclists held a most important meeting at the Denison House, in this city, to-day, and adopted a constitution and by-laws. Officers were elected as follows: M.L. Bridgeman, Boston, President; E.C. Bode. Chicago, Vice President; W.H. Kirkpatrick, Boston, Secretary and Treasurer, and a Board of Directors, consisting of the President and T.W. Eck, Minneapolis; A.L. Atkins, Chicago; W.F. Murphy, Brooklyn, and H.C. Tyler, Springfield, Mass.

PHILLIPS, July 29. -- All that is known of a certainty forty-eight hours after the destruction of this town, regarding the loss of human life, is that sixteen persons perished by fire and water in the burning of the raft on which they sought an escape from the flames on the bayou.

The Rev. John A.B. Wilson, pastor of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Church, Eighteenth Street, near Eighth Avenue, preached yesterday on "The New Departure of the Roman Catholic Church on the Temperance Question," He said that to-day, as from the first, the greatest foe of the temperance movement was the Catholic Church.

There was more than the usual gathering of roadites on the breezy piazzas of the Fleetwood Clubhouse yesterday morning, and the harness racers in training at the track were paraded and speeded as they have not been in many weeks since the record-breaking Summer weather set in.

From The London Daily News. M. Casimir-Perier, the President of the French Republic, was yesterday for nearly three hours before the cameras of a band of photographers, Parisian and provincial, who went by appointment to the Petit Bourbon, where he is still staying. Our Paris correspondent writes: "The ushers did not know the artists were expected, and began by refusing to let them into the palace with their boxes and three-legged implements.

VIENNA, July 30. -- The Politische Correspondenz prints, under a St. Petersburg date, a semi-official communication, which Says: "As far as Russia's interests are concerned, it would be better if there should be no war between China and Japan, inasmuch as the victory of neither would be of advantage to her.

BERLIN, July 29. -- The dissensions of the Ministers over the policy to be pursued toward the Anarchists have become acute. Count Botho zu Eulenburg, the Tory Premier of Prussia, leads the ministerial group which demands exceptional laws to stop the spread of Anarchic and Social Democratic propaganda. Dr. Hinzpeter, once the Emperor's tutor, is said to be exerting all his influence in favor of Eulenburg's proposals.

There is one point about the Vigllant's racing on the other side that it is good and useful to bear in mind, because of illustrates one of the most creditable of British traits. The Vigilant has been beaten frequently, and yet nobody on the other side who speaks with any authority on these matters ventures to say that the races have proved that the Britannia is very much the better boat.

It may be in the nature of a revelation to the majority of the citizens of Brooklyn when it is said that ex-Alderman James McGarry, who died on July 4, was in possession of an estate which will foot up in round numbers $1,000,000.

NEWPORT, July 29. -- The purchase of six miniature bulls and cows by Oliver H. P. Belmont attracts much attention here, especially as he will bring them to New-port next Thursday. He bought them in India while he was there last Winter with W.K. Vanderbilt, whose guest he was on the steam yacht Valiant.

PITTSFIELD, July 29. -- A serious thunderstorm passed over Pittsfield at 6 o'clock this afternoon. Lighting struck at George Castle's camp, at Onoto Lake, and killed George Castle, thirty years old, and severely shocked Charles Johnson and Charles Wagner. The three men were seated under a large tree near Castle's cottage, which is situated on the northwest side of the lake.

MANHATTAN BEACH, July 29. -- Senator Calvin S. Brice of Ohio spent to-day at Manhattan Beach. He left Washington Friday night, and said he expected to return to the capital in time to attend the session of the Senate to-morrow.

The handsome thousand-dollar silver piece that the late Commodore Colt gave last year for a race between the cup defenders is to be a perpetual challenge cup, held by the Larchmont Yacht Club. It will be raced for every Fourth of July by the class of the season, and will be held by the winning boat until the opening of the next yachting season.

FIRE ISLAND, N.Y., July 29. -- The opening ball of the season was held in the Surf Hotel last evening and was a brilliant affair. The guests of the hotel, in addition to many visitors from New-York, Brooklyn, Bay Shore, Babylon, ana vicinity, filled the parlors and danced to the music of an excellent orchestra, while cool breezes kept the temperature at a point which made dancing a pleasure.

CONEY ISLAND, July 29 -- "Gus" Tuthill, the broker who took $200 from ex-Police Captain Doherty of New-York and, according to Doherty's story, earned for him $22,000 "in the Street" in five months, quietly slipped into a hotel here at 1 o'clock this morning and engaged a room.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 29. -- The steamship Australia arrived yesterday morning, six and one half days from Honolulu, bringing Hawaiian advices to July 21. Peace prevails throughout Hawaii and the new Government appears to be firmly established.

The marKet for railway bonds for the past week has been exceptionally dull even for a midsummer period, and except for a slightly better demand for A No. 1 and short-date bonds there has been little to chronicle. Atchison securities have declined sharply on the report of an over-statement of earnings during the past few years, amounting to over $7,000,000.

When arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday Patrick Curtis described himself as a man without a home. He had on a pair of trousers which Henry Witte, a sailor of the steamship Advance, described as part of his goods and chattels. The sailorman proved his claim, and the man without a home found one in the prison in default of bail and trousers.

SHANGHAI, July 29. -- The Chinese war ship Tsao-Khan, which was captured by a Japanese war ship off the coast of Round Island, is a vessel of an obsolete model, and was poorly equipped for fighting. Although completely outmatched by the Japanese cruiser, the troop ship offered some resistance, and lost fully a hundred men, killed and wounded, before she yielded.

ALBANY, July 28. -- The local security market was as dull as the weather was hot. The Only transactions reported were sales of Municipal Gas and Hudson River Telephone stocks. The bond market was lifeless, with no changes in prices. The only event to break the monotony was the report that the savings institutions of this city would soon reduce their rate of interest from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent. per annum.

The disclosures concerning rebates paid or promised by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company -- the significance of which we pointed out immediately after the publication of the statements of Accountant Little and Secretary Kobbe -- have now become the subject of sharp comment by the press throughout the country.
There were eight deaths from the heat in this city yesterday. In Brooklyn there were four.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 28. -- The dullness in the local stock market continues and but few shares have changed hands during the week. Prices generally are weaker, although the offerings still continue light. But few sales have been reported. Providence Washington Insurance has sold at 38 1/4, a small lot of Third National Bank at 59 1/2, and Mechanics' National Bank a 52 3/4.

It was another week of hesitation and doubt in the stock market. The Atchison disclosures relative to the overstatement of the income of the company for a series of years had a disturbing influence, not only in this country, but among the foreign holders of American securities, and the latter were quite free sellers of all international stocks in the early part of the week.

From The Ephrata (Penn.) Review. Joel G. Miller of this place placed a num- ber of outlines in the Cocalico Creek, expect- ing to have a fine mess of fish toy next morning, and was considerably surprised when he learned that he had caught both a snapper and an eel on one hook: The eel weighed two pounds, and had evidently been caught first.

The first convention of the Independent Order of American Israelites was begun yesterday at 257 East Houston Street. The order, which is the first one organized under the new insurance law, has already 1,750 members. It is the outcome of a factional fight in the Order of the Sons of Benjamin which arose over the election of Register Ferdinand Levy to the office of Grand Master for the fourth successive time.

CONEY ISLAND, July 29. -- One hundred thousand persons visited Coney Island today and made a numerical record that has not been equaled this season and that was surpassed but once last year. Everything was conducted in the open, and about the only thing lacking to make the day a genuuine McKane Sunday, as far as the conduct of business was concerned, was the absence of the dethroned Czar.
LUCERNE, July 29. -- Cardinal Ledochowski died here yesterday.
It is probable that the Central Labor Union will reconsider its resolution not to dabble in politics, and will this year try again to make itseif felt as a political factor.

A full description of the powerful new French battle ship now in process of construction, and which has been rechristened Le Carnot, in honor of the dead President, is given in the current issue of The Naval and Military Record. The vessel is described as being practically a sistership to the Charles Martel, which was launched at Brest one year ago.

Our readers will find in another column a communication from the Post Office Clerks' Association to members of Congress. It requests support for the Post Office Clerks' Classification bill, and presents facts which make it plain why successive Postmasters General have favored the bill.

The question of what the Senate will do about the tariff is not half so simple as Mr. Gorman and Mr. Smith would like the House to believe. The immediately important question is: What will the conferrees do? If they have the sense and courage to agree on a bill that gives free coal and iron ore and does not give special favors to the Sugar Trust, the course of the Senate is hardly doubtful.

John Emery, thirty-eight years old, boatswain's mate of the United States cruiser Cincinnati, lying at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was so badly injured by a trolley car yesterday, that he died last night in the Brooklyn City Hospital.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 29. -- The Oneida was obliged to go to New-Bedford for coal, but is again here, the Benedicts being guests at Gray Gables to-day. The Oneida will leave for New-York in the morning.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, Showed a decrease in reserve of $2,200,875. The banks now hold $71,903,725 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $1,009,000, a decrease in specie of $401,900, a decrease in legal tenders of $3,078,400, a desrease in deposits of $5,081,700, and a decrease in circulation of $109,600.

DETROIT, Mich., July 29. -- The annual Hilsendegen twenty-five-mile bicycle road race over the Belle Isle course took place yesterday afternoon, and the world's record of 1:09:26 1-5, made over this course June 16 last by W.W. Grant of the Detroit Wheelmen, was shattered by Charles Barthol, who made the distance in 1:05:58. Twenty-five other riders also broke the world's record.

SARATOGA, July 29. -- Ever since The New-York Times told in an Albany dispatch last Winter that Mayor Gilroy would not accept a renomination, it has been the general understanding that the Mayor has been fully determined not to run.

Mrs. Robert B. Roosevelt, Jr., who was Grace Guernsey Woodhouse, only child of Lorenzo G. Woodhouse of 34 West Fifty-third Street, died yesterday at Shelter Island, of blood poisoning, the result of tonsilitis. Mrs. Roosevelt went to Shelter Island in May in perfect health.
ASBURY PARK, July 29. -- Large audiences greeted the speakers at the several services to-day in the Asbury Park Auditorium, which is situated near the beach.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 29. -- Florence Maud Sammons, a Titian-haired mite of six months, looked bravely but wonderingly to-day out of her big blue eyes at several thousand persons who were gathered in the auditorium of Prohibition Park to witness the dedication of her life to the work of the Salvation Army.

SARATOGA, July 29. -- Ex-Secretary of the Navy Tracy, who is a guest at the United States Hotel, has received information regarding the Hon. Levi P. Morton which will interest Republicans generally and cause mortification to a large number of worthy gentlemen whose lightning rods are in position for attracting the Gubernatorial nomination.

From The Philadelphia Times. The only occasion that gave Gov. Pattison an opportunity of speaking to the public since the Chicago strike was the celebration of the centennial of Halifax, on the Susquehanna, River, on the 18th of July. Lawlessness had then just begun to assert itself with formidable power, and he discussed the maintenance of law and order as the first duty of the citizen.

Paris Dispatch to The London Daily Telegraph. A notorious criminal and daring forger, who had already been convicted and sentenced to fourteen years' imprisonment at Mooltan, has contrived, by a very ingenious ruse, to escape during the progress of his trial for further offenses. The prisoner was brought up to the court from the jail each day, and it appears to have occurred to him that this afforded a chance of getting free.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Large bills for damages to and destruction of railroad property by the strike rioters are now coming into the City Hall. J.T. Brooks, Second Vice President of the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad, has presented a bill which aggregates $449,691

The Letter from Mr. A.H. Saxton, which we published on Saturday morning, directs attention to the real character and effect of one of the Senate's amendments to the Wilson bill and shows that the American manufacturers of screws are not at present handicapped by duties on the wire out of which screws are made.

Mr. Otken is by no means a cheerful man, for, if he is to be credited, the South and the Southern people never were in a more Pitiful condition. At the outset we must declare that the author is perfectly honest in his convictions, and that the book is, as it purports to be, written in no hostile spirit to any class of men.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 29. -- The three Guinan children, who strayed away from their home on Broad Street, this city. Thursday afternoon, have been found dead.

The greed of the Socialist leaders has just lost them influence among a large number of working people, and their enemy, Joseph Barondess, is again at the head of his old organization, the cloakmakers.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 29. -- The New-York Times was again an early visitor to-day in this great wilderness of mountains, lakes, and forests. The special train bearing to-day's Times reached Saranac Lake at 4:45 P.M. and arrived here less than half an hour later, to the delight of the harmony of companionable people here.

From Our Little Ones. Willie was asleep, and Dan was lonely, Willie is the minister's son; Dan is his dog. It was Sunday morning, and every one was at church but these two friends. It was warm and sunny, and they could hear the preaching, for their house was next door to the church.

Policemen were the executioners yesterday of two mad dogs that terrorized east side streets, and of one animal whose offense was that he kept up too rapid a circular pursuit of nothing in an east side back yard and aroused suspicions as to his sanity.

All arrangements have been completed for the inaugural entertainment of the Seaside Athletic Club on Wednesday night. The six men, Leonard, Pierce, Downey, McBride, Winters, and Holmes, have prepared with care for their respective bouts, and in view of the brief time they have been in training with the uncomfortable weather, they are in quite as good condition as might be expected under more favorable conditions.

James Mulligan, who died at Maynard, Mass., Saturday, became prominent as a witness before the committee of the House of Representatives, which investigated the Pacific Railroads in 1876. He had possession of certain letters which seemed to show that James G. Blaine had been guilty of using his public office to further his private interests.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 29. -- The announcement of the department of English regarding the courses to be given during the year 1894-5, made just before the examination period in June, showed that there was to be a general upheaval in the department, and that strenuous attempts were to be made systematically to develop the study of English composition in the college.

When Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn some weeks ago issued an order that the liquor dealers of Brooklyn must obey the law regarding the sale of liquor to minors, he believed that it would be observed, but after a time he discovered that the liquor dealers paid no attention to it.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- John W. Love, who was President of the Board of Trustees of the village of Watkins, N.Y., and cashier of the National Bank there when he mysteriously disappeared Feb. 8 last, was found alive and well in this city last week by a detective, who had been on his track for several months, and is now a prisoner at his old home.

Miss Ida B. Wells told a large audience in the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, in Sullivan Street, last night, about her visit to England to arouse public sentiment against the lynching of negroes in the Southern States.

From The London Standard. After 465 years Edinburgh has been enjoying the peculiar sensation of gazing on the skull flit King Robert the Bruce. The relic, it is true is not the actual cranium of the hero of Bannockburn, but merely a cast from the original, which, we trust, for the honor of Scotland, may be permitted to lie for evermore undisturbed in the Abbey of Dunfermline.

(Reported by.Messrs. Dick Brothers Lawrence, 30 Broad Street, New-York.) PITTSBURG, July 28. -- The price changes to local securities as a result of the week's operations leave very little, room for extended review. They are counted in small fractions, and are only found in the most active things on the list.

From The Helena (Mon.) Independent. The well-known circle on the pasture lands about six miles east of Helena, near the old overland stage road, and which has been a curlosity and a source of speculation for years, is identical with the fairy rings so common to some parts of England. There were formerly two of these rings, but one has entirely disappeared within the last few years.
Four persons were injured and others badly shaken up as the result of a collision between two cable cars at 9:30 o'clock last night at One Hundred and Elghty-fifth Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BERLIN, July 29. -- Here, as elsewhere on the Continent, all eyes have been turned eastward throughout the week. Chancellor von Caprivi several days ago sent his instructions to Freiherr von Gutschmid, German Minister in Tokio, and Freiherr von Schenck, German Minister in Pekin. He told them to support strongly England's initiative to restore peace between China and Japan, and, in the event of continued hostilities, to maintain an attitude of absolute neutrality.

From The Indianapolis Sentinel, July 28. If any doubt has existed as to the attitude of the Indiana Democracy with reference to the controversy between the trusts and the people now in progress at Washington, it will be removed by the publication in The Sentinel this morning of interviews with many hundred representative Democrats in nearly all the counties of the State.

From The Philadelphia Times. The Rev. John S. Eberlie of Pottstown, Penn., has for a generation eaten only once a day. The Rev. Eberlie is a Baptist clergyman, residing at Glendale. He moved there recently from the Falls of French Creek. For about thirty years he has eaten a hearty meal at noon, but fasts during the othier twenty-four hours of the day.
The Jap might as well yield gracefully as to Corea.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 29. -- It is now settled that Gen. Samuel E. Merwin of this city will be a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor this Fall. An announcement to this effect has been made by Gen. E.S. Greeley, a neighbor of Gen. Merwin, and the President of the Republican League of this city.

From The London Daily News. Paris artists depend largely for their models on the Italians. Out of every hundred, at least seventy are Italians. They are better figures than the French, and they are better models -- they can take more easily the poses which the painter desires, and fall into them more gracefully.

What should prove one of the most interesting cricket games played in New-York this season will take place to-morrow, when representative teams of English and Irish players will battle for supremacy at the wickets. The English cricketers of New-York have long held their own against all comers, and it has been their boast that they could defeat a combined team of all other nationalities.

JERSEY CITY, July 29. -- The people of this city are thoroughly satisfied that they have the worst drinking water to be found anywhere in the United States. This is no sudden conclusion of theirs. It is the result of a steady growth, born of an experience extending over eight or ten years.

William Q. Judge, Vice President of the Theosophical Society, who was recentlyacquitted, in London, of charges preferred against him by Mrs. Annie Besant, has arrived here with is friend, Dr. J.D. Buck of Cincinnati.

What is done this week in the independent police investigation by the Police Commissioners will depend on how long it takes to try, in the Court of General Sessions, ex-Ward Man Jeremiah Levy, who was to have been tried with Capt. Doherty and Ward Men Meehan and Hock.

The result of the Longwood tennis tournament conclusively proves that Larned is the best of the tennis cracks at this stage of the game. Since the early part of June he has not suffered a single defeat. His victory over Hovey will probably establish the belief shared by many critics that he is about the most likely of the Newport candidates.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 29. -- Though the last of the Grand Circuit card had but two classes, one of them furnished enough sport to occupy all yesterday and add more sensations to those which were seen earlier in the week. As on Friday, the pacers furnished the excitement, the more so since the crack Nebraska colt. Online, was defeated by his slower opponents.

Harry Glanville Southwell, a money lender of London, England, is making an attempt in the Supreme Court of this county to get possession of practically the entire estate of young Pearsall Humphrey, which was left to him by his father, William M. Humphrey, who died in this city on March 12, 1890.

The foreign exchange market was firm owing to the limited supply of bills. The posted rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.88 for sixty-day bills and $4.89 for demand. Actual business was done at 54.87 1/2 for sixty-day bills, $4.88 1/2 for demand, $4.88 3/4 for cable transfers, and $4.86 1/2 for commercial.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 30. -- There are no off years in Southern politics. Every Southern white man is a politician.

Private Henry Wolf of Battery A, First Artillery, in the United States Court, in Brooklyn, before Commissioner Bellows, yesterday pleaded not guilty to the charge of forging the name of Col. Loomis L. Langdon to a check for $262. Wolf had been detailed as a clerk in the Quartermaster's Department.

PEKIN, July 30. -- The report that a large Chinese army has crossed the northwestern frontier of Corea and is marching down the peninsula is confirmed. No details of the reported battle at Ashan have been received. It is reported that Japanese cruisers have sunk several Chinese transports at Taku and captured a number of others.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Secretary Carlisle to-day appointed Lawrence Hanley Special Inspector of Customs at the New-York Custom House.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 30. -- Twenty acres of lumber piles, containing about 25,000,000 feet of lumber belonging to the Shevlin-Carpenter Lumber Company, situated on the west bank of the river within a quarter of a mile of the centre of the city, were destroyed by fire this afternoon, causing a loss of fully $300,000.

A letter was received at Mayor Gilroy's office yesterday from Lord Mayor Dillon of Dublin asking the Chief Magistrate of New-York City, who was addressed as "The Lord Mayor of New-York," to give his substantial sympathy to the families of the drowned Achill Island harvesters. A similar letters was received yesterday by Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 30. -- The weather at the camp this afternoon was pleasant, the heat being tempered by a stiff breeze. The officers' school was held at 2:30 o'clock beneath the trees on the bluff, overlooking the river.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Government has determined to establish a naval coaling station for the North Atlantic and Caribbean Sea fleet at Key West. It has been the custom of the Navy Department for many years to order vessels cruising in the Caribbean Sea to coal, generally, at either Kingston, Jamaica, Cartagena, or Colon.
"My mamma says she is very glad to have me off the streets."

The five five-story brownstone flats 330 to 338 West Fifty-ninth Street, south side, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, have been sold by Mrs. Vollhart on the basis of $200,000, part payment being made by the exchange of a dwelling in West Seventy-second Street. Three of the flats are 29 feet front each and two are each 19 feet front.

It is not at all likely that any "grave international complication" will arise over the fact that a vessel sunk by a Japanese cruiser, with nearly all on board, was a chartered transport flying the British flag. That could only happen if the British Government were anxious to pick a quarrel with the Japanese Government.

A would-be leader in a crusade against the Roman Catholic Church to prevent its ecclesiastics from carrying out the order or decision of Mgr. Satolli, in which he unequivocally condemns the liquor traffic as it is carried on in the United States, has arisen in the person of J.P. Smith, the editor of The Wine and Spirit Gazette.
PEKIN, July 30. -- The following official version of the recent engagement between the Chinese and Japanese fleets has been issued by the Government:

When the conference committee of the House and Senate adjourned yesterday, it was to meet again at the call of the Chairman. There was in reality no conference. There was simply a demand by the conferrees of the Senate for an unconditional surrender by those of the House, which was, of course, refused.
Five jurors were impaneled yesterday in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, to try Policeman Jeremiah S. Levy of the Thirty-first Precinct for bribery. The jurors are:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As your editorial of to-day on "Government Ownership of Railroads" is addressed to workingmen. will you allow a workingman to answer it from his point of view? You assume that as a matter of course, if the Government owned and operated the railroads they would be run corruptly and in the interest of ringsters and politicians.

A twenty-foot sailboat, in which seven young men started for a trip up the Hudson River, was capsized during the thunderstorm Sunday evening when opposite Hastings. Three of its occupants were drowned. Their companions had a hard struggle to save themselves from a similar fate.

It is a characteristic piece of impertinence in Representative Boutelle of Maine to rush in with a resolution recognizing the "free, sovereign, and independent republic" of Hawaii, and declaring that the President of the United States" shall give proper notice of that recognition to the President of the Republic of Hawaii."

AMHERSTBURG, Ontario, July 30. -- The seized American fishing tug Louise has been released by orders of the customs authorities at Ottawa. The Maritime Department is sending Inspectors to Pelee Island to investigate the case.
FREDERICK, Md., July 30. -- The tariff reform Democrats of Frederick County held an enthusiastic meeting in the Court Square here to-night.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30. -- The engagement is announced of Miss Helen Taft of Providence, who is visiting at the cottages, and James P. Scott of Philadelphia. Miss Taft is of a Rhode Island family of high standing, a niece of ex-Gov. Royal C. Taft. Mr. Scott is a millionaire.

Nicholas Ennis, a tinsmith, had a marvelous escape from instant death by coming in contact with electric light wires at Twenty-third Street and Third Avenue yesterday. He was seriously burned about the face, arms, and body, but the physicians at Bellevue Hospital said last night he would recover.

Frederick Schneider, janitor of the tenement houses 418 and 420 West Sixteenth Street, tired of quarreling tenants and petty animosities caused by his strict attendance to his duties, was almost prepared yesterday to start for San Francisco, where his brother keeps a hotel. He is now in the New-York Hospital, probably dying of four bullet wounds inflicted by Albert Arndt, who for two years had been his friend.

The body of Chiko, the valuable chimpanzee who died in Dayton, Ohio, last Thursday, reached the Museum of Natural History, in Central Park, yesterday noon. It was in a good state of preservation, due to the embalming fluid which had been used.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1895, as reported to the Senate to-day from the Committee on Appropriations, carries $35,061,685, being an increase of $2,538,301 over the bill as it passed the House, and $95,683 over the estimates on which it was based.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 30. -- The first Kansas sorghum sugar mill was built in 1886. That was before the days of "sugar bonds," and the necessary bonus to secure the sugar mill was made up of contributions from the citizens. In this instance the stockholders were not gulled, because they believed that they were simply "investing" their money in an experiment which would never be made except in just that manner.

Judge Truax, in Special Term of the Supreme Court, has granted judgments against the Manhattan Elevated Railroad in actions brought by John Watts De Peyster and Abraham Stern as executors of the will of Bernhart Stern, to recover damages to property and for loss of rentals by the operation of the road.
BERLIN, July 30. -- Although tropical heat prevails throughout the empire, the Summer military drills have been carried on without any appreciable alteration of programme.

The demand for harmony in the ranks of the Democracy of this State meets with the approval of the rank and file of Kings County Democrats. There is a strong sentiment in Brooklyn in favor of harmony, and it has been strengthened by ex-Senator Platt, now that he has made it plain that his party is animated solely by the desire to secure political plunder.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 30. -- There was held here to-day a cycle tournament full of close finishes and finely-fought races filled with surprises. The Lafayette Military Band arranged the meet. Over 3,000 people attended and the track was the finest horse track yet ridden upon. The prizes were not up to the value, but the fields of starters were unusually large, and good racing resulted.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The points that marked to-day's session of the Senate were an oppressive heat and, as a result of it, a general apathy in regard to all matters of legislation that came up for action. Throughout most of the day there was not one-third of the eighty-five Senators present.

There was an interesting and rather lively examination in supplementary proceedings before Judge Fitzsimons of the City Court yesterday of Henry J. Davidson, Jr., the well-known clubman and former President of the Paxton Press Publishing Company.

HARTFORD, July 30. -- The forty-two members of the historical pilgrimage party which left Philadelphia early this morning reached here at 2:05 this afternoon. They were met at the station by Charles Dudley Warner, James J. Goodwin, P.H. Woodward, Secretary of the Board of Trade; the Rev. J.H. Twitchell, Forrest Morgan, Secretary F.B. Gay, and other members of the Connecticut Historical Society, and were driven to the United States Hotel, where luncheon was served.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 30. -- The changing of the racing hour from morning to afternoon did not materially change the attendance at the races to-day. The crowd of visitors from Albany and Troy that was expected to come here to play the races did not put in an appearance, and the special rates made only resulted in bringing here a handful of Albanians.

Plymouth, N.H., July 30. -- Fire this morning destroyed the plant of the Eastern Lignoid Casket Company, the Alden Woods Fibre Company, and Dearborn Brothers' tannery at Livermore Falls. The buildings covered about two acres of ground, were built principally of brick, and it will cost from $40,000 to $50,000 to replace them, equipped as they were.
SARATOGA, July 30. -- Lou Payn's prophecy that the Republicans could elect a "yaller dog" this year is becoming "wobbly."

The members of the Republican County Committee from the Eighth Assembly District, the members of the Assembly District Committee, and the proposed election officers of the same district have adopted resolutions indorsing the action of the Republican State Committee in referring to a sub-committee the question of the "regularity" of the Platt-Milholland faction.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The President to-day sent to Congress the latest dispatches received from Minister Willis. The first, dated July 8, described the customary Fourth of July celebration by Americans, in which the islanders heartily participated, and the second dispatch, written the following day, relates to the new Constitution, the proclamation of the republic, and the Minister's recognition of the new order of affairs.

HAMILTON, Ontario, July 30. -- The Philadelphia cricketers in their match with the Hamilton eleven to-day spread themselves and put together 233 runs before they were disposed of in their first inning. The weather was warm but pleasant, and the attendance , fair. The feature of to-day's play was the really splendid cricket put up by E.W. Clarke, who ran up a score of 91 he was given out leg before wicket.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., July 30. -- The Rev. J.H. Nason, who went to Phillips in charge of the supply train sent from here, returned to-day. He said that the reports of twenty lives having been lost were far short of the truth. The total loss of life will be at least forty. Eleven bodies had been recovered up to noon to-day.

ALBANY, July 30. -- The Democrats of Albany have been much impressed with the dispatches from Saratoga and to-day's editorial in The New-York Times advocating harmony in the Democratic Party, and pointing out how all the discordant elements in the party can be brought together under one common banner, so that victory can be assured this Fall.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Not a step was made toward settlement to-day of the tariff contest between the Senate and the House.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Sugar Investigating Committee spent its session to-day in trying to make another recalcitrant witness answer questions.

Houses having trade with China were informed yesterday that Canton and FooChoo had been added to the list of places in China to which messages cannot be sent according to the cable code or in cipher. This leaves Hongkong, Shanghai, and Amoy the only places in China to which cipher messages can be sent by merchants or officially.

BOSTON, July 30. -- The market for local securities showed no special feature of interest, but the general tone was firm, though transactions were very light. Boston Gas seconds recovered 1, to 51, and the stock 5/8, to 5 7/8. Orders from insiders are believed to be the cause of strength. The "telephones" were firm, Bell selling at 198 and Erie at 46, the latter 1/2 off from the last sale.

TRENTON, July 30. -- William Noon, an elevenyear-old boy, residing in this city, was shot and killed this morning by Matthew Pursell, aged fourteen, who lived next door. Noon was playing in the street with some companions when Pursell took his father's gun and pointing it out of the window of his home pulled the trigger. A number of shot entered Noon's body, and the lad died almost instantly.

Ex-Police Captain Doherty's brother, Patrick Doherty, yesterday called at the office of Louis J. Grant, the ex-Captain's attorney, in expectation of meeting his brother there, and presumably for the purpose of talking over the course to be pursued by the Captain in the future.

Assemblyman William H. Friday called on Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn yesterday and protested in behalf of his constituents against the exhibition, so-called, with which the Seaside Athletic Club, Police Justice Tighe's latest favorite, is to take possession to-morow night of the old Coney Island prize ring.

SARATOGA, July 30. -- All the visiting Democrats at this political centre approvingly discussed the editorial in to-day's New-York Times calling for party unity. They said to each other that it was a long time since a newspaper utterance embodying so much political importance had been brought to their attention.

ON BOARD THE NICTHEROY, RIO JANEIRO, July 5. -- The 24th de Mayo, formerly the Aquidaban, now lies in the dry dockhere, with agaping hole through her bow, through which the torpedo appears to have passed, exploding on its way, and shattering her sides for ten feet in every direction.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The first two of the proposed petitions for the impeachment of Attorney General Olney for his part in the late strike troubles, which officers of the Knight of Labor came to Washington to prepare and circulate, were laid before Congress to-day.

LONDON, July 30. -- The absence of official news from Great Britain's representatives in Pekin and Tokio has caused much complaint in the House of Commons. The Foreign Office therefore telegraphed orders this afternoon to the British Consuls and Ministers in China and Japan that they must send more comprehensive dispatches, and not permit the Chinese or Japanese officials to delay the forwarding of the same.

At Bergen Point yesterday afternoon the steamship Britannic cricketers suffered defeat at the hands of the New-Jersey Athletic Club by 6 wickets and 20 runs. The victors batted first and did very well, considering what little practice they get. F.H. Orton hitting hard for his 45, while W.L. Walters and B. McGrath each secured double figures.

ROCHESTER, July 30. -- As a Democrat I gladly welcome and sincerely approve the sentiments expressed by The Times in its leader this morning calling for a restoration of party harmony in this State. It seems to me that the need of a better understanding among Democrats has not been so imperative at any time In recent years as it is now.

Laurel, J.P. Dawes's mare, who on one or two previous occasions during the past fortnight has been beaten badly in races at upward of a mile, ran again yesterday, and, with a good price against her, had no difficulty in defeating horses which have beaten her under similar conditions. On Friday last George Dixon, with ninety-nine pounds up, won from Laurel, the favorite in the mile and a sixteenth race, in 1:51.

A more delighted crowd, to judge from their oft-repeated expressions of pleasure, never thronged a place of amusement in this city than that which passed through the doors of Huber's Palace Museum yesterday. There were old patrons in the throng who said they could not believe that they were in the same house as that run by the enterprising museum manager in years gone by, and, except for the site, they were not.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 30. -- Gov. Rich will enter the convention to-morrow with 650 of the 939 delegates back of him for renomination for Governor. Pingree men concede this to-night, but are making a hot fight for recognition on the remainder of the ticket. This afternoon Pingree with-drew for the sake of harmony.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: When the Chickasaws departed from their old homes in Mississippi there were two points to which they were escorted by the Government -- Fort Townsend, on Red River, and Fort Coffee, on the Arkansas. The party I was with came overland to Fort Coffee. This was in March, 1839.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- If the "conservative" Senators, who are doing their utmost to influence the conferrees, could read all the communications which are received daily by Senators and Representatives in relation to their action, they might get a faint idea of the condemnation which is piling up for them in all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Senate rejected to-day the nomination of E.J. Taylor of Lockport, to be Collector of Customs at Suspension Bridge. This action was expected, as the Committee on Commerce, of which Mr. Murphy is a member, brought in an unfavorable report upon the nomination several days ago.

The New-York Yacht Club was fifty years old yesterday, and to properly celebrate such an auspicious event an informal reception was given at the clubhouse, 67 Madison Avenue, last evening. There was a holiday air about the building all day yesterday that betokened to the layman something out of the ordinary. Pennants and vari-colored flags of handsome design floated from every window, and there was a bustle and activity about the place at once attractive.

SEDALIA, Mo., July 30. -- The Japanese Government, which has been searching for Major J.R. Wasson, who rendered a signal service to the Emperor during the Formosan troubles, has finally found him in this city. The Major is likely to take an important part in the war between China and Japan.

The annual sweepstakes catboat race of the Ruffle Bar Yachting Association was held over a fifteen-mile course in Jamaica Bay yesterday afternoon. Fifteen of the fastest yachts in the bay competed, and the racing was both spirited and interesting. Commodore James White acted as judge and tinier, while Vice Commodore Charles Edwards and Secretary Frank Agnew were referees.

Ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton's letter to ex-Secretary Tracy, in which he spoke of his return to this country from France, his health, and the Gubernatorial nomination, brought trouble to candidates yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 30. -- Readers of The New-York Times in this city were greatly pleased with the article published this morning on the condition of the city's water supply. They were not only pleased with the tone of the article, but they also expressed the hope that, with the aid of The New-York Times, they might be able to get the relief which they so greatly need.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Twenty-five hundred men went to work at the Illinois Steel Company's plant to-day. The works had been closed since the strike began. One thousand more workmen will be given employment before the end of the week.
BERLIN, July 30. -- The Chinese Government has ordered the construction, of four torpedo boats by German shipbuilders.

Commissioner of Accounts Wahle and two accountants began an examination yesterday of ex-Police Commissioner John McClave's accounts as Treasurer of the Police Board, and of the Police Pension Fund. It will require about a month's time to examine closely all the accounts.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Freight traffic on the railroads has completely recovered from the effects of the strike, and has resumed normal conditions. The returns of last week's shipments show that completely. They were as heavy as the weekly average before the strike began, and did not differ very materially from those of the corresponding week of last year.

ORANGE, Mass., July 30. -- Albert Southworth, aged fifty, of Warwick, stabbed his brother's wife, Carrie F. Southworth, aged forty, five times in the breast and neck, at her home in Warwick, last night. She may recover.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 30. -- There is every indication of a hot political battle for the Republican Congressional nomination in the Thirtieth District, composed of the Counties of Niagara, Orleans, Genesee, Wyoming, and Livingston. For the last four years James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo has served this section of Western New-York in the House of Representatives.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- The selling of West Chicago was very heavy to-day, and prices declined to the lowest point for weeks. It is believed that a well-defined bull movement was started some days ago, and that it was the intention to run the stock up much higher than the figures were when the break commenced, but that the liquidation was so heavy that it was found impossible to prevent a decline.

FLUSHING, N.Y., July 30. -- Several horsemen who won purses last week at the track here -- William Morris, the bookmaker; Henry Warnke, Jr., Owen Golden, and P.A. Butler -- have, through their attorney, Clinton B. Smith of this village, entered suit for same against Daniel Feist of Feist Brothers, the cloakmakers of 57 Walker Street, New-York, who is the backer and Treasurer of the club, for the purses won.
There were four deaths from the heat in this city yesterday and one in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Senator Murphy kept his word to-day, and secured the confirmation of Charles De Kay to be Consul General to Berlin. The nomination was reported only a few days ago, and would have been confirmed on the same day but for the fact that the business preceding it occupied a good deal of time on a very hot day, and this nomination had to go over.

A well-dressed man and a pretty young woman with blonde hair boarded a crowded Sixth Avenue surface car at Twenty-third Street at 9:30 o'clock last night. A moment later another man jumped on the car and, pushing his way in, struck the man with the blonde-haired woman squarely in the face.

The eighth annual rowing regatta to be given in connection with the Labor Day carnival of sports of the Staten Island Athletic Club will be held on the Kill Yon Kull, as usual, this year. There will be but two races, open to all amateur clubs, and the distance for each will be a mils and a half straightaway. The events are junior and senior eight-oared shells.

Schmelz's tail-end aggregation celebrated their last appearance at Eastern Park yesterday by trouncing the Bridegrooms 10 to 6. This victory gave the visitors the rubber of the series and filled them with joy. The game was far from being in the championship class, yet it was interesting and the Washingtons won on their merits.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 30. -- The Democratic State Convention will be held in Des Moines next Wednesday. The temporary Chairman will be J.M. Parsons of Rook Rapids. The permanent Chairman will be ex-Gov. Boies of Waterloo, whose speech will be the keynote of the Democratic campaign this year in Iowa.
Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant turned over his report yesterday as receiver of the St. Nicholas Bank to Hamilton Odell, the referee appointed to pass upon his accounts.

A bill has been reported in the House of Representatives for the establishment of a National Board of Arbitration for the settlement of labor disputes.
