The idea seems to be to furnish a permanent tribunal which would presumably commend confidence, and to which the parties to such disputes could resort for a determination of any controversy.

Speculative interest centred in the Granger stocks yesterday, Burlington, Rock Island, and Northwestern being notably weak. St. Paul was also heavy, but its loss was not so great as the others named. Some long stock was sold, but the short interest was at the same time largely increased. In Burlington there were a number of transactions "seller 60," most of which were made from 1 to 1 1/4 points below the regular price.

At a meeting of citizens of the annexed district in Loeffier's Hall, One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street and Willis Avenue, last night, the sub-committee appointed to protest against the dumping of garbage at Hiker's Island reported that its reception by Mayor Gilroy had been "chilly, very chilly."

PARIS, July 31. -- The current number of the Revue des Deux Mondes contains an account of an interview had by Jules Simon with the German Emperor in Berlin in 1690, when M. Simon was attending the international conference on social questions.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 31. -- Mayor Wanser does not think that this city stands in any immediate need of a new water supply, notwithstanding the numerous complaints on the subject.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 31. -- A thunderstorm cooled the air to-day and the weather at camp was very pleasant. Col. Merriam explained the Merriam pack this afternoon to the officers and non-commissioned officers, one of the latter from each company attending in heavy marching order. The Signal Corps held a school this afternoon, at which instruction was given in the use of the telegraph Instruments.

LONDON, July 31. -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir William Harcourt, Chancellor of the Exchequer, moved a time limit to the discussion of each clause of the Evicted Tenants bill, with a final closure of the committee stage on Aug. 7. The fact that there were twenty-two pages of amendments to the bill justified summary procedure.

The Catholic Publication Society of 12 East Seventeenth Street is financially embarrassed, and yesterday William Angelo was appointed receiver by Justice Stover of the Supreme Court on the application of the Trustees of the concern in pursuance of a resolution adopted by the stockholders On July 6 for the dissolution of the company.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- There are indications to-night, and many of them, that the Senate has, after consideration, come to the conclusion that it will be impossible and unwise to longer insist upon its determination to dictate a surrender by the House without terms.

BOSTON, July 31. -- The members of the American Society of University Extension, who arrived from Hartford, Conn., last night, on their pilgrimage over the historic ground traversed by Gen. Washington, gathered in the old South Meeting House this forenoon, where, at 10 o'clock, an old-fashioned "town meeting" was held.
State Committeeman Edward T. Fitzpatrick of the Ninth District, who is a member of the Board of Coroners, one of the most conservative of the leaders of Tammany Hall, said last night:

The good fellowship existing between the New-York and Larchmont Yacht Clubs was more firmly cemented than ever on the occasion of the informal reception on Monday evening commemorating the New-York's fiftieth anniversary. A beautifully engrossed series of resolutions, presented by the Larchmonts, read as follows:

Notice has been received by Drexel, Morgan Co. of forgeries on the London banking house of Coutts Co. Circular notes of 150 each, bearing the name of this house, have found buyers on the Continent of Europe. Fearing that some of them might reach the United States, Coutts Co. asked Drexel, Morgan Co. to warn bankers, and others who might be interested, against the notes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- Brooklyn lost to Philadelphia to-day through their inability to hit Harper. The latter was only hit to any extent in the second and fourth innings, but only one of the 6 runs was earned. Kennedy was easy for the home players, each, with the exception of Harper, making one or more hits.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 31. -- William J. Barkalow of Freehold, N.J., was shot and mortally wounded by Policeman Uriah Bennett of the Long Branch police force late this afternoon. The cause of the shooting was Barkalow's refusal to stop driving his horse over the sidewalk when requested by Bennett.
OMAHA, Neb., July 31. -- Major E.W. Halford, Paymaster in the army and former private secretary to President Harrison, was badly injured in a runaway here this afternoon.

One of the largest crowds of the season saw a superior article of ball at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants had the champion Bostons as opponents, and from he beginning until the last man was out interest in the game never lagged. The New-Yorks won, and it seemed to an observer that every one of the 8,000 persons present was glad of it.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 31. -- The formal celebration of the starting on the work of the hydraulic canal which is to supply 100,000 horse power at Love's Model City, near Lewiston, took place to-day. Some 2,000 people were present at the ceremonies. They came on special trains from Buffalo and Rochester.
How strong the desire for party harmony is with the thinking men among Democrats in this city was again made evident yesterday.

Orange, N.J., July 31. -- The woman who committed suicide this morning by drinking oxalic acid was identified this afternoon as Mrs. Daniel Bradley of 74 South Twelfth Street. Newark She was formerly an inmate of the Essex County Insane Asylum, but was recently discharged. She was sent to the asylum for melancholia. She had attempted suicide once before.

Henry Martin of Samuel Street and the Western Boulevard was drowned last evening in the Bronx River, near West Farms. A boat occupied by himself and young William Rogers, a neighbor, was upset. Rogers saved himself only after a desperate fight for his life with young Martin.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The board which inspected the Minneapolis on its recent record-breaking trial trip made its report to-day. The only notable feature of the report is the concluding remarks of the board:

BATH, N.Y., July 31. -- In answer to your telegram of July 31, I have the pleasure to state that for years the Democrats of the First Assembly District of Steuben County have always heartily and loyally supported the nominees of their party in both State and National elections. During this period our conventions have always been harmonious.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 31. -- On the 6th of August, 1894, William C. Oates Representative in Congress from the Fourth Alabama District, will be elected Governor of the State, whose credit and honor he has maintained at Washington for sixteen years. Democracy has fought a hard fight, and the strain is not over, but that it is to win no longer admits of doubt in reasonable minds.

There was a great deal of discussion yesterday among the liquor dealers of New-York over the challenge to Archbishop Corrigan issued by J.P. Smith, editor of The Wine and Spirit Gazette. The sentiments expressed by the liquor dealers were not very favorable to Mr. Smith. be quoted in a discussion involving the attiThe liquor dealers were naturally loth to tude of the Roman Catholic Church toward their business.

ORANGE, N.J., July 31. -- The road map of New-Jersey has been issued by the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen. The State is divided into eight sections, on an index map, which shows all the macadam and stone roads by green lines and other cycling roads in red lines, the scale being six and onehalf miles to the inch.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 31. -- The interviews with leading Democrats printed in this morning's New-York Times on the subject of party unity were eagerly read by the members of the party who are here and by Republicans, who are not at all pleased with the progress of the Democrats toward harmony.

There is evidence from trustworthy sources that the firmness of the House and of the President, backed by the sentiment of the Nation, is telling on the three or four Senators who have been threatening to kill all tariff legislation if the Sugar Trust be not satisfied. These men now see that they are in grave danger of being taken at their word.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 31. -- The Democracy of Jefferson County will gladly cooperate in the adoption of every proper measure to secure better unity in the party for the coming elections. But, in advance of knowing the demands which may be made by those who desire representation in its conventions, it is not worth while to offer very definite suggestions.

ALBANY, July 31. -- It is needless to say that the Democrats of Albany are delighted with the course of The New-York Times in its efforts to arouse the Democratic leaders to come together for harmony and victory. Scarcely a visitor enters the Executive Chamber whose attention is not called to its definition of the true party policy to be followed this year.

Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy, member of the Democratic State Committee from the Fifteenth District, said; "I am heart and soul for harmony, and we must get together to carry the State this Fall. The fight this year is but the skirmish before the great battle of 1896. If the Democrats lose this city and State this Fall, the Republicans are almost sure to carry the State in 1896 for their Presidential candidate.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- The crack new cruiser Minneapolis met with the same fate as her sister ship, the Columbia, when she grounded in the Delaware River. The flyer has three dents in her bottom.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The question of the most suitable site for a new Government Printing Office was raised in the Senate to-day by an amendment reported by the Committee on Appropriations, at the recommendation of the Cammittee on Public Buildings and Grounds, directing the Secretary of the Treasury to purchase the property known as the "Mahone lot."

NEW-ORLEANS, July 31. -- Capt. W.G. Randolph, Treasurer of the Parish of East Baton Rouge, who was shot in a barroom duel at Baton Rouge yesterday by Dr. King Holt, died early this morning. The two contestants were members of the most aristocratic and wealthy circles of the State capital and have always held prominent public positions.
YOKOHAMA, July 31. -- The Japanese Government has issued the following official statement of the differences which led to the rupture between China and Japan:

While Sergeant Burfeind was at the desk in the West One Hundredth Street Police Station yesterday morning his meditations were disturbed by a well-dressed, goodlooking Englishman, about thirty-five years old, who bustled into the office and up to the desk. He was evidently much excited, and he made the Sergeant gasp when he blurted out "Captain, I want to get married."

A committee of residents of the city above the Harlem River, who have been complaining about the stenches from Riker's Island caused by the dumping there by the Street-Cleaning Department of the city's refuse and garbage, appeared before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday to urge an immediate appropriation to pay for the covering of the dumped refuse with fresh earth to the depth of two feet.

District Attorney James W. Ridgway of Brooklyn, Democratic State Committeeman from the Second District, who has been at Saratoga, returned home yesterday morning. Early this morning he will start for Washington, where he will meet Senator David B. Hill, and report to him the result of the Saratoga conversations of the Democratic leaders.

-- Long Branch, N.J., July 31. -- Fire at 3:30 o'clock this morning, which started in the baker's shop of Townley Co., and which spread to the adjoining house of Henry Kroener a wholesale grocer, caused a loss of over $8,000. The entire building of Townley's bakery was consumed and a large portion of Kroener's two-story wholesale house was also destroyed.

MADRID, July 31. -- The Spanish Consul at Marseilles having telegraphed that cholera is epidemic there, that the number of deaths daily is very large, and that the authorities are concealing the actual situation, the Government has ordered stringent precautions to be taken at air Spanish ports and on the frontiers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- There was a decided tendency toward lower prices at the opening. The principal point of attack was St. Paul, which the traders sold down. The tone changed quickly, however, and an attempt to cover sent the price up to 57 3/4, and it closed practically at the top. It was the most active stock on the list, contributing over one-third of the business.

BOSTON, July 31. -- The annual report of the Boston and Albany Railroad Company to stockholders was issued to-day. The general figures for the year ending June 30 have been previously given, but details furnished by to-day's report show that the past year was one of the worst ever experienced by the Boston and Albany.

WASHINGTON, July 81. -- The Senate Committee charged with the investigation of the alleged speculation of Senators in sugar stock is preparing a report exonerating Senator Camden from the covert allegation or insinuation that he had bought 500 shares of sugar stock in the pendency of the Tariff bill.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 31. -- The Republicans of Michigan, after a bolt of one of their Gubernatorial candidates and the development of a storm with its centre over the party, to-day placed in nomination the following ticket:

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Windsor Beach, a new fashionable Summer resort on the south shore of Lake Michigan, within the city limits, was the scene of a double drowning this afternoon. Julius Greenburg, a married man, living at 480 Paulina Street, and Minnie McCann were drowned in sight of 5,000 pleasure seekers.

ELLICOTTVILLE, July 31. -- Democratic national success two years hence depends very largely upon the action of New-York State Democrats this Fall. The Democratic Party sustained defeat in the past with fortitude, and hoped for the future because they all stood together. I am satisfied that were the consequences appreciated by the voters last Fall, the State ticket, Senate, and Constitutional Convention would to-day be Democratic.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31. -- A part of Oliver Belmont's menagerie arrived here this morning by the Fall River Line. The bulls, sacred cows, and deer, however, are detained in New-York, subject to the quarantine laws. When ample time has elapsed to remove all fears of disease, the cattle Will be sent here, their arrival being looked for in about seven days.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- The annual tennis tournament for the championship of Long Island began here to-day on the grounds of the Meadow Club, before an enthusiastic crowd. The events will consist of singles, doubles, and mixed doubles, with consolation prizes in the men's singles and doubles. The interest of the day centred around the play of M.F. Goodbody, who is well known in England as an expert wielder of the racket.
ALBANY, July 31. -- The Argus will print the following to-morrow under the head "An Omen of Victory":

OGDENSBURG, July 31. -- It is the plain duty of every Democrat in this State to do whatever he can toward securing his party's success. The Democratic and Independent voters embrace a clear majority of the voting population of the State. If the Democrats nominate clean party men they will command the independent vote.

Gustave Wasner, who is also known as Karl Werner, and who appeared before the Lexow committee as a witness against Capt. William S. Devery, was a prisoner in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of bribery. He was arrested on Monday evening by order of Capt. Cross.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 31. -- A squad of sixteen ex-convicts from New-York City, in charge of a representative of The New-York World, reached this city this morning. They were ex-inmates of the Reformatory, who had been gathered in by the drag net with which that paper reached out into the shady corners of New-York when it began its fight against that institution.

ALBANY, July 31. -- The session laws of 1894, just from the press of State Printer Lyon, are bound up in two large volumes, which contain 1,995 pages of laws and 94 pages of index. These are the first results of the new order of printing, instead of engrossing, the chapters for final reading, and there are fewer mistakes marked by the asterisk than heretofore.

ALBANY, July 31. -- The Committee on Preamble and Bill of Rights met with a defeat in the Constitutional Convention tonight by having its report on the five-thousand-dollar limitation of liability proposition set aside. The committee last Thursday made a favorable report on this amendment. The day following it reversed this judgment and submitted an adverse report.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 31. -- Deputy Attorney General Hogan to-day secured from Justice Mayham of the Supreme Court an order annuling and forfeiting the privileges and franchises of the New-York Juvenile Guardian Society. The action was the result of the irregularities disclosed by the recent investigation into the society's affairs by the State Board of Charities.

Some of the shareholders of the Sherman Bank, now in process of liquidation, met at the Holland House yesterday afternoon and decided to request the Directors of the institution to make at an early date a detailed statement of the condition of the bank.

There are indications of the waning of the Populist movement in the South, and one of these is the effort to strengthen it by a fusion of Populists and Republicans in several States. Something of a test of public sentiment on this subject will be afforded by the election in Alabama next Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Tariff bill is not the only measure over which there is a dead-lock between the two houses of Congress. The River and Harbor bill, which is now in conference, is not only dead-locked, but it was intimated this morning that it may either fail altogether or its further consideration may be postponed until next Winter.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 31. -- The Ocean House, for many years one of the leading hotels at the Branch, was closed to-day, and the Sheriff took possession of the property. The last of the guests will move out to-morrow. Most of the employes have already left.
Police Commissioner James J. Martin, member of the Democratic State Committee from the Eleventh District, said:

Samuel A. Beardsley, Michael Rickard, and Alfred C. Chapin, comprising the State Board of Railroad Commissioners, gave a hearing in the Park Avenue Hotel yesterday relative to the crossing at grade of the Long Island Railroad tracks by the Brooklyn City Road, at Flushing Avenue in Brooklyn.

KINGSTON, July 31. -- Concerning the efforts toward harmonizing the Democratic Party in the State, The Leader will say tomorrow morning: "The Leader has frequently said that there was no room for two or three Democratic Parties in the State of New-York, and this has been said notwithstanding the fact that some superzealous persons have attempted to manufacture more than one Democratic Party.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 31. -- An attempt of Tillman's friends to howl down Senator Butler at Union to-day caused considerable excitement and some of the crowd became very boisterous and broke down the fence around the speakers' stand. Butler, however, was cool, calm, and collected. He scored the ones who tried to prevent him from speaking, and made a long and eloquent speech.

The death of Walter Pater was announced by The New-York Times yesterday. He was born in London Aug. 4, 1839, and educated at the King's School, Canterbury. He entered the University of Oxford at Queen's College in 1858, and was elected to an open fellowship at Brasenose, wherein he has held various offices.

BOSTON, July 31. -- To-day was one of the dullest. The only local security which showed any activity was Dominion Coal, which declined 3/4, to 20 1/2. The reason assigned for the decline was the adverse rumors from Washington as to the duty on coal. Bell Telephone was steady, at 198. Boston and Albany was quiet, at 206, and Boston and Maine was strong, at 148.

Superintendent Byrnes, President Martin, and Commissioner Sheehan had a conference in Mr. Martin's room, at Police Headquarters late yesterday afternoon. They were together for more than half an hour. What they talked about they would not reveal. It is supposed that they were considering the cases of Capts. O'Connor, Slevin, and Price, which the board may pass upon to-day.
DENVER, July 31. -- One result of the recent strike at Cripple Creek is the organization of a band of robbers, who have terrorized the country in the immediate neighborhood of the mines.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 31. -- The Baptists of this State, as a denomination, are forcing an issue into the campaign that is going to perplex and plague each of the political parties. This sect has a college at Wake Forest, a small town fifteen miles from here. It receives no aid from the State, which, before and since the war, has appropriated money to susutain the university at Chapel Hill.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- West Chicago was the conspicuous feature to-day. It was very feverish and decidedly-active, selling as high as 131 and as low (as 127 7/8. There seemed to be a general conviction that the late heavy selling of the stock was by insiders conscious of some unfavorable developments to come out in the near future.

The naval battle reported to have been fought between China and Japan confirms the showing made by the previous attack of the Japanese upon the transports conveying Chinese troops for service in Corea and upon the men-of-war convoying these transports. It shows, that is to say, a much higher degree of naval efficiency on the part of the Japanese than upon the part of the Chinese.
BUFFALO, July 31. -- In reply to your question regarding the Democratic situation in this State, permit me to quote the following paragraph, from an editorial article in to-day's Courier:

Has ex-Police Capt. Doherty seen a vision or has he been misrepresented? It was stated on Monday by those who were supposed to know that the ex-Captain was on the point of making a clean breast of everything in a manner which would incriminate persons who were his superiors before he was dismissed from the police force of the city.

Although practically ruled off the turf, William C. Daly was a visitor to the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, and in five of the races on the card his colors were carried. He succeeded in winning one purse with Captain T., which will probably be his last for some time to come. The action of the Stewards of The Jockey Club in ordering the refusal of his entries was much discussed at the track yesterday.

A jury was found yesterday to try Jeremiah J. Levy a policeman of the Thirtyfirst Precinct, and formerly ward man of the Eleventh Precinct, for bribery, and the case was begun by an address for the prosecution by Assistant District Attorney Osborne. It is possible that the defendant may know his fate to-night.

FLUSHING, N.Y., July 31. -- Jeter Walden, the horse owner, made things interesting at the race track to-day by abusing judges, timers, starters, jockeys, and everybody, in fact, connected with the track. Mr. Walden's actions were caused by the club ruling him and his horses off of the track, he having brought suit for purses won.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- By command of Gen. Schofield, the following general orders, issued during the late troubles, for the government of the army, are made public:

Richard Theil of 161 Gold Street, Brooklyn, was a dog-catcher until yesterday afternoon. He thought a few weeks ago that dog-catching was a pleasant and remunerative political position. He resigned yesterday because brickbats, stones, old shoes, shotguns, revolvers, crockery, glassware, chunks of iron, and various other things had impressed on his mind, by means of his body, that he had made a mistake.

NEWTOWN, L.I., July 31. -- A welldressed man, in a stupefied condition, was found this morning by a policeman under a tree near the Grand Pier, at North Beach. He was taken to the Beach Police Station. A physician worked over the stranger for over two hours, but without effect. He had taken poison, and it had gotten thoroughly into his system.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. Jacob Cole sold, to A. Embury, plaintiff, at $1,500 each, the three two-and-one-half-story frame dwellings, 2,050 to 2,052A Pacific Street, south side, 233.4 feet west of Saratoga Avenue, together 66.8 by 107.2 1/2. To John B. Holman, plaintiff, at $1,000, he sold the two-story frame building, with store, 167 Thatford Avenue, northeast corner of Sutter Avenue, 25 by 100.
DALLAS, Texas, July 31. -- Two large brick buildings on Elm Street, occupied by the Wells, Fargo Co. Express Company and L.C. Craddock's grocery, collapsed today.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Gov. Matthews of Indiana, who is spending a few days at Old Point Comfort, was asked by a United Press reporter this morning what were the sentiments of the Democrats of Indiana as to the tariff situation. The Governor, after some deliberation, authorized the following statement:

PHILLIPSBURG, Penn., July 31. -- Mrs. Richard Jones was shot by James Myers this morning. The woman's husband is one of the striking Pardee miners. Myers also worked in the mine before the strike, and this morning, with about thirty others, went to the mine to begin work at 40 cents a ton.

OSWEGO, July 31. -- The Democracy can win the victory in this State the coming Fall only by burying the past and uniting earnestly for party success. We must know the snapper and the anti-snapper no more. We must cease being Hill men or Cleveland men and all be Democrats once more. We must cut loose from factions and individuals and swear allegiance anew to party.

A fire which was extinguished early yesterday morning in the pocketbook manufactory of Scheyer, Nathau Co., at 438 Broome Street, the building fronting on Broadway, would have developed into a very big and destructive blaze had it not been for a lucky accident, which aided the Fire Department materially.

SHANGHAI, July 31. -- Another battle between the Chinese and Japanese naval forces was fought yesterday. After a fierce fight the Chinese iron-clad man-of-war Chen Yuen, the largest, with one exception, and most recently built ship in the Chinese Navy, was sunk, and two Chinese cruisers, built by the Armstrongs, at Elswick, were captured by the Japanese.

A number of interested persons attended the sale under foreclosure of the Casino property by Mr. Henry W. Donald of R.V. Harnett Co., in the Trinity Building salesroom yesterday. What was sold was the leasehold property, which consists of the theatre building. The lease of the ground extends until 1902.

LIMA,. Ohio, July 31. -- The leading prize of to-day's race meet of the Lima Cycling Club was won by Julian Bliss, the little record breaker. It was a great contest. Bliss gained the pacemakers' rear at the outset, and hung there. On the back-stretch Murphy passed Sanger and worked to the front, rounding into the straight in the lead.

Charles H. Sherrill, Jr., the ex-Yale athlete, who was instrumental in arranging the recent contest between Yale and Oxford, arrived on the steamship Chester yesterday. To a reporter for The New-York Times he said: "I suppose excuses will be in order, but we do not wish to make any. When, we left here we were confident of success, and we did not give up until Oxford had beaten us.
BOSTON, Mass., July 31. -- Regarding the Corean imbroglio. Mr. Percival Lowell, who was counselor to the first Corean Embassy that was ever sent to the United States, says:
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Residents of this place witnessed some good tennis to-day, especially in the doubles of the Long Island championships.

BUFFALO, Aug. 1 -- Grover Cleveland is the recognized official leader of the Democratic Party. Upon him more than upon any other man the immediate future of the party depends, and if disaster shall come, upon him must rest, in large measure, the great responsibility.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 1 -- To-day's Democratic State Convention has been notable, for the soundness of its Democracy Tariff reform seems to be more firmly established than it ever was before in the party in Iowa. Every reference to the Wilson bill was enthusiastically received.

SARATOGA, Aug. 1 -- The latest report to-night about Senator Edward Murphy's expected arrival is that he will be here Friday. If he does get here it is probable that the call for the meeting of the Democratic State Committee will be issued Saturday or Monday.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The Spanish Government purchased three cruisers from English firms to-day. These vessels will be sent at once to the Philippine Islands to protect those possessions of Spain against the encroachments of Japan, whose ambition to become the dominant power in the East, it is feared, may lead her to take advantage of the troubles on the Island of Mindano and land troops there.

Speaking of Mgr. Satolli's decision regarding liquor dealers in their relation to the Catholic Church and the recent letter of Archbishop Corrigan in regard to the matter, Charles V. Fornes, who until a month ago was President of the Catholic Club, said yesterday:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The accusation of improper executive interference or dictation preferred by Senator Gorman and others might seem to deserve serious attention and might be misleading if the motive were not so transparent.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1 -- With the intention of proving that Senator Gorman does not represent the people of Maryland in his tariff ideas, an afternoon paper published eight columns of interviews with more or less prominent Democrats of the State, outside of Baltimore. It is explained that Baltimore's loyalty to Mr. Cleveland and the Wilson bill as evinced in interviews published last week.

Capt. Duke of the steamship Glenogle, that arrived yesterday, with a cargo from China, consigned to Carter, Macy Co. of this city, was spoken with yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times upon the subject of the war between China and Japan.

A proposed amendment upon which the Constitutional Convention has been wasting some time of late declares that the Legislature "may" enact laws "requiring" citizens entitled to exercise the right of suffrage to exercise such right. As this is not mandatory, it is not at all likely that such laws would be enacted, for citizens like to have their rights protected, but not to have them turned into legal obligations and forced upon them.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- There has been too much steam turned on in the traction stocks. They all opened strong and advanced, but later In the day the weakness of the general market helped to drag them down. Electric Traction, which is never active except in a very small way, led the list.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- All the Republican caucuses in Chautauqua County have now been held, and there is said to be little doubt that S. Fred Nixon will be renominated for member of Assembly.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The Earl of Kimberley, Minister of Foreign Affairs, received a dispatch this morning from Hugh Fraser, British Minister in Tokio, announcing the declaration of war. He was visited this afternoon by the Japanese Minister, who personally communicated to him a similar announcement of the declaration.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Please remind Senator Gorman and others that "only the wounded bird flutters," and the quicker they subside the less likely they will be to subject themselves to public ridicule. It is the unanimous opinion of Connecticut Democrats that the members of the Chicago Merchants' Club were about right when they congratulated the people of these United States upon the fact that "our President knows his duty."

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Flames to-night destroyed, more property, and in a shorter space of time, than any fire in Chicago since the big conflagration in 1871. Over $3,000,000 worth of buildings, lumber, electrical apparatus, cars, car wheels, castings, stoves, patterns, and other material were consumed in a blazing furnace of over a half mile square in less than three hours' time.

WELDON, N.C., Aug. 1 -- The biennial factional fight in this, the Second Congressional District, between the Republicans has begun. At the convention held here the seats of several delegates were contested, and in the settlement of this question Solicitor George H. White lost several votes.
WASHINGTON, July 1-- ER. Judge Advocate General Joseph Holt, Major General United States Army, retired, died at 2 o'clock this morning at his residence, 236 New-Jersey Avenue, in this city.

From The Hudson Register, (Dem.) To-day The New-York Times is not only the most reliable and conservative newspaper in New-York City, but it is also the most sincere advocate of the Democratic cause. The following extract from its editorial columns is convincing proof of this:

Horace D. Baker, who was arrested at Vineland, N.J., on July 30, has defrauded a number of banks during the last two years, realizing probably $60,000. Pinkerton's, agency gives his record as follows:
The following is a complete list of the passengers booked to sail on the Norman- nia to-day for Southampton and Hamburg:
The motives given to the Chamber of Deputies by M. Charles Dupuy for the articles of the new press law proposed by the Government, and these articles are textual ly as follows:

The proceedings before the Park Board after several contracts had been awarded for the Castle Garden aquarium were enlivened yesterday by a dispute between Consulting Architect Harvey T. Woodman and a representative of the Edgewood Company, which constructed the slate tanks for the fish.

The Majestic of the White Star Line arrived yesterday with part of the crew of the fishing schooner Antelope of Burin, N.F., which she sank off the Banks on Monday morning. The crew of the Antelope consisted of eight men, six of whom were saved.

The fight in the Socialist camp between Danie De Leon and Charles Sotheran has resulted in a partial victory for De Leon. The New-York Section of the Socialist Party met on Tuesday evening and considered De Leon's charges that Sotheran had slandered a good fellow-Socialist. De Leon demanded Sotheran's expulsion from the section.

There are not many such games in a season as that which gave the Giants a glorious victory over the proud Bostons at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Indeed, such a stubbornly-fought contest, prolonged beyond the usual limit, does not often reward the patrons of the national game. Eleven innings were played, and in the New-Yorks' final time at the bat the winning run came in on Capt. Ward's little bounder over Tucker's head.

The entries for the annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which takes place on Saratoga Lake, Aug. 10 and 11, show no diminution of interest in the blue ribbon rowing event of the year. Each race has a representative list of entries, and, with favorable weather, some grand sport should result. Secretary Fortmeyer yesterday made public the nominations in the several events.

The State Board of Health, according to a dispatch from Albany yesterday, has directed the authorities of this city not to allow the dumping of refuse within six miles of shore, and then only during the out tide.
Five favorites were overthrown successively at Brighton Beach yesterday. It was a dejected crowd that left the track.

TOKIO, Aug. 1 -- The Government has wired instructions to the Japanese Minister in London, to offer an apology to Great Britain for firing upon and sinking the Kow Shing while she was flying the British flag. The Minister is also instructed to inform the Government of Great Britain, that the commander of the Japanese cruiser was unaware until after the fight that the Kow Shing was a British vessel.

James J. Corbett, the pugilist, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Majestic. Several of his friends had chartered the tug C. E. Evarts, and with a brass band went down the bay to meet Corbett. They cheered the pugilist when they reached the steamer's side and then went to the dock, where a big crowd of admirers of the pugilist were ready to welcome him.

State Senator Timothy D. Sullivan said: "I agree fully with the sentiments expressed by The New-Tork Times for Democratic harmony. If we get together, I think we can carry the city and the State in spite of the general demoralization that seems to have seized on the Democratic leaders.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 1 -- A sub-committee of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, composed of Amos J. Cummings of New-York, J.P. Dolliver of Iowa, H.D. Money of Mississippi, and J. Fred C. Talbott of Maryland, to-day made an inspection of the manufacture at Homestead of armor plate by the Carnegie Steel Company, Limited.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 1 -- A riot took place to-night between a number of excursionists and the crews of the tugboat Idlewild and the barges Coxsackie and Columbia at Sylvan Beach Grove, eight miles below Elizabeth, on the Staten Island Sound. There were about 1,000 excursionists from Brooklyn, and at the hour appointed for departure some of the excursionists objected to the boats leaving.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 1 -- There has been a moat active organization of Democratic clubs in this State. Once more the system will be put to a test, and the result will be shown on Aug. 6, when the election for Governor takes place. It was late when the work began, but from all parts of the State come encouraging reports.

The gentlemen who thought it possible to conduct horse racing without the bookmakers made a hard fight at Elkwood Park, but, after several days' trial and constantly-decreasing attendance, have given up the struggle. Messrs. Sykes, Daly, and John S. Hoey, who managed the meeting, gave to the amateur sport a degree of discipline which was pretty nearly up to the mark set by the big tracks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent disturbances in Chicago must have caused all reflective minds, to ponder afresh upon the vexed problem of labor and capital. Like the tariff question, it would seem that the man is yet to be born who has genius enough to solve these enigmas, which, with every decade, grow more complex and more difficult of solution.

Andrew McLean, editor of The Brooklyn Citizen, is one of the shrewdest political observers in that city. His newspaper is the recognized mouthpiece of that wing of the Democratic Party which was until last Fall in power in Brooklyn. He is close to the Democratic leaders and understands their sentiments on questions of party management, and he speaks with authority when he outlines a proper policy to be pursued.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Ex-Gov. James E. Campbell, who is counsel for the Ezeta brothers, formerly President and Vice President of Salvador, saw Secretaries Gresham and Herbert to-day in behalf of his clients, whose release he hopes to secure from the United States steamship Bennington, where Gen. Ezeta and three of his countrymen are still confined in asylum.

Justice Bartlett, in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday heard more about Lillian Russell's contract with Canary Lederer, when the case came up again on a motion to continue the preliminary injunction served upon Miss Russell before she sailed for Europe.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- In consequence of the action of the Unionists yesterday in deciding to abstain from further participation in the discussion of the Evicted Tenants bill, the front Opposition benches were vacant when the House of Commons resumed consideration of the bill to-day.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- In an interview had by a representative of the United Press with Sir Edward James Reed, M.P., formerly Chief Constructor of the British Navy and the designer of several of Japan's war ships, Sir Edward said that the only vessel in the navy of Japan worthy of being called, an iron-clad was the Fooso.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 1 -- Advices from Yashan state that the Chinese are strongly intrenched there, and that repeated attempts have been made by the Japanese troops to dislodge them. In every instance, however, the attacking forces, after hardfought engagements, were repulsed at all points with heavy losses.

Mrs. Dora Goldberg of 175 Madison Street is in Bellevue Hospital suffering from injuries inflicted upon her late Tuesday night, as she alleges, by members of Charles Karansky's household, who beat her because she wanted to sit on their front steps.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- The Democratic members of the Constitutional Convention, overwhelmed as they are at the present time with the important questions now under consideration, are taking the liveliest interest in the efforts of The New-York Times to bring about harmony in the Democratic Party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The House today agreed to the conference report on the Agricultural Appropriation bill, the Senate receding from its amendment appropriating $1,000,000 for the extinction of the Russian thistle in the Northwest, and then took up the contested-election case of Moore vs. Funston from the Second District of Kansas.
Edward Smith, an aged negro who makes his living as a caterer, was not allowed to board an elevated railroad train at Bleecker Street and South Fifth Avenue yesterday after depositing, his ticket.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net decrease in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during July of $1,544,821.40. The interest-bearing debt increased $700, the non-interest-bearing debt decreased $64,605.50, and the cash in the Treasury increased $1,480,915.90.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- It was announced by Adjt. Gen. Porter to-night that a second additional week would be added to the camp season, extending from Aug. 11 until Aug. 18. Next week being the first extra week, camp will be occupied by the First Battery, Capt. Wendel, the Second Battery, Capt. Wilson, and Battery K of the First United States Artillery, Capt. Dillenbeck.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- A special meeting of the Jeffersonian Club, among whose members are Gov. Flower, Judge Denis O'Brien of the Court of Appeals, Judge W.F. Porter of the Court of Claims, ex-State Assessor John D. Ellis, and other prominent Democrats of Jefferson County, was held in this city to-night.

The Chicago Inter Ocean remarks that "in Illinois the great raw material is coal, which Mr. Cleveland insists must be put on the free list," and then asserts that the removal of the duty on bituminous coal "would carry poverty and misery into the cottage of every miner in this State."

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 1 -- The President's sister and Miss Maude Harrison, who have been visiting Mrs. Cleveland, returned home to-day. During the severe hot weather Mrs. Cleveland finds much enjoyment in an occasional sail down Buzzard's Bay in the President's catboat Ruth, accompanied by the President's faithful skipper, Stillman B. Wright, one of the most skillful yachtsmen in Buzzard's Bay.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- The Pullman Relief Committee, on behalf of the Pullman strikers, to-day issued an appeal for aid to the public, in which it says:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor and party returned from Bar Harbor this noon in the Nourmahal, and Mr. Astor sailed at once for New-York, with Dr. Seward Webb and Adolph Ladenburg as guests. Mrs. Ladenburg went to Wakehurst, J.J. Van Alen's guest, Mr. and Mrs. F. Yznaga arrived to-night, and are visiting Mr. Van Alen.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 1 -- The experiment now making at Gallipolis, under the auspices of the State of Ohio, in the study and treatment of epilepsy, is of great interest. For more than a year men and boys afflicted with this disease have been received and cared for there. Nearly 200 are now grouped in the various cottages.

The Palisade Boat Glut's tennis tournament brought out some fairly good tennis yesterday afternoon. Quite a large crowd assembled on the courts near Glenwood Station, Yonkers, and plenty of applause greeted good strokes. The tournament is a handicap on the English or point system, 72 points constituting a match. Odds varying from 2 to 33 points are allowed, Harry Beecher, the famous football player, being scratch man, though playing from the two-point mark.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The keg which had contained the missing $10,000 of gold, stolen while in transit from Havre to Paris, has been found empty at a suburban station.

NEWBURG, Aug. 1 -- The Register most heartily indorses the stand taken by The New-York Times in the interest of Democratic harmony and consequent Democratic success in the Empire State this Fall. It was an initiative step which no old-line Democratic paper in the State could have taken, since most of them have had more or less of factional feud and fight in their respective parishes.
LIVERPOOL, Aug. 1 -- Next Saturday and Monday will be holidays in the grain market. Next Monday will be a holiday in the provisions market.
The new marine aquarium, which is gradually being evolved in the old Castle Garden, is adding to its attractions daily.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The commission which has been listening to the stories told by hostile convicts and ex-convicts against the reformatory and Mr. Brockway summarily threw out of court several of the prosecution's star witnesses to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A delegation representing 600 of Kelly's commonwealers, accompanied by Col. Tracy, Commissioner of Charities, waited on the District Commissioners to-day and asked to be sent home. The men stated briefly that they had been deluded in coming here, and that they were now at the point of starvation.

OSWEGO, Aug. 1 -- There is no division of sentiment among the rank and file of Democrats as to the necessity of harmony for Democratic success this Fail. There is great diversity of opinion whether harmony ought to be brought about by the abandonment of Democratic principles, which are upheld in letter and spirit by 95 per cent, of the Democratic voters.

The new Southern Railway Company, which took formal possession yesterday of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia lines, the Charlotte, Columbia and Augusta, and the Columbia and Greenville lines, now comprises a compact railroad system of about 3,000 miles. Wtihin another month the Georgia Pacific, the Louisville Southern, and other subsidiary lines Will be added, constituting an aggregate mileage of 4,500 miles.
The Board of Walking Delegates that met yesterday afternoon determined not to postpone the strikes on several public schools which it had ordered to be put in force this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Senate was enlivened by a little speech from Senator Hoar (Rep., Mass.) who referred to a printed petition of Coxeyite origin presented to the Senate to-day. This petition, with the heading "Let Congress Resign," had been circulated in Boston, purporting to have been adopted at public meetings in Faneuil Hall and upon Boston Common.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- At a meeting of the Board of Village Trustees last night the fact was presented to the members that the Village Treasury is bankrupt. The collector has just begun to collect the annual taxes, amounting to $15,000.

Ex-Controller Theodore W. Myers, when asked for his opinion as to the necessity for Democrats to unite for a vigorous campaign, following the advice of The NewYork Times, which has aroused the party throughout the State, said:

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- The 95 academic departments in the secondary schools in 1879 grew to 283 in 1893. This fact is brought out in the bulletin of the State Regents' office on "High Schools and the State," which has just been published.

Dullness continued to be the feature of the stock market yesterday. The transactions were a little over 105,000 shares, but the bulk of the trading was done in half a dozen stocks. In the railway list Burlington, St. Paul, and Rock Island were the leaders, while in the industrials Sugar and Chicago Gas were the most prominent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The feature of the Grand Circuit meeting here to-day was the defeat of the crack trotter, J.M.D., in the race for the purse of $5,000 in the 2:25 class. Two weeks ago, at Detroit, the fleet Baltimorean had landed, a purse of $8,000 in very hollow fashion over a big field. Cobwebs, who started in that race, went one mile to a false start, and finally had to be drawn.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Taxation gave a hearing this afternoon on the proposition to change the method of taxing trust companies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- This has been a day prolific in rumors about the Tariff bill.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- A representative of the United Press has been enabled to obtain the original copy of Mr. Gladstone's letter in reply to the recent invitation of 100 representative Americans to the ex-Premier to pay a visit to the United States. The letter was inclosed with a personal note to CoL Gouraud, requesting its transmission to the committee who had extended the invitation.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Dominion Coal was the only active stock in the local list to-day. It opened at 20 3/4, 1/4 above last night's close, and advanced to 22. Rumors of free coal from Washington were the cause of the rise. Bell Telephone declined 1/2, to 197 1/2. Boston and Albany opened 1/4 off at 205 3/4 and recovered later to 206.

GLOVERSVILLE, Aug. 1 -- It should be apparent to every Democrat that harmony and united action are not only advisable, but absolutely indispensable, this year if New-York is to remain a Democratic State. When it becomes Republican look out for four years more of Republican National rule.
Capt. James K., Price of the Twentieth Precinct was acquitted by the Police Commissioners yesterday on charges preferred because last Spring a gambling house existed at 345 West Thirty-first Street.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 1 -- The watchword of "Unity," proclaimed so ably and earnestly by The New-York Times, has been heard in Rochester and is being passed along the Democratic line. Hardly at any other portion of the State is such a watchword needed so much as right here in this city and the County of Monroe, where party dissension has been particularly rife.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The New-York Times has compelled the members of Congress in the House from the State of NewYork to take notice of the articles it has been printing from day to day on the subject of party unity as a necessary condition precedent to a successful campaign in the State and in the City of New-York.
ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- The Constitutional Convention to-day adopted the resolution offered by Mr. McClure for the appointment of a committee of five to consider means of protecting the forests.

The Timothy D. Sullivan Association scored a great success at its nineteenth annual picnic and athletic games at the Harlem River Park yesterday. The park was crowded with the friends and guests of the association. It was estimated that at the opening of the games in the afternoon fully 3,000 persons were on the grounds.

Details of the engagement between the war ships, of Japan and China will be studied with absorbing interest by naval officers of this and other nations. Much of the capabilities and weaknesses of a modern ship of war are problematical, and, this being the first practical test to which they have been put, will, consequently, have much, interest for students of naval war fare.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Under the abmonitions of The New-York Times, the Board of Works to-day awoke from its lethargy, and President McArthur sent out all the available laborers to blow off the pipes through the fire hydrants. The work was begun on the Heights, and during the day nearly 100 hydrants were opened.

The taking of testimony in the trial of Patrolman Jeremiah S. Levy, formerly ward man in the Eleventh Police Precinct, who is charged with taking bribes from Capt. Carl Krumm, the proprietor of a concert saloon, for the privilege of allowing him to conduct his business without a license, was begun before Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday morning.

The matrimonial adventure of the Rev. W. Kearsy-Thomas was brought to a presumably happy conclusion at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when he and Miss Margaret Lietze, formerly of Cincinnati, Ohio, were quietly married at the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 116 East Forty-seventh Street, by the Rev. William Walter Smith, acting in the absence of the Rev. D. Parker Morgan.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 1 -- The old Coney Island Athletic Club's arena had a familiar appearance to-night, when it was reopened to the public as a sparring resort, known as the Seaside Athletic Club. The programme was of a much milder order than the affairs which took place under the old management, when John Y. McKane ruled supreme on Coney Island.

In a story published in two morning newspapers yesterday charges were made by Edward M. Knox, the hatter, that through the influence of President Martin of the Board of Police he had been discriminated against in his business, and had been deprived of the privilege of supplying the Winter helmets and Summer hats to the police force.
KINGSTON, Aug. 1 -- The objects urged by The Times are highly commendable and much desired by all good Democrats.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Burglars broke into the Post Office here last night. They blew open the safe with forcite powder and secured postage stamps and cash to the amount of $900.
Youthful minds are often confused and baffled by the intricacies of politics. Maturity and habituation best cure that defect. As in other pursuits, experience is the great teacher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- It is probable that the Senate Sugar Committee will make its report to the Senate to-morrow. As to the part the Sugar Trust has taken in the making of the Tariff bill there will be a divergence of views.

Linnaeus Moyer Peterson, twenty-six years old, a drug clerk, employed at 437 Amsterdam Avenue, took cocaine yesterday afternoon, jumped into the pool in Central Park, near One Hundred and Third Street and Eighth Avenue, and fought desperately in 15 feet of water with Park Policeman Dooley, who rescued him.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 2 -- The fourth bicycle meet of this Summer for record-breaking purposes only began this afternoon on the Waltham track, and was made not-able by the breaking of five world's records. Harry C. Tyler of Springfield, Mass., was the central figure of the meet and will try for more new records Friday and Saturday.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Judge D. Cady Herrick of Albany, who is passing the Summer here, joins with the other prominent Democrats of New-York State in approving the counsel of The New-York Times for harmony in the Democratic Party.

The Cleveland Leader, which is the foremost McKinley journal in Ohio, remarks that according to Mr. Havemeyer's testimony before the Senate committee, "the profits of the Sugar Trust are about $11,000,000 a year, or 13 per cent, on the grossly-inflated capitalization of $85,000,000."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- A tack dropped in a picker machine caused a seventy-thousand-dollar fire this evening in the four-story mill at Randolph and Jefferson Streets, occupied by Closkey O'Hara, carpet cleaning works, and John A. Cronin Co., yarn spinners. Two firemen were killed and seven injured by a falling floor.

Ernest H. Friedrichs died at 182 Second Avenue yesterday morning from the effects of inhaling fumes from a carboy of nitric acid that was broken in his store, at 140 Sullivan Street, Wednesday morning.

Chairman Midgley of the Western Freight Association has decided that he has no authority to appoint a committee of representatives of Western lines to confer with a similar committee of Eastern railroad men on the subject of car mileage rates. Such a conference was suggested at the recent meeting in this city of the joint committee of the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- There has been little doubt hitherto among Democrats that the Sugar Trust has been in possession of the Senate conferrees, much as those worthy gentlemen may have repudiated the assertion.

Acting under orders from the Board of Walking Delegates, a number of painters and carpenters employed in repairing the public school buildings in this city began a strike yesterday, which, if the intentions of the board are carried out, will include nearly all the men making repairs and alterations to the buildings, and throw out of employment 1,500 men, principally carpenters and painters.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The market was dull. Lately at times one or two stocks have been active for a few days, but a market like to-day's takes the heart out of a trader. The fluctuations in Electric would be considered wide, and attract attention if any good round lots changed hands, but they don't.

The Industrial Trust Company's building, which is the most pretentious structure in Providence, R.I., was formally opened for inspection last Friday. The building is a nine-story structure. The main room of the Industrial Trust Company's offices, on the ground floor, is entered through the Westminister Street hallway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Mr. Chandler was absent from the Senate Chamber at the time of the sensational speeches in relation to the Tariff bill and the President's letter to Mr. Wilson, and lost an opportunity which only those who know his predilections can estimate at its true worth.

In a suit begun against The Times Publishing Company by a small stockholder to recover the amount of his subscription to the capital stock, counsel for the company demurred to the complaint. On hearing the complaint read yesterday, Judge Barrett remarked: "There is nothing in this," and at once sustained the demurrer, throwing the case out of court.
CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 2. -- "It is of the most vital importance that harmony should be established in the Democratic Party of New-York. Unless it is done we will lose the State."

The patrons of the Brighton Beach track are becoming educated to following the big money that is bet on a race, and as every winner but one yesterday was heavily backed, the majority of the speculators left the track in a happy frame of mind. Only one of the horses that opened favorite yesterday finished first, but the weight of money was bet on him, and the public profited accordingly.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- The Suffrage Committee reported adversely to the Constitutional Convention to-day the dozen propositions that had been referred to it to grant women the privilege of voting. The introducers were Mr. Dean of Chautauqua, Mr. Moore of Clinton, Mr. Foote of Monroe, Mr. Lincoln of Cattaraugus, Mr. Tibbets of Tompkins, Mr. Abbot of St. Lawrence, Mr. McKinstry of Chautauqua, and Mr. Bigelow of New-York.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 2 -- Unofficial reports received by The Commercial-Appeal from eight counties in Western and Middle Tennessee leave no doubt that the Democratic tickets have gone through with majorities greater than in 1892. The counties heard from are Gibson, Haygood, Fayette, Madison, McNairy, Rutherford, Davidson, and Shelby.

Russel B. Hoyt was committed yesterday in default of $10,000 bail by United States Commissioner Alexander to await examination on a charge of counterfeiting United States notos Mr. Forsyth, Chief of the Secret Service Bureau, who made the arrest, refused to give details, on the ground that the arrest of others believed to be implicated with Hoyt might be prevented.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- There was a horse race here to-day that was worth going many miles to see. It was for the Montana Stakes, at a mile, and in it the fleet sprinter Dr. Hasbrouck managed to lower the colors of the great horses Lamplighter, Clifford, and Key El Santa Anita, the latter winner of the rich American Derby.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 2 -- A dispute as to the ownership of a rowboat was the cause of a lively bout at fisticuffs here lost evening, between Moses G. Wanzor, a sugar broker at 100 Wall Street, New-York, and a member of the New-York Stock Exchange, whose Summer home is here, and William Miller, a green grocer and peddler.

Palmer Cleveland, thirty-eight years old, of 237 West Forty-eighth Street, well known as a sporting man and a race-horse trainer and driver, was a prisoner in Yorkville Court yesterday afternoon, charged by Mrs. Kate A. Mullane, thirty-two years old, of 251 West Fifty-first Street, with assault. Mr. Cleveland is of slight build and good looking.
The following plans for new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

The story published in a morning newspaper yesterday that permission had been given to Superintendent Byrnes by the Western Union Telegraph Company to tap its wires at Houston Street, and thus receive news from distant points, was indignantly denied at the Western Union office yesterday.

Berlin, Aug. 2 -- Major General van Gossler, Director of the Prussian Department of War, has gone to Wilhelmshaven to urge the Emperor to countermand the annual military manoeuvres in the Elburg district owing to the prevalence of cholera.

If readers of The New-York Times who are unable to obtain a copy of this newspaper will communicate that fact to the Publication Office, stating the location of the newsdealer who was unable to supply them or whose supply was stated by the dealer to have been exhausted, it would be appreciated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A bill to further restrict immigration to the United States, drawn at the Treasury Department and approved by the Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of State, was presented in the Senate to-day by Mr. Hill, Chairman of the Committee on Immigration.

Commissioner Daly transmitted to the Mayor yesterday his report of the operations of the Department of Public Works for the quarter ended June 30, 1894. The expenditures from the various funds were as follows:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 2 -- The agitation of the water question by The New-York Times has prompted the people of this city to more decided action than they have ever taken before. Not only has the Board of Works begun to blow off the pipes, a work it positively refused to consider a week ago, but the people have begun to hold public meetings on the subject.

The applications of Election Inspectors, poll clerks, and ballot clerks of the Committee of Thirty were filed with the Clerk of the Police Department at Police Headquarters, at 2:08 P.M. yesterday. A list of the names was at the same time placed on record at the Bureau of Elections.

Dog Catcher Thomas O'Keefe of 234 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, has been suspended. He does not mind that. He would not accept reinstatement at a salary of $5,000 a year, he says. He agrees with Robert Theil, who resigned a few days ago, that the public has a dangerous prejudice against dog catchers.

Toledo, Ohio, Aug. 2 -- Edward Henrahan, who came here from Binghamton, N.Y., and who was supposed to have been drowned when he jumped into the river with suicidal intent Tuesday night, swam ashore, and coming to this city persuaded Miss Mabel Rackie, for whose hand he had been an unsuccessful suitor, to elope with him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The envoys of ex-Queen Liliuokalani, who have been here since Tuesday night, will be received by Secretary Gresham as a delegation either to-morrow or the next day. This is according to the information given out by Mr. Wideman, one of the Commissioners, who saw the Secretary at the State Department this afternoon, shortly after 1 o'clock.

ELMIRA, Aug. 2 -- An attempt was made to burn the State Reformatory during the darkness of the night preceding the closing day of the prosecution's case at the investigation. Two men, at least, armed, had scaled the walls and were making their way toward the most inflammable part of the buildings when a guard discovered them.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 2 -- There was a large attendance at the temperance camp meeting today. The address at the morning period was made by Mrs. M.C. Leavitt, the around-the-world white-ribbon missionary. "The Democratic Party," she said, "although boasting some honorable men, is managed by servants of Satan. The same is true of the Republican Party.

TIEN-TSIN, Aug. 2 -- The Emperor of China has issued a manifesto in response to Japan's declaration of war. The manifesto declares that the Emperor accepts the war which Japan has thrust upon him and orders the Viceroys and Commanders of the imperial forces to "root these pestilential Japanese from their lairs."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The special committee appointed by the Senate to investigate the alleged sugar scandal presented to the Senate to-day a report, which is signed by every member of the committee. A supplemental report has been prepared by Messrs. Lodge and Davis, Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- In speaking of the year's foreign commerce of the United States, Mr. Worthington C. Ford, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, said to-day:

A newspaper published a story yesterday that Russell Sage and George Gould might part company, because Mr. Gould was wasting his time and money yachting in England. Mr. Sage had let other stories take care of themselves, but he drew the line at this one by a statement making a complete denial of it.
The minority report or Messrs. Lodge and Davis is as follows:

Mr. John Jacob Astor, who arrived in town from Newport yesterday, said there was no truth in the story that he had bought the Hotel Metropole property, on Broadway, between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A spirit of indolence manifested itself in the House to-day, the result of combined hot weather and lack of necessity to do anything, and at 3 o'clock adjournment was effected without anything of importance having been accomplished.

Santo Caserio killed President Carnot in a landau, in the Place de la Bourse, at Lyons, June 23, at 9:15 o'clock P.M. Since then the police have been on the track of his accomplices. It has traced his itinerary from Cette to Lyons, every step of which he has himself apparently described truthfully.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The Daily News correspondent in Berlin says that a German Colonel commands the Japanese forces in Corea. Major Freiherr von Gotschreiber, formerly of the German general staff, is organizing the national general staff of Japan.
The weekly budget of news Issued yesterday by the League of American Wheelmen Racing Board, contains another list of Class B men and other announcements of interest to all cyclists. The items follow:
ROCHESTER, Aug. 2. -- While the Democrats in this section are falling into line, the Republicans of Western New-York are falling out.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 2 -- For some reason not ascertainable, the Pei Yang squadron, which sailed for Corea, returned to Che Foo this afternoon.
CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 3. -- West Brighton has been in darkness since midnight. On account of an accident in the gas works, the supply has been shut off.

John Lindlau, a cigar merchant of 110 East Houston Street, applied to Justice Simms, in the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday, for a warrant for the arrest of Carl Werner, or Gustave Wasner, the Lexow witness, who keeps a saloon at Fifth Street and Avenue B. Werner was held in $2,000 ball last Tuesday, to await the action of the Grand Jury, for attempting to bribe Policeman Cohen of the Fourteenth Precinct.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- All the testimony taken by the committee with reference to sugar speculation by Senators accompanies the report. A great deal of it has been published in these dispatches, but much of it is new and very interesting. That of Senator Camden and Senator Smith is of particular interest.

LYONS, Aug. 2 -- The trial of Santo Caserio for the murder of President Carnot began here this morning. Caserio was transferred from the prison to the Palace of Justice at 5 o'clock under a strong escort of gendarmes.

London appeared as a buyer of the international specialties early in yesterday's market, and for a time prices were distinctly strong. The foreigners evidently shared the opinion of conservative onlookers on this side, that an adjustment of the tariff dispute will be reached and that ultimately a bill of some kind will be passed by Congress.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Compared with the closing figures of yesterday, West Chicago advanced 2 1/4 points, closing strong at 133 3/4, after having sold at 134 1/2 in the first part of the last session. Opening at 132, it remained steady for a time, and then declined to 131 1/2, which proved to be the lowest price of the day.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 2 -- he bone of contention in to-day's Democratic State Convention was the platform of principles upon which the candidate nominated will go before the people of the State. There was no trouble about the nominees, all contention having been eliminated by the decisive action of the primaries except in one instance.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- The special order at the evening session of the convention was the report of the Committee on Privileges and Elections unseating the five Democratic delegates from the Sixth (Gravesend) District and seating their Republican opponents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Senator Walsh has had prepared by the Treasury Department a statement showing the average ad valorem rates of duty of the Mills bill, McKinley law, and Senate bill, and the percentage of reduction made by the Senate bill. This table will be incorporated in a few remarks Mr. Walsh will make in the next few days.

ow utterly blind to the one fact more important to their calculations than all others are the professional politicians! From February to July, for one full half year, the Democratic leaders of the Senate were laboring to avoid the condemnation which they thought the country would visit on the Democratic Party if "some sort of a tariff bill" were not enacted.

From The London Globe. Here is another contribution to a complete dictionary of the English language during the nineteenth century. The pretty little word "liftlet" veils under a decent obscurity the prosaic piece of cork which finds a home in the boots of those who wish to look taller than they really are. It is, of course, chiefly used by the new manlet.

Flemington, N.J., Aug. 2 -- During a shower early this morning lightning struck and burned George Van Sinderan's barn. The season's crops and four horses were consumed. The loss is about $4,000. The large hay barn belonging to Edward Deats, filled with hay, was also burned. Loss, $2,500. A barn containing three horses and six cows, belonging to Ross Jones, was also consumed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Senator Smith of New-Jersey has addressed to certain of his constituents living in Englewood, who criticised his course on the Tariff bill, the following letter:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The Hydrographic Office has gone to some expense in issuing a chart showing the tracks of storms during the months of August, September, and October for a period of six years from 1888. The information is compiled from the records of the office and the United States Weather Bureau.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 2 -- It is reported from a semi-official source that the Government here, desiring a prompt settlement of the Japanese-Chinese conflict is willing to act in complete accord with Great Britain. Should the joint efforts fail to restore peace, Russia is determined not to let any power take possession of any part of Corea.

The Brooklyn Presbytery held a special meeting in the South Third Street Presbyterian Church, South Third Street and Driggs Avenue, yesterday afternoon, to take action on the dismissal of two of its presbyters to outside parishes.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 2 -- A meeting of the American Railway Union at Argentine 400 Santa Fe railway employes, who were recently summoned to appear before the United States Court at Topeka, took action, refusing to obey the mandate of the court. During the recent, strike the strikers were served with copies of restraining orders from Judge Foster's court at Topeka enjoining them from trespassing upon or molesting the company's property.

A short while ago, while on a visit down East, the Giants stopped over at Boston and took part in three games of ball without winning one. For the last few days the Boston champions have been basking in the sunshine on the Polo Grounds, and they departed for home last night with two defeats and a drawn game charged against them.
Ex-State Treasurer Elliot F. Danforth on the need of Democratic harmony, said:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 2 -- The identity of Vyvian Grey, the English newspaper man who recently tramped from Boston to Monterey, Mexico, on a wager that he could cover the journey in a given time without spending a cent, has become known here. To Gov. McKinley's private secretary, James Boyle, Grey said his real name was Sir Henry Wilmot, Bart., V.C., K.C.B.. of Chaddesden Hall, Derbyshire, England.

The fair and horse show to be given at Leesburg, Va., on Aug. 20, 21, 22, and 23, by the Loudoun County Fair Association, ought to be the finest exhibition seen in the South since the war. E.P. Burch, President, and Henry Sellman, Secretary of the association, have been at work perfecting the many details, and nothing has been left undone which experience gained at similar exhibitions in New-York suggested.
CHRISTIANIA, Aug. 2 -- The fishing vessel Malygen has arrived at Tromso from North Spitzbergen, with Capt. Bottolfsen and three seamen of Walter Wellman's Ragnvald Jarl aboard her.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- There was a record broken at to-day's bicycle race meet in this city, but not for speed. The number at entries in the contests was more by 101 than those at Springfield, Mass., last year. The total entry to-day was 646. The former record was 535. The heats for Friday and Saturday's tournaments took all the afternoon to run and were uninteresting.

The case for the prosecution was closed yesterday in the trial of ex-Ward Man Jeremiah S. Levy of the Eleventh Police Precinct, Eldridge Street Station, on the charge of bribery in having accepted money from Charles Krumm, the Chrystie Street concert hall keeper, for permitting him to conduct his place without a license.

Charles J. Patterson, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the reorganized Democratic Party of Kings County, of which Edward M. Shepard is the leader, is strongly in favor of Democratic harmony. He said:

ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- Interest in the efforts to promote harmony and unity in the Democratic Party is increasing. The general feeling here is that the Democrats will come together sooner or later, and that by the time the State Convention is held -- about Sept. 25, at Saratoga -- the party will be in prime condition to meat and defeat the common enemy.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 2. -- At this morning's session of the National Convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union fraternal greetings were received from the International Woman's Christian Temperance Union, the non-partisan Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Minneapolis, and the Veronica League of Philadelphia. The Keeley Leagues at Dwight also sent greetings.

The sub-committee of five of the Republican State Committee met yesterday in Parlor D R of the Fifth Avenue Hotel to listen to the arguments of the contesting Republican factions in New-York and Syracuse. The hearing was preliminary to determining which, faction, in these cities should be recognized by the State Committee and so be considered regular.

Two young members of the Nautilus Boat Club of Brooklyn were rescued from drowning yesterday afternoon in the bay, off Bay Ridge, by a crew from the Sandy Hook steamer Monmouth, after clinging to their overturned boat for about half an hour. Although they came to the city on the steamer, no one thought to ask the men for their names.

A new company for the distribution of spirits in competition with the Whisky Trust has been organized and will be in operation without delay. Several large distillers outside of the trust have come together in this combination. The new company will have its headquarters in this city and branches in the principal cities of the Eastern and Western States.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- I most unqualifiedly approve of the efforts now being made by The New-York Times to unite all elements of the Democratic Party in this State and in the Nation.

RIVERTON, N.J., Aug. 2 -- The sportsmen who journeyed to the grounds of the Riverton Gun Club to-day were amply repaid for their trouble, as they were enabled to witness one of the firest exhibitions of trap shooting ever given in this country. The occasion was the sixth match in the series for the Riverton Challenge Plate. The contestants were Robert A. Welch and James Wolstencroft.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2 -- Baroness von Keyserlingh left to-day for Long Branch. She will return.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- M.F. Goodbody, the English expert, is the winner of the first prize in the Long Island tennis tournament, and to-morrow will meet W.A. Larned, the present holder of the championship. Goodbody defeated John Howland, the Yale crack, pretty easily to-day in the finals.

The cause of civil service reform has recently gained a very substantial advantage -- greater perhaps than any conquered since the Pendleton bill was established. The United States Civil Service Commission has been given the appointment and control of the clerks in its employment.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 3 -- Strange circumstances are developing regarding the man who represents himself as Charles M. Hobbs, and who, it is alleged, endeavored to swindle the Michigan Electric Company out of $50 by claiming that he was the Chas. M. Hobbs, who is purchasing agent of the Denver and Rio Grande Railway Company.

Army. -- The following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Corps of Engineers are ordered: Lieut. William L. Sibert will be relieved from duty under immediate orders of Col. Orlando M. Poe, Corps of Engineers, and will proceed to take station at Little Rock, Ark., relieving Capt. Carl F. Palfrey, who will proceed to Detroit, Mich., and report to Col. Poe for duty.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

-- Lawyer Kapper yesterday obtained an order from Justice Bartlett, in the Kings County Supreme Court, enjoining the Nassau Electric Railroad Company from crossing the tracks of the Brooklyn and Rockaway Beach Railroad Company at Flatlands, on the ground that the company had not secured the privilege of crossing the tracks as prescribed by law.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -- Five sealing boats fastened together have been found floating in the Bering Sea by a British man-of-war. In some of the boats were hunters' guns and a quantity of ammunition, but no provisions.

The Giants had an excellent opportunity to move up a peg in the League race yesterday, but they failed to embrace it. They were scheduled to play two games with the Brooklyns. As the latter have not been putting up championship ball of late the followers of the club of this city naturally looked for a couple of victories.

The road run to Port Jervis, N.Y., will combine more to interest the cycler and tourist than almost any run out of New-York of the same length.
