Hills will be found numerous and steep, but without hills there can be no scenery and grand views. Incidental to the trip are Lake Hopatcong, Delaware Water Gap, and Manunka Chunk.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Sir Halliday Macartney, Councilor of the Chinese Legation, and the new Chinese Minister called at Osborne House to-day and the Minister presented his credentials.

The prospects of a spilt in the Republican Party in this city this Fall were promising yesterday. Both the Milhollandites and the adherents of the Bliss-Patterson faction were full of right after the stormy Hearing before the State Committee's sub-committee Thursday. The serious business of the day was the drawing up of briefs, which will be submitted to the State Committee, which in to meet next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The last of the appropriation bills -- the General Deficiency -- passed the Senate to-day and will now go to a conference, in which the disagreeing votes of the two houses will be reconciled and adjusted.

HAMILTON BEACH, Ontario, Aug. 3 -- About 2,000 people lined the shore at Hamilton Beach this afternoon to witness the trial heats in connection with the fifteenth annual regatta of the Canadian Association of Amateur Oarsmen.

The industrials were the feature of yesterday's stock speculation, the trading in Sugar being so heavy as to practically overshadow the remainder of the market. It opened anywhere between 103 and 104, and held between those figures until late in the day, when it touched 105 1/2, and closed at 105, 2 7/8 points higher than yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 3 -- Democrats generally and friends of the Administration particularly are felicitating themselves over the happy outcome of the State Convention yesterday. The result was a pronounced victory for the Cleveland and sound-money men.

The loan of $1,800,000 referred to in The New-York Times yesterday was made by the Mutual Life Insurance Company as a building loan on the New-York Hotel property, at Broadway, Washington and Waverley Places, and Mercer Street. This property was bought by Mr. Randolph Guggenheimer and the late Henry Clausen at auction in a partition sale of the John Jay estate a few months ago at $1,300,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A cablegram was received at the Japanese Legation this evening saying that on July 29 a portion of the Japanese troops stationed at Seoul made an advance upon the Chinese position at Shan Yeng, where were stationed a larger number of soldiers than in the Japanese body, and, after a fight which lasted several hours, the Chinese were routed and driven from their stronghold.

The story of the new opposition to the Whisky Trust which was published in The Times yesterday was read with marked interest in Wall Street circles. The trust has imposed on the trade its own terms for so long a time that it was difficult for many of its friends to realize that at last it was to meet with real competition in the distribution of spirits.

The final match in the Palisade Boat Club's tournament was decided yesterday afternoon on the courts at Gold Street and the Hudson River, Yonkers. After a close finish with P.C. Myers, Carroll Moore was selected as challenger for the Baldwin team's trophy. His match with Walter E. Hodgman, the present holder of the emblem, will take place this afternoon.
LYONS, Aug. 3 -- Santo Caserio was to-day convicted of the murder of President Carnot. The jury had been asked to pass upon these two questions:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- An address has been issued to the colored citizens and voters of Alabama, signed by C.H.J. Taylor, President of the Negro National Democratic League, and R.G. Still, chief of the Bureau of Organization of the Democratic Congressional Committee, acting under authority of the Negro National Democratic League.

A dispatch was received in Montclair, N. J., last night from London announcing the death of George Inness, the noted landscape painter, who was a resident of Montclair. He died in Scotland, where he was traveling for his health. The body will be brought home for burial, it having been arranged that it be sent on the Steamer Anchoria, sailing from Glasgow next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A special order issued from the headquarters of the Department of the Columbia, Vancouver Barracks, Washington, brings into sharp relief the fact that there are portions of the States last admitted into the Union which have never yet been thoroughly explored.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Lieut. James A. Maney, Fifteenth Infantry, goes scot free. The court-martial which tried him upon charges of breach of discipline, growing out of the killing of Capt. Alfred Hedberg, Fifteenth Infantry, found Lieut. Maney guilty of writing a menacing letter and not guilty as to all the other charges and specifications made against him.

"Would you be surprised to tear," as the late Lord Chief Justice, when Sir John Coleridge, used so frequently to inquire in his cross-examination of the "Claimant," that the question of Oliver Cromwell having a statue in Westminster Hall has been debated in and out of Parliament for fifty years?

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Things are rapidly taking shape here now. The Democratic State Committee has been called to meet here next Thursday evening, at 7:30 o'clock, and at the meeting of this committee it will be decided to call the Democratic State Convention to meet in this town on Tuesday, Sept. 25, the week following the Republican State Convention.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 3 -- The farmers of Riverhead fasted to-day and prayed for rain to save their crops from ruin. The rain came even while they prayed, and now no happier lot of tillers of the soil can be found.

An event of much interest to wheelmen will be the twenty-five-mile handicap road race on Labor Day, Sept. 3, under the auspices of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey. The Race Committee having in charge the details of the event predict that it will be the biggest affair of its kind ever held in the State. Entries are already pouring in from the crack roadmen, thus early showing the interest displayed in the race.

A prompt response came yesterday to the appeal of St. John's Guild for help for its Floating Hospital. The following letter was received by Col. William L. Strong, Treasurer of the guild, and the Trustees sincerely hope, for the sake of the suffering little ones, that other clubs, as well as individuals, will extend their aid:
A jury in Coroner Dobbs's court yesterday found that Daniel J. Fagan of 67 West One Hundredth Street came to his death at the hands of a person or persons unknown to them.

ALBANY, Aug. 3 -- It is possible that the Judiciary Committee of the convention, which has practically completed its work, will report to the convention on Tuesday or Wednesday of next week the new judiciary article. A few details are yet to be arranged before the committee will take the risk of launching its work in the convention.

That the movement to bring about unity in the Democratic Party is meeting with hearty support received additional proof yesterday. Many more prominent Democrats put themselves on record as indorsing The Times's attitude.

When the subject of sewage disposal is treated you have to call into play the experiences or "many engineers, chemists, and biologists"; accordingly, as Mr. Waring says, the literature of sewage is as voluminous as it is "clouded with much speculation and conflicting testimony." We concur in Mr. Waring's modest assumption, "that the art of sewage disposal is now only at the threshold of its real success."

SARATOGA, Aug. 3 -- The New-York Times has undertaken many political enterprises, but none, in my judgment, so popular with Democrats as its efforts to secure harmony in their party preparatory to the Fall campaign. Families have their bickerings and bitter quarrels, but, after suggestion and deliberation, good counsel prevails and reunions are the order of the day.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 -- Some activity was shown in the market for local securities today and prices generally were firm. The "Telephones," especially, manifested strength, New-England Telephone selling up 1 3/4, to 65, and Erie Telephone, 1, to 47, receding later to 46 1/2. Bell Telephone was quiet at 198.

Josie Gorman, a pretty young woman, of 566 Broome Street, says she heard her parrot down stairs calling out: "What you want?" several times, yesterday afternoon. Unfortunately, she did not heed the question of the intelligent parrot. She wished she had when a friend entered her room and asked her if she had sent a man out with her new gray silk and velvet dress.

It is quite as essential to national success in 1896 that the promises made to the people of the whole country in 1892 be kept as faithfully as the promises from year to year made by the State Democracy have been kept in New-York State. The feeling among Democrats throughout the State seems to be that all should be more interested in the success of their party than in creating or perpetuating factional strife.

There is something remarkable about the horse Tom Tough that his backers for a long time have been trying to solve. This horse can show remarkable reversals of form. About a year ago, at the Morris Park meeting, Clerico rode Tom Tough in a race in which Mr. Jordan's horse showed such a startling reversal of form that horse and rider were ruled off.
In the very middle of the day yesterday Alexander Newburger was made the victim of a murderous assault in his jewelry store, 1,317 Broadway, between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets.
"Talk about suffering from the heat: Why, even children do not suffer so much in hot weather as women do!"

ALBANY, Aug. 3 -- The Democratic State Committee will meet at the Grand Union Hotel, Saratoga, oh Thursday evening, Aug. 9, at 7:30 o'clock, when the time and place for holding the Democratic State Convention will be selected.

President Clausen of the Park Board has gone out of town and will not return until Monday. When he comes back he will probably bring with him the letter which his colleagues authorized him to write to Mayor Gilroy in answer to the one sent to the Mayor by Messrs. St. Gaudens, Chase, and White.

A real infant phenomenon keeps all the medical men and pedagogues of the good old town of Brunswick in a state of wonder and delight. The little son of a local butcher, a baby just two years old, can read with perfect ease anything written or printed in German or Latin characters. A few weeks ago three Brunswick doctors had the baby introduced to them at the house of one of the learned gentlemen.

LYONS, Aug. 3 -- An explosion took place in a factory to-day, and it was at first reported that Anarchists had set off a quantity of dynamite in consequence of the sentencing of Caserio, the assassin. This report was untrue. The police say the explosion was caused by a pattern designer, who carelessly dropped a match into the orifice of a shell, kept as a memento of the war of 1870.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 3 -- action of the Emperor in divesting Viceroy Li Hung Chang of the Order of the Yellow Jacket has fallen like a thunderbolt here, as it is feared that the incident will lead to his complete overthrow.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- The rain of this morning prevented all play in the tennis tournament in the early part of the day, and as it would be impossible to get the courts in firstclass condition before to-morrow morning the championship match in the singles between M. F. Goodbody, the Irish expert, and W.A. Larned was postponed by mutual consent until to-morrow morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3 -- The principal cottage entertainment to-night was a dinner party given by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt for her daughter, Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt. It was a gathering of young people over whom Mrs. Vanderbilt presided. The table was covered with a profusion of pink sweetpeas.

At a well-attended meeting of first mortgage bondholders of the Grand Trunk and North Michigan Division of the Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railway Company, held in the office of Cyrus J. Lawrence Co., in this city, yesterday afternoon, resolutions were adopted providing that a committee of five shall be appointed to represent the bondholders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Some escitement was created this afternoon by the report that the conferrees on the Tariff bill had come to an agreement upon the sugar schedule; that the conference soon would conclude its work, and that the Congress might adjourn within ten days.
SCHENECTADY, Aug. 3 -- The plea of The New-York Times for inter-party harmony can be made very effective if the Democratic press of the State will earnestly unite in an effort to that end.

A few days ago it was reported that a Veterinary Inspector employed by the Tuberculosis Commission had examined the dairy herd of the Oneida Community, found that thirty-one out of fifty-nine cows were tuberculous, and killed the diseased animals. It is now announced that the same Inspector has examined a dairy herd of thirty-four Jerseys in the town of Floyd, near Rome, and ascertained that twenty-five of these cows have the disease.

The match race for $2,000 between the well-known New-York trotters Captain Lyons and Cranston is to be trotted at Fleetwood Park to-day. In addition to this event the driving club has made up a programme of three other races, so that a full afternoon's sport may be assured. The proceeds of the meeting, which are to be turned over to local charities, bid fair to be substantial.
Let me now give you an instance of wonderful heroism, rising to meet the demands of a sudden crisis.

NEW-HAVEN., Conn., Aug. 3 -- Richard Battin, telegraph operator at Police Headquarters, New-York City, through his counsel, Assistant District Attorney McManus of New-York, appeared before Gov. Morris in this city this afternoon to argue for the extradition of Mrs. Angle E. Battin, proprietress of the Delano House, Greenwich, Conn., against whom charges were preferred and a warrant procured before Police Justice Hogan of New-York, July 23.
The following is a list of all those who are booked to sail for Europe to-day on the following steamships to-day:
GLENS FALLS, Aug. 3 -- I am fully in sympathy with the movement started by The New-York Times. I see no reason why it should not be successful.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 -- An Innocent man has served five years in the Maryland Penitentiary. He is George Lorber, sentenced in 1889 by Judge Stump to eighteen years' imprisonment, for arson. Had it not been for the recommendation of the jury, it is possible that Lorber would have been sentenced to death.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The export of gold to Europe and the discontinuance last November of the issue of Treasury notes under the Sherman silver-purchase law, show very pointedly in the Treasury statement of circulation, issued monthly.

Benjamin Greenwald of 164 East One Hundred and Eighth Street was a prisoner in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, charged with setting fire to a pile of boxes on Third Avenue, near One Hundred and Eighth Street, but he was discharged. His brother said the policeman who arrested him was intoxicated.

A man who was at the last Suffolk Assizes sentenced to fifteen lashes of the "cat" and to undergo a short term of hard labor for highway robbery at Great Cornard has just returned to his native village in Essex, and he has given a description of his punishment. Two other men who were jointly indicted with him were sentenced to similar punishment.

The Times is permitted to publish the following private letter from a Connecticut lady who has resided in Corea for several years. The letter is sent to Mrs. Arms from her daughter, Mrs. L. A. Scranton of New-Haven. It seems that she understands the situation there:
The arrest of Russell B. Hoyt and Samuel Massey, charged with counterfeiting, is said by Chief Forsythe of the United States Secret Service to be the most important that has been made.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The greatly-advertised mile race, unpaced, each man going his own gait, alone, took place at to-day's race meet in this city. The day was windy and cold. This race was reserved until the close of what was in every respect an ideal day's racing.
The Professional Woman's League had a second round robin yesterday afternoon. The round robin is to become, henceforth, a regular part of the league's literary exercises.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Horace W. Billington of 655 Jersey Avenue is a large property owner. He has been for years an advocate of a new water supply, and says the water drawn from the Passaic is as dangerous to health as it is unpleasant to taste and smell.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: One point in the objectionable Senate sugar schedule which seems to have escaped general observation is that any ad valorem rate on raw and refined will deprive consumers of that small concession in the McKinley bill which places sugar not over No. 16 Dutch standard on the same basis as raw.

From The London Daily News, July 18. On his way to Varzin yesterday Prince Bismarck briefly addressed the crowd who had gathered at the Berlin terminus of the Stettin Railway to welcome him on his arrival. Among the people there were numerous students, who had been deputed by their commilltones to greet the ex-Chancellor. He said:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Japanese Legation has received an official detailed report of the sinking of the Chinese transport, which shows that the Japanese acted only after considerable aggravation, the Chinese man-of-war Chi-Yuen having displayed a white flag above the Japanese ensigns, which constitutes the most unpardonable insult known to naval warfare.

PULLMAN, Ill., Aug. 3 -- When the steam whistle blew at the works this morning for workmen to begin their day's labor 500 men, a majority of whom were formerly strikers, reported for duty in the repair department. Forty more had applied for their old places before tire noon whistle blew. The total number of men at work in this department at work at the time of the strike was 600.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 -- Ten of the thirteen incorporators of the Meigs Elevated Railway system met at the office of Mr. George H. Towle, their counsel, in this city, today, and organized the Boston Elevated Railway Company.

In spite of the efforts of the Police and Sire Departments in this city and Brooklyn to discover the incendiaries who have terrorized tenement districts in both cities, they do not appear to make much headway.
The following plans for new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department during the past twenty-four hours ending at noon yesterday:

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 3 -- Mrs. Honora McCarty, who lives in Shaftsbury, Bennington County, on the line of the Rutland and Troy Railway, recently celebrated her one hundred and fourth birthday. She was born in the parish of Drumlake, County Cork, Ireland. Her parents were Patrick and Julia Collins, and she was the third of fourteen children, all of whom were dead when she came to America, thirty years ago.

Cycling for ladies has now become quite a recognized fashionable pastime in France, and a millinery establishment there has just brought out a new cycling hat, which is likely to please, as it is made of white pique, and is extremely light and comfortable in wear. It is stiffened round the edges and bordered with ribbon, and makes an efficient protection against the sun.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Theodore Burckner of 450 West Forty-seventh Street, New-York, committed suicide by shooting himself through the head in Juniper Avenue, near Maiden Lane, this evening. He made no statement before he died.

State Senator Charles L. Guy expressed himself enthusiastically yesterday in favor of Democratic unity, in which he has long been a believer, and of the wisdom and necessity of whiich he is now more than ever convinced. He said:

The recent distinguished foreign visitors to Windsor were greatly struck by the magnificence of the royal plate at the Castle. Even the Czarowitch, accustomed to the almost barbaric splendor of the Court functions in his native land, was fain to admit that for solid worth he had never seen the equal of the English plate.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As the defiant attitude of brave Japan against the colossal Chinese Empire is attracting general attention, some additional information about that country may be of interest.

The use of bicycles in all the armies of Europe has been enormously increased during the last two years. In Holland members of the various bicycle clubs who have already attained their twenty-first year and are proficient in their art are invited to join the army under certain advantageous conditions.
Wheat closed steady at a decline of 5/8 @ 3/4 c, with a dull trade, and influenced by the West, with foreign houses selling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Representative Dolliver of Iowa had an interesting interview to-day with the officials of the Japanese Legation, respecting the employment of American officers in the military and naval service of the Mikado.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Baron Nordenskjold the Swedish explorer, has telegraphed to the Geographical Society that an expedition for the relief of the Wellman party would be very desirable, as probably it will return very much exhausted to Mossel Bay.

-- In compliance with the expressed desire of Mayor John G. Peene in a message to the Common Council, that body has decided to turn several pieces of property along the river front into temporary parks or breathing places for the poor during August and September. Seats and electric lights will be placed in them.

-- In his "Kingdom of God Is Within You," Count Tolstoi attacks standing armies, and holds up the Emperor William to reprobation for various speeches to his guards. He thinks a great catastrophe is approaching. "We are standing on the threshold of the murderous war of social revolution, terrific in its miseries, beside which, as those who are preparing it tell us, the horrors of 1793 will be child's play."

Several of the first mortgage bondholders of the Carolina Central Railroad were in session at 60 Wall Street for more than two hours yesterday afternoon. The railway company defaulted on the July payment of the bonds, and the bondholders are trying to arrive at some agreement as to what action they shall take to bring the railway company to a proper accounting.

Londoners are noted as a weak and longsuffering race, but even in them there is a limit to patience. They tranquilly submit to be governed by Scotchmen, Irishmen, and provincials, and utter not a murmur; but when they are taunted with being "incapable of speaking other than London English," and, therefore, unable to conduct a case in the law courts, they have a right to turn round and resent what is a calumny.

A heavy thunderstorm broke over the city about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, and for an hour and a half rain fell in torrents. The storm was accompanied by a northwest wind that blew nine miles an hour, and the atmosphere was cleared and cooled. Nearly three-quarters of an inch of rain fell.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, Aug. 3. -- The second monthly ball of the season took place to-night in the Arverne Hotel. W. Johnson Quinn, the popular manager of the house, surprised his guests by the display of cut flowers, exotic and flowering plants, and decorations. The hotel parlor was a veritable garden spot. The music was furnished by the Imperial Hungarian Band.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 3 -- The election in this State yesterday was for the State judiciary and county offices. Only on the Supreme Court Judges' ticket were party lines drawn.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 -- An unsuccessful attempt was made last night to rob the Texas express on the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway, but the plans of the robbers were frustrated by the determined resistance of the express messenger, who received two bullet wounds while defending his charge. Train No. 3, in charge of Conductor Mansfield, left the St. Louis Union Station at 8:25 P.M.

The trial of Patrolman Jeremiah S. Levy, charged with bribery in taking money from Charles Krumm, the proprietor of a concert saloon at 107 Chrystie Street, and allowing him to carry on his business in violation of law after his license had expired, was brought to a conclusion yesterday, except for the verdict.

-- The cruiser New-York is now taking coal at Tompkinsville, S.I., preparatory to leaving for League Island Navy Yard, Philadelphia, where the Pennsylvania Naval Reserve Battalion will be taken on board Aug. 8 and given a three days' cruise. The vessel will then return to New-York.

The Hon. J.J. Stranahan is the Superintendent of the Government fish hatcheries at Put-In Bay, editor of The Chagrin Falls Exponent, and one of the most prominent men in Northern Ohio. When he went to Europe a few weeks ago he took his kodak with him. Being of an artistic turn of mind, he indulged in taking photographs here and there as he went about.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- By calling the Grand Circuit horses early to-day four events were disposed of, though it required seventeen heats to overtake the card. J.L. McCarthy of Chicago, who had been acting as one of the Judges earlier in the week, declined to serve again, and Col. Robert Hough, Secretary of the Pimlico Driving Club, Baltimore, took his place.

Miss L. E. Ramsey of Dublin, Ireland, a missionary of the English Presbyterian Church for five years among the densely populated and ignorant natives of ChinChew, China, is at the Occidental Hotel, Miss Ramsey and her friend, Miss Graham of London, also representing the English Presbyterian Church, are the only white missionaries in that part of China.

By far the most important subject with which the Constitutional Convention is Called upon to deal is that of separating municipal from general elections. Upon that depends absolutely the cause of reform in our City Governments. Without that as a condition there is little hope of success for local self-government or "home rule for cities."
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The Orpheus Glee Club of New-York furnished an artistic programme at the ladies' entertainment at the Montclair Club on Monday evening.

The backers of favorites had a hard day of it at Brighton Beach yesterday, for of the five races on the flat, only one was won by the favorite. The steeplechase was won by Frank D. Beard's good fencer St. Anthony, who was the favorite, but as there is not much speculation on the jumping races the talent did not get even on the day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Three priests of the missionary order of La Salette, with a party of students, arrived in this city in November, 1892, from Grenoble, in the Province of Dauphine, France, not far from Lyons, and established a seminary for the propagation of the missionary spirit among the churches of the Hartford diocese.

The Larchmont Yacht Club, the most progressive of all the yacht clubs in this vicinity, is already laying plans for next season. This season the racing in the twenty-one-foot class has furnished the best sport around here. The racing has been a success, but the boats for any other purpose than racing are worthless.

It would be difficult to find a more charming retreat from heat, noise, and fashion -- those three essentials to a popular Summer resort -- than "Ashland-among-the-Hills.'' Its climate well merited the encomium of "salubrious," which the hotel prospectus originally conferred upon it. And yet, when young Mrs. Dupont told Mason "Welles of her impending departure thither, she denounced the place as "poky," and its indwellers as "frights."
The crowds of mothers and sick babies who flock to the wharves touched by the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild on its daily trips show no signs of diminution.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The Bloomfield Cycling and Athletic Association, which opened its new and pretty clubhouse in Bloomfield Avenue, here, Wednesday evening, and entertained its friends with music by the Euterpean Society Orchestra, a fine collation, and a dance, at which some 150 guests were present, is a flourishing, although a young, organization.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 4 -- The corn crop in Indiana this year will be one of the largest this State has ever produced. This is the statement made by Mr. Frederic P. Rush, the largest buyer of corn in Indiana, and his estimate agrees with that of the Weather Department and the figures received at the office of the State Board of Agriculture.

Within the last few days quite a throng of Americans have appeared in London, enough to constitute an after-season or overflow to the one now so quickly on the wane. From a social point of view this American season is in no way memorable -- it makes no impression on the parks, and but little on the theatres.

SAN DIKGO, Cal., Aug. 4 -- The United States revenue cutter Wolcott came into this port this week, after a night cruise up the coast, with the bodies of many flying fish lying on her deck. The victims, attracted by the cutter'a lights, had swarmed toward the illumination as moths around an electric light, and thus came to an untimely end.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 4 -- August brought few changes in the personnel of guests at the Glenada. The charms of Cold Spring Harbor are such that visitors usually spend their entire outing here. Proprietor Gerard reports a large demand for quarters in his house for this month. So far, he says, the season has been remarkably good and much ahead of former years.

The coast of New-Jersey is celebrated for many unique things, among which may be enumerated its fishermen, the fish which they leave in the sea, the prices charged for harmless, necessary drinks, its bathing suits, its dumb mosquitoes, and its volunteer life-saving-service. The last named is by far the most remarkable of its products.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The proposed ship canal from Philadelphia to the sea is still engaging the attention of engineers and commercial men of several States. There is in existence in Philadelphia a commission with an appropriation of $10,000 to expend for preliminary surveys, and the commission will be ready in a few weeks to put their engineers to work surveying three or four different routes.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The leaders of the Unionist Party in Parliament have served notice upon the Government that if the Evicted Tenants bill is transformed into a voluntary measure it will have some chance of receiving the gracious consideration of the House of Lords. The provision for compulsory reinstatement of an evicted tenant with the assistance of public funds, the Unionists denounce as a species of plunder.

BUFFALO,N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Though the Grand Circuit programme was three classes behind to-day, no effort was made to do more than dispose of Friday's card. The meeting has been considerably handicapped by the work done in the judges' stand, each day bringing some new cause for dissatisfaction. This has evidently hurt the attendance.

Some excellent road-racing resulted in the tenmile handicap held yesterday afternoon on the Merrick Turnpike, near Jamaica, L.I., by the Kings County Wheelmen. A strong wind blew directly in the faces of the riders for a part of the journey, otherwise a new record for the distance might have been made. Despite the heavy rain, of the morning, the course was in good shape.

SHREWSBURY INN, Seabright, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Progressive euchre is one of the principal amusements at the Shrewsbury, and the prizes, are expensive. Yachting is immensely popular since Mr. H.E. Williams sailed into the Shrewsbury River with his fast yacht. Among the guests who have engages rooms for the season are:

One of the coolest, quietest places in Brooklyn these hot days is the shadowy little court with the cool stone walls of Grace Church rising on one side and the trees, shrubs, and vines of a long row of gardens on the other.

We are in a position to judge more correctly of the British cavalry soldier, as Cromwell originally made him. We should seek our ideas of the man not in modern pictures which make a cavalry action of the civil war as headlong a matter as the charge of the Grays at Waterloo, but in the old pictures of Wouvermans, where the cavaliers caracole about firing pistols in each other's faces.

From The Boston Journal. A woman remarked the other day that she did not see how anybody could marry a prize fighter. It was a speech that showed lack of reflection and Ignorance of history. For centuries ago the Roman matron, aye, the wife of a Senator, would forsake children, country, sister, husband for the sake of a gladiator.

GOOD GROUNDS, L.I., Aug. 4 -- On the south side of Long Island, a mile from the ocean and almost under the shadow of the great Shinnecock Lighthouse, lies nestled in placid and picturesque beauty Ponquogue. This is the old Indian name, and in all the extended realm of Long Island this was the most famed fishing and hunting grounds of the aboriginal inhabitants.

The young doctors at Bellevue Hospital wore long faces yesterday morning. Their protest against the quality of the food Friday had made no noticeable difference in the spread which greeted their aesthetic gaze at breakfast. Warden O'Rourke said, with considerable emphasis, that as soon as the doctors presented a properly prepared preamble of complaints he would present the matter to the committee.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 4 -- The Baptist Vineyard Association has arranged an elaborate programme, commencing Aug. 13 and ending Aug. 20. Over twenty-five prominent speakers interested in religious work have been engaged, and the series of meeting's trill be most interesting.

Edward M. Shepard, Chairman, of the General Committee of the Kings County Democracy, has been interviewed at his Summer home on Lake George by a reporter for The Brooklyn Eagle, on the subject of Democratic harmony and union in Kings County. The interview follows:

The great fire, after all, did less for London by far than our happy isolation in a basin of orick earth. Egyptian Thebes of the hundred grates was built from the hard red sandstone of the Nile and the still harder and redder granite of Syene. Periclean Atlhens was built from the marble of Pentelicus, in which Pheidias could carve out with freer hand the living sculptures of the Parthenon.

Rene Bache in The Boston Transcript. There are in the world five great collections of snakes. One of them is in Washington, the property of Uncle Sam. The others are in London, Paris Berlin, and Vienna, all of them belonging to Governments. The collection here is hidden from public view in an out-of-the-way corner of the National Museum.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- In the race for the Congressional nomination among the Republicans of this district much party feeling has been aroused. The leading candidate in the race now is Henry C. Brewster, cashier of the Traders' National Bank of this city.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 4 -- The orders of Collector Wilkinson, putting in force the provisions of the recently-enacted national quarantine regulations, have caused endless fears among shippers here. The State Quarantine enforces a detention on vessels from infected ports of three days, while the new national regulations provide five days' delay.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 4 -- socially, the past week has been rather quiet. But the list of events to come at the various hotels indicates that the calm was only temporary. The intense heat has brought large numbers of guests, transient and permanent, from New-York and Brooklyn, and the hotels, as well as the cottages, have teemed with pleasure-seeking humanity.

The last week closed with a continuance of the hopeful feeling among real estate men which was manifest the week before. Fewer brokers are in town, as August is the most popular vacation month, but those who are here are on the alert for business. Many of them, also, have transactions in hand that are not only noteworthy but promise well.
NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 4 -- The hunts continue regularly twice a week and are well attended. Max W.Caspar of Leesburg, Va., brought a stable of fine horses to the Pier this week.

Senator Smith of New-Jersey testified before the Gray committee on June 16 that he had neither bought nor sold, directly or indirectly, "since the beginning of this session of Congress," any Sugar Trust stock, or shares, or certificates. Afterward there was brought to the attention of the committee the assertion of somebody that Mr. Smith had bought Sugar Trust stock.

The brain-wrecking quarter-fifteen system of handicapping will be again tested by the Staten Island Cricket Club in the tennis tournament for club members which began yesterday afternoon on the courts at Livingstone. The quarter-fifteen system comes from England, but it will in all probability be laid on the shelf, as its delicate gradings and shadings and complicated scoring when owed odds are given would tax the brain of a Newton or a Laplace.

Why does Mr. Collier call his particular Indian "Mr. Picket-Pin"? Because "the short, stout, wooden pin driven into the ground to hold down the sides of the lodge, or used as a fixture to which to picket a pony at night, plays the same part among shillelahs that Mr. Picket-Pin does among his fellows."

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- The British steamer Ethelred, Capt. Hopkins, which, left here Aug. 3 at 8 P.M. for Port Antonio, Jamaica, returned here this morning in a damaged condition, having been in collision with the two-masted schooner J.K. Manning, Capt. Camp, of and from Philadelphia for Hingham, coal laden.
SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The sixty-third annual camp meeting will begin next Thursday on the old camp grounds about a mile north of this village.

WOODSIDE, L.I., Aug. 4 -- This village is alarmed over the actions of a strange woman who makes her appearance in the vicinity of the Episcopal Church every night and frightens passers by by thrusting a big pistol in their faces.

The Rev. George T. Rider. The Rev. George T. Rider, a well-known teacher and writer on religious subjects, died at his home, 726 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. He had been of late years engaged in writing for The Churchman, of this city and The Living Church of Chicago.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 4. -- The Missouri corn crop is in all sorts of conditions. In the northwest the corn has been almost entrely destroyed in a dozen or more counties, and all through the northern half of the State the drought has done great damage.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The regular season of the State Camp closed at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The Third Battery assembled at 2:30 and marched to Roa Hook Station, dragging their Gatling guns. Fifteen minutes later the Fourteenth Regiment marched out of camp, headed by the regimental band.

Our domestics are not very troublesome to provide for. They need neither bed nor blanket, but roll themselves up in a rug and sleep where they feel "so disposed" -- on the kitchen floor cometimes. Wages are infinitesimal. A cook, who is also laundress, gets 12s. a month, a housemaid 6s., and a boy to look after the mules and do odd jogs, 16s.

One of the severest minor trials of thousands who live in cities is the difficulty of keeping pets. Birds are naturally the easiest; cats come next, and small dogs now make a strong third, since the change in municipal rules for their registration. But, with all the drawbacks, hot weather reveals that city residents do manage to keep hosts of pets, notwithstanding.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 4 ARKED is the change the 1st of August always sees on the river. Tourists who come here for the month of July return home and their places are taken by the August crowds.

Muhlhausen may be said to consist of two classes -- millionaire manufacturers and lawyers, doctors and professors, managers and clerks, together with a fair proportion of well-to-do shopkeepers and other tradesmen, who are mostly Protestants; and a vast body of operatives who were almost exclusively Catholic, but many of whom have now given up religion and have become Social Democrats.

Take the years of birth of three great Frenchmen and arrange them in numerical order. Balzac was born in 1799, Hugo in 1802. Dumas in 1803. To all intents and purposes, they may be said to have entered into life about the same time. All three of them were subjected to the same influences. They were not far removed from that period of social upheavals the effects of which are not stilled to-day.

A young man battling for life with a monster sharkl Such combats are often, read of in dime novels, but seldom witnessed. Nevertheless, this was the experience of Alilton Shane at Pablo yesterday, and he bears now twenty-six separate wounds of more or less seriousness as the result of the sea monster's ferocity.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 USY indeed was Wednesday in Richfield. There were not so many changes as usual in the hotels, and as more came than moved on to the village celebrated.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- The United States cruiser Atlanta, Capt. J.R. Bartlett, arrived in the harbor from Boston about 7 o'clock this morning. Her bow presents a much-marred appearance, the white paint being scraped oft in streaks where she rammed the floating wreck of the Golden Rule, about twenty-five miles southeast of the New South Shoal Light.

SARATOGA, Aug. 4 -- Ex-Mayor Smith Ely of New-York talked with a reporter for The New-York Times this afternoon on the subject of harmonizing all elements of the Democratic Party in the approaching campaign. Mr. Ely came to Saratoga Friday.

ALEXANDRIA BAY., N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The annual meeting of the Anglers' Association of the St. Lawrenc'e River was held at Clayton on Wednesday. This association was formed about five years ago for the purpose of protecting the game fish from the depredations of netters and all unlawful fishermen.

The announcement is made that Lady Somerset and Miss Willard are projecting a scheme to encourage the use of the bicycle among women, not so much, from the machine side of the question, as to make the use of the bicycle dress common and familiar, and thus put in a big entering wedge for dress reform.

Considerable commotion was created in the neighborhood of Tottenham Court Road last night by the appearance of many ladies, arrayed in tunics, knickerbockers, gaiters, and -- the words must be writte -- stockings of various hues, seated on bicycles, who dashed up in vigorous style to the doors of the Ideal Club and entered therein.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Grand Trustee Robe of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks gave out for publication to-day the following proclamation of the Grand Exalted Ruler:
STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 4 USPICIOUSLY this beautiful village of the Catskills has entered upon its midsummer season of social life, and those who enjoy its festivities are finding no lack of amusement.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 4 -- The reports of crop correspondents to the Illinois Department of Agriculture are that the area devoted to corn this season is nearly 3 per cent, larger than in 1893, when 6,416,488 acres were reported by the Assessors. In the northern division of the State the average Increase is 1 per cent., giving 2,871,266 acres of corn in this section.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 4 -- Iowa will have the smallest corn crop this year that she has had since any record of crops has been kept. It will not exceed 50 per cent, of the average yield, which is thirty-three bushels to the acre, and it is more likely to fall below that.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The annual fair of the Ladies' Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church was a feature of the week. The fair was held in the chapel, which was handsomely decorated and illuminated. The members of the society were ably assisted by ladies of New-York and Brooklyn, who are spending the Summer here.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The complaint comes from along the entire New-Jersey shore that the fish laws are being very generally violated. Several communications have been sent to the Fish Commissioners calling attention to the open defiance of the law passed by the recent Legislature prohibiting fishing with any form of nets in the Barnegat Bay between April and November.

The attempt to convict ex-Ward Man Jeremiah S. Levy of blackmail and extortion resulted in a mistrial. After deliberating nineteen hours, during which time thirty ballots were cast, the jurymen re-entered the court at 3:15 P.M. yesterday, and informed Judge Martine that they could not agree on a verdict, and he discharged them.

From The Albany Argus, (Dem.) In closing up the Democratic ranks to fight the battle against the threatened domination of Mr. Platt of the Empire State, there should be no faltering and no squabbling. Minor differences in regard to party organization or local matters should vanish before the calamity which threatens the people of the State.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The Democratic. Party is no man's party, it is the party of the people, and when the rank and file are united on candidates and policies the party is sure of success. New-York is Democratic if Democrats join hands.

Nobody who spent last month in New-York Will be disposed to dispute that it was one of the most trying months of which he has any remembrance. Everybody would be prepared to hear that the mortality, especially among children in tenement houses, was beyond anything on record, and that the record of deaths directly due to prostration from heat had also been broken.

ELMIRA, Aug. 4 -- Am heartily in favor of any honorable means to secure Democratic success this year, as well as two years hence. There is no division worth mentioning in Chemung County. Control of Federal paitronage has perhaps encouraged the bolters of last year somewhat. In neighboring counties the defection can only be overcome by Democrats all submitting to the decision of the majority, expressed in caucus and conventions.

The Englishwoman-suffrage statistics are in as well as those this side the sea. The total number of signatures received to the women's suffrage appeal is 248,874. Of these, 50,913 are from Scotland, 6,830 from Ireland, 51,136 from London, the remainder being distributed throughout England and Wales.
Lillie Callahan of 22 Rose Street, Brooklyn, had a narrow escape last night from drowning by failing from the gangplank of an excursion barge at Pier 28, North River, at the foot of Murray Street.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 4 -- I take pleasure in saying that I heartily sympathize with The New-York Times in its laudable efforts to reunite the Democracy of this State. No good Democrat can truly say that harmony in the ranks of the Democratic Party of this State is not now a consummation devoutly to be wished, provided such harmony can be secured and maintained without ignominious surrender of Democratic principles.

It was in the dingy, sunless workroom of a "millinery institute" on Fourteenth Street that this daring man, this careless invader of woman's sacred, rights, was found. He was young and cheerful and content, yet he was making bows to trim the hat poised familiarly, not to say jocularly, on his knee.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The season is at its height at Centre Moriches now, and for countless quiet attractions it is unsurpassed by any near-by resort. Pure air, no mosquitoes, hosts of companionable people, fine drives, and a superb expanse of the Atlantic Ocean at its door are among the many good points that win those who regard Centre Moriches as an ideal place in which to spend the warm months.

WEST POINT, Aug. 4 -- Private excursion parties from New-York and other cities keep pouring into this place all the week. Boats are not allowed to land at the dock without having previously secured permission from the Superintendent. In many instances this formality is forgotten, and it is only when the blue-coated sentinel demands the necessary paper that such a thing is thought of.
One of the largest suits for damages ever brought against a newspaper was commenced yesterday by Charles R. Flint against The Evening Post Publishing Company and Horace White, editor of that sheet.

LAKE SUNAPEE, N.H., Aug. 4 HEN you leave the rustling White Mountain express at Claremont Junction take the easycross-country Concord and Claremont Railway, you perceive a little stream, now pushing alongside, now dodging under the roadbed, and again darting out of sight behind a hill soon to reappear, suggesting the Philadelphia pride, the Wissahickon.
CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 4 -- More people were here last week than for any week for five years past.

The officers of the first platoon or the Twenty-third and Twenty-fifth Precincts had their annual games and clambake at Braun's Pavilion, Sixty-fifth Street and East River, yesterday afternoon. Besides the athletic games there was a pie-eating contest, a hod-carrying match, boxing, a boal race, an acrobatic exhibition, and a chase for a greased pig.

When the prisoner in Morocco hears the doors of the jail close behind him, he knows, if he be poor and without friends, however trivial be the ofiense for which he has been imprisoned, that he may possibly not leave those walls alive. It is a matter of indifference to the authorities how many are imprisoned, for these wretched captives are no cause of expense to the State.

In every trade and in every profession, in business and in the Government services, the Armenian sees himself without a rival and in full possession of the field. He equips the postal service by which you travel, and if you are so fortunate as to find an inn the landlord will be an Armenian.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 4 HE month of August at Shelter Island began with its usual gayety. A number of People started for the mountains, but many arrived to take the places of those who left, and the hotels and cottages are now full to overflowing.

The first quarterly payment to pensioners from the Pension Bureau's new establishment in Sixth Avenue, near Tenth Street, was made yesterday. It is estimated that there are 60,000 pensioners in New-York. Of this number fully 3,000 formed in line yesterday in front of the Pension Office.

While Wall Street is still figuring on something great to come when the interminable Tariff bill is disposed of -- if it ever is, and is speculating in Sugar for want of anything, else, it is slowly permeating the speculative mind that there is, after all, something serious in the direction of the corn crop.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- KINDLY and much needed showers have been features of the week, and have served in a manner to alleviate the fears of a water famine.

The reporter quitted his room, which is not larger than a pocket handkerchief, but the windows of which open on antique gardens. His entrance into the park was saluted by a veritable explosion of joy among the birds, the leaves, the Japanese ducks, and the swans. It pleased him because he knew that they were disinterested and would not expect him to describe their dress or the charm of their conversation.
Portland (Ind.) Letter to The Chicago Times. The torrid weather of the past few days has revived the memory of Jay County's great serpent and refreshed the many wild, weird tales told concerning it.

SARATOGA, Aug. 4. -- Gov. Flower walked down Broadway from the United States Hotel about 11 o'clock this morning, smoking his morning cigar and enjoying the delightful weather with which Saratoga was favored to-day. Mayor Gilroy was seated on the long piazza which reaches from the main entrance to the Grand Union Hotel reading the morning newspapers.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 4 -- From investigations made by the correspondent of The New-York Times covering the entire State of Kansas, at noon to-day it is certain that the corn crop, which two weeks ago promised to surpass the great crop of 1889, will be almost a failure.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The event of the week has been the tennis tournament at the Meadow Club for the championship of Long Island. The trophy was a handsome solid silver pitcher. The playing has been very sharp, and there were many surprises in the way of unlooked-for defeats. The tournament will be closed with a ball.

Mrs. Maria McGlone a widow, is the housekeeper of a four-story tenement at 237 West Sixtieth Street. Her husband died a few years ago, leaving her with two children. Teresa, the younger was eleven years and ten months old yesterday. She helped her mother in the morning to sweep the halls and stairways, and about at o'clock she was allowed to go to the yard to play "jacks."

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 4 ARELY has the gayety at this cosmpolitan resort been at such a height. The inrush of visitors has not ceased, and present indications point to an unusually long season for the hotel keepers.

LEW BEACH, Sullivan County, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Copper wire snares for trout were found yesterday concealed in the rocks opposite "Jersey's," where recently a miraculous midday catch of trout was made by three men, one a reputed trout getter. Nothing has yet been done in this case or to punish or restrain those who pollute the Beaverkill with sawdust and disfigure it with sawmill refuse, and eel spearing goes on as usual.

Najili Maloof, an importer at 73 Washington Street, and Nahoum Moukarzel of 69 Washington Street were held in the Tombs Police Court yesterday in $500 bail each for examination on Wednesday on charges of spreading scandalous reports. The complainants were Dr. A.J. Arbeely and Najeeb J. Arbeely, editors and proprietors of The Kawkab America, (Star of America,) a Syrian newspaper published at 45 Pearl Street.
The fourth race of the Larchmont series for twenty-one-footers was sailed yesterday. The Vaquero won, but it was a fluky day, and as far as showing superiority went the race counted for little.

ELLENVILLE, Aug. 4 -- Every person who believes in the principles of the Democratic Party must heartily commend The New-York Times in its efforts to unite the party of this State. It is only in such an emergency as our party is in to-day that leaders who have been inflated by success pause in their career and cry for "help, or we perish."

That the limit of speed at which a small craft can be drive through the water has not yet been reached is shown in the recent performance of the Thornycroft torpedo gunboat Daring That vessel has set the pace at 29 1/4 knots, and marine engineers are now confident that even this clipping gait will be excelled by some later vessel of the Daring's type.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The East Bay Yacht Club held its annual race over the club course this afternoon. As there was a light fluky north wind but four of the seven yachts entered contested. After the start a fine breeze sprang up from the southwest, making the race very interesting to the spectators aboard of the email yachts, which dotted the bay to the number of 100.

Judge D. Cady Herrick of Albany, in his interview on Democratic harmony printed in The New-York Times of Friday, pointed out how the desired harmony could best be brought about, in his opinion, by making all the primaries open and fair to all sides. In a decision rendered within the past year, Judge Herrick had occasion to treat the question of primaries judicially, and among other things he said in his opinion:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Although the conferrees on the Tariff bill have but very little to say to-night, concerning the outcome of their deliberations, they, have managed to convey the impression that the situation is much easier than it has been at any time in the last week.

An informal gathering of a few relatives and intimate family friends will be had at the residence of Joseph H. Tooker, 133 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, this evening, in recognition of the occurrence of the centennial birthday of the Commodore's father.

The annual reunion and State Convention of the Volunteer Firemen will be held at Oswego the week beginning Aug. 21. The most important subject to be brought before the convention is the matter of the Firemen's Home at Hudson, which, though finished, is closed because the bills for its construction have not been paid.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Christina Robinson, fourteen years old, started out from her home near this village on Thursday morning to pick huckleberries in the woods. She wandered along unmindful of the distance she was geting from home or of the lapse of time. She had taken a rather large pail with her, and was anxious to fill it.

On Thursday last The Evening Post published a synoptical statement of certain legal papers constituting a part of a lawsuit begun by Charles F. Watson against Charles R. Flint. John P. Townsend, and The New-York Times Publishing Company, and also the points of one action begun by Richard Sibley against the same defendants, the object in both cases being the recovery of money paid for certain shares of stock in The Times Publishing Company.

The little King of Spain, Alfonso XIII., is, as many of you know, a very little fellow, indeed. He has just passed his eighth birthday, and though he does not seem to have a very strong constitution he has battled with a good many severe illnesses, and is now said to be growing as an eight-year-old boy should.
ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The season is at its height. Every cottage is taken and there are few vacant rooms in the hotel.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 4. OUR gossips and wiseacres had something to talk about when the Ocean House closed its doors Tuesday. There were plenty of people who nodded their heads and remarked:

UTICA, Aug. 4 -- If The New-York Times can bring itself to a frame of mind desiring and asking for harmony and a united Democracy in New-York State, no Democrat, no matter how bitter, unjust, or uncalled for may have been his attacks upon other Democrats, should have any difficulty in cultivating the same desire.

From The Detroit Free Press. The drummer had just finished a rather remarkable snake story as he sat in the country store after he had sold a bill of goods,and a countryman, with some young pullets to sell, had been listening. The drummer's story was about a snake of his acquaintance which had a habit of stealing eggs.

From The Port Jervls Gazette. The creek comes rushing down through a ravine, at the head of which was built a dam for the storage of water to furnish power for a sawmill, situated on a small bluff on the river bank, which manufactured into lumber the original forest nearly a century ago.

BAST MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Life at East Moriches has been a round of pleasure this week, with cool breezes, fishing, bathing, and sailing parties in plenty and pretty girls galore. It doesn't need anything more to complete one's happiness.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Japanese Legation received to-day a cablegram, delayed in transit, from the Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs, stating that on Aug. 1 an imperial rescript was issued by the Japanese Emperor formally declaring war against China. This was supplemental to the written notice, given two days previously to the foreign representatives at Tokio, that a state of war existed between China and Japan.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- Yesterday's activity was not continued to-day, but prices held firm, though transactions were very limited. New-England Street Railway sold at 48 1/4, the same as yesterday's close. This company is laying new tracks along some of its important routes, and is about to extend one of its suburban lines.

COWES, Aug. 4 - The Vigilant handsomely retrieved her reputation to-day in a splendid tussle for a prize of $500 over the course of the Royal Yacht Squadron. She beat the Prince of Wales's cutter, the Britannia, in a brisk breeze that held almost true from start to finish, over a course of forty-eight nautical miles, a third of which was in the open water of the English Channel.

Napoleon forbade the use of cotton or of foreign wood for the furniture of the imperial palaces; he desired that the people who were invited to the drawing rooms at Court should dress only in silk, so as to encourage the Lyons manufactories. He declared war on Indian cashmeres, but his power was impotent against the tyranny of fashion, and against routine.

There were no complaints presented to the Police Commissioners yesterday against any members of the police force. The indications are that during the present week the complaints against Sergts. Clark, Liebers, Jordan, McKenna, and Parkerson and exWard Men Mallon and Levy, growing out of the trial of Capt. Doherty, will be presented and the trials of these officers begun.

At last the Giants are happy. They have earned for the opportunity of administering a pronounced sat-back to the common enemy, the Brooklyns, and yesterday their fondest hopes were realized. They whipped the youths from across the bridge in two games in one afternoon, and sent them home sad and forlorn.

A meeting of the walking delegates was held at 139 Fifty-ninth Street yesterday afternoon to consider the strike on the public school buildings. Reports were received from all parts of the district, and, according to the leaders, they were all favorable. All the men, they insisted, were out.

The imports of the week, exclusive of specie, were $10,478,290, of which amount $1,830,532 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $156,738 and the exports of specie were $3,694,445.

When John Edgar, who was born in the West, came to New-York, he hail received "an excellent collegiate education" and "had graduated from his law school with honors." His chidhood had not been cheerful. His parents had "small minds." which "ran to the details of their religious beliefs." When he was fifteen years old, he impulsively kissed his Sunday school teacher "full on her rosy lips."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- HIS great town, truthfully named the Midsummer Capital, has not for years been so lively as it is at present. The visitors thousand those of a year ago, and the season will not finish till the end of October, a month later than usual.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Driving is one of the principal recreations of the Summer sojourners here, but during the past month, the prolonged drought has seriously interfered with, this pleasure. Until the welcome rain began to fall yesterday, the dust along the country roads hereabouts was exceedingly disagreeable.

A story is told of Miss Genevieve Ward and English, royalty that will bear a trip across the Atlantic. As is well known, the Prince of Wales is very fond of the theatre, and is as well a great admirer of the genius of Miss Ward. When she was playing Stephanie in "Forget-Me-Not" the English Prince called upon her in the greenroom to congratulate her upon her work.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 4 -- There are fewer cottagers going away to the seashore this year than before for many years. Lenox is more and more like an English country town. It covers twenty-five square miles of cottages and mansions. It is disappointing to strangers because restricted in admissions to its society.

ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- Ex-Mayor James H. Manning of this city, son of, Daniel Manning, first Secretary of the Treasury for Mr. Cleveland, is one of the best-informed Democratic politicians in Albany County. He was a delegate to the Chicago Convention of 1892. Last evening Mr. Manning gave his views to The Times's correspondent.

The factory-building of the T. New Roofing and Manufacturing Company, at 529 to 533 East Nineteenth Street, and 540 East Twentieth Street, caught on fire about 6 o'clock last night, and damage to the amount of $20,000 was caused. The interior of the building was burned out.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Bathing is the thing. Boating and driving are all right in their way, but when the temperature of the water is 75, and there isn't a ripple in the calmness of old ocean, why bathing takes precedence of everything else! There are plenty of strong swimmers here among the girls, and they have grace as well as strength.
BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- The Chinese Minister here has received an official dispatch stating that the Chinese iron-clad war ship ting-Yuen rammed and sunk a Japanese war ship off Jerome Gulf on July 20.

In the new, palatial dwellings erected throughout the country by American millionaires, the bathroom has been brought to a point of perfection, in which there seems nothing left to desire. Within three years modern plumbing, and its accessories, has taken a leap to the summit of sanitary science and brought with it, in every detail, elegance and exquisite taste.

Some interesting studies may toe made of the common roadside plants. They are much like people. There is the modest, unpretentious kind, that needs to be sought for, hiding under the shelter of some tawdry, glaring neighbor, whose more conspicuous appearance and behavior attract the casual attention.

WEST POINT, Aug. 4 -- A new invalid bed, supplied with every convenience for the comfort and care of the sick or wounded, was exhibited hero a few days ago. The Surgeon Generals of the army and navy appointed boards to pass upon its merits early in the present year, and it was strongly indorsed by them.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- [Copyright, 1894.] -- The circulation of notes and coin increased during the week L1,000,000, and the bank reserve was consequently reduced. One million Treasury bonds matured, beins replaced by Treasury bills. These movements had no effect in reducing the supplies of money, and rates are weaker than ever.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Black Rock Beach, with the George, and the many handsome Summer homes filled with merry parties, was never gayer than at this time. The efforts of the guests at the hotel to arrange entertainment never cease, and the result is a series of hops; tennis and archery contests, boat races, or drives to the many beautiful and romantic spots in the vicinity.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 4 -- The very large Summer population that is passing the heated term in this city is waiting with unusual interest the coming of the New-York yacht squadron next week. The arrival of the fleet is the great event of the season to the Summer colonists, and they anticipate it with the keenest pleasure, for it brings festivities that are not enjoyed at other times.

If the property of a corporation or company in which the laboring men, the capitalists, the widows and orphans, the savings banks, properties in which any or all our people are interested, cannot be respected and protected, then the cottage, the hamlet, and the little personal property of the humblest citizen is in jeopardy, liable at any moment to be confiscated, seized, or destroyed by any traveling band of tramps.

Celia Parker Woolley published her first novel, "Love and Theology," in 1887. It was a clever, resolutely radical little story, and the critics at once classed it with the "African Farm," "John Ward," and the renowned "Robert." Its author, however, has since then gone far ahead of Mrs. Deland, Mrs. Ward, and even Olive Schreiner in the demonstration of her religious convictions.

Russell B. Hoyt of Brooklyn, who was arrested by Secret Service Detective Forsythe for complicity in a big counterfeiting scheme, is still in the New-York County Jail, in Ludlow Street, having failed to procure a bondsman.

The Long Island Railroad Company is anxious to purchase the property rights of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company, an Brooklyn. The latter company owns the right to use Atlantic Avenue from Jamaica, to South Ferry, and this is thirty-five feet wide the entire, length of Atlantic Avenue. Negotiations, it is said, are now pending regarding the purchase of this valuable prop-. erty right.

UNIONTOWN, Pernn. Aug. 4 -- Sixty-five of Jeffries's Industrial Army, from Washington State, charged with trespassing on railroad property at Connellsville last night, were fined $3 or five days in jail here this afternoon. As the men had no money to pay their fines they were sent to jail. Jeffries made a speech to-night and took up a collection.

The Sixty-ninth Battalion held its annual games at Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday afternoon. The weather was all that could be desired and the track was in the best of condition. In throwing the fifty-six-pound weight over bar for height, J.S. Mitchell of the New-York Athletic Club beat the record by 7 1/2 inches. Summaries follow:
Few cities in the world, if any, have viler drinking water than the cities in New-Jersey which depend upon the Passaic River for their water supply.

Henry C. MeLear, Secretary of the Carriage Builders National Association of the United States, has issued a circular giving full particulars respecting exhibits to be made by members of the Carriage Builders' National Association at the exhibition which will be held at Philadelphia on Oct. 16, 17, and 18.

For a Saturday, as business has been running recently, there was a very fair market. It was a holiday on the London Exchange, so there was no business from that centre. Nevertheless, in the two hours during which the Exchange was open the trading ran up to more than 83,000 shares, and it vas fairly well distributed.

Studying the modern Italians, and more particularly those who treat social questions, we should be inclined to think that their emotional qualities give a peculiar color to their work. In the volume under notice, Signor Nitti's endeavor is to explain what are the economic, demographic, or social influences which, tend to increase or decrease population, and, if possible, to formulate certain laws.

It is rather strange that while the ruins of Egypt and the mounds of Assyria and Babylonia and Syria have been actively explored during the past fifty years, so little excavation should have been carried on in Palestine, the past of which equals in interest and, in some respects, exceeds in importance that of other seats of ancient culture.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- As has been announced, John McBride could not meet his engagement with the Hon. Carroll D. Wright to discuss the affirmative of the compulsory arbitration question to-day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Never was a prettier or more exciting day's sport seen than at the third and last day's bicycle racing in this city. Chicago turned out a crowd of over 10,000 persons. The day was cool and bracing, a cold northeast wind blowing on the backstretch.

DENVER, Aug. 4 -- Internal Revenue Collector New of the District of Colorado and Wyoming has unearthed some fraudulent Chinese registrations at Rock Springs, Wyoming, which he thinks will lead to the discovery of a great many in Pacific coast districts.

Two dozen tennis players yesterday afternoon visited the courts of the Bergen Point Tennis Club at West Ninth Street and Avenue A, Bayonne, N.J., and played handicap singles and scratch doubles. Most of the perennial candidates for fame were entered, Gould, John Hobart, Cragin, Howard, Sydney Smith, Crowninshield, and Fischer being the most prominent.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Miss Elizabeth Neuert of South Jefferson Street and Samuel H. Benedict of New-York were married on Wednesday afternoon in All Saints' Episcopal Church by the assistant rector, the Rev. Herbert S. Sharpley.

ROUSE'S POINT, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- On account both of the excellent fishing and of the delightful weather which has been experienced for the last month at Rouse's Point the Summer resort hotel there, the Windsor, has been filled almost to its utmost capacity. On Sunday last over 100 guests were receiving the hospitality of its new and energetic manager, Mr. Howe, and more are daily expected.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The City by the Sea has closed the most prosperous July recorded in the annals of this all-the-year resort. The railroads figures show an unprecedented flow of passengers. The hotel men have few rooms unoccupied, and the smaller boarding houses and cottages are gradually crowding.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 4 -- "Repentance" was the subject under consideration at the 10 o'clock session of the Northfield Conference to-day. Dr. Gray of Boston was the chief speaker, and he was followed by D.L. Moody. The Rev. George C. Needham of Northfield also spoke. The Rev. George L. Mackay of Formosa and Edgar Young of Dakota will deliver missionary addresses next Friday.
Lace shawls are stylishly resurrected for draping skirts.

Car No. 83 of the Brooklyn Bridge service "rode" the rails at the "pusher " engine switch of the north, or New-York track, at the Brooklyn terminus, at 3:15 P.M. yesterday, bumped over the ties and toppled over on the engine-room path, then slid to the north roadway, where it blocked all traffic westward.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 4 -- In regard to the fact that the Auditor has ordered the Attorney General to institute a suit against the Illinois Building and Loan Association of Bloomington, the attorney of the association says that the only difficulty is a difference of opinion between the Auditor and the association as to the right to collect from the stockholders a fund to pay the expenses.

The sixth annual regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club was sailed yesterday on the Sound oft Greenwich. The wind was light and fluky all day, and slow time was made over the courses. Fifty-three yachts started, and in spite of the weather the contests were very good. Two new boats made their appearance. They were the Infanta, a Fife boat, and the Wave, a one-rater, brought over by A.L. Barber on the Cleopatra.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- "I shall join the New-York Yacht Club's cruise at New-London. The Volunteer is in strictly cruising trim. I shall, therefore, not enter in the race for the Goelet Cap." The foregoing from ex-Commodore J. Malcolm Forbes of the Eastern Yacht Club dispels the last hope that the Volunteer and the Navahoe might meet in a race this season.

From The San Francisco Examiner. It is not unpleasant to have the rats if you can keep them under control. There, is a young man by the name of Charles Quincey Brown living on Bush Street who has about fifty of the rascals who recognize him and accept his general style of handling them as all right.
All Souls' Summer Home, at Sea Cliff, L.I., is now open for the season, and 115 poor children of New-York City are reveling in the joys and comforts provided for them by that institution.

The Commercial Cable Company made the following anouncements yesterday: "The Chinese land line from Tien-Tsin, north through Manchooria to Helampo, where it joins the Great Northern Telegraph Company's line through Siberia, is interrupted.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 4. -- Another full second has been sliced off the world's bicycle record for a mile with a flying start and pacemakers. Harry C. Tyler of Springfield did it very easily this afternoon, and lowered the 1:54 4-5 record of J.P. Bliss of Chicago, made on this same track, to 1:53 3-5.

The disappearance of William Homeyer, a well-to-do saloon keeper of 998 Avenue A, was reported at Police Headquarters yesterday by Charles Rphrs, his manager, and H.W. Krumwiedge of 438 Tenth Avenue, Homeyer's cousin.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- Emperor William's first interview with the Chancellor, after returning from the North, concerned recent Cabinet discussions of the steps to be taken for the repression of Socialism and Anarchism. The discussions were reported at length by the Chancellor. They impressed his Majesty with the necessity of acting at once against the revolutionists.
ANTWERP, July 21 -- A poem written in 1610 by one Carolus Scribanus began with this verse:

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 4 -- With no rain during the next five days, corn in Nebraska, taking the State as a whole, will be less than half a crop. A week has passed since the scorching south winds withered and cut short the growth of as promising a yield as was ever planted, and since then the drought has, with few exceptions, continued unabated.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Many lumber dealers whose yards are in the partly-burned district believe the two fires of this week in that region were of incendiary origin. They have engaged an extra force of watchmen to guard their property at night. They were also impelled to take these extra precautions by the fear of having their insurance policies canceled.

The friends are to hold their First Day School, Religious, and Philanthropic Conferences, from the 9th to the 16th of this month, at Chappaqua, N.Y. It is the first time that the three have met at the same time and place.

The denizens of Chinatown have spent an anxious week because of the uncertainty of the news they have received about the war between China and Japan. The accounts have been contradictory, and their hopes and fears have risen and fallen with the news.

-- Mrs. Babetle Scholle, widow of the late Abraham Scholle of Scholle Brothers, is dead. Mrs. Scholle was a native of Kips, Germany, and came to the United States forty-seven years ago. She was well known in Hebrew circles because of her charities, being a patroness of every Jewish benevolent institution in the city. Mrs. Scholle leaves two sons and two daughters.

WASHINGTON, Aug -- The receipts of the Patent Office during the last two months have been lower than at any time for three or four years. The receipts during July of last year were $88,000, while this year the month's aggregate was $86,OOO. In June of this year the receipts aggregated $99,000, a decrease of about $1,000 from June, 1893.
Mowbray, the English Anarchist, did not address a gathering of his kind in the Labor Lyceum, Myrtle Avenue and Myrtle Street, Brooklyn, last night, because the police would not let him.

A regular personification of deceased pensioners has been discovered at the station of Dapoolie. This is a delightful, healthy place in the District of Ratnagiri, about five miles from the sea, at an elevation of 600 feet. It was the residence of veteran sepoys who had been pensioned after doing good service in 1857-8.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- There is something going on in Mars just now which greatly excites astronomers. So far as laymen may penetrate these mysteries, it seems that some shining specks, quite unlike anything ever seen before, have been discovered, and that the circumstances are exceptionally favorable to the hypothesis that Martians are trying to signal to us.

Many critics of the Chinese Navy will read with some surprise the laudatory account of its progress and the recent evolutions in the Gulf of Pechili which is sent to The Times by a correspondent at Che-Foo. It is only fair to the correspondent, however, to say that his handsome compliments are re-echoed in the press of the East.

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y,. Aug. 5 -- Thanks to the special train through the Adirondacks bearing The New-York Times, the supply of to-day's issue of the paper for this place arrived on time this afternoon. It was warmly welcomed by the visitors here, and every copy was sold within an hour after arrival.

Because he knew that it had teen planned to send him to an asylum, John B. Hunt, an insane paperhanger and house decorator, shot and instantly killed his wife Barbara in the presence of three of their children in the family living rooms on the third floor of 1,490 Second Avenue, yesterday morning.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 5 -- A Washington dispatch to-day notes the receipt by the Japanese Ambassador of a document in which a number of young men in this country offer to go to Japan and enlist in the army of the Mikado. A brief note to the effect that the offer constitutes an offense against the laws of the United States is appended to the dispatch.
