In a few days from now steamships arriving at New-York will, if fortune favors a lone navigator who yesterday, set sail for Europe, bring reports which may read like this:

In the Palo Duro Canon, lying north of Amarillo, Texas, the hacking away of a large piece of alluvial earth has recently revealed a singular trace of prehistoric life. This consists of the unmistakable trail of some large animal going over the rocks, followed by another, probably of the human kind, or at any rate of a gigantic specimen of the ape.

-- The Astoria Homestead Company of New-York will build a track for horse and bicycle racing and athletic sports on its premises between Flushing Avenue and the Bowery Bay Road, in the town of Newtown, L.I., and will light the grounds with electricity so that racing and athletic sports can be conducted at night. The premises upon which the race track is to be constructed overlook Bowery Bay.

BUFFALO, Aug. 5 -- Congressman Lane N. Lockwood has no desire to succeed his townsman, William F. Sheehan, as Lieutenant Governor. In Buffalo it is well understood that Mr. Sheehan will not be a candidate for renomination, and Mr. Lockwood gave the politicians to understand to-day that he will not run.

MANHATTAN BEACH, Aug. 5 -- Edward B. Harper, who has himself been spoken of as the Republican nominee for Governor, told a reporter for The New-York Times today, at the Oriental Hotel, that Levi P. Morton had written, from Paris, a personal letter to a prominent Republican of New-York City, intimating that he might consent to head the Republican State ticket this Fall.

Gen. Isaac S. Catiin of Brooklyn recognizes the need for harmony in the Democratic Party, and of confident that it can be attained. "The way for the factions to secure union is to unite, as Greeley said about resumption," is the way the General puts it.

A fire in the Vandyke Studio Building, 939 to 945 Eighth Avenue, at 6:45 last night, burned out the studios of half the colony of artists on the upper three floors. Most of the artists are away on their vacations, and they will return to find their whole stock of pictures and works in preparation destroyed beyond redemption, while the studios of others are wholly wrecked by fire and water.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 5 -- I approve the object urged by The New-York Times in the direction of party, unity most heartily. There is no obstacle serious or otherwise to the harmonious and united action of the Democracy of this country in the coming campaign, and I sincerely hope that this will be the condition of the party throughout the State when the time comes for action.

Old Grosson, who for long years was in charge of the Chateau d'If, made famous all the world over by "Monte Cristo," has died, and some amusing anecdotes are being recorded about him. He cajoled himself as well as visitors into the belief that Edmond Dantes and the Abbe Faria had really been imprisoned in the sea fortress.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 5 -- The weekly postal-card reports to the Weather Bureau give a disheartening story as far as corn is concerned. The hot and dry weather continued during the first part of the week and was succeeded by weather so cold that frosts were reported in the northern part of the State.
George Ethelbert Walsh, describing the animals in Central Park menagerie in the August number of St. Nicholas, says:

As the result of the law passed at the last session of the Legislature forbidding the Dock Department of this city to do its own work of construction and requiring that work to be done by contract, the building of the massive sea wall, which is essential to the improvement of the water front, will have to stop indefinitely.
It is a very long journey from the great delta of the River La Plata in South America to the valley of the Genesee, especially when undertaken by an animal, and that animal a toad.

News has been received in this city of the death of Brevet Brig. Gen. Daniel Macauley in Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, July 5, and Lafayette Post, No. 140, G.A.R., of which Gen. Macauley was a member, has adopted a set of resolutions on his death. The General went to Nicaragua in May as the resident representative of the Nicaragua Canal Company.

The stock market last week was extremely dull and prices, as a rule, were irregular. The extent of the stagnation will be better appreciated when it is stated that of all the stocks on the list in only seven did the transactions for the entire week exceed 10,000 shares. The seven active ones were Sugar, Burlington, St. Paul, Rock Island, Chicago Gas, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, and Missouri Pacific.

ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- There was a strong undertone to both the local stock and bond market during the past week. The strength and activity were unexpected, as it was thought that, after the July investment demand was satisfied, prices would recede somewhat from the dullness ensuing. The most notable advance was in Albany Railway 5 per cent, bonds.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 5 -- During the past twenty-four hours reports have been received in this city from regular crop reporters in every county in the State. They verify the reports which have been sent to The New-York Times, so far as they tell anything.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 4 -- There has been a somewhat better demand for investments during the past week, but, owing to the light offerings of the more popular stocks, few sales have taken place, and prices generally rule about the same. In the bank stock list. Commercial National has sold at 48 1/2 and Rhode Island National Bank at 27.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Aug. 5 -- One hundred years ago to-day a band of sturdy warriors, under command of Gen. Anthony Wayne, were cutting their way through the great forests of the Northwest, between Greenville and this city, to recover the ground lost by the disastrous campaign of Gen. St. Clair and effect a settlement with the Indians at any cost.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 5 -- The election in this State to-morrow will be for Governor and the other State officers, one-half the Senators, and all the members of the House. The Legislature chosen will be charged with the duty of electing a successor to United States Senator John T. Morgan.

WATERTOWN, Aug. 5 -- Ex-Secretary of State John W. Foster, who is at Henderson Harbor, near here, with his family, and has recently returned from China, Corea, and Japan, was interviewed by a representative of the United Press to-night on the China-Japan war and the deprivation of Li Hung Chang of the yellow coat.

George Hughes, a produce merchant who lives at 62 West Tenth Street, judged a man by his clothes yesterday morning. It cost him $5. The man he judged was Capt. Delaney of the Charles Street Precinct. The Captain was in plain clothes. He was bound to the station house by way of a Christopher Street car.

PENN YAN, Aug. 5 -- I cannot too strongly express my approbation of the plan to Taring about party harmony. No one who understands the prominence of the Empire State in national politics can overestimate the significance of the coming State campaign upon national issues. The loss of the State last Pall was almost a fatal blow to our national policy, and, if repeated this Fall, will surely culminate in irretrievable disaster.

The Question of taking part in politics was again discussed at the meeting of the Central Labor Union in Clarendon Hall yesterday. A letter had been received from the Central Labor Federation asking for the appointment of a harmony committee to confer with the federation's harmony committee to-morrow night, and, if possible, make some arrangement for concerted political action. August Waldinger, George McVey, Charles Opperman, and George H. Smith were named on the committee.

BRAZIL, Ind., Aug. 5 -- David Wilson and Henry Wright, residents of Attica, were attacked early this morning by a crowd of men on the Jackson Street crossing of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad, and horribly beaten.

WOODSIDE, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Between the strange woman who has been thrusting a horse pistol in the faces of several women ana a gang of daring burglars who have been busy during the last few nights, the people of this village have become somewhat alarmed.

JAMESTOWN, Aug. 5 -- There is no question as to the necessity of unity in the Democratic Party if we are to be successful this Fall. Defeat in this State this Pall would probably mean defeat in the Presidential election in 1896. Every Democrat who has the interests of his party at heart will lend his best efforts to uniting the factions of our party.

A funeral procession which wended its way through Brooklyn streets yesterday afternoon attracted more than usual attention. It was that which followed the remains of Jeremiah Johnson, late dynamo machinist of the United States cruiser San Francisco, from the Sands Street Navy Club to the burfal grounds of the Naval Hospital.

-- Dr. Albert B. Miles, House Surgeon of the Charity Hospital, and probably the most prominent surgeon in the South, died at New-Orleans yesterday. Dr. Miles's skill gave him high rank. His reports of operations in the Charity Hospital and essays on its statistics are to be fouud in nearly every practitioner's library. He was born at Prattville, Ala., May 18, 1832.

It was my melancholy business to record a fatal accident that has just happened to Mr. Charles Peach, an old resident of Dehra, who for many years was in the employ of the late Frederick Wilson. Mr. Peach, was staying with that excellent sportsman, Rajah Runbeer Singh at Kamsrau, in the Eastern Dun.

-- The Town Board of Jamaica has retained counsel to sue the Excise Commissioners of the town for the amount due for licenses issued to saloon keepers on Jamaica Bay. The Excise Commissioners, it is claimed, accepted only one-half of the usual fee for licenses because the saloon men did business only during the Summer.

In the current number of The Idler, Mr. Robert Barr discourses in a most edifying manner on the use of profane language, and remarks that he learned with regret that many great men have been known to swear. It is said that when the great Duke of Wellington received his morning mall he was in the habit of marking on some of the communications the letters "E.B.D."

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 5 -- The Rev. Dr. James M. King of New-York lectured this afternoon in Prohibition Park on "The Relation of Roman Oatholica to the School Question." Dr. King began with a historical account of the origin and development of the public sohool in foreign countries and America, and spoke of the peril which from time to Time has threatened the free-school system.

Ex-Ward Man Jeremiah S. Levy, who was sent back to the Tombs prison by Judge Martin en Saturday in default of $7,500 bail on the Krumm indictment, passed a quiet Sunday. He devoted most of the time to reading newspapers. Talking of his case, he said:

This Alpine land, which is usually a quiet district, resembled a disturbed ant hill. From all sides dark figures hurried across the fields or down the narrow paths, while the sound of horns in distant villages gave notice of our approach. Before their huts stood the old people; then they knelt down, clapped their hands, and held out bundles of grass, apostrophizing me in flattering terms.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 5 -- The authorities seem to have made up their minds that, with the exception of blowing off the hydrants and a sort of informal attempt at filtering the water at Belleville, which may or may not produce good results, they will make no further attempt at purifying the water furnisned to taxpayers.

The Albany Journal, which is the leading Republican paper in the State capital, has some claim to be regarded as the official State organ of Republicanism, continues to be very much exercised over the proposition to harmonize the New-York State Democracy. Each day now it prints sneering editorials, setting, forth what it is pleased to regard as the inequitable and ridiculous features of the proposition.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- There is a prospect of a report by the conferrees on the Tariff bill not later than Wednesday.

The following Indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date in 1893. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

President M. Casimir-Perier, who, as you have already been informed, took up his abode in the Presidential residence of the Elysee yesterday afternoon, occupies with his family the left wing of the building, the same in which Mme. Carnot lived. Mme. and Mile. Casimir-Perier joined the President last evening.

There came to The Inquirer office the other day a statement of railroad earnings in lines and figures that were a work of art. The figures were so clearly and beautifully formed that they could not fail to excite remark from any who saw them. A short distance away they appeared to have been made by mere mechanical process.

Mr. H.J. Staff, a Liverpool clerk on a touring trip in Ireland, has had a remarkable escape from death at Howth. On Tuesday evening he descended by the grassy slopes which lie some distance downward, from the top of the cliffs for the purpose of gathering wild flowers. He was thus engaged at a point between the Nose of Howth and the Bailey Lighthouse when he accidentally missed his footing and went toppling downward.

-- A fire, which is supposed to have been caused by a defective gas flue, caused considerable excitement and destroyed the contents of two apartments in the five-story tenement 595 Tenth Avenue at 8:30 A.M. yesterday. The fire started in the rooms of Paul Scheabuea on the second floor, and the family had to leave in a hurry.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 5 -- The general meeting of the Summer School section of the Harvard Teachers' Association, which was held on Thursday evening, brought out a valuable discussion upon the question of secondary education in relation to admission requirements. In all, there were six speakers chosen from among the teachers and members of the Summer School, representing the three departments of English, modern languages, and physical science.

"WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The relay bicycle race to Denver is attracting much attention from cycle riders all over the country. The great race of 2,037 miles from Washington to Denver will start from this city to-morrow. Washington wheelmen, will make the first run of seventy-seven miles to Hagerstown.

COWES, Aug. 5. -- The Vigilant, Britannia, and Satanita will take part in the Royal London Yacht Club regatta to-morrow. They will compete for a prize of 130 guineas subscribed by a number of yachtsmen. The start will be made at 10 o'clock, and the course will be around the Isle of Wight, keeping outside of Noman Fort and the Bembridge Ledge Buoy.

" The Workman and His Club" was the subject of the Rev. Alfred E. Meyer's sermon last evening, in the Collegiate Church, Twenty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue. "There are 300 clubs in this city," he said, "that are abodes of elegance and luxury for those who frequent them, while there are more than 8,000 workmen's clubs that are gaudily fitted up, and are attractive to those who toil with their hands.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $2,850,025. The banks now hold $69,053,700 more than the legal reaulrements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $670,900, a decrease in specie of $96,000, a decrease in legal tenders of $3,078,400, a decrease in deposits of $3,369,800, and a decrease in circulation of $58,900.

-- "Jce" Taylor, one of the owners of Golden Valley, who won the second race at Brighton Beach Saturday, was one of the maddest men at the track after his filly won. In spite of the filly's good race a few days ago, Mr. Taylor did not think she could beat George Dixon Saturday, and backed Dixon to win and Golden Valley for the place.

NEWPORT, Aug. 5 -- Heavy showers interfered with the social programme yesterday, but not with a subscription clambake at Easton's Point, arranged by Center Hitchcock and William R. Hunter. A baseball game followed the repast. Prescott Lawrence was umpire. He made the most errors.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- The announcement that bills for the repression of Socialism and Anarchism will be laid before Parliament is in all mouths. That it preludes a bitter political conflict nobody can doubt. Before it was made, the report was abroad that several heads of Federal States, notably Bavaria, Saxony, and Baden, had been urging the Emperor to assent to the renewal of the old exceptional laws in modified form.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 5 -- It is reported that there has been another engagement off the Corean coast, in which three Chinese war ships were captured by the Japanese. The report has not been confirmed.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Aug. 5 -- Miss Lavinia L. Harris, a young and attractive daughter of Congressman Harris of Kansas, was quietly married here to-day to Wade D. Bonhannon, proprietor of a livery stable at Luray, Va.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 5 -- Reports received last night and to-day from all parts of the West indicate that, with the exception of Iowa and Nebraska, the corn crop was not damaged by last week's hot winds so much as was at first feared.

An exhibition of a novel kind for Italy has been set up on the Lido, near the principal bathing establishment, by two Venetian artists, the sculptor Piazza and the painter Giu. The exhibition is a representation of the execution of the Doge Faliero, placed in a large wooden erection in the style of the ducal palace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Cleveland has received a communication from the United States Civil Service Commission calling his attention to what the commission considers a violation of the spirit, if not of the letter, of the civil service law. The document is signed by Commissioners Proctor, Roosevelt, and layman, as expressing their unanimous opinion.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 5 -- The Yale men who went to England with the athletic team to shout for the blue at the Oxford games are beginning to return to this country, and during the last week a few of them have come to this city, and they tell of details of the international battle which did not appear in the cabled accounts of the games.
Henry E. Abbey, the impresario, and his wife were passengers on the Aurania, which arrived at the Cunard clock yesterday, and they went to the Waldorf.

The fact that Li Hung Chang has been deprived of his yellow jacket does not at first sight, nor indeed on a second inspection, appear to be an epoch-making event. Nevertheless, it is worth some consideration as a vivid illustration of the Chinese methods of enforcing discipline and of arousing enthusiasm.

We reprint from The New-York Times an interview with Gov. Flower on the Democratic situation in this State. It is pregnant with sound advice. He discusses frankly what can be done to heal every sore in the party, and his suggestions are both timely and practical.
KOKOMO, Ind., Aug. 5 -- The death of Peter Hersleb, at a Philadelphia hospital, throws additional light on the life of this noted recluse.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The Chicago-Cincinnati ball game this afternoon, at the West Side Park, was cut short by the cry of fire. In the panic that came a little later many persons were hurt.
Democrats must get together and work for the common purpose of downing our political enemies this Fall.

The lately celebrated Mr. Debs is evidently learning a good deal that was not dreamed of in his philosophy as Chief Striker, or, rather, as Chief of Strikers, for we believe he has not so far found it necessary to give up his own income. A few days since he was reported to have formed the intention of abandoning strikes and counseling the labor unions to go into politics.

William Cunningham of 324 East Sixtieth Street, whose child, born a week ago Saturday last, was to have been buried in Calvary Cemetery, but was instead taken to the Morgue, told the circumstances last night:

The city is contesting the payment of its share of the State tax for the support of the insane, and the Attorney General, on behalf of the State, has applied to the Supreme Court in Albany for a mandamus to compel Controller Fitch to pay over the amount of its quota, which is nearly $700,000.

Two close contests, one in singles and one in doubles, were the features in the handicap tennis tournament of the Staten Island Cricket Club yesterday. Peters beat Ball in two of the three sets necessary to decide in the single match, while H. Peters and Slade won a rather up-hill contest from McLean and Youle in the doubles. The preliminary round in the singles has been declared finished by the Tournament Committee.

Two handsome bay horses, attached to a stylish victoria, dashed madly through Thirty-seventh Street eastward to Broadway shortly after 8 o'clock last evening. On the box was a man in livery, who held the lines and struggled with all his strength to stop the team.

When a safe and a closet in the office of the Secret Service Division of the Treasury Department in the Post Office Building had yielded up substantial evidence of criminality yesterday afternoon and W.P. Hazen, Chief of the division at Washington, and W.H. Forsyth, one of the operators of the Treasury Department, had talked of these Treasures, a vastly interesting story of expert counterfeiting had been told.
Senator James Smith, Jr., of New-Jersey gives to the public a signed statement in which he says:

Messrs. L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Samuel Hirsh the six-story brick business building 18 and 20 West Fourth Street, south side, between Mercer and Greene Streets, 50 by 91. The property was bought in 1891 for $166,750.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 7, 12:30 A. M. -- Late returns indicate that Oates has carried the State by 15,000 majority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The army doctors are greatly interested in an order which has been issued by Gen. Howard, from the headquarters of the Division of the Atlantic at Governors Island, N.Y. It is the peculiar wording of the order which has directed to it more than passing notice. It is as follows:

When North Dakota was framing its first State Constitution, Judge Cooley, the greatest American authority on constitutional law, said to its convention, "Don't in your Constitution-making legislate too much. In your Constitution you are tying the hands of the people. Don't do that to any such extent as to prevent the Legislature hereafter from meeting all evils that may be within the reach of proper legislation."

BUFFALO, Aug. 6 -- Not more than 3,000 people patronized the sulky races here to-day, though there was a very good card to start the second week of the Grand Circuit meeting. The day was much warmer than the closing ones of the first week, and most of the heat-winners improved their records, Of all the heats, the most notable was the mile, in 2:12, paced by Directly, a two-year-old.

QUEBEC, Quebec, Aug. 6 -- Distressing intelligence as to the condition of many of the Indian tribes in Central Labrador has reached here. The famine in the Winter consequent upon the scarcity of game in sections that had been swept by forest fires is contributing to the approaching extinction of some of the aborigines.

VALPARAISO, Ind., Aug. 6. -- Samuel Ensign, who left this city twenty-one years ago to make a trip as engineer of an ocean steamer, returned to this county yesterday and told a strange story of his absence. The vessel on which he shipped went to Cuba, where the Captain got into trouble, and the crew was seized by the Spanish authorities.
Locked in a stateroom on the New-Haven steamboat C.H. Northam, a pretty young woman fought for her life last evening with a man who, crazed by drink and jealousy, was trying to kill her with a razor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Mr. Smith of New-Jersey was an object of great curiosity to-day to Senators who had read the statement published in a New-York paper over his signature purporting to give his views regarding the sugar schedule.

The suit brought by the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company to compel the Long Island Railroad Company to furnish better facilities for railroad travel was before Justice Gaynor, in the Kings County Supreme Court, yesterday. The plaintiffs claim that the defendants are violating the terms of their contract in not giving better facilities to the public east of Jamaica.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Here is a list of the House Democrats who have fallen in with the Gorman-Bynum caucus idea. They may not succeed in swinging the House into line for the Senate bill.

The simple announcement, "Fire at 5:25 A.M. on first floor of five-story tenement, 263 Broome Street, occupied by Elias Ganse as liquor store; damage, $50; not covered by insurance; cause unknown," was telegraphed to Police Headquarters early yesterday morning.

-- The petitions circulated for a new ticket in State Division politics have thus early stirred up considerable opposition to the list likely to comprise the "regular" nominees. The fact that Isaac B. Potter is the choice of those who desire a change is significant as showing, so the reformers assert, that he is the strongest man they could pit against Chief Consul Luscomb, the present incumbent.
Permits have been granted for the erection of the following new buildings in Brooklyn:

The Governing Board of the International League of Press Clubs met in the Marlborough Hotel yesterday at noon. It was the first meeting of the board since the convention of the league in Atlanta last Spring.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Michael J. Reilly of 196 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, and Thomas Gallagher of Haverstraw, were arrested this evening for passing counterfeit silver dollars. They went to several stores and tried to pass the spurious coin. A policemen followed the men into a saloon and caught them trying to pass countereit money.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Preparations were made to-day by the officers of the Whisky Trust to pay the tax on the immense stock of spirits which it has on hand. Collector of Internal Revenue Mize at this point sent six gaugers to the trust distillery at Pekin, Ill., to assist in the work of gauging out the whisky stored there. The men went there en orders from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Senate has passed the Anti-Anarchist bill. This is the substitute offered by Mr. Hill to the House bill calling for the inspection of immigrants by United States Consuls at foreign ports, and is regarded as a very strong measure.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 6 -- The funds of this village, which are kept in the Flushing Bank, have been attached in supplementary proceedings. A judgment was rendered against the village in July, 1893, because the Board of Trustees refused to call a special election to fill a vacancy in the village board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- While the press dispatches and commercial telegrams contain rumors of naval and land engagements between the Japanese and the Chinese forces, the legations of these countries in Washington and the State and Navy Departments receive no official messages to confirm or deny them.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 6 -- Dr. Bruce, in whom the farmers of the towns of Staford, Clinton, Milan, and Rhinebeck have a deep interest, went on the witness stand in the County Court to-day and attempted to throw the sole responsibility for the theft, last Winter, of a large number of fowls upon Orrin Friday, his whilom friend, companion, and landlord.

Capt. William S. Devery and Policeman Edward Glehnon will, on Thursday, go on trial before the Police Commissioners on charges prepared by Assistant District Attorney Wellman as counsel for the independent investigation of the Police Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The gold reserve was further reduced to-day by the engagement for export by to-morrow's steamers of $500,000. This leaves the reserve at $52,026,615. The balance, which includes the gold reserve, is to-day $119,117,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

Martin E. Yates of Goshen, Ind., committed suicide in this city yesterday, Mrs. Rosa Gross swallowed carbolic acid with suicidal intent, and John Schafer left on the bank of the Harlem River a note saying he was about to take his life.
One of the most prominent old-line Democrats of the Produce Exchange is Henry D. McCord, the grain merchant. He has been a Democrat all his life. At present he is allied with the State Democracy.
An attempt to escape from the prison on Blackwell's Island resulted in the death of one of the convicts yesterday. John Pender, another convict, narrowly escaped drowning.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The members of the Summer School of the University of Pennsylvania, who have been making a pilgrimage through New-England, and who are known as the Revolutionary Pilgrims, arrived here this afternoon and were taken in carriages and stages to visit the places of historic interest about the town.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Democrats of Montclair who are dissatisfied with Senator Smith's course as to the Tariff bill have forwarded to him this protest, signed by about 100 of the best citizens of the town. The signatures comprise the names of Montclair's member of the Democratic County Committee, the President of the Democratic Club, and the Chairman of the local Democratic organization:

JACKSON, Mich., Aug. 6 -- Ex-Gov. Austin Blair died at 1:20 o'clock this morning. The end was painless. For the last twenty-four hours he had lain in a comatose state, and only once or twice did he recognize his family about him. The cause of death was uraemic poisoning and inflammation of the liver.

-- The Pennsylvania end of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, running from York, Penn., to Delta a distance of forty-one miles, was sold at the Court House, in York, yesterday, by United States Marshal Golesberry. The road was purchased by G.A. Wilson of Baltimore for $43,000, subject to a judgment for $281,000, secured by Warren F. Walworth of Cleveland, Ohio.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Lillian Vandewater, a widow living at East Meadow, has just disclosed the details of an attempted robbery that stamps the perpetrator as one of the meanest thieves on earth. Mrs. Vandewater has three children, and supports them by doing such work as her neighbors can give her.
COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 6 -- Mr. S. L. Gracey, who was recently United States Consul at Foo-Chow, China, says of the Li Hung Chang yellow jacket incident:

It is good for New-Yorkers and Americans generally that the Summer of 1894 has thus far been unusually eventful. The weather has been a "leading topic," to be sure, but only one of many, and by no means the most important. It has never been the single, absorbing topic, as it often has been in Summers not fairly comparable with this in the matter of prolonged heat.
John McCarten wants a wife, and he is not at all backward in making the fact known to the public.
PARIS, Aug. 6. -- The trial of thirty Anarchists began this noon in the Court of Assizes, with M. Dayrus presiding and M. Bulot conducting the prosecution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- J.D. Porter of Tennessee, who to-day was nominated by the President as United States District Judge for the Middle District of Tennessee, has had an interesting experience in public life.

For the first time wheat and corn sold yesterday at the same price -- 58 cents per bushel, for September delivery. In former years the price of wheat at this season was about double that of corn, the usual price of which was not far from 45 cents per bushel. The explanation of present prices is the simple one that wheat is plenty and corn scarce.
The following is a list of passengers booked to sail to-day on the Spree, for Southampton and Bremen:
The New-York Times is glad to acknowledge the following receipts for the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild: H.F.H., $25; E.D., $25; H.D.W., $2.
The will of the late Jules Reynal de St. Michel, better known in New-York society circles as Jules Reynal, was filed yesterday for probate in the Surrogate's office.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Dispatches from TienTsin say thalt Li Hung Chang continues to direct the war preparations of the Chinese. To-day he reviewed the newly-arrived troops. The absence of his yellow jacket was the subject of much remark.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 6 -- The crop outlook has grown worse the last two days, and the report of the State Crop Bureau, to be given out to-morrow, will contain some startling figures.

Contracts have been entered into by the North German Lloyd Steamship Company and by the Hamburg-American Line for the construction of buildings to be erected on the Russian frontier of Germany for the control and examination of intending steerage passengers from Russia. These control stations are to be established at Illowo, Prostken, Eydtkuhnen, Ottlotschin, and Bojohren.

A meeting of the General Reorganization Committee of the A'tchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad will be held at 32 Liberty Street to-day, for the purpose of receiving a supplementary report from Expert Accountant Stephen Little regarding the condition of the books and accounts of the Atchison system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Most of the day in the House was spent in discussing the conference report on the Indian Appropriation bill. The conferrees had come together upon every item except the one relating to the ratification of the treaties with the Siletz, Yankton, Sioux, and Nez Perces Indians for the cession of portions of their respective reservations.
DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 6 -- The White Republicans of Texas, called the "Lily Whites," met in State Convention this afternoon.

The reports and statements which have appeared in our columns in the last few days leave no room for doubt that the water supply of Jersey City, drawn from the Passaic River, is so polluted from the drainage of the towns further up the stream as to be unfit for use, at least for drinking purposes.

For the first time in many weeks, Sugar was not the most active stock in the market yesterday. It was strong early in the day, advancing to 106 1/4, but subsequently it reacted a couple of points, but recovered and closed at 105 3/4, a net gain of 3/8 on sales of 18,459 shares. The other industrials were extremely quiet and were without feature.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Business was very quiet to-day, outside of West Chicago. There was an absence of news of any kind, and the prevailing sentiment was rather more bearish than otherwise. The support given to the market seems to have been withdrawn, and there is but little public trading.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- Commander Harrington, United States Navy, lectured in the War College course to-day on the place and office of a ram in a fleet. It was expected that he would refer to Friday's performance of the Atlanta, which was damaged in ramming the derelict schooner Golden Rule, and there was a large attendance.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 6 -- That in the affairs of a political party, as of any other voluntary association of mankind, dissension and disaster are inseparable yoke-fellows, is a truism too obvious to need comment. It is inevitable that, when faction intrudes and associates who should pull together begin to pull apart, from that moment the weakness of division begins to supplant the strength of unity.

Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, sitting in Brooklyn, became very angry yesterday because he thought Lawyer Farquhar, representing the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, did not want to conduct a case before him.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- Countess Sierstorpff entertained at dinner to-night. She had twelve guests. The decorations were pink hydrongeas and maidenhair ferns. The guests included James J. Van Alen, Count Raventlow, the Danish Minister; Mr. and Mrs. R.H.I. Goddard, Miss Josephine Johnson, Miss Schermerhorn, Mrs. J.B. Harriman, Mrs. Whitney Warren, Richard T. Wilson, Jr., and C. Raoul Duval.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The President has approved acts authorizing a bridge over the South Canadian River, near Livingston, Oklahoma; a pension to the widow of Gen. John M. Corse; amending the Arizona Funding act of 1890; exempting from duty the articles of foreign exhibition at the inter-State fair at Tacoma, Washington; amending the act to organize the Life-Saving Service; establishing a fog signal at Kewaune, Wis.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 6 -- The detectives from the Treasury Department succeeded yesterday afternoon in unraveling the mystery which has surrounded the movements of the gang of counterfeiters, and unearthed the headquarters of the party. The work of months was rewarded by the finding of the plates with which the bad money was made, the engravers' tools, and thousands of dollars of counterfeit money ready to be placed in circulation.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Sanitary Superintendent Roberts received a report yesterday from Assistant Chemist Beebe of the Division of Bacteriology of the Health Department on the examination made by him of specimens of the cheese which Inspector Fuller seized last week, which the State Board of Health reported as containing germs of diphtheria.

The struggle that is before the Democracy of this State may well command the best thought and the best work of Democrats for the success of the party. Peculiar conditions that there is no disposition to ignore confront us. Democrats in New-York State outnumber the Republicans by 50,000 at least, yet last year in this Democratic.

One through train each way between New-York and Chicago will be discontinued by the Vanderbilt lines, beginning next Saturday. Train No. 1, which is the New-York and Chicago limited, leaving here at 10:30 A.M., will be withdrawn, as also will Train No. 20, which leaves Chicago at 1:30 P.M. and is known as the North Shore limited, east-bound.
Frank and Frederick Deloni and Antonio Porceo are three unfortunate Italians who reached New-York Sunday on their way home to Italy.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- There was another flurry in People's Traction at the opening of business this morning. The first sale was at 49, and it jumped without a transaction to 49 1/2, and subsequently moved up to 50 5/8. Some of the shorts closed out to-day, but there are a few of them left. The principal reason for the boom was the large increase in receipts on yesterday's business.

-- Palmer's Theatre. -- As already announced, the season of 1894-5 at Palmer's will begin Sept. 3, When Helen Dauvray will appear there in "That Sister of His." by William Gill. The following Monday Mr. Palmer will produce, by arrangement with Joseph Brooks, for the first time in New-York. Augustus Thomas's latest play, called "New Blood," which has been successful in Chicago.

The Giants did not play up to their standard of last week when they closed their engagements with the Bridegrooms at the Polo Grounds yesterday. In fact, they did not act like pennant seekers at all, for, during the nine innings played, Father Foutz's boys cracked the sphere for just twenty-five hits.

The fourth annual exhibition of the Westchester County Horse Show Association will be held on the association's grounds, at White Plains, N.Y., on Sept. 25, 26, 27, 2S. and 29. There are twelve classes, arranged under fifty sub-classes, which cover pretty much every variety of equine blood used for pleasure and en the farm.

"WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The increasing evidences that New-York State Democrats are impressed with the necessity of harmonizing their differences preparatory to the coming campaign are hailed with satisfaction by Democrats from other States, who appreciate the effect such unity would have upon the party throughout the country.

It would be a very long while, indeed, between drinks if the Governor of Arizona were to meet any other and bibulous Governor in the Astor House, where the former is at present staying. For Gov. Hughes of That Territory neither drinks nor smokes, and he has ideas on all subjects which he does not hesitate either to express or to put into practice.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Mr. Voorhees has sounded a note of warning to Mr. German and his fellow-conspirators in the Senate which ought to convince them that their attempt to shape the Tariff bill to suit their selfish ends is bound to end in failure.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 6 -- In one month from to-day the State Convention of the two great parties will have been held and the campaign will have begun, yet more hard work will be done during this coming month in the contest between the two principal aspirants for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination than in the entire subsequent campaign between the two parties.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 6 -- What promises to be one of the most interesting of this season's tennis tournaments, especially at this stage of the Summer's play, was begun at picturesque Norwood Park this afternoon. As this is the week previous to the national championship meeting at Newport, this meeting is unusually important.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- A dispatch from TienTsin says that Jules Leon Dutreuil de Rhins, geographer and explorer, has been murdered in Thibet. His body was found in a river. His diary and scientific data are missing.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Aug. 6 -- To-night on the eve of the great centennial celebration, this city has taken on a fete appearance. The streets are already thronged by hundreds of visitors. Flags and banners float from every available point, and the entire city is draped in the centennial colors of buff and blue.

Made desperate by hunger and the sight of his starving wife and child and old father, Allen McLean turned highwayman three weeks ago. He had never before been guilty of a dishonest action. From early boyhood he had worked faithfully at everything he undertook. But somehow he never prospered.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 6 -- It looks as if the Republicans of this State are in for a hard time of it this Fall. Within the last few days, Gen. Merwin of New-Haven, Col. Frank W. Cheney of Manchester, ex-State Senator O. Vincent Coffin of Middletown, Col. John A. Porter of Hartford, and ex-Mayor William H. Marigold of Bridgeport have stated publicly and definitely that they are after the Republican nomination for Governor of Connecticut.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 6 -- John Weibert, a saloon keeper, living at Woolsey and Ninth Avenues, came very near being lynched to-night by his neighbors for beating his wife. Weibert is about thirty-five years old, and his wife is thirty years old. They have one child. Mrs. Weibert was only recently discharged from the Astoria Hospital, where she was treated for severe wounds inflicted by her husband.

COWSS, Aug. 6 -- Forty-three years ago, when Queen Victoria was in her matronly prime, she saw England's peerless pleasure fleet defeated by the Yankee schooner America. To-day her son, the Prince of Wales, saw his own cutter, the Britannia, vanquished handsomely over the same course, from Cowes around the Isle of Wight, that the America traversed when she taught British tars the value of a beamy model.
Committee of Thirty Republicans of the Fourteenth Assembly District have won the distinction, of being the first organization to put a candidate for Mayor in the field.

The body of the woman who committed suicide on Sunday morning in New-Utrecht by shooting herself, in the left breast after taking carbolic acid, was positively identified at the Brooklyn Morgue last night.

Stephen Brodie, the Bowery saloon keeper, who has made a comfortable living out of his reputation, as a bridge jumper, and who is at St. Vincent's Hospital with a stab wound in his neck, as told in The New-York Times, was reported out of danger yesterday. The surgeon said he would leave the hospital on Saturday, probably.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The British steamship Lismore Castle, which left London for Port Natal on Aug. 3, came in collision yesterday with a steamer near the island of Ushant. She arrived at Plymouth to-day with, a large hole in her bow.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- A cigarette cast away by a small boy in the pavilion of the Philadelphia Ball Club, at Broad and Huntingdon Streets, this morning started a fire that completely destroyed the grand stand and the bleachers and wrecked and ruined the grounds for further play this year.

Jacob Schaefer. the wizard of the cue, arrived in this city from Havre yesterday on La Navarre. He was accompanied by his wife. At the pier many well-known billlardists greeted the great player, who seemed to be pleased to be once more in America. Schaefer's return at this time was brought about by the closing of all the billiard academies in Paris on account of the gambling element attached to them.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- The Casino dance to-night was the most brilliant in some years. Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor were there for the first time this season.

Mrs. Mary Sallode, who owns the house at 53 West Twenty-fourth Street, appeared in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, and asked Justice Voorhis to issue a warrant for the arrrest of Jacob Schneider, the proprietor of the Arlington Hotel, at 54 West Twenty-fourth Street. The hotel is opposite Mrs. Sallode's house.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The following official statement is made by Brig. Gen. Flagler regarding the cause of the caisson disaster at Chicago, in which several soldiers were blown to pieces:

Affairs in the horse world are beginning to be more interesting than has been the case for several weeks past, and arrangements for several important sales of thoroughbreds and hackneys are now under way. The new venture in pony racing, which is to be begun to-morrow at the Parkway Driving Club's fine little track, has put new life into amateur sportsmen, who have every reason to expect a good meeting of fifteen days.

If President Cleveland's fidelity and persistence in doing what he thinks right were dependent on decent treatment from those who differ from him in politics they would not hold put long. Happily, he is not "built that way." He has had a good many tests of his courage and firmness, and he has met them with great simplicity and directness and with a remarkable degree of success.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- The following companies have been incorporated with the Secretary of State:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Smartly-at-tired women and stylish traps of all kinds made the scene at the Casino at Norwood Park this afternoon a pretty one. The matches in the second day of the invitation tennis tournament were played before a large and enthusiastic crowd, and the results of the day's contests prove the attractive uncertainty of the same.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 7 -- J.H. Carpenter, General Manager of the Carpenter Steel Company of Reading, Penn., against the reliability of whose armorpiercing shells Wesley H. May, an ex-employe of the company, has made charges, was in this city to-day. Mr. Carpenter was apparently not perturbed by the alleged exposure.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The Russian newspapers are abandoning the idea of an amicable understanding between England and Russia with respect to Corea, and are publishing anti-English articles. Especially suspicious of England is The Novoe Vremya, which declares that England is secretly supporting China, and that Japan will soon find this out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Senator Gorman is quoted as saying: "The House conferrees refuse to do anything. They will not agree, nor will they consent to report a disagreement. They will have just forty-eight hours longer in which to make up their minds to do something.

ORILLIA, Ontario, Aug. 7 -- The regatta here to-day over the Lake Couchiching course was very successful, the races being witnessed by 4,000 people. The weather was fine and warm. The events included the professional single scull, professional double, and a couple of local races. There was a slight southerly breeze. The course was two and one-eighth miles.

First, harmony; second, new men for candidates. This is the sum and substance of the judgment of ex-Mayor Daniel D. Whitney of Brooklyn, as to the future course of the Democracy of New-York City and the State.

ELKHART, Ind., Aug. 7 -- A bold attempt was made at Kessler's Siding, just before daybreak this morning, to hold up the Lake Shore express train, which passed this city at 12:30. As the train approached the station the engine struck a pile of ties, which had been placed on the track. The obstruction was pushed aside and Engineer Buntin opened the throttle, and the train, under full speed, struck a second obstruction.

From The Milwaukee Wisconsin. Two young fellows once entered a Western train and took seats. They were unaccustomed to railway travel, and were constantly on the watch for some accident. Every few minutes they would raise the window and look out. Presently, as the train came around a curve, one of them saw a fence which he seemed to suppose crossed the track.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- Almost everything looked, and was, weak at the opening; even the tractions looked toppy. The floor traders were especially bearish on St. Paul, and in the early trading it was lower in Philadelphia than in New-York. Shortly after noon the temper changed, and the scramble to cover a number of stocks became very strong.

SARATOGA, Aug. 7 -- Members of the Democratic State Committee are beginning to put in an appearance, preparatory to the meeting, which will be held here Thursday. A half dozen or more are here, chiefly from New-York City and Kings County. Other Democrats are coming, and it is expected that there will be men who are prominent in the party from about every county in the State.
Capt. Hugh R. Garden, a leading member of the Southern Society and a conspicuous figure in Democratic politics of the best sort, in speaking of the political situation, said:
While Sadie Levy, twenty-four years old, of Baltimore, Md., was walking through Ludlow Street yesterday afternoon, she was seized around the neck by Mrs. Lena Levy, who lives at 177 Ludlow Street.

Until late in the day, yesterday's stock market was dull and uninteresting. In the early trading London sold a few stocks, but the movement was not important, and only had a sentimental effect on prices. Great dullness ensued until the final hour, when, under a general covering movement, the whole list moved upward, and closed above the last prices on Monday, and at the highest prices of the day.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Aug. 7 -- At daybreak this morning the people of this city and the surrounding country were startled into activity by the booming of the cannon at Fort Defiance firing the grand salute of 100 guns as the initial act in the great three-day centennial celebration in commemoration of the founding of Fort Defiance by Anthony Wayne, Aug. 8. 1794.

A detailed statement showing irregularities in the bookkeeping of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company was laid before the General Reorganization Committee yesterday by Stephen Little, the expert accountant. It confirmed Mr. Little's first report that the gross earnings of the company had been overstated on the books to the amount of about $7,400,000, and showed the various entries which make up that sum.

CITY ISLAND, Aug. 7 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Susquehanna, Joseph Stickney; Emeline, C.W. Roche; Siesta, George Green; Judy, T.R. Hostetter; Talisman, S.A. Maxwell, and BoPeep, E.H. Townsend. Schooner yacht Speranza, O.D. Wilkinson.

BRAZIL, Ind., Aug. 7 -- Traffic on the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad at this point was stopped for twelve hours to-day by the burning of two bridges a few miles north and west of this city, one of them being on a branch line. The money loss to the company will be very large. Strikers or their sympathizers are suspected of setting the bridges on fire.

-- The New-Haven Yacht Fleet is now on its eleventh annual cruise eastward. About twenty boats make up the squadron. The fleet left Deering Harbor yesterday morning for New-London in a light southerly wind. Gertrude, Thomas T. Tabor, owner, led the fleet into that harbor, followed by Rival, Henry S. Dickinson; Flora, Rear Commodore Hammer, and Thelma, Commodore Holcomb.

BUFFALO, Aug. 7 -- Five classes were decided at the Grand Circuit meeting here to-day, keeping the harness racers busy till dark. The attendance is still falling off, though the faster events that are to come later may help matters. There is considerable grumbling every day about the laxity in the judges stand, and the pool buyers are not speculating as heavily as usual.

The Long Island Pony-Racing Association will begin a fifteen days meeting at the Parkway Driving Club's track at Gravesend, L.I., to-day. Besides the pony and hurdle racing there will be races for thoroughbreds. Several owners have decided to take their horses from Brighton to this track. The racing will begin at 3 P.M.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 7 -- The boiler of the dredger Philadelphia, at work in the Delaware River, exploded this afternoon and five men were badly injured and one is missing, supposed to have been blown into the river and drowned. The injured are:

The year 1894 completes a century of existence for the great drug house of W.H. Schieffelin Co. To emphasize this fact the firm has issued to its friends a handsome pamphlet of fifty-six pages, entitled "One Hundred Years of Business Life," that contains a full historical sketch of the firm's increase from what nowadays would be considered a small beginning.

From The Portland Oregonian. An unusually interesting case is that of John Kelleher of Grant's Pass, now under treatment for rattlesnake bite at the Good Samaritan Hospital. The patient is a tall, brawny son of Erin, with muscles like iron and a frame of steel; but the sharp-pointed fangs of a venomous "rattler" thrust into his thumb laid him low and brought him near to death.

The party of pilgrims which has been visiting points of historical interest in the Eastern States and along the Hudson reached this city yesterday afternoon. They went to the Park Avenue Hotel, where they were received and welcomed to New-York by Col. Asa Bird Gardiner on behalf of the Sons of the Revolution.

The second meeting of the Flushing Jockey Club will begin to-day at the Flushing track, near Whitestone, L.I. The programme for each day will include five races, with purses of $60 for each, race. To-day's card is as follows:

-- The, Waddington, Canton and Southern Railroad Company was incorporated with the Secretary of State in Albany yesterday, to construct a standard-gauge steam road, about twenty-eight miles long, with the following termini: A point on Dry Island, in the St. Lawrence River, near Waddington, and a point near High Falls, on the Grasse River, in Canton, St. Lawrence County.

New-York shared in Western fluctuations for corn yesterday, if not in the excitement that prevailed at Chicago, and when business ended for the day, prices for September deliveries were 63 1/2 cents per bushel for corn and 60 1/8 cents for wheat.

Our dispatches of yesterday indicated that the suggested new schedule of sugar duties which we explained on Monday morning was at one time practically accepted by the conference committee. When the work of the committee was resumed on Monday, "the language" of the proposed schedule, our correspondent say, "was being prepared by the House conferrees, under the direction of the Secretary of the Treasury."

The New-York Auxiliary Association of the National Dairymen's Union met yesterday at the New-York Mercantile Exchange, Hudson and Harrison Streets, and adopted a resolution thanking Senator Hill, Congressman Grout, and Chairman of the Committee of Agriculture Hatch for the courtesies and assistance extended by these gentlemen to the delegation from the union on its recent visit to Washington.

-- The sixth annual report of the Scandinavian Sailors' Temperance Home of Brooklyn shows that during the past year 1,368 sailors lived at the home 15,868 days and that the Directors paid $43,681.67 for the sailors to their families in Sweden and Norway. There is on deposit for account of sailors $7,778,17. There is a deficit in the home's accounts for the last eighteen months of $743,16.
HAVERSTRAW, Aug. 7 -- I am for harmony, as every true Democrat should be, and I believe that such is the sentiment of the body of the Democracy of this county.
Ten little maidens sitting in a line. One took her chair away, and then there were nine.

RIPON, Wis., Aug. 7 -- Sanger won the twomile open race at to-day's meet of the Ripon Cycling Club. Ripon has a national reputation for its fine race meet. Every man, woman, and child turns out for the races, the stores close, and race day is a local holiday. The city's population of 4,000 all turned out for to-day's meet.

The Kings County Board of Supervisors met yesterday at the Brooklyn Court House. Supervisor at Large Fitchie presided. It being the annual meeting, the annual reports of Surrogate Abbott and County Treasurer Adams were rendered.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- Since the unwelcome suspicion that, by the amendment of last Winter to the fish and game laws, the open season for deer in this State was apparently reduced from two and a half months to one month the State Fish and Game Protector and the Attorney General have been besieged with inquiries.

The lives of six firemen were imperiled yesterday noon, while fighting a fire in the paint store of Alien Tofts, at 212 Eighth Avenue. The store is on the southeast corner of Twenty-first Street, in a three-story brick building.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 7 -- Rioting took place to-day at South Omaha as the result of the packing houses putting new men to work. Two of the employes were caught outside the works by a crowd of strikers, and seriously injured. The crowd pounced on to the workmen, but a force of stock-yards men, who were near, succeeded in driving the strikers off.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Gorman is in a desperate way with his fight against any Tariff bill except that of the Senate, "without the dotting of an 'i' or the crossing of a 't.' "

John C. Brassington, nineteen, years old, who lives at 47 Ludlow Street, Mount Vernon, who has been frequently heard of, owing to his hydrophobia fits during the past year, caused great excitement in the counting room of The New-York Herald about 1 o'clock this morning.
The American Jockey Club, a new name for the New-Jersey Jockey Club, racing under the old charter of the American Jockey Club, will begin racing to-day at Jerome Park.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 7 -- Notre Dame is to-day the scene of an important event in the ecclesiastical history of the Catholic Church of America. It is the first assemblage of the members of the Priests' Eucharistic League in this country. This order was inaugurated at Lille, France, April 25, 1881. Its membership is confined to the clergy, and its object is the promotion of devotion to the most blessed sacrament.

"The notice in The New-York Times that brought the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild a donation from President Cleveland has done us more good than any one thing that has happened this year," said William L. Strong, President of the Central National Bank, and Treasurer of the Guild, to a reporter for The Times yesterday afternoon.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Mr. Walbaum, the President of the Saratoga Racing Association, attempted to put some of his Guttenberg buldozing tactics in force in the betting ring here to-day, and met with a rather unexpected rebuff. The heaviest beltor at the track, as well as the nerviest, bookmaker, is Riley Grannan, a young Westerner.

SARATOGA, Aug. 7 -- There is some question to-night as to whether the Democratic State Convention can be held here during the week of Monday, Sept. 24, if it is desired to hold it in the new Convention Hall. It has been ascertained that the Unitarians have secured this hall for four days of that week.

We must confess we cannot understand the drift of The New-York World of late. While The Times, The News, Daily America, and even The Sun, are printing articles in favor of a united and harmonious Democracy in the Empire State, The World is printing articles that smack more of guerrilla warfare than harmony and Democratic success.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- T.W. Russell, the Liberal-Unionist member for South Tyrone, has an article in to-day's Pall Mall Gazette concerning the future of the Evicted Tenants bill. He urges the adoption of an amendment making the reinstatement or the evicted tenants in question voluntary instead of compulsory.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 7 -- Never during the past ten years has the corn crop of Illinois cut such a figure on all speculative boards as is manifest over the condition of the present crop, and as many diversified opinions are had from as many different places regarding the actual condition of the crop of 1894.

QUEBEC, Aug. 7 -- This city was last night the scene of a disgraceful and riotous demonstration. The French Baptist Mission has recently been established in this city, with its headquarters in a building on Bridge Street, and belonging to a Mr. Samson.

Sir Henry Parkes entered his eightieth year to-day, (May 28,)" writes the Sydney correspondent of the Westminster Gazette, "and he has received congratulations from all quarters, and birthday presents ranging from flowers to turkeys and cases of champagne, and he has been enrertained at a banquet by the citizens or Sydney.

Dr. James Strong. Dr. James Strong, Professor Emeritus of Exegetical Theology at Drew Seminary, died yesterday of heart failure, after a few days illness, at Round Lake, N.Y. He was acknowledged to be the most thorough master of Bible exegesis in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Senate was in session to-day for only two hours and did not take up any question of general interest or importance. About half a dozen bills were passed, of which one was to facilitate the collection of Sate, county, and municipal taxes from corporations in the hands of receivers, under orders of a United Slates court.

Bridget E. Dillon, a widow, appeared as complainant in the Harlem Police Court before Police Justice Taintor yesterday against Marshall R. Delaney, whom she accused of swindling her out of $411. The Justice held Delaney for examination.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 7 -- The Iowa Crop Bureau makes the following statement as to the condition of crops in the monthly review issued to-day covering July:

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- There was again little in the market outside of West Chicago, most of the business being purely professional, although there are quite a number of outside orders for small amounts of stock. The speculators are attracted, by the fluctuations in the grain market, and not a few operators usually interested in stocks were giving their attention to corn and wheat.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- A series of rapid upturns in corn the past few days culminated this morning in a veritable panic on the Board of Trade, and ore of the wildest and most exciting openings that has been seen in years was witnessed when the bell tapped at 9:30. Wild brokers were rushing from pit to pit, and messengers were flying back and forth from the telegraph booths to the trading centres.

The quarter-fifteen handicap tennis tournament of the Staten Island Cricket Club was continued yesterday on the Livingstone courts. The preliminary doubles were finished according to the schedule. The favorites and scratch men, Willis and Rome, proved unequal to the task of giving the required odds to Lawrence and Von Bernuth and did not get a set.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 7 -- The residents of Greenville seem at last to have made up their minds to take some positive action in regard to the vile water furnished by the city for domestic purposes.
Writing from Springfield, Mass., Mr. Charles Jacobus gives this glowing account of an outing along the Northern Maine border:

ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 7 -- The Washington-Denver bicycle relay riders reached this place at 5:03 o'clock this afternoon, and two minutes later resumed their travel, going like the wind when they reached the outskirts of the town. They reported good roads generally and did not seem to be any the worse for their hard work a-wheel.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- Dominion Coal was still weak, selling down 1/2 on small transactions. West End Street Railway, both common and preferred, reflected the street rumors of largely increased earnings, an average of about $1,000 per day over last year, and economies in operating. The items together must result in a large increase in the net.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 7 -- Joseph R. Wilson, the El Paso County Deputy Sheriff who was captured by Adjt. Gen. Tarsney in Missouri, has made a full confession, and has given to Chief of Police Armstrong the names of all the men connected with the outrage upon the Adjutant General committed in Colorado Spring some weeks ago.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- The best portion of the session of the Constitutional Convention to-day was consumed by Jesse Johnson of Kings, who discussed the proposition of home rule for cities which was reported from the Committee on Cities, of which he is Chairman.

-- Brooklyn cyclists are talking of having a Sunday run to church. A Jersey City minister recently said from his pulpit: "The bicycle mania is spreading far and wide, and we rejoice in it, for wheeling is a noble sport and destined to improve the American stock. The craze is more than a passing fad. It is an abiding and increasing popular form of recreation.
Mrs. Adelaide Stock, thirty-five years old, shot herself through the head at her home, 368 Eighth Street, just before midnight Monday, and fell to the floor lifeless.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The dispatch boat Dolphin will fly the flag of the Secretary of the Navy for the next thirty days. She left New-London yesterday for Washington, where she will be provided with stores for a long cruise, and next Monday or Tuesday will leave for the New-England naval stations, having on board Secretary Herbert, accompanied by his son and daughter.

The loyal cohorts of Congressman Timothy J. Campbell, accompanied by their sweethearts, wives, and babies, descended in force yesterday upon College Point, L.I., and took possession of Witzel's Point View Grove, where they abandoned themselves to sport and revelry.

The victory of the Democrats in Alabama appears to be so decisive that Kolb can hardly reiterate his old cry of fraud without making himself more ridiculous than ever. The fact is that all the disreputable methods of which there is any evidence have been resorted to by his followers.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- A dispatch from Shanghai concerning the action of Chinese soldiers in seizing Japanese subjects aboard the British steamer Chung King last week says:

BRIGHTON BEACH, Aug. 7 -- Detective John T. Norris of Springfield, Ohio, and a squad of New-York and Brooklyn detectives spent the afternoon at the Brighton Beach race track trying to find three swindlers who have been working the "gold-brick" game in the West. The trio is said to have made more than $500,000 in the West during the last month.

Although Police Captain Devery's trial has been, set by the Police Commissioners for to-morrow, it is doubtful whether it will begin, for the Captain is said to be quite ill at his home, 353 West Twenty-eighth Street, and unfit to appear at Police Headquarters. In addition to this, his lawyer, Col. Edward C. James, is on his way to the scene of the Japanese-Chinese war.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 7 -- An important equity case is now having its final hearing before the law court, and attracts a great array of lawyers from all parts of the State. It is the Somerset Railway in equity against Lewis Pierce and others. The Somerset Railroad Company in 1871 issued bonds to the amount of $450,000, secured by mortgage.

The indorsement of ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton by the Republicans of the Twenty-fourth Assembly District for Governor and Col. S.V.R. Cruger's refusal to be a candidate for Mayor were the chief topics of discussion in Republican circles last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- In sending his third veto message to the present Congress to-day, the bill disapproved being one to authorize the President to appoint Capt. Eugene Wells, late of the Twelfth Infantry, a Second Lieutenant of artillery in the army, and to place him on the retired list on account on disability, the President says:

The Times unreservedly approves Senator Murphy's declaration that Democratic hairmony can be brought about through the primaries, and in no other way. "Let those who distrust the present State organization," says the Sen- ator, "turn, out in full force at the pri- maries to be held for the election of delegates to the State Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The crop bulletin issued by the Weather Bureau to-day shows the following results: New-England. -- Crops improving in south, excellent in north; haying mostly completed; all English hay fair crop in south, heavy in north; meadows good everywhere; all hay extra quality and secured in splendid condition.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- The big Anarchist trial was continued to-day in the Court of Assizes. The Prosecutor and Presiding Judge examined at great length Felix Fenepn, formerly clerk in the War Office; Armand Matha, publicist; Phillpe Leon Ortiz, shop clerk, and the Italians, Bertani and Chericotti.

Paris Correspondent London Telegraph. Awards have now been given to the successful competitors who ran horseless carriages to Rouen on Sunday last. The first prize of L200 has been divided by the Petit Journal organizers between MM. Panhard and Levasseur of Paris, and MM. Peugeot of Valentigny, Doubs.

The arraignment of the thirty Anarchists in Paris is a novel procedure and is the first fruit of a novel law. It is made possible by the anti-Anarchist law passed only last week. That law is the first answer, in a new code of legislation, to a new crime, unforeseen and unimagined by the framers of previously existing codes.

-- The Staten Island Athletic Club has announced that a tennis tournament will be held on the club grounds on Labor Day, Sept. 3, in connection with the club's usual Labor Day celebration. The tournament is open to residents of Richmond County and members of Staten Island clubs. Men's singles and doubles will be played, and first and second prizes are offered in singles, a first prize being the only trophy for the doubles.

William Roberts, who was convicted in the Court of General Sessions in February, 1889, for having been caught with burglar's tools in his possession, and was sentenced to imprisonment in State prison for six years and ten months, was before Judge Truax, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday upon a writ of habeas corpus secured by his counsel.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 7 -- The returns from the State of yesterday's general election have been rolling in slowly to-day, only to increase the majority for Oates and the State Democratic ticket. To-night Oats's majority over Kolb and the Populist ticket is estimated to be from 25,000 to 30,000, with a chance for more.

There was a brief hearing upon the writ of habeas corpus obtained by Henry J. Faison of the village of Faison, N.C., before Judge Truax, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, to compel his wife to produce in court their child, Raymond, who is three years and eight months old, and to show cause why he should not have its custody.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 7 -- The steamship Culmore, looking as trim as a pleasure yacht, steamed down the bay last night for Port Antonio, Jamaica, in charge of Capt. James E. Atkinson. At noon to-day she was tied up at Brown's Wharf, looking as if she had been through a West Indian hurricane.

The dry goods firm of Zeimer Co. of 225 and 227 Sixth Avenue made a general assignment to Simon Schwartz yesterday, giving a preference to Samuel Zeimer, father of one of the partners, for $34,771 for rent of the store paid by him and which the firm agreed to repay, and for merchandise sold to the firm by Zeimer Feldstein, which claim was assigned to Samuel Zeimer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- For two hours to-day the eorn market was in a high excited state. The wild scenes of yesterday were re-enacted with this difference, that prices were going in a different direction. that such an irragular and uncertain action as marked the trade to-day and yesterday was not followed by some failures was nothing short of wonderful.

There were from 1,50O to 1,800 persons at the Parkway Driving Club's track at King's Highway yesterday, the opening of the Long Island PonyRacing Association's fifteen days' meeting. Five books and a paris mutuel, the latter exclusively for 1 -- 2 -- 3 betting, were on hand to accommodate the speculators. There were as many rumors floating around as horses.

The Long Island Railroad Company gained a victory over the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company yesterday when Justice Gaynor, in the Kings County Supreme Court, denied the motion to enjoin the Long Island Railroad Company from running trains from the Flatbush Avenue Station, Brooklyn, according to the present Summer timetable.

ALBANY. N. Y., Aug. 8. -- In the Constitutional Convention this morning, the Committee on Legislative Powers reported favorably Mr. Dean's amendment abolishing State commissions, Mr. McDonough's providing for the referendum for laws affecting localities, and Mr. A. H. Clark's in regard to the division of counties.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 8. -- Last night Sheriff Bowers returned with two prisoners from Denver. One was exDeputy Sheriff J. K. Wilson, who was arrested in Missouri, and the other Dr. J. T. Reed of the Union Gold Mining Company, one of Colorado Springs's most prominent citizens, who was arrested on a charge of carrying concealed weapons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The New-York Senators managed to-day to dispose of eleven of the nominations of New-York Postmasters, which had been pending for months. Through their efforts the Senate rejected four of these nominations and confirmed seven.

Paris Correspondent of The London Telegraph Truculent warfare is being carried on between the white and the colored students of the Colonial School here. This institution is a nursery for colonial officials, and among the candidates for future posts in Tonquin Senegal, and other places are negroes and half-castes.

Two games for one admission was again the offering at Eastern Park yesterday, but the enthusiasts who desire to see the Brooklyn team a factor in the League race did not feel that they got their money's worth. They saw the Baltimore team floor the aged Bridegrooms twice in succession, and in such clever style that, left no doubt in the minds of bleachery critics that the home team was somehow severely handicapped.

DOVER, N. J., Aug. 8. -- As an old Democratic newspaper man please, let me congratulate you on the stand your paper has taken for Harmony (with a big H) in the Democratic Party of New-Tork State. Harmony and united action are necessary to success at any time, and particularly so now, when some of the pseudo-Democratic papers are preaching and practicing anything but the proper course for Democratic success.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 8. -- There seems to be litile doubt that the water furnished to the people of this city is daily becoming worse. Or perhaps it would be more exact to say that its foulness is being more evenly distributed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 8. -- It the fine weather continues and no accident happens to the riders, the great relay bicycle race from Washington to Denver will end many hours ahead of the schedule time. The message, which the wheelmen are currying from President Cleveland to the Governor of Colorado, left this city at 1:42 o'clock this afternoon in charge of " Tom " Roe and Frank Clemens.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- A dispatch dated at Yokohama on Aug. 6 says: " The Japanese, after suffering a trifling, loss, have routed the Chinese and taken Seikwan. The Chinese fled to Koshin; their, loss was 500 killed. The Japanese are now holding an important position above Yashan, and have established complete connection, With their troops there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Senator Murphy will not be present to-morrow at the meeting of the Democratic Committee at Saratoga. He said to-day to a correspondent of The New-York Times that in view of the present tariff situation and the absence of a pressing demand for his presence in Saratoga he felt it to be his duty to remain in Washington.

President Clausen's letter to Mayor Gilroy, written in behalf of the Park Board in response to the Mayor's request for action on a demand of Cornelius Vanderbilt, Augustus St. Gaudens, Stanford White, and W. M. Chase for the employment of a landscape architect to supervise the construction of the Harlem River Speedway, was made public yesterday by Willis Holly, the Mayor's secretary.

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 8. -- The convicted Anarchists who led the memorable riots of the silk workers during March and April last, and who were convicted for assaulting workmen, throwing bombs, and writing threatening letters, were sentenced this morning by Judge Hopper, in the Court of Quarter Sessions.

From The Westminster Gazette. German journalism is getting on. It is comparing its own newspapers to those of other countries, and that, in itself, is a proceeding which ought to be valuable to the German press. The Strassburger Post, one of the most enterprising and lively among them, has already taken a good, many hints from its English and French contemporaries, but it cannot yet make up its mind to insert personal paragraphs.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8. -- The plans which the Republicans had laid for the opening of the campaign in this State early in September have been disarranged. It was proposed to have a monster demonstration in this city on Wednesday, Sept. 5, at which ex-President Harrison would deliver the principal address and sound the keynote of the campaign.

Jerome Park assumed its old-time appearance yesterday. The favorite old race course has been overlooked of late, but the patrons of the turf have not forgotten the scene of many a hard-fought battle, raid when the starter's flag dropped for the first race yesterday, fully 5,000 persons were within the inclosure.

OCEAN GROVE. N. J., Aug. 8. -- The anniversary of the Woman's Home Missionary Society was observed here to-day. The services were opened by the President, Mrs. Clinton B. Fisk, who made an interesting address upon missionary work. Then followed an address on " The Alaskan Mission." by Mrs. Henry M. Teller of Washington.

STONY ISLAND, Aug. 8. -- I am heartily in favor of the action and purposes of The New-York Times. There are, however, in my judgment, three things necessary to any successful issue of Democratic efforts.

From The London Daily News. Louis Tabernet, President Carnot's cook, is about to resign his important functions into other hands. The new President brings with him to the Elysee his own chef, Fleuret, one of the masters of contemparar'y culinary art. Fleuret's salary is said to be one which many a professional man would envy.

The news from Washington is, if not cheering, at least more satisfactory. No sincere tariff reformer would be likely to find much cause for cheer in the Senate's revision of the Wilson bill, but it is now predicted that the two houses will agree This week, and the terms of their probable agreement are foreshadowed in detail.
