MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 8. -- This place and Bloomfield seem to be on the verge of another typhoid fever epidemic which bids fair to become as violent as the one which visited this locality last May and carried away nearly fifty of its inhabitants.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 8. -- Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock gave a dinner this evening at the Tiffany cottage, Clay Street. Her guests were Baron A. Leghait, the Belgian Minister; Count Raventlow, the Danish Minister; Mr. and Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks, Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Fitzhugh Whitehouse, Count A. Sierstorpff, Mrs. William Post, Robert Center, Mrs. Paran Stevens, Miss Josephine Johnson, Miss Gammell, Center Hitchcock, and James Otis.

The Eldorado ballet girls met again at Clarendon Hall yesterday afternoon and discussed the matter of salaries owed them by the Eldorado management. About fifty of the " living picture " girls were there too. The meeting was called to order by Philip Kelly of the Theatrical Protective Union. He told the girls the thing for them to do was to organize and join the Central Labor Union.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 8. -- The pilgrims of the American Society for the Extension of University Teaching, who have been making a tour of the Revolutionary battlefields, reached Trenton this afternoon. At the State House Adjt. Gen. William Stryker read his own history of the battle of Trenton.

There is no analogy whatever between the case of the head of a municipal police and the Sheriff of a county. The Sheriff is an elective officer and his functions belong to the judiciary system of the State. The county is a civil division of the State for certain purposes of administration, and the Sheriff, though locally elected, is an agent of State authority.

From The Mail and Express of Yesterday. PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8. -- Commenting on the transfer of the news-distributing headquarters of the Western Associated Press from New-York to Pittsburgh. The Times to-day says editorially:

The reports of the Treasury Department show that in the last fiscal year the value of our exports of iron and steel and manufactures of the same for the first time exceeded the value of our imports of such products. The following:

Cyclists attending the Denver meet will have good cause to remember the league's 1894 races. For the four days following the Battles a-wheel a programme of sightseeing has been arranged that cannot fall to delight even those familiar with the region. The opportunity to visit points of natural interest adjacent to Colorado Springs will be an unrivaled one, and it is safe to predict that all those who can will enjoy the programme offered.
judge Gildersleeve of the Superior Court gave a decision yesterday which affects the title to the property of the Clausen Brewing Company in Forty-seventh Street, between First and Second Avenues.

The August election in Alabama is the precursor of the " Fall elections " of the year, and the solid victory of the Democratic Party there is an encouraging omen. It shows what can be done under adverse conditions by united and earnest effort, and affords an early indication of the drift of political sentiment in the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Washington defeated New-York to-day by better all-round playing, especially at the bat. Three visiting pitchers were tried, and Westervelt, who finished the game, was quite effective, but the lead which the Senators gained before he entered the box was too much for the Giants to overcome. Sullivan pitched an excellent game.

BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- West End Street Railway was again the feature of the market for local stocks, and rose still further, to 51 1/4. An unusual amount of stock was dealt in, and the indications are that the shorts have come in on the run. Telephones were strong, American Bell selling at 199 1/2, an advance of 1/2; Erie at 47, and NewEngland at 66.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

William Grenville Banner, now in the Tombs awaiting indictment for an attempt to commit grand larceny, has, on investigation by the police and by officials in the District Attorney's office, been found to have an interesting history.

The stock market yesterday was somewhat irregular in the early trading, but subsequently developed strength and closed at about the best prices of the day. The possibility of something of the corn crop being left and the likelihood of an early agreement on the tariff were the principal factors of the day's speculation.

WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S. I., Aug. 8 -- There was a sharp fight in the annual school election at this place last night between the A. P. A. and the Roman Catholics for the control of the school, in which the A. P. A. was the aggressor and was signally defeated.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- There was a further improvement to-day in the tone of the general market and higher prices were made in a number of stocks. St. Paul was quite active, and the transactions in it, Reading, and Philadelphia Traction composed almost the entire business. The short interest in St. Paul has made rather a stubborn fight.

Letter to The Rockdale (Texas) Banner. A " Mexican Bull Fight" was billed to take place at the amphitheatre in Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, just across the river, at 5 o'clock, and, Having a desire to witness the great national sport of that country, I boarded a street car and made for that point.

THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEWYork, by the grace of God free and independent, to EDWARD T.R. APPLEGATE. Ellen D. Hunt, John E. Hunt, Mary T. Hunt Du Bois, Georgianna Hunt Van Derveer, Edward T. Hunt, Marie Hunt Story, Lilian Talmage, Thomas Hunt Talmage, Edward T. Hunt Talmage, John F. Talmage, Jr., Brooklyn Trust Company, as general guardian of the property of the said John F. Talmage, Jr.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- While awaiting definite action on the part of the tariff conference committee. Senators to-day manifested an utter indifference to all other matters of legislation, and were unable to furnish a voting quorum on the only important bill for which consideration was asked.

NEWTOWN, L. I., Aug. 8. -- A policeman of the North Beach force found the body of a man floating among the rocks near the shore front on the Flushing Bay side of Sanford's Point about 8 o'clock this morning. The body was near an old bathing house, about half-way between the Grand Pier and the Sanford's Point Hotel.
MONTGOMERY, Aug. 8. -- Election returns are in from all counties except Baldwin and Covington, and the unofficial count gives Oates in round numbers a majority of 26,000.

PARIS, Aug. 8. -- The records of Ortiz and Henry, as burglars, were considered first at the Anarchist trial here to-day. MM. Gobert and Delhomme, experts in handwriting, testified that the letter sent by the Fiquileur burglars to Mme. Postal were in Emile Henry's handwriting

From The London Telegraph. Folk lore is full of alarming stories about encounters with, the " Cunning' One," who assumes no end of shapes and forms in order to effect his wicked purposes. In children whom he wishes to destroy, for instance, he appears in the fanciful form of " dog's senility."

La Salle, Ill., Aug. 8. -- Joseph Schurmann, a Polish coal miner, is dead and Deputy Sheriff A. A. Colley is lying dangerously wounded, the result of a conflict in Schurmann's house while the Sheriffs were attempting to arrest Schurmann. The officers were met by Joseph, his wife, and father and mother, all armed with cavalry sabres.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 8. -- The Dominion Government has at last decided to take some action in regard to the protests entered by Americans who are now summering at Alexandria Bay and other points on the St. Lawrence, against the obnoxious and stupid fishery regulations which prevent Americans fishing in Canadian waters.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- A suicide and probable double murder occurred at 1214 Montgomery Avenue at 7:30 o'clock this morning. William Evans, aged twenty-nine years, shot and killed Louis Hecht, of the same age, shot Evans's wife, Eva, and then committed suicide. The women is seriously wounded.

ALBANY, Aug. 8. -- The Republicans in the Constitutional Convention are in a state of mind. Only seventeen working days are left and a great deal of unfinished business is before the convention, with over 100 voluble lawyers, charged with speeches on every subject of Interest.

SARATOGA, N. Y., Aug. 8. -- It was reported about town last night and this morning that Walbaum had decided to keep Riley Grannan from making a book at the track here. But Grannan drew in to-day as usual and made a book, Walbaum deciding that he could not afford to combat public opinion in this matter, as it was entirely against him.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 8. -- An accident occurred on the Newburg-Monticello turnpike yesterday afternoon which came near terminating the Summer outing of a number of New-York City and Brooklyn people who are spending the Summer here. A large party had been formed for a trip from Monticello to Katrina Falls on an old tally-ho coach drawn by four horses.
The Buffalo Times, which has been a stanch, supporter of Lieut. Gov. William C. Sheehan in his local struggles, makes the following significant appeal:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The House, sitting in Committee of the Whole, to-day took favorable action upon several bills authorizing the erection of public buildings, but they got no further in the progress to passage. They provided for buildings at the following places, to cost not exceeding the sums named: Newport, Ky., $75,000; Brockton, Mass., $75,000; Paterson, N.J., $200,000; South Omaha, Neb., $200.000; Pottsville, Penn., $60,000; Cumberland, Md., $75,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Afro-American Bureau of Organization of the Democratic Congressional Committee, with Recorder of Deeds of the District of Columbia C. H. J. Kyler heading the Advisory Board, has Issued the following call:

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 8. -- Directum made his first move of the season in public this afternoon, and showed himself to be the same great trotter that he has been since he started as a twoyear-old. The famous black horse was not asked to break a record, or, indeed, do anything more than the stiff work he is now getting to prepare him for his engagements.

From The Watertown Reunion. On our seventh page to-day we printed from The New-York Times interviews with Gov. Flower and the Hon. D. G. Griffin on the Democratic situation in this State that contain much sound advice. They discuss frankly what can be done to heal every sore in the party, and their suggestions are both timely and practical.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- The local security market is now in the midst of Summer dullness. Speculators find more interest in markets which fluctuate and offer more opportunities for in and out speculation. There is undoubtedly a tendency toward better times, but vexatious delays in tariff legislation and continued gold exports, with bad crop reports, are not at all encouraging

COWES, Aug. 8. -- The Vigilant was the only one of the trio of big single stickers that was ready this morning to take part in the fifty-mile contest for a prize of $500 over the course of the Royal Yacht Squadron, and the race was declared off. The Britannia was much more injured than it was originally thought by striking on the rocks at Ventnor in Monday's race.

From The Vassar (Mich.) Pioneer. Last Saturday the Rev. J. R. Robinson, United Brethren pastor in this place, and his wife spent the day with Nathan Sherman, a farmer of Fairgrove Township. During the day Mr. Sherman invited the reverend gentleman to go with, him to the orchard, where a very remarkable spectacle was presented to his view.

The London Daily Telegraph declares that the County Court Judges of England have come to a momentous decision. According to a paragraph, " it is announced that the County Court Judges have passed a new rule enabling them, without loss of dignity, to wear straw hats during the hot weather." Many people, remarks The Spectator, " will no doubt read this paragraph with amusement

John E: Milholland's faction was " turned down" last night by the sub-committee of the Republican State Committee, if rumor is to be believed. The sub-committee was in session from 8 o'clock to nearly midnight, and when it adjourned the report that was authorized was:

From The London Daily Telegraph. A perusal of the evidence given in a case heard at the Kirkham Police Court, where in an able-bodied seaman named Rowe sued the master of the sailing ship McLaurin for wages due, seems to carry one back to the far-gone days of the press gangs, which are still dear to the hearts of writers of nautical romances.

Lizzie McDermott made a mistake recently in addressing a letter, and as a result she pleaded guilty to grand larceny in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday and partly exposed a series of stamp robberies. Several other young women are said to be implicated in the robberies, and it is expected that more arrests will soon be made.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 8. -- Major Frederick Brackett, who has been selected as General Manager of the Baltimore Centennial Exposition, to be held in 1897, states that this exposition will be the greatest ever held in this country, excepting the centennial at Philadelphia and the Chicago World's Fair. It is expected that, outside of all expenditures by private corporations or individuals, at least $5,000,000 will be expended upon the fair.

RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 8 -- The Democratic State Convention met here to-day with a very large and intelligent representation. J. C. Buxton presided as temporary Chairman, and was succeeded as permanent Chairman by Lieut. Gov. R. A. Doughlon.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL,. N. Y., Aug. 8. -- The event of the week at the camp, the review of the artillery battalion by the Adjutant General, took place this afternoon. The three batteries were lined up on the north parade ground, Capt. Dillenback's regulars having the right of the line.

The trial of Capt. William S. Devery of the Old Slip Police Station and his former ward man, Edward Glennon, who are charged with corruption and bribery, which was to have come before the Police Board to-day, has been, postponed. This action was taken by the Police Commissioners at their meeting yesterday, at which Surgeon Nammack presented the following certificate:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Gen. Schofield has sided with CoL Volkmar of the army, Adjutant General's Department, in the controversy between Volkmar and Gen. Howard. The latter had offered Col. Volkmar certain quarters at Governors Island as an officer of his staff, but Col. Volkmar wanted the quarters occupied by Capt. Kingsbury of the Sixth Cavalry.

From The London Daily Telegraph. A perusal of the evidence given in a case heard at the Kirkham Police Court, where in an able-bodied seaman named Rowe sued the master of the sailing ship McLaurin for wages due, seems to carry one back to the far-gone days of the press gangs, which are still dear to the hearts of writers of nautical romances.

Lizzie McDermott made a mistake recently in addressing a letter, and as a result she pleaded guilty to grand larceny in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday and partly exposed a series of stamp robberies. Several other young women are said to be implicated in the robberies, and it is expected that more arrests will soon be made.
NEW-YORK SUPREME COURT, CITY AND County of New-York. -- THE UNITED STATES LEATHER COMPANY against ADIN V. CHIPMAN and LEE J. CALLEY.

The increases in earnings reported by several of the Southern railroads and a few of the Western lines, although not large; may be accepted as an assurance that the business of railroad transportation is beginning to improve. According to reports from Chicago, last week's railroad shipments, on both Eastern and Western lines, were equal to if not greater than for the corresponding period of last year.
The Floating Hospital has a mascot. She went down the bay on the barge yesterday, and the greatest good luck prevailed all day, and all the children on board were as happy as could be.

Senator Murphy might without impropriety have spoken more at length about the work of the Democratic State organization in the Presidential canvass of 1892. In the history of politics there is no chapter that tells of more loyal and strenuous exertions in behalf of party candidates.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 8. -- Another poor day for racing, but the yachts of the New-York Yacht Club reached here this afternoon in good shape and early too. The fleet got under way at 7:30 A.M. at Morris Cove and sailed out of the harbor. There was a rattling good breeze from the southwest, and the outlook was fine for a good race to this port.

Now that the legal delay for paying in the Italian silver pieces in France has expired, it is estimated that a very large number remain in circulation. According to some, their total value is as much as 30,000,000f., but, supposing that this is an exaggeration, and that the amount represented is really from 15,000,000f. to 20,000,000f., it is evident that the pieces in Question will cause a good deal of embarrassment in trade.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 8. -- An Italian named Panetti was arrested here last night with several dynamite cartridges in his possession. He came from America and was on his way to Italy, where, the police say, he expected to commit an Anarchist outrage.

J.W. Reinhart, President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, and one of the three receivers of that great system, sent his reply to Expert Little's disclosures of irregularities in the Atchison bookkeeping to the General Reorganization Committee yesterday afternoon. The report of the expert accountant, Mr. Reinhart's letter, and a statement from John J. McCook, Atchison's general counsel and one of the receivers, were subsequently made public.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9. -- A smallpox riot took place to-night on the South Side. Five policemen were seriously injured by the mob, and many arrests were made. Chief of Police Janssen and fifty policemen had a hard fight with a mob of 4,000 rioters. A number of citizens were also injured.

Before the Hamburg-American Line steamship Fuerst Bismarck sailed for Hamburg yesterday Capt. Albers. the vessel's master, was presented with a ball of beautiful workmanship by the Columbian Liberty Bell Committee. Accompanying the bell was the following letter, which explains itself:

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 9. -- Two men were killed and five injured by the falling, at 3:30 this afternoon, of a wall of the City Hall being built on the block bounded by Montgomery, Henderson, and Mercer Streets. One of the injured men is not likely to recover.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- Dr. W. Seward Webb drove a coachload to Narragansett Pier, crossing the ferries, to-day. Mrs. Webb was on the box. Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Miss Vanderbilt, and Perry Belmont were among the party. They lunched at the pier, and returned at 3 o'clock.

BERGEN POINT, N.J., Aug. 9. -- For the expressed purpose of indorsing the attitude regarding tariff legislation of United States Senator James Smith, Jr., and those other representatives of New-Jersey who contended for the protection of home industries, and in response to a call signed by the employes of a leading Constable Hook industry, a meeting of Bayonne workingmen was held this evening.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The feature of to-day's racing was the run for the Sea Foam Stakes, for all ages, at five furlongs and a half, in which Clifford proved the victor over a field of high-class sprinters. Dr. Hasbrouck and Correction were both backed to win, as well as was the actual winner, the betting being fast and furious over the event.

The English papers are devoting quite a little attention just now to what they conveniently call the question of free trade in the United States and the delays and complications that have prevented what they evidently thought was bound to be the outcome of the elections of 1890 and 1892.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 9. -- An attempt was made in the Democratic Convention last evening to rush the platform resolutions through without debate, but it failed summarily. The report favored the free coinage of both gold and silver at a ratio of 16 to 1.

Perfect weather and a fair card were the conditions responsible for a large crowd at historic Jerome Park yesterday. It was the second day of the meeting, and, as three favorites got home first, the talent had an even thing of it with the bookmakers. Daily America, Jodan, and Cockade were the winning favorites, and; although two of these were at odds on, they received heavy support.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- In the Constitutional Convention this morning Chairman C.B. McLaughlin, from the Committee on County, Town, and Village Government, reported that it had given all the amendments referred to it careful consideration, and that it had reached the conclusion that no amendments should be made to the present Consti- tution as proposed by the suggestions submitted to the committee.

A delightful breeze came into the grand stand at Parkway track yesterday, which made it a pleasant place to spend an afternoon. The attendance was fully as large as on Wednesday, and betting was much more active. The ring is none too large to accommodate the speculators, and it was not easy to reach the books for the second race.

Eastport, Me., Aug. 9. -- The Kendalls' sardine factory, together with a large smokehouse and outbuildings, owned by George Grady Co., and operated by Dennis Collins, was burned this morning. Loss on buildings, $2,300; Insured for about half. Collins's loss on stock, fittings, , is $5,000; Insured for $2,000.

QUARANTINE, S.I., Aug. 9. -- Frances Laura Welsted Croker, mother of Richard Croker, died here this evening of general debility at the residence of her son-in-law, Health Officer Jenkins. Mrs. Croker was eighty-seven years old. About two years ago she suffered a fracture of the thigh, and had been an invalid since.
CALIFORNIA MINING STOCKS. SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9. -- The official closing quotations for mining stocks to-day were as follows:

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Allegra, S.V.R. Cruger; Helvetia, C. O'D. Iselin; Nourmahal, John J. Astor: Viking, H.A. Hutchins; Viola, F.W. Hawley, and Orienta, E.R. Ladew; schooner yacht Tempest, S.M. Roosevelt.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The Monmouth County Open-Air Horse Show's exhibition is to be held at Hollywood Park, Long Branch to-day and to-morrow. There are ten classes to be shown and judged this afternoon. Roadsters, saddle horses, tandems, high jumpers, Saturday's programme includes about the same as the foregoing, and also four-in-hands, to be driven by amateurs.

From The Sun of Yesterday. We hope that Mr. Charles R. Flint will succeed in his most praiseworthy effort to discipline The Evening Post. Mr. Flint is one of those men who in this town are rightly held of much account. He is a merchant, and no one of his years' has done more than he to build up the commerce of this port.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- A dispatch from Tien-Tsin to the Central News says: "The Emperor of China has directed that a levy for war tribute be made upon the Viceroys of the different provinces. A foreign war loan is mooted.

The Police Commissioners seem to be much puzzled about what Captain they shall try next, seeing that Capt. Devery is too much incapacitated by congestion of the brain to undertake his defense. The question is puzzling. The choice is not wide, because there are so few Captains whom the present Commissioners would venture to try.

The Republican leaders who actually control the policies of that party in the State and City of New-York determined long ago that the Milholland faction and the Committee of Thirty should be brought together. Later they decided that Milholland's faction must be suppressed by the full and exclusive recognition of the Bliss faction.
SARATOGA, Aug. 9. -- Mayor Gilroy of New-York offered the following resolution at the meeting of the Democratic State Committee this evening:...

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Business was extremely light in stocks to-day, with prices practically where they were yesterday. Operators are content with limited transactions, and until there has been a radical change for the better it is not at all probable that outsiders will give very much attention to the local stock market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Information from an authoritative source received in Washington shows that Li Hung Chang did all that he could to prevent the Chinese-Japanese war. He was in complete accord with the efforts of foreign powers, including the United States, to bring about a peaceable adjustment of the differences between China and her island neighbor, and appeared willing to accept moderate proposals of Japan for a settlement.

BATH BEACH, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Crockery by the wholesale was smashed to smithereens last night in a hotel here. For a time there was a scene of what even the most conservative novelist and wordpainter would call wild excitement in the place.
RUSHVILLE, Ill., Aug. 9. -- The WashingtonDenver relay message passed here at 1 o'clock P.M., twenty-one hours ahead of time.

"I want to go to prison, your Honor. That's why I tried to break into the place," said Charles Wallbury, nineteen years old, of 73 Bowery, when arraigned before Justice Simms, in the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday, to answer a charge of attempted burglary. "The officer caught me in the act," he continued, "and I plead guilty."

BALTIMORE, Aug. 9. -- Ex-United States Shipping Commissioner L.P. Dryden, who, after refusing to resign when requested to do so by Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle, was yesterday officially dismissed from office, says he will riot leave without a fight. The department is convinced that SecretaryCarlisle has a perfect right to remove a Shipping Commissioner, and Albert C. Kirwin, who was appointed yesterday, received his commission this morning.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The threatened typhoid epidemic here and in Bloomfield is causing increased uneasiness among the townspeople, and the article in The New-York Times this morning, giving the details of the spread of the disease, was read with great interest by every one.

Messrs. Jones Co. have sold for James Jack to Miss Annie James, at $7,000, the three-story, brick flat 527 Eleventh Street, 20 by 50 by 100, and for Mrs. Eliza Guyer to James Jack, at $6,000, the lots, 50 by 100, on the east side of Seventh Avenue, 25 feet north of Fifteenth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- The market was a halting one. It was rather strong at the opening, but sold off. People's was noticeably heavy. The opening sales were at 50, but the price declined on selling by clique brokers to 49 5/8. The rest of the tractions were dull and neglected. A little Baltimore was sold at 14 3/4, some Philadelphia at 96@96 1/4, and Electric changed hands around 88.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Gorman and his "pals" on the "revision committee" have succeeded in interrupting again the progress of the conferrees of the Senate and the House on the Tariff bill, and are now depending upon a new form of devilment to kill the bill, which the conferrees would be able to put into shape for acceptable report of the power of the three McKinley Democrats of the trust committee were once removed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The effect upon Treasury finances of the uncertainty caused by prolonged agitation of tariff changes has been very marked. During the period when the McKinley bill was under discussion the decline of Treasury receipts was almost as noticeable as during the present tariff contest.

COWES, Aug. 9. -- In a good clubtopsail breeze, through white-capped, but not tumultuous, seas, the Britannia defeated the American sloop Vigilant to-day, over a course of about forty-eight nautical miles, by 2 minutes and 13 seconds actual time, and 4 minutes and 17 seconds corrected time. About half of the contest was windward work, in which the British cutter had decidedly the better of it.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 9. -- There is considerable talk and not a little excitement in this city caused by the announcement in The New-York Times of this morning that typhoid fever has again appeared to an alarming extent in Montclair.

John J. McCook, the general counsel of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company, who attended the meeting, was asked for his views upon the points covered by Expert Little's report, so far as given out. He replied: "I have, from day to day, delayed speaking upon this subject, until I could see the text of Mr. Little's report to the General Reorganization Committee.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The statue of Frederick T. Frelinghuysen, State Attorney General, United States Senator, and Secretary of State, was unveiled this morning in Military Park, within a stone's throw of the house that was for many years the home of the distinguished citizen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- In the House Committee on Foreign Affairs this morningChairman McCreary stated that day before yesterday a letter was received by the State Department from President Dole, announcing the formal creation of the new republic.

The New-York Times correctly stated yesterday that Messrs. Wadsworth, Proctor, Odell, Dunn, and Quackenbush, forming the Sub-Committee of the Republican State Committee to decide which of the local county factions was regular, and to pass on the Belden-Hendricks dispute at Syracuse, had "turned down" Milholland and paved the way to conciliation in Onondaga County.

BOSTON, Aug. 9. -- Dominion Coal and West End Street Railway were the only local stocks which showed any activity. The former opened 1/4 off, at 21, advanced on further tariff rumors to 21 3/4, which brought out so much stock that it declined to 21. The preferred sold at 97 1/2. West End Street Railway opened up 1/2, at 51 3/4, advanced to 52 1/2, and closed at 52.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The efforts being made by private parties to secure food for the starving natives of Corea were heartily indorsed to-day by the Corean Minister in Washington, and, while he will not issue a formal appeal to the charitable, he expresses the hope that Americans will respond liberally to help his unhappy people.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- The condition of the savings banks of New-York, Kings, and Westchester Counties is better, as a whole, than on Jan. 1, 1894. From the reports of these institutions, 40 in number, made to the State Superintendent of Banks for the year ended June 30, the principal items show in the aggregate:

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Some excitement was caused here this morning when it was learned that the waiters of the Hotel Athenaeum had gone out on a strike. This hotel is run by the Assembly, and is in the immediate charge of Superintendent Duncan. The youngmen who are the waiters claim they have been overworked and not fairly paid.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn said some time ago that the present Board of Education was too large and unwieldy, and that its duties could be performed better by a beard of fifteen members. He also said he would appoint an advisory committee to look into the standards of the Brooklyn schools and to act upon certain suggestions he would make.

Corn advanced in the local market yesterday from 1 1/4 to 2 1/2 cents per bushel. The market escaped the violent fluctuations of Wednesday, and the recovery in price seemed to complete the natural rebound from the swift decline of Wednesday morning. To-day the Government crop report will be issued.

BROAD CHANNEL, JAMAICA BAY, L. I., Aug. 9. -- The identity of the young man and woman drowned in Jamaica Bay yesterday, when their fishing skiff was run into by the sloop yacht Caroline, owned by Charles Fuller, a hotel keeper here, was established this morning, their effects being recognized by Jacob and Leo Ebstein of 152 Powers Street, Brooklyn, as belonging to their brother Abraham and their sister Fannie.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- Fifty years ago Newport was a whaling town and Bristol had quite a shipping trade. There were very few pleasure yachts in those days, and it was a rare thing to see any in these two old ports. Now Newport is the central point for yachtsmen, and from early Spring until late in the Fall there are always several at anchor in the pretty harbor.

From The Niagara Falls Cataract. The Lockport Journal and The Buffalo News, the latter in a less marked degree, endeavor to console themselves with the thought that the present agitation for Democratic harmony is confined to one faction of the party -- though what that faction is these papers are not quite agreed.

Albany, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- In reply to a communication from Town Clerk Beck of Owego, Attorney General Hancock has written an opinion holding that the additional Election Inspector provided for by the O'Connor bi-partisan Election Inspectors law of last Winter should be appointed by the minority Election Inspector in each board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Although he received many telegrams asking him to hurry to Saratoga, Senator Murphy decided that he could best serve his country by remaining in Washington. He answered the Democratic leaders in Saratoga to that effect. He dined to-night at the Shoreham, with Senators Hill and Smith.

A bill of complaint was filed yesterday in the United States Circuit Court in which charges of conspiracy and fraud are made against John Vermeule, late Vice President of the Holland Trust Company of this city; R.B. Roosevelt, George M. Van Hoesen, ex-Judge of the Court of Common Pleas, and Warner Van Norden.

That is a very curious and suggestive announcement that comes from Baltimore, that the remnant of Coxey's army, eighty-eight in all, has been confined in the Maryland House of Correction on a charge of vagrancy. It suggests primarily how much trouble these unfortunate tramps took to attain a result that might have been attained without the trouble.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 9. -- The report of the Grand Jury to the District Court gives a clue to some startling facts, which, upon investigation, prove that the worst of the Cripple Creek miners' strike is yet to come. The evidence before that body is held under lock and key and could not be seen, but from outside sources some of the conditions that exist at Cripple Creek have been learned.

HYATTSVILLE, Md., Aug. 9. -- Coxey's army was rounded up here this morning. A special train from Baltimore brought a platoon of police to the Commonwealers' camp, and eighty-eight men were arrested. Most of the men took their arrest good naturedly. One said it was the first piece of good luck he had encountered since he joined the procession.

Superintendent Byrnes preferred charges before the Board of Police Commissioners yesterday afternoon against the five Police Sergeants implicated in accepting Mrs. Augusta Thorow as bondswoman for the girls arrested in her house after they had received orders to drive her out of the Fourteenth Precinet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- In the House to-day Mr. Meyer (Dem., La.,) called up for consideration the bill to increase the efficiency of the militia. Mr. Meyer concluded his speech, begun yesterday. He referred to the failure of the State authorities to maintain peace and order in Chicago during the recent riots there, as a good reason for the passage of the bill.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10. -- A telegram sent from Seoul, news of which is brought by the City of Pekin, which arrived here today, announces that the Russian flag is to be seen on the Island of Getsubito. It is surmised that Russia has seized it.

on a parity with London prices. The Philadelphia market was stronger most of the day than the New-York market. The early news from Washington was that some kind of a bill might be passed to-day, and this helped to steady prices. On later and more unfavorable news from Washington the market became very dull, with an inclination to sell off.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The following companies were incorporated to-day:

COWES, Aug. 10. -- The Prince of Wales's cutter had no competitor in her sail around the Isle of Wight to-day for the Meteor Challenge Shield, presented by the German Emperor. Although the general impression yesterday was that the Vigilant would compete for the shield, she was in fact specifically excluded by the conditions which require that every competing boat be of European build and owned by a member of a European yacht club.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- There was a large attendance to-day at the Methodist Episcopal Camp Meeting, and to-morrow a still greater crowd is expected to stay over Sunday, which is the great day of the meeting.

KOKOMO, Ind., Aug. 10. -- The Kokomo Natural Gas and Oil Company, thinking one of its wells was dry, drew the casing two weeks ago, when a tremendous volume of water and gas gushed out from the one-thousand-foot hole, driving the crew from their work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- A formidable petition, containinig the signatures of 500 managers or proprietors of iron-working establishments in New-England, was brought to Washington this morning by James L. Cowles of Farmington, Conn.

It was fondly supposed when John Y. McKane and some of his henchmen were sent to State prison and the penitentiary, that the taxpayers of Gravesend were freed from the grip which the McKane gang held upon their throats, but such does not appear to be the case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- There is a diversity of opinion among Senators as to the status of the Tariff bill. The majority, however, holds that the bill and the report must come back to the House granting the conference and not to the body asking it. In this case the Senate granted the conference.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- Because of the interest in the yacht race there were but few cottage entertainments to-day. Mrs. Butler Duncan, Jr., gave a dance at the residence of her mother. Mrs. T.A. Havemeyer. There were fifty guests. Mrs. William Gammell and Mrs. R.I. Gammell entertained at dinner to-night. The sewing class met with Mrs. Clapp this morning.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 10. -- The Omaha Guards and the Thurston Rifles, State militia, were ordered to South Omaha by Acting Gov. Majors this morning. Four other troops arrived during the day. The workmen passed unmolested to the packing houses under the guard of the militia. No hostile demonstration was made by the strikers, and the crowds dispersed as soon as the soldiers approached.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 10. -- The fastest mile ever ridden by bicycle riders on a tandem with bicycle pacing was the crowning feature of to-day's race meet on the mile track of the Minneapolis Track Association. Fred J. Titus and L.D. Cabanne of New-York and St. Louis did the mile in 1:52 4-5 on a tandem. This broke the record of 1:59, made by the same team at Ripon last Wednesday.

Traders held aloof from the market yesterday awaiting developments from Washington on the tariff situation and the publication of the Government crop report for August. The tariff news which came into the Street during the day was very conflicting and afforded little comfort to any one. The crop report was not given out until after the close of business.

Decent and law-respecting people on Staten Island are just now complaining of the indifference of the Richmond County authorities to the lawbreaking and misbehavior when have apparently intrenched themselves in a certain section of the island. It is a topic that is discussed with vigor by those who resent the invasion of Richmond County by the hordes who proceed thither nearly every afternoon from the Alsatias of the metropolis.

WASHTIGTON, Aug. 10. -- Effort is being made again this year to remove a great injustice under which the mates of the navy have for many years rested. It is one of the inconsistencies that is sometimes encountered in the Government service, and which lives through all the years despite the efforts of the department officers and Congressmen to remove it.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The opening day's races of the twenty-second annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen were held here this morning. The attendance was small, owing to the fact that the local committee had done nothing to advertise the races properly, and what pushing had been done had been by the members of the Executive Committee of the national body.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- An earnest effort was made this afternoon to clear up most of the classes that remained on the programme of the Grand Circuit meeting. The horses were started early, and kept at it till dark, but at the end of nineteen heats there was still an unfinished race. This leaves three classes that will necessitate going on to-morrow.

Mr. Robert Grier Monroe, the Secretary of the New-York State Democracy, professes to have not the slightest doubt "that the State Democracy will get its proper recognition and representation in the next Democratic State Convention," but he declares further that "if it does go in, it will be upon its own terms and not upon the terms of Mr. Murphy or anybody else."
A story printed yesterday about the sale of the Worth house, at Broadway and Twentyfifth Street, was interesting to several real estate men, but it was not true. The property has not been sold.

If Mr. Gorman and his employers of the Sugar Trust succeed in defeating all legislation as to the tariff by the system of complicated treachery, mendacity, and corruption which they have been pursuing, it will not be a result over which honest tariff reformers need shed tears either of regret or shame. It will not be the first time that a petard of this sort has hoisted its evil-minded engineers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Gray, (Dem., Del.,) in pursuance of the notice given by him yesterday, moved, at 12:20, to proceed to executive business.

From The Binghamton Leader. Some of the Democratic papers do not cordially indorse Chairman Murphy's plan to bring about harmony in the Democratic ranks. They seem to think that the organization will control the primaries, and that the anti-organization elements will not be able to achieve much in the way of recognition.
It is the little comforts and conveniences on the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild that mothers interested in the work appreciate most on visiting the barge for the first time.

Harmony in the Democratic Party is to come largely through the primaries. On this point nearly every observant man interviewed since The New-York Times sounded "the keynote of the campaign" has expressed his firm conviction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Capt. W.J. Johnson, a retired army officer, will be tried by a court-martial at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., on the charge of non-payment of debts. The officer has been tried for a similar offense once before and was acquitted. He was at one time an examiner in the Pension Office.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Senator Hill to-night gave out the following statement in regard to his action to-day with reference to the Tariff bill:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- The presence of many yachtsmen enlivened the Casino dance to-night. Both galleries were full of spectators, and the attendance of dancers was large. Mrs. Duncan Elliot, who, as Miss Hargous, was the belle of many seasons, was warmly welcomed. She wore a strikingly-becoming gown of heliotrope. Others present were:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- An interesting report has been received at the Navy Department from the Board of Visitors which attended the graduation exercises in June at the Naval Academy. The Board recommends, generally, as follows:

The champion Bostons met the aged Bridegrooms at Eastern Park yesterday, and, under conditions favorable to Father Foutz's men, walloped them soundly. Four runs in the very first inning and a like number in the third gave Capt. Nash's ball players a lead that the Brooklyn team never overcame. The final score was 12 to 6, and this in spite of the fact that the home nine was backed up by their Star pitcher.

The racing yesterday at Parkway was the beat that has been had at the track. The starts were good and the finishes close enough to cause genuine excitement, particularly in the first, second, and fourth events. Had the boys been changed on Tacony and Marcola colt, the result would have been changed also.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 10. -- The Minnesota Democratic Association held a meeting in St. Paul to-night. The Democratic State Central Committee was denounced for refusing to indorse the President in his attitude on the tariff. Secretary Smalley offered the following resolution, which was unanimously adopted:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The bicycle races at the athletic grounds this afternoon attracted nearly 3,000 spectators. They were run under the direction of the Asbury Park Athletic Association. The competitors for the valuable prizes included Harry Tyler, George F. Taylor, Fred Graves, W.H. Mulliken, H.R. Steenson, O.S. Brandt, Watson Coleman, George C. Smith, and G.F. Royce.

J.W. Reinhart has resigned as President and Director of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, and also as receiver. His determination to retire from active business was made known to a few of his friends some weeks ago. The state of his health has for some time been a matter of grave concern with his family, his nervous system having been seriously impaired.

Heinrich Conried, lessee and manager of the Irving Place Theatre, returned from Europe yesterday. He has been abroad three months, and a large portion of that time was devoted to traveling through Europe in search of fresh attractions for his theatre.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Among the Republican politicians of Rochester the principal topic of conversation for the last few days has been Mayor George W. Aldridge's promising boom for Lieutenant Governor. The Democrat and Chronicle perpetrated the richest joke of the season on Monday morning when it announced in double leads that Mr. Aldridgre "has been persuaded to announce himself formally a a candidate for the Lieutenant Governorship."

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- John J. Donnelly, Samuel Donnelly, and James Bundy are in custody of Sheriff Elliott at Delhi charged with breaking in the house of Myron Hill, in Kortwright, Delaware County, and attempting robbery early last Monday morning. There was a desperate fight in darkness. Mr. Hill attempted to shoot the burglars, but the cartridge failed to explode.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 10. -- Not since the campaign of 1882, which elected George W. Glick, the Democratic standard bearer, Governor of Kansas, has there been such an awakening among the Democracy of this State as the present campaign is developing.

This, in an artistic sense, is the least commendable of Zola's books, but, as its literary method was exactly similar to that of his masterpieces, the critical reader will have less difficulty in finding it interesting than one may think who reads only to be edified or amused.

The little 300-ton British ship Margaret Murray, since her arrival here on June 29 last, has been the subject of marked attention by the United States authorities, beginning with Custom House officials and reaching as far up as the Secretaries of State and of the Treasury. These attentions have not been of a very pleasing kind to Capt. Thomas Walters, who commands the craft.

The alleged counterfeiters, Russell B. Hoyt and James W. Murphy, or Davis, whose plant to strike off ten-dollar United States Treasury notes with a Webster vignette, ten-dollar notes on the Mystic River Bank, and twenty-dollar gold notes with a Garfield vignette was dug up or found on Lorenzo Hoyt's farm at Bethel, Conn., were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Alexander.

It appears now to be the settled purpose of Mr. Gorman, Mr. Brice, and Mr. Smith to prevent the enactment of any Tariff Revision bill, in order that the Sugar Trust may continue to enjoy the provisions of the McKinley tariff's sugar schedule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Unless there shall be furnished to the Senate when it shall meet to-morrow a report showing that the tariff conferrees have either agreed or disagreed, an effort will be made by Mr. Hill to instruct the conferrees on the part of the Senate to report a disagreement. This was made clear to-day by the proceedings in the Senate Chamber.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10. -- Canzalio de Heusado and Mr. Rubens, the attorneys of New-York engaged to defend the recent Vice President of Salvador, Antonio Ezeta; Gen. Colcheco, Gen. Kolonos, and Lieut Col. Cienfuegos, now aboard the Bennington, have arrived here. The Bennington is expected to arrive to-morrow. The attorneys say:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 10. -- At the close of the fiscal year, on June 30, the total deposits in the Dominion Post Office saving banks amounted to $25,257,868, a net increase, as compared with the previous fiscal year, of $1,104,675. The interest allowed to depositors during the year was $835,800. The deposits amounted to $7,524,286 during the year and the withdrawals to $7,473,585.

BOSTON, Aug. 10. -- West End Street Railway again absorbed what attention there was to spare for local stocks, and it scored an advance of 1 1/8 points over last night's close. No news seems to be regarded as good news as far as this road is concerned, and with the reported decision of the officials to give out no figures of monthly earnings, speculation in it is a very blind game.

The card offered at Jerome Park yesterday was not particularly attractive, yet a large crowd visited the old saddlebags track and found numerous opportunities to speculate. The historic race course never looked prettier, and to the beauties of the scene was added a refreshing breeze, which played through the grand stand to the delight of the spectators.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Gov. Flower has appointed Aug. 22 as the time for the hearing in the matter of the charges preferred against Sheriff Duffy of Westchester County. The Governor to-day gave out the answer of Sheriff Duffy to the charges, which have been made against him by B.G. Bayne, representing the League for the Enforcement of Criminal Law, for alleged failure to close a poolroom in that county.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The session of the House to-day was almost wholly taken up with the consideration of the first conference report on the Sundry Civil Appropriations bill. The principal subject of discussion was the appropriation to enable the Government to make an exhibit at the Atlanta Exposition, which afforded an opportunity for several "bridge-the-bloodychasm" speeches, that were applauded warmly.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- It was an off-day at the races here this afternoon, but in spite of the fact that the quality of the horses entered for the several events were of a rather commonplace character and no stakes were on for decision, there was a good crowd on hand, as nearly all of the visitors who came to the rowing regatta round up the afternoon with a trip to the race track.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- While the trading in West Chicago was very heavy, as usual, that stock was not the feature of the market, as it has been. One of the most dormant of all the securities. Alley "L," became decidedly but unfavorably conspicuous. A well-known broker early in the first session began selling the stock, offering the first lot at 1/3 lower than the closing price of yesterday, or at 12 1/2.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 10. -- More than 1,200 persons filled the grand stand and stood round on the grass in Hollywood Park this afternoon to watch the contests at the Monmouth County open-air show. It was 7:30 P.M. before the last ribbon for the day was awarded. The show was favored by the weather, and it is an emphatic success.

From The Albany Argus. In closing up the Democratic ranks to fight the battle against the threatened domination of Mr. Platt of the Empire State, there should be no faltering and no squabbling. Minor differences in regard to party organization or local matters should vanish before the calamity which threatens the people of the State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Bessie L. Tyree, the well-known actress of Daniel Frohman's stock company, has filed an application in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia for divorce from Dr. Joseph S. Tyree, a druggist of this city, to whom she has been married over five years. The papers were withheld from publication.
LONDON, Aug. 11. -- The Times's correspondent at Shanghai says that 12,000 Japanese from Fusan and 8,000 from Gensan are marching on Seoul.

The interest among Democrats yesterday over the action of the State Committee the preceding day in recommending that not less than six days' notice of the primaries be given was widespread. The views of some of them appear in to-day's issue. In order to obtain an expression of the views of Democrats up the State, a telegram was addressed to the editors of Democratic newspapers, reading as follows:

We are inclined to think that it would be well for the Constitutional Convention to make the changes necessary to separate municipal from political elections and leave all other questions relating to city government to the future. The theory upon which the separate-elections plan is advocated is that it would divorce municipal administration from party politics and give us a non-partisan City Government, such as the best-regulated cities of Europe now have.

A slender man, with a thin face and a long, sharp nose, sauntered into J.H. Johnston's jewelry store, 17 Union Square, yesterday afternoon. He wore a dark alpaca coat and waistcoat and dark trousers, and carried a respectable-looking black leather bag. His appearance suggested the business man on his way home.

Several misguided men attempted a few days ago to disrupt the social basis of a Summer picnic and, in the language of their kind, "to clean out the outfit." But even as the cackling of certain geese saved a large and populous city, so on this occasion the wielders of the trombone, the piccolo, and the E-flat clarinet proved to be the heroes of the assembly and the preservers of picnic peace.

American railway securities were fractionally higher in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Louisville and Nashville, 3/4, to 52 1/4; Canadian Pacific, 5/8, to 69; Atchison, 3/8 to 4 3/4; Union Pacific, 3/8, to 9 7/8; Wabash preferred, 3/8, to 16; Ontario and Western, 1/4, to 17; Illinois Central, 1/4 to 94 3/4; Erie, 1/3, to 14 7/8; Northern Pacific preferred, 1/8, to 16, and Kansas and Texas, 1/8, to 14 1/2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- At the general office of the Rock Island Road in this city, only a meagre report of the wreck near Lincoln, Neb., last night, had been received. This report stated that the accident seemed to have been caused by wreckers. Several of the employes of the road confirm the statement that a fishplate had been wrenched loose from the rails.

ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- The Constitutional Convention to-day adopted the resolution determined upon by the Republican caucus to hold three sessions every week day, from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M., 3 to 5 P.M., and 8 to 10 P.M., except on Saturday, when there shall be only one session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The different contingents of the "unemployed working-men" composing the Army of the Commonweal, now encamped at Roslyn on the Virginia side of the Potomac River, did not vacate their rendezvous to-day in accordance with Gov. O'Ferrall's proclamation ordering them to do so.

The burial of Frances Laura Welsted Croker, widow of Eyre Coote Croker and mother of Richard Welsted Croker, will be in the Croker family vault at Woodlawn some time in September. Until then the coffin will remain in a receiving vault at the cemetery. It will be taken there to-day from Health Officer W.T. Jenkins's cottage at Quarantine.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 10. -- After each of the five experts in the Norwood Park tennis tournament has played one match with each of the others, including the two defaults of Richard Stevens, the result to-night is a tie for first place between Robert D. Wrenn. champion of the United States, and Malcolm Chace, the Providence expert. Each has won three matches and lost one.

ATLANTIC CITY, Iowa, Aug. 10. -- The relay message which crack road riders along the route are carrying from Washington to Denver reached this place at 2:50 o'clock this afternoon, twenty-six hours and twenty-six minutes ahead of the schedule time. Bixby and Grimm, two of the fastest cyclists in Council Bluffs, brought it here, and on their relay gained nearly half an hour.

William C. Mainland, who runs an unlicensed intelligence office at 136 Liberty Street, and who claims to be the agent of an estate at Arsdale, N.Y., was arraigned before Justice Taintor, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday, for conducting an illegal business.

The hall-marked Republican County Committee, of which William Brookfield is President, met last night at Lyric Hall, in Sixth Avenue, and this resolution, offered by Gen. C.H.T. Collis, was unanimously adopted:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- To win a Goelet Cup is the ambition of all yachtsmen. The two cups given each year by Ogden Goelet are considered the championship emblems of the season. They are beautiful pieces of silver. That for the schooners is worth $1,000 and for sloops $500.

Shady Side Grove, a picnic ground overlooking the Harlem River, near the site of old Port George, was totally destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. Four men who were employed about the place were badly burned, and one of them, Frederick Rowe of 5 West Eighteenth Street, died from his burns yesterday afternoon at Manhattan Hospital.

DENVER, Aug. 10. -- A special from Los Angeles announces the formation of a new secret political order. The name of the order is the United Sons of America, and its emblem is the Stars and Stripes and the letters "U.S.A."

BROAD CHANNEL, JAMAICA BAY, L. I., Aug. 10. -- The bodies of Miss Fannie Ebstein, and her brother, Abraham Ebstein of 152 Powers Street, Brooklyn, who were drowned while fishing in Jamaica Bay near this place Wednesday, were recovered today and sent to their home.
A sermon on the benefits of economy to the rich was delivered for the guidance and instruction of a member of the Astor family yesterday by Justice George C. Barrett of the New-York Supreme Court.

Every step that is taken toward the adjustment of differences in the Democratic Party is an assurance of ultimate success. The resolution of the State Committee declaring that six days' notice should be given of the holding of primaries was an advance in that direction. The committee might have gone further.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Officials in Washington have been surprised by the publication of a dispatch from Valparaiso stating that Brazilian troops were moving toward the Missiones Territory, and that President Peixoto explained this by announcing his intention to take possession of the country, since he knew that President Cleveland's decision as arbitrator of the ownership of the disputed territory would prove favorable to Brazil.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 10. -- Trainwreckers, it is thought, are responsible for the wreck last night, reported in The New-York Times this morning, by which eleven lives were lost at the place where the Rock Island and Pacific Railroad crosses the Burlington and Missouri River Railroads.

Mme. Janauschek is to contribute a history of the drama to the book which is to become a lasting monument to the intellect, industry, and versatility of the members of the Professional Woman's League. She read the first installment to the members of the league in their lecture hall yesterday afternoon, and was received with tumultuous applause.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 11. -- Many of Akron's manufacturers report an increase in orders and all agree that business prospects are much brighter.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Aug. 11. -- The big sturgeon of the Connecticut River have been a long time coming to market, but they seem now to have arrived. Local fishermen have discovered that the fish, despised in the local market, is worth money in NewYork, and they have prepared nets with a twelve-inch mesh in which to take the monsters.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Aug. 11. -- State Senator John Lewis Childs, one of the Trustees of the Floral Park Methodist Church, has withdrawn from that body owing to a dispute over a mortgage for $2,500 that he held on the church property.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The usual Saturday mounted inspection of Battery K was held this morning. Pieces were drawn up in battery front on the south parade grounds, caisson and limber chests were opened, and, while the men stood at attention, Capt. Dillenback rode down the line of each section.

YONKERS, Aug. 11. -- The Democrats of this city are not divided into opposing factions, though there may be a few dissensions among the rival leaders of certain wards. A six days' notice would be amply sufficient for the leaders to call together the primaries in order to consult as to the selection of candidates.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 11. -- While the special trains which conveyed the Waterbury contingent of the Second Regiment was passingthrough this city, Private David Cavanaugh of G Company and another member of his company, whom he refuses to betray, quarreled before the company left Waterbury. Shortly after the train left this city they came to blows.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The two events of the week were the big tennis tournament at Norwood Park and the open-air horse show at Hollywood.

The Vosburgh Veterans of the old American Guard, Seventy-first Regiment, New-York Saate militia, held a rousing meeting last Wednesday evening in their new headquarters, 906 and 908 Third Avenue, with Henry F. Liebenau in the chair. Some fifty old veterans who served under the late Col. Vosburgh answered roll call. The meeting was opened with prayer by Chaplain S.L. Sentis.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 11. -- All the fashionable and benevolent people of this town are looking forward with great interest to the grand outdoor fete to be given for the benefit of the Mountainside Hospital at the grounds of the Montclair Athletic Club next Tuesday afternoon and evening.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Bracing air, cool breezes, and plenty of fishing, excellent bathing and any number of pleasure boats, combine to make life at East Moriches enjoyable and health giving. The natural beauties of this place, coupled with the perfect accommodations provided by man, have attracted visitors who come here year after year.
Mr. Augustin Daly returned to New-York yesterday after an absence of fifteen months in Europe. He came on the steamship Paris, and was accompanied by Mrs. Daly and Miss Ada Rehan.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The Norwood Park tennis tournament is a thing of the past, and R.D. Wrenn, champion of the United States, is the winner of first prize and the holder of the trophy. Malcolm Chace gets the second prize, and the other contestants take away with them the memory of a pleasant week of expert tennis.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11. -- The New-Yorks were ignominiously defeated by the Baltimores to-day. The latter batted Westervelt at will, ran bases with great daring, and fielded without an approach of an error. They gathered in 15 of their 20 runs in three innings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Whenever Gorman and the Sugar Trust Senators can find a champion he will sing the same song about this deadlock of the Tariff bill. It is all through the fault of the House, in refusing to take the Senate bill without change. That is the first explanation. But there appear to have been suggestions from the Senate conferrees that there should be changes.

The London Chronicle publishes two views of the position of the Australian colony in Paraguay, founded by Mr. Lane, a journalist, but now split up into two sections, one under Lane and one under a Mr. Frederick Kidd. The first account gives the Rev. Frederick Hastings's impressions on a flying visit to the colony, which is run upon communal principles and without alcohol.

Gogol's well-known play, "The Inspector," he completed and produced on the stage in the same year, (1836.) It is one of his writings which is best known in this country, for it has been translated into French by Prosper Merimee, and twice quite recently into English. The plot is extremely simple.

BALDWIN'S, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Burglars broke into two houses here yesterday and into one at Oceanside. The three robberies were committed in daylight, and while in each case the value of articles secured by the thieves was very light, they made up for it by destroying many articles too bulky to be carried off. All the families were absent at the time, and there is no clue to the burglars.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11. INTEREST in the recent robberies of cottages has been renewed by the recovery of the silverware stolen from Arthur B. Turnure.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11. -- The steamer City of Peking brings details of the destruction of the American Presbyterian Church at Shuklung, near Canton, a mention of which was contained in the Oriental mail. It seems that anti-missionary riots began in the prefectual town of Tung Kan, in June, as the result of the posting of placards containing base charges against the Christians.

There has been little movement in the stock market during the week, because the conditions upon which movements would be based were merely a continuation of those of the previous week. The interminable tariff controversy remained in the same state of uncertainty. The later reports on the corn crop merely confirmed the earlier ones.
BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- Marine insurance agents in town are now charging, as a war risk, one-quarter of 1 per cent. additional on cargoes for Chinese and Japanese ports.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 11. -- The grounds ablaze with Chinese lanterns, the spacious halls and parlors tastefully decorated, gave proof before the opening of the eighth annual hop of Beach View House that it was to be the event of this as well as previous seasons at this popular seaside resort.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The outer doors of the vault in the bank at West Winfleld were blown open this morning with dynamite. A second cartridge with a fuse was placed in the last door, when the villagers, who had been alarmed by a young man who had seen a light in the bank at 3 P.M., scared the burglars away.

From The London Telegraph. Another form which the devil assumes in Russia pretty often of late is that of the cholera, who, of course, is a female. In the district of Barnaul the other day the peasants were determined to make short work of the "Cunning One" in that odious role of his. They clubbed together and lay in wait.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, Aug. 11 Keeping cool is easy to do here. The Arverne Hotel' daily bulletin giving the direction of the wind, the hour of high tide, and the difference in the temperature between here and New-York with always a very big difference in favor of Arverne, is a source of great amusement to the guests.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- There was a stampede to-day among the bulls in corn owing to a drop of 2 cents, in the price of September and 3/4 cent for May. This makes a fall of 7 3/4 cents in the price from the high point last week. This drop was in spite of the Government statement indicating a decrease of fully 115,000,000 bushels in the corn crop, compared with last year.

More than half of the Grand Circuit has been completed and the world's record at either of the harness gaits remains as safe as ever. Before the midsummer campaign began the opinion of a number of prominent breeders and trainers was asked by the writer regarding the likelihood of 2:04 being beaten this year.

Rome Correspondent London Telegraph. Bicycles caused no end of bad blood -- in more senses than one, it is to be fearedbefore finally obtaining the right of citizenship among orthodox vehicles of the road; and, universal though they have now become among ordinary mortals, they have still a deal of up-hill work to accomplish before acquiring a status among the surroundings of royalty.

The American Line steamship Paris, from Southampton, six days and something out, reached Quarantine early yesterday morning and swung her ornate figurehead into the American Line slip shortly before S A.M. On board was a mighty collection of notables.

SIOUX CITY, Aug. 11. -- In the Woodbury County bond injunction case some startling evidence has been brought out. From the testimony of ex-Deputy Auditor Roberts it appears that there has been an organized movement among certain officials to rob the county. Roberts implicates himself and a number of other officials.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- [Copyright, 1894.] -- Lombard Street rates for money are again slightly easier, only 1/4 per cent. being charged for day and week leans, and for three months' paper 9-16 per cent. The activity on the Stock Exchange may improve the demand, if it continues, but the outlook is, on the whole, for continued ease.

"There is a national taste in perfumes as distinctive as national features, expression, or dress," said the manager of the American branch of a well-known European business. "When we first imported our goods, we brought prominently forward those perfumes which had met with favor in England, but we soon learned that Americans had their own preferences.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. -- Arrangements for the annual court tennis tournament were completed to-day. The first match will be between Alexander Morton and E.A. Thompson of New-York on Tuesday, and Fiske Warren of Boston will play the winner on Wednesday. All matches will be played at the Casino and will be refereed by Tom Pettitt, the professional.
SUMMIT, N.J., Aug, 11. -- The fashionable set came out Tuesday afternoon and evening to attend the lawn fete for the benefit of the Fresh Air Home.

SHELTER ISLAND, Aug. 11. -- The list of arrivals for the past week is not as large as that of the first of the month, but few people have gone. The dry weather has made bathing more popular and attracted attention to aquatic, rather than land, pastimes.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 11. -- Soho will soon erect a spacious and imposing brick school building to replace the old frame structure which for a long time has been inadequate to the growing needs of the district. Plans have already been prepared and accepted for the building, which will be situated in Montgomery Avenue, bordering on the Second River.

For a time all goes well with the enthusiastic, ardent young men who give to their employers the full benefit of all their talents and learning and increasing experience. By and by, however, the political partisanship or the editorial supervision of the paper changes. New questions arise, on which the editors or proprietors and the leader writers find it difficult or impossible to agree.

Judge Barrett has in effect decided that $15,000 a year is enough as an allowance for the maintenance and education of two minor children, even though there is a large estate in trust upon which to draw. He has not only held that that is enough, but that it is all the children's father can have for the purpose out of the estate of their deceased mother.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 11. -- Late last night the remains of Andrew Hansen, a farmer of McPherson County, Neb., one of the victims of Thursday night's train wreck, were identified by a watch found in human bones. George Davis, a colored man, suspected of wrecking the train, was arrested by the police late last night. Shortly after the wreck he applied to a hackman and asked to be driven up town.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- There was a disposition on the part of the traders to call a halt to-day. The market showed it by the diminished volume of business. The few who were on the floor seemed rather disposed to hammer St. Paul. The short interest in that stock in this market has not yet begun to cover.

If a scourge of infidelity, apostasy, or schism should come upon Brooklyn at the present time, the City of Churches would not come out of it without serious loss. The spiritual health board is at present out of town.

Civil and mechanical engineers have for many years been asking iron manufacturers to produce tubes without seams. There can be no stronger piece of iron or steel put into use in the erection of buildings, bridges, and other structures requiring the use of such materials than the ideal tube, without seam, "blow" hole, or other defect to weaken it, due to the method of manufacture.
Author of "The Golden Hope: A Romance of the Deep." "A Sea Queen," "The Wreck of the Grosvenor," "My Danish Sweetheart," ,

LEW BEACH, Sullivan County, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Trout angling may be nearly over -- the last legal fishing will be Aug. 31 -- but interest in it will last until the law permits the use of rod and line in 1895, because all signs and predictions point to the next open season as a phenomenal one, and to a new era for the glorious Beaverkill.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 11. -- The centennial of Fort McHenry as a military post of the General Government will be celebrated on the 12th of September. That is not the exact anniversary, but it is the special date in Baltimore's calendar of patriotism, ranking next to, if not almost equaling, the Fourth of July.

BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- The market for local stocks was dull, and prices changed but little. Dominion Coal declined 1, to 20. The recent fluctuations of the stock have been entirely a matter of chance, being regulated by the conflicting tariff rumors from Washington. West End Street Railway had a slight reaction, selling off 1/4, to 52 1/2.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate a veto message on the bill restoring Passed Assistant Paymaster Louis A. Yorke to the retired list.

From The Halifax Herald. Is a frog a fish? This is the problem which the officials of the Dominion Fishery Department have recently had to consider. Petitions were forwarded to the department from the inhabitants of Northumberland, Ontario, praying for a close season for frogs.

George Lowthrel, a real estate broker, walked in his sleep, as it is supposed, out of a window in his apartments, in the Hotel Winthrop, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue, at 10 o'clock last night, and sustained injuries from his fall to the courtyard which proved fatal in a few minutes.

BLOCK ISLAND, Aug. 11. BECAUSE of the six weeks' dry spell, there has not been the usual good fishing here until a week or so ago, when the generous two days' rainfall induced the gamy and much-sought bluefish abounding hereabout to once more seize the tempting trawl of elongated eelskin with a voracity that results in his being landed in the "bar'l" prepared for his reception in the catboat.

HUNTER, N.Y., Aug. 11. IDSUMMER'S last days are being very gayly passed in this charming little town among the Carskills, and as yet there seems to be no disposition among the large number of guests to leave.

It was a typical midsummer Saturday half-holiday market yesterday. The trading was light in all the specialties, and the changes were not important. There was some selling of the Grangers on the Government crop report, but the news of the breaking of the drought in the corn belt induced covering of short contracts and much of the early loss was recovered before the close.

The people live much in public, and the poorer classes, instead of eating their meals at home, as is the manner of the unsociable Hindu, seem usually to breakfast and dine at one of the itinerant cookshops to be found at every street corner. More exclusive people may be seen buying the small packets of curry and rice wrapped in fresh plantain leaves, and pinned with bamboo splinters, which are intended for home consumption.

Contractor Michael J. Dady, the intimate friend of John Y. McKane, and business successor to John Curran, said yesterday that he would continue work upon Neptune Avenue, Coney Island, and complete it in spite of protests of land owners, and that it would be finished in about a year.

NYACK, Aug. 11. -- Six days' notice of a primary is very short -- in fact, too short. Ten to fourteen days would be better. Posters should be thoroughly distributed throughout the district and notices inserted in the newspapers. To show Democrats that the party managers will conduct the caucus in all fairness, let the fact be made known and then carried out faithfully.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 11. -- There was a cool wave here this week and it did not interfere with the fun at all. The parlors were crowded. Progressive euchre and progressive whist were favorites. The breeze has made yachting on the Shrewsbury a great pleasure.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 11. -- The season has reached the high-tide mark here and the number of guests indicates that Cold Spring Harbor is capable of holding its own with any of the resorts. The week has been full of social affairs. They have crowded in upon each other so fast that it almost required the services of a private secretary to keep track of a popular man's engagements.

A main difference between our times and mediaeval times is that then the scientific constructor and the artistic constructor were one person. Now they are two. The art of architecture is divided against itself. The architect resents the engineer as a barbarian; the engineer makes light of the architect as a dilettante.

TRENTON, Aug. 11. -- The New-Jersey State House is to have a glided dome, to indicate that it has reached the golden age of its prosperity. When a bird's-eye view is taken of Trenton from some elevated point, the dome of the State House looms up like a black bird cage, and no stranger would suspect that it was the crowning point of the magnificent Capitol Building that New-Jersey is so proud of.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 11. -- The chief topics of conversation of the Summer colony are the new assembly room, soon to be built in connection with the Ridgefield Club, and the anticipated coaching parties daily from Stamford under the control of ex-Commodore Lottimer of the Stamford Yacht Club.

While the Orioles were piling up runs against the New-Yorks in Baltimore the Brooklyns were rendering valuable assistance to the Maryland pennant seekers by giving the champions a set-back, and today Boston is only a few points ahead for first place in the League race.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11. So far the gymkhana games Monday afternoon proved to be the biggest thing of the season. It was a beautiful day for out-door exercise, and a glorious day to sit in the refreshing breeze and watch a dozen athletic young men struggle with their captions ponies on the dusty recetrack.

An omnibus indictment against Capt. William S. Devery and Special Duty Officer Edward Glennon of the First Precinct charges fifty-six specific offenses growing out of Their duty in the Eleventh Precinct.

From The London Daily News. In The Engineering Review for this month Sir Henry Bessemer has an article on the steel industry which bears his name. He reminds us that a third of a century ago Sheffield' steel made from the costly bar iron of Sweden realized from u50 to u60 a ton.

The sixth annual games of St. George's Athletic Club, held yesterday afternoon at Weehawken, N.J., were productive of some pretty contests. There was a fashionable crowd of spectators on hand, and everything combined to make the event very successful. The club's grounds are very pleasantly situated on the Palisades above the old Weehawken Ferry.
