A visit to the paper mills which supply The New-York Times with its huge rolls of paper may convince one that no industry of to-day is more interesting than that of paper making, and that no mills are more worthy to represent the industry than the ones visited.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 11. -- Ninety out of ninety-six counties in the State have forwarded returns of the recent election for Supreme Justices and Secretary of State. The missing counties are Seautchie, Sevier, Grainger, Grundy, Coffee, and Henderson. The totals are:

WASHINGTON, Aug., 11. -- Never before since Mr. Gorman came to be regarded as a Democratic leader and as the foremost man of his side in the Senate has he been put to such straits as he has resorted to since the Tariff bill came back from the first conference and was returned to the conferrees after his speech against his associates and against the President.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- There was no further liquidation of Alley securities to-day. The forced sales which were impending for several days were consummated yesterday, and the semi-fright spent itself at the close of the last session. To-day there was some demand for the stock, the purchases, amounting to about 1,500 shares, being made at 9 3/4@ 10.

DESMOINES, Iowa, Aug. 11. -- Showers last evening broke the drought over the central and northern part of the State. The rain came too late to do corn much good in this section, although late fields will be benefited.
ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The indications are that this extraordinarily successful season will extend to the very last of September.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- The British dailies continue to publish vehement denunciations of Japan. Every repulse of the Japanese in Corea or Corean waters is welcomed editorially, as a would-be triumph of British, arms, and every Japanese success evokes a storm of disapproval and appeals to international law.
FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 11. RETTY girls who make life at this seaside city charming are at their best, now that their cheeks are tanned. They have had a month of great gayety.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- That the end of the "Commonweal" movement, or nuisance, as it has grown to be, is at hand, was evidenced this morning by the action of the authorities of the State of Virginia in driving the remnant of the body of men who have long been an eyesore to this neighborhood, under the guise of an "industrial army," from the soil of the State.

L.S. Hubbard, an expert accountant and a member of the New-York Athletic Club, was complainant in the Yorkville court yesterday against a prominent and wealthy saloon keeper and a well-known business man of the west side.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. -- Golf has come to be the great attraction at Newport, as it is the popular, sport on the Shinnecock, Hills. The Newport Golf Club Contains a large number of members, and its social features are among the interesting and gay events of this resort.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Attorney General Moloney appeared in the office of the Circuit Clerk of Cook County to-day and filed a petition for a bill in equity against the Pullman Palace Car Company, calling upon it to show cause why it should not be prohibited from further doing business under the laws of the State.

From The New-Tork Times, June 15, 1884. There was a well-attended meeting last evening of the Tammany Hall Committee on Organization, John Kelly in the chair. Mr. Kelly referred to the way in which Tammany Hall had been excluded from State Conventions, and said he thought it should have a just representation in the Saratoga Convention.

WEST POINT, Aug. 11. -- The Philadelphia Branch of the American Society for the Extension of University Teaching paid a long-expected visit to the post last Monday. The members were warmly received by Adjt. John M. Carson, who gave them every facility for inspecting all the objects of interest connected with the Military Academy.

The most curious incidents connected with memory are, of course, its entire lapse, and such cases are not by any means so infrequent as is generally supposed. It is startling enough, no doubt, to hear a fellow-creature asking another fellow-creature to tell him who he is, but such things haveactually happened.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 11. -- There have been more visitors to Cape May during the last week than at any time for many years. Ten of the leading hotels have had to turn away applicants for accommodations. There are more New-Yorkers here than ever before.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 11. THE FORT GRISwold House has been thronged with guests this week, and today not a room was to be had for late comers who sought accommodations at this delightfully situated hotel overlooking New-London Harbor and the Sound.

PARIS, Monday, July 16 -- For several years past Parisians have neglected the 14th. Not because the date was obnoxious, but simply because the thing got to be an old story. Official attention, in the way of flags, lights, military reviews, and so forth, were elaborated for the provincials, who came flocking into the city, delighted to sea the show and overjoyed at the extra day for shopping.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11. DALLY the hotels become more crowded and the landlords happier. The crowds were larger this week than usual, and although the "standing room only" sign has been displayed at the hotels for several weeks, the newcomers managed to find accommondations somewhere.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The open-air horse show was concluded to-day under a cloudless sky with an attendance of over 3,00O persons. It has been such a pronounced success that arrangements are already under way for repeating it next year. The scene on the grand stand and lawn to-day was even more brilliant than yesterday.

BAT SHORE, L.I., Aug.11. -- The most elaborate entertainment thus far under-taken at the Prospect House is the Subscription Cotillion, which takes place this evening in the hotel ballroom. This event is due to Mrs. Isaac Mason and the Misses Mason. The cotillion will be led by Mr. Charles G. Dumont and Miss Blanche Taylor.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. NEWPORT is in the midst of her annual duty of entertaining the yachtsmen, and she is doing it in royal style. There seem to be not so many boats here as in Previous years.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 11. -- The second annual regatta of the Patchogue Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon in a brisk south wind. Fifteen yachts entered in the races. The starting signal was given at 1:16 P.M. Every one of the boats got a good start. Not one of them carried a reef throughout the race, though the wind kept their scuppers under a greater portion of the time.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 11. -- Ground has been broken for a new society dormitory building by the Delta Psi fraternity of the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University. It will be built at 133 College Street, and named St. Anthony's Hall. The material will be East Haven sandstone, the same as in the chapter house of the society near by.

NIVERVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Gov. Flower to-day commenced his visits to farmers' gatherings, which are to continue this and next month. This afternoon, at Niverville, he addressed the farmers of Columbia and Rensselaer Counties. The Governor began his remarks as follows:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- It was a veritable gala day at the race track here this afternoon. The pretty clubhouse and the lawn about it were a mass of color, flags and bunting being scattered about with a liberal hand. A couple of large marquees had been erected on the lawn, and a half dozen smaller tents were scattered about between the great beds of flowers that were rich in color.

It was entirely a banquet, everything cooked and eaten "faa Samca" (a la Samoan!) and all the eatables laid on banana leaves. There were dozens of pigs, varying in size from a rabbit to a sofa, the latter being the centrepiece; quantities of chickens and ducks, every kind of native fruit and vegetable, and before each guest a leaf of large pink prawns, which are plentiful in the waters from which Vailima takes its name.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11. -- Everybody who has followed the cause of Coxey knows that it was the idea to make the army a "Good Roads Association," and now Warden Moore of the Maryland House of Correction intends to accord eighty-eight of the soldiers an opportunity to show the practicability of the association.

As it was anticipated by all the Fifteenth Army Corps on the night of the burning of Columbia, S.C., that the next day destruction would be continued, but by details and positive instructions, we were not at all surprised when the Orderly Sergeant commenced at the head of the list and detailed a few men, under a Sergeant, to report to some officer at a certain place and time.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 11. -- Robert H. Bogus of this city has received a letter from Miss Lulu F. Whilden, a missionary in China, at Canton, in which she says:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The card offered by the Asbury Park Athletic Association attracted nearly 5,000 to the bicycle track this afternoon. The eight races scheduled were run off with a dash, Harry Tyler, the Springfield crack, capturing the most valuable prizes for the Class B men, and George Smith of New-York the trophies for the A men.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11. -- The Administration scored a point against Senator Gorman to-day when Naval Officer Barnes Compton resigned as Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee. Mr. Compton's resignation is given in accordance with the wishes of the President, who, as stated in the United Press dispatches last Thursday, desires that all Maryland Federal officials shall sever their connections with political organizations.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Aug. 11. -- Fire on Pilley's Island, in Notre Dame Bay, on Wednesday last, destroyed the premises of Joseph Strong, manager of the Trading Company, consisting of a shop, a dwelling, and two stores. The fire originated in the fish store, and quickly spread to the adjoining buildings.

The rumor in Washington that it was the purpose of the Democratic leaders in the House, by passing the Senate bill as it stands, to thwart the elearly-revealed determination of "the Senators from Havemeyer" to prevent all tariff legislation, has caused Mr. Hill to throw off some of the disguises he had been wearing.

TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 11. -- The crews of twelve Spanish fishing schooners, which were seized and brought to this port last month by the revenue cutter McLane for violations of the revenue laws and quarantine regulations, were discharged to-day from the vessels by an agent who came from Havana in the interest of the owners.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Before the racing was begun to-day William Easton sold at auction for the breeders, Gen. Stephen Sanford Son of Amsterdam, thirteen head of yearlings. They were a good-looking lot, in prime condition, but as the imported sire, Laureate, is untried, there was not the active demand for such good lookers as there would have been had his get been raced.

HYDE PARK, L.I., Aug. 11. -- A little over a year ago the Rev. Father Thomas McGronen, pastor of St. Bridget's Church at Westbury, visited this village, and, securing free use of a hall from P.J. Miller, a hotel proprietor, celebrated the first Catholic service ever held in this place. As a result of the work thus started by the Rev. Father McGronen a handsome Catholic Church will be dedicated next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Engineer in Chief Melville of the Navy has proposed to the City of New-York a method of disposing of the city's garbage in the most effective manner, and the designs, which are the result of many years' study on his part, he has offered gratuitously.

HORNELLSVILLE, Aug. 11. -- It has been customary in this city to give only two or three days' notice of primary meetings; all called for the same hour of the same evening. This has been regarded as ample time and perfectly satisfactory to all factions. A notice in a conspicuous place on the local page of the Democratic paper, from the recognized proper authority, has always been regarded as satisfactory by all factions here.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- It is as if a thick, black curtain had been hung up between us and the far East. It is now fully a week since any current news whatever has reached here from the seat of war, and the last batch of tidings which did come consisted almost wholly of point-blank contradictions of what had been previously told us.

The State Bankers' Convention, will be held at Saratoga on Wednesday and Thursday of this week. The convention is the result of a movement among prominent bankers of the State of New-York to bring about a permanent State organization of bankers similar to those which are in existence in nearly all the Western States.

PORTLAND, Conn., Aug 11. -- This is a town of 5,000 Inhabitants, half way between New-York and Boston, and is given over to brownstone. The scent of brownstone is in its air, the taste of brownstone is in its mouth, the brownstone itself is imbedded in its soil. If a day laborer gets "forehanded" enough to put up a frame cottage of a story and a half, he has a foundation of brownstone.

A few sales and quite a number of exchanges have marked the dealings in real estate in this city during the past week. Such indications as are afforded by the trend of inquiries continue favorable to a good Fall business. There has been a marked absence recently of dealings by speculators or operators.

The last annual report of the Commissioners in Lunacy has been, issued in England as a Parliamentary paper, and has created no small stir. It appears from this report that there has been during the last year a remarkable increase in the number of lunatics in England and Wales.

The extensive pine forest which cover the dunes of Southwestern France, stretching from the "Bassin d'Arcachon" on the north for many miles southward toward Biarritz, is the home of a curious caterpillar, Bombyx pythiocampa, of the same family as the silkworm. These insects possess a few interesting characteristics.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 11. -- Life among these grand old mountains has taken on a new phase since the season opened some four or five weeks ago. Pretty girls in the airiest of Summer finery, and gallant youths in the most comfortable of neglige attire, sit about the spacious piazzas of the stately old Homestead, or, at fancy, plunge into the swimming pool, or wield the tennis racket on the well-kept lawns.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 11. -- Some rich finds of Indian relics have been made in counties adjoining this within the last few days. Western New-York is always yielding rich returns to the Indianologist, Livingston and Ontario Counties being especially prolific. Little Yates is not far behind, for it was on the shores of Lake Keuka, only a few months ago, that one of the largest skeletons of an Indian ever found was discovered.

The New-York Times, June 18, 1884. SARATOGA, June 17. -- The Democratic State Committee met at the United States Hotel at 8:30 o'clock, with Daniel Manning in the chair and Walter H. Bunn acting as Secretary. * * * The Chair then asked for contested counties to come forward and be heard.

NEWPORT, Aug. 11. -- Miss Emily Tooker, daughter of Gabriel Mead Tooker, gave a charming dinner to-night, with white decorations. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Warren, Judge J.C. Gray of the New-York Court of Appeals and Mrs. Gray, James Otis, Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock, Mr. and Mrs. J.J. Wylong, Mr. and Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks, Baron Leghait, the Belgian Minister, and Miss Ruth Morgan.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 11. -- At the Moody conference this morning, Mr. Meyer spoke on "The Baptism of the Holy Spirit." Dr. Mabie followed on "Separation," which does not mean separation from fellow-man, but from everything that hinders spiritual life. Dr. Dixon of Brooklyn also spoke.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert and Miss Lucy Haley of Brooklyn entertained a party of about thirty in number at Nanyang on Monday, the occasion being a chowder party given in honor of their guests, the Rev. and Mrs. Herbert Bliss, Henry Yonge, and Philip Farley, all of Brooklyn.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Announcement was made this week that deer might not be lawfully hunted until Sept. 1, the season opening that date instead of Aug. 15. The New-York Times will be the first to contradict this rumor so disagreeable to the thousands of city people who are waiting in the mountains for the opening of the hunting season.

MOLDE, Norway, July 16. -- The initial trip of a first-class ocean steamer to the Land of the Midnight Sun deserves something more than a passing notice, and for such a journey no more worthy ship could be chosen than the Augusta Victoria, commanded by Capt. A. Kaempff. Thursday, June 28, amid general rejoicing and to the sound of gray music, the vessel steamed out into the sunlit waters of New-York Harbor.

From The London Daily Graphic. Col. Rhodes, who has just reached England from the Cape, brings news of a highly interesting archaeological discovery in Mashonaland, which seems to point toa previous occupation by a different race of people, probably Arabs. Shortly before the outbreak of the war a prospector discovered a sealed cave, similar to those used by the Mashonas for burying their dead.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 11. AT this time there are always many arrivals of people who come to spend their vacation at the camp meetings. This place was first settled and owned by the Methodists, and it was not until some time later that it became a popular resort.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 11. -- The hotels are full, and the fears of hard times entertained at the beginning of the season have vanished. Store and hotel keepers are happy. There has been an unprecedented number of entertainments.

The close of the Covent Garden opera season has called forth from the London papers a chorus of praise for the impresario, Sir Augustus Harris. It appears to have been thoroughly deserved, too. There were seventy-four opera nights in the combined Covent Garden and Drury Lane seasons, but on eighteen of these nights two operas were given in conjunction.
From The Troy Press. The designation of Sept. 25 as the date and Saratoga as the place for holding the Democratic State Convention will meet with the general approbation of the party.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11. THE cottagers are beginning to return from the seashore already. J.W. Davis and his family, who have been spending two weeks at Bar Harbor, returned on Wednesday of this week.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Out here on the shore of the Great South Bay, with cool breezes and delightful scenery, one never wants for entertainment. There is stopping here a colony of very agreeable people, who are always doing something to amuse. There is never a dull moment during an outing spent at Centre Moriches, and both day and night find the Summer colony astir.
John E. Milholland and the band of Republicans who constituted the late "Milholland movement" are still loud and bitter in their declarations that they have been "not beaten, but betrayed."

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 11. -- The yachts on the New-York Yacht Club cruise begun to arrive here soon after 4 o'clock, and kept on coming in until late this evening. The run was a good one, but very flukey, and many more surprises were furnished the yachtsmen.

The Constitutional Convention has decided to employ its time pretty closely during the remaining five weeks of its session. It has unanimously adopted a resolution to hold three sittings every week day, except Saturday, when there will be only one, these aggregating seven hours a day.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 11. -- G.M.B. Mudge, President of the committee which met at Fairmount Hall, on the Heights, to arrange for holding an indignation meeting to protest against the quality of the water furnished to the people of this city, to-day announced the names of the members of the Executive Committee, which is to have active charge of the arrangements.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Edwards of England won the international five-mile bicycle race at Herne Hill to-day. Wheeler of America was second and Louvet of France was third. Arthur Zimmerman and James Verheyen collided in the last lap. Verheyen was stunned by the fall. Zimmerman, the champion wheelman of the world, covered a quarter mile in 0:30 4-5.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 11. -- The New Point Hotel, since its opening, has been taxed to its utmost capacity to accommodate those desiring rooms. The cool, bracing air leaves nothing to be desired in the way of comfort to the guests. Ex-Senator S.M. Griswold of Brooklyn gave a talk on "Palestine in the Nineteenth Century" this week.

At its first establishment the inexpertence of its founders was by no means the worst peril which the bank had to encounter. It was surrounded by enemies, whose opposition arose partly from political and partly from selfish motives. The goldsmiths, in whose hands the banking of London, such as it was, had developed into a most profitable trade, were naturally disposed to set every obstacle in their rival's way.

LONDON, Aug. 11. --The Central News correspondent in Shanghai says that to-day the Japanese made a second attempt to disperse the Chinese fleet at Wei-Hai-Wei, on the Chinese coast, and to thus gain access to the port.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- This Adirondack suburb of the metropolis is at present entertaining more visitors than any other half dozen resorts in America; the season is the most prosperous that has been enjoyed for a decade, the hotels and boarding houses, which have a capacity for over 30,000 guests, are rapidly filling up, and in a few days the season will have climbed to its height.

From The Bath Advocate. The New-York Times for several days past has labored to spread an interest among the Democratic leaders of the Empire State, looking to a solidified and united vote of the Democratic voters of the State at the coming election. The Advocate is glad to indorse and assist in so necessary and important a movement.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 11. HILE last week here by the sea was considered something phenomenal, yet the past seven days so far exceed it in point of the number of arrivals that the question of how to accommodate the thousands that are arriving every day is perplexing the mind of every hotel and boarding-house proprietor.

Sir Augustus Harris, the English theatrical manager, who is reported to have had in contemplation the purchase of the Broadway Theatre, and who was a passenger by the American Line steamship Paris, from Southampton yesterday, was accompanied by Lady Harris and Miss Florence Harris.

LAKE PLACID, Essex County, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Never in its history has Lake Placid had such a rush of people as have registered at the various hotels for the last two weeks. Tents have been resorted to for some time past, a departure in Summer life which the visitors greatly enjoy.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- The precise intention of the Government as regards the repression of Socialism and Anarchism is still the subject of anxious doubt and surmise. The newspapers are filled with articles of advice and warning, but none ventures to say exactly where the Government blow will fall or how it will be dealt.

"What you need, Herbert Brant, my boy, is quest and riot -- I mean, rest and quiet," said my old friend the doctor, with a mischievous twinkle in his eyes which belied the genuineness of the mistake. "You have been burning the candle at both ends; you must now be chary of the butt, or there'll be no but about it.

The "cooking" of the Atchison accounts, would have been, only one shade more immoral had it been undertaken for the purpose of covering up the direct stealing of the company's money. As generally understood, the falsifications exposed by Mr. Little's report were resorted to chiefly in order to enable the company to market a greater quantity of securities, at a satisfactory price.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Aug. 11. --In selecting this historic spot for holding their convention, the Quakers chose a locality delightful in romantic scenery and interesting reminiscences. Chappaqua is in the town of New-Castle, Westchester County. Roaring Brook tumbles down through a notch in the Chappaqua Hills, just west of the tracks of the New-York and Harlem Railroad, which is a single-track road here, as it winds its way through this hilly country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- "On this question the yeas are 35 and the nays are 35, The Vice President votes in the affirmative, and the motion is carried."

Nicholas Fredericksen has returned to the land of his adoption with a strange tale of persecution and imprisonment at the hands of the minions of the Czar of All the Russias. He arrived here yesterday from Southampton in the steerage of the steamship Paris.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 12. -- Mrs. Virginia N. Lount, who claims to be an elocutionist and a lecturer on economic topics, was sent to jail today for non-payment of a small board bill at the Eutaw House. Mrs. Lount claims to have written for New-York newspapers and magazines. She came here from New-York on July 31, and was to have delivered a lecture next Thursday in Washington under the auspices of The Washington Post Company.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 12. -- The last relay rider bearing the message from Washington to the League of American Wheelmen meeting here arrived to-night at 10:40, and immediately delivered the message to Gov. Waite.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- The market for local securities was quiet, with few changes in prices during the week. There was a very bullish feeling on Albany Railway securities. The earnings for the month of July were said to be the largest in the history of the company. The recently established City Belt Line has proved to be a popular move and has increased the travel much more than was hoped for.
The first detailed account of the recent trouble in Nicaragua, which resulted In the killing of several persons, was had yesterday, when the schooner George W. Whitford arrived in port.

ATCHISON, Kan., Aug. 12. -- The floods of the Missouri River have been gradually washing away the east shore above the Winthrop Railroad Junction, nearly opposite this city. The north and east roads approach the east end of the fine new bridge across the river at this point, and cross into the city on the same track.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 12. -- The Australian steamer Arawa arrived at noon today, having left Sydney, N.S.W., July 20. Among her passenger is Count Bismarck, a distant relative of Prince Bismarck. He is traveling for pleasure.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 12. -- This charming place, famous as the Summer home of President Cleveland and Actor Joseph Jefferson, now has the pleasure of getting its Sunday New-York Times on the day of publication. The special train bearing to-day's Times reached here at 4 o'clock this afternoon, and the supply soon disappeared. The novelty was appreciated, and The Times's enterprise was widely commended.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12. -- The Medical Faculty of Yale University has issued a statement of the course of instruction in the Yale Medical School and of the facilities at the command of the Faculty for carrying out the plan of instruction. It has been prepared for the information of the medical alumni of the university and others interested in the progress of medicine at Yale.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 12. -- Three men entered the barroom of William H. Roberts's hotel, in Oramaupum Street, early this morning, and, after drinking $1 worth of liquor, laid 20 cents on the bar.

From The Westminster Gazette. A New-Ross telegram reports that an extraordinary occurrence took place on Thursday in Slade fishing village in South Wexford. An Irish-American who had become insane was picked up in a small boat about twenty miles out to sea by a fishing trawler from England. He had two trunks and a number of parcels of meat and bread.
The cry of John E. Milholland, as he pushed away the plate of crow which was offered to him by the Brookfield Republicans, was:

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Rain fell yesterday over a great area in the West, including a large part of Illinois, Iowa, and Indiana. Reports from some points in this State indicate that in consequence there will be an average crop of corn. It was reported from other localities that crops had been too much damaged to be much benefited by the rains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Senator Chandler of New-Hampshire said to-night that he had no idea that there was going to be any immediate or sudden change in the situation, notwithstanding the impending caucus to-morrow, and its expected results.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The Board of Managers for the proposed Woman's Relief Corps Home for Aged and Dependent Veterans and their Wives, Veterans' Widows, and Army Nurses has just made a visit to this place to inspect a site offered for the proposed home by Mrs. Sarah Upton Edwards, it being the first place which the board has visited in the State.

The passengers of the French Line steamship La Champagne, which arrived yesterday from Havre, had an experience during the voyage which is familiar enough to the mariner, but something of a novelty to the average ocean traveler.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 12. -- The great Ocean Grove Auditorium, the largest evangelical audience room in the world, was formally dedicated to-night to the service and worship of God, by the Rev. T.L. Bowman, D.D., the senior Bishop of the Methodist Episeopal Church, assisted by his colleagues, Bishops Walden and Fowler, and the 200 clergymen of various denominations who were present.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 12. -- C.R. Lathrop of Chicago was arrested Friday, and now is lodged in Belem prison at the instigation of the Mexican District Messenger Company. The arrest is the outgrowth of the war on between the American and Mexican stockholders, who are fighting over the management of the company. Manager Commagera has been shut out of the office.

With the exception of the Victorias, all the clubs competing for the cricket championship of New-York played interesting games last week, and the changes in the batting averages were particularly noticeable. T.S. Jevons of the Staten Island Cricket Club added another notout innings to his already peculiar record, and, after playing five innings, he has now an average of the total number of runs scored.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 11. -- The week closed to-day in an unbroken midsummer market for local speculatlves. With so-called investments, it is pretty much the same story. In the meantime, no concessions are being made by holders, and so long as money rules as plenty as for months past, no material changes need be looked for.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 12. -- Miss Agnes Murray, an eccentric woman, who lives on a handsome property on Greenfield Hill and is reputed to be very wealthy, and who has gained much notoriety because she keeps a pack of vicious dogs on the premises and does not allow anybody to enter, is again in trouble. It is all on account of her dogs.
From The Philadelphia Press, Aug. 11. The Rev. Dr. George Dana Boardman, pastor emeritus of the First Baptist Church, had a narrow escape from being drowned about two weeks ago at Atlantic City.

From The Naval and Military Record, (British.) Naval men have been waiting a considerable time for a practical demonstration of the "utility" of that most deadly instrument of modern warfare, the torpedo. From the far East news has come to justify their impatience and dispel any lingering doubt which may have existed as to the officacy of the invention.
"If I ever beat her it was no more than she deserved," doggedly said Joseph Blaha, a Bohemian, of 420 East Seventy-second Street, yesterday to Justice Taintor in the Yorkville Police Court.

COLLEGE POINT, L. I., Aug. 12. -- The tug Clara of New-York, Capt. Mark Creamer, which tied up in Stoiber's Dock Saturday, caught fire early this morning. The Captain and crew of five men barely escaped with their lives.

A spotted fox terrier and a well-dressed woman and a colored man both of whom claimed the dog, occupied the attention of Justice Voorhis, in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning. The disputants were Mrs. Anna Ryder of 57 West Fortyfifth Street and James Church of 346 West Forty-first Street.

When John Curran, who held the contract for grading Neptune Avenue, Coney Island, died last November, he left a wife, a son, John Curran, Jr., and several daughters, who were heirs to his estate. This included the contract for Neptune Avenue, worth $290,000, and the following contracts with the City of Brooklyn:

The Japanese residents of New-York, Brooklyn, and neighboring towns and cities have aroused themselves and are taking a great interest in the war between their own country and the Celestial Empire. They are not only patriotic to a degree, that being a trait of Japanese character, but they are also highly enthusiastic.

Staten Island Leader. The open and manly overture made by Senator Murphy to the different facrions who cliam to be Democrats has the ring of the right mettle about it. No person calling himself a Democrat can any longer from an excuse for aiding in the election of Republican office-seekers.

The case of Capt. William S. Devery of the First Precinct, who was to have been tried last week, with his special-duty officer, Edward Glennon, on an omnibus complaint, charging fifty-six specific offenses, has taken on a new aspect.

MANHATTAN BEACH, Aug. 12. -- Thomas C. Platt had some visitors this afternoon, who came to discuss the political situation in New-York. They were John Sabine Smith of counsel for the Committee of Thirty in the factional quarrel which the State Committee attempted to settle, and Police Commissioners Kerwin and Murray. They called on ex-Senator Platt at the Oriental Hotel, and remained with him for nearly an hour.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 12. -- "When there are two members of this church who wish me to resign, my resignation is ready," said the Rev. Alexander Hamilton, rector of Emanuel Church, Lyons Plains, on Sunday, Jan. 14. "After twenty-five years' preaching I stand before you a condemned man."

COTTAGE CITY, Masa., Aug. 12. -- It is two years since the New-York yachtsmen spent a Sunday at this quaint resort. Last year the fleet was fog-bound at Newport. It got to Vineyard Haven on Monday night, and left early the next morning. This was a sad disappointment to the hundreds of pretty girls here, who always look forward to the visit of the New-York Yacht Club squadron.

RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Capt. A.H. Chamberlain of the Union County Roadsters is very enthusiastic daily over the bright outlook for the great twenty-mile road race on Labor Day over the Union County course. He says that from the great interest already manifested in the race by wheelmen all over the country a big affair is assured.

Thomas Hole, forty-seven years old, sexton of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Atonement, Seventeenth Street, near Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, last night killed his wife by shooting her three times and cutting her throat with a knife and a razor in their home. 361 Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn. Holt was Insane.
VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 12. -- Advices from Honolulu, under the date of Aug. 3, say:

From The Naval and Military Record, (British.) The military system of Japan has been almost entirely revised since the rebellion of 1877. In that year, it may be remembered, Marshal Saigo, Commander in Chief of the army, revolted, and for eight months Japan was harassed by a terrible and bloody struggle, in the course of which upward of 7,000 men were killed and over 10,000 were wounded.

The death of George Inness, N.A., while traveling in Europe, has called attention to a career that has many points of interest to American artists. Inness was great in the two fields, if fields they may be called, of the landscapist and colorist, which contain the finest work of our native artists.

There are still a good many good people who will consider it as odd and out of character that the President of the United States should intrust a message to the Governor of Colorado to the first of a series of relays of wheelmen who are endeavoring to establish a creditable record for a journey on bicycles from Washington to Denver.

The following letter in part from E.A. Nelson, the American cyclist now in Austria, to a friend in this city, contains much that will interest local wheelmen, and explains the curious treatment foreigners have received from the National Cyclist Union of England. Mr. Nelson and other foreigners had traveled many miles to compete in the English championships at Birmingham.

The final collapse of Coxey seems to indicate that the American method of disposing of embodied tramps may have its advantages over the European method. When it was reported that tramps in considerable numbers were making their way from various parts of the country to the capital, and subsisting on the country traversed, many European critics were disgusted with the apparent weakness of the American Government and its inability to maintain public order.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The Shanghai correspondent of the Central News has been enabled to obtain from an official Chinese source a full confirmation of the report that Li Hung Chang has been reproved and degraded by the Emperor for dilatoriness in prosecuting the war. The correspondent says:

The question as to how the $1,000,000 appropriated by the Legislature last Winter to provide work in the parks for the unemployed was spent, came up again yesterday before the Central Labor Union. Secretary John L. Henry read a letter from Deputy Controller Storrs in reply to a request from the Central Labor Union for an itemized account of the expenditure of that money.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- The weather is unusually cold, a dry southeast storm being in progress. The latest subscribers to the Casino ball are John Jacob Astor, C. Norman Fay, Joel B. Wolfe, James Stillman, A. Augustus Low, Thomas F. Cushing, and William F. Bunder. The number now reaches thirty-six, and the success of the ball is early assured.

The volunteer firemen of the city have been indignantly discussing for several days the charge which, it was reported by telegraph, was made last Thursday at the Central New-York Volunteer Firemen's Convention, in Ithaca, against the Trustees of the New-York Exempt Firemen's Benevolent Fund.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- Chief of Police Willard this morning received a telegram from Inspector McLaughlin of New-York City asking him to arrest Millie Herrowitz, a woman twenty-five years old, who was a passenger on the night boat which arrived here to-day from New-York City. The message stated that a warrant for the woman on the charge of grand larceny was in the hands of the New-York police.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12. -- The new United States Marshal for Connecticut, Richard C. Morris of New-London, who has been appointed as Marshal Strong's successor by President Cleveland, the appointment dating from Aug. 4, is one of the most influential Democrats in Eastern Connecticut.

It is evident that, as our London correspondent pointed out yesterday, the Orientals have their own way of making war, and that modern protected cruisers and topedoes do not suffice to constitute European warfare. European curiosity and European opinion would insist upon getting some account of what is going on, but there does not seem to be an effective Asiatic demand in that direction.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- A very cool night and a day of cold and heavy showers were not at all favoring to the first Sunday gathering in the Methodist Episcopal Camp on Sing Sing Heights. The meetings, however, were very largely attended, and no unfriendliness on the part of the elements could lessen the enthusiasm of the audiences.

The eleventh annual outing of the Hickory Club, of which Excise Commissioner Michael C. Murphy is President, was held at College Point. L.I., yesterday. Fully 1,000 residents of the First Assembly District attended, and the affair, like those of former years, was thoroughly enjoyed, and came to an end without any serious mishap.

STAPLETON, S. I., Aug. 12. -- The arrest of four constables for malicious trespass, and of three New-York business men on charges of assault in the third degree, today, brought to light a singular story of proceedings in a levy upon chattels in a civil action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The House will not surrender yet. After a consultation tonight of leading House members, including Speaker Crisp, and a review by them of the situation of the Tariff bill with reference to the course that is to be pursued to-morrow in the House caucus, it was decided that there was abundant reason for believing that there would be a bill passed satisfactory to the Senate and the House.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- The great Anarchist trial ended to-day in the acquittal of all of the thirty defendants on the charge of anarchy. Three of the prisoners, however, were found guilty on other charges.

Despite the absence from town of many of the habitues of Fleetwood Park's cozy clubhouse, there was a goodly number of horsemen on the porch watching the trotters take their exercise yesterday. President McMillan and Secretary Mason were present, fresh from Buffalo, where they had been during the week, in the interest of the club's Grand Circuit meeting, which opens Sept. 3.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- The struggle between the Socialist boycotters and the ring brewers does not grow less. Although both parties have suffered enough to welcome the end, neither one thinks of yielding a point.

The announcement that the Navy Department has authorized Lieut. W.H. Beehler to place his solarometer aboard the North German Lloyd steamer Weimar, in order to give the instrument a thorough test under the conditions of deep-sea navigation, will be received with interest by all persons interested in the management of ships.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Aug. 12. -- Luther Challis, who has been a prominent figure in this city and Atchison in the last twenty years, and was at one time a most daring speculator in New-York, lies dead at his home in Atchison.

Rex, a black spaniel dog, belonging to Frank Raymond, the Republican politician, disappeared from his home, at 63 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, on Saturday night, and his whereabouts was unknown until yesterday afternoon, when he walked into the house as unconcerned as if nothing had happened. When the dog left he wore a silver collar, on which was a license tag, numbered 1,601.

We think that Mr. Wilson was misled by the person who informed him that the Sugar Trust had already procured $112,000,000 worth of raw sugar in excess of its normal supply at this season. That would mean an excess sufficient to satisfy the demands of consumers for a whole year, for the value of the raw sugar imported in the fiscal year 1893 was $115,000,000.

To any one acquainted with the topography of the Passaic River and its banks above the "intake" of the Jersey City Water Works, it must be obvious that the water supply of that city cannot be wholesome. The mere fact that it receives the sewage of cities and towns and the drainage of factories on such a scale is evidence enough of contamination.

When Mr. Beecher went over to England to make speeches for the Union and spread enlightenment about the right and wrong of the war of the rebellion, the hardy Britons who sympathized with the South announced that they were going to give him "a perfectly disgusting reception."

From away up at Bar Harbor, Me., where society disports itself in the tumbling breakers or enjoys the breezes of old ocean on the piazzas of fashionable hotels, comes substantial remembrance of the puny, suffering babies in this sweltering metropolis, and the poor, overworked mothers, who have a day-to-day struggle to provide even the necessaries of life for their little ones.

LAKE GROVE, L.I., Aug. 13 -- The country residence of Dr. A. Peschmann of NewYork, at this place, was totally destroyed by fire early this morning. August Rollman, a friend of the owner, Mr. Rollman's sister, and a young daughter of Dr Peschmann's were in the house. Mr. Rollman escaped in his nightclothes and rescued his sister and Miss Peschmann.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 -- John Jacob Astor is taking lessons in driving four horses, his instructor being Dr. W. Seward Webb. They mwy be seen on Bellevue Avenue any morning. Mr. Astor will soon purchase a coach.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The report of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company of New-York City for the quarter ended June 30, last, shows gross earnings from operation, $2,485,665; operating expenses, $1,440,120; net earnings, $1,045,544; other income, $204,177; gross income, $1,249,722; fixed charges, $656,4I8; net income, $593,303; cash on hand, $346,956; profit and loss, (surplus,) $5,623,197.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 13 -- Owing to what appears to be a misunderstanding regarding the accident to the Atlanta's machinery while on her way to Newport week before last there has been considerable discussion in naval circles concerning the advisability of United States war vessels ramming derelict ships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The House caucus turned out just as the Speaker had expected it would. Mr. Wilson made his statements, speaking for an hour to relate the difficulties of the conferrees on the part of the House. Without telling who the Senators were, he did tell his associates that the Senate was in the grasp of the Sugar Trust, and that four Senators held the reins of legislation in bthalf of that trust.

Charles Krumm, proprietor of the concert saloon 167 Chrystie Street, the Lexow committee witness, and the man whose charge against ex-Ward Detective Jeremiah S. Levy, now under suspension, caused the latter's indictment on a charge of bribery, was a prisoner in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday morning.

"Politics is war, and war means defeats as well as victories, but for us it doesn't mean surrender," declared John E. Milholland, with much enthusiasm, before a crowded meeting of his followers in the First Assembly District last evening. In calling the meeting to order in the hall at 212 Greenwich Street, the Chairman announced that the assembly had come together to let "the other fellows know we are not dead."

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 13 -- It was a great disappointment to the Cottage City folk when they found it was raining this morning. A regular eastern storm had set in and very few braved it to go to Eastchop to watch the squadron sail away. At 6:30 o'clock the flagship signaled the fleet to get under way at 7:30 o'clock.

In reply to a question asked by Mr. Gourley, in the British House of Commons, concerning the emission of dense masses of smoke and jets of flame from the funnels of the torpedo cruiser Hornet, during that vessel's recent speed trial, Sir U. J. Kay-Shuttleworth made the following statement:

Persons who have taken an active interest in the readjustment of the affairs of the Central Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia are authority for the assertion that the reorganization plan is practically an assured success. Satisfactory concessions have been made to conflicting interests, and it only remains now for the parties chiefly concerned to get together and arrange the final details.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 13 -- Now that the Republican State Central Committee has decided to have the Republican State Convention in Hartford, Sept. 18 and 19, attention is directed to the probable date of the Democratic State Convention. It will be held in this city between the 10th and the 15th of next of month.

A secret session of the Police Board was held yesterday, at which Superintendent Byrnes and Mr. Wellman attended. Capt. Devery's case was considered. The result of the meeting was announced by President Martin.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The Constitutional Convention, on convening to-morrow morning, will resume its consideration of the proposed home-rule article for cities. To-morrow night the convention will conclude its discussion of the woman suffrage question, and take a formal vote on agreeing with the adverse report on the woman suffrage amendments, which, it is expected, will be agreed to.

The party of tariff reform, after twenty years of waiting, comes into a plundered inheritance. It is lord of the fee, but the estate has been ravaged. And the robbers and ravagers are of its own number and joint heirs! The pride and joy of possession are changed to shame and wrath, but if the Democratic Party would take vengeance on the spoilers, it must strike down its own kin.

Scientists are arriving in large numbers in Brooklyn for the forty-third annual session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which opens at 10 A.M. Thursday in the Polytechnic Insti tute, and continues until Aug 23. Among those who registered at the Institute yesterday were:

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- The market for local stocks was inclined to dullness; with the tone generally firm. The telephone stocks held their recent gain well, Bell Telephone selling at 200, Erie Telephone at 45 1/2, and New-England Telephone at 67. Dominion Coal fell 1/2, to 19 1/2, on the acceptance of the Senate bill by the House conferrees, but recovered later.

Wheeler H. Peckham of counsel for the Union Trust Company, which is the trustee of the general mortgage of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, expects to start for Topeka, Kan., to-day, for the purpose of presenting J. W. Reinhart's resignation as receiver to Judge Caldwell of the United States Circuit Court, and securing the appointment of a successor to Mr. Reinnart.
Gen. C.H.T. Collis offered the following resolution at the meeting of the "regular" Republican County Committee, at Lyric Hall, last Friday:

SALAMANCA, Aug. 13 -- In my judgment, six days' notice for primaries is sufficient. This notice should be posted In six or eight public places in each caucus district, and published in districts where a daily or weekly paper is published. An equal representation on the Board of Caucus Inspectors would insure fairness, and the

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R. 1., Aug. 13 -- The Narrangansett Casino was this afternoon the scene of a large gathering of tennis experts and enthusiasts to inaugurate the annual tournament for the Eastern double championship. Twelve pairs entered for the event, comprising wellknown experts who will be seen next week at Newport. The entries and the order in which they are to play is as follows:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 -- The New-Yorks won the last game of the series, the first they have captured here this season. Meekin was in good shape after his rest, and kept the Orioles from scoring unitl the last inning. Hawke retired after five innings. Esper was injured in the ankle by a terrifc drive from Farrell's bat in the eighth inning. Inks pitched the game out.

Republican State Committeeman William Barnes of Albany came to the city yesterday and was for a time at State headquarters. He has trouble in his political bailiwick. There are factions there after recognition and "spoils." One of them is directing its energies against the devoted head of Mr. Barnes himself in an effort to curtail his political power.

Macomb's Dam Road, by Hugh N. Camp, alter-Phoenix Ingraham Co., offered for sale, under foreclosure, the premises Nos. 544 to 548 East Eighty-sixth Street, 73 by 102.2, with two-story brick and frame buildings thereon.

A gray-haired woman, who says she is Mrs. Annie Verdell, was arrested yesterday afternoon on the charge of grand larceny. The principal complainant is the firm of B. Altman Co., Sixth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, who claim that Mrs. Verdell obtained from their store goods valued at 115.64 on the ground that they were intended for Mrs. Fred M. Robinson of 222 West Twenty-third Street, by whom Mrs. Verdell was formerly employed.

"Democrats must get together. There must be harmony this Fall, or we shall lose the State. No man, no sane man, can believe that the Democratic Party can win in New-York State this election if there is faltering or sulking by any faction of Democrats," said Mayor Gilroy to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday, on his return from Saratoga.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Central News says that a strong Chinese fleet has left the coast. The impression in Shanghai is that this fleet will seek to intercept the transports which are carrying Japanese troops to Corea.

Justice William J. Gaynor of Brooklyn, when asked yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times for an expression of opinion on the present situation of the Democratic Party in the State, was rather guarded in his statements on the purely political aspects of the case, but on one point he spoke very clearly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- There was nothing dramatic in the opening of the last scene over the Tariff bill. When the House met the galleries were not filled, and they held only the usual audience of chance visitors and regular attendants. The Members' Gallery was not half full, and over the whole assemblage there was the dull light of a cloudy day.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The Daily News, in commenting on the action on the Tariff bill, says: "In yielding to the Senate's obstruct tion, the House only stoops to conquer. The decision was a sudden but wise one. The prolonged suspense is removed, and a measure of certainty secured. Free wool will be the test by which Americans will judge free trade.
JERSEY, CITY, N.J., Aug. 13 -- The discussion of the water question has brought to light a peculiar fact, which illustrates the manner in which the Water Department has been managed.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 13-- Starter Creveling of St. Louis rang the bel at 1:30 this afternoon on what is the greatest meeting in point of purse ever givn in the history of harness racing. The purses will aggregate $91,000. That there will be sensations on this 2:04 track this week was shown by the fact that two world's records were beaten on the opening day.

The play, "A Night Off," with which Augustin Daly will open the preliminary season at his theatre in this city on Aug. 25, will possess a peculiar interest not only to the patrons of that house of the drama, but to the whole theatre-going public as well, since it will serve to introduce Henry E. Dixey as a member of the regular Daly stock company.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 13 -- The numerous desertions from the Populist Party during the past week included ex-Congressman B. H. Clover, who was elected from the Third Kansas District by the "reformers" in 1890. Mr. Clover was State President of the Farmers' Alliance in 1889-90, and it was under his administration that the order reached its zenith in power and influence.

The Democratic State Committee met at Saratoga last night and fixed the date for the State Convention for Sept. 25. It will be held in the convention city of Saratoga. Six weeks will remain then between nominations and election day. The time is sufficient. In the present day of rapid transit and speedy distribution of information long campaigns are not necessary. Six weeks ought to give us a spirited campaign that would not be exhausting.

The Democratic State Committee at its session last night called the Democratic Convention to meet at Saratoga Sept. 25, or exactly one week from the date of the Republican Convention. The date is about ten days earlier than that of last year, but not earlier than the average date of State Conventions. The campaign will be about six weeks in length, and every day of that time ought to be devoted to earnest work.

In the final tussle yesterday at Eastern Park between the champion Bostons and Father Foutz's boys, the latter emphasized their ball-playing ability by trouncing the Bay State crowd in fins style. When the game was over the Bridegrooms had 13 runs and the leaders 5. This victory gives the series to Brooklyn, Capt. Nash's warriors having won but one game.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- The determination of the Republican leaders in the Constitutional Convention to force the final adjournment on the date fixed by law, Sept. 15, is interpreted in only one way -- that another Richmond has entered the field for the Gubernatorial nomination in earnest. Mr. Joseph H. Choate, President of the convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Tariff bill of 1894 -- the Wilson bill as emended by the Senate -- was passed by the House this evening, at 6:30 o'clock, by a majority of 77 in a vote of 287. It will now go to the President, and with his approval, or without it, unless he shall be constrained to interpose his veto, it will be the law in ten days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Mr. Breckinridge of Arkansas, who, while not a member of the conference, has been in constant attendance upon the meetings of the conferrees, made a statement to-day in which he says:

The Delaware Club went on its annual outing yesterday. The party consisted of most of the stalwart Democrats of the Twentieth Assembly District and many invited guests. Several hundred braves gathered at the clubhouse, 144 East Sixty-fifth Street, early yesterday morning, and were met by Thomas J. Dunn, the President of the club, and his aides, who furnished all with white caps and canes.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 13 -- In all former contests the Kansas Populists have been the aggressive party and the Republicans defendants, arraigned for all their sins of commission and omission of a quarter of it century. This campaign is changing the order, and the Populists are defending their record of the past eighteen months.

Substantial advances, covering all active stocks and bonds, make up the record of yesterday's operations at the Stock Exchange. Various causes contributed to the improvement. Rains in the West, with reports indicating that the percentage of estimated crop loss might be lowered, helped the Granger properties.

PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 13 -- A man who registered at the Lafayette Hotel last Saturday as "F.M. Williamson of Boston," committed suicide this morning in his room by shooting himself in the head. The body was found this afternoon. An order book marked "Louis G. Wemyss, 100 West Sixtyfourth Street, New-York" was found upon his person.

Thomas Holt, the sexton of the Episcopal Church of the Atonement, Brooklyn, who murdered his wife, at 361 Seventeenth Street, in that city, Sunday night by shooting her three times and cutting her throat with a knife and a razor, was arraigned before Justice Walsh in the Butler Street Police Court yesterday.

The discussion of the "home-rule amendment" is to continue in the Constitutional Convention to-day, with some expectation of reaching a vote. This matter can be greatly simplified by agreeing to the section which provides for municipal elections in the odd-numbered years, and postponing action upon the other sections, at least until the rest of the separate elections scheme can be brought before the convention.

While the Senate Tariff bill does not meet the full requirements of tariff reform, for reasons with which our readers are familiar, it cuts down by a considerable percentage, as a rule, the tariff taxes of the McKinley act, where those taxes are not wholly removed, and enlarges the free list by the addition of several very important products.

At the Democratic State Convention of May, 1888, the following resolutions were reported from the Committee on Resolutions, "as the sense of that committee," and they are to be read in connection with the party platform then adopted:

John E. Beattie, nineteen years old, who has been boarding at 475 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, was a prisoner in the Myrtle Avenue Police Court yesterday, charged with stealing a suit of clothes, the property of George B. Livingston, who boards in the same house. The pawn tickets for the articles were found in Seattle's pockets, and he pleaded guilty to the charge of larceny.

There was a larger attendance at Parkway yesterday than on Saturday. Thirteen books had all the business they could handle. The track was fast. Belwood's performance in the first race at a mile is ample justification for the Stewards' action in respect to Johnson, who rode the horse on Friday. Hunn's riding of Comanche in the third race was most peculiar.

The franchise of the Staten Island Ferry will be offered by the city authorities for public competition on Sept. 6. The lease is for ten years, and includes the new piers, slips, and ferryhouse at the Battery. The rental of the slips and piers is fixed, and the competition will be as to the percentage of gross receipts to be paid to the city.
John E. Milholland and his followers last night declared war.
Respecting the Tariff bill, as agreed to by the lower house of Congress, the opinions of prominent business men in this city were sought yesterday by reporters for The New-York Times.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- Albany County polities, particularly the Republican end, are very sadly mixed. The most striking coincidence connected with the present condition in both of the big political parties is that neither the regular Democratic nor the regular Republican organization possesses a party organ; but, on the contrary, the irregular Democratic and the irregular Republican faction control two newspapers each.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 --The House Democratic caucus to-day adopted a resolution, by a vote of 130 to 21, discharging the House conferrees from further consideration of the Tariff bill and agreeing to the Senate bill.

The Inspectors on Ellis Island have been notified to keep a lookout for Christian von Woerle, who is one of the most notorious criminals of Denmark and who is supposed to be on his way to this country. Several days ago the United States Consul at Liverpool wrote to Dr. Sinner, the Commissioner of Immigration at this port, informing him that the Society for Befriending Criminals had paid the passage of this man to America.

The 120 Georgia editors, with their friends, who are staying at the Metropolitan Hotel, arose bright and early yesterday morning and after having their breakfasts dispersed throughout the city and its environs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The assertion by William L. Wilson, during debate to-day that the Sugar Trust, in anticipation of favorable legislation, had purchased sugar to the value of $112,000,000 abroad, has called forth the following letter from John E. Searles, the Secretary of the Trust:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- With the advancing market which to-day brought traders who have been bearish, especially in Reading, St. Paul, and the tractions, had fine exercise climbing after those stocks. They sold People's Traction last week at 49. It opened to-day at 52, advanced to 53, and closed at 51.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 13 -- In accordance with the understanding of Friday last, the Senate to-day immediately after some unimportant routine morning business went into executive session to take up the Chinese treaty. It had been agreed that the vote was to be had at once without further debate, and the roll call was taken shortly after the doors were closed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- First Controller Bowler rendered to-day a decisiion in the case of the accounts of Major E.W. Halford, United States Army, and John W. Foster, disbursing officer and agent, respectively, of the United States, at the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration at Paris.

It is hard to see how the bit of "taffy" recommended for Milholland by the Republican State Committee is to be administered. In the resolutions adopted by the committee it was recommended that in the appointment of Republican election officers "proper and just representation be given to the Republicans now enrolled in the organization of which Mr. Milholland is President."

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The feeling in the market was good to-day, although prices opened rather weak. West Chicago opened at 127 3/4. Later the offerings were decidedly lighter, and the demand seemed to increase, the result being an advance, so that not only the morning's loss was regained, but a further improvement of 1/2 point was established, sales being made up to 129.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 14 -- While the people of this city are making strenuous efforts to secure a new water supply, it may serve as an encouragement to them to know the difficulties that beset the residents of the old city in their efforts to obtain water, and the many failures that resulted previous to 1854, when the first water works were completed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics reports that the total values of the Exports of merchandise from the United States during the month of July, 1894, and during the seven months ended July 31, 1894, as compared with similar exports during the corresponding periods of the preceding year were as follows:

CENTRE ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Lieut. William H. Stayton, with Scudder Smith, L. E. Puzo, H. Southgate, H. Peil Haggerty, and J. Beall, members of the Fourth Division of the Naval Reserve, arrived here last night in a whaleboat, after being twenty-one hours on the water without food. They were welcomed and entertained by members of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, who fed them and provided sleeping accommodations.
There was a meeting of property owners of West Twenty-fourth Street at noon yesterday, in the office of Thorp Knowles, to discuss Mrs. Sallade's crusade against disorderly houses.

After a remarkably fine up-hill game New-York won from the St. Louis Browns on the Polo Grounds yesterday. For seven innings the Western players were in the lead, and in the eighth, just when the local enthusiasts were beginning to lose hope, the Giants made an onslaught on Mr. Clarkson's curves, and by a pretty display of safe and opportune hitting sent in 4 runs, just enough to win.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- An interesting and well-developed struggle is now going on between the two committees that have been intrusted with the responsibility of determining the question of sectarian appropriations for public and private institutions, namely, the Committee on Charities, whose Chairman is Edward Lauterbach, and that on Education, Chairman Frederic W. Holls.

SARATOGA, Aug. 14 -- With as fine a day as could be made for racing, a couple of good stakes on for decision, and a good crowd at the track, to-day's racing was an unqualified success. The feature was the race for the Foster Memorial Stakes, which broought Lamplighter, Yo Tambien, Ducat, and George Beck together.

At the meeting of the Pilot Board yesterday Capt. Charles A. Watt of the schooner Ocean Lilly submitted a written complaint, stating that while coming into this port from Petit Goave Aug. 2 he could not induce a pilot to board his ship. While off Barnegat several pilot boats, he says, spoke the Ocean Lilly, and asked how much water she drew.

The citizens of the annexed district held another meeting in Loefier's Hall, at One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street and Willis Avenue, last night, to take further action in regard to the Riker's Island nuisance.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The great lawn fete for the benefit of the Mountainside Hospital was held this afternoon on the spacious grounds of the Montclair Athletic Club. From 3 o'clock up to a late hour to-night there was a throng of fashionable people. Flowers, flags, Japanese lanterns, colored streamers, and a liberal supply of calcium lights added to the attractiveness of the scene.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- The discussion of the adverse report of the Suffrage Committee on the woman's suffrage amendment attracted a throng of women to the Constitutional Convention at the opening of the session to-night.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 14 -- The annual tournament for the championship of the National American Croquet Association begins here next Monday, and then should follow for a week the finest playing of the year. The experts of nearly two score clubs will be on hand to compete for the blue ribbon, and unless predictions are very much off the games will be closer than for a number of years past.

The office of United States Commissioner Alexander was crowded yesterday when Russell B. Hoyt and James W. Murphy, or Davis, or Hill, of the Bethel (Conn.) gang of counterfeiters of ten-dollar Treasury notes were arraigned. The gang consisted of Russell and Lorenzo Hoyt, Murphy, and Samuel A. Massey, all of whom were arrested.

An increased demand for money was made upon New-York banks by banking corporations and private individuals in the West yesterday. It was understood here that the desired currency was for the purpose of taking out of the United States bonded warehouses in the various quarters of this broad country merchandise on which the tax is increased by the new Tariff bill.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science began its annual meeting in Brooklyn yesterday, and will continue its sessions for one week. A number of important preliminary meetings were held yesterday in the various educational institutions in Brooklyn.

George M. Pullman, President of the Pullman Palace Car Company, who arrived in this city Monday from Chicago, issued a statement to the public yesterday through his counsel giving the company's side of the legal controversy which has arisen between it and the State of Illinois.

Signor Barri, the Siberian bear trainer with the Hagenbeck Arena company at Manhattan Beach, who was badly injured by one of his boxing bears some three weeks ago, returned to his work yesterday afternoon for the first time since the attack. The large audiences at the afternoon and evening performances went wild over a boxing match between his monster Siberian bear and Signor Barri, while the other feats performed by his brutes were well received.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The seventh annual meeting of the State Hotel Keepers' Association was held at the Grand Union this morning, about 100 delegates being present. President E.M. Tierney of Binghamton occupied the chair, with W.A. Rosekraus of Albany as Secretary. The session opened with an interesting address by the President.

The County General Committee of the German-American Reform Union of the City of New-York met last evening in Vienna Hall, Fifty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, to effect a permanent organization. After some debate the following officers were elected:

NUNDA, N.T., Aug. 14 -- I regard six days as sufficient notice of the primary meetings for the election of delegates from the several towns to attend the District Convention. In a majority of the seventeen towns at last Fall's primaries, upon three days' notice, nearly 75 per cent, of the Democratic vote was cast at the caucuses.

The tennis tournament of the Staten Island Cricket Club was continued yesterday, and singles and doubles were played during the afternoon. In the second round of the singles W.S. Callender, (scratch.) met J.A. Rome, (scratch.) It required three sets to decide the victor. In the first Rome was successful, winning 6 -- 3, but he was unable to hold his lead and lost the two following sets.

The Commissioners of Fisheries of the State of New-York met yesterday at their office at 53 Broadway. There were present L.D. Huntington, President, and Messrs. W.H. Bowman, D.G. Hackney, Robert Hamilton, and Isaac N. Cox; Edward P. Doyle, the Secretary and Engineer, and J. Warren Pond, the Chief Game and Fish Protector.

The business men of Brooklyn approve of the settlement reached respecting the Tariff bill. They say they prefer the Senate bill to no tariff legislation this session, and they hope that President Cleveland will lose no time in signing the measure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The "popgun" bills calling for free coal, free iron, free sugar, and free barbed wire now lie upon the desk of the President of the Senate. They were reported this morning, and at the instance of Mr. Manderson each was read the first time. Mr. Manderson objected to a second reading.

James T. Young and Lucien Oudin were appointed yesterday receivers for the Old Staten Island Dyeing Establishment, whose principal office is at 98 Duane Street, and whose works are at West New-Brighton, S. I., on the application of all the trustees, James T. Young, J. Davis Tileston, Edward Kalbfleisch, George C. Stayner, and Samuel Marsh.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Six days is ample notice for primaries in Westchester County, in my opinion. Notices should be published in the county papers and by handbills. That is and has been the custom in our county, and our caucuses are well attended and properly conducted. Every man entitled is allowed to vote, and his vote is counted.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 14 -- Owing to a bad track, due to a heavy rain this morning, the big twenty-four-thousand-dollar futurity for four-year-old trotters went over till to-morrow. Wilmarch was drawn to-day, owing to sickness, and there are 9 starters, out of 543 original nominations, that will respond to the call to-morrow for this great prize.

"Let the President sign the Tariff bill, even if it be imperfect, and give certainty in place of uncertainty in the business world," is the almost unanimous expression of the business men of New-York City.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. N.D. Clapp entertained a party of seventy-five young people to-night at the residence of her brother, Joel B. Wolf, in honor of her daughter. Miss Edith Clapp, who is one of the belles of the season. The grounds were illuminated with incandescent lights and Chinese lanterns.
Four sales are scheduled for to-day, all to be held at noon, at the Real Estate Sales-room, 111 Broadway. Details are as follows:

Five Police Sergeants -- Hugh Clark, George Liebers, Charles A. Parkerson, Felix McKenna, and James W. Jordan, all of whom had done duty under Capt. Doherty in the Fourteenth Precinct in 1892 and 1893 -- were tried before the Police Commissioners yesterday on voluminous charges growing out of their transactions with Mrs. Augusta Thorow, the former proprietress of a disorderly house at 23 Second Avenue.
The racing at Jerome Park yesterday was the most enjoyable since the track opened. The programme was not depleted by scratches.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- In view of the increased activity and advanced prices in other stock markets, the quietness in Chicago was rather surprising. One feature of the moderate business transacted cannot escape notice, the purchases of small blocks of dividend-paying stocks for investors. Prices were not materially improved by the partial settlement of the tariff issue.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- I think that the Democrats of Buffalo and Erie Counties will be entirely satisfied with six days' notice of the holding of primaries, and that the giving of such notice through the Democratic newspapers will insure sufficient publicity.

Mrs. Ellen A. Sullivan of 113 West Eighty-fifth Street yesterday petitioned Judge Bookstaver to have an "obnoxious creature" in the person of a Sheriff's keeper removed from her house, because his presence there "disgraces, humiliates, and annoys" her.

Lawyer John B. Meyenborg of Brooklyn, who for some time has been trying to collect a twenty-five-hundred-dollar counsel fee which he claims is due to him from the County of Kings, and which the court allowed to him for services in the litigation over the sale of county bonds to the East River Savings Institution, figured yesterday, through a Sheriff's assistant, as the possessor of the Kings County Clerk's office.

DENVER, Aug. 14 -- The second day of the nationhal meet of the League of American Wheelmen has been a big success here. The attendance has increased, and there are registered now about 400 visiting wheelmen. Few are from the East and the larger part are from west of the Mississippi. But those who are here are enthusiastic enough to make up for thousands.

The long suspense in regard to the office of United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New-York was finally settled yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, when James L. Bennett took the oath of office in the United States Courtroom in the Federal Building, Brooklyn.

The "Rev." Paul Balluff, who is charged with abandonment and bigamy, was tried before Justice Quigley, in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, on the charge of abandonment. Mrs. Balluff No. 1, who for the last six months has been living with the accused in the basement of the church, Schenck Street, near Atlantic Avenue, was present with her two children.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- There was more excitement on the floor at to-day's opening than at any time since the last flurry in Reading. There seemed to be a good demand for Pennsylvania at 50, with not much stock for sale. That company is reported as doing well for this season of the year, and its business seems to be rather on the increase.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- The market for local stocks was active and strong, many securities showing a good advance. Bell Telephone advanced another point, to 201, and New-England Telephone 1/2, to 67 1/2. Dominion Coal was quiet, at 19 1/2. Boston and Maine rose 1/2, to 146 1/2. Wisconsin Central 5s rose 1 3/8, to 53, and the incomes 1, to 9; the stock advanced 1/8, to 3.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The sensational defeat of the hitherto unbeaten Alar at the opening of the Grand Circuit meeting yesterday was followed by the downfall of another top-heavy favorite this afternoon. This happened in the 2:15 trot, which came second on the card and brought together eight fieet steppers. Of these Cobwebs was rated so much the best that he sold steadily at $100 to $30 over the field.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I am glad to see that you have taken hold of the question of the Jersey City water supply. No one who has not the misfortune to be obliged to use that foul liquid, miscalled water, delivered by the Jersey City Company has any idea what it means.

Charles Krumm, the proprietor of Kuenstler Hall, 167 Chrystie Street, was held in $100 bail yesterday in the Essex Market Police Court to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of violating the excise law. He is the man on whose testimony before the Lexow committee ex-Ward Man Jeremiah S. Levy was indicted for receiving money to permit the Chrystie Street place to be kept open without a license.

Kansas was the cradle of Populism. There the first seeds were sown in the discontent of the farmers when suffering from light crops and heavy mortgages. All causes of complaint and dissatisfaction were attributed to bad legislation and evil administration, wherein both political parties had been at fault from lack of capacity or from lack of honesty.

Surrogate Fitzgerald has given a decision holding that the will of Louis Lang is valid and should be admitted to probate. Mr. Lang came to this city fifty years ago from Germany, and lived the life of a bachelor. He was an artist of the old school, a memmer of the Artists' Fund Society, and also of the Century Club.

There is a good deal of talk in military circles about a proposed mobilization of the National Guard in the coming Fall. Already fragments of opposition to the project, based wholly on ignorance of its value, are appearing, and it is not at all unlikely that before the movement takes really definite shape it will be confronted with a considerable demand for its abandonment.
