WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The passage of the Tariff bill has led to various estimates as to the effect it will have should it not meet with a veto, (which is, of course, regarded as altogether out of the question,) upon the national revenue. The following figures from official preparations are of interest:

We expressed the opinion yesterday that Mr. Wilson had been misled by the person who told him that the Sugar Trust had imported $112,000,000 worth, or a year's supply, of raw sugar in anticipation of the new tax, because the surplus of imports in excess of a normal stock was only one-seventh of a year's supply for the twelve months ending on June 30.
QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 14. -- John Quincy Adams died this morning at his home, on Mount Wollaston, Quincy, of apoplexy. He had been ill but a short time.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Judiciary to-day finally concluded its consideration of the proposed amended judiciary article, and adopted it by an almost unanimous vote of seventeen members of the committee. After weeks of consideration and revision, Messrs, Countryman, Parmenter, and Gilbert do not wholly, approve of it.

Yesterday's business in the stock market was of a kind to leave traders no room for complaint. The volume of business was exceptionally large, reaching 331,784 shares. With the flood of orders that reached the market came the natural desire to unload by those who believe in pocketing profits as fast as they appear.

Alexander E. Orr. President of the Chamber of Commerce, acknowledged yesterday that a meeting of the Vice Presidents and other members of that body was held last Thursday to discuss candidates for Mayor.

The modification of the "home-rule amendment" proposed in the Constitutional Convention yesterday by Mr. Mulqueen is a great improvement upon the form originally reported and eliminates most of the objectionable features. It retains the provision for city elections in the odd-numbered years, but would shorten the terms of officers elected this Fall to one year instead of extending them to three.

THE COURSE OF THE SENATE CONFERREES. The only member of the Senate conference committee whose opinions and reflections concerning the outcome of the tariff contest were published yesterday, over his signature or otherwise, is Mr. Jones of Arkansas. His associates were Messrs. Voorhees, Harris, and Vest.

STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 14 -- There was a cessation of hostilities at the Cunard mansion, on Grymes Hill to-day. When deputized Constable Sykes, with his score of assistants and two truckloads of seized chattels, left the Bellevue Clubhouse last night he withdrew all of his guards.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- Chairman William F. Harrity of the Democratic National Committee, when asked his views as to the passage of the Tariff bill, said:

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The Duke of Devonshire spoke at length in the House of Lords this afternoon against the Evicted Tenants bill. He based his opposition on the ground that the Government was not justified in making the reinstatement of tenants compulsory.

ROME, Aug. 14 -- Several Anarchists were arrested yesterday at an open-air meeting in the suburbs. The police searched their lodgings near the middle of the city to-day and found there bombs, explosives, and tools, and chemicals for the manufacture of such articles.

When one takes a piece of bread into the mouth, this is what occurs: The motion of the jaws in chewing forces from little glands the liquid which we know as saliva. This contains a peculiar principle which at once attacks the food, dissolving or digesting it, with the production of certain sugar-like compounds, in which form it is absorbed.
Twelve persons narrowly escaped death early yesterday morning, when a three-story frame tenement at 29 Mill Street, Brooklyn, was destroyed by fire.

Democrats are still pointing to harmony in the party ranks as the only road to victory in the approaching campaign. The discussion of party unity which preceded the meeting of the Democratic State Committee at Saratoga has now coupled with it the action of the committee in recommending full notice for the primaries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Inquiries are reaching the Treasury Department as to the time the bill will take effect. The department assumes that it will be effective law from the moment it is signed by the President, or, in the event of his failure to approve it, immediately after the expiration of the ten days' limit during which he may hold it and then permit it to become law without his approval.

ON BOARD STEAMSHIP ORINOCO, Bay of Chaleurs, Aug. 11 -- After a delightful sail from Halifax, we reached Charlottetown. Soon after arriving on Thursday evening we were waited upon by a delegation of the leading citizens, who invited the gentlemen passengers ashore to their club and entertained them. A return invitation was given and a large party came on board the Orinoco and were entertained with a concert.

The "conservative Senators" have had heir way. They have succeeded in securing protection for the sugar interests of the sugar-growing and sugar-refining States of Maryland, Ohio, and New-Jersey. They do not disguise their satisfaction.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 14 -- The Democratic State Convention will meet here to-morrow to nominate a candidate for Governor. There is no opposition to the renomination of Gov. Peter Turney, which will doubtless be made by acclamation. There is much division among Tennessee Democrats on the silver question, but the disposition among the delegates who have so far arrived is toward compromise rather than contention.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The following resolutions were adopted at the meeting of the Democratic Tariff Reform Club of East Orange held on Monday evening:

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 14 -- The State of Wisconsin is about to sue the United States for $7,975,005,77. The claim is for munitions of war, , furnished in 1861, which were paid for only in part by the United States, under the act of July 27, 1861, and for interest on deferred payment. A United States statute of limitations may be made to apply to this case so as to bar part of the claim.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 14 -- Miss Jennie C. Haight, the artist who was injured in a runaway accident Aug. 6, died to-night. For nearly nine days she was in a semi-unconscious state, speaking only once during that time.

Police Commissioner Kerwin had something to say yesterday regarding the attitude of the Milholland faction in refusing to accept the findings of the Republican State Committee and to enroll under the Committee of Thirty organization.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The charter of the High Court of Illinois, Independent Order of Foresters, was declared revoked and annulled to-day by Supreme Vice Chief Ranger D.D. Aitken, acting for the Supreme Chief Ranger, Dr. Oronhyatekha. The revocation took place at the meeting of regularlyelected delegates to the annual High Court Convention for the State of Illinois, which was being held at Madison Hall, 146 West Madison Street.

The match race yesterday at Parkway track was a success. Mr. Beard's mount, Primus, was favorite at such short odds that there was practically no betting on the race. It was rumored after the event that an enterprising individual pushed his way through the ring, making a hand book that the riders would fall off, the odds being 2 to 1 against Boody and even against Beard.

The American League of Professional Football Clubs is the name of an organization formed for the purpose of giving games under association rules in six of the larger Eastern cities. The gentlemen interested in the venture met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday and perfected their plans for the coming season. All of them are connected with the National League in some capacity.
Three thousand people witnessed the laying of the cornerstone for the new National Headquarters of the Salvation Army on Fourteenth Street, west of Sixth Avenue, last evening.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- J.E. Powell, one of the largest glove manufacturers in Johnstown, was in Albany this evening on his way home. He said that he was hurrying back to New-York to begin active operations at his mills. He said the new tariff would be most beneficial to his business; he expected to see a general revival of business of the healthiest nature all over the country.

RYDE, Aug. 14 -- The Satanita and Britannia started at 10 o'clock this morning in the Royal Victoria regatta, the Vigilant lying off Cowes and not competing. The wind was strong from the west. The course was from the starting boat off Ryde Pier to a stakeboat off Cowes, thence around the Spit Fort to the Nab Light-ship and returning to the starting point; twice around, a total distance of fifty miles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Tariff bill was reported to the House Dec. 19, 1893, but its consideration was not begun until Monday, Jan. 8. The Ways and Means Committee was engaged several months in its preparation. There were no public hearings. The debate in the House was opened by Mr. Wilson.
While the heavy thunderstorm that came up shortly before 7 o'clock last evening was at its height, the steamer General Slocum of the Rocka way Line was driven on the bar off Rockaway Inlet.

No road race during the coming Fall is exciting as much interest as the twenty-five-mile handicap which will be decided on Labor Day under the auspices of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey. The contest will be decided over the famous. Elizabeth-Rahway course, and the prospects are that the crack road racers of the East will take part.

Breitenstein, a youth with a strong left arm and pretzel curves, prevented the NewYorks from winning a game yesterday. He handled the ball in such a skillful manner that the Giants scored in only one inning. The St. Louis men played winning ball, and deserved to win. They hit the curves of German with fair success, took every chance in the field, and, altogether, played a game of ball well worth witnessing.

PLAINFIELD. N.J., Aug. 15 -- The Crescent Wheelmen held their second matinee races on their oval track this afternoon. A record for a half mile was made by E.L., Blauvelt of the Tourist Cycle Club. With pacemakers and a flying start he made the half mile in 1:00 1/2.

The St. George's Athletic Club cricket team visited Berkeley Oval yesterday for their return game with the Morris Heights Cricket Club, and again suffered a bad defeat by 58 runs and 5 wickets. G.R. Cooper was in rare form with the willow for the winners, and he hit most vigorously for his inning of 58, in which there were only two singles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- When the Tariff bill was pending in the Senate an amendment was adopted admitting alcohol to be used in the arts and for medicinal purposes free. It was decided in conference that this amendment should be stricken out of the bill, and that would have been Its fate had the conferrees made a report.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The Constitutional Convention Special Committee on Forestry gave a hearing to-day at the request of the New-York Board of Trade. There were present E.P. Martin, Chair- man of the Forestry Committee of the board; W. H. Arnoux of the Committee on Constitutional Amendments of the board, Morton Parmalee, a large owner of Adirondack lands; Verplanck Colvin of Albany, representatives of the State.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Some good tennis was seen here to-day, and the contestants had no fault to find with the applause they received. The result of to-day's play leaves R.D. Wrenn and Malcolm Chace to play John Howland and A.E. Foote for the first prize in the doubles. Both teams are clever and a close contest for the handsome first prizes is expected.

The six days' notices for caucuses, which the Democratic State Committee recommended, meets the approval of nearly every Democrat who has expressed himself on that question. In reply to questions as to the advisability of giving rival organizations representation on the caucus boards, the replies have generally been in the affirmative.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 15 -- Azote, the unbeaten plow horse discovered by Salisbury, met his first defeat in a race this season to-day, when Pamlico, reducing his record quarter, to 2:10, beat the great Whips gelding home in the fifth heat of the unfinished 2:10 trot and took first money. Azote took the fourth heat to-day in 2:00 1/2, after a great battle with Pamlico, first one and then the other in the lead.

-- The Board of Education has approved plans for a new schoolhouse in District No. 10 at the corner of Prospect and Clinton Streets. There were two plans presented, and estimates will be asked for their construction. Treasurer Getty reported a balance in the Treasury of $54,434.51. Certain repairs to the other school buildings were ordered.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 15 -- The Democratic State Convention was called to order in Tomlinson Hall this morning, with a full representation of delegates, numbering over 1,700. Chairman Taggart's remarks were brief and characteristic of the man. He said:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The House reassembled to-day after a day's rest and the members showed the relaxation from the strain of Monday's session by a general listlessness. There were two propositions advanced looking to the enactment of legislation for a freer use of silver, but neither of them could secure consideration.

Ex-Chancellor Runyon, Ambassador to Germany, returns to his post this morning on board the Columbia of the Hamburg-American Line. The Ambassador has expressed himself to friends in Newark, and Washington as being highly pleased with Berlin as a place of residence. He has been particularly struck by the municipal order which reigns in the streets of the German capital, perhaps because our own great cities have so much to learn in that regard.

The proposed constitutional amendment relating to the government of cities has been referred back by the convention to its Committee on Cities, on motion of the Chairman of the committee, together with the substitutes and amendments that have been offered, in order that it may be "completed."
Navy. -- Leut. W. C. Gorga's order to the Thetis has been revoked, and he is ordered to the Philadelphia on the staff of Rear Admiral Beardsley.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- The formal call on the Stock Exchange this morning brought bids for good securities on a more liberal scale, although in most cases they proved too low to be accepted. When the bonds of the "Alley" Elevated were called, there was no response. Later some extension 5s were bought at 30, the stock selling at 9 1/2@9 7/8.
LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 15 -- John A. Faulkner of Faulkner's Woolen Mills says of the new tariff:

-- Some weeks ago a prominent actress, whose name is carefully concealed, borrowed $300 from Harry Miner, the theatrical manager. She gave as security a lot of jewels, which Mr. Miner turned over to his son. Edwin D., the manager of the Fifth Avenue Theatre, for safekeeping. Last Friday Mr. Miner found that the jewelry had been stolen.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Following is the full text of the amended judiciary arti cle, submitted to-day by the Judiciary Com mittee to the Constitutional Convention. Five thousand copies were ordered printed:

From The Buffalo Enquirer. Mayor Gilroy, in common with other members of the Democratic State organization, is not satisfied with the prospects. He thinks that the party must get together in order to win a victory at the coming election. The apathy and indifference which the antisnappers display to the appeals for harmony made by the various leaders alarm and excite him.

The meetings of the scientific societies being held in Brooklyn are of a most instructive and entertaining nature, and marked attention is being paid to the able papers read by the learned specialists. One of the most interesting papers read so far was that by Prof. J. W. Spencer, before the Geological Society of America.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 15 -- The United States steamship Bennington, with the San Salvadorian refugees on board, was sighted about thirty miles south of the Heads last night. The first intimation of her arrival was received in the city when the towboat chartered by the Government to intercept the gunboat returned to the city for provisions, after having delivered Government dispatches to the commander of the incoming war vessel.

EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., Aug. 15 -- The Republican State Convention met at noon to-day, with Major William H. Warner of Kansas City as temporary Chairman. The various committees were appointed and a recess was taken until 4 o'clock.
LYONS, Aug. 16 -- Santo Caserio, the young Anarchist, paid, early this morning, the penalty for the murder of President Carnot at the Lyons fetes, on the evening of Sunday, June 24.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- The special feature of the market for local stocks was the rise in Mexican Central securities, the stock selling up 1/2, to 7 3/4; the incomes 2, to 13, and the fours advancing 1 1/2, to 56 1/2. Sales were not very large, but the demand was greater than the supply, although it is supposed that the rise is too sudden to be other than manipulated.

-- The Long Island Department of the Life Saving Service is getting the crews ready for immediate service, instructions to that effect having been received from the Treasury Department at Washington. The life savers must pass a medical examination before commencing their duties. Hereafter the crews will go on duty on Aug. 1 and end their vigils on June 1, instead of Sept. 1 and May 1, as formerly.

WASHINGTON Aug. 15 -- There are many schemes on foot in connection with the attempt to pass the "popgun" measures. One which has no particular point, but which appears to have the indorsement of several prominent Democrats, contemplates the introduction of an amendment to the freesugar bill repealing the Senate Tariff bill.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The following companies have been incorporated with the Secretary of State:

The Milhollandites did not eat from the pan of crow which the Republican Committee of Thirty set out on the windowsill last night. Scarcely a man of them re-enrolled. The total enrollment in the whole city was, as nearly as could be estimated, considerably less than 900, and three-quarters of these were Plattites who had failed to get in out of the wet at the regular enrollment.

COWES, Aug. 15 -- The match race between the Britannia and Vigilant, for a five-hundred-dollar cup offered by Lord Woiverton, has been postponed until Saturday, to the great disappointment of the yachtsmen, particularly the Americans here. The gale which was predicted yesterday arrived according to schedule and combed up dangerous white-crested seas in the Channel, through which it would have been foolhardy for the yachts to race.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- Room traders here continue to be bearish, and whenever the market looks weak they hammer it. Shorts were covered in the last day or two, but they are coming out again, especially in St. Paul. Next to Reading, St. Paul was by far the most active stock on the list.

STAPLETON, S. I., Aug. 16 -- The battle of Grymes Hill, between the occupants of the Cunard Mansion and Deputy Constable Luke Sykes and his army of furniture seizera, was renewed with, redoubled vigor today, and the Incidents were more exciting than before.

Judging from the number of cabin passengers who were carried out by yesterday's outgoing steamships, the tide of eastward travel has begun to ebb. There were many staterooms to spare on the ships that sailed, but there were also many notables among the passengers, a full list of whom was printed in The New-York Times yesterday.

If the Police Commissioners think they can vindicate themselves by trying selected Captains upon charges of corrupt neglect of duty, they will, of course, persevere in that work. Mr. Sheehan has gone so far in the good work as to propose the bringing of charges against an Inspector, which is higher game than the Commissioners have flown at heretofore.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 15. -- J. P. Welsh, a Summer resident, who owns a handsome sloop yacht, missed it from its moorings on Monday morning. He notified Sheriff O'Brien of his loss and offered a reward to recover the boat.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Daily Chronicle's correspondent in Yokohama says: "Rumors are current that seven Chinese vessels were sunk in an engagement with the Japanese on Aug. 10." This is probably an echo of the Yokohama dispatch received on Tuesday reporting a naval engagement on Aug. 11.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Mr. Jesse Johnson, Chairman of the Cities Committee, at the opening of to-day's session of the Constitutional Convention, moved that the home-rule article which has been under discussion at intervals for the past week be referred, with the Mulqueen and Holcomb amendments, to the Cities Committee, with instructions to report anew.

Brooklyn scored enough runs in the first two innings of yesterday's game to win from the Chicagos. Again "Pantata" Anson sat on the bench, but this time he was forced to watch the slaughter of his innocents, as the Brooklyns played pennant ball and won in a very easy manner.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- The Committee on Education has adopted an article on education. All but the last section of the article was adopted by a unanimous vote. The last section was adopted by a majority of one vote.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- The opinions of many of the owners of woolen mills and others interested in the woolen industry in NewEngland coincide with those expressed today by Robert Bleakie, the Hyde Park manufacturer. Mr. Bleakie said:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The question whether the "popgun" bills shall receive the sanction of the Senate consumed nearly Bye hours of the time of that body to-day without any decision being reached. It was demonstrated, however, when a vote was taken on a motion to go into executive sessiori, that if the Free-Sugar bill should be placed upon its final passage it would receive a handsome majority.

Isaac Goldstein and his wife, Lena, were arrested yesterday on charges of beating and robbing Samson Wallach of 238 East Eighty-eighth Street of more than $600 in money, $1,600 in notes, and some jewelry.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 15 -- Thirty-two racing men, trainers, and managers arrived this morning in a special car gayly decorated with a banner inscribed, "American League of Racing Cyclists." This party came from Minneapolis, and included Sanger, Bald, MacDonald, the Murphy brothers. Brown, Johnson brothers of Cleveland, Cabanne, Goetz, Titus, Edwards, Goehler, and others.

The Long Island Railroad Company won another victory over the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday. It was in the case of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company in its application to restrain the Long Island Railroad Company and the New-York and Rockaway Beach Railway Company from operating the latter company's trains to Kockaway on Atlantic Avenue between Woodhaven and Flatbush Avenue.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- There were just 27 of the 107 delegates present at 7 o'clock to-night, when President Choate called the Constitutional Convention to order to resume the discussion of the adverse report on the woman suffrage amendments.

Starter Weir took more time and sent his fields away in improved style at Parkway yesterday. The fifth start was perfect, the seven horses getting off in a bunch. The real good things of the day were Aloha in the second event and Holy Port in the fifth. It was said that J. R. Beard bought Aloha after the race, subject to a veterinarian's examination, the price being $800.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Sugar Trust sooner or later will learn that the victory it won by the passage of the Senate Tariff bill was a deathknell to that monopoly. It looked yesterday as though the doom would come "sooner." There are today indications that the day of wrath may be postponed.

Defective electric-light wires on the fifth floor of R.C. Williams Co.'s wholesale grocery establishment, northeast corner of Hudson and Thomas Streets, it is supposed caused a fire yesterday afternoon which completely burned out two floors and resulted in a loss of about $250,000.

One of the worst "spills" of the Flushing meeting happened yesterday in the fourth race, and as a result three jockeys at the track were badly injured. Six horses went to the post, and they were sent away to a good start, with Coleman on Jim McLaughlin, slightly in the lead. Alanthracite, with little Frank Alford up, was at his heels.

Elliott Roosevelt, who died Tuesday night of heart disease, after only four days' sickness, at his home, 313 West One Hundred and Second Street, this city, was the only brother of United States Civil Service Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt. He was the nephew of James A. Roosevelt and of Robert B. Roosevelt, ex-Minister to Holland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Harris presented the following letter, which he had received from Secretary Carlisle, and it was read by the Clerk: The Hon. Isham G. Harris, Acting Chairman Finance Committee:
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Bomber Hall, in Greenville, was crowded to-night with indignant citizens to protest against the water supply.

After three hours of dilatory proceedings and legal sparring by police defendants and their lawyers, the full Board of Police Commissioners was able yesterday to proceed with the independent investigation of the Police Department. The Commissioners also found time to dismiss four Sergeants from the force.

There was no particular rush in this city yesterday to get whisky out of the Government bonded warehouses in consequence of the Increased tax provided for in the new Tariff bill. Several small lots, however, were withdrawn, but the amount of money paid to the Internal Revenue officers was not unusually large.

John Conlin and Joseph McConnell are two jolly cronies, who take life easy. Being burgiars by trade, circumstances, and inclination, it is quite evident why they, should take life easy, that being the burglar's method of taking everything, life included.

The two proposed amendments of the Constitution which are of special importance are those relating to the government of cities and to the judiciary of the State. The former is one of great general interest, and the latter is of interest to lawyers mainly. It seems to be generally admitted that the judiciary article is in need of revision.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 15 -- The colored Democratic League, after the visit this afternoon to the Democratic State Convention, adopted resolutions as follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- It was rather cool for comfort at the Grand Circuit meeting to-day, and the weather handicapped the horses at least two seconds. For the third time this week a pronounced favorite went down, when the bay stallion Mahogany failed in the 2:19 trot, which came first on to-day's-card.

We cannot doubt that the Tariff bill will become a law. A veto is out of the question. The Democratic Party must not fail of some visible result out of its months of travail. The business of the country must not be oppressed by the uncertainties of another general tariff revision.

The citizens of the annexed district who live near Riker's Island, recognizing that garbage is going to continue to be dumped there, now demand that it be subjected to deodorization before it is taken to the island. A resolution to that effect was passed at Tuesday night's mass meeting. This change of front is taken by the contractors to indicate that there has been an abatement of the odors complained of.

-- The White Plains Board of Education has decided to put a thirty-thousand-dollar addition to the Martine Avenue Schoolhouse. This will be in the shape of another or third story and two wings. This has been found necessary to meet the demands of the growing population. There will be eight new classrooms. The work will not interfere with the regular school sessions.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. N. D. Clapp of New-York gave her third dinner party of the week to-night. There were twenty guests. A display of night-blooming lilies and Egyptian lotus were the floral decorations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Senator Vest made admissions to-day in the Senate about the liberty he supposed he exercised as a conferree that made the refusal of the Senate conferrees to permit an agreement still less defensible than it has ever seemed. It was generally known that many of the rates of the Senate bill were too high, and, that they were to be reduced in conference.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout The day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The tariff discussion in the Senate was started by Mr. Berry, (Dem., ArK.,) who moved, as soon as the reading of Secretary Carlisle's letter was completed, that the Senate proceed at once to the consideration of the Free-Sugar bill.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Save for the foul riding in the third race the sport here was rather uneventful. Riley Grannon had another good day in the ring, the young plunger beating every one of the races run and winning some $15,000, for he played none of them very heavily. Gideon and Daly had sold Cactus to Robert Tucker, the price not being made public.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A telegram was received at the Japanese Legation at 4 o'clock this afternoon to the effect that on Aug. 7 nineteen Japanese men-of-war left Corean waters for Wei-Hai-Wei, which they approached at midnight on Aug. 9. A torpedo flotilla was sent out, and on the following morning shots were exchanged with the Chinese forts.
It is expected that the United States cruiser Cincinnati, which is now at the NewYork Navy Yard, will start on her trial cruise to-day.

Business in the stock market yesterday brought a check to the rush of speculation that had kept excitement high since Monday afternoon. The sharp advance in prices had been too tempting to be resisted by buyers at the bottom. When yesterday's market opened offerings were more plentiful than bids.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- As outlined in The Times to-day, the Committee on Charities of the Constitutional Convention has directed Chairman Lauterbach to submit to the convention the amendment given below to the Constitution. A report will so with the amendment.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- As outlined in The Times to-day, the Committee on Charities of the Constitutional Convention has directed Chairman Lauterbach to submit to the convention the amendment given below to the Constitution. A report will so with the amendment.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Dispatches to the Foreign Office confirm the Times's correspondent's report sent from Port Limon on Aug. 12. The narrative of the capture of Bluefields and the arrest of Americans and Jamaicans suspected of sympathy with Chief Clarence is corroborated in most respects.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 16 -- The great Nellie A. won the third and last of the Terre Haute Futurities to-day, the three-year-old purse, of the aggregate value of $14,000, falling to the game mare after an exciting battle of six heats. Six of the greatest three-year-olds in the country started. The veteran Budd Doble guided Axihite, John Kelly was behind Director's Flower, and Scott Hudson drove Nellie A.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. T. A. Havemeyer entertained the Young People's Dancing Class, numbering about sixty, this evening. The cotillion was danced in the ballroom of the Havemeyer villa and was led by Harry Whitehouse, dancing with Miss Havemeyer. The favors were corsage bouquets of Bride roses, tied with pink satin ribbon, for the young women, and canes, with boutonnieres of American Beauty roses and lilles of the valley, for the men.

Such propositions for amending the Constitution of this State as deal with the question of "home rule" for cities have provoked a great difference of opinion, and it is evidently not going to be easy to reach an agreement in the convention. That particular question deals with the powers of self-government to be allowed to municipalities, and the restrictions to be put upon the Legislature in interfering with their local affairs.
MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 16 -- The steamer Sunniva arrived here last night from Bluefields, Mosquito Reservation. She left Bluefields on the morning of Aug. 10. The Sunniva brings the following advices:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- President Cleveland, with Dr. O'Reilly, arrived at the Broad Street Station of the Pennsylvania Railroad in the private car of President Roberts at 10:40 o'clock this morning on the way to Buzzard's Bay.

Frederic R. Coudert has made a report to the Supreme Court, in which he finds that the suit brought by Joshua J. Green to recover nearly $300,000 from James F. O'Shaughnessy, arising out of transactions eight years ago in stock certificates of the American Cotton Oil Trust, must be dismissed, and that O'Shaughnessy is entitled to judgment on his counter claim for $70,466.16 against Green.

George De Forest Barton yesterday reported the details of the trade consummated by him last week. He sold for John Pettit, the builder, to Mrs. Kate B. Belloni, a sister of Theodore A. Havemeyer, the Hanover office building, a seven-story semi-fire-proof structure on a plot 36.3 by 111.10 by 39, 130 and 132 Pearl Street, running through to 94 and 96 Water Street.

From The Sketch. When the Mapleson Opera Company was in New-York, the fair ladies of that city were bitten by a mania for obtaining the autographs of the different illustrious artists, and would send their books with requests for signatures to be appended. In one of these books Signer Campanini had signed his name, and some one had written after it, "The finest tenor in the world."

The Staten Island Cricket Club was surprised yesterday by its neighbor, the Athletic Club, which, despite the lead of 142 runs of its opponents, set manfully to work and won the game by 16 runs and 5 wickets to spare.
At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Alliance, held at the office of ex-Senator John G. Boyd yesterday, the following resolution was offered by Adolph Luhrs:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 16 -- The Louisville Southern Railroad was sold to Drexel, Morgan Co. this morning for $1,000,000. The New-York firm was the only bidder. The total first mortgage indebtedness before the sale was $5,000,000. As the road sold for only $1,000,000, but 20 per cent. of its debt will be paid. The bondholders who put their securities into the reorganization will be benefited.
The German-American Reform Union of the City of New-York has decided to confine its attention to municipal politics and let ballot reform alone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16-- A conference on the silver question began to-day in the rooms of the Bi-Metallic League. Among those in attendance were Gen. A. J. Warner, Senator Stewart, Representatives Bell and Price, Judge Seldon of Connecticut, A. Wolcott of Indiana, Judge Gerry of Colorado, Secretary Divine of the league, Col. Lee Crandall of this city, Capt. George Thacher of Colorado, J. H. Randall of Chicago, and A. S. Dulin of Colorado.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The first race of the Corinthian Yacht Club's midsummer series was sailed to-day in a light and streaky southeasterly breeze, which gave the lightweather boats a chance and disappointed several racing men who thought they had a sure thing. The series this year is for twenty-one-footers, twenty-one-foot cats, and the keel knockabouts.

UTICA, Aug. 16 -- The manufacturing industries of this city and vicinity, say representative men interested in them, will immediately commence to realize the benefits of a settlement of the tariff situation. Most of the manufacturers here are not possessed of very large stocks.

The Rockaway excursion steamer General Slocum was floated from the bar off Rockaway Inlet at 7:1O last evening, and proceeded at once to her berth at the foot of West Twenty-second Street, where she was laid up for the night.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 16 -- The Crescent Wheelmen will hold a race meet Saturday on their oval track. The track is in fine condition. Many of the Class A men have entered, and fast time is expected, to be made. The full list of entries follows:

The attendance at Jerome Park is growing with the improvement in racing. A much larger crowd than on any previous day of the meeting was present yesterday. The card was a good one, and was not chopped to pieces, only three scratches being made out of the forty-four entries. It is this sort of thing that pleases racegoers, who want to see well-filled events.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Society was pleasantly surprised to-day to hear the official announcement of the engagement of Miss Charlotte Hunnewell to Victor Sorchan, both well known in fashionable circles. Miss Hunnewell is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Hunnewell of Boston, and owns and occupies a cottage on Yosenga Avenue.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 16 -- Grasshoppers are proving a great pest and source of annoyance and loss to farmers in Western NewYork. Reports have come from nearly all counties of damage being done the crops by them. In the eastern part of Livingston County they are very numerous. Last year they visited that section about two weeks later than this, but there were not so many as there are this year.
Following are the programmes of the Seidl Society's concerts at Brighton Beach Music Hall this afternoon and evening:

Lizzie Patterson, seventeen years old, the wife of George Patterson, the forger, who is said to have swindled several Broadway jewelers with forged checks, was arraigned in the Court of General Sessions yesterday before Recorder Smyth, charged with passing a counterfeit certified check for $100 on Flomerfelt Co., at 644 Broadway, on May 23.

Willie Robert Lamberton, whose death at Saybrook, Conn., on Aug. 9, in the thirtythird year of his age, has been announced, was the only child of the late Col. W.H. Lamberton of Carlisle, Penn., and Mrs. Constance Lamberton-Miller of this city.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 16 -- There are probably 2,500 people, including delegates and visitors, at the Populist State Convention in Nelson's Grove, near the city, to-day. The representation is sectional rather than general. A number of Congressional Districts are not represented. Hugh Cavanaugh, of Cincinnati presided, and C. H. Martin of Tiffin, who was chosen Secretary of the McBride State Labor Convention, was made temporary Secretary, indicating that a fusion will be made.

The combination police trials were resumed at the Central Office yesterday. As on Wednesday, Capt. William S. Devery and Edward Glennon, his ward man when he was in command of the Eleventh Precinct, were tried together on charges of bribe taking, and James Burns, Inspector McLaughlin's ward man when he was Captain of the precinct, was tried alone.

QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The funeral of the Hon. John Quincy Adams was held this afternoon at 3 o'clock from his late residence at Mount Wollaston the flags at the City Hall and all the public and many private buildings were at half mast all day and the offices of the City Hall were closed at noon.

The following road run, except for a few blocks in Newark of granite, has for every foot of its firstclass Telford roads, and takes the rider through a beautiful country and over the famous Irvington-Millburn course:

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The general tone of the security market was decidedly better. The feeling among merchants, manufacturers, and bankers is now improving, and there is a better demand for money, well distributed, with rates held firmly. Investors are beginning to look around, tired of idleness and believing in better times now the Congressional agony has practically ended.

The out-of-town delegates to the convention of the National Association of Newsdealers, Booksellers, and Stationers were entertained at dinner at the Hotel Vendome last night by the New-York Newsdealers and Stationers' Protective and Benevolent Association. The dining room of the hotel was handsomely decorated for the occasion.

CUMMINGTON, Mass., Aug. 16 -- Pleasant skies and the presence of distinguished speakers and poets, together with the desire to do honor to the memory of William Cullen Bryant, drew hundreds of visitors to this little town to-day, and the centenary of the birth of the poet was celebrated.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 16 --Never in Grand Circuit history was there so much speed as was furnished this afternoon, Robert J. came within a fraction of touching the world's record, and Fantasy trotted the best mile of the year at that gait. The splendid young mare accomplished her feat in company with Robert J., the two cracks from Village Farm having a friendly encounter of two heats.

?DENVER, Col., Aug. 16 -- Four world's records broken in one day, and five other close and exciting races stamp this day's sport at the races of the national meet the greatest of many seasons. The attendance, too, broke the record for the season; over 10,000 persons crowded into the four grand stands.

Police Justice Voorhis and Capt. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station had a warm exchange of words in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. The trouble was caused by Justice Voorhis criticising Capt. Price for being absent from court during the hearing of the case of Joseph Morin of 261 West Thirtieth Street, who is charged with stabbing Charles Morris of 238 West Twenty-seventh Street, to death on the night of Aug. 4.

Tobacco merchants get little comfort from the new Tariff bill. It provides for a duty of $1.50 per pound on wrappers, unstemmed, imported in bale, box, package, or in bulk, and a duty of $2.25 per pound on stemmed wrappers. The McKinley bill taxed unstemmed wrappers at $2 and stemmed at $2.75 per pound.

Deputy Collector Couch, the tariff expert at the Custom House, went to Washington last night to confer with the Treasury Department authorities on the new tariff. There had been no expectation at the Custom House that the Tariff bill would pass Congress in the form in which it passed. Consequently no one there was prepared for the inquiries regarding its operation which importers and their agents have been pressing since Monday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Aldace F. Walker was appointed receiver of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad to-day, to succeed President J. W. Reinhart, resigned. The appointment was made by Judge Caldwell of the United States Circuit Court on the motion of Wheeler H. Peckham, representing the Union Trust Company of New-York, trustee for the bondholders, all other parties to the record assenting.

While other nations busy themselves with desperate endeavors to reform their upper legislative houses or to enact tariff laws that will please every one, France calmly pursues her historic course of benefiting mankind at large by investigations in medical science and applications of the results to the arts.

WESTPORT, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The Twentythird Congressional District is bubbling over with Republican politics. Nothing like it has ever been seen in this section of the State. Money is flowing like water in some sections of Esses County, an innovation in politics that is not only distasteful to the old, conservative voters, but is meeting with the severest condemnation.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- This was annual Grange Day at Chautauqua. There was the largest crowd on the grounds that has assembled here since Gen. Grant's visit in 1890. Gov. Roswell P. Flower was given a tremendous ovation. Bishop Vincent welcomed the Grangers at the 11 o'clock platform meeting this morning.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- Local stocks were rather quiet, but prices were strong generally, and one or two specialties made a good advance. Mexican Central 4s rose 1 1/2, to 58, receding later to 57; the incomes were steady at 13 and the stock strong at 8, an advance of 1/4. Wisconsin Central 5s rose 2 1/4, to 55 1/4, and the incomes 1 3/4, to 10 3/4.

ASBURY PARK, N. J, Aug. 16 -- City Marshal John Graham of Jersey City, who is living in Ocean Grove this Summer, was promenading the board walk last night when he saw two men sitting in the Asbury Avenue Pavilion whom he thought he recognized as pickpockets. Graham consulted with Capt.Rogers of the beach squad, and the suspects were taken into custody and locked up in Park Hall over night.

It was the Count de Saint-Aulaire who undertook to announce the catastrophe to her, and I have the tale from his own lips. I do not think It has ever found Its way into print. It was early morning when he reached Blois and the Empress was still in bed. Nevertheless he was admitted to her presence, and she rose into a sitting posture, her feet peeping from under the coverlet.

Both Griffiths and Lucid pitched good bal yesterday, but the Chicagos managed to bunch their hits, and in consequence won from the Brooklyns. The field work was sharp on both sides, and altogether the game was a pretty one to witness.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Saratoga form was vindicated here to-day in the second race, which was the feature of the day's sport, in spite of the fact that there were stakes on the card for decision. The race was a run of a mile and an eighth, with seven starters, Cactus and Blue Garter having been scratched.
ALBANY, N.T., Aug. 16 -- The following companies have been Incorporated with the Secretary of State:

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 16 -- A private letter received by the steamer Tacoma announces that the expectation among the English residents of Japan is that the great naval engagement of the war will be fought for the possession of Nagasaki, Japan, the best coaling station and the one nearest to China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Those who went to the Senate Chamber to-day expecting to witness lively scenes in connection with the "popgun" bills were disappointed. Routine matters alone occupied the attention of the Senate until 2 o'clock. There was a noticeable lack of interest on the floor of the chamber, and this gave to close observers in the galleries an intimation that an arrangement had been effected for disposing of the bills.

Park Commissioner Nathan Straus sat in his office at R. H. Macy Co.'s yesterday afternoon and for some time discussed the possibilities of uniting all factions of the democrats in this city and State in the approaching campaign.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

SOUTH BEACH, S.I., Aug. 16 -- Frederick Bergmann was shot and killed at his home at noon to-day, and the circumstances all tend to show that he was deliberately murdered by Thomas Burke, his father-in-law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The large unoccupied spaces on the floor of the hall of the House of Representatives to-day demonstrated more thoroughly than, any other fact could, probably, that the end of the session is near at hand. The attendance was about the same as on Friday night's pension session, and the presence of a quorum, it is believed, could not have been obtained.

John Unlicker and his wife, Maude, who were found helpless in Chambers Street on Wednesday night, were sent from Bellevue Hospital yesterday to the Charities and Correction Building, at Third Avenue and Eleventh Street.

The meeting of the Flushing Jockey Club ended yesterday, but racing will be continued at the Murray Hill track under the auspices of the Whitestone Jockey Club, which offers its initial programme to-day. The betting rlng will be shifted to the Whitestone side of the track, where it will remain to conform with the betting law during the present meeting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The four members of the Royal Hawaiian Commission who came here to secure redress for exQueen Liliuokalani, or to prevent the recognition of the new republic, have left for Honolulu.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Mr. Gladstone has written a reply to the address presented to him by the Liberal Federation on the ocasion of his retirement from office. He excuses himself for his delay in answering on the ground of the weakness of his eyesight. In referring to the summary of the achievements of his political lifetime contained in the address, Mr. Gladstone says:

The Hoboken Turtle Club ate, drank, and was merry at the King's Bridge Hotel yesterday. It was the third day's outing in commemoration of the ninety-eighth year of the club's existence, and it was notable because it had, as an accompaniment to its usual turtle-eating feats, a variety of dramatic artists who contributed to the fun, which continued all day.
Following is the text of that portion of the Tariff bill which provides for an income tax, as it passed both houses of Congress:
Democrats of standing from many counties of the State have declared, during the recent discussion of party harmony, that rival organizations are unknown in the section where they live.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The Constitutional Convention began to-day to put on he full head of steam and the high rate of speed which are expected to endure untill Sept. 15, when the final adjournment is expected to take place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A resolution offered yesterday by Mr. Kyle, (Pop., S. D.,) prohibiting the use and sale of intoxicating liquors in the Senate wing of the Capitol during the recess of Congress, was taken up to-day, and was the cause of an amusing debate.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- The Committee on Canals has about finished its work. The committee will to-morrow report favorably one very important amendment to Section 3 of Article VII. of the Constitution, which amendment reads:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 16 -- Gov. McKinley says, in discussing the new tariff law, that the action of the Democrats put the question of protection before the country as the great political issue in a more pronounced way than ever before. The friends of protection must see that proper protection is promptly restored in every industry that suffers from this legislation.

Mrs. Annie Alten, thirty-three years old, of 160 West Forty-fifth Street, is locked up in the Tombs charged by Nathan Arnold, a manufacturer of linings at 27 West Houston Street, with writing threatening letters to him. Arnold says that on June 23 Mrs. Alten wrote him a letter saying that it he did not send her picture to her she would go to his store and cause trouble.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Sugar Trust Senators are glad of any excuse for serving their employers. There may be excellent reasons for refusing to pass a freesugar bill, and Secretary Carlisle may have furnished the best of them, but, whatever they are, they prove agreeable to the men who have forced upon the Democratic Party a bill half made up, and disliked by the very men who did the forcing.

Circumstances alter cases. While it has been perfectly well known from the beginning of the tariff debates that a duty upon sugar was part of the Administration's policy, that commodity being a perfectly proper subject for revenue duty, it does not follow that an insistence upon that policy is either necessary or advisable now that the scandal of the Senate's dealing with the sugar schedule is known to the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- In the course of an editorial in this week's issue of The Bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association, James M. Swank, the general manager of the association, takes a hopeful view of the country's future under the operation of the new Tariff bill. Mr. Swank says:
TROMSOE, Norway, Aug. 16 -- Walter Wellman and his companions, with the crew of the wrecked steamer Ragnvald Jarl, arrived here yesterday from Spitzbergen aboard the fishing yacht Berntine.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The Berlin correspondent of The Daily News says that the negotiations for the Chinese war loan are still proceeding. A conference was held yesterday in which were represented several financial institutions, including the Disconto Gesellschaft and the Deutsche Bank, interested in the German-Asiatic Bank, whose manager, Herr Rinkel, has started for London on business connected with the loan.

RYDE, Aug. 16 -- Whatever chance the Vigilant may have had in the race to-day for the Ryde Town Cup, valued at $500, she was forced to sacrifice it in jockeying with the Britannia, which clung to her throughout the contest, occasionally forcing her into shallows, where in windward work she found it impossible to use the full depth of her board, and thus made leeway, which was beneficial to the Britannia.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- William Brookfield, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, has been here for two days, ostensibly to help the Constitutional Convention pass a measure that will protect the Adirondack forests from vandals and preserve its beauties for the benefit of the State.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The Republicans of Chemung County held their convention to choose delegates to the State and Congressional Convention at Horseheads this afternoon.

It would, perhaps, be going too far as yet to state that the American Association for the Advancement of Science is an equivalent of the British association which is organized and meets for a like purpose. But the City of Brooklyn was pervaded and permeated yesterday by just exactly such an atmosphere as that in which the incorporated wisdom and learning of Great Britain progress and thrive on their great holidays.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A report was made yesterday adverse to a resolution of Mr. Call (Dem., Fla.,) authorizing the Committee on Patents to sit during the recess to consider the patent laws and to visit such places as the committee may consider advantageous, gave rise to considerable discussion, involving the practice and propriety of "junketing trips of committees."

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Six days' notice of caucuses, published in local papers, both daily and weekly, and prominently posted in public places throughout the county would be sufficient, and where opposing factions exist harmony would be promoted by allowing each an Inspector and watcher.

All but the most sanguine among the woman suffragists must long ago have foreseen their defeat in the Constitutional Convention. There has at no time been any probability that the convention would vote to submit that proposition to the people. It is better that no further time should be wasted in the effort to confer suffrage upon women.

Miss Bessie Kirkland, known on the stage as Odette Tyler, arrived at this port from Europe yesterday morning on the steamship Havel. Gen. W. H. Kirkland, her father, said that she went to Europe simply for a pleasure trip, and that her engagement to Howard Gould, which was broken last Winter, had not been renewed and a renewal had not been contemplated.

The weather was cloudy and cool at Parkway yesterday. On the surface the track was dry, but the going was dead. Golden Valley, Aloha, and Elkwood were strong favorites in the first three races, and won, making a record for the talent as judges of form at this track.
From all classes of business men of NewYork there comes an urgent appeal to President Cleveland to sign the Tariff bill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- President Cleveland, in company with Dr. O'Reiliy, left Washington for Buzzard's Bay by the 7:10 train on the Pennsylvania Railroad this morning. Mr. Cleveland before leaving the city took no action on the Tariff bill beyond sending it to the Secretary of the Treasury for a report, as is customary with revenue bills.

The route for the twenty-flve-mile road race on Labor Day under the auspices of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey is announced to be as follows: Start from Morris Avenue, Elizabeth, N. J., at 11:30 A. M., thence to Springfield. Westfield, and Rahway, to Elizabeth, and turn and finish in Rahway at the Stone Bridge. The rider going over this course in the fastest time will get The New-York Times gold medal.

Herr Breitenstein took a rest yesterday and the Giants incidentally took a game from the St. Louis Browns. The day before the left-handed youth kept the NewYork batsmen fanning the atmosphere, but yesterday it was different, as Hawley was put in to pitch. On Wednesday their batting average suffered considerably, but they more than made up for the loss against the pitching of Hawley.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- There were still a number of women suffrage advocates about the Constitutional Convention Chamber to-day.

That Caserio has been put to death is a vindication of justice and civilization. That he died a craven death is still more favorable to the safety of society against wretches like himself. When he set out to kill Carnot he informed one of his intimates that he would die better than Henry did.

Senator Vest's speech in the Senate on Wednesday was notable and gratifying for several things. One of the most notable and gratifying is the demonstration it made that the Senator from Missouri felt himself to be on his defense before the country. That is a very wholesome attitude for almost any member of the Senate of the United States to be forced into taking just now.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- The full report of Santo Caserio's execution in Lyons this morning shows that he died less courageously than did Vaillant or Henry. When first brought before the examining magistrate in Lyons he boasted: "I am ready to be executed, tout I shall die bravely, not as did Henry. He faltered at the last."

The Committee of Thirty closed its enrollment books at 9 o'clock last night in the various election districts of the city, after having kept them open for two successive nights in the hope of catching large numbers of stray Republicans and Milholland men.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- The market started out this morning as if it were bent on higher prices. In the early trading Reading was most active. An attempt was made to depress it which was partially successful, for a while, but as soon as the pressure was off, buying orders appeared and the price advanced to the equivalent of 19 1/2, closing practically at that figure.

Solomon Steigman, a cigar dealer or 386 Seventh Avenue, complained to Inspector Conlin at Police Headquarters yesterday that Policeman Edward O'Neill of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station had refused to follow a thief when requested and had used abusive language. Steigman said that while sitting in front of his store Wednesday afternoon his wife saw a negro come from behind the counter.

The New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor maintains an admirable fresh-air work by the operation of the ocean party excursions and the Free Home for Ailing and Crippled Children.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- Tracy Becker of Bufalo, who is Chairman of the committee which has charge of the proposed amendment providing for a legislative reapportionment, to-day consented for the first time to talk on the work of the committee so far as it has advanced. He said:

Is Poland dead? The Sviet, which has always arrogated to itself the special duty of keeping a watchful eye upon the Poles, declares that there now exists nothing more than a merely passive and harmless feeling of resistance to Russian authority, and even this sentiment is confined to an insignificant section of the Polish nobility.

Ex-Senator J. Sloat Fassett arrived here on the night train from Elmira yesterday morning. He was interviewed by a reporter for The New-York Times, who found him in a particularly happy frame of mind, owing to the handsome manner in which his Republican friends in Chemung County treated him on Thursday night.

Creditors of Kraus Brothers, who kept sales stables at 338 to 342 East Fifty-ninth Street and two in Brooklyn, are very much exercised over their failure, which was reported on Aug. 10, and have taken legal means to protect their interests. The firm's liabilities are not definitely known, but are reported at over $50,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The gold reserve was increased to-day by $332,959, bringing it up to $53,112,902, the highest it has been since Aug. 3. A steady gain has been in progress since Aug. 8.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Treasury Department has invited proposals for striking 23,757 medals of award for exhibits at the World's Fair. The bids will be opened Sept. 5.

The Polled Commissioners resumed yesterday the combination trials pf Capt. Devery and Ward Man Glennon, Capt. Cross and Ward Man Smith, and Ward Man Burns, on changes of bribery and corruption. As on the previous days, Capt. Devery was absent and unrepresented by counsel. Glennon and Burns were defended by Friend House, and Capt. Cross and Smith by Charles A. Hess and ex-State Senator McClelland.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- From, present indications the plan to hold sessions of the Constitutional Convention on Saturday and Monday will prove an ignominious failure. Fifty-six delegates were excused for Saturday alone, and it is safe to add that twenty more delegates will absent themselves without leave.

Seventeen bookies had all the business that they could attend to at Parkway yesterday. The ring was crowded. A fair estimate placed the attendance at 2,500 to 3,000. The spectators were struck heavily by Susle R's defeat in the first event. She was an even-money favorite, but at no time was better than third at the finish, next to last, about twenty-five lengths behind the winner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Senate Committee on the Judiciary has again exercised its privilege of rejecting an appointment made by the President to a Judicial office, the nominee this time being James D. Porter, nominated to be United States Judge for the Eastern and Middle District of the State of Tennessee.

It is understood that the committee of the Constitutional Convention on Legislative Organizations has definitely decided upon increasing the number of Senators to 50 and the number of Assemblymen to 150. This will change the existing ratio between the two bodies from 1 to 4 to 1 to 3.

The Giants won a pretty game from the St. Louis team at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, the score being 7 to 6. It was a postponed contest, and handily filled in the open date. Rusle and Clarkson were the pitchers, and honors were about even between them. In the first three innings Rusle's curves were hit hard a runs resulting.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 17 -- Col. William A. Harris, the most unique figure in Georgia politics, died to-day. For forty years he had been connected with the Georgia Legislature, first as a Senator, and for twentyfive years as Secretary of that body. During that time he has been practically Czar of the Senate.

Some years ago the State took possession of the land adjacent to the Falls of Niagara for the purpose of preserving and protecting the natural features of scenery that constitute the setting of the great spectacle of the cataract. Since that time the right has been granted to a number of corporations to tunnel above the falls and draw off the water for various mechanical purposes.
Charles Robinson, the first Governor of the State of Kansas, died yesterday at his home near Lawrence, that State, after an illness of ten days. He was seventy-seven years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The rumor was freely passed around at the Capitol to-day that Secretary Carlisle would retire from the Cabinet, and that in his place would be Mr. Wilson of Weat Virginia.

NEWPORT, R.L., Aug. 17 -- Mrs. Ogden Mills gave a supper dance to-night, which was the particularly attractive entertainment to society this evening. The gathering was at 11 and the dance was till 2 A. M. The cottage was beautifully decorated with flowers, and the lawn was illuminated with Japanese lanterns.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Many priests and sisters were present at St. Joseph's Convent this evening, when twenty-four novices took the veil for life and eight young women entered upon their novitiate. Bishop McDonnell of Brooklyn presided at the services. He was attended by twelve priests.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 17 -- Old Father Time received another severe drubbing to-day at the second day's racing of the National League of American Wheelmen meet. Pour records were lowered yesterday, two of them important competitive records. Today four more important records fell, one of them twice, and another was the fivemile record of yesterday, from which four seconds were cut off in a Class A race.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- J.J. Couch, Special Deputy Collector of the Port of New-York, and Daniel McKeever, a wellknown tariff expert from that city, conferred with the Secretary of the Treasury with reference to the literal meaning of Section 2 of the pending bill, which concerns the duty on goods in bond before the approval of the act.

The new Tariff bill, if signed by the President as expected, provides a definite basis for business. No supplemental legislation is thought possible until next year at least. Large improvement has been expected from any settlement, the more because of a vast amount of business deferred from week to week in the hope of more definite conditions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Secretary Lamont has made an important change by which the recruiting service is entirely reorganized. The depots at Davids Island, N.Y.; Jefferson Barracks, St. Louis, and Columbus, Ohio, will be abandoned as depots, and will hereafter be garrisoned by troops from the line.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- In the Constitutional Convention to-day Augustus Frank, Chairman of the Banking and Insurance Committee, reported for printing the following amendment, proposed by Andrew H. Green:

The poor record has a bad time of it in Summer. It does not make any difference what kind of a record it is, trouble waits for it in hot weather. It may be an old and venerable record or it may be a young and giddy record, just arrived and brimful of pride and vainglory. It does not matter.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Le Journal says that the police have frustrated an Anarchist plot to assassinate Premier Dupuy. The Premier is in Vernet-les-Bains, not far from the Spanish border. He is accompanied by three Paris detectives, as rumors of a plot against his life have been numerous recently. The Anarchists had been warned of their danger the night before the police expected to arrest them, and fled to Spain.
The record of the long and fruitless proceedings of the tariff conference committee is incomplete without the following paragraph from the Washington correspondence of The Sun on the 15th inst.:

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Trading in stocks was heavy in almost everything on the list. For the first time in a long while West Side did not monopolize attention, but that does not mean that the stock was not dealt in largely. On the contrary, the transactions surpassed in amount the business done in these certificates on any day during the week.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Six locomotive firemen were arrested on their engines in the Long Island Railroad yards in this city this morning for burning soft coal. A number of engines were pouring out big clouds of black, smoke at the time, and on some of them the firemen were shoveling coal preparatory to taking out trains.

Hope in official quarters of an immediate large increase in the Treasury gold reserve has been modified somewhat by what is happening in respect to the movement of crops. Heretofore transfers of money to the South and West at this season have been made through the Sub-Treasury. The process was for the banks to deposit gold and the Treasury Department forwarded greenbacks to the applicants for money.
JERSEY CITT, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Fully 1,000 persons gathered in Bergen Square, on the Heights, this evening, to protest against the water supply.

A large crowd of Uncle Sam's postal employes had a gala time at Su Harlem River Park yesterday afternoon and evening. Shortly after 3 o'clock they had a set of games, and in the evening there were dancing and a good time generally. Many friends of both sexes joined in making the event a very pleasant one.

At least eighty-eight papers -- according to the press agent who is trying to follow the movements of the scientists -- were read yesterday before the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which is holding its annual meeting in Brooklyn this week. Furthermore, the returns were not in from all the meetings when a reporter for The New-York Times called at the press agent's office yesterday afternoon.

Democrats from many counties in the State have declared there is no need of any efforts to secure harmony, because it now exists. These present an array which, Including nearly one-half of the State, stands with solid front against the Republican forces in the approaching campaign.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- All yesterday the police here made domiciliary searches on the strength of information obtained through the arrest of fourteen Anarchists on Wednesday. The results were beyond all ex pectation. Many letters proving conclusively the intimate relations, if not the cooperation, of Berlin and Paris Anarchists, were seized, and much Anarchistic litera ture was destroyed or confiscated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Matters are fast coming to a head in the Senate with respect to the "popgun" measures. The Republicans and some of the Democrats have combined to block action upon all these bills. The Senate adjourned to-day, after a short session, because of this combination, and to-morrow it is expected that the test which must result from this union of the opponents of the bill will be brought about.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 17 -- The settlement of the tariff has given an immediate impetus to the development of the black plate and tin plate industry. Plans that have been held in abeyance for months are now being put into effect, and considerable eagerness is displayed to invest money in this direction.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Western tennis players ought to feel encouraged after such an honor as C. R. and S. B. Neel wan this morning by defeating the Yale champions, Arthur E. Foote and John Howland, who had defeated such a strong team as Wrenn and Chace for the Eastern championship yesterday. The Neels play an odd sort of a defensive game for the most part.

Our Republican friends would like to have the people forget some things which, we think, will not be forgotten for some time to come. They would like to have them forget that the Sugar Trust's differential protection of 1/8 of a cent a pound, in the new tariff, was saved for the Trust only by the vote of Mr. Quay, a Republican Senator.

RYDE, Aug. 17 -- The Vigilant did not sail in to-day's race around the Isle of Wight for the Commodore's Cup, valued at $400. She was entered, but as she had damaged the head of her mainsall in yesterday's contest, it was deemed advisable to devote the day to mending it and Preparing the sloop for her match race tomorrow, fifteen miles to windward and back, for the Wolverton Cup.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United States Sugar Trust Senate is ready to adjourn. The trust appears to have sent a message to that honorable attachment to the American Refineries Company, that it has no further business to communicate, and that it is at liberty to go away and get such rest as an indignant public will allow it to take.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- There has been no let-up in the fight for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Twentythird District. The whole contest turns upon the result in Essex County. Should Wallace Foote and his checkbook defeat Rowland Case Kellogg, a genuine revolution might result, Foote's election might be contested, and the claim for recognition thrown out of the Congressional Convention which will be held in this town next Thursday.

It Is doubtful which is the more -- or the less -- disturbed by the temporary residence in Sweeny's Hotel, Park Row, of Oliver Sumner Teall -- the Second District, which has gained him, or Fifth Avenue, which has lost him as a citizen. Happily for both, he is not going to stay long -- only just long enough to redeem the east side to the Republican Party.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 17 -- Representative Sayers of Texas, the Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, has submitted a comparative statement of the appropriations for the current fiscal year, which will be pointed in Saturday's Congressional Record. A brief summary of this statement appeared in The New-York Times of to-day. The full statement is as follows:

The stock market was somewhat broader than on Thursday, but still more than 63 per cent. of the trading was in the four stocks which have been the leading specialties ail the week -- Sugar, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, St. Paul, and Burlington. Outside of these, General Electric and Rock Island were the only stocks in which the transactions exceeded 10.000 shares.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Cities this afternoon, after consultation with the Committee on County, Town, and Village Organization, adopted a section on the limitation of the debts of counties and cities. The changes made in the present Constitution are as follows:

"The men we represent have money to invest. Your enterprise is promising and the returns likely to be satisfactory, according to the facts you submit. There is one preliminary, however, to be arranged. What security can you offer that you do not represent liars and swindlers?"

The narrow escape of the French steamer La Champagne from cutting down a Norwegian bark on the Grand Banks a few days ago calls attention once more to the need of some quick and certain method of communication between vessels in a fog. The accounts of the occurrence repeat the old statement that it is very difficult to tell in a fog the direction from which a sound comes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The report of the naval board which spent the month of July in testing machine guns was made public to-day.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- When David H. Perkins of Mansfield, in this State, was arrested at Dover, N.H., charged with attempting to sell a ten-thousand-dollar sugar certificate for 52,800, the accused said he received the certificate from his wife's sister, Mrs. Charles Waitt of Boston.

After many years of earnest endeavor and Steadfastness of purpose, Mr. Meredith still stands apart from the public, English and readers of English, whose favors make fortune and prodigious fame for the novelist. He is cheered by a comparatively small company of admirers, and since "Evan Harrington" there has even been a Meredith cult, which probably still exists in a flickering way, but has never helped its hero's fame very much with the multitude.
The steamship Campanis of the Cunard Line arrived at this port yesterday, breaking all records for the westward passage from Queenstown to New-York. Her time was 5 days 9 hours and 29 minutes.
There is but one sentiment among the business men of New-York in reference to the disposition to be made of the Tariff bill, which has passed Congress and is now in he hands of the President.

The committee of holders of the Kansas Pacific consolidated bondholders has issued a circular to the consolidated bondholders, stating that efforts are being made in the interest of the Trustees to obstruct action, for the benefit of the bondholders. The circular reviews the situation of the security in detail, and refers to the efforts of the reorganizers to provide for bonds not earning interest by a new general mortgage bond at 4 per cent.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17 -- Society ladies here had a catboat race to-day. It had been long talked of, and proved very exciting. Many of the cottagers were interested, and were out in small boats. J. J. Astor had a big party on his electric launch, the Progress, including Baron Le Ghait, Miss Bend, Miss Winthrop, Hamilton Cary, and Belmont Tiffany.

Senator Murphy's resolution declaring it to be the sense of the Senate that no further tariff legislation should be attempted this session undoubtedly reflects the views of all the Republican Senators, of all the Sugar Trust Senators, both Democratic and Republican, and of all the McKinley Democrats.

ALTOONA, Penn., Aus. 17 -- United States Bank Examiner Miller shot himself through the temple this afternoon, causing instant death, in the Second National Bank of this city. His home was at Mercer, Penn.

PUTNEY, Vt., Aug. 17 -- The barn on the farm of Dennison Davis, sixty-five years old, a wealthy resident of this town, was burned late last night, and Mr. Davis claims that during the fire $6,000 was stolen from his house.

TIFFIN, Ohio, Aug. 17 -- John B. Gormley, assignee of the Foster interests, filed his first report with Probate Judge Kiskadden to-day. The document embodies a plea on the part of the ex-Secretary of the Treasury to be released from the entanglements which he dropped into by indorsing paper for the firms in which he is interested.

Frederick Tuttle, twenty-four years old, a lineman on the Brooklyn Heights Railroad, was burned about the face, hands, and body yesterday by coining in contact with a wire over which was passing a current of 500 volts. Tuttle was repairing a wire at Division and Kent Avenues. His wrench was not properly insulated, and through this the current reached his body.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A dispatch from Paris to the Exchange Telegraph Company says that Prince Emmanuel of Orleans was arrested in Bordeaux to-day while on his way to visit Emperor Franz Joseph of Austria.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- It was an off, day at the track to-day, the card being made up of races for the poorest class of horses. Yet there was fairly good sport and lively betting. Necidah won the opening dash of five furlongs, much to the regret of the plungers, who had made Buck Massie and Achiever the favorites.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- Local stocks were active, and prices generally higher. Wisconsin Central 5s were firm at 55. Bell Telephone rose 1, to 201, the highest price since the decline. Erie Telephone was quiet at 46. Boston and Albany rose 1 1/2, to 20S. Fitchburg preferred sold at 70. West End Street Railway advanced 1 1/4, to 52 3/4, and was strong at that figure.

Four persons were severely burned at a fire at 83 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Ludwig Klein has a grocery store on the ground floor, with living apartments above it. His fourteen-year-old daughter Sarah was leaning out of the real window, and, in shifting her position, she knocked over an oil stove.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 17 -- World's records went by the board again to-day. Alix, the phenomenal trotter, carrying off the honors by beating the world's race record in either a pace or a trot by winning in the great time of 2:06, 2:06 1/4, and 2:05 1/4. This reduced the mare's record from 2:07 3/4 to 2:03 1/4, equaling Directum's mark of the latter figure.
Eugene Lawrence, author and historian, died yesterday at his home, 340 West Nineteenth Street, this city.

There was a quiet little family affair at Jerome Park yesterday, and "Willle" Sims, the jockey for the Dwyer-Croker combination, was the medium through which five of the horses owned by the "family" were piloted in to first place. Five successive victories is a record of which any jockey might be proud, and that Sims accomplished yesterday.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 18 -- If the people continue to come during the rest of the month in such numbers as at present, the season of 1894 will have been the most successful in the history of Nantucket. There have been several excursions weekly from various towns on the cape, which have brought several hundred visitors a day to the island.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Charles L. Fair, surviving son of ex-Gov.
