Fair, began another effort in the Probate Court to-day to secure $1,000,000 of his mother's estate, the amount being the aggregate legacy of his deceased brother and himself. Mrs. Fair left $500,000 to each of her sons, James to receive his at thirty-five and Charles when thirty years of age.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The most interesting regatta of the season of the Shrews bury Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon. Wind and weather were all that could be desired, and the yachtsmen's hearts were glad. A number of special prizes had been presented by Edward Kemp, the club's Commodore, and there were other trophies given by the local club.

The Inter-State cycle meet at the Trenton (N. J.) Fair Grounds on Saturday, Aug. 25, has over 200 actual entries, which easily makes it the biggest event of the season in that vicinity. The feature of the races is conceded to be The New-York Times club team contest for the championship of this State, New-Jersey, and Pennsylvania.

The clubs of young women in the country are coming distinctly to the front. The Civitas Club in Brooklyn, in its brief half-year of existence, has made for itself a name widely known, and its promise for future good work is assured and bright. In another city, Chicago, is a club of ma- trons, the Fortnightly, whose fame is extensive, going beyond the limits of the club-woman's world.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 18 -- The second geman of the season was given by E.M. Earle at the Earlington this evening. The whole house was brilliantly Illuminated, and the grand dining hall, where the dancers assembled, was banked with greens, tropical plants, and flowers. The dancing was led by Robert L. Crawford of New-York, and he mingled several new and very pretty figures with old favorites.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Although Parliament will not rise for a week, all interest in its proceedings is dying out. The party debates are ended, and only the annual supplies necessary for the expenses of administration are left to be voted.

The venerable adage to " make haste slowly" is held in particular esteem in Middle Village, Conn., as applied to the matter of becoming acquainted. The Middle Villagers are true conservatives. Thus: It was early Spring when a little colony of young New-York people came up to this rural corner and established themselves in an old abandoned parsonage, there to keep house and write articles and paint landscapes and raise a vegetable garden.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Aug. 18 -- An event of unusual interest, marking the height of the season here, took place last Saturday afternoon. The coaching parade was the result of a scheme formulated the previous week by the young people at the Wiscasset and carried to a successful termination by them.

I have seen much of the grandest scenery in the world, but I doubt if any land can rival in picturesque beauty the lovely valleys that lie between the ramparts of the Alleghany and Cumberland ranges, stretching from tHe Ohio south till they fall away into foothills in Georgia and Alabama.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- A cable dispatch from London to The Herald says:

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The Fresh Air and Convalescent Home of this place, for the benefit of which many entertainments have been given of late by the fashionable folk of this vicinity, is very soon to enjoy a more substantial and valuable addition to its already commodious quarters by the building of a number of delightfully-arranged little cottages, which are to be devoted exclusively to the care and treatment of infants.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18 -- September promises to be one of the liveliest Lenox has seen since the time, when ex-Secretary Whitney occupied the old Haggerty place. This season people who went to the seashore made their stay shorter than usual. There is already a large number of guests at the Various cottages. They always formed the most exclusive society, and are more and more exclusive every year.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 18 SHELTER ISLAND never had a gayer crowd than at pressent. Frequent rains have freshened the lawns and flowers. Young people are numerous, and enthusiasm seems to be the characteristic of every phase of life.
The National Conservatory of Music of America will hold its annual examinations as follows:

MOLDE, Norway, July 28 -- A previous letter told the readers of The Times about the journey of the excursionists on the Augusta Victoria across the Atlantic, about their short stay at Hamburg, about their arrival in the Land of the Midnight Sun, and about their progress up the coast as far as Bergen.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 18 -- The long-talked-of cotillion took place here last Saturday and was a charming affair. The ballroom was beautifully decorated with flags and streamers, and large branches of goldenrod and potted plants, and from the ceiling were hung Japanese lanterns of every shape and color.

Details of a daring robbery, accompanied by violence and brutality, that occurred in an unoccupied furnished flat at 256 West Thirty-ninth Street, July 31, came to light through the arrest on Friday night of John Deegan, twenty-six years old, who describes himself as a clerk, and who, at the time of his arrest, was living in seclusion at 5 Walton Avenue, Morrisania.

LYONS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- At the Republican County Convention, held here this afternoon, resolutions were unanimously adopted indorsing Senator Saxton as the unanimous choice of the Republicans of Wayne County for the nomination for Governor. The convention requested Senator Saxton to select and present to the convention tie names of the delegates and alternates to the Republican State Convention.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 18 -- The Georgia Pacific Railroad was sold under foreclosure in this city to-day. It was bid in by C.H. Coster of New-York, who announced that be purchased it for the Southern Railway Company, which Drexel, Morgan Co. have lately reorganized out of the old Richmond Terminal.

NEWPORT, Aug. 18 -- The annual coaching parade took place to-day. The coaches were assembled on Narragansett Avenue, and long before the starting time, 12:45, crowds gathered along the line of the parade.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug 18 -- The Crescent Wheelmen held their August meeting this afternoon. Their oval was in first-class condition, even better than at previous meets. There were several spills, but only two were of a serious nature. In the one-mile handicap, when on the homestretch, T.S. Darling fell. Be was riding out from the bunch, and the only one injured was himself.

The name Dunmow, in association with a flitch of bacon, long ago passed into a proverbial expression, but what is popularly known regarding the origin and purpose of the quaint ceremony attanding the presentation may be briefly described as vague and indefinite. Most people seem to regard it as merely a curious and unmeaning custom, unworthy the notice of individuals of a practical turn of mind.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Charles S. Vandusen for several years humorist editor of The Morning News of this city, and later night editor of The Palladium, left his home. 599 George Street, shortly after lunch yesterday, and has not been seen by the members of his family since. Editor Vandusen used crutches. Yesterday afternoon a man answering his description hired a small open boat at Tomlinson Bridge and rowed down the harbor.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- At all the Republican town caucuses throughout St. Lawrence County, to-day delegates were elected for the County Convention who will support Gen. N.M. Curtis for Congress and George R. Malby for Assembly.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- The steamer China, which arrived from the Orient this afternoon, brings advices to Aug. 7.

The County Convention of the Socialist-Labor Party was held last night at the Labor Lyceum, 64 East Fourth Street. One hundred and sixty delegates were present. The Chairman of the meeting was F.H. Martin. The following candidates were nominated for the Fall elections:

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 18 -- A lawn party was given at Eagle Rock, Monday evening, by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Harris, in honor of their little daughter. Miss Flossie Harris. Among the guests were Miss Sarah Hillman and Benjamin Hillman of Chicago; the Misses Berla and Moses G.W. Berla of Newark, the Misses Sullivan and George Greason, Jr., of Eagle Rock; Mrs. Heinaman, Mrs. Harris, Mrs. Wells, and Mrs. Snow of East Orange.

PORT KENT, LAKES CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., Aug. 18. IF you asked the average New-Yorker what he knew about Port Sable Chasm, and the scenery surrounding beautiful Lake Cham plain, he would say, "Very little," and yet this part at the Empire State is full of interesting natural wonders.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 18. -- Advices from the Yukon River district up to July 1 have been received here. Capt. Lyon, who has gone down the Yukon River to take command of the steamboat P.B. Ware and four other men were capsized and drowned at Five Finger Rapids.

The inmates of a tenement house in Brooklyn were saved from death by fire this last week by a cat that save the alarm and roused her mistress. It is not the first instance of the kind which has happened In or near New-York. Those who regard cats as stupid animals should know more of their history, which is good proof of their intelligence.

'A' very curious frame of mind was developed on the part of Mr. August Seel, Jr., by some proceedings in the Jefferson Market Police Court on Friday. Mr. Seel is a member of the Young Men's Christian Association. This fact not only did not prevent him from fabricating and uttering forged checks, but he seems to have thought that he could use it in his business.
Thousands who cross the Brooklyn Bridge dally are wondering what the Improvements at each end of the bridge are for and when they will be finished.

The London Sunday Times says: "The United States will be visited during the Winter by a number of our best-known concert artists. Despite the serious commercial crisis, the Americans seem to be able to find money readily enough when anything good in the way of music comes along.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 So great is the throng of visitors here at present that the additional presence of several organizations scarcely attracts more than passing attention, and in this respect Saratoga closely resembles New-York.

The big sailing ship General Knox, which has braved storms and other ocean perils of the deep throughout a dozen years, yesterday met with disaster while moored to an East River pier. Fire ravaged, her inflammable cargo, and it was only by great efforts on the part of the Fire Department that the ship itself was saved.

WEST CAMPTON, N.H., Aug. 18 -- This has been a very pleasant season at the Stag and Hounds, the delightfully unconventional Summer hotel conducted here for so many years by Mr. E.H. Sanborn. Some new faces have been seen, but the greater number of guests have been families whose fondness for the place is of many years standing, and who have been accustomed for more than a decade to greet each other here.

I sometimes think of presentments as a sort of intellectual mirror; the truth is hove up, coastlike, beyond the boundaries of the mental vision, and you feel its presence though you may be unable to distinguish its character.

The grand Wagner festival of the Semi Society in the Brighton Beach Music Hall will commence next Tuesday evening. This is neither a mendicant nor a commercial essay, and, while money will be welcomed and devoted at once to the purposes of the festival, it will be accepted in the interest of popular musical education and development in trained cognizance of the most refining of all arts.

The announcement that The Saturday Review has changed hands is not at all unexpected and not at all unwelcome. The paper has been going for some years from bad to worse, it has apparently fallen off very much as a property, and it has become evident, as has so often been said about an even more august and venerable British institution, that it must "mend or end."

Over the gateway or the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church is a sign on which is inscribed: "Wanted, 500 boys, between the ages of ten and twenty-one years, as recruits in the Baptist Boys' Brigade. Apply here, Monday evening, between 8 and 9 o'clock."

G.S. Scally, the leader of the Third District in the State Democracy organization, is a special agent at the Custom House. He lives at 186 Chrystie Street, and was at one time a member of Tammany Hall. He said:
FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 18 EVERY form of pleasure that the seaside can afford is enjoyed here. The gayety that has prevailed so far this promises to continue until the end of the season.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 18 -- The closing half hour of the Denver Wheel Club and the League of American Wheelmen National Tournament was made brilliant by a series of record-breaking trials. The day's races had been excellent in every way. One record only was broken in competition. This was the mile, Class A, by Louis A. Callahan, who won a heat in 2:11 4-5.

From The Baltimore Herald. Thirty-seven parrots and a monkey formed part of the Gated which Capt. H.B. Eaton of the barkentine Geneva brought into this port from Orchilla. He entered the parrots at the Custom House as being valued at $68. They come in free, but, if he wants to land the monkey, the latter will be liable to a duty of 20 per cent.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 18. GLORIOUS the weather of the past week has been, and everybody who owned or could borrow a horse has made the most of it in driving through the beautiful country.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- The market for local stocks was not active, but prices were generally firm, though no special feature was developed. Mexican 4s advanced 1/2 , to 57 1/2 , with the stock 1/8 up, at 8 1/8 . Erie Telephone was quiet, at 46. Boston and Albany was firm, at 208, and Boston and Maine was off 1, to 146.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- The grand Fall parade of the Garde du Corps took place on the Pempelhofer Feld. The Emperor was accompanied on horseback by the Empress, who wore the uniform of her own Pasewalk Cuirassiers. With them rode the whole imperial suite in the glory of full gala dress. The review was as imposing as ever.

TRENTON, Aug. 18 -- Dog days in New-Jersey have not interfered with the plottings of the politicians, and the campaign is already under way. The election of members of Congress, six Senators, and a House of Assembly on the county basis, which will vote for a new United States Senator, are the elements of importance that enter into this campaign and give to it zest.

In Mr. Anthony Hope's "The Prisoner of Zenda" there was an endless amount of action. It was a transformation of the nineteenth century into the sixteenth. Rapiers flashed, and there was the merriest clicking of steel, with innumerable gasconnades in the true d'Artagnan method. The wonder was how well the business was managed, for if Alexandre Dumas was not redivivus, at least he was happily recalled.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 18 -- By a decision filed in the Clerk's office by Justice Bartlett of the Supreme Court to-day, the title of Stephen B. French, ex-Police Commissioner of New-York, to property in Sag Harbor now valued at $40,000 becomes void. Christopher C. Loomis was in 1873 the owner of certain lots of land in Sag Harbor, which he mortgaged for $1,000 to George D. Whittlesey, an ex-Postmaster of New-London.

John S. Dodge claims to have made some very interesting history which has never been published. He enlisted at the age of fifteen years in the Sixth Massachusetts, one of the three-month regiments, and was wounded and taken prisoner at the first battle of Bull Run. After his release he recruited Company G, Eleventh Maine Infantry, and was made Lieutenant.
A noted Jailbird, known as "Red" Goss, was arrested yesterday after being chased, besieged, and finally clubbed by the policemen who captured him.

From The London Telegraph. Romance was eclipsed by reality in the case heard this morning by the Judges of the Second Civil Chamber. A Mile. Maquet put in a claim for L6,000, the amount of a legacy bequeathed her by a M. Poncault, Who recently died in America. Poncault's career was a strange one.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: It seems to me that in their effort to spur the Democratic Senators to approve of the House bill as fitly representing the views of the Democracy and fulfilling its pledges, many Democratic newspapers have made a serious mistake in asserting that the acceptance of the Senate measure by the House would discredit and dishonor the party, and endanger its future success.

They have been, much laughed at, and perhaps they deserve it where they attempt to tie on the Milesian, race to Magog, second son of Japhet; but the Irish were not the only mediaeval people who tried the same feat. When the pagan nations became Christian, they wanted to enter in some way into the history of the past; not to be entirely left out of the plan of God's dealing's with man.
ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA, Aug. 18 THE week has been full of interest. Dinners, receptions, yachting, parties, and beach parties have followed each other in quick succession.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 18 -- After a great week, witnessing the smashing of many world's records and the distribution of the largest aggregate purses -- $91,000 -- in the history of the American trotter, the meeting ended this afternoon in a rainstorm that prevented two of the three events of the card from being completed. John Splan's black gelding Newcastle won the 2:30 trot as he pleased.

The article which appeared in The New-York Times of last Sunday upon the exodus of Brooklyn clergymen and the dearth of ministers of the Gospel in the City of Churches at the present time received much attention and caused no little discussion.
A correspondent addresses as the following query concerning the income-tax provisions of the Senate Tariff bill:
William H. Vogel shot Louise B. Bartlett yesterday afternoon and used the weapon twice upon himself. One bullet entered his right side and the other his left side, near the heart, killing him.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The Orange Athletic Club easily outplayed the Oritani Field club at the Orange Oval this afternoon in a ball game witnessed by 3,000 persons. The score:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 18 -- The week at the George, Black Rock Beach, has been a delightful one. The hops have been well attended, the cool evenings making dancing very enjoyable. Tennis, pool, progressive hearts, ten pins, and shuffle-board help to pass the time.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 18 -- The sliver anniversary of the Ocean Grove auxiliary to the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society was celebrated to-day. Mrs. Dr. E.H. Stokes presided. The opening prayer was made by Mrs. William Skidmore of New-York, and a Scripture reading followed by Mrs. Bishop Harris. A number of returned missionaries addressed the audience with reference to their work in the foreign field.
The Democratic State Convention has been called, and now the town caucuses will soon be in order.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 18 -- This week has been the gayest the Hot Springs has ever known. The weather has been delightful. The event of the week was the german given on Tuesday evening and led by Mr. Edward Hanawinkle of Richmond and Mrs. H.C. Rutter of New-York. The ballroom was beautifully decorated with cornstalks, catstails, spruce trees, and flowers, reminding one more of a large garden than a ballroom.

Upon a certain spot on the lawn of one of my neighbors, year after year, without fall, there springs up a most singular crop. For the first two years of its appearance it was looked upon with curious awe by the proprietors of the premises, and usually ignominiously spurned with the foot by the indiscriminating and destructive small boy.

There was a very significant incident in the proceedings of the Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee last week, which conveys a warning to the party that ought not to be overlooked. When the Finance Committee met to consider the Free Sugar bill sent over from the House, the Republican members unexpectedly declined to vote to report it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Thomas W. Heathcote, Chairman of the Pullman Strike Committee, resumed the stand at the opening of this morning's sitting of the National Labor Commission. It cost the Pullman employes, Mr. Heathcote said, $4,000 to join the American Railway Union. Each of the 4,000 employes paid $1 for a membership card.

The series of match races begun by the American Jockey Club are beginning to look like nice, soft sports for the public to drop their money, for the second of the series, between Dobbins and Dorian, was won easily by the latter yesterday, much to the regret of the confiding public, who bet thousands of dollars on the Croker candidate.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- One of the best racing cards of the year was offered at the track here to-day, the feature being the running of the Moet Chandon Handicap at a mile, in which the four best handicap horses of the year met, with Yo Tambien, the speedy Western mare, giving weight to all the others.

This has been a great season for cycling, records, but there are meetings yet to come, notably the twenty-five-mile handicap road race over the nevr Elizabeth-Rahway course, that promise extraordinary time. This event will take place on Labor Day, and an unusually large number of prominent road men have signified an intention to compete.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- The revolt which was alluded to in this morning's New-York Times broke out this afternoon, when the Democrats discovered that only 83 out of the 168 delegates to the Constitutional Convention were present.

Gossip of National Guardsmen yesterday was about the following manifesto, which was drawn up Friday night at the Tompkins Market Armory and signed by Capts. William Desmond of Company L.T.F. Lynch of Company K. John McCauley of Company A. Charles Healey of Company I, and Edward T. McCrystal of Company B. of the Sixty-ninth Regiment:

S.H.M. Bvers in McClure's Monthly. When we reached the Cape Fear River, in the Carolinas, we found there (at Fayetteville) a splendid arsenal, built in former times by the United States. Now it was used for making arms to destroy the Government. Sherman burned it to the ground, but first he took me all through the building, and explained its complicated machinery and apparatus.
MANCHESTER, N.H. Aug. 18 -- The Amoskeag Manufacturing Company will start running in every department Monday, Aug. 27, forty hours per week. This means work for 2,000 more operatives.

It is a long time since there was such, an active day on a Saturday as yesterday. The sales amounted to over 165,000 shares, and practically everything dealt in advanced. As visual, the principal activity was in the four specialties -- Sugar, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, St. Paul, and Burlington -- but there was a fair amount of business in the general list.

The Trustees of St. John's Guild gratefully acknowledge many prompt responses from thoughtful and generous friends of the little ones to their recent appeal through the newspapers. A partial list of those who contributed to "name trips" on the Floating Hospital is here given:
NEW-LONDON, Aug. 18 PEQUOT HOUSE is a that of the Summer home of well-known society people, but the house has never had as brilliant a season as that of the past two months.

CITY ISLAND, Aug. 18 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Embia, John H. Hanan; Viking, H.A. Hutchins; Linta, Walter Luttgen; Marietta, H. B. Moore; Helvetia, C. O'D. Iselin; Halcyon, Andrew R. Culver; Hirondelle, C.G. Evans; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg, and Empress, F. A. Schermerhorn. Schooner yacht Atlantic, C. Barnum Seeley.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The first assembly, in the Town Hall on Monday, and the full-dress concert given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Van Lennep last night, have been the chief events of the week. The dancing room in the Town Hall was prettily decorated for the assembly, which proved to be a great success.

T.O. Moore in Blue and Gray. The following story, recently related to me by Capt. Ben T. Wright, will, I trust, prove interesting to all old soldiers, North and South, and to all Americans who revere the memory of the grand old silent soldier, U.S. Grant. I relate it as it was told me:

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- If a person who had not visited Sing Sing Prison within the past six months should call there today he would hardly know the place, except that the long main portion, where the galleries are, will strike him as familiar, but all the other externals are so changed that it is hard to remember just how the old place looked.

It is evident that the Federation of Woman's Clubs has reached a stage where its influence can be felt. Mrs. Brown, its first President, said in her farewell address last May, in Philadelphia, that on her shoulders and those of her associate officers had been the burden of organization; to those who should come after would be the benefits of accomplishment.

The champion cricket team of the New-Jersey Athletic Club expected a close struggle with the Manhattans yesterday at Prospect Park, and was agreeably surprised when it found itself a victor by 100 runs.

D.B. Dickinson, a naturalist and taxidermist, who lives on the banks of the Passale River, near Chatham, N.J., has for years been engaged in the cultivation of owls. He has what may be termed an "owlery." He used to raise owls by inducing old birds to nest upon his place. The inducements he offered were in attractive sections of hollow logs, closed at the ends and provided with convenient holes.

William M. Benger, said to have formerly been a Methodist clergyman, was charged in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday with renting apartments in the Dore art fiats at 141 to 151 West Thirty-fifth Street, of which he is part owner, to disorderly persons. The complainant was Mrs. Sarah Neville, who said Mr. Benger deceived her when she rented an apartment from him by saying that all his tenants were respectable.

The scientists who are holding a convention in Brooklyn went on an excursion on the steamer Mary Patten yesterday up the Shrewsbury River to Pleasure Bay. The steamer left the Battery Pier at 9:30 A.M., having 210 learned persons aboard, mostly members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

From The Boston Journal. One of the prettiest sights of a Summer evening in the country is a meadow covered with a swarm of flitting fireflies. Many intensely practical people have laughed at any suggestion that this firefly light could be utilized in any way by man. Yet scientists have long been at work on the problem, and one of the number, Secretary Langley of the Smithsonian Institution has arrived at some startling conclusions.

We cannot believe what we see, for nothing is more deceptive than sight. Of all our senses it is the most misleading. Look at Figure 1 and study it a little. The horizontal lines appear crocked, bending to each other toward the ends, when in Figure 2 they widen apart at the ends. If the paper is held so that the eye looks lengthwise of the lines they are parallel.

The theory which gives to the Lords coordinate power with the lower house precludes their interference with the elections of members of the Commons, and they are forbidden to take any part in the construction of the People's Chamber. Nevertheless, some peers do interfere and exert their influence in favor or against some particular candidate.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- [Copyright, 1894.] -- There is very little change in the condition of the money market. Preparations for the disbursement of about six millions in railway dividends to-day and the Stock Exchange settlement scarcely affected rates. Discounts are only a fraction harder, and short-time money is still lent at one-quarter of 1 per cent.

Chicago Aug. 18 -- Four French exhibitors who had goods in the Manufactures Building at the time of the fire Jan. 8 have sued the World's Columbian Exposition Company for damages. The complainants say that at the time of the fire their wares were packed ready for shipment, and had been for some time. The amount of dam- ages claimed is $16,000.

What police officer is to be tried when the cases against Capts. Devery and Cross are concluded? That was the question which agitated police circles yesterday to the exclusion of all others, but it was not answered.

STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 18. COOL, almost frosty nights, and the song of the katydid, unfailing signs of apProaching Fall, seem to have created a feeling among the hundreds of gay people Sere that all enJoyment possible must be had while the season lasts.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- To-day's single session was a lively one. It was also notable in that the industrials were all very active. New-York Biscuit, generally a quiet stock that does not record sales of more than a couple of hundred shares, was especially conspicuous. Opening at 54, 1 1/2 points over yesterday's price, it sold at the former figure for a few transactions.

New-York ball players had an excellent opportunity to gain on the leaders yesterday, but they failed to embrace it. In other words, they met Anson's team of Colts from Chicago, and the latter played all around the Gothamites. They won the first game with Stratton pitching against German, in a most skillful manner
NARRAGANSETT PIER, Aug. 18 -- Among the recent arrivals from New-York are these:

The committee of Savannah and Western Railroad bondholders, headed by Simon Borg and R.C. Martin, has succeeded in securing from the Georgia Central Reorganization Committee an offer of 90 per cent., in place of 80 per cent., as was originally proposed. New incomes, it is said, to the amount of 15 per cent., will also be given.

With the goldenrod blossoming by the wayside and the katydid singing in the trees, there is perhaps, an excuse to turn one's thoughts toward Autumn, although the midsummer sun still shines in the heavens, and the air has lost little of its fervid heat. Fashion-makers must always be forehanded, and already, while pretty women are gowning themselves in airy laces and gossamer tissues and gauzes, the models for Fall frocks are beginning to be seen.

Mr. Beerbohm Tree is spending his holiday in Marienbad; Mr. George Alexander has gone to Sherringham in Norfolk, and among other well-known actors who are enjoying the vacation season in the same district is Miss Olga Nethersole, who is bracing herself up for her provincial tour and subsequent American engagement.

Mr. J. Hampden Dougherty has talked with a reporter of The Brooklyn Eagle on the question of Democratic harmony, but he differs from The New-York Times. He says that "The Times is always bright and readable and usually sagacious in its Judgment, but he cannot fully indorse its sentiments respecting harmony."

Balloons have played an important part in war for more than a century. In the French Revolution they were used with success. Gen. Jourdan is said to have won the battle of Fleurus by observations taken from a balloon, which, after surveying the Austrian lines, was brought down by means of a windlass.

The Imperial Hotel, at Broadway and West Thirty-second Street, has become the home of a mystery -- a mystery which so far defies solution and threatens to stay, though destitute of oaggage. One of the most aristocratic hotels of New-York, it has been invaded, without notice, by a romance, which has, so far, failed to pay for itself in advance.

From the New-York Navy Yard yesterday there came the thunder of many guns. The salutes announced the arrival of the dispatch boat Dolphin, from whose mainmast truck rippled the broad pennant of the Secretary of the Navy.

ANTWERP, July 28 -- It is generally admitted that the principal feature and gem of the Belgian exhibition is the part known as "Old Antwerp," or, in the quaint Flemish dialect, "Oud Antwerpen." Until within a comparatively recent period, Antwerp was a city of irregrular and picturesque streets. No town was dearer to the heart of the romantic writers of 1830.

After running away to Bristol, where he bound himself as a servant for four years, he was duly transported to Barbados and there sold. Having faithfully served his term, he shipped himself to Jamaica, determined to follow his naturel bent in the direction of piracy, and at once found a satisfactory engagement.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Arrived -- Steamers Tillie, New-York Yacht Club, W.H. Star-buck, from New-York; Aida. New-York Yacht Club, W.P. Douglass. Schooner Edith of New-York. Sloops Twilight and Katrina.

Racing wheelmen will be interested in the list of prizes offered for the Good Roads tournament at Asbury Park on Aug. 30, 31, and Sept. 1. No such collection of desirable articles has been "hung up" for competition this Bauson. The list la headed by The New-York Times, which gives a gold medal of unusually attractive design tor "green" riders to struggle for.

HIGHLAND BEACH, N.J., Aug. 18 -- This place is becoming a favorite excursion resort. It has features, perhaps, that no other resort on the Atlantic coast possesses. On the east is the mighty Atlantic and on the west the pacific Shrewsbury, flowing from Sandy Hook Bay past the riverside retreats, Navesink Highlands, Oceanic, Fair Haven, and Red Bank.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The American refineries mustered in force in the Senate to-day, and by the direction of such a skillful adjutant as German there was a dress parade and a demonstration of force calculated to meet with the entire approval of the Sugar Trust and its allies in and out of the United States Sugar Trust Senate.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- This week usually marks the height of the season, from the standpoint of both the hotel proprietor and the devotee of society.

ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- There has been plenty to do this week for even the most fastraious fun seeker. With the season at its height, the hotel and cottages crowded, it isn't possible for Elberon to be dull.

TOTLAND BAY, Aug. 18 -- The original intention of the committee in charge of the match race between the Britannia and the Vigilant for the Wolverton Cup was to have the racers towed to the starting point by the royal steam yacht Osborne and Mr. Gould's Atalanta. There was enough breeze from the northwest, however, to allow the yachts to put out from the rendezvous here under their own sail.

PARIS, Saturday, July 21 -- A kind American friend took me to-day to a new and delightful cycle resort. True to his native Christopher-Columbus-discovery instinct, he had found, he said, a garden of roses, honeysuckle, and pansies, with a montagne russe possibility thrown in Where one could learn to pedal or run races at will.

The Washington Star observes: "If the sculptors believe that they are going to have an easy time preparing or procuring designs for the new dollar, they will find themselves much mistaken. One reason why the work of designing has always been given to the mint engraver is that the designing of medallic work requires a peculiar knowledge, which few engravers and fewer artists possess.

A meeting of citizens of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards was held Aug. 14 in Loeffler Hall, Willls Avenue, to further protest against the Riker's Island nuisance. Many well-known people spoke in denunciation of the officials who permit the nuisance to exist with a full knowledge of its unpleasant and detrimental effects.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- F.W.J. Hurst, the well-known yachtsman, said tonight that the race to-day between the twenty-one-footers was the finest he ever saw. Many others here are of that opinion. The breeze was due south, and blowing so heavily that when scudding before it, the frail craft were lifted out of the water so far that one could almost see their fins.

Mr. Hastings was the copy of our ancient nobility. In hunting, but not in warlike, times. His house was perfectly of the old fashion, in the midst of a large park; a bowling green in it, lone but narrow, full of high ridges, it being never leveled since it was plowed; they used round sand bowls, and it had a banqueting house like a stand, a large one built in a tree.

PALMYRA, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Wayne County primaries will toe held under the following- rules, framed one year ago, being the resolution adopted at the Democratic County Convention held at Newark Sept. 26, 1893:

WALTON, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The beautiful new Methodist Episcopal Church in this village, which has just been dedicated by Bishop Cyrus D. Foss of Philadelphia, is with the exception of the Gould Memorial Church at Roxbury, the finest church edifice ever erected in Delaware County. It is colonial in style, the south corner being surmounted by a tower 90 feet high, with a smaller tower on the opposite corner.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Commissioners Bailey, Reeves, and McKinstry of the State Civil Service Commission were in session here all day, at work upon a reclassification of the positions in the State service. It will be some weeks before the work will be fully completed, although great progress was made to-day.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 18. -- This has been simply an ideal week here. The weather for once has been almost perfect. During the day the temperature was seldom more than 76, and at night-time it has teen ten degrees cooler. The water, however, has been at the very desirable temperature of 72 every day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Edward H. Thompson, member of Assembly from the First District of Dutchess County, now serving his second term, and a prominent financier and politician of Eastern Dutchess County, has resigned as President of the Millerton National Bank and executed a deed transferring his real estate, which is valued at a large sum, to the bank, the consideration named being merely nominal.

Lowell's friendship with Poe was not destined to good fortune. There had been mutual good-will and respect, with kindly offices, on both sides. The connection of Poe with Briggs in the editorial conduct of The Broadway Journal was the occasion of an exchange of views and facts between Briggs and Lowell which left Poe's reputation very much impaired in Lowell's judgment.

From The Memphis (Tenn.) Appeal-Avalanche. I can close my eyes and see it now as I saw it then -- the dark-brown waters of the bayou, flowing sluggishly southward between the steep and bushy banks; the dusty road on the further side, and beyond that the wide flat overgrown with palmettos, and bordered on the rear with a stretch of forest that to my boyish mind had no limit of length or breadth.

The Fall yachting season will open here in a few days. The yachts that went to the East during the Cruise of the New-York Yacht Club are returning as fast as possible, and will take part in the regattas already scheduled for the end of August and the month of September.

WEST POINT, Aug. 18 -- The past week has been an unusually pleasant one in the Highlands. Cooling thunder showers swept through the mountains and made the roads perfect for driving. A little over an inch and three-quarters of rainfall was registered during the heavy shower Wednesday afternoon.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18 -- The entertatnment in aid of the Village improvement Association, which is one of the chief events of every year here, took place Thursday. Like air its predecessors, it was a great success, and will add a large amount to the treasury. These entertainments net from $1,500 to $2,500, and the funds are always put to the best uses in permanent improvements around the village.

HAMBURG, Mich., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Julian Butler, forty-five years of age, who lived near here, is supposed to have poisoned her father, mother, husband, and herself, all of whom are dead; Harry Whitlock, the hired man, who is dying, and Dr. Elias Smith of Whitmore Lake, the family physician. Dr. Smith is broken in health, and attributed his illness to partaking of food at the woman's home.

Gainesvllle (Ga.) Letter to the Atlanta Constitution. Lieut. Gen. James Longstreet, who is now the ranking living officer of the late Confederate States Army, lives here in quiet retirement with his children. He spends his time between attending to a large vineyard, which does not pay him; receiving visits from his old comrades in the field, who never tire of listening to his reminiscences, and perfecting a history of the war.

When Kolb was defeated for the office of Governor of Alabama at the recent election he raised the cry of fraud, Claimed to have been elected by a majority of 18,000 votes or thereabout, and uttered threats of setting up a government in opposition to that of Oates, the lawfully chosen candidate.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The season is at its height, and fully 2,800 tourists are at this famous resort. Every train brings in from 300 to 500, and the hotel managers are resorting to Cottages in order that they may accommodate their guests.

As we all know, horses became very scarce toward the end of the war, and as dismounted cavalrymen were sent to the Infantry, a remount became a serious question with many troopers. Jim -- of the Rockbridge Troop, had lost his horse, and, unable to get another, possessed himself of a white mule named Simon. Jim became very proud of his mule, and was loud in his praises.

The market Would have gone up ten to twelve points within six days of the passage of the Tariff bill, had it not been for the disaster to the corn crop. It has actually gone up about half that. The strength it has displayed in face of such a calamity has been amazing. As soon as the bill was passed it seemed to send an electric thrill through the market.

NEWPORT, Aug. 18 Dinners have characterized the week. A season of dancing is in order now, and all Pleasures are attended by almost perfect weather, without a threat of the fog which is usually a feature of mid-August.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Miss Mary Lydia Griffin, daughter of Mrs. William Griffin of State Street. Bloomfield, and Addington E. Newhall of New-Haven. Conn., were quietly married at the home of the bride on Wednesday afternoon by the Rev. Mr. Ailsworth.

While responding to a fire alarm at 303 South First Street, Brooklyn, last evening, Andrew Taylor, an engineer attached to Engine No. 16, fell dead just as he stepped off the engine, a short distance from the building that was in flames. Engineer Taylor had been in the Fire Department about twenty-two years and six months, and was also a member of the Volunteer Fire Department.

The end of the Staten Island Cricket Club's tennis tournament is in sight. The semi-final round was finished yesterday, G.A. Willis beating J.A. Maclean in two straight sets, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2. Maclean received a large handicap from Willis, but seemed unable to take much advantage of it, succumbing to his opponent rather easily, as the score shows.

Police Commissioner Kerwin is quoted as saying that the men on the police force who have been "detected in corruption" are to be "pitied as well as blamed," because they have to suffer for "sins which result in a great measure from the system in which they live." This is very true, but who has been responsible for the existence and long continuance of the "system" ?
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Some of the artists who are passing the Summer on Shinnecock Hills have experienced much annoyance from the Shinnecock tribe of Indians, whose reserve is near by.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Summer girls, Summer young men, lawn tennis, sailing, rowing, bathing, and driving are the attractions here. The girls are pretty, the young men gallant, and the other attractions everything one can desire to make Summer days and Summer evenings enjoyable.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 18 -- The moonlight nights are much appreciated by the visitors at Sea Cliff. Hardly a night passes that large parties do not take advantage of the opportunity for moonlight excursions by stage or boat. The old-fashioned straw rides are very popular.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 18 -- By the steamship Empress of India, which left Yokohama Aug. 6, two days after war was declared, comes the substance of the dec- laratlon. It says:

Wilkle Collins had studied French cookery and made friends when in France with every good hotel cook he could interview. During his friendship with my father he managed to instill into him some of the enthusiasm he felt in this matter, and conversation at dinner often turned upon the mode in which to flavor dishes in the most approved French style.

STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 18 -- Thomas Burke, the old squatter who is suspected of having shot Frederick Bergmann, his son-in-law, at South Beach on Thursday, is still locked up at Police Headquarters here, and the police refuse to allow any one to see him.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 18 -- This has been the most eventful week at the Summer. The festivities began last Sunday, when the New-York Yacht Club spent the day in the harbor. The Oak Bluffs Club took the lead, as usual, in the matter of entertaining, and kept open house While the fleet was here.

Herr Breltenstein was again in evidence yesterday. The youth with the pretzel curves faced the heavy hitters of the Brooklyn team, kept them down to two hits, and disposed of them without a run. It was the prettiest piece of pitching witnessed here this year. Stein, for the Brooklyns, also pitched a creditable game. He kept the Browns down to half a dozen hits, and under ordinary conditions would have been credited with a victory.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The Tien-Tsin correspondent of The Times says that the North Chinese squadron, under Admiral Ting, has searched the Gulf of Pechili for the Japanese fleet, but without success. The Admiral has reported that the Japanese have left those waters.

Everybody who has visited the Wild West, either in Europe or America, has been attracted by the superb riding of Prank Hammitt, chief of the cowboys, but few know that he is the son of an ex-Governor of Colorado. Loth to talk about himself, Hammitt dropped into a conversation the other night with a reporter and told how he became a cowboy.

SARANAC LAKE, Adirondacks, Aug. 18 -- The honor of having shot the first deer of the season is claimed by both ex-Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn and Commander Leonard Chenery. Both these gentlemen brought in big bucks on the morning of the 15th.

The introduction of sugar into England is often dated so late as the fifteenth century; but it was really in use there in the thirteenth. Zucre is mentioned in the wardrobe accounts under date of 1243, and in the same records have been discovered many allusions to the sugar-consuming propensities of the English Court in mediaeval times.

WEST POINT, Aug. 18 -- The wildest grandest, and most romantic part or the Highlands is not as many suppose, in the neighborhood of Storm King and Cro' Nest. Those who travel on the river by boat or along its shores on trains have few opportunities to become acquainted with the natural scenery which, in all its primitive simplicity, remains unchanged on the high ground above.

An interesting development arose to the surface in State Division politics yesterday when it came out that Dr. E.M. Santee of Cortland would be a candidate for Chief Consul to oppose I.B. Potter of Brooklyn. The former will head the ticket said to be favored by the present Chief Consul, C.H. Luscomb, who has announced that he will not again be a candidate.

The semi-annual report of the race agent of the American Rules shows the work at pigeon fliers for the year to date to be quite up to the average. The best speed for each distance of the series made to Aug. 1 is as follows:

The comic tune is everywhere the prope accompaniment of the comic song or ballad, and Shakespeare has married every kind of nonsense to immortal verse. Nonsense has two main forms -- wit and humor. They are hard to digtlnguish, for each is perpetually overlapping and mingling with the other.

A Birmingham man advertises that he has found "An open-face (filled) gold gentleman's watch." Now, it is probable that an "open-face" gentleman can be found, even in Birmingham, though recent conditions are very much against its probability, considering the material and political troubles they have passed through.

In New-York, Kings, Erie, Monroe, and some other counties, from which Democrats have spoken, there is more than one organization in the Democratic Party. In most, if not all, of these the points of difference have been said to be chiefly local.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 18 LONG Branch is still talking about the open-air Horse Show. Its success, from a financial standpoint was so remarkable and so unexpected that all the persons who were concerned in the enterprise are enthusiastic.

There was good sport at Parkway yesterday. The horses were of poor class, but the fields were evenly matched and not too large. Starter Ware's work with the flag, with the exception of the third event, was as good as he has done at the meeting. In the last race the seven horses were sent away to a beautiful start, all being in motion and close together.

"London to Paris in one hour -- no stop -pages" -- sounds like a curious announcement, but in the near future there is a probability that the front sheets of the daily papers will promulgate some such advertisement. For the past few years Mr. Maxim has been busy near Bexley in perfecting a machine capable of propelling itself through the air with passengers, c., under the control of competent engineers.
A member of the imperial family of Japan, a cousin of the Mikado, is sick at the Windsor Hotel, in this city.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 18 -- The crusade started yesterday by the police against the soft-Coal nuisance maintained by the Long Island Railroad Company was continued to-day. A squad of policemen, under command of Capt. Woods, entered the railroad yards early this morning, and made an inspection of the engines.
The sales referred to in the accompanying detailed list will be held at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- "Harmony," in Onondaga County, when it applies to Republican politics, means "open warfare." The decision of the State Committee allowing the Belden and Hendricks factions, the regulars and independents, as they have been called, to settle their differences at the caucuses has been acceptd with alacrity by both sides.

Carrie Roche, who sometimes calls herself Mary Martin and sometimes Katie McLaughlin, is a little woman seventy-two years old, but within about a month she has committed three robberies and secured about $500 worth of property. She was arrested yesterday on a charge of robbing Mrs. Catherine Kernaghan of 854 Sixth Avenue of a quantity of clothing and jewelry on Aug. 6, and was locked up in the East Fifty-first Street Police Station.

Mrs. Adeline H. Kernan, widow of James Kernan, has begun in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn a suit against Thomas Kernan, her husband's brother, who lives in Baltimore. Margaret Burns and Celia Higgins, sisters of Trenton, N.J.; Catherine Kernan of the Ursuline Convent, Columbia, S.C.; Annie Kernan, William Kernan and Willam Kernan, the second, and Celia Kernan of Newark, N.J.

The club regattas seldom interest outsiders, but the annual races of the Friendship Boat Club on the Harlem River yesterday proved an exception. Members and their fair friends filled the boathouse verandas, and along shore Quite a number of people congregated to enjoy the sport. The races were, finished off the clubhouse, which is now situated several hundred yards north of the Madison Avenue bridge on the Mott Haven shore.

Deputy Collector Couch returned yesterday from Washington, where he went early In the week to consult the Treasury Department officials with reference to the operation of the new tariff. The special subject of inquiry was in regard to goods in bond. Duty under the new law will be less than under the old one upon many of these goods.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 18 -- One of the reasons why Lebbens B. Ward of the State Water Board so firmly believes in a State water-supply system is the rapidity with which the population is increasing. The ratio of increase is greater than in the City of New-York, where the growth is considered phenomenal.
The following statement was given out by Henry George last night:

Before this week is finished the monotonous dullness of things theatrical, which for many weeks has been relieved only by the unexpected prosperity of the revived "Mikado" at the Fifth Avenue Theatre, and the roof-garden shows, will be over. Next Saturday night three of the city playhouses will be reopened for the season of 1894-5.

TREMPER HOUSE, PHOENICIA, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The Tremper House, one of the leading hotels in the Catskills, is filled with guests, and has never had a more successful season. Tuesday evening the guests save a series of living pictures in the hotel parlor, which was a most enjoyable affair.
Annie Stephanie of 647 Fifth Street took her boy baby Franz to Bellevue Hospital yesterday, and while Dr. Phillips was examining the child it died in her arms.

A century run that should attract many riders is that to fee held on Sept. 23, under the management of the Westchester Cycling League. Extensive preparations are being made for the affair, and an enjoyable run is assured, with favorable weather. The route from Yonkers to Hicksville lays through a picturesque country that cannot fall to attract the eye of the most inveterate globe trotter.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The pleasures here are innumerable, and thousands enjoy the chief of them, which is bathing. The hotels are crowded, but the prospects are that visitors will return home in two weeks. Clambakes are popular, and balls are nightly affairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Sugar Trust says that there is not to be a quorum of the Senate from this time on until the adjournment. That is the chief excuse given now, except that there is a willingness to fall in with the refiners' plans to prevent legislation, to account for the failure of the Free-Sugar bill.

Purifying a neighborhood on Dr. Parkhurst's plan is not pleasant work, Mrs. Mary Sallade has found this out in the course of her efforts to rid West Twenty-fourth Street of disorderly houses, and a similarly unpleasant incident yesterday befell G.A. Kraft, who is engaged in the same sort of a crusade in West Twelfth Street.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 19 -- In their crusade against Sunday excursionists here, the Trustees and law and order people showed a determination to-day which frightened oft 2,000 picnickers, who attempted to land at Summers.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 10 -- Rumors were afloat here to-day that the President sailed for New-York on the Rodgers this morning. The steamer left early this morning for a sail down the bay, and to Onset, but returned this afternoon. The President did not go on the cruise.

The scientists who invaded Brooklyn in such overwhelming numbers last week mysteriously disappeared yesterday. No one could say just where they had gone. Some of the few who remained were of the opinion that their fellow-scientists were resting in their rooms from the effects of their outing on Saturday.

The cornerstone of the new Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, on Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, was laid at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by Bishop McDonnell. The exercises wore led by the Rev. Father J.J. McAteer, the pastor of the church. The Rev. Father James Donohue of St. Thomas Aquinas Church preached the sermon.

The trials of Capts. Cross and Devery end ex-Ward Men Glennon, Burns, and Smith are to be continued this morning at Police Headquarters. The method of trial will be the same as that adopted last week -- that is, Capt. Cross will be tried separately, and Capt. Devery will be tried in contumacy, while Glennon, by the advice of his lawyers, Friend House, will be mute, because his "material witness," Devery, is absent.

The body of George Inness, the artist, who died suddenly at Bridge of Allan, Scotland, Aug. 3, arrived in this city last night on the steamship Anchoria of the Anchor Line. On the steamer were Mr. Inness's widow, his son George, who is well-known as an artist, and also Mr. Inness's daughter, Mrs. J.S. Hartley, and her husband, the sculptor.

Howls, screeches, handclapping, and thumping of feet greeted Kmma Goldman last evening. In the Thalia Theatre, on the Bowery, on her first appearance before the Anarchist public after her release from Blackwell's Island, where she had been doing unwilling work for New-York County as punishment for using incendiary language and inciting to riot and bloodshed.

M. Jules Simon's notes on his interview with the German Emperor will appear in the Revue de Paris to-morrow. The French politician and writer went to Berlin in order to attend the congress on Socialist questions, and he was most graciously received by the Emperor and Empress. The Kaiser somewhat resembled, according to M. Julea Simon, a young Norman noble in appearance and manners.
The action of the Democratic State Committee at its Saratoga meeting in recommending six days' notice for primaries has met the indorsement of almost every Democrat who has spoken on the subject.

The Coryphees' Protective Association held a secret meeting yesterday at Clarendon Hall. A pale, narrow-shouldered Anarchist porter, armed with a baseball club, mounted guard at the door of the meeting room.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The Shanghai correspondent of the Central News gives in to-day's dispatches a gloomy view of affairs at Wei-Hai-Wei, the fortified city in the Shantung promontory. There is little doubt that the Japanese intend to attack this Chinese stronghold shortly, despite the tradition of the Chinese that the place is impregnable.

Philip Gilbert Hamerton, in speaking of the lack of intellectual curiosity in the better sex, tells of a woman, who declared that she did not see the value of sailing vessels, since they could go only in the direction toward which the wind blew. Mr. Hamerton says the woman had doubtless often seen vessels beating to windward without really observing it or feeling a desire to know how it was done.

NEW-CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Bright and early this morning groups of citizens were standing on the corners and patrolling back and forth in front of the butcher's, barber's, newsdealer's, and baker's shops, varying the monotony with an occasional visit to the livery stables or to the druggist's for a soda water.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- In a little two-story house on Davis Avenue, Kearney, a tragedy occurred at 2 o'clock this morning that resulted in the death of one man and the probable death of his wife and brother-in-law, and an attempted murder of four children.

In January, 1799, at the town of Aquila, in the Abruzzo, then held by a garrison of 400 French troops, the peasants broke into the town, and, though they were driven out by the French, they continued to give serious trouble. They even drove the French into the fort, and made ready to bombard them with heavy guns.

James Foster of 354 East Eighty-ninth Street and James Shortell of 154 East Eighty-fourth Street were committed in $300 bail each by Police Justice Meade, in the Yorkville Court yesterday, on a charge of petit larceny. Foster called at the residence of Mrs. Minnie Humphries, 443 East Seventy-eighth Street, Saturday afternoon, and said he had to deliver to Mrs. Hart, a neighbor of Mrs. Humphries, a package that she had bought at Bloomingdales'.

The steamer Mohawk, which arrived at her dock, foot of West Twenty-sixth Street, last evening, brought a large and the most valuable consignment of English-bred racing horses ever brought here. The horses are consigned to James R. Keene, J.B. Haggin, and Marcus Daly.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $803,800. The banks now hold $67,806,650 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $1,676,100, a decrease in specie of $24,300, an increase in legal tenders of $1,791,200, an increase in deposits of $3,852,400, and a decrease in circulation of $23,500.

Lord Amherst was Governor General of India for about four years, beginning in the Summer of 1823. He succeeded Lord Hastings, and found a war with Burmah all ready for him on his arrival at Calcutta. He knew little about India at the time when he was called upon to direct the operations of the English forces against the Burmese, and was as ignorant as a schoolgirl of the arts of war.

The stock market was more animated last week than for many months, and price improved from the opening on Monday until the close on Saturday almost without a reaction. The passage of the Tariff bill by the House as amended by the Senate was responsible for the marked improvement in the situation.

Some years ago I paid a visit to a friend who rented a cottage on Hughenden Manor, where the late Earl of Beaconsfield reared the celebrated white peacocks, which he ultimately bequeathed to Queen Victoria.

A correspondent of The Naval and Military Record (British) gives the following account of a torpedo attack and mock action which took place off Belfast shortly after war was declared between the Red and Blue squadrons of the British fleet. It is, of course, only a make-believe war, and the manoeuvres are for drill purposes only.

William McKay Hoge, a commission merchant, fifty years old, of 168 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station last night, charged with larceny and obtaining goods under false pretenses. He was arrested at Shelter Island early in the day.

The conditions for road work yesterday were particularly favorable, but only light training was indulged in by the cracks entered for the Associated Cycling Clubs' handicap on Labor Day. Those who live near the Elizabeth-Railway course are fortunate, for they have the opportunity to familiarize themselves with this excellent path.
Two trains are speeding across the continent toward Vancouver, B.C., on one a number of high rank Japs, and on the other several hundred Chinamen.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- Manufacturers and exporters interested in the American trade are somewhat elated over the passage of the Gorman bill. In the textile industry the relief from the last months of suspension is especially apparent. Exporters expect an increase of business with the United States in about everything except raw sugar.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Several gentlemen, who are deeply interested in the water question, have taken exception to statements in the interviews with Lebbeus B. Ward, published in The New-York Times. They say that they are as firmly opposed to syndicates as he is, but they do not fear that they will ever get control of the situation, or that they will be desirous, even if able, to shut out small towns.

What a campaign that was, through swamps and woods and over bridgeless streams! Joe Johnston's engineers had told their chief that Sherman never could march or swim an army through the lower part of North Carolina in midwinter, but he was a commander who never stopped at such obstacles as rivers and swamps when marching: for a desired object.

The dogs in Brooklyn give more trouble to Mayor Schleren and his administration than the tax rate and the office seekers put together. The numerousness of the dogs is as much a characteristic of the city as are the churches, whose spires stick up above the foliage of the trees on nearly every block.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 19 -- An extensive conflagration visited Ocean Grove early this morning, and the town was saved from destruction by the good work performed by the Asbury Park, Ocean Grove, West Grove, and West Asbury Park Fire Departments.

As the time draws near for the Grand Circuit trotting meeting in New-York there is a noticeable increase in the Sunday morning attendance at Fleetwood Park, where the road riders gather to see the local trotters exercised and incidentally to exchange news and gossip of the fliers of the big circuit meetings. Yesterday there was a larger crowd on the clubhouse than at any time since the midsummer season set in.
SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- At the Methodist Episcopal camp meeting to-day there were about 5,000 persons from all over Westchester County and New-York.

HAMBURG, Mich., Aug. 19. -- Dr. Elias Smith of this city, who attended the father, mother, and husband of Mrs. Julia Butler, who killed them and herself with poison and gave poisoned food to the hired man, Harry Whitlock, and the doctor, made the following statement in regard to the case: ...

While the stock of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company was not the most actively traded in in Wall Street last week, its manipulation by those who are loaded up with it was one of the most interesting features of the week. In all, more than 180,000 shares changed hands, being considerably in excess of half the capital stock of the concern.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 -- Newport had its biggest Sunday to-day. The cottages were full of visitors, and thousands of excursionists came in from the hot cities near by. The attendance at the Casino concert to-night was the largest in the history of the place. Every chair that could be found in all the building's was in use, and many sat about the lawn.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- The Constitutional Convention has at last reached the forks in the road that lead to patriotism and politics. Up to the present time, where corporate influence was not exerted, the proceedings have been marked by a personal disinterestedness and patriotism that went far beyond the sentiments expressed by President Choate when he assumed the office of President of the convention.

The death of ex-Gov. Austin Blair of Michigan removes the last but two of the famous "war Governors" of our time. The other exceptions are ex-Gov. W.P. Sprague of Rhode Island, afterward a United States Senator, who still survives, and holds the dignified position of policeman at Narfagansett Pier, and ex-Gov. A.G. Curtin of Pennsylvania.

The entries to the Fleetwood Grand Circuit trotting races are the most numerous ever received for a meeting in New-York, and the quality of the horses named in the various classes is such as to assure a rousing series of harness races during the week of Sept. 3-8.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- The local security market was not influenced by the passage of the Tariff bill. This, however, occasioned no surprise, as the local market was too inactive to respond, partly due to the midsummer dullness. It must not be forgotten that only a few of our local enterprises have been affected by the business depression which has prevailed.

The placing of works of the fine arts on the free list is an experiment worth trying; perhaps a time of business depression like the present is the best for all concerned. Importers of the only kind of pictures that American collectors want have made their preparations and have been able to enlarge their stocks by as much as the tariff rate would have come to.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The Orange Lawn Tennis Club is arranging to hold a club championship tennis tournament at its handsome grounds, at Montrose, beginning Saturday, Sept. 8. The winner in the singles will play Duncan W. Chandler, the present holder of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club challenge cup. The cup was first offered in competition in 1890, and must be won three times by the holder to become his property.

SALEM, Mass., Aug. 19 -- An alarm of fire at 5:15 o'clock this afternoon was for a disastrous fire in the machine shop or the Boston and Maine Railroad, at the foot of Northey Street, on the North River. The works are used for the construction of bridges, switches, and supplies, and were fitted with improved machinery in every department.

When Monroe Salisbury lost control of Directum at the close of last season, some horsemen wondered what the grand old man of the trotting turf would do for a free-for-all horse in 1894. And when, a little later, Honest John Kelly severed his connection with Mr. Salisbury many admirers of the renowned California turfman lamented the departing glory of the Pleasanton colors.

Considerable change took place in the records of the cricket clubs battling for the championship of New-York and the averages of their members by the games played last week. The Staten Island Cricket Club advanced above the Manhattans, and the individual averages all came down. T.S. Jervons still leads, but H.C. Wright and F.J. Prendergast are close after him.

A lot of smoke, many fire engines, and a small fire attracted a large crowd last night to the vicinity of Broadway and Reade Street. Three alarms were quickly sent in, and twelve engines, a water tower, and the reserves from the Sixth Police Precinct were soon at hand.

It was discreditable to the Constitutional Convention that after deciding to do a full week's work each week until Sept. 15 more than half the delegates broke away and failed to attend the Saturday session. There are just four weeks of working time between now and Sept. 15.
The meeting of the Republican State Committee in this city this week is expected to help some Gubernatorial booms, and possibly hurt others.

Due notice, publicly given, is one of the indispensable conditions of a fair party primary. The action of the Democratic State Committee in recommending that six days' notice be given of the time and place of holding the primary meetings for choosing delegates to the district conventions by which State Convention delegates will be named has given general satisfaction.
NEW-SPRINGVILLE, S.I., Aug. 12 -- The residents of this village are greatly excited to-day over the visit which a desperate burglar paid to the house of William H. Palmer early this morning.

When Rose Curran, thirty-nine years old, and Mary Shanpland, thirty years old, occupying adjoining apartments in the tenement at 428 East Fifty-first Street, and long known as great friends, got through arguing a question of maternal obligations in the rearing of children yesterday and other tenants of the house had gathered Mrs. Curran up, it was found that two of her ribs were broken, her left arm was broken, and her lip was split.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 19 -- The coalition of the representatives of organized labor and the People's Party here this week has seriously raised the question whether the movement which has disrupted the old parties in the West and South has entered Ohio in a form that calls for any apprehension from the old organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- There is a rule of the United States Senate which provides that intoxicating liquors shall not be sold in the Senate restaurant. This rule, like many others to which the antiquated body has given its assent, is observed only in the breach. One who thirsts may drop into the restaurant and be served with anything in the liquor line from beer up to champagne.

With the passage of the Tariff bill there came an increased demand for investment securities, as well as speculative bonds. In fact, the last week has been a busier one in Wall Street than for some time past. Among the active railroad bonds on the Stock Exchange were Atchison 4s, Chesapeake and Ohio general mortgage 4 1/2 S, Northern Pacific seconds, and the various Reading issues.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Government officers have gone aboard another vessel in the Tyne, because they were convinced that she was fitting for service in the Chinese-Japanese war. The work on the vessel has been pushed with the greatest haste since the declaration of war, and recently materials of war have been placed aboard her.

A subject has been forced to the front in New-Jersey by the pressure of the water supply question in Jersey City which will ultimately have to be considered in every State that has populous cities and towns. The tendency of population to industrial and commercial centres is one of the social phenomena of the time, and it increases with the development of means of quick and cheap communication.

The golf links of the Shinnecock Hills (L.I.) Club presented a gala appearance last week. An unusually large attendance of players and spectators gathered, on the grounds each day, the occasion being the competition for a silver plate offered by the Board of Trustees. Play commenced each day at 1 o'clock. There were a goodly number of contestants, and many excellent scores were made.
CITY ISLAND, Aug. 19 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Lorna, W.L. Stone, and Emeline, C.W. Roche, Schooner yacht Montauk, Lew in Cass Ledyard, Sloop Ventura, D.E. Austen.

The Central Labor Union and the People's Party in this city will probably work together in politics this year. The Central Labor Union wants to go into politics, and it had the alternative of joining the Socialist-Labor Party, or of making a combination with the People's Party, if it wanted to make any show at the polls.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The police have in custody the leader of the gang of thieves that have been committing acts of piracy in this harbor and along the Sound in this vicinity. For months past complaints have been very numerous from boat owners of thefts from their boats. Vessels left unguarded had been stripped of everything portable, and in some instances anchors were raised and taken and vessels allowed to drift.

Mr. Ebenezer R. Tasker, a son of one of the party who rescued the bodies from the famous Willey landslide in the White Mountains sixty years ago, has been visiting in Lewiston recently, and has told the story of the landslide. He said:

PITTSBURG, Aug. 18 -- Neither the stock nor local money situation shows any very marked change this week. Bankers still report funds in good supply, but, in keeping with the old-time policy, are not shaping inducements to encourage borrowers. Collaterals are in fact being scanned more closely than formerly, and the only hope for a drop in interest charges comes with the offers of money by Philadelphia capitalists in this market.

SPRING CITY, Penn., Aug. 10 -- The quaint ceremony of feet washing was the great feature at the Mennonite Brethren's camp meeting in Egolf's Woods today. More than 100 men and women washed each others' feet, and this was supplemented by the laying on of hands for the healing of the sick.

George Parkes, who for so many years was a member of Augustin Daly's company of players, died at the Edwin Forrest Home, at Holmesburg, Penn., Saturday. He was admitted to the home May 10, 1893, being at the time a confirmed invalid, unable to act or gain a living by any other means.

A cry is raised that Paris is losing its promenades. It is certainly true that gradually the Champs Elysees have been sacrificed in order to meet the demands of the proprietors of cafes, concerts, panoramas, and gardens which revive the sins and follies of the gay Mabille, whose site has long since been lost in a maze of stone and cement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Heirs of the late Judge Joseph Holt, ex-Judge Advocate General of the Army, asked yesterday, by petition, for the settlement of the estate by the Probate Court. A long search has been made for a will, without success, and the petitioners say they believe he died intestate.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- George F. Sanford of this city, one of the big, muscular athletes who represented Yale at the Oxford games, has one trophy of the trip to London that will be a reminder of Yale's first contest abroad, and also of the patriotic effort of the American students to celebrate the Fourth of July in a foreign land in true Yankee style.

Thomas H. Senior and his wife Kate, who, with their five children, applied for lodgings at the Mercer Street Station House Saturday night, were taken to Jefferson Market Court yesterday. Four of the children - Anna, aged ten; Florence, eight; Jaines, seven, and Lottie, two -- were provided for by the Gerry Society for the night, while Senior and his wife, and infant, ten days old, slept in the station house.

Several hundred persons congregated again last evening at Third Avenue and Seventy-second Street to watch for the ghost which, it is alleged, has been walking for several nights in the vacant room at 1,253 Third Avenue.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- James Hogan, W.E. Burns, R.M. Goodman, J.F. McVean, and Martin J. Elliott, the Directors of the American Railway Union, flied an answer in the United States Circuit Court yesterday to the information against them charging contempt of court. In addition to the general answer to the information, they also filed answers to the interrogatories of the Government regarding the conduct of the strike.

The inhabitants of Poplar, who work hard and live frugally in order to pay their taxes honestly, must be highly gratified to learn that they have been wearing their fingers to the bone to assist William Edwards, an inmate of their workhouse, to become so fat that it takes him half an hour to stoop to pick up a pin and another half hour to raise himself to the perpendicular.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Prof. Edward C. Pickering, director of the Harvard Observatory, is always on the alert to keep Harvard in the front of all astronomical investigations. The expected shower of August meteors offered a field for new inquiries. Consequently, acting in connection with Prof. Elkin of New-Haven, preparations wore made last week for a complete observation of the Perseids.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 19 -- A congregation numbering 1,200, in Prohibition Park this afternoon, heard an address by the Rev. Dr. H.M. Gallaher of Brooklyn. Dr. Gallaher's subject was "The Religious Side of the Irish People."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt, daughter of Cornelius Vanderbilt, had a coaching picnic to-day, which was the chief event in society. Four coachloads were taken to the Vanderbilt farm in Portsmouth, where luncheon was served. Mrs. William Astor, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Frederick Bronson, and Mrs. Ogden Mills were the chaperons.

EBENSBURG, Penn., Aug. 20 -- Judge Parker filed his decision this morning in the Galitzin school case, in which W.T. Kerr of the Junior Order of United American Mechanics sought to restrain the Board of Directors of the Galitzin public schools from employing nuns as teachers.

The attention of The New-York Times has been called to the reduced circumstances of Mrs. Louise Sleight, eighty-three years old, who occupies a garret room at 231 West Houston Street, by William Butler, commander of E.H. Wade Post, No. 520, G.A.R. The members of this post have assisted Mrs. Sleight from time to time.

PUEBLO, Col., Aug. 20 -- Otto Ziegler, the Californian, was twice beaten to-day at the national meet of the Rovers Cycle and Athletic Club in the circuit. All interest centred in the mile open race. Sanger, Brown, Kennedy, Ziegler, Taxis, C.M. Murphy, J.S. Johnson, L.A. Callahan, and York was the order as the men lined up on the tape.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- A match yacht race took place to-day over the ten-mile course of the Shrewsbury Yacht Club, between Edwin D. Miner's Maygus and J. Frank James's Pauline. The yachts are catboats of about the same size. The Pauline won by 1 minute 11 seconds, corrected time, the sailing time being 1:19:17.

Paris Correspondent London Truth. A member of a great novel-publishing firm tells me that it now does not pay to bring out novels unless there is some great name on the title page. Zola still makes money: but this business man believes the turn in the tide has in his case begun. The explanation given me for this state of the book market is that novels have ceased to be works of fiction.
