Mrs. Josephine Pomeroy, who lives at 125 East Sixty-second Street, called at the East Sixty-seventh Street Station yesterday and complained that a stranger had been loitering about her house of late, and every evening about 9 o'clock was in the habit of depositing letters at her basement door. This he had done regularly for two weeks, and from the character of the letters she believed the man was a crank and might prove dangerous.

No American would feel surprised if the attitude at the British public toward the owner and handlers of the Vigilant should deter yachtsmen from this side of the water from again venturing to beard the lion in his den. It is impossible to avoid recalling the entirely different manner in which the American public treated the last English, vessel that sought yachting honors in the waters off Sandy Hook.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Aug. 20 -- Since the postponement of the sale of the Staten Island Ferry franchise until Sept. 6 there has been a revival of the movement to secure a five-cent fare from New-York to St. George. Petitions are in circulation, asking She New-York Sinking Fund Commissioners to insert in the franchise a provision that no more than 5 cents shall be charged upon the ferry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Marshal Arnold of Chicago, who had charge of the Federal deputies in that city during the great strike, is in Washington to arrange for the payment of Marshals' fees incurred in preventing lawlessness and for protecting United States property. His bill amounts to about $100,000. Its payment la provided for in the Deficiency Appropriation bill.

The announcement of the marriage of Mrs. Adele T.A. Ronalds, the widow of Thomas Lorillard Ronalds, to Franclyn Reglid, a young actor, formerly connected with the Rosina Vokes company, has caused some surprise. The bride is seventy years old, and the bridegroom about thirty.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- After four weeks of misery on a small island in the Carribean Sea, ten shipwrecked Scandinavians from the Norwegian steamship George Sealey were landed at this port to-day by the steamship Gurley from Port Antonio, Jamaica, at which point they had arrived with difficulty from the Central American coast.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 20 -- While strolling along the shore front at Rockaway Point yesterday afternoon, Smith George and Gustav Meyer, two residents of the beach, saw the body of a man being tossed about in the surf. They secured the body, and put it on the beach beyond the reach of the high tide.

The Constitutional Convention has thrown out another of the numerous propositions submitted to it, which are born of distrust of the legislative power, growing out of its abuse in the past. There is no doubt that In the last twelve or fifteen years the Legislature has created an unnecessary number of commissions, and that one motive for it has been the desire to multiply offices and increase official patronage.
The Populists of New-York City have determined to nominate their own city and county ticket, and have asked organized labor to enter the field of politics and unite forces under their standard.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 20 -- Nothing of a sensational nature was accomplished at Washington Park to-day, the second day of the Northwestern Breeders' meettlng, but for all that there were several decidedly impressive performances hung up. The weather was cool and threatening. The track was a trifle too soft to be remarkably fast, and the crowd slim, despite the fact that the card offered was a good one.
Thomas Cramer of 363 Lenox Avenue, a manufacturer of upholstery goods, is lying at the point of death in the Manhattan Hospital, with a dislocated neck.

BERGEN POINT, N.J., Aug. 20 -- The large plant of the defunct Carr Hobson (Limited) Company's agricultural implement manufactory, extending from the junction of Avenue A and West First Street, Bergen Point, to the Kill von Kull shore and terminus of the new Hudson County Boulevard, was burned early this morning.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 20 -- For the second time at the Republican primaries held here Saturday Senator Anthony Higgins completely routed the forces of J. Edward Addicks in the battle for the United States Senatorship from Delaware, as far as the power of the Republican Party to dispose of it may be concerned.

The next Captain of Police to be placed on trial by the Police Commissioners in following up the charges brought out by the Lexow committee will be John T. Stephenson, now in command of the Tenth Precinct, (Mulberry Street Station.)

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- President Eugene V. Debs of the American Railway Union took the stand at the beginning of the morning's session of the National Labor Commission. He said he was thirty-eight years old, and in addition to being at the head of the American Railway Union was editor of The Locomotive Fireman's Magazine.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The actionof the Chemung County Republicans in instructing their Congressional delegates for Major Charles W. Gillet of Steuben makes sure the renomination of that gentleman to represent the Twenty-ninth District in Congress. The district consists of Steuben, Chemung, Schuyler, and Seneca.

The task, somewhat difficult for a place of amusement whose "season" includes twelve months each year, of achieving a real "first night," was accomplished last evening at Koster Bial's Theatre, and with no small measure of success at that. It would be hardly accurate to assert that the traditional "everybody" was there, but enough were present to crowd the big theatre to a degree that approached the uncomfortable.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Trustee George N. Paff of the Unlondale School District, near this village, was beaten out of his boots at a special school election held in that district to-day. Paff is the Trustee who suspended Miss Jennie L. Patterson because she declined to sift ashes and teach school. Miss Patterson was reinstated, despite Trustee Paff's vigorous opposition.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 20 -- George E. Payne, a real estate and insurance agent at 75 Jackson Avenue, this city, and a son of exCorporation Counsel Alvin T. Payne, was arraigned before Police Justice Duffy this morning charged with assault in the third degree, by George E. Clay, a real estate and insurance agent at 5 Jackson Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The "popgun" bills, amended in some particulars, were reported to the Senate to-day by the Finance Committee, and, after some delay, were placed upon the calendar, from which they can only be recalled by a majority vote of the Senate. As the quorum has already disappeared, there is not the slightest probability that any effort will be made to call them up in the present session.

From The London Telegraph. Mme. de Menibus, who, as Mile. Duoos, once brought an action against Gen. Boulanger for the recovery of love letters, is before the courts again. This lady married the Comte de Menibus in 1890. She had a daughter in September, 1892, but her father, a rich Bordeaux merchant, states positively that the child is not her own.

Rare courage and presence of mind saved six young Brooklyn people from drowning in New-York Bay Sunday afternoon. Their was found floating bottom upward Sunday along the Staten Island shore, but its occupants, instead of being at the bottom of the sea, as those who found the craft at first conjectured, were safe in their Brooklyn homes, still marveling, however, on their almost miraculous escape.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The subject of chief interest in the short session of the House to-day was the bill of Senator Hill for the exclusion and deportation of Anarchists. This bill was passed with remarkable promptness by the Senate. When it came over to the House an effort was made to put it through without reference to the Judiciary Committee, an effort that was balked by the resistance of Messrs.

G.A. Kraft of 221 West Twelfth Street, who is engaged in an attempt to purify West Twelfth Street in the vicinity of his home, appeared in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to press the charges against Georga Preston, a barkeeper for Saloon Keeper Eichner of 229 West Twelfth Street, of violating the excise law. The saloon is only three doors from Kraft's house.

It is generally assumed and expected that the President will sign the Tariff bill, and we regard as sound and convincing the arguments in favor of such action. It will be possible under the provisions of the laws, however, for him to withhold his signature until the end of this week.

A few days ago The Times pointed out the advantages that would accrue to the State by the unification of the system of public instruction by a system under which the Superintendent should be appointed by the Regents of the university.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Six months ago to-morrow William A. Beach of Syracuse was nominated to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Twenty-first New-York District. He was confirmed to-day. But for the good offices of ex-Mayor William B. Kirk of Syracuse, there is not the slightest doubt that he would not have been confirmed at all.

Republicans as a rule do not set a high value upon the opinions which Democrats obligingly contribute to the discussion about the adjustment of the quarrel between the factions of Milholland and Bliss. Conversely, Democrats are not greatly influenced by the comments of Republicans or those who are practically Republicans upon the attempts now making to reunite their party.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 20 -- Dispatches from Port au Prince say that President Hippolyte is mortally ill.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- The Casino Theatre was thronged with many dancers this evening, for Monday is the evening for the hop. The gallery was overflowing with sightseers, and the broad piazzas were filled with promenaders.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 20 -- William A. Lewis, a prominent lawyer and member of the Board of Trade of this city, is firmly convinced that the Bradley bill providing for putting the potable waters of New-Jersey under control of the State is strictly within the limits of the Constitution. Mr. Lewis was for several years Corporation Counsel, and his legal opinion on any matter is generally regarded with respect.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 20 -- The Breckinridge storming of W.C. Owens's home to-day was a failure, so far as converting citizens of Dick Johnson's old home to the Breckinridge faith was concerned. Special trains were run from all points in the Ashland Congressional district, and probably 2,000 people landed in the city.

Commissioner White of the Department of City Works, Brooklyn, does not want to excite or alarm the residents of that city, but he has requested that they shall for the present be very careful in the use of water. The daily consumption is still very large, and no less than 76,000,000 gallons were used on Sunday.

Miss Emma Schaffner, twenty-two years old, of 70 West Fiftieth Street, accompanied by Mrs. Beatrice Graham, who lives with her husband and four-year-old daughter next door, were returning along East Drive from a ride in Central Park shortly before 7 o'clock last evening when the horse started to run away near the Hamilton statue at Eighty-second Street.

A mass meeting of the Milholland Republicans of the Seventh Assembly District was held in the rooms of the Levi P. Morton Club, the headquarters of the organization in the Seventh District, 22 First Avenue, last night.

Nineteen books aid business at Parkway yesterday for an attendance of about 2,500. Peter Jackson gave the talent an upset in the first race. His opening price was 15 to 1, but the books soon cut him down to 10 to 1, at which price he went to the post. Malinda, the favorite, was never better than third, and at the finish was next to last.

-- Eden Musee -- The Mikado of Japan and the Chinese Emperor in wax are the new attractions at the Eden Musee this week. They were put on exhibition Sunday. The Mikado has an open, intelligent countenance, and looks as if he might be a graduate of Yale or Harvard. He is dressed in the height of fashion, and shows plainly that his measure is taken by a London tailor.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- A dispatch to the Central News from Shanghai says that Li Hung Chang's army, 50,000 strong, and a large body of Japanese troops are nearing each other, and a battle is imminent.

CLIFTON, S.I., Aug. 20 -- The inquest into the killing of Frederick Bergmann at South Beach was begun to-night before Coroner Halloran and a jury of ten men. District Attorney Fitzgerald conducted the examination of witnesses.

The American Line steamship Berlin, which arrived yesterday from Southampton, had two very narrow escapes from collision during the voyage. The ship was crowded with passengers, and many of them had an opportunity of seeing by what a slight margin accidents during a fog are avoided.
LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- A notice of six days is ample, if notices are properly posted, and, where possible, the same is published in the local papers.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Ten thousand cotton operatives are idle in the streets to-day. The great Strike came about as threatened, and Secretary Ross of the Spinners' Union says it has come to stay. Thousands of working people assembled about the twenty-seven mills, excepting at one or two of the South mills, but so few went in that the machinery was not started, except in five.

The best race or the day, so rar as class was concerned, at Jerome Park yesterday was the third. It was a run of a mile and a sixteenth, with four starters, of which Roche was a strong favorite at 1 to 2, with Merry Monarch a strong second choice, the theory being that Saratoga, air and water might have converted him into a high-class racer.

Opinion in financial quarters in regard to a broadening market for securities as the forerunner of general business revival, was reflected yesterday in the coarse of prices at the Stock Exchange. Nearly all stocks opened at Saturday's quotations or better No special buoyancy appeared in the general list, but those who wished to depress prices soon abandoned the wish, finding buyers ready to absorb offerings and to hold them firmly.
SARATOGA, Aug. 20 -- A very heavy track, a very poor card, and a slim attendance and easy victories for the winners, save In the opening event, made the sport very tame at the track here to-day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Charities has completed its report on the reasons which led it to draw up the charity provisions of the Constitution, which were reported favorably to the convention last week. The report is a lengthy one, in which the committee gives the following reasons for the formation of State Commissions on Charities, Lunacy, and Prisons, as suggested in its proposed amendments:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 20 -- The hotels are filled with horsemen in anticipation of the opening of the circuit meeting here to-morrow. The number of entries exceeds those of any circuit meeting ever held here, there being over 200.

ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- During the three hours of the morning session of the Constitutional Convention to-day, two subjects were disposed of after the usual, daily, painful, and nerve-rasping talk, talk, talk.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The Irish Nationalists in the House of Commons lost their patience early this morning and showed plainly their disgust at the failure of all Irish legislation. Sir William Harcourt, Chancellor of the Exchequer, had proposed the postponement of taking the report of supply, including the vote for the Lords and officials.

If there was anything to be particularly noticed in the proceedings yesterday of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, it was the fact that fewer women were in evidence than on last Wednesday. Whether it was due to the weather or whether it was due to the lull necessary for proper mental digestion, it cannot be denied that a temporary abatement in feminine interest was observed and commented upon.

An engrossed copy of the new Tariff bill, as passed by both houses of Congress, was received at the Custom House in this city yesterday. In view of the prevailing impression that the bill is to become a law, Collector Kilbreth set his heads of departments at work studying the details. Should the President affix his signature before the alloted ten days, the bill becomes operative instantly.
Who was the author of the troublesome paragraph in the new tariff concerning alcohol used in the arts? The New-York Tribune referred to this paragraph yesterday as follows:

-- Recorder Smyth. in Port I. of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday sentenced Mrs. Lizzie Patterson to three years and six months in Auburn Prison. She had been found guilty of attempting to pass forged checks on Tiffany and other jewelers. The Recorder said the Jury would have made no recommendation to mercy had they known her previous career.

After striving hard to get an eleven together, W.D. Hickey succeeded yesterday in placing a team of cricketers in the field to represent the French College, Blackrock, Dublin. He obtained a first-class eleven, which had little difficulty in scoring an easy victory over the Bloomingdale Club at Morris Heights by 92 runs.

Confidence was still expressed by the New-York bankers yesterday that their supply of small bills would be nearly sufficient to meet the demands of their customers in the South and West. Information is also received here that the Chicago banks are paying out large amounts of small bills to help move the crops, and that output relieves the demand on New-York considerably.
The ferryboat Fanwood, belonging to the Jersey Central Railroad, ran into and sank the steam launch Alert shortly after 10:30 yesterday morning.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The canal and commercial interests of the State generally have been trying for several weeks past to secure a favorable report from the Constitutional Convention Committee on Canals of an amendment providing for improvements contemplating an expenditure of $7,000,000 or $8,000,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- There is weeping and wailing in the Italian colony here over the sudden disappearance of Glovanni de Fuccio, who conducted a "Banca Italiana" at 24 Boyden Street. De Fuccio was supposed to be wealthy and the owner of a valuable row of brick houses on Boyden Street, where his bank was situated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Secretary Lamont issued an important order to-day, which will return to their regiments all officers now congregated at the headquarters of the different military departments. For years officers who have conspicuous and responsible places in the line have been called to duty on the staffs of departmental commanders without regard to the inconvenience of the service or to whether the regiment was efficiently commanded by those who remained.

While there is a general sentiment among steamship men, shipping agents, commission merchants, and others directly affected by the tariff measure, that the new bill should become a law, some fears have been expressed that it will operate adversely on the export trade to South America and to Spanish-American ports.

MAPLEWOOD, N.H., Aug. 21 -- The day of the great Bethlehem coaching parade opened cloudy and raw, and a bleak wind from the north made overcoats and wraps necessary. The parade was formed at Maplewood, the first division being led by a regimental band from Concord. A squad of bicyclists from Littleton, St. Johnstoury, and Lisbon led the coaches, following the mounted aides.

A shark attacked Catherine L. Beach, who poses as Diana in one of the living pictures at Koster Bial's, while she was bathing at Woolsey's Point, Long Island City, yesterday afternoon. At least, she declares it did. As proof of her story she calls attention to the shark which was killed and is on exhibition at Ninety-second Street and East River.

Early in the session of the Constitutional Convention an amendment was proposed, emanating from, the National League for the Protection of American Institutions, which prohibited the use of public credit or public money in aid of any "institution, society, or undertaking which is wholly or in part under sectarian or ecclesiastical control."

SARATOGA, Aug. 21 -- That the racing season here is practically ended is evident on all sides. Stables are leaving daily for Sheepshead Bay and the West. The two stakes on for to-day had but few starters, the horses being reserved for more valuable engagements in the future, and the risk of running them over the sticky track was not taken.

Rosie Czeisler, fourteen years old, the daughter of Louis Czeisler, a furrier, of 192 Stanton Street, was either drugged on Monday or swallowed poison with the intention of taking her life. She is now in Gouverneur Hospital in a critical condition.

SOUTH BEACH, S.I., Aug. 21 -- An unusually thick frontal bone in William Kavlin's forehead and a fortunate slant to the muzzle of a policeman's revolver were all that saved this place from another fatal shooting case this morning.

The tax rate in New-York City for the present fiscal year will be the lowest known in thirty-two years. At yesterday's meeting of the Aldermanic Finance Committee the rate was fixed at $1.79 per $100. Last year the rate was $1.82, and previous to the first term of Mayor Grant the rate had not been below $2 since 1862.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 21 -- A tally-ho belonging to Sunset Pavilion, and loaded with eighteen guests, mostly women, was overturned at the Mine Central here this morning. The coach, was demolished, but no one was very seriously injured. They were on the way to the coaching parade at Bethlehem, and the accident was due to the carelessness of the driver in turning too quickly.

The proposed race across the ocean between the schooners Lasca and Selene, as told exclusively in The New-York Times yesterday morning, caused considerable comment in yachting circles. Mr. John E. Brooks thought when he went to England last Spring that he would have lots of racing and would be able to show how much superior an American schooner was to those built on the other side.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times telegraphs under yesterday's date:

ROCHESTER, Aug. 21 -- The factional differences in the Democratic ranks of this city, which caused the party to be badly beaten last Fall, have not as yet been adjusted, but loyal members of the party are now hoping for a harmonious settlement by the appeal to the Sub-Committee of the State Committee appointed for a hearing of grievances.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- A petition against The Traveller Publishing Company was filed in the Insolvency Court this morning by C. F. Berry of Boston. The Traveller is the only Boston paper that could ever be induced to surrender its membership in the New-England Associated Press, and thus abandon its connection with the United Press, and join the Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press."

The reports of increased railway earnings from week to week now largely exceed in number the reports of decreased earnings. This is a refreshing change from the monotonous and disheartening weekly records of losses that have extended over so many months. The fact denotes a very encouraging change in the general railroad situation, and the figures clearly show that the business of railroad transportation is steadily improving in almost every section of the country.

The racing at Jerome Park yesterday was positively stupid. The card had forty horses named for the six races, but sixteen of these were scratched, a majority of them before people got to the track, which very rightly gave the impression that the entries were originally padded to draw people to the track. The scratching proved to be disastrous to the now-unfortunate plunger.

Visitors to the Polo Grounds yesterday witnessed an old-fashioned game of ball. They saw the New-York and Chicago players make home runs, triples, doubles, and singles galore, and tally runs in nearly every inning. These low-figure scores are all right at times, and keep the onlookers in a ferment of excitement, but for good, unadulterated enthusiasm an old-time contest is hard to beat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- If the people of Iowa accept the remarks of Representative D.B. Henderson of Aug. 15 on the appropriations for 1895 without question they will manifest a susceptibility to be gulled that will not be creditable to their discernment or to their curiosity. It is not truthful.

FALL, RIVER, Mass., Aug. 21 -- To-day the mill situation is not improved. A canvass of the mills in this city shows the following conditions: Shut down -- Barnard, Narragansett, Sagamore, Stafford, Stevens, Wampanoag, Weetamoe, Flint. Anawan, and Fall River Manufacturing. Running on full time -- American Line, Iron Works, Metacomet, Globe Yarn, Sanford Spinning, King Philip, and Kerr Thread.
At Brighton Beach Music Hall to-night will be given the second programme of the Wagner festival by the Seidl Society. Following are the programmes for the day:

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 21 -- The Louisiana sugar planters have not yet surrendered all hope of securing the bounty on the growing crop. Preparations are being made for the filing of a suit in the Fall by one of the wealthiest planters in the State to test the legality of the abrogation of the bounty by Congress after it was partly earned.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Vamoose, Frank T. Morrell; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg: Helvetia, C. O'D. Iseiln; Orienta, E.R. Ladew, and Lorna, W.L. Ston. Sloop yachts, Queen Mab, Percy Chubb, and Katrina, George Work.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- At the session of the National Labor Commission this morning the first witness was Michael J. Carroll, editor of The Eight-Hour Herald. Mr. Carroll believed Government ownership of railroads the true solution of the labor problem. He cited the situation in Australia, where the Government owns the telegraph lines, as proof that his ideas were practicable.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- With sixty-two entries the great tennis event of the year, the annual tournament of the National Lawn Tennis Association, opened to-day on the Casino courts. It was a perfect tennis day, except for a high wind, which at times rather interfered with the lobbing of the players.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Notwithstanding the positive assurances given to the correspondent of The New-York Times by several prominent physicians, in connection with the condition of the Passaic water, that there was very little typhoid fever in the city at present, reports from the various public hospitals contradict their statements.

At a Summer resort not far from New-York a debating society, composed of citizens calling themselves Afro-Americans, recently discussed the important question, "Which is the more dangerous animal, a horse or a sailboat?" Undoubtedly this question was suggested by the accidents which have happened recently and not by the pecuniary disasters which accompany racing on either land or water.
The British steamship Cam, which arrived yesterday from Coosaw, S.C., may furnish material for an international complication after she leaves this port.

Aldace F. Walker, who is now in Paris, France, has cabled to the Atchison Reorganization Committee and to the counsel of the Union Trust Company his purpose to accept the appointment of receiver of the Atchison system, in place of J.W. Reinhart. He expects to reach New-York on Sept. 2, and he will qualify for the office without delay.

What is officially known as the second session of the Fifty-third Congress is drawing to a close and will doubtless end within a week. It corresponds to the ordinary first, or long, session of Congress, and, taken with the first session, makes this Congress the most important elected since the close of the war for the Union, now nearly a generation gone.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Emma Goldman, Charles Wilfred Mowbray, John Edelman, and an Italian woman Anarchist named Mrs. Roda were the speakers at the Anarchists' meeting in Phoenix Park Hall to-night. The hall was filled to its utmost capacity. Chief of Police Hopper had three detectives in the audience, and with Capt. Charles Glori of the Fourth Precinct, waited at the latter station with a detail of reserve men should any trouble occur.
The trials of Capts. Cross and Devery and ex-Ward Men Smith, Glennon, and Burns were continued at Police Headquarters yesterday, and there was no change in the manner of conducting the cases.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- Any doubt that Mr. Choate is a candidate for Governor was dispelled this morning by the speech which he delivered against the proposition in the judiciary article to increase the number of Judges of the Court of Appeals from seven to nine.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- The chief social event of the evening was Mrs. W. Fitzhugh Whitehouse's ball, in honor of her daughter, Miss Lilly Whitehouse, who made her social debut on this occasion. Mrs. Whitehouse, assisted by the Misses Fanny and Lilly Whitehouse, received.

At no time was the result of the St. Louis-Brooklyn game in doubt yesterday. In three innings the local players secured a lead of 8 runs, and finally won, 20 to 11. Like the NewYork game, it was a hard-hitting contest. Breitenstein, who has been pitching great ball, apparently had an off day, and the Brooklyn players took advantage of the situation by making twenty-four hits and getting half a dozen bases on balls.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 21 -- Crazed by drink, Charles T. Dawson, a former telegraph editor on The Times and a wellknown newspaper man, used a knife and a revolver in an attempt to kill Detective Philip Demmel at 8 o'clock this morning, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Smithfield Street.

The George C. Flint Company, whose place of business has been at 104 and 106 West Fourteenth Street for many years, has moved into its new furniture store at 43, 45, and 47 West Twenty-third Street. The store will be opened this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Until the Presi- dent has returned and signified his intentions toward the Tariff bill the direction of the Sugar Trust that the Congress shall cease from troubling itself about legislation and go home will not be fully carried out. Meanwhile there is speculation without limit as to whether the bill is to be approved, vetoed, or allowed to become law without approval.

The Russo-Slavonan Bank at 141 Attorney Street has been conducted by Eugene Dudinszky and Emile Volkay without the permission of the State Banking Department, which is a misdemeanor under the laws of the State. Dudinszky was arrested yesterday on a charge of grand larceny, but his partner is out of the city. Katie Metez of 224 Second Avenue deposited $85 in the bank on June 30.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 21 -- Stock Broker James Campbell, one of the prominent figures in St. Louis financial circles, swore out a warrant this afternoon for the arrest of Philip J. Rohan, President and principal owner of the Rohan Boiler Works, charging attempted highway robbery.

Charles Griffith Moses reports the sale of the lot. 28 by 113 by irregular, on Macomb's Dam Avenue, west side, 28 feet south of One Hundred and Fifty-third Street, for the estate of Thomas Faye, for improvement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Imported goods now in bonded warehouses and placed on the free list by the new Tariff bill are to be assessed at the rates prescribed by the McKinley law, while goods in bonded warehouses on which the duty is lowered by the Senate bill, but which are not placed on the free list, are to have the lower rates.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- The Direct Legislation League of New-Jersey met in conference here to-day to agitate the proposed amendment to the State Constitution providing for direct legislation by the people.

The question whether the old duties shall be paid on imported goods now in bond which are on the dutiable list under the McKinley tariff, but on the free list in the new tariff, arises because, in the new tariff, the general provisions concerning dutiable imports are different from those relating to goods on the free list.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 21 -- Justice of the Peace William H. Bannister of Orangetown, Rockland County, was called for examination before Justice Finnerty, in the West Brighton Police Court, this aftenroon. Justice Bannister is a jolly-looking man, thirty-five years old, and is a member of the law firm of Lexow, Bannister Wyre, which is known through the State as Senator Lexow's firm.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- The twenty-one-footers had another race to-day. It was for a silver cup valued at $100. The course was a triangular one. It was from an imaginary line between Brenton's Cove Buoy and a stakeboat, thence to and around a stake off Taylor"s Point, thence to and around Bishop's Buoy to and around a stakeboat near the start, and repeat, a distance of thirteen miles.

OWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Six days' notice for caucuses is sufficient in Tioga County. The convention call is always printed in two issues of The Owego Weekly Gazette before the convention with the call for caucuses included. Could fuller publicity be given?
A sensational tragedy of hopeless, despairing love was enacted in the early hours of yesterday morning in one of the loneliest parts of Central Park.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- The Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts has joined with the American Numismatic and Archaeological Society, the Architectural League of New-York, the College of the City of New-York, and other institutions and organizations in a movement to secure new designs for the silver currency.

Mrs. Hearn keeps a boarding house at 427 West Twenty-third Street, and has in her employ as a cook Delia Varian. Delia has a niece, Eila Quinn, who lives with her mother and her stepfather, John Livingston, at 454 West Twenty-seventh Street. Eila frequently visited her aunt, the cook, and about a month ago Mrs. Hearn employed the girl's stepfather to clean and whitewash the cellar of her house.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The twenty-second annual convention of the State Firemen's Association opened at Normal Hall, in this city, at 10 o'clock this morning, with 450 delegates. President Schlosser presided. The delegates were welcomed in behalf of the city by Mayor John D. Higgins, and in behalf of the old volunteer firemen by the Hon. C.N. Bulger.

Some time ago The Times published as part of the report furnished by the Associated Press an extract from an article printed in The New-York Evening Post, in which it was stated that certain stockholders in The New-York Times had entered suit against the Directors of The New-York Times Publishing Company to recover money paid for certain shares of stock in the company, on the ground that their subscriptions had been obtained by "fraudulent misrepresentation."

Assistant District Attorney Wellman seems determined to get up a police expose entirely of his own. Yesterday he subpoenaed about half a hundred of the leading merchants in the provision district, and it was announced that a case was being prepared against one of the Captains of Police for presentation to the Grand Jury.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- A petition was filed in the Court of Chancery to-day, praying for the release of James A. Barremore from the insane asylum at Amityville, L.I., where, it is claimed, he is confined although perfectly sane. Mr. Barremore is a wealthy man. He was formerly a member of the diamond brokerage firm of Randal, Barremore Billings of 51 Nassau Street, New-York, from which he derived an income of $7,000.

Royal Phelps Catroll, Rear Commodore of the New-York Yacht Club and owner of the cutter Navahoe, hits been anxious to race his boat all this season against the other elghty-five-rooters. He has been very much disappointed because none of them has been in commission in American waters. The Navahoe went to England last year, but had about the same luck there that the Vigilant is having this year.

Col. George W. Dunn and Senator O'Connor, both of Broome County, N.Y., were in town yesterday. Col. Dunn talked in favor of Levi P. Morton for Governor, and Senator O'Connor supported J. Sloat Fassett, although he said his county is not for Mr. Fassett.

The objections interposed by Mr. Warner in the House to Mr. Hill's Anti-Anarchist bill are reasonable. It is not creditable to the Senate that the measure should have passed that body without any real debate. Probably it was regarded there as a mere denunciation of Anarchy, and therefore one of the few things to which it is quite safe for a Senator to commit himself.

We showed yesterday that the paragraph in the new tariff relating to alcohol used in the arts, which The New-York Tribune calls "the stupid mistake of the Democrats," was a Republican amendment, offered by Senator Hoar. We presume that this Senator is now chuckling over the mischief he has done.

The City and County Convention of the Prohibition Party was held last evening in Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue and Forty-second Street, and nominations were made for the city and county ticket in the approaching elections. The Congressional Conventions of the party for the Eighth, Ninth, Tenth, Eleventh, Twelfth, Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Districts were also held in the same hall, after city and county nominations were made, and nominations were made for Congress.

The prize list for the tenth annual exhibition of the National Horse Show Association was issued yesterday by Secretary John G. Heckscher. Premiums aggregating $30,000 are to be distributed at Madison Square Garden during the week of Nov. 12-17, for horses of all breeds, from thoroughbred racers to heavy draught animals.

The anxiety of certain circles in Brooklyn, as described in The New-York Times of last Sunday, to arrive at a comprehension of the attitude of the local religious world toward the bold utterances, almost challenges, of Prof. Brinton and other members of the Association for the Advancement of Science, gained a decided whetting on Monday evening.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The President left here for Washington this afternoon. At 2 o'clock a rowboat was at the wharf at Gray Gables. An hour later Mr. Cleveland, Dr. O'Reilly and Capt. Robley D. Evans boarded the boat and the two sailors rowed them to the lighthouse tender John D. Rodgers, then at anchor in the channel.

GREENBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The Beard of Assessors has just completed its assessment roll for the year. Edwin Gould is assessed on $50,000 personal property, Anna Gould on $5,000, Howard Gould on $50,000, Helen Gould on $50,000, and the heirs of Jay Gould on $100,000.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 22 -- The triennial convocation of the General Grand Chapter of the United States Royal Arch Masons was held at the Masonic Temple here today. Three hundred and fifty prominent members of the fraternity, representing Grand Chapters with an aggregate membership of over 150,000, were present.

A short session of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association was held in the Oriental Hotel, at Manhattan Beach, yesterday afternoon. Questions regarding rates were reported upon and briefly discussed. Gen. J.W. Thomas, President of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Road, of Nashville, was Chairman.

The Park Board at its meeting yesterday decided to discharge immediately the 422 men employed on Riverside Drive because the appropriation of $150,000 had been exhausted. If more money be allowed by the Board of Estimate, some of the men may be re-employed. The work was being done under the One-Million-Dollar Appropriation act.

CHITTENANGO, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- In this locality six days' notice of caucus is ample time. There is nothing that assures attendance so well as to have candidates for office. In this locality those who care to, always know of the caucuses, but many only attend them when they have some point to gain personally.

SARATOGA, Aug. 22 -- The racing here to-day was of the most commonplace character, and there was a decided failing off in the attendance. Ex-Assemblyman David Gideon, Fred Cowan, Philip J. Dwyer, Col. Abe Daniels, and a host of other New-Yorkers have deserted the Springs, and the exodus of New-Yorkers will be complete to-night.

That there is a vastly better feeling among the Democrats of this city and of the State at large now than there was a month ago is quite as apparent as is the fact that the Republicans are becoming very much disturbed over the evident intention of Democrats to harmonize their difficulties and to present a solid party front in this campaign.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 22 -- Interest in the great camp meeting is increasing daily. The early morning meetings to-day were well attended, and hundreds were unable to get inside the temple where the young people's meeting was held. Evangelist Yatman's theme was, "Jesus, God of the Whole Earth."

With little noise and no fuss, the work of elevating the tracks at the upper end of Manhattan Island of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, and other railroads running out of the Grand Central Station, has been going on for several months, and it has progressed so far that now a good idea can be obtained of the magnitude of the undertaking.

Four persons were injured, several horses were maimed, and the wagons to which they were attached were smashed to kindling wood, and a house was considerably damaged by the explosion yesterday afternoon of a cartridge containing a large charge of dynamite, used for the purpose of blasting rock for cellar excavations, at 129 and 131 West Eighty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- The majority members of the Constitutional Convention Committee on Cities have adopted a revision of the city home-rule article on the lines indicated in last night's dispatches. The section providing for the separation of local and general elections is unchanged. The section in regard to election Inspectors and the State Board of Elections is stricken out and the following substituted:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 22 -- The Whisky Trust has succeeded in borrowing all the money it needs for the present, and to-day deposited over $1,000,000 in one of the city banks. This was borrowed in small lots, and parties are offering the trust money in all directions. There are now more than sixty gaugers employed here regauging.

The second week of Souza's great musical festival at Manhattan Beach concludes Sunday night. There are complete changes of programme twice daily. In point of popular interest the present festival surpasses any of its predecessors. The concerts during the latter half of last week attracted to Manhattan over 100,000 people. This week's attractions are novel and varied.

LONG BEACH, Aug. 22 -- At Dr. Burrell's Summer Parliament the labor problem Was discussed to-day by the Director. Dr. W.F. Crafts, by Mrs. Isabella Charles Davis of the King's Daughters, and by Francis Carruthers, who also read the speech which Samuel Gompers had prepared, but was prevented from delivering in person, being obliged to testify at the strike investigation in Chicago.

The September number of The American Federationist, the organ of the American Federation of Labor, will publish some correspondence that has passed between Samuel Gompers. the President of the Federation, and Judpe P.J. Grosscup of Chicago in regard to the recent railroad strike and riots in that city.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 22 -- As early as 8 o'clock this morning people commenced swarming the streets here, preparatory to attending the big Owens barbecue at Woodland Park. There everything was in readiness. Scores of beeves and sheep had been cooked and palatable burgoo was ready to be dished out by the gallon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22 -- The second Meadow Brook polo team won the Newport Cup offered by the Westchester Polo Club to-day. They and the second Rockaways were the only teams entered. The attendance was very large, carriages being three deep on the sides at the field allotted to them. The teams and handicaps were as follows:

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The New York State Firemen's Association concluded its twenty-second annual convention here today, and adjourned to meet at Troy the third Tuesday in August, 1895. The following officers were elected: President -- John F. Schlosser; Vice Presidents -- W.Y. Elliott, Elmira, and J.R. Maboney, Lockport; Secretary -- Thomas Honohan; Treasurer -- G.H. Scott. Coxsackie; Statistician -- W.E. Churchill, Weedsport.

There is a birch-bark letter in this city that has an unusual history and is rather unusual itself. It is a tough piece of the inner bark of the birch tree and is about two feet in length and seven inches wide. The writing, though, about thirty-one years of age, is still legible, and the letter is intact except for a fragment torn from one corner.

Preparations are steadily going on for the big meet of the Mercer County Wheelmen next Saturday at the Inter-State Fair Grounds, at Trenton. It promises to be the greatest event that has yet taken place in cycling circles this year in New-Jersey, New-York, or in Pennsylvania.

The body of Julius Marcus, who killed Mrs. Juliette Fournier in the Ramble in Central Park Tuesday morning and then shot himself, was buried yesterday in Bayside Cemetery, Long Island, by a Hebrew benevolent society. Mrs. Fournier's body will be buried in Evergreens Cemetery, Brooklyn, to-day, after funeral services at her husband's home, at 2:30 o'clock P.M.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 22 -- A.S. Judge, brother-in-law of Pierre Lorillard and General Superintendent of the old Iron Pier at West Brighton, made a bet some time ago with Harry Sturdevant of the bathing pavilion that he would not be frightened at meeting any kind of animal at any hour of the night on the dark pier.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- The end of the second day's debate on the judiciary article found the convention through twelve of the twenty-three sections. Thus far the Judiciary Committee has been able to withstand the assaults made in the way of amendments, save in one instance, where the number of Judges of the Court of Appeals was reduced from nine to seven.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- The representatives of canal interests are still here considering the question of constitutionally providing for canal improvements. The outcome of their deliberations, it is confidently expected, will be the insertion in the Constitution of a provision giving the Legislature discretionary power as to the scope of the canal improvements, and to provide the necessary funds.

Immediately after the re-election of President Cleveland there was a revival in the wool trade in this city, and the New-York Wool Warehouse Company was formed for the purpose of erecting a large building in which the wool interests of the city and the contiguous territory might be brought together under one roof.

Several prominent journals of the Republican Party are filling their editorial columns with false or misleading assertions as to the sugar duties in the new tariff and the attitude of the Republicans in the Senate toward those duties. In this way preparation for the coming Congressional campaign is made.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 22 -- In a quiet spot about a quarter of a mile from Greenlawn Station, toward the village of Huntington, a band of Christians and mission workers from New-York City and Brooklyn are holding an old-fashioned camp meeting.

The police of the Twelfth Precinct, Brooklyn, arrested two men yesterday who are supposed to have committed a number of robberies in that city during the past two weeks. The men are John Williams, twenty-two years old, and James Mansfield, thirty-one years old. They refused to give their residences.

Some of the most peaceful-looking denizens of Chinatown had a small riot yesterday for the purpose of squaring accounts after the law, as administered in a police court, had, as they thought, failed of its purpose. The result of the riot was that the law will have another opportunity to assert its majesty, and this time its scope will take in the celestial partisans that were on both sides of the original controversy.

Joseph Goldwasser, a carpenter, of 205 East Ninety-eighth Street, was arrested yesterday morning for cruelly beating his fourteen-year-old boy, Benjamin, a deaf mute. The boy, because of his infirmity, was unable to remonstrate or make complaint.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- What is usually called Commencement Day in schools and colleges goes by the name of "Recognition Day" here. At that time those "who have completed the four years of study of the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circles are recognized and diplomas are conferred.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22 -- H.B. Duryea gave a cup for the twenty-one-footers to race for to-day and then won it with his yacht Vaquero. The race was the best of the series, especially so as the course for the first time was a single run into the wind and return, and thus the boats had six and a half miles of continuous windward work and as much before the wind.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Miss Lizzie Jones, a nurse girl in the family of Mrs. Taylor of Orange, N.J., had a narrow escape yesterday from drowning in the channel opposite the house where the family is stopping.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 22 -- When the Nebraska Republican Convention got together in Exposition Hall this morning ex-Gov. Thayer, ex-Gov. Saunders, and a score of other old wheelhorses of the party were present on the platform. Banners and bunting were draped about the walls, but these did not attract the attention that a series of caricatures of Congressman Bryan did.
SANDY HOOK, N.J., Aug. 22 -- "With those three guns in position, New-York City is safe against the strongest navy afloat."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 -- The Riverton challenge plate for live-pigeon shooting was again won to-day by Robert S. Welch, his opponent this time being Leonard Finletter. Welch won by 1 bird, the score being 91 to 90. The match was shot on the Riverton (N.J.) Gun Club grounds, and proved to be the most exciting of all the contests for the famous prize.

DANBURY, N.C., Aug. 22 -- A squad of revenue officers, commanded by A.H. Vanderford, has just had an exciting raid on the moonshiners in the famous Smith settlement in the northeastern part of this county. The raiders were piloted by "Jim" Smith, a former blockade distiller.

Mrs. William Leary, thirty-four years old, of 104 West Third Street, was almost burned to death last night, and her neighbors say her husband is responsible for her injuries. She is now in St. Vincent's Hospital in a critical condition, and says her injuries were the result of an accident.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 22 -- About 300 delegates attended the biennial Prohibition Convention which met in this city to-day. Over seventy towns and all the cities were represented. There was complete harmony between the machine and the former dissenters.

PARIS, Sunday, Aug. 5th -- It is such fun! Even during the curious trial of the half-black-sheep Anarchists, which will go down to history as the proces des trente -- and perhaps, give to prosperity more information on the subject than it seems likely afford us -- a good, big, enjoyable smile was given to all Paris by the following true incident:

The Senate of the United States now consists of 88 members, when its membership is full. Owing to the failure of the Legislatures of Montana, Washington, and Wyoming to elect at their last sessions there are three vacancies at present. Of the 85 Senators 44 are Democrats, 37 Republicans, and 4 Populists, including among the latter Stewart of Nevada.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- A dispatch to a news agency in this city states that the King of Corea has declared himself independent of the Chinese Government and has appealed to Japan for assistance to expel the Chinese from the country.

The half-mile trade at Parkway is rather narrow to admit of a good race with a big field, and, solely on this account, several races yesterday that promised to be exciting were spoiled. The first race of the afternoon had twelve maiden two-year-olds, against any of which as good as 4 to 1 could have been obtained.

A letter warmly indorsing the Good Roads tournament has been received from Senator David B. Hill, and the Hon. Edward Borrough. Commissioner of Public Roads for the State of New-Jersey, has also written in the same vein. The tournament promises to be a splendid success in every particular. Large parties of cyclists from Boston, Baltimore, Buffalo, and Philadelphia, as well as other cycling centres, will be on hand.

From The Albany Argus. Now that each of the Democratic organizations is complete, with its recognized heads, they should get together and make one Democratic Party in the County of Albany. Why should not the two General Committees, the old and the new, consolidate and arrange for a system of joint primaries this Fall under their joint auspices?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- There is some talk of abandoning the purchase of discharges in the army. The proposition is made in view of the law regulating enlistments, which will make the term three years of service. This is considered by some authorities as a sufficiently short period to make unnecessary any desire for buying a discharge.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- After the lively work of the Grand Circuit horses here yesterday, this quiet old city woke up a little, and sent a much larger crowd to see the races this afternoon. The four classes were interesting to the end. Daisy De Spain, with two heats of the 3:19 pace to her credit from last evening, sold at long odds over the six that opposed her today.
Wheat lost 5/8 @ 7/8 and closed weak on reports of more favorable weather abroad, weaker West, and local realizing, with trading fair.

-- In Supreme Court, Chambers, before Justice Beach, a motion was signed yesterday for the remoral of an action brought in this county by Michael B. and Peter T. Moore against William Moore, to recover $106,000, to Albany County. Michael B. Moore and his son. Peter T. Moore, for years carried on business in Cohoes as manufacturers of knit woolen and cotton goods.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- The market for local stocks was not as active as yesterday, and fluctuations were narrow. The special feature was the activity of Mexican Central stock and the strength of all the securities of that road. The stock sold up 1/4, to 8 3/4, and the 4s and income bonds were steady at 57 1/2 and 14, respectively.

From The Westminster Gazette. In the height of the Summer season, the vicar of Kirk Braddon, Isle of Man, holds morning service in the churchyard, instead of the church. The practice has developed into an honored tradition, had when the weather is warm and bright and fine, as seems usually to be the case, the service is attended by a great multitude of people.

"Parting is such sweet sorrow," and of a sweetness so invariable that the American Association for the Advancement of Science could not forbear yesterday from testifying, with visual evidence, how keenly it felt to find its annual holiday was over. Brooklyn, truly a stormed and captured fortress, over which flew the neutraltinted ensign of Eruditia, had scarcely been taken by storm before, under stress of time, it had to be evacuated.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- The will of the late Arthur Rotch, the well-known architect, gives mere than $100,000 to public and charitable purposes. To Abbott Lawrence Rotch and William Caleb Loring, his trustees, he fives $25,000 in trust to pay the income to his aunt, Joanna Rotch of Milton, during her life, and at her death the whole of the principal is to so to the Massachusetts Charitable Eye and Ear Infirmary.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- Two scouts from Chautauqua County drifted into Albany this morning in the persons of Jerome Fisher of Jamestown and S. Fred Nixon of Westfield. the candidate for member of Assembly from that county. They were reconnoitring for their friend Arthur C. Wade, who will go to the Republican convention as a candidate for Lieutenant Governor with a solid Chautauqua delegation at his back.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22 -- The sixty-two men who started in on Tuesday in the tennis tournament at the Casino have now dwindled down to sixteen, who are yet to battle for the right to claim the championship. The solitary match in the preliminaries and all the matches in the first round have been completed, and the tournament is well under way.

Nearly 180,000 acres of rich agricultural land in the Province of Quebec has been given away in bounties for large families in the last four years by the Provincial Government. These bounties are regulated by law, and are paid at the rate of 100 acres of Government land for every family of twelve or more children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A communication in The New-York Times of Sunday, signed "Business." asking why, if Senators Vest, Hill, and Blackburn, are as much opposed to the Senate rules as they profess to be, they do not make a united effort to change the rules, illustrates the popular misconception of the obstacles in the way of this much-needed reform.

"Mike" Dwyer's fondness for matchmaking will probably cool off a bit. Yesterday's experience at Jerome Park ought to do it. The mere fact that he lost both the matches he made may not cue so much of a figure in causing this cooling off as the vast amount of dissatisfaction which the match between Stonenell and Gienmoyne brought about.

Business at the Stock Exchange lost in volume yesterday, falling 30 per cent. below that of Tuesday, both in stocks and bonds. In its early course the market followed Tuesday's lead, and pointed toward realizing sales and a reduction in prices. This tendency was checked by midday. Then the market turned, and improvement held to the close of business.

"When the Senate committee, which was appointed to investigate municipal departments in New-York City, meets, Sept. 10," said Chairman Lexow yesterday. "its sessions will be conducted as heretofore, and the proceedings will have the same character as those in May and June."

HIGGANUM, Conn., Aug. 22 -- This is the home of the Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, Clinton B. Davis. The day before last Christmas Mr. Davis became seriously ill with a savage attack of the grip, and he has been under the weather, as it were, ever since. The past two months he has spent in Norfolk, Conn., building up his health and nursing a throat trouble.

From The San Francisco Chronicle. The Chronicle is in receipt of an interesting letter from that enthusiastic sportsman, John K. Orr, who is spending a vacation in Northern Sonoma and Mendocino County. Mr. Orr forwards with his letter a photograph which presents a beautiful piece of mountain scenery in Mendocino County, and is remarkable because showing a deer caught in life by the camera.
Oliver Sumner Teall made his debut in east side politics last night by joining the James G. Blaine Republican Club of the Second Assembly District.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 22 -- William Myers of New-York, who for a number of seasons past has occupied a cottage at 216 Fifth Avenue, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Borough Marshal Smith, charged with keeping a disorderly house, where gambling was carried on and liquor sold in violation of law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- At the opening of this morning's session of the National Labor Commission. Chairman Wright announced that the majority of witnesses for labor had been heard, and that the railroads and the Pullman Company would now be allowed to present their side of the case.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Aug. 22 -- The Sons of Veterans encamped here discussed important changes in the national organization to-day. The age of admission was changed from twenty-one to eighteen years. The Sons of Veterans Guard was done away with as an independent organization and placed under the jurisdiction of division commanders.

MERRICK, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Within three nights half a dozen burglaries have been committed in Smithville South. The heaviest losers have been the farmers. Their houses have been raided, their fields pillaged, and in some instances growing crops destroyed by the miscreants. Robberies have been committed in two of the village hotels and a number of private houses.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- The Imperial Health Commission has been notified of the occurrence in Dantzic of five new cases of cholera. The disease has made its appearance at Kattowitz, in Prussian Silesia, and the Governor of this district has ordered that a strict quarantine be established along the Russian frontier.

There was a conference in the Collector's office at the Custom House yesterday over the provisions of the new Tariff bill. Copies of the bill were distributed a few days ago among the heads of departments, and all hands have been studying the new schedules, noting the changes, This they have done in expectation that recently-enacted tariff will be allowed by the President to become law.

Notwithstanding all the reports that have been circulated and the seeming mysteries that have surrounded the movements of the agents for the British steamship Cam, a reporter for The New-York Times was told yesterday that, as yet, no war material of any description had been put aboard the steamship for China or Japan, or had been purchased for her cargo.

The defense of Capt. Cross, on trial betore the Police Commissioners, was interrupted at the beginning of the first session yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Wellman, who called the Rev. Dr. William Hamilton, who was pastor of the Allen Street Memorial Church from 1891 to 1894, as a witness in the case of Capt. Devery and Policeman Glennon.
The following is a list of the passengess booked to sail to-day in the Augusta Victoria, for Southampton and Hamburg:

From The London Daily News. Though Sir Walter Raleigh was the first to introduce tobacco into this country, inquirers into the history of the weed are familiar with the fact that it had already been imported into Europe long before Raleigh was born. The facts are retold in an official summary by Sir George Bonham of the recent financial statement of the Spanish Minister of Finance.

From the Philadelphia Times. The historical pilgrims, who made themselves familiar with the State House. Carpenters' Hall, and other historical objects of interest in this city, before leaving for New-York and Boston, accomplished much in the way of personal interest and historic discovery by their trip.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The President's return to-night, in good health and in condition to resume the work he dropped for a few days, has increased interest in the fate of the Tariff bill. While there are but four days left for doubting, the anxiety to know whether the bill is to become a law with or without the signature of the President is general.

The Republican faction fight in Albany County caused another meeting of the subcommittee of the Republican State Committee at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, and will cause a meeting of the State Committee itself to-day.

Horatio T. Saunders was arraigned in the Court of General Sessions yesterday on a charge of bigamy, brought by a woman who claims to have been married to him five years ago. They have been living at 253 West Seventeenth Street. In court was another woman, who claims to have been married to Saunders twenty years ago.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Electra, Elbridge T. Gerry; Nourmahal, John J. Astor; Lorna, W.L. Stone; Nada, C.R. Flint; Aquilo, George A. Thayer; Spindrift, E.H. White, and Almy, F. Gallatin.

The Treasury statement of the money received for customs at this port is completed to Aug. 20. For the ten days preceding that date, with receipts of $4,652,982, the proportion of gold was only eighttenths of 1 per cent., or 80 cents on every $100. Silver certificates were 57.5 per cent, and Treasury notes 21.7 per cent., forming together 79.2 per cent., or practically four-fifths of the total receipts.

Correspondence London Telegraph. In the Tshirigin District (Government of Kiev) a well-meaning woman, meeting a hungry, discontented-looking peasant, told him to be of good cheer, as she had it in her power to make him rich in a twinkling, so to say. "Well, mother," he replied, "you won't come across a more deserving fellow than myself between this and the place you've come from, however far that may be."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- President Cleveland returned to Washington to-night from his outing at Gray Gables. Mr. Cleveland seemed in the best of health.

AUBURN, Aug. 22 -- Wells College, at Aurora, has called William E. Waters. Ph. D., of the University of Cincinnati, to its Presidency, to fill a vacancy occasioned by the resignation of the Rev. E.S. Frisbee, D.D. Prof. Waters has accepted, and will enter upon the discharge of his duties at the opening of the collegiate year nest September.

The confirmation of the President's appointment of Mr. A. Augustus Healy of Brooklyn to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the First District would give a marked forward impulse to the cause of Democratic harmony in this State. In Mr. Healy's case the Finance Committee of the Senate, we suppose, awaits the pleasure of the Senators from the State of New-York.

The news that the Tariff bill had passed had no more than reached Lewiston than the manufacturers of cotton and woolen textile fabrics in this city, regardless of party, hastened to acknowledge that the settlement of the tariff question would greatly benefit the cotton and woolen manufactures.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The case against Frank Cornell and Contractor R. Cole to restrain Cornell from constructing a bridge across a stream which separates Manersing Island from the mainland was called this afternoon before Justice Baruch at this place.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Theodore Babcock, an actor, living at 240 West Thirtyseventh Street, New-York, and Mary McConnell, an actress, of 31 West Sixty-fifth Street, NewYork, were married in this city this afternoon by Justice Christian Geiger at his office in Gregory Street. The witnesses were J.J. Spires and Louis Parsons, friends of the couple.

A few of the 10,000 pages of The Congressional Record, reporting one of the thousand or more speeches on the question of the tariff in the second session of the Fifty-third Congress, were occupied recently by copious citations translated from a speech by M. Leon Chotteau of Paris.

It seems already to have been demonstrated that the Chinese Navy, cannot keep the sea against the Japanese, and consequently cannot convoy or protect troops destined to disembark in Corea. The only other way of getting them into Corea is to march them over or through the mountains at the back of the peninsula.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The Second Assembly District Republican Convention of Monroe County was held here tonight, when the following delegates to the State Convention were elected: D.W. Powers, George C. Buell, Max Brickner, James G. Cutler, E.H. Makk, Martin W. Cook, J.C. Woodbury, and John U. Schroth.

Two big political and social clubs had their annual outings yesterday. The Columbian Club of the Fifth Assembly District went to Donnelly's Grove, at College Point, L.I., and the Schnorer Club went to Roton Point, on the Sound.

Louis Hermann, twenty-five years old, of Third Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street borrowed a horse and business wagon yesterday morning from George F. Zinn, an expressman of 201 East Seventeenth Street. Hermann did not return the outfit, but tried to sell it for $25 in the horse market. First Avenue and Seventy-first Street, to a man named Murray.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs gave a ball to-night in the Casino Theatre in honor of her sister. Miss Virginia Fair. The interior of the theatre was elaborately decorated with plants. The galleries were festooned, and the stage, where the orchestra sat, was a bower of rare tropical plants.

Capt. Owen of the steamship Alps of the Atlas Line arrived here yesterday with his ship from Haiti and Jamaica. He was asked by a reporter for The New-York Times about the condition of political affairs in Haiti, while he was there. He stated that at all the Haitian ports at which he touched everything was quiet and tranquil.

A hearing will be had upon the application of Mrs. Elizabeth Garnett at Bristol, England, for the removal of the receivers of the Jarvis-Conklin Mortgage Trust Company, before Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court next Tuesday. The papers upon which the application will be made are on file with the Clerk of the Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- At Washington Park today, Directum was sent for a fast mark, but the black horse is evidently not fit yet. Hickok gave him a warming-up mile, which he did in 2:08 1/2. Then he was sent for a fast turn, and could not do better than 2:10. He pulled up very tired. The race for the 2:08 class pacers furnished a surprise.

NEW-BEDFORD, Aug. 23. -- Richard B. Barry of Lynn and Richard B. Warner of Taunton, members of the State Board, arrived in town this morning to investigate the strike. The third, member, Charles H. Wolcott, is now on his vacation, and was not informed of the visit.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The convention of the State firemen will be concluded to-morrow with a big parade of firemen and fire apparatus. The contests to-day were exciting, and much interest was manifested by the immense crowd that witnessed them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Secretary Gresham and Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador, have agreed upon a convention, to be ratified by the United States and Great Britain, providing for a commission to meet at Vancouver to consider the amounts of damage to be paid by the United States for seizing Canadian sealers more than three miles from land from 1886 to 1890, inclusive.

The present idea of the Republicans in Congress seems to be to prevent anything thing done that can by any possibility be for the advantage of the country and the credit of the Democratic Party. In the case of the alcohol amendment, they have gone one step further and incorporated in the Tariff bill a distinctly dangerous and damaging provision for which they now seek to hold the Democrats responsible.

The Committee on Cities of the Constitutional Convention has reported its socalled "home rule" amendment in revised form. In two respects it is decidedly improved. It provides for three classes of cities, instead of two, to which general laws shall apply, and the provision for a State Board of Election Commissioners to appoint the election officers of cities is stricken out.

Boston, Aug. 23. -- A fire in the blocks 2 and 8 High Street, shortly after midnight, badly damaged the leather and shoe findings stock of F. W. Whitcher Co. Stephen Dow Co.'s stock of fancy leather also suffered much damage. Richard Young, dealer in fancy leathers; F.W. Henderson Co., and several other concerns were losers by smoke and water.

The special Committee of the Constitutional Convention on Forest Preservation has reported the unanimous conclusion that the forest lands now owned and hereafter acquired by the State, and the timber thereon, should be preserved intact as a forest preserve, and not under any circumstances be sold.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The following companies have been incorporated with the Secretary of State:

Whatever there was of interest about yesterday's meeting of the Republican State Committee had to do with the talk of those who came to the city to attend the meeting about the canvass for the Gubernatorial nomination.
PANAMA, Aug. 16. -- Advices from Chile to The Star and Herald say:

Howard E. Raymond, Chairman of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen, got back from Denver yesterday feeling in high spirits over the fact that he had seen the greatest meet in the history of the League of American Wheelmen. Mr. Raymond was loud in his praises of the local management, saying, among other things, that it left absolutely no stone unturned to make the event the best the league ever had.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 23. -- George Taylor of this city broke the bicycle record for the unpaced half-mile with flying start at Hampden Park this afternoon. The track was fine and the atmospheric conditions favorable for speed, and the distance was covered in 1:00 1-5. The record for the distance was previously held by Walter Sanger, at 1:01 2-5.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 23. -- CoL J.M. Winstead, one of the most prominent citizens of Greensborough, N.C., and President of the Piedmont and the People's Banks of that city, committed suicide here this morning by jumping from the tower of the City Hall, a distance of ninety-four feet. His body fell upon an iron railing near the pavement and was horribly mangled, every bone in the body except the skull being broken.

Karl Werner, known also as Karl Wasner, who was one of the witnesses before the Lexow committee, was arraigned before Recorder Smyth in the General Sessions yesterday to plead to a charge of bribery. He pleaded not guilty, and when the Clerk asked him who his lawyers were he said Mr. Goff, Mr. Moss, and former Assistant District Attorney Jerome.

The board of engineering experts appointed by President Cleveland to determine the length of the span of the proposed bridge across the North River from New-York to the New-Jersey shore has completed its report, which will reach the Secretary of War at Washington to-day.
SARATOGA, Aug. 23. -- Judge Hunt presided at this morning's session of the American Bar Association. He introduced Moorfield Storey of Boston, who read the annual address.

After posing fastidiously before the camera of Photographer Joseph Hall, at Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, July 28, and ordering two dozen pictures, price $8, a smirk, fair-spoken young man offered a check for $15 on the Fourteenth Street Bank to the photographer. Mr. Hall did not have $7 at hand, but he took the fifteendollar check and gave his own check for $7 on the Brooklyn Bank to his smoothspoken young customer.

The Democrats of Brooklyn are awakened to the necessity for harmony. The Republicans are going to make a strong fight to carry the city and county this Fall. They are encouraged by the victory or the fusion ticket last November. Two members of Mayor Schieren's Cabinet are to be voted for -- the City Auditor and the City Controller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The special committee of the House which has been investigating the charges affecting the reliability of the material for the new ships furnished by the Carnegie Company of Pittsburg laid its report before the House to-day. The report shows that the contract with the company covered a period of two years and three months, from November, 1890, to February, 1893.

The disturbed condition of east-bound railroad rates, both freight and passenger, occupied the attention of the joint committee of the trunk lines, the Central Traffic, and the New-England Associations, in this city yesterday. For sometime past discontent has been brewing among the several lines in these associations in consequence of the apparent unequal division of business.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The efficiency of the dynamite pneumatic gun for harbor defense was once more demonstrated to-day in the official tests made in the presence of the Government representatives. The test to-day was a comparatively brief affair, and only dummy shells were fired, but it was nevertheless of great importance, as it showed as in the other tests that the gun exceeds in every particular the requirements of the Government contract.

The report that the New-York State Democracy will propose to Tammany Hall that delegates elected by it -- the State Democracy -- should have one-third of the seats in the State Convention, is premature. The men who will talk about such matters and advise their followers as to what they think is in the best interest of party unity, have not yet met, and many of them are now out of town.

A change in the date for the closing of the entry list for the important twenty-five-mile handicap road race over the Elizabeth-Rahway course on Labor Day has been made. The original date was Aug. 31, but, owing to the large list of entries promised, it was deemed advisable to close on the 29th. Intending competitors should make a note of this change.

ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- There were 126 savings banks doing business in New-York State July 1, 1894. This is four less than on the corresponding date in 1893. These 126 banks are distributed through thirty-one of the sixty counties, New-York leading, with 25. Kings County is second, with 14; West-Chester third, with 10, and Albany fourth, with 9.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- This was the banner day of the Grand Circuit meeting. The attendance was the largest and the sport quite the most interesting of the week. A hot wave which came this morning enabled the horses to go several fast miles. This was notably the case in the 2:14 trot, which brought together a field of eight well-seasoned campaigners.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The long-continued drought has left the ponds and streams of Sullivan County the lowest they hare been in years, and in many instances wells and springs have gone dry. If a prolonged rain does not fall before the Winter closes in the people will suffer. On top of the drought have come myriads of grasshoppers to aid in destroying that which may have escaped the dry, heated term.

The Xavier Club was the purchaser of the four-story stone-front residence property 205 West Fourteenth Street, the sale of which, by Jefferson M. Levy, at $29,000, was reported last week. The club will us the property as a clubhouse, after renovation, abandoning its present quarters at 27 and 29 West Sixteenth Street, to the Apostleship of Prayer, which will come here from Philadelphia Smyth Ryan were the brokers in the sale.

District Attorney Fellows, Assistant District Attorney Wellman, and President Martin had a long conference after Wednesday's session of the trial of Capt. Cross, which was assumed to relate to the independent police investigation.

ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- The strongest proposition to preserve the State's forest lands from the hands of the despoller was brought into the Constitutional Convention this morning by David McClure of New-York, Chairman of the special committee which was appointed to determine what action the convention should take in the matter.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The Republican delegates to the Constitutional Convention are in a state of mind over the apportionment plan which The New-York Times printed July 23, and which proposes to carve the State into 50 Senate and 150 Assembly districts, Instead of 32 Senate and 132 Assembly districts.

BALLSTON LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- In my judgment, six days' notice of primaries in rural districts, where rival factions exist in the same party, is not sufficient. Laws governing primaries in rural districts are insufficient to secure political rights, and should be amended. The primaries should be held for State and national elections on the same day throughout the State, and for district elections on the same day throughout the respective districts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23. -- United States Marshal Baldwin, accompanied by four deputies, Lieut.
