Storey, and Salvadorean Consul Calderon, left this morning on a tug for the cruiser Bennington, which has been lying off the Heads and beyond civil jurisdiction for many days awaiting orders from Washington to enter this port.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- General Manager St. John of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Road appeared as a voluntary witness before the National Labor Commission this morning. Mr. St. John testified that the Rock Island Road had 12,517 employes. He then read a series of briefs covering the strike on the Rock Island Road from day to day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The judiciary article was adopted by the Committee of the Whole at 10:30 to-night. Not one of the fifteen amendments that have been offered since the debate began on Monday was accepted, unless the Judiciary Committee accepted it.

The world, in spite of the dire prophecies of Wiggins and other birds of ill omen, is still young. At any rate, it has much to learn. For instance, the English language is still the victim of a good deal of leather-bound ignorance, and some honest, respectable words are goaded even unto madness.
LONDON, Aug. 23. -- The Central News has advices from Shanghai to the effect that the Japanese Government has declared rice to be not included among the articles contraband of war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Both the Treasury balance and the gold reserve are feeltag the beneficial effects of a revival of business. The net balance to-day stands at $122,710,000, a gain of $700,000 to-day, of which $54,382,000 is in gold. This gives the Treasury Department a very comfortable balance, outside of the gold reserve, upon which to carry on the business of the Government.

James Giblin, Superintendent of Construction at the new Appraiser's Stores Building, at Greenwich and Christopher Streets, and Edward Murray, a bricklayer engaged upon the work, were killed there yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 23. -- To-day's attendance at the Kansas City Athletic Club tournament was but little larger than yesterday, the poorest two days' attendance of the season and smaller than any single day. But three Class B events were run. The one-mile open had a set of pneumatic tires for a prize, and but two outside riders started.

A dead heat between two maiden two-year-olds, Midstar and Albert A., in which the former was successful in the run-off; three other races in which the winners were victorious by the very narrowest of margins; three victories for the popular but never very successful Preakness Stable's horses, and three winning mounts for Martin Bergen and two winning mounts for Sims were the features that furnished excitement for race-goers at Jerome Park yesterday.

Gov. Flower sent some communications to the State Board of Health, which met yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel. The date of the meeting had been advanced because of the board's anxiety to resume the Investigation of the Newtown Creek nuisances.
FLUSHING, L.L., Aug. 23. -- A check for $200, issued by the village of Whitestone, has been dishonored by the Flushing National Bank.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The handsome Summer residence of R. Frank Downing, at this place, was the scene of a festive gathering this afternoon, when 200 prominent New-Yorkers and Westchesterites assembled to attend his ninth annual clambake. As the guests arrived they were received by Mr. Downing, who wore a white yachting costume.
Mrs. Margaret Leary, who was severely burned about the head, face, and body Wednesday night, as was told in The New-York Times of yesterday, died in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday morning.

Frederick Hoffman of 111 West Eighty-fourth Street, Efford King of 473 Columbus Avenue, Annie Levy of 114 West Eighty-third Street, and Mrs. S.W. Oliver of 109 West Eighty-fourth Street, who were injured by the explosion of a dynamite cartridge on Wednesday in an excavation at 131 West Eighty-fourth Street, were reported yesterday as much improved and not seriously injured.

Yesterday's stock market encouraged those who believe that an end has come to dullness and bottom prices. Heretofore large business has been traceable to movements in speculative specialties, notably in the industrial stocks. These stocks were active yesterday, but they did not monopolize attention.

"The Democracy of Texas has declared for Cleveland and for sound money" was the triumphant assertion of The Galveston News after the action of the State Convention at Dallas last week. The Democratic Party has such a tremendous ascendency in the Lone Star State that it has a tendency to divide upon inevitable differences of opinion, among its leading men.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 23. -- The Executive Committee of the State University Board of Regents met this evening agam for the purpose of hearing the trial of Dr. Ely, Professor of Political Economy, on charges of Socialistic teachings preferred by State Superintendent Wells.

There was but one expression among the Democrats of Brooklyn yesterday In regard to the suggestion of The New-York Times, that the confirmation of the President's nomination of A. Augustus Healy of that city to be Internal Revenue Collector in the First District, would give a marked forward impulse to the cause of Democratic harmony in the State.

No-thoughtful American, we think, can read Judge Cooley's address to the Bar Association at Saratoga without coming to the conclusion that the author chose precisely the most important topic that can just now engage the attention of American lawyer, or, indeed, of American laymen.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- A few days ago, brief dispatches received from Managua, Nicaragua, stated that Bluefields had been taken by a Nicaraguan army. Nothing else has been heard officially.
CARMEL, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Putnam County has aspirants for the offices of Governor and Lieutenant Governor in the persons of Gen. Daniel Butterfield of Cold Spring and Col. Hamilton Fish of Garrisons.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The Republican Congressional Convention for the Twenty-third Congressional District assembled at the Witherill House this afternoon at 2 o'clock, and, after organization, in view of the attendance and interest, adjourned to the Court House.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- In the race for twenty-one-footers for the second Citizens' Cup to-day H.P. Whitney's Dorothy won. She lost 1 minute and 10 seconds at the starts, but she was handled grandly by her owner and Tom Hitchcock. The race was witnessed by Secretary and Miss Herbert on Royal Phelps Carroll's Navahoe, Mr. Carroll flying the Secretary's pennant at the masthead of his boat.

-- General officers of the Illinois Central Railroad give it out in Memphis that after Sept. 1 that road will own and control the Chesapeake and Ohio Southwestern, and will run its fast passenger and freight trains from New-Orleans to Chicago through Memphis over the Yazoo and Mississippi Valley and the Chesapeake and Ohio, abandoning the route for fast trains through Jackson, Miss., and Jackson, Tenn.

Amos Rusie pitched one of those games on which he made his reputation, yesterday. For some time past the Hoosier Hercules has been out of sorts, and, in consequence, batsmen of opposing clubs have been treating him in a manner most distasteful to the big pitcher. But he faced the Colonels from the big Kentucky city yesterday, and in only one inning did they score.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 23. -- Mrs. Katherine Robbins Howe, the confidence woman, who is now languishing in the Hartford County jail, in this city, was a popular temperance lecturer here twenty years ago, soon after her marriage with the Canada missionary, Clayton. She worked under the auspices of the Temple of Honor and lectured in the Centre and First Methodist Churches.
Inness, to whom a Hellenic people would have raised statues, received yesterday the most delicately-impressive homage that the modern world may pay.

The third meeting of the Garbage Commission, appointed by the Mayor to receive plans for disposing of the city's garbage, was held in the office of the United States Supervisor of New-York Harbor, in the Army Building, yesterday afternoon. There were present Lieut. Commander Daniel Delehanty, Supervisor of the Harbor; President Wilson of the Board of Health, Street Cleaning Commissioner Andrews, and Franklin Edson.

SARATOGA, Aug. 23. -- The feature of the sport here to-day was the success of the Western lightweight, Perkins. He had mounts in all of the races, and brought his horse home winner in every race except the Morrissey Stakes, in which he had the mount on George Beck. This stake was won by Ducat, the favorite in the betting, and a horse that has been wonderfully improved by his visit here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- James B. Mc- Creary, Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, and one of the Democratic lead- ers of the House, in reviewing the work of the House during the present session of Congress, said to a representative of the United Press to-day:

The three little dancers, Carlotta M., Leonora H., and Florence B. Ewer, who are known on the stage as La Regaloncita, La Graciosa, and La Preciosa, appeared be- fore Acting Mayor McClelian yesterday in the act they wish to give in the perform- ance of "1492," for which they have been engaged by E.E. Rice.

The United States cruiser Cincinnati left the New-York Navy Yard yesterday morn- ing and steamed up the Sound, where dur- ing the next week the vessel will undergo a series of speed and manoeuvring trials. These will have no reference to premiums for well-doing or penalties for failure, as the cruiser was built under Government supervision and by navy yard workmen.

The six races run at Jerome Park yesterday afternoon brought to a close the Summer meeting of the American Jockey Club. It was not a brilliant closing, and that was not expected, for the meeting has not been of a class to warrant it. As a matter of fact, the racing was very commonplace and of the business sort, with little of the sporting phase about it.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The Mercer County Wheelmen had the town ablaze with red lights to-night. Just to put the place in a bicycle fever for the great inter-State meet to-morrow, they had a street parade, and 200 wheelmen turned all the corners in the centre of the town, blowing horns and whistles, and burning red and blue lights.
Two men were taken to the Harlem Hospital yesterday afternoon under very pecullar circumstances.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Robert J. paced a heat to-day at Washington Park in 2:05, gaining the race record. It was in a match race with Joe Patchen for $5,000 a side that the wonderful performance took place, and 4,000 persons saw the fast stepping.

PALATKA, Fla., Aug. 24. -- R.C. Scott. City Treasurer of Jacksonville, and Market Inspector McCurdy of that city are under arrest here charged with kidnapping B.W. Helverstor of Live Oak. a delegate from Shawnee County to the Second District Democratic Convention, now in session here. Helverstor says that Scott and McCurdy, with two other men, took him in a closed carriage to a lonely spot outside of the city and gagged him.
Paul Ritter, the steward of the Union Club, Bedford Avenue and Taylor Street, Brooklyn, had a terrible hand-to-hand encounter with a burglar early yesterday morning.
Following is a complete list of saloon pas- sengers who have been booked to sail by the vessels of to-day's outgoing fleet:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The third and last day of the Bar Association meeting was devoted to business. Prolonged discussion of papers read Wednesday and Thursday crowded out most of the business which was on the programme for yesterday morning and last evening, and to-day's session was three rolled into one.

The Giants had a batting bee at the Polo Grounds yesterday and used the downtrodden Colonels from Kentucky to retrieve the balls. Batting averages mounted higher and higher as the game progressed, and not for a long time will the Louisville players forget the exercise they got in this game with Ward's men. It was a veritable slaughter, twenty-six hits being the sum total resulting from Mr. Knell's work in the box.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Secretary Herbert entertained at dinner to-night at the Renaissance Cottages. His guests were Commodore and Mrs. Gerry, H.P. Whitney, Mr. and Mrs. R.J. Wilson, Capt. Anderson, United States Army; Mrs. Loring, Miss Herbert, Goold H. Redmond, Roman Baldwin, Capt. G.H. Perkins, United States Navy; Miss Perkins, and H.A. Herbert, Jr.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Chief of Police Foley to-day arrested Jesse Stone, thirteen years old, and his brother Elias, ten years old, on a charge of forgery. They are the sons of Elias Stone, a New-York lawyer of 21 Park Row, who lives at 1 Cooley Place, this city. The youthful forg- ers were arraigned before Judge Bard this evening and held in $250 bail each to appear for trial on Monday.

-- The pleasing announcement comes from Macmillan Co. that they will issue in September Bartlett's long-promised "New and Complete Concordance, or Verbal Index to Words, Phrases, and Passages in the Dramatic Works of Shakespeare." Mr. Bartlett has been engaged in this work for more than twenty years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24. -- The Salvadorean refugees were brought before United States District Judge Morrow at 11 o'clock this morning on warrants charging them with murder, robbery, and arson. Attorney Pierson for San Salvador asked for a postponement of the case to obtain evidence of Ezeta's guilt. Attorney Rubens made an argument for the release of his clients on bail.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Malodorous Newtown Creek was the subject of a special investigation to-day by a committee of the State Board of Health, selected by Gov. Flower, to look into the many complaints lodged against nuisances maintained along its banks.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- An auction sale of the first large shipment of California fruit brought to this country by the steamer Paris was held at Covent Garden to-day. All parts of England were represented among the 500 persons in attendance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The long-standing dispute between the steamship com- panies at New-York and the Bureau of Immigration at Washington is now in a fair way to an amicable settlement. Superin- tendent Stump has submitted a plan, which it is understood the steamship companies will ratify, to charge 25 cents per head on each immigrant landed, in addition to the head tax.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- The prominent feature of the market was the activity and strength of the Bay State Gas securities, resulting from a rumor that the internecine warfare in the management of the company had ceased. The 5s sold up 1 1/4, to 82 1/4; the seconds 1 1/2, to 61 1/2, and the stock 1/2, to 10. Mexican 4s were firm at 57 3/4, and the stock at 8 7/8.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- All of the appointments that will be confirmed at the present session of the Senate were confirmed to-day. At least this was the understanding, and, while there is no reason why the Senate should not attend to more executive business, which does not absolutely require a quorum, as to-day's, proceedings showed, the Senate will probably try to be consistent about this announcement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Tariff bill will become a law on Monday, and will begin to take effect from midnight of that day. This was the information obtained yesterday, as stated in dispatches to The New-York Times, and it has received corroboration from several sources to-day. From all the available sources of information the impression is derived that the bill will become a law without any comment whatever from the President.

To the Editor of The New York Times. The dispatch published in The New-York Times from Oswego over the signature of Anthony Salledin, Jr., Chairman of the Democratic County Committee, is misleading in some respects, particularly as to the statement that "there is only one Democratic organization in Oswego County."

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Of the ten Chicago east-bound lines, four at least, and probably six, are cutting freight rates freely. The cutting began on provisions, ostensibly to meet competition of the lake lines. It has now extended to all high class freight on the list, and in some cases to grain. All the rate-cutters are members of the east-bound freight pool, and are bound by it to the absolute maintenance of rates.

Secretary C.A. Underhill of the Harlem Wheelmen does not agree with many of the critics in the statement that the Manhattan Field track is unsafe for fast cycling. He explains his views in a letter to The New-York Times as follows:
CREEDE, Col., Aug. 24. -- Four miners in the Amethyst Mine this morning were roasted to death. They were:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Mail advices from Japan, including official and private letters and files of newspapers, have been received at the Japanese Legation in this city. The Tai Won-Kun. father of the King of Corea, has been declared Resent of that country.

ORIENTAL HOTEL, MANHATTAN BEACH, Aug. 24. -- After a three days' session the Southern Railway and Steamship Association had a final meeting late this afternoon and formally re-elected the old officers and declared the regular rate schedule in force for another year.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 24. -- Many thousand people paid their respects to the memory of the late Vicar General Stephen G. Wall during the last twenty-four hours.

This afternoon what promises to be the grandest race meeting of the year will begin at the track of the Coney Island Jockey Club at Sheepshead Bay. The interest in the racing will naturally centre in the race for the Futurity, which will this year be worth $65,000, a vast sum of money to be raced for.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The assistance of the Sheriff of Onondaga was called for this afternoon by the citizens of Onondaga Valley, a suburb of Syracuse, to quell a pitched battle at a caucus between the recently-harmonized factions of the Republican Party -- the clans headed by Congressman James J. Belden and ex-Collector Francis Hendricks.
Dun's Review, in to-day's issue, will de- scribe the condition of trade as follows:

At the annual fair of the Westchester County Horse Show Association, which takes place on the show grounds at White Plains on Sept. 25, 26, 27, 28, and 29, there will be some very desirable special prizes offered for road tandems, high steppers, professional driving, The association offers $100 as first prize and $50 as the second in the race over a mile and a half for road tandems.
On the 20th of this month the proper committee of the State Constitutional Convention reported the following amend- ment with reference to taxation:

The chief point of interest yesterday in the trial of Capt. Adam A. Cross before the Police Commissioners was the examination of the defendant, who took the witness stand in his own behalf. Before the Captain was called several witnesses were called for the defense, but their testimony was not startling.

"If I don't find some place to live, I'll shoot myself." Julius Turschmid, a coachman, of 3,476 Third Avenue, who has been out of work some time, told his wife when, having been served with a dispossess notice last Tuesday, he started out to seek new lodgings, and also to look for work again. As Mrs. Turschmid has not seen him since, she notified the police yesterday, fearing her husband had made good his threat.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- The morning call was the liveliest the Exchange has had for many weeks. The market was purely a speculative one and confined entirely to West Chicago. Opening at 126, it was sold as rapidly as bids were made on a declining scale downward until 123 1/8 was reached, a break of 3 1/8 from yesterday's weak close and 4 1/4 off from yesterday's opening.

The annual report of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad was issued yesterday in pamphlet form. It contains some interesting facts, and figures, and shows the property to be in very good condition. On July 31 last the company owned 1,278.1 miles of line, being an increase of 28.3 miles. Of this mileage, 68.4 miles are double track.

BUFFALO, Aug. 24. -- Sheriff Taggart's posse of twenty-five men, assisted by fifteen policemen, put to flight "Count" Rybakowski's army of 250 tramps this afternoon, after a lively battle, in which twenty-five of the "hoboes" and Deputy Sheriffs were injured.

ASTORIA, Oregon, Aug. 24. -- W.M. Kenney, who was a passenger on the coast survey steamer McArthur, and was in the whaleboat when Lieut. Freeman H. Crosby and four of the crew were drowned, says that the McArthur was anchored off Joe Creek, three-quarters of a mile from shore and fifteen miles north of the entrance to Gray's Harbor, on the Washington coast.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The devastating possibilities of a modern engine of war were never more forcibly illustrated than they were here to-day at a trial of the so-called Zalinski pneumatic dynamite gun, that can throw 500 pounds of nitro-gelatine, the highest known explosive, a distance of a mile and one-half with the greatest accuracy and precision.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- For the last appearance of the Grand Circuit campaigners at this city to-day there was another fine exhibition of speed. The old champion Mascot, freed from his tormentor. Robert J., was a different horse this afternoon, and won an unexpected victory in very fast time. He sold for $12 in pools of $150 in the first betting on the free-for-all pace, with Guy the favorite and Crawford second choice.

A man apparently fifty years old threw himself from the south roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge, about twenty feet west of the New-York pier, at 8:30 o'clock last evening. He struck on the roof of the shed of the Clyde Steamship Line pier. The force with which he fell was sufficient to break a hole in the planking that forms the roof.

A swordfish recently displayed in front of a cafe bore the following legend: "Caught off Block Island by H.W. Halliwell, Secretary of the Board of Education. It measured when caught between 35 and 40 feet." As displayed, the fish, which was intact, measured about 15 feet.

The District Attorney and the Recorder were quite naturally moved yesterday to make some remarks upon the occasion of the last jury trial in the brownstone building that has for so long been an eyesore in the City Hall Park, and that is so palpably unfit for the uses to which it has been devoted.

It is, or, at any rate, it has been, gen- erally conceded that a man has a right to cut off his own beard, always providing that, in case he was a married man, his wife did not object. But it now appears that there is a secret order of Chebra Swats, one of whose constitutional man- dates is that no member shall remove his beard.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Two thousand people gathered around the championship court of the Casino this morning, clapped their hands, and cheered while M.F. Goodbody, the Irish crack, and Clarence Hobart of New-York fought out a bitter struggle on the green court. Such excitement is rarely seen at a tennis match, even in a final or championship round, and this match was only in the third round.

Ernest Harvier, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Independent County Organization, and the representative in that organization from the Ninth Assembly District, has declared that united action by all Democrats is needed this year to insure the return of Democrats from the Congressional districts of New-York and Brooklyn.

-- The annual regatta of the New-England Rowing Association will take place on Labor Day over the Charles River course, Boston, and in order to induce contestants to compete, the association will furnish free transportation for all contestants to and from Boston. They can leave Saturday night, and have Sunday and Monday in Boston, and return in time for business Tuesday morning.

Getaway day at Parkway was celebrated yesterday by eight races. The previous fourteen days of the meeting had met with public approval, but with yesterday's racing there was something radically wrong. The trouble sarted in the second race when Salvini was left at the post. Lillian L. was left in the third race, and in the fourth, when the horses were at the post.
Here is the Republican situation as it looked to impartial observers last night:

Mrs. Emma R. Gould, a widow, who kept a boarding house at 90 Sands Street, near Jay Street, Brooklyn, and who claimed to have been at one time very wealthy, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by taking cyanide of potassium.

Robert Higginbotham, formerly a patrolman under Capt. Stephenson, in the Thirty-fourth Precinct, who was retired last year on a six-hundred-dollar pension, was held in 85,000 bail by Judge Fitzgerald, in General Sessions, yesterday, to answer the charge of receiving bribes. Higginbotham was arrested at his home, 892 Washington Avenue. Thursday night.

There was one circumstance in connection with the visit of John G. Carlisle, the Secretary of the Treasury, to New-York on March 29 and 30 of this year which has not heretofore been published, but which has excited surprise and speculation among those who are in possession of the facts.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Six days notice ought to and, in my judgment will, afford ample time and opportunity for all interested to attend primaries. In rural communities, notice by posters in prominent places, and in cities or populous villages where a daily paper issues or largely circulates, would be the best mediums for issuing the call, supplemented where necessary by other means peculiar to locality and known to local organizations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The President has approved the following bills:
WASHINGTON, Aug 24. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

Changes in the stock market yesterday were not important, except in Whisky and Tobacco, but the volume of business nearly equaled that of Thursday, and the strength then displayed among buyers still held prices firmly. Several times in the day the short interest tried to place itself at an advantage, but whenever stocks yielded at all, purchasers came to their support with such vigor that they more than recovered the effects of assaults upon them.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The Chautauqua Assembly at Point-of-Woods, on the beach near here, will close on Labor Day. Unless the stockholders and supporters of the assembly come forward with financial aid, it is feared that the grounds will not be opened next season.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 24. -- Shortly after noon to-day an explosion of gas took place in the workings of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company's colliery at Gilberton, by which one man was killed, one fatally injured, and seven others more or less seriously burned.

PEORTA, Ill., Aug. 24. -- James S. Gibbs, Cashier of the Illinois Trust and Savings Hank of Chicago, has been in conference with Vice President Beggs and others of the Whisky Trust all day, and at about 10 o'clock to-night it was understood that the conference had ended satisfactorily for the trust people, and that a loan had been arranged.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Aug. 24. -- Fully 10,000 persons assembled at the encampment grounds yesterday afternoon to witness the sham battle by the State National Guard. Several serious accidents occurred, caused, it is said, by the recklessness of Capt. R.R. Stevens, United States Army, who is stationed in Nebraska, and who was ordered here as instructor.

The American Line steamship New-York, which early in her career established a new speed record between this port and Queenstown, arrived here last night, completing a voyage from Southampton in fifty-nine minutes' quicker time than any other vessel has succeeded in doing.

ALBANY, Aug. 24. -- The Republicans in the Constitutional Convention continue to be in a disturbed state of mind over the apportionment question. As indicated in today's New-York Times the report of the committee in charge of this subject was not forthcoming. Three of the unsettled counties, Kings, Erie, and Monroe, had patched together a makeshift for appearance anly, but the dozen districts of New-York City were still unformed.

-- The greatest scoring ever done in a first-class match in this country resulted from the recent meeting between the amateurs and professionals of Philadelphia, G.S. Patterson and A.M. Wood batted first for the amateurs, and before a wicket fell 217 runs had been tallied by perfect cricket. G.S. Patterson made 113 and A.M. Wood 108, and the total reached 326.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24. -- Most of the horses that are good for anything having gone either to Sheepshead Bay or the West, the racing to-day was very poor. The story of the day's sport is sufficiently told in the following detailed summary, which tells how the horses finished and the betting against each of the starters:
"No vacation for me this year." Mr. J.Z. Clinton, a prominent business man, seemed quite cheerful as he made this remark.

The Court of General Sessions and the District Attorney's office, which have occu- pied the old brownstone building in the City Hall Park for over forty years, will next week be settled in the new Criminal Court House in Centre Street. The proposed re- moval was referred to by Recorder Smyth and District Attorney Fellows yesterday, during the last criminal trial in the building.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 24. -- Fire in the sixth level of the Oregon Improvement Company's coal mines at Franklin, thirty-four miles from this city, at 1 o'clock this afternoon imprisoned all the men working there.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Aug. 24. -- The Ladies' Aid Society in session this morning, elected the following national officers: President -- Miss Madge Hewey. Illinois; Vice President -- Miss Pearl Wills. Indiana; Treasurer -- Mrs. Ella Jones, Pennsylvania: Chaplain -- Mrs. Major A.P. Davis, Pennsylvania; Chief of Staff -- Mrs. John Morgan, New-York; Inspecting: Officer -- Miss Kate Raynes.

Imagine that you are only superficially acquainted with the history of American literature, and that Mildred Rutherford's handbook falls into your hands. Its size recommends it at once, for the smaller the book the fewer, one would think, are the chances for an aggravation of unimportant details.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- General Manager St. John resumed his testimony at the opening of to-day's session of the National Labor Commission. Questioned as to the existence of a black list. Mr. St. John said that the General Managers' Association had never kept a record of the men who took part in the late strike.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- Commodore and Mrs. E.T. Gerry entertained at dinner to-night on board the Electra, with pink and white decorations. The company included the Misses Gerry, William Cutting, Jr., Lispenard Steward C. Sands, and Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt.

That the swords of his gallant adherents who fell on Drumossie Moor should be found by a descendant of his hereditary enemy of Argyll in a fence at Twickenham is certainly a very singular circumstance. In his pamphlet, "Notes on Swords from the Battlefield of Culloden," (C.J. Clark,) Lord Archibald Campbell gives an account of his discovery, with some notes on the blades, and on Andrea Ferrara.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25. -- The meet of the Associated Cycle Clubs of St. Louis held to-day on the Pastime Athletic Club track was a great success. Over 5,000 people were present, although it rained all the morning. The race of to-day was the mile open, in which prizes were placed at the end of each lap. The men got away in the following order: Goehler, Bald, Brown, Sanger, Kennedy, Dodson, Johnson, and Charles Murphy.
There is every prospect that the Brooklyn Board of Excise will soon make it very lively for a certain class of saloon keepers in that city.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 25. -- During the last week, while the people in the city have been enjoying the first comfortable time of the Summer, furs and ulsters have been in order on the island. Some interesting records of temperature kept this season by the hotel keepers show that the mean variation during twenty-four hours is only 6.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 25. -- Republican politicians interested in the success of the party in Ohio this Fall are doing all in their power to smother a very disagreeable scandal over the State printing, which has just come to notice and is likely to be brought into the courts.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA. N.J., Aug. 25. -- The weather is the prevailing theme during the entire season. This week young, old, and doubtful have been loud in their praise of the well-high perfect days. It has been cool enough to suit the most exacting, yet during the bathing hours the air has been mild and balmy, while the temperature of the water was seldom less than 74 .

Temptation to enjoy the substance of good things rather than the shadow induced dealers whose holdings of stocks showed good profit to make tangible this result yesterday by transferring their credits from brokers' books to the banks of deposit. No one seemed to fear that prices would suffer if not burdened with sales.

PARIS, Texas, Aug. 25. -- A party of Indians surrounded the home of Albert Jackson, in Cedar County, Choctaw Nation, Thursday night. He was sick in bed, but he was forcibly taken out in the yard, where he was shot fifty times.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 25. -- Steps have been taken within the last two weeks by members of the A.P.A. and the Junior Order of United American Mechanics, a kindred organization, to form a company of militia and ask admission to the Thirty-second Regiment.

ARVERNE-BY-THE-SEA. L. I., Aug. 25. -- Arverne Day was a great success. The big Arverne Hotel was a mass of bunting when the sun rose this morning, while the many pretty cottages were gay with flags and streamers. The hotel people and the cottage residents fulfilled their promises as to decorations Skirting the board walk that runs along the ocean was a row of posts.
Paris. Aug. 25. -- On the 23 inst., a statue of Juan of Arc was unveiled at Domremy, her native place. The ceremonies were witnessed by over 2O,OOO pilgrims.
"Hello, Bilby! Still in the patent fire extinguisher business?"

Miss Agnes Cooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J.T. Cooney of 1,720 West Fayette Street, died early yesterday morning, after an acute illness of three weeks. Miss Cooney was seventeen years of age. Her twin sister Julia, died on Oct. 11, 1893, and her death made so deep an impression of sorrow upon Agnes that she never recovered from the loss.

PROFILE HOUSE, N.H., Aug. 25. -- This evening the American Forestry Association convened here. The discussion was opened by George B. James of Boston, editor of The American Cultivator and President of the New-Hampshire Land Company. Mr. James was followed by a representative of the Appalachian Club, who spoke of the work of the club in the White Mountains.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Never in the history of cycle racing in Mercer County was there such a successful meet as that held this afternoon at the Inter-State Fair Grounds. The crowd in attendance was larger than at any previous contest, and the racing was above the average.

The Central Labor Union expects this year to have a larger parade on Labor Day than it has had for several years past. As this is the first year in which the day will be celebrated as a national holiday, several trades unions which have never particluated before will march in line.

The Clydesdales, perhaps the horses most highly-esteemed by farmers, especially in the hilly countries, are bred in districts bordering on the Clyde, and owe their origin to one of the Dukes of Hamilton, who crossed some of his best Lanark mares with stallions he imported from Flanders. This breed is conspicuous for its high courage, activity, and endurance.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 25. -- The Homestead is a name famous for more than a century as that of the Summer home of well-known society people, but the house has never had as brilliant a season as that of the last two months. Two germans in one week will attest the great popularity which the place has attained among the younger set.

At the Lyceum Theatre E.H. Sothern will begin his eighth annual engagement to-morrow night in a new comedy by Paul M. Potter, called "The Victoria Cross." It is in four acts, and treats of life and adventure in Rampoor, an independent State of the northwest provinces of India, governed by a native Nawab, under the supervision of a British Resident.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 25. -- Thirtyseven miners of various nationalities were killed yesterday afternoon in the Oregon Improvement Company's coal mine, at Franklin, King County, thirty-four miles southeast of Seattle. The miners were trying to save the mines from destruction by fire, and were suffocated by smoke.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The attendance at the track to-day was fully up to the average, for it was get-away day. The principal event on the card was the Spencer Handicap. Lamplighter was an odds-on favorite, but was not equal to the occasion. Victorious led until the stretch was reached, when Yo Tambien came in a furious drive, and won by a neck, with Lamplighter only a head before Victorious.

Little Rock. Ark., Aug. 25. -- John T. King of this city. Past Supreme Representative of the Knights of Pythias and Chairman of the National Pythian Sanitarium Committee, has received a telegram from the Hot Springs Chamber of Commerce stating that the city had raised the necessary funds for the National Knights of Pythias Sanitarium.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the Cunard steamship Umbria were John A. Adams, Henry B. Adams, Miss Jessie Adams, W. P. Aldrich, the Rev. Charles H. Arndt, Mrs. F.L. Backus, Mrs. John H. Bailey, Sir H.O. Bax-Ironside, Judge A.C. Bond, Mrs. A.P. Buckingham, C. Freedman Cadmus and Mrs. Cadmus. Mrs. J.A. Crocker, Miss J. Crocker,

Jacob Conrad, forty-six years old, committed suicide some time during Friday night at 90 First Avenue. Mrs. Haas, with whom he boarded on the top floor, found him hunting in his room at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. He had been sick, was without money, and became despondent.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 25. -- Summer residents of Great Barrington have spent a very quiet week, the only excitement being the second Assembly dance at the Town Hall. The first in this series of subscription dances was given one week ago, and was quite as much of a success as the one which took place this week.

It was a thoroughly holiday crowd that assembled at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday to welcome the opening of the Coney Island Jockey Club's Fall meeting. It was by no means as large a crowd as had been expected at the track to see Butterflies place the richest race of the year to the credit of Gideon Daly, who have once before won the Futurity with their game and good colt.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The closing weeks of the season, contrary to all precedents, witness a continued influx of tourists. The hotel proprietors during the last fortnight have had all they could do to house their guests. Traffic on the river this season is somewhat peculiar, in that it is transient.

B. Altman Co., Sixth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, have received an advance shipment of their Fall goods, including many handsome dresses fresh from Paris, and many of the latest novelties in dress goods. The department devoted to these importations is the central point of interest in their store, for every one wishes to see the very latest turns the fashions have taken.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Henry B. Hyde, whose country house, on the South Road, east of here, was robbed nearly a fortnight ago, to-day offered a reward of $1,000 for information that would lead to the arrest and conviction of the guilty parties. The District Attorney has been authorized to accept State's evidence, and a determined effort is to be made to secure the arrest of the burglars.

Commencing on a comparatively small scale, the growth of the Flanders galleys was steadily progressive. They were, in fact, the true pioneers of the great mercantile navies or the present day. All that reached England from India was brought to her shores by these vessels, together with the "fashions of proud Italy," then the centre of taste and luxury.

United States Commissioner John A. Shields holds, in addition to that office, clerkships in the United States Circuit Court and the Circuit Court of Appeals. Congress recently passed a Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Apportionment bill, which prohibits any person holding a Government position, of which the salary is $2,500 or more, from retaining any other Government position.

NEW GRAND HOTEL, Summit Mountain, N.Y., Aug. 25. REFRESHING rains and the return of warmer weather have worked wonders with Dame Nature on and around the mountain top where this beautiful hotel is situated, and the excellent condition of the roads has made driving more popular than ever.

The business of childhood, absorbing as it is to those engaged in it, is often amusing to older on-lookers. The other day two little daughters, eight and nine respectively, were watched approaching the house by their two mothers. The youngsters were in a most animated conversation, their mobile features showing the play of two deeplyabsorbed minds.

Ouida has a perfect appreciation of the Italian peasantry. Their ideas are fixed, and we see among them an arrested development as positive as if agricultural Tuscany were a Chinese province. There are subtleties in Italian brains which are apparently not to be understood. The Tuscan "never completely trusts his nearest or dearest, his oldest friend, his truest companion, his fondest familiar; be he gentle or simple, he never gives himself away."

This new volume will neither hurt nor help the reputation of the author of "The Raiders" in this country. It Is neither an exciting romance nor a study of character, but, rather, a prose epic of the killing time in Scotland when the stanch Covenanters were slaughtered In the effort of Lauderdale to establish episcopacy.

WESTPORT-ON-LAKE CHAMPLAIN, N. Y., Aug. 25. -- The Westport Inn season is at its height, the last few weeks being one continued round of gayety, coaching parties, boating excursions, mountain climbs, germans, impromptu hops, euchre parties, , following each other in rapid succession.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 25. -- A terriblydisastrous cyclone swept alone the shore of the Sea of Azof to-day, working immense damage. In some instances entire villages were swept into the sea. Many steamers were sunk or driven ashore and wrecked, and it is believed that at least 1,000 persons perished.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Aug. 25. -- Mrs. Gen. Grant's family evidently propose to make their permanent home in this city. U.S. Grant, Jr., bought a handsome home here last Winter, in which his mother and family live, save when Mrs. Grant takes excursions eastward and elsewhere. This mansion, which has been described in The New-York Times, is one of the finest houses in town.

Detective Daniel Kash of the West Thirtieth Street Station, one of the handsomest men on the force, announced, last night, at the station that he had been married. The manner in which the detective met his bride is quite out of the ordinary.

Amzi Benedict Davenport, father of John I. Davenport, ex-United States Supervisor of Elections, died in the Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, Friday morning, from pneumonia, which set in while he was a patient at the hospital undergoing treatment for a broken thigh, which he received by being accidentally knocked down by an unknown man about two weeks ago.

The Long Island Traction Company, it is said, proposes to issue collateral trust notes having a face value of $3,000,000, bearing interest at 6 per cent., and payable in gold, to be dated Aug. 1, 1894, and to mature Aug. 1, 1897. Of this amount $2,500,000 is to be at the disposal of the stockholder at 85.

CHAPTER V. -- UNDER HATCHES. The man that came into the saloon was the thin, wiry, soldiery rogue with the yellow mustache. He stepped to the head of the table, close under the skylight, and, on looking at him again. I was as convinced that he was the man that I had seen at my stepfather's as that my eyes were those I had viewed him with.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Aug. 25. -- Word reached here this morning of the drowning of four persons twelve miles north of this village. Adam A. Parrett, ex-County Commissioner, and his wife and three children riding in a spring wagon, attempted to ford the Scioto River, it being very low, but the team struck a sink hole, and all the occupants of the wagon were drowned except a twelve-year-old boy, who got to shore.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 25. -- The tally-ho Penataquit was out twice this week. Tuesday it carried a party of prominent guests to Vanderbilt's place, Oakdale. Friday Mrs. James Peers Foster of New-York chartered a coach and took a party of guests to the country circus at Islip and all had a jolly time.

The Horseshoe Harbor Club aquatic sports were held yesterday, and it was a gala day at Larchmont. The Horseshoe Harbor Club has a pretty little house a short distance from the famous Larchmont Club. It is a new organization, having been organized in 1889, and is already so popular on the Sound that its races and games attract a big crowd.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 25. AS the season wanes, society events crowd upon each other here at this quiet little colony at the mouth of the Thames. Dinners and dances follow each other at a pace that keeps the favored ones in a whirl of gayety.

-- Columbia. -- The regular season at the Columbia Theatre will open to-morrow night with the presentation of "The Passing Show," which closed its New-York run at the Casino last night. Canary Lederer's entire company, consisting of 110 artists, will appear, and the scenery and costumes will be the same as used in this city. On Sept. 3 John Drew will begin a week's engagement at the Columbia, presenting his latest comedy, "Christopher, Jr."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The Autumnal weather of the week has driven thousands from the hotels and boarding houses, but the new-comers outnumbered those who have gone, and to-night the hotels show no signs of the approaching close of the season. The 1st of September is the date fixed by custom for the starting of the annual exodus from the Park.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 25. -- The past week at Shelter Island, with its lovely weather and its varied attractions, was one of the liveliest of the season. Fewer people have left for the mountains than is usual here the last of August, and a large crowd of guests find daily amusement in the many pastimes afforded by this popular seaside resort.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 25. -- There is to be a genuine old-fashioned barn warming in this pretty resort Sept. 10. The entire day is to be given over to the event. The promoters of the unique social function are Mrs. David S. Egleston, Mrs. William A. Jenner, Mrs. William S. Hawk, Mrs. Newton M. Shaffer, Mrs. A. Newbold Morris, Mrs. Melbert B. Cary, and others.

During the warm weather egg's are a most wholesome substitute for the hearty product of the meat stalls. Good authorities claim that at all seasons eggs are cheaper than meat. They are at once the easiest to prepare of all cooked foods and the oftenest poorly prepared, yet perfection is the only excuse for their being encountered.

The local horse market last week lost none of the gain in values and demand of the week previous. There was, for thus season, a good demand for green workhorses, and prices were rather better than were obtained for the same class the week before. At Fiss Doerr's regular Monday auction sale fifty-odd head of streeters were sold, and bidding was freer than has been observed during the hot spell.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 25. -- About 2,500 persons occupied the Brand stand at the old race track in this city this afternoon to see the Withers bicycle races. The track was rolled well and the racing was good, but the poor track management tired many before the ten events were run oft, so that they left before the last race was run.

Dr. D. Bryson Delavan of 1 East Thirty-third Street is "high rod" of the Beaverkill, so far as Salmo fontinalis is concerned, this year. Very large Salmo fario have been caught durinf the season which closes next Friday night, but no native American brook trout as magnificent as the one he took out of the lower Beaverkill last week has been reported.

The year 1900, the last year of the present century, is to witness a great exhibition in Paris, and the correspondent of The London Daily News notes that the Minister of Commerce has opened a prize competition for the plans and general arrangement of the exhibition. Only Frenchmen need apply.

As the Grand Circuit that has been in progress for the last seven weeks draws to a close, the uniform improvement in the rate of speed that both trotters and pacers are showing this season becomes more and more apparent. From Saginaw down the line of the great lakes the race record at one of the gaits or both of them was lowered at every point but Buffalo.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Kanapaha, the Rev. William L. Moore, Talisman, S.A. Maxwell; Marietta, H. B. Moore; Evelyn, J.K. Hegeman: Norma, Charles H. Merrill; Hustle, Richmond Pease: Halcvon, Andrew R. Culver, and Embla, John H. Hannon. Schooner yachts Agnes. J. Norton Winslow, and Halcyon, D.S. Hammond. Yawl Andix, Henry W. Eaton.

JAMAICA, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Jacob Reinheimer, a blacksmith in business at Clarenceville, has recently passed through more trouble than is usually allotted to a man in a lifetime.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 23. -- This season is demonstrating that the greatest need in Cottage City at present is a new and more modern hotel. Two years ago the Sea View was burned, and last season the Highland House was also burned to the ground. That left only the original hotels, which are fifteen years old.
Ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton is expected to arrive here this morning on the steamship La Normamdie, from Havre. It is thought that the steamship will be in port soon after sunrise.
ORANGE, N.J., Aus. 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rothschild gave a lawn party at their home, in Carlton Street, East Orange, on Thursday afternoon, in honor of Miss Dora Rothschild's birthday.

ANTWERP, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The Veteran Soldiers and Sailors' Monument erected by the citizens of Antwerp in memory of the men of this town who went to the front at the first call for loyal troops in 1861 was unveiled here to-day with impressive and appropriate ceremonies.

The thin end of the wedge toward utilizing the roofs of cities as living places in the Summer for those who must be city dwellers in that season has been amply inserted. The theatre roof gardens and the several elevated restaurants have emphasized the resources of an immense upper area of the town, and many private roofs have been converted this Summer into air parlors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The military prison at Fort Leavenworth was run upon an economical basis during the year. The expenses leave a balance of nearly $3,000 out of the appropriation of $76,000. It has cost nearly $18,000 to furnish provisions for the 517 prisoners who are crowded into the cells of this institution, and $300 more to supply them with tobacco.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 25. -- The interest in the great camp meeting is increasing daily. The workers turned out early this morning and all the side meetings were exceptionally interesting. There were ten inquirers in Evangelist Yatman's meeting and many others were seeking salvation around the altar of the Tabernacle.

The address of Judge Thomas M. Cooley to the American Bar Association on the 22d had much specific as well as general value. What seems to us the most valuable contribution made in this address by the veteran constitutional lawyer lay in his searching treatment of the popular notion of official arbitration of labor disputes.

The meeting of the Manhattan and Morris Heights Cricket Clubs, yesterday at Berkeley Oval resulted in a genuine surprise for the Manhattans, who are running the Staten Island Cricket Club a tight race for second place in the league. They fully expected a victory, but the day suited the Morris Heights men, and they won easily by 68 runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Everybody who reads the newspapers read this morning the story in The New-York Times about the Secretary of the Treasury and the Sugar Trust. Its publication in The Times seemed to have a special significance and impressiveness to newspaper readers. To say that the account produced any deep surprise among members of Congress would be to speak too strongly.
Dectective Sergeant George V. Zundt of the Central Office, Brooklyn, will be arraigned for trial before Police Commissioner Welles in the Municipal Building next Tuesday.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 25. -- From information received by the steamer Gussie of the Southern Pacific Line, which arrived last night, the Nicaraguan Government has defied the Governments of both the United States and Great Britain, and has taken into custody representatives of both nations.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 25. -- Kansas now comes forward with a weather prophet, J. C.H. Swann of Whitewater, who, it is claimed, outrivals Wiggins, Tice, or Foster. He has kept a scientific record of the weather for nearly sixty years, and has devoted much time and close attention to making daily comparisons.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 25. -- With the generally-regarded end of the Summer season of 1894 but one week off, Atlantic City is at present quartering as many visitors as made the beginning of August such a remarkable period in point of prosperity. Usually at this time the proportions of the outgoing rush of the "long-termers" exceed those of the influx:

The Good Roads tournament, which takes place at Asbury Park next Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, promises to be the event of the season in Eastern cycling affairs. The list of entries is the most brilliant ever offered an Eastern gathering, and many new men will be seen for the first time this season at this tournament.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 25. -- After a jury in one case against "Abe" Buzzard and six of his associates, for larceny and felonious entry, had returned a verdict of not guilty this morning, the same defendants were placed on trial for entering Fahnestock's mill. in Ephrata Township, and robbing the safe, and this afternoon Buzzard was found guilty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- There is a movement on foot the consolidate the artillery of the army with the Marine Corps. At the next session of Congress a bill yill be introduced for the formation of a marine artillery, and to this new arm of the service the artillery of the army will be assigned.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 25. -- B.H. Yard, proprietor of the Indian Harbor Hotel, gave his annual reception and ball at the hotel this afternoon and evening to the yachtsmen of Greenwich and vicinity.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25. THE week's record of sport is a chronicle of three ball games -- three of the closest, most exciting ball games ever played on the grounds.

There is little speculation in police circles as to the verdict which will be announced as a result of the trial of Capt. Cross. He made a very favorable impression on the stand, and there is a general feeling that his strong defense will secure his acquittal.

The second week of Sousa's brilliant and altogether successful musical festival at Manhattan Beach concludes with concerts this afternoon and evening. The festival has attracted immense throngs of people during the last three days, and is voted to be the most unique and brilliant musical event in the history of Manhattan.

OLEAN, Aug. 25. -- I think sir days' notice will be ample in order to give all Democrats full knowledge of primaries. Notice should be published in newspapers in localities where they exist. Where none are published, I would advocate the publishing and posting of printed notices of the same in the moat conspicuous places.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- Nobody is more thankful than the Ministers that the end of the legislative session has come. They are now hurrying off to Scotland and the Continent for a rest after the exceptional weariness of the last weeks.

A large shark was caught the other day at the foot of Eighty-third Street, East River, and two others on the same day off the coast of Long Island. We are very fortunate not to have such visitors oftener. Some years ago there were so many sharks around the lower end of Staten Island that bathing in those waters was decidedly unsafe.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 25. OLF has been tea principal theme of conversation among the members of the Lenox Club during the present weekSince the men interested in outdoor sports have returned they have looked about for a place to lay out the links.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- A dispatch from Shanghai to a news agency here says a letter received in Che-Foo on the 24th from Chemulpo, Corea, reasserts, that the Japanese were defeated by the Chinese at PingYanp. Thirteen Japanese transports, convoyed by nineteen war ships, arrived in the estuary of Taston-Kang on the 18th inst., and landed a force of 6,000 men, who advanced upon Ping-Yang.

An excellent opportunity will be afforded to investors and home-seekers on Monday, Sept. 3, to secure building lots in one of the most desirable sections of the new Thirty-first Ward. Mr. Johnson will offer on that date the remaining portion of lots on the Jones farm, adjoining Bensonhurst. These lots are the very best of the original offering, being situate on Stillwell Avenue and King's Highway.

Brooklyn will probably have the first long stretch of wheelway ever built for the exclusive use of cyclists. When completed it will extend from Prospect Park to Coney Island, a distance of five and a half miles, a straight run to the sea. Its natural advantages should make it the most attractive path in the world.

Mr. Julian Sturgis is already favorably known as a writer of prose romances, and it is quite in the common order of things literary that he should come before the public as a poet. It seems, therefore, unnecessary that he should have introduced his rhymes with a somewhat apologetic preface.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 25. -- The explosions of caissons in the batteries under Major Randolph, now manoeuvring at Evanston, have been discovered to be directly chargable to a device which forms a part of the equipment of schrapnel shells. This device, faulty in construction, and therefore more dangerous to friends than to foe, is to-day under the ban of the army, and it has been ordered out of service.

Two defeats were charged against the Louisville Colonels yesterday. The Giants played grand, ball, and from start to finish the visitors never had a chance to win. In the first game the local players won by a score of 18 to 6 and in the second they captured the ball by figures of 5 to 1.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The Bayonne Rowing and Athletic Association held its seventeenth annual regatta this afternoon, several hundred friends watching the contests. The course was nearly one mile, with a turn on NewYork Bay, in all rowing events except the invitation race. The wind was southwest, strong at first.

Under Section 89 of the new Tariff bill, the "reciprocal trade arrangements" existing at present between the United States and the Spanish-American countries are destroyed, and the business men of this city have already begun to show anxiety as to what will supplant the present condition, under which American goods have a decided advantage over those from other countries.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Wheat traders were not very anxious to do business to-day, the scenes in the pit bearing a great resemblance to those of the closing day of the year, when everything is given over to amusement and business discipline is relaxed. During the last half hour there was a slight improvement in strength and activity, the result of heavy Atlantic seaboard clearances -- 580,162 bushels.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The hoboes have disbanded and those who are not in custody are on the way to some more congenial climate. Another batch of twenty-five of the tramps was sent to the workhouse this morning for periods of from five to twenty days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Almost all of the professionals were ready to go short of West Chicago at the opening this morning, but they were deterred temporarily by a good buying order, which opened the market for this stock at 123 5/8, or 1/4 higher than the close of last night. When there were no more purchasing orders, attack began.

ALBANY, Aug. 25. -- Although barely a quorum was present at the morning session of the Constitutional Convention, the debate on the McDonough amendment on convict labor was continued. It ran through both the morning and afternoon sessions, and was not different from that which has been poured into the Legislature annually for the past ten or twelve years.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- The most notable feature of this holiday season has been the complete lack of articles and speeches hostile to France. In former dull seasons some frontier incidents have been produced regularly and have been magnified, by party editors and orators until all the traditions of international hatred had been thoroughly revived.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25. -- The recent announcement in The New-York Times that Congressman Isidor Rayner had withdrawn from the fight for renomination for Congress, which he could easily have won, and had entered the lists for the Governorship of the State, is an unexpected complication in Maryland politics.

ALTOONA, Penn., Aug. 25. -- As the result of the defalcation of Cashier Harry A. Gardner and by reason of some bad paper held by the institution, the stockholders of the Second National Bank are called upon to raise $150,000. The stockholders met this afternoon, and for several hours were in consultation with Chief National Bank Examiner Coffin.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., Aug. 25. -- All the prominent Republicans of the First Maine Congressional District and many from other sections of the State attended the opening rally here this afternoon. Congressman Reed arrived at 12:30 o'clock from Portland, and the 1 o'clock train brought Gov. Perham and others.

There were very few subjects indeed on which he could not talk, and talk admirably. He was as fluent in the French and in the German as in the English language.

There were few business men in New-York who did not discuss yesterday the publication in The New-York Times of the fact that the Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. Carlisle, on the occasion of his visit to this city -- March 29 and 30 last -- had been seen going into the headquarters of the American Sugar Refining Company, in Lower Wall Street.

Joseph Colligan of 634 East Sixteenth Street, a workman on the Third Avenue cable line, was probably fatally injured at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning by falling on a cable and being crushed on a wheel in the subway. The accident happened in front of 119 Park Row.

WEST POINT, Aug. 25. -- The past week on the post has been lively. Excursion boats from New-York and Philadelphia have landed thousands daily. They roam over the plains and wonder at the marvelous escapes of the young soldiers, tearing down the drill grounds at artillery practice. Wednesday the boom of cannon resounded through the hills.

Frank Dillon, twenty years old, of 108 West Thirty-third Street, and Mortimer Sheridan, twenty-eight years old, of 215 West Thirty-first Street, were stabbed by a young man supposed to be William Bernard, but whose home is unknown, at Thirty-seventh Street and Sixth Avenue at 11:30 o'clock last night.

SOUTHAMPTON. L.I., Aug. 25. NE of the chief attractions here is golf. Every pleasant afternoon the roads leading to the links on Shinnecock Hills are crowded with equipages filled with stylishly-dressed cottagers.

Lying on Mrs. Lymn Linton's table in her sitting room was a large bundle of manuscripts, upon which I naturally remarked to my hostess: "What a lot of work you have there on hand! Surely that means two or three new books."
The Lone Star Boat Club's pretty clubhouse, on the Harlem River, was crowded yesterday at its annual regatta. The upper floor was given up to the ladies.

ROCHESTER, N.Y. Aug. 25. -- The Livingaton County Republican judiciary Convention was held to-day at Geneseo. These delegates were elected to the Republican Judiciary Convention of the Seventh Judicial District, and instructed for Judge William E. Werner of Monroe County and Judge William Rumsey of Steuben: John R. Strang of Geneseo, District Attorney William Carter of Avon, and George Atwell, Jr., of Lima.

We shall never, in all likelihood, grow to share the French taste for the edible snail, though the big escargot is common enough in many parts of England, where tradition says they were introduced by the Romans, and still live on round the sites of their villas. The escargot is really at its best when taken in the vineyards at the end of March and the beginning of April.

When Summer rises, begins to put on her drab-and-russet wrap, and says, "I really must be going," the in-dwellers of cities who have been playing with the country for a couple of months glide gently away in her train. "God made the country, but man made the town," say they, and as soon as the fierce heats are by, they begin returning to the places whence they came.

There commenced yesterday, before a special sitting of the Hainault Assize Court, at Mons, one of the most sensational criminal trials ever known in Belgium. The prisoners, thirteen in number, of whom two are women, have been kown as the Black Band of the Centre, under the leadership of a one-armed man named Van Ham.

The young Emperor chafes visibly against the leading strings of her Majesty the dowager, and is bravely struggling for freedom. The extravagances of the approaching celebration of her Majesty's sixtieth birthday are warmly resented by the Emperor.

Since his return, to London, Seymour Hicks, who was one of the bad sisters -- the amusing one -- in "Cinderella," at Abbey's, has been appearing in the "Little Jack Sheppard" burlesque as Jonathan Wild, and has made a great hit by copying the droll-tramp act of Walter Jones in "1492." Mr. Jones's tramp, in its turn, bears a strong family likeness to William Hoey's in "A Parlor Match."

SARANAC LAKE, Aug. 25. NUMBERS attended the dedication of the new Catholic chapel at St. Regis Lake Sunday last. The Right Rev. Bishop Gabriels, who secured for Chauneey M. Depew the latter's audience with the Pope, was celebrant, and preached.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25. -- The Rev. A.R. Morgan in charge of the Methodist Protestant Missions in Japan, writes from Nagoya, under date of Aug. that on July 29 the Japanese gained a.e. piete victory over the Chinese at Songhwan and on July 30. at 7 A.M. marched on San, the headquarters of the Chinese forces in Corea. Mr. Morgan continues as follows:

Eden Musee. -- Frequent additions will be made to the wax figures in the new reception parlor at the Eden Musee. Besides the famous rulers of the world. Gladstone is to have a favored position in this room. Bismarck and Caprivi will be given distinguished places among the crowned heads. A new figure put on exhibition to-day is that of the young Queen of Holland.

SARANAC LAKE, Aug. 25. NUMBERS attended the dedication of the new Catholic chapel at St. Regis Lake Sunday last. The Right Rev. Bishop Gabriels, who secured for Chauneey M. Depew the latter's audience with the Pope, was celebrant, and preached.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25. -- The Rev. A.R. Morgan in charge of the Methodist Protestant Missions in Japan, writes from Nagoya, under date of Aug. that on July 29 the Japanese gained a.e. piete victory over the Chinese at Songhwan and on July 30. at 7 A.M. marched on San, the headquarters of the Chinese forces in Corea. Mr. Morgan continues as follows:

Eden Musee. -- Frequent additions will be made to the wax figures in the new reception parlor at the Eden Musee. Besides the famous rulers of the world. Gladstone is to have a favored position in this room. Bismarck and Caprivi will be given distinguished places among the crowned heads. A new figure put on exhibition to-day is that of the young Queen of Holland.

The males begin their march several days earlier than the females, who form the main body of this exodus, their battalions extending for a mile or a mile and a half in length, with a breadth of forty or fifty paces. So closely do they march together that the noise of their shelly integuments as they jostle each other is said to resemble the rattling of the armor of a regiment of cuirassiers.

In the March of 1865, while the young Russian Princess Troubetzkoi (whom he had married some years before, and though far more than double her age, had fascinated as he fascinated every one) was preparing, all unconscious of the impending doom, a mid-Lent ball -- de Morny died. He had been ill for some time, Ill with a mysterious illness about which the physicians seemed reticent, but which he bore with a stoic calm.

The next big race meet, and the one that is likely to prove to be one of the largest of the year in this section of the country, will be the much-talked-about good roads tournament, at Asbury Park. It begins on Thursday of this week, and lasts three days, the large number of entries making it necessary to extend over that period of time.

Broadway cable cars were operated yesterday at a higher rate of speed than the company had ever before attempted. The trip from Fifty-ninth Street to the Battery has been made on the schedule time of forty-six minutes, or an hour and thirty-two minutes for the round trip. The new schedule, which went into effect yesterday, allows only thirty-four minutes each way, or one hour and eight minutes for the round trip.

From The Rochester Union and Advertiser. The Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press" is singularly unfortunate in many of its announcements. It made the Vigilant the winner of the first race, and subsequently confirmed the United Press dispatch saying the Britannia had won.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The naval engineers are busily engaged upon some intereating work authorized by the latest Appropriation bill. The present engine and boilers of the cruiser Chicago will be removed. They are considered antiquated affairs, and the engineers called them behind the times as far back as when a civilian expert employed for the purpose recommended the present machinery for the vessel.

From The Saratoga Sun. A good deal has been said about the need of harmony in the Democratic ranks in order to elect our ticket in New-York this year. This is always a doubtful State. The vote not strongly attached to any political organization is so large as to be a decisive factor, when cast solidly, in any election.

Mrs. Eunice White Beecher, the wife of the late Henry Ward Beecher, was eightytwo years old yesterday. She spent the day quietly at the Summer home of her daughter, Mrs. Scoville, the wife of the Rev. Samuel Scoville, at Cornwall, Conn.

The other day Mr. Aitken laid before the Royal Society of Edinburgh the results of 15,000 observations made in different parts of the world during the last few years. This is a monument of patient observation, unfortunately made in his search for health. It must be kept in mind that the greater number of dust particles found in the air the greater is the condensation of the vapor and the thicker is the atmosphere.

A great many persons have a vague belief that some day or other there is going to be a millennium, but they are not quite sure what a millennium is. It all depends upon the point of view. To a politician the millennium will exist when there is nothing but harmony in his own party and the other party has not enough voters to provide itself with candidates.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 25. -- The local stock market has been somewhat stronger during the week, and a tendency toward higher prices is quite apparent. Inquiry for investments still continues, although few shares have changed hands. In the local money market there is little activity at present. Rates of discount for commercial paper are quoted at 4@5 per cent., and call loans between banks are at 2 1/2@3 per cent.
The sales reffered to in accompenying detailed list will take place in the New-York Real Estate salesman at 111 Broadway, expect as otherwise stated.

Secretary Fellows of the Coney Island Jockey club announces the following as the weights for the Twin City Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, to be run at the Sheepshead Bay track to-morrow. The weights seem very nicely and cleverly adjusted, and If the handicap brings out a fair lot of acceptances. Instead of a lot of "dodgers." it should result in one of the best races of the season.

The five clubs of the HudsonHeights Tennis Association held their annual tennis tournament Saturday on the Una courts, in Hoboken. The only matches of the day were men's singles. In these Paul Salembier of the Americus Club appeared to best advantage. He started rather clumsily, but soon recovered himself and played much steadier thereafter.

From The Kingston Leader. There is hearty agreement among all Democrats whose opinions are of any value whatever that there should be a cessation of factional dispute in this State, and that the ticket to be nominated at Saratoga Springs next month should have the united support of the party, without regard to past differences.

There are various opinions concerning the value of the Vedanta philosophy. Some esteem it to be philosophy of the highest type; others pronounce it rubbish, and still others, taking an eclectic view, say, while the mass of it is tiresome and inconsequential, there is so much of valuable thought in it that it is well worth study.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 26. -- The three services to-day at the beach auditorium attracted large congregations. The Rev. B. Fay Mills, the noted evangelist, preached in the morning from the text, "The earth is the Lord's and the fullness thereof." At the national service at 4 o'clock Col. H.H. Hadley of New-York, Mrs. Margaret Bottome, founder and President of the King's Daughters, and Miss Sarah Wray.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- Mrs. George B. De Forest entertained at dinner to-night.

The proposed union of the Central Labor Union with the Populists for political action in the coming campaign may not be brought about without friction. At the meeting of the Central Labor Union, where the subject was again discussed yesterday, there were indications of difficulties that may not be easily overcome.

Only a few more games remain to be played to decide the championships of the Metropolitan District Cricket League, and, as the time draws near for the final games, the interest and enthusiasm aroused in the matches is increased very materially. The New-Jersey Athletic Club still preserves its unbeaten record and can hardly now be prevented from winning the first section pennant.

From The London Daily News. The Minister of Commerce has opened a prize competition for the plans and general arrangements of the Universal Exhibition of 1900. Only Frenchmen need apply. In four months' time a public exhibition of plans sent in will take place. A jury may award three prizes of 6,000f., four of 4,000f., five of 2,000f., and six of 1,000f.

M. Turpin's "angel of death" was not experimented upon, writes our Paris correspondent, because no engine was submitted by the inventor to the War Office Technical Committee. He only worked out his idea for them on paper. The cost of constructing the "angel" and the shell, the idea of which he had in his head, would be very great.

From The Boston Journal. Lovers of Boston, and the town is worthy to be loved, will hear with pleasure that during the Summer the city and its suburbs have been as thoroughly photographed as any foreign town of popular resort ever was. Boston has been photographed before, but as a rule the pictures have not been satisfactory.

Secretary Carlisle wrote two schedules of sugar duties for the use of the subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Finance. One of them is the schedule now found in the new tariff -- the schedule of the bill passed by the Senate -- and the other is the one a fac simile of which has been published, with his interlineations on a printed text.

Mrs. Emma R. Gould who committed suicide at her home, 90 Sands Street, Brooklyn, Friday night, by taking cyanide of potassium, was burled in the Cemetery of the Evergreens yesterday. Her stepson, George R. Gould, whose sister is the wife of I.V. Brokaw, had charge of the funeral.

The Hudson County Wheelmen held club races Saturday afternoon on Communipaw Avenue, Jersey City. Over 2,000 persons lined the avenue and watched the contests with interest. The mile handicap was won by William L. Darmer. Walter Roome was second and Ralphs third. A fifty-yard slow race caused lots of amusement for the onlookers.

LEW BEACH, SULLIVAN COUNTY, N. Y., Aug. 26. -- The State fish hatchery building at Rockland was accepted from the contractors last Monday by Fisheries Commissioner L.D., Huntington, and Charles H. Walters, foreman of the Cold Spring Harbor hatchery, a well-equipped pupil of Fred Mather, the Superintendent of that station, was placed in charge.

Andrew F. Schickling spent Sunday in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, charged with attempting to shoot Mrs. Wilhelmina Clauss in her beautiful home, 946 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, because, as he alleges, she spurned him and refused to become his wife.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- To-morrow will witness the beginning of another of those great gatherings for which Washington has become notable in recent years. Its nucleus will be the annual meeting of the Supreme Lodge of the Knights of Pythias, which, while of great interest to the members of the order, will not have that general attractiveness of its auxiliary, the assemblage of thousands of Knights of the Uniformed Rank.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 26. -- An accident occurred on the new suburban electric line to Eagle Rock this afternoon, at 4:30 o'clock, in which fifteen people were seriously injured. All the other passengers in the car were more or less injured by cuts and bruises.

NEW-BEDFORD, Aug. 26. -- The Howland Mill, the Rotch Mill, and the New-Bedford Manufacturing Company's mill will open to-morrow morning, when the help will return to work on the old basis of pay. It is not expected that any demonstration will be made, as the operatives have been especially cautioned not to be demonstrative.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Judge Morris Marks of New-Orleans, representing a number of Louisiana sugar planters, is here for the purpose of entering suits in the United States Court of Claims for the recovery of the sugar bounty for the year 1894-5.

In a learned book which he has just published at Shanghai, Dr. Martin of the Imperial College, Pekin, pays the Chinese people a compliment which Western readers will, under the circumstances of the day, find interesting. The Chinese are regarded as the Tories of the East, while their enemies, the Japanese, are regarded as the Radicals and Progressists.

The Journal des Debats publishes some interesting notes on the Japanese Army, made in 1892 by a French military expert, who had the opportunity of following the grand manoeuvres of that year in Japan. These manoeuvres take place every two years, and would have been repeated this year had they not, unfortunately, been replaced by real warfare.
