"Archbishop Corrigan and Our Saloons" was the subject of the sermon preached by the Rev. Madison C. Peters yesterday morning in Young Men's Christian Association Hall, Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. He said among other things:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- There was no abatement to-day of the interest displayed yesterday in the statements in The New-York Times about the visits made by the Secretary of the Treasury to the offices of the Sugar Trust in New-York, in March and July. The subject was discussed everywhere, and with great freedom, although the objection to expressing opinions, in the absence of any answer from Mr. Carlisle, was general.

The silver jubilee or the French Catholic Church of St. Louis, in Ellery Street, near Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, was celebrated yesterday. There was a solemn high mass in the morning. Bishop McDonnell was the celebrant. He was assisted by Canon Jules Jollon, rector of the church, and the Rev. James H. Mitchell, Chancellor of the diocese of Brooklyn, preached the sermon.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 25. -- The local money market reflects a better demand at the close of business to-day, but as yet no change of rates is sighted. The better demand is described, however, as coming with the lifting of whisky from bond. There was also more inquiry from legitimate trade centres, but the loans so made were not much above the average.

VIENNA, Aug. 26. -- The annual international grain fair will open here to-morrow. The official crop estimates for 1894, as compared with 1893, are given by percentagesa and are not so complete as last year, none being received from Bulgaria and several divisions of Russia. In some instances, merely the combined percentages are given, Instead of separate estimates of Summer and Winter grain.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 26. -- Stockholders of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad received circulars yesterday from the Reorganization Committee of the Santa Fe Company, inviting them to join the Protective Committee, and to deposit their holdings in its care, in return for which they will get negotiable certificates.

A woman of middle age, insane from drink and armed with a carving knife, which she seemed anxious to put to its legitimate use, ran through a street in " Little Italy" yesterday. Brandishing her knife and screaming defiance, she chased to cover every one who came in sight.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The manoeuvres of the North Sea fleet have been in progress for the last four days. Eleven iron-clads and forty other vessels take part in the evolutions. The commander in chief is Admiral von der Goltz, whose flagship, the Woerth, is distinguished by having Prince Henry of Prussia as its commander.

Democrats who are lukewarm when the question of harmony in the party is suggested should remember that it the Republicans elect their ticket this Fall, thus securing control of the State Government, they will engraft on the laws a new apportionment measure, which will insure their remaining in power for twenty years.
Miss Jennie Maxwell of 249 West Fifteenth Street was kept in pawn for more than four hours in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, to secure the payment of a carriage bill for $20.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 20. -- The army of Methodists camping in Ocean drove were up with the sun to-day, and after a hasty meal went to the tabarnacle. where a consecration meeting was held at 5 o'clock. From that hour until nearly midnight they were on the go. A majority of them managed in some way to take part in nearly every one of the sixteen services held on the camp grounds during the day.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Under the restraint of an injunction issued by Judge Beach last Monday the authorities of this place, who, with a squad of special police, prevented the landing of 2,000 excursionists last Sunday did not Interfere with the steamer J.G. Emmons, on which the T.J. Warren Association of the Ninth Ward, New-York, arrived at Summers picnic grounds to-day.

Levi P. Morton, ex-Vice President of the United States and one of the many who are in the hands of their friends in respect of a nomination by the Republicans for the Governorship of New-York, arrived yesterday by La Normandie of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, rested a few hours at the Murray Hill Hotel, and took the 3:45 local on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad for his country seat, Ellerslie, near Rhinebeck.

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date in 1893. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- One hundred and five firms who had exhibits at the World's Fair, in Chicago, have sent to Home Secretary Asquith a memorial, expressing their sense of obligation to the British Commissioners. After formally thanking the commission, the exhibitors criticise it severely. They regretted, greatly, they said, that the Commissioners were not in close touch with the exhibitors.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 26. -- The Rev. Dr. McGlynn delivered an address in the Prohibition Park auditorium this afternoon, and nearly 2,000 persons listened to him for over two hours, frequently interrupting him with applause.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 26. -- The results of the Democratic primaries held throughout Delaware yesterday practically determined in advance the nominations that will be made by the Democratic State Convention, which meets at Dover next Tuesday. Ebe W. Tunnell of Lewes, Sussex County, win be nominated for Governor beyond a doubt, and all the probabilities are in favor of the nomination of Samuel Bancroft, Jr., of Christiana Hundred, New-Castle County, for Representative in Congress.

Mr. G.P. Mills, who about a month ago performed the astounding feat of riding on a bicycle from Land's End, in Cornwall, to John O'Groat's House, in Northern Scotland, in less than three days and a half, without having a wink of sleep on the way, has been replying to the strictures of The Lancet on the subject of such feats of endurance.

Fine weather favored the novice run from this city to Long Branch and return yesterday, and about seventy-five riders took part. The affair was under the management of the Young Men's Institute Wheelmen, Edward Gerbereux being the prime mover. Starting from the Washington Arch at 6 o'clock, the schedule time was maintained as far as New-Dorp on the return trip.

Early in the seventeenth century the Czar Boris Godunof, brother-in-law of Ivan the Terrible, 'the real founder' of the Russian Empire, sentenced the Bell of UgHeh to be flogged by the public executioner, to have its ears cut off, and to be exiled to Siberia, The bell had given the signal for the insurrection.

From The Buffalo Enquirer. The way to reorganize is to reorganize. The solution of the problem lies with the Democrats who are dissatisfied with the existing conditions. They are in the majority, and if they get together and vote for what they want they will get it. The suggestion made by The Courier is an eminently sensible one.

Arthur J. Caton of Chicago has reported that his wife was robbed of a quantity of valuable jewelry while on board the French Line steamer La Touraine, which left New-York for Havre May 28. He has offered a reward of $1,000 for its recovery.

Diphtheria will have lost all its terrors it information just issued by the New-York City Board of Health shall be proved reliable. Instead of being among the most dreaded of diseases, with a percentage of fatal results almost unequaled, it will be reduced to one of the most ordinary ailments, according to the Health Board officials, in all cases where medical treatment and the proper remedy can be obtained.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The market for local securities was inactive but strong this week. All the changes in fluctuations were toward higher figures. The large July investment demand absorbed about all the offerings at current prices, and the present demand resulting from the passage of the Tariff bill and the improvement in Wall Street is difficult to supply.
In a few weeks The Century Company will issue a book on "The Mountains of California," by John Mulr, the discoverer of the great Muir Glacier of Alaska.

Paris Correspondent London News. Dr. Yersin, a pupil of the Pasteur Institute in Paris, claims to have discovered the bacillus of the Chinese plague. His diagnosis corresponds with that given by Defoe of the plague which decimated London in the reign of Charles II. According to Dr. Yersin, the period of incubation is short -- from four to five days.

John Prehn, an ex-soldier, forty-two years old, asked Justice Martin in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning to commit him to prison for life, because he was unable to obtain employment and had stolen a pair of slippers. The slippers were worth 75 cents, and Prehn stole them on Saturday from Leon Hersh's shoe store, 176 Grand Street.

The lighter-bred British horses at the end of Elizabeth's reign evidently needed improvement; and fortunately an incentive to the propagation of better equine types was not wanting when James I, ascended the throne. This Prince had introduced horse racing into Scotland, and soon after his arrival this sport was established in England.

"From Chungking to Bhamo I walked rather more than 1,000 miles, and I can hardly recall an occasion -- so well was everything managed for me -- when I felt any distress whatever from overexertion. A Journey like this furnishes constant novelty, and is never monotonous; it will surely be undertaken more and more commonly every year.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $1,088,000. The banks now hold $66,718,650 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $2,464,900, a decrease in specie of $283,600, a decrease in legal tenders of $580,200, an increase in deposits of $896,800, and a decrease in circulation of $4,700.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Aug. 25. -- The United States International Boundary Commission has arrived here, and is completing the work of establishing: 258 movements marking the line between Mexico and the United States from El Paso to the Pacific Ocean, a distance of about 700 miles. The Commissioners are Col. Barlow, United States Army; Lieut. Gaillard, United States Army, and Mr. Mossman of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- If there ever had been a lingering hope of more legislation during the remainder of this session of Congress, that hope was dispelled by a remark made behind closed doors Friday afternoon by Mr. Quay, that it was to be understood that there should be no more legislation at this session in connection with contested matters.
To the average landsmen of these latitudes, the months of August and September have no meteorological significance beyond that which is furnished by the vagaries of the thermometer.

The breaking of a ten-inch water main at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon flooded several streets in the vicinity for over an hour. Unlucky spectators of the accident were drenched, and the liberated waters from the Croton Reservoir invaded cellars along the avenues and thoroughfares.

The road run to Rockaway Beach is a fine one, although not generally known to cyclers, because it was only this June that some parts of the roads were changed from unwheelable sand to first-class Telford.

President John Newell of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway and President of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad, died at the Tod House, Youngstown, Ohio, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. About noon Saturday, while President Newell was in his private car near New-Castle, en route to Cambridge, Penn., suddenly he was seriously attacked.
Charles Wilfred Mowbray, the English Anarchist, it is announced, has left New-York and is on his way home. It is said he did not find in America a sufficiently fruitful field for his labors.

The demand for railroad bonds, both speculative and for investment, last week was very large, and prices advanced materially. Special features in the more active bonds were the Reading issues, which all recorded higher prices than for the preceding week. The general mortgage 4s, which carry over 4 per cent, accrued interest, sold up to 80.

Assured good feeling over the business outlook was reflected in the security market last week. While large sales and advancing prices were expected in the preceding week as a direct result of the end of tariff agitation, the course of last week's market was regarded as the test of returning confidence.

From The London Telegraph. A terrible accident, of a perfectly unique character, occurred yesterday in Paris. A carman was driving a dray drawn by two horses, and loaded with casks containing sulphuric acid. In the Rue de Moulin, which is excessively steep, he forget to put on the drag, and the ponderous vehicle soon acquired a velocity which the horses were unable to withstand.

TRENTON, Aug. 25. -- The Republicans fired the first gun of their campaign at the Cape May Convention Thursday, when Henry C. Loudenslager was renominated for Congress in an exceedingly harmonious convention. There was no particular need of the convention, excepting the mere requirements of the law, for there was no opposition to the Congressman.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 26. -- Connecticut laws in regard to the commitment of persons insane or supposed to be insane appear to be, if properly and honestly executed, sufficient to prevent fraudulent commitment, but this "if" may mean volumes. That abuses are committed under the law is a matter of record.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Great interest is manifested by Democrats here in the meeting at Syracuse Wednesday of the sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee appointed to hear and settle grievances. Before this sub-committee the factional troubles in Monroe County will be ventilated and the contention and its causes fully discussed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Capitol was crowded this morning with visiting Knights of Pythias and their wives and daughters, and the red, yellow, and blue colors of the order imparted a gayety to the galleries that was unusual. They needed all the cheer that was brought in by the Pythian Order to make up for the dullness on the floor.

Ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton's announcement that he would give the Republican proposition to make him, the party candidate for Governor "serious consideration" made most of the local members of the party believe yesterday that he would agree to accept the nomination and make the run.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Another move in the conduct of the Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press" was a raise of 50 per cent., which was made last week on all its Chicago members and clients.

The sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee will show by Its works what spirit possesses it. Every Democrat who reads the newspapers will know from day to day just what the committee is doing to promote or obstruct union and harmony in the party. There can be no concealment.
The Anarchists of this city unwillingly admitted, yesterday that Charles W. Mowbray, the English Anarchist, has returned to his home in England.

WARSAW, Aug. 27. -- Count Tyszkeewicz, whose estates are near Krottingen, in the Government of Wilna, has been on bad terms with his tenants for several months. Several tenants refused to pay rent. On Saturday the Count seized thirty head of their cattle as security. The peasants were intensely excited by the appearance of the Count's officers, and let the cattle go only after having been driven with clubs from the sheds.

It was expected when the Grand Jury ordered an indictment for forgery against William Miles of Brooklyn last Friday that the indictment would be filed in Part I. in the General Sessions to-day. This is not probable now, owing to action taken by former Supreme Court Justice Noah Davis.

CITY ISLAND, Aug. 27. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Ava, John H. Gauslie; Stella, James H. Breslin; Alicia, H.M. Flagier; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Shearwater, E.M. Brown, and Aquilo, George A. Thayer. Schooner yachts Magic, A.W. Mott, and Gevalia, H.W. Coates.

Good feeling over the business outlook, which has manifested itself in the security market in the last fortnight, seems to improve at the Stock Exchange. Monday trading, especially at this season of the year, is apt to run light. Sales yesterday were less than the recent daily average, in the general list, following the Monday precedent.

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- A stranger who drifted into the Assembly Chamber at any hour to-day while the Constitutional Convention was in session would have imagined he had fallen into a bear garden or an east side Socialist gathering. The black flag of politics was dragged into the deliberations early in the day, and for the first time since the convention began work, debate took not only a peppery, but occasionally a personal, character.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- A medical commission, composed of Army Surgeons Girard, Mundy, and Clendenin, on duty at Fort Sheridan with their regiments, was appointed to-day by Gen. Miles to make an examination of Lieut. Blanton C. Welch of the Fifteenth Infantry, who struck Col. Crofton, commanding the regiment, twice in the face at the camp outside Evanston yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- An Immense crowd attended Charley Bennett's benefit at the South End grounds to-day, and it is estimated that the popular beneficiary will receive $6,000. Bennett was present at the game, and as he came upon the field on crutches he was given a grand ovation. James Corbett played on the Boston team.

"Decided in the fourth round; time, fourteen and a half minutes," was the announcement last night at the "tournament" of the Seaside Athletic Club by Referee James Carroll when the prize fight between Al. O'Brien of Philadelphia and Charles Burns of Cincinnati had been fought to a conclusion.
That Tillie and Lizzie Meyer did not commit suicide last ntight is providential, fort both made up their minds about a week ago that they should kill themselves.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- The election of officers and members of the Governing Board was the principal business of the Lutheran Synod to-day. The following Trustees were chosen: The Theological Seminary, Columbus -- M. Loy, E.C. Tressel, C. Lenski, L.H. Burry, six years; C. Benzin, four years, and C. Nagel, two years.

Because of the lack of satisfactory security, the President and brokers of the Whisky Trust were unable to borrow in this city yesterday the few millions of dollars needed by them to release from bond their large stock of whisky in the West.

From The London Daily News. The scrupulous clerics who appealed to Rome for guidance in the difficult question of the seemliness of the clergy using cycles can hardly be the inhabitants of these isles. Catholic clergymen in this corner of the world, like those of other denominations, have for some time past taken advantage of the cycle.

Dr. Bernhard Grunhut, the physician who is supposed to have fallen or jumped overboard from the steamship Bothnia on the voyage from Liverpool to Boston, where the steamship arrived Sunday, was well known in this city. At one time he had an extensive practice. He engaged in the real estate business two or three years ago, the firm being Sammet, Grunhut Co., at 153 Broadway.

The Republican scheme which is under way in the Constitutional Convention for fastening on the Constitution of the State an unjust and gerrymandering plan of reapportionment which cannot be shaken off by the will of the people, or by any act of a Democratic Legislature for at least twenty years, was the earnest and serious subject of discussion yesterday, among all classes of Democrats.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Secretary Carlisle telegraphed instructions to the various Collectors of Customs to-day respecting the collection of duties under the new tariff. The message was as follows:

NORTH HECTOR, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The Velnette Yachting Club was organized here Saturday afternoon, with W.A. Stevenson of Sayre, Penn., as President, and D.K. Hamilton of the same place as Secretary and Treasurer. Among the share owners are J.N. King, Superintendent of the Seneca Division of the Lehigh Railroad, and Benjamin Swartwood, one of the managers of the Elmira Reformatory.
AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The Republican Assembly Convention at Cayuga County met here to-day and unanimously renominated B.M. Wilcox for member of Assembly.

-- Madison Square Roof Garden. -- The season for roof gardens is rapidly drawing to a close. The last week began at the Madison Square last night, before one of the largest audiences of the season, which was treated to one of the best bills yet offered on this roof. Maggie Cline was the bright particular star, and her songs evoked the vociferous applause to which she is accustomed.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The Methodists continued their revival services to-day. A number of people attended the meetings of the Perfect Holiness Brethren in the tabernacle, and the Rev. Mr. Yatman's meeting drew many persons to the temple. Dr. Stokes conducted the family devotions in the big auditorium.

W.J. Morgan of the Executive Committee of the Good Roads Tournament, which begins at Asbury Park on Thursday, returned from a trip to Springfield and Boston yesterday highly elated over his success in securing entries. He was particularly fortunate in the former place, where he met many prominent wheelmen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Judge Cole of the District Supreme Court this morning rendered his decision in the matter of the application of Mr. Littleton T. Dryden of Baltimore for a writ of mandamus directed against Secretary Carlisle to compel the latter to restore him to the position he formerly held as United States Shipping Commissioner at the port of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- President Cleveland has written the following letter to Representative Catchings of Mississippi, in which he sets forth his views of the new tariff law, and gives his reasons for not approving the bill:

-- Last Week of Sousa's Band. -- This is the last week of Sousa'a famous band, which has been heard by a million people at Manhattan Beach this season. The third week of the musical festival begins Thursday next and continues until Monday evening, Labor Day. The band leaves for the St. Louis Exposition next Tuesday.

A melodrama called "Coon Hollow" had its first New-York presentation at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last evening and won the enthusiastic applause of so nearly everybody present that it is hardly necessary to take into consideration the views of the unenthusiastic and unapplauding dozen or so who made up the remainder.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 27. -- The first appearance upon the dramatic stage to-night of Miss Nora O'Brien of this city was a social event of no mean proportions. The performance was given for the benefit or the families of Policemen Dunn and Neary, who, a few months ago, were killed by a train on the Northern Central Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- Following upon the heels of last week's rumors regarding the purchase of the stock of the People's Traction Company by the Philadelphia Traction Company, came reports of a still greater transaction. The control of the People's Traction is said to be a mere incident to the big scheme to join the traction companies in this city wih the Metropolian Traction Company of New-York, and Manhattan Elevated Railroad system.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 27. -- In the articles published in The New-York Times in reference to the water furnished to the people of this city, it has frequently been stated that whenever any one raised his voice in condemnation of the Passaic, he was at once charged with being the agent of some syndicate.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- A story is published here that Mother Mandelbaum, the notorious "fence," who lived for a long time in New-York and who was reported to have died recently in Montreal, is not dead.

BIRMINGHAM., Ala., Aug. 27. -- The properties of the Birmingham Furnace and Manufacturing Company were sold at public outcry to-day by order of court. The purchasers were Fuller Hogsett and associates of Pittsburg, Penn., bondholders The price paid was $350,000.

The new tariff provisions, steamship men think, will have an early effort upon steerage traffic. Throughout the past year emigration has been in excess of immigration, but a turn in the tide is looked for soon after the tariff measure has become operative.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The War Department has been notified that Private Andrew F. Wetton, Company F. Twenty-third Infantry, won the sold medal in the department of Texas rifle competition, held at Port Clark, Texas. Silver medals were awarded Second Lieut. F.W. Kobbe, Twenty-third Infantry: First Sergt. F.G. Miller, Twenty-third Infantry, and Sergt. John McCormick, Eighteenth Infantry.

Mr. R.H. Edmonds, editor of The Manufacturers' Record, published at Baltimore, who was in New-York one day last week, said, in speaking of the South, that there is a very decided tendency of capital to seek investment in that section. "In fact," added Mr. Edmonds, "the investment of money in the South promises to become a conspicuous feature of the times -- a fad, if it may be so called.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- Dispatches from Yokohame say that the Japtanese war fever is at a white heat, and that the people are demanding a quick, hard blow at the heart of China. Everybody there is eager to see all Japan's land forces concentrated and marched against Pekin.

NEWPORT, Aug. 27. -- A pony parade attracted much attention from the cottagers to-day. It is an annual affair. The Judges were Prescott Lawrence, Ogden Mills, and W.R. Hunter. The parade went alone Annandale Road between 3 and 4 o'clock. Baroness Selliere, Mrs. Cornellus Vanderbilt, Mrs. Prescott Lawrence, Mrs. David H. Ging, Jr., were among the throng of spectators.

The Rev. Dr. Edward Beecher, the oldest surviving member of the famous family of which the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher was the most prominent, celebrated his ninety-first birthday at his home, 182 Macon Street, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Celia Thaxter, the poet, died in her home, at the Isle of Shoals, N.H., Sunday night. The New-York Times printed, a year ago yesterday, a charming impression of her drawing room, where Prof. Paine and Dr. Mason often played the piano, and artists in painting and literature talked. Her father, Thomas B. Laighton, was a disappointed editor and politician of Portsmouth, where she was born June 29, 1836.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- George M. Pullman, appeared before the National Labor Commission this afternoon as a voluntary witness. Mr. Pullman said that the reasons for reducing the wages were purely a matter of business, as the manufacturing department was losing money. He saw no reason why the company, although it had this year declared a dividend of $2,800,000, should raise the wages of men in a department which was losing money.

Gossip and new facts in regard to both the independent investigation of the Police Department and the coming session of the Lexow committee abounded yesterday. Much of the talk was based on the return to active work of John W. Goff, the senior counsel for the Senate committee, and his conference with Assistant District Attorney Wellman, who has prosecuted the defendant police officers at the Central Office.

The raids by the police on Sunday at 12 and 14 Pell Street, 17 Mott Street, and 23 Bowery, resulted in the arrest of thirty-five Chinamen and thirteen white women. Eight men were also arrested for gambling at 171 Eldridge Street.

The story, published exclusively in The New-York Times yesterday, that time had been reserved for Miss Lillian Russell at Abbey's Theatre, beginning Nov. 5, was read with astonishment by theatrical people. Canary Lederer, who secured an injunction of the Supreme Court forbidding Miss Russell to sing this season, except under their management, were particularly interested.

One of the special orders set down for the consideration of the Constitutional Convention on Thursday evening is the report of the sub-committee of the Committee on Legislative Powers, relating to the diversion of the waters of Niagara River. The report as now presented in printed form varies somewhat from the draft report as originally published.

STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 27. -- There is a party of well-known officials and business men of this place, noted for their practical Jokes, who are wishing to-night that their joking had not taken so practical a turn.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- All the dancing cottagers were at Mrs. Robert Goelet's cotillion to-night, which was led by Elisha Dyer, Jr., with Mrs. Goelet. The dance was in the large hall of the villa. The favors were flowers and hats for the ladies and pieces of silver for the men.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- The Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge and the corporations of the Cities of New-York and Brooklyn have begun suit in the United States Court in this city against John E. Dubois. the lumber operator of this city and Dubols, Penn., to recover $9,000 costs in one of their bridge litigations.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Mrs. George Swift, a prominent resident of Bay Shore, while driving past the country seat of Malcolm W. Ford, the well-known athlete, here, this afternoon, was thrown from her carriage and seriously injured.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 27. -- For the first time in the history of the Grand Trotting Circuit a meeting has been undertaken without the adjunct of the betting ring. The five-days' card which is on at Charter Oak Park this week began this afternoon without the semblance of speculation, and very appropriately the events were all for breeders.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- The all-comers' tournament is over, and it has been won by Goodbody, who has shown, himself strong enough to down three of the best American players. The flnal match took place this morning, when Learned was defeated by the Irishman in a flve-set match, the scores of which were 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3.
Robert Peel does not seem any nearer the blissful state of matrimony than he was on his landing from England on the 4th day of this month.
All the Coroners and the attaches of the Coroners' office were angry yesterday because of alleged discrimination in the furnishing of the new Criminal Courts Building.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- In consequence of the capsizing in Portland Roads of the Britannia's dinghy, through which two of the crew were drowned, the Prince of Wales has canceled all of the cutter's engagements on the western coast. The bodies of the drowned sailors have not been recovered.

When the Lord Keeper North left London, during his last illness, his brother writes: "The family physician went with us, and he had his chests of medicines as if we were going a voyage to the Indies." Patients liked to swallow an appreciable quantity; in one of the Verney letters, a lady describes her husband as taking more than twenty pills, and feeling great relief after the sixteenth!

It Is believed by many persons that the poor men who wander idle and hungry about the streets are unwilling to work. Those who are inclined to accept this idea should see the work that such men are now doing at the home of the Industrial Christian Alliance, 170 Bleecker Street.

-- Mrs. Francis J.A. Darr has as her guests at Morristown. N.J., this week, the Misses Elmer of this city, whose miniatures and decorations of the Hotel Waldorf have attracted much attention. The tapestries in the salons of the hotel made by Miss Etta Elmer are pronounced excellent by critics, while the exquisite miniatures done by Miss Mary Elmer have elicited much praise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Tariff bill of 1894 will be the law of the land from tomorrow. The bill that reached the President Aug. 15, and which had been in his possession ten full days at noon to-day, becomes a law without bis signature, and with only his qualified approval, expressed in a strong private letter to Representative Catchings of Mississippi.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Two thousand acres of valuable timber land in this section of Long Island have been burned over by a forest fire during the last two days. The fire started in the woods about two miles west of Good Ground. Several houses narrowly escaped destruction.

The Secretary of the Treasury yesterday issued instructions to the Collectors of Customs at this and other principal ports of the country, advising them that "all articles heretofore subject to duty but made free by the provisions of the new act may be withdrawn from warehouses on and after Aug. 28, 1894, without the payment of duty."

We observe that one or two of our exchanges have fallen into the error of asserting that The Times has charged Secretary Carlisle with being "in collusion with the Havemeyers," and with obtaining "direct from the managers of the Trust" the information about the sugar duties which he has so freely given out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Representative Shaw of Wisconsin, who has been ill for some weeks, died this morning at his home at Eau Claire, Wis. As soon as the intelligence reached the Capitol, a meeting of the Wisconsin Representatives was held, at which were present Messrs. Haugen, Barwig, Cooper, and Somers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Secretary Carlisle might have been surprised this morning if he had time to read The Washington Post, for on the editorial page of that paper, edited by Mr. Beriah Wilkins, late a Representative from the State of Ohio, he was very zealously, not to say tumultuously, defended from the "Mugwump discussions" of Mr. Carlisle that have appeared in The New-York Times for a day or two, to Mr. Wilkins's apparent annoyance.

In the speech with which he opened the campaign in Maine, ex-Speaker Reed had a great deal to say about the sugar duties and the alcohol paragraph in the new tariff, and nearly all that he said on these two subjects was either untrue or misleading.

Druggist J. Fred Windolph, whose store is at 564 State Street, near Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has made a study of the powerful effects of concentrated ammonia, and he frequently thought that this would make a formidable weapon in case he ever found burglars in his store.

Two-year-old George L. Shroeder, whose parents live at 834 Eighth Avenue, was being wheeled in his carriage along the side of the lake in Central Park about 9:30 yesterday morning, when the nurse let go the carriage and it rolled into the water.

Police Captain Michael Doherty and his ward men, John Hock and Bernard Meehan, who were recently removed and dismissed from the force by the Police Commissioners upon charges of having been paid by Mrs. Augusta Thorow for protection, have taken their cases into the Supreme Court for review, and yesterday, upon the application of their counsel, they procured from Justice Beach a writ of certiorari to have the determination of the Commissioners reviewed.

-- The Atlantic Coast Line special, which left Jacksonville, Fla., last Sunday, with Florida Knights or Pythias, at 4:20 P.M., Eastern time, and arrived in Washington at 8:09 A.M. yesterday, made the run of 780 miles, after deducting stoppages, in 880 minutes, an average speed for the entire distance of 55 1/2 miles per hour.

Twelve thoroughbred yearlings, the property of the Faustiana Stud, and the get of Faustus and Free Knight, were disposed of at Tattersalls last night. The sale was well attended, and the prices, for the class of animals offered, were good. The highest priced one in the lot, and the best-looking one, was purchased by John Harding for $950.

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- The Republican majority were guilty of as gross an exhibition of petty and partisan politics in handling the apportionment question as ever was seen by a machine-ridden Legislature. From the brilliant beginning of patriotism, the majority suddenly dropped to-night to the gutter of lowest politics.

One of the workmen engaged in varnish-in the newly-painted big double-deck tenement, 144 Forsyth Street, dropped a lighted candle into a pot of varnish in the hallway on the third floor yesterday afternoon. In his excitement he kicked over the pot, and the varnish ran in blazing streams over the floor and down the stairway.

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- The Republican majority were guilty of as gross an exhibition of petty and partisan politics in handling the apportionment question as ever was seen by a machine-ridden Legislature. From the brilliant beginning of patriotism, the majority suddenly dropped to-night to the gutter of lowest politics.

The fourth meeting of the Garbage Commission, which was appointed by the Mayor to consider plans for the disposal of the city's garbage, was held yesterday afternoon at the office of the Supervisor of the Harbor in the army Building in Whitehall Street. All the members, with the exception of ex-Mayor Edson, who was out of town, were present.
It is reported that J.B. Smith has sold the four-story stone dwelling, lot 15.6x100.11, No. 121 West Ninety-seventh Street, for about $18,000.

An order was obtained from Judge McAdam of the Superior Court yesterday to show cause why a commission should not be appointed to inquire into the sanity of William J. Scanlan, the actor, who has been confined in Bloomingdale Insane Asylum during the past two years. The application was made on the petition of Augustus Pitou.

TRENTON, Aug. 27. -- The Mercer County Wheelmen intend to make the presentation of the banner won by the Riverside Wheelmen team of New-York at the Inter-State Fair Grounds on Saturday a formal affair in the near future. The banner was the prize given by The New-York Times to the team scoring the largest number of points in the learn race at a distance of one mile.

From The New-York Weekly. He (after the wedding tour) -- Um -- my love, these bills are piling up at a fearful rate; but, of course, my angel, with your large income, you are willing and no doubt anxious to help me pay them.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27. -- O.W. Tinan, forty-five years old, was found nearly dead in his office, at 740 Broad Street, at 11:30 A.M. to-day, having tried to kill himself with chloroform. He was taken to the City Hospital, where he died at 12:30 o'clock.
A morning newspaper has been running a series of sensational articles for a week or more purporting to give the views of various persons on the subject of suicide.

Charles F. Phillips, who was in a syndicate with the late Henry S. Ives, began suit in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, before Justice Gaynor, yesterday, against Mills W. Barse, George W. Stryker, as executor of the estate of Henry S. Ives, William C. Boone, Charles H. Graham, George W. Saul, and Henry Morehead.

The County General Committee of the Populist Party in this city has made a concession to the Centarl Labor Union, or, rather, David Rousseau, whose withdrawal from the Populist Conference Committee was asked by the Central Labor Union on the ground that he was an enemy of labor and did not employ union men, yesterday voluntarily withdrew from the Conference Committee and also from the County General Committee of the party.
From The Chicago Record. It was the same old story; she was rich, he was poof, and both were floundering helplessly in the flower-twined meshes of love.
The youth and beauty of the Parish of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, at the corner of Barclay and Church Streets, made merry last evening at the annual Summer festival.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 28. -- The big Sound steamer Connecticut, bound in from New-York, went ashore this morning on the sand bar at Field's Point, not two miles from her dock. After passing Point Judith the Connecticut encountered fog. Every mile up the bay the fog became more dense, and great caution was observed in proceeding.

Two motions were made yesterday before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, by Treadwell Cleveland, In behalf of Mrs. Elizabeth Garnett of Bristol, England, and Benjamin M. Fowler, debenture bondholders who are dissatisfied with the way the receivers are conducting the affairs of the Jarvis-Conklin Mortgage Trust Company.
The full significance of Secretary Carlisle's authorized interview or statement of April 29 is not seen unless the dates of certain events and the utterances of other persons are recalled.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28 -- Wiry "Bob" Wrenn is still the tennis champion of America. This morning he met the defeater of so many crack players, and by beating Goodbody of Great Britain in four sets retains the title for another year.

By heavy batting in the first and seventh innings the New-Yorks won from the Clevelands yesterday. The fleld work on both sides was ot a good character, but clever pitching on the part of Rusle saved the Giants. Doyle's work at flrst was excellent. He made several pretty plays, and was warmly applauded. In the fifth inning a fire was discovered under the grand stand, but a few buckets of water extinguished it.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- A dispatch from St. Louis, capital of the French possessions in Senegambia to the Journal des Debats, says that the Touaregs recently surprised the French, and, after three days' fighting, pursued them to Timbuctoo, where another fight took place, resulting, as before, in favor of the Touaregs.

DENVER, Colo., Aug. 28. -- Gov. Davis H. Waite was arrested this evening on a warrant charging him with opening and retaining a letter addressed to Mrs. Likens, formerly matron at Police Headquarters. The warrant was issued by United States Commissioner Hinsdale, who also issued warrants for the arrest of President Dennis Mullins of the Police Board, Hamilton Armstrong, Chief of Police, and Kate Dwyer, matron at Police Headquarters.
Simon Stevens, a prominent lawyer and an authority on riparian rights, died suddenly yesterday morning at 2 o'clock from heart failure at his home, 37 East Twentieth Street.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The Morning Post prints this dispatch from Shanghai:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Anna Kubersky, nineteen years old, employed as a domestic by a Mr. Pauly of 321 East Fifty-first Street, New-York, came to this city on Sunday to visit at the home of Fritz Steinhausen, at 631 Blackwell Street. She appeared to be in excellent spirits, but her friends noticed that she made frequent reference to the suicide in Central Park of Juliette Fournier and De Marcus.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- The amended cities article, which was doctored by President Choate and Chief Navigator Root, is in a very bad way. It is discredited by 30 per cent. of the Republican delegates and 100 per cent. of the Democratic members, but it is slated to go through under the gag, spur, and boot of the caucus.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Ex-Senator Fassett was seen at his office in this city to-day, and shown the statement, which Levi P. Morton handed out to the press representatives upon his arrival home Sunday morning. When asked to pass judgment upon it, Mr. Fassett said:

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- The caucus of the Republican members of the Constitutional Convention this afternoon lasted an hour and a quarter. Mr. Vedder called the caucus together and E.R. Brown presided. The question of the manner of making amendments to the reports of the majorities of committees in such a manner that the majority delegates may know whether to vote for the report or the amendment was discussed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Operators on the floor of the Exchange were awaiting developments to-day. The public will not buy on a declining market, and as ours has been nothing else for some time, there was no outside interest. Most of to-day's business was in the way of "turning," there was comparatively little of this to do, and the differences were very slight.

Business fell below its recent average volume yesterday, at the expense of prices. There was no general movement to put out short contracts, for that would have induced activity. Those who had bought at lower prices than are now quoted evidently thought it a good time to realize upon their judgment.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- The Boston News Bureau to-day is authority for the statement that the Bay State, Brooklyn, and Jamaica Plain Gas Companies of this city have agreed to consolidate, and the Standard Oil and Beckton interests will hereafter control the gas supply of Brooklyn, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- At the beginning of this morning's session of the National Labor Commission, Chairman Wright announced that he had requested the different railroads centring in Chicago to file statements of losses caused by the recent strike. The gross loss on the Alton was estimated at $286,360.

Stafford, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The Tanner House, one of the largest hotels in the western Catskills, was burned to the ground about 8 o'clock to-night. Cause, lamp explosion. The hotel was about a mile from the village and beyond the reach of Fire Department assistance. All the fifty guests escaped. Loss, about $20,000; partially Insured.

A number of men, most of whom are members of the Chamber of Commerce, have been for some days arranging to call a meeting of representative citizens, with the end in view of starting a citizens' movement for use in the municipal campaign in this city this Fall.

When the Board of Aldermen met yesterday, one of the earliest arrivals was Alderman Parks, just returned from ills vacation at Asbury Park, where, it is alleged, he had an interest in a gambling house. He was released on bail after his arrest. Concerning the charge, he made an explanation to the board.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- It is of vital interest to the Democratic Party that some sort of an amicable adjustment of the Monroe County Democrats be reached at the meeting of the sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee at Syracuse tomorrow. Loyal Democrats are hoping for a harmonious settlement.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- The worsted spinning mill, the moquette spinning mill, and the print mill of Alexander Smith Son's extensive carpet mills will start operations to-morrow as a result of the passing of the Tariff bill. The company has a large quantity of new wool in bond, which will be withdrawn at once.

Col. Robert O. Ingersoll, in common with many other persons, has a grievance against a newspaper of this town. The newspaper in question appended the name of Col. Bob to some statements justifying a resort to suicide in certain cases, and leaving the suicide himself to judge whether one of these cases had arisen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The second session of the Fifty-third Congress ended today at 2 o'clock. The scenes on the floors of both houses were uninteresting, and the occasion was only saved from tedious dullness by the presence of an extraordinary throng in the galleries, most of whom wore the uniform or colors of the Knights of Pythias.

There may be trouble, if not punishment, under the criminal law for the morning newspaper and its contributors who have been counseling the advisability of suicide. A great many complaints have been made against this straining after sensationalism, which, it is conceded, has caused several persons to end their lives.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- The general expectation that a partisan disturbance would enliven the opening proceedings of the Constitutional Convention this morning, as a consequence of the tumultuous racket yesterday on the home-rule-for-clties and the apportionment proposition, was not fulfilled, barring an interchange of parliamentary courtesies between Mr. Holcomb (Dem., New-York,) and President Choate, during which the sympathies of the convention were plainly with the former.
There was much surprise in this city yesterday when it was announced that Convict William B. Hayes had been released from Sing Sing Prison.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
It pleased ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt to make a remark yesterday afternoon which led to the comment:

When The Times opened its contest for decent government in Kings County last year, it struck its first blows at prize fighting in Coney Island. It was met by statements from every member of the McLaughin gang who was directly or indirectly responsible -- and especially from the Sheriff, the District Attorney, and the Mayor -- that the brutal fights at Coney Island were not "prize fights" within the meaning of the law.

APPLEDORE, ISLE OF SHOALS, N.H., Aug. 28. -- Funeral services over the body of Mrs. Celia Thaxter, the poet, were held in her residence today. The Rev. James De Normandie of Boston officiated. Mr. William Mason of New-York, an old friend of Mrs. Thaxter, played several appropriate selections on the piano.

DOVER, Del., Aug. 28 -- The Democratic State Convention met here to-day, and, as predicted in The New-York Times of Monday, nominated Ebe Tunnell for Governor and Samuel H. Bancroft. Jr., for Congress.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- The ball which was given at the Newport Country Club this evening by Counts Zichy and Hadik was the finest affair of its kind thus far this season. The verandas were inclosed and elaborately decorated with flowers. On the grounds were hundreds of lanterns and colored lamps.

Dr. Reuben Curtis Moffat, the oldest homeopathic physician in Brooklyn, died early yesterday morning at his home, 17 Schermerhorn Street, of pleuro-pneumonia, Dr. Moffat was seventy-six years old. He leaves four sons and a daughter. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 2 P. M., in the Church of the New Jerusalem, corner of Monroe Place and Clark Street.

-- The apparently easy manner in which the baseball team of the Orange Athletic Club has disposed of a large majority of its competitors this season has prompted the management to arrange for a game In which its real playing strength could be tested. A large crowd is sure to witness the work of the home team against the St. Louis League Club on Friday.

-- Henry Bridger, three years old, of 29 Clarkson Street, while crossing King Street, near Varick Street, at 6 o'clock last night, was run over by a team and a wagon of the New-York and Boston Transportation Company, and died before an ambulance arrived. William McGuire, the driver, was arrested and locked up in the Macdougal Street Police Station.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- With just enough cloudiness to lessen the effect of the sun's brightness, the Knights of Pythias had an ideal day for their great parade. The parade assembled at Camp Washington, on the monument grounds, at 4 o'clock, and marched up Seventeenth Street to Pennsylvania Avenue, where the procession turned, and the knights marched in reviewpast President Cleveland.

ELIZABETH, Aug. 28. -- The Board of Health here has at last felt the necessity of doing something to abate the spread of typhoid fever in this city. The board has ordered that all the wells on Railway Avenue, where the disease first appeared and where it has gained the most foothold, shall be closed.

Ex-Senator John McCarty of Brooklyn has started for Syracuse to attend the first meeting of the sub-committee of five, which was appointed by the Democratic State Committee at its recent meeting at Saratoga to hear and decide upon contests within the party.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- The Republican Convention for Ontario County was held in Canandaigua to-day. The delegations elected were not instructed, but it is understood that those for the State Convention will favor the nomination of Morton or Fassett. Those for the District Judicial Convention favor the renomination of William Rumsey, and the nomination of William E. Werner to succeed Judge Yeomans of Rochester, Gov. Flower's appointee, to the Supreme Court bench.

The sub-committee of the State Democratic Committee which is clothed with authority to adjust all contests within the party arising from the claims of rival organizations in the appointment of election officers will meet in Syracuse to-day.

Frances Anselma, thirteen years old, of 250 Mott Street, was for some time a careful and willing maid-of-all-work at the home of Miss C.M. Westover of 464 Columbus Avenue, but she is now a prisoner under charges of larceny.

The section of the municipal amendment which provides for separate elections was adopted in the Constitutional Convention yesterday without change, but it still remains bound up with other provisions as part of the same "proposed amendment." The section relating to election officers was stricken out as unnecessary, since the subject is covered in a general amendment previously agreed to.

The proceedings at Police Headquarters yesterday in the case of ex-Ward Man Burns, accused of bribery and neglect of duty in connection with his service under Captain, now Inspector, McLaughlin, in the First and Eleventh Precincts, were dreary and monotonous.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- In obedience to the order of the Emperor, the Civil Governor of the Prussian Provinces has issued a rescript forbidding the gathering of large numbers of civilians on the occasion of the military manoeuvres in those districts, owing to the consequent danger of infection and the spread of cholera.
The Brooklyn Biscuit Works, 46, 48, and 50 Fulton Street, and extending back to Doughty Street, Brooklyn, was totally destroyed by fire at 1:45 this morning.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES. published this morning, consists of TEN PAGES. It contains:

-- The Butterflies was named after the successful comedy in which John Drew played for so many months last season. Charles Frohman. Mr. Drew's manager, and "Dave" Gideon are warm personal friends. After the Brooklyn Handicap Mr Gideon took Mr. Frohman over to his stables and showed him his horses. Then he told the theatrical manager that he might name any of the two-year-olds.

It is a curious fact that no such sensation has been for years caused in theatrical circles by the death of a man connected with the drama as was occasioned yesterday by the unexpected decease of one who, although related to the stage for many years, had never been seen upon the boards by the public except through sheer accident.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 28. -- Cincinnati banks loaned $2,500,000 to take whisky out of bond in this and adjacent districts. About $800,000 of this went to the Whisky Trust. A stir was created late last evening by the sudden and unexpected withdrawal of the largest single lot of the year, consisting of 466 immense casks of cherry juice and fruits preserved in alcohol and brandies.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- At a meeting or the Trans-Jersey Ship and Canal Commission this afternoon it was decided to adopt the report of Lewis M. Haupt, engineer in charge, and put parties in the field to-morrow to survey two proposed routes for the sluiceway.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 28. -- Edmond H. Hoffmann, who disappeared from this city Aug. 2, leaving his family and his business, has been heard from in Paris. In a letter to a friend, Hoffmann declares that old debts pressed on him so heavily that in paying them he made it impossible to keep up with his current obligations.

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn put himself on record yesterday as indorsing the brutal prize fights of Monday night in the arena of the Seaside Athletic Club, Coney Island, in the course of which Charles Burns of Cincinnati was " knocked out" in the fourth round by "Al" O'Brien of Philadelphia.
The Executive Committee of the New-York State Democracy met in the meeting room of the Cooper Institute last night, and to a certain extent defined the position of the party.

GRAND RAPIDS, Wis., Aug. 28. -- Vesper, a lumbering village in Wood County, was wiped out by forest fires this afternoon. A sawmill, planing mill, and 9,000,000 feet of lumber, belonging to Sherry Cameron Co., were completely destroyed. All residences and household goods on the west side, including that of Manager Cameron, were burned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- One of the characteristics of the Sugar Trust contingent in Washington has been a total disregard of public opinion on the sugar question. It has been sure of its Senators, for what reason only those Senators know, and they can be expected to tell only on their deathbeds.

Gerrymandering, or dividing a State into representative districts in such a way as to give an advantage to one political party over the other, not determined, by its actual voting strength, has been a reproach to our Legislatures for many years. It is condemned by all honest and fair-minded men, regardless of party.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- This has been an eventful day at the Military Academy. It marked the return of the furlough class, and several unexpected changes in cadet officers, which, with the unexplained absence of three cadet Sergeants and two privates, and some attendant mysteries, furnished many subjects for comment and speculation.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- The State Board of Arbitration and Conciliation was in executive session this morning for over an hour. The situation at Fall River and New-Bedford was reviewed at length, and it was concluded that the hour for definite action in the matter had not arrived.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The change from the McKinley tariff to the new tariff law, involving great reductions in rates of duties and numberless alterations in matters of detail, because of the well-oiled wheels of the Governmental machinery was accomplished this morning, as far as the Treasury Department is advised, all over the United States, without a hitch or a break.

NEWPORT, Aug. 29. -- Secretary and Miss Herbert will conclude their stay here tomorrow morning at 7 o'clock, when the Dolphin will leave for West Island, where the Secretary's party will spend a day, guests of the Fishing Club. They will leave for Wood's Holl Friday, and will go thence to Boston.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Everybody in this bustling Summer city has apparently caught the cycling fever, and if the Good Roads Tournament, at the athletic grounds to-morrow, Friday, and Saturday, is not a record breaker, at least in point of attendance, it will not be for a lack of enthusiasm on the part of Founder Bradley's folks.

-- Residents of Huntington, L.I., are arranging a series of races between local yachts for Labor Day. It is proposed to have three classes, for jib and mainsall boats, catboats more than twenty feet on water line, and cats of that length and under. The course will be on Huntingten Bay and will be triangular in form and about ten miles long.
Alexander K. Orr. President of the Chamber of Commerce, received the following letter from ex-Mayor Hewitt yesterday:

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The National Labor Commission expects to complete its work by the end of this week. To-morrow witnesses for the American Railway Union will appear in rebuttal, and the sitting of the commission may come to an end at that date. It is probable, however, that it may last one or two days longer.

One of the finest exhibitions of cricket seen in New-York this season was given yesterday at Staten Island, where the famous Germantown Club of Philadelphia, the premier cricket organization of this country, played a combined team of the New-Jersey Athletic Club and Staten Island Cricket Club. The home players gained a victory by 27 runs, but this does not show the closeness of the play or the excitement caused by the finish.

Helen Agnes Keane, the third wife or Hugh L. Keane, who was well known in the real estate and wholesale liquor business, and who made a considerable fortune in Wall Street, has brought an action in the Supreme Court against him to set aside certain deeds of conveyance of the property 262 West Fifty-third Street.

There was a dull and featureless game or baseball at Eastern Park yesterday. The Brooklyns met the Pittsburgs, and won with little or no effort. Ehret, a youth with auburn hair, was in the box for the visitors, and his delivery was hit at will by the members of the local organization, who scored 16 hits for a total of 24 bases and 11 runs.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 29 -- The Official Journal publishes a dispatch giving an account of the disaster to the Dutch forces on the Island of Lombok at the hands of the troops of the Rajah of Lombok, which shows that the Dutch losses aggregate over 500 men, killed, wounded, and missing.

MARTINSBURG, West Va., Aug. 29 -- For the seventh time, and by acclamation, Congressman William L. Wilson, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, received the nomination to-day for Congress from the Democrats of the Second District of West Virginia. The convention simply resolved itself into a mass meeting.

The American Line steamship Paris, from Southampton Saturday last, has 400 first-cabin and 325 second-cabin passengers, and is expected to reach this port to-morrow evening or early Saturday moraine. The Paris comes out under command of Capt. W.G. Handle, but will sail from here on Wednesday, Sept. 5, with Capt. Frederick Walkins in command, he having taken out his American citizenship papers.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Fire destroyed a tract of woodland a few miles northwest of here this afternoon. It burned five hours before the farmers were successful in checking the flames.

The news that President Cleveland had signed the commission of A. Augustus Healy to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the First District of New-York pleased Mr. Healy's friends in Brooklyn. It was regarded as an emphasis of the President's determination to stand by his appointees in spite of Senatorial opposition.

The Constitutional Convention adopted yesterday a section of the proposed amendment "to provide home rule for cities" which gives the Governor of the State power to remove the heads of police departments and leaves it to the Legislature to provide for filling vacancies.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 29. -- There was a great improvement at the Grand Circuit meeting to-day, both in attendance and the character of the sport. The Charter Oak Stake, which has been a leading feature here since 1883, brought visitors from New-York, Boston, and Providence. Among the delegation from the Hub were Col. HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 John A. Thayer and J. Malcolm Forbes, the respective owners of Ralph Wilkes and Arion.
The funeral of Mrs. Jane M. Aspinwall, wife of the late John L. Aspinwall, was held yesterday forenoon at Grace Church, Tenth Street and Broadway.

The system used by the Brooklyn surface car companies to propel their cars by the use of trolleys, the return current of electricity going underground, has compelled the Commercial Cable Company to change the location of its cable from the conduit through Brooklyn and bring it around outside of Coney Island and up the bay to this city, where it will be landed at Pier A, North River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Secretary Herbert has withdrawn the permission which he granted to Passed Assistant Engineer F.M. Bennett to write for a magazine a series of articles on conditions in the navy. The articles have been appearing in The United Service, a monthly publication, over the signature of the author, and have discussed certain conditions which are recognized as faults in the service.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn is evidently not in accord with the views of his Police Commissioner as to the views of his Police "scientific contests" which took place Monday evening in the arena of the Seaside Athletic Club at Coney Island.

Sebastian Lind, seventeen years old, went into the jewelry shop of C.F. Pearce, at 187 Broadway, Tuesday morning, and presented an order, written on notepaper, bearing the name of F.J. Finley, jeweler, of 150 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, asking for two gold chains. He also had a blank check, signed "F.J. Finley," which the note said he was to fill in when he got the chains.

-- Excise Commissioner Dalton stated yesterday that the board had decided to revoke the license of the "Saloon of All Nations," 263 Seventh Avenue, which is run by Joseph Meyer. Complaints had been made of the place. The detectives who had been detailed to get evidence gave their testimony before the Excise Board yesterday.

-- The Red Star Wheelmen is the name of a new cycling club organized at Amityville. L.I. The club has already a membership of seventeen. The Captain is Charles H. Lush, who for several years held the championship of Suffolk County. The club will at once commence preparations for a meet on the track of the Amityville Driving Association.

The new factory and plant of the Brooklyn Biscuit Company, at 40 and 48 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, were destroyed early yesterday morning by fire, and a loss of $40,000 was sustained. The company is composed of Congressman M.D. Harter, President; J.R. Strachan, Treasurer, and Frank Held, Secretary, and is an anti-trust concern.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- Secretary Carlisle has sustained Deputy Collector of Customs Fiske of this port in the decision which the latter official made yesterday relative to the duties on unbonded goods at the Government warehouses.

The woman who wore her nails away sewing buttonholes in shirts did not work my harder than did the clerks in the Custom House yesterday in their frantic effort to keep up with the deluge of applications for withdrawals of goods from bond which kept pouring in on them as a result of the new tariff law.

We have recently spoken of the exports of American carpets to England and the sale of them in London, Liverpool, and other English cities. It appears that the American manufacturer is competing with the English manufacturer in Australia also. A prominent firm in Melbourne, advertising a sale of carpets in June last, offered American Axminsters, concerning which it published the following:

-- The New-York team, to play Lord Hawke's English eleven here next month was selected yesterday at a meeting of the league sub-committee, held at the Cricketers' Club. T.S. HopeSimpson, James D. Boyd. Robert J. Steward, W. Fenwick, and Jerome Flannery being the men appointed for the difficult task of picking the team.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Commander V. Behr of the Russian cruiser Kreisser and Lieut. Istomeson of the Russian cruiser Rynda passed through the city yesterday. They are en route from Corea, where they were in the Siberian squadron, having been recalled to take command in the battle squadron.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Before Washington was fairly awake this morning. President Cleveland had eaten breakfast and been driven to the Pennsylvania Railroad station, where he took a train for New-York, en route to Gray Gables for a long rest.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- West Chicago opened 3/4 higher than the closing figures of yesterday, jumped 1/2 more on a few purchases, but gradually receded to 125%, where it was held firm by many bids around that price. In the afternoon, sales were made at 125 3/4, and closed strong at 125 7/8 bid.

Walter J. Freeman, an electrical engineer, who has an office at 130 Liberty Street and lives at 230 West Thirty-sixth Street, was arrested last night by Agents Moore and Deubert of the Gerry society, on a charge of abducting Sarah Knight, fifteen years old, from her home in Boston.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A morning paper says:

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- The feature to-day has been the decline in Bay State Gas, which. It is said, takes the place in our market that Whisky now holds in the New-York market. The opening sale was at 12, an advance of 5/8 over last night's close, with a subsequent decline to 9 1/2, finally rallying on the close to 10.

Frederick E. Bader, one of the Gravesend Election Inspectors who was sentenced last March by Justice Brown of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to five months in the Kings County Penitentiary for concealing registry lists, was released from imprisonment on Tuesday evening, his term having expired.

Two cases of destitution came before the Essex Market Police Court yesterday. One was that of Mrs. Kate Flynn, who has been living at 433 East Thirteenth Street without food or furniture. Two months ago her husband deserted her and her five children, and except for the benevolence of her neighbors the family would have died of starvation.

Mrs. Ellen Lawler, twenty-seven years old, jumped from the pier at the foot of Grand Street, East River, yesterday afternoon, with the intention of drowning herself. She was rescued, after a struggle, by James McGinniss of 357 Madison Street and Henry Hanson of 174 Christopher Street, and taken to Gouverneur Hospital, where she is detained in the prisoners' ward.

ALBANY, Aug. 29 -- Albany politicans see in the developments to-day a carefully and scientifically laid plan to defeat the nomination of Levi P. Morton for Governor by the Republicans by scaring him out of the field. John E. Milholland, the protege of Thomas C. Platt and of Whitelaw Reid, arrived in Albany this morning on a very mysterious mission.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 29 -- The day of days of the White Mountain season, the one appointed for the great East Side coaching parade, attracted, it is estimated, over 15,000 people to this place. The throng was focused about the Kearsarge House, which was beautifully decorated, and where the judges' stand was situated.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 29 -- All sorts of rumors are afloat concerning the battle alleged to have been fought between the Japanese and Chinese troops on Aug. 13, but nothing official has been received here. According to reports received by the native press, a force of 5,000 Chinese troops attacked the Japanese forces guarding the Ping-Yang passes in Northwest Corea and drove them from their position.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Before leaving Washington to-day to investigate charges against the Postmaster at Lancaster, Penn., Civil Service Commissioner Roosevelt expressed some characteristically vigorous views respecting the work of the commission, the practices pursued in the departments, and the construction of the laws relating to the commission.

On Friday last The Union printed a catalogue of false reports circulated by a Western wildcat press association among the papers which serve their readers with that sort of "news." On the same day this dispatch was sent out by the wildcat concern here to its victims, from one of which in New-York we take it:

Chesterfieldian urbanity graced the beginning of the trials before the Police Commissioners yesterday. When Ira Shafer and John Vincent appeared with their client, Capt. John T. Stephenson, Assistant District Attorney Wellman rose and asked suavely, while he toyed with the lapel of his coat: "Is Capt. Stephenson ready to go on trial?"
The steam yachts Now Then and Vamoose had a race up the Hudson yesterday afternoon, and the Vamoose passed the Now Then as though she was tied up, and won easily.

-- The Jockey Club has refused to grant a license to James O. Gray, who proposed to conduct a race meeting over the old Saugus track at Franklin Park, Mass. The reason given is that "the Stewards are disinclined to grant a license to an individual venture of this nature, and have not granted licenses except to organized associations."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29.--The Casino subscrlption ball, which is always looked upon as the culminating society event of the season, was held to-night, and was very much more of a success than usual this being due especially to a larger number of subscribers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company, through its Secretary, C.H. Swan, complains of the delay caused to its enterprise by the postponement by the Secretary of War of the publication of the report recently made by the Board of Expert Engineers appointed under the law authorizing the bridge.

There was another good crowd and another good day's sport at the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday. Lander's Band furnished delightful music for the amusement of the throng between the races, and there was no reappearance of the brutes who were participants in the Coney Island prize fights.
Philip Kuhl, who had been a witness before the Lexow committee, was indicted for perjury in giving straw bail, by the Grand Jury yesterday, and complaint of Louis Wiens of 425 Sixth Avenue.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The Daily News says: "The tariff is at best a compromise and stopgap, giving some expression to the national condemnation of extreme protection as pronounced at the last Presidential election. Business must benefit by ending the uncertainty which has long affected commerce in and with the United States."
Mr. Charles Griffith Moses has sold for George T. Myatt, to Thomas Brown, the lot, 25 by 100, on the north side of One Hundred and Eightieth Street, 100 feet west of Eleventh Avenue.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The discussion of the water question, which has been going on in this city for some time, and which has been fully reported in The New-York Times, has more than a local interest. It concerns the entire State, and has from time to time engaged the attention of the Legislature, while four Governors have found it necessary to consider the matter in one or more of their annual messagres.
Three persons lost their lives in a fire which swept swiftly through the six-story building at 226 Rivington Street at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, and a fireman was seriously injured.

J. Edward Addicks of Boston went to Brooklyn some time ago, bought several gas plants, and entered into a cut-rate war to force the Standard Oil Company, that owned one or two gas companies in Brooklyn, to do as he desired.

Victor Mealin, a poor, half-starved Frenchman, twenty-two years old, was arrested for insanity, on the American Line steamship New-York, at the foot of Vesey Street, yesterday, just before the vessel sailed.
Wheat declined 8/3@1/2c on easier cables and large receipts West, rallied 1/8c on covering, and closed steady at 3/8@1/2c under yesterday, with trading fairly active.

Amsterdam, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- De Witt Clinton Chase, ex-Postmaster of Burtonsville, Montgomery County, committed suicide yesterday by cutting his throat. He was over seventy years old, and had been in poor health. He was for over twenty years Postmaster at Burtonsville. He was also an ex-Justice of the Peace, and a well-known Republican. He leaves a wife.

All law abiding persons in this Commonwealth must discourage and reprehend the commission of suicide under ant circumstances for the simple reason that it is a crime, though without penalties, according to the Penal Code of the State, and that an attempt to commit it is a felony, for which the penalties of felony are provided.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 29 -- The big passenger steamer Northwest of the Northwest Steamship Company went aground in a thick fog this afternoon off Point Pelee, striking bow on in twelve feet of water. Shortly afterward the wind, which had been in the southwest, veered to the north and began to blow off shore, which lowered the water on the bar, driving the vessel on harder than ever.

Herman Clarke, formerly of the defunct stock brokerage firm of Hunter, Clarke Jacob, who has been out on bail on charges of forgery, was surrendered yesterday by his father, who was his bondsman. Clarke is now in the Tombs.

There were enough conspicuous Republicans in town yesterday to make up a dozen State tickets. Most of them went to see Thomas C. Platt. Some of those who did not go to see Mr. Platt went to see Levi P. Morton, to whom Mr. Platt has offered the nomination for Governor. Some went to see both.

-- State Controller Nicholas Staub of Connecticut denies having officially "boomed" the Kinga. Queens, and Suffolk Company, which runs a single-track bicycle electric railroad on Long Island. Recently the Trustees of the road issued a circular containing a fac-simile letter of recommendation written on paper, with an official State letter head, and signed by Controller Staub and Prison Director Frank C. Sumner.

Commander Ballington Booth and the Victory Brigade of the Salvation Army held a service last evening in Association Hall, Fulton and Bond Streets, Brooklyn. The hall was well filled with a class of men and women seldom seen at such gatherings.

ALABANY, Aug. 30 -- Through the combined forces of John E. Milholland. State Controller Roberts. United States Collector of Customs John M. Bailey, and the local Austin-Benson faction of Republicans, State Committeeman William Barnes, Jr., was taken Into camp so quickly to-day that it made his head swim. Mr. Barnes gained a point over his opponents last night In the Third District Convention, which was paid back with Interest to-day in the First District Convention.

CHIPPEWA FALLS, Wis., Aug. 30. -- Forest fires in this section of Northwestern Wisconsin have been intermittent for two months, and the aggregate loss is not less than $3,000,000 among the pine-land and sawmill owners, besides the loss to individuals. Reports to-day are that fires prevail on the outskirts of Prentice, which was almost destroyed a few weeks ago, and fire apparatus has been sent there from this city.
"The weapons with which monopoly [the Sugar Trust] has fought us they [the Republican Party] have forged and tempered and supplied." -- William L. Wilson's Speech at Martinsburg, West Va., Aug. 29.

-- "The use of bicycles in all the armies of Europe," says an exchange, "has been enormously increased during the last two years. In Holland members of the various bicycle clubs who have already attained their twenty-first year and are proficient in their art are invited to join the army under certain advantageous conditions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3O -- "We have not as yet even thought of Mr. Newell's successor," said Cornelius Vanderbilt, the railroad magnate, to a reporter last night. Mr. Vanderbilt politely declined to be further interviewed. General Manager J. M. Toucey of the New-York Central was seen in Mr. Newell's car before the departure of the train for New-York.

Charles M. Pond, ex-State Senator and ex-Treasurer or Connecticut, died in Hartford yesterday, aged fifty-seven years. He was born in this city in 1837, and was a son of Charles F. Pond, President of the Hartford, New-Haven and Spring-field Railroad Company. His mother was a daughter of the late Anson G. Phelps of the old firm of Phelps, Dodge Co., and the founder, of Ansonia, Conn.

"To this mission [the lifting from the backs of the American people the burden of tribute to privilege and monopoly] the immediate representatives of the people gave themselves earnestly and faithfully. In that work they were at all times cheered and encouraged by their great leader, who for eight years, in defeat and victory, has led them In the movement for tariff reform."

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- The market for local stocks was quiet, and prices showed a slightly lower tendency. Mexican Central 4s declined 1/4, to 57 3/4, and the stock. 1/4, to 8 1/4 Bay State Gas was steady at 10, and the second bonds at 60. West End Street Railway was 1/4 stronger, at 54, with preferred at 79 1/2.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Stanford White, the architect, is preparing the plans for one of the most unique exhibitions ever devised, which will open in the great amphitheatre of the Madison Square Garden next December. It may properly be described as "Fairyland for the Children."
