For the first time in its history, the great amphitheatre will be turned over to young New-York, and Manager Frank Sanger expects the juveniles to enjoy themselves thoroughly.

We commend to the serious attention of our readers the report in this paper of an interview with Mr. W. M. Ivins upon the investigation into the charges brought against the Elmira Reformatory by a newspaper of this city. The investigation is not yet concluded, the testimony for the defense not having been put in.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The opinion that "short" selling of wheat had been too popular during the past few weeks obtained in wheat to-day. Whether the modest advance scored to-day was a forerunner of what was to come, or whether it was only a natural rally, remains to be seen, but, in anyevent, shorts are beginning to feel the necessity for caution.

-- The final game between the New-Jersey Athletic Club and the Orange Athletic Club teams will be played to-morrow afternoon on the Orange Oval, East Orange. This contest promises to be a hard-fought one, as the two teams have been keen rivals for some time. The New-Jerseys are confident of winning. Their followers believe that their team is stronger than Orange, and will go along willing to back their opinions heavily.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The following amendment has been made to the "quarantine regulations, to be observed at ports and on the frontiers of the United States," viz.:

There was a marvelous reversal of form at Eastern Park yesterday. Brooklyn was scheduled to play two games with the Pittsburgs, and in consequence there was a large crowd in attendance. The first game was marked by the liveliest kind of batting, and Brooklyn won with over half a dozen runs to spare. It was voted that the second game was an easy thing for the local players, but in this the wiseacres erred.

The effluvium committee of the State Board of Health met yesterday at Police Headquarters to listen to the complaints made toy the residents in and about New-town Creek against the bone fertilizer and fat rendering factories that line its shores.
UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The sub-committee from the State Democratic Committee appointed to adjust grievances, has given decisions in the two cases in which hearings were had in Syracuse Wednesday.

Samuel S. Whitehouse, ex-President of the Kings County Democratic General Committee, addressed a letter yesterday to Commissioners John Gilbertson and George Russell, the Democratic members of the Brooklyn Board of Elections, protesting against the appointment of election officers representing the Democratic committee of which Edward M. Shepard is Chairman, on the ground that the latter organization is not regular.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The "spooks" are still at it at the Military Academy. The reduction in rank of several cadet officers has not had the desired effect of laying them, and, while the boys profess to deplore the invasion of the classic precincts by such irreverent bogies, the memory of the indignity which they think was put upon them when their fondly-cherished "color line" was abolished, is still fresh in their minds.

The meeting of Domino and Ducat in the race for the Ocean Handicap, at a mile, was the feature of the racing at the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday afternoon. A crowd of very considerable proportions was on hand to see this and the other six races that were run, and the sport was of the most satisfactory character aside from the great race, which was a positively delightful performance.

HORNELLSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Gov. Flower, accompanied by his staff, arrived here this morning, and was met by Mayor Willet, who welcomed him on behalf of the city. This afternoon the Governor was escorted to the fair grounds by a battalion composed of the Twenty-sixth and Thirtieth Separate Companies of Elmira, the Forty-third Separate Company of Olean, and the Forty-seventh Company of this city.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 30. -- The Kolbo-Populo-Republico combine has made a change in its Congressional slate, adopted two days ago. The New-York Times's correspondent learned to-day, on the very best Republican authority, that Reuben Kolb, the defeated candidate for Governor, would be nominated by the Triple Alliance to run against Congressman Denson in the Seventh District.

So plain has it become to many of the Republicans of this city that the Constitutional Convention is being used by the back politicians of their party for partisan purposes of a most unsavory character that they are beginning to fear the political bosses are ruining whatever chances the party had through the instrumentality of the Constitutional Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30. -- While the market had a strong undertone to-day its activity and strength were due to manipulation rather than to public buying. Room traders and their following in such a limited market need not be considered in this connection. A quotation may be marked up and down a point by them without changing the real character of the market, which appears not to be quite ready for a sustained bull movement.

NIAGARA, Ontario, Aug. 30. -- The greatest tennis ever seen in Canada was witnessed here to-day. Matthews, the Canadian champion, put up a superb game in the first set against Malcolm Chace and beat him on his merits. Score. 6 -- 4. Chace's staying power won him the next two sets by the score of 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

"While he [President Cleveland] scrupulously abstained from interference with the work of those intrusted with reform legislation, he was instant, in season and out of season, in urging that the pledges on which we had come into power should be fulfilled in the letter and in the spirit, and that the blessings of reduced and just taxation should be fully and honestly secured to the American people."

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 30. -- Six thousand people saw the races here to-day. Taylor's Missouri phenomenon, the great Joe Patchen, did the only sensational performance of the afternoon. In the 2:18 pace he went the third heat in 2:06, equaling his record and lowering the track record of 2:06 3/4, made last year by Roy Wilkes.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 30 -- The steamer City of Topeka, which has arrived from Juneau, Alaska, gives details of a battle among the Chilcat Indians, which resulted in six men being killed and a large number wounded.

"One way I'm sure I can, and one way I'm sure I can't," said one of the little girls at the vacation school at the corner of Ludlow and Delancey Streets, yesterday morning. The school held its closing session yesterday, and to-day the children will have an excursion to Coney Island, where the Society for Improving the Condition of the Poor, under whose auspices the vacation schools were opened, has its seaside home.

-- Mrs. Anna Verdelle, forty-four years old, died in the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital yesterday. She was formerly In the employ of Mrs. Frederick M. Robinson, who lives in the Chelsea apartment house. After being discharged, four weeks ago, she began to buy goods in her former mistress's name from Stern Brothers, B. Altman, and other stores where she had been with Mrs. Robinson shopping.
Up to the close of business at the Custom House in this city yesterday afternoon there had been about 12,000 withdrawals of Imported merchandise under the provisions of the new tariff law.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- The Constitutional Convention disgraced its dignity again today, and, in the language of Mr. Mulqueen of New-York, "ceased to be a Constitutional, but became a political convention." The words were justified In view of the proceedings, which, so far as the Republicans were concerned, were of the rankest partisan character.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Deputy Internal Revenue Collector Watson last night raided three illicit whisky stills between Lodl and Woodridge, Bergen County. He confiscated the stills, a lot of liquor, and arrested four of the "moonshiners." They are Louis Meygert, John J. Mallard, Pierie Liendert, and Christian Swartz.

"WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Secretary Lamont has notified the commanding officers at army posts that they must personally look into all charges which are presented to them regarding officers and men. He positively prohibits charges being sent to Washington on insufficient inquiries, or none at all.

Mrs. Kate Schubert, one of the principal witnesses in the police trials against Capts. Cross and Devery and the ward men whose trials have just been closed before the Commissioners, is now on her way to Hamburg with her husband.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 30 -- President Cleveland arrived at Gray Gables at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Just before 1O o'clock the lighthouse tender Rogers, having on board the President and party, was sighted coming up Buzzard's Bay, and the flag was immediately hoisted on the flagstaff at Gray Gables.

ROCHESTER. N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Edward H. Parmelee of Bergen, a pension agent under arrest for fraudulent practices, committed suicide to-day by throwing himself in front of the east-bound southwestern limited express, as it was passing that place.
SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 30 -- Smoke from forest fires has settled over this city like a pall. It is impossible to see clearly more than a block. Navigation on the Sound Is dangerous.

Americans will be dissatisfied with the results of the season of yacht racing on the other side of the Atlantic if the Vigilant and the Britannia do not have a struggle for the Cape May Cup. As a matter of record, this trophy has not been popular with yachtsmen on this side of the water, or, rather, the conditions attached to a contest for It have not been attractive.

An end came yesterday to the pressure to sell stocks, and the market resumed its upward coarse. Early in the day those who had begun the movement for lower prices on Wednesday round their plans checked by buying orders. Since sellers have lost recently much of the boldness that carried them to success ha the last year, their offerings ceased by midday.

The sudden death of the famous trotting stallion Pamllco creates a big gap in the free-for-all field of the Fleetwood Grand Circuit meeting. The handsome little son of Meander was entered to start in New-York next week, and not a few observing horsemen believed he had a fighting chance to win, even as against Alix. Ryland T., Lord Clinton, Moquette, and Azote.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30. -- Special reports to The Manufacturers' Record from all parts of the South indicate a steady improvement in business interests. Southern merchants, who have been in Baltimore during the week in larger numbers than at any time for several years, give the most encouraging facts as to the abundant crops, the good financial condition of the people generally, and as to the outlook for an unusually large volume of trade.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- After a fourteen days' session, the National Labor Commission adjourned at 3 o'clock this afternoon, to reassemble in Washington Sept. 26, when it will receive any communications bearing on the settlement of the difficulties that come between labor and capital and hear any witnesses who may desire to testify.

"To this mission [the lifting from the backs of the American people the burden of tribute to privilege and monopoly] the immediate representatives of the people grave themselves earnestly and faithfully. In that work they were at all times cheered and encouraged by their great leader, who for eight years.

To our readers was given yesterday a report of the speech of Mr. Wilson in accepting the nomination for Congress in the Second District of West Virginia. They will find scattered through our columns this morning a number of the most significant and telling passages of that speech, and they will find in every one of them the true ring of honest and bold Democracy.

"That action [his renomination by the Democrats of West Virginia] comes at the end of one of the greatest and most momentous struggles that has marked our political history." -- William L. Wilson's speech at Martinsburg, West Va., Aug. 29.

No friendly hand was ready to assist the Giants against the Clevelands on the Polo Grounds yesterday. McGarr, whose inglorious muff was responsible for the victory the day before, appeared on the field like a "pantata" who had undergone an examination before an investigating committee. He had probably been handled without gloves by Capt. Tebeau, and promised never to repeat his offense.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- The Republican members of the Constitutional Convention went into caucus at 5 o'clock this afternoon, and at 9:30 o'clock to-night the home-rule article for cities was dead as a door nail. The only section saved was the first, which provides for the separation of municipal and general elections.

Farmer Dunn of the Weather Bureau In this city is not to be a weather professor at Washington. He received the results, yesterday, of the competition held at Washington recently, and found that he was fourth on the list.

LAVAL, France, Aug. 30 -- Abbe Bruneau, formerly vicar of the church at Entrammes, who, on July 13, was convicted of murder, robbery, and arson, was put to death by the guillotine at 5 o'clock this morning, in the presence of 8,000 persons.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Twelve houses were entered by burglars last night, and they carried away money, jewelry, clothing, chickens, and beer. Twelve shots were fired at the burglars from one house, but none of them was hit.
In all branches of trade merchants realize that the period of depression has passed, and they look forward to continued activity and profit for some time to come.

CORTLAND. N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The Republican County Convention for Cortland held a five hours' session this afternoon. A slate had been prepared, anil the slate was defeated in every candidate. There were sharp contests, but sood feeling. Wilbur Holmes was nominated for Assemblyman, defeating ex-County Judge A. P. Smith, in a sharp contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Congressional Campaign Committee for the Democratic Party is confronted with a problem which will tax the Ingenuity of its members. They are laying out their plans for distributing documents, and all at once It has become apparent that a great deal of care must be exercised in the selection of speeches.

Louis C. Raegener, lawyer, of 280 Broadway, has been honored by the Venezuelan Government with the decoration of the Busto del Libertader for services rendered Joaquin Crespo, present President of Venezuela, when Crespo was engaged in fighting to overthrow the old Government. The steamship South Portland was lying in the bay of this port on Sept. 9, 1892, loaded with about $40,000 worth of ammunition consigned to Gen. Crespo.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- The United Press correspondent at Apia, Samoa, writing under date of Aug. 15, per steamer Mariposa, which arrived this afternoon, says:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The Post Office Department has prepared a statement showing the Presidential Post Offices nominations to, which were not acted upon. They number fifteen, and are all New-York offices. All of the incumbents to-day were reappointed and will hold office until action shall have been taken by the Senate. They are as follows:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug, 30. -- Count Castellane of Austria and C. Raoul Duval jointly gave a ball to-night in the dining tall of the Renaissance Cottage, which was one of the gayest events of the season. Every feature was lavishly carried out, and in some respects the affair has not been surpassed here.

William V. Helfrich, thirty-eight years old, is a prisoner in Jefferson Market Prison. He was arrested early yesterday afternoon at the offices of Charles A. Baldwin Co., brokers, 40 and 42 Wall Street, by Central Office detectives.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 -- Pursuant to the request of President Cleveland, Dr. Frank T. Shaw, Collector of Customs at this port, will on Monday hand in his resignation as Chairman of the Carroll County Democratic Committee, and Deputy Collector Diffenbaugh will also resign as Secretary of the same committee.

Now that the Constitutional Convention has the election section of the cities amendment separated from the other provisions, it is to be hoped that it will be kept separate, and that this and the changes necessary in other articles of the Constitution to effect a complete separation of municipal and general elections will be put in a form to be submitted to a vote by themselves.

"As the President well said, we have gained a vantage ground from which we can continue to shell the camp of monopoly. The day of mad protection is over In this country; McKinleyism will disappear as a dark and hideous blight from our statute books." -- William L. Wilson's Speech at Martinsburg, West Va., Aug. 29.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 30. -- The great bicycle race meet which opened here to-day in the interest of that laudable project, the good-roads movement, started off favored by the weather and the Summer society which annually pervades Founder Bradley's seaside city. The first races were good, but to-morrow's should be better, and on Saturday there ought to be, judging by the entries, high-class work in a number of contests.

Rumors have been circulated in Brooklyn that the friends of John Y. McKane were making efforts to secure his release from Sing Sing after election, and that Gov. Flower had been asked to pardon him. It is said the Governor has thus far declined to commit himself on the subject, but an impression prevails that after the Fall campaign is settled he will sign an order for the ex-boss's release.

BEAVER FALLS. Penn. Aug. 30 -- Masked robbers broke Into the residence of Dr. A. Mercer about 3 o'clock this morning, and, after beating the doctor and his son Into insensibility, ransacked the house. They got but $19 and a few pieces of jewelry.

CHICAGO. Aug. 30. -- The statement was sent out last Saturday by the Associated Press that The Dayton Times had relinquished the news service of the United Press and contracted for that furnished by the Associated Press. The misstatements uttered by the latter organization have been so numerous that it is scarcely necessary to say that the Item referred to was false.

The Casino returned last night to a form of entertainment something like that with which its long-established note has been conected. The programme called the production "vaudeville-operette." Of course no one knows Just what a "vaudevilleoperetta" is and what is perhaps, more to the point.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 30. -- A daring and mysterious, attempt at robbery was made late last night on a trolley car running from this city to Bergen, Point and Bayonne. The car left the Jersey City and Bergen station at 7:30.

QUOGUE, L.I., Aug. 30. -- About six square miles Of timber has been destroyed by fire. The strong northeast wind is sending dense smoke toward the village. The fire started along the railroad, at East Orange, and has burned across the island, to Peconic Bay.

WASHINGTON, Aug 30. -- The Census Office to-day made public the principal results of the investigation of farm and home proprietorship which was made in all of the States and Territories. This is the first investigation of the kind ever conducted for this or any other country.
William M. Ivins, when asked by a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday as to the charges against the Elmira Reformatory management and the present status of the investigation, said:

The veteran cricketers of New-York and Brooklyn played a return game yesterday at Prospect Park, where the Brooklyn men reversed the result of the last game by winning easily by 86 runs. They had the assistance, however, of an old New-York player, whose batting and bowling were of material aid, while J. Rose and Dr. Torres also did good work with the willow.

The great question now among New-York City Republicans is whether a majority of the delegates elected to the Republican State Convention, to be held at Saratoga on Sept. 18, will be for ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton for Governor or against him.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 30 -- So many forest fires are burning in the vicinity of Poughlteepsle that the sky to-day was clouded with dense smoke. No rain has fallen for weeks, excepting one or two light snowers.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 30. -- The maps defining the wards and precincts that are to take the place of the old Assembly districts in this city were filed in the City Clerk's office this afternoon. They divide the city into twelve wards, from each of which one Alderman and one Freeholder are to be chosen.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 30. -- A score or more of the fattest men in the country ate sea food in astonishing quantities at Roton Point to-day. They were members of the Fat Man's Association, which has been holding annual clambakes along the Sound during the last twenty eight years.

DENVER, Aug. 30 -- The novel spectacle of the Governor of the State on trial for conspiracy brought a large crowd to the Federal Building this morning. The Governor conducted his own case, and had, several tilts with the District Attorney.

BRADFORD, Penn., Aug. 30 -- A large tract of valuable timber between Watsonville and West Line, this county, is being destroyed by a forest fire, and several smaller fires are burning between this city and Kinseau. In the valley between Corwin and Rew City fire Is also burning.

J. C. Wilson, one of the receivers of the Atchlson, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, accompanied by W. F. White, General Traffic Manager, and C. A. Higgins, Assistant General Passenger Agent, made a short trip of inspection over the Atchison lines a few days ago. Receiver Wilson expects to be in New-York next Monday to meet Receiver Walker, who is expected home from Europe about that time.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 30. -- One of the largest prizes that will be distributed among the trotters this season was raced for at the Grand Circuit meeting here to-day, but the contest was far from being sensational. The event was the Nutmeg purse of $20,000 for foals of 1891, and of the six young trotters that competed for the rich premium not one seemed able to beat 2:20.

-- Robert Downing Sued. -- Edmund Collier, the actor, has brought suit in Washington against Robert Downing for $1,980, which he asserts is due him for salary last season. Mr. Collier in his complaint says that Downing engaged him for his company at a salary of $150 a week, should the organization be on the road twenty-five weeks, or $123 if the season lasted thirty-five weeks.

In the bierstube of the Liederkranz Hall. 115 East Fifty-eighth Street, a number of the personal friends of Charles de Kay met last evening to tender him a farewell dinner before he departs to assume his official duties as Consul General to Berlin.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 30 -- The torpedo boat Ericsson, built by the Iowa Iron Works at Dubuque, Iowa, reached this harbor at 9 o'clock to-night, and is now at anchor in the river. She was due here early this afternoon, and the representatives of the builders anxiously awaited her arrival.

Of course ex-Mayor Fitler of Philadelphia complains about the removal of the duty on binding twine. That was to be expected. It could have been foreseen, also, that Mr. Fitler would again predict the ruin of the industry. He made that prediction some months ago, and now he repeats it. Here is what he says:

The latest news from the French in Timbuctoo is much sadder than any impression which its mere relation may convey. The French garrison sent a detachment against the Tauregs. It fought against them for three days, and was finally beaten; a second detachment was compelled to retreat.

The bicycle races at the New-Jersey Athletic Club Labor Day Olympiad have received a very large entry, and the racing should be of a sensational character. George C. Smith, better known as "Riverside Smith," of the New-York Athletio Club, one of the fastest Class A riders in America, and present champion of the Metropolitan District, is scratch man in both events, one and two miles.

-- Plans have been prepared for a large hotel to be erected at Garden City by the company controlling that place. The present hotel is surrounded with roadways, and cannot be enlarged. It is said that a feature of the new hotel will be piazzas inclosed with glass for use in the cold season.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30. -- The steamer Mariposa arrived this afternoon, bringing the following letter from the United Press correspondent at Honolulu, dated Aug. 23:

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 30 -- About 10,000 persons this morning attended the closing exercises of the Twenty-fifth camp meeting here. A large number attended the young people's and consecration meetings at the Temple and Tabernacle about 6 o'clock. Incoming trains brought hundreds of visitors from the towns and villages for fifty miles around.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- A bushel basket would not hold all the telegrams and letters received at the Treasury Department concerning Section 61 of the new tariff law, relating to the payment of the rebate on alcohol used in the arts and medicinal compounds, which reads as follows:

Yesterday's stock market brought nothing new to the situation. Buyers seemed to think it worth while to wait for lower prices than those now ruling, while sellers felt no encouragement to put out short contracts with the view of depressing prices. With each side waiting for the other to act and neither disposed to be aggressive, dullness was inevitable.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- The fact that Mr. Morton had expressed his willingness to take the Republican nomination became known in the Constitutional Convention soon after the assembling this evening. The news was first communicated through the newspaper correspondents to the delegates.
HONGKONG, Aug. 31. -- Fire started yesterday among some hundreds of flower boats that were moored stem to stern in the Canton River, and nearly all the craft were destroyed.

The Board of Police Commissioners yesterday dismissed from the force Capts. William F. Devery and Adam Cross, and ex-Ward Men Edward G. Glennon, George Smith, and James Burns, all of whom have been tried for bribery and corruption, and have been convicted.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Although the Count of Paris began to sink late yesterday afternoon and the family and servants at Stowe House were called to his bedside while the last sacrament was administered to him, the Count was still conscious at midnight and able to converse with his family.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- State Controller Roberts made the prediction to-day that the delegation from Albany to the State Convention would favor his candidacy for the Gubernatorial nomination. The active part that his deputy, Col. Morgan, and the antiPlatt forces, headed by John E. Milholland, have taken in the district conventions held in the county gives color to the statement.
The record of suicide and attempts at suicide still keeps up. Yesterday the following cases were reported to the police:

The Independent Order of Odd Fellows intends to have a great field, day at Asbury Park next Monday, Labor Day. Col. George Wailes, Deputy Commander of the Canton Regiment of New-Jersey, has sent special invitations to the cantons of NewYork and Brooklyn and members of the order in general in this section of the country to be present and take part.
Oswald Ottendorfer, editor of the StaatsZeitung, and President of the GermanAmerican Reform Union, returned to this city on the steamship Furst Bismarck from Hamburg, yesterday forenoon.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 31. -- Robert J., Mr. C.J. Hamlin's wonderful pacer, achieved imperial honors here to-day, beating the 2:04 record. He was sent against his record of 2:04 1/4 at the Fort Wayne Driving Club, and finished the mile in 2:03 3/4, the greatest record in the history of light harness racing, and one that crowns him king of the turf.
The Tilden Club, the State Democracy organization of the Ninth Assembly District, met for the first time in its new clubhouse, at 244 West Fourteenth Street, last night.

Judge Bischoff of the Court of Common Pleas continued yesterday the temporary injunction granted some time ago in the suit brought by Thomas A. Maitland to restrain the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company from building a third track on its Ninth Avenue line.

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Aug. 31. -- Miss Millie Hines, daughter of W. H. Hines of St. Louis, and Mr. Hugh P. Wright eloped last evening. Miss Hines has been here for some time with her father and mother, and when she exhibited a preference for young Wright was kept under lock and key at the Morehead Hotel.

--Judge Fenn of Hartford, Conn., has filed in the Superior Court of Connecticut his finding on the application of the Bristol and Plainville Tramway Company for the approval of the route from Bristol to Plainville, and of the Hartford Manchester and Rockville Tramway Company for the approval of a layout from Burnside to Manchester.

The trial of Police Captain Stephenson was resumed yesterday before the Police Commissioners. The prosecution ended its case when the morning session closed. A number of merchants testified to paying for sidewalk privileges.

Philip Kuhl, the Lexow committee witness who was indicted for perjury by the Grand Jury last Monday, surrendered himself yesterday at the District Attorney's office in the new Criminal Court Building.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- Local stocks were dull, but prices held well to-day. Bay State Gas is still the most active stock in the local list. The price remained the same as yesterday, closing at 10 3/4. It is rumored that Mayor Mathews of Boston is to be at the head of the new gaa consolidation. West End Street Railway declared 1 1/4 per cent. dividend, payable Oct. 1.

--All the canoe clubs of the Passaic River in front of Arlington, N. J., are practicing in preparation for their annual regatta. The Orange Canoe Club will hold its regatta to-day. The starts will be made from the clubhouse, near Midland Avenue bridge. There will be sixteen events. In the sailing race the winner will receive the Passalc Associated Club's trophy cup.

Some effort was in the Constitutional Convention yesterday toward rehabilitating that part of the cities amendment which has been relegated to the committee and which contains the socalled "home-rule" provisions, but the subject was flnaily "iaid on the table" and another taken up.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Henry Harmon Noble, Assistant Secretary of the Long Island Chautauqua Assembly Association, has commenced suit against the association to recover $30, the amount of his salary, which, he alleges, remains unpaid. Trouble has been brewing between the association end its creditors for some time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The committee of the Knights of Pythias which yesterday determined to prepare a report to the Supreme Lodge recommending that saloon keepers and bartenders should hereafter be ineligible for membership has concluded to go a step further and include in its report a recommendation that all those who are at present members of the order and are engaged in the liquor business shall be expelled.
Commenting upon trade conditions for the week, Bradstreet's will say to-day:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

No candidate ever accepted more gracefully than Mr. Morton a party nomination three weeks before the meeting, of the nominating convention, and few epistolary communications addressed to the wide world have ever brought joy to more anxious hearts. From where Mr. "Lon" Payn watches the sun go down over the Catskills to where its ruddy gleams light up the eastern windows of Mr. Commodore P. Vedder, the land is now all bright.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- One of the most active seekers for the nomination for Congress on the Republican ticket in Sullivan County is William L. Thornton, formerly County Judge. The county has not been recognized since George M. Beebe of Monticello, the present Judge of the Court of Claims, was elected in 1875.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 31. -- Justin Huntly McCarthy, son. of Justin McCarthy, M.P., the leader of the Irish National Party in Parliament, was married in this city on Wednesday to Miss Marie Cecilia Loftus, better known to music-hall habitues as "Cissy" Loftus, the singer. The ceremony was performed by the Sheriff.
The Invitations to the conference to be held by the various anti-Tammany organizations were sent out yesterday by W. Harris Roome of the Good Government Club.

On the evidence presented, and, according to the well-known facts, the decisions of the sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee in the Rochester and Cohoes cases were right. The sub-committee has done justice between the warring Democratic factions In those cities.
Wheat closed steady and unchanged to 1/4c up, with an active business, chiefly in switching, and influenced by the West.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- Before proceeding to the consideration of the education article, the majority in the Constitutional Convention to-day indulged in another exhibition of arbitrary partisanship that will tend to diminish the reputation of the convention for dignity and usefulness.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 31. -- Duke d'Albe of Madrid arrived to-day, and is the guest of James J. Van Alen, who has registered him at the Casino and Casino Club. Other arrivals to-day are:
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- The races here closed to-day, and the 1,500 persons present witnessed the best contests of the week.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 81. -- Secretary Gresham to-day received a cable dispatch from Minister Baker, at Managua, stating that a decree had been issued banishing the Americans and English accused of fomenting the trouble in Bluefields. The decree was authorized by an extraordinary act of the Nicaraguan Congress.
The real estate market revived a little yesterday from the dullness of the past few weeks, and a number of large sales were made.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 31. -- Two very good contests marked the close of the Grand Circuit meeting here to-day. The quality of the horses and the speed shown deserved a larger patronage, but less than 2,0OO persons were present. The Hartford Guaranteed Stake of $5,0OO, for 2:22 trotters, came first, and seven fleet young steppers came out for this valuable event.

Official announcement was made yesterday that August Belmont Co., Vermilye Co., and J. Kennedy Tod Co., representing the underwriting syndicate for the Olcott committee of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway stockholders' reorganization committee, had received subscriptions for the entire $7,500,000 of new securities provided for in the amended plan of reorganization.

Dwight Townsend, who occupies part of the office and is connected with Col. Robert G. Ingersoll in business enterprises, said to a reporter for The New-York Times on Monday last, in Col. Ingersoll's office, in regard to a letter attributed to Col. Ingersoll on the subject "Is Suicide a Sin," published in The New-York "World:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Naval Hydrographic Office to-day issued its pilot chart of the North Atlantic Ocean for September. Among its special features It shows the track of the famous derelict Fannie E. Wolston, accompanied by the following notice:
FLUSHING, L. L, Aug. 81. -- At the Republican Town Convention to-night delegates were chosen to meet Sept. 4 in the Town Hall to select delegates to the convention at Saratoga on Sept. 18.

Winfield S. Moody, for many years a merchant in New-York City, died at his home in Norwalk, Conn., on Thursday, Aug. 30. He was born at Unity, N. H., Oct. 23, 1815. He came to New-York in 1835, and engaged in the tea business at 75 Bowery where he continued until 1861, when he retired from active business.

Edward M. Shepard, Chairman of the General Committee of the Democratic Party in King's County, yesterday made a reply to Samuel S. Whitehouse's s advice to the Board of Elections to ignore the request of that committee for recognition in the appointment of election officers this Fall, on the ground that the General Committee was not regular.
RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Shortly before 6 o'clock this evening Levi P. Morton gave out the following letter:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug 31. -- The monthly report of the City Hospital, which will be filed with the Health Board to-morrow morning, will show that there were thirty cases of typhoid fever in August, a larger number than has been reported in any one month within the last three years. Only one case has terminated fatally, however.

NEWPORT, Aug. 31. -- Successive dances have so fatigued the cottagers that the attendance at the Casino hop was not large to-night, though it was representative. Sir John and Lady Lister Kaye were present, attending with Mrs. Fernando Yznaga.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 31. -- Albert Stout, freight agent for the Charles Warner Company of this city, was arrested this morning on a warrant charging him with the murder of Katie Dugan, aged eighteen years, on the night of Oct. 19, 1892. Katie Dugan was employed as a domestic in his family.
The rush of business at the Custom House is beginning to tell on the physical condition of the clerks, especially those in the Third Division, where the withdrawals of goods in bond are attended to.

Mr. Janvier writes not of the whole theme which old New-York supplies, out of certain striking phases of it. For Greenwich Village, he has positive affection, and his writing plainly discloses his love. For another chapter he chooses the meadows of Lispenard; for another, the Battery, (inocent for all past time of bellicose acts against any enemy;) for another, the ancient pleasure gardens, or Love Lane, or the prison of the debtors.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 31. -- It has been discovered that the torpedo boat Ericsson struck a submerged pile or some similar obstruction while coming out of New-York Harbor yesterday, by which two flanges of the starboard propeller were bent. A protest was noted at the Custom House this morning.

There are estimated to be now in NewYork over 4,000 buyers from all parts of the country. They represent every class of trade, and nine-tenths of their number have some here within the past week, since the tariff question became settled.

It was an off day at the Coney Island Jockey Club races yesterday; and the attendance was below that on any afternoon since the Autumn meeting opened. There bad been a goodly number of entries for the six races on the card, but very many of these had been scratched, so that the fields were generally small, and, as the class was not high, the sport was rather commonplace.
STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 31. -- The inquest into the shooting of Frederick Bergmann at South Beach on Aug. 16 was continued before Coroner Halloran to-night.
-- The Scribners expect to issue at once the third and concluding volume of the Memoirs of Chancellor Pasquier, which relate to the years 1814 and 1815.
The Riverside wheelmen will take their annual club run to Hartford this season In time to attend the cycle races on Labor Day. These will be given under the auspices of the Hertford Wheel Club.

"You know, for you have followed with watchful interest the varying history of our attempt at tariff reform. You have followed with rising hopes and hearty approval the action of the House of Representatives in the framing and passage of a measure bearing the badges of Democratic principles and fraught with promised benefits to all the people.

Perrin H. Sumner, the lawyer who through his connection with the Edgar murder mystery in Yonkers some years ago gained the name of the "Great American Identifier," was the complainant in Jefferson Market Court yesterday against Miss Theresa Moll, whom he charged with unlawfully retaining the deeds to four lots in Westfield, N.J.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 31. -- Cleveland, Canton and Southern people had an all-day conference in this city yesterday. There were present C. W. Fairbanks, counsel for the first mortgage bondholders and for George W. Smalley; Mr. Smalley himself, W. O. Chapman and Charles H. French of Canton, I. C. Pennock of Ohio, the car builder; Mr. Morgan Rotch and William Rotch, the latter Treasurer of the company; John T. Bullard, Messrs.

The entries for the much-talked-about Elizabeth-Railway twenty-flve-mile road handicap. which wheelmen regard as the cycling event on Labor Day, were announced yesterday by Secretary Chamberlain. The list is a most promising one, and assures a great contest for The NewYork Times's medal, given as the first time prize. The scratch men are:

-- This is ladies day at the Sea Cliff Yacht Club, and the pretty clubhouse on the shore of Hempstead Harbor will be a scene of gayety. The club has had a very successful season, and the race to-day will no doubt equal, If not surpass, all others held this year by the organization.

-A monument to Emperor William T. is to be placed in the courtyard of the new Post Office at Frankfort-on-the-Main by the Chamber of Commerce of that city. The design must include a bust of the old Emperor and a female figure, seated or standing, which shall represent Frankfort's commerce.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 31. -- The all-absorbing topic of conversation among the politicians of this city to-day, especially among Democrats, has been the decision of the sub-committee regarding the differences existing between the Democrats in Monroe County. The rendering of the decision so soon was a surprise, while the decision itself was a still greater one.
Michael J. Collins, a cigarmaker, whose home is at 247 Cherry Street, was found last night in a dazed condition at Ninth Avenue and One Hundredth Street.

The most interesting topic of discussion in police circles and around Headquarters yeserday was the disappearance of Katie Schubert, who was the principal witness against Capts. Cross and Devery and former Ward Men Glennon, Burns, and Smith.

-- Mrs. Thomas H. Burchell, who is known on the stage as Delia Stacy has brought suit in the Court of Common Pleas for divorce from her husband. The suit came up yesterday on a motion for temporary alimony. Mr. and Mrs. Burchell were married on July 31, 1893, and separated July 23, 1894. Mrs. Burchell says she was abandoned, and her husband claims that he is the one who was deserted.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The feature of the market was the break in Alley "L." Its opening bid was 6 1/4, against a closing price last night of 8 3/4. A broker then began offering any part of 500 shares at 7 1/2, and finally the entire block was taken. None of the previous bids was within a point of this price, but subsequently some were sold at the same price and 1/4 above.

-- Margaret Jacobson, two and a half years old, of 60 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, was killed by a runaway horse near her home yesterday. The baby was in her carriage, which was in charge of a little boy, who left it to watch a game of craps. The carriage rolled into the gutter and frightened a horse owned by Henry Winters, an Iceman, of 413 East One Hundred and Ninteenth Street.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 31. -- F. H. Alien, the Springfield Class A crack, was too heavily handicapped to win at the Worcester Wheel Club races to-day, but he broke the track record for the half-mile, riding in 1:01 1-5, and caught first prize in the half-mile open, with ease. Summaries:
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- A dispatch to The Central News from Shanghai says:

The idea of the old-fashioned economists that the basis of the greatest part of trade is clothing is suggested by the reports we published yesterday morning of the very sharp impulse toward activity in business. It was in the wholesale dry goods district that the evidences of this new business were most clearly given.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31. -- It is reported that the United States authorities have been informed that friends of Gen. Ezeta had laid plans for him to escape from the officers who are now holding him as a prisoner in a hotel here, and that his guards have been doubled, the doors locked, and the windows barred.

"You know, for you have followed with, watchful interest the varying history of our attempt at tariff reform. You have followed with rising hopes and hearty approval the action of the House of Representatives in the framing and passage of a measure bearing the badges of Democratic principles and fraught with promised benefits to all the people.

DEPERE, Wls., Aug., 31. -- A petition has been circulated by the members of the ArchiConfraternity of St. Joseph from Northern America, established in this city, requesting Cardinal Gibbons to convoke an American Eucharistic Congress, similar to the one held in Jerusalem last year. The initiative for the project was taken by the Rev. J. P. Durin, Director of the Archi Confraternity.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Winding up or the September transactions by either transferring contracts into more distant months or by closing up the trades was the notable feature of to-day's business in wheat. That some people did not make new deals is evidenced by the widening of the difference between September and December from 3 1/4c yesterday to 3 3/8@3 1/2c at the close of to-day's session.

City Works Commissioner White of Brooklyn, backed by Mayor Schieren, is determined that the citizens of New-Utrecht shall not be imposed upon if he can prevent it by Supervisor Cornelius Furgueson, the Board of Improvement Commissioners, and the contractors who have been given fat contracts for grading and macadamizing the streets.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Giuseppi Arace, another of the alleged murderers of Antonio Prisco, the Italian padrone and New-York politician, who was found dead on the railroad track near Franklin Park, this county, April 26 last, was captured on his farm at Rockville Centre, L.I., and is now in jail in this city, having been placed there late last night.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The sleeping-car train from Montreal to New-York, on the Delaware and Hudson, was wrecked near Port Kent late last night, and two baggage cars, two day coaches, and one sleeper were tumbled into the road. The rear sleeping car did not leave the track.

The Seidl Orchestra, in the closing concerts of the season, to-night, to-morrow night, and Monday night, at Brighton Beach Music Hall, will be effectively reinforced by the singing of Mr. Emil Fischer, the celebrated basso. Following are the programmes for to-day:

It is all very well for the Mayor to see La Regaloncita go through her performance and decide as to whether she shall give it in public or not, and it is all very well for the agents of ex-Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry's society to sit around and nudge the Mayor and whisper to him not to give in.
Through the tardiness of Police Justice Koch yesterday, the wheels of justice in the Court of Special Sessions were delayed for an hour and a quarter.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- There is great rejoicing in Albany to-night over the decision of the sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee in favor of the regular organization in the Fourth Assembly, or Cohoes, District. The Albany County Democrats regard it as the entering wedge of the harmony for which The New-York Times has been contending for the last month and which the committee by its action has emphasized and shown the necessity for.

Philadelphia, Aug. 31. -- A four-story brick building, occupied by the La Roche Electrical Manufacturing Company, was damaged to the extent of $10,000 by fire to-day. Stock worth $50,000 was rendered useless. Insurance was $24,000.

--The New-Jersey Athletic Club will meet an unknown quantity to-day at Bergen Point, when the Brooklyns, who have always played a good game against the Jerseymen, will meet them for the second time this season. A good game ought to result from the meeting of the Victorias and Manhattans at Prospect Park, while the only other league game will be between Harlem and Columbia at Central Park.
(Exchange.) It is not often that science makes a discovery that demands special investigation on the part of the newspapers. Once in a while it does, however, such as occurred in New-York recently.

It was reported yesterday at the headquarters of the United Garment Workers of America, in Lafayette Place, that nearly 35,000 workers in the clothing trades in New-York would most probably go out on strike for an advance of wages and against the day-task system.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas., Aug. 31. -- Meagre reports have reached here of a terrible flood in Uvalde and other counties west of here. Six deaths by drowning in the town of Uvalde are reported, one-half of that place was flooded, and the homes of about fifty families were swept away.

Eighteen thousand baseball enthusiasts saw the New-York Giants administer a setback to the Boston champions yesterday that will long be remembered. Baltimore, Boston, and New-York are having a close face for first honors this year, and as yesterday was an off day Manager Selee thought it advisable to come here, play off a postponed game, and, as he put it, take some of the conceit out of "Ward's men.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 31. -- After indicting eleven members of the City Council, including its President, and the Engineer the term of the Grand Jury expired to-day, and it was discharged by Judge Moise, after presenting a report which is a most scathing denunciation of the ness rampant in the City Hall.

Some of our Republican contemporaries appear to be disturbed by the condition of the wood-alcohol industry. The distilleries, The New-York Tribune says, have been "closed by the new tariff," and our neighbor also asserted a few days ago that the industry would "be absolutely wiped out if the German bill becomes a law."

A bronze statue of heroic size, to be placed in a public square of Toronto, Canada, was exhibited yesterday by the HenriBonnard Bronze Company, at the foundry in West Sixteenth Street. The illustration gives one view of it, but not the best, owing to the difficulty of photographing it in the shops of the company.

BOSTON, Aug. 31. -- Gen. N.P. Banks is dying at his home in Waltham of Drain trouble, which has caused him two years of suffering. Dr. E.H. Cutler is in constant attendance. Mrs. Banks and Miss Maud Banks are with him. His son, Joseph, of New-York and Mrs. Paul Sterling, a second daughter, have been summoned.
The Cunard Steamship Line yesterday achieved the rare triumph of lowering two ocean speed record in a single day.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31. -- Cardinal Gibbons has been summoned to Rome, and will so in October or November. No special importance is atached to his visit to the Vatican, as he is compelled to go there once every few years. He has not been in Rome since he received the red hat.

The Culberson family seem to have a strong pull with Texas Democrats. The father, David B. Culberson, has been a leading and most prominent member of Congress for twenty years, and the son, Charles A., has been promoted from Attorney General of Texas to the Governorship, for his recent nomination by the Democratic convention means his election.

If Mr. Huxley were a trifle less aggressive, how comfortable it would be to live with him. We may probably lose sight of how annoying it must have been for him to be constantly nagged and pestered by a lot of people who had not a tithe of his knowledge. When fairly aroused, Mr. Huxley is the hardest of hitters, and pretty generally his adversaries are demolished.

-- Police Captain Eason of the Fourth Precinct yesterday submitted to Commissioner Welles an amended report on Daniel Leahey's clubhouse, 990 Bedford Avenue. He found that the rooms were used by the "Governors' Club," and that poker playing was indulged in, but the Captain was convinced that the players were not professional gamblers.

One of the funniest thing I know regarding the game happened to the greatest authority in whist now living. When, as a young man, he first joined a club of repute he was (he says) very modest. As a spectator he was watching four old gentlemen playing their game, when he saw a card on the floor face downward beside one of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Col. Carroll D. Wright, Superintendent of the Census and Commissioner of Labor and ex-officie Chairman of the Labor Commission which conducted the strike investigation at Chicago, returned to Washington this morning. This afternoon he left for Boston, to be gone several days on business connected with the commission. Before leaving he said:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The delegates to the Republican State Convention from Levi P. Morton's home county (Dutchess) were to-day instructed to vote for him at Saratoga, and resolutions of a highly eulogistic character were adopted with a view to speeding him on his road to the nomination.

Dr. Joseph C. Thoms of 1.280 Herkimer Street and Ham Bing of 539 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, have incurred the enmity of the Hoes San Con Pshan, a Chinese Society of this city, because they object to the swindling methods employed by some of its members.

For a perfect appreciation of the best modern Hungarian romance writing this novel of Maurus Jokai's gives the opportunity. Hungarian fiction has peculiarities which are not always assimilated by the American or English reader. It varies from the wildest fantasy to what is at times sober prosaicness. Generally, a minor key is struck. It has, however, a physiognomy of its own. Perhaps the peculiarities of style are too often lost in the translations.

The autumnal equinox and the harvest moon are the principal events of September. The equinox has been regarded from childhood as a period of strong winds, deluging rains, and heavy seas. Sometimes the gale is a little late and sometimes a little early, is the sun, in tripping across the line, not uniformly succeeds in pulling out the stopper of heaven's big reservoir.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Comanche, H.M. Hanna; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Helvetia, C. O'D. Iselln; Sapphire, A.L. Barber; Mindora, Charles H. Merrell, and Hirondelle, E.G. Evans, Schooner yachts Comet, W.H. Longley; Cavalier, Jefferson Hogan, and Ruth, Henry Marquand.

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 1. -- Gen. Nathaniel Prentiss Banks, renowned as a statesman and a soldier and respected as a citizen, died at his home here at 8 o'clock this morning.

Orr's Island(Me.) Letter to The Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle. My good long vacation in this cool region has braced me up once more. There are two notable points to show up about the State of Maine. One is the fact that no one can get up a corner on land here, there is so much of it. I mean land for Summer pleasure use.

"One of the oddest vagaries of English life," said an observant American not long ago," is the way they have of eating in every room in the house: a cup of tea, often a regular breakfast, in one's bedroom, breakfast proper in the library, luncheon and dinner in the dining room, tea in the drawing room, the boudoir, the sitting room, wherever my lady may fancy."
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Judge Lippincott to-day granted a writ removing to the Supreme Court for review as to its constitutionality the new law to divide the city into wards.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Bishop McQuaid has issued an order forbidding the Rev. Father Flaherty to attend services hereafter at either the Dansville or Mount Morris churches. Father Flaherty was suspended from the pastorate of the Mount Morris Church some time ago. He was convicted on a criminal charge, but was granted a new trial.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 1. -- A garden tea was given by the women of the Christian Union Congregational Church in Anderson Grove, Upper Montclair, Thursday afternoon and evening. There were refreshments and fancy articles for sale and a "Lady Bountiful" to supply the wants of the children.

Simple-minded people, of course, notice such things more than others, but at Ocean Grove, where the biggest religious gatherings of the country are now being held, they are talking more of the slips in the speech of Dr. Stokes, who bosses everything there, than they are of the sermons.

Ex-President Benjamin Harrison is an interested spectator of the game of politics as it is played by the Republicans in this State just now. He is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where he will remain until to-morrow night.
Among those who sailed for Europe yesterday, a full list of whom was printed in The New-York Times, were:

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 1. -- Surveyor of the Port Buchanan Schley, as Chairman of the last Democratic State Committee, has appointed State Senator Battersley W. Talbott of Montgomery County, Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 1. -- The American Dental Association, together with the dentists of this State, organized under the name of the Connecticut State Dental Association, will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the discovery of anaesthesia, by Dr. Horace Wells, on Dec. 11. The American Association will observe the anniversary at Philadelphia on that date.

ASBURY PARK, Sept. 1. -- Fortune smiled on the Good Roads Tournament this afternoon in no shy, half-hesitating manner. Everybody with a drop of sporting blood in his veins went out to the picturesque athletic grounds, bought an admission ticket and a grand stand coupon, passed through the turnstiles, and shouted for good roads and good races in one and the same breath.
The money market continued easy. Call Joans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

The first course of lectures for the coming season before the "Woman's Law Class of the University of the City of New-York" will begin Monday, Nov. 5, at 11 A.M. As Mrs. Leonard Weber, President of the Woman's Legal Educational Society, will not return from Italy before the end of October, all inquiries in relation to the class and the society's matters should be addressed to Prof. S.F. Russell, 120 Broadway, New-York.

It seems to me, indeed, that the word diner (in one or other form) is more used in the South of France than in the other parts. I have often been surprised to find how little it is used among the peasants, though now, no doubt, since communication is so easy, the word is everywhere understood.

Railroad business throughout the country during, the latter part of August has been such as to put railroad men generally in better spirits than they have manifested for more than a year. More than five-sixths of the roads that make weekly reports of earnings report for the third week in August increased earnings over the corresponding period of last year.

The reindeer Lapps and the Samoyeds stand, in intelligence and morale, at the two extremes of the Esquimau group -- the Lapps at the top, the Samoyeds at the bottom. You can imagine how tantalizing it is for me to be so near this interesting people and yet to be prevented by want of time from studying them properly, for the great Autumnal southward migration of the Samoyeds has not yet set in.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- There was a good, healthy, and active market to-day. West Chicago being the feature. A determined attack was made on it at the opening, one broker offering the first lot 1 point below the closing of yesterday. Subsequently, he marketed more at 125 1/4. All offers were readily taken, and when this particular source was exhausted traders bid for the stock, sending it up gradually to 127.
"Better times have already reached the Pacific coast, and business prospects are brightening daily," said W.B. Dennis of Port Townsend, Washington, to a reporter for The New-York Times, yesterday.
LONDON. Sept. 1. -- The Pall Mall Gazette, commenting on the result of yesterday's yachting under the auspices of the Royal Dart Yacht Club, says:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 1. AFEW years ago the vacation season used to reach an abrupt conclusion with the advent of September. But times have changed, at least so far as this resort is concerned. Thousands of visitors are here, and the season is still under full swing, and will continue so for several weeks to come.

Tashkend has long been known as a refuge for damaged reputations and shattered fortunes, or "the official purgatory following upon the Emperor's displeasure." One of the finest houses of the city is occupied by the Grand Duke Nicholai Constantinovitch Romanoff, son of the late General Admiral of the Russian Navy and first cousin to the Czar, who seems to be cheerfully resigned to his life in exile.

The "Afrikaansche Taal" is not the Dutch of modern Holland. In its origin it represents the old Dutch of the country districts in the Netherlands, together with a tendency toward the Flemish dialect. It has incorporated a great deal of English and a little French. Above all, its pronunciation is quite different to that of the classic Dutch, and lends itself much more readily to English tongues and palates.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- It was indeed a far-sighted policy that prompted Gen. George Washington to establish a mil- itary post at the northern gateway of the Hudson for the training of young army officers. The promontory of West Point was selected because of its great natural defenses and commanding situation.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 1. -- The 1st of September has made no appreciable difference in the gayeties of Hot Springs. As the season wanes, society events crowd upon each other, and dinners, luncheons, and dances follow in quick succession.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- A certain NewYork paper which is forced to rely for its news upon the Chicago organization styling itself the Associated Press startled its readers this morning by announcing some remarkable geographical discoveries. Under such headlines as "Exploration Extraordinary," "Here's a Discovery!" "An Adirondack Mountain Higher than Any in the Rockies," , it printed the following edifying information:

(Copyright, 1894.) LONDON, Sept. 1. -- The money market here remains in the same stagnant condition which has prevailed for many weeks. The demand for funds for settlements on Stock Exchange transactions has been met without effecting a rise in rates. Discounts show a tendency to become easier.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Society folks here are devoting their attention to the tableaus phantasma, to be presented in Howard Hall next Thursday and Friday evenings for the benefit of the Fresh-Air and Convalescent Home, under the direction of John W. Sherman.

The Non-Sectarian Hospital and Home for Epileptics, at 1,038 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, was opened to the public yesterday. It is a new charity and has enlisted the sympathy and support of many prominent Brooklynites.
From The Chicago Journal. Bright and early Monday morning in the window of one of the largest Japanese stores in this city this sign was hung:

-- Referee Joseph F. Daly yesterday offered for sale at public auction the Yonkers Clubhouse property, in North Broadway, on foreclosure proceedings. There were two bidders, W.F. Cochran, who holds the mortgage, and the Trustees at the club. Mr. Cochran's bid was $14,950. The Trustees bid $14,900. Mr. Cochran, it is said, will present the building to the new St. John's Riverside Hospital, to be used as a physicians' house.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Sept 1. -- The number of guests at the Prospect House leads one to believe that the season is at its height. This is always a delightful month along the south shore, and the indications are that many will remain to enjoy it. The cottage residents seldom close their country places until the 1st or middle of October.

Fishermen off Point Loma, San Diego, Cal., were surprised recently to capture a specimen of the man-eater shark, or Carcharodon carcharias, as the scientists call it. This kind of shark is rarely captured. What caused the men greater surprise was the fish found clinging to the shark's side. It was a new fish to San Diego fishermen, who never before saw a pilotfish, nor were they aware of its peculiar habits.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Miss Louise S. Anderson, daughter of John Anderson, and Sumner C. Blackman were married at the home of the bride in Dougherty Street Wednesday evening by the Rev. W.W. Hubbard of Auburn, N.Y. Miss Emma Anderson and Miss Lucy Blackman were the bridesmaids, and William Blackman was the best man.

The toxic effects of tobacco among the lower classes in England are comparatively not infrequent. The form which the poisoning takes is that known to ophthalmic surgeons as "tobacco amblyopia." The men come to the hospitals complaining of loss of sight. Commonly they are found to be bootmakers, or those to whom the opportunity occurs of smoking while they are at work.

The following account of the last illness and death of Gen. Judson Kilpatrick is from the pen of the Rev. Arthur Wright, who is now the pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church of Riverside, Cal., and was part of a Decoration Pay address delivered at that place:

Those New-Yorkers who have been doomed to stay in New-York during August cannot have any adequate conception of the havoc that has already been wrought, and the greater havoc that is threatened, by the continuance of the drought. It affects a great part of NewEngland and of the Middle States, and it has devastated the pasturage of the whole dairy region to such an extent that it deserves to be ranked as a national calamity.

-- An attempt was made yesterday to make a match race between Clifford and Domino, over a seven-furlong course, the Coney Island Jockey Club agreeing to add $5,000 to any stakes the owners might wish to put up. Mr. Keene agreed to race if they would make the distance the Futurity course, but this did not suit Mr. Rose, who wanted the distance seven furlongs.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Preparations are making here for the celebration of a most interesting event, the dedication of the old Holland Land Office at this place in honor and in memory of Robert Morris, the great financier of the Revolution and the first Secretary of the Treasury of the United States.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The local Republican factional war was continued today in a number of town caucuses, and when the smoke of the battle had blown over, it was found that Napoleon Hendricks had won the day. It looks more and more as if the ex-Collector were going to name the next Congressman from the Twentyseventh District.

The Nautilus Boat Club of Bay Ridge held its tenth annual regatta yesterday. About 300 persons, members and their guests, were in the clubhouse and along the beach. The women outnumbered the men, and were enthusiastic spectators of the several contests in which their brawny escorts and friends were participants. An excellent quintet played the tunes of the day between events, and in the evening furnished music for dancing, which followed a collation.

-- Members of the Eastern Committed of the Western Passenger Association have passed a resolution favoring a joint committee meeting of trunk lines. Central Traffic, and Western Passenger Association, in connection with the convention of the American Association of General Passenger Agents to be held in Quebec on the 28th inst.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Mr. Gladstone's contribution of L100 to the Irish National Parliamentary Fund, and the speech of Mr. Dillon in Dublin Wednesday, when he intimated to the Government that the Irish Party would be obliged to reconsider their position unless the Ministry promptly and plainly declared its policy in regard to the House of Lords, are the current political topics.

Changes in prices were slight in yesterday's market. Nearly all stocks in the rallway list made better quotations than those of Friday, but the best improvement was fractional. Had a large short interest accumulated in stocks, professional aversion to carrying contracts over a holiday would naturally have induced covering.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 1. -- The flood which visited the country west of this city, beginning at a point about fifty miles distant from here and extending for nearly 200 miles, was one of the most terrible catastrophes that has visited the State since the Indianola calamity, when all of the coast towns were swept into the Gulf of Mexico.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 1. -- A loan collection of heirlooms in a Colonial mansion and the sight of a lone ship anchored at the old Derby Wharf at Salem revive a host of memories of the famous "sea kings" of that ancient port, and add interest to a midsummer sojourn in historic Essex County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The conduct of the regular troops at Chicago during the recent strike is made the subject of a report to the Secretary of War by Capt. J. M. Lee of the Ninth Infantry. He says:
Thomas C. Gilroy, son of Mayor Gilroy, was a passenger on the steamer Paris, which arrived yesterday from Southampton. Just previous to sailing he met his father at Southampton.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The six Assembly districts of Erie County to-day elected delegates to the Republican State Convention, with instructions to them to vote for and work for the nomination of James A. Roberts of Buffalo for Governor.

A sufferer from partial insomnia, involving great loss of sleep in the earlier hours of the night, once confessed to her physician that she dated her want of sleep from the time when she ceased to say her prayers before retiring to rest, and was immediately recommended to resume her religious duties in the usual attitude just before lying down.

Like the tea question, the discussion of salad making seems perennially timely. At tills season the relish of a salad is grateful and the materials varied and abundant, but at many tables and daily throughout the land is a wilted oil-drenched, or watery compound offered that only by a most valiant courtesy on the part of its consumers can be called a salad.

ALBANY, Sept. 1. -- The discussion on the educational proposition in the Constitutional Convention was closed this afternoon, after the majority had delivered a number of speeches which created the utmost indignation among the Catholic and Irish members of the convention.

The bond dealers are pushing with much energy the plan of independent expert inspection and report as to the affairs of railway corporations. It is not a new thing with them. One of the most conservative and intelligent houses in the business, whose circular for September we have before us, has long advocated this principle, but with a voice unheeded in the Street.

From The London Telegraph. Mr. James Dermesteter, the well-known Persian scholar, has very appropriately named the Parsees the remnants of a great nation. The same fate has overtaken their ancient literature which has overtaken the race; so that the grandest religious literature in the world (next to the Jewish Scriptures) is now known to us in an extremely fragmentary condition.

The bronze doors of the main entrance to Trinity Church are now in place, and the long line of passers-by that their beauty arrests, even in the busiest hours, may make evidence of many theories. The most impressive of these is that art ever commands.
LEW BEACH, Sullivan County, N.T., Sept. 1. -- Trouting for 1894 ended last night with unprecedentedly low water and as many anglers on the stream for the last day of the season as in balmy May.

BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 1. -- The annual crop estimates issued by the Hungarian Minister of Agriculture are published to-day, the delay in their issuance having been due to the care bestowed upon the revision of the report.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 1. -- A notable event in journalism in the West is the celebration to-morrow of the twenty-first anniversary of the establishment of the Cincinnati Freie Presse.

It is rather late for thistles, but perhaps some of you little girls may find some this veek. If you do, cut the steins as long as possible. Then with a small penknife remove all the green points. They are tough and will prick, so you will need a pair of thick kid gloves if your hands are at all tender.

Dr. S.L. Baldwin of 1,218 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, and for twenty-two years a worker in the populous mission field at FooChoo, China, is probably as familiar with the present status of American missionaries in the far East, and particularly at the scene of warlike operations, as any one in this vicinity.
There is one man in Brooklyn who probably knows more about the streets of the city than all the rest of the population put together.

PARIS, Wednesday. Aug. 1. -- Thanks to the horseless carriage contest, new notions are already being started. In many provincial towns there are no railroads, no tramways; only a small village bus to go to the nearest market or to the station. Several of these localities have already sent to inquire as to the cost of one or more steam wagons, which can be made useful to the general public.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 1. SEPTEMBER begins the say season in Lenox. The people who havd been at Newport, Narragansett, and Bar Harbor are now coming to Lenox in large numbers to spend the glorious Autumn months.

The intimation that Mayor Schieren issued a license to the Atlantic Athletic Club of Brooklyn on Friday with even more dissatisfaction than accompanied his compliance with Justice Gaynor's mandamus in the matter of the kindred Seaside organization has found many believers.

De Wolf Hopper's fifth annual engagement in this city will begin at the Broadway Theatre to-morrow night, with the first production here of "Dr. Syntax," a comic opera adapted and arranged for him by J. Cheever Goodwin, who is responsible for the libretto, and Woolson Morse, who composed the music many years ago, and has new added many new tunes.
Frank S. Henderson of Henderson Son, undertakers, Myrtle Avenue and Jay Street, Brooklyn, was probably fatally injured in a runaway accident at Fulton and Flatbush Avenues, Brooklyn, last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- An interesting case is now under consideration at the Catholic Legation here. The Rev. P. O'Farrell, formerly of the Trenton Diocese, lived for some years past in Kentucky, but for the last two months or more has resided in Washington. He has petitioned Archbishop Satolli to be reinstated in the diocese in which he was ordained.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 1. MUCH pleasure is anticipated from the visit of the Monmouth County Hunt Club to the Peconic Country Club on Shinnecock Hills. The visiting club is to bring its horses and hounds to hunt the boar and wild fox several times a week.

Brooklyn had a good day. The Louisvilles played at Eastern Park and lost two games. In the opening contest, with Hemming opposing Stein, the spectators saw a good game, in which the local players proved victorious by a single run.

BUFFALO, Sept. 1. -- Western New-York is almost literally burning up. The dry vegetation has taken fire in many places, and valuable timber tracts are threatened with destruction. Farmers lament damage to crops, and fear further losses by fire and the starvation of stock. Everywhere the health, comfort, and property of the people are imperiled.

Froissart was not a historian; he was only a chronicler; and in the long list of chroniclers, whereof France is Justly vain it nay seem modest to classify him particularly as the first reporter that the modern world has known, but the modesty is only relative. There is really nothing more elevated than to be sincerely a reporter.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 1. NO MATTER how successful the season may have been or how fine the weather, it seems an unvarying rule that Atlantic City's Summer throngs will not take advantage of that most delightful month here by the sea -- September.

The Passaic Tennis Club's championship contests were held yesterday afternoon on the club's fine clay courts at Passaic Bridge, N.J. Owing to the fact that five championships had to be decided, the tournament goes over until Monday, when it is expected that the games will be far enough advanced to permit the champions to face their challengers.

Monticello, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Daniel R. Bonnell, one of the wealthiest farmers of Sullivan County, cut his throat yesterday at his home in Liberty and died. Two years ago he caused the arrest of ex-Sheriff B.W. Winner of Liberty on a Charge of procuring money under false pretenses. The case was set aside last February, and the defendant had been arranging to prosecute Bonnell. This worried Bonnell's mind, and he became melancholy.

The oyster season opened yesterday, and with it came a rush of smacks from the dredging grounds oft Keyport and in Prince's Bay. Fifty-two heavily-loaded oyster sloops came into the North River at break of day, and made port at the oyster market, foot of West Tenth, Charles, and Perry Streets.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 1. -- A deal was consummated to-day by which the controlling interest in the stock of the Detrolt Citizens' Street Railway Company passes into the hands of R.T. Wilson Co. of Wall Street, New-York. With them is associated Major J.M. Edwards of the same city.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 1. -- The News, giving the dates of cotton planting in the different sections of the State and the condition of the young plant, says: "The crop grew nicely during May, and suffered only slight local damages from hail and washes in North Texas. At the close of May cotton was reported well worked and in excellent condition, and early planted was blooming.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- Chancellor von Caprivi is in Carlsbad, and the burder it Government business has fallen upon the shoulders of Count Botho zu Eulenburg and Dr. Miquel. The Premier and the Finance Minister are conferring with the Federal envoys now in the city concerning the work of the next Parliamentary session, and are putting out the customary feelers to learn what can or cannot be done in the Reichstag.

It is brand-new ground that Mr. Kirk Munroe has opened up in this story of Alaskan adventure. The Aleutian chain of islands, the Pribilofs, the Bering Sea, and our great northern coast all contribute novel situations, which make his book interesting.
Author of "The Golden Hope: A Romance of the Deep," "A Sea Queen," "The Wreck of the Grosvenor." "My Danish Sweetheart." c.

WEST POINT, Sept. 1. -- The breaking of camp marks the turning point of the season at this place. The cadets begin their studies Monday, and have little time afterward to pay court to the bewitching Summer girls who haunted "Flirtation Walk" during the past three months.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 1. HERE the air is ideal, the advent of September is sending city people homeward from the Catskills in large crowds. The trains of the Ulster and Deiaware and West Shore Roads are running in two, and even three, sections to accommodate them.

Labor Day this year will be a busy one for yachtsmen. Until this year the NewYork Yacht-Racing Association has had a monopoly of the day, but last Winter some clubs dropped from the association, and this year they will have regattas of their own. These clubs are the Indian Harbor and the Brooklyn.

The opening of September this year finds the conditions attending real estate in the city much improved as compared with the close of the Summer of 1893. By this it is not meant to convey the impression that each individual parcel of realty within the city limits would sell for more to-day than it would have done a year ago, or even more readily find a purchaser.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Summer guests at Sea Cliff had picnics this week by way of diversion.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Central News Shanghai advices received this morning say the result of the attack upon Port Arthur is not positively known. It is reported that 4,500 Japanese troops, were landed, and they, with fourteen war vessels, took part in the attack.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 1.
