THE cool weather of the last fortnight has thinned out the visitors at the hotels on both sides of the river here, but it has not lessened the number of guests at the Pequot or Fort Griswold House to any noticeable extent. The most delightful weather of the season is yet to come -- a fact that is realized by those who have spent September and October hereabout.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 1. -- The Louisiana Leper Board, a State institution, provision for whose formation was made by the last Legislature, has organized and begun work. Mr. A.A. Woods was elected president, and Dr. H.J. Scherck, Secretary. Committees have been appointed to select a site for a Leper Hospital, and active operations looking toward the establishment of an asylum for all the lepers in Loiusiana have already been taken.

One of the shrewdest bear moves made in the stock market for a long time was the timely dispatch from Chicago of an interview with President Cable of the Rock Island, wherein that gentleman expressed himself strongly bearish on the situation, and hinted that his company might have to pass its next dividend.

ELBERON, N.J., Sept. 1 -- It is a selfevident fact that the Summer is drawing to a close, but the casual visitor to Elberon would never guess it. A few trunks are carried to the station every day, but quite a number are delivered, too. The hotels and cottages are still filled, and it is safe to say that they will be right through this month.
The Brooklyn Citizen of Saturday makes the following comment upon the interview with Oswald Ottendorfer printed in The New-York Times yesterday morning:

A parcel of men stood upon the, Hoboken dock of the Hamburg -- American Packet Line about noon yesterday. One was a small, gray-mustached man, with glasses, Central Park Superintendent William A. Conklin, who is the New-York agent of the great wild-beast firm of Carl Hagenbeck of Hamburg.

Lieut Henn. who in 1886 raced his cutter Galatea against the Burgess sloop Mayflower for the America's Cup, and, of course, lost, says Long Island Sound is "the finest yachting ground in the world." Lieut Henn ought to know what he is talking about when he makes such an assertion, because he has sailed all over the world, and raced wherever there is any yachting.

Chicago has had several narrow escapes from not having a Postmaster Hesing. No less than half a dozen times while in pursuit of pleasure has Washington Hesing found himself in the midst of death's revelry, unconscious of the grim presence until the mask was suddenly removed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 1. LONG BRANCH'S season of 1894 is almost over. There are about ten days or possibly two weeks left. Farewells will soon be said, and the Summer girl will hie herself to the mountains until the town season opens.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 1. -- "Jack" Mason's troubles seem to have culminated. For the past month reports of all kinds have been floating about the street. Some said that the actor had returned to the careless habits he had hoped to leave in Maine, at the gold cure, in the Spring. Some said "Jack" and his wife, Marion Manola, had parted.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: An article in a New-York paper recently, written by a correspondent who went to Saratoga to look up its horse racing and gambling, reports it as the wickedest place in America.

The latest trust that is making itself felt in trade in this city is the peanut trust, known as the Virginia Peanut Association. It is said to be making strenuous efforts to drive out of business the independent traders.

The facts about Jersey City's drinking water have not been exhausted in published statements. An examination of the Passaic River below Paterson has revealed additional evidences of the pollution of the stream from which the city draws its supply of drinking water.
The sales referred to in the accompanying deailed list will be held in the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broad-way:

A reporter for The New-York Times called at Mr. Shayne's establishment in Forty-second Street, near Broadway, yesterday afternoon. "Well," exclaimed Mr. Shayne, in his usual cordial manner, "how can I be of service to you?"

ALEXANDRIA BAY, Sept. 1. THE season at the Thousand Is lands draws to a close on on or about the 1st of September. This month is really the most delightful of the year here, although the average tourist does not seem to appreciate the fact.

RlDGEFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1. -- The Summer colony is in gloom at the sudden death of Mrs. Edward Livingsrston Youmana, whose obsequies were largely attended this morning. Besides the numerous Summer visitors, friends from New-York came specially to pay the last respects to her rare personality.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Two Democratic caucuses to send delegates to the County Convention Sept. 5 were held in Ithaca Wednesday night. The anti-Cleveland Chairman of the County Committee called a mass caucus instead of holding one in each of the ten districts. Protests were made against his action on the ground that it was against fair play.

Henry M. Tanzer, thirty-one years old of 158 East Fifty-sixth Street, Superintendent of the Delivery Department in Bloomingdale Brothers' dry goods store, Fifty-ninth, Street and Third Avenue, was arraigned yesterday before Justice McMahon in the York-villa Court, on a charge of obtaining money under false pretenses, and held in $5,000 bail.
Justice William J. Gaynor in Brooklyn yesterday rendered a unique decision in a dog case, which should endear to him every dog-owner in Brooklyn.

The sidewheel steamboat General Slocum of the Knickerbocker Steamboat Company, whose sister boat for the Rockaway Beach service is the Grand Republic, was totally disabled yesterday off Jewell's Wharf in a collision with the tugboat R.T. Sayre of the New-York Lighterage and Transportation Company. The Sayre was also disabled and more seriously damaged than the larger vessel.

ASBURY PARK. N.J., Sept. 1. -- Trunks are being packed, "good-byes" are in order, and thousands are preparing to leave the twin cities by the sea for their city homes. The exodus this week was enormous, the breaking up of the Ocean Grove camp meeting being responsible for the rush cityward.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 1. -- The Orange and New-Jersey Athletic Clubs played a tie game of baseball at the Orange Oval this afternoon in the presence of about 8,000 people. Cronen was in the box for Orange until the last inning, when Clare was put in in his stead. The score:

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1. -- Edward Owen is now actively engaged in making preparations for the annual parade through Ice Glen. It is quite probable that it will be held next week. This torchlight parade is one of the fixtures of Summer life in Stockbridge.
Of the twenty-three Presidents of the United States, fifteen, or about two-thirds, were college-bred men.

The Fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club was sailed yesterday, and, like all other events that have been decided in connection with this club, it was a big success. Forty-one boats competed in the different classes for the handsome prizes offered by the club, and in nearly every class the race was a close one.
The decisions of the Racing Board for the current week, announced yesterday, are as follows:
September will be a month of unusual political importance. Both the Democrats and the Republicans will hold their State Conventions at Saratoga -- the Republicans Sept. 18 and the Democrats Sept. 25.

A recent fair to raise funds for a church organ was so spirited and original in its design and carrying out that it was not only unexpectedly successful in securing the entire amount needed, but made itself a model for other similar entertainments. There were eight booths, each trimmed in some effective tint of the cheap art muslin whose beauty, fortunately, does not depend upon its price.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- President Cleveland will have a prominent army commission to fill on Nov. 8, when Gen. O.O. Howard, who will then have reached his sixty-fourth year, goes on the retired list. The command of the Department of the East, with headquarters at Governors Island, will devolve on Gen. Miles, who is in Chicago.

Gen. Banks had so long outlived himself that the announcement of his death will come to the younger generation as a startling reminder that he has so lately been alive. Indeed, "before the war" is already remote and mythical, and a man who attained eminence in that period seems now to belong to a distant past.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The rifle competition in the Military Department of the East is closed. It has been in progress this year at Fort Niagara, N.Y. Sergt. Sellenz, Company F. Ninth Infantry, wins the gold medal, with a total of 605 points, which is 2 points better than the score of Corp. Spurgin, Company C. Twenty-first Infantry, who won the first prize in 1893 with a record of 603.

-- Andrew Peterson, a sailor on board the schooner yacht Republic, anchored off Whitestone, is missing, and the supposition is that he was drowned while trying to board the boat in the darkness Thursday night. He was a brother of Mate Peterson of the yacht, and had been on shore on leave of absence. The next morning the yacht's yawl was found safe at the end of the boat boom, but Peterson was gone.
SARANAC LAKE, Sept. 1. BALAMY days and nights are making thousands linger in the mountains longer than ever. Indeed, the eud of the Summer season is not to come for three weeks or a month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Another army scandal at Vancouver Barracks, Washington, where a court-martial will meet on Sept. 5 to try Capt. W.P. Goodwin on a charge of drunkenness, was developed to-day in the appointment of a court-martial for the trial of Major and Paymaster Joseph W. Wham.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- Commander Converse, commanding the torpedo station has received orders to confer with Capt. Kane of the Miantonomoh, which is to take on board the Rhode Island Naval Reserves Sept. 17, and arrange a plan for their instruction in torpedo warfare. The companies are organized as torepdo companies, but have never been permitted to work.

The first section of the fourteen-mile extension to the Mackay-Bennett Commercial Cable was successfully laid in place yesterday. The landing place of the cable, which is now on Coney Island, near the Oriental Hotel, has been found to be unsuitable, and it was decided by the company to extend the submarine line to this city direct.

Griffith Roberts, an intelligent young Englishman, presented a pitiable appearance when he was arraigned before Justice Burke, in the Harlem police Court, yesterday morning. Both his eyes were black and swollen, his cheeks were scratched and cut, his left ear was lacerated, and the back of his head was covered with bruises.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 1. -- Gen. William B. Franklin of this city, President of the Board of Managers of the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers, will soon have his report completed for the year ending June 30, 1894. It will show what has been accomplished by the National Government in behalf of its disabled veterans since the war.

Col. Craddock tells the following story in his usually unique style in The Paris Kentuckian-Citizen: "'Yes, you may record in The Kentuckian-Citizen that I am the tallest of the Baptists,' said Miss Anna Luman of Mount Carmel vicinity, at the Baptist Association, at Mayslick. 'I am 6 feet 6 inches in full dress, and weigh 143 pounds.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 1. -- An explosion of natural gas occurred at the main power house of the Citizens' Street Railway Company yesterday, wrecking the house and boilers and destroying the furnaces. The loss will exceed $20,000. M. Bagen, engineer, and J.H. Gallagher, fireman, were injured by flying pieces of the furnace, and the condition of both is serious.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 1. -- Norval A. Hawkins, cashier of the Standard Oil Company in this city, and a well-known society man, was arrested this afternoon on the charge of embezzlement. The complaint was made by the Standard Oil Company, which charges that during the last year and a half Hawkins has embezzled $15,000.

There is no subject of greater social importance than the manner in which the poor of a great city are housed. Not only is the trend of general population toward large cities, but this tendency is especially marked in the poorer classes, who settle in certain congested areas, and from consequent overcrowding and various unsanitary conditions are apt to sink still lower in the social scale.

Wilson Barrett has already produced his dramatization of "The Manxman," by Hall Caine, at the Grand Theatre, Leeds. It is in five acts and five scenes, and includes only the story of Pete Quilliam. The more heroic scenes of Philip Christian's career -- the Tynwald scene, the court scene, and the castle scene -- do not appear in the drama.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- An exploration party will be sent out from the military post of Fort Sherman, Idaho, by Gen. Otis, Department of the Columbia, under command of Lieut. James A. Leyden of the Fourth Infantry, to consist of two noncommissioned officers, two privates, and a civilian packer, all properly armed, equipped, and rationed for the trip, and with six good pack mules for the transportation of the necessary baggage and subsistence stores.

The promoters are enthusiastic over the prospects for the twenty-five-mile road race on the Elizabeth-Rahway course to-morrow. The latest inspection of the route was highly pleasing to Secretary Chamberlain, and he still clings to the belief that the distance will be covered in close to record time, if, indeed, a new mark is not created.

TROMSO, Norway, July 23. -- July 19, at 7 in the morning, the arctic circle was crossed. The air was not cooler, and one could not think of arctic regions as one looked at the green valleys surrounding Bodo, a town which owes its life and prosperity solely to fishing. It has great gray mountains in the background.
COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Sept. 1. -- A great number of the cotagers have alrready quitted, and the hotel registers are not crowded.

It was only a small, informal dinner at the Farleys'; but enjoyable from its delicate cookery and its dainty serving. Those present belonged to that class to whom these qualities are more essential than a restaurant's profusion -- a class of goodly numbers, by the way, the man from Altruria to the contrary notwithstanding.

Summer literature is apt to find itself between flimsy or tasteless covers, and the woman who is willing to take a little pains to do away with an ugly thing, slips on as quickly as may be an adjustable cover that glorifies at least the exterior of the volume. It is a pity, it may be added, that some transforming touch is not available for the interior as well occasionally.

From The Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle. Mr. Henry C. Raworth of Augusta, the oldest living railroad engineer, is lying critically ill at the home of his daughter, Mrs. W.B. Sprague, in this city. He is gradually sinking from waste of body and mind.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- Western Europe is just beginning to awaken to the fact that the most savage cholera epidemic of modern years is sweeping along to its very doors. We have been seeing standing cholera announcements in the papers all the year, chronicling devastations in far-off places, and have paid no attention.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 1. -- The eleventh annual ball of the Hotel Glenada was held to-night in the Casino on the shore, and was a brilliant success. About 300 persons participated.

Charming racing weather and a card that promised the best of sport brought a very large crowd of people to the pretty Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. The weather remained all that could be desired, but the star attraction of the racing performance was ruined by the withdrawal from "the Omnium Handicap of Domino, Sir Walter, Ducat, Yo Tambien, John Cooper, Candelabra, Longdale, and Redskin.

The unwillingness of the Reformer to pull the beams from his personal eyes has always been one of his most prominent characteristics. There is a large association of women formed for the express object of compelling men to abandon various practices upon which women look with disfavor.

The performances of the Campania and Lucania, which came to a termination on Friday evening and which left the ocean record in a shattered condition, are quite appropriate to a season of record breaking. Such speed as these splendid steamers have attained would have been regarded twenty years ago as an impossible vision, just as the possibility of a trotting horse's making a mile in two minutes would have been regarded.

-- Amphion. -- At the Amphion Theatre last night, Manager Augustus Pitou revived ''Struck Oil." a comedy which, fifteen years ago, made a great success in this city and through the country, with J.C. Williamson and Maggie Moore in the leading parts. The characters originally played by them were assumed last night by A.H. Wilson and Jane Stuart, and their work was thoroughly appreciated by a large audience.

Apropos of letters from literary persons, they are, from a literary point of view, seldom worth reading, chiefly from their brevity. To paraphrase a famous line, "Their worst they give, their best they keep" -- for printing purposes. The demand for their productions from the public is too great and pressing to admit of their favoring private friends beyond a genial word or two.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As a Summer resident of Staten Island and a daily user of the boats of the Rapid Transit Company, I wish to offer a word of protest against some reflections upon the service of that company made recently in the city newspapers. I have never found suburban trains more punctual or the transit service in general more satisfactory than on Staten Island.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 1. -- Six negro barn burners were taken from the custody of officers at Millington last night and shot to death by a mob of unknown men. Millington is a village in the northern part of Shelby County; on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad. Recently there have been a number of fires in the vicinity under such circumstances as to indicate that they were the work of an organized gang of incendiaries.

From The Baltimore Sun. Many curious letters find their way into the Dead-Letter Office. One of the most curious, as well as one of the most ancient, turned up a few days ago. It was dated July 30, 1815, and was addressed by the writer to his mother in Ireland by a midshipman in the English Navy, who was stationed on the English brig Bellerophon, which conveyed Napoleon Bonaparte from France to St. Helena.

The Children's Aid Society Building, East Broadway and Gouverneur and Henry Streets, headquarters of the Sick Children's Mission, which is under the auspices of that society, has the appearance every morning and evening of a dispensary on a large scale.

DARTMOUTH, Sept. 1. -- The Vigilant and the Satanita started in a race this morning for the Bay Club Prize, valued at u40. The course was triangular, from Dartmouth Range southwest to a markboat off Torcross, thence by the east markboat and back, three times around, the total distance being forty-two miles. The wind was light from the northeast, the weather hazy, and the sea smooth.

Again the Giants failed to take advantage of a rare opportunity to gain on Baltimore and Boston. They were scheduled to play two games with the Cincinnati Reds, and, naturally, everybody expected the local men who are playing good ball now, to take both. Instead, however, the honors were equally divided, and the Giants were fortunate to even save themselves from a disastrous setback.

A unique series of thirty-three examples came up for sale with the collection of the late Lord Cheylesmore, in May, 1892, and affords an easy medium of comparison. The best pictures appear to increase in the same ratio as the less excellent examples decline. "The Monarch of the Glen," so well known through T. Landseer's very successful engraving, is a masterpiece, and is never likely to sustain any very pronounced depreciation in value.

The sedative novel must not be actively stupid. Foolishness, irrelevance, lack of coherence, bad grammar, are irritants, which should have no place in the novel which is meant to give rest to the mind. The man who is made to grind his teeth and mutter "What infernal bosh!" is not getting his sedative, nor is the woman soothed who is perpetually being forced to declare that she never read such English.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept.1. WORN out by entertainments hitherto unequaled in brilliancy, cottagers hall Sunday with relief. For next week a single ball, that of Mrs. H.M. Brooks, is announced.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept.1. WORN out by entertainments hitherto unequaled in brilliancy, cottagers hall Sunday with relief. For next week a single ball, that of Mrs. H.M. Brooks, is announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Those persons who were puzzled by the very imperfect, not to say misleading, synopsis of the report made by the board of experts on the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge, and who prefer to get their impressions directly from the report, rather than as filtered through the War Department, will find the full report intelligible and interesting.

The leading toreador is probably the most popular man in Spain. Women throng the seats, the Queen herself attends in the Plaza de Toros at Madrid, and it is women who lavish presents most profusely on the hero of the ring. A successful performer descends into the arena blazing with jewels worn on the neck, breast, arms, and fingers, the gifts of his lady patronesses.

John Good, President of the John Good Cordage and Machine Company, Broad and Beaver Streets, commenting on the statements made by ex-Mayor Fitler of Philadelphia concerning the effects of the new tariff on the binder twine industry of this country, said yesterday:

Of all Bible stories none is more popular with children than the tale of the Witch of Endor. On wet Sunday afternoons the most admired plate in the folio Bible is that Which shows Saul falling forward on the earth, and the witch woman shrinking back in astonishment and awe, and the whitebearded, shadowy figure of the Prophet rising up from the silence of Sheol.

The clothing finishers, met yesterday in New Irving Hall, in Broome Street, and decided to strike this morning for an advance of wages and to abolish the taste system. The street was crowded with cloak makers and tailors, who were waiting to learn the result of the meeting.

The games played last week for the cricket championship of New-York resulted in strengthening the positions of the leading clubs, while the weaker organizations fell back. The Manhattan and Brooklyn teams have played their last games, and will have to be content with third and fourth positions, respectively. The Harlems have also finished their schedule, passing through the series with but one defeat, which places them in the lead.

There was but little doing on the Harlem River yesterday, and the boathouses were generally deserted in the afternoon, except by the veterans who are on deck every day in the open season. The Charles River regatta, which comes off today, has taken several of the Harlem crews to Boston, as well as individual members of the clubs.

Now that business is clearly reviving, and especially now that our foreign trade is showing a marked increase for the time being, and is to be conducted on a radically different basis as to duties on imports, it is interesting to glance at the statistics of the year closing on the 30th of June and to note wherein the changes lay of which we all have a general notion.

Carl Feigenbohm, who was arrested early Saturday morning for the murder of his boarding-house mistress, Johanna Hoffman of 544 Sixth Street, was held without bail to await the action of the Grand Jury by Justice Simms, in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday.

On the saloon passenger list of the French Line steamship La Bretagne which arrived from Havre yesterday, appeared the name of Jules Verne. The passengers were very anxious to make the acquaintance of the man who bore the name of the great French romancer, and many thought that the two were identical.

ALBANY, Sept. 1. -- Local stocks were more active than local bonds this week. This has not occurred for some weeks, and is regarded as an evidence of growing confidence in local securities. The most encouraging bit of news was the announcement that the Walter A. Wood Company, within a short time, would reopen its works at Hoosick Falls.

The concluding concerts by Anton Seidl and his orchestra at Brighton Beach will be given to-day. The season of concerts will be gratefully remembered by music-loving persons. The concerts were instituted with the purpose of educating the people, and this object has been fully attained. Mr. Seidl has received the congratulations and thanks of hundreds of citizens of New-York and Brooklyn who have visited Brighton Beach during the Summer.

Nicola Feglie, twenty-two years old, an Italian laborer living in the big tenement at 100 Mott Street, was stabbed in the side yesterday afternoon by Girardo Rosaldo of the same address. Feglie learned that Girardo had insulted his sister, Philomena, and, meeting Girardo, was about to punish him, when the other cut Feglie in the left side with a knife.
The Rev. E.J. Haynes of St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, preached yesterday morning on "The Preacher in New-York City."

The opening services of the Washington Heights United Presbyterian Church, at One Hundred and Seventy-second Street and Audubon Avenue, were held in the basement of the church at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The basement, which is to be used as the Sunday school room, is the only part of the church finished, and services will be held there every Sunday until the rest of the structure is ready for use.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 2. -- An extensive fire, which is believed to have been of incendiary origin, was discovered at 6 P.M. in an unoccupied shed belonging to the Erie Railroad Company in Pavonia Avenue. The building had formerly been used as a receiving depot for potatoes, but had lately been given over to tramps.
PINE CITY, Minn., Sept. 2. -- Three towns -- Hinckley, Mission Creek, and Pokegama -- are in ashes to-night, and more than 200 dead bodies lie in the region around Hinckley.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 2. -- Telegraphic communication has been re-established as far west as Marengo Junction of the Wisconsin Central and Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railway. A trestle 3,000 feet long at Marengo Was wholly destroyed, but trains from here to Duluth are ordered via Ashland.

The game of politics, as ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt has been playing it this year, has puzzled some of the astute men "up the State," who are supposed to keep closely in the path which Mr. Platt marks out for them.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 percent, throughout the week.

The champion cricket team of the New-Jersey Athletic Club expected a close fight with the Brooklyns Saturday at Bergen Point in their second game of the series for the championship of New-York. It did not come off, however, and they won easily by 84 runs.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 2. -- The relief train which was sent from here last night on the St. Paul and Duluth Road to succor and save the victims of the forest conflagrations between this city and what was the town of Hinckley returned at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon. The party counted the charred arid half-burned bodies of seventy-five dead people along the railroad tracks.

The vigilance with which ex-President Harrison watches the politics of the Empire State is natural, and, considering the interests at stake, not unpraiseworthy. He knows that this is the only State in the Union that has furnished a President of the United States who (1) was elected, (2,) renominated and defeated, and (3) nominated again and elected.
To the long list of suicides there were yesterday added the names of many more unfortunates. A few who attempted self-destruction failed, but most of the efforts to curtail life were successful.

The market for investment bonds last week, while not as active as for the previous week, was strong, and in many issues showed material gains. The most marked feature probably is the lack of good bonds offering. With the enormous amount of money uninvested, and the renewal of confidence, it is probable that prices will gradually advance still higher.
BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 2. -- The elopement of a young couple from Belair and the subsequent marriage in this city resulted last night in an exciting personal encounter at the Hotel Rennert.

Significance attaches to the record of last week's market in that prices did not suffer material decline. Wall Street's habit of discounting events, so that when they happen the good effect in prices has already been accomplished, and declines become the order, led the professional element to suppose that, with tariff legislation out of the way, and with Congress adjourned, stocks would become weak.
A curious story was told yesterday by a pariah seaman who was brought as a prisoner to Ellis Island and turned over to the authorities there as a stowaway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- For the first time in two years and more the receipts of the Treasury for any one month have reached $40,000,000, those of August aggregating $40,417,605. This is nearly $6,000,000 more than the receipts in July. The sources of and amount of receipts for August, cents omitted, were: From customs, $11,804,914; internal revenue, $27,562,278; miscellaneous, $1,050,412.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 1. -- Tradespeople, bankers, and the private capitalists quit business in a better mood to-day, but it cannot be said that general conditions meet the expectations which were raised a few weeks ago, based on an early end of tariff discussion. The better movement of staples made a fair demand for money, but in view of the supply of idle funds in bank there is little prospect of a hardening of rates.
-- A volume of "Familiar Letters of Henry David Thoreau" has been prepared by Frank B. Sanborn for issue this season by Houghton, Mifflin Co.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 1 -- The local stock market is still characterized by Summer dullness, and few changes in the quoted prices are worthy of note. The stock of the American Screw Company is in much better demand, having recently advanced some $15 per share. The par of the stock is $250 and the dividend rate 6 per cent.

NEWARK. N.J. Sept. 2. -- To the great surprise of the many spectators at the first day of the eighth annual meet of the Associated Canoeing Clubs of the Passaic River, held at West Arlington, yesterday, the champion club four of the Ianthe Canoe Club was beaten for the third time in eight years. Its opponent was the crew of the Orange Canoe Club, and it was beaten scarcely a half length.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Sept. 2. -- Mrs. Helen M. Gougar of Indiana, who has a national reputation as an advocate of woman's suffrage and constitutional prohibition of the liquor traffic, delivered an address in Prohibition Park this afternoon before an audience of 1,000.

"The Spirit of '76" is the name of an attractive monthly magazine, the first number of which is now current. It is printed at 14 Lafayette Place and is edited by William H. Bearley. As its title indicates, the magazine is devoted to the revival of patriotism, the perpetuation of the memories of the heroes of the Revolution, and the promotion of the principles for which they fought.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Sept. 2. -- John Stimmel outwitted the local police to-day and succeeded in petting a party ashore at his picnic grounds, notwithstanding the fact that Judge Beach's injunction does not now apply to Sunday.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 2. -- A welldressed man was found unconscious in an open lot at Flushing and Steinway Avenues this morning. He died without telling his name soon after being taken to the Astoria Hospital. An autopsy showed that acute meningitis was the cause of death.

ALBANY, Sept. 2. -- Many of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention are disgusted over the political trend of the debates of the past week. And a number of them, including such earnest Democrats as John Bigelow, William P. Burr, Francis Forbes, and John A. Deady, express themselves in no uncertain language over the deterioration of the moral policy of the convention.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Truly this is a philanthropic age, in which the heart of the people is as active as the head. As an instance, no one can recall the financial distress of last year, and its consequent suffering, without gratefully acknowledging the quick, noble, general response and the active relief which met the demands of that long and painful Winter.

The teaching of Col. Robert G. Ingersoll touching suicide was yesterday the theme of discussion in the pulpit and on the lecture platform. The Rev. G.M. Searle of the Catholic University at Washington preached on suicide in the Church of the Paulist Fathers in this city. W.L. O'Neill, a New-York lawyer, addressed a gathering of laymen on the same subject at Union Square Hall.

The loss of his life is the forfeit paid by a man known only as "Tim" on a wager early yesterday morning that he could swim across the East River, from Pier 37, at the foot of Market Street. His body is now at the East Twenty-sixth Street Morgue.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 2. -- The controversy between the Rochester division of the Naval Reserve and the Board of Supervisors of Monroe County over the question of the erection of suitable quarters for the reserves to be built at the expense of the county will come to a crisis to-morrow at the annual meeting of the Supervisors.

The work of extending the Commercial Cable from its old landing place on Coney Island was completed yesterday. The first section of the new line was brought through the shoal waters of Gravesend Bay Saturday afternoon, and the end buoyed in deep water there.
Brooklyn mysteries sometimes have a string tied to them. This was the case with a story published yesterday by one of the newspapers of that city.

Goodbody deserves a vote of thanks, according to lovers of tennis. His appearance at Newport imparted a kind of international flavor to the proceedings and roused the interest in the game to the highest pitch. The result of his victories will be the revision of some American ideas of the game, and just now the prospects are that international contests will take place on both sides of the water.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 2. -- Opposition to the working of the peach-yellows law has of late developed at a rapid rate among the farmers of the central portion of the State. In Middlesex County there have been threats of bidding the State Inspector defiance, and of quoting at him the law against trespass if he should attempt to enter upon premises in defiance of the owner's will.

The Canal Boatmen's Union sent W.C. Clark yesterday to the Central Labor Union to ask that body to urge upon the Constitutional Convention the necessity of acting on the request of the canal boatmen to deepen the State canals, and thus enable them to compete with the large ship canal which the Canadians propose constructing.

Ex-Gov. Samuel J. Kirkwood of Iowa, whose death The New-York Times referred to briefly yesterday morning, died in Dubuque, Iowa, on Saturday. Gov. Kirkwood was best known in his own and other States as the "old war Governor of Iowa."
MORA, Minn., Sept. 2. -- One hundred and forty-three bodies have been taken out of Hinckley and places in the vicinity. The near-by town of Pokegama is wiped out.

TRENTON, Sept. 2. -- Gov. Werts this week begins his star engagement as an attraction for the county fairs. Custom has ordained that the Governor of the State of New-Jersey must show his deep concern for the dear people, and rural citizens in particular, by going the rounds of the fairs and putting out his right hand to whomsoever may desire to pump it.

BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., Sept. 2. -- The curious condition of the atmosphere in this vicinity to-day caused much speculation regarding the cause. Although the sun shone all day. It cast no shadow. It was so dark that lights were necessary in many churches and dwellings. The sun was very red, and looked like a ball of fire all day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The news from Berlin that sixty-two foreigners in Samoa, including two Englishmen and one American, have asked the German Government to annex the islands, is all the more significant in view of the present attitude of the United States concerning Samoan affairs.
A hardy undertaking was concluded yesterday when the British bark Lottie Moore arrived in port.

Lovers of athletic sports will have a rare treat to-day at the grounds of the New-Jersey Athletic Club at Bayonne, N. J. There will be a carnival of sport from 10 o'clock until sunset, and Many of the crack athletes in the country will compete. The frames will begin at 1 o'clock with a football contest between the Red Star team and that of the Centreville Athletic Club.
LONDON, Sept. 3. -- A Berlin dispatch, to The Standard says:
There was a rumor afloat yesterday that ex-Capts. Cross and Devery had concluded to make formal statements in their own defense, and that these statements would be of a most sensational character.

-- The league game between the Manhattans and Victorias at Prospect Park resulted in one of the closest finishes played in the championship series this season, the Prospect Park aggregation just winning by 8 runs. j. Rose played in fine form for the Manhattans, and put on 42 in free style, While A. Smedley added 27 and A.H. Stratford 19.

The chemist who repulsed two burglars the other day by the employment of concentrated ammonia as a projectile suggested the revival of a custom by no means new. There wag a time when it was not uncommon for the Chinese in naval battles to hurl glass balls loaded with such discouraging drugs as sulphuretted hydrogen upon the decks of the enemy's vessels.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- The Tribune to-morrow will say, editorially: "The news item of Saturday, the only happening which attracted universal attention -- the great loss of life by forest fires in the Northwest, so graphically and fully set out in detail in to-day's Tribune -- was given exclusively to Cincinnati in yesterday's issue of this paper through the United Press service.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 2. -- With five Republican candidates for first place on the State ticket, the politicians in the two parties are expecting a good deal of a smash among the Republicans this Fall, a smash that will bring into peril the harmony and unity of that party, and consequently jeopardize the much-heralded and much-predicted success at the polls in November.

The finishers in the clothing trade went out on strike yesterday, as they said they would, to abolish the day task system and get an advance of wages. This is the beginning of what will probably be the largest strike in the clothing trades that has taken place in New-York, as it will include, besides the finishers, the tailors, basters, cloakmakers, and suitmakers.

-- The first volume of the English, "Pony Stud Book" has been issued. The society which sues the book, and of which Mr. Frederick R. Hill of Felhampton Court, Church Shelton, Engand, is Secretary, was organized in June, 1893. The object is "the improvement and encouragement of the breeding of high-class riding ponies." The standard for foundation stock was fixed at 14.2 hands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The peculiar haze that has been noticeable in the sky all over the country for the last week or so, has been a matter of great interest to meteorologists, and many experiments have been going on in different observatories of the country to determine its cause and nature.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The Rev. Dr. John L. Scudder, pastor of the Congregational Tabernacle, returned from his vacation on Saturday and resumed his duties yesterday.

Justice Grady was called upon in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning to decide the ownership of a gray Spring overcoat claimed by two men, one of whom was under arrest for stealing it. He didn't decide the question.

Our attention has been called to a published interview with Senator Lodge of Massachusetts concerning the new tariff. This interview, which appears to be a statement prepared for publication by the Senator himself, fills two and a half columns in a Boston newspaper. In those parts of it which relate to the new sugar schedule the calculations and estimates of The Times are misrepresented, for political effect.

The book programme for the Brooklyn Jockey Club meeting, which opens on Friday of this week, was issued on Saturday. The meeting will last for fourteen days, and as usual the purses are $1,000 each. Secretary McIntyre has made his usual clever programme, and has made the following allotment of dates for the stake races:

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 2. -- The Citizens' Committee this evening telegraphed to Falmouth to Sherman Hoar to go to Gray Gables and request President Cleveland to attend the funeral of Gen. Banks. It is confidently expected that Mr. Cleveland will arrive in this city Tuesday. An invitation has been extended to all regularly-organized military and civic bodies to participate in the funeral procession of the deceased General.

It is pretty generally admitted that for campaigning abilities horses bred at Brookdale during the life of D.D. Withers had no superiors. They raced early, often, and for many years. They have won stakes of all kinds and values, and have always been great breadwinners, horses of the wear and tear sort that every owner likes to have in his stable.

The Central Labor Union annual parade has been announced to start promptly at 10 o'clock this morning, and a large number of workingmen are expected to take part. When a delegate from the cloak and other clothing makers spoke of their grievances before the Central Labor Union yesterday, a delegate of the union suggested that those people join in to-day's parade.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $897,825. The banks now hold $65,820,825 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $1,116,200, an increase in specie of $443,000, a decrease in legal tenders of $1,293,800, and an increase in circulation of $28,100.

A decision of considerable importance concerning the construction of electric railways on lines parallel to existing steam railroads was made on the 31st ult, by a Judge of the Connecticut Superior Court. At the recent session of the Connecticut Legislature there were granted to many companies charters for the construction and operation of electric roads.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- If the police had allowed the Sedan celebration to take its course to-day, there would have been such a demonstration as the empire has seldom seen since the war. Not only in Berlin, but also in the provinces, the rumors of an effort to suppress the festival caused a strong reaction of feeling.

After varying fortunes the star performers of the harness-racing brigade have reached the metropolis. The Driving Club of New-York was the first member of the Grand Circuit to offer substantial prizes this season, and the seven purses which were opened very early in the year received a large support from all parts of the country.

We reprinted the other day from The Rochester (N.Y) Union and Advertiser an article showing the most wonderful record for blundering that was ever made, by anybody. This article referred to the great number of erroneous statements that had been put out during the months of July and August by the Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press."

Mr. Morton's avowed candidacy for the Gubernatorial nomination cheers the Republicans more than it alarms the Democrats. He is very rich, he is fairly popular, he will make a good race. It would be foolish for his opponents to ignore or underestimate his strength. But there are Democrats in the State who can defeat him, plenty of them.

The eleven days' meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, the most successful in its history, from a racing as well as a financial standpoint, will be concluded this week. The card for today will furnish some rarely good sport, unless the owners dodge their engagements and so spoil the features, the Flatbush Stakes and the handicap at a mile and a quarter.

BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 2. -- Archduke Charles to-day opened, on behalf of Emperor Francis Joseph, the International Hygenic Congress in this city. The Archduke was accompanied by Dr. Wekerle and all the members of the Cabinet and by many courtiers and savants. Redonte Buildings was crowded with a brilliant assemblage.

Elections for State officers and members of the Legislature will be held in September in Arkansas, Maine, and Vermont, and the two latter States will elect Representatives in Congress. Arkansas will elect its Representatives in Congress in November, but the voters of the Second District will fill on Monday the vacancy in the present Congress caused by the resignation of the Hon. Clifton R. Breckinridge.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- James J. Van Alen gave his first entertainment, a dinner at Wakehurst, to-night in honor of Sir John and Lady Kaye. The tables bore a charming decoration of pink roses in bunches and garlands, and the valuable George IV. service of the host was brought into use.

"The Union League Club has been tied to the wheels of the chariot in which Thomas C. Platt is now riding victorious after his battle with that organization," was the comment of a Republican yesterday.

The Brooklyns expected an easy victory over the New-Yorks at cricket at Central Park yesterday, but the latter strengthened their team by several Harlem men, and they put up a good game, and were defeated by only 12 runs. The scoring was very low on both sides. L. Webster doing great execution with the leather for NewYork, while A.A. Adams and A. Brown divided honors in the trundling department for Brooklyn.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 3. -- The "White Wings" branch of the State Democratic Convention was called to order at Oxford Hall at 11 o'clock by Senator A.B. McKinley, who spoke favoring the harmonization of the two factions. The women delegates then marched into the hall in a body and were received with prolonged applause.

Six representatives from each of the antiTammany organizations will meet at the Coleman House to-night to discuss the kind of platform upon which it is proposed to fight Tammany. It is intended to start the plan of combining against Tammany in this way. The invitations were sent out yesterday, and read as follows:

CORNING, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- At the Yates County Republican Convention the following were unanimously named as State delegates: George P. Lord of Starkey, Harvey C. Talmage of Benton, John T. Andrews of Milo, and Delmar J. Knapp of Barrington. This resolution was passed:

The trial of Police Captain Stephenson will be resumed at Police Headquarters this morning. It was again said yesterday that charges would be preferred against four more Captains, but their names will not be made public until the case of Capt. Stephenson has been concluded.

With twenty-two entries in the singles and only two courts at their disposal, the members of the Essex Tennis Club of One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, between Fifth and Lenox Avenues, played their first open tournament yesterday from start to finish, and played part of the matches In the doubles. Most of the local clubs were represented in the entry list, and the play was of a high order for the class of men entered.
The auction sales of real estate set down for to-day in the New-York Real Estate salesroom, at 111 Broadway, are as follows:

It is to be hoped that no intelligent person interested in the commercial progress and prosperity of New-York failed to read the full report, printed in Sunday's Times, of the board appointed by the Secretary of War to "recommend what length of span, not less than 2,000 feet, would be safe and practicable for a railroad bridge" across the North River.

The picnic of the Central Labor Union at Brommer's Union Park was brought to an abrupt termination very early last evening, because the manager of the park failed to keep his agreement to have only union beer and cigars, and food, and union waiters to serve the picnickers.

DETROIT Mich., Sept. 3. -- Forest fires in this State are hourly increasing in fury. They are raging along the entire line of the Michigan Central, from Bay City to Mackinaw. Gagetown is surrounded by flames, and the people are battling to save the town. Gladwin is also threatened with destruction.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 3 -- There was the gayest kind of a gay time down on Long Island this afternoon. It didn't really extend all over Long Island, and it is just possible that there were some persons on the island who didn't know anything about it at all. But to those who did it seemed as though there were fun enough and girls enough to cover a much larger area.
The party should calmly ponder the improved and unimproved political respects In which renomination would present the Governor to the suffrage of the State.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Four thousand persons saw the races of the Rambling Wheelmen at Pleasure Beach track this afternoon. There was a stiff breeze blowing, and the air wan very chilly. No fast time was made. Summary:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 -- Society spent most of Labor Day at the golf club grounds witnessing the close of the ladies tournament, the finals being between Miss Anna Sands and Miss Winthrop, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Buchanan Winthrop, Miss Sands having won from Mrs. Ogden Mills In playing off their tie. The match between Miss Sands and Miss Winthrop was very close.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- When the evening session of the Constitutional Convention convened, Chairman Root of the Committee on Rules reported the following time limits on debates: That a half hour be given to the naturalization amendment; one session of three hours to the three canal amendments; a half hour to the terms of office of Governor and State officers, and that the vote on the apportionment amendment be taken at 3 o'clock Thursday.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The twenty-seventh annual Trades Union Congress was opened at Norwich this morning. 380 delegates being present from all parts of the country. Mr. John Burns opened the congress with an address, in which he said that, although the number of delegates in attendance was smaller than at previous meetings, the congress was no less a representative one.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 3 -- The Japanese Marquis Saigonje arrived in Chemulpo on Tuesday last, and congratulated the King of Corea upon having achieved his independence.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Sept. 3. -- The Cherokee Club, the Democratic organization of the Twenty-second Assembly District of New-York, of which Maurice Featherstone is the leader, had its tenth annual outing and games in Stimmell's Park here to-day.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Permit me to thank The Times for suggesting the name of Edward M. Shepard of Kings as one of its "'baker's dozen who are types of the kind of candidates called for" this year. You say that the Republicans, in selecting Mr. Morton as their man for Governor, have taken not the slightest advantage of the circumstances that made the present situation extraordinary.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- The Constitutional Convention began operations this morningwith only sixty-two delegates present. The amendment to preserve the waters of the Niagara River from undue diversion for commercial purposes and to restrict the rights already granted was first considered. Substitues offered by Messrs. Benhite, Marshall, and Root and the amendment to Mr. Root's substitute offered by Mr. Dean were read.

The laws of the State of New-York affecting primary elections, passed by the Legislatures of the years 1892 and 1893 for the purpose of protecting the enrolled voters of the various parties against the wiles and machinations of those politicians pure and simple and others who may prefer devious to straight ways for effecting their purposes, are clearly defined and readily understood.

The plan of apportionment reported to the Constitutional Convention last week is expected to come up for consideration to-day. We have heretofore shown that this is partisan and unfair, and its purpose plainly is to give the Republican Party control of the Legislature, even when it fails to command the support of a majority of the voters of the State.

BIRMINGHAM. Ala., Sept. 3 -- Near Newsite, Tallapoosa County, this morning, James Ashley and his son Robert went into a field where Robert Cross, a young farmer, was harvesting. Robert Ashley held Cross while his father fired seven bullets into his body.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Department Commander John C. Shotts of Yonkers, returned Saturday from one of the pleasantest visits among the Grand Army of the State he has made since he became Department Commander.

Nelson Logan, a colored man, thirty years old, who, in his capacity as butler in the boarding house of Mrs. W.F. Gott, at 24 West Thirty-second Street, for many years had been trusted implicitly by his employer, was a prisoner in the West Thirtieth Street Station House last night.

The Court of General Sessions abandoned the old Court House, in the City Hall Park, yesterday, and occupied its quarters in the beautiful new Criminal Courts Building on Centre Street just north of the Tombs. There were no ceremonies further than the formal opening and adjourning of the court.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Labor Day in Albany was observed by a parade in the morning, consisting of the different trades unions and the Federation of Labor, and in the afternoon by two picnics, one given by the federation and the other by the Knights of Labor. The parade was the largest ever held in this city, and the picnics were largely attended.

Tn interesting tennis tournament, open to allcomers, formed the main attraction on the list of sports which occupied the members of the South Orange Field Club yesterday afternoon. Thirty local players entered. A dark horse turned up In the person of J.D. Forbes of Morristown, N.J., hitherto unknown in local tournaments.

There was a yacht race down the bay yesterday, and the police boat Patrol, with three of the Police Commissioners, Superintendent Byrnes, Capt. Hoadley, a Sergeant or two, and a few plain policemen, went down to look at it.
The drills of the National Guard at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday were attended by about 700 persons, and were in every detail a success.

HINCKLEY, Minn., Sept. 3 -- A United Press reporter boarded the first train out of Pine City for Hinckley at 7 o'clock this morning. It was a work train, but carried many members of the different committees appointed at Pine City last evening.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 3. -- A private dispatch from Pine City says the number of victims near that place from forest fires will reach at least 425.

DUBLIN, Sept. 3 -- The Freeman's Journal publishes a number of letters which passed between Mr. Timothy M. Healy, M.P., and Mr. Bernard C. Molloy, M.P., on the subject of Mr. Gladstone's recent contribution of L100 to the Irish Parliamentary fund. Mr. Molloy, in opening the correspondence, asks: "Does the acceptance of Mr. Gladstone's subscription endanger our independence?"

Like the Giants, the Brooklyns won two games yesterday. They had for opponents the tail enders from Louisville, and had little or no trouble in winning. The opening game was fairly well contested, but in the second the result was never in doubt after the second inning. Brooklyn won both games by superior work with the bat.

One of the largest racing crowds of the year was at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, and a good day's sport they had, even though the field for the Labor Day Stakes, a handicap at a mile and a quarter, was reduced from fourteen horses to five, mainly because nine trainers thought they had no chance to defeat Yo Tambien, the Western mare, who is considered invincible in and around Chicago.

James S. Conover, a well-known business man of this city died at his Summer residence in Stratford, Conn., Sunday morning. Mr. Conover had been ill for four years. He was born in Freehold, N. J., seventy-seven years ago. He came to New-York when eighteen years old, and was clerk in a mercantile house.
The annual regatta at the New-Rochelle Rowing Club, held yesterday on Echo Bay, was a very successful affair. A novel feature was the ladles' race. The course was a quarter of a mile. The summary:

Before his departure for Europe, a few days ago, Mr. Charles Emory Smith, editor of The Philadelphia Press, who was Minister to Russia when Mr. Harrison was President, permitted some of his opinions concerning the new tariff to be published by The Tribune. He predicted that there would be a revival of business, but expressed regret because Mr. Cleveland had not vetoed the bill.

The sale of the Brookdale yearlings brought a large crowd of turfmen to the American Horse Exchange last night. Twenty-nine head from the Brookdale Stud and a few others owned by James B. Clay of Kentucky, including a brother to Hurlingham, were disposed of. The youngsters brought fair prices, the highest sum being given for a half brother to Arab.

The Grand Circuit trotting meeting opened at Fleetwood yesterday with an attendance which was more than gratifying to the officials of the Driving Club and to all admirers of the harness horses in New-York. There were nearly 5,000 persons on the grounds, and, although the day's programme developed nothing very exciting in the way of well-contested racing, everything went off with a dash, which aroused enthusiasm in spite of straight heats and one-sided finishes.
ALBANY., Sept. 3 -- A meeting of the Council of Administration of the New-York State Bankers' Association was held here to-day.
The Single Taxers of this State held a conference at the Cooper Institute yesterday to determine what action, if any, they should take in the campaign.

BOONTON. N.J., Sept. 3 -- The bicycle races given by the Boonton Athletic Club to-day on the five-lap track proved a success. Ray Dawson was the hero of the occasion, and the promising local rider added three handsome diamonds to his season's gaines. Hodgon, the Kingsland rider, while riding a tandem in practice with Harrington, his companion, took a fall and broke his collarbone.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Engineer A. J. Menocal, United States Navy, is endeavoring to recover his infant from Mrs. A.M.A. Neilson, mother of his wife, Mrs. Menocal and child came here early this Summer. Two months ago Mrs. Menocal's health failed, and she went to Hot Springs, Ark., leaving the child's grandmother to care for the infant.
This morning's Buffalo Express, which receives the alleged news of the Western Associated Press, said this:

RAHWAY, N. J. Sept. 3 -- The great handicap road race, the feature of the sporting events in this section of the State to-day, was won by a Jersey rider, but The New-York Times prize, coveted by all the contestants, was captured by a crack from the Columbia Cycle Club, his being the best time over the twenty-five-mile course.

The contract tailors of New-York and Brooklyn celebrated Labor Day yesterday by going on a strike. Ten thousand men are directly Involved in the strike. What is wanted by them is the abolishment of the present "task" system and the substitution of weekly wages, arranged on the basis of ten hours a day.
CONEY ISLAND, Sept. 3. -- There will soon be an end of the Coney Island season. The carnival period came to a close to-day.

Aldace F. Walker, the successor of J.W. Reinhart, as receiver of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway system, reached New-York yesterday on the steamship Friesland, from Antwerp. He was accompanied by his wife, and they expect to remain in this city for some weeks.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The eleventh annual tournament of the Hartford Wheel Club was well managed, the entries were full, the weather was about perfect, but the racing was rather tame. Nearly 5,000 persons were present. W.W. Taxis of Philadelphia won two of the Class B races, the mile open and the quartermile open.

Of all the "living pictures" which will be seen to-night in the various theatres which are to supply them with home, none will be so vivid, so frightful, so full of awful suggestion, as the living picture which, without the help of any stage manager, thrilled many spectators on Park Avenue a little before daybreak yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 3. -- The case of Antonio Ezeta of San Salvador is ready for hearing before Judge Morrow in the United States District Court to-morrow. It is probable that Carlos Urrutia, formerly private secretary of Carlos Ezeta, the deposed President of the Republic, will be one of the chief witnesses for Antonio during those proceedings.
ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The following reports for the year ending June 30 last have been filed with the State Railroad Commissioner:

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 3 -- The camp ground at Sea Girt is filled with marksmen from all parts of the United States. A strong twentymile wind blowing over the grounds from the northeast, in a great measure prevented any extraordinary scores. A heavy mist was hanging over the targets, almost making it impossible to discern them.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Prof. H. Morse Stephens, M.A., of England has been chosen to succeed the late Herbert Tuttle as Professor of Modern European History at Cornell University. Prof. Stephens is a graduate of Oxford, and is prominent among the younger historians now carrying on the traditions of the Oxford School, headed by Bishop Stubbs, Goldwin Smith, and the late Prof. Freeman.

The manufacturers of New-York and Brooklyn are uniting in a general protest against certain amendments to the State Constitution which have been proposed In the Constitutional Convention. The ground of opposition to these amendments Is that they are especially injurious to the manufacturing and commercial interests of the State.

The annual regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Club was to have been sailed yesterday. A stiff easterly breeze was churning up the Sound all day long, and the Regatta Committee thought it would be unwise to start the boats, and so postponed the race until next Saturday afternoon. This was a disappointment to all the Larchmont visitors, and so a race was arranged between the catboats Fairy, Water Witch, and Myra.

Mr. De Wolf Hopper's revival of "Cinderella at School," under the title of "Dr. Syntax," at the Broadway Theatre last evening was received with great favor by a large audience, and will doubtless please the town for some time to come. The operetta is not new, for it was produced at Daly's Theatre in 1881, when several of Mr. Daly's company were heard and seen as comic opera singers.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 3. -- Secretary Hester's New-Orleans Cotton Exchange report on the cotton crop was issued in full to-day. After stating that the crop for 1893-4 was 7,549,879 bales, an excess of 849,452 over last year, Mr. Hester says the largest part of the gain was in Alabama, Georgia, Florida, and North Carolina, which ran ahead.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The third and last of the series of races for the Osborn Cup, for twenty-one-footers; a special race for the Mills Cup, for cabin catboats, and a match race between the forty-footers Banshee and Crocodile were sailed to-day under the auspices of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The Republicans of Jefferson County held their convention in this city to-day for the purpose of electing delegates to the State and Congressional Conventions, and to nominate a member of Assembly. The convention was of more than usual interest because of the fact that the county has two candidates for places on the State ticket, and that it was almost unanimously opposed to a Jefferson County man for Congress.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 3. -- The latest advices from the scene of the big fire indicate that there will be a total of nearly 400 lives lost. This includes the fatalities at Hinckley, Pokegama, Rutledge, Sandstone, and all the area of country covered by the conflagration.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- The open race of the South Boston Yacht Club, sailed to-day off City Point, furnished some good sport for the yachtsmen participating. The wind was fresh from the eastward, and the boats which failed to put in a single reef wished they had done so before the race was over.

PINE CITY, Minn., Sept. 3. -- At Hinckley the walls of the schoolhouse, the iron fence about the Town Hall property, the bank vault, and one absolutely uninjured building are all that is left to mark the site where stood a score of store buildings and a dozen times as many dwelling houses.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 3. -- The names of all those who perished in the fire will never be known. It is the exception when a body is identified.

Charles Belmont, and Ella Belmont, the four Chicago "badgers," were again arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning. They were suffering when brought before the Justice, and trembled violently as they leaned heavily against the railing.

The Executive Committee of the NewYork State Cleveland League, an organization of colored Democrats, held a meeting last night at the Gilbert House, 254 West Twenty-sixth Street, to arrange for the Fall campaign.

A somewhat serious dilemma just now confronts the good citizens of Brooklyn. They respect the law, and desire to abide by it without failure or uncertainty. The trouble with them is that they do not feel sure what is lawful and what is unlawful.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Exceptionally fine weather and smooth water were the conditions at the twenty-seventh annual regatta of the Palisade Boat Club this afternoon. The various events were witnessed by a large number of guests from the decks of the steamer Caroline A. Peene, which accompanied the races. Excellent music added to the general enjoyment.

-- General Manager J.J. Frey of the Atchison system has issued a circular relative to the re-employment of strikers, in which he says: "Under no circumstances or conditions will agitators and others who were instrumental in causing the strike and its continuance, or interfered in any way with the operation of the road be reinstated in their former positions or re-employed in any capacity whatever."

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 3. -- Acting under Washington advices, the Custom House, Post Office, Sub-Treasury, Mint, and other departments of the Government in this city have not observed Labor Day, but transacted business as usual.

The new national holiday was observed in Brooklyn yesterday by all labor organizations and many social societies in an appropriate manner. Parades, picnics, and other forms of entertainment were the order of the day, and it passed off without mishap to mar the celebration.

Ex-President Harrison has graciously intimated that should his former companion in victory be named for Governor of New-York he may make arrangements to deliver a few speeches in his behalf and in support of the party by which they have in their several ways been so highly honored.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Three thousand persons witnessed the New-Jersey Athletic Club Olympiad to-day. The quarter -mile cinder path was in fine condition for track events, but was not just what wheelmen most desire. The oval was dry and hard. Three prizes of good value were given in each event.

FORT SNELLING, Minn., Sept. 3. -- In accordance with an order issued by Gen. Merritt, Commander of the Department of Dakota, Company G, of the Third United States Infantry, stationed at Fort Snelling, left on a special train this afternoon on their way to Hinckley, under command of Capt. Hale.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Much interest is being manifested by lawyers throughout the State in the appointment of the State Board of Law Examiners, which is provided for by a law passed by the last Legislature. The board is to consist of three members, to be appointed by the Court of Appeals, to serve for one, two, and three years, respectively.

The estimates of the wheat crops of the world which were published on the 1st inst. by the Hungarian Minister of Agriculture are said to have been prepared with great care. They indicate that the world's output of wheat for this year will be 2,476,000,000 bushels, as against 2,279,000,000 in 1893 and an average of 2,280,000,000 for the last ten years.
DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 3. -- The relief train which left here at 4:30 P.M. yesterday returned with about 250 refugees, who tramped in across the country from Sandstone this morning.

The Rutherford Club held a tennis tournament at its courts on Montrose Avenue yesterday. Men's singles and doubles were both contested. In the former, F.K. Hollister reached the semifinal round, beating C. Parker in consecutive sets, without much difficulty, the score being 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- In view of the recent developments in Republican politics and the determination of Mr. Platt to and a candidate with boodle, the debate in the Constitutional Convention to-day was particularly suggestive, if not instructive. The matter under discussion was the article reported from the Judiciary Committee relating to bribery for nominations and at elections.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Sept. 3. -- The Salvation Army held a field review at Prohibition Park to-day, and fully 500 uniformed members of the army were present from New-York, New-Jersey, and Connecticut, representing thirty-five separate corps. Over 1,000 spectators were attracted to the park during the day.

The Republican papers are publishing wild estimates of the pecuniary value to the Sugar Trust of the protective duties on refined sugar in the new tariff. The New-York Tribune asserts that these duties will "put in the pockets of the Trust every year" $24,000,000, and The Cleveland Leader says that, aside from the "$46,000,000 of revenue," the "gigantic monopoly will also take $40,000,000 a year more out of the pockets of American consumers."

New-York's aspirants for baseball honors celebrated Labor Day in a most fitting manner. They won two games from the Cincinnati Reds and played in the presence of 20,000 spectators. It was a profitable day for the Giants, who, by securing the two victories, managed to hold the leaders in check.
Detectives Larkin, Devlin, and Grennan were threatened with serious trouble for a few minutes Sunday night while making a raid on the basement at 22 Mott Street.

National Labor Day was fitly observed by a parade and other events yesterday in this city. The date was set by act of Congress, which was signed by President Cleveland June 28, 1894. Congressman Amos J. Cummings, one of the most ardent advocates of the measure, rode as Grand Marshal for Typographical Union No. 6, at the head of the Fourth Division of the paraders.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In your editorial this morning on "The Democratic Nomination" you place before the public the names of a number of Democrats who are of the type whose nomination for the Governorship will bring about union in the party, and after union victory.
Mrs. Gibert, whose son's domestic troubles were told in the Supreme Court in this city about a year ago, arrived Sunday on the French liner La Bretagne, and went to her residence, 150 Madison Avenue.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Great form was shown by E.C. Taylor of Buffalo, George Taylor, H.C. Tyler, and E.A. McDuffle, in the Press Cycling Club races to-day, at Waltham tract. Over 10,000 persons witnessed seven races, all exciting, but

Never since the time when Noah battened down his hatches, drew in his gangplank, and let the ark go adrift has there been seen such a well-behaved, quiet, willing, and obedient lot of animals from the jungles under one roof as are at present at Madison Square Garden:

-- The woman who was rescued from the North River at Twentieth Street on Sunday, and who gave her name as Mary Ann McCarthy at the New-York Hospital, stated yesterday that she Is the wife of Patrick Griffin of ITS Seventh Avenue. Mrs. Griffin is forty-one years old. Her husband said she had been acting strangely for a long time. He supposed she attempted suicide, although he said she never tried to destroy herself before.
The armored cruiser Maine was taken out of the stone drydock of the New-York Navy Yard last Thursday. Yesterday she had a preliminary trial of her starboard engine.

ELIZABETH, N.J. Sept. 3 -- The ninth race meet of the Union County Roadsters, held on their track here this afternoon, was one of the most successful in the history of the organization. Over 2,000 spectators were present, and everything passed off most pleasantly. Of the five events, four were bitterly contested, while several exhibitions by crack riders in efforts to lower the track record added to the interest of the meet.

The New-York Yacht Racing Association always has its annual regatta on Labor Day, and nearly every year a storm that comes on that day or the day before mars the day's sport. The association is made up of small clubs, and yesterday's high wind was too much for many of the small boats, and instead of their being over one hundred starters in the different classes there were only fifty-one.

To pass a resolution declaring that no man who permitted his name to go on the Tammany ticket should have their support, and to declare that they would do all in their power to bring about a union of anti-Tammany forces and to engender feelings that will not pass away for some days, was about the sum total of the remarkable gathering of anti-Tammany organizations at the Coleman House last night.
DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 4 -- The death roll resulting from the forest fires increases, and now over 650 are known to be lost, the greater part women and children.

It is well enough for those concerned in manufacturing, industrial and commercial affairs in this State, out of abundant caution, to give expression to their opposition to proposed amendments to the Constitution which would injuriously affect their interests, but it is hardly conceivable that the collection of preposterous propositions which they have got together for this purpose will be adopted or will receive serious consideration in the convention.

The tennis tournament of the Park Hill Country Club was continued yesterday on the courts at Park Hill. Stephen F. Thayer of the Yonkers Club placed two more matches to his credit at the expense of Vidaud and Getty both of whom he defeated with ease. By his two victories he wins the first prize, Ernest Getty receiving the second.

"There is no record," says The Cleveland Leader, "that any representatives of the Sugar Trust ever Interfered with the tariff legislation of the Republican Party. No Senator from a State not interested in sugar refining ever threatened to prevent the Republican Congress whieh framed the McKinley law from passing any tariff bill unless the interests of a big monopoly were well taken care of."

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- The visible supply statement, with its increase of 2,178,000 bushels in wheat stocks, was a surprise to everybody. What were thought to have been extravagant estimates placed the increase at 1,750,000 bushels, and few people looked for more than a train over last week of 1,500,000 bushels. The figures, when they were bulletined, produced a weak feeling

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 4 -- The funeral of Gen. N. P. Banks was held this afternoon with military pomp and ceremony. Every walk in life was represented at the exercises, from the Governor of the State to the humblest citizens of Waltham, who knew the General as a lifelong friend of the poor and lowly.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning, consists of TEN PAGES. It contains:
The working season for Brooklyn school children commenced in earnest yesterday morning.

MAWEAUKA, Ill., Sept. 4. -- At the Assumption coal shaft, about seven miles south of here, at an early hour this morning. In lowering a cage, when about 200 feet from the bottom, the wire cable broke and the cage fell to the bottom, demolishing everything in its way. The shaft is 1,000 feet deep.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- The New-York State Board of Equalization met to-day and adopted the equalization table for 1894 as submitted by the State Board of Assessors.

Religion, or suspicion of religion, seems to cause about as much heat in the discussions of the Constitutional Convention as politics. It has appeared to a quite unnecessary extent in the debate on the amendment reported by the Committee on Education, and the warmth has been produced by a clause in the section prohibiting the use of public funds for sectarian schools which seems to us to be out of place.

New-York. -- Walter McCready, thirty-two years old, of 403 West Fifty-fourth Street, and W. H. Atherson, forty years old, of West Brighton, Staten Island, who are employed as bookkeepers at 40 White Street, were struck on the head by a piece of gaspipe while attending to their duties yesterday. The pipe was accidentally dropped by a plumber, who was working on the fourth floor.

Many brokers who have been absent from the city throughout the Summer were on the Exchange yesterday, and almost without exception they have returned pronouneed bulls on the market. Their operations, however, were not large, although they were purchasers of stocks, presumably for clients.

After one of the liveliest and most spirited games seen on the Polo Ground this season, the Giants won from Pittsburg yesterday. The youths from the Smoky City put up an excellent article of ball, stubbornly contesting every inning, and made a metropolitan reputation for gameness and perseverance. Several times they appeared to be out of the hunt entirely, but they bobbed up serenely and kept the Giants hard at work.

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn has refused to grant the German Hospital Society a permit to parade in Broadway, Brooklyn, with a band on Sunday, Sept. 23, when the cornerstone of the new German Hospital in Ridgewood is to be laid.

-Representatives from several States attended the meeting of the Executive Committee of the League of American Wheelmen in Boston on Monday. The object of the gathering was to determine what each State requires In the way of legislation to bring about an improved condition of the highways. It is the design of the league to throw Its entire moral support into the movement whenever It Is carried on.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Sept. 4 -- Nearly all those who survived the terrible forest fires in Northern Minnesota have now been removed to places of safety in Superior arid Duluth, and, as a heavy rain has quenched the flames, there will be no further casualties. The work of searching for the dead is progressing in earnest.
There is no telling just how much fun there is going to be in the Republican situation before the party's State Convention meets. Every day adds to the merriment.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- The Republican leaders are sorely perplexed over the question of final adjournment. It is inevitable, now that the Constitutional Convention will be unable to transact all the business remaining before it by Sept. 15.
