Not one calendar of bills on the order of third reading has been prepared, or will be until next week.

The first news of the Peary relief expedition's steamer Falcon since she left Brooklyn on June 20, was received yesterday by The Brooklyn Standard-Union in the shape of a cablegram dated Disco, July 17, via Copenhagen, Sept. 4.

The women of the College Settlement and their friends have taken up the cause of the striking tailors. In response to a call sent put by Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell and by Dr. Jane E. Robbins, head worker of the College Settlement Society, a meeting was held last night at the headquarters of the society, 95 Rivington Street.

The situation for the Republicans in this State does not clear so rapidly as was expected when the announcement of Mr. Morton's willingness to fight in the ranks or at their head was made. If the great body of the party had been of like mind with the zealous and eager workers who acclaimed the advent of Mr. Morton's name on the "banner" and on checks, there would have been no difficulty.

The trial of Capt. John T. Stephenson of the Tenth Police Precinct was ended at Police Headquarters yesterday. The announcement was made that no superior officer of the department will for some time be placed In jeopardy through the independent Investigation ordered by a majority of the board against the vote of Commissioner Murray and prosecuted by Superintendent Byrnes and Assistant District Attorneys Weliman and Osborne.

The first verdict given in the new quarters of the Court of General Sessions was "not guilty." It owas found by a jury in Part III, Judge Fitzgeraid presiding, yesterday morning. The prisoner was Anthony Cortez, twenty-one years old, of 557 West Thirty-second Street. He was charged with robbery in the third degree.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 4 -- It is now admitted by Judge Krueger, the heaviest stockholder in the defunct United States Credit System Company, that the concern will not be able to resume business, that the $288,500 subscribed by stockholders is a total loss, and that, even with the sale of the company's Newark property, hardly enough will be realized to meet in full the claims of outstanding policy holders.

The attendance at the Sheepshead Bay races yesterday was far below the average at the present meeting. This was not surprising; however, as there is always a falling off after a holiday, and then the weather was very threatening at about the time that people usually start for the track. But, while the weather conditions were anything but agreeable, there was enough to keep the crowd interested from the outset of the racing.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- A dispatch from Shanghai to the Central News says a large number of Chinese recruits are arriving at Tien-Tsin, where they are receiving their arms and equipment. The Province of Shan-Tung is showing much discontent and little or no sympathy with the war against Japan, and is withholding the men and supplies which have been demanded of that section of the country.
The will of the late Mrs. Maria L. Daly; wife of ex-Chief Judge Charles R. Daly of the Court of Common Pleas, was filed yesterday for probate.

In comparison with the big crowd which witnessed the Grand Circuit trotting races it Fleetwood on Labor Day, yesterday's attendance looked light, but there were about 3,000 persons on the grounds. The course itself was in poorer condition than on the day before, its worn-out surface soil having broken away more or less in many spots, leaving the footing somewhat mealy and loose for the trotters.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Reports from the farming districts of Western New-York say that all that is needed for a repetition of the recent horrible calamity in the Northwest is to have a fire once get a start in that section.

ST. JOHN'S, N. F., Sept. 4 -- Considerable apprehension is felt here for the steamship Miranda, which should have reached Sydney last week. She left here with the Cook arctic expedition for Greenland, July 14. She returned two days later for repairs, having struck an iceberg and stove in her bow.

-- Falstaff Hackett's Prompt Book. -- Manager Joseph Brooks, who has spent a good deal of his leisure time this Summer in looking up material relating to "The Merry Wives of Windsor," made a find recently in Chicago. While in McVicker's Theatre in that city he came across an old and dusty bookcase hidden away behind a mass of material.

HINCKLEY, Sept. 4 -- The special train sent out by the citizens of Minneapolis, bearing supplies and medical relief to the suffering people of Hinckley and vicinity, had on board eleven physicians and surgeons, with a full supply of drugs and instruments, and fifty canvas cots.

SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Good scores were made by the marksmen at the rifle range here to-day in the inter-State match, as well as in the Hilton Trophy match. The world's record for team shooting at 20O yards, seven shots each, with twelve men was broken. The record is 364, and the New-Jersey team ran up a total of 367.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- Gossip and interest in our market still continue around Bay State Gas matters, though there has been even in that stock only moderate activity, with small fluctuations above $10 per share. The Street believes the fight between the Bay State Gas Company and the Brookline Gas Company, which is understood to be controlled by the Standard Oil people, has been virtually settled.

SARATOGA, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- No more beautiful spectacle was ever witnessed here than the floral parade and battle of flowers which took place this afternoon. It was given under the popular management of the Floral Festival Association, which achieved a signal triumph with Its initial fete.

The Executive Committee of the Brotherhood of Carpenters, the United Order of Carpenters, the Amalgamated Socipenters met last evening at Lexington Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street to receive reports from the walking delegates of the various organizations and from the men who were ordered on strike yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 4 -- The Anne Arundel County Convention of the Moss-Bannon faction of the Democratic Party to-day selected seventy-five delegates to the Fifth District Congressional Convention, which meets to-morrow. Resolutions were adopted indorsing President Cleveland, Chairman William L. Wilson, and the House of Representatives "in honestly and faithfully trying to give genuine tariff reform to the American people," and condemning the "conservatives or pretended Democrats."
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day:

In view of the necessity of having an operating officer clothed with full power at the head of the Lake Shore Railroad, a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors was held last Monday. and D. W. Caldwell, President of the Nickel Plate Road, was appointed General Manager. John Newell was both President and General Manager.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday. Mr. Stephen R. Jacobs, as referee, sold to the plaintiff, Julia Sahn, at $3,300, the two-story frame dwelling 251 Harmon Street, northwest side, 140 feet northeast of Evergreen Avenue, 20 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- A dispatch from Denver, Col., in which it was stated that the Denver delegates to the convention of the Inter-State Association of Irrigation, which adjourned from Denver to Greeley, were somewhat exercised yesterday over a statement in a letter from Secretary Morton, was shown to Mr. Morton, who was found at his desk in the Department of Agriculture to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- A statement has been prepared at the Treasury Department giving the amount of specie and bank-note and paper circulation of the United States in years specified from 1800 to 1859. From the latter year the figures have formed a part of the report of the Secretary of the Treasury.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 4 -- A message was carried by signaling with sunlight from the top of the Equitable Building to the summit of Pike's Peak, sixty-six miles in an air line, yesterday. Several days ago Sergts. McGlone, McLaughlin, and Bissell left Denver for Pike's Peak to make the experiment. This was the message which was flashed from the top of the peak:
Messrs. Mandelbaum Lewine have bought of Good Carpenter 419 to 425 West Thirteenth Street, north side, 50 feet east of Washington Street, 100 by 103.3, with old buildings, for about $60,000.

The 1,327 soubrettes who have paid Loie Fuller the compliment of each becoming the "Only Original Serpentine Dancer in the World," were rather flustered by a statement which was In circulation yesterday. This was the allegation, made in a somewhat substantial manner, that Miss Fuller at last contemplated matrimony, and has accepted the attentions of no less highly-esteemed and famous a public man than Senator Cantor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- West Chicago Street Railway stock started on the up grade this morning. The first sales were made at 1271/2%, an improvement of nearly a point, as compared with Saturday's close. From this point the price moved up steadily to 129. Trading was unusually active. Many strong houses were the principal buyers.
Ex-President Benjamin Harrison has completed his observations of the game of politics in New-York City and has gone away for the present.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 4 -- The sentiment, "A new water supply or a new Mayor," given to the people on Sunday night by the Rev. John L. Scudder, but which was practically suggested by The New-York Times last Saturday, is likely to be popular, even though it may not be carried into the charter election.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- James J. Van Alen had his annual dance at Wakehurst to-night. About forty couples danced the cotillion, the favors for which were rubber toys, small shovels and pails, and other such objects designed to provoke fun, all of which were wheeled upon the floor in a baby carriage by Mr. Van Alen himself.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- For three hours this morning the Constitutional Convention was befogged by politics and the debates, and results took such a turn as to throw the Democrats into transports of encouragement for this Fall's election, and of delight over the bad split with which the majority found itself confronted on the educational question.

The New-York Post Office, the telegraph and the cable companies, all bear convincing testimony to the revival of trade which has followed the settlement of the tariff question. These three agencies of communication between business men are to be likened to trade barometers, so accurately and promptly do they record the varying conditions of the commercial affairs of the country.

KOENIGSBERG, Sept. 4 -- The Emperor and Empress arrived here at noon to-day, the former to officiate at the unveiling of the monument to the memory of his grandfather, Emperor William I. The city was gayly decorated with flags, flowers, and triumphal arches, and the streets were thronged with people.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Weather Bureau furnishes the following reports of crop conditions for the week ended yesterday:

ALBANY, Sept. 4. -- A cold-water shock was delivered to the machine Republicans in this vicinity this evening, when it became known that ex-Senator Warner Miller, who was to-day elected Chairman of the Herkimer delegation to the State Convention, and Henry G. Burleigh of Whitehall were in town, and had declared themselves as hostile to the nomination of Levi P. Morton for Governor.

The next race meet of importance to attract the attention of the wheelmen, of the metropolitan district will be that of the Mercury Wheel Club at Flushing, L. I., on Saturday. Unusual preparations have been made for the affair, and it Is likely the attendance will form the banner crowd for Flushing. The race most talked about Is the mile for the championship of Long Island.
PINE CITY. Minn., Sept. 4 -- The list of dead brought to Hinckley continues to swell, and will reach at least 400, if not 30O, in Hinckley and neighboring towns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Secretary Carlisle has decided to appoint a commission of experts to draught regulations to carry into effect the sugar schedule of the new tariff law. These experts will be selected from the force of United States Inspectors now employed In the United States Custom House Service at the large Importing cities, together with Treasury officials employed in the Customs Service.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Our market to-day opened strong, but the activity soon ceased, only to reawaken in the last hour, when large transactions in St. Paul were made. The closing was almost buoyant, and was at the highest prices of the day. Philadelphia bought largely of Pittsburg common and preferred.

A conference between the Philadelphia and the Olcott Reading Reorganization Committees was held at the offices of the Central Trust Company in this city yesterday. George H. Earle, Chairman, and S. F. Tyler represented the Philadelphia committee. It was agreed to consolidate the two committees, and a sub-committee of three persons was appointed to draft a plan of reorganization.

William Freeling, forty-one years old, a carpenter of 100 Ten Eyck Street, Brooklyn, attempted to drown himself in the Harlem River at the foot of East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, Monday evening. He was rescued by a policeman.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The contributions of Mr. Gladstone, Lord Tweedmouth, and other English Liberals to the Irish Parliamentary Fund in response to a circular signed "Justin McCarthy, William O'Brien, John Dillon, and T. P. O'Connor," has led to inquiry, which proves that the circular is a forgery designed to compromise the McCarthyites.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Mayor George W. Aldridge to-day appointed the election officers submitted by the City Central Committee of which Richard J. Decker is Chairman. This he did in defiance of the decision of the sub-committee of the Democratic State Committee, which found that the Central Committee headed by J. D. Spellman was the regular Democratic organization of Rochester.
PINE CITY, Minn., Sept. 4 -- The General Executive Committee in charge of the relief work in this section has made a report of the dead bodies recovered thus far, as follows:

The clever little player from Morristown, J. D. Forbes, who made so favorable an impression during the early rounds of the South Orange Field Club's tennis tournament, was beaten rather easily yesterday by S. T. Carter, another candidate for fame from the same town. Forbes played an excellent game at the base line, his ground strokes and lobs being cleverly executed, but his attempts to volley high balls underhand were disastrous failures.

The testimony taken yesterday by the Governor's commission which is investigating the Elmira Reformatory made it plain that the convicts' stories of abuse and cruelty while undergoing punishment were to a large extent untrue. The evidence was given by keepers who were present when the convicts who have testified for the prosecution were spanked.

It is strange to see (writes a correspondent of a London paper) how music, or at least musicians, have come to the front in Paris. The vogue is entirely for them as celebrities. One judges from the windows of the photograph shops. Verdi is everywhere, and he seems to have brought in with him Massenet and Thomas, and Bruneau and Saint-Saens.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 4 -- Newport had a veritable Derby day marking the opening of the series of meetings of the Newport Racing Association. The course is at Coddington Point, and, though it is temporary, the appointments are complete. The site is picturesque, overlooking the bay on one side and a beautiful country beyond on the other.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- At the opening of the East Port Chester public school this morning there was a conflict of authority between two sets of Principals and teachers. The old School Trustees at the conclusion of the school term in July engaged Samuel Caldwell as Principal, Miss Ida R. Stillwell as assistant, and Miss Mary Busted and Miss Sadie Tompkins as teachers.
The Rev. Dr. James Clark Welling, President of the Columbian University of Washington, D. C., died at his Summer home in Hartford, Conn., yesterday morning, of heart disease.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Fire at about 1 A. M. this morning destroyed the bieg Hotel Guernsey, at Grand and Seventh Avenues, owned and managed by Messrs. Lunger and Steinmetz of Philadelphia. The building, which was a substantial four-story structure, was totally burned in an hour from the time the fire started.

BALTIMORE. Sept. 4 -- Capt. Frietsch, who sailed from New-York four weeks ago for Queenstown alone in the fore-and-aft schooner Nina, a tiny craft of 24 feet on the keel, was spoken Aug. 26 by the Atlantic Transport Line steamer Menantlc, which arrived at this port yesterday from London, by way of Swansea.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day granted the application of the Waddington, Canton and Southern Railroad Company for permission to construct a steam road, about twenty-six miles in length, in St. Lawrence County, running from Canton to Waddington.

Park Commissioner {Nathan Straus is slim and wiry and fleet of foot. He was driving in West Seventy-fifth Street on Monday afternoon, with nine-year-old Carl Eisendreth of 317 West Seventy-fifth Street. When near the Boulevard Carl pointed out a little boy who had attacked him on the street, with several other boys, last Friday night and had robbed him of a quarter.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your editorial this morning upon the Democratic nomination for Governor presents the right kind of types of men which should be considered in making the selection. This is going to be a year in politics in which the candidates are going to count more than ever.

-Martin M. Ramsay. Guy G. Rogers, and J. J. Cheatham have qualified for admission to the navy and become full-fledged Assistant Paymasters. Mr. Ramsay is a son of Rear Admiral Ramsay, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation; Mr. Rogers is a son of Capt. Rogers, United States Army, retired, and Mr. Cheatham is a son of the late Gen. Cheatham of Tennessee.
The golden wedding of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Bell was celebrated last evening in their magnificent apartments in the Knickerbocker, 247 Fifth Avenue.

An extraordinary meeting of the Order of Scottish Clans was called to order in the Metropolitan Hotel about 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The delegates, about eighty-five in number, were welcomed to the city by Acting Mayor McClellan. Royal Chief Walter Scott, Jr., of Brooklyn, presided.

There was published a few days ago in The Congressional Record a speech made in the House on the 13th ult. by Mr. McMillin of Tennessee, a prominent member of the Ways and Means Committee, and in this speech attention was directed to certain paragraphs of the new tariff law which, we think, have been overlooked by many persons.

Business at the Custom House continues active, although the rush to withdraw goods from bonded warehouses has abated considerably. Deputy Collector King of the Third Division said yesterday that he expected to be able to restore matters in his department to their normal condition within two or three days.

In the absence of his traditional companion in mischief, the parrot, Pantata, a small monkey belonging to Dixie Hines of The American Wheelman, had a good time of the very first and finest quality in Patterson Brothers' hardware store, 27 Park Row, on Labor Day. The monkey had been purchased for a fourth prize at the Good Roads' bicycle tournament, and was won by Mr. Goehler of Buffalo.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- When the Constitutional Convention took up the apportionment article to-day, Chairman Becker of the Committee on Legislative Organization opened the debate. Mr. Becker dwelt upon the theories upon which the committee had based the new apportionment. The last apportionment was made at an extra, or adjourned, session of the same Legislature that ordered the enumeration.

The success of the Westchester Horse Show, which will be held on Sept. 25, 26, 27, 28, and 29, at White Plains, is already assured. Viewed as a social function, these affairs have always been delightfully entertaining, not only to the residents of Westchester County, but to visitors from a radius of a hundred miles of the metropolis.
AITKEN, Minn. Sept. 5. -- Fires are around three sides of this town, and the Fire Department is hard at work. One boy is reported burned to death from the township of Nordland.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 5. -- The Republican State Convention to-day nominated Charles A. Busiel for Governor. It was called to order by Col. S.S. Jewett of Laconia, Chairman of the State Committee. Charles H. Bartlett of Manchester was elected Chairman, and made a speech. Chairman Gilmore, for the Committee on Credentials, reported 748 present out of 749 entitled to seats.

About a score of citizens of the Twentyninth Assembly District, in the Annexed District, met in Parshall's Hall, One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street and Washington Avenue, last evening, and formed Good Government Club W. Among those interested in the new club are Civil Justice William G. McCrea, the Rev. George Harris, pastor of St. Ann's Episcopal. Church, arid the Rev. J. Reynolds, pastor of St. Mary's Methodist Episcopal Church of Mott Haven.

The seventh annual championship meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, which will take place on Saturday. Sept, 16. at Travers Island, will, of course, be the most important athletic meeting held this year, simply because It will bring together the crack amateur champions of all the associations, and It remains to be seen whether the Metropolitan Association will carry off most of tha honors.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- There is no feature of Interest in our market. Bay State Gas has been marked a little higher, partly on a growing belief that the gas war has been settled. Fitchburg preferred sold up from 70 3/4, and the last quoted sale to 72 1/4, for no stated reason. Telephone stocks remain firm, but almost without quotations.

There has been the following correspondence between Secretary of War Lament and Charles H. Swan, representing the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company, in relation to a hearing to be given before the Secretary of War upon the report of the commission of expert bridge engineers appointed by President Cleveland:

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 5. -- The steamer Belgic arrived from the Orient at 11 o'clock last night, bringing Hongkong advices to Aug. 1, and Yokohama advices to the 14th. China's declaration of war is as follows:

NEWTOWN, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Judge Bowman of Winfleld had a narrow escape from drowning this afternoon while attempting to swim on a wager a certain distance in Long Island Sound, near Oriental Grove. Judge Bowman and a party of about twenty-five of the Democratic leaders of this town were at the grove for the purpose of discussing the political outlook.

The fourth annual competition of the New-Jersey Rifle Association is held this week on the State range at Sea Girt. Its programme presents not only matches for the local organizations, but plenty of others, like the Kuser, the Hayes, the Trenton Cup, the All Comers' Military, the Schuetzen, and the President's, open to everybody, under the rules adopted.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- Two well-known Boston clubmen, Sumner Paine and E. A. Wilkie. will appear before Judge Luce, at Waltham, to-morrow morning, to answer to the charge of "breaking the Sabbath." This was done by playing the game of golf, a game which the authorities of the town of Weston. where the offense occurred, think should not be played on Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- The market to-day was dull. The Chief trading was in the traction stocks. People's sold at 57, and there was considerable business clone in odd lots. Baltimore was strong, round lots changing hands at from 14 3/8 to 15. The buying was by inside brokerage houses. Philadelphia Traction was wanted up to 99.
There was a regular political variety show at the Cooper Union last night.

The Pequod Club had Its second annual outing and shore dinner at Donnelly's, College Point, yesterday, and when the excursionists had returned and landed, the President of the association, John C. Sheehan, accepted congratulations that were tendered and merited.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 5. -- Secretary of the Navy Herbert arrived at the navy yard in Charlestown at a little past 10 o'clock this forenoon, from the Dolphin. He was received by Commodore Miller, commandant of the yard, Capt. Phillips, executive officer of the yard, and other officials, and the customary salute was fired.

It is the opinion of the racing sharps that no meet this season, particularly in the East, will excel the "diamond tournament," which takes place at Springfield, Mass., next week. No cyclist with any pretention to speed will be absent from it, and with the talent at hand the Springfield Bicycle Club counts on record performances.
Dr. George A. Brandreth of Sing Sing, who has been mentioned as a compromise candidate for Governor on the Republican ticket, said yesterday:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Mrs. Margaret H. Welch of the staff of The New-York Times read to-day in the Department of Health of the American Social Science Association, which is in annual session here, an ably-prepared and interesting paper on the subject: "Is Newspaper Work a Healthful Occupation for Women?"

The discovery of the efficacy of what la called anti-toxine in the treatment of diphtheria is one of the results of a long series of experiments made in Berlin at the laboratory or institute of Prof. Koch. Some of these were made by Prof. Koch himself and others were the work of those who were pursuing investigations under his direction.

WAVERLY, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The races on the State Fair grounds were close and interesting to-day. There were three events, two trots in heats, and one five-furlong running heat race. This was won by Jim McLaughlin in 1:04 1/2 and 1:03 1/4. Following are the summaries of the trots:

FORT WAYNE. Ind., Sept. 5 -- The selection of Mr. Caldwell as chief officer of the Lake Shore will probably involve his retirement from the Nickel Plate. According to the inter-State commerce law, no two competitive roads are to be consolidated of placed under the same officials. It the laws of the country are observed, Mr. Caldwell has but one thing to do, and that is to quit the Nickel Plate.

(All letters for this column, suggesting candidates for Gubernatorial nomination, must bear the signature of the writer, not necessarily for publication, but as a guarantee of good faith.) To the Editor of The New-York Times: I believe I am one of many Democrats who would favor Daniel Magone of Ogdensburg for the Democratic candidate for Governor this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 5 -- It was expected, when the Ezeta case was resumed before Judge Morrow to-day, that counsel for San Salvador would Introduce oral testimony, but they simply put Consul Calderon on the stand to Identify the documents asking for extradition proceedings, which documents had been sent to him by his Government.
Marguerite Lange, a servant in the home, at 68 East Fifty-fifth Street, of Robert M. Gailaway, President of the Merchants' National Bank, proved yesterday to be a plucky girl.

FLUSHINGS, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Some grand sport is expected at the Driving Park next Saturday, when the meet arranged by the Mercury Wheel Club takes place. The entries have closed, and in number and quality are very gratifying to the management.

COWES, Sept. 5. -- The Prince of Wales wired from Homburg this morning that he approved of the decision of the Sailing Committee of the Royal Yacht Squadron to accept Mr. Gould's withdrawal of the Vigilant's challenge for the Cape May Cup.

McCafferty Wishard, the owners of Buckrene and various other horses of more or less erratic proclivities, were not ruled off the turf, as some of the wiseacres would have it that they were going to be. Instead the Coney Island Jockey Club Stewards, who have been investigating the running of their horses, reported yesterday that they "do not find proof sufficient to warrant action being taken" in the Buckrene case.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 5 -- The Convention of the State League of Republican Clubs was beld here to-day, nearly 200 delegates being present. A. Wilson Norris of Harrisburg delivered the address of welcome, which was responded to by President Robinson of the State League. York was unanimously agreed upon as the place for the next convention.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The Standard's Berlin correspondent says that the Princess Bismarck is gaining strength and the Prince is becoming more cheerful. He drives opt In an open carriage daliy. He was Invited to attend the unveiling of the old Emperor's monument in Koenigsberg yesterday, but sent regrets to the committee".

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- The trade In wheat was light, the range narrow, and the tone barely steady to-day. The receipts In the Northwest attracted considerable attention, not for their enormity, but for their unusually slim character, 408 cars only coming in at Duluth and Minneapolis.
A conference was held yesterday afternoon and evening between committees representing the contracting tailors and their employers.

With four races on the programme at the Grand Circuit trotting meeting yesterday, darkness came on before the big card could be disposed of, and the very best contest of the week thus far had to be postponed until to-day. There was a slight increase in the attendance at Fleetwood Park as compared with the day before, and the races, as a whole, were much better conested than those of the first two days.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Ingram Adams, son of the late Judge Adams of Pennsylvania, and Miss Amina Goodwill, the well-known pianiste, were married to-day in All Saints' Church, Margaret Street. There were present a large number of persons, including many Americans. The service was fully choral, and three clergymen officiated.

Miss Elizabeth H.M. Lord, an eccentric spinster, who died in June at 685 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, left $13,000, which she bequeathed to Mrs. T. De Witt Talmage. Relatives of the dead woman who live in NewHampshire and Maine have commenced action to nullify the will.

If there was any justice in the disqualification of Dobbins and the giving of the Omnium Handicap to Roche last Saturday there was equal reason for the disqualification of Roche in the race at a mile and an eighth at Sheepshead Bay yesterday afternoon and giving the race to Hornpipe. The foul was no worse in the first case than in the last.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 5. -- The two Japanese spies who were surrendered to the Chineseauthorities by the United States Consul, under whose protection they were, were promptly tried and beheaded. In consequence of this summary action, all of the Japanese remaining in Shanghai, about 700, decided to leave the city at once.

The increase of railroad earnings through August was remarkable for its rapidity and the wide extent of country covered. With scarcely an exception, the railroads of this country are enjoying ingood measure the benefits of a substantial revival of trade. The volume of traffic has been increasing steadily since the middle of July, until now it has attained the character of a "boom," so far as the railroads in the South and West are concerned.

His vacation ended, and, with a lot of hard, work, staring him in his sun-burned face, William H. Crane returned to the city yesterday forenoon, and later in the day was seen at the Star Theatre, where he was directing a rehearsal of "The Merry Wives of Windsor."

Representative William L. Wilson of West Virginia, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, sailed on the Paris for Southampton yesterday. Representative Isidor Straus of this city was with him. They will remain in London about two weeks, and expect to return early in October.
The State Commission in Lunacy resumed its inquiry yesterday into the conduct of the city asylums for the insane and other institutions under the care of the Department of Charities and Correction.

More contributions are needed by the department of hygiene of the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor to prosecute to a successful termination Its fresh-air work, so admirably maintained under the efficient supervision of F. S. Longworth and Mrs. M. Fullerton and the indefatigable visitors in direct charge of the details of management, Mrs. Tompkins and Mrs. Clark.

Both Cleveland and Brooklyn played good ball yesterday, and the Brooklyns won by a single run. From the fifth inning the game was a "tie." but the local players, by good batting, sent in the one run necessary to win in the last half of the ninth inning, with two hands out. Kennedy and Young pitched strong ball, and the field work of both teams was of the gilt-edged order.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 5. -- Almost a dozen records fell to-day as a prelude to the great Springfield meet, for which the racing men are gathering to-day by scores and hundreds. At this meet the real championships each year are decided. It is said that Fred H. Allen, Springfield Bicycle Club, will go into Class B at this meet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Deputy Collector Couch of the New-York Custom House was in consultation with Secretary Carlisle for an hour this morning discussing practical questions growing out of the administration of the new tariff law. No new decisions resulted from the conference, all disputed points presented by Mr. Couch having heretofore been decided as they arose.

The final rounds in the open tennis tournament of the South Orange Field Club were reached yesterday afternoon, after some sharp play. The contests to-day will be the final in singles between Robert M. Mills, Jr., the well-known Orange player, and S. T. Carter, who has proved the surprise of the tournament; the match in doubles between Cragin and Gennert and Ward and Miles, and the consolation final, probably between Gould and Gennert.

ALBANY, Sept. 5. -- A movement has been started in this city within the past twenty-four hours for the sole purpose of defeating Thomas C. Platt's plan to nominate Levi Parsons Morton for Governor on the Republican ticket. The candidacy of Warner Miller of Herkimer was formally announced to-day.
Gen. George Stoneman, ex-Governor of California, died in Buffalo yesterday, at the home of Mrs, Benjamin H. Williams, his sister.

Messrs. L. J. Phillips Co. have sold for Michael Brerman, to E. A. Jonea, at $40,000. the new four-story-and-basement brick and brownstone dwelling 11 West Seventieth Street, 20 by 60, with 16-foot extension by 100.5.

Lovers of baseball will have only one more opportunity of seeing the Ciants play a championship game at home. This afternoon the New-Yorks will meet the Pittsburgs, and then start on a Western trip, where the season Trill be finished.

The cultivation of large tracts of land in Argentina that were used. only for pasturage until a few years ago, or not used at all, and the extension of railroad lines through these tracts, have largely increased the world's supply of wheat. The appearance of Argentina in the world's markets with an exportable surplus of more than 50,000,000 bushels has very perceptibly affected prices.
James Coleman Drayton has instituted proceedings to secure a divorce from his wife, Charlotte Augusta Drayton, a daughter of William Astor, of the family of which John Jacob Astor was the founder.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 5 --The Minnesoia forest fires have extended into the woods on the Canadian side. A dispatch to-night from Ratportage, a town 100 miles east of here, says: "Rainy River, on both sides for the whole length, excepting ten miles at the mouth, is one huge mass of flames.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The rifle shoot continued to-day at the butts at this place. The New-York team did not stay to take part in the sweepstakes which were to be shot for to-day.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- The Tompkins County Democratic Convention, held in this city to-day, was controlled by friends of the State machine, and that control was exercised in a planner foreign to all idea of harmony of action in the campaign this Fall. A temporary Chairman was announced from the platform, and a roll call of delegates directed.

A St. Vincent's Hospital ambulance ran into a heavy express wagon at Third Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon. The driver, Bernard McDonald, and the ambulance surgeon were thrown from their seats to the ground and received painful bruises.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Opening at 131, West Side was bought and sold heavily througrhout the first session. The determined effort on the part of the bears to break the stock was frustrated by an army of brokers with their cards filled with buying orders for both speculators and Investors. Trading was heated and animated.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- The long-talked-of match race between the fin-keeled sloops Drusilla, owned by Lewis M. Rutherfurd, and the Memory, owned by James Murray of Philadelphia, a Summer resident of Jamestown, was sailed to-day. Both are Herreshoff boats, and are fliers. The wind blew half a gale from the southwest, and in the bay the sea was choppy and outside it was much rougher.

The members of the sub-committee of the Conference Committee of the German-American Reform Union who voted in favor of the Townsend resolution at the Coleman House conference of anti-Tammany organizations Tuesday night came in for considerable censure at the meeting of the General Committee of the Union at Terrace Garden, Fifty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, last evening.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The result of the Nyack tournament this afternoon leaves Talmade and Paret still undefeated, and to-morrow they will meet in the finals. It was one of Talmade's off days to-day, and he played in a Talmadge's off style, driving repeatedly into the not. His opponent was Davia, woo opened weil, taking the first set, 8 -- 6.

-- Otav Augriers, thirty-three years old. of 76 West Houston Street, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court for complicity in the robbery of John MeLean of jewelry valued at $15O. It was charged by McLean that Aueiers held the door of his office at 81 Bleecker Street, on Saturday night, while another man threatened him with a revolver and took his jewelry.

-- Koster Blal's. -- The regular Fall and Winter reason at Koster Blal's will begin next Monday night, when the programme will be entirely new. The Nilsson aerial ballet will then be presented for the first time in America. It has been the chief sensation in Paris for the last six months. Other features of the new bill will be the first appearance in America of Mile.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Chief Consul James S. Holmes, Jr., of the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, returned today, to his home in this city from Boston, where, on Monday, he attended a conference of the Executive Committee of the League of American Wheelmen, with the Chief Consuls and other high cycling authorities from the various Eastern States, who met to discuss legislation affecting the interests of wheelmen.

CHIPPEWA FALLS, Wis., Sept. 5 -- A late report from Bruce says the little village was completely enveloped by the forest fire that has been surrounding the place for several days. The people escaped by running to the creek, covering themselves with wet blankets and allowing the flames to sweep over them.

NORTH SYDNEY, C.B., Sept. 5. -- The fishing schooner Rigel of Gloucester, Mass., Capt. George W. Dixon, arrived here this morning with the passengers and crew of the ill-fated steamship Miranda, which left New-York July 7, carrying Dr. Cook's arctic expedition.

For the fiftieth time this season the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild, with gay banners floating overhead and Its usual long passenger list of sick babies and tired mothers, all made as comfortable and happy as tender care, wholesome food, fresh air, and pure salt-water baths could make them, made an excursion up and down the Bay yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- Controller Roberta's department has just completed a table showing the bonded indebtedness of the counties, cities, towns, villages, and school districts in the State on Jan. 1 last. This Is the first tabulation of the kind made by the department in over thirty years, and shows the total bonded indebtedness of the counties, cities, towns, villages, and school districts in the State to be $209.913.587.

The evidence in the investigation into the Elmira Reformatory management yesterday disposed of some more of the "cruelties" which The New-Tork World and its criminal assistants have been charging against the institution.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 6 -- The Ohio Wool Growers' Association, in its annual convention to-day, wailed bitterly against free wool and adopted an address or appeal to wool growers, farmers, and the people in genera to unite for the undoing of the alleged great owrong done by the American Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Chief Hazen of the Treasury Secret Service received a telegram to-day announcing the arrest in St. Louis, Mo., this morning of Secretary Smith of the St. Louis Bank Note Company.

-- The following assignments or additional Second Lieutenants to vacancies of Second Lieutenancies are announced: Additional Second Lieut. Hagh D. Berkeley, First Cavalry, to be Second Lieutenant, First Cavalry, Troop D. vice Rivers, promoted. Additional Second Lieut. Albert E. Saxton, Eighth Cavalry, to be Second Lieutenant, Eighth Cavalry, Troop C, vice Evans promoted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Appreciating the benefit your great paper is conferring on Jersey City by your support of its citizens' efforts to obtain pure water. I write to protest against the insinuations of various local sheets against the integrity of the motives of the gentlemen who have given their time and money in patriotic support of the movement for pure water.
John P. Jones, formerly Republican Sentor from Nevada, now allied with the Populists, was interviewed yesterday at the Astor House by a reporter for The NewYork Times.

WAYNE, West Va., Sept. 5. -- Ex-Gov. Wilson, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate to succeed Camden, spoke here last evening. After Wilson had finished, United States Marshal Vinson, who is a strong Camden man, attempted to address the crowd.

That Jones of Nevada, should have left the Republican Party would at no time have been an epoch-making fact. That he should have left it upon the ground that he saw no hope of getting out of it any rehabilitation of the silver dollar is, so far as it goes, a stroke of luck uor the party.

At an informal meeting yesterday of the Atchison General Reorganization Committee, of Which R. Somers Hayes is Chairman, the subject of the company's prospects for business was discussed, and some encouraging reports were listened to. Receiver Aldace F. Walker attended the meeting. He said that he had ascertained that it would not be necessary for him to remain In this city after next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The United States Coast and Geodetic Survey hag received notice by telegraph that that six parties commanded by members of the survey have completed the mapping of the vicinity of the boundary line between Alaska and British Columbia, on which they have been at work for two years.

The steam yacht Alicia, owned by Millionaire H. M. Flagler of the Standard Oil Company, was badly smashed in the East River oft Eighth Street yesterday morning, as the result of a collision with the transfer boat Express of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept 5. -- The going over of Senator Jones of Nevada to the Populist Party is regarded here, by such politicians as remain after the general dispersal of Congress, as an indication of the determination of some of the silver men to create a distinctive silver party out of the dissatisfied elements of the two old parties.

Charlotte Augusta Astor, third daughter of William Astor, granddaughter of John Jacob Astor of Waldorf, founder in America of the Astor family, the fame of the wealth of which is universal, was married to James Coleman Drayton by the Rev. Morgan Dix, OCt. 20. 1879.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Scant progress was made to-day in the trial of the nine Directors of the American Railway Union who are charged with violating the injunction issued by Judges Grosscup and Woods of the United States Court during the recent railroad strike.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- The second day's debate on the partisan apportionment scheme of the Republicans in the Constitutional Convention was drawn to a close this evening, leaving to the Democrats a very great advantage. Those who spoke to-day were Messrs. Lincoln of Cattaraugus, Gilbert of Franklin, E. R. Brown of Jefferson, Mr. Barrow of Onondaga, Col. Morton of Kings, on the part of the Republicans, and Messrs.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Burtsell, who was deposed from the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany in this city by Archbishop Corrigan and assigned to the parish of St. Mary's, in Rondout, N.Y., was a passenger by the Cunard steamship Aurania, which yesterday arrived from Liverpool.

Charles F. Amburger, fifty-seven years old, was arraigned before Justice Grady in the Tombs Court yesterday morning and remanded until to-day. He is charged with swindling Lumber merchants. H. C. Maeruder, a representative of the FarmeleEccleston Lumber Company, at 1 Broadway, was the complainant.

Oswald Ottendorfer, editor of The StaatsZeitung and President of the German-American Reform Union, gave further reasons yesterday why he had voted against the resolution which was rushed through the conference of anti-Tammany organizations at the Coleman House Tuesday night, and which declared that the parties to the conference would not support any candidate who would permit his name to go on the municipal ticket nominated by Tammany Hall.

The Pierrepont House, in Montague Street, and the Athenaeum, in Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, were centres of political interest in Democratic circles last evening, for at those places the Executive Committees of the two factions of the Democratic Party met to arrange for the Fall campaign.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- There is trouble between the Republicans in this Congressional district. It is well known that Charles W. Hackett proposes to hand the Oneida delegates to the State Convention over to Platt, to do with them as he pleases. They are supposed to be for Morton for Governor, first, last, and all the time, if Platt and Hackett say so.

The courteous and studiously non-committal letter of President Cleveland to President Dole of Hawaii adds nothing to the official recognition of the new "republic" by our Government. It is a reply to a letter from Mr. Dole announcing the establishment of his "republic," and reciprocates the friendly sentiments therein expressed.

Out of the conference held in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall last night by the gentlemen who were called together by the committee brought into existence by Gustav H. Schwab, Hugh N. Camp, and William E. Dodge came the authority for the appointment of a Committee of Seventy.

-- In the case of the Warren Judgment against the Monmouth Park Association, Mr. James Galway, one of the securities on the bond, who had his Preakness farm levied on, has taken the case into the United States court, and his counsel, Senator Griggs of Paterson, intends to bring every stockholder of the bankrupt concern on the witness stand.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- At to-day's sitting the Trades Union Congress approved the introduction of a bill giving rural laborers holding land allotments a guarantee of tenure for the same. A resolution was passed declaring that employers ought to be legally punished for importing extra labor into any locality where the existing supply is sufficient to meet the needs of the district.

WEST POINT, Sept. 6. -- Rain commenced to fall about 6 o'clock this morning and continued for several hours. The forest fires which have been burning for several days from Cro' Nest to Bear Hill were extinguished.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept, 6. -- The last half hour's trade in wheat to-day saved the market from being characterized as one of the dullest on record. Up to that time the reuse covered but 1/4 c, while a good stiff undertone to prices was quite apparent. The announcement of unusually started estimates of to-morrow's arrivals started the crowd to covering.

After three months' investigation of the discipline of the police force of the cityconducted by direction of the Commissioners -- Superintendent Byrnes has made a report of the results of his inquiries, with certain recommendations of his own. He finds that the police are doing their duty fairly well in the enforcement of the laws, with the exception of the excise law.

A wild Texas steer was the principal owner of several West Side streets for a long time after 5:30 yesterday afternoon. His tantrum came to an end when he was lassoed in the butcher's shop of Leonard Beck, 592 Eighth Avenue, where he was trying to revenge on Mr. Beck, with his horns, his brethren whose carcasses lay or hung about him.

There was a large and picturesque gathering of Scots at Snlzer's Harlem River Park yesterday to witness the thirty-eighth annual games of the New-York Caledonian Club. More than twenty clans were represented, including the Royal Stuart, McDonald of Clan Roland, Cameron of Argyll, McPherson, Campbell, and Gordon.

-- On the steppe near Borki, that point on the railway where an accident happened in 1888 to the train carrying the Russian imperial family, rises a church built in the Muscovite style of the seventeenth century. It was erected, adorned, and filled with paintings by the subscriptions of the faithful in all parts of the empire, and cost about $125,000.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Gov. Werts and staff visited the fair at Waverly to-day. There was a coaching parade of prize winners and some good trotting. Summaries:

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 6. -- It now remains only for Jupiter Pluvius to be on his good behavior for the great race meet of the Mercury Wheel Club next Saturday to be a success. The entries were made public this evening, and the management has cause to feel proud, for they form a really meritorious batch.

The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen save a public hearing yesterday on the application of the Columbus and Ninth Avenue Railroad Company to extend its lines through West One Hundred and Ninth Street to Manhattan Avenue, thence up Manhattan Avenue to West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.

Sullivan, who was formerly a member of the New-York team, proved to be an enigma to the Brooklyns yesterday, and they only made two hits off his delivery. Up to the eighth inning he shut the club out without a single hit, but at that stage Daly and Lachance broke the spell, each making a single.

PINE CITY, Minn., Sept. 6. -- The worst has probably been told at Hinckley, and it is doubtful if there will be any very large additions to the list of the dead. Last night several bodies were found in a cellar, but they were so badly burned that it was impossible to determine whether there were three or four bodies.

Chancellor MacCracken of the University of the City of New-York made public yesterday at the office of William S. Opdyke. Secretary of the University Executive Committee, the substance of the report made to the university committees in charge of the new movements of the institution.

Henry Eugene Davies, who died yesterday at Middleborough, Mass., was widely known in this city, where he had built up an enviable reputation as a lawyer. He retired from business about three years ago and went to his country residence, at Fishkill-on-the-Hudson. There he lived until six months ago.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Pardon me for taking exception to some remarks in your editorial columns on Sunday, Sept. 2. It is so seldom that I find occasion to differ with you in anything that graces this department of your model journal that for once I may be pardoned.

For the past few weeks imaginative newspaper writers throughout the South have been engaged in constructing extensive and complicated railroad combinations, with the new Southern Railway system as a basis. Each scheme has involved the names of the Vanderbilts and Drexel, Morgan Co., While the latest story deliberately builds up a great financial copartnership between the Vanderbilts, the Rothschilds, Drexel, Morgan Co., and J. S. Morgan Co. of London.

The announcement that the Andorrans have determined to throw off the yoke of France and to declare and maintain their independence is calculated to produce a sympathetic thrill in the American bosom, without reference to the incidental questions how they came to be under the French yoke, what the burden of that yoke is, who the Andorrans are, and where Andorra is.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6. -- United States Judge Morrow to-day decided the motion to discharge Gen. Colocho, one of the Salvadorean refugees, against whom the defense held there was no testimony. Judge Morrow read a number of excerpts from depositions which connected Colocho with several of the alleged crimes, but they were so indirect that the court ordered his discharge.

The final match in doubles at the South Orange Field Club's courts yesterday afternoon was a tennis game for four sets, and a one-act farce for another. Cragin and Gennert and Ward and Miles played good sound tennis until the score reached two sets all, when Cragin and Gennert asked for a postponement, as it was getting too dark to play.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- The sixth fire in Asbury Park within a few days was discovered at midnight last night. The big barn of C. Burdette Polland and two other barns, filled with a dozen or more horses, wagons, hacks, and fine turn-outs, were destroyed. The fires were undoubtedly the work of incendiaries.
Two fifteen-year-old boys, who claim to have run away from homes in Philadelphia, are now in the Tombs in default of $300 bail. Their names are Charles Fuerst and Henry Nussbaum.

The White Star steamship Germanic, from Liverpool, arrived off Quarantine last night at 10:40 o'clock. Among her passengers were the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Parkhurst, S. Bellerly, H. Coper Cliffe, the Rev. Dr. E.B. Coe, the Rev. Dr. Christie, the Rev. Jabbot French, Mr. and Mrs. S.H. Graves, the Rev. Dr. W.N. McVickar, M. Soyeschima, Capt. C.W. Woolsey, and Col. J. Hayes Sutter, British Consul General at Chicago.

The Democratic General Committee of Kings County, of which James D. Bell is Chairman, last night, by an overwhelming majority, voted down Chairman Bell's resolution to divide the election day patronage with the independent organization. The committee also unanimously defeated Bernard J. York's resolutions for joint union primaries.
Suit was brougut in the Somerset County (N.J.) Circuit Court, July 18, 1894, by Edward Tantz Sons, bankers of London, England, against Hallett Alsop Borrowe to recover u450.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Dear Sir: The month of May, 1893. saw the inauguration of the great World's Columbian Exposition, and, in common with thousands of other manufacturers, I became an exhibitor, and at a very large expense, in the face of a panic in many respects unprecedented in severity, taking the stand of good citizenship that all should to the utmost of their ability contribute to the success of the fair.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 6. -- Great indignation is manifested here on account of an outrageous canard which was circulated to-day to the effect that the mining town of Scotch Valley, near Hazleton, had been destroyed by a cave-in which engulfed the the entire village.

VIENNA, Sept. 6. -- The Austrian manouevres ended to-day with a battle under the Trails of Landskron. The cavalry's work was especially creditable. Two bodies from the opposing armies charged at full speed, with lances rested, across the Schlossborg fields and baited within forty paces of each other.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- Mrs. Paran Stevens gave a farewell cotillion at Marietta Villa to-night. Count Castellane led the cotillion. The favors were unique and pretty. About one hundred were present.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The drought has at last been broken, and copious showers are now falling. For forty days the sun has evaporated every particle of moisture, and none has been returned, except in slight dews. Last night at 12 o'clock it began to rain, and has continued with slight intermissions.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: During the past year severe criticisms of the Department of Charities and Correction have been published by the press of this city, and in many cases the root of the evil criticised has been found in the standard of care set by the annual appropriations.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 6. -- No political news in months has excited the quidnuncs of the Republican Party in this State so much as the announcement that Gen. Asa S. Bushnell of Springfield had decided to become a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination next year. Gen. Bushnell is an excellent business man and has many elements of strength, but that is not the cause of the excitement.
AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Gov. Flower and Representative Michael D. Harter of Ohio were the speakers at the fair grounds here to-day. Not as many were present as yesterday.

An account of the recent important discoveries upon the power of sunshine to destroy microbes has been given in The Nineteenth Century by Prof. Percy Frankland. The power of the sun to destroy these organisms has only recently begun to be understood. The capacity of these germs to reproduce themselves is enormous.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- Boston and Maine came suddenly into activity this morning, and advanced from 147 1/2 to 151 bid, with no stock in sight at the higher figures. There is no special reason visible for the advance, except the scarcity of good investment stocks, which yield 4 per cent., taxes paid.

SPRINGFIELD, Mas., Sept. 6. -- Julian Pye Bliss, the Chicago rider, succeeded to-day in recapturing the mile flying-start record, doing the mile in 1:52 3-5. The former record was 1:53 4-5, made by Harry Tyler at the Waltham track Aug. 4. 1894. Bliss also broke the three-quarter-mile record, doing it in 1:23 2-5. Tyler's time for this distance was 1:24 1-5.

The inquiry of the State Commission in Lunacy into the conduct of the city asylums for the insane and other institutions under the care of the Department of Charities and Correction will probably continue two weeks longer. Both the prosecution and the defense have considerable evidence to produce.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- A dispatch from Shanghai says it is reported that the Japanese have threatened to withdraw their promise not to attack Shanghai unless the Kiang-Nan Arsenal there is closed. The motive for the threat is not apparent, but it is surmised that the Japanese are anxious to provoke British interference.

The New-York Rovers, a cricket team organized by W.O. Wllkinson to play mid-week games, had their first match yesterday at Morris Heights, where they gained an easy victory over six men of the Bloomingdale Club by a margin of 98 runs.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- Gov. William McKinley of Ohio arrived in Boston to-day on his way to Maine, to take part in the Reed, campaign. The Governor found time this afternoon to call upon his cousin, Gen. Osborne, at his home in Roxbury, and while there he granted an interview to a reporter on the political situation.

We have been informed by The Tribune that "the absolute failure of the Democratic Party to revoke or repeal the essential features of the protective tariff is the highest possible evidence of the strength of that tariff with the people."

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Edwin Mulford and his bundle of telegrams were the only features of to-day's session in the contempt cases against the officers and Directors of the American Railway Union. President Debs was in court early, and remained throughout the proceedings.

NYACK. N.Y., Sept. 6. -- J.P. Paret of the Lenox Tennis Club was the winner of the singles in the Nyack Country Club's tournament here this afternoon, scoring a decided victory over "Jack" Talmadge of Yale. Talmadgre, who has just returned from Europe, does not seem up to his old-time form, and his play throughout the week has been wild, his drives being either into the net or out of court.

More of the statements of the convicts who are helping The New-York World in its attempt to ruin the Elmira Reformatory were shown to be untrue at the session of the investigating commission yesterday.

Matters at the Custom House have quieted down to their normal condition, and the clerks in the Third Division are no longer obliged to work nights. The receipts for duties yesterday aggregated $531,333, which is a fair day's work. Since the new Tariff bill went into effect, the total number of entries cleared off the books aggregate 13,225. About 2,500 applications remain undisposed of.

In theory, the Republicans who were at political headquarters in this city last night had Levi P. Morton laid nicely away on the shell. They had figures to back the theory and they were confident that the result would come out to correspond with their figures.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6. -- The Daily Report of this evening says:

ALBANY, Sept. 6. -- The Constitutional Convention Committee on Charities has been in session about all the day, and will meet again at 9 o'clock in the morning to conclude its work. The committee has gone all over again its work on the charity article, discussing at length a new proposed article, which reads as follows:

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Mayor William C. Farr of Bayonne this morning approved the action of the City Council last night providing for the execution of a contract to supply the city with water for twenty-five years. This is a substantial victory for the present administration, whose efforts to abandon the supply of foul Passaic water taken below Paterson have been rewarded after one year's faithful work.

As Senator Jones takes himself out of the Republican Party, every rational member of that party can say to him, in the words of Hamlet to Polonius: "You cannot, Sir, take from me anything that I will more willingly part withal."

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 6. -- An appeal for financial aid recently issued by Victor F. Lawson, President of the Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press," seems to have fallen rather flat in this region.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

During the eleven days or the meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, just ended, 274 horses contested in the 71 races, and $183,045 were distributed among owners. The principal winning owners were as follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee will issue its campaign book Sept. 12. A list of the contents is as follows:

The Knights of Labor tailors decided last night to strike, and in consequence about 4.000 men will be thrown out of work in New-York City alone. In all, it is said, 12,000 men will be out to-day in NewYork and vicinity.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- The second day of the first Newport racing meeting drew a large number of spectators. Excursions were run from all near cities and towns, bringing hundreds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The gentlemen at Republican Congressional headquarters in this city are already at work with their arithmetics. They are represented as being much elated over the returns from Vermont and Oregon, although the returns from Oregon are so well seasoned that gentlemen, even at Republican headquarters might be expected to restrain their glee about that election, out of regard for the supposed dejection that exists in the Democratic camp.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The report of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company of Brooklyn for the year ended June 30 last shows gross earnings from operations, $4,303,717; operating expenses, $2,673,391; net earnings from operations, $1,629,725; other income, $189,339; gross income, $1,819,065; fixed charges, $1,764,512; net income, $54,552; cash on hand, $13,641; profit and loss, (surplus,) $115,520; betterments, $55,590.
The Fall meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club begins to-day at the Gravesend track the first race being called at 2:15 instead of 2:30 as heretofore. The following are the entries for the opening day:

To-day the Giants are in second place. They have passed Boston and are now on the track of those obstinate pennant seekers of Baltimore. The change in the position of the clubs yesterday was due to the defeat of the Pittsburgs by the New-Yorks and the failure of the Bostons to win in their game with Louisville.
(All letters for this column, suggesting candidates for Gubernatorial nomination, must bear the signature of the writer, not necessarily for publication, but as a guarantee of good faith.)

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 6. -- The Health authorities here have carefully investigated the case of the Bavarian immigrant, John Peter Walter, who died on a train at Cumberland, Md., the other immigrants having been brought to this city. The opinion of the authorities is that Walther's case was not one of Asiatic cholera.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- A number of cottagers, headed by Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry, have decided after mature consideration to take steps to prevent the publication in newspapers of alleged slanderous articles. It is complained that stories have been sent from Newport this season which have been without foundation and have tended to ridicule and defame the cottagers.

The silver wreath which is to be presented to Johann Strauss, the "Waltz King," by his American admirers, on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of his accession to the position of conductor, will be the handsomest tribute ever presented to a foreign composer.
SARATOGA. N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The principal address to-night before the American Social Science Association was delivered by Charles Dudley Warner on "The Elmira System." He said:

Much of the opposition of rural Republicans to the proposed nomination of Levl P. Morton for Governor is due to the fact that the "up-country" members of the "G.O. P." think that the nominee for Gubernatorial honors should be selected by a convention and not by Thomas C. Platt.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 6. -- Indianapolis track now holds the world's pacing record, and came within a fraction of a second to-day of the world's trotting record. Robert J. made the second heat in his match with Joe Patchen for $5,000 in 2:02 1/2, being the fastest mile ever paced.
Indications that the utmost harmony does not prevail in the ranks of the German-American Reform Union seem to be increasing.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- It was rumored a few days ago that another great combination of Chicago breweries was well under way. It is now said a large part of the capital necessary to effect the combine has been procured. H.M. Bigelow, who organized the present brewery combination, is credited with being the promoter of the new deal.

Mrs. Alice Ellbogan, thirty-eight years old, was asphyxiated in one of the bedrooms of her flat, 213 East Fifty-sixth Street, last night. Whether the woman's death was due to accident or caused by herself may never be known.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 6. -- Bernhard Altenberger, who murdered Katie Rupp of Rome, N.Y., at Snake Hill. May 13, was hanged in the Hudson County Jail at 10:04:30 A.M. to-day. His body will be cremated at Fresh Pond, L.I., under the direction of the Rev. E.A. Meury, who attended him to the scaffold.

Outside of Sugar and Distilling and Cattle Feeding, there was very little in yesterday's stock market of interest. In the absence of new buying, and on what was considered good evidence of profit-taking on the long side, prices were irrgular. Burlington was under pressure, particularly in the afternoon, and it closed a point down.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- The annual statistical report of the American Iron and Steel Association for 1893 has just been issued. The report is the work of General Manager James M. Swank.
CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 6. -- The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated Col. Henry O. Kent for Governor by acclamation. He was the only candidate before the convention.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 6. -- James Cole- man Drayton's suit for divorce from his wife, Carrie Drayton, gave society a great surprise, for it was generally felt that a separation had been mutually agreed upon and was regarded by the Astors as the wisest course.

CHICAGO, Sept 6. -- Among the insane patients examined by Judge Donnelly to-day was Anton von Karab, son of Count von Karab, who is now a member of the Cabinet of the Emperor of Austria. He was adjudged insane this morning and committed to the Jefferson Insane Asylum.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 6. -- The Wisconsin Democratic Convention to-day renominated George W. Peck for Governor. This action was taken on the third ballot. The platform warmly indorses the Administration, declaring that President Cleveland's course has been wise, patriotic, and courageous, and that it commends itself to the country.

A man who, from papers found in his possession, is believed to be Dr. H.G. Cresson, about forty-five years old, of 1344 South Seventeenth Street, Philadelphia, committed suicide about 10:15 o'clock last night by shooting himself through the head.

-- Postmaster Dayton has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship Belgic arrived at that port last Wednesday with mails from Hongkong. Aug. 1: Shanghai, Aug. 5; Yokohama, Aug. 14; Honolulu, Aug. 28, due to arrive in New-York Sept. 10.

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad yesterday, Directors were elected as follows: Simon Borg, Joseph W. Ogden, James M. Hartshorne, Frank C. Lawrence, Jr., H.O. Armour, Alfred Sully, C. Minzesheimer, Henry Sanford, Harvey E. Fisk, John I. Blair, Garret A. Hobart, Horace W. Fuller, and Roswell Eldridge.

There has been a general revival in all classes of business consequent on the settlement of the tariff question, and the restoration thereby of public confidence. The New-York Times prints interviews to-day which show something of the extent to which the improvement has been felt by the business men of this city.

Judge O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, yesterday granted writs of certiorari in the cases of Capt. Adam Cross, late of the Eldridge Street Police Station, and his ward man, George Smith, who were dismissed from the force by the Police Commissioners on Aug. 31 last. The writs are returnable in twenty days, when the action of the Commissioners may be reviewed.
Messrs. Stabler Smith have sold, for George J. Harlow, to a Mr. Clare, the three-story extension dwelling 43 West Ninety-fifth Street, 17 by 52 by 100, for about 824,500.
The Board of Police Commissioners yesterday found Capt. John Thomas Stephenson of the Tenth Precinct guilty of bribery and dismissed him from the force. The vote to dismiss was unanimous.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 6. -- The Manufacturers Record, in reviewing the business conditions of the South for the past week, says:

-- Testimony is being taken in the Auditorium Hotel, Chicago, in the suit which the Cincinnati and Chicago freight bureaus are prosecuting against the Southern roads for refusing to obey the order of the Inter-State Commerce Commission directing them to reduce rates from Chicago and Cincinnati to Southern points so as to equalize rates with those in effect from New-York.

The announcement, made exclusively in The New-York Times of yesterday, that the estrangement of James Coleman Drayton and his wife, who was Charlotte Augusta Astor, and the merits of her husband's accusations were to be exposed to the fierce light of a legal contest was a source of great mortification to the families of the litigants and hundreds of friends.

While the Grand Circuit trotting meeting at Fleetwood has been somewhat disappointing in the matter of sensational speed, not a day has parsed since Monday when the programme failed to develop one or more exciting and high-class contests.

The success of the strike of the clothing workers must be gratifying to all humane persons, but the success is not more gratifying in itself than in the manner in which it has been obtained. In the first place, the strikers had a tangible and undeniable grievance. They were not entirely unskilled.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The promise of rain which has been in the air for the last few days has brought hope to the hearts of the people of this city, for the reason that they have been told that as soon as the Autumn rains come the quality of the Passaic water will Improve.

"The" Allen, who has recently been keeping on alleged real estate office at 146 Bleecker Street, was taken to the Mercer Street Station by a policeman of the Tombs squad last night charged with violating the pool law. The policeman also had in his custody Henry Livingston, who is said to be a partner of "The" Allen at 146 Bleecker Street, where the real estate office is said to have been a "blind."

There are no longer any croakers at the condition of business. The merchants and business men of all classes in this city have found out, to their satisfaction, that the revival of trade which immediately followed the settlement of the tariff question was not ephemeral, but is keeping up vigorously, and is all the time increasing, gathering momentum as it goes.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 7. -- Secretary Hoke Smith and Speaker Crisp addressed a large and enthusiastic Democratic mass meeting in this city this evening.

CHESTER, Penn., Sept. 7. -- The largest steel plate ever rolled, not only in this country, but in the world, was turned out yesterday in this city by the Wellman Iron and Steel Works. The dimensions of the plate are 450 inches long by 130 Inches wide and 1 1/4 inches thick.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 7. -- More records fell on the famous Springfield track to-day. Early in the afternoon, W.F. Sims of Washington, D. C., mode a successful trial for the unpaced Class A mile, doing 2:16. The record stood at 2:16 4-5, where Louis A. Callahan of Buffalo placed it at Denver as a parting shot before he entered the Class B ranks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The list of eligible candidates for the Governorship you gave the other day contains several Judges. One of them was Judge Robert Earl of the New-York Court of Appeals.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The market was rather quiet to-day. The houses that were active on the bull side of West Chicago ceased operations to some extent, and the result has been a gradual easing off in prices. Sales at the extreme close last night were made at 130 1/4, and the opening this morning was 1/4 below that point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Secretary Carlisle this afternoon issued an official circular regarding the marking, , of goods under Section 5 of the new tariff law, in regard to which much uncertainty of construction has existed. After quoting the section in extenso, the Secretary says:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- W.E. Murray's Memory won the third and deciding yacht race to-day in the series between her and Louis M. Rutherford's Drusilla, and with it the two-hundred-dollar stake, and Mr. Rutherford, the loser, pays all expenses. It was one of the most exciting finishes seen here in years, and though the Drusilla, crossed the line six seconds ahead of the Memory, the latter wins on time allowance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 7. -- Col. Cienfuegos, who is charged jointly with Gen. Ezeta with having killed Thomas Canas. near San Salvador, resumed his testimony before Judge Morrow in the extradition proceedings this morning. The entire morning session was occupied by Cienfuegos, in giving evidence as to the State of politics in Salvador since 1885, when he entered the army.
The system and theory on which the State Reformatory at Elmira is conducted were detailed yesterday to the commission which is investigating that institution.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 7. -- Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks entertained the dancing class at Rockhurst last evening. Reginald Brooks led the cotillion, the favors for which were flowers and pretty boxes tied with ribbons. The floral decorations were more elaborate than has been usual with these entertainments.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 7. -- Frederick Cook returned home this evening from his visit to Senator Hill at Albany.

In his remarks opening the conference of Thursday night in behalf of a combination municipal ticket, Chairman Larocque said that it was a "mistaken notion that municipal government had something to do with State and National politics." Mr. Hewitt, in his letter, declared that the "fundamental condition" of good government for the city is "that it shall be divorced from the control of any political pary."
Some matters of the greatest importance to the Police Department were in abeyance yesterday, and will be undecided until next Week.

The Story now told by Slenator Blackburn is an important contribution to the record of the contest between the House and the Senate over the Senate's additions to the Wilson Tafif bill. It increases the burden of popular condemnation and contempt which Gorman and his fellow-conspirators must bear.

The State Board of Health committee met yesterday afternoon in the offices of the Health Department, Police Headquarters, and continued its investigations into the nuisances alleged to exist in Newtown Creek.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The enormous falling off in United States customs receipts during the pendency of the Tariff bill, gave some idea of the great decrease in the amounts and values of articles exported from foreign countries to the United States during that period, but customs officials and others having to deal with the assessment of duties were hardly prepared for the showing contained in reports received and just complied at the State Department.

-- Marked success has attended the publication in London of Hall Caine's "Manxman," in one volume, instead of in three. The first edition of 20,000 copies was sold in a fortnight, and a second of 5,000 copies has been printed since.
LONDON, Sept. 7. -- Chauncey M. Depew was seen this afternoon by a reporter for the United Press, who asked him whether he would accept the Republican nomination for Governor of the State of NewYork.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The Waverly Fair closed to-day. There were about 7,000 persons on the grounds. The races resulted as follows:

William Steinway, the distinguished Democrat, citizen, and business man, was Interviewed yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times, on the political situation in the city and State and the necessity for Democratic harmony.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 7. -- What promises to be the best race meet ever held in this place will come off to-morrow at the Driving Park, beginning at 2:30 o'clock, under the auspices of the Mercury Wheel Club. One hundred and five entries have been made in the several events, and a plenty of competitors is assured in each race.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 7. -- The movement here for the prevention of the publication of slanderous articles in newspapers is mere talk as yet, but the persons that have taken the matter up are terribly in earnest.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
