Washington, Sept. 7. -- Many thousands of gallons of oil were destroyed this afternoon in a firein the frame storehouse of Nicolai Brothers, oil dealers in the southwestern part of the city. The building was burned to the ground. The gas tanks of the Washington Lighting Company were within 100 feet of the storehouse, but were not burned.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- According to a statement in The National Zeitung, the Emperor in revising the list of guests invited to the state banquet at Koenigsberg last evening cancelled the names of Count von Mirbach, Count von Kanitz-Polangen, and Gen. von Klitzing.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 7. -- Under the caption "Journalism up to Date" this morning's Times says editorially:

The rejection by the Democratic General Committee of Hangs County on Thursday night of the resolutions proposed by Chairman James D. Bell and Bernard J. York, which were intended to reconcile the two Democratic county organizations and unite the party this Fall, was received by the rank and file of the Democratic Party with keen disappointment.

At the opening of the stock market yesterday there was a fair amount of activity, the tendency of prices being toward a lower level. London did very little, but it sold more stocks than it purchased. After the first half hour trading became very dull, but prices were fairly steady.
Messrs. Bennett Graff have sold, for Livingston Dunn, the four-story limestone and Milwaukee brick dwelling 332 West Eighty-eighth Street, 20 by 55 by 102.2.

When the strike of the clothing workers will end is now more uncertain than when it started, notwithstanding the fact that the Clothing Contractors' Protective Association has accepted the terms of the strikers.

Irishmen in this city and Brooklyn are much interested in the convention of the Clan-na-Gael now being held at Philadelphia. The delegates are from every part of the United States, and the chief scheme of those who advocate the "force" policy to free Ireland is to have the convention indorse the Redmond faction, which believes in dynamite and the shedding of blood.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- The decision of the Republicans, as declared through the Committe on Rules to-night, that on Tuesday the calendar of third reading of amendments will be started, and that no other business will be allowed to intervene until this order of business is finished, clearly indicates a determination to crowd out of consideration all subjects not then debated in Committee of the Whole.

Justice Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday decided that Police Justice Quigley had not the right to sentence Andrew Schickling to the penitentiary for nine months for threatening to shoot Mrs. Wilhelmina, Clauss and her brother. Caspar George, of 946 Bushwick Avenue, several weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- "It is the first I have heard of any such offer." said Acting Secretary Uhl of the State Department, when shown a dispatch from Ottawa saying that Sir Charles H. Tupper, Canadian Minister of Marine and Fisheries, had received a dispatch from Victoria telling of the agreement of interested sealers to take the $425,000 offered by the United States Government as a settlement of the dispute about seizures.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Sept. 7 -- The President had as guests at Gray Gables today three members of his Cabinet. The flagship Dolphin came to anchor near Wing's Neck early this forenoon, Secretary of the Navy Herbert coming ashore on the launch.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- The closing hour's debate on the Apportionment bill in the Constitutional Convention to-day was marked by as unseemly an exhibition of partisanship on the part of the Republicans as ever led to tumult and turbulence in the final day of a legislative session.

To take its wit and wisdom in homeopathic doses of varied qualities has become a settled custom at the meetings of the Professional Woman's League, and Round Robin Day comes with as absolute regularity as the days of the week.

-- Edward Welsh and John Clark of One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Third Avenue were sentenced yesterday by Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, to three years and six months each in the State's prison. They broke into the Morningside Presbyterian Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-second Street and Columbus Avenue, before daylight on Aug. 24, and stole the big pulpit Bible and the church clock.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 7. -- The bubble of Republican harmony in Onondaga County burst this evening with a report that has signaled the clans to war again. The Belden City Committee, headed by Dr. J. Wiltsie Knapp and under instruction from James J. Belden himself, met in solemn conclave and resolved to bolt, to ignore completely the decision of the State Committee which they accepted so cheerfully a month ago.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- Bay State Gas has been the feature in our market to-day, declining rapidly 2 points, from 10 3/4, last night's closing. There seems to be a disposition on the part of recent purchasers to go out of the stock; this is due to an impression which is graining ground that the settlement of the Brookline Gas war does not by any means involve the adjustment of the Boston Gas war.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 7. -- It is expected by the cycling sharps that the great tournament here next week will prove to be more of a success than the previous big meets at Hampden Park. If this should prove to be the case, then there will be no doubt of the coming meeting being the very best of the season, not even excepting the great national tournament at Denver.

POKEGAMA, Minn., Sept. 7. -- A courier brings a report that the bodies of twenty-three Chippewa Indians, braves, squaws, and pappooses, lie upon the baked sands between here and Opstead, a small settlement on the eastern shores of Lac Mille Lacs. They are scattered over ten miles of country, and will in all probability become food for buzzards and wolves, as the country where they are is too far from civilization for burial ceremonies.
LONDON, Sept. 7. -- It is reported that the Chinese Government has arranged to buy half of the vessels comprised in the Chilean Navy.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The Committee on Train Rules and the Committee on Safety Appliances of the American Railway Association have been in session at the International Hotel here this week preparing their reports to be presented to the annual meeting of the American Railway Association, which is to be held in New-York in October.

A thick fog which hung over the bay and rivers yesterday was responsible for a number of mishaps. The first of these was a collision between the ferryboat Robert Garrett of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company and an unknown schooner.

Joseph Larocque, who is Chairman of the organization which met at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall Thursday night, said yesterday that he would not name the Committee of Seventy which was authorized by that meeting until next Tuesday or Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- Hilborn T. Cresson, the physician who committed suicide in New-York late last night, as told in The New-York Times to-day, was well known in this city up to within three years ago. At that time he lived at 224 South Broad Street. He was married, and his wife and youngest son are now in Paris.

Interesting details of the meeting of the Executive Committee of the League of American Wheelmen, in Boston early this week, were made public yesterday in the following circular letter, sent out from President Luscomb's office:

The carpenters' strike against the "lumping system" is progressing favorably for the carpenters, as a number of the contractors have agreed to re-employ the men at union rates and abolish the sub-contractors, or "lumpers." Others have expressed a willingness to do so, and about 400 men returned to work yesterday.

Yachtsmen are already beginning to make preparations for next season. Designers are getting out specifications and designs for new boats, and the outlook is very encouraging. A. Cary Smith has had three orders placed already. Two are for yawls and one for a schooner.

The report of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad for the year ended June 30 was issued yesterday. It shows gross earnings amounting to $31,327,950, a decrease of $2,647,104; operating expenses, $20,114,332, a decrease of $2,373,775, and net earnings, $11,213,618, a decrease of $273,328. The total fixed charges are $7,065,215, an increase of $438,532, and the balance on hand is $3,714,732, a decrease of $807,668.

Funeral services in memory of Mrs. Brent Good, who died at the Murray Hill Hotel on Wednesday, will be held to-day at 1 P.M. at Holy Trinity Church, Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street. In the absence of the rector, the Rev. Dr. Walpole Warren, the Rev. Dr. Rice of Jersey City, of whose church Mrs. Good was at one time a member, will officiate.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Gustave Quick, Austin Crook, and Robert Brown, three workmen, while at work on the new addition to the Westminster School Building, at this place, to-day fell from a scaffolding to the ground and were badly hurt. The school building is one of the largest in the vicinity of New-York, and the school numbers among its patrons some of the wealthiest people of Westchester County and New-York City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The second-class battle ship Maine, now at the navy yard in Brooklyn, will have her trial trip up Long Island Sound some time next week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- An attempt was made to-day by the Government's counsel in the contempt cases against Debs and other officials of the American Railway Union, to compel the defendants to produce their documents, records, telegrams, and private correspondence. Judge Woods decided to hear from the prosecution next Tuesday.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The play in the State championship lawn tennis tournament was continued to-day on the Woodlawn Oval before a good-sized crowd, who became very enthusiastic in the finals of the gentlemen's doubles, and the hand clapping resounded like a fusillade of small arms at the brilliant play of Messrs.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept 7 -- The final match of the doubles in the Nyack Country Club's tournament here this afternoon resulted in a victory for Carroll Post and "Jack" Talmadge, who succeeded in defeating J.P. Paret and Bostwick in three straight sets, 6-3, 6-3, 7-5. Post and Talmadge were easy winners, although Paret continued his good work of yesterday, and, together with his partner, Bostwick, fought stubbornly to the end.
STAPLETON, S. I., Sept. 7. -- The inquest into the death of Henry Bergmann, who was killed at South Beach Aug. 16, was completed last night. The jury rendered two verdicts.

"Gus" Zimmerman, the champion sharpshooter of the New-York Independent Schuetzen Corps, came back from Germany on the Columbia yesterday with a trunk full of coveted trophies won in the Fatherland, and the information that more were to follow. Mr. Zimmerman was enthusiastically welcomed at the steamer's pier in Hoboken by a large delegation from the Schuetzen Corps and escorted to Weber's Hotel, where he held a levee.

The latest annual report of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, which was issued in pamphlet form yesterday, is an uncommonly complete and systematic document. The income of the company from all sources during the fiscal year ended June 30, including $10,300 received for interest, was $6,486,343, a decrease of $2,885,877, as compared with the previous year.

TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 7 -- The United States District Court, Judge James W. Locke presiding, began here yesterday the hearing in the cases of the twelve Spanish fishing schooners seized by the revenue cutter McLane in July last for violation of the revenue laws and quarantine regulations.
The sales at auction referred to in the accompanying detailed list will be had at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated:

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 8. -- A handsome new house of Worship is to be erected here by the Calvary Episcopal Church. Plans have already been accepted and work will be begun on the building at once. The new church is to be located on one of the prettiest sites in the park, and will be early English in design.

A well-dressed man, unconscious, lying on Second Avenue near Thirty-seventh Street, was found about 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning by Policeman Crahan. The man's coat and waistcoat pockets had been cut open and his trousers pockets were turned inside out.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 8. -- Thousands have gone. Outdoor sports were prevented by the atmosphere, charged with smoke of the forest fires that the rains of Wednesday and Thursday have quenched, and deer hounding will commence Monday.
Statistics -- There was no death at the Grand Prix of Paris.

State Insurance Superintendent Pierce, with two other officers and four clerks, yesterday, held possession of the office of the Mutual Benefit Life Association of America, at 177 Broadway, which was declared on Friday to be insolvent. The clerks said that President William H. Whiton was the only person who could give any information, and that he never appeared at the office on Saturday.

The Horseshoe Harbor yachtsmen have had hard luck with their annual regatta this year. They postponed it from last Monday to yesterday on account of the high wind, and yesterday they had to sail in heavy rain squalls.
The hotel at 318 Seventh Avenue was the scene yesterday afternoon of a shooting affray which may result in the death of a young woman, who says her name is Florence Edwards.

The White Star line stewards, who constitute the Germanic Athletic Club, had a very pleasant outing at Oak Point yesterday, despite the rain. The programme included a lively set of trade and field games, in which H. Gill again distinguished himself. His aggregate score for the season entitles him to possession of the Ismay Trophy, value 10 guineas.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 8. -- A lawn bazaar and festival for the benefit of the Home for the Crippled Children was held at the home of Mrs. George Mitchell, in Hollywood Avenue, East Orange, on Monday after-noon. The prettily-draped and well-stored booths were in charge of Mrs. Richard Berry, Mrs. R. Ashley, Mrs. H. O'Neill, Mrs. A. McCutcheon, Miss Hattie Skinner, Miss Hattie Berry, Miss Adelaide Baldwin, and Miss Anna Mandeville.

With rain coming down, in sheets and a track that had been converted into a river by the masses of water that had fallen, the racing at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday was something about as far removed from sport as possible.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 8. -- A feature of the third day of the races here was a sudden downpour at rain, coming just when the big event of the meeting was on -- the flat race by gentlemen riders for the valuable silver cup given by the ladles. Gov. Brown and staff were present to-day.

William T. Winsor of 89 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, committed suicide by shooting himself in the right temple with a revolver at the Astor House some time between midnight Friday and noon yesterday. He engaged his room at the hotel three days in advance of his suicide.
MANHATTAN BEACH, Sept. 8. -- David W. G. Bishop of New-York, who inherited the bulk of the late Catherine Lorillard Wolf's fortune, had a narrow escape from being drowned this morning.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 8. -- Greater was the throng at the Union Station to-day than on any previous day, but as yet the great bulk of the crowd to the Grand Army of the Republic encampment has only begun to arrive. Trains coming into the city were late and the addition of an extra section was found necessary on all the through lines.

The Darrows were people of considerable importance in the town of Pergamos, for they attended to this weighty matter themselves. They were four less than the poetical seven, for which general thanks were due. There was Samuel Darrow, husband, father, and ostensible head of the household, portly and arrogant, with a speaking countenance, which said "Get out of my way."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8. -- The death of Josiah Parsons Cooke, Erving Professor of Chemistry and Mineralogy, which took place at Newport Monday last, was not wholly unexpected. When the college year of 1893-4 ended last Commencement Day, it was known that Prof. Cooke was in very feeble health, owing to the severity of the Winter just passed.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 8. -- The last week in August marked the anniversary of an interesting historical event of this city and of Livingston County, for it was fifty-three years ago that the remains of Boyd and Parker, two soldiers of Sullivan's army who were tortured to death by the Indians, were removed from Cuylerville, on the banks of the Genesee River, and buried in Mount Hope Cemetery.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- There was no military post on the Hudson that the British coveted more than West Point. They looked upon that stronghold as a second Gibraltar, and used every strategy to accomplish its downfall. Washington had early foreseen the advantage to be gained by having fortifications of more than ordinary strength on such a commanding position, controlling as it did the principal waterway of the Northern States.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Veto, George Law; Linta, Walter Luttgen; Ortenta, E.R. Ladew; Corsair. J. Pierpont Morgan; Tillie, W. H. Starbuck, and Trophy, E.H. Bennett, Schooner yachts Avalon, Francis L. Leland, and Emerald, J. Rogers Maxwell.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 8. -- During the severe electrical storm which broke over this city this afternoon William Smith, thirty-five years old, of 35 Crawford Street, was struck by lightning and instantly killed on the Government Dyke, in Newark Bay.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept. 8 SEPTEMBER began auspiciously in the Catskllls. The Summer season was one of the best ever known, and it is expected that many of those who made it brilliant will remain until late in October.

Willie Lang, the four-year-old son of Archibald Lang of Blake and Montauk Avenues, Brooklyn, has been missing from his home since Friday afternoon, and it is feared that he has been drowned in the marshes off Old Mill Creek.

From The Washington Post. "That is a sure sign of death," said an elderly lady, who affected extreme girlishness, addressing a young man and his wife -- a petite brunette, by the way -- as they were standing near the south entrance of the Soldiers' Home. The remark was occasioned by hearing a passing horse utter a mournful neigh.

In the desert the mares and foals and stallions stand day and night before their master. There are no grooms in our sense. Black slaves keep the ground clean, and the wives and daughters of the tent folk wait upon the mares, and romance becomes reality when a drooping mare or a motherless foal is taken into the best part of the tent to be nursed.

There was an aggravating delay on the Brooklyn Bridge shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when a wet and angry crowd of Barooklynites who are engaged in business in New-York were anxious to get to their homes.

The study of history by school children may be made easy, entertaining, and vastly profitable, or it may be made difficult, tedious, and almost inconsequential in benefit. All depends on the manner in which the history is, taught -- to speak specifically, an the teacher and the text book. Men whose schooldays date back twenty and twenty-five years wonder sometimes at their slight knowledge of history.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Sept. 8. -- A decision of the Supreme Court of the Territory handed down at noon to-day nullifies all divorces granted by Probate Judges in Oklahoma since March, 1893. Fully 400 divorces have been granted, and as a very large percentage of the persons so divorced have been married since, they are guilty of bigamy.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- It would seem almost incredible that a week before the final adjournment of the Constitutional Convention a call of the house was necessary to transact the business before it. And yet this step was necessary his afternoon, when, upon reassembling after recess, only twenty-one delegates responded to the call of the roll.

There was a race for catboats under the auspices of the Riverside Yacht Club yesterday. Seven boats started in two classes. The judges, ex-Commodore Beltz. W.E. Luke, and W.A. Hamilton, were on the Alcedo. The schooner Nirvana, owned by Commodore Tyson, and J.H. Hanan's steamer Embla accompanied the racers over the course.

James Trainor, thirty-two years old, an ex-convict, of 543 Greenwich Street, and Hugh J. Markey, ninetenn years old, of 229 Hudson Street, were held for trial yesterday morning by Justice Voorhis in the Jefferson Market Police Court for highway robbery.
Here is an instance of superstition in England as late as 1668. It Is in a suit brought against Susan Haynes for possessing supernatural powers:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 8 DECADE or two ago the curtain of the season was generally, by consent or exodus of quests, rang down by Sept. 1. Times and conditions have changed, for at present Saratoga is entertaining thousands of guests, and will continue to do so for several weeks to come.

Has Asiatic cholera found a new home in Russia? The original home of this disease is in India, where the habits of a dense and ignorant population with respect to the use of water tend continually to cause choleraic ailments and fevers. The mortality from fevers in India is appalling.

Pa, with the garden hose, is watering the lawn and Thomas sits lazily by in his canvas chair, smoking as usual, when Gregory appears, carrying a book, which he waves in wild glee, to indicate that he has now found a masterwork, whose glory carping criticism cannot dim.

Palmerston was fifty years in the House of Commons before he led that assembly; and during that half-century, although constantly in office, he had not been a regular speaker, or even a regular attendant in the House. "I can't get that three-decker Palmerston to bear down," Mr. Canning used to say; and Palmerston always hesitated to formulate views upon any subject which was not his special care at the moment.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Private Finnegan of the Sixty-ninth New-York Battalion carried off the honors here to-day by winning the Wimbledon match. The distance was 1,000 yards, position prone, thirty shots. There were thirty entries. Finnegan's score was 116.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Claude Waller, a member, of the firm of Patterson Waller, lawyers, was shot in the groin and probably fatally injured this afternoon by Leo Roeder, chief clerk for Brand Hoffman, lawyers.

We of America are prone to fancy our hunting country stiffer than the Englishman's, and point to the timber of Long Island to bear us witness; but there is so great a dissimilarity between the two that comparison can scarcely be made. They differ totally in that the jumping of one is all open, while with the other it is practically all hidden.

Miss Mary Proctor is the daughter of Prof, Richard A. Proctor, the distinguished astronomer. She is further noteworthy as a young woman who has achieved considerable success in that abstruse science upon her own account, having not only studied and written much concerning it, but also lectured upon it.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The sub-committee of the State Land Board has decided to report favorably on the application of the Niagara River Hydraulic Company for a grant of land under water at Buffalo. The lands applied for surround the riverside of Squaw Island, in the Niagara River, with the exception of a strip over which the International Bridge runs across the middle of the island.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Two Assembly District Democratic Conventions were held in Dutchess County to-day. Both were marked by enthusiasm and harmony. The delegates included Cleveland and Hill men, and the best of feeling prevailed.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 8. -- One of the handsomest houses in Plainfield is that of Corporation Counsel Craig A. Marsh, on Eighth Street. It is Queen Anne in style. Philadelphia green stone, rock-faced, is used in the porch pillars and also upon the lower story, artistically combined with pressed brick and terra cotta.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 8. -- Every day increases the dissatisfaction among all classes of Populists -- except the office holders -- over the record of the "reform" administration and the kind of campaign Gov. Lewelling is making for re-election. Many prominent members of the party came to the convention opposed to the renomination of Lewelling on account of the rumors of official corruption among the State officers.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Although the contest in the Democratic Convention for Greene County, held at Cairo to-day, was animated, it was entirely personal, with no distinction of Snapper and Anti-Snapper's Cleveland, men and Hill men, heretofore so called, united in support of each set of State delegate candidates.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The selling orders in West Chicago the past week cannot be traced to any particular source, although the offering's all came from one broker, who at one time was closely identified with the North and West Chicago Railway system. On the other hand, it is known that the best of buying orders emanated from insiders and from those who already have a large line of the certificates.

New-Yorkers who were born in New-York have under their feet roots of great length, so securely tied under the Boll that it requires frantic efforts to dislodge them. It they go to the seashore they have to send to the bookbinders their unbound books, put pepper in their furs, settle their affairs, and then it is extremely difficult to make them return.

The refusal of the clothing contractors to give bonds individually to the United Garment Workers of America that they will reemploy their striking workmen and keep them at work at union terms for a year has renewed the strike, which it was believed had been settled on Friday.

Prof. Glardon had quitted New-Rochelle for an hour already, and still "he walked' in the woods, his pipe between his teeth, and the load of an ox on his back. He carried an umbrella, a telescope, a folding chair, and a bag made of whip cord filled with food.

From The Chicago Inter Ocean. Mr. Wellman, the Assistant District Attorney, who is pressing the Police Captains so hard, and who is sure to have their scalps in his belt, tells me that the testimony, incriminating as it is, does not begin to tell the story of the extent of the corruption which has been the rule for years in the police force which New-Yorkers have fondly considered the finest in the world.

(Copyright, 1894.) LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The circulation of both notes and coin has expanded during the week, and the reserve in the Bank of England is in consequence nearly u500.000 less than last week, standing now at about u30,500,000.

Christopher Bricklein, a laborer living with his wife, Barbara, and five children in poorly-furnished apartments at 532 East Twelfth Street, while suffering with a hallucination that enemies were after him, leaped from a third-story window into the street, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and only sprained his ankles.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The Rockland County Republican Convention was held at New City this afternoon. Enoch C. Bell of Nyack was Chairman, and George B. Helme, Secretary. A resolution was adopted recommending the name of Senator Clarence Lexow for Governor.

With the beginning of the Fall season a renewed impetus has been given to golf, and from now until wintry weather sets in the game will be played with much enthusiasm by its devotees. The members of the St. Andrew's' Golf Club, at Yonkers, are gradually completing arrangements for the great championship, professional, and amateur contests, which are to come off on their grounds, at Gray Oaks, in October.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The sittings of the Trades Union Congress at Norwich closed to-day. The Moderates made a strenuous protest against the election of two Socialists as members of the Parliamentary Committee, but a majority of the delegates voted to retain both. The result was received by the Socialists with resounding cheers.

Business among the horse dealers last week was quiet, but showed no falling oft in volume over the preceding week. Prices held their own, both at public and private sale, but the influence of the peculiar weather was against activity. The carriagemakers received more inquiries for fine goods than for two months past, but sales were few.
BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 8 IN FORMER, years the 1st of September saw the end of the Summer season here at the Prospect House. This year is an exception.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 8. -- A.L. Cary, who was appointed Special Master to investigate charges made by the Ives faction in the Northern Pacific affairs that Mr. Oakes, as President of that road, had made millions by buying branch lines cheap and selling them at high prices to the Northern Pacific, filed his report to-day.

There is not a neophyte in the politics of Brooklyn who does not know that the rank and file of the Democracy -- the men who vote, but who do not aspire to lead -- want harmony. They want it and they intend to have It.

From The Chicago Times. Can a man fly? Learned professors of the science of aeronautics agree that he cannot, and a formidable commission of experts appointed by the German Government to investigate into the possibilities of aerial navigation have finally and decisively and officially said that it is impossible.

M. van der Mensbrugghe, member of the Academic des Sciences, Brussels, has been investigating the true nature of clouds. It is supposed that clouds are an assemblage of little hollow vesicles, or of little full globules of water, but there is a doubt as to which, and M. van der Mensbrugghe is in favor of the latter hypothesis.

BOSTON, Sept. 8. -- Bay State Gas still remains the only thing of interest in the local market. Sales have been fairly free, though the fluctuation is within 3/4c limit. The air is full of rumors that the stock is going to sink entirely out of sight. These, however, are not substantiated, and the buying at the reduced prices la by pretty good people.

An interesting review of the article in The August Fortnightly Review by Elizabeth Barney, on the "American Sportswoman," is by a writer in The London-Queen, who finds that it facilitates. the comparison between what may be termed the athletic development of women in the United Kingdom and the United States.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 8. -- The last of the hotels, with the exception of Iauch's, was closed yesterday. The Scarboro was closed Monday, the West End Thursday, and the Howland yesterday. The United States was in the hands of the Sheriff early in the week.

The great majority of the churches of England are private property. When a large estate is purchased, the parish church, or churches, go with the rest of the property. The landlord -- or the patron of the livings, as he is caned with reference to his relations to his church property -- chooses the clergyman for every parish on his property and sees to it that the revenue attaching thereto goes to him.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The Count of Parts died at Stowe House at 7:40 o'clock this morning. He began to sink visibly at mid-night, but at intervals was conscious, recognizing the Countess and his children as they bent over him, and murmuring words of affection for them. All the members of his family were around him when he died.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The War Department has a censor of the press. Assistant Secretary Doe, whose few years' services as an Adjutant General of a Western State gave him the highly appreciated title of "General," has added materially to the duty which naturally devolves upon the second head of the department by a critical survey of all that is published in the papers, directly or remotely relating to the War Department and the army.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- Since Mr. Parnell's death Irish politics have been for most people a sort of Serbonian bog, whence proceeded from time to time unintelligible squeaks and groans, and through the obscurity of which vague shadows now and again may be seen flitting about, but no one seriously tried to follow what is going on or to understand what it is all about.

Leather guns are somewhat of a curiosity, the honor of having invented them being a matter of dispute between the nations of Sweden and Scotland. According to one account, they were built of the most hardened leather, girt about with hoops of iron and brass; according to another, they had a core of tin and were bound round with cordage.
"The Senate Committee will meet Monday and transact business," said John W. Goff, hurriedly, at his office yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- When Mr. Cleveland was making up his Cabinet, and before the name of the new Secretary of the Navy had been mentioned, the choice leaning toward the East, Senator Chandler asked a newspaper man if he could tell who was to be Secretary. The newspaper man could not tell.

Anti-Platt Republicans who were in this city yesterday hailed the announcement of Chauacey M. Depew's candidacy as the starting point for an opposition to Mr. Morton which will count in the convention.
Julius Siegl and Sigfried Siegl, two Vienna bankers, were arraigned before United. States Commissioner Alexander yesterday morning on charges of forgery and embezzlement committed in Austria.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 8. -- This was Governor's Day at the State Fair. A big crowd was in attendance, the largest so far at this exhibition. Gov. Flower arrived here last evening. Early this morning, in company with officials of the State Agricultural Society, he drove to the State Fair grounds, where the exhibits were viewed.

It is extremely improbable that genius derives any peculiarly-appropriate nutriment from a fish diet, and it is certain that genius gives no thought to the subject. Mr. Carlyle and Lord Tennyson smoked pipes -- because they were men enough to smoke pipes -- but we do not suppose that cigarettes would have made a decadent of Mr. Carlyle or an "impressionist" of Sir Joshua Reynolds.

The feeling of confidence which has been so manifest during the past fortnight in mercantile circles has caused a similar feeling among real estate men. There is a lack of the listlessness that came near be coining chronic during the past fifteen months, and in its place has come a well-settled impression that realty must share in the prosperity which the new conditions promise.

Army. -- A board, of which Col. R.T. Frank, Second Artillery, is President, and Major G.B. Davis Judge Advocate, And Capt. J.W. Pullman Quartermaster's Department, are members, will meet at Port Monroe, Virginia, to draft rules governing the collection of funds toward a sewer system at that place.

WEST POINT, Sept. 8. -- Mrs. J. Pierpont Morgan and daughters sailed, from Europe last Wednesday. Mr. Morgan has been cruising on his yacht Corsair since their departure. He Is expected at Cranston's about the time his family returns. Painters are brightening up the Morgan residence.

A new writer has appeared upon that always interesting theme, the Arabian horse. This is Major Gen. Tweedie of the English Army, who has been for a number of years past Consul at Bagdad, and who seems to have had excellent opportunities to learn the real facts with regard to this much-discussed subject.
LENOX, Mass., sept. 8 AIN Is all that is needed, to make the Lenox Autumn season one of the gayest and most successful that this resort has ever known.

With the one exception of Distillers, prices at the close yesterday were only fractionally changed from the closings of the previous week. Nevertheless, it looked as if it had been a bear week, because the market generally did not advance, and there were breaks in certain stocks instead of jumps.

NEW-LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The waning season is not dull, for the society' people keep in a whirl while the end approaches. The Fort Griswold House is practically closed to-day, although a special party of about 300 from New-York is to be entertained there to-morrow. The families in the cottages at Eastern Point will not quit while the Autumn weather lasts.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- The Cities Committee has made another effort on home rule, and by a series of contortions that excited the smiles of those delegates who were behind the scenes, has presented a new article to the convention, in the place of that which was slaughtered a fortnight ago. Jesse Johnson, Chairman of the committee, by unanimous consent succeeded in getting the following new scheme before the convention this afternoon:

The cycle meet of the Harlem Wheelmen, upon which a special committee of that enterprising club has been working for many days, takes place at Manhattan Field next Saturday. A large number of prizes are promised for competition, including a diamond pin valued at $300, which will be given to the winner of the five-mile special "open."

-- Daly's Theatre. -- This will be the last week of the Daly comedy company during the preliminary season at Daly's. "A Night Off" will have its final performance to-morrow night, and on Tuesday evening Mr. Daly will revive another of the comedies which have become famous in the repertory of his theatre, "Seven-Twenty Eight."

SHELTER ISLAND, Sept. 8. -- The Sum- mer season, which has been so gay at this place, is fast drawing to a close. Many of the cottagers have rented their homes till the 20th of this month, and a large number of them are still open, but the large hotels will close their doors the first of the week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 8. -- Senator John P. Jones of Nevada, having renounced Republicanism and espoused Populism, will probably aspire to a position of eminence or leadership in the Populist Tanks. But there are obstacles in the pathway of the distinguished advocate of free silver.

There is a strange variety of pawnshops in Germany. We find institutions under public control working side by side with private establishments. The latter lend lower amounts, but at a higher rate of interest, than the royal, state, ducal, county, and municipal pawnshops. In no case, however, can it be more than 24 per cent.

RATON, New-Mexico, Sept. 8 -- The California express, west bound, on the Santa Fe. was ditched at Dillon Junction, two miles south of here last evening. The engine, baggage car, mail car, and express car are a complete loss. Four men were slightly injured.
Hermann Ludwig Ferdinand von Helmholtz, to whom physical science is forever indebted, died in Berlin of a second attack of paralysis yesterday.
On the Brooklyn water front, just south of Fulton Street, an interesting scene is to be witnessed these days.
Some one has remarked that the greatest pleasure a woman derives from a Summer in the country is an occasional day in town. Shopping in a strange town is the keenest delight.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 8. -- The diamond tournament of the Springfield Bicycle Club on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday of next week gives early indication of being the chief event of the year. Nearly everybody of prominence in the cycling world will be here, and for the first time this season all the acknowledged fast men will be in line.

To the great majority of Americans, a term which the dwellers in Uncle Sam's domain seem to have monopolized, the Dominion of Canada is practically an unknown land. They have learned a little about Montreal, Quebec, Toronto, and the smaller towns which dot the shores of the broad St. Lawrence and the northern coast of Lake Ontario.

"While we have been away this Summer," relates a woman, "my little girls, eleven and thirteen respectively, learned for the first time that by reading three chapters every week day and five on Sunday the Bible could be finished in a year. They forthwith resolved to begin, and all would have been well, except that there was only one Bible between them.

For days the sun has looked like a Japanese lantern hung in the sky, and in spite of clouds and haze many of us grow weary of looking for rain. There is no mystery about these dark days, for the forest fires fully account for them. Nevertheless, special observations have been taken throughout the country, and wise men are studying the dust collected from the air, and hope to make some important discoveries.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- The Hon. Joseph O. Miller, Chinese Inspector for the Port of Boston, will not comply with the special order of the Treasury Department issued yesterday, transferring him to the Portland (Me.) district. "I will not go to Portland and I will not accept the transfer, as I do not wish to get further away from my family, which is residing in New-York.
The $11 received Friday by The NewYork Times from "M. B." for the fire sufferers was delivered yesterday to Acting Mayor McClellan, to be added to the fund in his possession.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- The market opened, strong. St. Paul was a half point over yesterday's closing. After the first few hours dullness reigned, and continued to do so until the close. Choctaw, first assessment paid, gained its assessment, and advanced to 7 8/4. The reorganization is now complete, and the stock bids fair to become active, at higher prices.

With the rain that fell yesterday to end the long drought was an accompaniment of vivid lightning and loudly-reverberating thunder. It was a pyrotechnic display that brought danger, however, to this city and surrounding towns.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 8. -- A pretty lawn party and fair were held last night on the grounds at Ryerson and Bloomfield Avenues by members of the Caldwell Methodist Episcopal Church. An excellent musical programme was provided.

The Varuna Boat Club held its twentieth annual regatta yesterday off the clubhouse, foot of Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn. Judging from the number of interested spectators, many of whom were ladies, the rain and damp weather did not keep any truly enthusiastic lovers of boating away. The upper balconies of the clubhouse were filled with guests, and the large main room on the ground floor was tastefully decorated with Sags and bunting.

SALEM, Mass., Sept. 8. -- An article in The Sunday Times of Sept. 2 recalled the ancient maritime glory of this port. A substantial monument of old-time commercial prosperity remains in the imposing Custom House, which faces the deserted wharves and maintains for old Derby Street something: of its former pomp and circumstance.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 8. -- New-York lawyers, headed by Mr. Foltz, appeared yesterday in the State Attorney's office and asked that Indictments for conspiracy be returned against James A. Brady and H.W. Nolan, comprising the law firm of Brady Nolan; Hiram C. Stout, and D. Spencer.

Potato fields flourished thirty-five years ago on the level plain at the foot of Lookout Hill, Brooklyn, and where the reaches if Prospect Park Lake now invite the eye, arm hands industriously dug the weeds and heaped mounds or earth around the green vines.

A most gratifying feature at the Wild West last week was the presence of so many children. Now that vacation has drawn to a close, and the little folks must again take up their text books, there was a universal desire among them to see this unique, original, and instructive exhibition.

In "The Bauble Shop." at the Empire Theatre Tuesday night, John Drew will be seen for the first time since his name has been printed on the bills in big letters in a sentimental rale. "The Masked Ball" was frankly a farce, while "Butterflies," while somewhat apart from that order of dramatic composition, was not at all above it.
JEFFERSON, N. H., Sept. 8. -- Those persons who praise September in the mountains praise clear, pure air and variety of colors.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- Emperor William's Koenigsberg speech is the universal topic. The divine right of Kings is discussed the whole length and breadth of the empire, and every editor is expressing his opinion as to what may or may not be done "by the grace of God." The Radical and Social Democratic dailies teem with adverse criticism.

-- The collection of portrait sketches, single and in groups, ascribed to John Trumbull and shown for some months last Spring by Messrs. Dodd, Mead Co., is still for sale. It is owned by Mr. Edward Frossard, coin and medal expert, 108 East Fourteenth Street. He obtained it from a Virginian, who claims to have Inherited it from his maternal grandfather.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept 8. -- Secretary Hoke Smith, who spoke here last night, announced that he will remain in the South until October. He will deliver a number of speeches of a political nature, and has already accepted an invitation to speak at a meeting of Democratic clubs at Raleigh on the 20th inst.

George Wilbur Peck, whom the Democrats of Wisconsin have placed in nomination for a third term as Governor of that State, was born Sept. 28, 1840, at Henderson, Jefferson County. N.Y. In 1843 he went to Wisconsin with his parents and settled in the namesake of his home county. He received a common-school education, and learned the printing trade, following this occupation until 1863, when he enlisted in the Fourth Regiment, Wisconsin Cavalry.

The King of Siam, P.P.M. Chulalonkorn, whose reported death last week created a good deal of excitement in Europe, is, this month, forty-one years old. He came to the throne at his father's death, Oct. 1, 1868.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 8 LAIN are the signs that the gay season is almost over. Newport has had its annual rush of entertainments of all sorts, and now the quieter pleasures are in order, and in the next few weeks outof-door attractions.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- It is well known that a certain large section of the State of New-York lying near its centre has been the market maker for the entire hop product of the United States until within the last few years. This section Includes the greater part of Oneida County and not a small section of Madison County.

The heavy rain yesterday interfered with the finish of the postponed programme at the Grand Circuit trotting meeting: at Fleetwood Park. When the horsemen gathered at the track in the morning a good deal of rain had already fallen, and by fits and starts the showers continued until late in the afternoon, when a deluge of rain came camme down.

I have in my possession a letter signed by the assistant editor of an evening London paper, asking me to secure an engagement at the promenade concerts for a young lady, a friend of the editor's wife. It includes this sentence: "When she comes out there, Mr. -- expects us to give especially good notices of the concerts, and, of course, we shall do so."

PARIS, Friday, Aug. 10. -- How hard it seems to be to grow old gracefully! I am not thinking of women, for to my mind would rise Queen Victoria, who certainly takes her years with pleasant welcome, variation, and kindliness; and then, too, that lonely Countess de Pourtales, who will never be old, even if thrice a bonne-maman.

The rain thrashed the decks; at intervals the glass paled to a dim violet glare of listant storm: this, perhaps, reconciled most of us to our imprisonment. The steward oustled about with glasses and drink; and (the ladies consenting) the Colonel and Mr. jackson smoked cigars.

If there are any residents of Brooklyn with aches and pains who are anxious to keep all knowledge of them from their friends -- it would be a remarkable instance of reserve, but such a thing might happen -- and if, having this feeling, they hesitate to consult a doctor, for fear of being discussed as a "case," they may dismiss their fears.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Sept. 8. -- "Gen." J. S. Coxey was very busy opening his campaign to-day, and in trying to find twenty farmers willing to give twenty horses to help haul his circus over the road. He has personally supplied twenty horses.

The match game of billiards between William Sexton of this city and Edward McLaughlin of Philadelphia will begin in Maurice Daly's new academy. Broadway and Thirty-first Street, tomorrow night. The men will play the balk-line game, 1,500 points. In blocks of 250 each night. Sexton is the ex-champion, and is better known as "Old Comanche."

One would think that the female convict would be the last person in the world to think of personal adornment, but this, it seems, is not so. The majority of convicts are pronounced, by some one who has looked into the matter, to be the vainest of the vain daughters of Mother Eve.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- An interesting and important competitive test has been conducted at the naval proving ground, Indian Head, to discover the best material for shields for the secondary battery of war ships. These shields are intended principally for the protection of the gunners of the six-pounders, and usually are not more than one inch in thickness.

TRENTON, Sept. 8. -- Enthusiasm over the good-road movement is indicated by the fact that to-day the people of Mercer County had a jubilee, with a brass band and speeches from prominent citizens. The occasion was the completion of the macadamizing of the old Scotch Road, leading through Ewing Township into the City of Trenton.

The sixth race for the twenty-one-footers in the Larchmont series was sailed yesterday in a heavy rain squall. It was anything but a pleasant day for yachting, but every one made the best of the bad weather and a rattling good race was the result.

There was very little that was of interest in yesterday's stock market. Sugar was the most active stock, and the trading in it was considerably less than 9,000 shares. Distilling and Cattle Feeding and St. Paul were the only other stocks in which more than 6,000 shares were done. Fluctuations were exceedingly narrow.

No little curiosity has been occasioned this season among the Summer residents of that fine old Connecticut town of Litchfield by the number of flags which have been seen day after day waving gayly in the breeze from the tops of some of the loftiest trees occupying commanding positions on prominent hills or knolls.

With faces tanned by country suns and ocean breezes, and minds and bodies reinvigorated by rest, Brooklyn's preachers will return this morning to their pulpits and resume the campaign against sin which was temporarily suspended during the hot season.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 9. -- The question of Constitutional revision promises to be one of the leading issues in Connecticut in the coming campaign. The time-honored document which stands as the organic law of this State, in the same terms almost as when it was adopted in 1818. it is felt cannot last much longer.

John McElvaney died in Bellevue Hospital yesterday of a fractured skull. C. Reilly Solomon, one of his employers, stated last evening that he intended to ask the hospital authorities to invsetigate the manner in which the patient had been treated.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Benjamin F. Haggerman, son of E. Haggerman, a wealthy merchant of 1329 Marshall Street, Philadelphia, is locked up at the City Hall, charged with burglary.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Louise Bergenthal, thirty-five years old, wife of Henry Bergenthal, Superintendent of the National Distilling Company, was found dead in bed this afternoon by Officer William Hase at her residence, 647 Twenty-ninth Street. Two eras jets were turned wide open in the room, and the gas had filled the whole house when the officer broke in the front door.

From The Pall Mall Gazette. Sir: In the paragraph on the Britannia and Vigilant flasco in your issue of the 20th inst. you are inclined to the view that the success of each yacht in its own waters shows "the superiority of the American yacht designer to be merely local and not general."

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Another one of the "greatest schemes on earth " has come to grief. Between forty and sixty Newarkers have for the last ten days been wondering just where they will stand when the Industrial Land Development Company and its affairs are settled, for what was promised to be a never-ending source of profit and wealth to those interested has proved a failure.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent. throughout the week.

From The Newark Daily Advertiser. The final supremacy of English over all the languages of the world was the subject of one of the most interesting papers read before the American Social Science Association at its recent session at Saratoga. This is a question about which there can be but one opinion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The first reciprocity arrangement under the McKinlely law was entered into Feb. 1. 1891, with Spain, to secure trade with Cuba and Puerto Rico. On April 1, 1891, an arrangement was effected with Brazil. Another arrangement was made with San Domingo Sept. 1, 1891. On Feb. 1, 1892, arrangements were made with Salvador, British West Indies, and with British Gulana.

The stock market was not active last week, although there was considerable business in a few of the specialties. The developments in the commercial world continued, to indicate increasing business activity, and there is no longer room for doubting that an end has come to the long period of depression.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- The seventeenth army Corps manoeuvered near Schlotitten yesterday. The western division made an advance. The commander of the eastern division sent forward cavalry to attack the enemy's right wing. Two hussar regiments led the charge, which was executed magnificently, despite the unevenness of the ground.

The retirement on Thursday last of Admiral Erben and the consequent promotion of Commodore Meade may be said to have completed one of the most remarkable series of advancements to flag rank ever accomplished by the combined action of the officers concerned, the Navy Department, and Congress.

At the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, Boulevard and West Sixty-eighth Street, last evening, the pastor, the Rev. Madison C. Peters, in his prelude spoke against the granting of State aid to sectarian Institutions. Among other things he said:

Although severely handicapped by the inclement weather, the games of the Printers' Benevolent Association were brought to a fairly satisfactory close in Harlem River Park Saturday. The athletes entered seemed to revel in the deluge and the sloppy going it occasioned, and very few declined the combat.

London Sketch gives a picture of a curious wedding ceremony which has been celebrated at Christ Church, under the axispices of the New-Zealand Dress-Reform Association. The bride, Miss Kate Walker, and the bridegroom, Mr. J.R. Wilkinson, had already joined hands by publishing a pamphlet on "Dress Reform and What it Implies."
To picture the surroundings of a hospital one does not outline a goose market on one side and a boiler shop on the other.

W.M. Wilkison, Alexander Salvini's manager, arrived in New-York on the French Line steamship Le Bourgogne yesterday morning. Mr. and Mrs. Salvini had expected to sail from Havre on the same steamship. They were detained at Havre, however, by the illness of Mrs. Salvini. They sailed Saturday for New-York on La. Champagne.

From The Boston Journal. So far as the terminology of the game is concerned, the Sunday golfers of Weston were in a scrape. For one of the troubles of the golf players in Scotland is " the little hole which the rabbit makes in the sward in its first efforts at a burrow; this is commonly called a rabbit's scrape, or simply a scrape.

This will probably be the last week of really active tennis in and near New-York, though all the clubs will keep their courts open until frost stops out-door play. There are several unfinished tournaments to be disposed of, and two or three new ones will be started. The East Orange and Orange Clubs will begin to-day, the Orange tournament having been postponed last Saturday on account of rain.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 9. -- The Browns and Brooklyns broke even to-day. Out of ten times up Connor hit safe eight times, one of them a home run. Lucid was knocked out of the box in the first inning of the second game and Kennedy finished it. Clarkson was batted out in the second and Hawley took his place. Breitenstein was fined $10 and indefinitely suspended for refusing to replace Clarkson.

A neatly-dressed woman, whose identity is unknown, committed suicide at the bridge station of the Brooklyn elevated railroad shortly after 10 o'clock last night by throwing herself under Locomotive No. 15 while it was backing out of the station from a train it had brought from Greenwood.

The strike of the clothing makers against the task system and for an advance of wages was continued yesterday, although several contractors were said to have yielded to the demands of the men. The antagonism to the Knights of Labor, however, was manifest throughout the proceedings of the leaders of the strikers.
Tobias Cart, Captain of the big ice canalboat Patrick Dwyer, lying at the foot of West Sixteenth Street, fell overboard yesterday morning and was drowned.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 8. -- The week in the local stock market has been one of dullness. It was so devoid of feature and there were so few changes in quoted prices that comment is unnecessary, and the quotations as given below will tell the story.

The Rev. Dr. George F. Pentecost of the Marylebone Presbyterian Church, London, preached in the Rev. Dr. John Hail's Presbyterian Church, in Fifth Avenue, yesterday, a sermon on literary criticism of the Bible. His text was from the second book of Peter, i., 19: "The sure word of prophecy."

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Sept. 9. -- The cloudburst here last night did damage to the extent of $60,000. The flooded district is more than a mile square, and extends toward the Monocacy Valley, and includes portions of Bethlehem proper, West Bethlehem, and South Bethlehem. Residences in many places were flooded to their second stories.
VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 9. -- Honolulu advices, per steamship Warrimoo, under date of Sept. 1, say:

Our Newport correspondent averred in last Saturday's Times that a large number of persons in Newport are disgusted and annoyed at the invasion of their private affairs that has been made by various newspapers. There is nothing at all surprising in this statement. The only wonder is that it was not made months and years before.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 9. -- T.H. Aldrich, ex-General Manager of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, has announced himself as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Ninth District. He is a brother to W.F. Aldrich, the millionaire coal operator who is the Republican nominee in the Fourth District. T.H. Aldrich will get the nomination, and, like his brother, will receive support from Populists and Kolbites.
CONEY ISLAND, Sept. 9. -- More than 40,000 persons were here this afternoon, and the majority remained until the last train left, the weather being very warm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- A lone traveler came to the capital the other day, soon after the dreary season set in, with very little business to attend to, and an unsatisfied desire to see some of the sights, in spite of the hot weather and the very obvious fact that, Congress being away, there was nothing much to be seen alive this side of the Zoo.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The Constitutional Convention will utilize every available moment during the coming week, when it is expected that final action on about all of the amendments which are to be submitted to a vote of the people this Fall will be taken.

Capt. Eason of the Classon Avenue Police Station, Brooklyn, and his policemen raided the establishment known as the Governors' Club, 990 Bedford Avenue, early yesterday morning, and arrested the proprietor, Daniel Leahy, and George B. Walters of 43 Tillary Street; Joseph E. Patterson of 703 Union Street, William H. Seymour of 751 Lafayette Avenue, and James Murray of 5 Quincy Street.

The Lexow committee will resume its sessions in this city to-day. Whether it will prosecute its inquiries continuously or adjourn over the period of the political conventions of next week and the week after is an unsettled question, but the general impression is that it will adjourn at the end of this week to the 1st of October.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The Morning Post will print to-morrow this dispatch from Shanghai:

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Despite the heavy downpour of rain yesterday afternoon the annual ladies' regatta of the Sea Cliff Yacht Club was sailed. Owing to the storm it was after 5 o'clock when the boats were ready to start. Only three took part in the race. Each had a number of ladies on board. The yachts and their fair crews were:

From The Denver Daily News. The recent and sudden growth of the Jewish population in Palestine is hailed in many quarters as the beginning of the realization of the dream of centuries, the first practical step toward the restoration of the Jews to their ancient lands. The movement has undoubtedly assumed surprising strength.

The conference of so many prominent Republicans in Albany Saturday, who discussed ways and means of defeating ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt's Gubernatorial candidate had the effect of interfering somewhat with the Tloga statesman's Sunday rest and peace of mind yesterday.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Bound East. -- Steam yachts Lagonda, Edwin Gould; Vision, Clarence McKim; Alicia, H.M. Flagler; Lorna, W.L. Stone. Schooner yachts Palmer, Rutherford Stuyvesant; Viator, W.G. Brokaw; Agnes, J. Norton Winslow. Sloop yachts Moccasin, N. D. Lawton; Nirvana, John Moller, Jr.

The Senatorial investigation of the NewYork Police Department will be resumed today. The Lexow committee will come together once more at 10:30 o'clock this morning, in Part I. of the Superior Court, in the County Court House.

The Roman Catholic Church has grained a convert from Episcopalianism in the person of the Rev. Walter Clayton Clapp. The Rev. Mr. Clapp was received into the Catholic Chuch Friday by the Rev. Father Elliott, at the Paulist Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

WINFIELD, L. I., Sept. 9. -- Mary Fisher, thirteen years old, whose home is in NewYork, and who has been deaf and dumb for eight years, recovered speech and hearing last evening, after having been stunned by lightning.

Mrs. William T. Winsor arrived at her home, 89 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, from Margaretville, Delaware County, yesterday, and arranged to have her husband's body removed there from Naughton's undertaking shop, in Mott Street, to-day. She remained in her house, and refused to see any callers.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- The local security market was fairly active this week. Transactions were reported in Municipal Gas, Albany Railway, and Hudson River Telephone stocks and in Union Railway of New-York bonds. Although there appeared to be an increase in the amount of stock offered, the sales were nearly all made at advancing figures.

From The Albany Evening Journal. Gen. Charles W. Darling of Utica, Corresponding Secretary of the Oneida Historical Society, has prepared the following article on the first Bible printed in English in America:

The statements made by Mrs. Addie Flower Brow at Detroit, reflecting on St. Martha's Home, 34 West Twenty-second Street, were all denied by the sister in charge yesterday. It was also said that no one was known to the institution by the name of Mrs. Addie Flower Brow.

Mr. Curzon has already published two excellent books, one on "Russia in Central Asia," the other on "Persia." The present volume is the first installment of a work upon the kingdoms and principalities of the far East, or the countries that lie between India and the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan, China, Corea, Tonquin, Anam, Cochin China, Cambogia, and Siam.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- It is too early to say what effect the Emperor's speech will have on the Agrarian opposition. The noblemen at the head of the Agrarian League have given no clear sign of response, whatever their intentions may be. They are still sullen and discontented.

The General Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County, of which Edward M. Shepard is Chairman, in view of the recent events indicating inability to unite with the organization of which James D. Bell is Chairman, has decided to send a delegation of its own to the convention at Saratoga.
Three hundred and thirty thousand children will be wending their way toward their respective schoolhouses this morning, after a vacation extending over two months.

When it was decided at the anti-Tammany conference last Thursday evening to appoint a Committee of Seventy, the notion seemed to prevail that prestige would be gained by adopting the number of the famous committee of 1871. But there is no analogy between the situation of that time and the present situation, and no similarity in the functions which the committee is to exercise.

Alfred Strong, seven years old, son of James Strong, a coachman of 268 Warren Street, was crossing Smith Street at 6 o'clock last night, when trolley car No. 209 of the Brooklyn and Coney Island Railroad (Smith Street Line) came along at a high rate of speed. Before the boy could get out of the way he was knocked down and crushed under the forward wheels.

Robert A. Thompson, an advertising agent well known to many business men of New-York, Boston, and Philadelphia, was found dead in his room in the Coleman House, Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday morning. The gas in the room was turned on, and Deputy Coroner O'Hare, who viewed the body within two hours of the time of its discovery, said that death had resulted from asphyxiation.

Athletes all over the country are preparing for the Amateur Athletic Union Championships which will be decided at Travers Island next Saturday. All the athletes in this country and in Canada who can come anywhere near championship form will take part in these contests, and the games are likely to prove the best that have been held in this vicinity for a long time.
Merchants, almost without exception, continue to report active business resumption.
MINDEN, La., Sept. 9. -- Link Waggoner, a noted desperado of North Louisiana, and Eastern Texas, was shot to death in his cell in the parish jail by a mob at 1 o'clock this morning.
Nellie Sweeney, twelve years old, living with her parents in the second-floor tenement, back, of 535 Kast Fifteenth Street, tried last night for the third time within a year to kill herself.

The New-York Tribune Was moved to make some remarks yesterday concerning: the Sugar Trust and the duties on sugar. "The Republican Party," our neighbor said -- " -- has even greater reason than it had in 1890 to refuse any duty on imported sugar and any favor whatever to the Sugar Trust.

Gov. McKinley took up the tale of woe at Bangor, Me., on Saturday night, recited all the disasters that the Democratic Party had brought upon this once happy land, and appealed to the misguided Republicans who have been voting the Democratic ticket to come back under the Republican banner and rally once more to save their country from the ruin already so far accomplished that only their united efforts will rescue anything from the wreck.

Willie tang, the four-year-old son of Archibald Lang, who was reported to the police of Brooklyn on Saturday as missing, and who, It was feared, had been drowned in the marsh near Old Mill Creek, in the Twenty-sixth Ward, near which he had been seen, has been found.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 9. -- Alarming rumors have been coming in here since 6 o'clock this evening to the effect that forest fires are to-night sweeping several counties of Northeastern Minnesota.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The railroad wreck a short distance from the central shaft in Hoosac Tunnel Saturday night was one of the worst which ever took place in this vicinity. By it two men lost their lives and three others were very seriously injured. A freight train had to stop in the tunnel to repair a break on the engine.

The Boston Zingari cricket team, under the management and Captaincy of R. Turner, will start a week's cricket with the metropolitan clubs this morning. They were to have played here last July, but were unable to come at the last moment, and the trip was then postponed. The first match will be played against the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston this morning.

The Rev. Dr. Louis A. Banks, pastor of the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, as a prelude to his sermon last evening, spoke on "Promises of Deliverance for the White Slaves of the Sweat Shops." In the course of his remarks he said:

Charles H. Nichols, thirty-two years old, who gave his residence as 342 Lexington Avenue, this city, and his occupation as a broker, was arraigned yesterday in the Tombs Police Court on a charge of attempted larceny, and was remanded by Justice Grady under $2,500 bail for a hearing Tuesday. He was unable to get bail.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 9. -- The efforts of The New-York Times to convince the Jersey City authorities that public health demanded a new water supply, and that the city's financial interests have suffered and would suffer more because of the imposition, of taxes for vile Passaic water, have been successful.

National encampments of the Grand Army of the Republic have now been familiar for nearly a generation, yet these annual meetings of veteran soldiers can never fail to attract the sympathetic interest of the people.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- Attorney General Knowlton proposes to make a determined effort to compel the American Sugar Refining Company to comply with the laws of the Commonwealth. Some time ago he filed an information in the Supreme Court, and from the subsequent decision of Judge Barker the corporation appealed to the full bench of the Supreme Court. That appeal is now pending.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 10. -- The biennial convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen was called to order here to-day with about 400 delegates present. The only business of importance was the submission of Grand Master Sargent's report.

"Reciprocity" was so distinctly a party cry during the campaign of 1892 that the facts regarding trade with the countries south of us were pretty generally ignored, misunderstood, or misrepresented, and for this the speakers and writers of one party were about as much responsible as those of the other.
"I should like to have now one of those cool weeks we had in August," sighed one of the public-school teachers yesterday morning, as she passed her handkerchief over her flushed cheeks.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Local securities have been fairly active and strong. West End Street Railway common continued its recent advance to 57, closing at 56 1/2; the preferred sold at 79 3/4 for odd lots. Bay State Gas stock and bonds sold off at the opening, the stock being quoted at 7 1/2, but recovered later, selling as high as 8 5/8, and closing at 8 1/2.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The first performance of Charles H. Hoyt's latest work, "A Black Sheep," was given here to-night at the Academy of Music.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Secretary Carlisle has addressed the following official letter to Commissioner Miller of the Internal Revenue Bureau, on the subject of alcohol:

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- The Republican Party began the last week of the convention by playing into the hands of the corporations, by defeating the Roche proposition to compel the Legislature to bond the state for $12,000,000 to improve and enlarge the canals. With this proposition out of the way, Mr. Baker of Oswego offered a resolution that the Legislature be authorized to enlarge and extend the capacity of the canals.

Mr. Joseph Mauley of Maine, who is credited with a large share of the brains in the Republican politics of that State, is reported to have taken the occasion of Mr. McKinley's visit to announce that Mr. Thomas B. Reed will be a strong candidate for the Republican nomination for the first place on the national ticket.
The Brooklyn "Board of Accidents," as the Aldermen of the City of Churches have come to be known, met yesterday afternoon for the first time in four weeks.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 -- The attendance at the races to-day showed a decrease, and the committee decided not to put up another card for Wednesday, as intended. The meeting, therefore, is closed.

It is evident that the Constitutional Convention will not be able to finish its work this week, and the law provides that the delegates shall receive no pay after next Saturday. The purpose of that provision was to secure prompt action and the completion of the process of revising and amending the Constitution in time to have the result submitted to a vote of the people at the election of this year.
Karl Friedrich Brugsch. Karl Friedrich Brugsch, Brugsch Pasha, the Egyptologist, died in Berlin yesterday. He was born in Berlin Feb. 18, 1827.
T. Thomas Fortune writes to The NewYork Times to say that in the last Congress a resolution was offered by Congressman Blair directing an investigation into the lynchings in the South.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 10 -- Gov. Northen, replying to a telegram asking his views concerning the English committee sent here to investigate and denounce Southern lynchings, makes the following statement:

The revival of trade and the restoration of public confidence consequent on the settlement of the tariff question are accepted facts which no New-York business men, in the face of the facts and their cheerful experience, are desirous of disputing.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A dispatch from Shanghai says that, according to the statements of Chinese officials, the Japanese war ship Hiyei, after an engagement with the Chinese cruiser Chen-Yuen, sank while endeavoring to reach Japan in order to make repairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- It is well known that Philadelphians are heavy holders of West Chicago Cable stock. A member of a prominent Philadelphian brokerage house made his appearance upon the Exchange this forenoon, and this was taken as an indication of a rise in the stock, as the Quaker City generally lumps large blocks of these certificates whenever the market is abnormally low.

?Twenty-five tennis players entered the Orange Tennis Club's championship tournament, which began yesterday afternoon on the club's pretty courts, at Montrose. Eight teams entered for the doubles prize. The play had just been fairly started when the rain stopped the contests for the day. Only four matches were finished in the singles, and nothing was done in the doubleThe winner of the singles will challenge Duncan Candler for the Orange Cup. The scores follow:

The fate of the North American Phonograph Company, capitalized at $6,600,000 in 1888 and virtually declared bankrupt, with $25,000 assets on its original capital and with $300,000 debenture bonds, illustrates the fickleness of the public in a scientific fad.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 10 -- The famous sword of Gen. Wolfe, which J.C. Patterson, Minister of Militia, has bought at the cost of $1,500 for presentation to the people of Canada, has arrived here.
Wheat closed steady at 1/4@3/8 c decline, with a dull trade, and influenced by the weakness West, and longs realizing.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 10 -- The manner in which Henry Villard unlawfully enriched himself at the expense of the Northern Pacific Railroad is described in Master in Chancery A.L. Gary's report at great length. It appears that Villard derived the greatest profits from the purchase by the Northern Pacific Company of the Manitoba lines which were started and developed by Villard for the sole purpose of selling them to the company.

MONTICELLO, Iowa, Sept. 10 -- The annual encampment of the First Regiment of the Iowa National Guard ended last night. The regiment was to break camp this morning, but about 150 of the militiamen did not wish to stay in camp all night, and at about 11 o'clock made a rush through the line.
The heat yesterday combined with the great amount of humidity, caused a number of prostrations.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 10 -- Residents of this city are overjoyed to know that at last they are to have a new and pure water supply, and to-day they freely expressed their thanks for the unceasing and vigorous and finally successful struggle made by The New-York Times in their interest.

A circular has been issued by the Protective Committee of Atchison stockholders asking for proxies to be used in electing an entirely new Board of Directors at the annual election, to be held in Topeka, Kan., on Oct. 25. The circular Says: "Certain Directors have been for years in financial control of the Atchison property.

The first race of the series between Wilmer H. Hanan's catboat Almira and W.E. Elsworth's catboat Mary was sailed yesterday. The stakes are $100 a side, and, as the boats are very evenly matched, considerable interest is being taken in the contests. The races are being managed by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, F.B. Jones, Fred Doremus, and W. Osborn, Jr., being the Regatta Committee.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Sept. 10 -- The town of Dalton, Ohio, eight miles from this city was fired by an incendiary this morning and forty-seven buildings, exclusive of barns, were burned, entailing a loss of $250,000 and rendering eleven families destitute.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- I.E. Dean of Honeyoe Falls, Chairman of the Populist State Committee, has arrived in town, and opened headquarters at the Commercial Hotel. A meeting of the committee will take place to-morrow morning to perfect the preliminary organization of the State Convention, which will be held to-morrow and Wednesday.

John Gorman, who has signed an engagement to box "Jack" Skelly at the Seaside Athletic Club next Monday night returned from a week's work at Long Branch yesterday. From now on up to the 17th he will do his work at Coney Island. He looks and says that he is in first-class condition. If he wins he wants a bout with Lavigne.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- William Barnes, Jr., the Republican State Committeeman, will control the delegation from Albany to the State Convention, and this is equivalent to a majority of the twentytwo delegates for Levi P. Morton for Governor.
The Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press" furnished its newspaper clients and their readers with the usual penny-dreadful sensation on Saturday.

Miss Josie was the prima donna. There might have been some dispute about the honors, but Miss Josie introduced an original minuet divertissement that wasn't on the programme at all and made a distinct hit. Miss Josie was the lady bareback rider. She wore a beautiful orange-scarlet or scarlet-orange silk gown, artistically trimmed with white lace, that set off the grayish pallor of her complexion to perfection.

The General Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County, of which organization Edward M. Shepard is Chairman, held an enthusiastic meeting in the Brooklyn Atheneum last night, and decided by almost a unanimous vote to ignore the old Democratic organization, of which ex-Police Commissioner James D. Bell is Chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- The market opened with a demand for stocks far exceeding the supply, and quotations were rushed up accordingly. There are few stocks for sale at present prices, and although traders hammered all day, only a fractional concession rewarded their efforts. Choctaw was strong; the buying was of the very best.

-- Eden Musee. -- The return of Dr. Parkhurst caused many visitors to pause before the excellent wax reproduction of the reformer at the Eden Musee last night.
