Thousands of people have been attracted to this popular resort by the superior afternoon and evening concerts by Danko Gabor's Royal Gypsy Band. The concert last night was exceptionally good.

The conference committee of the striking carpenters, consisting of three delegates from each of the four unions involved in the strike, remained in session from 8 o'clock until midnight at 8:45 Third Avenue last night, with the contractors from whose buildings workmen have been withdrawn.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- The final tests of the pneumatic battery were made this afternoon before Lieut. Heath of the Ordnance Board, and R.T. Kinsman, President of the Pneumatic Torpedo Construction Company, and W. De B. Wilmot, Frank Creelman, and Capt. John Rapier, all of the torpedo company.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The delegates chosen last Saturday evening to the Republican Convention, which will meet Wednesday afternoon at Ballston Spa, are divided in the Gubernatorial choice between Warner Miller, Levi P. Morton, and Controller James A. Roberts, as to their personal and factional predilections, without either having a definite majority.

The Harlem Opera House was thrown open for the season last night, somewhat later than usual, because of the delay in finishing the improvements Mr. Hammerstein has planned for his handsome west side theatre. Harlem theatregoers found that the changes justified the delay. The lobbies and foyer have been enlarged, so that the comfort of frequenters of the house will be greatly increased, and all the new decorations are rich and handsome.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 10. -- In the village of Setauket, two miles from here, there is a street running down to the shore front that has caused considerable trouble, considering its length.

The entries for the seventh annual championship meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union closed yesterday with Chairman James E. Sullivan, and at a meeting of the Games Committee held in the afternoon the order of events was decided upon. The entry list is without doubt the best ever seen at a championship meeting in this section of the country.

The testimony taken yesterday by the Governor's commission which is investigating charges brought by The New-York World against the Elmira Reformatory was a revelation of the characters of some of the convicts, who are assisting, that paper, and it was so disgusting that, the commission stopped the witness.
The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn met last evening at 44 Court Street. Frederick B. Bailey presided.

The anti-Platt Republicans in this city and some from up the State devoted their energies yesterday to the discussion of NewYork City's delegation in the convention. New-York County will have 127 delegates.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 10 -- The Smoky City is to-night in possession of the boys that wore the blue. There are acres of bunting, myriads of flags, and all the contrivances and wonders of electricity blazing from arches, towers, and business blocks.
It was stated last evening at the residence of Oswald Ottendorfer that he was greatly improved, and that, in all probability, he would be out in a few days.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Incoming vessels this afternoon report the sinking of the three-masted schooned Dora M. French of Bangor, Me., from Hoboken for Boston with a cargo of coal, by the steamer Portia of Liverpool, N.S., Capt. Ash., from St. John's, N.F., for New-York, at noon to-day, about 112 miles east half south from Vineyard Sound lightship during a thick fog and fresh southwest wind.

There was some good cricket seen yesterday at Staten Island, where the Boston Zingari team played the first of its week's series of matches with the Staten Island Cricket Club. The Islanders proved easy winners, gaining the victory by 80 runs, but it was totally on account of poor work in the field that the visitors suffered defeat.

-- Orrin H. Crosby died at his home, 149 Sip Avenue, Jersey City, Sunday night. He was eighty-nine years old. He was born at South-east, N.Y. He was one of the organizers of the Bergen Presbyterian Church. He gave shelter in 1863 to several negroes who fled from New-York during the riots, and a mob went to his barn to drive the negroes out.

Application was made in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Lacombe, yesterday, for temporary receivers for the Colorado River Irrigation Company, and for an injunction restraining the Directors of the organization from carrying on its affairs, except by permission of the court.

Police Justice Patrick J. Divver, at the head of a procession of nearly 2,000 members of the P. Divver Association, and their guests, yesterday morning marched from the clubhouse, 59 Madison Street, to Catharine Slip, where they boarded the Iron Steamboat Sirius, on their annual outing and games at Witzel's Point View Grove, College Point, L.I.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- Premier Crispi unveiled in Naples to-day the memorial erected in honor of King Humbert's visit to the city during the cholera epidemic of 1884. He made a notable speech, beginning with a historical review of recent Italian politics, and closing with a declaration as to the social problems of to-day, especially the revolutionary movement.

The opening yesterday of the public schools enforces the necessity of immediate provision for the accommodation of all the children who may apply to be taught at the public expense. This should mean accommodation for all children of school age for whom provision is not made in private schools.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10. -- The General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor, in session here, passed a resolution indorsing President Debs of the American Railway Union, approving his action before the investigating committee, and offering the moral, and, if necessary, the financial support of the Knights of Labor.

The Lexow committee yesterday resumed its inquiry, in Part 1. of the Superior Court, into the doings of the Police Department. The first thing that developed was a hitherto unsuspected mine which the Central Office detectives have evidently had pretty much to themselves.

Editor Horace White, who is President and Trustee of The Evening Post Publishing Company, was at the Union League Club when a reporter for The New-York Times called his attention to the report of Master A.L. Cary on his investigation of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company affairs.

Mr. Martin E. Dotson, the colored broker, has sold for William Scardefield to Ransom Parker the dwelling 314 West Sixteenth Street. Mr. Dotson was also the broker in the recent sale to Mandelbaum Lewine of 419 to 425 West Thirteenth Street.

It was a delightful change for racegoers from the superheated and moisture -- charged atmosphere of the city to that at Gravesend, where the cooling seabreezes made life somewhat more endurable and pleasureable. The track, which had been like a canal on Saturday, had dried out, until the dust flew so badly that sprinklers had to be brought into requisition to lay it along the homestretch.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10 -- The prospect for the great success of the Diamond Tournament at Hampden Park grows more flattering as the time for the meet approaches. The weather to-night promises to be fair for the trial heats to-morrow, and, as the track is as fine as human hands can make it, the cycle sharps are predicting much in the way of records.

There were two important questions for the consideration or the Bridge Trustees at their meeting yesterday afternoon. One was the question of a two-cent fare, and the other was the question of choosing a method for lighting the bridge cars.
Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy arrived Back from his short vacation trip to London and Paris on the steamship Trave yesterday. He is in sturdy health and in excellent spirits.

The last five sections of the new Tariff act constitute a law against Trusts and similar combinations. Mr. McMillin of the Ways and Means Committee has declared that these sections are "the most stringent anti-Trust law ever enacted in this country," and that they "carry into law the most effective means ever yet devised for controlling and curbing the power of Trusts."

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 10. -- The South Carolina Dispensary riots of last March were discussed in the United States Circuit Court to-day before Judge Goff. The matter came up in the form of an injunction suit to prevent Gov. Tillman or any State officers under him from taking possession of the arms and accoutrements of the Washington Light Infantry Company of Charleston, S.C.

Activity was not a feature of yesterday's stock market, and three stocks contributed almost half of the small volume of business. The three were Sugar, Burlington, and St. Paul. The first-named was strong in the early dealings, but developed weakness after it had advanced to 106 1/4, and broke rapidly to 103 5/8. It closed at 104, a net decline of 1/2.

The cornerstone of the new Five Points Mission Building which is being erected on the old brewery site at 63 Park Street was laid yesterday afternoon by Bishop R.S. Foster of Boston. He also made a brief address, in which he told of the organization of the mission, at which he was present, forty-five years ago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Word was received in this city to-night from S.A. Beardsley of Utiea, Chairman of the Democratic State Sub-Committee, expressing his opinion concerning the recent action of Mayor Aldridge in appointing the Decker, or Hill, Board of Election Inspectors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Mrs. Stanford has paid off the last of the debts from the Stanford estate, and is now anxious for a distribution of the estate, so that she may secure personal control of the property of which she is executrix.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Brayton Ives had some interesting things to say to a correspondent of The New-York Times to-day in relation to the report of A.L. Cary, who was appointed Special Master to investigate charges of improper conduct of affairs of the Northern Pacific Railroad and of improper acts of Thomas F. Oakes as President of that railroad.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 10 -- The Owens Club of Franklin County has issued the following manifesto:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- It was the intention of the managers of the local nine and the Giants to play two games here to-day, but the programme could not be carried out, because of the rain. However, one game was played, and the Giants won with apparent ease. For six innings it was nip and tuck, but in the lucky seventh the New-Yorkers made a spurt, took the lead, and were never headed.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Controller Roberts for several months has been making a quiet investigation into the State's landed interests in the Adirondacks, and the result of his efforts will lead to proceedings that may force some of the State's sworn officers to indemnify the State heavily for betrayal of their trust.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Harvard University is to try an Interesting experiment in the employment of a medical adviser and medical inspector. Dr. George W. Fitz, a graduate of Harvard Medical School and instructor in physiology and hygiene in the Lawrence Scientific School, has been chosen for the place.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 11 -- "A friendly graft upon the charter given by King Charles II. to Hartford colonists" Judge Lynde Harrison of this city called the original document which was the supreme law of Connecticut.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- A dispatch to The Times from Wei-Hai-Wei of yesterday's date says:

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 11 -- The trotting race for The Clark's Horse Review Stake of $18,725 to-day was won by B.B.P., 2:13 1/2, a son of Pilot Medium. He won the rich prize today in straight heats after losing the first to Cut Glass, the Kentucky favorite, who appeared the only one in the crowd to give him any sort of a contest.

A petition, signed by Max Sundheimer and half a dozen other residents of Harlem, was read at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, asking that body to take such action as will compel the Harlem River Railroad to stop the limited express trains from Boston at Harlem. The trains go to the Grand Central Station, and the petitioners say residents of Harlem are compelled to ride back five miles to their homes.

A Gubernatorial boom for Justice William J. Gaynor has been started in Brooklyn by leaders of the Bell faction of the Democratic Party, and it is thought probable that the delegates to the State Convention representing that wing of the party will be sent with instructions to vote for Justice Gaynor's nomination.

Republican primaries to elect delegates to the Assembly District Conventions to be held on Friday evening, when delegates to the State Convention will be chosen, were held in more than 600 election districts in Kings County last night.

The annual amateur swimming championships will take place in conjunction with the athletic championships at Travers Island on Saturday next. The entries this year are more numerous than ever before, and the calibre of the contestants such that the swimming should be first-class in every particular. A.T. Kenney of Philadelphia, who was formerly an Australian and admitted by every one to be one of the fastest men in America, has entered in all the events.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 11 -- The Democratic State Convention, recalled to nominate two candidates for Congressmen at Large, to fill vacancies caused by the death of Hannibal K. Sloan and the declination of Joseph C. Bucher, met here to-day. Owing to the enforced absence of W.U. Hensel, Chairman of the June convention, ex-Congressman B.F. Meyers of this city was made Chairman by unanimous vote.
The Democratic campaign in this city is about to open.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Secretary Carlisle has refused to pay sugar bounty to Louisiana sugar planters. His grounds are stated in a letter mailed to-day to Senator Caffery. The letter is as follows:

H. Robinson of the Executive Board of the United Brotherhood of Tailors said yesterday: "About 2,000 tailors have returned to work, 4,000 more will be at work to-morrow, and by the end of the week we expect to have all our men employed."
The cooperage works of William Becker Co., 74 to 80 Withers Street, Willlamsburg, was destroyed by a fire which started about 12:30 o'clock this morning.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- The Hill malcontents, styling themselves the Democratic organization of Albany, intend to make mischief this Fall, if possible, in Albany County. The New Democracy, as these men, the majority of whom are office holders, prefer to have their organization called, had intended to form an agreement with the Republicans this Fall similar to that of last Spring, and in that manner work injury to the Democratic ticket.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11 -- After years of experience in the management of race meets. President Miller of the Springfield Club realizes that it is to the racing men he must look for good sport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Democratic politicians in Washington are not worried in the least over the news from Maine, for they had full knowledge of the extraordinary efforts put forth by the Republicans, and looked for a largely increased Republican vote. Mr. Lawrence Gardner, Secretary of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said on this subject to-night:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- As remarked in this letter yesterday, Choctaw is bound for higher prices. It sold to-day at 10, being an advance for the day of over $1 a share. The chief Interest in the local market centred in People's Traction, Electric Traction, and Hestonville. Rumors of the consolidation of these roads under one system were rife in the early morning, and the consummation of the deal was all but officially announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- At the next session of Congress First Assistant Postmaster General Jones will urge the enactment of a law prohibiting boycotting, which has been extensively practiced upon newly-appointed Democratic fourth-class Postmasters by their Republican predecessors and Republican patrons of the office.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11 -- Immediately after the meet closes, Johnson will go to Waltham and try for the mile paced and unpaced records, and also for the one-hour mark. He will be paced by the Callahans, "Tom" Cooper, Berlo, and Rich. L.A. Callahan will try for the fifty-mile record on the same track.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. J. Klauss, a widow, living on a farm south of here, was beaten and nearly killed by two tramps last night during her son's absence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Assistant Secretary McAdoo took charge of the navy to-day, relieving Admiral Ramsay, who has been doing double duty for the last three weeks. Mr. McAdoo will have five or six days of complete authority before Secretary Herbert returns, but in that brief time, it is understood, he will correct an omission in the official code of etiquette of the department.

Among the passengers of the Berlin, which arrived at her dock yesterday morning, were the principal members of George Edwarde's "A Gaiety Girl" Company, which is to make its American debut next Tuesday night at Daly's Theatre.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The People's Party has methods for raising campaign funds that have never yet been practiced by either the Democrats or the Republicans.

Wall Street has felt the effect of the general revival of business which sprang up as soon as the tariff question was settled. The improvement has also cast its brightness over Liberty Street, and the real estate operators are greatly encouraged. They see the improvement manifested not only in firm prices, but in the ease with which good property is sold and in the hesitancy with which it is offered.

Nothing new of importance was developed at the inquiry of the State Commission in Lunacy yesterday into the management of the City Asylums for the Insane. Letters from Superintendent Macdonald of Ward's Island to Architect Eldlitz of the Department of Charities and Correction, complaining of delay in constructing branch houses on Ward's Island, were produced.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 11 -- An encounter, which came near ending in a terrible tragedy, took place in the restaurant of Frank Davis here this morning. The principals in the affair, in which pistols played a prominent part, were Prof. C.H. Alberti, a prominent Owens man, and Col. John R. Alien, County Attorney of Fayette, a follower of Breckinridge.

Judging from the present outlook the probabilities are that the meet of the Harlem Wheelmen to be held on Saturday at Manhattan Field will be one of the cycle events of the season. Entries are pouring in from all quarters, particularly for the one-mile novice race, in which The New-York Times offers a handsome gold medal.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- The Secretary of the American Board of Commissions for Foreign Missions, whose office is in this city, has received a cable dispatch from Aintab, Turkey, which announces the arrest and imprisonment of a number of professors in the American schools at that point, and also at Marash.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 11 -- The September term of the Hudson County Grand Jury began this morning at 10 o'clock. Judge Lippincott's charge dealt with four subjects -- crimes of violence, Sunday liquor selling, trolley accidents, and water. On the water question he spoke as follows:

For the first time since the Republicans of this city reorganized and made the election districts, instead of the Assembly districts, the unit of representation, primaries were held last night, preparatory to selecting delegates to a State Convention.

The New-York State Association of Trotting Horse Breeders commenced their tenth annual meeting at Fleetwood Park yesterday, and will continue four days The organization is one of the most prominent of its kind in the country, having among its members about all the breeders of trotting horses in the State. Its annual trotting meetings rank, as a rule, among the best of the year, and always prove a strong attraction wherever held.
What will be left of the New-York Police Department when the Lexow committee has finished?

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Republicans of Monroe have nearly completed their arrangements for their trip to Saratoga next week, and are fondly nursing the George W. Aldridge boom for Lieutenant Governor. The delegates are going on a special train, and are intending to boom things "all along the line."

The physical traits of Signer Palmiro Tamburini were so happily invented and renewed by Henry Dixey last night that his portrayal seemed entirely new. Nature was the actor's first collaborator, since it gave to him a fine head, eyes quick, expressive, and turbulent, and nerves that are strung in accordance with the minute hand of the clock.

When the people who went to the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night entered, they were representatives of the wealth, the culture, and the refinement of the metropolis of the foremost nation in the world. As they came out, they appeared to one who had watched the droll Lilliputians in their new production of "Humpty Dumpty" like gigantic caricatures of those who earlier in the evening had assembled at the theatre.
J.S.T. Stranahan and the Rev. Sylvester Malone, two of Brooklyn's most venerable and distinguished citizens, called yesterday on Mayor Schieren and met in his office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Navy Department has completed arrangements for the horse-power trial of the first of the battle ships, and it is expected that the Maine will make an official run on Long Island Sound about the end of the present week. The trial will be exclusively for the development of power, no consideration of speed or manocuvring being involved, the hull being the product of Government workshops at the New-York Navy Yard.
The Red Cross Line steamer Portia arrived at her dock, at Warren Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning from Halifax, N.S., with eighteen members of the Cook arctic excursion party on board.

The visiting Boston cricketers played the second game of their New-York tour yesterday at Prospect Paris, and again met a defeat, the Brooklyn Cricket Club gaining the advantage over them on the first inning by 59 runs.

Several hundred members of the Association of Railroad Masters of America are In this city for the purpose of holding their fifteenth annual convention. The association comprises about 1,000 members and represents 100,000 miles of railroad. The officers of the association are:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 -- Two games were played here to-day between the Giants and the Clevelands, and each won. It was hard for the New-Yorkers to drop a game at this stage, when they are striving to overtake the speedy players from Baltimore, but they ought to feel satisfied to take two of the three games from the Clevelands, who are now playing better ball than any of the Western teams.
HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Democratic District Convention of Columbia County was held in this city this afternoon. Samuel J. Tilden and his aides were in full control, and all was harmonious.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- Of the three classes that made up the Grand Circuit programme here to-day, one was for pacers, and it occupied all the afternoon. It was for a purse of $2,000, opened last March, and known as the Turf Club Stake. In honor of a popular local organization. The speed limit of this was 2:10, and among the horses named for it was the chestnut gelding Paul, a well-known campaigner from Boston.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Trolley traffic was suspended in this city for a short time to-day, while employes of the Steinway Electric Railroad and ex-Mayor Gleason's trolley road disputed as to which line wag stealing power from the other.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Red Men representing every part of the United States assembled in Stone Hall this morning at the Great Sun Council. Great Incohence Thomas J. Peckinpaugh of Iowa called the body to order, and Past Great Sachem George E. Green, Mayor of Binghamton, made the address of welcome, to which the Great Incohonee made response.

The most serious charges, in one sense, that are brought by the latest witnesses before the Lexow committee are charges which do not directly concern the police at all. People are now prepared to believe anything that is incriminating against almost any person on the police force from bottom to top.

Messrs. J.N. Kalley Son and E.P. Hamilton Co. have sold for Boehm Coon the five-story brick, iron and stone store and office building, 45 Maiden Lane, 21.4 by 129 by 134, to Henry Auchincloss, at $200,000. The building was finished on May 1 of the present year, and is rented for $14,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Corned beef which was purchased in Washington Market, New-York, last Saturday, has poisoned a family of eight persons living in Kearney, N.J., and at least two of the victims will die.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Under the caption "Pons Pontificis," The Pall Mall Gazette prints an article with the object of showing that Premier Crispi is rapidly bringing about a reconciliation between the King and the Pope.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Twenty commanderies and a dozen bands are here on an annual pilgrimage, the occasion being the regular yearly conclave of the Grand Commandery of Knights Templar of the State of New-York. The very best of weather greets the visitors, and they are making the most of their visit.

Peter McArdle, a circus performer, thirty-two years old, while suffering with delirium tremens yesterday morning, threw his seven-year-old niece, Mary McArdle, out of a second-story window at 32 York Street, Brooklyn, and then jumped after her.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Representatives of the Edison United and the North American Phonograph Companies were in the Chancery Chambers this morning to be heard on the order to show cause why the receiver of the North American Company should not be compelled to secure a bond from the purchasers of phonographs, so that the machines should not be sent abroad.

The mortality percentage in those parts of Europe where cholera prevails has become very high. This is shown as well in the districts where the number of cases is small as in those where the disease has been epidemic for a long time and has caused great loss of life. Cholera this year in Europe is exceptionally dangerous and virulent.

Banquet was in good form at Gravesend yesterday, and won easily. Banquet's race was at a mile and an eighth, and in it he beat Saragossa, Yo Tambien, and Sir Knight, who finished behind him in the order named. With Taral up, it was expected that To Tambien would show some of the phenomenal form and speed which the Chicago "boomers" assert she is possessed of.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11 -- The curtain-raiser to the big Diamond Tournament promoted by the Springfield Bicycle Club was offered to a thousand enthusiasts at picturesque Hampden Park to-day, in the shape of forty-six trial heats. The contests were chiefly interesting because all the cracks were seen together for the first time this season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 11 -- In the Ezeta case, Judge Morrow to-day overruled the demurrer of the counsel for the Salvadorean Government to the plea of lack of jurisdiction entered by Gen. Antonio Ezeta's counsel. This means victory for Ezeta.

As a fabled monster or old demanded the sacrifice of at least one life every day, so the Associated Press (Western) continues its diurnal recitation of fatalities that have as little foundation in fact as any of the tales of mythology.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Congress of the Associated Chambers of Commerce opened here to-day, Sir Albert K. Rollit presiding. In his opening speech, the presiding officer said that all current data concurred in promising a revival of trade. It was one of the greatest of facts that any movement causing a relaxation of the tariff in America must be beneficial to British trade.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 11 -- The trial of the American Railway Union contempt oases was resumed in the United States court, before Judge Woods, to-day, after a three days' recess. Judge Woods announced that he had granted permission to Eugene V. Debs to be absent a few days, that he might attend to some business in Pittsburgh.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- This was Governor's Day at the Binghamton Industrial Exposition. The Governor's address was devoted to a discussion of the new tariff. In the course of his remarks he said:
(All letters for this column, suggesting candidates for Gubernatorial nomination, must bear the signature of the writer, not necessarily for publication, but as a guarantee of good faith.)

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11 -- President Miller of the Springfield Club was in a splendid humor to-night over the prospects for the next two days. He predicts that the track will score some phenomenal records. "The offering of the special prize by The Times," said he, "will instill greater energy among the "A" men to make fast time.

The Orange Tennis Club continued its club championship tournament yesterday afternoon on the Montrose courts. Two matches were played in doubles and three in singles. Robert Miles and Clifford Gould wiped out their defeat at the South Orange tournament last week by beating George Miles and Holcombe Ward in straight sets.

QUARANTINE, S. I., Sept. 11 -- Capt. F. H. Boujer of the Netherlands-American Navigation Company's steamer Spaarndam, and W.H. Van den Toorn, the New-York representative of the company, have been Knighted by the Queen of the Netherlands for their distinguished services.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Bay State Gas securities were active in the local market, the stock declining to 7 1/2 and closing at 8. The Street is filled with rumors of the stock being entirely wiped out. The bonds were also active, the seconds declining to 50 and recovering to 54 1/2. The firsts sold down to 78 on small offerings.

LOWVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Lewis County Republican Convention was held in this village this afternoon, C.L. Knapp presiding. Every one of the eighteen towns was represented, and there were no contesting delegations. The convention was entirely harmonious, and all the nominations were made by acclamation.

The Almira won the second race and the series with the Mary yesterday oft Indian Harbor. It was a much closer race than Monday's. The wind was strong from the north-nortwest. and the course was six and a half miles to leeward and return. The starting signal was given at 1:05, and three minutes later the handicap gun was fired. The boats had been luffing with each other for position, and both were left.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 11 -- In the matter of the controversy between the officers and the United States Treasury Department over the issue of special warrants, the Governor and State Treasurer this morning gave their personal cognizance to appear before the November (1894) term of the United States District Court in this city, upon the request of Attorney General Olney through District Attorney Lee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The New-York manufacturer who recently wrote to The New-York Times on the subject of the delay in furnishing the World's Fair awards will undoubtedly be very much disgusted when he learns that several months will pass before the Columbian medals authorized by the Treasury Department will be ready for distribution.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 11 -- There have been larger parades in connection with a national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic than that in this city to-day, but the turnout of gallant veterans was creditable in every respect. In the matter of numbers the Ohio and Pennsylvania divisions were pre-eminent, while the attractive appearance and military bearing of the posts from New-York, Massachusetts, Illinois, and the Department of the Potomac were noteworthy.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The result of the Republican caucus in Syracuse today confirms the opinion given in The New-York Times's dispatches several weeks ago that Francis Hendricks, ex-Collector of the Port of New-York, would succeed in defeating Congressman James J. Belden.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 -- The golf tournament for the championship of America was finished this afternoon, W.G. Lawrence of New-York, a member of the Newport Golf Club, winning. The tournament, which was under the auspices of the Newport Club, was very successful and developed very fine play. The club gives the winner a beautiful silver cup, which he wins outright.

The testimony given yesterday at the investigation by the Governor's commission which is trying to get at the facts concerning the management of the Elmira Reformatory was the most direct, indusputable, and authoritative exposition of the punishments administered there that has yet been brought out.

Cowperthwait Co. will open their new furniture store at 104 West Fourteenth Street to-day. The New-York store is a branch of the firm's large Brooklyn store in Flatbush Avenue, near Fulton Street. It has been established to accommodate the firm's New-York and New -Jersey customers.

This coming campaign will be remarkable in many respects. There will be an unusual multiplicity of ballots. Besides the ballots for candidates, there will be additional ballots for the questions as to whether this city shall build the rapid-transit road at its own expense, as provided by the law of this year relating to rapid transit; as to whether there shall be a Greater New-York, and upon the adoption of the new Constitution.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 12. -- At a meeting of the Democratic County Committee held this morning in this city it was decided to hold the County Convention on Oct. 8. The caucuses to elect delegates to the Assembly districts. Assembly nominating, judicial, and county conventions, and to elect town and ward committees will be held Sept. 20.

A fire from some unknown cause in the cellar of the four-story double tenement at 183 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning, caused a damage of $300 to the property, $200 to the saloon on the first floor, and created a big scare.
Many lessons may be learned by him who threads his way through the purliens of the east side to the corner of Orchard and Broome Streets.

We remarked yesterday that six days had passed since Senator Blackburn of Kentucky gave to the public his story of the agreement made by him with Speaker Crisp and other prominent Democrats of the House, at the suggestion and with the authority and support of six prominent Democratic Senators, concerning the passage by the Senate of a supplemental Sugar bill in return for the acceptance of the Senate Tariff bill by the House.
LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 12. -- Roy Foster, a well-known and respected citizen of Burlington, was shot and killed by three unknown highwaymen near Billerica Centre at 1 o'clock this morning.

It seemed perfectly idiotic for the bookmakers at Gravesend to offer 6 to 1 against Patrician in the only fixture on the card yesterday. This was the race for the Bayshore Stakes, for three-year-olds and upward, at a mile and a sixteenth. But it was a piece of idiocy that the public forced them to.

Geologists inform us that all the water now on the surface of the earth is destined to sink into the interior, leaving mankind to perish of thirst. This unpleasant prospect does not make the average man unhappy, for the reason that he bears with equanimity the misfortunes of his remote posterity.

Tammany got to work yesterday for the Fall campaign. Its Executive Committee or Committee of Sixty, met at the Wigwam in Fourteenth Street and made the preliminary arrangements. There was a large attendance, and in the main room there was the usual large crowd of members of the organization who had dropped in to see how things were going on.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 12. -- The Republican State Convention to-day nominated A.W. Mclntyre of Conejos County for Governor, John Campbell of El Paso County for Judge of the Supreme Court, Judd Brush of Greeley for Lieutenant Governor, Albert B. McGaffey of Denver for Secretary of State, and H.E. Malnix of Arapahoe County for State Treasurer.

At a meeting of the Police Board yesterday afternoon, a communication was received from Mayor Gilroy, calling attention to the serious nature of the charges made by the New-York City Civil Service Supervisory Board, in connection with the examination of candidates for appointment on the force.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 12. -- The Quaker Church of America promises to have a heresy trial as celebrated in its limits as the Briggs case in the Presbyterian Church. Dr. Dougan Clark, professor in the Theological School at Earham College, it was recently disclosed, had been baptized with ten other advanced Quakers, at the Yearly Meeting in Damascus, Ohio, during the last Summer.

ALBANY, Sept 12. -- The "tub committee," so called because its headquarters are in a bathhouse, has received orders from John E. Milholland to send a contesting delegation from the Fourth Assembly District to the Republican State Convention. This is to be done simply to demonstrate to the people the strength of the Milholland idea.

Benjamin F. Angel died at Geneseo, N.Y., Tuesday evening at the age of seventy-nine years. Mr. Angel was born in Otsego County, in November, 1815. In his early youth he went to Geneseo and was admitted to the bar at the age of nineteen years. At twenty-two he was made Surrogate of Livingston County, and held the office for eight years.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- State Controller Roberts has completed the computation of the taxes which are to be levied for the support of the State Government for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, 1894. The total amount of taxes to be collected is $9,155,742, which is levied on property throughout the State, the aggregate equalized valuation of which is $4,199,882,058.

VIENNA, Sept. 12. -- M. Witte, the Russian Minister of Finance, who is sojourning at Abazzia, is giving to representatives of the Austrian and German press a series of interviews which are attracting widespread attention and are regarded as hopeful signs of peace. In an interview published in the Neue Freie Presse, M. Witte disclaimed any intention on the part of Russia at any time to make a Russian province of Bulgaria.
The Lexow investigating committee adjourned yesterday until Monday, Oct. 1.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 12. -- Alix, 2:04, is the way it reads now, for to-day the game little mare guided by McDowell equaled Nancy Hanks's mark, made on this track Sept. 28, 1892, which has stood for nearly two years.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12. -- To-morrow's entries for the bicycle races here include absolutely all the prominent men of the country, with the exception of O. Zeigler, the Pacific coast champion, who refused to come East for fear that he would not receive fair play.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 12. -- The Misses Gibert will give a dinner Thursday evening in honor of Lady Lister-Kaye and the Duc de Alba.

The Vaquero won the seventh race of the Larchmont series for twenty-one-footers on Tuesday. It was one of the prettiest races of the series, and in a rattling good breeze the Vaquero, ably handled by her owner, Herman Duryea, showed that she was either several minutes faster than the other boats in the class, or else that she had been handled better than the other boats.

The Race Committee of the Harlem Wheelmen has selected the officials who are to serve at the meeting on Manhattan Field next Saturday, and made their names public yesterday. Howard E. Raymond, Chairman of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen, will be the referee. The judges will be President Charles H. Luscomb of the League of American Wheelmen, Elliot Mason and H. Strugnell of the Harlem Wheelmen, and F.P. Prial.

QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 12. -- Capt. Adolph Frietsch, the Finnish sailor who left New-York Aug. 5 in the schooner-rigged skiff Nina, without any companion, arrived here at 12:30 P.M. to-day. His boat was somewhat damaged, her rudder having been lost, and she was leaking.

William S. Andrews, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, has submitted a letter to the department through William Robbins, General Superintendent, with the request that it be communicated to each officer of the department.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- "Buncombe," "trash," "nonsense," were heard repeatedly in the Constitutional Convention to-day during the debate on the Brown (Rep., Jefferson,) amendment to prohibit all public officers, including notaries public, from accepting railway passes or franks. In the course of the debate, the tone of the convention was further lowered by the unbridled personalities that passed between delegates.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 12. -- Attorney General Knowlton applied in the Supreme Court, before Judge Barker, to-day, for a preliminary injunction to stop the business of the American Sugar Refining Company, commonly known as the Sugar Trust, in this State, until it shall have filed its financial return with the Corporation Commissioner and paid up certain forfeitures, as required by the Laws of 1891 and 1894.
Messrs. Cook Brothers have sold the four-story brownstone dwelling 43 East Fifty-seventh Street, 21 by 62 by 100, at about $55,000.

Cubans and Spaniards in this city are excited over the discovery of a shipment of 50,000 cartridges in casks marked tallow, found in the cargo of the Ward Line steamer Yumuri, at Havana, Aug. 28. Commodore Hughes, manager of the line in this city, said that he had received a telegram from Havana in relation to the finding of the cartridges, but could say nothing further about the matter.

The stock market yesterday was a very dull affair, but the tendency of prices was toward a higher level. Sugar was, as usual, the most prominent stock. It was weak in the early trading, but recovered in the late trading, and closed 1/4 higher than on Tuesday. The early selling was based on rumors of dissensions in the management, but it is fair to assume that no great differences prevail.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- The rumored discovery of a new wheat exporting country was reported on the board to-day. The rumor was generally discredited, but, nevertheless, it assisted materially in depressing prices. It came from New-York, and was to the effect that a cargo of wheat, amounting to 450,000 bushels, had been shipped from Chile to New-York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- It is understood that the presence in Washington during the last week of Frederic Penfield, United States Diplomatic Agent and Consul General to Egypt, is connected with the negotiation of a new commercial treaty with the Government to which he is accredited, and that on his return to Cairo he will be in a position to conclude the convention preparatory to its submission to the Secretary of State for approval.
Spirits of turpentine dull; easy; 28 1/2@29c. Resins quiet; steady: common to good strained, $1.15@$1.20.

The cable announcement printed in yesterday's New-York Times to the effect that Augustin Daly had engaged Cissy Loftus, the youngest and most popular star of the London music halls, and her recently-married husband, Huntly McCarthy, a former member of Parliament, was the topic of club and professional gossip yesterday.

The Republicans of Kings County held their primaries Tuesday night for the election of delegates to the Assembly Conventions, but as there are 682 election districts in the city, it was not until yesterday that the complexion of the delegates elected could be defined.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12. -- Sanger said, after the mile open race to-day, that he would not have taken 5 to 1 on his chances when he rounded the last turn. Johnson had then five lengths lead on the big fellow. Sanger rode grandly in making up this lead.

The trotting meeting of the New-York State Breeders' Association at Fleet-wood Park is bringing about more well-contested harness racing than came from the more pretentious Grand Circuit series last week. The two events on yesterday's card furnished about the best sport of the week thus far, split heats and fallen favorites being among the features of both races.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Local securities were for the most part active and higher. A few shares of New-York, New-Haven and Hartford sold at 183 1/2, 1 point above yesterday's closing. Boston and Maine sold at 152, a point and a half higher than yesterday, while Bell Telephone at 204 1/2 and Fitchburg preferred at 74 3/4 about held the recent advance.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Sept, 12. -- The naphtha launch Alsace, belonging to Joseph Fahys, President of the Fahys Watch Company, took fire while about two miles out in the bay this afternoon. On board were Mrs. Henry F. Cook, Miss Swan, Master Benjamin Swan, and the engineer.

The County Committee of the State Democracy met last night in Cooper Union Hall, and, although at 8 o'clock, the hour named for the gathering, there were not a hundred persons assembled, half an hour later the hall was well filled.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- It was a local market pure and simple. Choctaw led in strength and activity, and advanced to 12, with final sales at a fractional concession. People's Traction opened at 61, on the news of the consolidation between it and Electric. Realizing sales by unbelievers broke the stock rapidly to 59 1/4, and its tone continued heavy throughout the day.

Cornelius N. Bliss, who was Chairman of the Committee of Thirty and who has been mentioned for Gubernatorial honors by some of the Republicans of this State, was a passenger on the White Star steamship Teutonic, which arrived yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 12. -- The charge made by Judge Lippincott to the Grand Jury yesterday in relation to the water supply was the subject of an official conference at the Mayor's office this afternoon. There was much indignation expressed at what the Commissioners deemed an injustice, and it was decided to issue an official reply in the form of a letter to Charles B. Thurston, foreman of the Grand Jury.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 12. -- Loss of life was caused by a cyclone which swept over Memphis to-day, leveling a number of houses, unroofing others, uprooting trees, and doing much other damage.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12. -- All through the Class A races the amateurs showed their liveliest paces to establish a title to The New-York Times Medal. Up to the time that Sims shattered the record in the mile handicap, the best Class A time for the distance was 2:23, made in the one-mile 2:40 class.

The two-masted schooner George Hurst of Port Eaton. L. I:, loaded with sand for Kingston, N. Y., was run into by the lighter M. J. Leonard yesterday noon, while rounding the Battery, and now lies in twelve feet of water about 100 yards from the Battery wall, with all sails set.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- It is now three days since the friends of surveyors in the field in connection with the Geographical Survey had their anxieties aroused by a dispatch dated San Francisco, and sent out by the Chicago organization styling itself the Associated Press, giving publicity to a rumor that a Government surveying party had been massacred near El Paso on the Rio Grande.

Gov. Flower made some very sensible remarks to the farmers at Binghamton on Tuesday with reference to the tariff. A close student of fiscal legislation might have found more to say as to the bearings of free wool upon the industry of the country, and a more determined advocate of Democratic principles might have exposed the treachery to those principles in the history of the new tariff.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 -- There is no doubt that Maryland will send a solid Democratic delegation of tariff reformers to the next House of Representatives. In the Sixth District, where anxiety was felt, the dissensions in the Republican ranks have given new confidence to the Democrats, and they will make every effort to defeat George Wellington, who has been nominated by the Republicans.

ROME, Sept. 12. -- The Osservatore Romano, apropos of the reported rapprochement between the Vatican and the Quirinal, declares that it sees no sufficient reason for such an assumption. The clamors of the Liberal press are based upon two facts, both of a purely religious character, relating to the establishment of an Apostolic Prefecture in Massowah, and the royal assent to the appointment of Cardinal Sarto, the Pope's nominee, as Patriarch of Venice.

The Rev. Dr. Talmage, who is now touring in Australia, considered this question of sufficient importance to make it the subject of a recent sermon. Happiness is not a question of bank account or material prosperity, but rather of health, and this can only be enjoyed where the digestive organs are performing their proper functions.

The commission which is investigating the management of the Elmira Reformatory held a short session yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and then adjourned until today, to meet at Elmira. The defense expects to complete its case this week, and the most important witness yet to be heard is Mr. Brockway himself.

The Boston cricketers suffered another defeat yesterday, and they are beginning to think that metropolitan cricket is much better than they at first supposed. The team of the Staten Island Athletic Club downed the visitors this time in a game at West New-Brighton, where they lost by no less than 121 runs, in a one-inning game.

Dr. Frederick A. Cook, the organizer of the disastrous Miranda expedition to Greenland, some of whose excursionists returned to this port in the equally unfortunate twin steamship Portia on Tuesday, had nothing to add yesterday to his denials that the Miranda was unfit for the trip or was badly equipped, or that the expedition was mismanaged, or that parsimony marred the pleasure of the excursionists.
LONDON, Sept. 12. -- A private mass for the dead was celebrated at Stowe House at 7 o'clock this morning. The ceremony was attended only by members of the Count of Paris's family.

From The Newark Sunday Call. It would be wise legislation if the State of New-Jersey should proceed to take control of the water supplies and the sources of the same in every part of the State. The management of water supplies has become too great a matter for any single municipality to manage by itself.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 12. -- Wednesday was designated in the official programme of the Citizens' Executive Commitee as "Banner Day" of Grand Army week. "What with the reunions of no less than eighty-seven army corps, the opening of the encampment, and of the conventions of the Women's Relief Corps, the Ladies of the Grand Army, and kindred organizations, and the parade of the ex-prisoners of war, the designation proved anything jut a misnomer.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- The affidavit of Thomas A. Edison which is attached to the bill praying for the appointment of a receivership of the North American Phonograph Company has just been filed. Jesse H. Lippincott, who was the originator of the North American Company, became insane when he lost all his money.

When the annual tax rate of this city is reduced, there is very often a vigorous claim that the reduction has been made for political purposes through the medium of an increased valuation of the property.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 12. -- Counsel for the Government in the American Railway Union contempt cases received a decided surprise to-day, when the witnesses from whom they expected to elicit testimony damaging to the defendants flatly refused to answer any questions in regard to their connection with the union, and were sustained in their stand by Judge Woods.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Shanghai says that the chief officers of the Chinese Army in Corea have telegraphed for supplies of Winter clothing, evidently expecting that the war will last a long time.

"Morton will be nominated on the first ballot." shouts T.C. Platt. "Morton will be nominated," echo the little Platt fellows. "Morton has the best chance to be nominated," quietly say the anti-Platt men in this city in confidence to their friends.

The General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor, while in session at Buffalo, passed a resolution urging all the assemblies of that order to prepare charges against Attorney General Olney, so that they may be placed before Congress at its next session and upon which an indictment of the Cabinet officer may be based.

The Brooklyn Young Republican Club held a special meeting in its rooms, corner of Flatbush Avenue and Nevins Street, last evening to consider a resolution that had been adopted at a joint meeting of the Executive and Advisory Committees.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12. -- The giants of the racing path made merry with two of Father Time's records at Hampden Park to-day. Five thousand persons saw them do it, and when the last event was over there was nothing but praise for the second day's programme of the Great Diamond tournament, the cycling event of the year.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 12. -- Col. Samuel D. Dickinson, who was Postmaster of this city at the time when " green-goods " men flourished here, and who was in charge of the Post Office at the time referred to by Applegate in his evidence before the Lexow committee, returned to this city to-day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Bearish tendencies were not popular on the Exchange to-day. The majority of brokers were bullish in their tendency. They believe that matters are improving all over the country, and, with the present monetary conditions and the revival in all trades, securities must do better.

Of the minor amendments of the Constitution adopted by the convention some are of a useful character and the rest are at least harmless. Striking " Coroner " from the list of county officers whose election is provided for will enable the Legislature to abolish the office altogether and get rid of the antiquated system of inquests which has come down to us from mediaeval times.

HARTFORD. Conn., Sept. 11. -- " The Connecticut laws regarding the commitment of the insane are sufficient, if honestly and intelligently followed," said Judge of Probate Freeman this evening. " They can, however, be improved. The fact that at least three mistakes are shown to have been made within a year proves that.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Certain disclosures contained in a letter recently sent out by the President of the Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press" have alarmed many of its members.
If there are any skeptics who refuse to believe that trade has sprung into a renewed activity, they should visit the congested thoroughfares which run along the river fronts.

Tammany's Committee on Organization met last night for the first time since last May. It was a noteworthy fact that the hall of the committee, which is in the basement of the Fourteenth Street Wigwam, was not large enough to hold all who wanted to attend the meeting.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 13. -- Fantasy. Hamlin a fleet four-year-old, stepped a great mile to-day, beating her previous mark of 2:07, the world's four-year-old record, and reducing it to 2:06. Ed. Geers drove the mare, and the quarters of her record-smashing mile were in 0:12 1/2, 1:04, 1:34 1/4, and 2:06. The attempt was made for a purse hung up by the Terre Haute Trotting Association.
"Opera, company, scenery, everything -- we shall go from the Lyceum to the new theatre Messrs. Abbey Grau have built in New-York, there to play through the Winter."

The College of the City of New-York opened yesterday with an attendance of over 1,500 students. This is more than the institution can accommodate comfortably, but the authorities hope the number will fall off to some extent during the next few weeks.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- The only sensible thing the Republicans in caucus have determined upon was done this afternoon, when a resolution which was inspired by the House of Lords was offered and adopted, that the convention adjourn at noon on Saturday, the 15th inst., until Thursday, Sept. 20, at 10 o'clock.

The Brooklyn Board of Elections will tomorrow appoint one Democratic and one Republican Registrar for each of the 682 election districts in Brooklyn, and as the board is non-partisan, the two Democratic Commissioners will appoint the Democratic Registrars and the Republican Commissioners will appoint the Registrars for their party.

The famous Seventh Regiment rifle team were beaten at Creedmoor yesterday. The team of the Twelfth Regiment were the victors in the State rifle match. The Seventh iren were more fortunate, however, in the First Brigade match, winning that over the Seventy-first Regiment team by a clear 36 points. The Second Brigade match went as usual to the Twenty-third Regiment.

The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen gave a hearing yesterday to the Metropolitan Traction Company on its application for a franchise to extend its West Side and Broadway Cable Road from One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Manhattan Avenue north through St. Nicholas Avenue and the King's Bridge Road to the upper end of Manhattan Island.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Superintendent of Insurance James F. Pierce this afternoon reported the Commercial Alliance Life Insurance Company of New-York to the Attorney General for him to begin proceedings to have a receiver appointed to wind up the affairs of the company.

Leo Wellinreiter and Henry Schwirnmann, brothers-in-law, thirty and twenty-six years old, respectively, who describe themselves as farmers from Denoes, Ill., arrived in this city yesterday morning with $1,000 and an avowed purpose to invest it all in "green goods." They also brought with them two carefully-loaded large-calibre revolvers, with which they intended to protect themselves against fraud.
The most astonished foreigner that has arrived in New-York in many a day is Singree, a native of Minjana, Africa, Who arrived last Sunday morning on the bark Liberia, from Monrovia, Liberia.

The progressive reduction of the rate of taxation in this city during the past two years is the occasion of two lines of comment; neither of which is Justified. On the one hand, it is claimed to be an evidence of municipal economy and careful financial management, and on the other It is attributed to an inordinate pushing up of valuations for the purpose of concealing extravagance and loose methods.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- What is considered to be the most satisfactory campaign book ever prepared under authority of the Democratic Congressional Committee is now nearly ready for distribution. It comprises 230 pages, and is so broad in its scope and dignified in its utterances that it cannot fail to be of great assistance to Democrats throughout the country in the present campaign.

It was not definitely determined yesterday by the Police Commissioners whether the trials of the accused members of the force begun during the former recess of the Senate investigating committee should be continued during the present recess. There is a strong probability, however, that there will be no more police trials until the adjournment of the Lexow committee.

It is rather a misfortune that the exigencies of "politics" have compelled the postponement of the Lexow investigation until after the convention. Such proceedings lose much by intermitting, in respect both of the disclosures reached and of the public interest, which is not less important.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 13. -- The Hupao says that the Chinese Admiralty has decided to order the transfer from the Yang-Tse coast to Pei-Yang of all war ships of large tonnage and armaments. These war ships will be accompanied by a number of torpedo boats from the squadrons at FooChoo, Canton, and Nan King.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Platt is on top in Niagara County. The old fight which ex-Congressman Richard Crowley and his followers have made in the Republican Party for recognition for the last six or seven years cropped out again in the County Convention held here to-day. Crowley wanted to head the delegation to the Republican State Convention in the interests of Morton for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Among the responses to a circular calling upon the official representatives of the United States abroad for information regarding assisted emigration, the Department of State has received a report from Consul Smithers, at Hiogo, Japan, saying that an emigration company was established at Hiogo in January, 1892, with a capital of 30,000 yen, (a yen is about 66 cents.)

When people reached the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday, they were greeted with the announcement that the Stewards of The Jockey Club had a "bombshell" that they would explode in the course of the afternoon.

Dr. Parkhurst yesterday announced that John W. Goff, counsel to the Lexow committee, was his choice for Recorder to succeed Recorder Frederick Smyth, whose term expires this year. Dr. Parkhurst is reported as having said, among other things:

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Nearly everything traded in held its own, except West and North Chicago Cable stocks. Lacking inside support, the market readily gave way, as it did yesterday. The business appeared to be in the hands of a few brokers, who did but little for the general public. Opening at 132, West Chicago broke gradually to 131 1/4 recovered to 131 1/2, and closed the first session at 131 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Inquiry was made at the Apostolic Legation here to-day in regard to dispatches from Rome intimating that Mgr. Satolll would be made a Cardinal at the next Consistory, in December. The reply given by the Apostolic Delegate was:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13. -- The big race of the day was the fifth on the programme. The three-hundred-dollar diamond, offered as the first prize, attracted the cream of the riders, excepting Tyler, who failed to qualify in the trials, Each was anxious to land the coveted trophy, but doubly so to win the honor attached to so important a contest.

Etta Graemer, a sixteen-year-old Brooklyn girl, has had a strange and sorrowful experience, if the story is true which she related yesterday to Superintendent Wilkin of the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

Senator Daniel Bradley, a member of the Lexow committee, who has taken occasion to praise the Brooklyn police, called on Commissioner Welles yesterday and talked over the testimony given before the investigating committee on Wednesday by Charles M. Patterson, implicating Detective George V. Zundt of the Brooklyn force.

W.H.C. Hargrave. W.H.C. Hargrave, special representative of the United Press, and for sixteen years prior to Jan. 1, 1893, manager of the Philadelphia bureau of the old New-York Associated Press, died at a hotel in Philadelphia shortly before midnight of Wednesday. Mr. Hargrave had been a sufferer from hemorrhagic attacks for several years.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- James W. Hinckley of this city, who has been named as a possible successor to Senator Murphy as Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, says in his newspaper, The Poughkeepsie News-Press:

The "Home Rule for Cities" amendment, as it is now before the convention, is severed from the separate elections amendments, and is shorn of all its positively objectionable features. While the measure of home rule which it proffers is far from satisfactory, it is all there is7 any prospect of getting from the convention, and it is better than nothing.
SARATOGA, Sept. 13. -- According to rumor, Thomas C. Platt will bring the Morton boom to town to-morrow and place it in the United States Hotel.

BOSTON, Sept. 13. -- The local railroad stocks were firm, but sales were small. There were a few shares done of Boston and Albany at 207, Boston and Lowell at 197, Boston and Providence at 257, and Fitchburg preferred at 74 3/4. Boston and Maine was advanced another half point, to 152 1/2, but no considerable amount of the stock came out.

Yesterday was an off day at the New-York State Breeders' trotting meeting at Fleetwood Park. All the events were so-called stakes, in which the entries closed and the horses were classed six months before the races were to take place, and, as is often the experience in such cases, one horse completely outclassed the field in each class, making the race a mere walkaway, which was devoid alike of interest and contest.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The first Rensselaer District Republican Convention, after wrangling for nearly three hours over a contested delegation, admitted each with a hall vote. The result was the defeat of ex-Postmaster Mann. The delegates chosen are C. Whitney Tillinghast, second; Don C. Woodcock, A.E. Bonestell, Joseph A. Leggett, and Charles S. Francis.

The Misses Mary J. and Sarah Mitchell, dressmakers at 417 Fifth Avenue, between Seventh and Eighth Streets, Brooklyn, found two burglars in their back parlor about 5:30 P.M. yesterday. Miss Mary Mitchell asked them what they were doing, and one of them knocked her down. The other burglar caught Sarah by the throat and forced her over to the bannisters. She fell down a distance of seven steps.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- A dispatch from Rome to Le Temps says that Premier Crispi's organ, the Riforma, denies that Crispi has "gone to Canossa." The Vatican, the dispatch says, maintains the greatest reserve toward the Quirinal. Although the Papal heads are pleased at his advances, their satisfaction is tempered by doubt as to the honesty of Signer Crispi's diplomacy.

The Constitutional Convention has done an extremely foolish thing in adopting the amendment which prohibits the working of convicts in prisons, jails, penitentiaries, and reformatories at any trade, industry, or occupation "wherein or whereby" their work or the product or profit thereof shall be" farmed out, contracted, given, or sold to any person, firm, association, or corporation."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Navy Department has received two long and detailed reports upon the work of the State Naval Reserve Battalions on their recent cruises on the flagship San Francisco and the New-York, and the tribute paid to their efficiency dispels the impression which seemed to prevail that the New-Yorkers would not take to the hard duties required of ordinary seamen on a modern war ship.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 13. -- The Prohibition State Convention was held here today In Association Hall. Prof. A.H. Evans of Ashburnham was Chairman. F.W. Clark of Boston was Secretary. The following nominations were made:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Department of State has received a dispatch from Minister Terrell at Constantinople announcing the results of American explorations now being conducted at the ruins of Niffer, near ancient Babylon. The expenses of the work are defrayed by an association of Philadelphia gentlemen, formed under the name of the "Babylonian Exploration Fund."

Widespread public interest has been aroused in New-York as well as in Connecticut by the articles which have appeared in The New-York Times, calling attention to the laxity of the laws in Connecticut for the care of the insane, and pointing out the gross abuses which prevail under the loose and inadequate requirements of the Connecticut statutes.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13. -- The first accident among society wheelmen occurred to-day, the victim being Mrs. Clement C. Moore of New-York, whose bicycle, turning too quickly, slipped in the mud. She was thrown heavily on her left knee, and sustained a severe sprain, which will confine her to her home for some time.

The convention of the Association of Headmasters of America, which has been in convention in this city since Tuesday, has concluded its labors, and the remainder of the week will be devoted to pleasure. The programme yesterday included a trip in a special train over the entire elevated system, and a visit to the aquarium at the Battery.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 13.-- In the Court of Sessions in this city this morning, with County Judge Griffith presiding, Michael Pillion, convicted of repeating at the polls in several wards in this city at the election last Spring, was sentenced to the Albany Penitentiary for one year and to pay a fine of $500, in default of which fine the prisoner is to be detained at the penitentiary for 500 days.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13. -- The Bannisters wharf fleet of catboats used by cottagers, and said to be the finest in the world, had their initial races to-day, cottagers giving a large purse for first, second, and third prizes. Woodbury Kane, who had general charge, and raised the prize money among the cottagers; Royal Phelps Carroll, and F.P. Sands, were the judges.
ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- Following is the text of the judiciary article adopted by the Constitutional Convention to-day for submission to the vote of the people:
John E. Milholland's faction of the Republican Party in this city was jubilant last night. It held its primaries for the election of delegates to the State Convention.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- At the Democratic caucus held in Goshen last evening, the following delegates were elected: State -- Henry Bacon, George W. Price, B.H. Levy, Thomas Finan, T.D. Tuthill, and Thomas Bradley. Assembly -- E. Dikeman, Frank Flynn, John Logan, H.C. Horton, Dennis Hayes, and James E. Millspaugh.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Judge Lippincott talked freely this morning at the Court House in regard to the statement issued by the Street and Water Commissioners as to the water and the need for a new supply.

Staten Island society was out in force yesterday afternoon to see the games of the tennis tournament of the Staten Island Ladies' Club. The attendance was larger than on Wednesday, and there was plenty of enthusiastic but indiscriminate applause.

The bears were active in the stock market yesterday, but their success was measured by very small fractions. They hammered the Grangers most of the day, but at the close Burlington and St. Paul were only down 7/8 each, Rock Island 3/8, and Northwestern 1 1/8. There is such a very narrow market for Northwestern that it is not difficult to depress it on relatively small offerings.

James, better known as "Red Jim," McDermott, has been heard from again. He has written a letter to The Freeman's Journal of Dublin, in which he claims to have just returned to England from a visit to America, and again denies that he had anything to do with the capture by Scotland Yard detectives of Dr. Gallagher and his associates.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13. -- As an afterpart to the big meet the usual attacks on the records were made by Titus, Johnson, "Charley" Murphy, and "Nat" Butler. The former rode the greatest record ride the world ever saw. He rode by a schedule arranged by Trainer Young, and beat his own schedule a full half mile, and the world's hour record by 1,362 yards.

The situation created by the avowed intention of a considerable party of the Louisiana sugar planters to act in national politics with the Republicans is interesting, but is not likely to be of great importance. It may give a few seats in the House to the Republicans, but on the issue of restoring McKinleyism, in full or in part, these few votes will have no material effect.

Although Chairman Raymond has been in Springfield all the week witnessing the record and racing trials, he has not neglected to pay attention to those transgressors of the League of American Wheelmen rules, and for the last week gives the following official news:
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13. -- Twenty-five records is a record in itself for one day.

Horace White, one of the proprietors of The Evening Post, and Vice President of the Chicago organization which calls itself the "Associated Press," was asked by a reporter for The New-York Times, yesterday, regarding the troubles of that association, but he showed no inclination to discuss the matter at length.

Mr. Cornelius N. Bliss said yesterday: "I do not know that there is any reason for an expression of my personal opinion regarding the present political situation, but, as something seems to be expected of me, it is perhaps well enough for me to say a few words. I will be very frank and very brief.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 13. -- Bernard Toker, a German farmer, was shot dead and his wife mortally wounded by Frank Morris, a sixteen-year-old boy, yesterday. Morris is a son of the man from whom Toker purchased his little farm.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 13. -- After one of the most heated contests in the history of the organization, Col. Thomas G. Lawler of Rockford, Ill., was this afternoon elected Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, defeating his only opponent, Col. Ivan N. Walker of Indianapolis, by the narrow majority of 11 in a total vote of 649.
The money market continued, easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The demurrer of Brokers Elverton R. Chapman of NewYork and John W. Macartney of this city to the indictments charging them with unlawfully refusing to answer questions before the Senate Sugar Investigating Committee will be argued Sept. 28 in the District of Columbia Criminal Court.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Z.R. Brockway, who has been for eighteen years Superintendent of the Elmira Reformatory, and who originated and made effective the system that has become known over all the world as the "Brockway" method of discipline, was to-day placed on the witness stand in the case which The New-York World has brought against the managers of the institution.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The Republican Convention for Sullivan County was held here to-day. All the towns were represented. The convention was not in every particular a harmonious one. The party is divided into two factions, known as the Couch and Thornton followings. Each party had a candidate for member of Assembly.
As the days go by there is no halt in the forward movement of the revival of trade. Encouraging reports of renewed activity are made by all classes of New-York business men.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 13. -- A burglar waited for a chance to enter the residence of George M. Pullman, at Elberon, last night. Mr. Pullman and his family have been absent more or leas from their Summer home during the month, and last night there was no one in the house except Sanger W. Pullman, the nineteen-yearold son of Mr. Pullman, and a friend.

THOMPSON, Conn., Sept. 13. -- An unsuccessful attempt to kidnap Clarence Ward, the ten-year-old son of Ferdinand Ward, the ex-Napoleon of Finance of New-York City, was made here yesterday morning. Since the death of his mother, while Ward was serving his term at Sing Sing Prison for his dishonest acts in connection with the Grant Ward failure, the child has been living here With his uncle, S.D. Green.
New-York's Postmaster, Charles W. Dayton, has been the subject of unusual attention in London during his vacation sojourn there.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- In support of the charge made by Controller Roberts that employes of the Forest Commission were in collusion with timber thieves in cutting trees upon State lands, the Controller to-day sent to the Forest Commission unsigned copies of affidavits in his possession, accusing Thomas Pofers, a forester, of allowing trees on reserved sections to be cut in consideration of certain sums.
SOMERVILLE, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Senator Hill of New-York delivered an address here to-day on the fair grounds. He talked on agriculture. It is estimated that 15,000 persons were present.

Mrs. Stella F. Langdon, the widow of Young M. Langdon of Dallas, Texas, has brought suit against the United States Mutual Accident Association of the City of New-York to recover $5,000 on an accident policy issued to her husband, under which she is named as the beneficiary.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club last evening held, in its clubrooms at 201 Montague Street, its first meeting since the early Summer, and adopted resolutions as to the tariff. The club also elected a number of officers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- An order making many changes in the stations of troops in the army will probably appear to-morrow from the War Department. The transfers are made necessary by the abandonment of the recruiting depots and the decision of Secretary Lamont, converting them into posts for troops, in furtherance of a plan to improve the methods of recruiting, already fully described in these dispatches. Army officers everywhere are greatly interested in the matter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- There has been some fear expressed that vacancies in the grade of Second Lieutenant in the army will drop off in years to come, and that within a very few years difficulty will be experienced in obtaining sufficient commissions even for the graduates of the Military Academy.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13. -- The local market is at present occupying all the attention of traders and customers in commission houses. The rush to buy the tractions is unabated. No regard is had for the intrinsic or speculative value of these stocks, and outside of Metropolitan Traction, which is on the bargain counter, all are selling at very high prices.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The announcement made yesterday that Messrs. Raines, Tracey, and Kelly had formed an alliance with Charler Roe, Fred. S. Minges, Collector Houck, and Marsenus H. Briggs, Whereby Mr. Tracey would retire as State Committeeman, to be succeeded by Mr. Briggs, has caused considerable comment here among Democrats.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13. -- The Grand Pris of an eventful season, the race which places the winner on the pedestal of Cycling fame, resulted to-day in a complete triumph for "Eddie" Bald of Buffalo in time which establishes a world record for a mile in competition.

A curious story was made public yesterday by Dr. George D. Barney of 101 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, in relation to the circumstances and motives surrounding the secret organization in the Spring of 1893 by Dr. Z. Taylor Emery, the present Health Commissioner, of the new consulting and visiting staff of the Kings County Hospital, at Flatbush.

There was a lively time in Koster Bial's Music Hall last night, which ended in the West Thirtieth Street Station House about midnight, when Oscar Hammerstein, partner of Messrs. Koster Bial, and George Kessler, a wine agent, who lives at 286 Fifth Avenue, appeared there. The latter was a prisoner on Hammerstein's complaint of disorderly conduct.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The already much discussed Government report will not "down." It still continues to receive attention of a hostile nature, however, and to indirectly affect the grain markets. The criticism by private statisticians of the correctness of its figures was the principal factor in the corn market, and, to some extent also, in the wheat market to-day.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The advance guard of the Republican cohorts made its appearance to-day. The headquarters will be established at the United States Hotel. Louis F. Payn of Chatham arrived this afternoon. He secured Parlor 6, and will be close to Thomas C. Platt, who has had Parlors 7 and 8 assigned to him in advance by telegraph, and will arrive Saturday.

The only interesting feature in the stock market yesterday was the movement in Chicago Gas. It opened at 73 3/4, which was its top price for the day; declined to 70 5/8, and closed at 70 5/8, a net loss of 3 1/4 points. There was no news regarding the property, and the decline occurred apparently with the consent of the clique which has been active in bringing about the recent advance.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 14. -- District Attorney Charles A.
