Butler, on petition of twenty-five taxpayers, to-day filed suit for the impeachment and removal from office of John Fitzpatrick, Mayor of New-Orleans, the document being filed in the Civil District Court, before Judge King. About forty-five specifications of malfeasance, non-feasance, corruption, and favoritism are charged in the petition, which makes seven columns of newspaper print.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14. -- The twenty-third annual report of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad has just been issued from the company's office. It shows a shrinkage in business caused by the general business depression and cites reasons why the regular dividend of 10 per cent. was reduced.

It is an interesting fact, and may be "significant of much," that the Republican delegates chosen on Thursday evening, who are counted as "sure for Morton," are mostly in the down-town districts, which are "hopelessly Democratic," and in which the Republican machine is still run by the old leaders.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Ferdinand Ward, of Grant Ward fame, this morning made a statement concerning the unsuccessful attempt to secure possession of his son at Thompson, Conn., yesterday.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

An early dissolution of the corporation of Koster, Bial Co., it was said yesterday, would be the outcome of the encounter on Thursday night at the Koster Bial Concert Hall, in West Thirty-fourth Street, between Oscar Hammerstein, one of the owners of the place, and George Kessler, the wine merchant.
Tammany's general Committee met last night for the first time since May.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 14. -- Robert J., the great bay gelding of the Hamlin stable, to-day paced off the fastest mile on record, accompanied by a runner, reducing his mark from the Indianapolis figure of 2:02 1/2 just a second.

Raiph Greenwood in Shooting and Fishing. I have been greatly surprised recently to observe the amount of public ignorance which exists in regard to firearms. Not long ago a gentleman visited Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, and after the performance asked the privilege of examining the guns which Miss Annie Oakley shoots, and the privilege was granted.

The ships of the American and Cunard Lines seem to have gone into the record-breaking business. The Campania and Lucania have been lowering records with great regularity here of late, and now the New-York of the American Line has got the racing fever.

A conference was held yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court, before Police Justice Voorhis, between a committee of property owners, who complained of the condition of Thirty-ninth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and Inspector McAvoy and Capt. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station.

The trials by the Commissioners of policemen accused before the Senate committee have been postponed, as the resolution adopted by the Commissioners yesterday puts it, "until the further action of the board."

It is quite clear that Mr. Brockway has been telling a straight story to the special commission appointed to investigate his management of the Elmira Reformatory. It is, as Mr. Ivins pointed out, the unreformable residuum of not more than one-fifth of the total number of inmates that gives all the trouble.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The local security market is broad in so far as West Chicago Cable stock is concerned -- broad in that there are two opinions, bears and bulls, and both are equally positive in their ideas. Although to-day's trade was not so active, it eased off from the opening at 132 1/4, and broke gradually to 130 7/8.

Justice Lawrence of the Supreme Court issued a writ or certiorari yesterday to Friend House, on the relation of ex-Ward Man James Burns, to compel the Police Commissioners to certify as to the proceedings taken before them during the recent trial of the relator, and which resulted in his dismissal from the police force.
Policeman Richard E. Mahoney of Brooklyn is in a fair way to be taken before Police Commissioner Welles on a charge of neglect of duty.

Police Justice Voorhis has on hand a peculiar case involving some of the questions brought into prominence by the Lexow committee, respecting the property alleged to have been stolen and in the hands of pawnbrokers.

The Republicans of Kings County held their Assembly District Conventions in Brooklyn last night for the election of delegates to the State Convention, to be held at Saratoga, next Tuesday. There was considerable interest taken in the election of the delegates, as there is a fight as between the Platt forces, led by Election Commissioner Jacob Worth, and the anti-Platt forces, led by ex-Naval Officer Theodore B. Willis.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14. -- An overcast sky and at times a drizzling rain kept but few society people from taking part in the bicycle run and dinner arranged, and given by James J. Van Alen to-night. The affair had been long talked of, and its novelty was a drawing card. About forty invitations were sent out, to which twenty-nine responses were received.

There was a statement in the Albany correspondence of The Tribune yesterday that "nearly all of the Republicans favor the plan of submitting the amendments together, so that the voter need cast only one ballot for the whole," apparently meaning that nearly all the Republican delegates in the Constitutional Convention are in favor of submitting the revised Constitution to a vote as a whole, and submitting none of the amendments separately.

Mr. John N. Golding has sold for S. Q. Brown, to Mrs. H. C. Martin, at about $60,000, the four-story carved-stone-front dwelling 243 Central Park West, 22.2 by 90 by 100. The dwelling is one of a striking and handsome row known as the Noble houses, between Eighty-fourth and Eighty-fifth Streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- It was apparent to-day that investors, speculators, and traders had come down town in a reflective mood, and seriously questioned the wisdom of climbing for traction issues. There is no question that those in a position to know the truth or untruth of the various rumors of consolidation and of the net earnings of the respective companies have been taking advantage of the enthusiasts, and marketed their holdings.

LIMA, Ohio, Sept. 14. -- John Kennedy of New-York was suddenly stricken with insanity on a Pennsylvania train here and conveyed to the station house. He has money and is ticketed from Chicago, to New-York. The heat and excessive drinking brought on his trouble.

The Budweiser Brewing Company of Brooklyn obtained yesterday from Justice Cullen of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, a temporary injunction restraining the United Brewers' Association of the State of New-York from continuing to boycott its product.

Dr. Frederick A. Cook, the leader of the arctic exploration party, who lives in Brooklyn, was annoyed yesterday by the publication of a dispatch from Oberlin, Ohio, to the effect that Prof. W.G. Wright of Oberlin College, who accompanied the Cook party, had said that on the evening the Miranda sank nearly all the sailors were so intoxicated that they had to be helped from the vessel when she foundered.

About Mrs. L.B. Walford there is this to be said: She is the portrayer of well-bred English men and women. Her Lord Carnoustie may be nothing more than a plodding, blundering Scotch laird, and Lady Carnoustie a pompous, self-conceited old woman, but they are proper people, and they talk good English.

The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst's attack on Recorder Smyth, and his declaration that there is a "judicial ring" in this city, attracted more or less attention yesterday. By many persons it was considered that the doctor had given out the interview in which he made this declaration with the single purpose of helping along the candidacy of John W. Goff for Recorder as against Recorder Smyth.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The Democratic members of the convention were in a state of elation to-day over the great victory which they had achieved over the Republicans by actually forcing them to positive action on the several great economic questions which the majority had originally contemplated burying in committee.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14. -- The Republicans have control of the House of Representatives in this State by a plurality of twenty-three and by a majority of twenty-two, there being one Prohibitionist -- the solitary representative of the third party being George L. James of Mansfield, Tolland County.

In spite of wet courts and threatening clouds, the tennis tournament of the Staten Island Ladies' Club was brought to an end on the courts at Livingston, S.I., yesterday afternoon. Miss Bradley of the Nyack Country Club was unable to appear to contest the final round in the doubles, so Miss Hellwig and Miss Atkinson took first prize by default.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- There is promise of a sensation in a suit just instituted in the District Court in this city growing out of the famous Chickasaw-Choctaw award. Henry Bacon, Chairman of the Board of County Commissioners of Oklahoma County, Oklahoma, and Frank Black, a lawyer of Guthrie, Oklahoma, have entered suit againat D.M. Rose, formerly of Oklahoma, but now a resident of this city.

William Gelhardt, sixteen years old, whose father, a Brooklyn policeman, not long ago killed a man named Green, for alleged alienation of his wife's affections, and committed suicide before he could be tried, was a prisoner in Yorkville Police Court yesterday.

The State Board of Mediation and Arbitration, consisting of William Purcell of Rochester, Edward Feeny of Brooklyn, and Gilbert Robinson of Troy, met yesterday, at the Broadway Central Hotel, to hear statements from the clothing contractors and the striking tailors. The tailors were represented by Hyman Robinson and the contractors by V. Witkowski.
FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 14. -- After the Democratic primaries last night some members of the party plainly expressed their feelings toward their Representative in Congress.

It was decidedly an off day at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track at Gravesend yesterday. The weather was not propitious, to say the best that can be said of it, and the quality of the horses entered was commonplace in the extreme. The attendance was remarkably good, however, under the circumstances, so that the management had no cause for complaint.

The unexpected arrival at the steamship New-York last evening upset the plans of many welcoming parties, and the committee of the Metropolitan District Cricket League, which had been appointed to receive Lord Hawke and his team of English gentlemen cricketers, was represented only by T.S. Hope-Simpson and Jerome Flannery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- There is talk of another war between Peru and Chile, and the military experts are greatly interested over the prospect. The situation, which has not been extensively advertised as yet, is regarded in well-posted quarters as very threatening.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 14. -- The Richmond County Republican Convention, for the election of delegates to the State and Congressional District Conventions, was held in Turn Hall this afternoon. The delegates were instructed to vote for Levi P. Morton for Governor by an almost unanimous vote.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 14. -- The Republican Party of Alabama has at last swallowed the Populite-Kolbite Party "lock, stock, and barrel." The Kolbites held their district convention at Blooton to-day. They agreed not to put a Congressional candidate in the Ninth District, and passed resolutions strongly-indorsing T.H. Aldrich, the nominee of the Republican Party. P.G. Bowman, W.H. Skaggs, S.M. Adams, and other leading Kolbites attended the Blocton meeting, and announced their affiliation with the Republicans.

A CARD FROM C.C. SHAYNE The past year was one of the most trying in the history of our country. Many merchants lost their business; many farmers lost their farms; many workmen lost their homes, all of which was brought about by conditions which are now well understood by the American people.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- It is said here that Chicago capitalists are going to New-York to invest some of their surplus cash. A syndicate has been formed, so the story says, to purchase the property on which the old New-York Hotel formerly stood. It occupies an entire block, bounded by Waverley Place, Washington Place, Mercer Street, and Broadway.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Sept. 14. -- The Brockway investigation by Gov. Flower's commission closed to-day after the remarkable claim had been made by the prosecution that this commission is powerless to act or even to make recommendations, and that its real case will begin when a report on the present proceedings has been submitted to the Chief Executive of the State.

Rear Admiral Edward Y. McCauly. Rear Admiral Edward Y. McCauly, United States Navy, (retired,) died yesterday at Jamestown, R.I., where he had had a Summer residence for several years past. He had been ill several months. He was born in Pennsylvania Nov. 2, 1827. He served in the Mediterranean squadron and in the war against the Chinese pirates in 1855, and resigned in 1859.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- A dispatch from Shanghai to the Central News says the foreign missionaries in the Shin-King province are fleeing to New-Chwang, fearing violence at the hands of Chinese soldiers, who it is reported are burning the Christian chapels.
NEWPORT, Sept. 14. -- Among the divorce petitions in order for the Supreme Court next week is that of Gertrude C.V. Hamilton vs. Schuyler Hamilton, Jr.

NORTHVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The Republican Congressional Convention for the Twenty-second District, composed of the counties of Fulton, Hamilton, Saratoga, and St. Lawrence, met here to-day. There were three candidates seeking the nomination, Gen. N.M. Curtis of St. Lawrence, the present insumbent: Gen. W.B. French of Saratoga, and Judge A.D.L. Baker of Gloversville.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 14. -- Great alarm has been caused by the report from both the Owens and the Breckinridge headquarters that hundreds of men secretly armed will be at each polling place in this city tomorrow, for the purpose of protecting their respective challenges.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- Local railroad securities were steady, Fitchburg preferred selling at 75, up 1/4, Boston and Albany at 206 1/2, off 1/2, while Boston and Maine scored a further advance of 1 per cent., to 153 1/2. There seemed to be considerable buying orders in Boston and Maine, and all stock offered was rapidly taken even at the advancing prices.
Can a girl with talent get on the professional stage without Influence?" was a question the Professional Woman's League was asked yesterday afternoon.

The New-York State Democracy, of which Charles S. Fairchild is Chairman and William R. Grace a leading member, took the initial steps last night toward sending a contesting delegation of ninety members to the Democratic State Convention to be held at Saratoga Springs on Sept. 25.

Rear Admiral Henry Erben, United States Navy, who until recently commanded the naval forces of this country on the European station, was a passenger by the steamship New-York, which arrived from Southampton yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Congressman W. L. Wilson of West Virginia was interviewed by a representative of the United Press, at the Hotel Savoy, this morning. Mr. Wilson said he was perfectly well, his health having improved greatly on the passage over. He was here, he said, merely on a pleasure trip, and would sail from Southampton for New-York on Sept. 29.

Ferdinand A. Marsily head of the firm of F.A. Marsilv Co., oil brokers at 18 Beaver Street, committed suicide yesterday morning, at his residence, 116 East Seventy-fourth Street, by shooting himself through the right temple. He was despondent because of ill health.

President H.H. Porter of the Department of Charities and Correction was the only witness yesterday before the State Commission in Lunacy, which is investigating charges of mismanagement of the institutions under the care of the department.

The sound of pistol shots in a stateroom on the steamboat Rhode Island, which reached her dock at the foot of Clarkson Street yesterday morning, caused considerable excitement during the boat's trip from Providence.

LEHI JUNCTION, Utah, Sept. 14. -- Enoch Davis, the wife murderer, died at 10:45 this morning with six rifle bullets in his breast. About thirty officers and reporters were present at the execution, but no minister. At 10:40 he was placed in a chair with a plank at his back.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 14. -- At a meeting yesterday of the Kelly-Tracy Second District Committee it was voted to address a communication to the Spellman Second District Committee asking it, in the interest of Democratic harmony, to hold a conference with the Kelly comittee to the end that it might be arranged to hold caucuses with an equal division of election inspectors.

Bradstreet's to-day will say: "All the features of improvement in general trade reported a week ago are retained, and from a number of the more important business centres still further gains are reported. Commercial travelers from Baltimore are making their second trip to the South, and regard the business prospects as exceptionally bright.

Having on Thurs'day anticipated by two days the end of the straw-hat season by battering all headgear of that character out of wearable shape, brokers in the wheat pit at the Produce Exchange felt themselves defied when William M. Stillwell entered the pit yesterday morning, wearing not only a straw hat, but a lawn necktie to match it.

Nobody can fail to sympathize with the efforts of the worthy people who are trying to purge certain neighborhoods in the city that have become disreputable, as a preliminary to rehabilitating them. But it must in justice be recognized that only a small part of the blame for the present condition of these neighborhoods ought to be put upon the police, and that the larger part must be borne by the property owners themselves.

NEWPORT, Sept. 14. -- Anxiety as to the short water supply here increases daily, and the matter has grown, so serious that the water works company has been, obliged today to publish a second warning against the free use of water and to request that those who have hose rights waive them and not use their hose till such time as the water supply is increased.

ALBANY, Sept. 14. -- It seemed more certain than ever that Mr. Morton's nomination would be made by acclamation when it was authoritatively announced this evening from Saratoga that Controller James A. Roberts had withdrawn from the race for the Governorship upon the advice of his political friends and his physicians.

CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The staid and humane residents of this place are indignant at the recent action of the Common Council in providing for the extermination of the colony of itinerant dogs which infests this locality. E.W. Barnes has been appointed official canine catcher and executioner.

The steamship Capac, which arrived here yesterday from Brazilian ports, had an exciting experience with fire during the voyage. The fire was discovered Aug. 11, in the amidship bunker of the vessel. The ship was then off the Brazilian coast.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 14. -- The Northern Pacific receivers will take no action to bring Henry Villard to account for his alleged fraudulent transactions in connection with the Northern Pacific Railroad unless Instructions are given them by Judge Jenkins.

The Harlem Wheelmen's race meet at Manhattan Field to-day should prove the most interesting event of the kind which New-Yorkers have had so near at home for a long time. The committees of the club have bene hard at work for weeks past, and everything that experience could suggest to bring out good fields and for the comfort of the contestants and public has been attended to.

Domino and Henry of Navarre will meet at 4:30 this afternoon in their race at a mile and an eighth at the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club. This hour has been fixed so as to accommodate business men who may wish to see the contest. A good day and a good track are necessary to the race, so that in case of rain it will not be run.

AUBURN, N. Y., Sept. 14. -- The Democratic Judicial Convention is called to meet in Rochester Thursday, Sept. 27, to choose two candidates for Justice of the Supreme Court for the Seventh Judicial District. The Republicans at their convention, Sept. 4, unanimously renominated Justice William Rumsey of Bath, and, with like unanimity, selected County Judge William E. Werner of Monroe to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Francis A. Macomber.

A radical change in the Board of Directors of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad has been brought about within the past two days. In recognition of a sentiment prevailing among the stockholders in favor of a change of management, several members of the old board resigned, and their places, as well as two or three previously-existing vacancies, have been filled by the election of new men.
Chauncey M. Depew arived home from Europe on the American Line steamship New-York last evening.

It ought hardly to be one of the functions of the Controller of the Currency to educate public opinion in the simplest and most fundamental principles of sound finance, but since that function is obviously and imperatively required, it is a great advantage to the country to have a Controller with so happy a gift for such work as Mr. Eckels.

The title of the very latest play by Henry Arthur Jones, author of "The Bauble Shop" and "The Masqueraders" Is "The Case of Rebellious Susan." It is a comedy, and it is to be played in London at the Criterion Theatre, by Charles Wyndham and his company and in New-York at the Lyceum by Daniel Frohman's company.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Sumner C. Blackman of Elm Street gave a reception at their home on Wednesday evening. Miss Gertrude Koehler, Miss Emma Anderson, and Miss Lucy Blackman assisted in receiving.

To clean porcelains, the best plan is to use soft soap, with an old toothbrush. Should they be very dirty, a little vitriol and water may be used, but not on those decorated over the glaze. The edges of a piece that has been broken and badly mended require the greatest care in cleaning, for, if not thoroughly cleaned, they cannot be made to properly adhere to one another.
PARIS, Sept. 15 -- The Gaulois says that on the occasion of the visit of the Due d'Aumale to Stowe House, after the funeral of the Count of Paris, the Due d'Orleans, bursting into tears, said:

The reactionary movement of the market has continued through the past week, and the close yesterday was weak. The material utilized to bear prices was the crop shortage, which has been very thoroughly worked up. None better for the purpose could be had, because a disaster to either one of our important crops is a calamity under any circumstances.

A gentleman who has just returned from a visit to the South, and whose opinions are accepted in financial circles, in this city as those of a conservative and careful observer, entitled to great weight, has some things to say concerning the condition of affairs in the Southern country that are worhty of consideration.
The sales at auction referred to in the accompanying list will be had at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated:

The word, "vignette," is commonly used to signify any small picture in a book, though originally it referred only to the vinelike border of a little picture. Webster gives another definition, a little picture the edges of which gradually fade away. "Vignettes," therefore, seems to be a happily-chosen title for these short sketches of New-York scenes, for they are certainly little pictures, and they fade away at the edges.

The construction of the new bridge and elevated railroad station in Washington Street, between Sands and High Streets, Brooklyn, has suggested many new things in the way of bridge improvements to the officers of the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad, as well as to the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Senator Faulkner, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, who has been in New-York several days for the express purpose of ascertaining the political situation, returned to Washington to-day, fully impressed with the opinion that the outlook for Democratic success in the State is much better than some people would have the country believe.

HE gayety and social life which have made the season in the romantic Catskills most delightful are now like a story that is told, but not forgotten. Autumn, with its clear, bracing air, has placed its mark upon the forests, and the view from every hill and mountain top is now one grand panorama of red and gold.

The coming October will mark the beginning of a new era in the history of the American merchant marine. About the 19th of that month, there will be launched from the yard of the William Cramp Sons Ship and Engine Building Company at Philadelphia the largest vessel ever built in this country.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Miss Elizabeth Edgar of Plainfleld, N.J., about sixty years old, who was visiting here today with her niece, Mrs. C.M. Morse of Buffalo, was run over and instantly killed by a trolley car in the Canadian Park, about 4 o'clock this afternoon. The accident occurred while Miss Edgar was attempting to go toward her niece, who was approaching in a carriage.
The tailors' strike was enlivened yesterday by an attempt on the part of the strikers to rescue one of their number from a policeman, and were in turn clubbed and arrested themselves.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The County of Westchester, the rapidly-growing northern suburb of New-York City, has a medical society, in the membership or which are enrolled the names of all the most prominent members of the profession in that district.

In another part of this paper will be found some very sensible and timely remarks from Garden and Forest upon the necessity of providing irrigation for the public parks. Whoever visited Central Park between the middle of July and the beginning of September was made aware that it will not do to depend, in such a Summer as this has been, upon the bounty of nature for the freshness and beauty of the Park lawns.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Probably the most unique fishing ground to be found in the United States, if not in the world, is situated in this city.

In the early days the three-card trick was not the national institution it has since become; the "gentlemen, of the road" at that time used the three thimbles. The Cambridge Line was much infested by these persons till cleared of them by a wellknown personage, whom I will call Mr. Hunt.

The Young Men's Association of Rutherford, N.J., held its first annual regatta on the Passaic River yesterday afternoon. Most of the races were, for canoes, and though started two hours late, proved very interesting to the crowds that waited patiently on both banks of the river. A large number of canoemen from neighboring clubs were present, and they obtained several of the prizes.
The new Committee of Seventy was announced yesterday afternoon.

The schooner Emerald won the Larchmont Cup; the schooner Viator beat the Loyal for a small cup; the cutter Wasp beat the Gloriana in a match race; the rater Pyzie beat the Madrine in another match, and the Dorothy won the last race of the twenty-one-foot series at Larchmont yesterday.
The woman violinist is still sufficiently rare to be marked, and even among the comparatively few of such musicians the soloist Miss Bertha Behrends is conspicnous.

I know Montmartre chiefly by night; it is not a place for the day; and the view of Paris which I am thinking of is the view of Paris by night.

Brereton, who visited Edinburgh in 1636, is not complimentary; he describes the people as "most sluttish, nasty, and slothful," and there does, indeed, seem to be a general consensus of opinion that their habits were not over nice, "only the nobles and better sort of them brave, well-bred men and much reformed."

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- By a vote of 26 to 19 the Fourth District Republican Convention to-day instructed its delegates to the State Convention to vote for Levi P. Morton for Governor and William Barnes, Jr., for State Committeeman for Albany County. This finally settles the contest over State Committeeman, and Mr. Barnes will be retained.

Mr. Thompson takes exception to the presence of Mgr. Satolli, "nominally Archbishop of Lepanto in Greece." "He is called the delegate, but in view of the fact that he fully represents the Pope as his other self, and that his powers are so complete and plenary that no appeal can be taken from his decisions, it is more appropriate to call him Pope."

The eleventh century established the rupture between the Greek and the Latin Churches, which has never yet been closed; but which, on the contrary, has, it is to be feared, been seriously widened by the proceedings of the Vatican Council of 1870 -- proceedings which appear to have so greatly sharpened the edges of Papal infallibility.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The removal of the air guns from the Vesuvius has been the occasion of interesting research, by ordnance experts. This research has had to do with the study of high explosives, their preservation and operation. Time was when the accepted view of high explosives did not admit of their being fired from a gun unless it was specially built for that purpose.

Detective Sergeant George V. Zundt, who is attached to the Brooklyn Fire Headquarters, made his report to Commissioner Welles yesterday in answer to the charges preferred against him by Charles M. Patterson before the Lexow committee.

In the face of the revelations of the last six months nobody pretends to deny the existence of serious abuses and corruption in the Police Department of this city, and it is not yet possible to discern the full limit of the evil. But the plea is made that the abuses are of long standing, and that no particular party or administration is responsible for them or has had the power to eradicate them.

In no country are municipal pawnshops more highly developed than in France, and in no city does the institution bulk so largely in public interest as in Paris. There is no general law regulating monts de piete in France. The business of lending money on pledges is removed from the control of individuals, and the establishment of pawnshops is made a matter of local and municipal concern.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- The New-Yorks won the ball game to-day by timely batting. Breitenstein. who has been reinstated, pitched a fairly good game, but the Giants bunched their hits. In the evening Breitenstein was married.

British service journals are devoting much space to a series of tests of a new type of capped shell which the Admiralty has ordered. The trials are for the purpose of arriving at the true result of the recent experiments which took place near St. Petersburg and in which the Russians claimed to have discovered a magnetic shell that could easily penetrate Harveyized steel.

Some, very interesting races characterized the National Circuit bicycle meet of the Harlem Wheelmen on Manhattan Field yesterday. There were about 8,000 persons present to enjoy the sport. Several falls happened, but, while the track is inferior for cycle racing, it cannot be said in fairness that it was responsible for all the bad "spills."

III. -- A Little Romantic Revival. The evening is chilly, and the lamps are lighted, in the little sitting room of the suburban cottage. Pa, who has had a good day in the city, sits at the centre table, his newspaper fallen on his knees, twiddling his eyeglasses in a pleasing reverie, and Ma, as usual, is occupied with her knitting.

The Paris correspondent of a London print has been interviewing our countryman, Mr. Ward McAllister, in the French capital, and puts him on record as loyal to American beauties over all others. But Mr. McAllister will have to refute the assertion that he is past seventy. No one who knows him can believe that. Says The Gentlewoman:

There was nothing to indicate yesterday that the Commercial Alliance Life Insurance Company of this city had settled its troubles with the State Insurance Department. The time by which the company was to furnish the $76,000 necessary to make good, the impairment of its reserve expired at noon.

BATH, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The Democratic Convention of the First Assembly District of Steuben was held here to-day and was a harmonious gathering. Every town was represented except one. The character of the delegations showed that the general design of all was for such harmonious action as would be crowned with, victory in November.

From Garden and Forest. The lower portion of Central Park, which was constructed first, was partially provided with facilities for watering, and here are many irrigated spots and strips which show how delightful the whole Park now might be if it had all been similarly treated. Liberal apportionments have been made for park maintenance in some directions.

The opening of the new season at Palmer's Theatre last night would doubtless have been livelier if the weather had been less warm and moist. Many representative "first nighters" were there, and the company in the auditorium was almost as brilliant as some gatherings in fashionable city theatres when the season is at its height.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The bicycle is to be used in the army to a certain extent. An officer of the Signal Corps stationed in Texas has been authorized to purchase a bicycle having a reel attachment. It is intended to use this machine in the construction of telegraph lines. The reel will carry the wire, and will pay it out as the bicycle travels along.

The Constitutional Convention has adjourned to next Thursday to allow the Committee on Revision to get in final shape the various amendments that have been adopted. It is expected that the convention will then decide upon the form and manner in which the several propositions will be submitted to a vote and adjourn sine die on Saturday.

Coffee houses have received advices from the planting districts in the last few days on which they are making estimates of the crop for the season of 1894-5. Figures vary, but the opinion seems general that the crop will be the largest ever grown.

At Huntsville, Ala., is a State Normal and Industrial School, the Principal of which is W.H. Councill, a colored man of much Intelligence, and attending it are between 150 and 200 negro students, male and female. Under Mr. Councill, the school has had much success. In the industrial department are taugrht such trades as printing, blacksmithing, wagonmaking, and shoemaking, and here the results have been especially gratifying.

Beside their crisp cleverness, their dainty humor, and the sunshiny atmosphere of the bracing, clear-cut West the language of criticism is flat, stale, and unprofitable.

Wagner came on the stage at the close of the fourth performance, ("Gotterdammerung,") and said in the course of a short allocution: "Have a will, and you will have an art; it rests with you." These words were immediately interpreted as meaning that, according to Wagner, art dates, in Germany, at least, from Wagner, and that all that has been done before him does not count.

A small cabinet of historical bricks was presented to the Maritime Exchange yesterday by Andrew Saul, a member of the Exchange Museum Committee and Superintendent of the New-York Merchant Police, as an addition to the curiosities in its museum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- When the President returns to the White House next month he will assuredly be impressed by the fresh appearance of the building. Inside and out, the mansion is being thoroughly renovated, and by Oct. 1 every nook and cranny will be fit for inspection by the most careful housekeeper in the land.

BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- The railroad stocks were inactive to-day, the only quotations being a few shares of Fitchburg preferred at 75, the same price as yesterday; Chicago Junction at 93, which was off 1/4, and the preferred at 100@100 1/2, closing at the latter figure, a decline of 1 1/2 per cent. Bay State Gas was the active feature of the local market.

Mrs. Lizzie Fanning of 52 West Twenty-sixth Street and John P. Powers, a driver for a dry goods firm, were the means of putting in the hands of the police yesterday afternoon two thieves who are believed to have committed many robberies up town.

The "Boscobel Tracts" supply the groundwork for the story of Charles II.'s attempted escape after the battle of Worcester, The blacksmith at Charmouth had been Called in, as one of the horses had cast a shoe, and it is somewhat hard to understand why he did not send for Capt. Macy and his soldiers on the chance of gaining the reward.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- Baltimore Traction was the feature of the local market to-day. It opened at an advance of 1 per cent., and continued active and strong the entire session. The traction stocks have been taken up in turn. People's and Piladelphia look toppy, and will be sold on Baltimore's advance, for Philadelphia has just appreciated the fact that the stock is cheap, by comparison with Hestonville common, at 57 1/2.
Rumor that the Senate committee will, Oct. 1, renew its exposure of police iniquity in a startlingly sensational fashion made the tongues of the rank and file of the department wag yesterday.

Some interesting facts concerning the tenement-house population of the city are given In a report which has been submitted to the Board of Health by Dr. Roger S. Tracy, Deputy Register of Vital Statistics.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The Asylums of Middletown, N.Y., were beaten at baseball by the Orange Athletic Club this afternoon in their third and deciding game of the season. It was largely a batting game, and quite evenly contested. About 2.000 people saw it. The score:

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 15. -- Capt. William R. Bridgman, United States Navy, former commander of the cruiser Baltimore, died here this morning at 8 o'clock of Asiatic, fever. He had command of the Baltimore until last July, when he left the vessel in Asiatic waters. He went to Tacoma last August to visit his brother.

A.A. Vantine Co. will open to the public to-morrow a truly remarkable exhibition, consisting of a series of rooms furnished after the styles of Oriental countries. Persian, Indian, Chinese, Japanese, and Moorish apartments are accurately reproduced.
"Yes, it is quite a hobby of mine," she said, with a smile.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Underneath a seeming stagnation of politics, two highly-important movements are progressing. The movement of first importance is the initiative step of the Chamberlain Unionists, who are about to merge with the Conservatives, partly with a view of consolidating the antihome rule forces in the coming general elections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- One who stood in front of the bulletin board of the United Press to-night could not help observing that intense interest was felt in the outcome of the attempt of W.C.P. Breckinridge of Kentucky to get a renomination to Congress. Hundreds watched the board from an early hour until it became apparent that Breckinridge was hopelessly defeated, and the majority expressed their satisfaction with the result.
"Our Forefathers' Day," the two hundred and fifty-sixth anniversary of the settlement on the shores of Delaware Bay by the Swedes, was remembered last night by the Swedish singing society Lyran.

Columbia College students, when they return to their studies the first of next month, will notice several changes in the library. The constant accumulation of books keeps the problem of properly shelving them continually before the librarian and his staff, and, as the room itself is not increased, it is a more difficult matter to solve year after year.

Auctioneer P.C. Kidd of Tattersalls held a Good sale of race horses in training in the paddock of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday morning, and for twenty-three head secured $15,280. The horses were the property of the Camden Stable, for which a receiver had been appointed; Messrs Gilpin Taylor, who have dissolved partnership; the Manhattan Stable, and a number of others.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Sept. 15 -- The steamer Sikh, sailing for the Orient to-day, carries away three Chinese who are in a peculiar predicament. They left China at the beginning of the trouble with Japan, landing at Victoria, and made their way across the continent, attempting an entrance into New-York.

The annual ladies' tournament of the Rutherford Tennis Club was played yesterday afternoon on the courts of the club at Rutherford, N.J. It resulted in a victory for Miss Bertha Parker, after a very exciting contest with Miss Adele Allison and Hiss Mabel Parker. Miss Allison won second prize. A large number of Members and their guests watched the contests.

Col. Henry Oakes Kent, nominated by acclamation for Governor of New-Hampshire by the Democratic State Convention at Concord on Sept. 6, was born and has always lived in the town of Lancaster, in that State. The family is of English origin, and its progenitor in this country was among the first settlers of Newbury, Mass., locating there in 1635.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The delegates denied seats in the Democratic Convention held in Ithaca Sept. 5, with a very large number of representative Democrats from every town in Tompkins County, assembled at the Clinton House this afternoon. Barnum R. Williams was chosen Chairman and Willis D. Crittenden Secretary. Prof. B.I. Wheeler, C.C. Platt, and Nelson E. Lyon were chosen delegates to the Saratoga Convention by acclamation.
The Volunteer Firemen's Association had its annual parade yesterday, headed by the Volunteer Firemen's Band.

BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- The Falcon, Lieut. Peary's boat, backed out of a berth at Constitution Wharf, this city, the evening of July 5, 1893, and under her own steam started for the open sea. At Portland Lieut. and Mrs. Peary boarded the craft, at St. John's she coaled up, and at Labrador dogs and furs were taken on board.

NEWPORT, R.I. Sept. 15 EWPORT is having a quiet September, partly because society was well tired out with August's merry making, and partly because the people who did so much to make; that month the gray one that it was feel that they have done their share, of entertaining.

NE scene follows another in rapid succession in this eventful town. Plumed knights, lawn-tennis enthusiasts, and Populists filled the conclave, tournament, and convention dates this week, and have disap- peared from the Saratoga stage.

The New Forest? But how new? The early Saxons called it "Ytene," and it was old to them. Possibly some of the oaks were saplings when Julius Caesar came to Britain. American lads know of the New Forest, because history books tell how Rufus, William's son. met his death there, but how he came to a sudden, end has always been somewhat of a mystery.

BERLIN, Sept. 15 -- Political interest has centred at Varzin for the past few days. Everybody more or less directly connected with the Government is surmising what Prince Bismarck will say to the 1,200 Posen farmers who are expected to visit him tomorrow, and to the West Prussian delegation which is to be received by him one week later.

From The Milwaukee Sentinel. Little Archie Crowley of Dellwood, Minn., is probably the youngest railway manager in the world. Archie is but seven years old, yet he controls an entire electrical railroad. It is true that the road is but one-tenth of a mile in length, nevertheless it is fitted out just as completely as any road that is run by grown persons.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- On Tuesday, the softest and yet the sunniest day of this season, which has been so gloomy with us, I drove from Buckingham to Stowe House to see Philippe VII., Comte de Paris, lying in state. No American visiting England, if he can secure a real English Summer day, should pass through without paying Stowe House a visit.

The Reading and Literary Circle of St. Francis Xavier's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, will hold a fair and bazaar in the clubhouse of the Xavier Club, Garfield Place, near Sixth Avenue, Prospect Heights, next Friday and Saturday nights. The object of the fair is to provide funds for furnishing the ladies' reception room of the clubhouse.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- A dispatch to the Central News from Tokio says: "News has been received from Fusan that a Japanese corps from Genian has engaged and routed the enemy at Sing-Chuen, and that the Japanese advancing army had engaged and routed the enemy at Chueng-Chwa.

In the eleventh century the Valley of the Danube was reopened, through, the conversion, of the Huns, and pilgrimages to the Holy Land began. By degrees the pilgrims came to march in armies. In 1099 the Crusaiders stormed Jerusalem, and in the early years of the twelfth century the Latin kingdom grew up along the coast of Palestine and Syria.

Yachtsmen are now beginning to discuss the probabilities of a race next year for the America's Cup. That there will be a race there seems little doubt, but there is sure to be a lot of correspondence on both sides before the conditions are agreed upon.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 15 -- There were flowers and pretty women and handsome horses in the tub parade this afternoon, and the affair was much of a success, owing mainly to the efforts of Miss A. Moller and J.W. Haven, son of G.G, Haven. They started out among the cottagers and got no less than thirty-one carriages in line, which is seven more than last year.

Chicago Gas almost monopolized the attention of the Stock Exchange yesterday. It opened weak at 69 1/2, sold down to 69 1/8, and then rallied to 70 7/8, closing at 70 3/4, a net gain of 1/8. The opinion was that the urgent liquidation had been completed, and that the pool was again ready to support it. More than 25 per cent, of the day's business was done in this stock.

We regret to say that this volume does not leave an agreeable impression. There runs through it an expression of intense dissatisfaction. Unquestionably, the life of the wife of a cavalry officer, who sees herself active service on the frontier, is a most comfortless one, since it subjects a woman to terrible inconveniences.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Republican leaders from all over the State arrived on the afternoon and evening trains, and the corridors and piazzas of the big hotels presented an animated appearance to-night.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- After a conference lasting an hour and a half, the receivers of the Reading Railroad Company to-day approved the reorganization plan conceived by George H. Earle, Jr., President of the Finance Company of Pennsylvania, and perfected by the Olcott-Earle Reorganization Committee.

Something very new in needlework is scrim, tinted and outlined with gold thread. As the greater part of the work is done with the brush, perhaps needlework is something of a misnomer, but a part of the labor, at least, is done with the needle, and the painting is so simple as to require no especial skill.

The champion cricket team of the New-Jersey Athletic Club played its second game of the championship series of the Metropolitan League with the Morris Heights Club yesterday, at Berkeley Oval, and gained an easy victory, by 91 runs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The market was very irregular. West Chicago was active, but varied only 14 in price, closing at 131, 1/8 above the last sales of yesterday. Strawboard jumped a point, to 34, on purchases of 300 shares. Diamond Match declined steadily from the opening, at 129 to 128 1/4 at the close, without reacting a fraction.

The lives of Turkish women are dull and monotonous in the extreme, but Friday, being the day they go to mosque or to visit their cemeteries, they often take that opportunity to look at the soldiers passing by. On the Bechiktache Road you see numbers of them squatted on the curbstone, where they remain for hours, chatting and looking about them.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 15. -- The will of the late Mrs. Jane M. Aspinwall of Messina, Barrytown, widow of John L. Aspinwall, has been admitted to probate by Surrogate Dorland, in the Dutchess County Probate Court. The estate will probably approximate $1,000,000, although the amount is not known yet.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- It takes money to run an election under the Werts ballot reform law. There are 5,322 Judges, Inspectors, and clerks of Elections, all under pay. The Judges and Inspectors of Elections number 3,548. These also serve as the Board of Registration. They each average about nine days, get $3 a day, and the law fixes eight hours as a day.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- Under the law which created it, the Constitutional Convention of the State of New-York, the first held in twenty-six years, should have adjourned today, sine die. It failed to do so, as did the convention of 1867-8, which, like this, was dominated by Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The loftiest civilization and the lowest features of the time when the world was young meet in Washington as elsewhere. Here there is a well-endowed college for the education of the negro, and there are men and women of color, equivalent in mind and polite usage to the best-trained in society, but here are also the most ignorant of the negro race.

Wesley Pittman or Singree, the African boy who came here last Sunday on the bark Liberia, from Monrovia, to be educated for a missionary, is still on board the vessel, waiting for some one to claim him.

The Democratic Commissioners of Elections of Kings County refused yesterday to name as Registrars of Election the men recommended by Edward M. Shepard for the General Committee of the Democratic Party. They recognized the committee of which James D. Bell is Chairman, and appointed 682 Registrars of Election on its recommendation.
LENOX, Mass., Sept. 15 HERE were three dances, archery, tub parade, dinners, tea parties, golf, and coaching parties this week, keeping Lenox in incessant gayety.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Here in Frederick. Md., lies buried Francis Scott Key, the author of our immortal national anthem, "The Star-Spangled Banner." On Sept. 12 (the anniversary of the battle of North Point, in 1814,) were held over the grave of the poet unusual and impressive ceremonies. Eighty years ago Key was held prisoner on a British ship the night through, watching, perforce, the bombardment of Fort McHenry.

The season of 1894-5 is to be a memorable one in the history of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. The bill of fare is now prepared, and such a feast of reason and flow of soul is awaiting the happy members of the institute that they may well be intoxicated by its richness.

Mr. George Curzon, in his book on "Japan, Corea, and China," devotes a number of pages to the subject of Christian missions in the far East. His account is mainly a statement of the difficulties with which the missionaries have to contend. Mr. Curzon gives the strongest commendation to certain features of missionary life in the East.

The Royal Mosque of Futtehpor-Sikri faces a cloistered quadrangle with massive colonnades supporting a broad, red sandstone roof, protected by a perforated parapet, and surmounted by a host of tiny cupolas. The barbed battlements of the outer wall suggest the former presence of those necessary defenses which rendered every; Eastern mosque and palace a possible fortress.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The bicycle races here to-day were run off in fine order and good sport was enjoyed by the people of the town and a large number of visitors from the neighboring towns. The day was almost perfect and the track in fine condition. The lists of prises offered were of the finest style and very costly.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 15 -- The Leader prints the following to-day:

A woman who has spent some time abroad tells as one of her most intersting experiences across the water of a trip from Paris to Constantinople on the famous Orient express, than which we have nothing really better in railroad service, even in this country, famed for such things. "Only sixty passengers are allowed on each train," she says, "and the fare is about $60 for a ride of two days and eighteen hours.

I, John Marshall, Doctor of Medicine and sort of all-round investigator, had my attention drawn to the peculiar state of affairs in Wall Street by the following headlines, which appeared in The New-York Times on the morning of Saturday, Aug. 4, 189 -- : "Panic in Wall Street. Tremendous Shrinkage in Values.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Secretary Carlisle has reiterated his decision not to pay bounty on sugar, in a letter sent to-day to Senator Manderson of Nebraska, in which he says:

The recent fight between two cock ostriches at the Coronado Ostrich Farm, across the bay from San Diego, Cal., was a memorable event. Cock fights, bull fights, and prize fights have little of the terrifying aspects of a contest between full-grown, angry ostriches. The amazing leg power of an ostrich surpasses that of the biggest, surliest Government mule in existence.

Pope's jingling rhyme about a little learning and the Pierian spring does not find a place among the maxims of the Chautauqua. Literary and Scientific Circle. That excellently managed and eminently useful institution owes its success chiefly to a conviction contrary to any belief that a man or woman who may not know a great deal about a given subject should be left altogether without knowledge of it.

The students of the Deaf-and-Dumb Institute, at One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street and the Boulevard, are going to learn more about gymnastics and athletic work this year than they ever knew before. Trevanion G. Cook, who was appointed physical director last Spring, resumed his work with the opening of the school a few days ago.

J. Lichtenstein Sons will open their new building at 64 West Twenty-third Street to-morrow. The event marks the addition of another handsome and thoroughly-equipped dry goods establishment to Twenty-third Street. The new store is six stories high and extends through to Twenty-second Street. The front is artistic, and its large show windows are well adapted to display the attractive goods that will occupy them hereafter.

The performance of the gelding Robert J. in pacing a mile at Terre Haute on Friday in 2:01 1 / 2 is calculated to arrest the attention even of those who take least interest in what used to be called the trotting turf, but must at present, for want of a better name, be called the harness turf.

The great cricket match of the year will start to-morrow morning, when Lord Hawke and his team of English gentlemen cricketers will commence their match with the New-York eleven. Every preparation for the game has been made, and a splendid wicket has been got ready on the handsome grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club, at Livingston.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The Yachting World, in an article under the caption, "The Lesson of the Season," says: "This has been the most remarkable year since 1851, and when the slight degree of friction occasioned by the unfortunate occurrences to the Vigilant has passed away it will be universally admitted that the pressure has been beneficial.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 15. -- The Peary main and auxiliary expeditions, with all well on board, arrived to-day from Falcon Harbor, which they left Aug. 26. Peary, with Lee and Henson as volunteers, remains at the headquarters at Falcon Harbor, to complete their explorations next season.

Policeman Owens of the Twenty-fifth Precinct was sent on Friday to watch the body of the suicide Adolph Marsilly at his home, 116 East Seventy-fourth Street. He was ordered to remain there from 3 until 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 15. -- By a fire, which burned from 5 A.M. until 10:15 A.M. to-day, and during which four firemen were injured by the fall of a root on which they stood, fully $300,000 damage was done to property in the heart of the business section of this city.

In the latest reports of the Brooklyn pilgrims to Lourdes, it is stated that a member of St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, has become a convert to the Catholic faith. As the reported recreant member has not yet returned from the pilgrimage the church has not been notified of any defection in its ranks.

The pretty, bare feet of little Dorothy Drew, Mr. Gladstone's granddaughter, are getting to be almost as well known and as much in evidence as those of the immortal "Trilby." It has been a theory of Dorothy's parents that she shall be brought up barefooted, and barefooted she is on most occasions.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 15 -- The popular notion that New-Hampshire when she made a statesman of Blair did her very worst was quite upset last week when the Republicans of the Second District of this State nominated "Salvation Cy" Sulloway to be Blair's successor. Blair could have had the nomination, but he beguiled himself into believing that he could be elected a United States Senator, and entered the field against Mr. Chandler.

Bettering conditons and more numerous transactions have been features of the past week in the real estate business. Brokers say it is easier than it was to get men to look at property, and that there is more of a disposition to buy. There is no "boom," or anything resembling it, but investors and traders are on the alert for desirable parcels, and orders are in many brokers' offices to buy specific kinds.

Heavy villains, leading gentlemen, Irish, Dutch, and Yankee comedians, song-and-dance men, musical artists, and other actors to the number of nearly 500 have joined the ranks of federated labor by taking out a charter under the American Federation of labor, of which Samuel Gompers is President, as the "Actors' Protective Union, No. 1, of the City of New-York."

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- The Committees on Privileges and Elections and Contingent Expenses reported to the Constitutional Convention this morning in favor of allowing the five delegates seated from the Sixth District $1,500 counsel fees and $500 expenses. Laid on the table.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 15 -- The cause of decency triumphed at the polls in Kentucky to-day.

NORFOLK, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Norfolk has beauties appreciated more and more every year, and an unquestioned claim as an ideal New-England town. In the list of Stockbridge, Lenox, Pittsfield, the Lees, and others, whose names evoke landscapes beautiful and restful, Norfolk must be included. It may not perhaps be as well known as others, but changes made within the past few years have added intensity to its natural beauties, advantages, and favor.

From The Washington Post. A well-known young attorney, living not a stone's-throw from the City Hall, was the principal actor in a comedy-drama that is at present convulsing the immediate neighborhood. He was returning from a nocturnal drive a few nights since, and, on turning into the alley where he stables his horse, that animal suddenly stopped, and, with a snort of terror, stood as if transfixed.

From Cassier's Magazine. With all that has been said of early ocean steamships and the historic transatlantic voyages of the paddle steamers Sirius and Great Western, away back in 1838, the fact is less well known that the real forerunner of the mammoth screw steamers of the present day was the steamship Great Britain, commenced in 1839 and floated in 1845 -- the first scew steamer to cross the Atlantic.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- A Small demand for gold for shipment to the Continent exists here. Some gold has also gone to Egypt this week, but the movement is a usual one at this time of the year. Neither of these influences is of much importance and has not affected interest rates, which remain weak.
The thirty-sixth annual convention of the German Roman Catholic Central Verein begins to-day.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- The politicians of Westchester County have begun to strive in earnest, and the aspirants for the various offices are flitting hither and thither in their endeavors to capture the delegates who have been chosen or to secura the support of this or that political leader in his township.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Acting Postmaster General Jones this afternoon notified Postmaster George at Providence, R.I., that the department had yesterday stricken from the rolls the name of Assistant Postmaster Williams of that place, because of irregularities by the latter in the performance of his duties.

County Clerk Henry D. Purroy, who returned from Europe on the Augusta Victoria Friday, agrees essentially with Mayor Gilroy on the necessity of nominating excellent candidates for municipal offices this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The indicated revenue for the month of September, as shown by the receipts for the first fifteen days, are $27,000,000. So far the receipts have aggregated $13,567,350, of which $9,762,000 have been from customs, $3,225,000 from internal revenue and the remainder from miscellaneous resources.
The Tammany Hall Committee of the Second Assembly District toad a brief and entirely harmonious meeting in the rooms of the Patrick Divver Association, 59 Madison Street, last evening.

Every year Yankee ingenuity evolves some new temptation for shoppers in the big dry goods stores in form of a luxury hitherto not possible to persons of moderate means. The flood of pretty pictures, daintily framed, now displayed in shops not claiming to be art galleries, turns those big marts into veritable educators to the masses.

In the matter of "athletic entertainments" of the Seaside Club of Coney Island, Mayor Schieren, with characteristic faithfulness, has not hesitated to do his duty, and do it to the full. Under his direction, Commissioner Welles has taken steps to put an end to the "knock-out" contests of the club.

"If I am sometimes lax in my churchgoing at home," says a New-York woman, "I never am while I'm away. Every summer Sunday sees me in the little country church at L --, and I insist that my children shall be equally regular at the Sunday school. The big city church does not need me but in that little, struggling congregation I and mine count appreciably."

It must have been the "wicked Mr. Hyde" who declined on Saturday last in the editorial columns of our neighbor, The New-York Tribune, to see any encouraging indication in the recent great and rapid increase of the pig-iron output, and who based his gloomy observations upon a comparison of the weekly output at present with the maximum weekly output in the year 1891, rather than with the rate of production two or three months ago.

From The Toronto Truth. It is very interesting to observe the progress of mind power in its struggle with the brutal forces of matter. A Boston woman has carried the science of mind power to such perfection that she asserts that it is not what one eats, but what one thinks he eats, that satisfies the stomach and sustains life.
Alexander Salvini, the actor, arrived in New-York yesterday on the French liner La Champagne. He was accompanied by his wife, formerly Maude Dixon, the actress.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Charles Krebs, a leading hardware merchant in this city, tried to commit suicide this evening by shooting himself in the head with a revolver at his home on Cross Street. He is still alive, but unconscious, and the three physicians who are attending him hold out little hope of his recovery.

Some of our contemporaries seem to find a sort of amusement in calling attention to the advocacy of reciprocity treaties by The Times and its comment on the reciprocal agreements made under Mr. Blaine as inconsistent with the Democratic platform. We confess it had not occurred to us to consult the platform, preferring to base our opinion on the statistics of trade.

The battle for the cricket championship of New-York is rapidly drawing to a close, and in two more weeks the contests will be decided. The New-Jersey Athletic Club preserves its unbeaten record, and nothing can now prevent its team gaining the pennant. The Harlem and New-York clubs are having a great race for the second-section championship, and they will wind up the season in all probability tied for the lead.

An elaborate plan and agreement for the reorganization of the Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railroad has been prepared by the Reorganization Committee and will be officially promulgated to-day. The committee is composed as follows: George W. Murray, Chairman; Thomas A. McIntyre, William H. Male, Joseph Richardson, and Henry S, Redmond. The Messrs. Hoadly, Lauterbach, and Johnson are counsel to the committee.

Michael De George, an Italian real estate and insurance agent at 33 Liberty Street, whose home is at 165 Avenue A, was arrested last Saturday morning, charged with attempted arson. In the Essex Market Police Court yesterday he was held in $2,000 bail for examination this afternoon.
The Rev. John Pilkinton, pastor of the Windsor Terrace Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, attended a mind-reading entertainment in the Criterion Theatre, Brooklyn.
The Rev. Dr. Louis Albert Banks spoke in the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, yesterday, on "The Hero and the Suicide in Modern Life." He said, in part.

John Swinton, the well-known journalist and orator, was taken ill suddenly yesterday afternoon while addressing a large meeting of the Kossuth Monument Association, at Arlington Hall, in St. Mark's Place.

COLUMBUS, Sept. 16. -- The prospect to-night is that the Democratic State Convention Wednesday will adopt a resolution censuring Senator Brice for his course in blocking the Wilson Tariff bill. If it shall not be done, it will be because the threat made by the Senator's friends that he will resign if censured and let Gov. McKinley appoint a Republican has whipped enough timid Administration men into line to make a compromise resolution possible.

MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 -- After being closed all of last week, the Washington Bridge across the Housatonic River, between the towns of Milford and Stratford, is open again for public travel. The Superior Court, in an injunction, ordered it opened.
CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 16 -- Congress reassembled this evening. The President read his message, which is substantially as follows:
Pastors of several Brooklyn, and NewYork, congregations made the question of the right of man to kill himself the subject of their sermons yesterday.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 16. -- New-Jersey has just reason to be alarmed about forest fires, for she now has 1,300,000 acres of land remaining in forests in what is known as the pine country, which embraces Salem, Cumberland, Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic, and Burlington Counties.

From The Westminster Gazette. A remarkable encounter with a strange sea monster is reported by the crew of the bark Loongana, which has arrived from the Gilbert Group at Sydney. The vessel was drifting along somewhere in the vicinity of the Santa Cruz group, when the helmsman shouted out that there was a whale alongside.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 16. -- Kate Field is to appear in the role of a will contestant, associated with George Riddle, the reader. They take exceptions to the will of their aunt, Mrs. Cordelia Sanford, and have filed here reasons of appeal from the probating of it. The case will attract great attention.

Senator Teller of Colorado still lingers, reluctant to say farewell, but not wholly at ease, within the Republican Party. He announced recently that he would stay" until the party shall ally itself absolutely with the gold standard." "Then," he declared," I shall part with that party, not to go to the Populists, but to some other party which will secure the free coinage of silver."

The managers of the Recreation Park Jockey Club of Long Island City, whose half-mile track was opened Saturday for a thirty days' meeting, decided yesterday to postpone further racing for one week in order to get the track in first-class condition, and to provide increased facilities for spectators. The track is not in condition for fast racing, and horse owners requested the managers to improve it.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- A dispatch from Tokio to The Chronicle says the Japanese won a great victory over the Chinese in a battle fought on Sept. 6. The fighting was very severe. The Japanese scattered the Chinese cavalry, and a detachment of Japanese afterward captured the castle of Hwan-Ju, thirty-five miles from Phong-Yang.

A decided improvement in the market is reported at the leading carriage and harness houses of the city, and the outlook is encouraging for the Full trade. The horse dealers in the Bull's Head district ere doing as good business as is usual at this season of the year, and most of them expressed themselves as satisfied with the present state of trade, and anticipate more activity with the coming of cooler weather.

From The Cleveland News and Herald. At the least calculation there is a smoke cloud lying over a territory equal to that of France, or twice the extent of the British Isles, as a result of forest fires in a comparatively small part of two or three States. The area which has actually been burned over is of no account in comparison with the vast region over which the smoke has spread.
The Rev. Dr. John A.B. Wilson, pastor of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, in his morning sermon yesterday, talked about the work of the Lexow committee. He said among other things:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Capt. Sampson, the Naval Chief of Ordnance, has received a detailed report on the results of an attack on thin steel plates. The test was part of the effort to demonstrate the best plate for secondary gun shields and a one-pounder was flred at the plates, which represented steel, nickel steel, chrome steel, and copper specially tempered.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent, throughout the week. The rate at banks and trust companies was 1 1/2@2 per cent.

BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 16. -- Emperor Francis Joseph received the Austro-Hungarian delegations here to-day. Addressing them, he congratulated them upon the fact that the confidence expressed in 1893, that peace would toe preserved and consolidated, had been confirmed by the establishment of a still more peaceful situation throughout Europe, and the existence of the moat amicable relations among all the powers.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 16. -- A curious discovery has just been made in the little village of Richvllle, in the town of Pembroke, Genesee County. The skeletons of seven human beings have been found on the farm of James Gabbey, a prosperous farmer in that vicinity, and for the past few days visitors have come from far and wide to view the remains and to try to establish their identity.
The Canstatter Volksfest Verein ended its thirty-fifth four-day festival yesterday at Sulzer's Harlem River Park, One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Second Avenue.

The market for railway bonds last week was generally steady, with a large demand for the choicer securities, of which, however, few were offered for sale. Consequently the week was dull, more, however, from a lack of sellers than buyers. In the more speculative issues, notably Philadelphia and Reading and Richmond Terminal, there was considerable activity.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 16. -- It is expected that the suit brought by the Central Trust Company of New-York as trustee of the holders of bonds of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railroad to recover about $12,000,000 alleged to have been misappropriated, will come up for trial in the Court of Common Pleas here to-morrow.

M.A. Bell of the brokerage firm of Bell Davis, Cleveland, Ohio, committed suicide some time Saturday night, in the New-York Hotel, Broadway, opposite Bond Street, by shooting himself behind the right ear with a revolver.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 16. -- The attempted murder of an old man by a youth whom he had befriended was thwarted by the timely intervention of the police at an early hour this morning. The intended victim was Matthew Hawkins, a well-known citizen, who has operated a farm in the southern end of the city, on the Clinton Township line, for a number of years.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $1,980,575. The banks now hold $59,953,700 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages shows an increase in loans of $3,385,700, an increase in specie of $579,400, a decrease in legal tenders of $1,846,400, an increase in deposits of $2,854,300, and an increase in circulation of $203,100.
The work of the woman suffragists, which was apparently laid aside in the city during the Summer, is about to be taken up again.

The stock market last week was dull, and was only interesting in spots. In the industrials, Sugar, Whisky, and Chicago Gas were prominent, while in the railway list the principal trading was in the Grangers, Richmond Terminal, Louisville and Nashville, and Reading. Outside of the Grangers, however, the business was not up to the average volume.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- Between twenty and twenty-five gentlemen convened in Senator Fassett's rooms this evening for the purpose of discovering " where they were at" The most prominent of the conferrees were Senator Fassett, Judge Leslie W. Russell of St. Lawrence, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford of Kings, and Gen. Butterfleld of New-York, with their personal representatives.

The Central Labor Union at its meeting yesterday discussed politics and trade matters. The fact that James P. Archibald, one of the Committee on Political Action, had become a member of the Committee of Seventy caused some comment. Mr. Archibald was not at the meeting.

The Kings County Tennis Club will begin its usual Fall handicap tournament next Saturday afternoon. The usual fine contests, men's and women's singles and doubles and mixed doubles, will be contested. Dr. Frazer will not enter the singles, as he intends to give some one else a chance at the prize, but nearly all of the club's strong players will be in the race.

The Right Rev. Henry C. Potter, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New-York, came home from Europe yesterday on the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm II. Accompanying him was his family. His wife and daughters had not set foot on American soil for a good while, having spent last Winter in Rome.

ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 16. -- The school facilities of West Orange are to be increased shortly by the completion of a handsome new building at the corner of Washington Street and Valley Road. Already, the foundations are nearly completed, and it is expected that the entire structure will be finished and ready for occupancy by the 1st of December.
SARATOGA, Sept. 16 -- It has been many years since Saratoga, the Sunday before the holding of a State Convention has been so crowded with delegates and politicians as to-day.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept 15 -- The local stock market is generally stronger, although prices remain about the same and few shares are changing hands. The bank stock list is neglected, and with the exception of a few shares of Commercial National Bank no sales have been reported. Prices of the insurance stocks have been gradually advancing, as was predicted some little time ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 16 -- The steamship Oceanic brings details of the murder in China of the Scotch missionary, the Rev. James Wylie. A New-Chwang correspondent of The North China Daily News, writing under date of Aug. 20, says:

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 16. -- The local political revelations of the past week were a cause of great uneasiness to Senator Anthony Higgins, as they showed that his Senatorial rival, J. Edward Addicks of Boston, New-York, and Philadelphia, is making strides that threaten to land him a winner as far as the Republican Party is concerned.
The cruiser New-York is in dry dock at the New-York Navy Yard, in Brooklyn, and cannot get out until there is such an unusually high tide as that on which she went in nearly a month ago.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- The newspapers have found little room for accounts of the great naval review off Swinemunde, although they devoted columns to the East Prussian military manoeuvres. The display of war ships, however, had the more political significance of the two. It was, in fact, a grand semipolitical function for the benefit of the gapins crowds which special trains took to the coast from all parts of the empire.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- The University of Pennsylvania has a squad of twenty-four men in training for the football team at Broadwater Island, on the Virginia coast. Much mystery surrounds the practice, no outsiders being allowed on the island, which is the property of the Broadwater Club, whose members are mostly Philadelphians.

The subject of the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur's sermon last evening in the Calvary Baptist Church, in Fifty-seventh Street, near Sixth Avenue, was, "The Sin of Suicide," and his text Acts, xvl., 28: " Do thyself no harm."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The announcement that the Rev. John L. Scudder would talk on "Scandalous Water," assured a larger attendance than usual at the Congregational Tabernacle this evening. His remarks were attentively listened to, and, after the services, Mr. Scudder was warmly praised for his services in behalf of a new water supply. He said:

Just at the close of the ceremonies over the laying of the cornerstone of the new St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon the temporary floor in the vestibule gave way, throwing about twenty-five persons into the basement and badly injuring several of them.

In contrast with the spirited scenes of the last two weeks, Fleetwood Park presented a deserted appearance yesterday. There was less than the usual gathering of road drivers present, and the track being a bit heavy after the recent rains, not much of importance took place in the way of trials of speed.

The mariners who reached this port yeserday had many tales of the sea to tell, and much to say about Atlantic weather Which was not complimentary. Some of the arriving vessels had met with derelict craft, and others had come very near being made derelicts themselves.

The convention of the German Roman Catholic Central Verein began yesterday with a solemn high mass in the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, in East Third Street. Delegates were present from St. Louis, Chicago, Milwaukee, Buffalo, NewOrleans, Brooklyn, Jersey City, and other cities, to the number of 400.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 16 -- Breckinridge's managers claim that Owens's plurality on the face of the returns from the primaries held yesterday is only 144, and say they will contest and have the election declared for Breckinridge.

VARZIN, Sept. 16 -- This little village never before saw such a festival as began here this morning. Preparations had been making for days to receive the Posen delegation of Prince Bismarck's admirers. With daybreak the visitors came from the surrounding districts by the score. They found the streets already decorated with garlands, flags, and arches spanning the roads which lead to the castle.
