If there is no law that will put a stop to the racing by electric light at Maspeth, in the outskirts of Brooklyn, the Stewards of The Jockey Club should do everything in their power to have an amendment to the so-called Ives Pool bill passed at the next session of the Legislature that will make racing at night illegal.

The Rev. D.C. Eddy of the First Baptist Church. Lee Avenue and Keap Street, Brooklyn, preached last evening on the evils of open saloons on Sunday, and accused Mayor Schieren of being responsible for this state of affairs, when he could by a single word cause the saloons to be closed. He said:

A new sign has appeared at the Empire Theatre this season. It reads: " House Full," and is placed on the sidewalk as soon as all the seats for a given performance have been disposed of. The old sign, "Standing Room Only," of which this has taken the place, has been relegated to the lumber room, and will never again see the light, so long as Charles Frohman controls the theatre.

WEST BRIGHTON, S. I., Sept. 16. -- Four fires were started at this place and at Port Richmond early this morning, each plainly the work of an incendiary, and all at places where, if the flames had not been opportunely discovered and quickly extinguished, they would have resulted in the destruction of much property, if not in loss of life.

The third of Pasquier's volumes confirms the impression made by the first and second. Pasquier aimed not so much to write memoirs as to write history. He wrote of his own times as might write some man of a later generation, in that he wrote dispassionately, and, so far as men can write, disinterestedly.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- The local security market was quiet, with few changes in quotations during the week. The asked price for Municipal Gas was advanced from 137 to 140; about all the stock in the market under 140 has been picked up. A block of Saranac and Lake Placid stock which was upon the market has been purchased.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Ed-ward Whittemore, a farmer, seventy years old; his wife, aged fifty-five, and his daughter, a pretty girl of fifteen, were the victims of a murderous assault by Mrs. Whittemore's nephew, Leonard Blodgett, Saturday night, in which Mrs. Whittemore was fatally shot and the others dangerously wounded.
There was more activity among the Harlem River boat clubs yesterday than for several weeks, many boats being out early in the forenoon and again between 3 o'clock and dusk.

Apart from what the returning survey parties have added to our knowledge of the mountains, rivers, and other features of the northwest corner of this continent, the accomplishment of the prime object of their long task is of great value.

The Rev. Edwin Homer Wellman, rector of the Church of the Atonement, Seventeenth Street and Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, delivered a sermon against suicide yesterday morning, and called Col. Robert G. Ingersoll severely to task for his expressions on the subject

Interest in yesterday's stock market continued in Sugar, Chicago Gas, and Distilling and Cattle Feeding in the industrials and in Reading in the railway list. Sugar was quoted ex dividend at the opening, and sold at 102. It was weak all day, receiving no support from the pool, and sold as low as 97 1/3, the flnal price being 97 1/4, a net loss of five points.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- It was the general opinion after the decision of the sub-committee at Syracuse in favor of the Spellmanites that the battleground in this Fall's Democratic caucuses would be in the Second Assembly District. Collector Houck gained control of the First District last Fall and Alderman Kelly retained the Third District.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 17. -- At the meeting of the Street and Water Board this evening, Commissioner Kellars offered a resolution providing for a new water supply, and instructing the clerk to advertise for proposals to be submitted to the board at a regular meeting to be held at 8 P.M., Oct. 22.

Sugar and Whisky engaged in plunges in yesterday's stock market, each of them recalling their best previous feats in that line. Sugar lost 5 points from the closing price of Saturday and Whisky lost 3 1/2 points.

From The Pittsburg Press. So unfortunate lately has the Associated Press been with its bogus news that it seems almost cruel to call attention to a new instance. Yet so boldly and shamelessly is its "faking" done that the public is entitled to be warned. Its latest exploit was to announce the death of the Comte de Paris in time for the New-York morning papers.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 17. -- As Charles B. Whaley, a produce dealer, was on his way to the market at 2 o'clock this morning, he found a policeman lying unconscious at Washington Avenue and Pearl Street. Help was obtained, and the man was removed to the City Hospital, where he died soon after his arrival.

When racegoers reached the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday they were greeted with a story that Faraday threw his rider on Sunday morning while at exercise, and ran three miles and a half at top speed, going the first mile and a quarter in 2.09. Any quantity of trainers were ready and anxious to tell all about the runaway and the time made in each mile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The head of the Subsistence Department of the Army, Gen. John P. Hawkins, will be placed on the retired list on account of age Sept. 29. He has had active service since he entered the army, in 1848. He has been in the Subsistence Department of the army since the outbreak of the war, and is an authority on the rationing of armies.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 17. -- The first arrivals for the Democratic State Convention came in to-night, and the situation regarding an anti-Brice resolution has begun to assume tangible shape. The majority of those on the ground to-night are Brice envoys and representatives, and they are bold in their declarations that no plank censuring the Senator will go into the platform.

As two elevated trains were slowly rounding the curve on One Hundred and Tenth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, just before 10 o'clock yesterday morning, several men and boys who were playing ball in a vacant lot near by saw the body of a man fall from the elevated structure to the street.

The Republican canvass in this State may be said to have really opened about the time that "Boss" Platt made up his mind as to the candidate for Governor, but the formal opening of the "campaign" may be dated from the convention at Saratoga. There seems to be no doubt about the nomination of Platt's candidate for Governor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.-- New-York won to-day's game after an exciting finish. With the score 5 to 0 in the ninth. Fuller fumbled Wilmot's grounder and Van Haltren dropped Anson's fly. Two bases on balls followed, forcing in a run. Decker batted for Parrott and tangled up the infield on a drive that scored Anson, but fell himself in running to first and was thrown out.

The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn met last night at 42 Court Street and spent two hours talking on the subject of harmony without coming at it directly, except in one instance, or taking any definite action. The general sentiment expressed was against joining with the independent faction, led by Edward M. Shepard.

Lugi Labbatte of 125 Mulberry Street and Antonio Lauria of 157 Mott Street were watching the James March Association's procession, at Mott and Hester Streets, last evening when a pickpocket grabbed Labbatte's watoh and ran.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 17. -- Before a large audience, including Gov. Rich and staff, at the Detroit Opera House to-night, Roland Reed presented for the first time the late David D. Lloyd's and Sydney Rosenfeld's comedy. "The Politician; or, The Woman's Plank," a satire in four acts upon politics and politicians.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17. -- A preliminary hearing in the case of Millionaire W. H. King versus George Gordon King and others was to-day heard before the Supreme Court. Judge Jere Wilson appeared for the plaintiff, with James Tillinghast of Providence and Edward Avery of Boston.

The will of Bridget T. Dalton, who died Feb. 9, 1894, was admitted, to probate yesterday, as the fifteen contestants at the last minute withdrew their opposition. Mrs. Dalton was the wife of the late Contractor Michael Dalton of Broolkyn.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The Republican State Committee to-night held a meeting which lasted just long enough to give a snub to the Milholland men and to arrange a programme for the preliminary work of the convention. All the members of the committee were present except Barnet H. Davis of the Twenty-eighth District, George W. Aldredge of the Thirty-first, and William J. Glenn of the Thirty-fourth.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Lightning struck the house of Jere Dunn, in Chilton Street, here, last night, during a severe thunderstorm, and shattered a corner of the building. The electricity descended to the bathroom and did considerable damage to the walls, besides setting the place on fire.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- Local railroad stocks were fairly strong. Fitchburg sold at 75 1/4, Chicago Junction common at 93, and the preferred at 101. Boston and Maine was in demand at 155, a further advance of a point and a half. Bell Telephone was steady at 204 for a few shares, while Bay State Gas fluctuated between 10 3/4 and 11 7/8, closing at 11 3/4.

The published reports concerning the practical completion of a Trust or similar combination controlling the manufacture and sale of tacks, shoe nails, and the like, suggest an inquiry as to the tariff on such products. It was in 1890 that the six leading manufacturing firms entered a combination which was chartered under the name of the Atlas Tack Corporation.

Mrs. Marian Coakley of 425 Union Street, Brooklyn, shot her husband, Daniel Coakley, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning. He is in the Brooklyn Hospital with a wound in the left side of his back and another in his thigh. His wife is a prisoner and their six-months-old child is in the care of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- M. Lockroy, who early this year was sent by the naval committee of inquiry to examine into the condition of the fortifications at Toulon and the efficiency of the French war vessels stationed there, has made his report. He says that when the torpedo fleet at Toulon was inspected only five vessels out of fifty-one were in condition to proceed at once to sea should the necessity have arisen.
Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, who sailed for Europe on the Anchor Line steamer City of Rome May 26, and who returned Sunday night, has much that Is Interesting to tell of his travels abroad.
The convention of the German Roman Catholic Central Verein reconvened yesterday morning in the school hall at 222 East Fourth Street.

PHILADELFHIA, Sept. 17. -- The first day's play in the international cricket match between Canada and the United States took place at Wissahickon to-day on the grounds of the Philadelphia Cricket Club. The wicket was in good condition for run getting. Capt. L.yon of the Canadian eleven won the toss, and sent his men to bat first.
Company G of the Seventh Regiment, 100 strong, visited the Wild West Show last evening. They were entertained at supper, and had a general good time.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 17. -- The Chicago organization styling Itself the "Associated Press" sent out a report this afternoon, dated Hazleton, Penn., that fourteen men had been buried in Honeybrook Colliery. Although this was a mere rumor, It was sent out for publication, and was published by the papers relying upon the so-called "Associated Press" for their news.
WHITESTONE, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Mosquitoes in unusually large numbers again invaded Willet's Point to-night and made things very uncomfortable for the soldiers in the engineer battalion.

Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer said yesterday that there was absolutely no truth in the story of a Chicago syndicate acquiring the New-York Hotel property. To begin with, he said, the price mentioned -- $1.200,000 -- was absurd. Its cost up to date has been about $1,500,000, and it has never been offered at less than $1,700,000.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- The political situation here in respect to the coming Republican State Convention continued through the night and early hours of the day to be as represented in The New-York. Times of this morning, but the arrival of the New-York and Kings County delegations and the New-York papers caused some changes.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- Oliver Sumner Teall sat on the piazza of the United States Hotel this morning telling a few friends how he had gone to live at Sweeny's Hotel and was intending to make great inroads into the forces of P. Divver in the Second District. He was wearing a blue aster in his lapel and was otherwise faultlessly attired.

"Struck Oil," a melodrama of considerable merit, which has not been seen in New-York for several years, was reproduced at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night under the direction of Augustus Pitou. The action of the play takes place during the war and the oil excitement in Pennsylvania. A. German shoemaker goes as a substitute for the man who holds a mortgage on his house, in return for the mortgage to the deeds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The strained relations which have existed for months between Secretary Carlisle and Supervising Architect of the Treasury Jeremiah O'Rourke came to their logical end late this afternoon, when Mr. Carlisle demanded Mr. O'Rourke's immediate resignation. Mr. O'Rourke was preparing to leave his office when Mr. Carlisle's curt letter was laid before him.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 17. -- The Virginia campaign this year promises to furnish more unique features than usual. The contest is confined entirely to the selection of the members of the House of Representatives. There are no State issues directly involved, and no local officers to be Chosen. It is strictly an off year.

The New-York Tribune has remarked several times in the last few weeks that the prices of iron and steel products are lower now by about 40 per cent. than they were in 1890. Our neighbor commonly makes this remark in connection with others of a pessimistic character not remotely related to politics.

The courts of the West Side Tennis Club, at Central Park West and Elerhty-ninth Street, were the scenes of some lively tennis contests yesterday afternoon, the club's Fall handicap tournament furnishing the subject of dispute. A pretty contest between H.S. Elliott and Arthur Taylor, in which the former player's handicap proved a trifle too much for Taylor, was followed by a contest in which the scratch man triumphed over heavy odds.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- The American Association of Football Clubs, at its annual meeting held in this city, adopted a rule designed to effectually prevent the National Baseball League from encroaching on its territory. The rule provides that no person who has signed a contract and played with any national league football club shall be permitted to play in an American Association contest.
The firm of R.H. Macy Co., Sixth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, had its thirty-seventh Pall opening yesterday, and will continue it today and to-morrow.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- A Central News dispatch, from Seoul, dated G.P.M. Sept. 16, says a great battle has been fought at Ping-Yang, between the Chinese and Japanese troops, in which the former were utterly routed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- A great many letters have been received at the Treasury Department recently making inquiries concerning the coinage of silver dollars and the redemption and cancellation of Treasury notes, and in order to avoid the labor of retailing the information in answers to each letter Secretary Carlisle to-day dictated the following memorandum on the subject, which he gave to the United Press for publication:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Secretary Gresham this afternoon received a cablegram from Consular Agent Alfred Cooper at La Libertad announcing the death of Consul General Alexander L. Pollock at Salvador from yellow fever.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 17. -- The sugar planters' convention to-day, at Washington Artillery Hall, was a large assemblage, and there were present many of the leading planters of Louisiana and some of the representative men of New-Orleans. Mr. E.N. Pugh called the meeting to order, and ex-Naval Officer Kernochan was made temporary Chairman and ex-Mayor Behan permanent Chairman of the organization.
SARATOGA, N.T., Sept. 17. -- The State League of Republican Clubs Convention was called to order by President G.E. Green at 12:30 P.M. Convention Hall was not one-quarter filled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The first matter that occupied the attention of Secretary Herbert to-day when he returned to the Navy Department after five weeks' absence was that of reinforcing the Asiatic squadron, and after a brief consultation with Secretary Gresham he issued preliminary orders to the commanders of the Machias and the Detroit to prepare to proceed to China as soon as possible.

The steamship Mississippi, Capt. McNeilly, of the Atlantic Transport Line, which arrived yesterday from London, brought Capt. Petersen and the crew of the Nor-wegian bark Hakon Jarl, which was abandoned in a sinking condition in latitude 49 degrees 45 minutes, longitude 30 degrees 3 minutes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The general order which appeared from the War Deartment to-day changing the stations of certain troops and abolishing nine posts on account of the alteration in the system recruiting in the army is the most important recently issued. It carries with it a reform of the service which, with the changes in the clerical methods of the War Department, constitutes the greatest impirovements in the service effected by the piresent Administration.

Lord Hawke made a most auspicious opening in his first American game yesterday at Staten Island, where the New-York team showed the Englishmen how the metropolitan cricketers can bowl and field. The dull, threatening weather kept the crowd away, but some 2,000 spectators were present during the afternoon, and they fully enjoyed and thoroughly appreciated the fine exhibition of the game that was seen.

Novices will have another opportunity to race for a New-York Times medal at the coming meet of the Crescent Wheelmen at Plainfield, N.J. The prize will be very similar to those given by The Times at other meets this year, and will be equally valuable. A large fleld is expected in this race, for many young racers have signified a desire to compete if The Times offered a trophy.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 17. -- M.E. Page of Brooklyn tried to kill himself with a knife this afternoon at Milton Street and Ashland Avenue. He plunged the knife three times into his breast, near the heart, and then severed several minor arteries in his neck. He was taken to the City Hospital. He may recover.

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 17. -- The steam-ship City of Topeka, which arrived from Alaska Sunday, brings news of a mass meeting which was held Aug. 23 to consider the needs of a cade of laws for the government of this vast domain, and the necessity for the establishment of a mail route into the Yukon country by way of Chilcat Pass.
"Have courage, my daughter. Your husband will become a Catholic."

The annaul report of the Iowa Central Railroad, of which Russell gage Is President, was Issued In pamphlet form yesterday. It covers the operation of the road for the fiscal year ended June 30. The figures were published several days ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- At least four lives, and probably six, were lost in an unusually rapid fire which this afternoon destroyed the handsome five-story factory of Stumph Brothers, makers of mattresses, at Massachusetts Avenue and K Street.

Michael De George, the Italian real estate and insurance agent who was arrested on Saturday charged with having planned to set fire to his rooms in the tenement house 165 Avenue A, was arraigned before Justice Simms at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday morning for examination.

The four boxing bouts arranged by the Seaside Athletic Club took a large crowd to Coney Island last night. Four bouts -- the principal one to be between "Kid" Lavigne of Michigan, who is anxious to meet "young" Griffo, and "Jerry" Marshall, the colored Australian, who wants to get on a match with George Dixon -- had been arranged.

The reception of the German Catholic Central Verein on Sunday evening was rendered noteworthy by the presence and particularly by the address of Archbishop Corrigan. Indeed, an assemblage of foreigners or the children of foreigners in the name of a particular nation as well as of a particular Church would at any time be worthy of note.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- The Wadsworth boom for second place on the Republican State ticket dropped very rapidly this morning, and in its place there grew up a boom for ex-Collector and ex-Senator Francis Hendricks of Onondaga County.
A number of clothing contractors broke away from the Contractors' Association on Saturday and Sunday and grave individual bonds to the Brotherhood of Tailors, where-upon their men returned to work.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- Since the ruling of the New-York Exchange against the arbitrage business, Philadelphia brokers and traders have turned their attention more closely to home securities. The trolley stocks have each in turn been bid up to what to conservative people seem very high prices, and when the traders think they have got a stock high enough they let it go and look around for something that looks cheap and promising.

William Q. Wood, a retired merchant and wealthy real estate owner, living at 239 Lenox Avenue, is the defendant In a suit for the recovery of $25,000 on a demand note, which it is alleged that he gave to Miss Matilda Darlington, a young woman living at 268 West Seventy-first Street, as a token of "love and affection."

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- Gov. Flower returned to the city to-day to get a fresh lot of material before continuing his tour of county fairs. The next one he will attend will be that at Schoharie on Wednesday, where he will go under escort of the Albany Burgesses Corps, an independent military company.

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- Superintendent of State Prisons Lathrop returned to this city to-day, and when interviewed concerning Gov. Flower's letter notifying him of complaints received regarding contract labor in the prisons, said all he cared to say was that the convict labor laws were strictly observed in the institutions under his care.
John Hanstrom, who made his home at a hotel in the Bowery, shot himself through the head while sitting on a bench in Central Park last night.

"It is not right that the City of NewYork, the metropolis of the Western continent, should be ruled by foreigners. The foreigners themselves would not say that was right if their candid opinion could be obtained. But they are not to be blamed for governing us while the 'good citizens' permit them the privilege -- and its emoluments. It is the 'good citizens' who are to be blamed.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 17. -- The Breckinridge forces did not lay down their arms when the battle ended Saturday afternoon. They have been as busy as bees ever since, trying to find some loophole for escaping from the verdict. Desha Breckinridge and several friends went down to Scott County to-day and attempted to enter a protest against certain precincts in that county, but failed.

H.H. Wylie, who formerly held the cycling record between this city and Chicago, will leave The American Wheelman office at 8 A.M. to-day and attempt to reach the Western metropolis inside of seven days. Wylie is confident of beating the existing record, and, under favorable conditions, thinks he can do the distance in about six and three-quarter days.

The Manufacturers' Association of Kings and Queens Counties held a regular monthly meeting in the Pouch Mansion, 345 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, last evening. The attendance was large, considering that the meeting was the first that has been held since the Spring.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- Charles K. Laurence, was arrested at the Tremont House this afternoon on the charge of being a fugitive from justice. He is said to be wanted at Lockport, N.Y., where a sentence of two years and five months in Auburn Prison awaits him, as he was found guilty of grand larceny a couple of years ago.

The new theatre at the northwest corner of Broadway and Thirty-fifth Street, called by its lessee and manager, Charles E. Evans, formerly a popular comic actor, and now a capitalist, the Herald Square Theatre, was thrown open to the public last night. It is a handsome, modern house, not quite equal in its appointments to some of the other Broadway houses, but good enough for anybody.
SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- New-York City's delegation to the Republican State Convention is divided, as usual. There are plenty of men whom Platt controls, and there are several whom he cannot control.
Naval Officer C.C. Baldwin appointed as Deputy Naval Officer yesterday D.J. Hagerty of Brooklyn, in place of Herbert Taylor, resigned.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 17. -- The disappearance of Borough Clerk Alexis McNulty remains as much a mystery as ever, notwithstanding the theories advanced to account for it. Representatives from the insurance companies he acted for -- the Sun of London, Queen, Home, Aetna, Lancashire, New-Jersey, and the Plate Glass Insurance Company -- find nothing of any deficit, and it is now firmly believed that, beyond $200 or $300 all told, no deficiency will be found.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- Hourly conferences were held to-day at the Grand Union between Mr. Fassett and the three other candidates for Governor, and each pledged the others to remain in the fight until some definite action would be taken -- till they should be beaten or nominated, but these conferences did not seem to affect the situation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 17. -- Barely 200 people attended to-day's National Circuit meet of the Pittsburg Athletic Club. This is by many hundreds the smallest attendance of the season. The Pittsburg Athletic Club took the date made vacant by the withdrawal of Scranton, as the Keystone Wheel Club of this city had Sept. 29 in the circuit and was preparing to give a grand meet at Shenley Park, on a half-mile nicely banked track.

FORT MADISON, Iowa, Sept. 18. -- The train-robbing industry in the West received another decisive setback at 3 o'clock this morning, when four masked men attempted to rob Train No. 5, Utah and Colorado express, on the Atchlson, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, near Gorin, Mo., seventy-five miles west of here.

There were two mysterious shooting affairs early yesterday morning on the east side of the city, and both the men shot are believed to be mortally wounded. In one case two men are under arrest on suspicion of having been concerned in the shooting, but in the other case the man who did the shooting is unknown.
The ferry charge from this city to Staten Island will not be reduced from 10 cents to 5. This was decided on at a meeting yesterday of the Sinking Fund Commissioners in the Mayor's office.
SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- The nominating and seconding speeches had now all been made, and the convention was ready to vote for its candidate for Governor.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- Chairman Brookfield called the conventon to order at 12:17 o'clock. He waited a moment for the noise to subside, and in that moment John Simpson, clothed with a dramatic atmosphere, came down the aisle, followed by Gen. Daniel Butterfield. After the prayer by the Rev. Dr. Cary, the roll of counties was called for changes in the roll of delegates. There were few changes.

Ex-Police Captain John T. Stephenson, who was dismissed from the force by the Commissioners upon charges of taking money from produce merchants for sidewalk privileges, has obtained from Justice Lawrence of the Supreme Court a writ of certiorari, for the purpose of reviewing the action of the Commissioners.

Charles T. Saxton, known throughout the country as the author of the ballot reform law, is a tall, handsomely-built man of military appearance, with silver-gray hair and mustache. His features and manner indicate determination and strength of purpose. He is a lawyer by profession and a State Senator from choice.

Well, "A Gaiety Girl" will be a tremendous success in New-York. An international question of vast importance is thus settled, and the public mind may now concern itself at leisure with other matters. There was some doubt, even among persons who had seen the thing in London and enjoyed it there, in its natural environment, about its ability to survive the rigors of an, ocean voyage.

Mr. John Jacob Astor has bought, through Mr. George R. Read, about 100 acres of land from the Pearsall estate, fronting on the north sides of the Bronx and Pelham Parkway, and also on the road from William's Bridge to Westchester Village. It is opposite the Morris Park race track, and, being advantageously situated, with reference to the future growth of the city, will rapidly appreciate in value.

The recrudescence within the last year of the crime of train robbery has become formidable in many parts of the country, and particularly in the West. The crime is so tempting and looks so easy and safe that one success in it is sure to be followed by many other attempts. It can be put an end to only by a striking demonstration that it is neither so safe nor so easy as it looks.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The trial before an ecclesiastical tribunal of the Rev. Luke C. Queal, D.D., opened in Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church to-day. Dr. Queal is Presiding Elder of the Geneva District, ex-Presiding Elder of the Auburn District, and was once pastor of the leading Methodist Episcopal Church of this city.

The Brooklyn Health Department was recently criticised in a vigorous manner by Prof. Claude D. Morris of Pawling, who, in a paper on "Meat Inspection," which he read before the State Convention of Veterinary Surgeons, in Albany, declared that the trade in old and diseased meat was surprisingly large, and that the present meat inspection in Brooklyn was a farce.

Speculation in the industrial stocks was practically the only feature in yesterday's stock market. Sugar, as usual, was the leader in point of activity, but Chicago Gas and Whisky were also largely traded in. No one attempted to explain the movement in Sugar. It was heavy at the opening, and was particularly weak in the early afternoon, when it sold at 94 3/4.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. T.A. Kerrigan sold at $2.725, to Peter J. Eiseman, the three-story frame dwelling 239 Devoe Street, norm side, 337.10 feet east at Bushwick Avenue, 25 by 100. To Moses Sahlein, plaintiff, at $6,000, he sold the three-story brick dwelling 51 Decatur Street, north side, 211 feet west of Throop Avenue, 18 by 100.

BOSTON, Sept. 18. -- The activity of Bay State Gas was again the feature of to-day's market, as far as local stocks were concerned. The stock sold up to 12, reacting to 11 1/4, and closing at 11 7/8, an advance of 3/8 over last night. Puts were offered on 6,000 shares of Bay State Gas at 11 for the balance of the week at 1/2 per cent.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 18. -- The report on the charge of Socialism made by State Superintendent Wells against Dr. Ely of the State University was made this afternoon. The committee, consisting of H. W. Chynoweth, John Johnson, and Dr. H. B. Dale, fully exonerate Dr. Ely and approve of his teachings.
The Republican platform is timid and weak as to finance. The resolution on that subject is as follows:

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 18. -- Lord and Lady Brassey left on the steam yacht Tillie to-day for Providence, where they are guests of W. H. Starbuck. They will return to NewYork in a few days and start for a trip across the continent. They will reach home for the holidays. Lady Brassey is a sister of the Earl of Essex.

The yacht Emerald again demonstrated that she is the best schooner of the year by yesterday defeating the Ariel in the New-York Yacht Club Fall sweepstakes race. The race was sailed over a triangular course off Sandy Hook. The wind was fresh from the east, and the sea was lumpy. The weather conditions were very much like those that prevailed for the last cup races last year.

The nomination of Mr. Morton by the Republican Convention, for which Mr. Platt had already prepared the public mind, and Mr. Flower's announcement that he will not be a candidate for renomination, which comes unexpectedly, create a political situation in this State altogether different from that which has been so complacently foretold by Republicans overconfident of victory and heedless of actual or prospective conditions.

The Fall campaign of the City Vigilance League was opened last night at the Park Avenue-Methodist Episcopal Church, Eighty-sixth Street and Park Avenue. Every seat in the church was occupied, nearly one-third of the persons present being women.

Albert Haight of Buffalo, the nominee for Court of Appeals, was born in Erie County in 1842, and was educated in the public schools and Springfield Academy. He studied law, and was admitted to practice in Buffalo. In 1872 he was elected County Judge of Erie County. Before his term expired he was elected Judge of the Eighth Judicial District, comprising the eight counties of Western New-York.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- A medium-sized man with brown whiskers and a bald head sat in almost the centre of the Convention Hall more than half an hour this morning before the doors were opened and delegates or anybody else came in.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 18. -- The Republican State Convention opened at Foot-guard Hall to-night, with a very large attendance of the 504 accredited delegates. The convention was called to order at 8 o'clock by Herbert E. Benton of New-Haven, Chairman of the State Central Committee, who presented ex-Congressman Willlam Edgar Simonds of Canton as temporary Chairman of the convention.

The primaries of the Democratic Party in Kings County, which were held throughout Brboklyn last night, were surprisingly well attended. It was estimated by the members of the General Committee that fully 10,000 votes were polled. Had the weather been propitious, double that number would probably have been cast, the committee believes.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18. -- The possibility of spiriting away a man under cover of the law and burying him alive, as far as all knowledge of his friends is concerned, was shown here to-day on the release from the New-Haven County Jail in $10,000 il of Erasmus Bennett of Topeka, Kan., of the firm of E. Bennett Son, said to be one of the largest horse-importing firms in America.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- John E. Milholland's faction of the Republican Party was beaten to-day in its fight for repognition by Platt, who eulogistically indorsed the faction in a famous official interview last "Winter. No one who came here as a member of the Milholland forces had any other expectation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Joy reigns in the local Republican camp over the action of the Louisiana Planters' Convention, but at the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Committee no especial significance is attached to the matter. The Democrats insist that the Republicans have no possible chance of getting more than one district, and express the opinion that even that will not be done.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Supervising Architect O'Rourke occupied his desk this morning in the Treasury Building as usual, as if his resignation had not been asked for. Officials and others on business came and went, and between these visits Mr. O'Rourke filled in his time in drafting his letter of resignation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 18. -- This has been, one of the most exciting days preliminary to a Democratic State Convention that has been seen in Ohio in years. It has been the first skirmish in the contest for Senatorial honors next year, and to-night Senator Brice has won a pronounced advantage over his opponent, Congressman Tom L. Johnson, the radical free trader from Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18. -- The market has become painfully dull lately. It has only been active when strong or advancing, and when each upward bulge is over it relapses into dullness. The opinions on Reading are conflicting. Philadelphia has arrayed itself on the bull side against New-York. There were good scale orders in this market to buy on declines This stemmed yesterday's flood, and turned the tide up-ward.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18. -- Lowering clouds and occasional showers rendered the outlook for the second day's play in the Canadian-United States cricket match at Wissahickon anything but promising this morning. When stumps were drawn yesterday the United States eleven had decidedly the better of the argument, having lost only three wickets in scoring 53, against their opponents' total of 155.
Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews applied to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday for an appropriation of $842,000, with which to establish his proposed new street-cleaning plant.

The cricketers of New-York met with a great disappointment yesterday, for, after the fine play in the opening of the game with Lord Hawke's team, there was every prospect of a big attendance at the second day of the match, and preparations had been made on the ground for the reception of one of the largest crowds that ever attended a game in tills vicinity.

Capt. William Churchill of Brooklyn, formerly in the United States service, has just received a telegram from Mount Uncompahgre, Col., announcing the success of an experiment in long-range heliographing between points 183 miles apart.
The money market continued easy. Call Zoans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- Within a minute from the opening of the evening session, Gen. Hedges of Rockland sprung a resolution to limit speeches nominating candidates for Lieutenant Governor to ten minutes, and to limit seconding speeches to three minutes.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- Gov. Roswell P. Flower and Senator David B. Hill came together this morning in the Executive Chamber of the Capitol. They compared notes, and when Senator David B. Hill emerged, after two hours' conference, Gov. Flower gave out the following typewritten statement:

MILLBROOK, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- This is a gay season at Halcyon Hall. The bugles of the tally-ho and the break are dally heard. The house break was out on Saturday -- Mr. Davison was whip. The party consisted of Mr. and Mrs. C. Ladyard Blair, the Misses Sturgis, Miss Dodds, Mr. Phyfe, Mr. William McElroy of New-York, and Miss Hastings of Boston.

Police Inspector Reilly of Brooklyn yesterday submitted to Superintendent Campbell the following report of his action in stopping the prize fights in the Seaside Athletic Club arena, at Coney Island, Monday evening:

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Percival Heale, a Canadian customs officer, who is charged with absconding with $6,000 belonging to the Dominion Customs Department, was arrested on the Strand to-day, his description having been cabled from Canada, and was arraigned in the Bow Street Police Court. He had on his person L631 in English gold and notes, and in his room at the Arundel Hotel were found L131 in English money and $1,000 in Canadian notes.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 18 -- This city is in a state of jubilation to-day over the successful issue of the fight for a new water supply, and chief among the lauded champions of the people stands The New-York Times.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 18. -- There are some very interesting rumors afloat concerning prospective changes in the management of the Lehigh Valley Railroad. These rumors gather strength from the general belief that President E.P. Wilbur, not only desires but intends to retire from the Presidency of the company.

The silver wreath to be presented to Johann Strauss by his American friends on the fiftieth anniversary of his becoming a musical director, which presentation will take place at Vienna on Oct. 15, will be placed on exhibition to-day by Tiffany Co.

A dispatch from Washington announces that the Secretary of War has approved the plans for the great bridge to be erected across the Delaware River by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. The plans were prepared by Chief Engineer Brown of the Pennsylvania Road. The changes required by the War Department relate merely to the location of the three-hundred-foot drawbridge across the channel of the bridge.

PERRY, Oklahoma, Sept. 18. -- A tornado from the southwest yesterday descended without a moment's warning upon the towns of Jennings and Mining. Fifty homes were demolished in the two places, and it is known that three persons, a young woman and two children, are dead, and several persons are injured.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- The retirement of Gov. Flower from the Gubernatorial race caused no excitement here. The news was received over the United Press wire while Chairman Quigg was delivering his speech.
The Executive Committee of the German-American Reform Union had a fierce battle last night behind closed doors at Terrace Garden.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Miss Katharine Weills, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John C.S. Weills of this place, and the Rev. Charles E. Deuel, rector of St. Michael's Church. Boise City, Idaho, were married to-day in Trinity Church. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, assisted by Bishop Talbot of Wyoming and Idaho.

Reminders of Henry S. Ives were suggested in Wall Street yesterday, when Detective Sergeant Nugent called at the office of Charles F. Phillips, in the building of the Manhattan Company. The officer had with him a Philadelphia detective, who had brought from that city a copy of an indictment by the Grand Jury against Mr. Phillips, a bench warrant for his arrest, and a requisition signed by the Governor of Pennsylvania.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 18. -- At 3:45 o'clock this morning the anti-Tillman convention, adjourned, without making any nominations. The vote was 120 against nominating and 104 in favor.

The appearance of Dr. Parkhurst before the Grand Jury either to-day or to-morrow is considered a matter of certainty by the officials in the new Court House. It is evident that the Sessions Judges -- especially Recorder Smyth -- expect his presence.

Levi Parsons Morton, the candidate for Governor, was born in Shoreham, Vt., May 16, 1824. He is of Puritan descent. His father was a Congregational minister. At sixteen years of age he was a clerk in a country store at Enfield, Mass., and subsequently went to Hanover, N.H., where he kept a general store.

The heavy downpour of rain in Brooklyn, last night did not prevent a large number of members of the Young Men's Christian Association and their friends from attending the reception which was given to the Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler and Mrs. Cuyler in Association Hall, Fulton and Bond Streets.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- The Republican Convention, through its Committee on Resolutions, absolutely refused to-day to adopt as a plank in its platform a resolution condemning the A. P. A., or American Protective Association.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The Shanghai correspondent of the Central News telegraphs as follows:

There will be many dry eyes over the retirement, by compulsory resignation, of Mr. Jeremiah O'Rourke from the office of Supervising Architect of the Treasury Department. He seems to have been as impossible in his supervising as he was in his strictly architectural capacity, and it will readily be believed that he left the Secretary of the Treasury no choice but to ask for his resignation.

One of the most extraordinary schemes of local improvement on record has come into public notice through an action which has been brought in the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, by taxpayers and citizens of the town of Flatlands, on the outskirts of the City of Churches.

SARATOGA, Sept. 18. -- Levi Parsons Morton of Rhinecliffe, Dutchess County, by the grace of Thomas C. Platt and the rejuvenated and perfectly-oiled Republican machine, was nominated for Governor of New-York in this city to-day in extraordinary circumstances.

A rainy day a very muddy track, small fields of horses, and the defeat of four favorites in the six races run is the story in brief of yesterday's races at the track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, at Gravesend.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- New-York defeated Chicago in two closely-contested games to-day. Rusie won the first by a home run over the left field fence in the seventh inning, with two out and two men on bases. Both pitchers did splendd work and were well supported, with the exception of bad errors by Dahlen and Fuller.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- The introduction of documentary evidence was all that was done this morning in the police court here in regard to the charge that Charles J. Kurth and other members of the Constitutional Convention had been guilty of bribery under Section 72 of the Penal Code, as stated in the information sworn to by Andrew W. Ford, managing editor of The Albany Argus.

TRENTON, Sept. 18. -- The appointment of Vicar General McFaul to be the Bishop of Trenton gives much satisfaction here, because the new Bishop was reared in this section of the State, and is highly esteemed for many excellent qualities.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Conventions to elect, delegates to the Democratic State Convention were held to-day in the six Assembly districts of Erie County. The regular organization controlled the six districts, and there was no opposition, all of the nominations being unanimous. Following is a list of delegates chosen to attend the State Convention:

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- The morning session was unprecedented in that there were only 35 shares of Cable stock dealt in. Had it not been for lively trading in Lake Street "L" at 18@18 1/4 and Diamond Match at 127 3/4@128, the call would have been nil, as only one trade in Alley "L" at 7 and one in Street Cable stock at 13 were made, aside from those mentioned.

FORT MONROE, Va., Sept. 18. -- The marriage of Miss Mary Lee Duvall, daughter of Lieut. William P. Duvall of the United States Army, to Louis E. Marie, a son of the late John B. Marie and nephew of Peter Marie of New-York, took place to-day at high noon, in the Star of the Sea Chapel.

The German Roman Catholic Central Verein began its third session in the school building, at 222 East Fourth Street; at 10:3O o'clock yesterday morning. Before the convention was opened, the delegates attended high mass at the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, in East Third Street.

George Aspinwall, a broker, who lives at 58 East Twenty-fifth Street, was in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon to press a charge against Frank Hayes, a horse trainer, who lives at 410 East Fiftythird Street, of stealing a dog valued at $100.

William G. Wood, against whom Matilda Darlington has brought suit for $25,000, claimed by her to be due on a demand note, the consideration of which was "love and affection," said yesterday that he felt very bad about the matter, and that he had supposed that the matter was settled satisfactorily.

SARATOGA, Sept. 17. -- After the platform had been adopted and preliminary business transacted Chairman Miller announced that nominations were now in order, and when Gen. Tracy of Brooklyn arose, cheer upon cheer followed him to the platform when he put Levi P. Morton in nomination for Governor in these words:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 18. -- Cleveland and Brooklyn played two games to-day. In the first Young kept Brooklyn's hits scattered, except in the fifth, when 3 earned runs were scored by the visitors. Childs accepted sixteen chances without an error.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- From telegraphic reports received at the Weather Bureau, the following crop conditions for the week ended yesterday are collated:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The Democratic situation here is becoming more and more complicated. It has been the opinion all along that the Kelley-Tracy men would not go near the Spellmanite caucuses to-morrow evening, and that the latter would stay away from the Kelley-Tracy caucuses on Thursday evening.

From The Ohio State Journal. This Southern Ute Reservation is 110 miles long and 15 miles in width from north to sout. It is crossed by seven large streams, which have their sources in the mountains to the north and which flow, southerly acre the reservation. The first bottoms of these rivers are narrow and contain but little farming lands, but lying between these rivers.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The Madison County Democrats held their County Convention at Morrisville to-day. Yesterday there was one of the bitterest fights ever made to secure control of the delegates from the town of Lenox, the fight for the State organization being led by ex-Sheriff Charles E. Remick and that for the Administration by Richard M. Baker, recently appointed Postmaster here.

It is creditable to the party loyalty of a journal like The Tribune that it accepts, with what grace it can, the complete triumph of Mr. Platt at Saratoga, and presents it to the readers of the editorial page as the outcome of an irresistible party sentiment, after fair discussion, but its readers must have found some difficulty in taking that view after reading the Saratoga dispatches of that paper.

BERLIN, Sept 19. -- The health authorities of East Prussia report that for the week ending Sept. 17 there were 28 new cases and 9 deaths from cholera. In the Elbe district only 1 new case is reported, and only 1 in Hesse-Nassau. Two new cases and 2 deaths are reported in the Rhine district, and 54 new cases and 23 deaths in Prussian Silesia.

From The Milwaukee Sentinel. Peculiar questions are asked the Superintendent. One lady said she remembered having seen, when a child, a cookery-book, the frontispiece of which represented the scientific carving of a goose. She could remember neither the title of the book nor the author; could the Superintendent help her to find It?

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 19. -- The Republican State Convention to-day nominated the following State ticket: Governor -- O. Vincent Coffin of Middletown; Lieutenant Governor -- Lorrin A. Cooke of Barkhamstead; Secretary of State -- William C. Mowry of Norwich; State Treasurer -- George W. Hodge of Windsor; Controller -- B.P. Mead of New-Canaan.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The Democratic electors of Sullivan County met in convention to-day at this place. The following delegates were elected to represent the county in the State Convention: Elmer Winner of Liberty, William Torrilly of Cochecton, and Sidney Wenzel of Callicoon. The delegates are uninstructed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The Spellmanite caucuses in the Second Assembly District were held this evening. Some opposition from the Kelly-Tracy faction, had been looked for, but did not materialize, and the caucuses were held without interruption or incident. But there is no doubt that the Spellmanites or Slocum faction will contest the Kelly-Tracy caucus to-morrow evening.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 19. -- The three strongest professional golf players in America, William Campbell of the Boston Country Club, William Dunn of the Shinnecock Hills Club, Southampton, L.I., and W.F. Davis of the Newport club, are having a contest here for a gold cup and a purse. The conditions were 36 holes, or four rounds of the Newport links.

The wills of Ernest A. Raupp and his wife Eliza, were yesterday contested in the Kings County Surrogate's office, Brooklyn, by Julius Raupp. The will is a joint one, and the testators gave all their property to a Mrs. Christie, who had cared for them in their old age. Julius Raupp claims that the will is not a legal instrument.

The marriage of Justice Edward T. Bartlett of the Court of Appeals to Miss Annie Richmond Platt took place yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock, in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, the Rev. Bishop Falkner, D.D., officiating.

From The London Lady. In Germany the principal festivities connected with a wedding take place on the evening preceding the marriage ceremony. There is a great deal of sense in this arrangement, for in England the flavor always seems to go out of the merry-making as soon as the bridal couple departs on the wedding day.

This is the proper time for the friends of aspirants to the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination to pay them the compliment of a "favorable mention." Custom sanctions the practice, and prudence sets no limit to it. It is a free-for-all competition. Some men even who would be glad to accept a lower place may without impropriety be mentioned for the highest.

From The Omha Bee. I started out to give the army officers a practical illustration of the value of a wheel for army service, in making long marches, or for carrying messages. I have been five and one-half days on the road between here and Fort Russell, and lost a day and a half by breaking my wheel and having to stop to repair it.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 19. -- A receiver for the Chicago Gaslight and Coke Company, the People's Gaslight and Coke Company, the Consumers' Gas Company, the Equitable Gaslight and Fuel Company, the Hyde Park Gas Company, the Lake Gas Company, and the Chicago Gas Company is asked in a bill filed to-day in the Circuit Court by Louis A. Levin of Philadelphia.

Next Sunday there will be a century run from Yonkers to Hicksville. L.I., and return, that gives every promise of being a record breaker. The route carries one over splendid roads through a country very picturesque. The start will be made at 4:30 A.M., and, according to the schedule, Yonkera should be reached on the return trip at 0:13 o'clock.

The reorganized Democracy of Kings County, familiarly known as the Bell organization, held its primaries for the election of delegates to the Assembly District Conventions last evening. The weather kept a large number of Democrats from the polls, but, notwithstanding. Chairman Bell and Secretary Farrell said there was a large number of votes cast.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 19. -- The eighteen Queens County Deputy Sheriffs employed as special policemen at the Maspeth race track are dissatisfied with their wages. Six of them were dismissed last night by Sheriff James Norton on making a demand for increased pay.

There is considerable mystery surrounding the sudden death of a young woman yesterday at 336 East Forty-second Street. She probably committed suicide. Pending the examination of the body by the Coroner, none of the circumstances attending the young woman's death will be disclosed by those acquainted with them.

ANSONIA, Conn., Sept. 19. -- Frederick Vr. Holden of Ansonia, the President pro tern of the State Senate, has been several years working for a change from the present Injustice which follows from Connecticut's old-time Constitution. During his career in the Senate he has championed bills designed to submit the question of holding a Constitutional Convention to the people.

The question of a division of rates between Eastern and Western railroads occupied the attention of a conference in the offices of the Trunk-Line Association yesterday. A similar meeting was held here on Aug. 8. Committees representing the Central Traffic Association, the Western Freight Association, the Trunk-Line Association, and the New-England roads were in attendance.

The professional golf tournament held last week by the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club was, in the opinion of golf enthusiasts who witnessed it, the best and most interesting match of its kind that has ever been held in this country. The professional tournament brought out five entries, the largest number of professional golfers who have ever come together in the United States to contest for supremacy.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19. -- The German Democrats of this city and State are fat from happy. Their attachment to the senior Senator has consisted very largely in their confidence in his power to command patronage. The faithful have depended upon it, and the party generally has looked to it for strength.

Mr. John N. Goldling has sold for Messrs. Mandelbaum Lewine the two four-story brownstone buildings 120 and 122 West 42d Street, each 12.6 by 100, at $91,000. The vendors at first acquired a one-fourth interest in this property, and only secured the remaining three-fourths after much work. Persistent rumors were circulated about a month ago that the property had been bought by Mr. C.C. Shayne.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19. -- Judging by the talk of the Democratic leaders and the Democratic papers in Connecticut, with the exception of The New-Haven Register, the first place on the Democratic State ticket this Fall will be occupied by the name of E.C. Benedict of Greenwich. It can safely be said that the Democratic State Central Committee is for Mr. Benedict for Governor.

From The Milwaukee Sentinel. The postal service in London, the best and most rapid in the world, is an interesting study, with its 6,000 employes. The average wage of the 2,000 assorters and stampers in the general office is 30s. a week. Most of these are married men. We hear that the best hope of the laboring classes must ever depend on the skillful administration of their earnings and the fight investment of their savings.

William Ellingwood Donnell, financial editor of The New-York Tribune, died suddenly in the Plaza Hotel at 7 o'clock last night. Mr. Donnell's wife is at Huntington, L.I., and he went to the hotel for dinner. He was apparently in perfect health. He had not been seated at the table in the hotel cafe more than a few minutes when he fell over in his chair.

With the surface of the track of the consistency of oatmeal porridge and the rain falling heavily all day long, the attempt at racing at Gravesend yesterday was very feeble. There were seven events on the programme, but, although they were well filled, there was not much speculation by the handful of bettors who made the journey to the track and who were not anxious to risk much on "swimming" matches.

SARATOGA, Sept. 19. -- The Republican State Convention, through its Committee on Resolutions, has gone squarely on record in its refusal to adopt as part of its platform a resolution declaring against the A.P.A. and its religious intolerance and bigotry, and thereby clearly established. In the most decisive sort of way, the kinship of the A. P.A. and the Republican Party.
SARATOGA, Sept. 19. -- The one topic among Democrats to-day is who will be nominated for Governor in the Democratic State Convention, which comes together here next Tuesday.

The next Mayor of New-York must do what Mr. Hewitt confessed himself unable to do -- he must put an end to blackmail, bribery, and corruption in the Police Department. Mr. Hewitt, with the beat intentions in the world, was practically powerless. He had no evidence, and it was difficult or impossible at that time to procure evidence.

Constance, the Countess Wachtmeister, who, next to Annie Besant, is the most famous woman, in the Theosophical Society, is in this city. The Countess, whose full name is Constance Georgine Louise de Bourbel de Montjuncon, arrived in this country by way of San Francisco in April last, having come from India, where she made a tour of the country.

It was New-York's wettest day in twelve years yesterday. The uninformed said it was the equinoctial storm, but Weather Observer Dunn, who knows everything in the weather line, from a zephyr to a blizzard, declared that there was no such thing in the weather catalogue, and that the storm was merely the usual September disturbance of the elements, and had nothing to do with the sun.
The Citizens' Committee of Seventy organized for the municipal campaign yesterday afternoon at the Chamber of Commerce.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 19. -- Forest Crowley, manager of the Roswell Woolen Mill, was found this morning murdered in a thicket near West View Cemetery. Circumstantial evidence points strongly to Will Myers as one of his murderers. The motive was robbery. Crowley had $700 on his person yesterday.

There was considerably less business done on the Stock Exchange yesterday than for some days, but prices were fairly well held. Opening prices were up in sympathy with a higher level in London, and the improvement induced covering by local shorts. London's principal purchases were in St. Paul and Louisville and Nashville.

SARATOGA, Sept. 19. -- None of the big Republican leaders is in town. The State Convention having adjourned at 2:10 o'clock this morning, it was possible to start for home as early as 7 o'clock. Mr. Platt was the first to "pick up his grip." He took the first train for New-York. Senator Saxton went as far as Albany with him.

In the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, before Justice Cullen, the case of Frederic R. and Charles Coudert against W.T. Bailey came up on a motion of the defendants to vacate a judgment of foreclosure of property on Coney Island which was formerly owned by Mrs. Morey. The motion was denied.

The German Roman Catholic Central Vetein Convention delegates attended a solemn requiem mass in the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer yesterday morning, after which they marched to the convention hall, 222 East Fourth Street.

PANAMA, Sept. 19. -- Advices have been received by The Star and Herald from Bogota that at 8 o'clock yesterday morning Dr. Rafael Nunez, President of the Republic of Colombia, was not expected to live more than two hours. He had been suffering from an attack of fever. The foregoing news was received by a Spanish steamer.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Most of the boomers of Mayor Aldridge, who left the city Monday, With streamers flying and bands playing, for the Republican State Convention, have returned, but the streamers are not flying, nor are the bands playing. The delegates and boomers, however, did not return altogether quietly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Assistant Secretary of the Navy McAdoo has decided to decline the nomination to Congress which his Democratic friends in his old district in New-Jersey desire to thrust upon him.
Townsend Montant, auctioneers, began yesterday at 87 Leonard Street the largest sale of imported and domestic silks ever held in this country.

Some of the best racing of the Fall is expected at the fourth meet of the Crescent Wheelmen at Flainfleld, N.J., on Saturday, Sept. 29. The one-third-of-a-mile track is very popular with all who have seen it, and fast time can be made over it with a degree of safety that the cracks will appreciate. This will commend Itself to the racing men, and a large list of entries is looked for.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- The public was not in the local stock market to much of an extent; trading seemed to be concentrated with the larger speculators. Lake Street "L" stock was probably the exception. Here orders were better distributed and the stock certainly looks strong. Sales this morning were around 19@19 3/8, with a steady closing at 19.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 19. -- Fully 20,000 people were at Narragansett Park to-day and the sulkies proved the chief attraction of the State Fair. Rain began to fall early in the afternoon, but the horses did not get a rest till four classes were decided. Two more were started, but after a heat in each, the storm became so violent that it was dangerous to go on.
In the presence of more than 300 persons Daniel Mullane, seventeen years old, was shocked to death by electricity while standing of the steps of 203 Chrystle Street about dusk last night.

The John F. Ahearn Association held Its annual picnic Monday at College Point. This club. It is almost needless to say, is named in honor of Senator John F. Ahearn of the Eighth New-York District. The members gathered in force in the morning at the clubhouse, 290 East Broadway, and marched to Pier 49 Bast River, where the steamboat Sirius was waiting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The Miles Planting and Manufacturing Company, a corporation situated in the State of Louisiana, organized for the purpose of planting and growing sugar cane and manufacturing sugar, filed in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia this afternoon a petition for a writ of mandamus directed against Secretary Carlisle and Commissioner of Internal Revenue Miller to compel them to make a preliminary inspection of the company's works.

Secrecy was voted by members of the Executive Committee of the German-American Reform Union, in regard to proceedings had at Terrace Garden Tuesday night, but what purported to be an account of the happenings was published yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Princeton University opened her one hundred and forty-eighth year to-day, with appropriate services in Marquand Chapel. In the absence of President Patton, who is returning from a Summer's sojourn in the Hartz Mountains, Dean Murray presided, and James W. Alexander of New-York, member of the Board of Trustees, delivered a short address on hazing.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 19. -- The State Democratic Convention was called to order at 12 o'clock to-day by Senator Irby, Chairman of the Executive Committee. Over 300 delegates were present, every county being represented. A large majority are Tillmanites, one delegation, that from Charleston, being conservative.

The handicaps for the New-York Athletic Club's Fall games, to be held on Saturday next at Travers Island, were completed yesterday. Great interest attaches to the marks received by the prominent men in some of the events, as many records may be made if the scratch men are sufficiently extended by the handicap runners.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Miss Molly T. Meeker of Asbury Park and George W. Morrison of Plainfield were married this evening in the First Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Howard Widdemer, pastor of the church. He was assisted by the Rev. W. A. Allen of the First Methodist Church.

ALBANY, Sept. 19. -- The Hill Democrats, styled the new Democracy, held primaries to-day, and elected full sets of delegates from the city to County, District, and Assembly Conventions. This means that there will be a contest for local offices. At each one of the primaries the voters passed upon the following favorably:
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Capt. Charles J. Chatfield of this city, aged fifty-three years, committed suicide early this morning by shooting himself through the head.

BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 19. -- A committee of the Hungarian Delegation, headed by Herr Berzeviczy and Count Apponyl, to-day accused the Roumanian Government of fostering anti-Hungarian agitations. The textbooks and maps used in the Roumanian schools, the committee asserted, designate Translyvania as Roumanian territory, and the Roumanian subvention for foreign schools of u20,000 is spent in Hungary.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- Bay State Gas is still the feature of the market for local stocks, and to-day registered its highest price in the recent run, gaining 5/8 over last night, closing at 13. The second bonds advanced from 58 to 59 1/2 at one jump. There is no particular news on these securities, and the rise smacks decidedly of manipulation.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 19. -- President Greenhut of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company has received the resignation of Nelson Morris of Chicago, who has been a member of the Board of Directors ever since the formation of the company. Mr. Greenhut did not discuss the resignation, and stated that Mr. Morris assigned no reason for his action.

WOLCOTT, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- An expert fruit man, who for fifteen years has made inspection trips through New-York State, Northern Ohio, Michigan, Missouri, Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, and Canada, has just returned, and to-day pronounced his opinion concerning the apple crop of 1894.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 19. -- Senator Higgins was practically bowled out of the Senatorial race by the result of the Sussex County Republican Convention held at Georgetown. The men who so successfully managed the canvass of J. Edward Addicks in Kent County and secured for him all the Republican legislative nominations there, were in charge at Georgetown, and the result was another victory for Addicks.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The Central News's Shanghai correspondent telegraphs that advices from Chinese sources report a severe naval engagement at the mouth of the Yalu River between the Chinese northern squadron and the Japanese fleet. The battle lasted six hours. During the fight the Chinese war ships Yang-Wei and Chao-Yung caught fire and were burned and run ashore, and the Chih-Yuen and the King-Yuen were sunk.
The steamship Victoria arrived here yesterday from Mediterranean ports. She encountered the outer edgre of a hurricane Sept, 9,10, and 11, and lost all of her booby hatches.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- In compliance with a resolution adopted by the Senate, and under the direction of the presiding officer at that body, it is made the imperative duty of the Grand Jury of the District of Columbia, beford the expiration of its present term, on the 2d day of October, to report to the criminal court whether Messrs.

There is something mysterious about the death of Mrs. Sarah Lasalle of Brooklyn. She was a widow, fifty-seven years old, and either fell accidentally or threw herself with suicidal intent from a third-story window in the rear of 72 Downing Street at 10 o'clock Tuesday night. She was taken to St. John's Hospital, where she died shortly after midnight.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Tony Ross, an Italian, twenty-nine years old, was committed to jail this morning on the charge of train wrecking. The accusation was made by John Connerton, engineer of passenger train No. 148 of the Lehigh Valley Road.

SARATOGA, Sept. 19. -- Judge D. Cady Herriek, who is here holding General Term, was asked to-night by a New-York Times reporter if he had any further views to express as to the Democratic situation as Gov. Flower's decision not to be a candidate left it.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- It has long been the custom to begin the theatrical season here the first of the present month, without consideration for wind or weather. Formerly, I believe, the theatres were never closed during the entire year. The change came about, not to suit the temperature, but because of the railroad facilities, and the fact that stars wished to be seen elsewhere.

We notice a misapprehension on the part of some of our contemporaries as to the real nature of the new defense against diphtheria which has been so warmly commended by the Board of Health in this city. The substance injected under the skin of the person to be protected is not the diphtheritic poison or an "attenuated" culture of it, but a substance which is hostile to that poison and is its most powerful enemy.
Leicester Holme. Excise Commissioner, has resigned, and yesterday Mayor Gilroy appointed Eugene L. Bushe to fill the vacancy.

GALESBURG, Ill., Sept. 19. -- The Galesburg track now holds the world's record for trotting, Alix clipping a quarter of a second off her record here this afternoon, going a mile in 2:03 3/4. The day was all that could be desired, the hot sun putting the track in perfect order.
The withdrawal of Gov. Flower has caused a big boom to be launched in Brooklyn for William J. Gaynor.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 19. -- At the Deep Waterways Convention here to-day R. C. Steele of Toronto said that, while he could understand the opposition of Buffalo and some other places to the objects of the convention, why New-York and Montreal should refuse aid to the movement for deeper waterways he could not understand.

At the meeting of the Board of Health yesterday the report of Dr. Edson, Chairman of the Sanitary Committee, on the subject of "shop" fat and "long" fat was approved, and his recommendation to re-amend the Sanitary Code so as to authorize the issuing of permits to bring "long" fat into the city was adopted.

CLYDE, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- This village tonight extended a welcome to Charles T. Saxton, on his return from the Republican State Convention, where he scored such a signal triumph in the contest for the Lieutenant Governorship. Col. Anson S. Wood and Assemblyman George Horton of Wolcott accompanied the Senator, together with M.C. McMullen, R.R. Barnes, and George S. Field of this place.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- There were several sensational incidents in the second day's sersion of the ecclesiastical tribunal now inquiring into the character of the Rev. Luke C. Queal, D.D., Presiding Elder of the Geneva district, and ex-pastor of the leading Methodist Episcopal Church of this city.

Lord Hawke thinks New-York quite an English city so far as the weather is concerned. When he was here three years ago there was a genuine London tog for two days, and a "Scotch mist" for the third, which brought the cricket game to an untimely conclusion. The steady downpour of yesterday positively precluded any possibility for play, and the ground presented a most dismal appearance.

If this will only result in Quick's Educational Reformers, the textbook we use being more widely read," said Miss Jennie B. Merrill, Superintendent of the department of pedagogy of the New-York Normal College, to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday afternoon, "I shall be glad it happened.

SCHOHARIE, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Gov. Flower, who arrived here at 10:30 A.M. and who intended to speak at the Schoharie County Fair, but was prevented from doing so by rain, held a public reception to the farmers at his hotel this afternoon, and, in response to a call for a speech, said that he should not again be a candidate for public office.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 19. -- Judge Lippincott this afternoon made a supplementary charge to the Grand Jury in relation to the water supply, in which he explained a portion of his original charge and the duty and powers of the Grand Jury in the premises. He spoke as follows:
Democrats in this city look upon the Republican ticked named at Saratoga, with Messrs. Morton, Saxton, and Height for candidates, as a combination to be defeated with ease.

It was reported yesterday morning that a subpoena had been issued for the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst to appear before the Grand Jury. This body, it was said, had for two days been considering Dr. Parkhurst's charges against Recorder Smyth.

Superintendent Byrnes gave the Inspectors, Captains, and commanding officers of precincts one of his periodical lectures yesterday. It is not unusual for the Superintendent to summon his lieutenants before him, for he often finds that discipline is becoming lax, and a wholesome "talk" works much good.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept: 19. -- The football eleven of the Orange Athletic Club has begun practice in the club gymnasium. The make-up of the team for this season has not been definitely decided on, and will probably not be for some time. Frank H. Coyne will captain the learn and L.D. Varlan will manage it. As soon as field practice is begun, A. Hamilton Wallis of Yale will coach the men.

While it is not safe to accept as conclusive the first report of any battle between China and Japan, it is evident that the European and America news service is now in such a condition that whatever is known in Tokio and Shanghai will straightway be made public in London and New-York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- Judge Gibbons this morning sustained the demurrer to the amended pleas of the Whisky Trust to the information in quo warranto and directed the Attorney General to prepare judgment of ouster against the trust.

SARATOGA, Sept. 19. -- John E. Milholland is here, and some of his followers are with him, and whenever they come together there is a protest against the way things went yesterday. Mr. Milholland and his men held a meeting this morning, at which the following resolution was adopted:
The money market continued easy. Can loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
The question of the proposed appointment of a landscape architect to supervise the work on the Harlem River Driveway was discussed again at the meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday.

The National Horse Show Association has decided to offer the following supplementary prizes for trotters. Altogether the prizes offered for trotters and roadsters amount to $6,550. The additional prize list is as follows:

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 19. -- Two steers from the West escaped this morning as they were being unloaded from a car at the abattoir, and before they were killed one of them had created a great deal of excitement along the line of the Pennsylvania Railroad, and had tossed a man ten feet in the air.

The State Democracy organization held primaries in each of the thirty Assembly districts of the city last night, and in each district elected three delegates and three alternates to the Democratic State Convention, which meets next Tuesday.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 20. -- The steamship John Wilson, which left Bluefields, Nicaragua, Sept. 15, brings news that the election passed oft quietly Sept. 8, and there has been no serious disturbance recently.

From the Pittsburg Commercial Gazette. "It was the night before we made our first all-night march, and the boys were pretty badly tuckered out. We hoped to go into camp that night, but Kirby Smith objected. The Fifty-second Ohio, with Dan McCook in command, was covering the retreat.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 20. -- The people of Pittsburg are so used to seeing the unexpected happen that when their ball team wins a game from the Giants they do not think it worth a second thought. Ward arrived this morning full of hope. He said it was a waste of time to play., the game in the afternoon, as he wanted the pennant the Orioles are striving for and intended to get it.

Copyrighted 1894, by The New-York Times. HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 20. -- When Republicans have been forced to a discussion of the question of constitutional revision, they have been often inclined to hide behind the fact that there is no way provided for a change except by amendments made by the General Assembly The Constitution itself does not provide for a Constitutional Convention.

Manager Edward E. Rice has at last taken steps to compel Camille D'Arville to fulfill her contract and sing for him during the coming season. In Boston yesterday a preliminary injunction was issued by the Supreme Court forbidding Miss D'Arville to sing after to-morrow night, when her engagement at the Tremont Theatre, in that city, closes, for any other manager than Mr. Rice.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- The statement given circulation this morning of a prospective competitor for the Diamond Match Company from the Gould interests was a bear argument which was responsible for the throwing over of nearly 1,500 shares of stock at the opening -- enough to have caused a most serious break had not support of a positive character developed.

Much to the surprise of the 3,000 people who went to the Gravesend races yesterday, there was not only a good, dry track, but a fast one to race over instead of one deep in mud, as Was naturally to be expected after the steady down-pour of rain during the past two days.

James M. White, one of the best-known members of the Cotton Exchange, died yesterday of consumption at 233 Park Place, Brooklyn. He had been ill for nearly one year, but quit business less than one month ago, retiring to Summit. N.J., where he had taken a Summer place, in the hope of repairing his health.
