WASHINGTON, Sept, 20. -- In a speech which he delivered recently in West Virginia, ex-President Harrtson said: "If you have felt the effects of the depression. If you think more of those effects and prefer not to lead the country through the slough of despondency, show it by defeating Wilson."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20. -- The political sensation of the week is the announcement that an effort is to be made to nominate John K. Cowen to succeed Congressman Isidor Rayner in the Fourth Congressional District.

The transfer of the title deeds to the Casino property, Broadway and Thirtyninth Street, was finally made yesterday by Receiver Gilbert M. Speir to be Organization Committee of the new Casino Company, of which Rudolph Aronson is to be the President and General Manager. The deed was given to H. Weinman, one of the committee, and covers all the property and the lease of the ground to May 1, 1902.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The fear engendered of late by the actions of Clinton Furbish, Director of the Bureau of American Republics, that the Government was about to embark in the business of soliciting advertisements for one of its periodicals, has been, dispelled by the action of Secretary Gresham.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The regular Democrats of Albany are in high feather tonight over the appointment of John P. Masterson as Surveyor of the Port, in place of John M. Bailey, the Sleicher Republican. A commission reached Mr. Masterson to-day. Mr. Masterson will have the appointment of two deputies at $4 a day, and four Inspectors at $3 a day.

Ayer, Mass., Sept. 20. -- Fire destroyed the barn of the Harvard Shakers, one of the largest in the State, this afternoon. It contained 125 tons of hay. 450 bushels of potatoes, and a large quantity of ensilage. A older mill containing twenty-five barrels of older and the icehouse, partly full, were also destroyed. The Ayer Fire Department was sent for, and did good work, saving all of the stock and large quantities of cordwood.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 20. -- Trading in the wheat market was fairly active to-day until noon, when it became exceedingly dull, continuing so till the close. The range for the day was narrow, being confined to 1/2c. The market started weak on lower cables, large receipts in the North-west, and in sympathy with the continued weakness in corn.

SYLVANIA, Ga., Sept. 20. -- Sheriff L.B. Brooker of Scriven County, was seriously shot this afternoon by George M. Zeigler and his son Sol. The shooting occurred at Zeigler Station, five miles from Sylvania. Brooker was coming from Savannah. When he boarded the train at Rocky Ford, he met George Zeigler.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 20. -- Robert Murray is badly wanted in this city. He came here from Southwest Missouri one month ago with a flourish, as a man with money to invest. He bought an interest in a Broadway branch of the American Brewing Company, and paid for his purchase in Vernon County bonds.

NEWTOWN, L. I., Sept. 20. -- Seven loaded freight cars of Sag Harbor freight were demolished here to-night. The train broke in two and was going down a heavy grade, when the rear portion collided with the head end. The cars were piled on top of each other. No one was Injured.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20. -- This week has added four more victims to the record of slaughter which this town has known since it was gridironed with trolley and cable roads. Within two years the victims have numbered over seventy, and they are fast nearing the hundred mark. In six months rapid transit in Baltimore killed more people than the horse cars did in twenty-five years.

LONDON, England, Sept. 9. -- The following statement, made by the late Dr. J. Milner Fothergill, the eminent scientist, who was physician for the London Hospital for Diseases of the Chest, has made quite a sensation. After denouncing oils and similar substances when used as food, he said: "Fatty, oily foods cannot be taken by those whose stomachs are weak or whose digestive organs are out of order.
The second meeting of the Executive Committee of the Committee of Seventy was held at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday.

The friends of Dr. Parkhurst and believers in the work he has in hand turned out in such numbers at the Eighteenth Street Methodist Church last evening that the building was not sufficiently large to hold them all, and an overflow meeting was held in an adjoining room.

GALESBURG, Ill., Sept. 20. -- A large crowd witnessed remarkable trotting and pacing on the Williams track to-day. Robert J. was started to beat his own record of 2:01 1/2 but failed, although the track was in splendid condition. His time was 2:02 3/4.
The stockholders of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company held their annual meeting yesterday at the office of the company, 214 Broadway. Thomas C. Smith presided.

ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- On the order of third reading to-night, the home rule for cities amendment was taken up by the Constitutional Convention. It also contains the provision limiting the debt for cities. Mr. Johnson explained its provisions.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- The market for local stocks, with the exception of the Coppers, was not very active. Bay State Gas was the only noteworthy feature. It declined 5/8, to 12 3/8, and the second bonds dropped 1 5/8, to 58 1/8. Dominion Coal railied 1 1/2 from yesterday's close, selling at 15 3/4. Lamson Store Service was quiet, at 23 1/4.

NEWARK, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The Wayne County Democratic Convention was held here to-day. As there are two distinct bodies of the party in this county, it had been predicted by some that there would be a stormy time in the convention and many contesting delegations, but in this there was a happy disappointment.

The entries for the Westchester County Horse Show Association's show, which begins at White Plains on Sept. 25 and continues to the 29th, inclusive, are the largest ever received by the association. The catalogue is made up of about 400 entries, arranged under 60 classes. Trotters will be better represented than heretofore, and saddle horses are well cared for in the prize list.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20. -- The singular experience of Erasmus Bennett, the Percheron horse breeder of Topeka, Kan., who was seized here and practically buried alive in a Connecticut jail for ten days, on a claim suddenly brought against him for debt, has called forth much discussion of the Nutmeg statute under which he was incarcerated.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- The market was strong, and that was the principal feature. The volume of business was somewhat greater than that of yesterday, but still trading was not active enough to encourage outside speculation. Although the fluctuations in Reading were very much less than the fluctuations in some other stocks, the market in it was more reliable and firmer.
Jean Baptiste de Rossi. Jean Baptiste de Rossi, the Italian epigraphist and archaeologist, died in Rome yesterday.

Until the Continental Match Company, of which Edwin Gould has become the mainstay financially, shall have accomplished something in the commercial field, officers of the Diamond Match Company, which now occupies that field, say they will not worry themselves.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- The cricket game here to-morrow between Lord Hawke's team and All Philadelphia should result in a splendid exhibition, and the large and fashionable gathering which is likely to view the contest ought to bring joy to the hearts of the visitors.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20. -- Oliver H.P. Belmont left to-day on his coach for Boston. His guests were Mr. and Mrs. William R. Travers, J. Neilson Howard, and William G. Lawrence. They have several relays of horses. They put up to-night in Taunton.

Another circular has been issued by the Atchison Protective Committee, calling upon the stockholders to give their proxies to that committee for use at the annual election next month. Assurance is given that the proxies will be voted in favor of a Board of Directors in no way identified with the past or present management of the company.

The Brooklyn Bar Association met in the Law Library in the Kings County Court House last night to take action on the candidacy of Edgar M. Cullen for renomination as Justice of the Supreme Court for the Second Judicial District.

PENN YAN, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- One of the Democratic contests that is likely to be the topic of much discussion at the coming State Convention is that in Yates County. Though in many counties of Western NewYork an effort was made by both the friends of the Administration and the State machine to insure party harmony, the representatives of the factions in Yates appear to regard their differences as irreconcilable.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 20. -- At to-day's session of the Ohio Bankers Association, the principal speaker was Controller Eckels of the Treasury Department. He said, among other things:

The gentleman or lady who insists upon looking at all works of nature and art exclusively from the point of view of the young person is almost sure to do wild work. The well-intentioned Mr. Anthony Comstock's last exploit in this direction was to announce that "Tom Jones" was an immoral work, and that it was his duty to suppress it.

The small fish hatchery which was established at Cold Spring Harbor eleven years ago has steadily increased its facilities and its output year by year, until now it is the most important one in the State.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. Jacob Cole sold, at $10,000, to William Gilfillan, trustee, plaintiff, the four-story brick flat 450 Throop Avenue, southwest corner of Lexington Avenue, 28 by 100. To the same purchaser, at $10,000, he sold the similar building 452 Throop Avenue, at the northwest corner of Quincy Street, 28 by 100 by 55.6 by jog 1 by 44.6 by 27.
Lexow witness Louis Stager was arrested by a policeman of the Tombs Court squad yesterday on a charge of grand larceny.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 20. -- Democratic politics in the Second Assembly District of Westchester County took a lively turn this afternoon in the Assembly District Convention, which was held in the New-Rochelle Town Hall.

The second annual convention of the Society of Electro-Therapeutists opened yesterday morning at the Berkeley Lyceum, in West Forty-fourth Street. The convention will close to-night. The society is devoted to the application of electricity to medical science. A large proportion of the delegates are women, and many of them come from distant States.

Parker's chances of winning the new club challenge cup of the West Side Tennis Club were settled yesterday afternoon by Fischer who defeated his clubmate for the second time in succession. Parker was to have owed his opponent half fifteen, but Fischer declined to take the odds, and the men played on even terms.

From London Truth. Desertion still seems to be as prevalent as ever at Halifax, N.S. A recent issue of a local paper states that within the previous fortnight a dozen men had deserted from the King's Regiment. Only two of the men have been recaptured, and for these two captures the Government is indebted to the enterprise of an intelligent farmer, to whom the deserters had applied for work.
The end of the ninety-eighth season of the Hoboken Turtle Club was fittingly observed yesterday at William Sperb's King's Bridge Hotel.

An important wedding took place last evening at St. Peter's Church, Twentieth Street and Ninth Avenue, the contracting parties being J.C. Cummings and Miss Marion J. Wright. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Olin S. Roche. The bride was given away by her uncle, J.P. Magovern, and was attended by Miss Jean Stryker, who acted as bridesmaid.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 20. -- "There are wars and rumors of wars" in nearly all the places hereabout just now over the question of granting or refusing to grant the street electric-road franchises of the many companies that at present have applications innumerable before the several local governing bodies.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20. -- The great suit of the Central Trust Company of NewYork for the bondholders of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railroad Company against Stevenson Burke and others to recover $12,000,000, the principal proceeds which are alleged to have been embezzled, and interest will be submitted to the court to-morrow.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Mrs. Louise Hile, twenty-two years old, who was married only five months ago, lies wounded in her home, 126 Union Street, the result of a desperate encounter with a burglar, armed with a razor, who entered her room at 2 o'clock this morning.

The investigation into the conduct of the City's insane asylums by the State Lunacy Commission was resumed yesterday in the Park Avenue Hotel. Dr. William A. Macy, General Superintendent of the male insane asylum on Ward's Island, said he received $2,500 a year. He thought the amount of food furnished patients was sufficient, but it might be more varied.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Trial was begun in the Circuit Court to-day of an action brought by Mrs. Emma M. Morgan against Daniel W. Powers, owner of the block, art gallery, and hotel bearing his name.
In this city Gov. Flower's withdrawal as a candidate for renomination has produced a condition that interests all Democrats.

The residents in the neighborhood of the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn, suffered considerable inconvenience Wednesday and yesterday evening by the cellars of their houses being flooded.

Joseph W. Little of 36 Butler Street, Brooklyn, and several of his relatives have discovered, they believe, that they are the real owners of the property which constituted the old Red Hook Lane. If they are able to prove a claim, they will be enriched by many millions of dollars.

AMITYVILLE, Sept. 20. -- The postponed opening of the County Fair, under the auspices of the Amityville Agricultural and Driving Park Association, took place here to-day. The attendance was large. The display in the agricultural department was the finest ever on exhibition in this section.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 20. -- With 133 individual entries, the Mercury Wheel Club expects to have the best race meet at the driving park here Saturday that has been held on Long Island this year. Two postponements of this meet have been necessary, but they have only served to make the programme additionally attractive.
LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The correspondent of the Central News at Tien-Tsin telegraphs further details of the naval battle off the mouth of the Yalu River, as follows:

The campaign for good roads in New-Jersey this Fall promises to be extremely lively. The League of American Wheelmen has taken up the contest in earnest, and no stone will be left unturned to aid the State Division in securing what the wheelmen believe to be their rights. Charles H. Luscomb, President of the league, drafted a circular letter yesterday which will be sent to every cyclist in the State within a lew days.

It is worth noting that on the day following the adoption of the stupid freesilver platform by the Ohio Democrats, the Republicans of Washington -- a latitude supposed to be much more exposed to the cheap-money infection -- voted down a free-silver resolution. That sort of contrast must not occur too often.

James Gunther, who is said by the police to be under indictment for writing policy slips, was held yesterday in the Yorkville Police Court by Justice McMahon, charged with a repetition of that offense.

The newspaper associates of "William E. Donnell, late financial editor of The NewYork Tribune, who died suddenly of apoplexy Wednesday night, met yesterday, on the invitation of F.T. Adams Co., 71 Broadway, in the office of that firm, for the purpose of formulating an expression of their opinion as to the characteristics of their long-time associate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The next test of armor at the Indian Head proving ground will be on a batch of eight-inch Harveyized plates for the barbettes of that greatest of cruisers, the Brooklyn, and that greatest of battleships, the Iowa.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- Miss Frances T. Kinsella of Brooklyn was married this morning, in the Church of the Passionist Fathers, in this city, to Douglas Robinson, son of Sir William Robinson, Governor of Victoria, Australia.

It was a graceful compliment to select the Second and Fourth Infantry as the recipients of the first installment of the magazine small arms now being issued, since their commanding officers, Col. J. C. Bates and Col. R.H. Hall, were members of the board that conducted the trials which resulted in choosing the Krag-Jorgensen rifle for our service.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 20. -- The Democrats of the Third Congressional District in this city this morning, in convention, nominated Joseph P. McCullen as their candidate over Congressman William McAleer. The vote was: McCullen, 18; McAleer, 10.
The delegates to the convention of the German Roman Catholic Central Verein, having completed their labors, enjoyed an excursion on the river yesterday, and a banquet at Sulzer's Harlem River Park.

The Sheriff yesterday received an attachment for $6,000 against Frank A. Wahlig, formerly a leaf-tobacco dealer at 168 Front Street, in favor of his wife, Rose Wahlig. In her complaint, she says that she had a bank account with Nathan Alexander Co., bankers, at 16 and 18 Wall Street.

ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- The investigation into the complaint against five Brooklyn Constitutional Convention delegates, alleging bribery in connection with the payment of compensation to them for the session days before they were seated, was resumed in the police court to-day.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Sept. 20. -- Luck was against the Keystone Wheel Club of Williamsport in the attempt to run a successful national circuit meet. Excellent prizes were offered and the largest entry list outside of Springfield in Class B was secured. All the chief riders, with the exception of Johnson, "Charlie" Murphy, and Titus were present.

ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- The first conference that has been held by the Democrats in the Constitutional Convention was held at 9 o'clock this morning on the apprehension that the Republicans proposed to snap a final adjournment on Saturday at noon. An unexpectedly large number of Democrats was present despite the early hour, and the utmost harmony prevailed.
The new Board of Studies of the Catholic Summer School of Aemirca held two important meetings last week at the Catholic Club.
Mr. Platt, having nominated an ex-Vice President for Governor, has begun to tell his lieutenants that he prefers to have the campaign conducted on "national lines."

Recent events in railway management in this country have emphasized the necessity of establishing a clear, self-proving, and uniform system of railroad accounts by which a central body, to which reports shall be made, can ascertain and report intelligibly the exact financial standing of each road.

Owing to the strike in the garbage-dumping branch of the Street-Cleaning Department and the storms of Tuesday and Wednesday, the housewives of the city were greatly put out yesterday. The storm, prevented the scows owned by the city from going to sea with their loads, and as soon as the collecting carts were once filled things came to a standstill.
